https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/26/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; For Moran Towing, A Presidential First
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/26/busin.body_text: **********The Moran Towing Corporation, operators of 80 tugboats from Maine to Texas, announced yesterday that Malcolm W. MacLeod had been named president and chief operating officer - the first president to be chosen outside the Moran family. **********Thomas E. Moran, 61 years old, relinquished the president's post to Mr. MacLeod and will continue as chairman and chief executive of the privately held company based in Greenwich, Conn. **********Mr. MacLeod, 59, graduated from the Massachusetts Maritime Academy at Buzzards Bay and went to work for Moran in 1954 as a mess boy on tugs. He spent his career with the company except for two years in the Navy and, naturally, he served as an officer aboard fleet tugboats. **********At Moran Towing, after he left the tugs Mr. MacLeod worked in sales and operations, was manager of a division in Puerto Rico and since 1978 has been president of a Moran subsidiary, the Curtis Bay Towing Company. **********Curtis Bay serves Philadelphia, Baltimore and Norfolk with tugs along with coastwise towing. Replacing Mr. MacLeod there will be Thomas Moran's brother, Edmond J. Moran Jr., 42, who joined the family concern in 1971. The changes are expected to take place by June. **********Thomas Moran, the great-grandson of the company's founder, Michael Moran, is the fourth generation to head the 126-year-old company. **********Mr. MacLeod said he planned no radical changes in Moran's operations. ''Moran has always maintained a fine reputation in the ports that we operate in and we will try to build on that,'' he said. **********The tug industry is suffering in the prolonged depression of the shipping industry that it serves. ''Some of our customers are in tough financial shape and the number of jobs are down,'' Mr. MacLeod said. **********But he is optimistic. ''I would look for things to turn around,'' he said. ''They've been down now for four or five years.'' **********As for Moran, he said: ''It's a great company to work for. I've never had any desire to work anywhere else.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/19/world.main_headline: Plan to Break Impasse in North's Testimony
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/19/world.print_headline: Plan to Break Impasse in North's Testimony
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/19/world.body_text: **********The Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair developed a proposal today for breaking the impasse with Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North over his refusal to give a private deposition before his public testimony. **********The proposal - to have Colonel North testify privately at a formal session of the committees before his public appearance - was submitted by the committees' counsels tonight to Colonel North's lawyer, Brendan V. Sullivan Jr. Lawmakers said the issue was not likely to be resolved until next week. **********Mr. Sullivan informed the committees this week that Colonel North, potentially the most important witness in the investigation, would not submit to private questioning by staff lawyers, as other witnesses have, because to do so would violate his right to due process of law. **********Colonel North, the National Security Council staff official who directed the arms sales to Iran and the operations to supply to rebel forces in Nicaragua, originally invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination and refused to testify. Then, the committees granted him immunity from prosecution based on his Congressional testimony. Under the law, that procedure requires him to testify or face imprisonment for contempt of Congress. **********There was mounting concern among committee members, however, that Colonel North might invoke the Fifth Amendment even after a grant of immunity, one investigator said tonight. **********Mr. Sullivan's due process argument was based on the contention, which most of the legislators dispute, that the law establishing procedures for Congressional immunity did not apply to private depositions. **********The committees contend that if Mr. Sullivan's objection is genuine, then he should accept the proposal that Colonel North's private testimony be given to an official session of the committees. **********Mr. Sullivan declined to comment today. **********Representative Dick Cheney of Wyoming, the top Republican on the House panel, said Mr. Sullivan was either seeking the ''best possible arrangement for his client,'' or was engaging in a ''delaying tactic so that Colonel North might never have to testify.'' **********If the latter proved to be the case, Mr. Cheney said, ''the Congress will vote contempt, and the vote will be virtually unanimous.'' **********Then, he said, Colonel North could no longer be perceived as someone with the best interests of President Reagan and the United States at heart and would be widely viewed as ''obviously not a pillar of patriotism.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/25/busin.body_text: **********The wave of mergers, acquisitions and buyouts that has swept through America's largest corporations has reached the country's leading corporate law firms. **********At a dizzying pace, large firms are gobbling up small specialty partnerships or hiring talent from the outside to form departments that concentrate on areas of rapid growth. Bankruptcy and real estate law are particularly hot areas. **********As their clients enter fields far removed from the traditional industrial base of American corporations, large firms are diversifying as well. **********Whether it is a biotechnology division that specializes in patent problems or a white-collar crime unit, the staid giants of business law are adding departments never envisioned a decade ago. Catering to 'Product Lines' **********''There is a great interest in creating in-firm boutiques for particular product lines, the way Macy's does with clothes,'' said Stephen Gillers, a professor at the New York University School of Law. **********The trend reverses the approach of the 1970's, when whole departments of major firms broke off to form their own small partnerships, specializing in such fields as environmental and product liability law, which emerged at that time. **********Numbers are difficult to come by because of the private nature of the mergers and acquisitions among firms. But lawyers who have participated in recent acquisitions and academic observers who follow the trends in the profession say the prices paid to draw in the small firms can run to hundreds of thousands of dollars per partner. **********With many major firms enjoying their most profitable year ever, according to a study by The American Lawyer magazine, there is ample cash available to attract the independent firms. **********Traditionally, large firms have maintained departments in litigation, corporate practice and taxes, while many areas involving a high degree of expertise were handled by smaller firms that served as specialists. The Seminal 60's **********Though the tradition began to change as early as the 1960's, the trend has accelerated dramatically in the last two years. **********In October, for instance, Charles M. Carberry will leave his job as a Federal prosecutor to join the New York office of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, the nation's third-largest firm, to develop a white-collar crime practice in New York. **********White-collar crime, which used to be handled mostly by small firms or solo practitioners with a background in criminal law, has emerged as a bigger business in New York lately in no small part because of the vigor of Mr. Carberry and other prosecutors. **********In his current position as assistant United States attorney in Manhattan, Mr. Carberry has helped direct the prosecutions of Dennis B. Levine, Ivan F. Boesky, Martin Siegel and other Wall Street professionals. **********Also this fall, Morrison & Foerster, a leading corporate firm based in San Francisco, will absorb Parker Auspitz Neesemann & Delehanty, a New York practice with 22 lawyers that is known for its expertise in litigation and entertainment law. **********Parker Auspitz was organized in 1977, when a handful of lawyers at two blue-chip firms in New York left to hang out their own shingle. Specialists Flourish **********''There is no such thing as a corporate lawyer any more,'' said Anthony M. Radice, a partner at Parker Ausptiz. ''There are securities specialists, takeover specialists, regulation specialists and all sorts of others.'' **********In other words, law firms have followed where their clients have led. The growth of the gene-splicing industry, for instance, has created a strong demand for patent lawyers who have scientific backgrounds and are experts in the new technology. **********The Wall Street scandal and political corruption in New York City and on the national level in Washington have created demand for criminal counsel from firms more familiar with public stock offerings and commercial law. **********The broadest changes have come in bankruptcy and real estate law, two specialties that had been considered less prestigious than the kind of corporate counseling practiced on Wall Street. 'It's Big Time' **********''Firms such as Milbank, Tweed and Davis Polk just wouldn't have gone into real estate, which was seen before as a kind of semi-sleazy work,'' said Steven Brill, president and editor in chief of The American Lawyer magazine. ''Now it's big time.'' **********But even within the traditional area of corporate law, the nature of transactions has become complex enough that established firms have been hiring specialists in such growing areas as merchant banking, mortgage-backed securities and futures. **********''The practice of law has become very transaction-oriented and clients are picking their lawyers based on their specialty,'' said Arthur Fleischer Jr., a takeover specialist with Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. ''In the securities area, for instance, there have been more innovations in the last decade than in the previous 50 years.'' **********The turmoil in the profession stems in part from the competition for clients. Every merger takes a client away from a law firm. Large Firms Are Nervous **********''Not too long ago, a firm could relax on a relationship with a few big corporate clients,'' said Carl A. Leonard, the managing partner at Morrison & Foerster. ''But large firms are now nervous about being dependent on few clients, because so many companies are being gobbled up.'' **********The competition for business has led to increased competition for talent as well. In the past, major firms would not have considered enticing senior partners away from competing offices. ''More and more firms are raiding each other's partners, so you can't get dependent on a few lawyers,'' Mr. Leonard said. ''This is quite different from the past, when the same people who started with you at the firm would retire with you.'' **********Legal circles were shocked almost 30 years ago, when Carolyn E. Agger, the wife of former Associate Justice Abe Fortas of the Supreme Court, led a mass defection from Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison to the firm now known as Arnold & Porter. Free Agency Among Lawyers **********In hindsight, that move was a harbinger of things to come. Now senior partners seem to be hopping from firm to firm much the same way that baseball players declare themselves free agents and move from team to team. **********''Firm loyalty has gone out the window,'' said Professor Gillers of New York University. **********The trend can perhaps most clearly be seen at such venerable firms as Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn and Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCoy. Until the last few years, neither firm would hire top partners from outside their ranks, choosing instead to work young associates who over the years climbed the ladder to coveted partnerships. **********Earlier this year, Milbank announced that it would take on Thomas P. Puccio, the former Federal prosecutor who handled the Abscam case, to bolster its litigation practice and perhaps handle some white-collar criminal work. He becomes one of a dozen partners hired from the outside in the last two years. Proskauer has hired a battery of partners to open two divisions. 'Willing to Make Changes' **********''It was a much more conservative profession before than it is now,'' said Edward Silver, a partner at Proskauer who heads its executive committee. ''People are willing to make changes when they were not willing to do that before.'' **********Among the biggest beneficiaries of the wave of diversification are legal headhunters. **********''I see '88 as a very strong year,'' said Alan Roberts, who recruits senior lawyers. ''As a result of firms expanding and servicing different clients, a firm may not have the right mix of talent to handle its business, so they have had to look to the outside for experts.'' **********Mr. Roberts said bankruptcy law had been one of the strongest areas of recruitment in the last few years, and he predicted that it would grow. **********''Many of the buyouts of the last few years have been financed by heavy debt,'' Mr. Roberts said. ''The debt will pull many of those companies down, and that will create more demand for experts in bankruptcy law.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/09/busin.body_text: **********Most of the faculty of the William E. Simon School of Business at the University of Rochester have signed a letter criticizing the university's decision this summer to rescind the admission of an employee of a competitor of the Eastman Kodak Company. **********The university took the action after Kodak officials expressed their concern that the employee of the Fuji Photo Film Company would gain access to some of Kodak's most sensitive information by sharing classes with the company's managers. **********Michael C. Jensen, a professor at the Simon School and at the Harvard Business School, said yesterday that 37 faculty members who had been reached so far approved of the letter. The school has three other faculty members who had not yet been reached. **********The brief statement said the episode had created ''the misperception that the Simon School is a Kodak trade school rather than a major national business school.'' The faculty members also apologized to the Fuji employee. **********The letter called upon the university's board of trustees to ''take the necessary steps to insure that such actions are not repeated.'' **********Robert Krause, a spokesman for the university, said it had no comment on the letter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/08/busin.main_headline: L.F. Rothschild to Cut Jobs and Part of a Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/08/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; L.F. Rothschild to Cut Jobs and Part of a Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/08/busin.body_text: **********L. F. Rothschild Holdings Inc. announced yesterday that it would dissolve a large part of one of its divisions and lay off about 700 workers throughout the company within the next three to six months. **********But officials of the securities firm said that it had ended negotiations about the sale of all or part of the company. **********''L. F. Rothschild is neither being acquired nor going under the auctioner's gavel piecemeal,'' Andrew L. Berger, president of L. F. Rothschild's broker-dealer subsidiary, said at a news conference at the company's headquarters. **********But Francois Mayer, co-chief executive officer of the company, said that, despite yesterday's announcement, the company still could be sold at a future date. ''I can't rule out anything,'' Mr. Mayer said. **********As part of the reorganization, L. F. Rothschild will phase out a ''substantial portion'' of its securities clearing operations in the next few months. **********The company is negotiatiing with the Broadcort Capital Corporation, a unit of Merrill Lynch & Company, to take up the clearing accounts, Mr. Berger said. He said there were no plans for Broadcourt to do the clearing for Rothschild's own accounts. **********After the stock market plunge in October, L. F. Rothschild said it had suffered losses totaling more than $44 million and laid off 150 workers. The company said at the time that it would stop underwriting municipal bonds and that it would scale back its trading risks, particulary in risk arbitrage. **********The plans announced yesterday would mean the company's work force will have been reduced by 40 percent since the beginning of this year from 2,000, to 1,200 people. Officials said the job cuts would be made across the board. **********The cuts are the largest percentage announced by a Wall Street firm since the plunge. On Friday, Kidder Peabody & Company said it would eliminate 14 percent of its staff. **********After the reorganization, Mr. Berger said, L. F. Rothschild would focus on fixed-income trading and sales, arbitrage, the retail brokerage business for high net-worth people, over-the-counter market making and investment banking.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/18/world.main_headline: WALDHEIM TO PAY OFFICIAL VISIT TO POPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/18/world.print_headline: WALDHEIM TO PAY OFFICIAL VISIT TO POPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/18/world.body_text: **********President Kurt Waldheim will pay an official visit to Pope John Paul II in the Vatican next week, the Vatican and the Austrian Government announced today. **********The trip will be Mr. Waldheim's first official trip outside Austria since he was elected to the largely ceremonial office last year under a barrage of charges that he had concealed his record in World War II. **********The United States has formally barred Mr. Waldheim from entry on the ground that he ''participated in activities amounting to persecution'' of Jews and others while serving with German forces in Greece and Yugoslavia. Other West European governments have quietly avoided inviting Mr. Waldheim to visit. **********The announcement of the Vatican visit came a day after the Austria formally protested to Washington that the American action against Mr. Waldheim violated international law and asked that it be withdrawn. The United States rejected the protest. It's an 'Official Visit' **********A spokesman for Mr. Waldheim said he would meet the Pope on June 25 ''with all the protocol of an official visit.'' The Vatican affirmed that the Pope would receive Mr. Waldheim ''on an official visit'' that day. **********It remained unclear at whose initiative the visit was arranged. Mr. Waldheim's spokesman, Gerold Christian, said the invitation had been issued by the Vatican. A senior Vatican official, however, said that the Pope ''never, never invites anyone to an audience.'' **********Vatican officials have in the past emphasized that the Pope's choice of meetings do not imply approval or disapproval and that he is prepared to meet with people whose behavior he does not necessarily condone. **********The Vatican official stressed that Mr. Waldheim was on an official visit, not a private one, and was returning a visit the Pope made to Austria in September 1983. 'No Consideration of Past' **********He said there has been ''no consideration of Dr. Waldheim's past, so far as I know.'' **********Mr. Waldheim is scheduled to visit Jordan in early July. His spokesman said he had also received invitations from Egypt, Hungary, Uganda, Libya, and some Persian Gulf countries. **********Yet the sensation created by the Vatican visit only underscored Mr. Waldheim's international isolation. An afternoon Vienna newspaper, Kurier, carried a banner headline with the news over a photograph showing Mr. Waldheim with his successor as the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar. Mr. Perez de Cuellar is in Vienna for a United Nations conference on drug abuse. **********Also in Vienna for the conference was Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, who issued the ''watch list'' order barring Mr. Waldheim from entering the United States. **********He said he could only repeat what he had said before, that ''we simply followed the law and the requirements of the law of our country,'' and that the American decision ''will not be changed by protest or anything.''  Jewish Groups in U.S. Outraged **********Several American Jewish organizations expressed outrage yesterday at the Pope's plan to receive Mr. Waldheim. Several likened the proposed audience with the Pope's meeting in 1982 with Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, and warned that it could strain Roman Catholic-Jewish relations. **********The president of the Synagogue Council of America, Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman, noted that Jewish spokesmen were scheduled to meet with John Paul when he visits the United States in September. The Waldheim meeting, Rabbi Klaperman said, ''may endanger our visit with John Paul in Miami.'' **********Rabbi Klaperman is scheduled to be the Jewish spokesman at a forum at which the Pope will meet with Jews in Miami on Sept. 11. **********Echoing other prominent Jews, the president of the American Jewish Committee, Theodore Ellinoff, called the proposed audience ''morally and politically incomprehensible.'' **********Other statements in opposition to the visit were issued by the American Jewish Congress, B'nai B'rith International, the Conference of Presidents of M,jor American Jewish Organizations and the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/09/world.main_headline: 10 Killed as Israeli Jets Hit Palestinian Areas
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/09/world.print_headline: 10 Killed as Israeli Jets Hit Palestinian Areas
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/09/world.body_text: **********Israeli jets struck Palestinian targets today in a refugee district near Sidon in southern Lebanon. The police said 10 people were killed and 40 were wounded. **********The Israeli raid, the third in the area in a week, was against positions in and around the Ain Khilwe district, the largest Palestinian settlement in southern Lebanon. **********An Israeli military spokesman quoted by the state radio monitored here said the planes attacked ''command posts used by terrorist organizations,'' a reference to the Palestine Liberation Organization and other guerrilla groups. **********Thousands of P.L.O. fighters who left Beirut in wake of the 1982 Israeli invasion have since returned, many to the area near Sidon. The majority belong to Al Fatah, the group led by the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat. **********The raid today came after a clash in southern Lebanon Thursday night between Palestinian guerrillas and Israeli troops. According to accounts by both sides, two Palestinians were killed and three were captured. **********The guerrillas were intercepted four miles from the Israeli border on the edge of the security zone maintained by the Israeli Army inside Lebanon. According to the Israeli radio, documents found on the Palestinians showed they intended to take hostages in Israel. **********Last month, two Israeli soldiers and several Palestinians trying to slip across the border were killed in a fight.
