KILBORN News Analysis WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - Friday's report of the biggest monthly deficit ever in the nation's foreign trade illustrates the power of partisan politics over theories of sound economics to which even partisan politicians say they subscribe. **********Most economists, including many in the Reagan Administration, attribute much of the trade deficit and the lost jobs and business it represents to the other big deficit, that in the Federal budget. The budget deficit, in turn, in their view persists mostly because of the President's refusal to yield on raising taxes. **********This viewpoint contends that the President has undermined the economically sound and politically calculated objective of Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, Paul A. Volcker, in steering the two-and-a-half-year decline of the dollar. Well before now, Mr. Baker could have assumed that the trade deficit would have shrunk enough to calm the anger in Congress over the jobs the nation was losing to foreign competition. **********Of course, a political impasse between the President and Congress cannot alone explain why America's purchases abroad are exceeding the sales of its goods. In the current situation, the expected effects of the dollar's drop have been offset by several other factors over which American officials have little control. **********For one thing, foreign companies have been willing to cut their profits to hold onto the market shares they have gained in the United States. For another, American consumers continue to show a preference for imported goods in the belief, justified or not, that their quality is higher. Also, the world economy has been growing too slowly to swallow larger quantities of American exports. **********All these circumstances have led to the persistent trade deficit that threatens the President with retribution from Congress in the form of a politically seductive but potentially damaging protectionist trade law. If enacted, it would limit the President's authority to negotiate free-trade agreements with other nations and impose new curbs on American imports of their goods. The Worst Probably Over **********Paradoxically, the protectionist measures might be enacted just as the nation has probably seen the worst of both deficits. Big as the trade imbalance is - $16.5 billion in July and running at a rate $12 billion more than last year's record of $156 billion - the figures camouflage a pronounced turn in the volume of trade, such as bushels of wheat and corn, and shipments of automobiles and computers, if not as yet in the monetary value. **********The turn, obscured by the sinking dollar, began a year ago, and since then much of the nation's farming and manufacturing businesses have been selling more abroad, restoring their edge against imports at home and reaping the rewards of more jobs and fatter profits. American trade, in fact, is now displacing business and consumer spending in leading the economy's growth. **********This month, next month, sometime soon, economists say the value of trade will start following the trend in volume, as it already has in agriculture. But the evidence of the turn has yet to influence the oratory of Congress. **********''We are in the sad situation of going from bad to worse,'' the Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, said in the aftermath of the trade report. In West Virginia, unemployment has dropped to about 9 percent from 11 percent a year ago, and the national rate, at 5.9 percent, is the lowest in eight years. **********''The Democrats had a partisan issue that they could exploit,'' said Richard N. Cooper, an economics professor at Harvard and an Under Secretary of State in the Carter Administration. ''They're not willing to back off because it means eating their words of a year ago.'' Smaller Budget Deficit **********Meanwhile, the budget deficit, to which economists attribute much of the trade deficit, is expected to plunge to around $160 billion this year, from a record $221 billion last year, and then rise to $190 billion in the next two years before declining again. As a percentage of the overall economy, the gross national product, it has fallen sharply from more than 6 percent four years ago to less than 5 percent last year. **********These changes in the gauges of the economy's performance would imply that the nation needs less restrictive trade legislation, not more, to exploit the rewards of a cheaper dollar. The fall in the currency's value raises the prices of the goods the nation imports and lowers the prices of its exports. **********But the shifts in the statistics have not been nearly so pronounced now as they have been in past instances of a falling dollar or persuasive enough to alter attitudes in some of the politically powerful sectors of the economy that suffered most from the dollar's rise in 1980 to 1985. **********The biggest reason for that, most economists say, is the size of the budget deficit, which keeps the dollar stronger than it would be otherwise. The Treasury sells securities to finance the deficit. Foreigners, like Americans, buy the securities, and they have to buy dollars to do so, pushing up demand and thus the currency's value. Partisan Gridlock **********The budget deficit remains large because of the continuing partisan gridlock over President Reagan's refusal to raise taxes and Congress's refusal to cut nonmilitary spending unless he goes along with a tax increase. The more intransigent of the two is the President, to the dismay even of many members of the Administration. They worry that, whatever the hazards of giving some ground on taxes, the hazards of the trade deficits are worse. **********''The economy's now on the right track,'' Mr. Cooper said. ''It would be desirable if the President would make a deal on a tax increase, but he won't.'' **********Aides to the President attribute his tenacity to his political priorities. His top priority is not free and open trade but stopping the growth of government, an objective he can meet by stopping the growth of taxes that pay for government. **********The Democratic leadership of Congress is tenacious, too, in resisting the President's proposals of further reductions in nonmilitary Government spending to cut the budget deficit. **********The President's stand has frustrated those of his associates who expected the protectionist crescendo in Congress. However much critics have faulted some of the Reagan Administration's economic policies, Mr. Baker, as the architect of the drive against the dollar, stands on the side of the angels on this one, in the opinion of most economists. His initiative was indisputably good economics, and it was widely applauded across the spectrum of economists and even by Democrats in Congress. Effects of Protectionism **********The alternative, protectionist laws to restrain imports, would help domestic industry for a while, but other countries would be expected to retaliate against the American protectionism, enacting tariffs, quotas and other restraints of their own. World trade would atrophy, inflation would rise, and countries could face a depression like the one of the 1930's that is often attributed in part to the American Smoot-Hawley tariffs. **********In the present case, bringing the trade deficit down required more than a campaign against the dollar. The strong, trade-surplus countries, especially West Germany and Japan, would need to speed up their economies so they would buy more American goods, and as yet they have delivered much less than Mr. Baker expected. And more important, reducing the trade deficit required solid reductions in the budget deficit. **********Some senior officials speak, without attribution, of a compromise under which the President would go along with a tax increase if Congress accepted the President's proposals for a balanced budget amendment or a line-item veto, which would give him authority to excise specific expenditures that Congress puts into the budget. But Congress has repeatedly rebuffed him on these, even when the Senate was in Republican control. **********Analysts say they expect that, with trade now helping the American economy, the protectionist passions of Congress will cool and that the trade law that emerges will be milder than some have feared. But because of the gridlock over the budget, they still expect a measure of politically expedient, unsound economics. **********''Any way we look at it,'' said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, ''the trade bill is going to be tougher and more restrictive than what we've got.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT; MANILA STRIVES TO TURN CORNER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/busin.body_text: **********After three years of painful and destabilizing recession, the Philippine economy is showing signs of recovery, perhaps even an impending boom, economists and diplomats here say. **********So far, it is only a thaw in an economic winter that has cut this nation's per capita income by 15 percent and that has nurtured a Communist insurgency. But economic statistics and anecdotal evidence suggest that the economy turned around sometime late last year, and private and public economists alike forecast a resurgence of growth beginning this year. **********''We have finally reversed the economic decline of the last few years,'' President Corazon C. Aquino said at a news conference this month. **********In a country in which seven persons out of 10 live below the poverty line, an economic recovery is essential if Mrs. Aquino is to consolidate her fragile authority. **********Philippine and foreign analysts say that the ultimate test of Mrs. Aquino's policies is whether they can alleviate the worst poverty in this island group of 56 million people, where per capita income is only $600 a year. Just over a year ago, the country was in disarray because of growing opposition to former President Ferdinand E. Marcos, and then a campaign after which both Mr. Marcos and Mrs. Aquino claimed victory. People took to the streets, and business confidence plummeted with the uncertainty. Even after Mr. Marcos fled to Hawaii in February 1986, the social disorder and possibility of a coup or gains by the insurgents dampened the business climate. Evidence of Improvement **********Since then, after some initial hesitation, the economy has shown signs of improvement. Statistics here are often out of date and not reliable, but analysts cite this evidence: *********** After falling in the first half of 1986, economic output swelled in the fourth quarter, resulting in 0.13 percent growth in gross national product for the year. That is meager, and well behind the population growth of 2.5 percent per year, but it is a welcome reversal from declines in G.N.P. of 3.8 percent in 1985 and 5.6 percent in 1984. *********** The rate of inflation dropped from 40 percent two years ago to less than 1 percent over the last year. Interest rates also have fallen sharply, allowing businesses to borrow again. *********** Capital flight, which had robbed the Philippines of billions of dollars in recent years, has abruptly stopped. Some of the money may return voluntarily, because of attractive investment opportunities. Some of it also may come back as a result of lawsuits seeking to recover the wealth of Mr. Marcos and his associates. *********** The price paid to farmers for copra, or coconut meat, has jumped two and a half times over the last year. A year ago, the money would have gone to a coconut monopoly, but since the monopoly was ended last year, the funds now go to the farmers. One-third of the Philippine population depends directly or indirectly on coconut farming, so the price increase has resulted in a vast infusion of buying power in rural areas. Consumer Sales Increase **********''The coming boom was already evident in the last quarter,'' said Bernardo M. Villegas, an economist at the business-financed Center for Research and Communication in Manila. ''Consumer firms were reporting sales increases of 20 percent to 25 Mr. Villegas, whose estimate for 1986 was on the mark, says his calculations suggest a boom. The Government forecast of 6 percent economic growth this year is ''chickenfeed,'' he said, and growth could amount to 8 percent. **********Most economists are not so optimistic, however, and think growth of 3 percent to 5 percent is more likely for 1987 - a still-robust gain for an economy that had been shrinking. **********For now, two forces seem to be at work in waking the economy: Government spending and consumer spending. The Government is starting some major housing and public works projects, while shoppers seem busier than they have been in a while. More Investment Sought **********But challenges remain. Simply to keep unemployment at the present 11.8 percent level, the economy must create 628,000 jobs this year. And to achieve stable growth, businesses must invest in factories and equipment so that production can be increased. **********''The real question is when investment in real assets will pick up,'' a Western diplomat in Manila said. **********The Philippines expected a jump in investment after Mr. Marcos left a year ago, but instead investment continued to fall. Overall investment fell 15 percent last year, on top of a 21 percent decline in 1985. The biggest drop was in investment in private construction, which plummeted 42 percent. One reason is that the economic contraction has resulted in enormous unused capacity at many factories. **********A boom in foreign investment also failed to materialize. For the first nine months of 1986, foreigners invested $137 million in the Philippines, not much more than the $95 million in the depressed year-earlier period. Hopes for Foreign Money **********But signs are emerging that Americans and perhaps Europeans may now invest more money in the Philippines, even though the Japanese may remain aloof. A group of 27 American executives toured the country last month and said at a news conference they found many attractive investment opportunities. **********One deterrent to increased investment has been the Government's slow pace in selling state assets. Officials are proceeding cautiously, partly for fear of criticism that they are holding a ''fire sale'' of hotels and companies owned by the Government. **********Revenue from the sale of the assets will go to finance a land distribution program, Mrs. Aquino announced this month. But some economists fear that the land program, while a crucial move toward greater equity, will absorb vast amounts of money without increasing agricultural production. **********Foreign investors will gain more confidence if the Philippines and its bank creditors reach an agreement soon on rescheduling some of the country's $28 billion debt. Officials in Manila are seeking a very low interest payment on those bank loans, to conserve dollars desperately needed at home. **********However, a continued impasse in the debt talks - or a freeze on interest payments, as is being discussed here - might frighten potential foreign investors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/busin.main_headline: Dollar Falls Nearer Key Test Levels
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS; Dollar Falls Nearer Key Test Levels
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/busin.body_text: **********The dollar slipped closer to critical levels in relation to the yen and mark yesterday. **********If the dollar breaches those levels, traders forecast, central banks would have to intervene forcefully or else see the dollar move substantially lower. The test could come as soon as today, they said. **********Yesterday's decline was substantial, and dealers said it was significant that so few participants were buying dollars. Bearish sentiment remains rampant, traders said. **********''The overwhelming interest is still to sell the dollar,'' said Paul O'Gara, chief foreign-exchange dealer at the Midland Bank in New York. Developments Watched Closely **********The dollar's decline suggested that higher interest rates would be needed to attract foreigners back to the dollar, and that sent bond yields to their highest level of the year. The selloff in the bond market in turn hurt equities, with the Dow Jones industrial average slumping 26.79 points, to 2,675.06; the average has dropped 47.36 points since hitting a record 2,722.42 on Tuesday.  [ Page D4. ]  Currency traders and market technicians watched the day's developments closely because the dollar descended near levels - 140 Japanese yen to the dollar and 1.80 West German marks to the dollar - that are considered particularly significant. **********Most participants assume that monetary authorities would like to see the dollar trade in a range of 140 to 150 yen and 1.80 to 1.90 marks. **********''It will be interesting to see if the market will hold here,'' one bank trader said. ''We are closing close to a very big signal. If we break 1.80 marks, I would not be surprised to see the central banks come in in force.'' There were unconfirmed reports yesterday that the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve were in the market yesterday, buying small amounts of dollars. **********In late New York trading, the dollar was bid at 141.70 yen, down from Wednesday's 142.95 and nearly 2 yen lower than Tuesday's rate. Dollar Off Against Mark **********The dollar slipped even more against the mark, dropping to a late New York bid of 1.8085 from 1.8249 on Wednesday. **********Gold also weakened yesterday. At the Republic National Bank in New York, the 4 P.M. bid for gold was $456 an ounce, down $1 from Wednesday. **********The testing of the dollar could come early this morning after the Japanese announce their trade results for July. **********''Around 6:30 Friday morning the Japanese trade numbers will be out,'' said Carmine J. Rotondo, chief corporate dealer at the Security Pacific Bank in New York. ''If that number comes out showing a surplus of more than $7 billion, and I think it will, that will be a bearish signal.'' A figure that large, he said, ''will give us an indication of how bad our own trade numbers could be when they are reported on Sept. 14.'' **********Mr. Rotondo's comments underscored a pervasive fact that has been running through the currency markets for the last two weeks: June's stunningly large $15.17 billion merchandise trade deficit. That number continues to prey on traders' minds and is at the core of why the dollar has fallen since early August. **********''The last trade number was really a slap in the face,'' one dealer said. Negative Feelings About Dollar **********That figure, plus the absence of any comment about the dollar from either Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d or Alan Greenspan, the new Federal Reserve chairman, has left participants with their own negative feelings about the dollar. **********''I'm not sure the central banks want to see the dollar go higher,'' said the chief trader at a major New York bank, ''but merely want to be there to insure that it doesn't go into a free fall.'' **********The trader added that the depth of the market's bearishness was brought out on Wednesday when, in spite of significant dollar buying by multinational companies, the dollar continued to slide. Corporations were absent from the market yesterday; trading was limited to professionals. **********''On Wednesday corporates bought well over $1 billion,'' the trader said. ''But the darn thing just kept going lower.'' Market's Pessimism **********The market's pessimism was compounded during the day when remarks by Henry Kaufman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, flashed across screens. **********In a reiteration of an earlier forecast, Mr. Kaufman predicted that the dollar would eventually drop below 130 yen and 1.70 marks. **********''Kaufman didn't move the market,'' one trader said, ''but he didn't make us feel any better.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/world.main_headline: WHERE CAPITALIST ROADERS CLING TO THE FAST LANE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/world.print_headline: CANTON JOURNAL; WHERE CAPITALIST ROADERS CLING TO THE FAST LANE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/world.body_text: **********South of the Yangtze River here, the frigid political gale from Beijing seems little more than a faint breeze, dissipated in a climate of brazen money making, spirited discussion and fashions that shout Hong Kong chic. **********Relentlessly, national newspapers rail against the evils of Westernization, the political sins of making and spending money and the pollution of ideas from the likes of Sartre and Freud. **********But here in Canton, and in Shenzhen, down the Pearl River, there are few signs that the political campaign against ''bourgeois liberalization'' means very much. There are even fewer signs that the country's new economic policies will stall here. **********Canton's province, Guangdong, ''is a place that has been opened to the West earlier than the rest of China,'' said Li Zuoxing, the deputy editor of The Yangcheng Evening News. ''These things came earlier. A lot of people here have relatives in the outside world. People here pay attention to the outside world.'' 'People Here Are More Open' **********''Every place is different,'' he continued. ''Every place has its own historical background. The people here are more open to the outside world, more relaxed. In history, our people were more like this.'' **********Both Canton and Shenzhen, a so-called Special Economic Zone created to attract foreign investment a bit more than 100 miles from Hong Kong, are at the heart of the economic policies devised by Deng Xiaoping, the principal Chinese leader, to invigorate the country's economy. Western and Japanese management practices are spreading, private businesses are germinating, and the Government is loosening its grip on economic activity. **********On People's Avenue here, young men in tidy jackets and ties and women in crisp pastel cotton suits with subtle padded shoulders dart along the sidewalks to their offices. Restaurants, both private and city-owned, swell with lunchtime crowds, and young entrepreneurs flash their Great Wall credit cards with the deftness of a New York banker on an expense account lunch. Flexible Private Enterprise **********''Each year since 1979, private enterprise has jumped,'' said Liu Xingya, who heads the Canton Individual Labor Association, a group formed to protect the interests of private shopowners and businessmen. ''Private enterprise is more flexible than state enterprise. It's scattered in every part of the city. Private enterprise provides more small business, more service.'' **********There are, Mr. Liu estimates, 150,000 residents engaged in some sort of private business, from the Changxin Fashion Shop with 40 employees to individuals who repair shoes on streetcorners. **********The surge of private business here has lent this city of three million a freewheeling character that contrasts markedly with Beijing's bureaucratic stodginess. It has also helped to insulate Canton and much of southern China, at least so far, from the political campaign against Western ways. **********In Beijing, Communist Party leaders and the press continue to focus on the need to struggle against ''bourgeois liberalization'' - the phrase is a pejorative catchword used to denote Western ideas that challenge the supremacy of the party - but in Canton, the notion is brushed off like a piece of lint. Using Hong Kong **********A Western diplomat in Canton argued that the desire of Chinese leaders not to upset Hong Kong, for fear that investors will pack up and leave, is a shield hoisted by southern China. **********''The south is using Hong Kong to fend off the north, to protect themselves from Beijing,'' the diplomat said. ''If things get out of hand in Beijing and Hong Kong starts to get nervous, the south sure points this out to the north. Nobody wants to upset Hong Kong. And they save themselves in the process.'' **********Despite the confidence exuded by many southerners, there remain limits on expression. In Shenzhen, a city that sprang from waterlogged rice paddies in the last eight years, city officials closed the popular newspaper, The Shenzhen Youth Herald, for, among other things, calling for the retirement of Mr. Deng, who is 82 years old. **********''The Youth Herald went against the aims of the party and went against the socialist road,'' said Zou Erkang, a Deputy Mayor of Shenzhen. ''It did not play the role it should play.'' **********Shenzhen, which abuts Hong Kong, has in fact developed very much like a bit of the West clinging to the edge of China. Tipping, a practice shunned in most of China, is encouraged. Factory workers punch time clocks, something anathema to China's notions of labor. Taxi drivers, whenever possible, disdain China's currency and demand Hong Kong dollars in payment instead. **********Although there is much talk in Beijing about of the process of economic change will be stalled, both Shenzhen and Canton officials insist that nothing will change in the south. **********''We will not slow down the economic reform,'' said Xu Zhi, a deputy secretary general for the Canton city government. **********''We have been carrying out correct policies,'' Mr. Xu said. ''We think we should continue to carry it out.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/06/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Movement At Pan Am
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/06/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Movement At Pan Am
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/06/busin.body_text: **********AFTER months of hunting for an investor to make a major infusion of capital in Pan American World Airways, a coalition of unions at the airline and their investment banker, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., may be getting closer to their goal. **********A team of consultants, some of whom are considered top experts in the industry, have concluded a six-week study of the airline for Kirk Kerkorian, the West Coast financier who said more than a month ago that he was interested in buying a stake in Pan Am. **********Sources close to the study said Mr. Kerkorian was expected to send the team back this week to begin talks with Pan Am's unions, seeking an agreement on a way to gain control of the airline. A spokesman for Pan Am said the company did not comment on takeover efforts. The leaders of the union coalition were in a meeting and could not be reached for comment. **********Mr. Kerkorian, the majority owner of MGM/UA Communications through the Tracinda Corporation, did not return telephone calls to his office. **********The fortunes of Pan Am's stock have been closely tied to takeover rumors. **********Pan Am's stock closed yesterday at $4.50, down 12.5 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock was trading at about $6 earlier this year when takeover speculation was at its height. But after Resorts International sold its 12.2 percent stake in July and Donald J. Trump, the real estate developer who took control of Resorts, also sold a block, the takeover speculation subsided. The price of the stock has sagged since then. **********The talks with the unions will be crucial in determining if Mr. Kerkorian pursues a purchase, the sources said. The unions indicated earlier this year that they would be prepared to offer about $180 million a year in concessions over three years. **********In return for the concessions, they said they wanted to increase the 7 percent stake that workers now have in Pan Am. The coalition also wants to control the board and gain other safeguards of employee interests. **********After months of trying to find an financial angel, however, it was unclear what the coalition's position would be in the upcoming talks. The coalition, known as the Joint Labor Council of Pan Am, represents about 20,000 of the airline's workers and is made up of four of the five unions at the company. **********The leaders formed the group to seize the initiative and protect the interests of its members if any attempt was made by management to find a buyer for the airline. The group at first hired the investment banking firm of Rothschild Inc. and then added Drexel Burnham Lambert. **********In August the unions held talks with Sir James Goldsmith, the financier, who also had a team of experts look at the airline. A source close to that effort said the Goldsmith exploration broke down when the team said the labor coalition would have to make much deeper wage cuts than the $180 million a year they had proposed. **********Although Pan Am has shown some recovery because of heavy traffic to Europe this summer, managment considers its costs too high to assure long-term survival. The company earned $10.5 million in the second quarter, in contrast to a loss of $152.4 million in the second quarter of 1986. **********The increased European travel is lasting longer lasting than expected. The airline reported yesterday that its traffic was up 14.4 percent in September, compared with last year. Its load factor, which measures how full planes are, was 62.2 percent for the month, compared with 54.1 percent in September 1986. **********The carrier has had much better results all year and may reach its goal of showing a profit this year, company officials have predicted, after many years of losses. **********Even if Mr. Kerkorian and his staff work out an agreement with the labor coalition, there remains a major hurdle - Pan Am's strongest union, the Transport Workers Union, which is not part of the labor group. Presumably an agreement would have to be worked out with the T.W.U. for a smooth takeover. **********Pan Am's board is scheduled to have its regular October meeting today, but it is not expected to consider any Kerkorian or union proposals. **********The union coalition has put Pan Am management in the unusual role of reacting to the coalition's drive to find a buyer for the company. Just as in the case of the takeover of Trans World Airlines by Carl C. Icahn, the switched roles at Pan American are another indication of how unions have been able to use their ability to give concessions as a way of playing a major role in any takeover of their airline.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/21/world.body_text: **********Amid reports that Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi is preparing sweeping changes in his party and administration, his sharpest critics were reported today to be planning a series of rallies across India to press for his resignation. **********The critics organizing the effort are led by Vishwanath Pratap Singh, a former Defense and Finance Minister who was expelled from Mr. Gandhi's Congress Party on Sunday. **********Leaders of various opposition groups met with Mr. Singh and his aides today and urged joint action to press for the resignation of Mr. Gandhi. Mr. Singh and other opposition leaders are planning joint speaking appearances, and political analysts have said his expulsion is likely to make him the undisputed leader of the national opposition. **********It is still difficult to determine how much support the dissidents have, and there were no reports of additional members of Parliament joining them today. Four lawmakers have already been expelled from the party and seven other Congress members of Parliament from have expressed their support. Mr. Singh says he has no immediate plans to start a new party, although he has not ruled out a split within the Congress Party. Personnel Shake-Up Foreseen **********News reports from Uttar Pradesh, the country's most populous and politically important state, said that at least 23 state-level legislators from the Congress Party had extended their support to Mr. Singh. More were expected to follow, an aide to Mr. Singh said. **********As for the Prime Minister's plans, a senior Cabinet member said today that Mr. Gandhi would undertake a personnel shake-up in an effort to resolve his current political problems and redeem his public image as an honest and decisive leader. **********''He is certainly thinking of going about it in a fairly decisive manner,'' said the Cabinet minister, who is a close adviser to the Prime Minister. The official asked not to be identified. The Cabinet official said that the changes were likely before Parliament convenes July 27, and others said the changes would involve the dismissal of several ministers, aides and secretaries in the Congress Party. New aides with extensive political experience are likely to be brought in, the Cabinet official said. Investigation of a Friend **********There has been speculation in the local press that several chief ministers or top elected officials in states where the Congress holds power would be replaced. But the Cabinet official said he could not confirm these reports. **********The Cabinet minister said an investigation into reports that a childhood friend of the Prime Minister who now lives in Switzerland, Ajitabh Bachchan, held illegal overseas assets is also expected to reduce the criticism of Mr. Gandhi and help him rebuild his public image. **********Critics have accused the Prime Minister of being connected with Mr. Bachchan, a charge that has been strongly denied, and of trying to shield him and his brother, Amitabh Bachchan, who is the country's most popular film actor. Amitabh Bachchan resigned his seat in Parliament last week as the scandal about his brother grew, embarassing Mr. Gandhi.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/31/world.main_headline: SEOUL APOLOGIZES FOR STUDENT'S KILLING BUT WARNS PROTESTERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/31/world.print_headline: SEOUL APOLOGIZES FOR STUDENT'S KILLING BUT WARNS PROTESTERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/31/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Lee Han Key apologized to the nation today for the police torture killing of a dissident student in January, but he warned opposition groups that the Government would not tolerate any attempt to embarrass it further. **********In a radio address, Mr. Lee expressed the Government's shame and regret over the death of the 21-year-old student, Park Chong Chol, on Jan. 14 under police interrogation and also over a subsequent cover-up. He said the Government wanted to end the national crisis caused by the death. **********''I express a deep sense of shame over the facts that a tragic incident occurred in a country which subscribes to democracy and respects human rights and that more wrongdoings were perpetrated in dealing with it,'' he said. **********Opposition leaders rejected the Government investigation that led to the apology and said today that involvement of high officials was being concealed. An opposition alliance said the opposition would go ahead with protests despite warnings. **********Mr. Park's death and a cover-up of how many officers were involved stirred national outrage. President Chun Doo Hwan dismissed Prime Minister Lho Shin Yong and other key ministers on Tuesday to try to defuse the crisis. Six police officers were arrested or indicted Friday in the killing and cover-up. **********Anti-Government students kept up their demonstrations today. Hundreds of students shouting ''Down with the military dictatorship!'' protested at Sungkyunkwan University. Students staged a protest and hunger strike at Seoul Methodist Theological Seminary. **********Mr. Lee warned opposition groups to stop playing up the death and questioning the Government's sincerity. **********''I make it clear that the Government will have no other choice but to deal resolutely with violent demonstrations and illegal assemblies,'' he said. **********The National Coalition for a Democratic Constitution called on the Government to resign. The newly formed alliance said it would go ahead with plans for national protests June 10. **********Officials announced Friday that three top police commanders, including a deputy chief of the national police, had been arrested for concealing how many officers took part in death. Three junior officers were charged Friday with the killing and torture of Mr. Park. Two other junior officers were charged with the death earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/world.main_headline: India Says Its Troops Are Nearly in Control of Tamil Rebel Center
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/world.print_headline: India Says Its Troops Are Nearly in Control of Tamil Rebel Center
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/world.body_text: **********An Indian official said today that Indian troops had ''more or less'' seized control of a Tamil rebel stronghold in Sri Lanka, but that the top rebel commander had escaped, perhaps with most of his associates. **********The official, J. N. Dixit, the Indian High Commissioner in Colombo, said ''pockets of resistance'' remained in the northern city of Jaffna, where ethnic Tamil guerrilla separatists have been under siege for nearly two weeks. He said these pockets included ''groups of young people in bunkers'' firing mortars and shells at advancing Indian forces. **********The reported escape of Velupillai Prabakaran, commander of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the Tamil separatist group, was likely to be seen as a major blow to Indian hopes for restoring peace to northern and eastern Sri Lanka. Tamil guerrillas have been fighting a war in these areas for a separate nation, or ''eelam,'' since 1983. **********Mr. Dixit said Mr. Prabakaran was reported hiding somewhere south of Jaffna near the town of Mannar. **********India has about 20,000 troops in Sri Lanka under a July 29 accord between the Governments of the two countries. The accord called for a surrender of weapons by the Tamil rebels in return for greater political autonomy in the north and east. **********Tamils are numerous in those two areas but are far outnumbered on the island as a whole by ethnic Sinhalese, who also dominate the Government and armed forces. Most Tamils are Hindus, and a far larger Tamil population lives in southern India. The Sinhalese are predominantly Buddhist. **********The Jaffna siege began Oct. 10, with about 8,000 Indian troops trying to encircle about 2,000 Tamil guerrillas firing at them with automatic weapons, mortars and rocket-propelled grenades. India says its forces have killed more than 600 members of the Liberation Tigers, and many bodies remain unidentified. **********Since the siege started, the Tigers have vowed to continue their attacks on military and civilian targets even if the Indian Army took Jaffna. Many analysts said the only hope of thwarting such efforts was to capture the group's leaders. **********''The main objective of the Indian offensive, in crude terms, has been to capture Prabakaran,'' said Neelan Tiruchelvam, a moderate Tamil leader who is a former member of Parliament. ''If they don't succeed in that, they haven't done very much.'' **********Some Tamil officials said today that they saw some hope of reconciliation in a recent Tiger statement that they would surrender their weapons if India guaranteed their personal security and the security of all Tamils. But Indian officials said the offer left too large a loophole for the guerrillas to continue fighting if they considered their security imperiled. **********Instead, India now insists that the guerrillas formally accept all the terms of the Indian-Sri Lankan accord and lay down all their arms. When the accord was first signed, Mr. Prabakaran announced that he would oppose it peacefully but would hand over the Tigers' weapons in deference to India.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/world.main_headline: A Tax Dispute Stalls the Japanese Parliament
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/world.print_headline: A Tax Dispute Stalls the Japanese Parliament
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/world.body_text: **********Growing opposition to a plan to overhaul Japan's tax system has brought Parliament to a standstill and threatens to weaken the political strength of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone. **********Today, for the 11th day in a row, Japan's Parliament did not meet, as opposition party members continued to boycott proceedings in protest at a proposed sales tax. **********Late this evening, however, negotiators between the ruling and opposition parties appeared to have won an agreement that Parliament would resume session on Thursday. But the political dispute over the tax was certain to continue. The sales tax is a key part of a planned revision of Japan's tax system, the first in nearly 40 years. **********Several of Japan's trading partners, including the United States, have called on Tokyo to change those parts of its tax system that reward saving and discourage spending, as one way of reducing Japan's huge trade surplus. **********Mr. Nakasone has staked his political credibility on winning passage of the plan, which would cut personal income tax rates, end a tax-free savings account system and impose a 5 percent sales tax. In addition to strong protests from the opposition parties, however, he is facing what amounts to an unusual rebellion from within his own party and from groups that are usually among his main backers. **********Several local chapters of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, including the Tokyo chapter, the party's largest, have publicly pledged to fight the sales tax, fearing that its passage would ruin their chances of re-election. Some politicians have also joined public rallies against the tax, an action for which they were publicly scolded by party leaders. **********Japanese business is also split. Some key supporters of the party, including people involved in small businesses and distributors, have vociferously opposed the sales tax, and some large-scale business organizations, like the Japan Chamber of Commerce and Industry, have also spoken against it. **********The dispute over the sales tax is becoming a barometer of Mr. Nakasone's political strength. Public-opinion polls conducted by the daily Yomiuri Shimbun show that support for his administration recently dropped by 10 percentage points in one month, to 38.1 percent. The reasons cited were the sales tax and his military policy. Last month, the Government decided to break with a decade-old policy and allow military spending to exceed 1 percent of the gross national product. **********The opposition to Mr. Nakasone's plan contrasts sharply with the victories he won when he obtained the change in military policy and when he was able to include the sales tax and the abolition of tax-free savings in the plan despite fears that these measures would prove unpopular. **********In his tenure as Prime Minister, Mr. Nakasone has tried to forge a new leadership style that would be more direct and more internationally visible than that of many of his predecessors. **********He has sketched out ambitious goals for change, including the privatization of several Government-owned companies like Japan National Railways and Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, as well as changes in Japan's educational system. **********In many cases, he has gone over the heads of other politicians and the powerful Japanese bureaucracy by creating what he calls independent advisory commissions. These have been filled with people whose professional qualifications are excellent but who could also be counted on to make proposals that reflected Mr. Nakasone's position. **********Although the public has usually applauded Mr. Nakasone's leadership style, some of his fellow politicians have found him to be abrasive and arrogant. Some of the opposition to the sales tax, then, may also reflect politicians' desires to weaken Mr. Nakasone's influence and pave the way for a successor. Mr. Nakasone's term officially expires in October. **********It is not clear whether the protest over the sales tax will force changes in the tax proposals. Mr. Nakasone and other leaders of the ruling party reaffirmed their support of the plan Monday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/27/busin.body_text: **********Boom Times for the Fax. . . **********Facsimile machine sales are humming these days. Unit sales of the devices, which transmit copies of documents over telephone lines, will reach 225,000 this year, and grow to more than 900,000 over the next five years, according to a recent study. **********''This is the next boom market in low-end telecommunications technology,'' said Casey Dworkin, general manager of Personal Technology Research in Boston, which conducted the study. Mr. Dworkin predicts that the use of facsimile machines by small companies will triple over the next five years until nearly half of small businesses are using them. **********Prices of facsimile machines have already dropped substantially, he said, and they will come down even further. ''Basic units that are now retailing for $1,299 will soon be selling for less than $500,'' he said. ''This means that new buyers will be entering the market by the tens of thousands, if not hundreds of thousands, quite soon.'' **********While lower prices may be a boon to the majority of small businesses, they could mean an end of the store-front facsimile service centers springing up in so many office complexes. The centers allow their customers, usually small businesses, to send or receive documents at prices of up to several dollars a page.  . . .and the MIDI **********What's MIDI? It's an acronym for Musical Instrument Digital Interface and - among musicians - a verb. ''To MIDI'' is to interconnect musical synthesizers, sequencers, drum machines and even personal computers. It's the technology that allows performers like Peter Gabriel to play, simultaneously, on more than one keyboard at live concerts. **********MIDI is also big business: Sales of computer hardware and software based on this technology have shot to an estimated $500 million since its introduction four years ago, according to Craig Harkins of Hamlin Harkins Ltd., a San Jose, Calif., consultant. **********''We are sure the market will at least double by the end of the decade,'' Mr. Harkins said. Already, MIDI technology, now sold mostly to professional musicians, is coming down in price. ''It's only a matter of time before this moves into the consumer market,'' Mr. Harkins added. **********Indeed, the five top manufacturers of musical synthesizers, which created MIDI - Yamaha, Korg, Roland, Kawai and Sequential - are including the musical-interface system with all but their lowest priced-instruments. And the latest generation of personal computers from I.B.M., Apple, Atari and Commodore can all accommodate the technology.  An Eatery's Image **********Restaurants with a certain ''look'' may now be able to stop copycats, thanks to a recent decision by a Federal appeals court in San Francisco. **********The decision in the case - Fuddruckers v. Doc's B.R. Others - extends the doctrine of ''trade dress,'' which usually applies to product packaging, to include ''the total visual image'' of a restaurant as well as its services. **********Fuddruckers, a chain of 107 upscale hamburger restaurants based in Texas, filed suit after Doc's, based in Pheonix, came up with an almost identical menu and decor, which includes glassed-in butcher shops and bakeries, serve-yourself melted cheese and sauerkraut cauldrons and cartons of supplies stacked between the tables. **********''To determine what a restaurant's trade dress is, you consider a lot of tangible things that aren't entitled to trade mark protection individually, but create an intangible whole that is,'' said Paul D. Gutierrez, a San Francisco attorney specializing in trade mark law. Predicting far more confrontations among similar businesses, he added: ''The law is going to be wide open for restaurants to make life difficult for their close competitors.'' **********Others question the significance of the ruling. ''People will continue to 'borrow' ideas for their operations,'' said Joan Lang, executive editor of Restaurant Business, an industry publication. ''It's an interesting development, but it won't stop Fuddruckers' problems or anyone else's.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/27/busin.body_text: **********Almost every major takeover deal that was in the works before the stock market began its slide has been drastically revamped or canceled. Several other major deals still alive are regarded as all but dead. But arbitragers and others emphasize that, on the flip side, lower stock prices present some unusual opportunities for new deals. **********As stocks plummeted, Jardine killed a tender offer for up to 20 percent of the stock of Bear Stearns, Dart abandoned its efforts to acquire Dayton Hudson, a GAF management team said it was reconsidering its $2.3 billion acquisition proposal and Revlon let expire its $5.41 billion proposal to take over Gillette. **********As the reports of failed deals litter Wall Street, though, some investors are trying to divine new ones. **********''A lot of people are buying things,'' said a leading corporate raider, ''and a lot of others are thinking of it.'' Sense of Caution Prevails **********Still, with the Dow Jones industrial average having dropped nearly 28 percent in the past two weeks, there is a sense of caution in the marketplace. **********''If you believe the market is going lower,'' said another corporate raider, ''then nothing is a bargain. There are no buyers for this stuff. I thought the market drop was a big opportunity to buy, and I still do, but it looks as if there could be a lot more blood before things get better. If I had a deal on the table, I'd lower my price.'' **********Among those showing particular caution is Irwin L. Jacobs, a major corporate raider based in Minneapolis. He sold Gillette, McGraw-Hill and Burlington Northern ''weeks ago,'' he said, and his group was ''not a buyer last week or Monday in what you'd call takeover stocks.'' He added, ''We're monitoring the market on a day-by-day basis.'' **********Carl C. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines, which has a $1 billion bankroll, also wants to sit out this part of the market action. ''Tremendous opportunities might be developing,'' he said, ''but I'm sitting on the sidelines.'' Question of Current Value **********Another cautious corporate raider who asked not to be identified said that while he thought he could get financing for a raid and could succeed in a takeover, he was not sure that the individual parts of an acquired company would maintain their current value. **********''People are getting very ugly in this market,'' he remarked. **********Still, some people have been looking for - and finding - what they consider good opportunities. Among them are Asher B. Edelman, the Manhattan arbitrager, who said that in the last two weeks he had been actively involved in the market. Mr. Edelman said he had spent $72 million for 11 1/2 percent of the Foster Wheeler Corporation. He said he said he bought half of it during the market slide. **********''I have confidence in the future of undervalued stocks,'' he said. ''I have been accumulating other stocks in the last week, too.'' Some of the Pending Deals **********Even if several may be in serious danger, here are some of the major deals that arbitragers feel are still alive: *********** The Bank of New York made a $1.4 billion bid for the Irving Bank Corporation on Sept. 25. This is considered one of the more important of the deals still on the table. Bank of New York confirmed yesterday that it was still very much interested -but left often the door to change its mind. Even as Irving's stock slid $9 yesterday, to $41.75, from $78 when the offer was made, J. Carter Bacot, chairman, said, ''We're still moving forward.'' He added, ''While there are no plans to change the terms, we reserve the right to do so.'' *********** Mr. Edelman announced a $876 million tender offer for the Telex Corporation on Oct. 8. Yesterday he said that not only was he ''still interested'' but had a $65-a-share tender offer under way even after Telex's stock sank $13.25, to $37.50. Telex stood at $61 when the offer was first announced. *********** Owens-Illinois Inc. announced on Sept. 17 a $750 million tender offer for Brockway Inc. Owens-Illinois, owned by an investor group headed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, announced on Oct. 21 that it was extending its $60-a-share tender offer for Brockway until Oct. 30. The stock, then $58.375, stood yesterday at $36, down $1.875. *********** The Utah Power and Light Company and Pacificorp, in a complex stock swap, signed a $1.9 billion definitive merger agreement on Aug. 13. In a deal that could give Utah Power stockholders between $32.25 and $38 in Pacificorp stock, Utah Power has the option to withdraw if the offering price falls below the $32.25 minimum. Utah Power stood yesterday at $24.50, down $1.125. Moreover, seven or eight states where the companies operate have to grant regulatory approval. *********** The Charter Medical Corporation got an $890 million buyout offer on Sept. 28 from a group headed by William A. Fickling Jr., its chairman. When the bid was announced, Charter was trading at $38.375, but by yesterday it had fallen to $26.25, down $3.125. *********** The Ford Motor Company and U.S. Leasing International reported on Oct. 12 that Ford was planning a $503 million tender offer. U.S. Leasing, at $67.25 at the time of the announcement, stood yesterday at $65, down $1. *********** The Gelco Corporation agreed on Oct. 2 to a $250 million merger with the General Electric Credit Corporation. Gelco stock traded at the time at $33.25, and by yesterday it had slipped to $30.50, off $1.25. *********** Hanson Trust P.L.C. agreed on Aug. 5 to buy Kidde Inc. in a $1.8 billion cash and securities deal. After rising to $66.125 at the time, Kidde's stock had slid yesterday to $50.125, down $4.25. Warrants to buy Hanson stock as part of the transaction tumbled from $4 then to less than $2 yesterday. And shares in the Interim Systems Corporation, which Kidde stockholders would also receive, have fallen from $3 then to about $2 now. A Setback for Some Deals **********Others deals that are either dead or uncertain include these: *********** Bear Stearns Companies and Jardine Strategic Holdings Ltd. of Hong Kong announced on Sept. 30 that Jardines would buy 20 percent of the investment firm for $390 million. At the time Bear Stearns stock stood at $20, but by yesterday it had fallen to $10, down $2. Jardine, 46 percent owned by Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd., announced on Oct. 23 that it had terminated the proposal. Bear Stearns said it was pursuing its legal options. *********** The Haft family of Washington proposed on Sept. 18 to pay $6 billion for the 95 percent of the Dayton Hudson Corporation it did not own. Dayton's stock immediately jumped to $60 but by yesterday stood at $26, down $2.50. On Oct. 20 the Hafts said they were selling their stock and would abandon the deal, taking a loss on Dayton stock estimated then at some $20 million. *********** The GAF Corporation announced on Sept. 8 that it had received a $2.3 billion buyout proposal from a group headed by Samuel J. Heyman, its chairman. Outstripping Mr. Heyman's $66.50 offer, GAF stock soared $13.25, to $67.75, with arbitragers speculating that the offer might be sweetened. By Oct. 19 the Heyman group said it intended to reconsider. GAF shares stood yesterday at $40.50, down $2.50, making the current deal unlikely. *********** Ronald O. Perelman, chairman of Revlon Inc., offered on June 17 to pay $4.8 billion for the Gillette Company. Under an agreement with the razor blade company, Revlon is not allowed to attempt a takeover for 10 years, but it sought permission, first to pay $40.50 a share and finally as much as $47 a share, or $5.4 billion. Gillette showed no interest. Gillette's stock initially jumped to $40.25 and reached a high of $45.875, but it stood yesterday at $23.50, down $4.25. Mr. Perelman, recognizing that his request was not getting anywhere, let the idea expire on Oct. 15. *********** Mr. Icahn, the head of T.W.A., offered on Oct. 16 to buy the 27 percent of T.W.A. he did not yet own. The $45-a-share offer, made at a time when the stock stood at $31.75, was withdrawn four days later as the stock tumbled $12, to $14. By yesterday T.W.A. shares were $16.50, off $3.125. Mr. Icahn, now watching the market, might try again later, arbitragers said. *********** T. Boone Pickens heads a group with 9.1 percent of the Newmont Mining Corporation. Newmont rose to $77 on Aug. 13 when the Pickens group first entered the picture and then to $92 when he offered on Aug. 31 to pay $95. With the approval of Delaware Chancery Court, Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. now owns 49.7 percent of Newmont, and Mr. Pickens is appealing the ruling to the court. Newmont stood yesterday at $30.375, off $2.625. **********Corporate raiders, meanwhile, are closely watching a market in turmoil. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/world.main_headline: SOUTH AFRICA VOTE STRENGTHENS HOLD OF BOTHA'S PARTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/world.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICA VOTE STRENGTHENS HOLD OF BOTHA'S PARTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/07/world.body_text: **********South Africa lurched further to the right in elections Wednesday, consolidating the Government of President P. W. Botha and apparently establishing the extreme right-wing Conservative Party as the official opposition in the white house of the segregated Parliament. **********As about two million whites cast their votes amid tight security, nearly 1.5 million black workers and students observed a nationwide work stoppage to protest the whites-only vote. **********President Botha's National Party was expected to increase its 127 parliamentary seats to 132. Its gains were at the expense of the relatively liberal Progressive Federal Party, which was expected to win 19 seats, down from 26. Conservatives Gain 6 Seats **********President Botha, whose campaign stressed resistance to Western pressures for racial liberalization and resentment of American sanctions, is expected to claim a strong mandate for his brand of cautious change. **********The four-year-old Conservative Party was projected to win 22 seats, all in Transvaal Province, a gain of 6, and it reduced the National Party majority sharply in 40 constituencies in all four provinces. The party urges more rigid racial segregation and territorial partition. **********In an unexpectedly high turnout, approaching 70 percent, English-speaking voters, who traditionally have voted for the opposition, switched to the National Party and Afrikaner nationalists flocked to the Conservative Party. **********Young urban Afrikaners, whom the Progressive Federal Party had hoped to attract, stayed with the National Party or voted for independents. Incidents of Unrest **********Political analysts said a combination of external and domestic pressure on white South Africans and a relentless law and order campaign by the National Party drove traditional opposition supporters into the Nationalist fold. **********In isolated incidents of unrest, white youths who marched on two polling places in the Transvaal and Natal Province were dispersed by the police, a suspected guerrilla of the African National Congress was arrested at a roadblock in the Western Transvaal, and firebombs were thrown at a school in the key Cape seat of Helderberg. **********But the heavy guard at voting booths insured that the white election went ahead in relative peace. **********The black protest, lead by trade unions, was one of the biggest in the country's history and indicated both the level of black anger at exclusion from Parliament and growing black solidarity. **********Murphy Morobe, publicity secretary of the anti-apartheid United Democratic Front, said the successful protest would show the Government that ''when they return to power on May 7, they will find us more determined and more united against apartheid and National Party rule.'' An Eerie Calm in Soweto **********In the sprawling black satellite of Soweto on Wednesday there was an eerie calm as hundreds of thousands of black workers relaxed at home and soldiers on motorcycles and security forces in armored vehicles patrolled the streets. **********South Africa's 25 million blacks have no vote in the Parliament, which has segregated chambers for the country's five million whites, three million people of mixed race and one million Indians. **********There are 3.03 million registered white voters, representing about 9 percent of the total population. This is 735,000 more voters than were registered in the last white election in 1981 when 770,000 people, 2.3 percent of the population, voted for the National Party and thus chose the Government that rules 34 million people. 'Vote Against Apartheid' **********The two-day black boycott gained momentum Wednesday after more than 500,000 workers and students stayed at home on Tuesday. **********Although black leaders have declared the whites-only election to be both an insult and of ''little interest'' to blacks, anti-apartheid leaders said they would be closely watching the results for signs that the dominant Afrikaners are prepared to break with apartheid. **********In an unexpected move on the eve of the election, Winnie Mandela, wife of the jailed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, said the Congress's message to whites was to ''vote against apartheid.'' **********But Mrs. Mandela said Wednesday that the protest by black workers and students would show that it was the black nation rather than white opposition parties that was the barometer by which the Government should measure the real opposition. Mock Election Held **********In a mock election conducted by the white-owned black newspaper The Sowetan, Mr. Mandela came in first, the exiled African National Congress president, Oliver Tambo, second, and the Anglican Archbishop, the Most Rev. Desmond M. Tutu, third. **********The large-scale defection of Afrikaner intellectuals and the entry of three National Party defectors as independent candidates, challenging the Government on the pace and content of its liberalization program, intensified interest in the results of the election. **********The three defectors ran strongly. Wynand Malan, who quit the governing party in January in protest against laws enforcing segregated residential areas, retained his Transvaal seat of Randburg with a comfortable majority. Dr. Dennis Worrall, a former South African Ambassador to Britain. came tantalizingly close to victory in the key Helderberg seat and Esther Lategan sharply reduced the National Party in Stellenbosch, the center of the Afrikaner intellectual rebellion. **********Mr. Botha's personal position was strengthened by the election results, which dramatically weakened the position of the two men most likely to succeed him as President and party leader. **********F. W. De Klerk, leader of the National Party in the Transvaal, lost nearly a third of the province's seats to the Conservatives and saw his own majority cut sharply. And Jan Christiaan Heunis, Cape leader of the National Party and architect of the Botha program of cautious change, scraped home with 39 votes against Dr. Worrall, The extreme right-wing Herstigte Nasionale Party forfeited its only seat and the New Republic Party lost 4 of its 5 seats. **********There are a total of 164 contested seats in the 178-seat white house of Parliament. The 12 seats not up for election are filled by presidential and party appointment. Of these, the National Party holds 10 and the Progressive Federal Party and Conservative Party one each. Record Number of Candidates **********A record 480 candidates contested all but two of the 166 elected seats in one of the most acrimonious and keenly fought elections since the National Party came to power in 1948. **********The National Party reached its most powerful in 1977 when it won 135, or 82 percent, of the elected seats and 66 percent of the vote. **********In 1981 this fell to 131 elected seats and 57 percent the vote when the Progressives gained seats and the Herstigte Nasionale Party dramatically increased its share of the national vote. **********When the Conservative Party broke away in 1983, the National Party total fell by 16 seats and has leveled off to its present 117 elected seats.
