https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/14/busin.main_headline: Iran Minister to Take OPEC Plan to Teheran
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/14/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT; Iran Minister to Take OPEC Plan to Teheran
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/14/busin.body_text: **********The oil minister of Iran, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, said tonight that he was leaving a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to consult with his Government about a potential agreement that would allow its enemy, Iraq, the freedom to produce as much oil as it wishes. **********Iran had strenuously opposed allowing Iraq to continue its uncontrolled production of oil. **********The agreement would also allow OPEC's present production and pricing structure to remain unchanged until June at least, another development that Iran had opposed. **********Ministers said OPEC will suspend its official gathering to await the Iranian answer to these proposals, which the minister said in an interview he would ''recommend to the Government.'' Significant Defeat for Iran **********The surprising development marks a significant defeat for Iran, if it goes along with these recommendations. For this reason, there is some speculation here tonight that despite the Iranian minister's recommendation, the Government in Teheran might reject it. **********A senior Iranian source, who asked not to be identified, suggested that even if Iran goes along with this accord, the Government will issue a strong statement outlining its views on what he said were the political maneuvering mounted by Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and Iraq here to isolate and corner Iran. **********Iran had objected to the present OPEC pricing and production structure, arguing that overproduction by several members has weakened prices by about 10 percent over the past few months. Iran has also demanded that Iraq be forced into accepting a production quota like all other 12 members of OPEC. And, it asked that the official OPEC price, set currently at $18 a barrel, be raised to $20.70. **********None of these demands are taken into account in the proposed accord, however. Total Output Levels Set **********As it stands now, the agreement, if accepted by Iran, would set total output for 12 members of OPEC at 15.06 million barrels a day, leaving Iraq's additional output of 2.8 million barrels outside the accord, free of restraint. **********In addition it also exempts a gift of oil from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait of another 300,000 barrels a day - given as a form of financial support for its war with Iran - outside the quota system, making Iraq's share 3.1 million barrels a day, the second highest in OPEC after Saudi Arabia. **********This makes total OPEC output about 18 million barrels a day without counting the ongoing excess output by the United Arab Emirates of around 800,000 barrels a day and excesses by other members of the group of about 500,000 barrels a day. **********Many oil experts argue this is far too much for world oil markets where demand for OPEC oil for the first quarter is estimated at 17 million barrels a day at most. The excess oil will weaken prices much further, they say. Prices now hover at an average of $17 a barrel. **********''This is a dissappointment for the market. If they cannot come up with a communique after five days of talks and after a weekend of protection from market forces, then there is going to be a negative reaction,'' said Peter Gignoux, manager of the international energy trading desk at Shearson, Lehman Brothers in London. **********''Even without cheating, this is substantially more than the market requires in the first quarter,'' said John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Research Industry Foundation in New York. **********A senior Arab minister who asked not to be identified said Iran had no choice but to accept this accord. He said the oil minister was ''totally isolated here''. He said the Iranian official is going back to Teheran to personally deflect responsibility for accepting such an obvious political defeat for Iran. He said even Algeria, a traditional ally, has abandoned Iran here. **********''He wants to make sure they won't blame him for this. He is going to get the O.K. from higher-ups there so no one can say later he fumbled this alone,'' the Arab minister said. **********Iranian sources here said they only considered this defeat to be a ''first round'' of an ongoing battle, suggesting that the bitter vendetta between Iran and its Arab enemies inside OPEC will go on in the future to bedevil OPEC. **********The episode, and the failure of OPEC here to address its production and pricing problems, marks the degree to which the seven-year-old gulf war has firmly installed itself as a spoiling factor in OPEC. The vows of revenge by Iran suggest the war's damage is here to stay. **********The bitterness of the war has also ended a somewhat personal relationship maintained between the Saudi oil minister, Hisham Nazer and the Iranian minister, Mr. Aghazadeh, which the Iranian official counted on to smooth things over in the past. Mr. Nazer has refused to meet with Mr. Agazadeh and rejected mediation attempts from the OPEC president, Nigeria's oil minister Rilwanu Lukman, to bring the two men together. **********Iranian sources said they were certain that as a result of the failure to come up with a new accord that would limit output, instability will return to oil markets. **********They said they fully expect to call for an extraordinary meeting of OPEC soon ''maybe in February'' according to one senior Iranian official. They said they were certain by then that many more OPEC members would join then in putting pressure on Iraq, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait to assume responsiblity for reining in the Iraqi runaway production as well as that of their ally, the United Arab Emirates. **********''We hope that in the meanwhile everyone appreciates that even this agreement we have will not be credible if countries like Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates overproduce, and that those who sign must accept their committments not to cheat,'' Mr. Aghazadeh said in the interview.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/11/busin.main_headline: In About-Face, Rochester U. Says Fuji Worker Is Welcome to Attend
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/11/busin.print_headline: In About-Face, Rochester U. Says Fuji Worker Is Welcome to Attend
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/11/busin.body_text: **********The University of Rochester reversed a controversial decision yesterday and invited an employee of Fuji Photo Film Inc. to attend its graduate business school. **********Under pressure from the Eastman Kodak Company, which faces intense competition from Fuji, the university had previously rescinded the admission of the Japanese applicant and had arranged for him to be admitted to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. **********The about-face came soon after the executive committee of the university's board of trustees had called the exclusion of the applicant a mistake. **********The committee asked the faculty of the William E. Simon School of Business to consider the matter, and a quorum of faculty members voted to notify the Fuji employee, Tfuneo Sakai, that he ''is welcome to join his colleagues in the Simon School class of 1989.'' **********Mr. Sakai, who now lives in Arlington, Mass., said he had registered yesterday morning at M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management. **********Reached by telephone last night, he said he had not yet received notification from the Simon School. But he said: ''I am very happy to be able to study at the Sloan School and have made many nice American friends here. I'd like to stay in Boston, but I will answer that question when I receive their letter.'' **********Paul W. MacAvoy, the dean of Rochester's Simon School, said, ''We did the right thing, we corrected a mistake, and we hope he will come.'' **********Mr. MacAvoy said the episode had made the university realize that its position ''is very fragile in terms of the public's perception of our integrity and independence.'' **********He added, ''Now that this has become a public matter, it was important to make clear our willingness to sacrifice everything, if necessary, for those principles.'' **********Yesterday's action addresses what had become a deeply embarrassing episode for the University of Rochester; its well-regarded president, Dennis O'Brien, and the Simon School, which is known for its advocacy of free-market principles. **********Since it became known two weeks ago, the decision to rescind Mr. Sakai's admission - which occurred without consultation with the Simon School's faculty, according to the statement of the trustee committee - has drawn pointed criticism from the school's faculty members and from its chief patron, William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary who is a highly successful financier. 230 Students From Kodak The university's statement said that the earlier decision had been made in an attempt to avert the ''severe problems'' that would ensue if Kodak withdrew ''up to 230 students a year'' that it sends to the various programs of the Simon School. **********The statement said that at the time university officials had told Kodak the ''action taken was specific to the individual, Mr. Sakai,'' and would not be applied ''to Fuji employees as a class.'' **********Nonetheless, the statement continued, the trustee committee was, at the recommendation of Mr. O'Brien, reversing that move because of the ''need to defend the integrity of the university not only in fact, but in perception.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/25/busin.main_headline: Hutton Said to Weigh Sale of Some of Its Parts
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/25/busin.print_headline: Hutton Said to Weigh Sale of Some of Its Parts
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/25/busin.body_text: **********The discussions about the sale of E. F. Hutton & Company have grown more complex, with the investment firm contemplating a dismemberment and the sale of its capital markets division separately from its retail brokerage system, according to Wall Street professionals close to Hutton. **********Hutton announced on Monday that it was actively talking with potential buyers. **********The professionals said Hutton was considering possibilities that ranged from the sale of the firm outright, to the sale of a stake to a major institution, to a breakup. **********One possibility would be the separate sale of Hutton's government securities business, perhaps to its managers. **********The division is led by Mark F. Kessenich Jr., the former head of Citicorp's North American investment banking operations who joined Hutton last year, bringing several other key Citicorp officials with him. **********Which approach Hutton chooses depends on which buyers step forward and how much of Hutton they want, the professionals said. **********The most serious potential bidders at this time are said to be the Transamerica Corporation, an insurance and financial services company; Dean Witter Reynolds, a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Company, and Shearson Lehman Brothers, which is controlled by the American Express Company. **********Shearson said on Monday that it had been contacted by Hutton and was keenly interested in a possible acquisition. L.F. Rothschild Also Seen on Block **********Hutton is not the only weakened brokerage house considering a dismembering of itself. L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin is also looking for a buyer or a substantial infusion of capital, Wall Street officials have said, in the wake of the problems that hit Wall Street after the stock market plunge last month. **********L. F. Rothschild had earlier asked its investment bank, Salomon Brothers, to explore the sale of all or part of the firm, and that search has advanced to the point where a deal could be announced within days, according to the officials. **********One avenue that has been explored is the sale of the firm's retail brokerage division, which has about 240 brokers. **********A number of brokerage houses, including Bear, Stearns & Company and Gruntal & Company, have been approached about their interest, the officials said. **********As for Hutton, Transamerica has previously been a major shareholder. And Peter V. Ueberroth, the Hutton board member who reportedly was key to the decision to put the firm up for sale as the environment on Wall Street turned gloomy, sits on Transamerica's board, too. Mr. Ueberroth is also the Commissioner of Baseball. **********An acquisition of the entire firm is still a great likelihood, the officials said. The brokerage houses eyeing Hutton would be unlikely to settle for less than full control. **********These potential bidders include Shearson, which failed in an attempt to buy Hutton a year ago; Dean Witter Reynolds, and Merrill Lynch & Company. **********Officials at Merrill Lynch and Dean Witter said they would not comment. But officials of these firms were ''kicking the tires'' at Hutton yesterday, as one official involved in the proceedings put it, sifting through its confidential financial data. **********The bidders have been told by Hutton's financial advisers, Salomon Brothers and the Blackstone Group, that some sort of bid should be delivered by next Tuesday. **********The sale of Hutton's government securities business, which trades a range of securities issued by the Treasury and other government agencies, would make sense if Hutton were acquired by a brokerage house. **********Hutton is one of 40 primary dealers, a prestigious group of brokerage houses that deal directly with the Federal Reserve and whose businesses are reviewed by the Fed. **********All three of the brokerage houses that have expressed some interest in acquiring Hutton are also primary dealers. Thus, Hutton's additional membership in this exclusive club would be redundant.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/07/busin.main_headline: Rukeyser Is Shifting From Time to Whittle
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/07/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Rukeyser Is Shifting From Time to Whittle
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/07/busin.body_text: **********William S. Rukeyser, a former editor of Fortune and Money magazines, is joining Whittle Communications, a magazine publisher based in Knoxville, Tenn., as editor in chief. **********''This is a company reaching critical mass,'' Mr. Rukeyser said. The company specializes in magazines, posters and other advertising vehicles for specialized audiences. **********Among its properties are Best of Business, a quarterly digest of business publications put out for distribution to Xerox Corporation customers, and Connecticut's Finest, a quarterly for clients of the Southern New England Telephone Company. **********Whittle's chairman is Chris Whittle, 39 years old, who with Philip Moffitt, 40, built a publishing empire that included Esquire magazine before they decided to separate last year. **********As editor in chief, a post that has been vacant since Mr. Moffitt's departure, Mr. Rukeyser, 48, will direct the editorial design and content of Whittle's 35 existing specialty publications, in addition to 24 publications under development, Mr. Whittle said. **********Mr. Rukeyser has worked for Time Inc. since 1967. His current title is director of international business. ''I'm committed to Time Inc. to March 15, through the launch of the French-language edition of Fortune, which happens in February,'' he said. **********Mr. Rukeyser was editor of Fortune until Time reshuffled editors in March and named Marshall Loeb to the post. At the time, Mr. Rukeyser said he had requested the move from Fortune after six years in the post. **********Mr. Rukeyser originally joined Fortune as an associate editor in 1967 and in 1972 was named managing editor of Money when it was founded. He was managing editor of the magazine for eight years before moving to Fortune as managing editor. **********Mr. Rukeyser said he would be spending three-quarters of his time in Knoxville. He now lives in Scotch Plains, N.J., with his wife, Elisabeth, and their son and daughter. **********Mr. Rukeyser has three, in his words, ''incredibly distinguished'' brothers. They are Merryle S. Rukeyser Jr., executive vice president for public information at NBC; Louis, host of the television program ''Wall Street Week,'' and Robert J., a senior vice president at American Brands.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/02/busin.body_text: **********Three major banking companies said today that their loans to Brazil would be placed on nonaccrual status, actions that would reduce their net income for 1987 by tens of millions of dollars. **********The moves by the BankAmerica Corporation, J. P. Morgan & Company and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company came six weeks after Brazil suspended interest payments on $68 billion of its debt and demanded a new solution to the debt crisis. **********Negotiations between Brazil and its creditors are scheduled to begin next Friday in New York, bankers said today. The banks said they expected to reach an agreement under which interest payments would resume. **********Many major banking companies have previously indicated that they might reclassify their Brazilian loans, but these are the first to do so. Analysts said other banks were likely to follow. **********''I would be quite shocked if they did not follow suit,'' said Douglas Stone, a banking analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities. ''I don't see how they couldn't.'' Recording of Interest Changed **********When a loan is placed on nonaccrual status, a bank recognizes income from it when interest payments are received. Normally, a bank records income when the interest is due, regardless of whether the payment actually comes in. **********The moves were announced too late to affect trading on Wall Street, but caused a sharp drop in Treasury bill rates in the credit markets, in what one market expert described as a ''mini-flight to quality.''  [ Page D25. ]  BankAmerica said the action would reduce its first-quarter net income by $40 million. If the deferral of interest payments continued, the bank said, the reduction in income for the whole year would amount to $140 million. The San Francisco-based banking company, which has been trying to recover from heavy losses, said about $1.9 billion in Brazilian loans would be affected by the decision. **********BankAmerica also said it was putting on nonaccrual status about $180 million of medium- and long-term loans to Ecuador, which is recovering from a severe earthquake. That action would reduce first-quarter earnings by $5 million and earnings for the year by $15 million. A 18 Percent Reduction **********Manufacturers Hanover said its action would affect $1.4 billion of medium- and long-term loans and would reduce its net income for the quarter by $18 million and for the year by $72 million. Those figures are about equal to 18 percent of the company's quarterly and annual earnings in 1986. **********J. P. Morgan, whose main unit is the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, said its net income for the first quarter would be reduced by $20 million and its income for the whole year by $72 million. Such a reduction would be equivalent to about 8 percent of Morgan's 1986 net income of $872.5 million. Morgan has $1.3 billion in medium- and long-term loans to Brazil. **********Several other banks said they were studying the situation. **********Citicorp, the largest lender to Brazil, said in mid-March that it might take such an action, which would reduce its net income by $50 million in the first quarter and $190 million for the year. The bank has lent $4.6 billion to Brazil. #90-Day Deadline Banks technically do not have to place loans on a nonaccrual status until the interest payments are 90 days late. However, the banks said today that it appeared that negotiations on rescheduling Brazil's debt would not be completed until after the 90-day periods had expired, so they decided to act now. **********Some banking sources said placing the loans on a cash basis could also give the banks a stronger bargaining position against Brazil because they would have already been hurt by Brazil's action. **********BankAmerica's move was somewhat surprising because it is the least able among the major banks to handle the reduction in earnings. **********BankAmerica recently succeeded in fighting off a takeover attempt by the First Interstate Bancorp and has said it was on the path to recovery from two years of losses from bad loans. The problems with Brazil could set back the recovery and perhaps even make the bank susceptible to another takeover attempt, some analysts have said. **********Recently, Moody's Investor Services downgraded the debt of BankAmerica, citing its Latin American loans and doubts about improvements in earnings. Gain From Schwab Sale **********However, BankAmerica said it still expected to record a profit for the first quarter because of gains from the sale of assets, such as Charles Schwab & Company. The sale of the discount brokerage was completed Tuesday. **********BankAmerica also said that ''barring substantially increased instabilities in developing countries'' it continued to anticipate an operating profit for all of 1987. **********Mr. Stone of Prudential-Bache said he had been expecting BankAmerica to record a net profit of 60 cents a share in the first quarter, equivalent to about $90 million in net income. He said he expected the bank to record a gain of $140 million from the sale of assets counterbalanced by an operating loss of $50 million. However, with the Brazil reduction, earnings will drop to about 30 cents a share, or $46 million, he said. **********Donald K. Crowley, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, said the actions by the banks would not have much effect on stocks because the market had already factored in the Brazil situation. He said he expected BankAmerica to have an operating profit for the year only if the Brazil situation was resolved. **********BankAmerica also said the special gain it expected from the previously announced sale of its consumer trust division to Wells Fargo & Company would be only $75 million pretax, instead of the announced $98 million, because BankAmerica would end up keeping certain accounts it had planned to sell. Its gain on the deal, which closed today, will not be recognized until the second quarter instead of the first.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/19/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; NCR Dismisses 13 for Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/19/busin.body_text: **********Thirteen employees have left the NCR Corporation, apparently because of their involvement in an effort to profit from trading in the company's stock options. **********NCR said that the employees had left ''in connection with activities which it deemed inconsistent with certain policies and practices.'' The Dayton, Ohio, maker of computer business equipment would not elaborate, except to say the employees involved left the company on April 27. **********The dismissals, although embarrassing, are likely to have little effect on the company, analysts said. ''If it were worse, we would have heard more,'' said Peter Labe, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. **********NCR would not identify the former employees, but company officials said that no senior managers had been implicated and that the amount of money involved had been insignificant. **********Industry officials who are close to the company said that the employees had tried to trade NCR's stock options before news about the company was released.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/03/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday introduced a desktop computer and a minicomputer that offer significant advances in technology at a competitive price. **********The introductions promise to lift the company's sagging credibility in the computer business, analysts said. **********A.T.&T. said that its desktop computer, which is based on the Intel 80386 microprocessor, could run programs that use both the Unix operating system, developed by A.T.&T., and MS-DOS, the operating system created by the Microsoft Corporation and used by the International Business Machines Corporation. First Fully to Use 80386 Chip **********By running both MS-DOS and Unix at the same time, the A.T.&T. machine is the first computer to make full use of the 80386 chip, the most powerful microprocessor in the PC market. Other computer companies have introduced 80386-based machines, but none has the capability of A.T.&T.'s computer. **********In separate announcements, the Unisys Corporation introduced three mid-range computers designed to compete with similar machines made by I.B.M. and the Digital Equipment Corporation, while the Hyundai Group of South Korea said that it would market computers under its own name. **********Analysts predicted that the A.T.&T. desktop would have wide acceptance. **********''From a corporate standpoint, it will have wide applications because of its multi-tasking and multi-user capabilities,'' said Charles Nichols, an E. F. Hutton & Company analyst. **********''This clearly hits on the fat part of the bat,'' said Jack Grubman, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc. ''This is a terrific product with very competitive price performance and will sell very well for them.'' Computer Commitment **********Analysts said that the A.T.&T. products reinforce its commitment to the computer marketplace at a time that many industry experts have expected the company to drop out of the business because of its dismal performance. **********Analysts estimated that A.T.&T. lost $800 million on computers last year and predicted that the company would succeed only in reducing those losses by half this year. Meanwhile, A.T.&T.'s core business of long-distance and telecommunications services is booming. **********A.T.&T. said that the new desktop system, called the 6386 Work Group System, could function either as a personal computer, using MS-DOS or the new O/S 2 applications when they become available, or as a minicomputer serving up to 32 people. **********The price of the new desktop ranges from $4,899 to $10,395, depending on configuration, and was considered competitive by analysts. A.T.&T.'s Strongest Minicomputer **********A.T.&T. also introduced its most powerful minicomputer to date, the 3B4000, aimed at the transaction-processing market, which generates annual revenues of $17 billion. These machines are used mainly to run airline reservation systems and automated teller systems. **********In its largest version, the 3B4000 can handle more than 43 million instructions per second and support up to 300 users at a time, A.T.&T. said. Its price starts at $187,000.  However, some analysts questioned the price performance of the 3B4000, and they noted the limited software applications available for Unix-based machines. Criticism of Sales Structure **********Although they lauded the technological advance of the new computers, analysts attributed A.T.&T.'s poor performance to the lack of a separate computer sales force reporting directly to the head of its computer division. Vittorio Cassoni, A.T.&T.'s senior vice president, Data Systems division, was recruited from A.T.&T.'s computer partner, Ing. C. Olivetti & Company, to turn the division around. **********In an interview at A.T.&T.'s computer products center in Parsippany, N.J., Mr. Cassoni said that the company had 600 field representatives devoted to selling computers and that the number would be increased to target specific customers. He also said that A.T.&T. recently received a contract from the McDonald's Corporation to place the 6386 system in its restaurants. **********Mr. Cassoni said that A.T.&T. expected to make at least two major computer announcements a year because of technological developments. **********''One announcement does not make a computer company,'' Mr. Grubman said, ''but it's a step in the right direction. We'll have to wait and see where they go from here.'' Unysis's Mid-Range Entries **********Unisys said yesterday that its new midsize computers, called Smallframe series A, were aimed at I.B.M.'s 9370 and Digital's VAX line of computers. I.B.M. and Digital have dominated the market for mid-range computers. But Unisys is hoping to gain greater market share with its new machines, which are aggressively priced and include a series of software packages. **********Meanwhile, Hyundai of South Korea introduced the microcomputer Super-286C, the first in a line of personal computers to be sold under the company's label. **********It is priced at $1,499 and will be available in late September.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/10/world.main_headline: CURB ON PRETORIA DEFEATED AT U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/10/world.print_headline: CURB ON PRETORIA DEFEATED AT U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/10/world.body_text: **********The United States and Britain today vetoed a Security Council resolution that would have banned all trade and other ties with South Africa because of its occupation of South-West Africa. **********Nine countries voted in favor of the draft resolution, which was similar to many vetoed in the past. West Germany voted against the draft, and France, Italy and Japan abstained. **********The resolution, which faced an almost certain veto, was widely seen as an attempt to draw attention to South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, after the Security Council's consideration of apartheid in February. One African diplomat said the weeklong debate on the text was held because the South-West Africa People's Organization fears that the Namibia issue has become submerged within the problem of apartheid in world opinion. Walters Backs Argument **********The United States' chief delegate, Vernon A. Walters, defended South Africa's argument that its withdrawal from Namibia must be linked to the withdrawal of Cuban troops from neighboring Angola, where South African and opposition troops are battling the Government. **********Mr. Walters called it ''wishful thinking'' to expect a South African pullout before a schedule for a Cuban withdrawal is agreed. **********''Namibia's security is inextricably linked to both Angola and South Africa,'' Mr. Walters said. ''The mutual security of these states involves the presence of tens of thousands of foreign troops in the region.'' **********He also voiced traditional United States opposition to mandatory sanctions, saying they would ''seriously limit the initiative of nations, such as the United States, that seek to bring about South Africa's implementation'' of resolutions calling for withdrawal. 'Excuse to Remain Intransigent' **********A British delegate said ''measures of this sort would have been counterproductive'' and would ''give South Africa the excuse to remain intransigent.'' **********Dozens of speakers criticized the British and United States positions. **********Earlier this week, the insurgent movement rejected proposals for milder resolutions that would have imposed temporary sanctions in the hope of avoiding the veto, several diplomats said. **********While any sanctions probably would have been vetoed, several diplomats said the insurgents took a hard line to stress their belief that South Africa's withdrawal cannot be negotiable.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/11/world.main_headline: Afghan Talks End Without Major Gain
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/11/world.print_headline: Afghan Talks End Without Major Gain
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/11/world.body_text: **********A new round of negotiations on the seven-year-old Afghan conflict ended today without producing the major concessions from the Soviet-backed Afghan Government that had been widely anticipated, a senior Pakistani official said. **********The official, Foreign Minister Sahabzada Yaqub Kahn, said he was disappointed that the Foreign Minister of Afghanistan, Abdul Wakil, had proposed only a 16-month schedule for the withdrawal of some 115,000 Soviet soldiers from Afghanistan, or two months less than the last Afghan proposal offered during the round of talks, which ended here March 9. **********Pakistan, which is backed by the United States, insisted in the latest round on the Soviet troops being withdrawn within eight months, one month more than it had earlier demanded. This narrowed the difference between the two sides from 11 months to 8 months, indicating that the Russians were still not ready for an agreement but were interested in keeping alive expectations of a pullout. **********A timetable for the withdrawal of Soviet soldiers is the last remaining issue subject to United Nations mediation. But even if the sides agree on a timetable, there still remains the problem of how to agree on the composition of the Afghan government after the Soviet pullout. There has been no sign that the Afghan rebel groups are in any mood to reach an accord with the Communist Afghan government. Hoping for a New Timetable **********The latest round of talks had been called by the Soviet-backed Afghan Government, and before its opening last Monday there was considerable speculation in Pakistan and at the United Nations that the reason for Kabul's requesting the meeting was to allow Afghanistan and the Soviet Union to reduce their timetable to 12 months, officials said. **********The so-called ''proximity talks'' involved Mr. Wakil and Mr. Kahn, meeting with the United Nations mediator, Diego Cordovez, the Under Secretary General for Political Affairs. The negotiations are termed proximity talks because Pakistan has refused to meet Afghanistan face to face since Soviet troops joined the fray in 1979. **********Mr. Cordovez said he believed that earlier progress at the talks, including a narrowing of differences over the timing of a troop withdrawal had helped touch off discussions in Afghanistan over the formation of a provisional, reconciliation government, and that he hoped this process would continue. **********The two sides had agreed to continue the talks, he added, but had set no firm resumption date. **********''They will reconvene when they are ready,'' Mr. Cordovez said. ''This will come through diplomatic channels.'' **********The Afghan proposal at the negotiations dashed hopes of significant progress, which had stemmed from Afghanistan's request for a resumption of the talks. 'We Were Disappointed' **********''We were disappointed that this round did not produce the results that we expected,'' Mr. Kahn said, adding that Pakistan had proposed an eight-month timetable, or one month more than previously. Previously, the two sides had been 11 months apart on a timetable. **********Mr. Kahn acknowledged that Pakistan had apparently expected Afghanistan to reduce the alloted time for Soviet forces to leave the country to 12 months. **********Although United Nations officials said they believed ''a little progress'' had been made during the current Afghan-Pakistani meeting, they acknowledged that it had failed to significantly narrow Afghan-Pakistani differences as expected. **********This week's meeting was apparently called under pressure from the Soviet Union, Western diplomats said, in what could be an effort to neutralize criticism from third world and nonaligned countries when a vote censuring the Soviet combat role in Afghanistan comes before the United Nations General Assembly in New York in October. In addition, the Western diplomats also speculated that the failure of Afghanistan to propose a more significant reduction in the timetable for the withdrawal of Soviet soldiers might represent a serious breach in the positions of Moscow and Kabul.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.main_headline: Mexico Market's Fall Is the Steepest
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.print_headline: Mexico Market's Fall Is the Steepest
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.body_text: **********Throughout the boom months of 1987, the volatile Mexican stock market performed more spectacularly than any other in the world. But with bulls having turned to bears all around the globe, Mexico is now suffering the steepest, most rapid slide of any leading exchange. **********Between Jan. 1 and Oct. 5, when the Bolsa de Valores here hit an all-time high of 387,000 points, the Mexican market rose eightfold. But in the last 15 days of trading, the index has fallen by more than 50 percent, to 183,662, and investors and traders here are braced for further plunges. **********On Monday, the market fell a record 16.7 percent, exceeding even the decline recorded on Oct. 19. On Tuesday, it slipped another 14.5 percent, meaning that the market's value had fallen by almost $2 billion from its estimated peak value of about $6 billion earlier this month. Drop Started as Local 'Correction' **********Brokers, bankers and other analysts here said the market tailspin, which began two weeks before Wall Street's collapse on Oct. 19, was initially a ''technical correction'' stemming from purely local conditions. But now, with the plunge in stock prices around the world, there are widespread fears that events may be moving beyond control. **********''The Bolsa has little to do with the real economy, even less so in Mexico than in other places,'' one American banker here said this week. ''But a panic psychology has definitely taken hold, and I don't know where it's going to stop.'' **********Some members of the investment community believe that the Government's intervention in the market earlier in the month rattled investors. Initial Intervention to Check Rise **********On Oct. 5, the Mexican Government intervened in the market, ironically to prevent stocks from going through the roof. One day earlier, the Budget and Planning Minister, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, had been named as the candidate of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party in next year's presidential elections, and the market surged 7.5 percent in the first 90 minutes of trading. **********The National Securities Commission said it had been forced to halt trading briefly twice that day to prevent ''disorderly conditions'' that ''could lead the price index up to undesired levels.'' But market analysts said the action set a precedent that may have led some major players to reconsider their positions. **********''By intervening, the Government signaled to speculators that they could no longer automatically count on quick and gigantic increases,'' said one broker, who asked not to be identified. Overvaluation Noted **********Market analysts also acknowledged that investors were beginning to realize that many issues were overvalued. By early October, some issues were trading at a price-to-net-worth ratio of well over 1-to-1 and a price-to-earnings ratio of more than 30, which brokers said was far outside the historical range of 10 to 12. **********In addition, there have been accusations in the press and by some brokers that a ''black hand'' is manipulating the market. In a cover story this week, the news magazine Proceso charged that both the rise and the fall of the Mexican market have been ''artificial,'' the deliberate product of maneuvering by a few powerful investors. **********A spokesman for the Mexican Stock Exchange denied those accusations today, saying that manipulation of the market ''does not exist, and if it did, it would be hard to measure.'' Nevertheless, brokers said the controversy had adversely affected confidence, especially among small investors who recently entered the market. **********By international standards, the exchange here is a small one, dominated by a half-dozen major brokerage houses and trading less than 200 issues. On an average day, about 50 million shares are traded here. Only 500,000 Investors **********No more than 500,000 Mexicans are estimated to own shares, compared with some 50 million Americans who invest in United States stocks. **********Mexican investors need not look back as far as 1929 to be chastened by the prospect of a market crash. In 1979, a spectacular stock-market surge fueled by the country's oil boom came to an abrupt end, pushing the index down by more than half and ushering in a period of stagnation that began to lift only in 1982. **********Outwardly, officials here are minimizing the significance of the Wall Street plunge. In a news conference last week, Manuel Somoza Alonso, president of the Mexican stock exchange, acknowledged the ''psychological effect'' of events in the United States but argued that the impact was unwarranted.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/21/busin.main_headline: Court to Weigh Liability Of 'Sellers' of Securities
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/21/busin.print_headline: Court to Weigh Liability Of 'Sellers' of Securities
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/21/busin.body_text: **********The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a person who buys securities he knows are unregistered and who brings other buyers into the deal may sue the seller for his own losses and avoid liability for the losses of the other buyers. **********The most significant issue in the case is whether a buyer who actively recruits other buyers can avoid the liability imposed by the Securities Act of 1933 on ''sellers'' of unregistered securities if he received no direct financial benefit from his promotional activities . **********The case is an appeal by Billy J. Pinter, a Texas oilman who was held liable for selling unregistered interests in oil and gas leases, which proved worthless, to Maurice Dahl, a California businessman, and to relatives and associates whom Mr. Dahl recruited to buy into the deal. **********Mr. Pinter, head of the Black Gold Oil Company, argued in his appeal that, because Mr. Dahl knew the securities were unregistered and actively promoted them to the other buyers, he was an equally responsible ''seller'' for purposes of the 1933 act. **********This, Mr. Pinter argued, meant that Mr. Dahl should not be able to sue him for damages, and that Mr. Dahl should have to share in Mr. Pinter's liability to other buyers who were recruited by Mr. Dahl. **********A sharply divided Federal appeals court, ruling against Mr. Pinter, held that Mr. Dahl was not liable as a ''seller'' of the securities because he did not personally expect direct compensation for the sales to his relatives and associates. A three-judge panel of the appeals court upheld, by 2 to 1, a Federal District Court decision that Mr. Pinter must reimburse Mr. Dahl and his relatives and associates for their losses, and that Mr. Dahl, who was not sued by the others, was not liable to share in Mr. Pinter's liability to them. The panel said both Mr. Pinter and Mr. Dahl were apparently unaware that the securities had to be registered, but that while this did not provide a legal defense for Mr. Pinter, it did for Mr. Dahl. **********The full United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit voted, by 8 to 6, not to reconsider the ruling in the case, Pinter v. Dahl, No. 86-805. Limited Service Banks **********Also today, the Court declined to hear an appeal from a lower court's decision upholding the Federal Reserve Board's decision to allow the U.S. Trust Corporation of New York to operate a limited service bank in Palm Beach, Fla., despite objections by the state. (Conference of State Bank Supervisors v. Board of Governors, No. 86-1024.) Today's action confirms the assumption by most experts that a Supreme Court decision last year on a related issue meant that the Bank Holding Company Act cannot be used to bar bank holding companies or others from using limited service banks to circumvent restrictions on interstate banking. **********But some other legal obstacles to limited service banks remain unaffected, Michael Bradfield, general counsel of the Fed, said in a telephone interview today. They include a Federal court injunction in another Florida case barring the Comptroller of the Currency from chartering limited service banks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/21/world.body_text: **********The Vatican issued a statement today pronouncing itself ''surprised and grieved'' that Pope John Paul II's decision to receive Kurt Waldheim, the Austrian President, had provoked doubts about the Pope's respect for the Jewish people. **********The unusual written statement was issued after Jewish groups in the United States, Europe and Israel protested the Pope's plan to meet Mr. Waldheim, who has been accused of taking part in deportations and executions of Jews and others in Greece and Yugoslavia when he was a German lieutenant in World War II. He has denied the charges. **********Several leaders of American Jewish organiztions met Friday in New York and said the planned audience for Mr. Waldheim had made ''inappropriate'' their own scheduled meeting with John Paul in Miami in September at the start of his visit to the United States. **********The Vatican statement was issued after an urgent meeting of John Paul and his top officials to discuss the harsh reaction to the announcement of Mr. Waldheim's state visit, which is to take place Thursday, a Vatican official said. **********John Paul agreed to receive Mr. Waldheim only after the Austrian President had repeatedly pressed his requests and after the Vatican had delayed giving him an answer several times, according to the Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls. Ties With Austria Stressed **********Vatican officials have repeatedly said the visit is viewed as an event involving the Holy See's relations with Austria rather than as a personal gesture toward Mr. Waldheim by the Pope. **********Mr. Navarro and Vatican officials in close touch with the Austrian clergy insist that Austria's bishops did not lobby for the visit. Instead, it was said to have been the Austrian Government that was most active in beseeching the Vatican to receive Mr. Waldheim. **********While the full nature of the exchanges between Vienna and Rome are still unclear, some Vatican officials believe that Austrian officials and in particular leaders of the Christian Democratic Party in Austria interceded on behalf of Mr. Waldheim, their standard bearer. **********In seeing the Pope, Mr. Waldheim will be on his first trip out of Austria since he was elected President a year ago. In April the United States Justice Department barred him from entering the country. **********Vatican officials have expressed concern in recent days that the audience could undo some of John Paul's many efforts to improve relations with Jews, based on a decision by the Second Vatican Council in 1965 to increase dialogue between the church and Jews. **********The statement issued today recalled John Paul's frequent condemnation of Nazi crimes against the Jews, and it specifically notes his repeated statements against the persecution of the Jews that he made on a trip to West Germany last May and his comments to leaders of Warsaw's Jews last Sunday, when he spoke of the ''terrible reality of the extermination.'' **********Perhaps more than ever before, the statement says, ''the nation of Israel finds itself at the center of the attention of the nations of the world above all because of this terrible experience.'' Background Is Explained **********The Vatican said it was ''surprised and grieved'' that the announcement of Mr. Waldheim's visit had provoked ''questions and doubts about the consideration and respect by the Pope and the Holy See toward the Jewish people and particularly their position regarding the inhuman persecution which struck them.'' **********After defending the Pope's position toward the Jews, the Vatican statement explained the diplomatic background to the Waldheim visit. The Vatican rarely offers official comment on the motives for a papal decision. **********The statement notes that Austria, ''an old and noble Catholic nation,'' is linked to the Holy See by ''cordial relations,'' and it says the Austrians democratically elected Mr. Waldheim a year ago. Mr. Waldheim had previously been elected to two terms as United Nations Secretary General and had ''carried out missions of great responsibility for peace and international cooperation,'' it added. **********The statement said Mr. Waldheim's official request for a audience had been granted as a result of the Holy See's relationship with Austria. **********Mr. Waldheim was quoted today as saying the allegations against him were ''fabrications, distortions and misinterpretations.'' According to news reports from Amman, Jordan, where Mr. Waldheim is due to make a state visit in July, he told Jordanian newspaper editors in an interview that he planned to publish a book later this month that will prove his innocence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Ladbroke Group's Offering Lags
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/06/busin.body_text: **********Ladbroke Group P.L.C. said that only about 1.68 million of the 70.4 million new shares that it offered at 378 pence a share, about $6.61, had been taken up. The British property and leisure group's $:256 million, or about $448 million, offer was to help finance its $:645 million (about $1.13 billion) acquisition of the Hilton International Company hotel chain from the Allegis Corporation. Charterhouse Bank Ltd. was Ladbroke's adviser and underwriter for the issue and Charterhouse said subunderwriters would be informed of the extent of their take-up on Friday. **********Although Ladbroke's was the largest outstanding share issue in the market since the market plunge, several other issues have received a similarly low response in the face of falling share prices. In all, underwriters could have been forced to pay about $:500 million, or about $875 million, for these unwanted rights offerings. Dealers said the already poor liquidity positions of many institutions means they may have to sell other holdings to meet their underwriting commitments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/16/world.main_headline: STREET PROTESTS BY SOUTH KOREANS RESUME AND GROW
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/16/world.print_headline: STREET PROTESTS BY SOUTH KOREANS RESUME AND GROW
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/16/world.body_text: **********Anti-Government protests spread Monday and early today as tens of thousands of South Koreans in major cities took to the streets in bursts of violence and choruses of prayer. **********For a sixth straight day, students skirmished fiercely with riot policemen on streets and at campus gates. **********Nowhere was fighting more ferocious than at Yonsei University in Seoul, where, in a familiar pattern, students hurled gasoline bombs and rocks at officers who responded with countless volleys of face-scorching tear gas. Clashes in 6 Other Cities **********According to South Korean press reports, similar clashes occurred in six other cities, involving more than 60,000 students at 45 colleges. Battles reportedly raged in the streets in the central city of Chonan and the southern city of Chinju. **********But as the country's political crisis deepened, demonstrations became increasingly dominated by ordinary South Koreans expressing frustration with the Government, its suppression of dissent and its overall timetable for democratic development. **********About 10,000 people, of widely varied backgrounds and ages, held a candlelight vigil in the capital Monday night following religious services at a Roman Catholic Cathedral that has been the focus of recent anti-Government opposition. The rally was one of the largest held in downtown Seoul in years, and it seemed certain that almost everyone there had gone as an act of protest. Cathedral Is Filled **********Men, women and children filled the Myongdong Cathedral and spilled over onto a flagstone plaza, where they stood in prayer or sat on the ground despite a drenching rainstorm. **********When the rain stopped, the crowd surged into the street outside, holding candles aloft and singing hymn-like songs of protest. They were held back by thousands of a police officers with riot shields stretched before them. **********In the front ranks, demonstrators were mostly students who shoved menacingly against the police, forcing them to step back and to make more room for the surging crowd. **********But for the most part, the rally was peaceful, reflecting a growing middle-class component to protests that the Government has characterized as an attempt at ''violent revolution.'' 'A Democratic Government' **********''We want the Government leaders to realize what the people want,'' said Im Jin Chang, a college professor who attended the Myongdong service. ''This is a time when the people unanimously want a democratic Government.'' **********The demonstrations and street violence began to reach new peaks last week after President Chun Doo Hwan and his ruling party formally designated Roh Tae Woo as their choice to succeed Mr. Chun. Mr. Roh - a former general, like the incumbent President - is all but certain to be chosen by an electoral college next December, and will take office in February. **********But protest was building even before last week, fed by disclosures of police torture of dissidents and cover-up attempts, and by Mr. Chun's abrupt cancellation in April of an ongoing debate over how to make the process for selecting a national leader more democratic. Opposition politicians charge that Mr. Chun's true objective is to perpetuate his behind-the-scenes power in a Government that they denounce as a ''military dictatorship.'' Cardinal Urges Reversal **********The overwhelming importance of this issue for many South Koreans was underlined at the Myongdong prayer service when Stephen Cardinal Kim Sou Hwan, Roman Catholic primate of South Korea, called on the President to withdraw his April decision. **********Protests spread Monday on a day of rapidly shifting moods, when it first seemed that the authorities had succeeded in ending the crisis, only to have it flare again. **********Late Sunday night and early Monday, the police cleared central Seoul's streets in an attempt to ease tensions by inviting a band of 220 radicals to end a tense six-day occupation of Myongdong without being arrested. Despite a brief clash between street demonstrators and policemen at midday Monday, the tactic seemed to work, for the dissidents finally agreed to leave. **********Their takeover of the cathedral had become the focus of the recent clashes as students and other sympathizers staged forays through downtown streets to express support. **********Myongdong is the center of South Korean Catholicism and an important national symbol. Although Catholics account for only an estimated 5 percent of the population of 41 million, they include many of the country's educated elite and wield an influence disproportionate to their numbers. **********Under a deal arranged by Catholic priests, the students left the cathedral in three buses with a promise of safe passage to their campuses. According to Seoul's police chief, Cho Chong Suk, no arrests will be made, a decision that represents a significant retreat by a Government that had promised to deal sternly with the dissidents. **********''The most significant thing about the situation,'' Cardinal Kim said later, ''is that it restored the trust of students in the Government. It is a step forward.'' **********It did not, however, stop the protests. Crowds surged through downtown streets into Monday night and early today, many of them people well beyond student age and seemingly without any specific political loyalty. **********At one point, more than 5,000 South Koreans - office workers, shopkeepers and strollers - held a spontaneous anti-Government rally in narrow streets near the cathedral. As they chanted slogans with growing exuberance, others waved from office building windows and threw flowers down to the demonstrators. **********Suddenly, without warning, helmeted policemen surged into the crowd, firing tear gas and sending people scattering amid shrieks of pain and surprise. The police action angered many bystanders. One elderly woman grew so incensed that she struck an officer on the head with her pocketbook. **********''There's a mood change under way,'' a foreign diplomat said. ''The Government has always tried to portray the students as radical, but it's not working. The people are not buying it this time.'' **********National police officials announced that 6,094 people had been taken into custody since the surge of protest began last Wednesday. Most were quickly released, but hundreds still face criminal charges. **********In addition, the Chun Government is weighing possible emergency measures should the situation deteriorate, but South Korean news reports said no action was contemplated now. **********It appeared that the Government wanted to see first if the protests would peter out on their own. Officials, including Mr. Chun, have warned repeatedly that they would be tough on dissidents, but they have held back, apparently for fear of further inflaming anti-Government sentiment. **********The major response has been to contain demonstrations through a heavy firing of tear gas. Thus far, the police have not carried firearms. Nor have they been seen using the sticks they carry on their hips.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/14/busin.body_text: **********A Foreign Ministry official today rejected as groundless arguments made by senior American officials who are trying to block the sale of an American microchip maker to a Japanese company. **********''They appear to be linking completely unrelated issues,'' said Shuichi Takemoto of the Foreign Ministry's North American division. ''We don't understand what their basis for blocking the acquisition would be.'' **********Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige has asked the White House to consider blocking the sale of the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation of Cupertino, Calif., to Japan's Fujitsu Ltd., American officials said. **********The officials also said the sale would leave the military too dependent on a foreign company for vital high-technology equipment. Pentagon officials said Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger was also opposed to the sale. But the move may also be linked to efforts to get Japan to open its domestic market to sales of more American supercomputers. **********Mr. Takemoto said national security should not be an issue since the planned purchase of Fairchild from its current owner, France's Schlumberger Ltd., did not include Fairchild's main defense-related division.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/21/busin.print_headline: Business and the Law; Broker Cases: New Rules
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/21/busin.body_text: **********ARBITRATION panels that resolve disputes between stockbrokers and their clients, burdened with an image that they favor the brokerage houses, are examining and changing some of their most significant rules. **********Reform comes as record numbers of securities disputes are being taken to arbitration, with experts predicting a further rise. It also follows by three months a ruling by a divided Supreme Court that has had the effect, in many instances, of closing the courtroom door to disgruntled clients. The ruling leaves arbitration at the leading stock exchanges as the principal means of redress for allegations of ''churning'' - excessive buying and selling on a client's account to increase commissions - or other malfeasance. **********''It's my sense that there was a perceived problem of fairness,'' said Aulana Peters, a commissioner at the Securities and Exchange Commission. ''The system in general has been working pretty well. But there are certain aspects of it, such as the ties of some arbitrators to the securities industry, that give it the appearance that it may not always be fair.'' **********For the first time in a decade, the S.E.C. has proposed broad changes in the rules governing arbitration panels appointed by the National Association of Securities Dealers and the New York and American stock exchanges. **********Officials of the exchanges say they have begun to make a number of changes and are studying the S.E.C. proposals. ''We're working toward their implementation,'' said Ed Morris, head of the arbitration division of the New York Stock Exchange. ''But there are things in there that you can't do overnight.'' The exchanges are expected to respond formally to the proposals by December. **********There were 2,828 securities-related arbitration cases at the exchanges last year, up from 830 in 1980, said Robert Love, special counsel at the S.E.C.'s division of market regulation. Complaints against brokers lodged with the S.E.C. more than doubled in five years, topping 15,000 in 1986. **********Arbitration experts predict the number of cases will increase from 25 percent to 50 percent next year, in part because of the Supreme Court's June decision in Shearson-American Express v. McNulty. The decision upheld a customer agreement providing for arbitration of any controversy arising from an account rather than a hearing before a Federal judge. **********But of the four dissenting justices, three expressed the opinion that arbitration has an image problem. ''Because of the background of the arbitrators, the investor has the impression, frequently justified, that his claims are being judged by a forum composed of individuals sympathetic to the securities industry and not drawn from the public,'' wrote Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun, speaking for himself and Justices Thurgood Marshall and William J. Brennan Jr. Some lawyers agree. ''The situation before the proposed reforms has been very troublesome from the point of view of the public interest,'' said Sheldon H. Elsen, chairman of the American Bar Association's task force on securities arbitration. **********Mr. Elsen pointed out a number of problems with the old rules. They do not prevent all of a panel's arbitrators - even those who were supposed to be independent of the industry - from being employees or lawyers of a brokerage house or relatives of someone in the securities business. No careful background checks are required on arbitrators to determine whether they have criminal records or have been disciplined. **********Moreover, Mr. Elsen said, the voting records of arbitrators in past cases have been known to many in the securities industry but not to the customers who bring the action. Relevant records subpoenaed by a party need not be disclosed until minutes before a hearing. And there has been no formal requirement of any knowledge of the law, meaning that arbitrators could be ignorant of legal trends. **********The S.E.C.'s proposals would change much of this. Arbitration panels would still include representatives of the securities industry, but the required representatives of the public who typically form the majority of the panels would not be allowed to have ties to the industry. **********More extensive checks would be made on arbitrators' backgrounds, and their voting records on all cases would be available to both sides in a dispute. (Both sides are allowed peremptory challenges to exclude an arbitrator from a case.) In addition, arbitrators would get involved in the discovery process at an earlier stage in the dispute so that records would be available to both sides earlier. The reforms also include uniform guidelines for the training of arbitrators and circulation of pamphlets on emerging developments in the law. **********The S.E.C. has also recommended that all contracts between customers and brokerage houses include a clause that permits disputes to be decided by independent arbitration panels, such as the American Arbitration Association. This nonprofit group last year heard 119 securities disputes involving a total of more than $15 million in claims. **********The association announced this month that it too had changed its rules so that fewer arbitrators would have securities industry affiliations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/busin.body_text: **********Hunt-and-peck typists who feel inadequate because they are not proficient at touch typing may now have something to be smug about. After studying touch typists, who use all fingers instead of just one or two, a Tucson, Ariz., group has concluded that they must cock their left wrists slightly to type and could be damaging tendons and nerves. It contends that the typewriter keyboard is the culprit. **********To visualize the problem, place your hands on a keyboard for touch typing. Note that as the middle finger of the right hand strikes the comma, K, I and 8 keys, it makes a straight line with the right forearm. Note that the middle finger of the left hand as it strikes the C, D, E and 3 keys does not make a straight line with the left forearm. The wrist must be cocked slightly. **********Barbara and Stuart Herzog, a typing teacher and lawyer, and Lee A. Moss, a hand surgeon, say that such a position can deform the carpal tunnel in the left wrist, irritating a key nerve and tendons and eventually causing carpal tunnel syndrome or tenosynovitis, both painful. **********Their solution is the Herzog keyboard, in which the left hand keys are in the same positions, but the columns of keys extend diagonally upward to the right instead of the left. **********Armed with a patent, the Herzogs have begun to try to persuade computer makers to switch keyboards. ''There have been expressions of interest, but it's too early to tell how serious they are,'' Mr. Herzog said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/busin.body_text: **********The Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that its earnings more than doubled in the fiscal first quarter, ended July 31, from a year before. The brokerage house earned $47.9 million, or 53 cents a share, in the latest quarter, up from $18.9 million, or 22 cents a share. Revenues rose to $482.7 million from $334.1 million. **********The earnings appeared so strong, analysts said, in comparison with a very weak quarter. A year ago Bear Stearns suffered trading losses, they noted, but it escaped many of the trading losses that afflicted other brokerage firms in May this year. **********The latest quarter's earnings were also helped by a low tax rate due largely to the cancellation of a deferred compensation program. **********''This period's earnings were routine - no real problems, but nothing spectacular either,'' said Michael W. Blumstein, an industry analyst with the First Boston Corporation. **********Brenda Davis McCoy, an analyst with Paine Webber, said Bear Stearns expanded its trading revenues, to $111 million, from $104 million in the quarter ended April 30.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/28/world.main_headline: SAUDI KING ACCUSES IRAN OF HAMPERING FIGHT WITH ISRAEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/28/world.print_headline: SAUDI KING ACCUSES IRAN OF HAMPERING FIGHT WITH ISRAEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/28/world.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia accused Iran today of seeking to impose alien ideologies on fellow Moslem nations in the Arab world to the detriment of the Arab campaign against Israel. **********''We now face another danger from our brothers in faith, who aim their arrows at our chests instead of helping us to liberate Holy Jerusalem and Arab Islamic land in Palestine controlled by Zionist colonialism,'' the Saudi press agency quoted King Fahd as saying. **********The accusation coincided with the unveiling of a new budget in Teheran that offered no indication of any readiness for lessened hostilities with Iraq. **********''The Government is committed to allocate its full potential to the war effort,'' Prime Minister Mir Hossein Mousavi of Iran told Parliament, according to a report by IRNA, Iran's official press agency. Chemical Weapons Threat **********The Iranian official was said to have catalogued an array of arms, including ''sophisticated offensive chemical weapons,'' produced in Iran. He was quoted as saying that Iran would not use the chemical weapons, which are prohibited under a 1925 treaty signed at Geneva, ''as long as it is not forced to.'' **********Prime Minister Mousavi also said Teheran had begun shipping domestically produced ballistic missiles to its front with Iraq, strengthening speculation that Iran plans a renewed push to break the stalemate since its last major offensive almost a year ago. **********''Shipment of these missiles to the war fronts started last week,'' Mr. Mousavi said. He was quoted as saying that the war would get priority in Iran's new austerity budget, which is expected to total about $30 billion next year. Reconciliation With Egypt **********The militant Iranian posture has provoked increasing alarm among many Arab nations, particularly the moderate sheikdoms and kingdoms that face Teheran's Islamic revolutionary government across the waters of the Gulf. **********The situation has produced a wide consensus of opposition to Iran, which was reflected in a meeting of Arab nations in November. The talks, in Amman, effectively permitted Egypt, which had been ostracized for making peace with Israel in 1979, to re-enter the Arab fold as a demographic and military counterweight to Teheran. **********King Fahd, the Saudi monarch, sounded his warning today about Iran's intentions at a meeting in Riyadh of Arab Persian Gulf states grouped in the Gulf Cooperation Council, which includes Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates as well as Saudi Arabia. The meeting opened Saturday and is expected to last four days. **********Iran's war effort was designed ''to expand and control and export ideas strange to our Arab Islamic society,'' King Fahd said. He apparently referred to the Shiite brand of Islamic Revolution practised in Teheran and perceived as a threat by the Sunni Islamic Arab leaders of the Gulf, who rule over Shiite minorities. **********The monarch's statement seemed also to reflect the deep religious rivalry between Saudi Arabia and Iran. The Saudis have accused Teheran of instigating riots last July in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, where hundreds of people died in the disturbances during the Moslem annual pilgrimage. Saudi leaders are the traditional custodians of some of Islam's holiest shrines, which lie inside Saudi Arabia, though Teheran disputes their right to this title. **********King Fahd blamed Iran for continuing the seven-year war with Iraq, charging that Iran had ignored ''every Arab and Islamic mediation effort.'' The war started when Iraq attacked Iran in September 1980. **********Some analysts believe the gathering is moving toward adopting its most unambiguous condemnation yet of Teheran's refusal to accept United Nations Security Council Resolution 598, which demands a cease-fire in the war. Positions on Resolution **********Iraq has said it accepts the resolution in full, while Iran wants Iraq branded the aggressor before making its position clear. The Riyadh summit meeting is expected to press Teheran to agree to the United Nations blueprint for an end to the war. **********Some Arab Persian Gulf states, notably the United Arab Emirates and Oman, are nervous about the loomimg power of Teheran just across the gulf from their more fragile regimes, and have urged that the Arab gulf nations should maintain a dialogue with Teheran. **********''Talks between gulf countries and Iran are essential,'' said Sheik Zaid bin Sultan al-Nahayan, President of the United Arab Emirates, shortly before the summit opened. Both his country and Oman have maintained good trading links with Iran. **********The Gulf Cooperation Council summit meeting followed several weeks of increasing violence in the so-called ''tanker war'' between Iran and Iraq. Both sides have attacked commercial shipping despite the presence of more than 80 United States and other foreign warships to protect vessels in the gulf. **********The most recent known attack came last Friday when Iranian veseels fired on a Saudi tanker off the coast of the United Arab Emirates in what some analysts saw as a signal to the Gulf Cooperation Council to refrain from attacking Teheran. **********Syria, Iran's strongest Arab ally, was reported to have mediated between Iran and Saudi Arabia in an effort to halt Teheran's attacks on Saudi and other vessels owned by member states of the Gulf Cooperation Council.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/28/busin.main_headline: No Adverse Effect Seen at Citicorp
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/28/busin.print_headline: No Adverse Effect Seen at Citicorp
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/28/busin.body_text: **********Between April and June, Citicorp's Investment Bank ran a series of full-page advertisements in a number of publications featuring huge photographs of Thomas C. Theobald, the vice chairman who headed the unit. Apparently, the ads were as much intended to promote the 50-year-old Mr. Theobald as the bank itself. **********The campaign seems to have worked. Yesterday it was announced that Mr. Theobald would leave Citicorp to take over as chairman and chief executive of the Continental Illinois Corporation, in Chicago. **********Although Mr. Theobald spent 27 years at Citicorp, his departure is not expected to have an adverse impact on the mammoth bank holding company. ''It will continue to be business as usual,'' said Carol Berger, a banking analyst at Cyrus J. Lawrence Inc. Room to Move Up **********Some analysts think Mr. Theobald's departure will benefit Citicorp by making room for other executives to move up and by putting an officer in charge of the investment banking unit who is likely to attract more enthusiasm from his staff. **********Sources within Citicorp said Mr. Theobald did not want to head the Investment Bank when he was asked to do so by John S. Reed, Citicorp's chairman, in 1985. For a dozen years Mr. Theobald had headed Citicorp's Institutional Bank, which conducts traditional banking business with companies and governments around the world. **********There had been great antagonism between officers of the Institutional and Investment Banks, in part because many investment bankers earned far more than officers of the Institutional Bank. The shift of Mr. Theobald to the Investment Bank was intended to reduce those tensions. **********That strategy seems to have succeeded to a degree. But the commercial banking mentality that Mr. Theobald brought with him to the Investment Bank, especially his reluctance to provide huge compensation to important employees, created resistance to him among his troops. A Successor Is Named **********As a result, many top officers left. Last year, for example, Mark Kessenich, who headed the Investment Bank's North American activities, quit to join E. F. Hutton & Company. **********Citicorp's depth of management is so great that practically anyone can be quickly replaced from within. Along with the announcement of Mr. Theobald's departure, Citicorp said that Michael A. Callen would succeed him. Mr. Callen, the 46-year-old group executive in charge of North American institutional banking, has been a rising star within Citicorp and many believe he will generate more enthusiasm among the investment bankers, even if he follows Mr. Theobald's policies. **********Mr. Theobald's departure from Citicorp took longer than many in the banking world had expected. Most thought he would leave shortly after he lost the race to succeed Walter B. Wriston as chairman and chief executive in 1984. ''Theobald walks, that's a given,'' said Thomas Hanley, a banking analyst with Salomon Brothers, when Mr. Reed was named Mr. Wriston's successor.
