https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/22/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: WALL STREET strategists, portfolio managers and analysts have a tendency to become obsessed with certain figures or industries. At various times, they have been single-minded about the money supply figures, the price of oil and, recently, the trade deficit figures. **********WALL STREET strategists, portfolio managers and analysts have a tendency to become obsessed with certain figures or industries. At various times, they have been single-minded about the money supply figures, the price of oil and, recently, the trade deficit figures. **********Since the stock market's plunge in mid-October, their obsession has been with ''cyclicals,'' the stocks of companies in such industries as chemcials, paper, steel and copper whose profits are more dependent on up-and-down economic cycles than, say, stocks geared toward consumers. ''Cyclicals are in vogue,'' said Harvey P. Eisen, president of Integrated Resources Asset Management. **********To be sure, strategists on Wall Street continue to be extremely skittish about the stock market in general. They are reluctant to pound the table in favor of any stocks. ''We're not wildly enthusiastic about stocks,'' said John D. Connolly, chief strategist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. But his firm is recommending that customers emphasize cyclical groups, instead of consumer-oriented issues. **********The earnings of many of these basic-industry companies, the strategists say, will benefit from the corporate cutbacks made in recent years, the recent pickup in capital spending and the expected increase in overseas sales resulting from the devalued dollar. The strategists agree that the continued economic expansion favors the producers of goods, instead of companies dependent on the consumer. The consumer, they add, was overextended even before the market crash in October. **********''Once in a blue moon they do well, and this is a blue moon,'' Suresh Bhirud, chief investment strategist at New York's Oppenheimer & Company, said of cyclical stocks. **********Analysts believe that the stocks of companies dependent on the consumer, like retailers, automobiles and housing, will continue to suffer. Strategists are not recommending many of these consumer-oriented stocks because they think individuals will cut back on spending. **********Greg A. Smith, chief investment strategist for Prudential-Bache Securities, is one who argues the case for cyclical stocks. By the beginning of next year, after more evidence on the economy is available, the stocks of these companies should become market leaders, he said. He favors such groups as the chemicals, papers and industrial metals. **********Because many of these stocks are selling at low prices, Mr. Smith said, they have little downside risk. Many are selling at price/earnings ratios equal to or lower than the overall market's multiple of 17. Thus, if the market drops again, he believes sellers will pound the high-multiple issues harder than lower-priced securities. ''It's easy to take a 16 multiple to a 13,'' he said. Mr. Smith also thinks a recession would hurt the stocks of consumer-oriented companies even more than the cyclicals. **********But a recession is unlikely, said Michael H. Sherman, chief investment officer of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. He added that the Government's policy continued to be ''geared toward expansion.'' In a continued expansion, the cyclical companies will do well, he said. **********And now that many cyclical stocks have fallen to the levels where they were one year ago, Mr. Sherman finds them ''cheap.'' Those he likes include Alcoa, Alcan, Reynolds Metals, Champion Paper, Georgia Pacific, Inco and Scott Paper. **********Strategists have to discuss something with their institutional clients, and cyclical stocks, along with the budget and trade deficits, are the hot topics at the moment. **********But portfolio managers at banks, insurance companies and mutual funds are not jumping on the bandwagon. According to a flow-of-funds analysis by Salomon Brothers, institutional investors continue to be net sellers of cyclical stocks, as well as those of other groups. **********Laszlo Birinyi, a Salomon Brothers vice president, said money managers were focusing on specific stocks, such as Dow Chemical and International Paper, but were not enamored of cyclicals as a whole. **********Mr. Eisen of Integrated Resources is one portfolio manager who is not placing on bets on cyclical stocks. He does not like most basic industry companies, he said, because they are capital-intensive and people-intensive, poorly managed, have little control over their markets and are simply terrible businesses. But Mr. Eisen concedes that the particular circumstances of strong commodity prices and a weak dollar make it a spectacular time for these companies. **********Steven A. Kroll, executive vice president of E.F. Hutton, also thinks Wall Street is overstating the case for the cyclicals. The increased overseas sales, he says, will not make up for the amount of business these companies will lose in what he thinks will be a much weaker economy. And he thinks stock prices are reflecting that fear. ''I.B.M. did not go from 170 to 116 because it's going to pick up market share overseas,'' he said. **********The portfolio managers at First Boston Asset Management are not going along with the cyclical scenario either. The economic expansion that began in 1982 is ''a little long in the tooth,'' said Michael F. Holland, the president. And if the economy goes into a recession, he said, the stocks of basic industry companies will not make good investments. What will? For his part, Mr. Holland owns high-yield utility stocks, which, he believes, provide a potential cushion against any economic downturn.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/busin.body_text: **********The McDonald's Corporation said today that it earned $113.6 million, or 89 cents a share, in the final quarter of 1986, up 9.8 percent from $103.5 million, or 80 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales increased 10.5 percent, to $3.17 billion, from $2.87 billion. For the year, McDonald's said it earned $479.7 million, or $3.73 a share, a 10.8 percent gain from the $433 million, or $3.32 a share, of 1985. Annual sales increased 13 percent, to $12.43 billion, from $11 billion. The company's sales have doubled in the last six years, Fred L. Turner, the chairman, said. About 500 restaurants will be added worldwide this year, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/11/busin.body_text: **********Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company today moved closer to a showdown that could force Texaco into bankruptcy proceedings as early as Monday. **********Top executives of the feuding oil companies met here this week to try to negotiate a settlement of their legal dispute. But as Texaco executives flew back to New York this evening for a weekend of strategy meetings at the company's White Plains headquarters, both companies filed legal documents suggesting that there was still a wide gulf between them and that a bankruptcy filing by Texaco remained a distinct possibility. **********Texaco contended in documents filed today with the Texas appeals court here that it could not afford to pay more than $1 billion of the $12 billion bond required for it to appeal a 1985 jury verdict against it. Being forced to post a bond or other security of more than $1 billion, Texaco said, would create further difficulties in obtaining financing and might force it to seek bankruptcy protection. 'Full Security' Sought **********But Pennzoil, in its filing, said it still wanted ''full security.'' It suggested as ''one possible approach'' that Texaco pledge an amount equal to half of a $10.3 billion damage award in collateral and promise to reduce the level of dividends paid to stockholders and to restrict the creation of new liens on its assets. Pennzoil contended that Texaco could provide the ''full security'' without be forced into bankruptcy. **********Pennzoil also asked that the Texas appeals court to delay a ruling on how much of a bond Texaco should post until Texaco submits a detailed proposal of how it would provide for Pennzoil's security. The appeals court is scheduled to hear arguments on the bond issue Monday, and Texaco has said that an unfavorable outcome could lead it to seek bankruptcy protection immediately. **********The companies are fighting about Texaco's acquisition of the Getty Oil Company in 1984, after Pennzoil had reached what it contends was a binding agreement to acquire three-sevenths of Getty. **********A Texas state court jury ruled in Pennzoil's favor in 1985 and awarded Pennzoil $11 billion in damages. A Texas appeals court upheld the verdict in February, but reduced the damages by $2 billion. Still, with interest, the damage award now totals $10.3 billion. **********Today's court filings came after a week of feverish activity here, with teams of executives, lawyers and financial advisers for both sides gathered for what could be a crucial turning point in the high-stakes case. **********James W. Kinnear, Texaco's chief executive, and Alfred C. DeCrane Jr., Texaco's chairman, met several times face-to-face with J. Hugh Liedtke, Pennzoil's chairman and chief executive, and Baine P. Kerr, the chaitman of Pennzoil's executive committee. Compromises Discussed **********During the meetings, held at Pennzoil's headquarters building here and at a Texaco office, the executives discussed possible compromises both on the bond issue and on an overall settlement of the dispute, according to participants in the case. **********No details of the settlement discussions were available. But people familiar with the talks said that Texaco had made several proposals and that Pennzoil was considering possible counterproposals. **********The threat of bankruptcy and the exchange of proposals have turned this latest round of negotiations into a high-stakes poker match. Pennzoil, which would become just another of Texaco's unsecured creditors in the event of a filing under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, must decide if Texaco is bluffing with its bankruptcy threats. **********For its part, Texaco must decide whether it is really willing to become the largest company ever to file for bankruptcy in order to escape the bond provisions. In bankruptcy, Texaco would risk the wrath of shareholders and creditors and suffer limitations on its ability to operate. **********Texaco is already under severe and increasing financial pressure. On Wednesday, according to court documents filed today by Texaco, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company canceled a credit line with Texaco because of the uncertainty over the company's future. **********Texaco is said to be studying its financial situation to determine how long it can continue to operate without bankruptcy protection. While creditors are becoming more and more jittery, Texaco is believed to have created a cushion for itself by drawing down several hundred million dollars from its credit lines earlier this year. **********In New York Stock Exchange trading today, Pennzoil's stock jumped $5.25 a share, to $92.25. Texaco, which was the most active issue, with almost 5.8 million shares changing hands, dropped 37.5 cents, to $31.875.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/13/world.main_headline: GHANA EMBRACES CHANGE (E.G.: A STOCK EXCHANGE)
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/13/world.print_headline: ACCRA JOURNAL; GHANA EMBRACES CHANGE (E.G.: A STOCK EXCHANGE)
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/13/world.body_text: **********Thirty years ago, Kwame Nkrumah mounted a floodlighted podium here and proclaimed that Ghana would be ''a shining light throughout the whole continent of Africa, giving inspiration beyond its frontiers.'' **********Ghana's President had every reason to be confident about his West African nation, the first of a string of European colonies in Africa to attain independence. **********At independence, Ghana, the former British colony of the Gold Coast, was the world's largest producer of cocoa, produced 10 percent of the world's gold, had about $1 billion in reserves and enjoyed a per capita income twice that of South Korea. **********In 1983, after 26 years of African socialism - a period that included five military coups and two years of drought - Ghana hit bottom. Civil servants fainted at their desks from hunger. An army private confessed to joining a coup attempt because the plotters promised him food for his children. South Korea started to send aid. Inflation Down, Exports Up **********Today, Ghana is climbing back. The difference appears to be four years of economic initiatives combining free enterprise and austerity that aid experts are closely watching as a test case for the revival of other stagnating, state-dominated African economies. **********Since the program was adopted in April 1983, inflation has dropped from 123 percent to 25 percent, and exports have climbed by 76 percent, to $773 million last year. After shrinking from 1981 through 1983, the economy expanded at an average of 5 percent a year from 1984 to 1986. **********The economic measures, largely drawn up by the World Bank, have been tough. In four years, Ghana's national currency, the cedi, has been devalued by 5,600 percent. It has dropped from a fixed rate of 2.75 to the dollar to a floating rate, currently 158, that is set by a weekly foreign-exchange auction. **********The Civil Service, which in the late 1970's was growing four times as fast as the population, has been trimmed and is scheduled to be cut by 15,000 workers, or 5 percent, in each of the next three years. **********The Ghana Cocoa Board has cut its ranks in half, from 92,000 workers in 1982 to 48,000 today. Some 10,000 more workers are to be let go this year. **********Thirty state enterprises are to be identified this year for liquidation or sale to private interests. The Cocoa Board plans to sell half of its 92 plantations. **********To cut cocoa smuggling to Ghana's free-enterprise neighbors, Ivory Coast and Togo, the Government has doubled real prices paid to cocoa farmers, the source of two-thirds of the nation's foreign exchange. **********Finally, in this city where African socialism was the unquestioned credo for so long, the Government is to inaugurate Ghana's first stock exchange next month. **********To ease Ghana through these changes, Western governments are committing increasing amounts of aid to Ghana, a nation of 13 million. Last year, donors made aid commitments of $391 million. This month, donors gathered in Paris to review Ghana's request for $575 million in aid for 1987.  [ They pledged to meet the request. ]  ''Ghana is beginning to pull in more and more because, frankly, most Western governments are looking for an African success story,'' an American economist here said. The Changes Are Startling **********The changes in this pleasantly laid out capital are startling. Beeping lines of passenger cars and brightly painted mammy wagons - small open-sided buses or trucks - clog the thoroughfares, a contrast with the empty boulevards of four years ago when drivers were allotted a monthly gasoline ration of six gallons. At the Makola Market in Accra, stalls are stacked with pyramids of tomato paste, bushels of rice and glinting displays of galvanized buckets. **********The bustling market symbolizes the ideological turnaround of Ghana's leader, Flight Lieut. Jerry J. Rawlings, 39 years old. When he seized power in 1979, he warred with Accra's formidable market women. He placed controls on food prices and had violators flogged and their shops bulldozed. In a losing battle with the laws of supply and demand, he eventually razed the market. **********After a hiatus of civilian rule, he seized power again on Dec. 31, 1981. After two years of indecision, he lifted price controls, and the stalls filled up with goods again. Last December, a new market hall with a metal roof and a concrete floor was inaugurated with great fanfare by Mr. Rawlings. **********Despite the crowded markets, many Ghanaians complain that they cannot afford the goods on sale. In the market, four tomatoes cost 25 cents. A bottle of beer costs 75 cents. ''Living conditions were better under the British - everyone knows that,'' said Augustus Yankey, secretary general of the Trade Union Congress. Despite his dissatisfaction, Mr. Yankey said he saw ''no alternative'' to the current economic program. **********But many Ghanaians say they resent the behind-the-scenes power of foreign economic experts here. University students, many of whom are studying for nonexistent jobs in the Civil Service, were cheered this month by the news that President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia had bowed to popular pressure and abandoned an economic austerity program similar to Ghana's. 'Beggar Status' Charged **********But many of their elders seem to be traumatized by the last 30 years, and they are slow in responding to the old nationalist fire bells. **********The current issue of Christian Messenger, one of the few independent voices here, carries a somber editorial titled, ''Thirty Years After Ghana's Independence.'' **********''Our once-rich and prosperous nation, which boasted of substantial revenues from exports of our abundant natural resources which in the past earned us the name Gold Coast, has now been reduced to beggar status, subsisting almost exclusively on foreign loans and aids,'' the editorial read. **********On March 6, the 30th anniversary of Mr. Nkrumah's proclamation, Ghanaians gathered once again around the huge black stars of the Independence Arch in Accra. **********''I think we must admit that independence has not brought to fruition the great hopes and dreams of our people,'' Mr. Rawlings told the subdued crowd. ''March 6, 1957, gave birth to political freedom. When are we, as Africans, going to translate this political freedom into economic freedom? When? That is the question that I want to leave to you tonight.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.body_text: **********The Sony Corporation, a leading Japanese maker of video equipment, said today that the rise of the yen had cut its profit by more than half. **********Earnings of the parent company and its worldwide subsidiaries plunged 56 percent in the five months ended March 31, to about 13 billion yen, equal to $93 million. The reporting period was only five months because Sony is changing its fiscal year to begin April 1 instead of Nov. 1. **********Sony's five-month sales fell 5 percent, to 548 billion yen, or $3.9 billion, while the yen strengthened from 193 to the dollar to 156 to the dollar. **********The yen's appreciation, about 45 percent against the dollar over the last year and a half, has put pressure on Japanese manufacturers by lifting the overseas prices of their products.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/18/world.main_headline: IN TRUCE, FILIPINO REBELS PRESS A POLITICAL WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/18/world.print_headline: IN TRUCE, FILIPINO REBELS PRESS A POLITICAL WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/18/world.body_text: **********Striding through rice fields, Ka Christine, nine months pregnant, sang to herself with more enthusiasm than melody: ''Wave the red flag, advance the revolution.'' **********Christine, a full member of the Communist Party of the Philippines at the age of 20, is a ''mass organizer,'' setting up a network of support through the countryside and recruiting fighters for the armed wing of the party, the New People's Army. **********As such, she is on the front lines of the country's 18-year insurgency, which is seeking to advance as much through political agitation as through armed confrontation. **********The Philippine armed forces chief, Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, has warned that the current cease-fire, while bringing a temporary halt to the fighting, has allowed the rebels to openly step up their propaganda work. It is an assessment that the rebels seem to share. **********Christine, who uses the revolutionary title Ka for ''kasama,'' the Tagalog word for comrade, moves from village to village, sometimes alone and sometimes with a partner. She introduces farmers to the concepts of feudalism, imperialism and bureaucratic capitalism, and teaches them to sing her revolutionary songs. **********''The revolution will not succeed through armed struggle alone,'' Christine said. ''The people must understand why armed struggle is necessary.'' **********One of her superiors, a veteran of 14 years who calls himself Ka Joe, agreed, saying: ''We are a political army. We are not only engaged in fighting.'' **********It is primarily the underground organizers like Christine, backed by force or the threat of force, who have spread the influence of their movement into what Joe said was more than 40 percent of the towns and villages of Pangasinan. 'A Victory Already For Us' **********Ka Levie, one of only two men from the original 60 New People's Army fighters who are still in the field after 18 years, said he believed that the 60-day cease-fire, which may be extended next month, was a ''big step forward'' for the insurgency. **********''Both on the local level and on the national level, and even overseas, we can present our programs openly,'' he said. ''No matter how the cease-fire comes out, it is a victory already for us.'' **********Noting that the ousted Defense Minister, Juan Ponce Enrile, had used much the same reasoning in condemning the truce, he said, ''Enrile is a very realistic person.'' **********During the first month of the cease-fire, which began Dec. 10, the Communists held 200 ''mass meetings'' with the people in Pangasinan, Joe said. The meetings were far more open and more frequent than those held before the cease-fire. A Dramatic Expansion **********The armed insurgency, which began not far from here in Tarlac Province in 1969 with 60 men and 35 weapons, now fields a regular fighting force estimated by American analysts at 16,000 to 23,000 troops. **********The rebels say they have 12,000 well-armed guerrillas and 20,000 part-time fighters, backed by thousands of active organizers like Christine. **********According to the military, the insurgency has extended its political influence into 62 of the nation's 73 provinces. **********Western analysts and Philippine military leaders say the insurgency's dramatic expansion in recent years is based on its political work at various levels as much as on military action. **********Indeed, since 1980, when the Communists brought their insurgency to this province in central Luzon, a three-hour drive from Manila, they have fought just 15 small engagements here with the armed forces, Joe said. **********And when military action is considered, he said, ''we are always thinking in terms of a political gain.'' **********In agreeing to let a reporter move about with them through several villages not far from the main highway, the rebels specified that the precise locations should not be identified. Discussion of Rebel Program **********Sitting in the living room of a sympathetic village chief one recent morning, Joe listened intently to a 10-minute interview on the Government radio station with Carolina Malay, one of the insurgency's leading spokesmen. **********As she answered the interviewer's respectful questions, it became clear that for the first time, the rebels' political platform was being seriously discussed as an alternative for the nation. In the interview, Ms. Malay discussed rebel proposals for land redistribution, economic restructuring and an eventual sharing of power between the rebels and the current Government. **********Pangasinan Province is a difficult challenge for the insurgency, Joe said, because most of the province is in a flat plain covered by a network of roads. **********For this reason, the rebels have been able to consolidate only a few areas that they fully control and can defend against attack. For the most part, they live in a shadow world just beneath the surface, relying on sympathetic villagers for food and lodging. 'It's All Mobile' **********''It's all U.G.,'' said Joe, using the insurgent jargon for underground activities. ''There is no physical base. It's all mobile.'' **********He said local residents provide information and protection against military patrols. **********''Before the military can reach this place,'' he said as he ate lunch at a farmer's house with his unit's weapons and communications equipment in full view, ''the masses will do their part in security, and we will be gone.'' **********That morning, Joe had been among the first to rise, drawing water from the village pump and sweeping the dirt floor as his hostess heated the wood stove for breakfast. **********Later, as the workday began and the family headed out of the house, Joe set to work in the front room, his radio transmitter beside him, his aides resting nearby. **********Messengers began to arrive, bringing dispatches on folded onionskin paper, and Joe, a ranking local rebel leader, scribbled replies that he then sealed thoroughly with tape. Plans A, B and C if Truce Falters **********He said his current assignment involved monitoring the cease-fire in Pangasinan. The rebels, he said, were prepared for a military offensive if the truce comes to an end. **********''There is a Plan A, there is a Plan B, there is a Plan C,'' he said. ''If the cease-fire breaks down, every unit will know what to do.'' **********In Pangasinan, Joe said, the rebel troops are organized mostly into compact platoons with some small assassination squads whose task is to seize arms from soldiers and policemen. **********There are also village militia units that enforce local control and can be mobilized as a reserve. **********At Christine's side as she walked through the rice fields the other day was her husband, Ka Bong, a soft-spoken 25-year-old soldier in the New People's Army. **********Bong is one of the elite regular troops, armed with automatic weapons, who Joe said may begin to carry out larger-scale engagements in the province in the next stage of fighting. 'Revolutionary Justice' **********Though he said he had taken part in few battles, Bong is experienced in carrying out ''revolutionary justice'' -reinforcing his wife's classroom lessons with selected ambushes and assassinations. **********Christine and Bong said they had not seen each other very often since their marriage a year ago, as they pursued their separate roles in the insurgency and made dates to meet every month or two. **********Christine, who comes from a farming family in Pangasinan, won a scholarship to study accounting in Manila, but left college in her final year to join the underground movement. **********Bong, who did not finish high school, began his work with the movement as a labor organizer before joining the New People's Army four years ago. **********Today, as they walked across the sun-baked rice fields, he was on a short furlough to be with her during the birth of their child, which they expected within days. Neither was armed. Leaving Baby 'With the Masses' **********Once the baby is born, Christine said, they plan to ''leave it with the masses'' to be reared by villagers sympathetic to their cause. **********''The revolution can handle the care and teaching of the baby as a revolutionary baby,'' said Joe. **********''I know it will be hard,'' said Christine, ''but I will do it for the sake of the people.'' **********One recent evening, a local mayor visited one of his distant farming hamlets, where Christine and her husband were spending the night. **********He seemed, in talking to a reporter, to be unaware that the hamlet had been thoroughly infiltrated and that most of the residents appeared to be supporters of the insurgency. **********When he had left, a group of local rebel supporters gathered openly with Christine for a discussion of their activities. **********Talking with a visitor during this discussion, their answers to questions had a well-drilled uniformity rarely encountered in this lively and opinionated country. Some Gains for Peasants **********According to Joe, the rebels have succeeded in many cases in winning lower farm rents, increased wages for labor and reduced interest rates on loans. He said some farmers have been organized into work collectives. **********In return, villagers offer logistical support and are urged to join revolutionary organizations and to make ''voluntary contributions'' to the rebels, he said. **********The social and agrarian benefits have been gained by organizing farmers to demand better conditions and by backing their demands with an implicit threat of force, and sometimes with force itself, Joe said. **********''If the landlord uses force against the peasant, the N.P.A. will use its political power against the landlord,'' he said. **********Christine said: ''The N.P.A. talks to the landlord three times. Then the military component takes over. This is something the landlords know.'' **********Within the local population itself, party control is maintained by a ''revolutionary committee.'' A List of 12 Victims **********In the thatched, dirt-floored house of a farmer where he and his wife were spending the night, Bong spoke in the light of an oil lamp about his work in carrying out ''revolutionary justice.'' **********On a scrap of paper he wrote the names of 12 men who had been killed after a revoutionary committee had determined that they had been involved in land-grabbing, usury, banditry, theft of animals or the brutal killings known as ''salvagings.'' **********Walking through the sunny fields the next morning, Christine said she had encountered a new difficulty during the past year in recruiting young men, who had begun asking why they should take up arms against President Corazon C. Aquino. **********And with the cease-fire, Christine said, she had a new task, revisiting a few of her own recruits who had chosen to accept Mrs. Aquino's invitation to surrender and return to their homes. A Welcome From a 'Rich Peasant' **********She told of one soldier named Janet whom she had persuaded to return to the hills, arguing that, good-hearted though Mrs. Aquino might be, ''nothing has changed in our lives since she became President.'' **********This morning, Christine and Bong visited another village where a well-to-do farmer classified by the revolutionaries as a ''rich peasant'' welcomed them to join his breakfast. **********''My home is open to them, day in and day out,'' said their host, who also works as a government official. ''In this area I think all of us are sympathizers. There are three or four houses whose sincerity we doubt.'' **********He said he held his government job to help support both his family and the rebels. ''Without my government work I would not be able to support the movement the way I do,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/22/busin.main_headline: Maxwell Could Issue Stock to Buy Harcourt
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/22/busin.print_headline: Maxwell Could Issue Stock to Buy Harcourt
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/22/busin.body_text: **********Robert Maxwell, the British publisher who has made a $2 billion takeover offer for Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., says that his British Printing and Communication Corporation may issue stock to help pay for the acquisition. **********''Whatever financing is required is available,'' he declared in an interview on Wednesday in his suite at the Waldorf-Astoria. **********Mr. Maxwell flew to New York on Wednesday aboard the Concorde to be here during today's scheduled meeting of Harcourt's board. The main item of business is expected to be the $44-a-share offer he made for the book publisher on Monday. **********Harcourt's stock, meanwhile, remained above the bid yesterday. On volume of almost two million shares, it closed at $45.75, down $1.25. The price suggests that investors still expect a higher bid to emerge. Shrugging Off Barbs **********In the interview, the 63-year-old naturalized British citizen shrugged off barbs directed at him by William Jovanovich, Harcourt's chairman, and he repeated his invitation for Mr. Jovanovich and other managers to remain if he acquires Harcourt. **********Of Mr. Jovanovich's allusions to Mr. Maxwell's Czechoslovak origins and to what a British Government board of inquiry in 1969 described as shortcomings in Mr. Maxwell's business practices, ''I put that down to emotional reaction, really,'' he said. **********''Mr. Jovanovich has, after all, built this business and done it well,'' he added. ''I prefer to ignore the personal remarks. The issues are economic.'' **********Mr. Maxwell also reiterated that he would not persist in his takeover attempt if the Harcourt board turned him down. ''To the best of my knowledge, such an offer is unique,'' he said. ''That's the only way I want to come into America.'' But if he is thwarted in his effort to buy Harcourt, Mr. Maxwell acknowledged, he plans to bid for another American book publisher. Assurances From Murdoch **********Mr. Maxwell also said that he had received assurances that Rupert Murdoch would not bid for Harcourt. A self-described socialist and one of the wealthiest men in Britain, Mr. Maxwell has feuded for two decades with Mr. Murdoch. Because Mr. Murdoch recently bought Harper & Row Publishers Inc., he has been mentioned as a possible suitor for Harcourt, which also publishes magazines and operates theme parks. **********But Mr. Maxwell said in the interview, ''I have heard from Murdoch that he's not going to bid for H.B.J.'' Asked when they had discussed the matter, he replied: ''Amend that. I understand that Murdoch's not interested in bidding for it.'' **********A spokesman for Mr. Murdoch said yesterday that he had no comment about the matter. **********If Mr. Maxwell does acquire Harcourt, he said, he will not break it up. ''I'm not an asset stripper,'' he said. ''In 40 years I've been a buyer, not a seller. I have never sold anything of substance.'' **********Mr. Maxwell owns Europe's largest printing and publishing company; his Mirror Group is said to be the largest non-Communist newspaper publisher, and he is one of the biggest printers in the United States after three recent purchases. The acquisition of Harcourt would make him the world's biggest educational publisher.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/20/busin.body_text: **********The Budd Company, one of the nation's largest automotive suppliers, said it would build a $100 million plant here that would employ as many as 400 people. Construction on the 75-acre site will begin this spring and is scheduled for completion in early 1988. The plant will be used to stamp and assemble such components as hoods, fenders, quarter panels and doors. **********Budd, a subsidiary of Thyssen A.G. of West Germany, said it had selected the site for several reasons, including state training assistance, labor and utility costs and ease of transportation. The plant will serve Budd's current customers, such as the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation, and the company said it also hoped to secure new business from the Toyota Motor Corporation. Budd, which is based in Troy, Mich., has three other stamping and frame division plants, in Kitchener, Ontario; Detroit, and Philadelphia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/19/world.main_headline: Fearing a Fuel Crisis, Burundi Turns to Peat
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/19/world.print_headline: Fearing a Fuel Crisis, Burundi Turns to Peat
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/19/world.body_text: **********The Irish sent bog engineers; the Finns sold harvesters, and the Americans financed stove research. **********The international effort is intended to help this central African nation develop an alternative energy source: peat, decaying plant matter that can be dried and burned as fuel. **********In the West, fears of an energy crisis have faded as oil prices, though rising, have remained releatively low. At the same time, interest in alternative fuels has waned. **********But in Africa, experts say, an energy crisis could cause problems by the end of the next decade. **********The consumption of wood in Africa, which has the fastest growing population of any continent in the world, is expected to double by the year 2000, compared with 1975. **********''You have very high population growth rates and very rapid rates of deforestation occurring at the same time,'' said Kjell A. Christophersen, director of Energy Initiatives for Africa, a United States-financed program based in Kenya and in the Ivory Coast. **********In Burundi, a densely populated nation where wood accounts for 90 percent of energy consumption, and peat accounts for only 2 percent, the Government is trying to discourage the use of one in favor of the other. **********''Wood was getting rare around here,'' said Daniel Kinigi, director of the National Peat Office, established by the Government a decade ago. **********Most of the money for the project came from a $9 million grant from the United States. The six-year funding expires in December. **********In addition to Burundi, Mr. Kinigi said, Kenya, Rwanda, Senegal and Zaire had recently done preliminary surveys to study the use of peat. **********Finland and Ireland, the world's two principal peat powers, sent engineers to survey and test Burundi's bogs. Thirty-three tons of Burundi peat were shipped to Helsinki for testing in different boilers. **********The central African peat was found to have a 20 percent ash content, compared with 5 percent for Irish and Finnish peat, making the African peat less energy efficient and requiring the use of different types of stoves and ovens. **********Engineers designed stoves and bakery ovens to be made from local materials like mud, brick and iron. For larger projects, Burundians hope to import industrial-size boilers from Finland. **********Peat experts here say there is no tradition in central Africa of burning peat, which generates slightly less heat than wood. But peat production figures show that the new fuel is gaining increasing acceptance. From a start of 42 tons in 1977, Burundi harvested 3,550 tons last year. **********Because of heavy rains in central Africa, enough peat for an entire year has to be harvested in four months - between mid-May and mid-September. It is currently burned largely in institutional kitchens: military camps, prisons, hospitals, bakeries and school restaurants. **********Chris Adams, the West German stove and oven designer, acknowledged that some design wrinkles had yet to be worked out. But noting the sharp increase in peat consumption here, he said the program had been a success. **********''When we came here, peat had a very bad image'' Mr. Adams said. ''People said it burned holes in pots. Our main success is that peat is accepted as a main alternative fuel.''

She said the furniture and computer system at the firm's office at 120 Wall Street were being sold this week. **********Mr. Greenspan, who was nominated in early June to replace Paul A. Volcker, is one of the nation's best-known economic forecasters. The firm employed more than 20 economists and operated computer models that simulated the national economy and various industries. At the request of the White **********House, Mr. Greenspan had agreed to remove his name from the firm's name and to dissolve Townsend-Greenspan by July 31. He has also said he will place his personal holdings in a blind trust. He is expected to assume the **********Fed post in early August, after confirmation by the Senate. **********Top members of the Townsend-Greenspan staff tried to reorganize the firm under a new name, with a well-known economist replacing Mr. Greenspan, but because of the deadline they did not have enough time, Ms. Hall said. **********Townsend-Greenspan was organized as Townsend-Skinner in the 1930's by William Townsend and Dana Skinner. **********Mr. Greenspan joined in 1953 and became principal owner in 1958.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/23/busin.main_headline: Fanciful Theories on Perelman's Obsession With Gillette
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/23/busin.print_headline: ANTIC OBSERVATIONS; Fanciful Theories on Perelman's Obsession With Gillette
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/23/busin.body_text: **********THIS week Ronald O. Perelman, chairman of the Revlon Group Inc., made his third offer in less than a year for the Gillette Company. To some, his quest is beginning to seem obsessive. **********Especially to Gillette, which thought it had bid good riddance to Mr. Perelman in November by paying greenmail - a premium for his stock - and having him promise not to buy any more Gillette stock for 10 years or ''seek control or influence'' over the company without its consent. **********Nonetheless, Mr. Perelman is once again seeking control - having asked Gillette's board this week for permission to make a formal offer. Obviously, the company underestimated his tenacity. While some analysts assume Mr. Perelman is merely trying to put Gillette in play so he can capture a $300 million raider consolation prize (which he'll get if Gillette is acquired by anyone else before Nov. 24), others believe he truly covets the company. ''Ron really wants Gillette,'' said Nancy Hall, an analyst with Smith Barney Upham & Company. ''It's exactly the kind of company Ron likes to buy. It has excellent cash flow, strong brand names and a lot of distinct pieces that can be sold off easily.'' **********But that's not all. With a little imagination, it is possible to concoct some other, deeper explanations for the remarkable doggedness of Mr. Perelman's pursuit, such as the following: **********The ad play. Under Mr. Perelman, Revlon's ads have become a lot more risque (the ice cube seduction commercial for Revlon's Intimate perfume is the best example) and he believes Gillette could profit from a similar infusion of tastelessness. He thinks the old Noxzema shaving cream campaign (''Take it off; take it all off'') was a model of personal care product advertising, although he reportedly considers it ''insufficiently flagrant.'' If done with style and genuine salaciousness, a new ad campaign, contends Mr. Perelman, could encourage men to shave two, three or even four times a day. **********The dental floss play. Gillette's crown jewel, as Mr. Perelman's sees it, is really the Oral-B unit, which controls 28 percent of the American toothbrush market. He wants the division for its astonishing advances in dental floss technology. He dreams of producing a scented, colored, flavored and completely edible floss that would finally eliminate the awkward disposal problems. He also wants to introduce $25 gourmet dental floss under the Claudia label (named after his wife). Supporting this theory is the fact that for years Mr. Perelman has given dental floss to friends on their birthdays. ''Ron thinks gum care is very important,'' said one acquaintance. **********Theme and variation. Mr. Perelman, a creative financier, needs another household name like Revlon to develop a unique kind of synergy. After taking Gillette private, his next task would be to bring Revlon public once again. A year later Gillette would reemerge as a public company, and Revlon would go private. The next year Gillette would go private and Revlon would come public. Divisions would be shuffled between the two companies so that laggards are sold to the public at a high multiple, while thriving units are taken private at a steep discount. ''It'll be like three card monte - with class,'' said a Perelman colleague approvingly. **********The trend play. There are various projects in the works at Gillette to design better razor blades, and some might be on the market in a couple of years. Mr. Perelman, however, is taking an even longer view. He believes that a current trend - the earlier onset of puberty -will accelerate rapidly in the future. One Revlon research scientist has convinced Mr. Perelman, who secretly prides himself on being a long-term investor, that by the year 2300, most five-year-old boys will be shaving regularly. ''Gillette,'' said a Revlon official, ''represents an entirely new investment concept - hormonal leverage.'' **********Lack of Growth. Richard Arbitrage, a psychotherapist specializing in takeover-related ailments, said that Mr. Perelman is going after Gillette because he's bald. ''Gillette has a strong position in male hair care products with The Dry Look,'' said Dr. Arbitrage, ''and that tells you all you need to know. Perelman's pursuit of Gillette is purely compensatory.'' **********Consistency. Mr. Perelman does not actually want Gillette, but he will keep pursuing it until his death anyway. The reason? He yearns to remove the one flaw in greenmail - the fact that it doesn't provide a predictable revenue stream. He seeks to achieve something no other raider ever has, a state of perpetual greenmail. If he succeeds, Gillette will pay him $30 million to $40 million dollars every year for not acquiring the company. ''Frankly,'' said one Perelman aide, ''we think 'tribute' is a much nicer word than 'greenmail.' ''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/world.main_headline: Rebels in Zimbabwe Said to Have Killed 16 People at Mission
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/world.print_headline: Rebels in Zimbabwe Said to Have Killed 16 People at Mission
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/world.body_text: **********The British Broadcasting Corporation said today that anti-Government rebels in Zimbabwe massacred 16 people, most of them white missionaries and their children, in the southern province of Matabeleland. **********A BBC World Service radio news bulletin said most of the dead were Zimbabwean citizens, that many were women and children, and that the youngest was six weeks old.  [ A newspaper editor contacted by telephone in Bulawayo said two Americans and one Australian were reported among the dead. The editor, Sheila White of The Bulawayo Bulletin, said the names of the victims had not been released.  [ Mrs. White said the attack took place at the Esigodini Mission, run by a little-known religious group called the Order of Reconciliation. **********She said the attackers, about 20 in all, raided the mission before dawn Thursday.  [ Mrs. White said the attackers were presumed to guerrillas of the Zimbabwe African People's Union, which is strongest in Matabeleland. **********The group's leader, Joshua Nkomo, has a rivalry with Prime Minister Robert Mugabe that dates from their days as leaders of separate guerrilla armies in the period before the white minority Government of Rhodesia was ousted in 1980.  [ Mrs. White said the attacks may have been reprisals for the recent eviction of squatters from mission land in the area known as New Adams Farm. **********The BBC quoted missionaries in Matabeleland as saying that the attackers burst into the mission, shooting and killing their victims before hacking them with axes and burning their bodies. **********It said two children escaped death and that one was given a note by the attackers to take to the authorities in Bulawayo. **********The BBC said there was no further explanation of the massacre and no word yet from the authorities in Zimbabwe. **********The BBC described the massacre as the worst single attack on white people since Zimbabwe gained independence seven years ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/02/world.body_text: **********Salvadoran rebel leaders, angered at a remark by El Salvador's President, have postponed a meeting scheduled for Sunday with Government officials to discuss ways to carry out a new regional peace plan. **********But a rebel leader, Jorge Villacorta, said the leftist guerrillas would meet informally with Salvadoran Government representatives in Guatemala on Friday. Mr. Villacorta told reporters here Wednesday that the two sides could still overcome ''all obstacles in order to give the Salvadoran people the peace they so much desire.'' **********Sunday's talks would have been the first between the rebels and United States-supported Government since 1984. The principle item for discussion was to have been a proposed agreement on a cease-fire in the eight-year-old war by Nov. 7, a deadline set in a new regional peace plan. **********The leftist rebels announced in the Salvadoran capital on Wednesday that they were canceling the meeting with Government officials. **********The rebel communique charged that El Salvador's President, Jose Napoleon Duarte, had ''referred to the Oct. 4 dialogue with a negative attitude that does nothing to contribute to creating a favorable climate for . . . the dialogue to reach a negotiated, political solution to the conflict.'' **********On Tuesday, Mr. Duarte said the meeting would be limited to discussions about the peace plan. He demanded that the rebels state publicly that they would abandon violence and take part in the democratic process.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/16/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Dallas Chief Leaves At Neiman-Marcus
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/16/busin.body_text: **********Neiman-Marcus Group Inc., the company that owns the Neiman-Marcus, Bergdorf Goodman and Contempo Casuals specialty store chains, has announced the resignation of David L. Dworkin, president of the Neiman-Marcus division. **********Mr. Dworkin, who is 43 years old, said that he was leaving after four years to seek other business opportunities. **********The company said on Friday from its Chestnut Hill, Mass., headquarters that it would name a replacement soon and that Richard C. Marcus, chairman and chief executive, would add the post of chief operating officer. It also named Lawrence Elkin, executive vice president for administration, to be executive vice president for sales and store operations. **********''I would consider myself to be a builder,'' the 43-year-old Mr. Dworkin said from his office in Dallas. ''I'm sort of ready for a new set of mountains to climb.'' **********Mr. Dworkin, who marked his 20th year in retailing in September, began his career in the executive training program at Abraham & Straus in 1967. Mr. Dworkin said that he and his wife decided to leave New York after they learned they were expecting their second child. **********In 1969, the couple moved to St. Louis, where Mr. Dworkin joined the Famous-Barr division of the May Department Stores Company as assistant buyer. While there, Mr. Dworkin also returned to school and graduated with a degree in liberal arts from Webster College in 1974. **********In 1977, he joined Saks Fifth Avenue, a unit of Batus Inc., before being transferred six years later to another Batus operation, Marshall Field & Company in Chicago, where he was named executive vice president for merchandise. **********A few months later, in January 1984, Mr. Dworkin was hired by Neiman-Marcus in Dallas as president of the company. According to Mr. Marcus, Mr. Dworkin was instrumental in successfully shaping the company after its expansion to 21 stores in 1984, from 11 stores in 1978. **********Asked what plans he had for the near future, Mr. Dworkin said that he was looking forward to a fishing and sailing trip in the spring and would like to try more writing. His first article, which was published as an About Men column in The New York Times Magazine two and a half years ago, discussed his personal quest for, and quandaries about, happiness. **********Referring to his two daughters, now grown, he wrote, ''They make me ask in the face of a life dedicated to achievement: 'Is this all there is?'' **********The Dworkins, who live in Dallas, also have a home on Cape Cod.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/24/busin.print_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE; Hong Kong's Uneasy Boom
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/24/busin.body_text: **********WHAT will happen to Hong Kong when China takes it over from Britain just 10 years from now? Will this thriving center of trade, manufacturing and finance wither away in the Communist embrace - or will it help to liberalize and invigorate the economy of China? **********Those were key questions when a group of Western economists organized by the American Committee on Asian Economic Studies recently visited Hong Kong, Shanghai, Wuhan and Beijing. **********Despite deep anxieties about what happens after 1997, Hong Kong is still booming. On the Communist mainland, one hears constant complaints about ''Chinese laziness,'' but in Hong Kong this myth is put to rest; laziness and zip are clearly functions of economic systems, not ethnicity. **********''There is a bustle, an energy, a sense of hard work and productivity that goes beyond even the obvious prosperity,'' Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said of Hong Kong. She called it a transportation planner's dream, with its trams, buses, clean taxis and harbor ferries, not to mention its new subway. She found no poverty of public service in this bastion of free enterprise: ''The new Harbor Tunnel was built by the private sector, as will be the next, and possibly the new airport.'' **********But private capital is poised for flight. Many business people say they are planning to leave for other countries; what is holding them now, some say, are aged parents whom they are unwilling to leave. A Chinese builder, whose home is in Singapore but who has projects going in Hong Kong, said everyone he knows is holding as much money as possible in foreign currency, ready to leave Hong Kong quickly. **********James T. H. Tsao of the United States International Trade Commission, who traveled with the group, said that several countries had already revised their investment laws to ease the inflow of capital from Hong Kong. Much of it is flowing to Singapore and Taiwan. China has its heart set on regaining Taiwan, but it will be much harder to acquire than Hong Kong, where the population of 5.5 million is dependent on the mainland for the bulk of its food and nearly half its water. **********China has 1.1 billion people, but its trade with tiny Hong Kong still matters greatly. Since 1951, China's trade balance with Hong Kong has always been in surplus. For the last 34 years, Hong Kong has been China's second-biggest trading partner, except for three years, 1965, 1968 and 1969, when Hong Kong held the No. 1 position. **********A Japanese economist, Miyohei Shinohara, chairman of the Institute of Developing Economies in Tokyo, startled the Chinese Prime Minister, Zhao Ziyang, at a meeting in 1982 by telling him that about one-fourth of China's exports were via Hong Kong and about one-third of the foreign exchange earnings came in through Hong Kong. **********He also warned Mr. Zhao that ''if China treats Hong Kong the same as China proper, Hong Kong business interests will flee to Taiwan and Singapore, taking with them their capitalist dynamism, with the result that Chinese exports via Hong Kong will sharply decline, causing the Chinese economy to fall into stagnation.'' He asked Mr. Zhao what he would say to that. The only answer he got from the Prime Minister was: ''The figures of one-fourth and one-third that you gave are overestimates.'' **********Nevertheless, the Chinese are highly aware of the danger of hurting themselves by hurting Hong Kong. On Sept. 26, 1984, Britain and China initialed an agreement permitting Hong Kong to keep its free-market economy for 50 years beyond 1997. Negotiations are now going on over civil liberties, freedom of the press and other legal and economic matters. **********Still, this has not quelled anxieties as ideology within China zigs and zags. The silencing of student protests in Beijing and elsewhere last year disturbed Hong Kong. And just last month, Chinese officials upset many people in Hong Kong by saying they would not interfere in Hong Kong before 1997 ''unless the British Government takes any measure which can influence events after 1997 or impede the smooth handover of Hong Kong.'' **********But China's concerns about the dangers of capital flight from Hong Kong and the crucial importance of keeping open this window to the capitalist world are reinforcing Deng Xiaoping's pragmatic and reformist course. The question is whether China is prepared to go far enough, both politically and economically, to avoid choking Hong Kong off and seriously damaging the development of China. The Chinese leaders, including Mr. Deng, are anything but closet capitalists. They insist they are searching for ''socialism with Chinese characteristics.'' And Hong Kong still feels itself menaced.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/09/world.main_headline: AMID ANGER, TURKISH CHIEF DEFERS U.S. VISIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/09/world.print_headline: AMID ANGER, TURKISH CHIEF DEFERS U.S. VISIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/09/world.body_text: **********Spurred by opposition and press criticism, President Kenan Evren of Turkey has postponed a visit to the United States this month in what diplomats describe as a display of anger at recent Congressional actions. **********The Turkish leader's decision, announced this week, underscores the unsettled nature of Washington's relationship with both Greece and Turkey, fractious neighbors within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. **********Greece has yet to commit itself publicly to renewing an agreement on American bases and, during a crisis with Turkey earlier this year, briefly ordered the closing of a United States naval communications facility. **********Some Western diplomats, moreover, fear the upset with Turkey might deepen long-term misgivings about the United States in the region. ''The Turks take alliances seriously and have long memories about behavior they consider unfriendly,'' a Western official said.  [ In Washington, the State Department expressed disappointment that Mr. Evren had postponed his visit. **********''We are disappointed the visit will not take place at the previously scheduled time later this month,'' a spokeswoman said. ''In coming days we will be in touch with the Turkish Government to discuss a possible new date for the visit.'' ]  President Evren's decision came after a move by the Turkish authorities to suspend ratification of a new military and economic cooperation agreement with the United States. 'Worms in the Apple' **********''We are not happy with the U.S. relationship with Turkey,'' a senior official here said. ''There has been a lot of anti-American feeling in the press.'' **********That hostility, the official said, fell short of a fundamental questioning of Turkey's role in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization or of its commitment to ''the U.S. defense umbrella.'' **********''We are not talking about the apple,'' he said. ''We are talking about the worms in the apple.'' **********The grievances, the official said, lay in recent Congressional moves to limit aid to Turkey and to link it with other issues - notably Turkey's military presence in northern Cyprus - and in a perception in Ankara that the Reagan Administration had made little effort to curb the Congressional actions. **********Part of Turkey's frustration, a Western analyst said, stems from what it sees as its inability to override the influence of a Greek lobby in Congress. **********Mr. Evren, a former general who led the country's military takeover from 1980 to 1983, had been due in Washington on May 27. The President wields wide political power, although formal executive authority is vested in the Prime Minister, Turgut Ozal. **********The visit was postponed until August, ostensibly to permit Mr. Evren to deal with domestic political issues that have caused a furor here, prompting speculation about an early general election. **********Prime Minister Ozal is seeking constitutional changes in what his opponents view as an effort to solidify his power base, eliminate a threat from former political leaders now barred from holding office and so open the way for a general election before the scheduled date of November 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/17/busin.body_text: **********Congressional negotiators tentatively approved a sugar re-export program today for Caribbean countries and the Philippines that could soften the blow of sharply lower United States sugar import quotas next year. **********Under the program, Caribbean nations would be able to ship up to 290,000 tons and the Philippines up to 110,000 tons of raw sugar to the United States above the sugar quota in the 1988 fiscal year. **********The Reagan Administration announced Tuesday that the sugar import quota for 1988 would be reduced 25 percent below levels of a year ago, to its lowest level in a century. **********Quota levels for Caribbean countries and the Philippines were cut sharply, and trade officials have expressed concern that the cuts would hurt those nations' already ailing economies.
