https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/world.print_headline: Pakistan Chief Assails U.S. on Nuclear Stand
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/world.body_text: **********President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan today accused his American critics of double standards on the question of nuclear nonproliferation, and reiterated that Pakistan is opposed to the production or acquisition of nuclear arms. **********He called on Congress, where a $4 billion military and economic assistance program is now frozen, to consider the consequences to American interests in South Asia before cutting off aid to his country. **********A Congressional amendment would demand such action if the Reagan Administration fails to certify that Pakistan is not producing enriched uranium, a key component of nuclear explosives. **********''Whether it is South Africa, Brazil, Israel, India or Pakistan, treat them all on one scale,'' President Zia said, charging that the Congressional policy discriminated against Islamabad. **********President Zia made his remarks at a lunch with correspondents after a four-day visit to Thailand.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/15/world.main_headline: Pace of Change Upsets Traditions for Malays
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/15/world.print_headline: Pace of Change Upsets Traditions for Malays
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/15/world.body_text: **********When Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad seeks to justify an unprecedented recent wave of arrests without trial, the closing of newspapers and the banning of public gatherings, he warns of the danger of rising animosity between the Malay people who gave this country its name and the Chinese who have been living among them for generations. **********Many Malaysians, including those critical of the unexpected crackdown, do not disagree that forces of change are coming together in Malaysia in an unsettling way for its two largest ethnic groups. But some politicians and scholars say the dislocation is being felt most disturbingly by the Malays, a rural people thrust into development by a Government intent on changing their lives in a generation. Expectations Are Raised **********Urbanization, the introduction of high technology and nationwide affirmative action programs designed to give Malays a larger share in the domestic economy - dominated at independence in 1957 by foreigners and ethnic Chinese - may have raised expectations too quickly, critics of the Government say. **********An economic recession then struck, dashing the hopes of an affluent future for many young Malaysians - not only ethnic Malays. But Malays may have been most deeply affected. A constricted economy has accentuated communal differences. **********A resurgence of Islamic fundamentalism has followed, and scholars are searching for clues to whether this was coincidental or a byproduct of social confusion among people whose ethnicity and religion are inextricably intertwined. To boost Malays was to open the way to an Islamic revival, some Malaysians say. Malays still describe their society as based on the kampung, or village, with its traditional headman at the top of the political structure and its religious leader in the mosque. Ethnic Chinese Are Merchants **********The Chinese in Malaysia are largely, though not totally, urbanized. The Malays have been farmers; the Chinese, now about a third of Malaysia's people, are the merchants with worldly knowledge and wide contacts. **********At independence, ethnic Chinese accepted Malaysian demands for the dominance of the Malay language, for Malay political leadership and for the choice of Islam as the national religion. **********Malays, assuming the continuation of the existing Malay sultanates in a different form, were not expected to make similar concessions in the interest of building a unified nation. **********As Malaysia has moved into the contemporary world, the closed system of the kampung has been ripped open for many people, not only the young. **********The poet and scholar Muhammad Haji Salleh wrote more than a decade ago of his view from a housing development to the farm across the road: **********You look across the asphalt to the farmer, sun-darkened and old in a field sarong sitting out on the steps. **********The new houses are foreign as the pictures on his flour-wrappers. **********For many, being suddenly cut off from their roots was painful enough, as contemporary Malay short stories and poems demonstrate. Now, to add to their problems, jobs are not available for them when they return home from study abroad or after they earn their degrees here. Tens of thousands are out of work. It is easy to convince them that Chinese entrepreneurs dominate the economy to their detriment. **********Some Malays have also come to believe that they have been let down by their own political leaders, around whom financial scandals continually arise. **********Whatever the cause, the Malay can turn to the mosque as the base of his or her culture. **********''In the past, people going to Mecca on the annual pilgrimage were over 40; now you get younger people in their 20's and 30's,'' said Mohammed Taib Osman, professor of Malay studies at the University of Malaya.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.print_headline: MARKET PLACE; Bond Traders Alter Tactics
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.body_text: **********CONFRONTED with large potential losses in their bond portfolios, investment professionals are trying to deal with the recent sharp rise in long-term interest rates. **********With rates for 30-year Treasury bonds up nearly a full percentage point since the end of March -and prices down by as much as 10 percent - analysts at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. estimate that through the close of trading on Monday potential losses in the $1.02 trillion Treasury bond market amount to about $20 billion. Of that, between $6 billion and $7 billion has been lost on bonds with maturities in the range of 25 years to 30 years. **********In response to the selloff, which abruptly ended an extended period of calm in the bond markets, money managers have reacted by sharply reducing the average maturity of their portfolios, a tactic they hope will lessen price volatility, which usually is worst among long-term issues. **********Many money managers also said they had become more aggressive hedgers by investing in the options and futures markets. **********But in spite of recent losses, officials at banks, pension funds and mutual funds, who collectively manage hundreds of billions in taxable and tax-free bonds, were not in a panic. **********In large part, the calm they expressed reflected a strong belief that the recent rise in rates is temporary, and will soon reverse itself. Also, the losses sustained in recent weeks have come after a five-year period in which bonds posted enormous gains. **********''We have hedged our positions as best we can and shortened some maturities,'' said Roland M. Machold, director of the division of investment for the State of New Jersey. The division manages a bond portfolio that had a market value of about $21 billion last June. **********''But some of this we will just have to ride through,'' he said. ''Then we will be getting back into the market. The economy is basically still very weak, and over time that fact will generally reassert itself in the market.'' **********Not surprisingly, some small investors have reacted with more alarm than the professionals. **********Officials at some mutual funds said that the recent rise in rates - an increase that has caused the asset value of some of the largest Government bond funds to fall by as much as 7 percent since the end of March - has led some small investors to redeem their holdings. **********''We have had some redemptions, but not a lot,'' said George J. Collins, president and chief executive of T. Rowe Price Associates, which manages more than $10 billion in taxable bond funds. ''What we are seeing more of is a switch from bond funds into money market funds.''  * * * **********The drop in asset values at the bond funds has halted, for the moment, a period of extraordinary performance. **********''Bond funds have been the big winners over the last five years,'' said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Securities, which tracks developments in the mutual fund industry. **********From 1981 until the end of 1986, the 308 fixed-income funds tracked by Lipper Analytical posted a total return of 121.4 percent, meaning that capital gains and dividends were reinvested. Equity funds, by comparison, were up 116.2 percent. **********The fixed-income funds stumbled in the first quarter, rising slightly more than 3 percent, far below the 19.8 percent gain posted by equity funds. **********''It is no longer a one-way street'' in the bond market, Mr. Lipper said. **********Through a combination of luck and foresight, a number of money managers sensed that rates might bounce up, and made or saved lots of money by selling or shifting their portfolios early. **********''A number of portfolio managers seem to have shortened maturities going in to the collapse,'' said Paula Treneer, a senior vice president and director of fixed-income research at the Frank Russell Company, a leading pension fund consulting firm that monitors more than 300 institutional money managers on a monthly basis. **********''But several of the leading investment firms I have talked to this week view current yields as a buying opportunity,'' she said. **********One professional who decided to lighten up on bonds in advance of the selloff is Fred Zuckerman, treasurer of the Chrysler Corporation and manager of its $3.5 billion pension fund. **********Early last month, Chrysler startled some in the investment community when it sold half of its $1 billion dedicated bond portfolio and moved the money into stocks.  * * * **********''We were directionally correct, and I wish we could have sold them all,'' Mr. Zuckerman said in a recent telephone interview, ''But we still have some bonds, and those are tucked away. A lot of forces have driven rates up to what I think are intellectually unsupportable levels. Six months from now, I have to think that rates will be a lot lower.'' **********Nonetheless, Mr. Zuckerman said that within the next year he wants the pension fund's portfolio mix to be half bonds and half stocks. Right now, Chrysler's bond portfolio has an average maturity of about 17 years. **********''When the bond market gives us the opportunity, I would like to cut the average maturity in half,'' Mr. Zuckerman said. William R. Buecking, senior vice president and director of fixed-income investments at Kemper Financial Services, which has more than $30 billion in fixed-income securities under management, said that ''about a month ago we shortened the average maturity of our funds by about 2 years, to between 5 years and 12 years, and that saved us a lot of money.'' **********''We also went short bond futures or bought put options,'' he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/20/busin.body_text: **********Soviet Signs Read 'Slow' **********Will Mikhail Gorbachev's glasnost translate into many more Soviet-American business dealings? Not anytime soon, according to a recent political-risk study by consultants Frost & Sullivan. **********The reform policies of the Soviet leader - along with last week's Soviet-American pact to limit the risks of nuclear war and an imminent treaty eliminating some land-based missiles - may be signals that bode well for foreign business ventures in the Soviet Union. But progress will be slow, the study concluded. **********''No one knows how much of their own decisions Soviet enterprises can make,'' said Ronald H. Linden, Frost & Sullivan's senior adviser on the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. ''Can they use foreign suppliers? Where will they get hard currency? It's only recently they've been able to engage in foreign trade.'' **********On the American side, the business community is likely to proceed cautiously because of negative experiences, Mr. Linden said. ''There is a lot of reluctance in the American business community because it was fairly badly burned after the invasion of Afghanistan,'' when trade with the Soviet Union collapsed. **********He added, however, that some high-tech companies in the United States could find a market now in the technology-starved Soviet Union, even with goods considered outmoded here. With the loosening of trade restrictions, he said, ''there's a wonderful opportunity for manufacturers like I.B.M - they could have a great market for previous-generation personal computers.''  Job Seekers Stay Put **********Fewer people are moving to find new jobs these days: The percentage of job seekers who are relocating reached its lowest point in six years in the second quarter of this year, and is likely to drop further, says John Challenger of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a Chicago-based outplacement firm. **********About 32 percent of job seekers are relocating, Mr. Challenger said, down from a high of 45 percent for first-quarter 1986 and an average of about 40 percent for the past few years. **********The economy's extended recovery, he said, is one reason people are staying put. ''In bad times, when there are fewer positions available, people have to expand their searches geographically.'' **********But there are sociological reasons, too, Mr. Challenger said - the number of two-income couples, for example. ''It's hard to take a new job out of town when the other member of a couple has a good position,'' he said. And increasingly, ''people want to put down roots in their community, rather than move around the country from position to position in order to get promoted.''  Dockominiums **********With each year bringing the manufacture of more pleasure boats, some private marina owners are turning bigger profits on boat slips by converting their rental slips to long-term leases - or by selling the spaces as ''dockominiums.'' **********The dockominium trend is most popular along the East Coast: ''In 15 years, in some areas, you will find a minority of marinas offering slips on a rental basis,'' said Edward Dougherty, president of the Marina/Consult Corporation of Cataumet, Mass. **********Marina operators may have little choice but to go condo, Mr. Dougherty said. Though they sit on extremely valuable assets - all that waterfront property - many have paltry profits, just 2 percent on sales. They need the up-front income from dockominium sales to maintain their marinas. ''It's very difficult to finance modernization of a marina because it's hard to demonstrate the ability to pay back the loan,'' he said. **********Boat owners, initially hostile to slip prices of $20,000 and up plus annual maintenance fees, are now snapping up dockominiums at a surprising pace. When Colton Homes Inc. offered 117 slips on the New Jersey shore, it anticipated the spaces would take five years to sell out. Instead, Colton says, it has sold nearly 50 slips within four weeks at prices from $22,500 to $58,250. Next year, it expects to be sold out.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.main_headline: A Sri Lanka Run on Saffron Robes May Bode Ill
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.print_headline: A Sri Lanka Run on Saffron Robes May Bode Ill
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.body_text: **********In what could be a curious omen of more violence, the authorities here have reported a run on saffron robes, the traditional garb of Buddhist monks. **********In Sri Lanka, where the politically powerful priesthood has been at the forefront of much of the recent violence, the robe, traditionally an emblem of tolerance and peace, has become a signal of militancy. **********With senior priests haranguing angry crowds and younger monks sometimes attacking police lines and throwing stones, secular agitators have also been reported to be donning saffron, the better to arouse emotions at demonstrations. **********Senior monks deny that they support violence, but also say it may be inevitable as they carry out what they see as their role as protectors of an embattled Sinhalese race. Centuries-Old Feuds **********Although the mostly Buddhist Sinhalese are a majority in this nation of 16.5 million, they see themselves in larger terms as a minority under pressure from the Hindu Tamil ethnic group and even from the smaller Moslem population. **********This sense of threat from the island's minorities is at the heart of the tensions that have led to centuries-old communal feuds that have produced sustained violence in the last four years. **********In their fight for a separate state, Tamil guerillas have received support from the much larger Tamil population outside Sri Lanka, including 50 million in southern India. **********A Sinhalese political scientist, speaking of what he called ''the 1,000-year war,'' said: ''They are on the offensive. We are on the defensive.'' 'A Nation Under Siege' **********''They will drive us into the sea, and we have no place to go,'' he said. ''The Tamils can join their brothers in south India. The Moslems can go to the Arab world. The Sinhalese have no place to go. We are a nation under seige.'' **********From Sri Lanka's earliest days, the protectors in this seige have been the monks, guardians of a culture whose roots are intertwined with the history of Buddhism itself. **********It is said that when Buddha was dying, he saw his teachings under threat from Hinduism and looked south to the little island now called Sri Lanka as Buddhism's sanctuary. **********As the Government takes steps to work out a compromise with the 15 percent Tamil Hindu minority, seen historically as encroaching from the north, the Buddhist clergy is fighting back. **********''The monks are angry,'' said the Rev. B. Wimalaratana, a senior Buddhist priest and a lecturer at Sri Jayawardhanapura University. **********''It has been traditional in the past for the rulers to consult the Buddhist clergy, and to listen to them,'' he added. ''But now there are many occasions when the elderly monks had discussions with the President but he doesn't care.'' **********A Sinhalese Buddhist scholar who disagrees with that view said, ''The monks don't think that violence in defense of the Sinhalese race is anything bad.'' **********Neelan Tiruchelvam, a moderate Tamil leader, said, ''The basic virtues of compassion, tolerance and nonviolence have been subordinated to the historic role the Sri Lankan Buddhists feel they have to protect the Sinhalese race.'' 'We All Are Human' **********Mr. Wimalaratana said: ''Thousands of people are coming to the temples to ask the monks, 'Why are you waiting? Why don't you take action?' '' **********''Violence is not the proper way,'' he said. ''But you see we all are human. We are not enlightened beings, and we may make mistakes because of our emotional feelings.'' **********He blamed hot-blooded younger monks for the violence, saying, ''They are teen-agers, and it is difficult to control their emotions.'' **********A demonstration last month by several hundred monks touched off the most recent wave of violence on the day before Sri Lanka and India signed an accord creating an autonomous Tamil province in northern Sri Lanka. **********In the burning early-morning sun, monks with their furled black umbrellas sat cross-legged under a sacred bo tree, a symbol of the place in India where Buddha attained enlightenment 2,500 years ago. **********Squatting on the ground around them were thousands of supporters, some carrying sticks and satchels filled with stones. **********''This is when it gets dangerous, when the men in orange get involved,'' said a Tamil chief inspector of police, standing uneasily nearby. **********One after another, senior priests shouted through a megaphone, in carefully-chosen words that avoided incitement to violence but called on their listeners to ''come forward to safeguard the independence and sovereignty of the motherland.'' 'Hour for Priests to Act' **********''This is the hour for the priests to act,''said the Rev. Maduluwawe Sobhita, a senior monk. ''We must be prepared to sacrifice our lives.'' Mr. Sobhita is now in hiding from the police, who arrested more than two dozen priests after the day's violence. More than 60 people were killed, most of them apparently shot by the police. **********One of the younger monks clustering close to the speakers said, ''If we are not militant, and if the country is not protected, then there will be no more Buddhism.'' **********S. P. Senaratne, a layman who helped organize the demonstration, said of the young monks, ''It has come to a point where they are uncontrollable.'' **********Asked if he favored violence, the young monk, a member of the militant Inter-University Federation of Students, said: ''Why not? We are being provoked. We are being shot. We cannot stand any more.'' **********At that moment, without warning, a small tear-gas canister arched its way into the crowd, leaving a fragile contrail under the leaves of the bo tree. **********More tear gas followed, and although most of the monks broke and ran, some charged toward the police line, shielding their faces from the gas with their saffron robes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/world.main_headline: Syrian Armored Force Is Reported Outside Beirut
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/world.print_headline: Syrian Armored Force Is Reported Outside Beirut
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/world.body_text: **********About 4,000 Syrian troops dismantled their camp near Beirut today and, according to unconfirmed radio reports, scouts from the force were in a suburb of the capital. **********The reports of movement were seen here as indications that Syria might be moving in to quell a week of fighting among Moslem factions in West Beirut. **********Moslem leaders in the Lebanese Government and chieftains of the feuding militias had requested such intervention during a meeting Friday with Syrian officials. **********Early today, a report by a Lebanese source in Damascus that the Syrian forces ''are already rolling'' was misinterpreted to mean that their troops and tanks had begun moving into West Beirut, the Moslem sector of the capital. It became clear later that they remained encamped outside the capital and had not moved in. Warning From Gemayel **********President Amin Gemayel, a Maronite Catholic whose influence does not extend to Lebanon's Moslem-held areas, said today that any move by Syrian troops to intervene in the fighting would be unconstitutional. **********At least 200 people have been killed and 400 wounded since the latest battle for control of West Beirut began Feb. 15. In the fighting, the militia of Amal, the mainstream Shiite Moslem movement, is pitted against an alliance of Druse militiamen and Lebanese Communists. **********Sources said the Syrian force poised outside Beirut consisted of an armored brigade of 4,000 troops with 100 Soviet-made T-62 tanks and 200 armored personnel carriers, backed by an elite special-forces battalion and a mechanized infantry battalion. **********The force camped three days ago in the central mountain resort of Sofar, about 15 miles east of Beirut, said a Lebanese Army official who said the force would move toward West Beirut ''once its deployment plan is finalized.'' **********''Today, they dismantled their tents,'' he said. ''That was the only indication they might move soon.'' It would take the Syrians at least four hours to reach West Beirut from Sofar. **********The state-run Beirut radio and the Moslem-controlled Voice of the Nation said a Syrian scouting patrol arrived in the southern Beirut suburb of Khalde shortly after nightfall. The Beirut police said they could not confirm the report. **********Local reporters said the Syrians had deployed hundreds of Soviet-made halftracks on both sides of a 28-mile highway connecting the town of Masnaa on the Syrian border with the mountain range in central Lebanon. ''The vehicles are guarding the supply route for the Syrian intervention force,'' said a Syrian Army officer who asked not to be identified. **********One reporter counted at least 75 Syrian trucks loaded with arms and ammunition driving to Sofar from Shtaura, 10 miles to the east. **********In West Beirut, the Lebanese Army set up buffer zones to separate warring factions in the Tarik Jedideh, Cola and Abu Shaker districts and near the Arab University. The Lebanese were aided by about 500 Syrian troops who have been in the capital since last year. **********The police said there was some sniping, and heavy exchanges of rocket-propelled grenades and machine-gun fire were reported in a Druse district. **********In Damascus on Friday, five Lebanese leaders signed a nine-point agreement to ''help impose security and stability'' in West Beirut, which has been ruled by Shiite and leftist militias since February 1984. **********The accord calls for dissolving and disarming militias and forming a security force to guard Government offices, embassies, the port, the airport and the highways linking West Beirut with eastern and southern Lebanon. **********The document was signed by the Amal leader, Nabih Berri; the Druse leader, Walid Jumblat; Prime Minister Rashid Karami and Education Minister Salim Hoss, both Sunni Moslems, and House Speaker Hussein Husseini, a Shiite. **********Syria, the main power broker in Lebanon, supports all of the feuding militias. It maintains about 25,000 soldiers in eastern and northern Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League mandate to keep the peace.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/05/world.main_headline: Election Panel Officials in Haiti Flee New Violence in the Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/05/world.print_headline: Election Panel Officials in Haiti Flee New Violence in the Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/05/world.body_text: **********Several members of the Haitian electoral commission were in hiding today after a second night of arson attacks against election officials. **********A 75-year-old election official whose home was a target bitterly accused the army-dominated provisional Government of complicity in the violence. **********Addressing Haitians and the ''international community,'' on capital radio stations, the official, Emmanuel Amboise, charged that ''assassins and arsonists,'' were running Haiti. He made a desperate appeal for protection. **********Two days after arsonists heavily damaged local election headquarters and gunmen sprayed machine-gun fire at a district voting office and the office and home of two candidates, the Government still had not assigned security forces to protect election officials and offices. **********Several election officials expressed serious doubts today that the presidential elections could be held as scheduled on Nov. 29. 'Total Insecurity' **********''We are in the midst of total insecurity,'' said Alain Rocourt, the head of the Methodist Church in Haiti and treasurer of the nine-member Electoral Council. **********The national election headquarters was set afire Monday, hours after the Electoral Council had rejected the presidential candidacies of a dozen associates of the former dictators of Haiti, Francois Duvalier and his son, Jean-Claude, who fled to France 21 months ago. Haiti's new constitution bars key officials of the family dictatorship from elections for 10 years. **********In another attack on Monday, arsonists also destroyed a hardware store owned by Mr. Amboise. On Tuesday night, they unsuccessfully tried to set fire to Mr. Amboise's home and the family car. **********After ignoring two earlier written requests for protection from the Electoral Council, the Government said in a statement last night that it had instructed the ''appropriate authorities'' to ''determine the necessary security measures'' to be taken ''to guarantee the progression of the electoral process.'' **********By midday, Mr. Rocourt said the Government had done ''nothing at all'' to provide security for any council members or the council's offices. Mr. Rocourt said a high-ranking Government official suggested that the council hire a private guard to protect the charred equipment and files in the headquarters. **********According to witnesses, Mr. Rocourt said, a half-dozen men with submachine-guns blocked the intersections at both ends of the street on which the headquarters is located by firing bursts into the air shortly before midnight Monday. Then, he said, men with chisels and metal cutters chopped through the steel doors of the offices and started the fire.  U.S. Condemns Violence **********WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -The United States today condemned the recent attacks in Haiti. **********''We deplore these actions aimed at derailing Haiti's elections and transition to democracy,'' said the State Department spokesman, Charles E. Redman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/25/busin.body_text: **********Glenfed Inc. said yesterday that Norman M. Coulson, the president and vice chairman of the nation's fifth-largest thrift institution, would add the duties of chief executive officer, effective July 1, completing a planned succession begun in 1985. Mr. Coulson, 54 years old, succeeds Raymond D. Edwards, who will retain the post of chairman at Glenfed. The holding company is the parent of Glendale Federal Savings and Loan Association, based in Glendale, Calif. Mr. Edwards, 68, will no longer participate in day-to-day operations, Mr. Coulson said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/13/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS; DOLLAR FALLS 1% FURTHER VS. MARK
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/13/busin.body_text: **********The dollar fell to a new six-year low against the West German mark in heavy trading on world currency markets yesterday, one day after European finance ministers acted to relieve tensions within the European Monetary System. **********The move to revalue the mark upward by 3 percent relative to a number of other currencies within the E.M.S., mainly the French franc, shifted the market's focus back to the dollar. Traders still regard the dollar as too expensive in comparison with such currencies as the mark and the Japanese yen. **********''The mood of this market has been that at some point the dollar had to be taken lower,'' said one foreign-exchange trader at a major New York bank. ''The only question was when.'' Comparison of Figures **********By the end of trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.8960 marks, down a bit more than 1 percent for the day. The yen, meanwhile, rose only slightly against the dollar, to 157.35 yen late in the day. **********A lower dollar should help to ease this country's foreign trade deficit by making imports more expensive to Americans and exports cheaper to foreigners. One negative effect could be a higher inflation rate resulting from costlier imports. **********Aside from preferring marks to dollars because of America's trade problems and less than robust economic forecasts, another source of strength for the mark yesterday was the weekend's E.M.S. agreement. Temporary Move Seen **********Many people in the foreign-exchange community, viewing the realignment as only a stop-gap measure, said further steps would be necessary after Germany's parliamentary elections are held Jan. 25. **********''The revaluation was a half-measure,'' said Richard E. Witten, vice president in the foreign-exchange department of Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''We had been anticipating something on the order of 5 percent.'' **********Failure to revalue the mark by more against other currencies within the E.M.S. creates a likelihood for additional strains within the system soon, Mr. Witten said. **********''It's almost a self-fulfilling prophecy,'' he said. ''To the extent the dollar weakens against the mark, the mark strengthens against the franc. The move may buy the Germans some time, but right now it doesn't appear that it will be very much time.'' Economic Factors Noted **********Behind the dollar's fall are some matters of fundamental concern to currency traders. These include the stubborn trade problems of the United States, its muted prospects for economic growth and its relatively low interest rates. **********These factors, along with modest intervention by some nations' central banks, were instrumental in yesterday's selloff. **********''Early in the day it became clear that the Bundesbank was not going to intervene,'' Mr. Witten said. ''That gave the futures and interbank markets license to do what they wanted to do: sell dollars.'' **********As a way of shoring up the dollar and protecting the value of their own currencies, West Germany's Bundesbank and the Bank of Japan had bought dollars heavily last week. Estimates of Activity **********Currency traders said yesterday that the Bundesbank was rumored to have bought small amounts of dollars in European trading. They said the Bank of Japan might have bought about $200 million through the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Such actions would temper the dollar's decline but not prevent it. **********Some forecasters are predicting much lower levels for the dollar during 1987. **********''We are looking for another pretty healthy decline in the dollar this year,'' said Jonathan Francis, managing director of the world economics group at Wharton Econometrics, an economic forecasting firm. **********By the end of this year, he said, the dollar should be 14.5 percent lower against the yen than it was at the end of 1986 and might fall 14 percent more against the mark. Various Choices Loom **********West German officials are not likely to take any additional monetary steps before their nation's elections, but several policy options are available to prevent the mark from rising further. **********The most widely discussed possibility is a cut in Germany's discount rate, a move the Bundesbank has been reluctant to take because of a rapidly expanding money supply and an abiding fear of inflation. **********Such a move by Bonn would win favor in Washington. However, a number of international economists say it is unlikely. **********''It would make sense for them to do it, but I don't think it will happen, even after the elections,'' said Charles Taylor, vice president for international economics at Prudential-Bache Securities. **********GOLD PRICES CLIMB

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/06/world.main_headline: BONN CASE TESTS ARMS EXPORT LAWS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/06/world.print_headline: BONN CASE TESTS ARMS EXPORT LAWS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/06/world.body_text: **********The West German Government said today that it rejected a request last year by a West German aerospace company that it sell $1 billion worth of transport aircraft to Iran. **********In a newspaper interview over the weekend, Sepp Hort, the deputy chief executive of the company, Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm, said the proposed sale was the subject of negotiations with the Iranian Government for 18 months. **********Mr. Hort, in the interview with the newspaper Bild am Sonntag, said the company ''was encouraged'' by the Bonn Government ''to go to Teheran.'' **********A spokesman for the Economics Ministry, Volker Franzen, said Messerschmitt officials inquired ''at a low level'' about the possibility of delivering the aircraft - twelve Transall C-160 military transports - but were told the deal would not be approved at least until the end of the Iran-Iraq war, now in its seventh year. The aircraft are built by a consortium of Messerschmitt and Aerospatiale, a French company. Debate Over Arms Exports **********The disclosure, against the backdrop of a recent effort by Bonn to widen political and trade ties with Teheran, has drawn unusual attention here because of recent reports of covert United States arms sales to Teheran. **********But it has also focused sharp attention on a widening debate over Bonn's arms export policy. That debate has played little role in the campaign for national elections Jan. 25, but commentators expect that a review of that legislation will be high on a new government's agenda. **********That debate was fueled recently by the disclosure that officials of a Government-owned north German shipyard had delivered blueprints for a diesel-powered submarine to South Africa. The action violated German arms export laws and contravened a 1977 United Nations arms embargo against the Pretoria Government. **********Later this week, a parliamentary committee will begin investigating the submarine deal, by the Kiel-based Howaldtswerke-Deutsche Werft. Committee members are considering calling Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Defense Minister Manfred Worner to testify. Restrictions in Force **********West Germany allows arms sales to its NATO partners, but limits them outside NATO and all but bans them to developing countries, to governments it considers oppressive and to potential war zones. **********Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has been among the staunchest proponents of maintaining rigid limits, but strong pressure has come from political and arms-industry officials who believe increased weapons shipments can be used to halt a decline in the trade surplus. **********The major player in the latter group, and the apparent initiator of the blueprint sale to South Africa, is Franz Josef Strauss, the conservative Premier of Bavaria. **********Mr. Strauss's state, a center of the West German arms industry, is home to major military contractors like Messerschmitt and the Siemens electronics company. The Premier is a Messerschmitt board member. He has also been the major supporter of arms sales to Saudi Arabia, which have been opposed by the Government out of concern for their effect on German-Israeli relations. Israel has staunchly opposed such sales. Interpreting 'a Positive Reply' **********In a newspaper interview last month, Mr. Strauss said that, at the request of the South African Ambassador in Bonn, he sought and obtained ''a positive reply'' from Mr. Kohl for the delivery of the blueprints to Pretoria. **********But Wolfgang Schauble, Mr. Kohl's chief of staff, said a positive reply meant simply ''that we would have to take a look at it and examine it.'' **********Critics of the deal say even that much goes beyond the letter of the arms export law. **********German Government officials have sought to play down the significance of the Transall negotiations with Teheran, but an Iranian arms dealer, Mohammed Hashemi, in an interview last week with ABC News, said he was assured a $48 million commission for delivery of the planes, after a delegation of Messerschmitt officials visited Teheran last year to discuss delivery of the aircraft over a two-year period. **********Bonn is a traditionally strong trading partner of Iran, and has sought in recent months to widen its trade relations, to build bridges for a possible improvement of political ties after hostilities between Iran and Iraq cease. **********In September, a delegation of Iranian officials, including the Minister for Heavy Industry, Behzad Nabavi, visited Bonn and toured German companies. **********But Government officials emphasized that improved trade ties would have to exclude the military sector.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/15/busin.body_text: **********Greyhound Lines Inc. signed final contracts to buy $80 million in assets from financially troubled Trailways Lines Inc. Greyhound agreed in the cash transaction to buy Trailways buses, terminals and garages, and operate some Trailways routes. Some workers will be laid off, said Fred Currey, Greyhound's president and chairman. The Trailways name will be retained, especially in areas where Trailways is the only bus service, he said. The transaction must be approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/world.main_headline: An Iran Affair Is Emerging in France
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/world.print_headline: An Iran Affair Is Emerging in France
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/world.body_text: **********In an affair that echoes the furor over the Reagan Administration's secret arms sales to Iran, French Defense Ministry officials have charged that a Defense Minister in the former Socialist Government approved sales of 450,000 artillery shells to Iran in violation of French law. **********The accusations, carried in articles this week in two French news weeklies, also charge that the Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, was told about the sales and that some of the money was diverted to the Socialist campaign treasury. **********The articles say about $120 million worth of arms were shipped in violation of a French embargo. Socialists Deny Accusations **********Socialist Party officials have called the charges without foundation and have accused the current conservative Government of disclosing details of a confidential army report to smear the Socialists before the presidential elections in April. **********''Do I look like someone who would sell weapons to Iran?'' said Charles Hernu, the former Socialist Defense Minister named in the reports. ''These scandals are going to be numerous before the presidential elections.'' **********Lionel Jospin, the Socialist Party's first secretary, said today that he ''denied totally these accusations, these fabrications and what is even necessary to call calumnies.'' **********The arms sales to Iran, which took place from 1983 to 1986, came to light in February 1986. The sales were disclosed by La Presse de la Manche, a small newspaper based in Cherbourg, western France. It reported that in 1985 two ships registered in the Bahamas carried more than 140,000 shells supposedly destined for Portugal, Brazil, Thailand and Pakistan. Instead, the 155- and 203-millimeter shells were shipped to the Iranian port of Bandar Abbas. **********Socialist officials were not linked to the sales at the time. The Socialist Defense Minister who succeeded Mr. Hernu, Paul Quiles, began an investigation that has focused on Luchaire, an arms maker that said it needed the sales to stay in business. Secret Army Report Is Disclosed **********Little more was heard until two magazines, L'Express and Le Point, ran articles this week about the contents of a secret report by the French Army's comptroller general, Jean-Francois Barba. **********The magazines reported that Daniel Dewavrin, Luchaire's president, told investigators that the Defense Ministry, including two generals, helped keep the sales secret. **********Pierre Joxe, leaders of the Socialists in the National Assembly, said today that he wants to question the Defense Minister, Andre Giraud, on Wednesday to determine how the allegations surfaced. **********An investigating magistrate, Michel Legrand, is expected to ask Mr. Giraud to declassify the report. Report Outlines Diversions **********According to the Le Point article, the army report says that 3 to 5 percent of the sales revenue went directly to the Socialist Party. The magazine added that the funds were diverted through intermediaries, private bank accounts, and foreign companies and could have totaled $7 million. **********The articles in L'Express and Le Point also said that Admiral Pierre Lacoste, former head of France's intelligence service, reported the sales to President Mitterrand and Jean-Francois Dubos, a technical counselor to former Defense Minister Hernu. **********According to newspaper report today in Beirut, the sales of the artillery shells were tied to talks with Iran on Teheran helping help win the release of French hostages in Beirut. **********The newspaper, As Safir, a leftist publication in Beirut that disclosed the American arms sales to Iran, also said the talks fell through at the last minute because the negotiations were disclosed or because France was unable to make a decision. **********Supporters of the Iranian revolution are believed to be holding five Frenchmen seized in Lebanon and to have executed a sixth. **********France severed diplomatic ties with Iran last July after an official in the Iranian Embassy here refused to appear before a French judge to answer questions about terrorist attacks in Paris.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/07/busin.main_headline: Argentina Gets Waiver For Emergency Loan
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/07/busin.print_headline: Argentina Gets Waiver For Emergency Loan
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/07/busin.body_text: **********Argentina yesterday was granted a a waiver from meeting economic performance targets set by the International Monetary Fund, Treasury and international monetary officials said. , The waiver would allow Argentina to receive a $500 million emergency loan from governments around the world. The loan had been contingent upon continued compliance with the I.M.F. targets on inflation, interest rates, government spending and currency exchange rates. Argentina had met virtually none of those goals but has adopted new policies intended to bring it into compliance. **********The waiver should go far toward quelling rumors that have swept the financial markets in recent days that Argentina was preparing to suspend interest payments on its foreign debt. The nation owes more than $8 billion to United States banks alone. 'No Interest Moratorium' **********''There will be no interest moratorium,'' one international banker said. **********The waiver for Argentina and a debt accord between a bankers' committee and Brazil ''are positive developments of key importance for world financial markets,'' David C. Mulford, the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for international affairs, said yesterday. **********For some time, bankers had held special hopes for Argentina. It was the first country to arrange new financial assistance after the decision last spring by the world's major banks to set aside reserves for loan losses equal to 30 percent of their third world loans. Bankers have hoped that disbursement of the new money will go smoothly, and the waiver means that it should. **********Meanwhile, a plan by Brazil and its leading creditor banks to pile new loans on top of old will face stiff opposition as they seek approval of the plan from banks around the world, banking analysts said. Terms of Brazil Plan **********The plan calls for Brazil to contribute $1.5 billion from its foreign-exchange reserves - and for commercial banks to contribute $3 billion -into a short-term loan fund for the country. The money will be used to pay off $4.5 billion in past-due interest that has been accruing since Brazil decided last February to suspend interest payments on most of its $100 billion debt. **********The plan also provides for the banks' contribution to be replaced quickly with longer-term bank financing, so it amounts to the banks' providing new loans to pay the interest on old loans. **********It is this aspect of the plan - formally known as interest capitalization - that has the investment community distressed. They consider the Brazilian package little different from the established pattern in debt talks on making new loans that are recycled as interest. 'This Is Not Prudent' **********''If you talk to any banker, he'll tell you that you shouldn't be lending interest to a delinquent borrower,'' said George M. Salem, the senior banking analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ''This is not prudent banking practices, and I don't think other banks will like it.'' **********But bankers involved in the talks defended the plan. **********''This preliminary understanding is the first step on the road back to creditworthiness for Brazil,'' said William R. Rhodes, chairman of Brazil's 14-member bank advisory committee. He declined to comment further, but international-banking sources said the plan had a number of positive elements from the banks' perspective. **********For example, they noted that at the meeting of the I.M.F. in Washington in September, the Brazilians told the bankers they would contribute nothing toward payment of the $4.5 billion of overdue interest. Under the plan announced yesterday, they will pay $1.5 billion. Payments May Start This Month **********Additionally, the bankers noted, because of the mechanics of the plan, the banks will receive a $500 million cash payment as early as later this month. Most importantly, Brazil has told its bankers that it hopes to use money from the I.M.F., the World Bank and governmental creditors to resume paying interest in full, starting Jan. 1. **********''All of those are major steps,'' said one banker who participated in the talks. **********Debt experts had feared that the stalemate between Brazil and its bankers might continue into 1988. What brought the two sides together was a threat that banking regulators in the United States might force the banks to write down the value of their Brazilian debt. **********Asked if the regulators had forced a deal, one banker said, ''It's a fair statement.'' He added that, in recent days, top bankers had been in touch on the matter with Michael Bradfield, the Federal Reserve's general counsel; Edwin M. Truman, director of the division of international affairs at the Fed, and Mr. Mulford of the Treasury.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/09/world.main_headline: Excerpts From Protocol: How the Missiles Will Be Eliminated
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/09/world.print_headline: THE SUMMIT; Excerpts From Protocol: How the Missiles Will Be Eliminated
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/09/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from a protocol to the arms treaty signed today, governing the elimination of missile systems:  Items of Missile Systems Subject to Elimination **********The specific items for each type of missile system to be eliminated are: **********For the United States of America: **********Pershing II: missile, launcher and launch pad shelter; **********BGM-109G: missile, launch canister and launcher; **********Pershing IA: missile and launcher; and **********Pershing IB: missile. **********For the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics: **********SS-20: missile, launch canister, launcher, missile transporter vehicle and fixed structure for a launcher; **********SS-4: missile, missile transporter vehicle, missile erector, launch stand and propellant tanks; **********SS-5: missile; **********SSC-X-4: missile, launch canister and launcher; **********SS-12: missile, launcher and missile transporter vehicle; and **********SS-23: missile, launcher and missile transporter vehicle.  Procedures for Elimination At Elimination Facilities **********Prior to a missile's arrival at the elimination facility, its nuclear warhead device and guidance elements may be removed. **********Each Party shall select the particular technological means necessary to implement the procedures required in paragraphs 10 and 11 of this Section and to allow for on-site inspection of the conduct of the elimination procedures required in paragraph 10 of this Section in accordance with Article XI of the Treaty, this Protocol and the Protocol on Inspection.  For the Pershing II: Missile: **********Missile stages shall be eliminated by explosive demolition or burning; **********Solid fuel, rocket nozzles and motor cases not destroyed in this process shall be burned, crushed, flattened or destroyed by explosion; and **********Front section, minus nuclear warhead device and guidance elements, shall be crushed or flattened.  Launcher: **********Erector-launcer mechanism shall be removed from launcher chassis; **********All components of erector-launcher mechanism shall be cut at locations that are not assembly joints into two pieces of approximately equal size; **********Missile launch support equipment, including external instrumentation compartments, shall be removed from launcher chassis; and **********Launcher chassis shall be cut at a location that is not an assembly joint into two pieces of approximately equal size.  For the SS-20: Missile: **********Missile shall be eliminated by explosive demolition of the missile in its launch canister or by burning missile stages; **********Solid fuel, rocket nozzles and motor cases not destroyed on this process shall be burned, crushed, flattened or destroyed by explosion; and **********Front section, including reentry vehicles, minus nuclear warhead devices, and instrumentation compartment, minus guidance elements, shall be crushed or flattened.  Launch Canister: **********launch canister shall be destroyed by explosive demolition together with a missile, or shall be destroyed separately by explosion, cut into two pieces of approximately equal size, crushed or flattened.  Launcher: **********Erector-launcher mechanism shall be removed form launcher chassis; **********All components of erector-launcher mechanism shall be cut at locations that are not assembly joints into two pieces of approximately equal size; **********Missile launch support equipment, including external instrumentation compartments, shall be removed from launcher chassis; **********Mountings of erector-launcher mechanism and launcher leveling supports shall be cut off launcher chassis.  Elimination of Missiles By Means of Launching **********Elimination of missiles by means of launching pursuant to paragraph 5 of Article X of the Treaty shall be subject to on-site inspection in accordance with paragraph 7 of Article XI of the Treaty and the Protocol on Inspection. Immediately prior to each launch conducted for the purpose of elimination, an inspector from the inspecting Party shall confirm by visual observation the type of missile to be launched. **********All missiles being eliminated by means of launching shall be launched from designated elimination facilities to existing impact areas for such missiles. No such missile shall be used as a target vehicle for a ballistic missile interceptor. **********Missiles being eliminated byt means of launching shall be launched one at a time, and no less than six hours shall elapse between such launches. **********Such launches shall involve ignition of all missile stages. Neither Party shall transmit or recover data from missiles being eliminated by means of launching except for unencrypted data used for range safety purposes.  Procedures For Elimination in Situ Support Structures: **********The specific elimination procedures for support structures shall be as follows: **********The superstructure of the fixed structure or shelter shall be dismantled or demolished, and removed from its base or foundation; **********The base or foundation of the fixed structure or shelter shall be destroyed by excavation or explosion; **********The destroyed base or foundation of a fixed structure or shelter shall remain visible to national technical means of verification for six months or until completion of an on-site inspection conducted in accordance with Article XI of the Treaty; and  Other Types of Elimination Loss or Accidental Destruction **********If an item listed in Section I of this Protocol is lost or destroyed as a result of an accident, the possessing Party shall notify the other Party within 48 hours, as required in paragraph 5(e) of Article IX of the Treaty, that the item has been eliminated. **********Such notification shall include the type of the eliminated item, its approximate or assumed location and the circumstances related to the loss or accidental destruction. **********In such a case, the other Party shall have the right to conduct an inspection of the specific point at which the accident occurred to provide confidence that the item has been eliminated.  Static Display **********The parties shall have the right to eliminate missiles, launch canisters and launchers, as well as training missiles, training launch canisters and training launchers, listed in Section I of this Protocol by placing them on static display. Each Party shall be limited to a total of 15 missiles, 15 launch canisters and 15 launchers on such static display. **********Prior to being placed on static display, a missile, launch canister or launcher shall be rendered unusable for purposes inconsistent with the Treaty. Missile propellant shall be removed and erector-launcher mechanisms shall be rendered inoperative. **********The Party possessing a missile, launch canister or launcher, as well as a training missile, training launch canister or training launcher that is to be eliminated by placing it on static display shall provide the other Party with the place-name and coordinates of the location at which such a missile, launch canister or launcher is to be on static display, as well as the location at which the on-site inspection of such a missile, launch canister or launcher within 60 days of receipt of the notification required in paragraph 2(c) of this Section.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/26/world.main_headline: AMERICANS IN CUBA ACCUSED OF SPYING
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/26/world.print_headline: AMERICANS IN CUBA ACCUSED OF SPYING
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/26/world.body_text: **********With relations with the United States at one of the lowest points in years, the Cuban Government is charging in an extensive television and newspaper campaign that many American diplomats here have been spying and plotting to assassinate President Fidel Castro. **********In a confidential diplomatic note that was made public by the Cubans, the United States said it ''energetically protests these latest acts of harassment'' and it specifically denied any plans to harm Mr. Castro. **********Cuba has given no conclusive evidence of spying by Americans or of attempts to kill Mr. Castro. But as part of its campaign, it has accused 151 American diplomats of various kinds of spying here over the last 10 years, and it published the names and full-face photographs of many of them, nearly filling two pages of a newspaper. **********The United States said in its note that the campaign had endangered the Americans' lives and obstructed their ''legitimate diplomatic activities.'' **********American officials here have been unwilling to discuss the espionage charges beyond what is said in the diplomatic note, which they acknowledge is authentic. **********Despite the bitter war of words being waged by the two nations, there was no indication that either intended to break the limited diplomatic ties re-established on Sept. 1, 1977, after 16 years without any such links. **********Cuba said it had no intention of expelling any of the Americans accused of spying, three of whom are still here. **********Western diplomats said this underlined the value that each nation places on the outpost it maintains in the other's capital. The United States considers its mission especially useful here because the Cuban Government controls all radio and television stations and publications, and no American news organizations are permitted to base correspondents here. **********Moreover, no sense of anti-Americanism is apparent in the streets of Havana as a result of the campaign. **********Western diplomats say they believe the campaign, begun July 6, was created to counter the embarrassment of the defection in May of a Cuban Air Force brigadier general, Rafael del Pino, a hero of the Bay of Pigs invasion and a veteran of Cuba's campaign in Angola. **********Mr. del Pino has been criticizing Mr. Castro and the Cuban political system in interviews on Radio Marti, the United States broadcast service beamed to Cuba. **********Many Cubans say they have found the general's defection and his charges shocking, but credible, and some say they believe the events may have led to the drive against the Americans. **********The United States charged in its strikingly blunt diplomatic note that ''all officials and employees'' of the Cuban diplomatic mission in Washington, ''without exception'' were members of the Cuban Intelligence Service, and it requested about a week ago that two of the 20 Cuban diplomats posted there be withdrawn. They were to leave Washington today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/26/busin.main_headline: Careers; A Variety Of Jobs In Credit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/26/busin.print_headline: Careers; A Variety Of Jobs In Credit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/26/busin.body_text: **********THE financially troubled Pan American World Airways recently made an agreement with New York's Citibank to borrow $75 million, and the bank said it would try to raise $75 million more. As collateral for the loan, the airline will put up some of its equipment and parts, such as engines, rather than its already-mortgaged planes. **********Innovative credit arrangements such as this have become quite usual these days, making the credit area all the more interesting for job seekers. **********There are good career opportunities in this field, according to John J. Morrison. He is assistant treasurer of Pfizer Inc. and has just taken on the additional job of treasurer of international operations for the company. **********Mr. Morrison is also the author of a study on the growing interest in a system called the ''electronic business data interchange,'' which connects companies, their suppliers and their banks in the electronic handling of purchase orders, billing and payments. For example, when the General Motors Corporation wants supplies, it can order electronically from suppliers hitched to this system, and it can make payments electronically. **********Mr. Morrison calls it the way of the future, adding that the system is not in general use yet except by G.M. and a few other large corporations. **********Recently, the Credit Research Foundation, which handles continuing education for credit managers, announced two new one-week summer courses at $2,500 each. One of them, called Treasury Operations and Profit Strategy, educates financial executives about new financing techniques. The other, Planning for Resource Optimization, stresses the management of working capital. **********Credit is so big a business that no one knows exactly how many people do this kind of work in America's more than four million companies. The National Association of Credit Management has 43,000 member firms, some of them holding more than one membership. **********George N. Christie, executive vice president of the Credit Research Foundation, said the number of credit managers and their assistants runs into the ''tens of thousands.'' **********Is education after college necessary for credit personnel? Mr. Christie thinks it is. **********In an interview last week, he said: ''The way a company uses its financial resources has a direct bearing on profitability. It is not enough to rely on inventory control and marketing. No sale is complete until the money is collected, and that is the first obligation of a credit department.'' **********He described a wide range of salaries that beginners might receive, starting with $14,000 for bookkeeper-typists who do not need college degrees but handle some credit tasks; $20,000 or so for a holder of a bachelor of arts degree who took courses in financial subjects, and more than $30,000 for a person with a master of business administration degree whose academic background is in finance and accounting. Department heads and treasurers of major corporations command salaries in six figures. **********Career progress for someone in this field might begin at the credit trainee level and move through such positions as credit analyst, senior credit analyst, credit supervisor, credit manager and director of credit. Above this would be such levels as assistant treasurer or assistant vice president, since credit often comes under the responsibility of either the treasurer or the financial vice president. **********The Credit Research Foundation runs a series of educational programs for credit people on behalf of the association, following the on-the-job training provided by many companies and basic courses offered by the National Institute of Credit. **********For example, there is the Graduate School of Credit and Financial Management program, to open at Dartmouth College on June 22 and at Stanford University on July 6. Companies send experienced credit executives to the program. The participants, who are expected to have a background in economics, finance and accounting, attend the 11-day intensive sessions for three consecutive summers, taking such courses as computer applications to credit and financial decision-making, managerial psychology, international credit and finance and modern marketing strategy keyed to financial and manufacturing policy. **********For middle-level credit and financial personnel, the foundation offers a one-week summer Mid-Career School at Pine Mountain, Ga., which provides technical expertise, and a one-week Advanced Credit Executive Studies program, to be held this summer at the Foxfire Country Club at Pinehurst, N.C.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/16/world.body_text: **********The storm of speculation about the death of a beleaguered West German politician whose body was found in the bathtub of a Geneva hotel last Sunday seemed to subside today, with indications the Swiss authorities were nearing a suicide ruling. **********At a news conference in Geneva Wednesday, a police spokesman, reporting results of an autopsy, said a fatal dose of five sleeping potions and tranquilizers had been found in the stomach of the man, Uwe Barschel. **********Mr. Barschel was forced to step down as premier of the state of Schleswig-Holstein over charges he had conducted a dirty-tricks campaign against his opponent in recent elections. **********The police spokesman stopped short of saying Mr. Barschel had committed suicide. But he said that the medications, which he did not identify, were sufficient to cause death, and that no signs of violence had been found in Mr. Barschel's mouth or throat, suggesting that he had taken the drugs voluntarily. **********He said Mr. Barschel was now thought to have died earlier on Sunday than 11 A.M., as previously reported. He said the previous determination had not taken into account the effect of the warm water in the tub.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/busin.body_text: **********The Continental Illinois Corporation said that it would sell its Toronto subsidiary, Continental Illinois Bank of Canada, to the Swiss Bank Corporation's Canadian unit. Terms were not disclosed, but Continental said that its gain would not have a material effect on operating results. **********Continental said that the sale was part of a previously announced program to reduce costs and streamline operations. Continental Canada provides commercial lending, capital markets and treasury advisory services. The bank has assets of $302 million. In a statement, Swiss Bank said that it was interested in expanding its operations in Canada.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/26/busin.body_text: **********The European Community proposed today to scrap quotas for most steel products by July 1988 and return the industry to free-market competition. **********The proposal, announced by the community's executive commission, would retain quotas for some steel products until the end of 1990, provided the industry itself agreed to cut capacity. The decision followed the recommendations of a special panel of experts, which concluded that maintaining the protective output quota system in the 12-member community was no longer justified. **********Production quotas were first adopted in 1980 to help restructure the ailing steel industry. **********A commission official said the proposal was not likely to create major disruptions in the European steel industry. ''We think it's a fairly gentle way to end the quota system,'' he said. **********The proposal will be submitted to the community's governing Council of Ministers for adoption Dec. 8. **********The commission said it wanted the quotas lifted on all products except heavy plate steel and heavy sections. For those, the commission would extend the quotas until 1990, provided that by next March the industry submits ''guarantees that closures are taking place.'' **********The commission estimated that, despite growing demand for steel, the industry still produced about 20 million tons of surplus steel each year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.snippet: LEAD: TONY THE TIGER and the Pillsbury Doughboy are getting a lot of company on the airwaves these days, as advertisers increasingly turn to animation in hopes of keeping viewers riveted to their screens.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.main_headline:
WHAT'S NEW IN ANIMATION;
Selling Raisins by Letting Them Dance
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.print_headline:
WHAT'S NEW IN ANIMATION;
Selling Raisins by Letting Them Dance
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: TONY THE TIGER and the Pillsbury Doughboy are getting a lot of company on the airwaves these days, as advertisers increasingly turn to animation in hopes of keeping viewers riveted to their screens. **********TONY THE TIGER and the Pillsbury Doughboy are getting a lot of company on the airwaves these days, as advertisers increasingly turn to animation in hopes of keeping viewers riveted to their screens. **********''For a while animation was believed not to be sexy,'' said Paul R. Vester, of Speedy Cartoons Ltd. of London. ''It's sexy now.'' **********''Almost anything goes as long as it's entertaining,'' agreed J. J. Sedelmaier, executive producer for the Ink Tank, an animation company that saw its revenues from commercial work go up about 50 percent this year. **********Indeed, the number of animated ads seems to increase on almost a daily basis. Cherry Coke flashes across the screen amidst a rapidly moving collage. Computer-drawn robots toting cans of Hawaiian Punch walk off an assembly line into a high-tech chorus. R.O. Blechman's squiggly line characters, often spotted in the New Yorker, move across TV screens in commercials for Ivory soap, Sears, Le Tigre sportswear, MTV and Budget Gourmet dinners. **********Clay raisins clad in high-top sneakers and dark glasses emerge from their box dancing to the 60's tune, ''I Heard It Through the Grapevine,'' while a ''noid,'' a small, rather malicious creature, does to delivered pizzas what legendary gremlins were said to do to airplanes. ''We have little kids who think the noid is a real little person,'' said Ernest G. Perich, senior vice president of Group 243 Inc., the Ann Arbor advertising agency that has the Domino account. ''And there are even some college fan clubs.'' **********Such commercials are not quick to make. It can take weeks, or even months, to do the intricate panel-by-panel photography or drawings required to make inanimate objects move onscreen. **********But the cost, industry insiders say, is not all that high. Commercials like that for the raisins, which use clay animation, cost as much as $6,000 a second or $180,000 to produce. According to Alison Johns, associate editor of Millimeter magazine, which covers the animation industry, that compares with $200,000 for a simple 30-second commercial using live characters and no special effects. Simple cartoon animation is even cheaper, about $40,000 to $60,000 for 30 seconds. But the price range is higher when cartoon characters appear next to real products or in real places - about $50,000 to $100,000 to produce a 30-second spot. **********But perhaps most important, industry insiders say that animated commercials stand out in a cluster of TV ads, and viewers are likely to pay attention to them. ''Advertisers don't want to get zapped by remote controls,'' said Ms. Johns. ''As an attention-getter, animation works. It is a pipeline straight to your imagination, something that says 'relax, you are going to be entertained.' ''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/07/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Bond Prices Gain Modestly
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/07/busin.body_text: **********Bond prices ended modestly higher in slow trading yesterday, lifted by a stronger performance by the dollar on foreign currency markets. **********Before the United States markets opened, Japanese and European dealers had bid up the price of Treasury securities by nearly a point, as the dollar flirted briefly with the psychologically important 150-yen level and also gained against European currencies like the British pound. **********However, most of that advance was retraced during trading hours in New York. **********''Things were really peppy early,'' said one government bond trader, ''but then it turned into a summer Monday, with patches of activity here and there but no particular flavor. Right now it seems like the market is having trouble finding something to focus on.'' **********Late in the day, the price of the Treasury's bellwether 8 3/4 percent 30-year bond was bid at 103 11/16, up 1/4 of a point, to yield 8.409 percent. **********Other long-term issues, like the Treasury's 9 3/8 percent 20-year bond, registered similar gains, with the 20-year rising by slightly more than 1/4 of a point, to a bid of 107 13/32, to yield 8.570 percent. **********Meanwhile, interest rates on short-term Treasury bills were little changed in secondary trading. **********One-year bills were bid late in the day at 6.25 percent, up 3 basis points, or hundredths of a point. **********At its weekly auction of $13.2 billion worth of new three-month and six-month bills, the Treasury said it sold the three-month issue at an average discount rate of 5.62 percent, the lowest such rate since June 8, when three-month bills had an average discount rate of 5.59 percent. The bills had an average discount rate of 5.82 percent at last week's auction. **********The six-month bills were sold at their lowest rate in more than three months, bringing an average discount rate of 5.68 percent. On April 6, six-month bills sold at an average discount rate of 5.63 percent. Last week the bills were auctioned at an average discount rate of 6 percent. **********Evidence that a stronger dollar is building confidence among foreign investors in United States debt securities appeared in Tokyo yesterday, where the Ministry of Finance announced that Japanese investors bought $14 billion worth of foreign bonds last month. **********In its report, the Ministry of Finance did not break down how many of those bonds were issued by the United States. But the figures came as something of a surprise. **********''The numbers surprised us a little bit,'' said John J. Niehenke, a senior vice president in the government securities department at Nomura Securities. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/14/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chairman of Colorcraft Confident on Kodak Tie
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/14/busin.body_text: **********D. Carl Hamill, chairman and chief executive of the Colorcraft Corporation, a major photofinishing operation, may soon be operating a business twice as large. **********Mr. Hamill, 55, would head the combination of Colorcraft and the photofinishing business of the Eastman Kodak Company, which would create the nation's largest such operation, with more than 25 percent of the market for developing film and making prints. **********The merger was announced last week and is expected to take place if Federal regulators do not object on antitrust grounds. Mr. Hamill said he was confident the deal would go through. ''We feel the consumer has so many choices, especially by using the new minilabs.'' he said. ''We can show to the regulators that in no way is what we're doing going to reduce options for the consumer.'' **********The minilabs to which he referred are photofinishing machines installed in retail stores, a development that has put pressure on such wholesale photofinishers as Colorcraft and idled parts of their processing plants. **********The result has been a consolidation in the industry that has squeezed the smaller wholesale photofinishers, Mr. Hamill said. Kodak, which has operated its own processing lab, began to acquire some of these independents about a year ago. **********Mr. Hamill is familiar with the Kodak style because he started out with the Rochester company in 1954, after graduating from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, and worked there for five years. **********Then he joined another company in Rochester that was subsequently taken over by the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company. Mr. Hamill became manager of the plant for 3M and worked there until he moved to Colorcraft in 1968 as vice president for operations. **********Colorcraft had been taken over by Fuqua Industries a year earlier. Under Fuqua, Colorcraft, based in Durham, N.C., has grown from a company with $3 million in annual sales to a $300 million operation. Sales are expected to double again with the addition of the Kodak units. Mr. Hamill has led Colorcraft since 1981.
