https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/26/world.main_headline: CAIRO, IN SHIFT, FOLLOWS ISLAMIC TREND
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/26/world.print_headline: CAIRO, IN SHIFT, FOLLOWS ISLAMIC TREND
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/26/world.body_text: **********The National Democratic Party of President Hosni Mubarak, in which the several contending factions range from socialists to free-wheeling capitalists, has increasingly begun to embrace Islamic symbols. **********In the parliamentary election last spring, the party's posters took on the color green and the crescent moon of Islam. Using the symbols is a significant advantage in a nation with a literacy rate under 50 percent. **********This week's issue of the Islamic Banner, the party's own Islamic newspaper, was devoted almost entirely to the annual hajj, or pilgrimage to Mecca. It also had an article explaining that women should not have the same right to divorce as men because women are more emotional. **********''This is the paper issued by the party of Mubarak,'' said Dr. Nawal el-Saadawi, one of Egypt's leading feminists. ''Who is paving the ground for these Islamic groups? It is the Government itself, and the first victim will be the Government.'' An Ambiguous Approach **********Other secular-minded Egyptians and some foreign diplomats say that Mr. Mubarak's regime has adopted an ambiguous and possibly risky policy of repressing violent Islamic fundamentalists while also trying to take advantage of Islam's growing popular support. **********''Clearly there is a two-track policy,'' said a Western diplomat. ''I don't think they make any bones about it. There is an attempt to bring responsible Islamic figures into the system and a very clear policy that fundamentalists who engage in violence are going to get clobbered.'' **********The security forces have rounded up hundreds of people suspected of membership in underground Islamic extremist groups. But the Government, cloaking itself in Islamic symbols, also has allowed the Moslem Brotherhood, which is still officially banned, to become the major opposition voice in Parliament. **********Government officials say the President, by offering a place in the Government to the Brotherhood, which was banned for its suspected involvement in a 1954 assassination attempt on President Gamal Abdel Nasser, hopes to drive a wedge between it and such clandestine fringe groups as the organization Holy War, or Jihad. That group assassinated Mr. Mubarak's predecessor, President Anwar el-Sadat, in 1981. Tactic Raises Questions **********But others question whether the ''Islamic trend,'' as it is called here, can be split. They see the various groups as generally united in purpose as well as religious belief. **********''Some in the Government say, 'Look, the tactic is working; The mainstream Islamic trend has renounced violence,' '' said a diplomat. ''But there's another theory that has a lot more doubts about the Moslem Brotherhood, the Islamic charities and so forth, that they are really a front, that in the end, the Islamic movement is all one and the same thing.'' **********Their tactics are different, he said, but the goals the same: the imposition of sharia, or strict Islamic law. **********The fundamentalists can point to some victories in their efforts to make Egypt more Islamic. A clause in the 1971 Constitution saying Islamic law was ''one of the sources of legislation'' was changed in 1979. It now reads, ''Islam is the religion of the state, Arabic is its official language and principles of Islamic laws are its main sources of legislation.'' Victories of Islam **********In the spring of 1985, Egyptair, the national airline, stopped serving alcoholic drinks after complaints from Islamic fundamentalists. **********A 1979 decree by Mr. Sadat, which required a husband to get his wife's consent before taking a second wife, was struck down in court in 1985. It was replaced by a watered-down version that did not give women the same protection. **********Last May, at the end of the Ramadan, the Moslem month of fasting, the Government lifted a long ban on public prayer rallies. **********The party members in Parliament who nominated Mr. Mubarak for another six-year term in October elections recently sprinkled their speeches with Islamic references. A deputy from the Moslem Brotherhood even chimed in and compared the President with the Caliph Omar, the second successor to Mohammed in the early days of Islam. Challenge Remains **********But it is the Government's television station that plays perhaps the strongest role in promoting Islam. Beside several general Islamic announcements each day, the station carries a weekly sermon by the charismatic Moslem preacher, Sheikh Metwali el-Sharawi, who mixes classical and colloquial Arabic and gives down-home examples of injunctions from the Koran. His popular hourlong sermon is watched by tens of millions each Friday afternoon, Even so, the Government is still challenged by underground Islamic terrorist groups that were blamed for recent assassination attempts on Hassan Abu Basha, a former Interior Minister who directed the roundup of fundamentalists after President Sadat was killed, and Makram Ahmed, an editor critical of the rise of fundamentalism. **********The key man in the Government's fight against the underground cells is the tough-talking Interior Minister, Maj. Gen. Zaki Mostafa Ali Badr, who cracked down on the city of Asyut in Upper Egypt after fundamentalists rioted there following Mr. Sadat's assassination. **********The other day at a police exhibit, General Badr took aside several reporters from the opposition press, which has been highly critical of him. 'I'd Arrest 20,000' **********''If the safety of Egypt was at stake,'' he snarled, ''I'd arrest 20,000 in an hour.'' **********Some diplomats are concerned about the general's tactics. **********''The instinctive response of the security people is not to do any investigative or police work, but just to pull the book out and round up the first 500 names and start roughing them up,'' one said. ''If they weren't Jihad when they started on them, they will be by the time they come out of jail.''

The total cost of the plant, whose first unit is scheduled to begin commercial operation next February, is now estimated at $5.3 billion. **********The project is owned by the Central and South West Corporation, the Houston Lighting and Power Company, City Public Service of San Antonio and the City of Austin. In December 1975, soon after construction began, the plant's cost was estimated at $1.2 billion. In 1982, the plant's total expected cost was raised to $5.5 billion. However, it was partly offset in 1985 when Brown & Root, Inc., the former project engineer and builder, agreed to pay $500 million in order to settle a lawsuit charging improper construction.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/23/busin.print_headline: DOW ADDS TO STRING OF GAINS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/23/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: The stock market moved higher into record territory yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average gained 24.66 points, to 2,445.51. **********The stock market moved higher into record territory yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average gained 24.66 points, to 2,445.51. **********The Dow has not lost ground in 11 consecutive trading sessions. Since May 20, when the average reached 2,215.87 - the lower end of a trading range it had been stuck in for six weeks - the blue-chip index has moved relentlessly higher. Some market analysts are beginning to talk about a 2,500 Dow. **********The stock market was bolstered yesterday, as in recent days, by gains in the bond market and by the firmer dollar. Receding inflation fears, underscored by a sharp drop in the Commodity Research Bureau's index, also contributed to a growing confidence on Wall Street. **********And analysts said that the continued weakness of the Tokyo and London stock exchanges might bode well for Wall Street, as foreign funds are funneled into American stocks and bonds.Trend Found Impressive **********The Dow's gains during its recent climb have not been spectacular, but the overall market trend is beginning to impress the experts, especially since many people had given the five-year-old bull market up for dead when the dollar plunged in mid-April and American interest rates started moving higher. **********But the dollar has rebounded modestly, to a level that analysts say should help American industry compete better. That, in turn, has raised hopes that the American trade deficit will become manageable. The bond market took its cue from that, and interest rates fell accordingly. **********''This market has good underlying strength; people just didn't believe it,'' said Laszlo Birinyi, head of research at Salomon Brothers. He noted, however, that the current Wall Street rally was still a blue-chip rally. ''It's not the over-the-counter or the $15 stock they're buying,'' he noted. **********One trader, who said the Japanese were big buyers, observed: ''This is all I.B.M., Digital Equipment, Merck, all the big boys. All the hot money is going from Tokyo to the U.S.'' **********Indeed, indexes that track the over-the-counter market and the American Stock Exchange issues - where many smaller companies trade -have underperformed the Dow in recent weeks. Yesterday, the Nasdaq index rose a meager 0.17, to 429.25, and the Amex index fell 0.85, to 339.05. **********But the major indexes that track Big Board stocks followed the Dow into record territory: The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.24, to 173.77, and the S.&P.; 500-stock index gained 2.68, to 309.65.Declines in Tokyo and London **********In Japan yesterday, the Tokyo Stock Exchange's 225-share Nikkei index fell 647.8 points, to close at 24,640.6, after falling 606.1 points last week. Yesterday's decline was the third-largest ever. The London market has also been sliding. The Financial Times index of 100 leading shares fell 21.5 points, to 2,244.6; it lost about 55 points in the two previous sessions. **********Analysts said the declines in London and Tokyo, where stock market records were recently set, was the result of profit taking and investor concern over the diminished chances for interest rate cuts in Britain and Japan. **********Many analysts now expect the Japanese to start putting more money into American stocks. **********''Where else can you buy a market at 17 times earnings?'' said Bernard J. Spilko, a managing director at Julius Baer Securities. He said many foreign investors ''feel that the U.S. is very undervalued'' compared with other markets where price/earnings ratios are much higher.Some Are Cautious **********Still, some analysts are holding up a caution flag. Jack Solomon, a technical analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company, said the Dow ''could probably go to 2,475, but that's it.'' **********Mr. Solomon added, ''The market didn't come up with the same breadth and the same volume that it has in the past.'' Mr. Solomon said he believed a lot of the recent rally was the result of portfolio ''window dressing'' by money managers who are buying stocks to make their returns look better before the end of the second quarter next Tuesday. **********''It will be June window dressing and July undressing,'' he predicted. ''They'll cream the market.'' Yesterday on the Big Board, 907 stocks rose and 692 fell. Trading volume came to 178.2 million shares, down from Friday's 220.5 million, when the options-related ''triple witching hour'' spurred trading. **********Among the blue chips, Du Pont added 1 1/4, to 120; Merck 3 1/2, to 169 1/4; General Electric 2 1/8, to 55 1/2, and I.B.M. 1 7/8, to 163 1/4. Other technology stocks were strong: Digital Equipment rose 2 3/4, to 170 7/8, and Cray Research 1 7/8, to 163 1/4. **********Acco World surged 4 7/8, to 28 3/8, in heavy trading after American Brands announced it would acquire the company for $29 a share. **********Mining stocks were hard hit, as gold fell. ASA Ltd. dropped 2 1/8, to 55 1/8. **********The Korea Fund, which had been pounded in recent sessions, apparently because of the political unrest in South Korea, rebounded 5 1/8, to 61 1/4.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/world.main_headline: A Vigil in Washington Protests Pope's Action
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/world.print_headline: A Vigil in Washington Protests Pope's Action
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/world.body_text: **********The meeting of Pope John Paul II with Kurt Waldheim today prompted harsh words and public protest in the United States. **********A crowd maintained an all-night vigil in front of the Vatican's mission in Washington in protest of the visit. Elsewhere, leaders of Jewish groups criticized the Pope for praising the Austrian President as a diplomat ''devoted to insuring peace among peoples'' and for not using the occasion to speak out about the crimes of the Nazis. **********Burton S. Levinson, national chairman of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, called it ''shocking and repugnant'' that John Paul ''failed to denounce or even make reference to the greatest sin ever perpetrated on mankind.'' **********Mr. Levinson and many other heads of Jewish organizations said they were reconsidering plans to meet with the Pope in Miami in September. **********The Washington vigil began at dusk on Wednesday when about 60 people gathered on the tree-lined street outside the Apostolic Nunciature and lit six candles, symbolizing the six million Jews killed by the Nazis. The vigil ended this morning after a stack of documents implicating Mr. Waldheim in the persecution of Jews and others during World War II was left on the doorstep of the mission. **********''Imagine how the millions who died would feel if they knew that the Pope had received Waldheim with full honors,'' said Rabbi Marvin Hier, dean of the Simon Wiesenthal Center, an institution that carries out research and education related to the Nazi crimes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/22/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: JUST before the stock market's plunge, a small newsletter called The Astute Investor was having a hard time finding deeply undervalued stocks. Not anymore. ''Bargains abound,'' said Charles E. Cardwell, the letter's editor, in his November issue. **********JUST before the stock market's plunge, a small newsletter called The Astute Investor was having a hard time finding deeply undervalued stocks. Not anymore. ''Bargains abound,'' said Charles E. Cardwell, the letter's editor, in his November issue. **********Mr. Cardwell, a private investor who has published the newsletter for six years from Kingston, Tenn., describes himself as ''sort of a disciple of Benjamin Graham,'' the father of value-oriented securities analysis. The newsletter publishes several lists identifying stocks selling below book value (net worth) and below net current assets (a company's working capital minus all liabilities). **********Mr. Cardwell said his own preference was a list of stocks trading under net current assets with profitable operations. In that category, the newsletter pointed to, among others, Glenmore Distilleries, selling last week on the American Stock Exchange at about $25, with $30 in net current assets and $38 in book value, and Oak Hill Sportswear, trading over the counter at $4.25, with $5.39 in net current assets and $6.30 in book value. **********Another Astute Investor list identifies more speculative stocks selling for at least 30 percent less than their net current assets. A third list picks stocks selling below book value with an earnings yield - earnings per share divided by the stock's price - of at least 16 percent. **********Mr. Cardwell believes in buying attractive values, particularly ''when everybody is scared silly.'' The Astute Investor's emphasis on bargain-hunting may have guided Mr. Cardwell in setting a price for subsciptions to the monthly publication. At $24 annually, the letter is among the lowest-priced in the industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/29/world.print_headline: AN OFFICIAL'S ROLE IN AN UNOFFICIAL WAR: A FORMER AMBASSADOR'S ACCOUNT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/29/world.body_text: **********At the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair yesterday, Lewis A. Tambs appeared before the joint committee to discuss his role in Central America while he was United States Ambassador to Costa Rica. Here are excerpts from his testimony: **********At the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair yesterday, Lewis A. Tambs appeared before the joint committee to discuss his role in Central America while he was United States Ambassador to Costa Rica. Here are excerpts from his testimony:  A 'BROAD MISSION' **********MARK A. BELNICK, EXECUTIVE ASSISTANT TO STAFF COUNSEL. The instruction from North, as you've testified to it, was to open a military front against Nicaragua, the Sandinista Government, in the south, from Costa Rica, right? **********A. Yes. **********Q. Sir, that's not a typical ambassadorial function, is it? Opening military fronts? **********A. Well you must understand that ambassadors have a very, very broad mission. One of them, of course, is to defend the United States against all enemies foreign and domestic. And you're undoubtedly aware that the second stanza of the Sandinista hymn opens with the phrase declaring that the United States is the enemy of humanity. So one might suspect they have a certain position regarding the United States.  * * * **********Q. Do you recall in June or July of 1986, when a plane got stuck in the mud at the airstrip? **********A. Well, but that's why I suggest to you - **********Q. Yes sir. **********A. Mr. Belnick, that perhaps the field was not completed, because they had at least, was it three or four aircraft eventually stuck in the mud there. **********Q. All right, sir. And do you recall that in the specific occasion that I'm referring to, June or July of 1986, the plane which landed there and got stuck there was carrying military cargo? **********A. It was, indeed it was. **********Q. All right, sir. What happened to that cargo, do you know? **********A. What happened to the cargo? **********Q. Yes, sir? **********A. Well, eventually it was lifted out. **********Q. Did there come a time in the same period - **********A. May I - may I also pause here a moment? **********Q. Yes, sir. **********A. And that is that the agreement we had with the Costa Rican Government was that the airfield would not be used either for storage of supplies or provisions. And that any aircraft landing there would have already completed its mission. And that it would land empty and it would be refueled. And so I was consequently somewhat surprised to find out that the aircraft was stuck in the mud. That's probably why it was stuck in the mud, because it was loaded and I guess it was an emergency.  NOT JUST BAND-AIDS **********Q. Were you surprised also to find out that it was carrying military cargo? **********A. Well, it did not really, you know, I never saw a manifest. But I did not certainly assume they were only dropping - **********Q. Do you want to finish the sentence? **********A. No, not really. **********Q. You didn't assume they were only - **********A. Band-Aids, how's that? **********Q. Band-Aids? Right? **********A. Band-Aids, how's that, okay? **********Q. So it didn't surprise you that military cargo was involved? **********A. No. **********Q. All right, sir, did you speak to Colonel North, or any other official of the United States Government about your concern that the plane being loaded, period, violated the agreement you had negotiated with the Government of Costa Rica? **********A. Oh, I believe I fumed around but I don't recall calling Colonel North. **********Q. All right, did you speak to Tomas Castillo about that? **********A. Yes, you must understand one thing, Mr. Belnick, we're dealing with American lives. And if American pilots, private American pilots, are on this aircraft and there is an emergency, obviously you must choose to - in my opinion, right - I would choose to save American lives, rather than have the aircraft crash. **********And also, a downed aircraft in Costa Rica would certainly be a greater embarrassment than even one stuck in the mud.  A TALK WITH SINGLAUB **********Q. Sir, you know General John Singlaub? **********A. Yes, indeed I do.  * * * **********Q. He came to Costa Rica in the spring of 1986 and you saw him there, right? **********A. That's correct, yes.  * * * **********Q. Tell me what the discussion was. **********A. Is that General Singlaub came to Costa Rica and called the embassy and asked for the courtesy of the mission. All right? And consequently, as an old friend, we invited him over . . . So Tomas Castillo and I sat down and gave him an unclassified briefing . . .  * * * **********Q. Did you discuss also Eden Pastora? **********A. We discussed Eden Pastora, as we did the other forces down there.  * * * **********Q. All right, sir. Now after you had your discussion with General Singlaub, did he contact you again and tell you that he had seen Commander Pastora? **********A. . . . Let me make this clear to you . . . No one in the mission had anything to do with arranging a meeting between him and Comandante Zero.  * * * **********Q. Did you speak to him about his meeting with Commander Pastora? **********A. Yes, he called up and said that he had seen Pastora, and since my mission was always to try and find out what was going on and tell our friends up here in Washington, I said, ''Why don't you come over for dinner?'' And I remember we had tacos that night. Okay?  'UNITED STATES-IANS' **********Q. Aside from the tacos, did he give you a copy of an agreement - that is, General Singlaub - give you a copy of an agreement that he had entered into with Commander Pastora? **********A. Yes.  * * * **********Q. All right, sir. Now, the agreement provided as set forth in your cable - quote - the United States will provide food, ammunition, medicine, maps, military needs for Pastora's troops, including new men who join his army, training advisers. Correct? **********A. Yes, and when I saw that I said, ''You cannot negotiate for the United States Government.'' He said that does not mean the United States Government. He said that means we private United States-ians - huh? **********Q. United States-ians? **********A. That's right. That's a good Spanish word, right?  * * * **********Q. Sir, did you record in your cable - **********A. Well, I . . . Obviously, I have to send the text as given to me. I can't change the text. **********Q. I understand, sir. Did you make comments at the end of this cable . . . ? **********A. Well, the fact is that the comments were given verbally to the deputy C.I. **********A. representative in Costa Rica, right? And he took them down and sent it out and I did not review the cable. Right? May I read the comments? **********Q. Yes, sir. And let me read it because the copy is somewhat blurry. Ambassador's comments: In spite of written agreement, we have reservations that Pastora will comply. However, since Singlaub is envoy of Senator Helms and will report to him his observations, and his own reservations upon return to Washington, Senator Helms may re-evaluate his position regarding Pastor **********A. Singlaub and his colleague, Barbara Studley, assisted - assured Ambassador, rather - that Pastora agreed that all supplies, equipment, training, will be delivered, provided, via UNO, the United Nicaraguan Opposition. Nothing will be delivered until Pastora's men are moved inside Nicaragu **********A.  'NOT EVALUATING' **********A. Well I was reporting, not evaluating. **********Q. But that is the report you made concerning the agreement? **********A. Yes, but that's a report. That's what you get paid to do. **********Q. All right. Now sir, did you receive a quick response from the State Department to this cable? . . . A cable signed by Deputy Secretary Whitehead, but coming from and through Assistant Secretary Abrams to you, dated March 29, 1986? **********A. Yes. **********Q. . . . Assistant Secretary and Deputy Secretary said, among other things: I was astounded by the report of the agreement concluded between General Singlaub and Eden Pastor **********A. I fail to understand how you and the C.I. **********A. representative could associate yourselves with an agreement which purports to commit the United States to provide military materiel and advisers in exchange for a series of undertakings on Pastora's part. **********Now sir, did you understand from the text of the agreement how the State Department might have concluded that this was an agreement that purported to bind the United States of America? **********A. Well, first of all, we did not associate ourself with the agreement; we were reporting on an agreement between two private individuals.  * * *  A QUESTION OF USE **********Q. It did not occur to you that despite disclaimers of U.S. Government involvement, somebody might be able to use the text of that agreement to indicate that the United States, through the embassy, had committed itself to supplying military needs of Eden Pastora? That was not your view? **********A. My view was that we should report to Washington what we had found out. And that's what we did. **********Q. Sir, would you look at LAT Exhibit 4, which is a cable that you then received from the Secretary of State, in which he told you that in his request the State Department legal adviser had reviewed the legal issues raised by the agreement and the secretary continued - quote: Based on his review, the legal adviser concludes that it is impossible to rule out the possibility that your disclaimers of U.S. Government involvement notwithstanding, Pastora might attempt to use the Singlaub agreement to pressure or embarrass the United States Government. You are therefore instructed to inform Pastora that Singlaub is not authorized to negotiate on behalf of the United States, that the United States Government does not consider itself bound by Singlaub's agreement and that U.S. Government policy remains as stated to Pastora on March 7 by me, Secretary of State Shultz and Assistant Secretary Abrams, etc . . .  * * * **********Q. Sir, did you carry out the instruction to inform Eden Pastora that the United States Government did not consider itself bound? **********A. We did.  * * * **********Q. Did you . . . convey the information that the United States Government disclaimed that agreement? **********A. Well, I wasn't going to talk to him anyway - because I never talk to him. **********Q. So you didn't speak to him about that? **********A. No. **********Q. And did you speak to General Singlaub about that? **********A. No.  WHO KNEW OF STRIP?  * * * **********SENATOR DANIEL K. INOUYE. Would you be surprised if you were told that Secretary Abrams has testified that he was not aware of the construction of the airstrip before it was started? **********A. Well, I can't speak for Secretary of State Abrams. I would be somewhat surprised, but - **********Q. Is his memory failing him? **********A. Well, he might have been distracted. . . . I can't speak for him.  * * * **********Q. Secretary Abrams has testified that he does not recall discussing this assignment with Ambassador Tambs during the September 1985 Central American chiefs of mission conference. **********A. I did not know, sir, that he testified that. **********Q. But you are convinced that at that time he did discuss it with you, as you've testified? **********A. Yes, sir.  * * * **********SENATOR WARREN B. RUDMAN. Did you feel you were being kind of hung out to dry? **********A. No, the fact is that, as Ambassador I am responsible and was responsible. What I find to be disconcerting, to put it mildly, is to see officers who were carrying out what they believed to be orders from their legitimate superiors now in effect seeing their careers sacrificed. . . .  ACTING ON ORDERS **********Q. But everything you did in relation to the southern front and all of the things involved even with General Singlaub were essentially a result of directions that you got from relatively high ranking officials in the White House, the Agency and the State Department? **********A. That's correct sir. **********Q. And you assumed that they had authority to give them? **********A. Yes. **********Q. And you carried out their orders to the best of your ability? **********A. Yes sir. **********Q. And now that you did, and you're no longer part of the establishment -now you're off in Arizona teaching -people are kind of suggesting in their testimony that Old Tambs did it all by himself. That outrage you? **********A. Well, it's very complimentary in a way . . . I thought they were doing a splendid job and I was delighted to be working with them because they wanted to win. **********Q. And they ought to stand up and tell us what a splendid job they were trying to do, shouldn't they? **********A. Well, I can't speak for them, but - **********Q. But you would advise that? **********A. Yes.  * * * **********REPRESENTATIVE DANTE B. FASCELL. And if you were doing something that was constitutional, and within the law, and certainly a worthwhile objective - keeping the Communists out of Central America - why would guys cut and run at this point and leave you hanging out there in the wind, with regard to this issue? **********A. I don't know, sir; you'd have to ask them. **********Q. But you do feel that way, don't you? My perception of what's happened is correct, is it not? **********A. Well, I do feel that the field officers have not - who went forward, right, are not being backed up by the superiors who gave them the orders.
