https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/09/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS; REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A COLONEL'S SELF-ASSURANCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/09/world.body_text: **********Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's description of his secret meetings in bathrooms, his purchase of leotards for his daughters, the poison pill he took along with him to Teheran provided another day of drama in the Senate chamber today. **********Colonel North held his ground, presenting himself as a man sure of his objectives and not at all displeased wth his own ingenuity. **********''I saw that idea, of using the Ayatollah's Khomeini's money to support the Nicaraguan freedom fighters as a good one,'' he told the Congressional committee and the nation at large. ''I still do. I don't think it was wrong. I think it was a neat idea.'' **********Such homespun touches as calling a scheme to use funds from an Islamic revolution to finance a Central American insurgency ''neat'' seemed to work in the colonel's favor. **********''I'd say it was a powerful performance,'' said Senator Paul S. Trible Jr., a Virginian Republican. **********But some members of the committee and spectators were dismayed by what they viewed as his disregard for the law and his contemptuous attitude towards the Congress.  A Question of Pride **********For a covert operative, Colonel North also appeared to take peculiar pride in the way his fame had spread. He recounted how the Iranian middleman Manucher Ghorbanifar told him, '' 'I have read about you, you have been in the papers' - in fact, by then I think I'd even been in Izvestia -'And I know what you really do in your spare time. You support the Nicaraguan resistance, don't you?' '' **********''Among other things,'' the colonel said he answered. **********''All our enemies knew it,'' replied John W. Nields Jr., the House committee counsel, ''and you wanted to conceal it from the United States Congress.'' **********The two men, both boyish in appearance, both projecting intensity and commitment, both leaning forward on the edges of their seats in the crowded, ornate hearing room, seemed to personify a generational cleft tracing back to the 1960's. The dichotomy was most sharply drawn in the split-screen television images: Colonel North in his crisp uniform, his thick, dark hair closely cropped, his face baleful; Mr. Nields, a battered tan briefcase by his side, his thinning blonde hair falling over his ears and collar, his expression suggesting restrained and righteous anger.  Close to Contrite **********Questioned about a security system installed at his Virginia home by others involved in the operations and for which he submitted phony bills, Colonel North came as close as he has so far to sounding contrite. ''I did probably the grossest misjudgement that I have made in my life,'' he said. But he added that the Government should have paid for the system because it was his service to the nation that had placed his life and those of wife and children in jeopardy. **********Colonel North also displayed strong emotion when he turned to the subject of his purchases, with money earmarked for the covert operation, from a store called Parklane Hosiery. **********''You know that I've got a beautiful secretary, and the good Lord gave her the gift of beauty, and the people snicker that Ollie North might have been doing a little hanky-panky with his secretary,'' he said in dead earnest. **********He then went on to testify, ''Ollie North has been loyal to his wife since the day he married her. And the fact is I went to my best friend'' - he said, referring to Mrs. North - ''and I asked her, 'Did I ever go to Parklane Hosiery?' **********''And you know what she told me?'' he continued. '''Of course you did, you old buffoon, you went there to buy leotard for our two little girls.''' **********He wrote the check on an operation account, he said, because he was owed money for ''what I spent in pursuing that covert operation.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/21/busin.main_headline: Advertising; GSD&M Wins Coors Beer Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/21/busin.print_headline: Advertising; GSD&M Wins Coors Beer Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/21/busin.body_text: **********After a creative shootout among its three agencies in the last six weeks, the Coors beer account has been awarded to GSD&M Advertising of Austin, Tex., which has generally been known as a specialist in the Hispanic market. **********The account for the nation's fourth-largest-selling beer, which is spending an estimated $40 million for advertising, had been at Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago. Coors arrived in New York for the first time earlier this year. **********''We've identified the need to become more attractive to the young beer drinkers,'' said Bob Fox, brand director for Coors, the leading product of the Adolph Coors Company. ''We feel that GSD&M had a creative spark and might be able to come up with something.'' **********GSD&M, which has three other Texas offices, reported billings last year of $85 million. It has been an agency for the **********Golden, Colo., brewing company since 1983, when it received the assignment to handle the Hispanic advertising for both Coors and Coors Light. **********Foote, Cone will continue to handle the smaller Coors Light account, as well as two other company brands and two new brands coming on the market. The company's third agency, Tatham-Laird & Kudner in Chicago, will still do the advertising for Coors Extra Gold beer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/05/world.main_headline: U.S. Aides Say Summit Could Be 'Turning Point' for Afghan Withdrawal by Soviet
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/05/world.print_headline: U.S. Aides Say Summit Could Be 'Turning Point' for Afghan Withdrawal by Soviet
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/05/world.body_text: **********Senior State Department officials said today that the summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev next week could turn out to be vital for a withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan. **********''This certainly could be a turning point toward an Afghan settlement,'' said Edward P. Djerejian, Senior Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs. ''But that depends on the Soviet Union translating its state of intent to withdraw into actual facts on the ground.'' **********Another senior State Department official confirmed that the Afghan war would be ''a major topic of discussion.'' **********Mr. Gorbachev said in an interview with NBC News this week that he would discuss a timetable for withdrawal of Soviet troops with Mr. Reagan. Arms Embargo on Iran **********In other regional issues, Washington is expected to press Moscow to support a United Nations resolution imposing a global arms embargo on Iran for refusing to accept a cease-fire and settlement with Iraq in their seven-year-old war. President Reagan has also said in recent statements that he would bring up problems in Central America. **********But the officials acknowledged that despite the heightened expectations here, there is a strong possibility that no progress would be made on Afghanistan, on other regional issues, or on scientific and cultural exchanges and similar topics, which are referred to as bilateral issues. **********Arms control dominated the summit meetings between the two leaders in Geneva and Reykjavik, despite predictions that regional issues would be high on the agendas. **********The United States has been heartened by indications from Moscow that it is dropping its insistence that the composition of an Afghan coalition government has to be decided before agreement can be reached on a withdrawal timetable. The indications were relayed by First Deputy Foreign Minister Yuli M. Vorontsov to Under Secretary of State Michael H. Armacost in Geneva last month. **********''They sure as hell are talking a different game,'' a State Department official said. Afghan Withdrawal Date **********The United States is pressing the Soviet Union to set a date for withdrawal from Afghanistan. An Administration official said today at a White House briefing that the United States wants a withdrawal of Moscow's 115,000 troops before the end of 1988. **********The Russians have hinted that they are willing to withdraw if the United States cuts off military aid to the Islamic guerrillas and helps set up a coalition government that will prevent the killing of Afghan officials who have supported the Soviet presence. **********''We want to avoid a situation where after the forces pull out there will be bloodshed, which may result in the deaths of thousands of people, maybe millions of people,'' Yevgeny M. Primakov, a Soviet specialist on the Middle East and head of the Institute of World Economy and International Relations, said at the Brookings Institution today. **********As for the withdrawal timetable, Mr. Primakov said: ''I believe the force will be withdrawn next year. This is my personal point of view.'' Can't 'Leave Them Prey' **********This week the Afghan leader, Najibullah, said the withdrawal of Soviet troops could be completed within 12 months. **********Under accords already signed by Pakistan and Afghanistan at United Nations-sponsored talks in Geneva, the withdrawal process must begin and all outside aid to the Afghan insurgents must end 60 days after an agreement on a timetable is signed. In a television interview Thursday, President Reagan said the United States would not make a commitment to suspend aid to the guerrillas for a year if the Russians agreed to withdraw within that time. ''You can't suddenly disarm them and leave them prey to the other government,'' he said of the guerrillas. **********Trying to clarify the President's remarks, an Administration official said in today's briefing that ''noninterference presumably would begin'' after the 60-day period, ''as well as Soviet withdrawal.'' Impasse in Gulf Talks **********Moscow sent troops into Afghanistan in December 1979, saying it had been asked to help the Government put down domestic resistance. At the same time, the Afghan leader was overthrown - in the third coup in less than two years - and Mr. Najibullah's predecessor, Babrak Karmal, was installed as the leader. **********On the Persian Gulf, the United States is said to believe that the arms embargo against Iran is even more urgent since efforts by the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, to persuade Iran to accept a cease-fire reached what seemed to be an impasse Thursday. **********''We will be asking the Soviets to come forward with their position during the summit,'' Mr. Djerejian said. **********Thus far, the Russians have refused to begin discussions at the United Nations on an arms embargo, indicating that they prefer that Mr. Perez de Cuellar continue his negotiating efforts. **********''I don't think that any resolution on an end to supplies of arms to Iran will stop those supplies, because the main source of supply is a free market,'' Mr. Primakov said today. Arab-Israeli Conflict **********Other regional issues that could be raised at the summit meeting include the Arab-Israeli conflict, and other areas where Soviet or Soviet-backed troops are involved, such as Nicaragua, Angola, Cambodia and Ethiopia. **********In addition, President Reagan is expected to raise with Mr. Gorbachev the impasse between the two countries over new embassies in each capital. **********The United States is considering whether to raze part or all of its new embassy in Moscow, which is riddled with Soviet electronic eavesdropping devices. The United States has refused to allow the Russians to occupy a new diplomatic compound in Washington. **********Additional issues likely to be discussed include improving access for American officials to the Soviet public, scientific agreements on ocean study and sharing of basic science, and cultural exchanges. **********The plight of Eskimos living on the American side of the Bering Strait, who are separated from their families on the Soviet side, may also come up. Administration officials have assured Senator Frank H. Murkowski, an Alaska Republican, that they will discuss helping the American Eskimos visit their Soviet relatives.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/24/busin.main_headline: Real Estate; CONNECTICUT BUSY AREA FOR OFFICES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/24/busin.print_headline: Real Estate; CONNECTICUT BUSY AREA FOR OFFICES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/24/busin.body_text: **********IN some real estate circles the conventional wisdom has held that when a New York company relocates to the suburbs, it moves near the top executives' homes. **********As skilled lower-rank workers get harder to find, however, more companies base their decisions to move on the housing needs and commuting convenience of all their employees. **********For this reason, in the past few years the eastern part of Connecticut's Fairfield County - where the average cost of a house is only about a third as much as in the Stamford-Greenwich area - has emerged as a fair-sized commercial office center. Black & Decker, Chesebrough-Pond's, ITT, Tetley Tea, TIE Communications and Richardson-Vicks are among the companies that have built or leased office buildings there. **********According to Richard F. Gretsch Jr., a senior vice president and broker with the Stamford office of Albert B. Ashford Inc., a real estate brokerage company, there is now a total of more than four million square feet of new office space in eastern Fairfield County, which includes the towns of Trumbull, Shelton, Bridgeport, Stratford and Fairfield. Most of it has been built in the past 10 years. **********Among builders who have responded to the stepped-up demand for office space in the area is Robert D. Scinto. Since 1978 he has put up more than one million square feet of office space in 16 buildings in Trumbull, Shelton and Fairfield. His development company has approval for the construction of an additional one million square feet of space in the area. **********''This office market is definitely driven by the affordability of the area's housing,'' said Mr. Scinto, who started in the construction business as a plumber. ''Also, the area was the next logical location for a major development push after Stamford. The land was available, the appropriate zoning was in place and the utilities could support the growth.'' **********The expansion of Route 8 three years ago, which provided easier access to Bridgeport, Stamford and Waterbury, was another factor in the area's commercial growth. **********Two years ago Christopher McLeod, a senior vice president of Comp-U-Card, a computerized buying service with headquarters in Stamford, started seaching for expansion space for the company. But what it would have to pay for new offices was not his primary concern. **********''Comparative rents were not the most important consideration,'' said Mr. McLeod. ''In our serivce-oriented business, labor costs are the dominant figure. In order to hire and keep the type of people we need, we wanted to be in a location that was most convenient for them.'' **********Recently 300 Comp-U-Card employees moved into a new building in Trumbull, a town that is no more than 15 minutes from home for most of the company's employees. **********So far much of what has been built in eastern Fairfield County has been relatively modest in size, compared with new office structures in Stamford and nearby Westchester County. Mr. Scinto's buildings, for example, have averaged less than 80,000 square feet. But last month the developer broke ground for his largest project to date: a 10-story, 291,000-square-foot office tower in Shelton. Mr. Scinto said his new building would be the largest speculative office structure to be built in Fairfield County outside Stamford. **********The new building is part of a 50-acre office complex at the intersection of Bridgeport Avenue and Commerce Drive. Known as Enterprise Corporate Park, it already holds two 140,000-square-foot office buildings. Among the tenants are Olivetti USA's Bunker Ramo banking division. **********The office building, which will be the first of two towers planned for the complex, will have floors that average 28,620 square feet in size. The facade will be of red granite and silver reflective glass, and there will be a parking garage for 990 vehicles. **********Mr. Scinto said he also plans to build a 250-room hotel in Enterprise Corporate Park. **********Despite the pace of development and the continued demand for space in eastern Fairfield County, not all office buildings have found tenants quickly. According to Mr. Gretsch, the vacancy rate for the region is about 22.3 percent. Of the 4.5 million square feet of office space, a little more than one million square feet stands empty. **********To set his buildings apart, Mr. Scinto said he tries to offer unusual design and top quality materials. ''These kinds of things are loss leaders,'' said Mr. Scinto. **********Space in the new office tower will average $17 a square foot, excluding utilities. Occupancy is planned for the second quarter of 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/30/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz called on South Africa yesterday to move peacefully past apartheid and toward a constitutional system of pluralistic democracy that would guarantee universal voting rights, freedom of speech and the press and other liberties. **********Speaking to the Business Council for International Understanding in Manhattan, Mr. Shultz conceded that the problems in South Africa ''appear overwhelming.'' But he added that they contain ''some hopeful elements.'' **********''There are efforts to expand communications between the races,'' he said, ''and there is evidence that those efforts can bear fruit.'' **********Mr. Shultz avoided any mention of the trade sanctions enacted by Congress nearly a year ago over President Reagan's veto. But he rejected the notion that American business could better influence South Africa by leaving. **********''It would be counter to the objective of ending apartheid if we were to isolate South Africans and withdraw our influence from that society,'' he said. **********''That is why we strongly support the continued presence of American business in South Africa. American companies have been in the forefront in the business community in promoting equal opportunity for their employees and in developing the managerial skills of blacks.'' Gloomy Report Is Hinted **********President Reagan is scheduled to send Congress a report this week on the impact of the sanctions. Mr. Shultz gave no hint of what the report would say. However, a State Department official said, ''Since last year's bill was passed by Congress, apartheid is still there, reform is stalled, violence and repression continue, negotiations have not yet begun.'' **********Nevertheless, Mr. Shultz cited some hopeful signs, including a meeting last July in Dakar, Senegal, between dissident Afrikaners and officials of the outlawed African National Congress, the principal group fighting to overthrow the apartheid system. The meeting was strongly criticized by South Africa's President, P. W. Botha. **********Mr. Shultz added: ''I emphatically reject the fatalistic notion that the country's future has already been written, that it is too late for accommodation. I know that there is hope for the future.'' **********He said that because many South Africans had urged the United States to state clearly not only what it opposed, but what it was for, Mr. Shultz had decided to spell out, in some detail, his vision of the kind of society that should emerge after the apartheid system of racial separation is ended. **********This included ''a new constitutional order,'' he said, ''establishing equal political, economic and social rights for all South Africans without regard to race, language, national origin or religion.'' He also called for ''a democratic electoral system with multiparty participation and universal franchise for all adult South Africans.'' Human Rights 'Guarantees' **********Mr. Shultz also urged ''effective constitutional guarantees of basic human rights,'' including ''the right to liberty and security of persons; the right to freedom of speech and the press, peaceful assembly and association, and practice of religion.'' **********He also cited the ''right of labor to organize and pursue peacefully its economic objectives; the right not to be deprived of property except by due process of law and upon payment of just compensation; the right of movement within the country, emigration and repatriation, and the right of individuals and communities to use their own languages and develop their cultures and customs.'' **********In addition, Mr. Shultz called for an independent judiciary, a division of power between the national Government and local authorities and an economic system that ''enables all South Africans to realize the fruits of their labor, acquire and own property and attain a decent standard of living for themselves and their families.'' **********''I particularly feel the frustration,'' he said, ''of having only limited influence, of not being able to make things right down there.'' **********However, he added: ''It is not within the power of the United States or any other country to impose a solution to South Africa's problems. The solution must come from South Africans.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/busin.main_headline: Figure in Winans Case Indicted on 55 Counts
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/busin.print_headline: Figure in Winans Case Indicted on 55 Counts
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/busin.body_text: **********A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted David W. C. Clark, a lawyer who formerly worked in New York, on 55 felony counts in an extension of the insider trading case centering on R. Foster Winans, the former reporter for The Wall Street Journal. **********The indictment accused Mr. Clark, 37 years old, of participating in the insider case and evading income taxes in 1980, 1981 and 1982, according to Howard Wilson, the chief of the criminal division of the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan. **********Mr. Clark was also accused of embezzling $3.7 million from clients at Appleton, Rice & Perrin, the law firm where he worked, and of failing to report it as income. **********Carl H. Loewenson Jr., the assistant United States Attorney in charge of the case, said Mr. Clark, if convicted, could be sentenced to as much as five years in prison on each of 53 of the counts and also fined ''hundreds of thousands of dollars.'' **********Mr. Clark's attorneys, F. Lee Bailey and Kenneth Fishman, both based in Boston, did not return telephone calls to their offices. Mr. Bailey was understood to be in Florida, where Mr. Clark now lives. **********Two years ago Mr. Clark was named in the civil case brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission that charged Mr. Winans with ''fraud and deceit,'' accusing him of trading in stocks on the basis of advance knowledge about articles in The Journal. Mr. Winans and three other defendants in the civil case were subsequently indicted on criminal charges as well. But criminal charges were not filed against Mr. Clark. Mr. Loewenson said he would not comment on why Mr. Clark was not indicted until yesterday. **********The other defendants in the case were David J. Carpenter, Mr. Winans's roommate and a former clerk at The Journal; Peter N. Brant, a former stockbroker at Kidder, Peabody & Company, and Kenneth P. Felis, also a former Kidder broker. **********Mr. Brant pleaded guilty to three counts, agreed to cooperate with the investigation and is awaiting sentence. Mr. Winans, Mr. Carpenter and Mr. Felis were convicted after trial. **********Mr. Winans was sentenced to 18 months in prison, five years' probation, 500 hours of community service and fined $5,000. Mr. Carpenter was sentenced to three years' probation, 200 hours of service and fined $1,000. Mr. Felis was sentenced to six months in prison, to be served on weekends, and five years' probation; he was fined $25,000. Supreme Court to Hear Case **********The Supreme Court has agreed to hear an appeal of the case, so all of the penalties have been held in abeyance until then. **********Also pending against Mr. Clark is a suit brought by Roger W. Wilson, a 29-year-old actor. Seeking $12 million, Mr. Wilson sued two years ago, accusing Mr. Clark and others of using the actor's inheritance for their insider trading. **********Mr. Clark, the Government said, was indicted on 19 counts of mail fraud, 17 of securities fraud, 11 of wire fraud, three of income tax evasion and one each of conspiracy, making false statements to a Government official and perjury. **********The Government said Mr. Clark lives in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. No telephone number was listed for him in the area, and he could not be reached for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/23/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Rates Fall Sharply Once More
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/23/busin.body_text: **********Short- and long-term interest rates declined sharply for the fourth consecutive day, spurred by speculation that the Federal Reserve would adopt a more generous monetary policy as the stock market's gyrations cause the economy to weaken. **********The decline in stock prices yesterday added to concerns about the economy and helped raise bond prices by more than three points. At the same, continued declines in commodity prices helped reduce fears of future inflation, which also propped up the bond market. **********Although analysts are not sure about the extent or longevity of the Fed's moves toward an easier monetary policy, the belief is widespread that the Fed has already eased policy modestly. **********Besides acting early and often to add funds to the banking system this week, the central bank has acted behind the scenes to defuse the crisis atmosphere by eliminating its limits on the amount of Treasury issues that government securities dealers may borrow from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. 7 Percent Range Seen ''The Fed has not eased in a broad-scale public sense by reducing the discount rate,'' noted Robert H. Ried, president of Ried, Thunberg & Company, a Westport, Conn., economic advisory firm. ''But we think they have eased enough so that Federal funds will fluctuate around 7 percent.'' **********The overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market was around 7 1/2 percent earlier this month and late last month. **********In London, the largest world's largest market for wholesale bank deposits, the perception that short-term rates would decline led to a sharp drop in rates on three-month deposits, to about 8.06 percent, down from about 9 1/4 percent on Monday. **********Elsewhere in the short-term market, Treasury bill rates continued to plummet, helped by strong demand from investors who want to avoid the risks of the stock or bond market until conditions are more stable. **********By late in the day, three-month bills were about 5.33 percent, down from 5.61 percent and well below the 6.66 percent rate for similar issues as recently as last Friday. #1-Year Bills Off Sharply At yesterday's auction of new one-year Treasury bills, the average rate of 6.45 percent was down nearly a percentage point from the previous auction in late September and was the lowest rate since July. **********In the long-term bond market, securities dealers said demand for Treasury, corporate and mortgage issues remained strong. Besides the demand from investors who have recently pulled funds out of the stock market, the appetite for debt issues has been greatly improved by emerging forecasts of a weak economy and low inflation, they said. **********Many mathematical models of the economy sugggest that consumer spending will decline by $5 billion to $10 billion within a year after a $100 billion decline in wealth. At the steepest point in the stock market's selloff on Monday, wealth had fallen by an estimated $1 trillion this month, causing some economists to predict a sharp slowdown in economic growth, or even a decline in gross national product for a quarter or more. **********Today, the Commerce Department is expected to announce a growth rate of about 3 percent for the G.N.P. after inflation during the third quarter. **********''The economic models all say that consumer spending falls in response to a drop in wealth, but it's a treacherous thing to forecast,'' said Fred J. Levin, chief money market economist at Citicorp Investment Bank. Wealth Measures Fluctuate **********Besides the difficulty of trying to measure how consumer psychology will change, he noted that wealth measures are still fluctuating as the stock market moves up and down. Mr. Levin also noted that economic forecasts must consider the stimulus from lower interest rates and the effects of changes in Government spending. **********Although securities dealers have been glad to see the revival of activity in the long-term bond market, many are amazed that investors have been so quick to set aside the fears of inflation, large budget deficits and interruptions in the investment of foreign capital that plagued the market earlier this year. **********One dealer with close ties overseas noted that some major European accounts were extremely wary of the sharp rise in Treasury bond prices, and that they are not convinced that the problems of inflation and the weak dollar are solved. **********''Some time down the road the market might wake up and realize that the old problems still exist, but for now the scenario people are looking at is a drop in consumer confidence and a weaker economy,'' said Bruce R. Lakefield, executive vice president in the Treasury securities department at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. **********That sentiment was powerful enough yesterday to lift the 8 7/8 percent Treasury bonds due in 2017 by about 3 3/8 points to an offered price of 97 23/32 to yield 9.10 percent. **********As recently as early Monday, that Treasury issue was traded at 85 3/4 to yield 10.45 percent. In the Treasury note market, the 8 3/8 percent issue due in 1992 rose more than 1 1/4 points to a price of 99 14/32 to yield 8.50 percent, down from about 10 percent early Monday. Corporations Jump In **********Corporations have been quick to take advantage of the renewed investor demand for notes and bonds, offering nearly $1.7 billion of new issues yesterday, on top of the $1.1 billion offered Wednesday. **********Strong demand for Treasury securities has helped create a problem for some dealers who have sold securities they did not own and were not able to find elsewhere. **********To alleviate the problem of ''fails,'' or incomplete trades that make dealers nervous about the financial condition of their trading partners, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York told dealers early yesterday afternoon that it was temporarily lifting its $150 million limit on the amount of Treasury securities any single firm can borrow from the Fed, as well as the limits on borrowing single issues. **********Experts in the Treasury market said the shortage of some securities had been aggravated recently by constant rumors of financial problems among dealers that have made many institutions unwilling to continue lending Treasury issues to securities houses. **********The only sector of the bond market not to benefit recently are high-yielding ''junk bonds.'' Those issues, particularly the more recent offerings, have been battered by a perception that companies will have difficulty selling assets at high prices, as well as a downturn in economic activity could hurt earnings enough to raise doubts about some companies'' ability to pay interest and principal on their bonds. **********In yesterday's trading, dealers said prices of junk bonds were mixed, with some issues rising, but others falling, depending on investors' perception of the particular company involved. **********Following are results of yesterday's auction of new one-year Treasury bills:  (000 omitted in dollar figures)          Average Price    93.478        Discounted Rate    6.45%        Coupon Yield    6.90%        High Price    93.529        Discounted Rate    6.40%        Coupon Yield    6.84%        Low Price    93.448        Discounted Rate    6.48%        Coupon Yield    6.93%        Accepted at low price    83%        Total applied for    $21,946,575        Accepted    $9,257,955        N.Y. applied for    $19,559,000        N.Y. accepted    $8,343,750        Noncompetitive    $268,110       The one-year bills mature Oct. 27, 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/25/world.main_headline: Mexico City Journal; And Where Are the Bureaucrats? Gone Fishing
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/25/world.print_headline: Mexico City Journal; And Where Are the Bureaucrats? Gone Fishing
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/25/world.body_text: **********Going on vacation is something workers everywhere eagerly look forward to. But according to a recent study, no one in Mexico does it better, or more often, than the country's two million bureaucrats, most of whom live and work here in the capital. **********When the Mexican Labor Congress recently took a look at the work habits of Mexicans, it concluded to its surprise that the average Government employee spends only 196 days a year on the job. The labor group's study found that every year the bureaucrats get two vacations of 15 days each and 12 days of paid personal leave, in addition to benefiting from 22 days of so-called ''bridge holidays.'' **********The ''bridge'' days are additional time off granted by the Government to extend a patriotic or religious holiday falling on a Thursday or Tuesday through the weekend. Holidays Cost Billions **********Economists say that President Miguel de la Madrid's austerity program, which has limited wage increases for workers in and out of public service, has made such paid days off more highly valued than ever before. **********The subject has a particular resonance now, as Mexico is experiencing its worst economic crisis in half a century and the Government is calling on all Mexicans to help the country get back on its feet. The newspaper El Financiero, which specializes in business news, estimated that the bridge holidays alone cost the country at least $1.5 billion a year and are a major contributor to low productivity. **********''If days in red appear on the calendar for January, February, May and December, plans are made to take some sort of trip,'' the newspaper complained, noting that many bureaucrats say they suffer from ''boredom'' on the job.  Raffish Street Life **********In recent years, jugglers, clowns, acrobats and especially fire-breathers have become one of the most familiar sights at any major intersection here. Men and women entertain motorists waiting at traffic lights with magic tricks, hoping to amuse them enough to receive a few pesos in return. **********This month, however, the Government decided to try to put a stop to the practice by offering the entertainers alternative employment: selling books to the commuters from the same street corners. Some 300 people immediately signed up, attracted by promises of commissions of up to 50 percent, and the intersections are now clogged with book salesmen. **********As part of the same program, the Government said it would soon offer scholarships to three-month job training programs for the fire-breathers and their colleagues. The goal, the Education Ministry said, is to enable the entertainers to have ''a dignified and active participation in the social and productive life of the country.'' **********The street corners continue to be the workplace of itinerant vendors trying to eke out a living by selling roses, windshield wipers, maps and chewing gum. They are clamoring to be made eligible for the program, but the Government has not made a decision.  Eros via California **********Telefonos de Mexico, the Government-run telecommunications company whose inefficiency and atrocious service make it a favorite target for abuse among Mexicans, is basking in some unexpected praise these days - not for something it did, but for something it has moved to prevent. **********Earlier this year, several hundred families here began receiving monthly phone bills including hundreds of dollars in long-distance charges. Assuming the utility must be at fault, the subscribers complained to TelMex, as the company is called, and on checking it found that many of the calls being challenged were to a single telephone number in Los Angeles. **********Further investigation revealed that the number in question belonged to a Spanish-language ''Dial-a-Porn'' service aimed at the Hispanic population in Southern California. Students from several schools and apartment complexes here had obtained the number and were making the long-distance, direct-dial calls to hear sexually explicit two-minute messages, sometimes several times a day. **********TelMex has now programmed its equipment to prevent callers here from dialing any pay-by-the-call public information exchange in the United States, and the complaints from parents have stopped. A company spokesman, Alejandro Hernandez Murillo, said the action ''demonstrates to subscribers that the charges on their bills are not the fault of the company and that the calls were indeed made.'' **********It is not yet clear, however, what is to be done about charges already incurred. Several dozen cases have been taken to the Consumers' Court here, including those of about 40 people whose phone service has been suspended after they refused to pay for calls to what has been dubbed ''the Los Angeles hot line.''  There Goes the Block **********When the offices of the city attorney and the judicial police were destroyed in the 1985 earthquake and law enforcement officials moved into temporary quarters in the Acacias district of the capital, residents of the area were sympathetic. But now that it appears prosecutors and the police are settling in permanently, people in the neighborhood have adopted a different view. **********''We demand that you go away!'' one shouted at a heated conference with city officials that was widely reported in newspapers here. ''We want to live in peace!'' **********Residents of the middle-class neighborhood in the south of the city are enraged by an increase in crime on their streets that they attribute to the police presence. They accuse the lawmen of assaults, shakedowns, theft of car parts and drunken behavior at a neighborhood cantina. **********Expansion of the building occupied by the officials and continuing shipments of office equipment have convinced residents that the police do not intend to move anytime soon. That impression was strengthened when the community association, whose membership has tripled since the uproar began, said it had learned that only $11,000 has been allotted for construction of a new headquarters. **********At a recent public meeting, Chief of Police Jesus Miyazawa promised to investigate the complaints and said he would assign a special police unit to the area to make sure order is kept. That suggestion, needless to say, did not exactly go over well with those present. **********''We don't want another police force just to watch the police,'' newspapers quoted one resident as replying angrily. ''All we want is for you to get out of here.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/06/busin.body_text: **********Markets **********Wall Street enjoyed one of its best days in history as the Dow Jones industrial average surged within reach of the vaunted 2,000 mark. In a hectic session, the Dow climbed 44.01 points, to 1,971.32, an advance that surprised many experts because it followed a 31.36-point jump on Friday. The blue-chip index has climbed nearly 4 percent in this year's two trading sessions. Experts attributed the surge to pent-up demand relating to the tax-law change.  [ Page D1. ]  Professionals remain optimistic about yet-higher stock prices, but they stress the prospect of wild price swings in trading.  [ D8. ] **********Bond prices continued a rally that began on Friday. The gains, which amounted to a half point or more for most long-term Treasury securities, came on very light volume.  [ D15. ] **********The dollar staged a modest comeback against major European currencies after market intervention by West Germany's central bank. In New York, gold rose 75 cents, to $402 an ounce.  [ D16. ]  Crude oil futures slumped below $18 a barrel, as traders appeared to be taking profits after last week's gains.  [ D16. ] Companies **********BankAmerica's board unanimously rejected a takeover bid from First Interstate and vowed to fight for BankAmerica's independence. BankAmerica also said it planned to raise additional capital, including the issuance of equity securities. The bank has been reluctant to issue new common stock because such a move would further dilute the value of its already depressed stock.  [ D1. ] **********Wheeling-Pittsburgh's chairman sold his 34.2 percent stake in the steel company, which is in bankruptcy proceedings. Allen E. Paulson, who will resign, sold his holdings to Lloyd C. Lubensky, a director who is expected to succeed him.  [ D1. ] **********Sales of new American-made automobiles rose 27.6 percent in the Dec. 11-20 period. Analysts said that most of the gain was borrowed from early 1987 and predicted a January slump unless new sales incentives are offered.  [ D4. ] **********Rockwell International plans to issue a new class of stock that is apparently designed to deter hostile takeover moves.  [ D4. ] **********Nucor plans to build a $200 million mill by 1989 to produce flat-rolled steel using a new process.  [ D4. ] **********Standard Oil plans to take a $30 million fourth-quarter charge after taxes to retire long-term debt.  [ D4. ] The Economy **********The Administration submitted a trillion-dollar budget to Congress for the fiscal year 1988, setting the stage for an unusually tense confrontation. Even Republican leaders in Congress predicted that the budget, which envisions a $107.8 billion deficit, would be substantially reworked.  [ A1. ]  The Pentagon plans to spend heavily on nuclear weapons and missile defenses.  [ A16. ] **********A Japanese construction industry practice that effectively bars U. S. companies from Japanese public works projects may also be having anticompetitive effects in the United States, according to a senator and a senior Commerce Department official.  [ D2. ]  International **********The chairman of Guinness will face growing pressure to resign, according to some of the company's large shareholders. The executive, Ernest Saunders, will soon meet with a group of outside directors amid new allegations of questionable actions by Guinness management during a takeover battle for Distillers.  [ D1. ] **********France raised its interest rates again in a effort to avoid a devaluation of the franc. The currency has come under speculative pressure because of a crippling 19-day rail strike and the threat of wider industrial unrest later this week.  [ D6. ] Today's Columns **********The Farm Belt can expect growth in employment in 1987 although gains in per-capita income are not likely to be as strong as in the rest of the nation, according to Claire Asklund, a senior economist for Data Resources. Talking Business.  [ D2. ] **********The outlook of investment newsletters now tends to reflect where the market stands, rather than where it is headed. According to the Hulbert Financial Digest, the best-performing newsletter for the year ended in November was the McKeever Strategy Letter, with a 58.9 percent return. Market Place.  [ D8. ]

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/06/world.main_headline: Vietnam's Issues May Be Next for Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/06/world.print_headline: Vietnam's Issues May Be Next for Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/06/world.body_text: **********Vietnamese officials expect to open talks with the United States before the end of this month that will for the first time address Vietnamese problems arising from the war, a high-ranking Foreign Ministry official said today. **********''For the last 12 years, we have handled humanitarian issues for the United States,'' the official, Nguyen Dy Nien, a Deputy Foreign Minister, said in an interview in his office here referring to the accounting of the 1,776 Americans missing since the war. **********''I think now the United States must - has already made a start to - deal with the humanitarian issues of Vietnam,'' said Mr. Nien, an expert on United States affairs. ''We can not carry on one-sidedly.'' **********Officials close to talks last weekend between the Vietnamese and an American team led by President Reagan's special envoy, Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., say that the American side balked at agreeing to a future meeting on strictly Vietnamese concerns. Action 'Is Important' **********''In negotiations sometimes there is only one word in the text and it can take hours to remove it and replace it with another word,'' Mr. Nien said when asked about the American attitude toward talks on Vietnam's human casualties. ''But I told the American side that the important thing is action.'' **********''We would like to close this chapter as soon as possible,'' he added. He recalled that in January 1986, Vietnam set a two-year timetable to resolve the issue. He declined to comment on what might happen when that period ends. **********The Foreign Ministry official said that Vietnam, one of the world's poorest countries, had limited expectations about what assistance it could get from the United States. The Reagan Administration has ruled out reparations or war damages. **********''The humanitarian issues of Vietnam are enormous,'' Mr. Nien said. ''But we know the limits. We are realistic.'' Children of Servicemen **********Mr. Nien said that in the recently concluded talks with the American delegation, the subject of the offspring of Americans based in Vietnam also came up. The Foreign Ministry official said it was his understanding that there might be a separate set of talks on this issue in the near future. Neither side knows how many of these children remain in Vietnam. **********But a number of the children are reaching the age of majority, and Anerican humanitarian organizations say that this could make them eligible for military service, particularly since many are street urchins who might be viewed as delinquents. **********Mr. Nien said Vietnam's political prison camp population, most suffering for their association with the United States-backed Saigon regime, had not been discussed with the Vessey party. He called this a political issue that was related to internal policies of Vietnam, Three years ago, Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, had challenged the United States to empty the camps. Secretary of State George P. Shultz responded by offering to resettle the political prisoners in the United States. Visit by Solarz **********But when Representative Stephen J. Solarz, the Brooklyn Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs, visited Hanoi in December 1984 and asked if Mr. Shultz's offer would be accepted, he was told that the prisoners could not be released unless the United States could guarantee they would not take part in ''anti-Vietnamese'' activities abroad. **********Mr. Solarz told Vietnamese officials that rights of free speech in the United States made such a promise impossible. **********Mr. Nien said today that he expected that General Vessey would ''keep up contacts'' with Vietnam, although he is not expected to be part of the next round of talks, which will be at the ''technical expert'' level. The Deputy Foreign Minister said General Vessey, a veteran of the Vietnam War, had been cordial but frank in the recent discussions. **********Asked if there was a chance that a further round of talks may be held in Washington, Mr. Nien laughed. **********''We are not so optimistic,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/busin.main_headline: Texas Bank To Report Large Loss
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/busin.print_headline: Texas Bank To Report Large Loss
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/busin.body_text: **********The First Republicbank Corporation, the largest bank holding company in Texas, said today that it expected to report a fourth-quarter loss between $325 million and $350 million because of the worsening condition of the troubled Texas real estate market. **********The anticipated loss would push First Republicbank's total losses for 1987 to about $650 million, including a second-quarter loss of $313 million from write-downs of foreign loans. First Republicbank also said that its directors voted today to halt payments on the company's quarterly dividend of 25 cents per common share, but to continue payments on four series of preferred shares. **********Joseph C. Bowles, a First Republicbank spokesman, said the company could experience additional losses from falling real estate values in 1988 because ''Texas real estate markets have not yet stabilized.'' $33.6 Billion in Assets The projected fourth-quarter loss would also be larger than any ever experienced by the two bank holding companies, the Republicbank Corporation and the Interfirst Corporation, that merged last June to create First Republicbank. The merged company's assets totaled $33.6 billion at the end of September. **********When the merger was completed, First Republicbank's chairman and chief executive, Gerald W. Fronterhouse, said that the company hoped to be profitable during the second half of this year because of cost cutting. In a statement released today, he said that First Republicbank had cut $30 million in operating expenses since the merger by eliminating 2,000 jobs. **********But a staggering excess of commercial office space in the state's largest cities - including Dallas, Houston, San Antonio and Austin -with vacancy rates of at least 30 percent in some cases, has affected most of Texas's major banks. Rising Foreclosures **********Georgia Head, a bank analyst with Rauscher, Pierce & Refsnes, in Dallas, said First Republicbank's projected loss was disappointing given Mr. Fronterhouse's optimism last summer. **********Sandra J. Flannigan, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc. in Houston, said that most large Texas bank holding companies, including First Republicbank, were expected to report losses through at least the first half of next year. **********Frank W. Anderson, an analyst with Eppler, Guerin & Turner in Dallas, said rising foreclosures would continue to make it difficult for First Republicbank to operate profitably next year because it must increase expenses to manage newly foreclosed property. Foreclosures more than doubled, to $571 million at the end of September, from $218 million at the end of March. In March 1986, foreclosures totaled $99.1 million. **********Mr. Bowles said First Republicbank's fourth-quarter loss would result from an increase in the bank holding company's loan-loss reserves, as well as from write-downs in values on foreclosed real estate and land held as collateral for other loans. He declined to estimate the amounts of the write-downs or increases in the reserves. **********First Republicbank's primary capital, including $1.4 billion in equity and $1.1 billion in loss reserves, amounted to 7.4 percent of the bank's total assets at the end of September. **********Nonperforming assets, including real estate foreclosures, were $3.1 billion, or 12.4 percent, of the total loans. First Republicbank's shares rose 25 cents, to $6.75, in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange. The announcement of the projected loss was made after trading closed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/busin.body_text: **********The Microsoft Corporation, as expected, yesterday introduced a version of its Excel spreadsheet program for International Business Machines personal computers. The software raises perhaps the most potent challenge yet to the Lotus Development Corporation's top-selling 1-2-3 software. At a news conference in New **********York, William H. Gates 3d, Microsoft's founder, said ''this is an infectious product,'' and several corporate users who have seen early versions of the software praised it for its ease of use. But analysts remained doubtful that Microsoft would make major inroads into Lotus's market share until I.B.M.'s newest computer line, the PS/2 family, becomes widely used. **********The program appears to operate dramatically faster than 1-2-3 in some applications, chiefly because Excel recalculates only selected figures on a spreadhseet when a new number is entered or an old one is changed. Lotus, in contrast, recalculates all figures on spreadsheet. **********Excel also operates in color, showing negative figures on a financial statement in red, for example, and adjusting on-screen charts and graphs as numbers change on a related spreadsheet.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; RJR Nabisco's Eurobond Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.body_text: **********RJR Nabisco Inc. yesterday conducted a $100 million offering of 8 3/4 percent Eurobonds due in 1994 at a price of 101 3/8 through underwriters led by Bank of America International Ltd. **********Prices of fixed-interest dollar-denominated bonds in the Euromarket soon came under pressure after the Volcker news. **********Noncallable for life, the bonds are rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.&P. The issue also features a ''put'' provision that allows bondholders to redeem the bonds in 1991 at par.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/24/busin.main_headline: Advertising; Celebrations Mask Fear At Agencies
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/24/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Celebrations Mask Fear At Agencies
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/24/busin.body_text: **********ON the surface, at least, Christmas is coming to Madison Avenue much as it usually does. There are parties. There are bonuses. But the frivolity is tempered by fear. Jobs thought secure have evaporated as the result of megamergers or the new economics of the business. **********''Forget your troubles; come on, get happy,'' is the lyric that could have been written to cover the last two weeks. Agencies have been feting the season, some more grandly than others. **********Lintas had a dinner dance for 600 at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria, while McCann-Erickson and Ogilvy & Mather chose that large barn, the Manhattan Center. McCann had a 1950's theme that allowed some of the over-served to show their prowess with the Hula-Hoop. This year the gang was given a bonus, something they didn't get last year. Ogilvy's party was a ''Red and White'' ball, inspired perhaps by the red necktie almost always worn by William E. Phillips, chairman of the Ogilvy Group, or the suspenders favored by David Ogilvy, the founder. It went well with the bonus, which was green. **********Backer Spielvogel Bates, which has been high up in the Saatchi & Saatchi machinations during the year, had its party for 1,200 at the Tavern on the Green. Survivors received bonuses. **********J. Walter Thompson, for which 1987 was a year of misfortune, played down its celebration. Just some egg nog and Christmas cookies one afternoon. **********N. W. Ayer, the nation's oldest agency, had its 1,000 troops at the Sheraton Center. Before the festivities they heard from Louis T. Hagopian, the chairman, who reported that it wasn't a banner year but it had its high points, like the winning of the $200 million Burger King account and the acquisition of Cunningham & Walsh, which added to its packaged-goods strength. **********The folks at FCB/Leber Katz Partners did not get a Christmas party this year. But don't feel sorry for them. To make up for it they are getting next week off. Indeed, three agencies in the top 20 are doing the Christmas to New Year's bit, according to the American Association of Advertising Agencies. The others are Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, which started the practice last year, and DDB Needham, its sister company in Omnicom, which is initiating it this year. **********''It is a tremendous morale builder,'' said John O'Connor, public relations director of B.B.D.O. **********At its 23d Street headquarters, Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt staged a ''Holiday Fest'' yesterday that departed from the standard boozy event - it was for employees and their kids and started at 9 A.M., running until 3 P.M. Lots of food and lots of Santa. **********Young & Rubicam also has a party for youngsters, but not its own. The work force entertains needy kids. And this year also marked the agency's first Christmas party for the press. **********At DDB Needham each department usually has a party, while at Grey Advertising the entertainment involves account groups. Everyone who works on General Foods, for example, had a blast at the Tunnel disco. **********Largely removed from that whole scene, but not averse to attending a party if opportunity arises, is Eugene Secunda, who after 22 years in the business is writing a doctoral dissertation while teaching communications at New York University. His view is a dark one. **********''It is probably the bleakest period in my memory,'' he said the other day. For some years he was public relations director of the J. Walter Thompson Company, the problems of which, starting with an unfriendly takeover, are well known. **********''There is fear and apprehension about the future among people in the business and a real concern about consolidation,'' he said, adding, ''The business is imploding.'' **********Employees know that the acquirers of agencies have promised to improve the margins, he said. ''But since there is no great potential for explosive growth, the only way to improve margins is to cut personnel. And that usually hits the people over 40. Then as the demand arises they bring in younger people.'' **********A similarly gloomy view is held by Judy Wald, a headhunter for 21 years and head of the well-known advertising personnel firm that bears her name. **********''I hate to be doom and gloom all the time, as I have for the last two years,'' she said. ''I hate it when I can't say something optimistic.'' **********''Every time the phone rings I think it's another person from J. Walter Thompson looking.'' **********The stock market collapse, she said, was the final blow, and it has made advertisers and agency people worry about ad budgets. In the recent past Judy Wald would be asked to find groups of people. Now she is seeking hard-to-find specialists. **********''They're calling me the Ferret,'' she said. **********Asked about the mood of the people at agencies, she said: ''They are so unproud of what they're doing. They feel unimportant and expendable. Now they are willing to take jobs on the client side. That never used to be the case.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/14/busin.main_headline: B.A.T. to Expand Saks 5th Ave. Chain
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; B.A.T. to Expand Saks 5th Ave. Chain
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/14/busin.body_text: **********iB.A.T. Industries of London said yesterday that it plans to spend $300 million in the next five years to expand its Saks Fifth Avenue subsidiary, a chain of 44 specialty stores that caters to affluent consumers. **********The program calls for a 30 percent increase in retail space at the New York flagship of Saks Fifth Avenue, the remodeling of more than 20 branch stores and the opening of five new stores in Denver; Portland, Ore.; Minneapolis; North Palm Beach, Fla., and Tyson's Corner, Va. **********At a news conference yesterday, Henry F. Frigon, president and chief executive of Batus Inc., the American subsidiary of B.A.T., said the company's goal was ''to capture additional market share and capture new markets.'' He said that the Saks New York flagship store was the most productive of all the Saks stores and was one of the most productive stores of any sort in the country. **********He also said that in 1986, for the first time in its 63 years, Saks exceeded $1 billion in sales and $100 million in operating profit. **********''When Batus purchased Saks in 1973, Saks consisted of just over 20 major stores and had sales of $270 million,'' Mr. Frigon said. ''Since that time, retail space has been increased by approximately 50 percent, to about 4.5 million square feet, and the number of stores has more than doubled.'' **********B.A.T. Industries, which last year closed its 36 Gimbel department stores, is investing heavily in its remaining retail outlets. Several weeks ago, B.A.T. announced a $120 million outlay to remodel the downtown Chicago flagship store of Marshall Field, a chain of department stores that also caters to higher-income customers. **********Melvin Jacobs, chairman and chief executive of Saks, said the expanded Saks store on Fifth Avenue would increase sales of three principal areas of merchandise: women's designer sportswear and ready-to-wear apparel; men's clothing, furnishings and sportswear; and fashion accessories, including cosmetics and fragrances. **********The New York store's expansion is part of a previously announced 36-floor office and retail development, which Saks is building in partnership with the Swiss Bank Corporation. He said that the first 10 floors of the complex would link with corresponding floors of the main store, while the upper floors would be the American headquarters of Swiss Bank.
