He replaced John P. Murray, Wilson's 60-year-old chief executive, who has become the company's ch...
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/31/busin.main_headline:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Wilson Sporting Goods Promotes Its President
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/31/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Wilson Sporting Goods Promotes Its President
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/31/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Glenn N. Rupp, president and chief operating officer of the Wilson Sporting Goods Company, has assumed the additional title of chief executive. He replaced John P. Murray, Wilson's 60-year-old chief executive, who has become the company's chairman. **********Glenn N. Rupp, president and chief operating officer of the Wilson Sporting Goods Company, has assumed the additional title of chief executive. He replaced John P. Murray, Wilson's 60-year-old chief executive, who has become the company's chairman. **********Wilson, the nation's largest producer of golf clubs, baseball mitts, footballs, tennis racquets and other sporting goods, announced the changes last week. **********Industry officials credit the 42-year-old Mr. Rupp with helping to engineer the turnaround of what was once a neglected division of Pepsico Inc. After recording a series of losses in the early 1980's, Wilson was sold to the Wesray Capital Corporation, the New Jersey investment firm headed by William E. Simon, a former Treasury Secretary. Since then, the company, which is based in River Grove, Ill., has regained its snap, largely through product innovations and doggedness. For the first six months of this year, the company reported a net income of $4.4 million, on sales of $167 million. It broke even last year after reporting a loss of about $30 million in 1985. **********The comeback has not been easy. While Wilson introduced a well-received fiberglass and graphite tennis racquet last year and plans to introduce another racquet later this year, the domestic tennis market has been shrinking. To offset that decline, Wilson has concentrated its domestic operations more on golf, which, incidentally, is Mr. Rupp's favorite sport. **********Wilson has also grown to depend more on its international divisions. In Japan, for example, the company has capitalized on a growing tennis population by jointly marketing tennis products with the Sony Corporation. **********Mr. Rupp, a native of Washington, joined Pepsico's Wilson division in 1983 as vice president and general manager of the international divison. Before that, he was vice president and general manager of Pepsico's North American Van Lines domestic and international operations before becoming general manager of Pepsico's European soft-drink operations in Frankfurt. **********Mr. Rupp received his undergraduate degree from Duke University and his M.B.A from Harvard. He is married and has two children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/30/world.main_headline: REAGAN CAMPAIGN AIDE IS FOCUS OF NEW INQUIRY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/30/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS; REAGAN CAMPAIGN AIDE IS FOCUS OF NEW INQUIRY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/30/world.body_text: **********A 1980 Reagan campaign official shared hundreds of thousands of dollars with a former personal assistant to the President who was paid to arrange private meetings at the White House between Mr. Reagan and conservative contributors to the contras. **********The role of the campaign aide, Martin L. Artiano, in helping to set up those meetings last year is being examined by Congressional investigators in the Iran-contra affair, his lawyer and other officials confirmed today. **********It had previously been disclosed that after he left the White House, Mr. Reagan's former personal assistant, David C. Fischer, arranged at least seven meetings between the President and wealthy donors for a $20,000-a-month retainer. **********But there is new information that Mr. Fischer, who was in charge of scheduling and advance operations in the 1980 Reagan campaign, split those proceeds with Mr. Artiano, his deputy in the campaign. Mr. Artiano, who now practices law in Washington, was a staff assistant to Mr. Reagan in 1975 and 1976 and worked briefly at the State Department in 1982. No Evidence of Illegality **********There is no evidence that Mr. Artiano did anything illegal in return for the payments. Mr. Fischer, who is 39 years old, has been granted total immunity by the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair in exchange for his cooperation. **********Mr. Artiano was working as a private lawyer in Washington when he and Mr. Fischer received the payments. He has never been employed at the White House, although he was an official on the Reagan campaign's transition team in 1980 and 1981. **********According to documents and interviews with knowledgeable officials, Mr. Artiano and Mr. Fischer were paid by organizations operated by Carl R. (Spitz) Channell and Richard R. Miller. Mr. Channell and Mr. Miller have pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges in connection with fund raising for the Nicaraguan rebels. Mr. Artiano and Mr. Fischer each received about $300,000 last year for arranging meetings between the President and wealthy conservative donors, the officials said. **********Although Mr. Artiano was paid for helping schedule those meetings, the full nature of his actual involvement is not clear and still is being explored by investigators. **********Mr. Fischer, who occupied a cubbyhole adjacent to the Oval Office until he left the White House in the spring of 1985, is much more widely known in the Administration than Mr. Artiano. **********Mr. Artiano declined to discuss the matter and referred calls to Richard A. Hibey, the senior partner in his law firm. 'A Private Arrangement' **********Mr. Hibey confirmed that Mr. Artiano, 38 years old, shared payments with Mr. Fischer, and he acknowledged that Mr. Artiano had been questioned by Congressional investigators. Mr. Hibey said Mr. Artiano received the money for ''consulting'' work, but he would not be more specific. **********''I don't know that there was anything special by the fact that it was Marty or Dave Fischer or any other of these officials in a private role to aid the contras,'' he said. **********''Whatever the arrangement was between him and David Fischer, it was strictly a private arrangement,'' said Mr. Hibey, whose clients include Jonathan Jay Pollard, the convicted spy for Israel, Ferdinand Marcos, the former President of the Philippines, and Mr. Marcos's wife, Imelda. **********Dan Howard, a White House spokesman, said today that Mr. Artiano ''never ever worked'' at the White House ''in any capacity,'' and that he had ''no idea about his dealings with David Fischer.'' Previously, White House officials have denied that the President knew that Mr. Fischer received payments for arranging meetings with contributors. Fischer Planning a Book **********One official said it was Mr. Artiano who negotiated the contract with Mr. Miller and Mr. Channell, in which the payments were originally to be $50,000 for each meeting arranged with the President, but were reduced to $20,000 a month. **********Mr. Fischer's lawyer, Charles R. Work, declined to comment on his client's relationship with Mr. Artiano. Binky Urban, a New York literary agent who is circulating a book proposal by Mr. Fischer on his years at the White House, said she did not know whether the book would cover Mr. Fischer's role in arranging White House meetings. **********Tom Dawson, a spokesman for Donald T. Regan, the former Chief of Staff who has had dealings with Mr. Fischer, said he had never heard of Mr. Artiano and speculated that he received the funds because of his friendship with Mr. Fischer. ''Fischer didn't need any one to help him try to set up a meeting,'' he said. **********Although Mr. Artiano never worked in the White House, his resume reads much like Mr. Fischer's: They both operated Mr. Reagan's advance operation in the 1980 campaign. Both hold law degrees, and both have worked in California for Mr. Reagan. President's Regard **********''They've known each other for a number of years,'' Mr. Hibey said. ''Mr. Artiano was very active in the early days of the effort to test the waters and bring on the candidacy of President Reagan dating back to 1976. I think the President has a good regard for Marty.'' **********In addition to working on the Reagan advance team in 1980 and transition team in 1980 and 1981, Mr. Artiano was acting deputy assistant secretary of the State Department's Bureau of International Organization Affairs for five months in 1982. He later joined the Washington law firm of Anderson, Hibey, Nauheim & Blair, where his clients include the Marriott Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/31/busin.body_text: **********The Higbee Company, a 127-year-old department-store chain in Cleveland, is being acquired by the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation and Dillard Department Stores Inc. for about $165 million in cash. The seller is Brierly Investments Ltd., a New Zealand-based company, which purchased Higbee in 1984 and also has a substantial holding in D. H. Holmes, a New Orleans department store. **********The DeBartolo Corporation, based in Youngstown, Ohio, is the nation's largest shopping-center developer. Dillard, based in Little Rock, Ark., is an expanding retail chain that has acquired several regional retailers in recent years. **********For DeBartolo, which bid to acquire the Allied Stores Corporation late last year and then later dropped its offer, the Higbee venture is believed to be its first retailing investment, although the company owns hotels and motels. **********Higbee, a subsidiary of IEPL Holdings Inc., will retain its name, the company said yesterday in announcing the transaction. Most of Dillard's acquisitions have adopted the new owner's name. **********''I guess we're a little different than the other acquisitions,'' Robert R. Broadbent, Higbee's chairman and chief executive, said in a telephone interview. ''Unlike those when they were acquired, we are a very healthy business, and we have a dominant name in northern Ohio. It makes sense that we retain our name.'' **********Mr. Broadbent said he would remain Higbee's chief executive. **********Higbee, which owns the real estate in 7 of its 14 stores and one warehouse, expects to end the year with sales of $312 million, against about $300 million in 1986, Mr. Broadbent said. He declined to be specific on earnings except to say, ''They will be moderately up this year.'' **********In a statement, Edward J. DeBartolo, the chairman of the DeBartolo Corporation, said the venture continued a 20-year relationship with Dillard. **********William Dillard, the chairman and chief executive of Dillard, said the venture would increase Higbee's growth and expand his company's geographic reach.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; REGULATORS PENALIZE FIRST EXECUTIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/busin.body_text: **********The New York State Insurance Department said today that it had fined a unit of the First Executive Corporation $250,000 and forced the parent company to inject an additional $151.5 million in capital into its New York insurance operation. **********The insurance department said First Executive, which is based in Inglewood, Calif., and its New York subsidiary, the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, had agreed to the fine and the capital infusion to resolve a dispute over requirements for reinsurance activities. The fine equals the largest ever levied by the department. **********Allan Chapman, a senior vice president of Executive Life, said the company did not believe it had violated the state requirements, but it agreed to the capital infusion and fine to settle the matter quickly. ''We could have gone to court, but it would have been a no-win situation,'' he said. **********Mr. Chapman said the capital going into Executive Life of New York would come from the company's Executive Life of California unit. ''We've just moved it from one pocket to another,'' he said. He said the shift would have no impact on reported earnings. **********The insurance department said that from 1983 through 1985, Executive Life of New York had engaged in reinsurance transactions - essentially a secondary market for insurance - that did not meet regulatory standards for financial prudence. The insurance department said the company had improperly accounted for those transactions, known as reinsurance treaties. **********The capital infusion became necessary to bring the company's financial position up to regulatory standards, in light of the department's assessment of the reinsurance transactions, the regulators said. **********''In our judgment, the $151 million is a cash replacement for all the treaties disallowed,'' said Kevin Foley, an insurance department spokesman. **********In addition, the department said, Executive Life had ''failed to facilitate'' the examination of its financial condition, had not received the necessary approval or filed the necessary forms for reinsurance transactions and had failed to comply with agreements with regulators on where it would keep its books and records. **********The insurance department said Executive Life had been fined twice in 1984, for a total of $150,000, for similar violations. First Executive's stock closed today at $18.50, down 25 cents, in over-the-counter trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Times Mirror Magazine Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/16/busin.body_text: **********The Times Mirror Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire four magazines from Diamandis Communications Inc. for $167.5 million in cash. The magazines are Field & **********Stream, Home Mechanix, Skiing and Yachting. Diamandis is the former CBS Magazine Group, which was taken private recently in a $650 million buyout led by the group's chief executive, Peter G. Diamandis. **********It had been widely expected that Diamandis would sell publications to help it reduce debt. Times Mirror, based in Los **********Angeles, publishes The Los Angeles Times, The Baltimore Sun and Newsday, among other newspapers. **********The latest deal reflects a strategy of ''concentrating resources in the core areas of print media, electronic media and information-based, professional publishing,'' said Robert F. Erburu, chairman and chief executive of Times Mirror. **********After the deal, Diamandis would still hold 17 publications, including Woman's Day and Car and Driver. **********Times Mirror said circulation was 2 million at Field & Stream, 1.2 million at Home Mechanix, 440,000 at Skiing and 150,000 at Yachting. **********Times Mirror already publishes four magazines - Popular Science, Ski, Golf and Outdoor Life.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/06/world.body_text: **********The security police have arrested seven people after the discovery of more than 30 pounds of explosives, two machine guns and a pistol in the cellar of a building in the 16th Arrondissement of Paris, the Interior Ministry announced today. **********The ministry said the action was carried out Wednesday by the Direction de la Surveillance du Territoire, the internal security service, during an investigation into terrorist groups. **********Interior Ministry spokesmen declined to identify the suspects or to provide any other information. **********The operation came less than a week after a court sentenced Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, the presumed head of a Lebanese terrorist group, to life imprisonment for complicity in the killing of two diplomats and the attempted murder of a third. **********It was not clear whether the latest action was related to the the case of Mr. Abdallah. Several Middle East groups have threatened to carry out terrorist attacks if he was convicted. **********Last September, supporters of Mr. Abdallah took responsibility for a series of bomb attacks in which 10 people were killed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/17/busin.main_headline: GRUMMAN TO END 1,500 JOBS ON L.I.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/17/busin.print_headline: GRUMMAN TO END 1,500 JOBS ON L.I.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/17/busin.body_text: **********Long Island's largest employer, the Grumman Corporation, said today that it planned to eliminate about 1,500 jobs in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. It is the first time in more than decade that Grumman has cut its Long Island work force. **********The reduction is part of a company-wide move to trim costs. The cuts will involve about 1,200 layoffs, the company said, with the remainder coming through attrition. The dismissed employees were not likely to be rehired later, officials added. **********''We are on a weight-reduction and muscle-building program,'' said John O'Brien, Grumman's president and chief operating officer. **********''The moves are necessary,'' he said, ''because of increasing pressure on defense budgets and increasing pressures on defense companies to be more competitive.'' The military contractor said the cutback would save it $50 million this year. **********Grumman, with a worldwide work force of 33,000, employs about 25,000 people on Long Island. Company officials said that although they were cutting the Long Island rolls by 6 percent, they expected to increase their work force in other parts of the country, including Melbourne, Fla., and Montgomery, Pa. Over all, they said, corporate employment should increase slightly or remain stable this year. **********In an interview at the company's headquarters here, Mr. O'Brien said that most of the job cuts would come in the corporation's Aircraft Systems division, which is building five types of planes, including the F-14, the Navy's principal fighter plane. **********The cuts are largely the result of a decrease in production of the F-14, to 8 planes this year from 24 in 1986. Mr. O'Brien said the sharp reduction was expected and resulted from an upgrading of the F-14, with electronic technology and a more powerful engine. **********Most of the job losses, the company said, would occur on the production lines at the company's Calverton, L.I., plant. But Mr. O'Brien added that cuts would also be made in the aircraft support services. He said he could not provide a breakdown. **********More broadly, Mr. O'Brien described today's actions ''as part of the transition of the Grumman Corporation from an airframe manufacturer to a company that focuses on outgrowths from that business,'' such as electronics and data services. 'A Tremendous Shift' **********''We are going through a tremendous shift in the skills mix that we need,'' Mr. O'Brien said. **********Grumman, which gives its employees free turkeys at Christmas, has a nonunion work force that is said to own more than a quarter of the company's stock. **********The company said it would begin notifying affected employees in the next few weeks. Those dismissed will receive severance pay based on their length of service. They also will get ''preferential consideration'' for openings elsewhere, the company said. **********But given the company's reputation for paternalism, Mr. O'Brien said the layoffs - the first since 1975-76, when the company cut nearly 2,000 workers - were ''particularly painful.'' **********Wall Street seemed noncommittal about the cutback. Grumman's stock fell 12.5 cents, to $25.625, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/20/world.body_text: **********An Israeli official who helped direct the espionage activities of Jonathan Jay Pollard in the United States told a Government commission investigating the affair that he acted with ''permission and authority,'' the newspaper Haaretz reported today. **********If the report is accurate, the testimony by the official, Rafael Eitan, directly contradicts what Israel has said since the Pollard affair started to unfold -that the incident was a ''rogue operation'' and that spying on the United States runs contrary to Israeli policy. **********Proceedings of the Cabinet-appointed commission are secret. **********A United States court sentenced Mr. Pollard to life imprisonment for stealing hundreds of classified American States documents and passing them to Israel. His wife, Anne Henderson-Pollard, received a jail sentence for her involvement in the conspiracy. **********After the Pollards were arrested, Mr. Eitan was forced out of his job as head of the scientific intelligence unit that directed Mr. Pollard's activities. He was then named to head the Israeli state chemical company. Another official involved in the affair, Col. Aviem Sella, has been placed in charge of one of Israel's largest air bases. **********Statements similar to those published today were attributed to Mr. Eitan earlier this week by another Israeli newspaper, but Mr. Eitan denied that report. The tabloid Hadashot reported on Sunday that Mr. Eitan had said: ''I will not be a victim. My superiors knew.'' The article said Mr. Eitan had told friends, ''All my actions, including the Pollard affair, were with the knowledge of those in charge.'' **********The same day, however, Mr. Eitan spoke on the Israeli radio, reading a denial of all statements attributed to him by news organizations, calling them inaccurate and damaging.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/19/busin.body_text: **********The Security Pacific Corporation said it had agreed to sell a 50 percent interest in its Japan Security Pacific Finance Company. Mitsui & Company will buy the unit for an undisclosed price. The new joint venture, with assets of $200 million, would offer consumer and commmercial loans and sell financial services.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/22/world.main_headline: New Soviet Offer on Afghan Withdrawal Reported
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/22/world.print_headline: New Soviet Offer on Afghan Withdrawal Reported
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/22/world.body_text: **********A senior State Department official disclosed today that during the summit meeting earlier this month, Mikhail S. Gorbachev made a new offer to have Soviet troops refrain from offensive combat operations during any period that is agreed upon for their withdrawal from Afghanistan. **********The official, Michael H. Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, called the offer ''positive'' and portrayed it as a step toward a formula for withdrawal that the United States would consider acceptable. Other unresolved issues include the length of time the pullout would take and the phasing of the departure of various military units, Mr. Armacost said. **********Another Administration official said the significance of Mr. Gorbachev's suggestion was not fully grasped during the summit meeting by tired Americans, who were concentrating on resolving differences in the language of a joint Soviet-American statement, which dealt mainly with arms control. The offer was not pursued.  The official said that only after notes of the conversations between Mr. Gorbachev and President Reagan were reviewed after the summit meeting did officials conclude that the Soviet leader had taken a conciliatory step. **********Still, Mr. Armacost took a cautionary tone on the implications of what Mr. Gorbachev had said. **********''He said that they would not engage in military operations, other than self-defense,'' Mr. Armacost explained. ''It's the latter, of course, that needs to be defined fairly carefully, since we all know that there's a very high level of military activity generally in Afghan society; and therefore if one's looking for an excuse, then there's always an incident to which one can refer.'' **********Nevertheless, ''I would regard it as positive in that it was something that, as far as I'm aware, they had never said before,'' Mr. Armacost said. ''It stands to reason that only a withdrawal of that kind would have any appeal, that one couldn't stand by and simply observe a withdrawal during which the Soviets attempted to use their residual power to go after the resistance.'' Protection for Soviet Units **********By the same token, other officials have portrayed the Russians as acutely interested in a commitment from the rebels not to attack withdrawing Soviet troops. **********Mr. Armacost said that there would have to be ''a detailed understanding of what is involved on their side'' before the United States could agree to put into effect its commitments under the proposed Geneva understandings. These, which are being negotiated by the United Nations between Afghanistan and Pakistan, provide for a cutoff in American aid to the Afghan rebels simultaneously with the beginning of a Soviet troop withdrawal. **********Mr. Gorbachev has spoken of a withdrawal period of 12 months or less, which the Reagan Administration feels is too long. **********''We think the withdrawal can be carried out much more promptly than that,'' Mr. Armacost said. **********In addition, he said, the United States would look at a schedule of withdrawal for various types of military units. Officials have said they do not want to see elite units left there months after the rebels' military supplies are cut off. **********Mr. Armacost's news conference was held to present a State Department report, ''Afghanistan: Eight Years of Soviet Occupation,'' that described a situation that is worsening from the Soviet viewpoint. **********''The military, political and diplomatic trends have changed in significant ways,'' Mr. Armacost said in introducing the report, ''which generally compound Soviet policy dilemmas in Afghanistan.'' **********Mr. Armacost also said that as far as American officials could determine, the proposed withdrawal would not be linked to arrangements for an interim, coalition government in Afghanistan. **********''The Soviets, in their discussions with us, did not insist upon a direct linkage between national reconciliation and withdrawal,'' he said. He noted that Najibullah, the Afghan leader, had recently indicated that a pullout could be accelerated if there is progress toward a coalition government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/25/busin.main_headline: Credit Markets; Bonds Fall On Fears of Japan Shift
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/25/busin.print_headline: Credit Markets; Bonds Fall On Fears of Japan Shift
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/25/busin.body_text: **********Reports in the Japanese press that the Bank of Japan has decided to tighten monetary policy and encourage higher short-term interest rates sent prices of Treasury bonds plummeting yesterday. **********The reports of a policy shift by the Japanese central bank came just a few days before meetings in Washington of the International Monetary Fund and finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrialized nations. An adjustment in Japanese rates could be contentious because American officials have been advocating for the last two years that Japan and West Germany adopt more stimulative monetary and fiscal policies. Trade Deficit Is a Factor **********The hope of American officials has been that faster growth in those two nations would increase the demand there for domestic and American products, helping to reduce the American trade deficit. But recent developments suggest that the Japanese authorities believe that the threat to their economy from inflation is of more concern than the American trade deficit. **********''If the report is true, it will invite a tremendous amount of criticism from U.S. authorities,'' said David Ressler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International, the New York affiliate of Japan's largest securities firm. **********Reports of the Bank of Japan's policy shift were carried by the electronic news wire service of Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a widely read and highly credible Japanese business newspaper. Stock Market Affected **********Translations of the report quickly spread through the credit markets in New York, and prices fell sharply in light trading. The bond market's weakness undermined stocks, ending the market's strong two-day rally. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 19.25 points yesterday, closing at 2,566.42.  [ Page D4. ]  Higher interest rates in Japan could lead to higher interest rates in the United States as the American financial markets strive to maintain the attractiveness of dollar-denominated investments. **********Analysts said the Bank of Japan's willingness to encourage higher short-term interest rates stems from its concerns about inflation. The inflation rate last year was zero, but consumer prices have been rising in Japan for the last five months, capped by a sharp rise of eight-tenths of 1 percent in August. Bank of Japan officials are also worried that rapid money supply growth - at a rate of 10 percent in recent months - brings with it the potential for inflation. **********Economists noted that earlier efforts by Japanese officials to encourage economic growth through stimulating domestic demand seem to be bearing fruit. The Japanese housing market is in the midst of a boom, with housing starts rising at an annual rate of more than 25 percent from April through July. **********Although overall growth of Japan's gross national product was zero in the second quarter of this year, Robert Brusca, an economist at Nikko Securities Company International, noted that domestic demand grew at an annual rate of more than 4 percent in the quarter. Need for Move Is Doubted **********Mr. Brusca and his counterpart at Nomura, Mr. Ressler, both agreed that the move to tighten monetary policy might not be needed. **********''Worldwide, I still see a situation of not much inflation, not much growth and a lot of idle resources,'' Mr. Brusca said. ''I don't see much reason to raise real interest rates, which are already high.'' **********Mr. Ressler acknowledged that domestic demand in Japan is improving, 'but not to the point where it threatens an inflationary spiral.'' **********He said the strength of the yen suggested that the world's financial markets do not see much risk of excessive inflation in Japan. He said that acceleration in Japan's money supply growth need not be inflationary, pointing to the United States' experience in 1985 and 1986, when the money supply grew by more than 13 percent annually but has not yet produced sharply higher inflation. Methods Are Detailed **********According to reports in Japan, the first step in the Bank of Japan's tighter monetary policy will be the imposition of stricter limits on growth of commercial lending, and a sharp decline in long-term lending. Coincidentally, a half-point increase, to 5.7 percent, from 5.2 percent, in the long-term prime rate of Japan's Long Term Credit Bank was announced yesterday, effective Oct. 1. **********The central bank will reportedly also tolerate an increase in short-term interest rates that is expected to occur next month with a large public stock offering by Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company. The purchase of that stock, combined with seasonal drains on bank credit in the last quarter of the year, is expected to pull about 10 trillion yen from the Japanese banking system, putting upward pressure on short-term interest rates that the Bank of Japan will not offset. **********Already rates on one-month and two-month discount bills in the Japanese money market have increased, rising about one percentage point yesterday, to about 3.8 percent. **********In the American market, the bellwether 8 7/8 percent Treasury bond due in 2017 fell more than 1 1/4 points, to 92 3/32, to yield 9.69 percent. **********''Higher rates in Japan are the last thing the U.S. markets wanted, because on top of all the other worries about the dollar and inflation, they now have to worry about narrowing interest-rate differentials,'' said Anthony Karydakis, a money market economist at the New York branch of Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. **********Another cause for worry about higher interest rates emerged early yesterday when August trade data for Britain showed a record visible trade deficit of more than $:1.5 billion. **********''The trade data suggest strength in the U.K. economy,'' noted Joseph Liro, an economist at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc. Signs that the economies of the United States, Britain, and Japan are strengthening in tandem ''add to the fears of more inflation worldwide,'' he said. **********Higher inflation, or the anticipation of higher inflation, normally brings falling bond prices as investors conclude that the purchasing power of their bonds will be reduced. Offering by Imperial Savings **********Elsewhere in the credit markets, the Imperial Savings Association is offering the first issue of notes collateralized by ''junk bonds.'' The 9 3/8 percent notes, rated triple A and due in 1990, were offered at 99.73 to yield 9.48 percent through Drexel Burnham Lambert as sole underwriter. **********The notes are collateralized by a pool of junk bonds whose market value is estimated at 175 to 180 percent of the new three-year notes. Every two weeks the value of the collateral will be evaluated by Chemical Bank, trustee for the issue. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/09/busin.body_text: **********Pressure is growing on American companies to completely sever business ties with South Africa - not just hand over local operations to South Africans. **********Guidelines issued in January by five of the principal anti-apartheid lobbying groups in this country urge the 19 states, 13 counties and 70 cities that prohibit investment of public monies in South Africa to tighten their laws - or at least their interpretation of them - to produce a nearly total ban on United States corporate contact with South Africa. **********Since most of the state and local divestment legislation is drafted in terms of ''doing business in South Africa'' or ''doing business with South Africa'' - considered relatively vague phrases - the lobbying groups' interpretation of exactly what a company must do to satisfy the laws is being widely adopted. **********Maxine Waters, a member of the California Assembly who helped frame her state's pension fund divestment bill, has promised ''to work overtime to insure that our legislation reflects these guidelines and continues to target any and all U.S. companies that are doing business in or with South Africa.'' Kodak's Example Is Noted **********Last fall several major corporations - including General Motors, I.B.M., General Electric, Coca-Cola and Kodak - announced their departure from South Africa, but only one seems to satisfy the new guidelines: the Eastman Kodak Company, which has sold its operations there and has agreed not to supply the South African market through importers. **********Under the guidelines, divesting American companies would have to forgo the franchising, licensing and management agreements that most have arranged with South African local interests. In many cases, such arrangements have been designed to avoid the political stigma of maintaining a presence in South Africa while enabling divesting companies to preserve their market share and a flow of profits from South Africa. **********With its new guidelines, the anti-apartheid lobby is demanding a complete end to arrangements that link departing American companies with their South African spin-offs. **********A number of companies, including the General Motors Corporation, have strenuously objected to the tighter interpretation. Various Remaining Links **********Most of the other companies that have announced disinvestment plans still have operations of one sort or another, such as these: *********** The Coca-Cola Company, the International Business Machines Corporation and G.M. are selling all of their South African assets, but will continue to make their product lines available to the companies buying them out. *********** The Fluor Corporation, an engineering company, has sold its operations to a European trust company, but it negotiated a buy-back clause, and it keeps 30 employees at the disposal of the new company. *********** The General Electric Company says it was ''out of South Africa as of Jan. 1, 1986,'' but says it maintains ''licensing and other arrangements for the sale of products'' there. *********** The Procter & Gamble Company sold its South African production plant and other assets last September, but it continues to ''license products'' and ''receive trademark royalties,'' a P.&G. spokesman said. **********An informal survey of officials in states and cities required by law to hold no interest in companies doing business in South Africa discloses skepticism about divestment plans. Wide Criticism of Plans **********Legislators, members of municipal boards and pension fund managers have described them variously as ''fictional,'' ''incomplete'' and ''unsatisfactory.'' And many of them say they will push the corporations to cut all ties with South Africa. **********Jennifer Davis, director of the American Committee on Africa, one of the principal pro-divestment lobbying groups, said the recent pullouts were a ''response to growing pressures here and in South Africa'' but represented corporate ''restructuring'' and not withdrawal. Ms. Davis also called the divestments an intermediate step ''intended to make a pullout easier in the future, but allowing the companies to carry out their business'' in the meantime. **********Dana Van Gorder, an aide to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, said the recent divestments of major American companies did not go far enough to make them eligible for pension fund investment or procurement contracts. Mr. Van Gorder said the divestment announcements were meant to ''circumvent'' municipal and state laws, such as San Francisco's, which bar city contracts with companies ''doing business with South Africa.'' Deadline in New Jersey **********In other states and localities, the trend is much the same. Roland Mackolin, director of the New Jersey Division of Investment, with responsibility for managing a $13 billion state pension fund portfolio, said, ''We're divesting like crazy to make the August 1988 deadline.'' By that time no state funds may be held in securities of companies ''that do business in or with South Africa.'' **********He said New Jersey had already sold $4.4 billion in securities of companies doing business with South Africa and expected $3 billion more to be sold. **********Citing the Sara Lee Corporation's acquisition of Kiwi Wax, Mr. Mackolin said his task was ''infinitely complicated'' by the takeover boom. He has to sell shares of a corporation if it buys a smaller company doing business in South Africa. **********Companies that sell their assets in South Africa but continue to provide the same goods or services through licensing arrangements are ''trying to appear clean, when in fact they are not,'' Mr. Van Gorder declared. **********More than $18 billion in securities have been sold to comply with state and local divestment legislation. In the last two years 74 United States companies have announced their withdrawal from South Africa, although most have cited declining profits, not political pressures. Pension Fund's Influence **********However, Claire M. Sheahan, a spokesman for the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association and College Retirement Equities Fund, called the $52.3 billion pension fund's pressure ''an important factor,'' adding that ''within three and a half weeks of our call'' for corporations to pull out of South Africa, ''General Motors and I.B.M. announced their divestments.'' **********Companies such as G.M. and I.B.M. are stung by criticism that they have not gone far enough. **********George Schreck, a G.M. spokesman, said his company's line of Opal and Isuzu cars will continue to be made available in South Africa through a new, locally owned company out of concern for G.M.'s ''3,000 workers and their 15,000 dependents.'' He called those who say G.M.'s divestment has not gone far enough ''irresponsible and usually not well informed.'' He said G.M.'s critics advocated ''total withdrawal, total suffering and total chaos.'' **********Other companies defend their withdrawal on the grounds that they have sold their assets to companies that have pledged to adhere to principles of racial equality in the workplace. Social Commitments Cited **********Ford Slater, a spokesman for G.E., said that while his company would continue to be linked through licensing agreements with its South African spin-off, Genwest, ''they have guaranteed they would maintain the same social commitments.'' He said that G.E. had always ''operated according to - at least - the minimum requirements of the Sullivan Principles'' and that a condition of the sale of its operations was a committment that ''Genwest continue to be guided by those principles.'' **********The Sullivan Principles are an evolving set of labor guidelines developed in 1977 by the Rev. Leon Sullivan of Philadelphia, a member of G.M.'s board of directors. **********For the last decade many companies doing business in South Africa tried to deflect criticism of their operations there by citing their pledge to follow the Sullivan Principles. As political and economic conditions have deteriorated in South Africa, however, the American anti-apartheid movement has turned to demands for divestment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/busin.main_headline: U.S. INDUSTRY IN JANUARY AT 79.7% OF CAPACITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/busin.print_headline: U.S. INDUSTRY IN JANUARY AT 79.7% OF CAPACITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/busin.body_text: **********American industry operated at 79.7 percent of capacity in January, the best showing in almost a year, as the manufacturing sector continued to provide signs that the worst of its trade problems may be ending. **********The Federal Reserve Board said today that it was the third consecutive monthly increase in the operating rate at the nation's factories, mines and utilities. The two-tenths of 1 percent January increase followed gains of one-tenth of 1 percent in December and four-tenths of 1 percent in November. **********Even with the improvement, the operating rate is still 2.1 percentage points lower than it was at the high point of this recovery in the summer of 1984. **********For the last two years, American manufacturers were forced to cut back on production and lay off employees because of increased foreign competition. But recently economists have been seeing signs that a weaker dollar is beginning to pay off for American producers, especially in higher sales abroad. **********''We are seeing a turnaround in manufacturing and it corresponds to the turnaround we are seeing in trade,'' said David Wyss, an economist at Data Resources Inc. of Lexington, Mass. ''The volume of U.S. exports has been rising at a 20 percent annual rate for the last six months.'' **********Donald Straszheim, chief economist at the New York investment firm of Merrill Lynch, said the improvement in manufacturing would be a slow process, held back by the fact that the dollar has not declined significantly against some of America's biggest trade competitors, Hong Kong, Taiwan and South Korea. **********''We have a little better data, but there is a long way to go before the manufacturing sector is healthy again,'' Mr. Straszheim said. **********The 79.7 percent operating rate in January was the best performance since American industry operated at 80.2 percent of capacity last February. It is still well below the 85 percent of capacity that many economists believe is necessary to spur increased business investment in new production facilities. For the last two decades, the operating rate has averaged 82 percent of capacity. **********The nation's manufacturers operated at 80.3 percent of capacity in January, up from 80.1 percent in December. Factories making durable goods, items expected to last three or more years, operated at 76.9 percent of capacity, while manufacturers of nondurable goods operated at 85.4 percent of capacity. **********The operating rate at the nation's mines edged up to 72.7 percent in January, compared with 72.5 percent in December, but the operating rate remained more than 14 percentage points lower than the average of the last two decades. This sector, which includes oil and gas well drilling operations, has been severely depressed because of the slump in world oil prices. **********The nation's electric and gas utilities operated at 78.4 percent of capacity in January, the same as in December.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/busin.main_headline: Saatchi Banking Plan: Is It Reaching Too Far?
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/busin.print_headline: Saatchi Banking Plan: Is It Reaching Too Far?
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/busin.body_text: **********No one could ever accuse the Saatchi & Saatchi Company of lacking ambition. It has transformed itself from an upstart London agency into the world's largest advertising company through a strategy of internal growth and voracious acquisitions, capped by last year's purchase of Ted Bates Worldwide Inc. **********Recently, Saatchi & Saatchi has branched into other business services, led by management consulting. But in the past week, it has become strikingly clear that the Saatchi brothers, Maurice and Charles, have far broader ambitions. They are now interested in buying a major bank or other financial institution. Bids for Banks Spurned **********Last weekend, it was reported that Saatchi had earlier this month discussed merging with Midland Bank P.L.C., Britain's fourth-largest commercial bank. Midland spurned the overture, saying the notion lacked ''commercial or strategic logic.'' **********Then, on Thursday, the Hill Samuel Group P.L.C., a major London merchant bank, said it had rejected an offer from Saatchi, with talks breaking off earlier in the day. Again, the absence of commercial logic to the proposed linkup was cited in declining Saatchi's advance. **********What is Saatchi up to? Its major shareholders are confused by Saatchi's efforts to plunge into the rough-and-tumble world of international banking, and their uncertainty has pushed Saatchi's stock price down 10 percent in the last week, to 590 pence a share. 'It's Just Totally Bizarre' **********In London, the Saatchi moves have been greeted with a mixture of amazement and derision. ''It's just totally bizarre,'' observed A. Gary Klesch, chairman of Quadrex Securities Ltd., a London-based investment bank. ''And the way they seem to be going around from place to place makes them look amateurish.'' **********Even big investors who own Saatchi shares and have a high regard for its chairman and acquisition picker, Maurice Saatchi, are baffled by the recent activities. ''Up to now everything Saatchi has done makes sense and has been successful, but this is highly questionable,'' one fund manager said. **********What bothers investors and analysts is that Saatchi's current business-service operations - advertising, management consulting, market research and others - seem quite different from finance. Both rely on professional skills but, unlike advertising and consulting, international finance is a capital-intensive business where success often depends on risk-taking traders. Leader in 'Globalization' **********Saatchi has been a leader in the business trend toward ''globalization,'' defined as building worldwide economies of scale in one or a few closely related businesses. Yet to many, the company's recent moves seem to stretch that principle past the breaking point. **********''Saatchi and banking do not really fit together,'' said Richard Sanderson, an analyst for Panmure Gordon & Company, a London brokerage. ''It would be a mixture of entirely alien corporate cultures.'' **********Saatchi is not making any official statements about its recent talks with London banks. However, some of its executives replied privately to the criticism. In Saatchi's view, the financial services field offers solid growth opportunites and, broadly defined, fits in with the company's existing operations. During the last few months, these executives added, Saatchi has spoken with ''several'' financial services companies, which they would not name, besides Midland and Hill Samuel. 'Informal Discussions' **********Most of these meetings amounted to ''informal discussions,'' often involving Maurice Saatchi and his counterpart at each financial institution. The talks with Midland fitted into that category, with Mr. Saatchi meeting Sir Kit McMahon, the bank's chairman, during the first week of September. **********The exception - and the only case in which Saatchi's brokers, Phillips & Drew, were involved - was Hill Samuel, with which it began discussions last Friday, shortly after the Union Bank of Switzerland had ended merger talks with the London merchant bank. **********The Saatchi executives said the merger talks with Hill Samuel broke down over the issue of price. They added that, though not engaged in merger talks with other financial institutions at this time, Saatchi would continue to look for acquisitions in banking and finance. **********Still, even people close to Saatchi find its reasoning flawed this time. One former Saatchi executive questioned the wisdom of plunging into a risky business where profits are under pressure even for the strongest, most-seasoned competitors. **********''Saatchi's has a reputation for being ambitious and smart,'' he said. ''But if it jumps into international banking now, it will be ambitious but maybe naive - and then sorry later.''
