https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/16/busin.main_headline: WHY THE U.S. LAGS IN JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/16/busin.print_headline: WHY THE U.S. LAGS IN JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/16/busin.body_text: **********The camera pans over New York Harbor, zooming in on a Japanese television star waving madly from a helicopter. Cut to the studio, where stars crowd around a shiny blue 1932 Plymouth roadster, selling for only 8,269,000 yen. **********The roadster is the first product offered on a flashy satellite home shopping show featuring mostly new American goods. For an hour and a half late this evening, Japanese television personalities pitched products ranging from the gimmicky - a custom-designed loveseat similar to the kind owned by Madonna - to the practical - brand-new Nautica windbreakers. The show's sponsors, Fuji Sankei Communications, hope this and other shows will prod Japanese to buy more foreign goods. **********Two years ago, the Japanese Government began a campaign to make the Japanese market more accessible to imports. And Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone added a personal touch at the time with a television appeal to the Japanese to buy more products from abroad. **********Recent trade statistics indicate the campaign has been succeeding, but only in part. While total imports are up in Japan, such extravaganzas as the home-shopping show may still be necessary to encourage more buying from the United States. Despite a drop in the dollar of more than 40 percent against the yen in the last year and a half, making American goods much cheaper in Japan, the country's imports from the United States have not increased dramatically. **********Imports from Europe and such newly industrializing countries as Taiwan and South Korea, meanwhile, have shown far larger gains, although measured against a smaller base. **********The explanations for the relative lag in American imports vary widely. Some Japanese blame American companies for not trying hard enough to modify their products to Japanese tastes. And yen prices of many imported goods have not gone down substantially, despite the changes in the exchange rate - for which Americans blame Japan's complex distribution system. **********American goods also face a distinct image problem in Japan. Where European goods have an image of luxury and craftmanship and Asian goods have compelling price advantages, surveys have shown that the Japanese suspect the quality of American goods. Moreover, Americans are most competitive in industrial goods, which may be harder to sell in Japan than consumer goods. American officials also say other countries have benefited from American efforts to reduce Japanese trade barriers. Technology-Transfer Problem **********''Most of the European goods are luxury items and the Asian goods are low-price items,'' one United States official in Japan said. ''As for American imports - if they're consumer goods, they don't have a brand-name image, and if they're industrial products, you get into the old problem that the Japanese want you to hand over the technology to a joint-venture partner and produce it here.'' **********Trade statistics released by the United States Commerce Department on Thursday showed that American exports to Japan continued to increase in March, rising to $2.14 billion, from $2.03 billion in February. **********Over all, in dollar terms, Japanese statistics show that Japan bought 12.6 percent more foreign goods from the United States in 1986 than in 1985. But that increase is surpassed by many of Japan's other trading partners. Imports from the European Community were up 57.3 percent, from South Korea 29.3 percent, from Taiwan 38.5 percent and from Hong Kong 39.9 percent. **********An extensive analysis of Japanese imports released this week by the Japan External Trade Organization sheds light on some of these trends. **********The Jetro report focused on manufactured goods imports, where Japan has lagged other industrial nations. Excluding imports of gold, which soared last year because Japan issued a special gold coin commemorating the 60th year of Emperor Hirohito's reign, Japanese bought 5.2 percent more manufactured goods from the United States, 47.7 percent more from the European Community and 37.6 percent from Asian newly industrializing countries, particularly Taiwan, South Korea and Hong Kong. Far Smaller Percentage Imported **********Although Japan's total imports of manufactured goods increased by a hefty 31.4 percent, the Jetro report pointed out that Japan still imported a far smaller percentage of manufactured goods than other leading industrial nations. While manufactured goods now account for about 40 percent of Japan's total imports, a record level for Japan, they account for 70 percent of West German imports and more than 80 percent of United States imports. **********Because of the dramatic shifts in exchange rates over the last year, import totals calculated in terms of dollars can be somewhat misleading. For example, some of the increase in European goods can be explained in currency terms - the dollar fell against most European currencies, making the European import totals appear larger in dollar terms. In yen terms, imports from Europe increased by 11.9 percent. **********In terms of actual products, Japanese are buying more cars and luxury goods from Europe and more parts and other manufactured products from their Asian industrial neighbors. While imports of American goods have not gone up so substantially, sales of such products as almonds, California wine, tractors and newsprint have picked up. **********Neither the American Chamber of Commerce nor the American Embassy's commercial section, however, could offer an example of an American company where sales had increased dramatically in the last year because of the exchange-rate shifts. Grapefruits and Lemons **********Department store sales also reflect these trends. At Takashimaya, one of Japan's leading department stores, sales of imported goods increased by 30 percent from 1985 and are expected to increase more than 20 percent this year, according to Mitsunobu Ochiai, chief of Takashimaya's foreign department. Customers bought the most products from France, then Italy and then the United States, he said. American goods selling well include grapefruits and lemons, bourbon, chinaware and aluminum cookers. **********But Mr. Ochiai said few foreign companies were willing to modify their products enough to sell in Japan. ''American and European companies do approach us, but when we request a change in goods to match Japanese consumers' tastes, they say their product is original,'' he said. ''For example, American and European companies do not accept our request to change dress patterns in order to make them fit better to Japanese bodies. They say our order is too small for them to increase the steps in the manufacturing process. It is too bad, because their designs are good.'' **********American businessmen here insist they are making enormous efforts to adapt their products to Japanese tastes and point to the success of many American companies - among them, Mister Donut, which has changed its doughnut recipe to make them less sweet here. **********One reason sales of some imports have not shot up may be that retail prices have not dropped dramatically. Wholesale import prices dropped 38.4 percent between September 1985 and this March, according to the Economic Planning Agency. There are no statistics available on average retail prices, but price cuts are thought to be far smaller. **********Foreign exporters blame Japan's distribution system, in which Japanese middlemen keep much of the exchange rate savings. At the same time, however, many foreign companies do not want to cut prices substantially, partly to make up for profits squeezed when the dollar was strong. **********Many importers have found that Japanese expect to pay top prices for foreign goods and fear that cutting prices too much might strip products of their cachet. In one often-cited example, importers of Johnnie Walker Black Scotch whisky, a popular and expensive gift in Japan, found consumers far less eager to buy the less-expensive Johnnie Walker Red whisky. **********There are, nonetheless, some encouraging signs on the horizon. The strong yen, for example, is causing the Honda Motor Company to begin ''reimporting'' motorcycles produced in Italy into Japan and to consider re-importing passenger cars produced in the United States, although no final decision has been made. **********At the satellite home shopping show, within two hours, two of the 11 Japanese cities in which the program was televised had reported sales to phone bidders of more than $1 million worth of merchandise. There were 29 bids for the $59,000 Plymouth roadster - a raffle will later determine the winner.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/busin.main_headline: Snuffing Out Smoking in the Office
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/busin.print_headline: Snuffing Out Smoking in the Office
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/busin.body_text: **********FOR the past 15 years, Charles L. Wrye has kept on his desk a sign that says, politely, ''Thank You for Not Smoking.'' An avid antismoker, he long ago decided that even though he has no right to force others to stop smoking, he does have the right to make his own work space smoke-free. **********This month, as editor and publisher of Successful Meetings magazine in New York, Mr. Wrye went a few steps further. Under growing pressure from many of his 35 employees, he restricted smoking to certain areas of the office - a policy intended to pacify the nonsmokers without overly angering the smokers. **********Mr. Wrye's middle-of-the-road resolution of the problem is typical of the approach taken by a number of companies over the past two years as employee pressure mounted to restrict smoking. Some 38 percent of employers have put smoking policies into place since 1985, according to a survey last year by the Bureau of National Affairs. The ''flexible'' guidelines established a year ago at Eastman Kodak, for example, have been typical of corporate America's solution to the smoking problem. The employees who will be affected vote on whether smoking will be permitted in conference rooms and classrooms. If it's a close call, supervisors help individual work groups compromise. ''Each company unit has the responsibility to designate smoking and nonsmoking areas,'' said Henry Kaska, public information director. ''When the preferences of nonsmokers and smokers conflict, the supervisors must work it out. When that's not possible, the preference of the nonsmoker prevails.'' **********Where smoking is permitted at Kodak, individuals may designate their offices as nonsmoking areas. In the cafeterias and lounges, nonsmoking areas are periodically re-evaluated to make sure they meet demand. The company maintains that these flexible rules have worked just fine: ''In 99.9 percent of the cases we've had no problem,'' Mr. Kaska said. **********Nevertheless, the toleration for smokers among executive policy makers is beginning to fade - particularly since last December when the Surgeon General reported that involuntary inhalation of smoke from other people's cigarettes can cause disease in healthy nonsmokers. That report appears to establish a basis for corporate liabililty, and some companies' policies are shifting from the democratic to the draconian. Last month, prompted by the discovery that materials used in some of its plants could be especially hazardous to smokers, the U.S.G. Corporation announced that workers could be dismissed unless they stopped smoking both on and off the job. IN FACT, the few companies that have tried total bans have sometimes been pleased with the results. James Tiffany, executive vice president of Lovejoy-Tiffany & Associates Inc., said he encountered few problems with the employee-initiated ban on smoking in his Ann Arbor, Mich., office, which has 30 employees. ''I had one person come up to me and say she would never have taken the job had she realized that there would be a nonsmoking policy,'' Mr. Tiffany said. ''But she is still working for us a year and a half later. Recently, I offered a chain smoker a job. When she learned of our policy, she took an extra day to consider the offer, but she did accept it.'' **********One company that has tried both a moderate and a complete ban on smoking - Pacific Northwest Bell, in Washington - says that smoke-free is the only way to go. In 1983, after studying the smoking issue and surveying its employees, Pacific Northwest Bell announced a flexible policy for its 750 office buildings. ''Basically, we said that there would be no smoking in training and conference rooms,'' recalled Leonard D. Beil, director of human resources planning. ''We adjusted the employee cafeteria from 20 percent seating for nonsmokers to 65 percent, and we left it up to individual work groups to determine smoking and nonsmoking areas. We also initiated a smoking cessation program for employees.'' **********But the policy didn't work. Even if the smokers observed the limits, the smoke itself did not. ''If one work group took a vote and 59 percent of the people agreed there should be smoking, you'd still have 41 percent who were bothered by smoke,'' Mr. Beil explained. ''Then there was the problem of smokers who bordered nonsmoking districts. Their smoke would drift over.'' **********After studying the problem further, the company decided to go smoke-free in all buildings. ''In addition, we agreed to pay for employees, their spouses and their dependents to attend any program - hypnosis, acupuncture, behavior modification -that would help them stop smoking,'' Mr. Beil said.  He concedes that some smokers do not like the ban, and that many people go outside the buildings to smoke. But of the 15,000 employees affected, not one has quit because of the policy and no lawsuits have been filed. **********The companies most likely to have official policies are in locations where workplace smoking laws are already in effect, according to the Human Resources Policy Corporation. About 10 states, including Connecticut and New Jersey, have some form of no-smoking legislation that applies to the private sector. **********But as complaints from nonsmokers turn into crusades, states and cities are tightening the old rules and issuing new ones. This month, for example, the New York State Public Health Council produced the toughest restrictions yet on lighting up in public. The council's regulations, which go into effect in May, prohibit smoking in any enclosed work area occupied by more than one person unless that area is occupied exclusively by smokers. Further, there will be no smoking in auditoriums, classrooms, meeting rooms, elevators, hallways, restrooms, medical facilities and most areas of public buildings. **********The tough new rules have provoked plenty of opposition. The Tobacco Institute, the industry's trade group, insists that laws that prohibit workers from smoking in offices or factories promote discrimination. Is it fair, the Institute asks, that a person with a private office is allowed to smoke but the typing pool and others in shared work spaces are not? **********But it is not just the tobacco industry that is objecting to the restrictions. Some companies see legislation as unnecessary because they do not perceive a problem in their offices. **********For example, the General Foods Corporation, which has its headquarters in Rye Brook, N.Y., may be forced to issue a smoking policy under the state's new restrictions. But Cliff Sessions, manager of corporate affairs, said there really was no need for one. ''Smoking has never been seen as a problem because of the spaciousness and ventilation of our offices,'' he said. **********Still, the Surgeon General's December report has sharpened corporate fears about health-related suits from nonsmokers. Adin C. Goldberg, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Spengler, Carlson, Gubar, Brodsky & Frischling, says this concern is justified. ''In terms of limiting liability, setting a corporate policy is probably the best way to go now,'' he advised. Mr. Goldberg cited a recent ruling by the Washington State Court of Appeals permitting a woman to sue her employer for negligence when she developed pulmonary disease after being exposed to what she claimed was environmental smoke from her co-workers' cigarettes. **********The U.S.G. Corporation introduced its absolute ban on smoking after the company discovered that mineral fibers used in nine of its acoustical-products plants could have adverse health effects, especially on smokers. Opponents say the action raises troubling questions about enforcement and smokers' rights outside the workplace. U.S.G. will give pulmonary function tests, electrocardiograms and X-rays to all employees periodically, but the company says the results will not be used to single out cheaters. ''We won't really be able to tell whether someone is smoking outside the workplace or not,'' said Paul Colitti, a company spokesman. ''We will have to rely on the employees' honor and their common sense.'' **********Athena Mueller, general counsel for Action on Smoking and Health (ASH), in Washington, D.C., foresees no adverse consequences to companies that adopt stern measures. ''We have lists of the companies that have instituted partial or full bans on smoking and, to our knowledge, not one has ever been challenged,'' she said. **********Another factor prompting action on the part of corporations is evidence that smokers cost money, Ms. Mueller said. In particular, she cited a Seattle University study reporting that individual smokers cost their employers up to $4,000 a year more than nonsmokers in lost time, absenteeism, medical expenses, insurance and property damage. **********How a company communicates a smoking policy seems to have a great bearing on how well it is accepted by employees. Joe Conlin, a senior editor with Successful Meetings, first heard about the magazine's new smoking policy when a fellow staff member plunked a smoke-absorbing ashtray on his desk. He was not pleased. ''Because of the way I found out, my first instinct was to throw the ashtray in a drawer and defy the rules,'' Mr. Conlin said. ''But then my mature side won out and I decided to use it. I think that most smokers will compromise when approached reasonably.'' **********Ms. Mueller of ASH agrees: ''We've seen quite a lot of support for smoking policies from smokers. We have found that 80 percent of all smokers want to quit. They appreciate it when companies do things to help them.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/08/busin.main_headline: CORPORATE PRESSURES SLOWING GIFTS TO CHARITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/08/busin.print_headline: CORPORATE PRESSURES SLOWING GIFTS TO CHARITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/08/busin.body_text: **********Corporate giving to charities is leveling off or even declining as oil companies and other traditional big contributors scale back because of restructuring pressures. **********The trend, reflected in two surveys, could be damaging for many of the country's 350,000 nonprofit organizations that look to companies for support of their activites in education, the arts and a range of human services. **********Many beneficiary organizations say they also are troubled by long-term signs of declining support from the business world. Some worry that leaders who were pacesetters in encouraging corporate involvement are being replaced by executives likely to give such programs a lower priority. **********These are uncertain times for fund-raisers as companies reposition themselves in the wake of mergers and buyouts, said Brian O'Connell, president of the Independent Sector, the country's largest philanthropic coalition representing foundations, corporations and national nonprofit organizations. **********''I hear enough concerns about corporate leadership's commitment both from former C.E.O.'s and present C.E.O.'s, so I have to believe something out there needs turning around,'' he said. **********William S. Woodside, executive committee chairman of the Primerica Corporation, formerly American Can, said the new crop of corporate managers was so engrossed in survival issues that ''it becomes positively un-American to look at anything except their own bottom line.'' **********This single-minded drive for profits, he said, was ''one of the negatives that has come out of the dramatic restructuring of American business in the past few years.'' **********In its annual survey, the Conference Board, a business research organization, found that corporate contributions in 1986 declined for the first time in 15 years. On the basis of responses from 439 companies, which represent 40 percent of total corporate giving, the survey, issued late in March, put the drop at 2.5 percent. **********Assessing the responses, Anne Klepper, director of the Conference Board's Contributions Management Institute, said: ''The heavy hitters - the multimillion-dollar givers - may have peaked in their contributions. But some companies, those in food, finance, pharmaceuticals and telecommunications, are riding the up escalator even as oil and steel are on the down. Hopefully, the medium-sized givers hovering around the $1 million mark will expand their programs and make up for the big-bucks cuts.'' 2d Survey Sees Gain A somewhat more positive outlook of corporate philanthropy came from ''Giving USA,'' the annual report by the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel, which agreed that increased support by smaller companies helped offset the losses. According to the Counsel's data, issued in May, the countrywide total of corporate giving actually increased modestly, by 2.5 percent, in 1986. **********Still, both studies suggest that the outlook is no longer as rosy as it was two or three years ago, when many fund-raisers praised corporate giving as the fastest-growing source of philanthropy.philanthropy. **********The fund-raisers, in their enthusiasm to win company support, seemed to forget that corporate giving has never accounted for more than 5 percent of private philanthropy, and that the overwhelming share continues to come from individuals. **********According to data from the Counsel, private donations to charities last year totaled $87.22 billion. Of this total, individuals contributed $71.72 and another $5.8 billion came from bequests. Companies contributed $4.5 billion and foundations $5.1 billion. For years, corporate and foundation giving has been almost equal. In 1986, helped by the bull market, foundations forged ahead. Oil Industry Cutbacks **********For some traditional big contributors, such as the oil producers, retrenchment has meant radical reductions in donations. The Arco Foundation, created by the Atlantic Richfield Company, cut its grant budget from a peak of $36.8 million in 1983 to $11.2 million this year. ''The challenge for us,'' said Eugene R. Wilson, president, ''was to cut but not become trivial.'' **********He said the foundation took a hard look at demographic data in its primary base of operations in the Southwest, taking note of rapid increases in Hispanic and Asian residents and the rising birth rates of minorities, and now concentrates more on education to curb school dropouts, and the improvement of urban schools and specialized job training. **********Analysts at the Independent Sector say it is remarkable that corporate giving has held up as well as it has in the face of declining profits and foreign competition. ''It also is understandable,'' Mr. O'Connell said, that business leaders concerned about staff layoffs, plant closures and other disturbing developments, are giving less attention to philanthropy. ''But there is a real danger that if the new crop of C.E.O.'s concentrates exclusively and too long on these top priorities, company contribution programs will be neglected,'' he said. Social Issues Stressed **********But Mr. Woodside of Primerica cautions against focusing too much attention on the money contributed by the business community while underestimating the impact that corporate leaders can exercise on social issues. ''Concerned leadership can have more impact than a few percentage points' increase in corporate giving,'' he said. **********When he was succeeded by Gerald Tsai Jr. at American Can earlier this year, Mr. Woodside was asked to continue directing the company's foundation. **********''I wish more retiring executives in my kind of position still directed company foundations,'' he said. ''But even then, the C.E.O. has to be at least sympathetic and supportive or nothing happens.'' 'Greed Is In' **********There is no question that there is an altered ''attitudinal atmosphere'' in the country today, says Andrew C. Sigler, chief executive of the Champion International Company. In 1981, he led a Business Roundtable group that produced a landmark - and controversial - policy statement that maintained that corporations, along with providing goods and services for profit, also had a social responsibility toward the community. **********Mr. Sigler said: ''Ten years ago the pressures on me were to see that Champion did more for the community. But the world has changed. Today, greed is in and we are told greed and intolerance are good for the country and for the company. But I don't see it that way.'' He said that company leaders had a stake in speaking out on issues such as housing, education and child care and encouraging their employees to volunteer for community activities. **********The surge of hostile takeovers and leveraged buyouts is one of the ''worst developments I have seen,'' he said. **********T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman who is a leading figure in recent takeovers, said: ''I don't pat myself on the back or build monuments to myself the way others do for giving away the company's money. Company giving has to be related to the company's interests; not be a gift to the ballet because my wife likes ballet.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/11/world.main_headline: 'Der Erich' Welcomed Home by a Saar Town
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/11/world.print_headline: 'Der Erich' Welcomed Home by a Saar Town
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/11/world.body_text: **********Erich Honecker, who has dedicated his major efforts as the East German leader to keeping the two Germanys separate, made an emotional visit today to his dowdy hometown in the Saar Valley. **********Now 75 years old, Mr. Honecker was a Communist youth leader in his 20's when the Nazis entered Saarland and he was forced to flee the country. He eventually made his way to Berlin and was imprisoned soon after by the Nazis. Mr. Honecker was freed by the Russians after a decade in prison. He returned here twice for brief visits after the war, but never after the two Germanys were formed in 1949. **********In comparison with the pomp and formality of his official visits to Bonn and to industrial centers on the Rhine, the visit to the Saar Valley, a former center of mining and steel production that has fallen on hard times, was heavy with sentiment and nostalgia. **********About 200 townspeople, heavily outnumbered by policemen and reporters, broke into polite applause from behind police lines as Mr. Honecker's motorcade pulled up to No. 88 on Kuchenberg Street, a plain green-stucco house built by Mr. Honecker's grandfather, a worker at the now-defunct Neunkirchen ironworks. **********Mr. Honecker's sister, Gertrud Hoppstadter, a 69-year-old widow, still lives there. Mr. Honecker walked through to the backyard, where he plucked an apple and shook some neighbors' hands before going in for a private visit. **********He and his sister then went off to visit the graves of their parents. The cemetery had been sealed off to the public and the press several hours before, and the police took care that Mr. Honecker would be out of range of cameras when he approached the black marble stone, ringed by neatly planted begonias and marked ''Family of Wilhelm Honecker.'' **********In an official visit dominated by the conflicting myths and images of a divided nation, the trip to the Saar region seemed particularly ironic. Here was a Communist leader responsible for throwing up the most infamous barrier between East and West, one moreover who has fervently rejected any notion of ever reuniting Germany, emotionally affirming a most personal link to West Germany. **********His hosts, however, seemed determined to make Mr. Honecker feel at home. On Wednesday night, at a private dinner in Saarbrucken with Oskar Lafontaine, the Socialist leader of Saarland state, Mr. Honecker was treated to Saar specialties and heard the Karlsberg Brewery choir sing the song ''To the Homeland I Return.'' **********To most of the townspeople who gathered outside his house, it was ''der Erich'' or ''Honny'' paying a call home in his old age, like so many others who left the area after its mines and ironworks began to close down. The giant complex in Neunkirchen, where both of Mr. Honecker's grandfathers worked, was shut eight years ago, leaving a ghostly tangle of giant rusted stacks and pipes hanging over the town, which is adjacent to Wiebelskirchen. A Schoolmate Remembers **********One of those who stayed behind was Mr. Honecker's schoolmate Erich Muller, also 75. He had been in the Communist youth organization and remembered Mr. Honecker as a ''good comrade - sincere and loyal.'' **********The small West German Communist Party posted portraits of Mr. Honecker around Wiebelskirchen with the message that has formed something of a refrain in his speeches, ''Never again war from Germany.'' **********A pub and a pizzeria near the Honecker house paid him something of a wittier tribute. The pub offered a ''Honny Special,'' made with Gorbachev vodka, fruit juice and apple wine, while the pizzeria offered a Honecker Pizza with extra red peppers. To make it spicier? the chef was asked. ''No, to make it redder,'' he said. **********Mr. Honecker had begun the day with a visit to the ancient city of Trier, where he laid 50 roses at a bust of Marx and visited Marx's house. In the guest book, he wrote of his sense of pride that Marx's ideas had been ''successfully developed'' in East Germany. **********Several small groups of demonstrators clustered on a square near the house, one holding a banner depicting Marx asking, ''Erich, what have you turned me into?'' Few There to Greet Him **********But as elsewhere along Mr. Honecker's route through West Germany, the ranks of both the demonstrators and the public were thin, especially when compared to the enormous buildup to the visit and the heavy coverage given it by the West German press. Most of the people who turned up, moreover, said they came out of curiosity, and not out of a sense of history in the making or concern over the issues at stake. **********Many of those met in various towns seemed to hope that the visit would bring some improvement in cross-border travel to East Germany and in the lives of the East Germans, but almost no one thought reunification was a practical possibility. A poll on the television program ''Report'' found that of 1,000 Germans questioned about the possibility of reunification, only 8 percent were positive, 58 percent said it was hardly possible, 33 percent said it was impossible. **********The findings seemed to confirm that the visit was less a breakthrough in relations than an affirmation that the relations of the two Germanys, 38 years after they became separate states, had found a practical form that no longer raised potent emotions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/01/busin.snippet: LEAD: ON Aug. 15, 1971, President Nixon announced that the United States would scrap the 1944 Bretton Woods agreement, which tied international currency rates to the dollar.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/01/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: ON Aug. 15, 1971, President Nixon announced that the United States would scrap the 1944 Bretton Woods agreement, which tied international currency rates to the dollar. **********ON Aug. 15, 1971, President Nixon announced that the United States would scrap the 1944 Bretton Woods agreement, which tied international currency rates to the dollar. **********Almost immediately, three men at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange had an inspiration: If international currencies were going to fluctuate in relation to the dollar, they could be traded on an exchange.in relation to the dollar, they could be traded on an exchange. **********Thus, in the tumultuous commodity pits of Chicago, financial futures were born. **********Leo Melamed, at the time the youngest chairman in the history of the Merc, Everette B. Harris, the Merc's politically astute president and Mark J. Powers, its first economist, quickly grasped that such currency trading could be a tremendous boon to the second-largest commodities exchange. (The Chicago Board of Trade is the biggest.) With a masterful combination of bravado and persistent salesmanship, Mr. Melamed and Mr. Harris spent nine months convincing their skeptical membership that trading money as a commodity was a good idea. Many Merc members passed up the chance to pay $100 for the privilege of trading in this new market-within-the Merc, called the International Monetary Market, or IMM. **********The Merc trio hired Milton Friedman, then an economist at the University of Chicago, to write a study on the subject. Mr. Friedman, report, ''The Need for Futures Markets in Currencies,'' was widely read by exchange officials. Within two weeks of the paper's publication, Illinois regulators gave the Merc permission to trade currency futures in the IMM. The Merc began the trading on May 16, 1972. **********Almost immediately, the currency futures stirred controversy. Large banks and foreign-exchange dealers were stunned by the idea that Midwestern pork-belly traders could buy and sell futures on foreign currencies. Currency trading had been dominated by an international coterie of bankers and dealers. **********Even later, in 1975, when the Chicago Board of Trade followed the Merc with Ginnie Mae futures, traditional currency traders weren't used to the idea. ''They looked at us as a bunch of grain traders,'' said Richard L. Sandor, a former chief economist for the C.B.O.T. and now a senior vice president at Drexel Burham Lambert Inc. ''They didn't believe Chicago's exchanges had the human capital, the talent, to trade financial futures.'' **********Back when the Merc started the IMM, some people simply thought Chicago had pulled a fast one on the financial world. And the man most obviously responsible was Leo Melamed. **********Mr. Melamed, whose family fled Poland in 1939, had joined the Merc in the early 1950's as a $25-a-week runner for Merrill Lynch. Once described as someone who could pass you in a revolving door after you had stepped in first, Mr. Melamed became the leader of a group known as The Young Turks - a group that took control of the Merc's board of directors in 1969. **********Mr. Melamed, who became Merc chairman that same year, was perhaps the most outspoken champion of financial futures, often working the floor of the Merc to push the IMM. ''He had an uncanny ability to persuade people to do something right by persuading them it was in their self-interest,'' said Mr. Harris. Said Mr. Powers: ''He's a master manipulator; he sells hopes and dreams.'' **********Under Mr. Melamed's leadership, the Merc, an ancestor of the Chicago Butter and Egg Board, aggressively challenged its rival, the C.B.O.T., with a dizzying array of new commodities. **********The list kept lengthening. Mr. Powers, who had written his Ph.D. thesis on pork belly futures, helped introduce futures contracts on a range of currencies - everything from British pounds and Canadian dollars to Mexican pesos and Dutch guilders. According to Bob Tamarkin, author of ''The New Gatsbys,'' a book about Chicago's commodity traders, the number of foreign currency contracts nearly tripled between 1972 and 1973. **********In 1974, the day that private ownership of gold was legalized, the Merc began trading in gold futures. In 1975, it initiated trading in Treasury bill futures. **********The same year, Congress set up the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to regulate the industry. The C.F.T.C. was given the job of defining what a commodity was. That set the stage for trading ''intangible'' commodities, such as stock index futures. **********In 1982, the Kansas City Board of Trade petitioned the C.F.T.C. to allow it to trade futures based on the Value Line Index of stocks. Instead of a buyer or seller actually taking delivery of the commodity - the way commodities had been long defined - Missouri exchange officials proposed that trades of stock index futures be settled with cash. Within months, other exchanges seized on the idea. A Merc contribution: The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index future, now by far the most popular index future.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/busin.body_text: **********Two prominent policy makers told the Securities Industry Association convention here today that they favored repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act under certain circumstances. The brokers seemed to take the idea in stride. **********The Glass-Steagall Act, which has separated banks and brokerages since 1933, has long been a staple on the securities group's agenda. But lately attempts to repeal provisions of the law have gained momentum. **********David S. Ruder, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said that he had not yet taken a final position but that so long as banks engage in brokerage activities through separate affilates subject to S.E.C. regulation, the commission would look carefully at such legislation. Three such bills are before Congress. Fed Official Favors Change **********Later in the conference, E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said he, too, favors change. **********''I do believe the near-term agenda should include repeal or substantial modification of the Glass-Steagall Act so long as it is reciprocal and does contain appropriate supervisory safeguards,'' said Mr. Corrigan, who in general believes brokerages and banks should be treated more consistently. **********In a news conference before his formal address, Mr. Ruder explained that he previously had some concerns about whether allowing banks to engage in brokerage activities might create serious conflicts of interest. For instance, would a bank with a brokerage subsidiary be reluctant to lend money to the subsidiary's competitors. And in a crisis, would the bank withhold credit because it was already losing money in the business. Concerns Alleviated **********''My concerns in that regard have been substantially alleviated,'' Mr. Ruder said. He added that bankers had reassured him that their willingness to lend would be unrelated to their own brokerage activities. **********Many brokers in the past weeks had pointed to First Options of Chicago, an options clearing subsidiary of the Continental Illinois Bank, which lost $90 million in the market plunge in October, saying it showed why banks do not belong in their backyard. But Mr. Ruder indicated that First Options had not changed his thinking. **********Mr. Ruder also said he believed the securities industry was ''healthy'' but proposed that a pool of emergency capital provided by a wide range of parties could address some of the liquidity problems exposed in October. In a crisis, troubled firms could tap the fund. **********But John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said in his own news conference that his constituents would oppose putting money into a pool over which they had little control. Potential Conflicts **********''Most of the member firms do not like that idea,'' Mr. Phelan said. He said these firms would rather buy specialist firms that get into trouble as a way of infusing capital into the system. Historically, investment firms have not owned specialist firms because of potential conflicts between underwriting and market-making functions, as well as large upfront capital commitments. **********''I think it's wonderful idea,'' said Louis Miceli Jr., a specialist on the American Stock Exchange, referring to the pool. ''Will it ever happen? No way. If they do that, I'm going to buy a Ferrari; why worry about capital.'' **********The debate about the need for more capital could not have been less academic. Even while Mr. Ruder addressed reporters, the hotel was buzzing about Shearson Lehman Brothers' imminent purchase of E. F. Hutton and Drexel Burnham Lambert's planned purchase of Carl H. Pforzheimer & Company, a specialist firm. **********Those two deals and this week's announcement by Paine Webber that it had agreed to sell an equity interest to a Japanese insurance company all reflect the continued blurring of lines between classes of financial players as firms hungrily seek capital. Inevitable Mergers **********''Those kinds of mergers are inevitable,'' Mr. Phelan said. **********Though the industry's official position has not changed, many brokers expressed little resistance to talk of change. John S. Chalsty, president of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and a new director of the securities group, said he understood the concern of his peers about additional competition from the banks, but he was not worried about the impact on his firm. **********''We neither welcome nor resist it,'' he said. ''If Glass-Steagall was repealed we'd continue business as usual.'' He cited his firm's ability to find profitable niches in the municipal finance area in the past in spite of competition from larger brokerages and, to a limited degree, from banks. **********Mr. Ruder also urged the conferees not to pare back office operations in their haste to retrench. He said the commission received double the usual number of complaints from investors about market malfunctions in past months. In that vein, Mr. Phelan announced new efforts to upgrade the exchange's ability to handle heavy trading volume like that seen in October. **********''History tells us it will happen again,'' Mr. Phelan said. In addition to the $200 million the exchange has spent over the last five years on capital improvements, the exchange's board has pledged another $200 million over the next five years. **********The Big Board has also formed an advisory committee to coordinate efforts to improve trading and communication throughout Wall Street. Until October, the exchange was not expecting 600 million-share days until 1991. **********''Nineteen ninety-one arrived in 1987,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/25/busin.main_headline: AD FIRMS FIND LOWER WEST SIDE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/25/busin.print_headline: REAL ESTATE; AD FIRMS FIND LOWER WEST SIDE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/25/busin.body_text: **********GEER DUBOIS INC., an advertising agency, was considered a daring pioneer when it left midtown in 1981 in search of moderate rents on lower Fifth Avenue. But within five years it had been joined by more than two dozen other advertising agencies. **********Now there are unmistakable signs that the advertising industry is laying claim to another part of Manhattan, an emerging office district on the Lower West Side, which lies at the western edge of Greenwich Village, north of the Holland Tunnel. **********Earlier this month Della Femina, Travisano & Partners signed a deal for 122,000 square feet of space in a building at 350 Hudson Street, between King and Charles Streets, that until recently housed printers and graphic artists. Ephron, Raboy, Tsao & Kurnit Advertising Inc. signed a deal in February for 16,5000 square feet across the street in the former loft building at 345 Hudson. **********Della Femina, Travisano is giving up about 74,000 square feet in the Nabisco Brands building at 625 Madison Avenue at 59th Street, and Ephron, Raboy will leave its 7,000 square feet in 800 Third Avenue at 50th Street. The Hudson Street buildings are owned by Trinity Real Estate, the real estate arm of Trinity Church. **********Although Jameson Advertising moved from 750 Third Avenue to 13,000 square feet in a building at 96 Morton Street last year, Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Worldwide, one of the largest ad agencies, is credited with blazing the trail to the Lower West Side. **********In 1985 the company, which is based in London, agreed to take nearly half the space in the 884,200-square-foot office structure being built at 375 Hudson Street, between West Houston and King Streets, by Tishman Speyer Properties. According to Mitchell Rudin, leasing director for the project, Saatchi & Saatchi has since signed for two more floors in the building, bringing its total there to 510,000 square feet. The company, which expects to move into its space by late summer, will not use all of it immediately, however. It is now negotiating with another advertising agency to take some of the space on a sublet basis. **********The relatively low cost of space in the area is its main drawing card. **********''Madison Avenue is second only to Park Avenue in terms of rents in midtown,'' said Stephen Fredericks of Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate brokerage company. ''Midtown rents are in the high $30's a square foot even in older buildings. Advertising agencies are extraodinarily conscious of operating costs because their revenues are so unpredictable. So they have not been a dominant tenant on Madison for quite some time.'' **********Cathie Payne, director of administration for Della Femina, Travisano, said that if the agency had renewed its lease in the Madison Avenue building the cost of its space would have nearly doubled. **********The asking price for space in the new Tishman Speyer building is in the ''high $20's'' per square foot and Trinity Real Estate is asking $22 a foot for renovated space in its bulding at 350 Hudson Street. But some renovated space in the area, mainly in smaller side street structures below Canal Street, is going for $16.50 a foot. **********Trinity Real Estate, the dominant property owner in the area, started to upgrade its loft buildings a few years ago as it watched SoHo and TriBeCa emerge as strong residential and commercial neighorboods and as the traditional boundaries of the financial district pushed north and west. **********''The location of these loft buildings is their most valuable asset,'' said Walter F. Spardel, managing director of Trinity Real Estate's 27 properties. ''But they have high ceilings and 250-pound floors that allow traditional office use as well as companies that have heavy computer needs.'' **********Trinity, which is calling the new office neighborhood Hudson Square, has already put several office tenants in the building at 345 Hudson Street and is renovating the 275,000-square-foot building at 350 Hudson Street. The modernization of the 1927 building will include new mechanical systems, new windows and a new granite and marble lobby. In addition to the Della Femina, Travisano lease, Trinity has signed a deal with the Athenian West Corporation to operate a restaurant in 4,500 square feet of ground floor space. **********Della Femina, Travisano expects to move 300 people into the fifth through the eighth floors of the building. In addition, Trinity is building a 17,000-square-foot ninth floor penthouse for the company's executive offices. **********Trinity Real Estate and Tishman Speyer are not the only developers in the area. Among other companies preparing office space on the Lower West Side are the Urban Land Corporation, which has properties at 250 West Street, near Watts Street, and at 11 Beach Street, between Hudson and Greenwich Streets, and B. F. Development, which has two small buildings at 375 and 377 Greenwich Street, near Moore Street. **********''Now that prices on lower Fifth Avenue and Park Avenue South, which used to be the reasonable office neighborhoods, have moved to the $25-to-$28 range,'' Mr. Fredericks said, ''the Lower West Side offers some of the best deals in Manhattan.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/15/busin.body_text: **********Beginning work on a compromise bill to raise $9 billion in taxes next year, House and Senate conferees agreed today to $1.8 billion in individual and corporate tax changes, including an extension of the expiring 3 percent excise tax on local and long-distance telephone service. **********The seven tax changes approved today, which are virtually certain to become law, also included proposals that would make overnight camp no longer eligible for the child care credit, and extend Social Security payroll taxes to money earned by inactive-duty reservists, farmhands and children and spouses who work in a family business. **********Another change would make restaurateurs and other employers pay Social Security taxes on cash tips earned by waiters, bartenders and other service employees. **********The action came as two separate groups of Congressional negotiators numbering in the hundreds began to work out the differences between the House and the Senate versions of the legislation needed to put into effect the budget compromise reached last month between Congressional leaders and President Reagan. **********One bill, the $606 billion catch-all appropriations bill, includes $7.6 billion of spending cuts agreed to in the compromise. The second bill includes the tax increases, and about $17 billion of Government ''user fees,'' the sale of Federal assets and cuts in Medicare, the health care program for the elderly, and farm programs. **********The seven tax changes approved today were provisions that were common to separate bills previously approved by the House of Representatives and the Senate. The one corporate change approved today would deny the benefit of lower graduated tax rates for ''personal service corporations,'' under which many doctors, lawyers and other professionals run their business. **********Included among the seven changes agreed to were proposals that would increase user fees for certain services provided by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, and impose a new fee for taxpayers who request a ''private letter ruling'' from the Internal Revenue Service. **********The $379 million in revenue to be raised over the next two years from the new user fees is in addition to the $9 billion in new taxes that the conferees need to raise for 1988 and the $14 billion needed for 1989. **********The conferees also agreed today, as expected, that their package should not include any ''technical corrections'' to the Tax Reform Act of 1986 nor any proposals that would cost the Government money. They are expected to consider on Tuesday another $5 billion of proposals contained in the House and Senate bills that are similar, but not identical. **********Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d cited strong objections by the Administration to proposals in the House bill that would strengthen the corporate minimum tax and make corporate takeovers more expensive. **********Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, gave no indication on how hard he might push to include those proposals in the final bill. But he did reiterate his objection to including a major provision included in both the House and Senate bills that would raise revenue by speeding up corporate estimated tax payments. He insisted that the tax package should include only ''hard repeatable revenue increases.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/29/busin.body_text: **********John Fairfax Ltd., the large Australian media company, received a sweetened buyout offer today from Warwick Fairfax. **********Mr. Fairfax said he had raised his bid for the Fairfax shares he did not already control by $1 a share, to $8.50 (Australian), or a total equivalent to $1.62 billion (United States). The company is the second-largest media company in Australia, after the News Corporation owned by Rupert Murdoch. **********James Fairfax, chairman of John Fairfax, and John B. Fairfax, the deputy chairman, said they would accept Warwick Fairfax's bid for their shares as long as no higher offer was made. Both men had opposed the takeover bid when it was first made at the end of August. Spinoffs Planned **********Under his proposal, Warwick Fairfax receives total ownership of The Sydney Morning Herald and other assets, while certain publications were to be spun off and relisted on the Sydney Stock Exchange under the name David Syme & Company. **********The fight for control of Fairfax has pitted Warwick Fairfax against Robert Holmes a Court, a wealthy businessman, and Kerry Packer, a publisher and financier. **********Mr. Fairfax made his original bid in response to stock purchases by Mr. Holmes a Court. Mr. Fairfax said at the time that his offer was intended to protect the company from a possible unfriendly takeover. **********After Mr. Fairfax's initial offer, Mr. Packer also bought Fairfax shares. Varied Stakes **********Mr. Holmes a Court now owns about 9 percent of Fairfax, while Mr. Packer holds about 4 percent. Members of the Fairfax family own a total of about 51 percent, with Warwick Fairfax controlling about 25 percent. **********As Mr. Holmes a Court and Mr. Packer raised their stakes in the company, Mr. Fairfax's bid to take the company private was threatened. As a result, he was forced to negotiate with Mr. Holmes a Court and Mr. Packer. **********As a result of these negotiations, Mr. Fairfax agreed today to sell three newspapers, including the Australian national business daily, and eight radio stations to Mr. Holmes a Court for an undisclosed price. Mr. Packer also gains several properties. **********A person close to the negotiations said Mr. Holmes a Court paid about $475 million (Australian), or about $340.6 million (United States), for the newspapers and the radio stations. Properties Divested **********The properties bought by Mr. Holmes a Court include the Australian Financial Review, National Business Review of New Zealand, Australia's Times on Sunday and the eight-station MacQuarie radio network in Australia. **********Mr. Packer will buy John Fairfax's magazine division, The Canberra Times and The Canberra Chronicle. **********Last week, John Fairfax reached an agreement in principle to buy the American magazine Ms. The future of that agreement was not immediately clear now that Fairfax has sold its magazine holdings. **********The company also sold several smaller publications and a radio station to the family of John B. Fairfax, the company's deputy chairman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/25/world.print_headline: IRANIAN SPEEDBOATS FIRE CLOSE TO COPTER OF U.S. GULF FORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/25/world.body_text: **********Iranian speedboats fired shots today near a United States Navy helicopter and a press-chartered helicopter in the Persian Gulf. Nearby, a commercial ship was reportedly attacked by Iranian boats. **********There were no casualties or damage reported in any of the incidents. **********In Washington, a Pentagon spokesman, Lieut. Comdr. Chris Baumann, said the unarmed Navy SH-60 helicopter had been about 4,000 yards from the speedboats when the shots were fired. **********He said the helicopter ''didn't stick around to determine if it was being fired on directly'' and returned to the missile frigate Elrod, on patrol about three miles away. **********Iran's official press agency, monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus, said that ''warning shots fired by Iranian naval units forced two U.S. helicopters attempting to disrupt patrol missions to flee the scene'' after ignoring radio warnings. It gave no other details. **********An Associated Press photographer, Greg English, who was on the press helicopter, said: ''I sighted smoke, but missed the flash of a shot. Then there was another flash. We backed away.'' **********The commercial ship Eastern Power was attacked by ''small Iranian boats,'' Lloyd's shipping intelligence unit said. It gave no details. **********Eastern Power is listed in Lloyd's Register of Ships as a Panamanian-flag freighter. But the London-based intelligence unit identified it as a 123,993-ton, Liberian-flagged tanker operated by the World Wide Shipping Agency of Hong Kong.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/27/busin.body_text: **********With an assist from Mother Nature and the cooperation of the stock index futures markets, Wall Street yesterday returned to a more normal trading volume and less volatility in stock prices. **********Monday's mixed session, with moderately higher blue-chip prices but declines in secondary issues, was a welcome relief for many harried traders who had seen stock prices fluctuate wildly on Friday, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing by 64 points before going into a 114-point tailspin. **********Yesterday the Dow started the session in retreat, but finished with a 5.76-point gain, at 2,107.28. Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange, after reaching a record 302 million shares on Friday, dropped sharply, to 138.8 million, yesterday. **********Jerome Hinkle, head trader at the Sanford C. Bernstein & Company brokerage firm, like many other Wall Street professionals, thought Friday's action was ''absolutely absurd.'' But he was equally surprised at what happened on Monday, when the market reverted to a very lackluster pace. **********''It's amazing what can happen one trading day to the next,'' Mr. Hinkle added. **********Part of the reason for yesterday's slowdown, traders and market analysts said, might have been the winter storm that blanketed the New York area in several inches of snow. Many traders arrived at work late, and this, along with the weekend break, may have relieved some of the tension that had built up in the marketplace. **********''It's been calm,'' said John Havens of Morgan Stanley & Company. ''As a matter of fact, it's been boring.'' **********At least by recent standards, it was. The Dow, which has risen to such lofty levels in recent weeks that profit taking was almost inevitable, fell about a dozen points in the first 35 minutes of trading. That decline, experts said, was due mainly to traders who were selling stocks and reinvesting their funds in stock index futures, an arbitrager action that has become commonplace of late. **********This type of arbitrager activity, because of where the stock and index futures markets closed on Friday, was predictable. And it was also short-lived, with these so-called program traders turning inactive after the opening onslaught of sell orders. **********By 10:30 A.M., blue-chip stocks had already begun to recover and the Dow was ahead about 5 points. From then on it was back and forth, with the Dow reversing direction several times. Secondary stocks, however, remained in arrears all day. **********The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.39, to 153.63; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 0.49, to 269.61, and the average share fell a dime. Losing issues topped gainers by 968 to 599. **********Other indexes that represented secondary stocks also declined. The American Stock Exchange index dropped by 1.36, to 294.09, and in over-the-counter trading the Nasdaq index fell 4.21, to 387.98. **********Donald Selkin, head of stock index futures trading at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said there was an obvious shift in interest in favor of the blue chips in his market yesterday. He noted that, during most of the day, the Major Market Index futures contract, which closely mirrors the Dow, rose sharply, leaving the other futures indexes behind. **********''The main factor in stock index futures,'' Mr. Selkin said, ''was a continuing move into the indexes whose underlying stocks are the big capitalization issues.'' But the preference of stock index futures traders broadened a bit late yesterday, Mr. Selkin said, when indexes that contain secondary stocks suddenly rose sharply. **********That about-face, the experts believe, might create a situation where the program traders will be buying stocks and selling index futures contracts when trading resumes. Same Optimistic Outlook **********The reasons stock index futures traders became interested in blue-chip issues yesterday were elusive. Generally speaking, however, there was, in those markets, the same optimistic outlook about interest rates, the dollar and the economy that has prevailed on Wall Street recently. **********The stock index futures markets, however, tend to be much more volatile than, say, the Big Board. And like the commodity markets, stock index futures markets often move quickly and without warning on the least bit of news, often pulling the regular cash stock market with them. **********Selling pressure from the program traders on Friday, for instance, came around the time the Federal Reserve's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, was issuing a relatively innocuous statement about dangers to the banking system. While nobody on Wall Street could say for sure that this statement prompted the record selloff, several mentioned the remarks as a possible trigger. Active Southern Down 1/8 **********Southern Company led the consolidated active list yesterday, falling 1/8, to 28 1/4, on volume of 3.4 million shares. International Business Machines, another active issue, rose 1, to 127 1/4, on a turnover of 1.9 million. **********Monsanto, which reported disappointing earnings, fell 1 3/4, to 82, in active trading. Upjohn rose 6, to 116, after its anti-baldness drug, Minoxidil, apparently moved closer to winning Government approval. **********Rexnord rose 3 1/4, to 25 7/8, after receiving a buyout offer from Banner Industries worth $26.25 a share. Minnesota Mining, with improved earnings, rose 2, to 128 3/4. Exxon gained 1 3/8, to 80 5/8. Its quarterly profits fell to $2.06 a share, from $2.43 last year, but the earnings were still better than analysts had expected.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/busin.main_headline: LAST CHANCE TO SET UP I.R.A. UNDER OLD RULE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/busin.print_headline: LAST CHANCE TO SET UP I.R.A. UNDER OLD RULE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/busin.body_text: **********Come April 15, another annual tradition will largely be relegated to tax history: the rush to earn a last-minute tax deduction by putting money into an Individual Retirement Account. **********For millions of taxpayers, the next few weeks represent a final opportunity to claim an I.R.A. deduction because of the new restrictions imposed by the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Under the new law, middle- and upper-income individuals who are covered by some sort of retirement plan at work will no longer be eligible for an I.R.A. deduction. **********Although the new restrictions do not apply to 1986 returns, tax professionals have detected considerable confusion among taxpayers as to whether time has already run out to claim an I.R.A. deduction. **********''They're under the mistaken apprehension that the new rules are effective for 1986, when they are not,'' said Sidney Kess, national director of tax policy at the accounting firm of KMG Main Hurdman. **********Part of the confusion stems from the fact that the I.R.A. provision is effective beginning in 1987. However, the new restrictions do not apply to contributions made for the 1986 tax year, which are allowed to be made after the tax year ends. Under both the old and new laws, taxpayers have until April 15 to make contributions for the previous tax year. **********Thus, every worker still has until April 15 to contribute up to $2,000 of earnings to an I.R.A. for the 1986 tax year and claim a deduction - on the 1986 tax return - for the amount deposited. Taxpayers are allowed to file their tax return and claim an I.R.A. deduction before actually making the deposit to the I.R.A. But the deposit has to be made by April 15. **********Only two provisions of the new law directly apply to 1986 contributions. As of Jan. 1, gold and silver coins minted by the United States Government are no longer prohibited investments for an I.R.A. Other collectibles, however, remain off-limits. **********The second change affects the contribution limits for couples in cases where the second earner brings home only a nominal amount of income. As has long been the case, one-income couples can contribute up to $2,250 a year. If both spouses work, each can contribute as much as they earn, up to a maximum of $2,000 each. **********Some couples fell into a crack, however, if the second spouse earned money but less than $250. In this case they were not able to contribute as much as one-income couples. Congress thought this was inequitable and corrected it in the new tax law so that all couples can now contribute at least $2,250. Concerns About New Law **********Even among people who are fully aware that the I.R.A. deduction is still available, many have had reservations about making the investment because of concerns about the future impact of the new tax law on money now placed in I.R.A.'s. Most tax advisers, however, believe it is worthwhile to make 1986 contributions. **********''Once you get into next year, I have strong feelings on I.R.A.'s, and they're all negative,'' said Peter Elinsky, a tax partner at the accounting firm of Peat Marwick. ''But this year you probably want to do it.'' **********In fact, money deposited in an I.R.A. for 1986 will be treated the same as before. Money in the account is allowed to grow and compound tax-free until withdrawn. The only basic change is that the value of the tax deferral will be reduced somewhat because tax rates will be lower. **********Another question arising from the tax law change is whether it still pays for someone who is hard pressed for cash to take out a loan to make an I.R.A. deposit by April 15. **********In the past, many taxpayers found they came out ahead even after paying interest on the loan. The interest cost was more than offset by the benefit of the I.R.A. deduction, the tax deferral on I.R.A. earnings and the itemized deduction for interest paid on the loan. More Things to Consider **********Now the equation has changed somewhat. While all taxpayers can still get a deduction on 1986 returns, the benefit of the future tax deferral will not be as large as before because of the lower tax rates. Furthermore, the new law places tighter restrictions on interest deductions. **********Nonetheless, Mr. Elinsky believes that taxpayers who borrow this year to finance an I.R.A. contribution will still come out ahead. ''It's still an extra cost, but I think that cost is worth it because of the I.R.A. deduction and the deferral.'' In addition, the interest may still be fully deductible. **********While there remains some uncertainty among tax professionals about the exact tax treatment of interest paid on I.R.A. loans, an I.R.S. spokesman said the interest is considered ''investment interest.'' Under the new law, investment interest remains fully deductible up to the amount of the individual's investment income. Keogh Plans **********In addition to contributing to an I.R.A., self-employed individuals can also make a tax-deductible deposit to a Keogh plan. Anyone with self-employment income can set up a Keogh plan, including people with sideline businesses, such as a schoolteacher who tutors privately after school, an office worker who plays trumpet in a band on weekends or an executive who serves on an outside company's board of directors. **********The limit on contributions to a Keogh plan depends on the specific type of plan established. The top limit is 20 percent of self-employment earnings, which applies only to ''money-purchase'' Keogh plans. This type of plan is rigid and requires a fixed level of contribution to be made each year - regardless of whether the business is profitable or not. **********Andrew Zuckerman, a senior tax manager at the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company, said this type of plan is best for individuals who expect their business to be profitable far into the future and can thus afford to put away a fixed percentage of income every year. **********Otherwise, individuals may be more comfortable with a ''profit-sharing'' Keogh plan. The maximum amount that can be contributed to this type of plan, however, is only 13.043 percent of earnings. Flexibility vs. Percentage **********The trade-off is greater flexibility. With a profit-sharing plan, individuals do not have to deposit the same percentage every year. They can even skip years when business conditions warrant. **********Those looking for a way to make the biggest contribution possible but still be able to put in less when they desire can set up both a profit-sharing and money-purchase plan. **********No matter which type of plan or combination is selected, contributions cannot exceed $30,000 a year. The only way to exceed that limit is to establish a ''defined benefit'' plan where contributions can be higher in order to achieve a particular level of benefits upon retirement. **********Contributions to a Keogh plan can be made even later than the April 15 deadline that applies to I.R.A.'s. If a taxpayer requests a filing extension, Keogh contributions can be made any time up until the extended due date of the return. The one catch is that for a Keogh contribution to be deductible on 1986 returns, the plan must have been set up by last Dec. 31. **********For those who missed the Dec. 31 deadline, there is the option of setting up a Simplified Employee Pension plan. While these plans, known as SEP's, play second fiddle to Keogh plans, they do offer a way to get a tax deduction at this late date. SEP as a Temporary Plan **********''If I wanted a Keogh but didn't get around to setting one up in time, I'd set up a SEP and then set up a Keogh plan for next year,'' Mr. Elinsky said. ''In other words I'd use the SEP as a bridge.'' Indeed, many self-employed people use the SEP only for one year and then turn to a Keogh plan on a permanent basis. **********The main attraction of SEP's is that they can be set up any time until April 15 to qualify for a deduction on tax returns due on that date. Unlike a Keogh plan, however, SEP contributions cannot be made any later than April 15 - regardless of whether the taxpayer has a filing extension. **********Many people choose to abandon SEP's after the first year because they find them less attractive than Keoghs in some respects. **********One drawback is that SEP contributions are limited to 13.043 percent of earnings, compared with the higher 20 percent limit with a money-purchase Keogh. **********SEP's also fall short when it comes to the tax treatment of withdrawals. Keogh plan withdrawals are eligible for favorable ''averaging'' treatment. SEP's are not. **********Self-employed individuals with employees have another reason for preferring Keogh plans: Often they have to provide coverage for many more exployees with a SEP than under a Keogh plan.  Next: Car and computer write-offs.
