The report was attribued to unidentified American officials. **********The protest note was sent by Deputy Foreign Minister Victor Hugo Tinoco to Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/04/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Polaroid Found Liable in Suit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/04/busin.body_text: **********The Polaroid Corporation has been found liable for damages in a class action suit involving allegations that company officials sold stock without disclosing information about the company's problems. A six-person jury in Federal District Court reached its decision Thursday after one day of deliberations. The amount of damages could reach $30 million. The total will be decided in a separate trial scheduled to begin next week. **********Samuel A. Yanes, Polaroid director of corporate communications, said today that the verdict would be appealed. The civil suit was brought against Polaroid by Irving Backman, a Boston securities trader, who contended that Polaroid officials and Edwin Land, company founder, should have given more notice of problems with the company's ill-fated Polavision instant movie system. Mr. Yanes said the suit centered on the public information provided about Polavision during the 1978 fiscal year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/21/busin.body_text: **********The British Government will sell its holding in the British Petroleum Company in late October for the equivalent of $12.1 billion, the Government's financial advisers said today. **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government, which has planned the sale for some time, will sell its remaining 31.5 percent stake in B.P. for $:6 billion, or $9.7 billion, and will also market $:1.5 billion, or $2.4 billion, of new shares, they said. **********About a fifth of the offering will be sold to foreign investors, said Anthony Alt, director of the Government's advisers at N. M. Rothschild & Sons. ''Considerable interest has already been shown from overseas, and a significant proportion of the offer will be made available in these markets,'' he said at a news conference. **********The investment houses handling the overseas portion of the stock offering include Goldman, Sachs & Company in the United States, Wood Gundy Inc. in Canada, the Daiwa Securities Company in Japan and the Swiss Bank Corporation International, Mr. Alt said. **********Six percent of B.P. is currently owned by foreigners, while more than half its assets are abroad. Last month it bought the rest of the Standard Oil Company for $7.8 billion, becoming No. 3 among world oil companies. **********By acquiring all of Cleveland-based Standard Oil, B.P. has raised its presence in the United States and stands to gain from Standard's large Alaskan reserves if oil prices start to rise again. Standard is the second-biggest producer of American oil. **********The British Government's stake in B.P. has been gradually reduced since 1977, from 68.4 percent, through four previous stock offerings - three of them under Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative administration. **********Most of this final offering will be aimed at British financial institutions and private investors. The portion earmarked for foreign investors from the United States, Continental Europe and Japan may be reduced if the domestic demand is overwhelming, Mr. Alt said. Earlier sales of state-owned companies, such as the utilities British Gas and British Telecommunciations, were heavily oversubscribed. **********Until now, the biggest sale of a state-held company has been the $:5.6 billion, or $9 billion, stock offering of British Gas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.print_headline: MARKET TURMOIL; Parley On Budget Opened
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.body_text: **********Reagan Administration and Congressional negotiators started discussions today over a budget compromise aimed at soothing agitated financial markets, but their initial sparring produced few conclusive results. **********After morning and afternoon sessions lasting a total of about four hours, Representative William H. Gray 3d, the House Budget Committee chairman, summed up the situation by saying, ''We're now down to the heavy lifting.'' **********Lawmakers from both parties reported that the conversations in closed session were candid and realistic about the possibilities for compromise, and largely free of the political acrimony that has marked most budget discussions for the last year. But two days of meetings have not yet been able to erase the major disagreements that still divide the negotiators. **********''The differences are narrowing, but we're still a long way apart,'' said Senator Pete V. Domenici, ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee. **********''There are obvious, major differences between where we are and where the Administration is,'' added Representative Gray, Democrat of Pennsylvania. **********One area of difference centers on a proposal, favored by the Reagan Administration and many Republicans, to trim the budget by freezing domestic and military spending at this year's levels. Differences on Priorities **********Democrats are dubious about the idea, because they prefer to set their own priorities and cut some programs more deeply than others. But the Democrats agreed today to have staff assistants make a study overnight of what a freeze would mean in practical terms. **********Despite the slow going reported today, lawmakers from both parties agreed that the tone and mood of the meeting were distinctly differeent from previous efforts on Capitol Hill to deal with the budget issue. **********A sense of deep apprehension, even fear, seems to have gripped negotiators on all sides of the table. With the financial markets watching their every move, the lawmakers say this is not the time to play their usual political games with the budget. **********''Nobody's threatening to walk away from this,'' said Senator J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, one of the Democratic negotiators. ''There's an underlying feeling that we've got to do it this time.'' **********''For good or ill,'' added Mr. Johnston, a senior member of the Senate Appropriations Committee, ''the feeling is that the markets are really looking at what we're doing. We're very conscious of the markets.'' Warning on Downturn **********Senator Warren B. Rudman, a New Hampshire Republican who is an influential voice on budget matters, said the markets were warning Congress that if it did not act decisively on the budget deficit, it could trigger a downturn in the economy. **********''Politicians don't like economic downturns,'' said Mr. Rudman, who is not a negotiator. ''Everybody in that room is very aware of that.'' **********Republicans, in particular, are acutely aware that economic troubles could seriously threaten them in next year's elections. **********At a breakfast meeting with reporters, Mr. Gray highlighted the political implications of the budget talks when he said of the Republicans: ''What are they going to be running on? Are we going to be in a recession?'' **********One Republican Senator, who did not want to be identified, said he hoped that the markets remained depressed until the negotiators reach an agreement. ''Realistically speaking, that's the only way we'll get together,'' he said. ''We have to keep the pressure on.'' Firm Foes of Tax Increase **********One group that remains unconvinced about the wisdom of a budget compromise is conservative Republicans, mainly in the Senate, who oppose any kind of tax increase. **********These Republicans say that the President basically agrees with them but has been swayed to consider a tax increase by some of his more moderate advisers, and by the turmoil in the stock market. **********''When he puts down his note cards, he's with us,'' said one conservative Republican, who met recently with Mr. Reagan in the White House. ''There's no question where his heart is. We've got to make sure his head stays with his heart.'' **********Since Mr. Reagan has been a reluctant convert to deficit reduction talks, some lawmakers still wonder whether he is fully committed to the negotiations now taking place. **********''The President is the only one who can cut the knot, and we're not sure he will,'' said an aide to House Democratic leaders. Freeze on Programs Discussed **********A freeze on all discretionary spending, programs financed on a year-to-year basis, was ''discussed as a starting point'' in today's meeting, according to Senator Johnston. Aides were studying the possible impact of various kinds of freezes. **********''We want to find out what it means,'' said the Louisiana Democrat, ''and whether it is do-able.'' **********Senator Rudman espoused the freeze concept, saying, ''It has the benefit of fairness and equity, and it saves a good chunk of money.'' **********A House Democratic aide, however, said that Democrats were unlikely to accept a freeze without a number of exemptions for programs that aid the poor. ''It's likely to come out looking more like slush than a freeze,'' the aide said. **********The negotiators have agreed to fashion a package of budget cuts and revenue increases totaling at least $23 billion, but they hold out the possiility of trying to save more. **********Some participants in the talks said they could conclude by Saturday, but others said that goal was unrealistic. The final deadline is Nov. 20, the day on which automatic budget cuts will go into effect, should Congress fail to enact deficit-reduction measures on its own.  6 OBJECTIVES FOR POLICY MAKERS  Last week's stock market collapse and the ongoing market tremors have raised the specter of an economic recession. Suddenly, problems that have been looming for months - giant budget and trade deficits - are being addressed with greater urgency. But there are no easy solutions. Lowering interest rates, for instance, might spur spending in America, but it would cut off much of the foreign funding of this country's budget deficit. Following are objectives and obstacles facing the President and economic policy makers.  RESTORE CALM TO THE MARKETS  Confidence in political and financial leadership has weakened because of stock market collapse. Huge budget and trade deficits could keep interest rates high and hold back U.S. economic growth. Prospects for military conflict in Middle East remain.   Markets will remain jittery until progress is made on budget deficit. Fear of another financial panic will keep President and Congress working toward that end. Greater international cooperation could result from danger of more trauma in foreign stock and money markets.   LOWER INTEREST RATES  Stock market and economy benefit from lower interest rates, but rates are difficult to cut because foreign investors are already skittish about investing in dollar-denominated securities.   Tug of war is under way. Interest rates at present or higher rates might be necessary to attract foreign buyers to help fund budget deficit. But **********Federal Reserve has been pumping money into banking system recently to lower interest rates and keep economy moving.   CUT THE BUDGET DEFICIT  Congress still sharply divided on where to cut budget for fiscal 1988. To make inroads that will help markets, Democrats will have to agree to deeper cuts in social spending, and Administration must agree to spend less on defense and seek more than the $12 billion in tax increases it has recently suggested.   Spending cuts of at least $23 billion are certain by Nov. 20 because of automatic spending cuts mandated by Congress. Renewed dialogue between White House and Congress increases chances for more cuts, perhaps to the $30 million that Wall Street analysts say is needed to help markets. Except for Social Security cuts, all possibilities are on the table, including tax increases.   CUT THE TRADE DEFICIT  Trade deficit should be improving by now. But Americans have developed a taste for foreign products and, with foreign economies sluggish, demand for American exports is weak. Other problems: Major trading partners are reluctant to improve access to their markets for American goods; dollar has not declined against some big trading partners, so their goods remain attractively priced.   Deficit will not change much in near future. Pending trade legislation would force retaliation against unfair practices of trading partners, but it is also widely viewed as protectionist, inviting retaliation against American goods.   STABILIZE THE DOLLAR  Currency markets are nervous, and their stability is necessary for interest rates to decline. Improving trade deficit may require another dollar decline to make American goods cheaper abroad. Coordinated support of dollar by central banks cannot stop slide if currency markets move en masse.   Dollar is likely to fall to help trade deficit. Stabiity will return when currency markets see progress on budget and trade deficits. Otherwise, foreign investors will stay away from U.S. securities and dollar sinks lower.   AVOID A RECESSION  Attitudes toward spending have grown more cautious since market collapse. This could slow consumer purchases and cause businesses to delay or pare back spending on plants and equipment. High interest rates to attract foreign investors might further slow economy.   Danger of recession has increased because of outlook for slower growth than expected. **********Recession not likely to occur if Federal Reserve pumps money into economy, driving interest rates lower and inducing spending.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/01/world.main_headline: CHAD SAID TO WIN VAST LIBYAN BOOTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/01/world.print_headline: CHAD SAID TO WIN VAST LIBYAN BOOTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/01/world.body_text: **********Western diplomats said today that military equipment abandoned by Libyan forces retreating from northern Chad was believed to be worth half a billion dollars. **********The Libyans, who were said to have left two more bases without firing a shot, are reported to have lost warplanes, helicopters, tanks, missiles and armored personnel carriers. **********''We have not sat down yet with an adding machine and a catalogue of acquisition costs,'' a diplomat said, ''but it is certainly hundreds of millions of dollars worth of materiel.'' **********According to Chadian military communiques, 3,603 Libyan soldiers have been killed and 1,165 captured this year. The communiques listed 35 Chadians killed and 82 wounded. **********Today the Government announced on the radio that Chadian forces took Libyan bases at Gouro and Ounianga Kebir on Sunday and Monday, capturing 30 soldiers, 15 Soviet-made T-55 tanks, 19 armored personnel carriers and four rocket launchers. **********Most of the Libyans at the bases -150 in Gouro and 450 in Ounianga Kebir - fled, the before the advancing Chadian troops, the radio said. **********The Libyans had occupied much of northern Chad since 1980, when they intervened in a civil war in Chad. The tide turned against the Libyans late last year when most of their Chadian allies switched sides. **********In February, Goukouni Oueddei, a former Chadian President who was ousted by the current President, Hissen Habre, moved to Algiers from Tripoli. the Libyan capital. **********In March, two ministers in the Habre Government visited Mr. Goukouni in Algiers to negotiate a reconciliation, and he is expected to return home soon. **********President Habre's military successes in the north seem to have won him wide support in a nation that only a few years ago was riven by armed factions. Last month, another political holdout, Col. Wadai Abdelkader Kamougue, Vice President in the former Goukouni Government, returned from exile. **********According to Chadian communiques, Libyan material losses this year include 94 T-55 tanks destroyed and 82 captured, 109 armored personnel carriers destroyed and 180 captured, and 31 fixed-wing aircraft and nine helicopters shot down, captured or destroyed on the ground. **********The communiques also listed 12 T-62 tanks destroyed, 73 heavy transport trucks captured, 60 14.5-millimeter cannon captured or destoroyed, 42 106-millimeter recoilless cannon captured, six radar sets and 12 antiaircraft missile batteries captured. **********A diplomat remarked that ''Chad has gotten more from Libya than from the United States and France.'' **********President Reagan recently authorized $10 million worth of aid, on top of $15 million worth of aid authorized in December. Military aid delivered so far this year by France, the former colonial power in Chad, is believed to be worth $50 million. French officils decline to give precise figures. **********The only recent statement on Chadian military plans was an announcement that there was no intention of sending troops into Libya. In the short term, the Government appears intent on expelling the remaining Libyans from the Tibesti Mountains in northern Chad. **********President Habre has proclaimed as his eventual goal the expulsion of Libyans from the Aouzou Strip, a 100-mile wide zone along the border that Libya occupied more than a decade ago. **********A Western diplomats said, ''I think he will chase them out of the Tibesti Mountains next and then move on the Aouzou.'' **********Military analysts interpret the large amount of captured materiel as a sign of low morale among the Libyans. **********They note that many Libyans have been shot while fleeing. Last week, many of the 1,200 Libyans killed in a battle at Wadi Doum died when they panicked and ran through mine fields. **********''I don't have any reason to think that the Libyan Army will fight any better in the Aouzou than in Fada or in Ouadi Doum,'' the Western diplomat said.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.main_headline: Successor to Chief Is Named at Cigna
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Successor to Chief Is Named at Cigna
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.body_text: **********The Cigna Corporation, a large insurance and financial services company based in Philadelphia, yesterday chose Wilson H. Taylor as the eventual successor to its chairman and chief executive, Robert D. Kilpatrick. **********Mr. Taylor, 43 years old, president of Cigna's property and casualty business, was named vice chairman, chief operating officer and a member of the board, effective Jan. 1. **********His selection for those posts, Mr. Kilpatrick said, ''is the next step in the succession process we began in 1985,'' adding, ''Bill is extremely well qualified to replace me upon my retirement.'' **********Mr. Kilpatrick, 63, is scheduled to retire in March 1989. Mr. Wilson was chosen from several candidates, none from outside the company, a spokesman said. The company's president is Hartzel Z. Lebed, 58, who was named in 1985. **********Cigna was formed in 1982 with the merger of the INA Corporation and the Connecticut General Corporation. Mr. Taylor who had joined Connecticut General in 1964, became chief financial officer of the merged companies in 1982. He is a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Trinity College. **********Mr. Kilpatrick, who had run Connecticut General before the merger, became a co-chief executive, with Ralph S. Saul of INA, afterward. Mr. Saul was later named chairman and Mr. Kilpatrick chief executive. After Mr. Saul retired in 1984, Mr. Kilpatrick became chairman and chief executive. **********With the appointment of Mr. Taylor, Mr. Kilpatrick said in a statement, ''We have established the top level of management of Cigna for many years to come.'' **********In a telephone interview, Mr. Kilpatrick added: ''We had a number of very viable internal candidates. We felt Mr. Taylor was best qualified among a group of well-qualified people. He had headed the property and casualty business. That was our biggest money loser, and he's turned it around to be our biggest money earner.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/07/busin.main_headline: Talking Business/with Currey of Greyhound; The Proposal For Trailways
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/07/busin.print_headline: Talking Business/with Currey of Greyhound; The Proposal For Trailways
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/07/busin.body_text: **********The Greyhound Lines bus company, which is now owned by a group of Dallas investors, received tentative permission late last week to take over the money-losing Trailways Corporation, its main competitor. Greyhound had asked for quick approval, warning that Trailways was in poor shape and that if the Interstate Commerce Commission took its time there would be little of value to take over. The Justice Department at first opposed the $80 million bid, saying that combining the nation's only two national bus systems could raise serious anti-competitive problems. Later, however, it found that the acquisition was necessary because Trailways was on the brink of bankruptcy. Fred G. Currey, the chairman and president of Greyhound and a past president of Trailways, discusses the competitive effects of his company's bid. Q. Must Trailways be taken over quickly?  A. According to the affidavits filed by its chief financial officer and its lead bank, which have been concurred in by the Justice Department, Trailways is a failed company. Frankly, without our intervention Trailways's collapse is imminent and inevitable.  * * * **********Q. What would the consequences be if the I.C.C. does not allow Trailways to be acquired? **********A. There would a massive discontinuance of service to hundreds of cities and towns across the United States that have no other form of public transportation.  * * * **********Q. With total ridership of national bus systems so small, couldn't the slack be picked up by smaller bus companies and other forms of transportation? **********A. No way. Because the only form of public transportation that can fill it is a private automobile. The people who would be affected are those who reside in the hundreds of communities that connect up to the thousands of communities that Greyhound serves. There is no alternative. The service can't be duplicated. Bus riders would be forced to spend the money to buy an automobile. Some just can't afford to.  * * * **********Q. Since Greyhound, with the acquisition of Trailways, would be the only national bus transportation company, what would prevent you from acting like a monopoly? **********A. I wish I thought we had enought muscle to set prices. There are three leading competitors and we price against these competitors today. They are the private automobile, the discount air fare and people who stay at home. With only 1.3 percent of the travel market, there is absolute certainty that we cannot raise fares. We have been squeezed down. We have cut fares between thousands of city pairs in the last 90 days and in many we have no competition except the private automobile.  * * * **********Q. How would bus service be affected? **********A. We believe that the impact will be positive. The bus system is like a kind of telephone system - the more places it connects the more valuable it is.  * * * **********Q. Could another national bus company emerge to compete with you? **********A. It's possible. Deregulation has eliminated many of the barriers of entry and the start-up costs are not large.  * * * **********Q. How will the smaller bus companies be affected? **********A. We will honor all the commitments of Trailways lines to the 34 independent bus companies. We will continue to exchange passengers with the independent companies that now interline with Greyhound lines. It should strengthen all those small companies. The small companies that now interline with Greyhound don't have access to the feed from the cities that are served by Trialways and vice versa. **********We see the combination of these two companies fitting hand in glove with using vans to extend service where it has been discontinued by either Trialways or Greyhound.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/12/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; S.E.C. Investigates Harcourt Offering
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/12/busin.body_text: **********Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission is conducting an inquiry into the company's $3 billion recapitalization plan. Under that plan, Harcourt offered its stockholders $40 a share and a share of new preferred stock in return for each share of common they held. The offer was designed to ward off a $44-a-share hostile takeover by the British publisher Robert Maxwell. **********The publishing company, based in Orlando, Fla., said the commission staff was seeking information about Harcourt's recommendation that holders of convertible debentures convert their securities into common stock to receive a special dividend. The S.E.C. staff also requested information about Harcourt's repurchases of its common stock and convertible debentures in late May. Harcourt made the disclosure in a registration statement filed for $1.28 billion of debentures that it plans to sell through the First Boston Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/07/world.body_text: **********More than 300 people here feared to have drowned in northern Zambia after their river barge hit a sandbar in what police called a navigational error. **********Eighty people survived Zambia's worst river accident and 23 bodies had been recovered by Monday night. A search went on today, with hopes fading for more than 300 other passengers, missing after the barge sank early on Sunday. **********The Zairean barge Maria, heavily loaded with passengers and luggage, sank on the Luapula River which forms the border between the isolated northern province of Luapula and Zaire. **********''It would appear that the coxswain of the barge was dozing and he hit a sandbank,'' the Luapula police commander, Baldwin Kaila, said. **********The Zairean coxswain, who survived and reported to Zambian officials, said about 470 passengers were aboard the vessel when it sank. They were believed to include both Zambians and Zaireans. Survivors Were on Top Deck **********''Those who survived were on the top deck of the barge,'' he said. **********Prospects of finding any more survivors were fading as poor communications hampered rescue efforts in the remote region. Officials said it would be difficult to confirm the final death toll with certainty. **********The barge, traveling between the villages of Mpweto and Kasenga, sank near Katabulwe Harbor, some 400 miles north of Lusaka, the Zambian capital. **********Kaila said the coxswain had not been arrested but was in police custody pending an investigation into the accident.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/12/world.main_headline: How the U.S. and Soviet Officials Agreed to Disagree on 'Star Wars'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/12/world.print_headline: SUMMIT AFTERMATH; How the U.S. and Soviet Officials Agreed to Disagree on 'Star Wars'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/12/world.body_text: **********With only a few hours left before the scheduled end of the summit meeting, American and Soviet officials were still wrangling at the White House over how to overcome their differences on how strictly a 1972 treaty limits the ''Star Wars'' missile defense program. **********The two sides had reached important agreements on questions relating to reducing long-range arms, and a joint statement summing up their work was virtually ready for publication. **********But two central issues lay unresolved - how much ''Star Wars'' testing should be allowed under the 1972 antiballistic missile treaty and whether the United States has a right eventually to deploy an anti-missile defense. Chose to Avoid Clash **********At this point, the Soviet and American sides chose to avoid repeating the direct clash that they had at the Reykjavik meeting last year that led to a breakdown in the talks. **********As President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev waited at the White House keeping the assembled reporters wondering for two hours what was happening behind the scenes, senior American and Soviet officials mounted a final effort to paper over their differences. **********The hurried White House meetings involved Secretary of State George P. Shultz; Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci; Lieut. Gen. Colin L. Powell, the national security adviser; Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, and Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, the chief of the Soviet General Staff, as well as their top aides. Put Off for Another Day **********Finally, with a few deft strokes of the pen, the confrontation over ''Star Wars'' was put off for another day. The officials agreed to include in the final statement a vaguely worded paragraph about observance of the ABM treaty that each side could interpret as it wished. **********Although Mr. Reagan today called the discussion about ''Star Wars'' a victory for his position, and not primarily cosmetic, a senior American arms control official differed. He said strong differences remained between the two sides on that issue. **********''I would not use the word 'breakthrough','' he said. **********Other agreements reached during the summit meeting on the issue of reducing long-range arms were less ambiguous. According to American participants in the talks, these were some of the high points: *********** The two sides agreed to set a limit of 4,900 on the number of warheads permitted on land-based and sea-based ballistic missiles, as a compomise between the American call for 4,800 and the Russian suggestion of 5,100. *********** To ease problems of verification, the United States appeared to reverse, at least temporarily, a decision by Caspar W. Weinberger, then Defense Secretary, to deploy some Trident submarine missiles with 12 warheads and others with 8 warheads. Following the recommendation of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the United States now apparently plans to deploy only 8 warhead versions of the Trident 2 missile. *********** The two sides also agreed to work out rules for counting the number of warheads on their missiles and the number of nuclear-armed cruise missiles on bombers. *********** The Russians also agreed that they would not encode any electronic signals during missile tests. The United States has charged that such encoding has impeded its ability to monitor Soviet compliance with limits in past treaties. Tuesday Meeting on ABM Pact **********On the issue of the ABM treaty, the arms control experts first staked out their position in a meeting on Tuesday afternoon. Paul H. Nitze, the senior advise to Mr. Shultz, led the American team while Marshal Akhromeyev led the Russians. **********At that session, officials said, the American side proposed language that would have affirmed Washington's right to proceed aggressively with its ''Star Wars'' program. **********The language that the Americans wanted to include in the joint statement affirmed the need to carry out tests in space, the right to deploy anti-missile defenses eventually. **********Soviet officials proposed that the United States observe the ABM treaty as it was ''signed and ratified.'' **********The reference to ratification was a troublesome buzzword for the American side. Senator Sam Nunn, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, had argued forcefully that the Senate approved the ABM treaty on the understanding that it set severe limits on ''Star Wars'' tests. Adamant U.S. Opposition **********By referring to ratification, the Soviet side seemed to be asking the Administration to agree to Mr. Nunn's view of the treaty. The American side was adamantly opposed to accepting the Soviet language. **********At one point, on Wednesday evening, the American side met by itself to reconsider its position. Hard-line officials urged that the Administration continue to insist on an affirmation of its need for space testing and eventual deployment of ''Star Wars.'' **********The American side returned to Wednesday night's negotiating session at 11 P.M. with its tough position. The result, one Administration expert said, was that the Russians ''gagged.'' The meeting broke up at 12:30 A.M. **********According to American participants, Mr. Shultz and Mr. Shevardnadze met Thursday morning at the Soviet Embassy. The purpose of the meeting was to make one more effort to agree on about a half dozen issues remaining before a scheduled 10:30 meeting between Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev. **********But the Shultz-Shevardnadze meeting still left the issues unresolved. Meeting for Final Push **********The Soviet side proposed that a group of high-level experts from each side meet at the White House for a final push to overcome the differences, and the meeting between the two leaders was delayed. **********Marshal Akhromeyev and Viktor P. Karpov represented the Soviet side. The American team consisted of Mr. Nitze; Max M. Kampelman, the chief American arms negotiator; Ronald F. Lehman, the senior negotiatior on long-range arms, and Col. Robert E. Linhard of the Air Force, the principal arms control expert on the staff of the National Security Council. **********In the talks between the experts, the Russians accepted an American demand that conventionally armed cruise missiles on aircraft should be left outside the scope of the treaty. **********On cruise missiles aboard ships and submarines, the two sides patched together a compromise. The United States agreed to a Soviet demand that a new treaty on long-range arms should include a ''ceiling'' on such weapons. But to satisfy the Americans, the Soviet side dropped its demand that the sea-based cruise missile be limited to certain types of vessels. **********That left several key issues undecided, including what limit to set on the number of warheads on ballistic missiles and how to intepret the 1972 defensive treaty limiting anti-ballistic missiles. **********At one point, with time running out, American officials reportedly suggested that they might show some flexibility on language on the ABM treaty if the Russians would agree to a limit of 4,800 on the number of warheads on ballistic missiles. Marshal Akhromeyev is said to have countered that the Russians would agree to a limit of 4,900 to 5,000 if all of the differences over the ABM treaty in the joint statement could be worked out. **********But the two sides were at an impasse on the ABM treaty, and the issue passed for resolution back to Mr. Shultz and Mr. Shevardnadze, who were at the White House. **********Now the final push began. The two men worked with Mr. Carlucci, Lieut. Gen. Colin L. Powell, the national security adviser, and the teams of American and Soviet experts. **********Again the issues were basically the same. The Russians wanted Washington to agree to observe the ABM treaty as ''signed and ratified.'' Washington wanted the Russians to affirm its right to deploy anti-missile systems. **********Mr. Shultz persuaded Mr. Shervardnadze to drop his insistence about including language in the joint statement about adherence to the ''ratified'' ABM treaty. Mr. Shultz reportedly argued that such language would be an inappropriate reference to the political debate over the treaty between the Administration and the Senate. **********The Americans did not get a direct reference to testing in space. Instead, the joint statement included vague language that each side could carry out testing it thought was ''required'' under the terms of the ABM treaty. Demand on Statement Dropped **********The Americans also finally dropped their demand that the joint statement should affirm the right to deploy anti-missile systems. Instead, the statement says that after a period of adherence to the ABM treaty that has yet to be determined, ''each side will be free to decide its course of action.'' **********This is line with an American demand that the United States should be free to deploy after the non-withdrawal period expires. But it also suggests that the Russians may be free to take counteractions to thwart those defenses, if they so choose. **********Mr. Shevardnadze reportedly resisted even this compromise appoach. But Mr. Carlucci is reported to have swayed him by reading from the notes of an earlier meeting between Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Reagan. In that exchange, Mr. Gorbachev reportedly made the point that after the period of observance lapsed, each side could take whatever actions it wished. **********Soon after that, the White House was trumpeting its claim that the Russians had backed off their demand that the ABM treaty be strictly interpreted. And Mr. Gorbachev was saying the two sides needed to take steps to prevent the militarization of space. **********Senior Administration arms control officials, for their part, were saying the two sides had deferred the key dispute over how to interpret the ABM treaty until another day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/26/busin.main_headline: Pilots Win Court Test At Eastern
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/26/busin.print_headline: Pilots Win Court Test At Eastern
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/26/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge ruled today that a 1986 collective bargaining agreement between Eastern Airlines and the Air Line Pilots Association is valid, allowing pilots to argue several grievances of that contract before a company hearing board. **********''This is a major victory for us and we're elated,'' said Ron Cole, a spokesman for the pilots. **********Eastern said it would appeal the ruling by Federal District Judge Lenore Nesbitt. ''We're disappointed that the court held that there was an agreement,'' said Robin Matell, a spokesman for the airline. ''We believe the court is wrong as a matter of law and we plan to file an appeal.'' **********The airline and the union reached the agreement hurriedly in February 1986, as Eastern struggled with a financial crisis that ended with its purchase by the Texas Air Corporation. But differences in the interpretation of the agreement quickly arose over such matters as pay parity, benefits and worker protection. **********When the pilots started to file grievances over these differences, Eastern filed suit in June 1986 to block their challenge of the contract. Eastern's suit was later expanded to argue that major differences between the airline and the union on many issues meant there had not been a valid contract agreement the previous February. **********A key grievance stemmed from the pilots' acceptance of pay cuts. The contract called for a 20 percent pay cut and work concessions, but Eastern had agreed that the pilots would receive pay increases if any other group of workers at the airline received them. **********The pilots' union filed a grievance after learning that Eastern, in the spring of 1986, gave a 20 percent pay increase to nonunion mechanic supervisors. The judge's ruling clears the way for the airline's System Board of Adjustment to hear the case.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/04/world.main_headline: Soviet Prosecutor Seeking 8 Years For German Who Flew to Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/04/world.print_headline: Soviet Prosecutor Seeking 8 Years For German Who Flew to Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/04/world.body_text: **********A Soviet prosecutor asked today for an eight-year term in a labor camp for Mathias Rust, asserting that the young West German's flight and landing near Red Square risked ''his own life and the lives of others.'' **********The prosecutor, Vladimir Andreyev, and Anatoly Bryulov, a witness described as an international aviation expert, also charged that Mr. Rust's single-engine Cessna at one point wandered into the flight lanes of Sheremetyevo International Airport, and could have endangered an incoming West German pasenger plane. **********Mr. Rust denied he was in the ''exclusion zone'' around the airport, and Mr. Bryulov did not indicate how close Mr. Rust's plane came to the West German airliner or any other aircraft. **********As on the first day of the 19-year-old pilot's trial, the courtroom was opened only to limited numbers of journalists - largely the West German and Soviet reporters but also including representatives of American, French and English news services, who provided details of the proceedings on the second day of the three-day trial. Sentences Near Maximum **********The sentences Mr. Andreyev requested - eight years for violation of international flight rules, four years for malicious hooliganism and two years for illegally crossing the border -were all near the maximum allowable for those offenses. Mr. Andreyev said the sentences would run concurrently. **********Mr. Andreyev's remarks showed the somber view Soviet officials have decided to take toward Mr. Rust's flight on May 28, which abruptly toppled Defense Minister Sergei L. Sokolov and led to a shake-up of the Soviet air defense forces. **********''Although he is not yet 20, he understood that he was risking his own life and the lives of others,'' Mr. Andreyev said. ''I underline that the law is the law, in the Soviet Union as in West Germany. He is a hooligan.'' **********Mr. Andreyev asked that Mr. Rust's term be spent in a strict-regime labor camp - the second most severe type of Soviet penal colony in terms of diet, work rules and housing conditions. A Three-Member Panel **********The trial is expected to conclude Friday with the verdict by the three-member panel and a sentence. The two lay assessors have equal voting rights with the presiding judge, and conviction requires a majority vote, not a unanimous one. **********The prosecutor used much of the afternoon session today interrogating Mr. Rust about his flight, his choice of a landing spot at the symbolic heart of Soviet power - a site regarded by many Russians with reverence, in part because of the presence of Lenin's mausoleum - and his apparent failure to pursue his ''peace mission'' after landing. **********Presiding Judge Robert Tikhomirnov also asked, ''You had a great opportunity to demonstrate your peaceful intentions'' when a crowd surrounded the aircraft as it was landing. ''Why didn't you use it?'' **********In its dispatch, Tass, the Soviet press agency, asked rhetorically: ''How did it happen that, while thoroughly thinking out a plan of this flight, Mathias Rust did not decide what he would do once it was over? It seems that Rust's 'peace mission' has been invented just for the sake of rhetoric.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/26/busin.body_text: **********After a frantic week of battling the stock market, Wall Street's brokerage firms spent the weekend cleaning up the debris and trying to assess the damage. **********Clerical employees worked all weekend preparing for today and tomorrow when the enormous flood of trading last Monday and Tuesday must be cleaned up on their books. The firms are required to ''settle'' trades - make sure a seller's records and a buyer's records are in accord - within five days. Only then can they properly assess what last week's plunge and partial recovery did to their own finances. **********''The Street is coming out of this pretty well,'' said Max C. Chapman Jr., president of Kidder, Peabody & Company. ''But I think Monday or Tuesday will be critical.'' Reckoning Remains Unclear **********Until then, the reckoning remains unclear. But it appears that the record volume may have been far from a disaster for the big retail houses. They deal with thousands of ordinary investors, who pay higher commissions than the volume discounts given institutional investors. **********In addition, the money that huge firms like Salomon Brothers made on inventories of bonds, which rose in value with the credit market rally, may counterbalance whatever beating they took in their stock holdings. **********Whether and how badly some firms may have been shaken may not be known for weeks. But the stocks of publicly traded brokerage firms were among last week's biggest casualties, a sign that the damage was expected to be serious. **********Three big securities firms - L. F. Rothschild, E. F. Hutton and Paine Webber - were among the 15 stocks hardest hit on the New York Stock Exchange. L. F. Rothschild's shares lost 51 percent of their market value, Paine Webber fell 40 percent, and E. F. Hutton lost 44 percent. **********The Street's strongest firms were hard hit as well. First Boston was down 32 percent, Bear, Stearns 33 percent, Salomon 32 percent, Morgan Stanley 23 percent, and Merrill Lynch 21 percent. **********''It makes perfect sense that they're down more,'' said John Keefe, an analyst who follows the securities industry for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ''If there was fundamental news to pin on any group of companies, it was the brokerage stocks.'' Firms Hurt by Lower Stock Prices **********Though the Wall Street firms routinely sell stock as well as buy it, Mr. Keefe said they are ''a net holder of securities.'' That means when market prices drop as they did last week, they are hurt by the fall in value of their inventories. **********That view was echoed by James E. Cayne, co-president of Bear Stearns Companies. ''Wall Street firms as a rule are 'long' the market,'' he said, using the Street's jargon for owning shares. ''So I would have to say Wall Street firms did not win. As a matter of fact, they lost.'' **********Bear, Stearns will be among the first to disclose the impact on its profits. In a few weeks, it will report its earnings for the three months ending Oct. 30. Most securities firms, in contrast, keep their books on a calendar year and will not have to make similar disclosures until after New Year's. Earnings Estimates Reduced **********Some Wall Street analysts, not taking any chances, are already reducing their earnings estimates for the publicly traded brokerage stocks. Michael W. Blumstein, a First Boston analyst, has chopped his estimate for Bear, Stearns' current quarter to 25 cents a share, from 55 cents - even though the firm is believed to have earned two to three times its usual commissions last week. **********Mr. Blumstein cited losses sustained in the firm's risk arbitrage unit, a department within Bear, Stearns that places bets on the outcome of takeover battles. Last week's tumult caused many takeovers to be scotched at the last moment, much to the dismay of arbitragers who owned the stocks. Bear, Stearns is also expected to sustain losses in its clearing activities, a service it performs for smaller brokerage firms for a fee. **********Mr. Keefe, of Drexel, has not yet downgraded the group, but thinks ''it's inevitable,'' despite the windfall in commissions most firms are expected to earn from last week's torrid trading. **********''Commissions per se won't really matter,'' Mr. Keefe said. ''Commissions as a revenue source are relatively minor these days, certainly relative to trading profits.'' Commission Income Not Vital **********Since May 1, 1975, when brokerage commission rates were opened to competition, commission income has declined in importance, and most Wall Street houses do not depend on that revenue. Firms that serve large institutional clients must be ready to execute the largest block trades for as little as a nickel or a dime a share. **********Merrill Lynch, with its extensive network of branches and huge retail customer base, said yesterday that it had done ''extremely well.'' But generally firms were not crowing about their results last week. Mr. Chapman of Kidder, Peabody said last week ''was a positive week, though certainly not spectacular.'' He said his firm experienced volume and commission revenues two to three times recent levels. **********George L. Ball, chairman of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the upheaval ''was not devastating'' to his firm's profitability. **********But the brokerages are not yet in the clear. **********As the volatility fuels opportunities for trading profits, it also increases the opportunities to make mistakes, said to Robert S. Salomon Jr., a managing director at Salomon Brothers. A 'Punishing Environment' **********''If someone under pressure gets an order fouled up, by the time you go to correct it,'' he said, ''the market may be extraordinarily different than where the mistake occured, so it is a very punishing environment.'' **********Bear, Stearns is already the target of lawsuits by investors. And other firms acknowledge that they too could face litigation.  How Brokerage Stocks Fared Company Friday's Weekly Close % Chng. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/busin.body_text: **********European Community industry ministers agreed today that surplus capacity in Europe's steel industry must be sharply reduced, but they put off the decisions on how and where to make the cuts, diplomats said. **********Steel companies and labor unions have applied enormous political pressure to escape the next round of plant closings and dismissals and to keep the current system of production quotas that guarantees them a share of a dwindling market. **********Diplomats said those pressures were reflected in the lukewarm reaction to a plan by the European Commission, the community's executive arm, to cut production by 30 million tons in the next three years at a cost of up to 80,000 jobs. **********''There was a broad consensus around the table that a healthy steel industry should be created at least by 1992'' one diplomat said. **********Kenneth Clarke, Britain's trade and industry minister, said that the ministers would refer the crucial problem of where the ax should fall to a special commission. **********Diplomats said most ministers had agreed that money would have to be found to persuade companies to make cuts, to compensate dismissed workers and to stimulate investment in regions already blighted by industrial decline.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/28/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Interest Rates Move Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/28/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates climbed yesterday as prices of all Treasury debt issues dropped in reaction to another steep decline in the dollar's value against major foreign currencies. **********Dealers described trading as orderly and the most active in recent weeks. Despite some late bargain-hunting, the market closed at its lows of the day, they added. **********In late trading, for example, the benchmark long-term Treasury bond, the 7.5 percent issue due in 2016, was offered at 98.07, down 1 7/32, and now yields 7.65 percent, compared with 7.52 percent a week ago. The decline in the bond became pronounced when the bellwether Treasury bond futures contract, the June delivery, closed down 1 1/32, at 99 21/32. The bond futures market closes at 3 P.M., New York time, hours before the cash market closes. Apparently Futile Efforts **********What initially unsettled the bond market were the apparently futile efforts by the Federal Reserve and the central banks of Japan and some Western Europe countries to arrest the dollar's decline. There was also concern in the credit market that American trade sanctions against Japan could create a climate that would inhibit the Japanese purchase of American securities. **********The resumed decline in the dollar also caused the stock market to post a sharp decline, sent the price of gold soaring by more than $10 an ounce and overshadowed improving fundamentals in the bond market, such as the smaller increase in the inflation rate in February reported yesterday. **********''It is bad and could get worse, despite the improving fundamentals,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''In fact, the selloff has already broken through critical technical levels and, to make matters worse, spread to all Treasury maturities.'' **********This included the three intermediate Treasury note issues auctioned this week. Late yesterday the 6.375 percent notes of 1989 sold Tuesday sold on a when-issued basis at 99 27/ 32, down 4/32, to yield 6.46 percent. Also on a when-issued basis, the 6.75 percent issue of 1991 sold Wednesday fell 11/32, to 99 24/32, and now yields 6.82 percent, while the 7 percent issue of 1994 that was auctioned Thursday at an average price of 99.772, to yield 7.04 percent, traded late yesterday at 99.60, for a yield of 7.15 percent. **********''While the selling of Treasury issues began in Tokyo and then spread to London, it became more pronounced here as dealers, including those who still hold sizable amounts of notes purchased this week, began to mark down prices in an effort to reduce risk,'' Mr. Sullivan noted. ''About the best news today is that there was very little selling from retail investors.'' Japanese Fiscal Year Cited **********Raymond W. Stone, chief financial economist at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, suggested that this week's selling of dollars and its ripple effect on the credit market could be related to the end of the Japanese fiscal year on March 31. As he explained: **********''It is reasonable to assume that many Japanese institutional investors preparing their annual statements would not like to show too many dollar assets on their books because of the sharp decline in the dollar's value against the yen in their fiscal year now ending. If so, then we may see a strong demand for dollars by these investors on and after April 1.'' **********As for the rise in the discount rates on Treasury bills yesterday, Mr. Stone said this reflected the fears of some market participants that the Federal Reserve might tighten credit to bolster the dollar. The Fed most easily can exert its power in the markets for bills and interbank overnight credit. **********The discount rate on the 90-day Treasury bills climbed seven basis points, to 5.65 percent; the six-month bills soared 13 basis points, to 5.71, and the one-year bills jumped 11 basis points, to 5.81 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/20/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Big Acquisition Is Part Of Rorer Leader's Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/20/busin.body_text: **********Robert E. Cawthorn has been rejuvenating the Rorer Group - and now he is seeking a big acquisition that would make Rorer one of the drug industry's major companies. **********One target of Mr. Cawthorn, it was disclosed last week, is the A. H. Robins Company, the pharmaceutical company that is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Part of its reorganization plan would allot $1.75 billion for women who contend they were injured by using Robins's Dalkon Shield birth control device. **********But that liability has not stopped pharmaceutical companies from courting Robins. The American Home Products Corporation first expressed an interest that was later withdrawn. Rorer's bid was made in late March, according to the Robins plan, which was filed last Thursday, and Rorer said it was still interested, although it added that there were no current negotiations. **********Mr. Cawthorn, who was born in Britain, first joined Rorer in 1982 as president of Rorer International. Rorer began as a small family pharmaceutical firm in Fort Washington, Pa., and its major product was Maalox, an antacid. Maalox is still a major Rorer product and the company is still based in Fort Washington. But most everything else has changed. **********Mr. Cawthorn, who became chairman and chief executive officer last May, was not available for an interview over the weekend but in the past the company has spelled out his strategy to make an acquisition that would put Rorer in the ranks of the top 10 to 15 drug companies. **********He has already doubled the company's size by acquiring Revlon's precription drug unit for $690 million, and he has restructured operations, trimmed the number of employees and recruited new executives. One member of the Rorer family, William H. Rorer 3d, resigned as a senior vice president in March to become president of Delaware Valley College. **********Mr. Cawthorn's strategy has been to focus the company's resources. It has taken a hard look at its research program, for example, and trimmed the least promising areas. **********Mr. Cawthorn, a graduate of Cambridge, moved to Canada in 1959 and joined Pfizer Canada. He spent a good deal of his business career with Pfizer, serving in Africa and Europe, before leaving to join Biogen, a genetic engineering concern based in Switzerland, where he was president for three and a half years before joining Rorer, where he became president in 1984.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/01/busin.body_text: **********Orders to factories, strengthened by another big jump in demand for military equipment, rose 2.3 percent in March, the Commerce Department said today. **********The department said orders for both durable and nondurable goods rose to a record $198.89 billion in March, surpassing the previous high of $197.15 billion set in December 1985. **********The March increase followed a 4.1 percent February advance, but the strength in both months was heavily influenced by a surge in demand for military equipment. **********Orders for military hardware shot up 39 percent in March. When that component is excluded, factory orders rose only 1 percent. **********Commerce Under Secretary Robert Ortner said the strength in the last two months should translate into faster economic growth. He said orders have been improving since the middle of last year, a trend he said was caused in part by the lower dollar's lifting of demand for American manufactured goods overseas. **********''We are beginning to recoup some of the business that we had lost in the last few years,'' Mr. Ortner said. **********But Bruce Steinberg, senior economist with Merrill Lynch & Company, said the March rise was ''not indicative of much strength in the economy.'' **********''It is consistent,'' he said, ''with our belief that the economy will be more sluggish during the current quarter.'' **********For March, the important category of nonmilitary capital goods rose 1.7 percent, the best increase since December. The category is considered a good barometer of business investment spending, an area that was weak all last year. **********The big jump in military orders, which followed an even bigger 48.5 percent increase in February, pushed total military orders to $9.7 billion. **********Orders for durable goods, items expected to last three or more years, rose 3.8 percent, to $105.76 billion, last month. This marked a revision from a report last week that had put the increase at 3.4 percent. **********Orders for nondurable goods edged up eight-tenths of 1 percent, to a March total of $93.13 billion, following a 1.4 percent February increase. **********Orders for transportation equipment had the largest increase, an 11 percent gain, to $30.3 billion in March, reflecting a surge in orders for military aircraft and ships. **********Orders for primary metals such as steel rose 5.9 percent, to $8.7 billion, and orders for non-electrical machinery rose 1.9 percent, to $17.1 billion. Orders for electrical machinery fell 4.6 percent, to $16.3 billion, a decline attributed to a drop in demand for communication equipment.
