https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/23/busin.body_text: **********SOME important Australian brewery officials made a stop in Times Square on Friday to light up a sign for Foster's. **********By Times Square historical standards, it is a rather undistinguished sign. No waterfall. No smoke rings. No moving parts. It just stands there.  All it says is Foster's - white against a blue background. There's also a red F inside a golden O. No indication of what product it is. The company and its agency, AC&R/DHB & Bess, obviously feel that most of its target audience will recognize the name from those delightful Paul Hogan commercials that brought word of the availability of Foster's Lager in these northern climes. **********To Peter T. Bartels, the managing director of Carlton & United Breweries, the very fact that the company is showing its colors at the Crossroads of the World adds a bit of sophistication to its image. **********Today in Australia, where Foster's is the only national brand, there will be a commercial showing the Times Square sign lighting. The point is to impress the loyal down-home Foster's drinkers and make them feel more sophisticated, just as they did six weeks ago when the brewery showed a spot about the new Foster's sign at Picadilly Circus in London. **********Carlton & United management has every right to have confidence in its trickle-back promotion method. It is just what they used some years ago to get a national franchise for Foster's Lager in a country where all the beers had been local. They introduced their brew abroad in places that had lots of Australians who would get hooked on the brand and bring their craving home with them. Today Foster's is Australia's No. 1 beer with a 22 percent share of the market. It is also sold in 80 other countries, having been introduced into the United States in 1983 by All Brand Imports. **********But it really did not have much advertising until 1985, when Paul Hogan, who stars in Australian tourism advertising as well as the movie ''Crocodile Dundee,'' was signed up to advertise Foster's. **********He helped increase the love which Mr. Bartles feels Americans have for Australia. ''They like the warmth and friendliness,'' he said, adding, half seriously, ''And we've got the only malt that's nuclear free.'' **********According to Ken Carnie, general manager of the brewery, imported beers account for 4.7 percent of the total United States beer market, and Foster's accounts for 1.8 percent of the 4.7 percent. But it is a big market. **********Meanwhile, if you're in the neighborhood and want to look at the 35-foot by 50-foot Foster's sign, check over the Panasonic wraparound on the northeast corner at 47th Street. **********Tell strangers it's a lager. They will be impressed by your worldliness.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/27/world.main_headline: China Won't Be at Soviet Fete Special to The New York Times
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/27/world.print_headline: China Won't Be at Soviet Fete Special to The New York Times
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/27/world.body_text: **********The Chinese Communist Party, rejecting overtures from Moscow, will not attend the celebration next week of the 70th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution, Soviet and Chinese officials said today. **********The rejection, while not unexpected, was a pointed reminder that despite Mikhail S. Gorbachev's offer to restore normal relations between Moscow and Beijing their estrangement remains deep. **********Nikolai Shishlin, deputy chief of the Propaganda Department of the Soviet Party Central Committee, said at a news conference that more than 80 Communist parties and 30 Socialist, Social Democratic and Labor parties would be represented at the two-day ceremony beginning Nov. 2. **********Asked if the Chinese would be among them, he said, ''So far we don't think that they are prepared, or have told us they are prepared, to participate.'' **********A Chinese official here said his country had decided definitely not to send a party representative, although a delegation from the Chinese-Soviet Friendship Society would be present. **********The Chinese party has boycotted Soviet Communist Party congresses and revolutionary holidays since the 1960's, when Mosow and Beijing split over ideology and foreign policy. The ideological differences that arose at the time of the Cultural Revolution in China have largely dissipated, and Mr. Gorbachev has overseen a general warming of relations. **********A Chinese official said no formal invitation was made to the Chinese party after Beijing rejected informal feelers put out by the Kremlin.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/27/busin.body_text: **********THERE was no cake or champagne, but an anniversary of some import to the financial world occurred last week. Ten years ago last Saturday, Treasury bond futures contracts were introduced by the Chicago Board of Trade to a skeptical and cautious investing public. **********''There was a lot of resistance'' to the contract, recalled Leslie Rosenthal, managing partner at Rosenthal & Company, a Chicago futures brokerage house. He served as chairman of the Board of Trade's financial instruments committee 10 years ago. **********''Dealers were opposed because they pretty much had a monopoly in the business,'' Mr. Rosenthal said. ''The contracts meant that they might be losing business, and that their spreads would narrow. A lot of them told us that interest rates didn't fluctuate enough to warrant such a contract.'' **********Such sentiments are long gone. Over the last decade ballooning Federal budget deficits, sharp moves in the value of the dollar and a large increase in the issuance of corporate debt have produced dramatic, daily moves in interest rates. **********Slowly, corporate and government bond holders came to the realization that establishing positions in Treasury bond futures was the most efficient way to protect themselves against those moves or to speculate on where interest rates might be headed. Today, the contract represents about 30 percent of all futures trading in the United States. ''In our first full year of trading, some 220,000 contracts changed hands,'' said Karsten Mahlmann, chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade. ''We now regularly trade twice that volume in one trading session.'' **********The board's bond futures contract requires a purchaser of one contract to take delivery of the equivalent of $100,000 in current United States Treasury bonds with a maturity of 15 years or more at a price set at the time of the purchase. A seller of the bond contract must deliver the bonds. **********Dealers who purchase bonds can hedge against a possible adverse price move by selling bond futures. In so doing, they spread the underwriting risk of Federal debt financing among the participants in the financial futures markets. **********In a classic hedging situation, if bond prices rise, the cash bond position profits and the futures position loses. If prices fall, losses are taken on the cash bond position, but the futures position gains in value. When set up correctly, the losses and profits from the hedge should be equal. **********Treasury securities are not the only cash instruments that can be hedged against with the Treasury bond futures contract. Because of its enormous size, price movements in the secondary market for government securities have a large impact on corporate and tax-free municipal bond rates as well. **********Because of that relationship, and because a corresponding product has not yet been introduced, holders of corporate bonds often hedge their positions in Treasury bond futures. A municipal bond futures contract was introduced on the Chicago Board of Trade in June 1985. The board plans to introduce a corporate bond futures contract this fall. **********''The only thing we lack is in the corporate sector,'' said Richard L. Sandor, director of financial futures at Drexel Burnham Lambert in Chicago. ''What the Treasury bond contract did was show what the potential for financial futures really was.'' Richard M. Kelly, president of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company and Deputy Assistant Secretary for debt management at the Treasury Department in 1978 and '79, said the contract had ''served as a useful hedging vehicle as well as an important speculative tool.'' He added, ''Moreover, as interest rate movements have become so important globally, this contract has been the focal point, along with the Treasury cash bond itself, of United States interest rates.'' **********The contract has also been a boon for the Treasury and, as a consequence, for American taxpayers. Initially, Mr. Kelly said, the Treasury was concerned that a futures market for Treasury securities might increase the volatility of long-term interest rates. **********On some days, experts said, the bond futures market might indeed make interest rates move more sharply than they otherwise would. But there is also little question, according to former Treasury officials, that the ability to hedge positions in a large, liquid market has made it easier for the Government to sell its securities. That, in turn, has lowered borrowing costs by a certain degree. **********''Either explicitly or implicitly, the Treasury bond contract has created a better environment for Treasury debt financing, especially as it relates to longer maturities,'' said John J. Niehenke, senior vice president for government securities at Nomura Securities International Inc. and Deputy Assistant Secretary (Federal finance) at the Treasury during 1984 and 1985. **********''The observable evidence is that the contract has added liquidity to the market, thereby perhaps adding efficiency.'' **********Current Treasury officials responsible for debt management were on vacation and could not be reached for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/busin.main_headline: REAGAN ASKED TO NAME VIGOROUS CHIEF AT S.E.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/busin.print_headline: REAGAN ASKED TO NAME VIGOROUS CHIEF AT S.E.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/busin.body_text: **********Members of Congress and the securities industry today urged President Reagan to nominate a Securities and Exchange Commission chairman who would continue to take a tough line on law enforcement and help restore investor confidence at a time when Wall Street is reeling from its biggest scandals since the 1920's. **********Their comments follow the White House announcement late Friday that John S. R. Shad, the former vice chairman of E. F. Hutton & Company who has headed the commission for the last five years, had been named Ambassador to the Netherlands. Mr. Shad won high praise from the lawmakers and the industry for his zeal in uncovering the major insider trading and securities fraud cases that have brought down some of Wall Street's most powerful figures. **********''This is probably one of those times in the history of the agency when the appointee is particularly critical,'' said Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the American Stock Exchange. ''I would suggest an S.E.C. commissioner who is an activist, and that means, unhappily, that he or she may have to interpret law as well as enforce it.'' **********Mr. Levitt, a Democrat, is one of the names mentioned as a possible successor to Mr. Shad. But Mr. Levitt said he had not been approached for the job and did not expect to be. Independence Emphasized **********Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, which has oversight of the commission, emphasized the importance of having an S.E.C chairman who could be independent of the White House. ''We need a commissioner who can carry out the law as written, not as the White House or the Office of Management and Budget or the Vice President's deregulation comission think it should be,'' he said. **********''The new chairman needs a staff that will fight for the budget and lawyers that are needed to properly enforce the law. He will need some tough lawyers, not some lace-drawer, ivory-towered economists advising him.'' **********Although lawmakers and industry officials said that the next S.E.C. chairman must have an intimate knowledge of the securities business, they agreed that naming an executive from a Wall Street firm would probably be a bad idea for the White House in the midst of the current scandals. ''Anybody from a firm who came through our committee would have to face some very hard questions,'' Mr. Dingell said. Short Term for New S.E.C. Chief **********Arthur Fleischer Jr., a prominent New York securities lawyer, noted that past Administrations turned to the American Bar Association's committee on securities as a source for S.E.C. appointments. He suggested the White House look to the academic community as well. **********''Whoever takes over is going to have a very short term, less than two years,'' he said. ''You really want to have somebody already well steeped in the securities field.'' Mr. Fleischer said that, in addition to enforcement activities, the new S.E.C. chairman would probably face the even more challenging task of helping to rewrite the nation's securities laws. **********Raymond E. Miles, dean of the Business School at the University of California at Berkeley, said the new S.E.C. chairman should be someone who has enormous public acceptance and who Wall Street views as a person of integrity. ''It's not clear to me we can prosecute our way out of this situation,'' he said. **********Senator William Proxmire, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, has already made it known that he favors legislation to slow down Wall Street's merger activity. A senior aide to the Senator said that Mr. Proxmire would welcome a new S.E.C chairman who shared these views. Mr. Proxmire's committee will have to confirm the Administration's nominee for the S.E.C. post. Strong Wall Street Background **********A senior aide to Senator Jake Garn of Utah, the ranking Republican on the Senate Banking Committee, said Mr. Garn preferred the S.E.C. chairman to have a strong securities background. ''We would obviously prefer to see someone at the end of his Wall Street career, as Mr. Shad was, rather than someone who plans to go back to Wall Street,'' the aide said. ''We want someone who can separate himself from the industry.'' **********The aides to both Mr. Proxmire and Mr. Garn said the White House had not yet asked the Senators for names of potential candidates for the S.E.C. job. Securities industry sources said they were unaware of any high-level White House search so far. **********''The names were flying all over the place last Friday, but nobobdy seems to know if there is such a thing as a list and if so who is keeping it, '' one source said. **********Among those mentioned as potential candidates for the job are Nicholas Brady, the chairman of Dillon, Read & Company; Robert Mundheim, dean of the law school at the University of Pennsylvania and general counsel of the Treasury Department during the Carter Administration; Lewis Black, a Delaware lawyer who is chairman of the American Bar Association's Securities Regulation Committee, and Frank Zarb, the former head of the Federal Energy Adminstration from 1974 to 1977 and currently a partner at Lazard Freres & Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/world.main_headline: The Indian 'War' Is Bitter; Can the Few Survive?
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/world.print_headline: BRASILIA JOURNAL; The Indian 'War' Is Bitter; Can the Few Survive?
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/world.body_text: **********Amid charges of conspiracy, forgery and espionage, a fierce battle has erupted between Brazil's Roman Catholic Church and powerful conservative groups that want commercial mining to be permitted on lands traditionally occupied by Indians. **********At stake, according to the church, is the survival of 230,000 Indians belonging to about 170 tribes who, almost five centuries after the Portuguese came to Brazil, still live off hunting and fishing in the Amazon jungles. **********''If the Indians are not defended now, they will disappear,'' Bishop Luciano Mendes de Almeida, president of the National Bishops' Conference, said. **********But to critics of the church the issue is also clear: should the territorial claims of fewer than two-tenths of 1 percent of Brazil's 140 million inhabitants be allowed to block exploitation of billions of dollars worth of minerals considered essential to the country's development? National Sovereignty Cited **********''The church's idea of a multi-ethnic society is that the Indians should be treated as independent nations,'' said Julio de Mesquita Neto, editor of O Estado de Sao Paulo, a conservative newspaper that has played a central role in the battle. ''That is an attack on Brazil's national sovereignty.'' **********The dispute itself is not new, but it has become heated in recent weeks as a special assembly nears completion of Brazil's new constitution. With the constitutional rights of both Indians and mining companies soon to be defined, every imaginable intrigue has been tried to influence the assembly's 559 members. **********The Indians themselves have been losing the battle against development at an accelerating rate over the last 20 years as first highways and hydroelectric dams and then peasant migrants, freelance gold prospectors and mining companies have encroached on once-impenetrable Amazonian refuges. **********The church has been almost alone in defending their rights to preserve their own culture on their own land. ''If the present irrational policy is maintained, no Indian group will survive,'' said Antonio Brand, executive secretary of the Council of Indian Missions. **********The church's lobbying of the Constitutional Assembly appeared to be bearing fruit this year as a majority of members began leaning toward protecting Indian lands against ''invaders.'' Soon afterward, the offensive against the church and its Council of Indian Missions, or CIMI, began. **********In August, O Estado do Sao Paulo charged that the council was trying to prevent commercial mining on Indian lands on behalf of powerful foreign mining interests that feared Brazil's low-cost production could further undermine world commodity prices. To support its claim, the daily presented four ''exclusive'' documents - two letters purportedly written by Mr. Brand, a letter from a so-called Christian Church World Council and a report of a purported meeting of Catholic and lay workers -along with extracts from available church documents. It also reprinted a map published by the Council of Indian Missions showing the location of both Indian tribes and gold, tin, bauxite and iron ore deposits. **********The church was outraged, charging that the ''exclusive'' documents were forgeries and that even the map had been altered. **********A special 18-member congressional committee was formed to investigate the charges, although political infighting between supporters and critics of the church have prevented it from completing its work. The writer of its report concluded that the documents were not authentic, but the committee's president refused to put the report to a vote, apparently preferring to leave the issue unresolved than to accept a defeat. **********Then, in early November, O Estado do Sao Paulo returned to the fray by publishing secret analyses of the role of the church and of the Council of Indian Missions prepared by the country's army-dominated National Secrity Council. The documents accuse the church of promoting Indian separatist movements, of having contacts with the Association of Tin Producing Countries and of campaigning against an army program to occupy Brazil's northermost borders. Justice Minister Complains **********Publication of these documents added to the controversy by demonstrating that the Government of President Jose Sarney also viewed the Catholic Church with hostility. Mr. Sarney denied to Bishop Almeida that he knew of the documents. But, in a separate meeting, Justice Minister Paulo Brossard complained at length to the Bishop about the Council of Indian Missions. **********While Brazilian mining companies view the church as their main enemy, the political heat generated by the Indian issue also reflects a more widely held view that this country must occupy the Amazon Basin to forestall expansion of foreign economic interests. **********Foreign criticism of deforestation and water pollution caused by migrants and miners is also seen by some officials to be part of a campaign to suggest the Amazon is the patrimony of mankind rather than exclusively Brazilian. **********In its lobbying of the Constitutional Assembly, Mr. Brand said the church was insisting that it did not oppose Brazil's development but believed mineral resources outside Indian lands should first be exploited. Mr. Mesquita, however, remained unconvinced. **********''We have discovered that all mining areas have Indians on top of them,'' he said. ''As soon as minerals are found, Indians suddenly appear.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/26/busin.body_text: **********Last week's sudden decline in interest rates led to a flurry of new issues in the corporate market, a trend that may continue this week, analysts said. **********More than $3.8 billion of new corporate notes and bonds were sold last week, most with maturities of five years and less. Even if corporations continue to be wary of issuing 30-year bonds, where interest costs would still exceed 10 percent for most issuers, investment bankers said many issues with shorter maturities are possible. **********Besides the opportunity presented by lower interest rates, corporate borrowers may want to sell debt before the market is hit with a heavy supply of new Treasury issues next week, analysts said. **********The only Treasury auctions this week are today's regular sale of three-month and six-month bills. Late Friday, the outstanding three-month bill was trading at about 5.26 percent, while the six-month issue was at 6.00 percent. **********Government securities dealers expect the Treasury to announce on Wednesday the details of the note and bond auctions for next week. **********Analysts expect the Treasury sales to consist of about $10 billion or more of three-year notes, $10 billion of 10-year notes and $4.5 billion of 30-year bonds. Recent quarterly financings have included about $9 billion of 30-year bonds and slightly smaller-sized three-year and 10-year issues, but the Treasury has only about $4.5 billion of authority remaining to issue bonds with an interest rate of more than 4 1/4 percent. **********Dealers expect the Treasury to auction more of the actively traded 8 7/8 percent issue due on Aug. 15, 2017, rather than offer new bond issues. Some analysts said that if additional money were needed, cash management bills - short-term securities that are offered in minimum denominations of $1 million - could be sold. **********In the Federal agency market, meanwhile, the Federal Farm Credit Banks plans to announce on Wednesday interest rates for three- and six-month bonds totaling $1.46 billion. **********Interest rates have also declined sharply in the tax-exempt market, but not enough to make it profitable for local governments to refinance large amounts of outstanding bonds. **********The following new debt issues are scheduled for sale this week:  TAXABLE  THURSDAY **********General Telephone of the Southwest, $80 million of first mortgage bonds due in 2017, A/Aa-3/AA-. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/13/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Yields on U.S. Bonds Decline
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/13/busin.body_text: **********Yields on Treasury bonds fell to around 8 1/2 percent yesterday for the first time since late April, in response to a slight decline in the trade deficit and slower than expected inflation. **********Government reports on the trade deficit and inflation went to the heart of the issues that have driven bond yields up sharply from about 7.55 percent since late March. **********Large American trade deficits had helped raise bond yields and depressed prices because many economists said a weaker dollar was needed to reduce imports and raise exports. Weakness in the dollar, in turn, discouraged the bond market because it creates losses for foreign investors at the same time as it puts upward pressure on inflation as prices of imports rise. Concern About Inflation **********Although one month of statistics is not enough to eliminate concerns about inflation and the effects of large trade deficits are far from gone, they have subsided enough for the yield of 30-year Treasury bonds to fall from more than 9 percent three weeks ago. The drop in Treasury bond yields has been in a period when the dollar has stabilized, a trend that continued yesterday. **********Yesterday prices of Treasury bonds began rising quickly when traders learned that the May Producer Price Index rose only three-tenths of a percent, or about half as much as expected, and the April trade deficit declined to $13.3 billion in April from $13.6 billion a month earlier. **********In London, the 8 3/4 percent issue due in 2017 jumped a point in a few minutes. When trading began in New York, those gains were extended, and the newest 30-year Treasury issue ended the day at 102 26/32, up 1 7/8 points, to yield aobut 8.49 percent. A day earlier, the closely watched long-term bond ended with a yield of 8.66 percent. The Note Sector **********In the note sector, the 8 percent issue due in two years rose more than 1/4 point, and was offered at 101, to yield 7.44 percent. **********''There was some good investor demand early in the day,'' said Robert Schumacher, a Chicago-based Treasury bond trader for Nomura Securities International. He added, however, that the investors who joined securities dealers in adding to their holdings yesterday, were primarily ''the market timing-type accounts'' who often add to their positions at the same time as securities dealers. **********''There was some sentiment that perhaps the bond market and the dollar have stabilized for a while,'' said Stephen Behnke, head of trading at Midland Montagu Government Securities Inc. While that sentiment clearly buoyed demand yesterday, he cautioned that confidence was not high enough to suggest that the market is on the verge of extensive price gains. **********''There are too many balls in the air about the economy, the dollar and the change in leadership at the Fed, which is keeping people cautious,'' he said. **********Other market sources said that many other potential bond investors remain on the sidelines. ''You could not describe this as a buying panic,'' one institutional salesman said. ''It was far more selective,'' he added, with many buyers preferring intermediate-term corporate issues to long-term Treasury bonds. **********Higher prices for Treasury bonds quickly led to new financings and plans for new financings in the corporate market. Besides yesterday's two large issues by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation and Chemical Bank, totaling $600 million, many more companies are considering note or bond sales next week, investment bankers said. **********The G.M.A.C. $300 million issue of 8 5/8 percent notes due 1992 was offered at 99.70, to yield 8.70 percent, through Salomon Brothers. Noncallable for life, the notes were offered with a yield of about 72-hundredths of a percentage point more than five-year Treasury notes. They are rated Aa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********Banking companies continue to show a hefty appetite for new capital in the form of notes due in 12 years or longer. **********The Chemical New York Corporation offered $300 million of 9 3/4 percent subordinated capital notes due 1999 at a price of 99.58, to yield 9.81 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. Earlier in the week, the Chase Manhattan Corporation offered a 12-year issue with a yield of 10.036 percent. Chemical and Chase are both rated A-3 by Moody's. S. & P. rated the Chemical issue A+.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/08/world.main_headline: U.S. Judge Orders Man Held on Israeli Charges
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/08/world.print_headline: U.S. Judge Orders Man Held on Israeli Charges
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/08/world.body_text: **********A United States citizen accused of taking part in a terrorist attack on a passenger bus in the Israeli-occupied West Bank was ordered held without bail yesterday by a Federal magistrate in Brooklyn after his arrest here on Wednesday. **********The defendant, Mahmoud M. Atta, 33 years old, who was born in Ramala in West Bank and became an American citizen in 1982, was taken into custody when he arrived at Kennedy International Airport after being expelled from Venezuela. He was held on an extradition warrant from Israel, which has an extradition treaty with the United States and Venezuela does not. **********According to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Mr. Atta has identified himself as a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********In the attack on the bus, which took place April 12, 1986, the bus driver was killed and three passengers were seriously wounded, according to documents filed in the case. **********The Mr. Atta did not say anything at his arraignment late yesterday afternoon before Magistrate John L. Caden in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. But his court-appointed lawyer, R. James Bradford, told the court that his client said ''he is not the person who is wanted'' and that there was also a question of jurisdiction.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/01/world.main_headline: Possible Mine Sightings Mount in Persian Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/01/world.print_headline: Possible Mine Sightings Mount in Persian Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/01/world.body_text: **********A new mine scare sent commercial shipping on a circuitous route through the northern Persian Gulf today as two convoys under United States Navy escort steamed north and south through the waterway. **********The latest reported danger zones were near Farsi Island, a stronghold of Iran's Revolutionary Guards. Gulf-based shipping executives said several possible sightings had been reported by ships sailing to and from Kuwait. **********British minesweepers spent a second day searching southern waters of the gulf, where possible sightings of mines had been reported, but they apparently found nothing. **********The 46,723-ton Gas Prince, one of nine re-registered Kuwaiti tankers sailing under the American flag, steamed south through the gulf on its second outbound voyage since the convoy operation began in mid-July. **********A Pentagon spokesman, Maj. Larry Icenogle, said another convoy moving north consisted of two Military Sealift Command ships carrying supplies, apparently to Bahrain for the Navy's Middle East Force. He identified the ships as the 39,000-ton transport oiler Gus Darnell and the motor vessel Patriot. **********The cargo ships were being escorted by the missile frigates Rentz, Ford and Thach, and the Raleigh, an amphibious landing ship. **********The convoy passed without incident through the southern gulf. **********Early today, an Iranian gunboat raked the 63,763-ton Greek tanker Koriana with machine-gun fire and rocket-propelled grenades as it sailed to Saudi Arabia. Damage was minor, and there were no reported injuries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/08/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; THOSE TRICKY MUTUAL FUND COSTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/08/busin.body_text: **********UNTIL recently, mutual fund investors faced a simple choice: They could buy no-load funds directly, or they could purchase load funds and pay a broker's commission of up to 8.5 percent. But now it requires a heavy dose of new math to compare the costs of different funds. Apart from the customary operating expenses and management fees, fund managers have devised a farrago of other charges - high or low loads imposed when you buy, exit fees when you sell and some hard-to-find fees levied while you hold the fund. **********''There are too many different types of charges today, and it's getting too confusing for the investor'' to sort through them all, said Kathleen Quigley Lantero, editor of Wiesenberger Investment Company Services. Of the 1,000 mutual funds the company monitors, about half impose front-end sales loads. About the same number have so-called 12b-1 plans, which were authorized by the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1980. **********These plans, named for the regulation that permitted their creation, let funds deduct up to 1.25 percent of their assets to cover advertising and other marketing expenses. Investors must typically plow through the fine print of a prospectus to find out if the fund has a 12b-1 plan; then they must check the most recent accounting statement to see what percentage of assets the plan absorbed. With 12b-1 plans, mutual funds ''can levy pretty much what the devil they want, and the only way you can find out is in retrospect,'' said Gerald W. Perritt, editor of The Mutual Fund Letter. **********Norman Fosback, president of the Institute for Econometric Research, in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., dismisses 12b-1 charges of less than three-tenths of 1 percent as a ''minor consideration.'' Charges of more than 1 percent he calls ''clearly abusive.'' **********Apart from 12b-1 charges, some funds impose redemption fees when investors sell their holdings. These may be levied as a flat percentage of the share price or on a sliding scale, ranging from 6 percent, say, if you sell in the first year, to zero if you hold your shares six years or more. **********All of this leaves investors in a dilemma. They cannot rely on funds advertised as no-load to be free of sales costs. And how do the various charges and fees stack up over the long term? If you plan to keep your funds invested until you retire in six years, for example, are you paying more in expenses if you buy the fund with the 8.5 percent sales load or the fund with the .75 percent 12b-1 charge and the sliding-scale exit fee? John Markese, director of research for the American Association of Individual Investors in Chicago, has come up with a possible solution: a series of formulas that convert the various expenses into equivalent charges. Using his formula, the investor can convert a front-end load into an equivalent annual percentage 12b-1 plan, or find the 12b-1's equivalent in a front- or back-end load. Many shareholders are surprised by the results, he said. **********Mr. Markese's first formula converts front-end loads to their 12b-1 equivalents for various holding periods. In this case, the 12b-1 charge equals the front-end load, stated as a percentage, divided by the investment holding period stated in years. For example, suppose a fund has a 3 percent front-end load and you hold it for four years; if you take .03 and divide it by 4, the answer is three-fourths of 1 percent - and that percentage would be the equivalent 12b-1 charge. **********This approach also lets you compare costs of no-load funds that have 12b-1 plans with an equivalent front-end load fund. For example, a no-load fund with a one-half of 1 percent 12b-1 plan held five years is cheaper than a 4 percent load fund, which over the same time period is equivalent to an eight-tenths of 1 percent 12b-1 charge. **********To compare a 12b-1 charge to its equivalent front-end load, multiply the 12b-1 annual charge, stated as a percent, by the number of years the investment is held. So, for example, an investor who holds shares in a no-load fund with a three-fourths of 1 percent 12b-1 plan for five years has paid the equivalent of a 3.75 percent front-end load. **********Investors who are not sure how long they intend to hold their mutual fund shares can compare charges by finding the break-even point at which the charges become equal: To do so, divide the front-end load by the 12b-1 annual charge, both stated as percentages. For instance, a one-quarter of 1 percent 12b-1 charge becomes equals to a 3 percent front-end load after 12 years (3 divided by .25 equals 12). Because annual charges build up over time, investors who expect to hold securities for longer than the break-even point would be better off with a one-time sales charge; those who expect to sell more quickly would find a 12b-1 plan the cheaper option. TO convert a back-end load into its 12b-1 equivalent, first multiply the number of years the investment is held (n) by the sum of 1 plus a discount rate (Mr. Markese uses 10 percent), raised to the nth power. Then divide the back-end load by the result. For example, a 4 percent back-end load for fund shares held four years converts to a .68 percent 12b-1 charge (Raise 1.1 to the fourth power and multiply by 4; take the product, 5.8564, and divide it into 4 for a result of .68 percent.) Some funds with front- or back-end loads also have 12b-1 plans, Mr. Markese pointed out. In these cases, you must add the annual 12b-1 charge to the 12b-1 equivalent for the load fees, to get the total fund expenses. Say you are considering a fund with a 3 percent back-end load plus an annual .5 percent 12b-1 charge. For a three-year holding period, the back-end load converts to a .75 percent 12b-1 equivalent; add to this the .5 percent 12b-1 charge, for a total annual cost of 1.25 percent. **********There are two reasons why it is worth the trouble to compare these costs. First, when you are talking about a long-term investment, particularly an Individual Retirement Account, cumulative deductions can make a big difference. **********''Small annual charges can significantly reduce your pot of retirement dollars,'' Mr. Perritt said. ''For example, over 15 years, a one-half of 1 percent 12b-1 charge equals a front-end load of about 7.5 percent.'' If you move your account around and each place siphons off a fee, he added, ''over time it adds up to a lot of money.'' **********The second reason is that the tax act has made these charges more expensive for the investor. The itemized deduction for miscellaneous business expenses will be harder to obtain, since only expenses in excess of 2 percent of adjusted gross income will qualify - and this means that most investors will have to pick up the tab for investment advisory fees paid on their behalf by the funds. Beginning in 1987, mutual funds must add these fees to dividends and other payments that are considered taxable income for the shareholder.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.main_headline: Moscow Confirms Gas Leak During Nuclear Weapons Test
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.print_headline: Moscow Confirms Gas Leak During Nuclear Weapons Test
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union revealed today that gas had leaked during an underground nuclear test earlier this month, but said there was no radioactive fallout. **********The announcement came after a report from Norwegian officials four days ago of a small increase in the level of radioactive iodine in the air of Norway, Sweden and Denmark. **********Officials from Norway's national radiation control authority said at the time that the increase might have been caused by a Soviet nuclear test but that it was in such small quantities that it presented no health hazard. **********The official press agency Tass, in an announcement, said an inquiry into the gas leak was begun because of ''incoming queries'' and ''claims circulated by the Western mass media, with the Americans being especially zealous in the effort.'' **********It said the leak occurred inadvertently during a nuclear test for military purposes on Aug. 2 on Novaya Zemlya island, north of the Arctic Circle. **********''Competent organizations of the U.S.S.R. have carried out an extra and all-round check, which has showed that after the explosion there took place the leak of an insignificant amount of gaseous products, which have not led to the formation of radioactive fallout,'' Tass said. **********''This excludes the possibility of radioactive fallout in any state as a result of the underground nuclear explosion on Novaya Zemlya island.'' **********The message also said, ''The population was not subjected to any danger of radiation effects.'' **********The Soviet Union has conducted 15 underground nuclear tests since Feb. 28, when Mikhail S. Gorbachev dropped a ban on such tests he began on Aug. 6, 1985. **********Mr. Gorbachev repeatedly appealed to the Reagan Administration to join in the ban, but the United States refused, saying it needed to catch up with advances in Soviet technology. **********The Tass report repeated a call for ''a general and complete prohibition of nuclear weapon tests.'' **********The Soviet Union promised fuller and quicker reporting on nuclear incidents after the explosion at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant April 16, 1986. It took Soviet officials days to acknowledge that the accident had occurred.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/11/busin.body_text: **********The Supermarkets General Corporation, the nation's eighth-largest food chain, is hunting for a friendly buyer, sources close to the search said yesterday. Working through its Wall **********Street adviser, Shearson Lehman Brothers, the company is understood to be approaching leading food chains in the wake of Monday's $1.6 billion takeover bid from the Haft family of Washington. **********No clear indication of interested bidders has yet emerged. **********But the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, No. 7 in the country, is among the chains mentioned. A.& P.'s chairman, James Wood, has been expanding through acquisition. Analysts said, however, that a deal with the A.& P. could pose antitrust problems. Investment bankers said that **********Supermarkets was probably studying other options, such as a management buyout or a restructuring and stock buyback. **********The Hafts are offering $41.75 a share. Supermarkets stock closed at $41.125 a share yesterday, down 62.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/busin.snippet: LEAD: Joseph F. Paquette Jr. studied civil engineering, went to work for a utility, showed a flair for numbers and became an accountant. Now, more than 30 years later, he is returning to operations.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/busin.main_headline:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
CMS Financial Official Shifts to Operations
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
CMS Financial Official Shifts to Operations
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Joseph F. Paquette Jr. studied civil engineering, went to work for a utility, showed a flair for numbers and became an accountant. Now, more than 30 years later, he is returning to operations. **********Joseph F. Paquette Jr. studied civil engineering, went to work for a utility, showed a flair for numbers and became an accountant. Now, more than 30 years later, he is returning to operations. **********Yesterday he was appointed president of CMS and president and chief operating officer of the Consumers Power Company, Michigan's largest utility. CMS, which is the holding company for Consumers Power, had hired him 18 months ago as its chief financial officer and then promoted him to vice chairman, a title he will now relinquish. **********''It's a radical change for me,'' Mr. Paquette said in a telephone interview. ''I will not have any financial activities reporting to me; I'll be in charge of supply, production and distribution.'' Mr. Paquette, who is 53 years old, said finance, accounting, planning and auditing would now be added to the responsibilities of S. Kinnie Smith Jr., 56, who remains vice chairman and general counsel of CMS and Consumers. **********William T. McCormick Jr., the 43-year-old chairman and chief executive of CMS and Consumers, will thus be freed of daily management cares to concentrate on expanding CMS's nonregulated businesses, in part through acquisitions, Mr. Paquette said. These businesses, which do not report to Michigan's utilities regulators, are grouped under CMS Enterprises and include oil and gas exploration and a co-generation company. **********''We are planning acquisitions in energy-related activities,'' Mr. Paquette said. ''They aren't things we're going to jump into tomorrow, but down the line.'' **********CMS was close to bankruptcy two years ago and is far from it today, a turnabout partly attributable to the financial restructuring that Mr. Paquette oversaw. The company was crushed by the debt that derived from its failed $4.2 billion nuclear plant project in Midland, Mich., the shell of which is now being turned into a gas-turbine co-generation plant in which Consumers holds a 49 percent interest. **********Michigan regulators allowed the nearly moribund utility a $99 million annual rate increase for the 1985-91 period on condition that CMS retire $1.9 billion of its debt. Mr. Paquette said $1 billion had already been paid off - $600 million of it through the calling of preference stock, the rest through the redemption of bonds. Earnings per common share, which stood at 44 cents for the first nine months of 1986, were up to $1.24 for the comparable period this year. **********Meanwhile, the company cut staff and halted most construction spending; today, a spokesman said, it has 251 customers per employee, the best on record and far greater than the 157 average of the industry as a whole. **********Mr. Paquette learned about financial bailouts in his first job, at the Philadelphia Electric Company, where he served the last eight of his 30 years' employment as chief financial officer. ''At the time the Midland plant was in construction, Philadelphia Electric was also building a nuclear plant of almost the same size,'' he said. ''I was involved with raising the funds.'' But opposition to the plant was weaker in Philadelphia, and so the project, which cost $6 billion, was completed. **********Mr. Paquette was born in Norwood, Mass., and received his B.S. in civil engineering from Yale in 1956. He and his wife, Ellin, live in Ann Arbor, Mich., and have three children.
