https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/05/busin.body_text: **********IN January, Bernan Foods, which for 25 years has marketed hors d'oeuvres primarily through kosher caterers and stores, introduced Bernie's East Bagel Dog, a kosher, all-beef frank encased in bagel dough that will be sold through supermarket chains. For the first time the Newark company is actively pursuing non-kosher consumers, through ads in general circulation publications. **********The Paskesz Candy Company in Brooklyn, which in this decade has added a dozen new products to its line of snack foods each year, has changed much of its packaging from black and white to four-color, redesigned its logo, and beefed up its national sales force. According to vice president Henri Schmidt, the changes have helped revenues quadruple since 1980, to $12 million last year. **********Increasingly, manufacturers of kosher foods are breaking away from their traditional word-of-mouth advertising policies. ''These companies are spending money on sustained advertising, sophisticated campaigns with slick slogans and graphics, direct mail programs, trade show appearances, and sales kits,'' said Menachem Lubinsky, president of Lubinsky Communications, a marketing firm. ''This had been unheard of in the kosher business.'' **********The Brooklyn-based Kedem Royal Wine Company, for one, has increased its ad budget to more than $1 million this year from $25,000 in 1980, and is buying space in gourmet food and wine magazines to advertise its 95 products, up from just 25 in 1980. And it has downsized its kosher certification symbol and moved it to the back of the label, in an effort to position its Chardonnay, zinfandel and other premium wines against French and California varieties. **********Kedem's goal is to overcome a widespread assumption - even among Jews - that all kosher wines are cloyingly sweet. ''Kosher wines definitely have an image problem,'' said David Herzog, Kedem's executive vice president. **********Kedem has already made some progress: Mr. Herzog says that Kedem shipped 1.1 million cases of wine and grape juice last year, up from 250,000 in 1980. He estimates that non-Jewish customers accounted for 20 percent of the sales. **********Some companies are using humor to persuade non-Jewish consumers to try their products, following the lead of the well-known ''You don't have to be Jewish to love Levy's'' campaign. Horowitz Margareten, a matzoh maker, ran a radio ad in which an enthusiastic Texan touted the glories of his wife's ''chile con matzoh farfel.'' **********Marketers of foods that are not as readily associated with the kosher market are touting their certification to Jewish customers. For the last few years, Procter & Gamble's Puritan Oil has promoted its kosher-for-Passover status by advertising in Jewish publications with cents-off coupons; according to a company spokesman, the redemption rate has been three to four times higher than for coupons appearing in general circulation publications. **********Similarly, Ronzoni is running a compaign featuring kosher pasta recipes in Jewish publications in New York, Miami, Philadelphia, San Francisco and Los Angeles. ''Many classic pasta recipes contain both meat and dairy, or pork, and we wanted to show Jewish consumers that we recognize them as a very important group of pasta users,'' said Carin Gendell, group product manager at Ronzoni.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/world.main_headline: Prosecutor in Soviet Rejects New Trial for War Criminal
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/world.print_headline: Prosecutor in Soviet Rejects New Trial for War Criminal
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/world.body_text: **********The public prosecutor in the Soviet Baltic republic of Estonia said today that he saw no grounds for holding a new trial for Karl Linnas, convicted of being a Nazi war criminal and sentenced to death in absentia 25 years ago. **********The prosecutor, Karl Kimmel, told state television no fresh evidence had come to light since the first trial by the Estonian Supreme Court and that Mr. Linnas had failed to tell investigators anything substantial since being deported to Tallinn from the United States in April. Mr. Linnas has asked for a pardon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/22/busin.main_headline: Big Firms Face Losses, Small Ones Shut Down
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/22/busin.print_headline: Big Firms Face Losses, Small Ones Shut Down
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/22/busin.body_text: **********A number of Wall Street firms suffered big trading losses from the stock market's plunge, although the true extent of the losses may not be known for several months, analysts say. **********''Every single firm that engaged in risk arbitrage lost money,'' said one analyst who asked not to be named. ''They had to. You can't hedge that.'' A sizable number of firms use risk arbitrage, the buying and selling of shares in anticipation of future market moves. **********The size of these losses may not be known until the firms issue their quarterly earnings in January. By that time, any gains from trading in the remaining months of the quarter will offset these losses, so the impact of the historic 508-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average on Monday may never be known. 3 Firms Suspended But if big firms face losses, some small securities firms have been squeezed out of business or forced to merge. The New York Stock Exchange yesterday suspended three member firms that fell below its capital requirements. Other small firms - an over-the-counter market maker and a Grand Rapids, Mich., broker -have closed their doors. **********The three Big Board firms were private partnerships that had traded for their own accounts and did not take orders from the public. One of them, Metropolitan Securities Inc., is an options trading house whose main partner is Jon J. Edelman, the brother of the corporate raider Asher B. Edelman. The other two are AIG Inc., which is not related to the large insurance company of the same name, and William D. Mayer & Company. Both are based in New York. **********In addition, capital inadequacy forced the closing of H. B. Shaine & Company, a Big Board member in Grand Rapids who customer accounts are being transferred to another broker under the supervision of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation. And Brown, Knapp & Company, an O-T-C market maker in listed stocks off the exchange floor, was forced to close. **********''At this time, the industry is diligently responding to the extraordinary circumstances of the last three days,'' David S. Ruder, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said. ''While there has been isolated firm failures and temporary operational difficulties, on balance, the industry remains strong.'' **********Perrin Long, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Services, observed: ''There's no question that firms who make markets in O-T-C stocks, who take equity risk arbitrage positions for their own account and those that position major equity blocks for institutional clients have sustained losses. The depth of the losses would be directly proportional to the number of shares in their inventory.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/busin.main_headline: Dollar Drops Late in Day Amid German Uncertainty
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS; Dollar Drops Late in Day Amid German Uncertainty
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/busin.body_text: **********After closing higher in relation to the West German mark in European trading yesterday, the dollar weakened in later New York trading amid uncertainty about whether the Bundesbank would cut its main lending rate. **********Also, currency traders were not impressed with Bonn's announcement of a widely expected package of economic stimulants, said Keith S. Cheverall, chief currency trader at the Nippon Credit Bank. **********Earlier, in overseas trading, the dollar had strengthened against the mark, an improvement that dealers attributed to intervention by several European central banks. But the dollar weakened when trading began in the United States. **********''Before our New York market opened, nervous traders in Asia and later in Europe bid the dollar up by covering what was substantial short positions,'' Mr. Cheverall said. ''The dollar buying was largely based on the expectation that the West German central bank would announce a cut of at least a quarter-point in its discount rate.'' **********In late dealings in New York, the dollar was bid at 1.6473 West German marks, down from Tuesday's 1.6570. The dollar ended at 132.57 Japanese yen, down from 133.40, after closing at 133.70 in Tokyo. **********The plan announced by the West German Government is aimed at bolstering the nation's economy by offering low-rate loans to local authorities and small businesses. But many analysts doubt it will spur growth much. **********The United States and other nations have been urging such steps. Washington contends that a stronger West Germany economy would lead to greater demand for American and other foreign goods, helping reduce the huge United States trade deficit. **********The Bundesbank's main lending rate, the discount rate, has been at 3 percent since it was last reduced in January. In West Germany it remained unclear whether the central bank would cut the rate today. **********Currency traders also reacted negatively to reports yesterday that Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg of West Germany said a meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations, reportedly suggested by Washington, would not be productive. **********In Tokyo the governor of the Bank of Japan, Satoshi Sumita, said it had no plans to cut its discount rate from the current 2.5 percent, already the lowest among major countries. **********''If the Bundesbank's discount rate is not cut, we can expect the dollar to resume its decline,'' said Mr. Cheverall of the Nippon Credit Bank, ''because the basic downward trend in the dollar remains intact.'' **********Albert Soria, chief currency trader at Bank Julius Baer of Zurich, said the thinking among many overseas currency traders was that ''the Treasury has created a monster by tolerating the erosion of the dollar's value, which, if not arrested by forceful economic measures, could cause precious metals prices to explode, and this in turn could easily undermine confidence in all markets.'' **********Gold bullion fell $2.75 an ounce, to $487.75, at the Republic National Bank of New York late yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/28/busin.main_headline: PHILIPPINES AND BANKS IN $13.2 BILLION DEBT PACT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/28/busin.print_headline: PHILIPPINES AND BANKS IN $13.2 BILLION DEBT PACT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/28/busin.body_text: **********In a move that appears to mark a turning point in Manila's debt crisis, creditor banks yesterday announced a restructuring agreement on $13.2 billion in Philippine debt. **********The banks said that, for the first time since the Philippine debt crisis began in 1982, they would accept interest payments in the form of notes that are essentially i.o.u.'s, in place of cash. The 17-year rescheduling accord would also set the interest on most of the loans at a more favorable interest rate. Something for Both Parties **********The agreement, therefore, apparently satisfied the needs of both parties. From a political point of view, Jaime V. Ongpin, the finance minister under President Corazon C. Aquino, will be able to argue that he kept the bank's spread to roughly what Mexico achieved in a debt accord last year, while at the same time preserving his nation's hard-currency reserves and winning investments in the Philippine economy. **********As for the banks, the accord was designed to allow them to book far higher returns on their Philippine debt than they do on their Mexican loans. In addition, Brazil's recent suspension of its interest payments had made them more concerned about reaching an agreement with Manila. **********''All parties can go home saying they got something,'' said Paul Sacks, president of Multinational Strategies Inc., a New York-based consulting concern. ''It clearly represents something of a compromise.'' **********Until now, the banks, which include Manufacturers Hanover, Citicorp and other money center institutions, have steadfastly refused to take ''paper'' for interest payments. They feared that such a practice might set a dangerous precedent, with many developing countries clamoring to settle their interest payments in i.o.u.'s. However, it had been anticipated that the new loan accord, reached late Thursday night, might represent a reversal of that position. **********At a news conference in New York yesterday, Mr. Ongpin said the bank creditors would take their interest in cash or in ''Philippine Investment Notes,'' issued by the central bank of the Philippines. Specifically, according to Mr. Ongpin, the restructuring agreement envisions three possible outcomes, all aimed at preserving the dollar reserves of the central bank and bolstering the troubled Philippine economy. **********Under the first, the central bank would periodically sell Philippine Investment Notes, or P.I.N.'s, through Wall Street firms. The notes, which are dollar-denominated obligations of the central bank, would be bought by foreign investors, such as multinational corporations. Then, the Philippines would use the dollar proceeds to pay interest to the banks. Incentive Plan **********The notes will be structured so that the multinational corporations that buy them would have an incentive to exchange the notes at the Philippine central bank for pesos, which in turn would be invested in the Filipino economy. **********A second possibility is that banks themselves would accept the notes. In this case, the banks would then sell the notes at a profit in the financial markets, much like banks trade in Government securities. **********The third eventuality calls for the banks to act like the multinational corporations in the first scenario. After buying the notes, the banks would redeem them for pesos, then use this money to buy a stake in financial institutions in the Philippines. **********In both the second and third cases, the plan's intent is for the notes to wind up in the hands of corporate investors who would want to exchange them for pesos and take equity positions in the Filipino economy. Similar Plans in Mexico, Chile **********Such a ''debt-for-equity swap,'' an approach involving substitution of outstanding debt principal for equity investment, is already under way in Mexico and Chile. **********''We will not pay interest out of reserves,'' Mr. Ongpin said at the news conference. ''We will sell P.I.N.'s.'' **********With the program, he added, an estimated $1 billion of foreign exchange outflows would be conserved over the 17 years during which the loans are to be restructured. **********While the restructuring could benefit the economy, the Philippines' bankers could also benefit. **********The reason is this: While the seven-eighths of a percentage point ''spread'' on the restructured loans is just a hair more than the 13-sixteenths spread that Mexico is paying on its new loans, the banks stand to earn much higher returns by trading the central bank's notes for a profit in the financial markets, or by redeeming them at the central bank for pesos. Guarantee of a Profit **********The Philippine Investment Notes will be structured so that banks will have an incentive to take the notes as interest payments in lieu of cash. Moreover, if the banks do exchange the notes for pesos, the Filipinos have agreed to guarantee a profit on the swap. **********In the view of many experts, however, the agreement also represented an exercise in obfuscation, although the parties hailed it as a historic first for the management of global debt. **********While the Philippines' creditor banks will be recording the same interest each quarter - seven-eighths of a percentage point over Libor - no one will ever know how much total return the banks really earn on their loans. The banks' trading in the investment notes, or any exchanges they make of notes for pesos, will be kept secret by the central bank. **********''The fundamental importance of the settlement is that all parties have agreed to something that is obscure,'' said Mr. Sacks of Multinational Strategies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/30/world.main_headline: U.S. STEP IN DEAVER CASE ANGERS CANADA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/30/world.print_headline: U.S. STEP IN DEAVER CASE ANGERS CANADA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/30/world.body_text: **********The attempt by the special prosecutor in the Michael K. Deaver case to compel Canada's Ambassador to the United States and his wife to testify in Mr. Deaver's trial has angered the Canadian Government, which had hoped that the diplomatic and political ramifications of its involvement with Mr. Deaver were at an end. **********The political storm that burst when Mr. Deaver's $105,000 contract with Canada became public last year subsided rapidly after a House of Commons committee held an inconclusive hearing on the affair. But after process servers arrived at the Canadian Embassy in Washington earlier this week with subpoenas for the Ambassador, Allen E. Gotlieb, and for his wife, Sondra, the issue was thrust onto the public agenda once more. **********In the House of Commons, there have been renewed questions about the propriety of hiring Mr. Deaver to assist Canada in its effort to obtain United States controls on acid rain. But on the narrower issue of the Gotlieb subpoenas there has been virtually no dissent, with opposition politicians backing the Government's stand that the Ambassador and his wife are protected by diplomatic immunity from any requirement to appear in court. State Dept. Supports Stand **********The Government's stand was outlined in two forcefully worded statements by the External Affairs Minister, Joe Clark, and was supported by the State Department, which sent lawyers to court in Washington Thursday to argue against the subpoenas. In Ottawa, a senior official in Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's office, Bruce Phillips, said today that no legal maneuvering by the special prosecutor, Whitney North Seymour Jr., would have any effect. **********''They're not going to be in court, no matter what,'' said Mr. Phillips, who served until recently as minister for public affairs in the Canadian Embassy in Washington. **********Mr. Phillips, who is now director of communications for Mr. Mulroney, said the Government was particularly incensed by Mr. Seymour's statement that Canada was guilty of ''duplicitous behavior.'' In fact, Mr. Phillips said, the truth was exactly the reverse, since Mr. Seymour had been told at the outset of his contacts with the embassy last year that there was no question of Mr. Gotlieb's waiving his diplomatic immunity. **********''I don't know, maybe he feels he has a weak case, and that's why he's coming down the pike with a totally different approach, and a totally different tone, than he employed last year,'' Mr. Phillips said, referring to Mr. Seymour. Planning Strategy **********Mr. Phillips said the embassy had planned its strategy in the Deaver affair with care from the onset of its contacts with Mr. Seymour last summer. The Canadian official, who took part in discussions at the embassy at the time, said it had been made clear to Mr. Seymour that the embassy's cooperation - in the form of written answers provided by Mr. Gotlieb to written questions from Mr. Seymour - in no way constituted a waiver of Mr. Gotlieb's diplomatic immunity. **********''As a responsible and friendly neighbor, it was our view that it would not be seemly for Canada not to cooperate with a legal inquiry in the United States,'' Mr. Phillips said. ''But right from the outset the No. 1 question for us was how to do that without eroding our sovereignty. We explained to Mr. Seymour that we were not going to cooperate at the expense of losing our diplomatic immunity. No country would do that, least of all the United States.'' 'Breach of Faith' **********At the External Affairs Ministry, officials said that the first they had heard of Mr. Seymour's plan to get the Gotliebs to testify was when the process servers arrived at the embassy on Tuesday. It was this peremptoriness, as well as what Canadian officials say they consider a ''breach of faith'' after the cooperation with Mr. Seymour last summer, that explained the angry tone of Mr. Clark's public statements on the affair this week, the officials said. **********Among opposition politicians, there has been a suspicion that some of the Government's anger derived from its chagrin at seeing an embarrassing issue revived. A legislator for the opposition Liberal Party, John Nunziata, used the controversy over the subpoenas to renew a demand in the House of Commons that Mr. Gotlieb be brought back to testify before the External Affairs Committee on the contract with Mr. Deaver. Mr. Clark refused that demand last summer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/01/busin.body_text: **********America's stubborn budget deficits - roughly $150 billion in the last fiscal year - are widely blamed for contributing to the Crash of '87. New York Times reporter Lawrence M. Fisher asked three former members of the Council on Economic Advisers for their views on what should be done about it.  William A. Niskanen  Member of the council, 1981-85. Now chairman of the Cato Institute. **********Though I don't think that Federal budget conditions contributed to the recent collapse of stock prices - the budget news was favorable, and an autumn budget confrontation has become routine - a reduction continues to be important. **********But it is important, too, to look at the means by which the deficit is to be reduced. Economists don't have all the information bearing on this issue - the choice is properly made within the political process. **********My political preference: Reduce the deficit entirely with spending reductions - including those programs that increased most rapidly during the Reagan years. Plus, increase user fees on Federal I favor a proportionate reduction of all programs over a general tax increase. But some tax rise will probably come out of the process. In that case, an economist's advice is more valuable. Here's mine: *********** Continue to broaden the tax base rather than increase rates. Consider such measures as substituting a $300 tax credit for the $2,000 personal exemption. *********** Reject any increase in the taxation of capital, including the ''takeover tax'' proposal. *********** Do not increase tariffs - this includes the several proposals for an oil-import fee. *********** Increase the beer-and-wine excise tax to restore the real value of this tax relative to the spirits tax.  Ezra Solomon  Member of the council, 1971-73. Now Dean Witter professor of finance, Stanford University. **********Decreasing the budget deficit in some credible fashion is the No. 1 item on the agenda. We are entering the sixth year of a peacetime recovery, and still have a deficit. It has no business being there. **********As far as the method of getting the deficit down, I think it's better to do it on the spending side, especially military spending. **********As for a tax increase, if President Reagan chooses to call it ''revenue enhancement,'' that's fine with me. My pet candidate - some sort of levy on oil. This would be a tax not just on imported oil or gasoline, but on all oil, so the burden falls on everybody. A $1 tax on every barrel of oil would raise $6 billion and tie in with long-range energy policy.  William Poole  Member of the council, 1982-85. Now professor of economics, Brown University. **********The case for the deficit's being the main culprit in the crash is extraordinarily weak. America has a deficit, but other countries with small deficits had crashes. This was a worldwide event, so we should be looking for some factor that was a cause around the world. **********Surely, the United States needs to address the deficit problem. Actions that merely alleviate the concerns for this year and next but fail to address the long-term problems will leave us in the same situation. We need some fundamental reforms. **********These days, the discussion is focused on taxes, but we have to look carefully at what kind of taxes. Some are more harmful than others - taxes that depress business activity, for example. The Tax Reform Act of 1986 has already transferred individual liability to business. We don't want to encourage a depression by discouraging business investment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/26/world.main_headline: IRAN REPORT, DUE TODAY, HAD MODEST BEGINNINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/26/world.print_headline: IRAN REPORT, DUE TODAY, HAD MODEST BEGINNINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/26/world.body_text: **********What was supposed to have been a blue-ribbon study of the procedures of the National Security Council evolved into a full-fledged investigaton of the Iran-contra affair, partly because the the panel obtained a wealth of N.S.C. computer memorandums, to the astonishment of the officials who established the panel. **********In the process of its investigation, the panel discovered abortive covert activities run by the National Security Council. **********Officials familiar with the Tower report, which is to be made public at a nationally broadcast news conference at 11 A.M. on Thursday, have said the panel also unearthed a political ''cover-up'' of the President's role in approving sales of American arms to Iran. **********These sources said the report would describe a President who was frequently briefed, but did not always pay attention to what he was being told, and a Secretary of State who understood and opposed much of the covert policy, but chose not to raise objections strenuous enough to block it. Criticism of Reagan and Casey **********A source familiar with the Tower report said it would be highly critical of the Central Intelligence Agency and its head, William J. Casey. The source said the criticism of Mr. Reagan was also harsh. **********''He let these guys run amok,'' the source said, referring to the report's findings on President Reagan. ''He should have been more alert. He should have run the ship better, rather than let it be taken over by others.'' **********The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today: ''The President has acted entirely appropriately. The question was, did he do anything wrong? I say no.'' **********The White House also confirmed a report in The Washington Post today that Mr. Reagan wrote a letter to the Tower board last Friday, explaining that he could not remember when he had approved the arms shipments to Iran. Mr. Reagan originally told the board that he gave his approval before the first shipment in August 1985, but at a second session he changed his account and said his approval had come after the initial transaction. Effort to Free Hostages **********Present and former Administration officials said today that the Adminstration's initial misleading public statements in early November about the dealings with Iran were motivated by a desire to preserve the possibility of freeing American hostages in Beirut. **********This became transformed later in November, they said, into an effort by several senior officials to compile a misleading chronology that would minimize President Reagan's role. **********In its report, the Tower Commission will give a detailed chronology of the Administration's misleading statements and the reasons they were made, officials said. **********One source familiar with the Administration's deliberations in early November said Mr. Reagan rejected requests to make a full disclosure, arguing that the lives of both the hostages and the Iranians dealing with the United States were at stake. **********Meanwhile, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, subsequently dismissed from the National Security Council staff was dispatched Nov. 8 on a frantic trip to Europe for meetings intended to gain freedom for all of the American hostages. He was working through an intermediary linked to Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, who had won the release of David P. Jacobsen on Nov. 2 with a single phone call, according to a source familiar with the dealings. **********Colonel North's effort failed, and present and former officials said the focus shifted to protecting the President from further political damage. **********It was against this backdrop, present and former officials said, that the inaccurate chronologies were developed and given to President Reagan for his personal statements on the issue. **********The investigative panel, which was appointed last November, comprises former Senator John Tower of Texas, former Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie and Brent Scowcroft, who was national security adviser in the Ford Administration. Not a Benign Inquiry **********The three pledged from the start that their efforts would not merely be a benign inquiry into the role of the National Security Council in policy making but would seek to unravel the Iran-contra affair. **********But Administration officials said nobody, least of all the White House, expected the zeal with which the Tower panel pursued the origins of the Iran arms sales and the diversion of profits to the contras. **********On Jan. 26, President Reagan was first questioned by the panel, the only investigative body exploring the Iran-contra affair that is likely to have the privilege. **********The panel's spokesman, Herbert Hetu, said at the time that ''we have found something.'' **********What the panel had ''found'' were backup copies of electronic mail sent among National Security Council officials on their computers. **********After receiving two extensions for its report, the commission has spent the last two weeks in a race against the clock to have the report ready by the Feb. 26 deadline.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/10/busin.main_headline: Bond Issue Set to Aid F.S.L.I.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/10/busin.print_headline: Bond Issue Set to Aid F.S.L.I.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/10/busin.body_text: **********Officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank system announced plans yesterday to sell a new variety of government agency bonds to recapitalize the insurance fund for savings and loan deposits. **********However, M. Danny Wall, the new chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, warned that the $10.82 billion bond financing, even when supplemented by more than $7 billion from deposit insurance premiums and sales of assets of defunct savings units, would not be enough to solve the industry's problems. **********''We will need more money after three years,'' Mr. Wall said yesterday at a news conference. But he added that the need for additional funds would be the problem of the next Administration and would probably not lead to any direct taxpayer support of the savings industry. 20% of Institutions Insolvent The Federal Home Loan Bank system is a Federal agency that operates as a central bank for savings and loan associations and oversees the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which insures their deposits. Large loan losses, primarily in oil-producing states, have pushed about 20 percent of the nation's 3,100 thrift institutions into insolvency, making them prime candidates for being merged, acquired or closed. **********Because the capital of the F.S.L.I.C. has been depleted to the point where it has a negative net worth and ready cash stands at less than $900 million, Mr. Wall acknowledged that the agency had had to proceed slowly in handling financially strained savings and loans. **********With the fresh injection of funds from the bond sales, ''we will pick up the pace of the resolution process,'' he said yesterday. **********Although the new bonds are not backed by the Federal Government, they are supported by several features never before used in a Federal agency financing. Principal payments will be backed by zero coupon Treasury bonds of similar maturity that will be purchased with up to $3 billion of capital that will eventually be contributed by the 12 regional Federal Home Loan Banks to the newly created Financial Corporation, the issuer of the bonds. **********Interest payments on the new bonds will be backed by a first lien on the deposit insurance premiums paid to the F.S.L.I.C. **********The first of about $1.2 billion of bonds expected to be sold this year will be a $400 million to $600 million issue of noncallable 30-year bonds at an interest rate to be announced Sept. 30. Maturities of subsequent issues, expected four to six times a year, will vary between 20 and 30 years. Expected Interest Rate **********Because the bonds are not directly backed by the Treasury, analysts estimated they would sell with an interest rate about three-quarters of 1 percent greater than 30-year Treasury bonds. **********The primary buyers of the bonds are expected to be large institutions such as insurance companies and pension funds, with Japanese investors buying a quarter to a third of the issue. Interest on the bonds will be exempt from state and local taxes, but not Federal income tax. **********According to a worst-case scenario described by Austin Downling, president of the Financial Corporation, interest on the bonds could be paid even if the bonds' average yield was 14.3 percent, the savings industry did not grow and 25 percent of the existing deposit base left the F.S.L.I.C.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/03/busin.body_text: **********GOOD to its word, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company will withdraw most of its advertising from the J. Walter Thompson Company, now British-owned, on Feb. 1. This year's billings could be around $40 million. **********In June, when the publicly held WPP Group of London was waging its campaign for an unfriendly takeover of the JWT Group, parent of J. Walter Thompson, James K. DeVoe, vice president for advertising of the giant rubber company, said: ''Goodyear will pull its advertising out of J. Walter Thompson if the agency is taken over by a British firm. We would not feel confident working with a firm controlled by an institution outside the country.'' **********The acquisition was effective July 1. **********Goodyear's reaction to the takeover is obviously an outgrowth of its own bitter but successful battle to fend off takeover attempts by a British group headed by Sir James Goldsmith. **********When queried on the status of the Thompson assignment, Goodyear said that two pieces of business were staying in place - at Brouillard Communications, the Thompson subsidiary that does corporate advertising, and at the Performance Group, the Detroit unit that does promotions connected with auto racing and handles Goodyear's high-performance Eagle brand tire. **********There were also threats or hints of punitive action against Thompson from Ford, Thompson's biggest client; Eastman Kodak and Philips International. They have taken no action. Thompson became the Goodyear agency in 1978. **********Although the tire company cut back its ad budget to about $25 million last year when it faced the British takeover threat, it will probably come in at a much higher figure this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/busin.main_headline: DOW TOPS 2,000 FOR THE FIRST TIME AS WALL ST. EXTENDS LATEST RALLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/busin.print_headline: DOW TOPS 2,000 FOR THE FIRST TIME AS WALL ST. EXTENDS LATEST RALLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/09/busin.body_text: **********Carried aloft by the stock market's stunning New Year rally, the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 2,000 yesterday for the first time ever. **********The 30-stock Dow average is now up 5 percent in just the five trading days of this year, and broader market indicators have done even better. **********''Two thousand! We have two thousand!'' one trader yelled across the room of his midtown brokerage firm yesterday a few minutes before 3 P.M., when the average first pierced the mark. A Nervous Ascent **********The Dow - the most closely followed of all the market gauges, tabulating 30 of America's best-known companies -gained a modest 8.30 points, to finish just over 2,000, at 2,002.25. **********For most of the session yesterday, stock prices were shaky, with investors who had earned a tidy sum over the previous four sessions generally willing to take profits as the Dow nervously moved toward the 2,000 level. But a firm bond market, renewed interest in American stocks by foreign investors and the momentum of the market itself made for a strong final hour. **********Many of the professionals working on Wall Street contended that a 2,000-point Dow is really nothing special. 'Not a Lot of Hootin' ' **********''I don't see a lot of hootin' and hollerin','' said Anthony Woodruff, co-director of equity trading at Kidder, Peabody & Company, as the market closed at 4 P.M. But he said the accomplishment may help the stock market improve on its perfect 5-for-5 record in 1987. ''We've never been there before,'' he said. ''It ought to bring new confidence into the market.'' **********The continuation of a powerful bull market at a time when many economists are predicting slack economic growth seems, at first, incongruous. But not so to many experts who note that a sluggish economy may keep a lid on inflation and interest rates - a prospect that buoys the confidence of stock investors.  [ Page D1. ]  Wall Street has cheered each new conquest for the Dow, but the cheers have grown softer over the last few years as the index passed each successive landmark wih relative ease. #10 Year Wait for 1,100 The Dow, for instance, stood at just 1,000 on Nov. 14, 1972. It took more than 10 years, or until Feb. 24, 1983, for it go the next hundred points. Then it become easier. **********The next milestone, 1,200, was reached on April 26, 1983, two months and two days after 1,100 had been scaled. While 1984 was a comparatively quiet year, as Wall Street digested its gains, the Dow passed 1,300, 1,400 and 1,500 in 1985. **********And last year, 1,600, 1,700, 1,800 and 1,900 fell victim to the bull market that was fueled, in part, by the lowest interest rates in nearly a decade. **********Wall Street professionals of late seem to have adjusted their thinking, and their celebrating. **********''As long as it keeps going, we're all happy - we don't have to cheer,'' said Rodney Berens, a managing director at Morgan Stanley & Company, who, upon looking around the firm's trading room, reported that he heard ''not a peep'' of celebration. **********The New York Stock Exchange index rose 1.12, to 147.55, yesterday, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumped 1.95 points, to 257.28. Once again, both were records.  Small Stocks Soar The stocks of smaller companies, meanwhile, continued to show perhaps the best performance of all. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq index rose 5.05 points, to 377.54. **********On the New York Stock Exchange, meanwhile, advancing issues outpaced losers by a solid margin -1,172 to 515. Trading volume remained strong, with 194.5 million shares changing hands, compared with 190.9 million on Wednesday. **********Since last Friday, the first trading day of the new year, stock prices have marched higher without interruption. Including yesterday's 8.30 gain, the Dow is now up more than 106 points, or around 5 percent, this year. **********And many market analysts are predicting that stocks will go higher before investors start reassessing matters. ''What's important is whether the rally is sustainable on the basis of an improving economy or lower interest rates,'' said Eliot Fried, research director at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ''And I think it is.'' **********Some analysts are predicting that over a long time, the Dow might be able to hit 3,000, or perhaps even 4,000. But most are keeping their estimates more moderate. **********Laszlo Birinyi, head of equity market analysis at Salomon Brothers Inc., for instance, said he has been predicting that the Dow will peak at 2,073. ''Then we have to stop and re-evaluate,'' he added. **********The market, always trying to anticipate developments, has apparently found consolation in the fact that the economy appears to be entering its fifth consecutive year of growth. Even the tepidness of that recovery is positive for stocks, some experts argue. They say that the Federal Reserve Board, which is credited with starting the bull market in 1982, when it rapidly cut rates, will probably keep borrowing costs down until business conditions improve. **********And low rates, aside from the beneficial effect they should eventually have on corporate profits, are also causing investors to pull their funds out of such financial instruments as bank certificates of deposits, where yields have now plunged to under 6 percent. That C.D. money, Wall Street believes, is headed its way. **********Analysts also believe money may flow to Wall Street from overseas. Money that had been invested, say, in Japan, might come back to Wall Street now that the dollar is down and foreign stocks are up sharply. **********Among individual issues, Aetna Life and Casualty led the active list yesterday, gaining 1/2, to 60 1/4, on volume of almost 2.8 million shares. **********The Dow gained despite drops by some of its most prominent members. USX fell 3/4, to 22, after Carl C. Icahn, the investor, withdraw his informal offer to acquire the company and threatened to stage a proxy battle. I.B.M., in active trading, lost 5/8, to 122 7/8. But while it did lose ground over all, I.B.M. was instrumental in pushing the Dow up late in the day. The stock had traded as low as 121 during the session. **********Elsewhere. Texas Instruments rose 4 1/4, to 124. ICN Pharmaceuticals gained another 3 1/8, to 25 1/4. The company is expected to give test results of its new AIDS drug today. Mesa, which is bidding for Diamond Shamrock, fell 1/8, to 3 5/8. **********Colt Industries rose 1 1/2, to 13. The company restructured last year by means of what is called a ''leveraged cash out'' and is now experiencing the popularity of other concerns that have gone this route. **********Litton rose 2 7/8, to 80 1/8. The stock rose, traders said, because of very vague buyout rumors. Litton's stock has occasionally moved higher in the past for the same reason. **********The American Stock Exchange index rose 2.79, to 281.65.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/world.main_headline: SRI LANK PRESIDENT VOWS TO RECAPTURE TAMILS' STRONGHOLD
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/world.print_headline: SRI LANK PRESIDENT VOWS TO RECAPTURE TAMILS' STRONGHOLD
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/world.body_text: **********President J. R. Jayewardene said today that troops must recapture the Jaffna Peninsula, a Tamil rebel stronghold. But he did not say when the northern peninsula should be retaken and did not announce a military offensive. **********Mr. Jayewardene, in an interview, also said he would welcome foreign assistance and ''help from the devil himself'' in fighting terrorism by Tamil rebels, who are seeking a separate homeland. **********Mr. Jayewardene said the air force might resume bombing of Tamil rebel targets. The attacks, suspended last week, were begun as retaliation for a car bombing that killed 113 people last month in Colombo. The Government blamed Tamil terrorists. **********Mr. Jayewardene also repeated plans to cancel the scheduled 1989 elections and to seek to extend the term of his Government unless the terrorism problem was resolved. **********Tamils, who are mostly Hindu, say they are discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese, who are Buddhists. **********In raids at Kandy, 72 miles northeast of Colombo, the police reported today that they had arrested nine people. The authorities said they found more than 50 hand grenades and homemade bombs.  ---- NO ALTERNATIVE, SEPARATIST SAYS **********NEW DELHI, May 2 (Special to The New York Times) - Tamil guerrillas will accept nothing less than an independent nation, Veerapalli Prabhakaran, the top leader of Sri Lanka's rebels, said today. He also called for more violence and bloodshed to achieve that goal. **********''There is no alternative except winning our freedom through struggle and shedding blood,'' he said in a statement. Mr. Prabhakaran heads the Liberation Tigers for Tamil Eelam, the largest rebel force. **********Mr. Prabhakaran is believed to be in a Tamil stronghold in Sri Lanka's northern province. His statement, the strongest recent remarks by a rebel leader, was given to reporters in the southern Indian city Madras. **********He also underscored the Tamil refusal to join efforts by India to broker a fresh peace between the warring sides. Mr. Prabhakaran said India had failed to understand ''the political machinations'' of the Sri Lanka Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/21/world.main_headline: SOVIET TO RESUME BLASTS, IT TELLS SCIENTISTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/21/world.print_headline: SOVIET TO RESUME BLASTS, IT TELLS SCIENTISTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/21/world.body_text: **********Soviet authorities told American scientists today that the Soviet Union would detonate a nuclear device within several days, ending an 18-month moratorium on nuclear testing. **********The American scientists were ordered this morning to shut off seismic measuring equipment that had been installed near the main Soviet testing site at Semipalatinsk in Kazakhstan, a lawyer for the monitoring team said. **********'We were told that there was going to be a test,'' said Jacob Scheer, a lawyer who is co-director of the monitoring team. ''We had to stop work for three days and possibly longer.'' **********Mr. Scheer spoke by telephone from Karakaralinsk, where an American team was completing installation of nine underground seismic measuring devices. **********The devices are the second phase of a joint Soviet-American project designed to demonstrate that it is possible to verify nuclear weapons tests, even at very low levels of explosive force. **********The Soviet Union halted nuclear testing in August 1985 and called on the United States to join in a permanent test ban. But the United States has continued testing, insisting that such tests are necessary to develop more modern weapons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/world.body_text: **********Poland's Prime Minister announced today that average consumer prices, excluding alcohol and cigarettes, would rise 27 percent next year. **********At the same time, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, in a move apparently designed to strengthen control of the party, filled key positions with supporters of his program for economic change and modification of the way Poland is governed. **********A meeting of the party's Central Committee named Mieczyslaw Rakowski to the Politburo, the party's highest decision-making body. **********Among other appointments, it named Slawomir Tabkowski, the former editor of the daily newspaper Gazeta Krakowska, to head the Central Committee's propaganda section. **********Both men are considered to be among the staunchest advocates of programs backed by the Polish leader. Price Rises Are Scaled Back **********Prime Minister Zbigniew Messner, speaking to the Central Committee meeting, said that prices would not rise next year as steeply as planned because not enough voters in a referendum Nov. 29 supported political and economic changes. **********''This will undoubtedly weaken the effectiveness'' of the changes, Mr. Messner said. But he said the ''possibility will grow of winning public understanding.'' **********He said the price increases would be spread over three years, instead of one year as initially planned, and would rise an average 27 percent next year, instead of 40 percent. **********The increases, he said, will be cushioned by higher incomes and direct compensation to consumers. **********The question of price increases is delicate because unrest and leadership changes followed price rises in 1956, 1970 and 1980. **********A particularly sensitive area is the prices of basic foods. The Prime Minister said these increases will be far lower than originally planned. Food prices were to have risen 110 percent next year but now they are expected to increase about 28 percent. Certainty of Hard Times **********The Government announced its policies to carry out the changes in general terms. None came as a surprise in a country in which the certainty of hard times ahead has been the principal topic of discussion for several months. **********General Jaruzelski, the 64-year-old leader, endorsed the program in a firm speech closing the session. He received only scant applause. **********He insisted the party would move ahead with measures to involve broader segments of society in making decisions. But he reaffirmed his resolve not to permit members of the political opposition to take part. **********''Our offer now is as open and as wide as it ever was,'' he said, ''Everyone is included with the exception of those who have ruled themselves out.'' **********The last phrase apparently was an allusion to the leasdership of the outlawed Solidarity union. **********''We will not allow the hidden detonator to be installed,'' General Jaruzelski said. Then, reiterating a justification for his actions in 1981, when he ordered paramilitary forces to crush the independent trade union, the general said, ''Thanks to our wisdom Poland did not become a Lebanon in Europe.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/31/world.main_headline: Uganda Rebel Priestess Imprisoned in Kenya
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/31/world.print_headline: Uganda Rebel Priestess Imprisoned in Kenya
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/31/world.body_text: **********The Kenyan Government said today that it had jailed the Ugandan priestess who sent her rebel troops into suicide battles against the Ugandan Government. **********The priestess, Alice Lakwena, and seven followers were arrested Saturday when they crossed illegally into Kenya, said Justis ole Tipis, Minister of State in charge of security. **********''She was subsequently convicted and sentenced to four months imprisonment,'' Mr. Tipis said in a statement. ''She will be repatriated to Uganda at the expiry of her prison term.'' **********In a campaign that began a year ago, the 27-year-old Miss Lakwena - the word means messiah in her language, Acholi - mesmerized Ugandans with claims that spirits spoke through her. Oil and Hymns, Sticks and Stones **********Sometimes called Mommy by her followers, Miss Lakwena, who was born Alice Auma in the northern Ugandan district of Gulu, inspired her Holy Spirit Movement troops to march into battle singing hymns and instructed them that oil smeared on their chests would ward off bullets. She told them their sticks and stones would explode like grenades. At its height, Miss Lakwena's army numbered 7,000. **********President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, who took power in January 1986, asserted last month that his National Resistance Army had killed 8,500 Holy Spirit rebels since January. **********The Holy Spirit Movement is one of a half-dozen rebel groups fighting the central Government in Kampala. It was never a serious military threat, but Miss Lakwena became a major embarrassment as her exploits were widely reported abroad. **********In October, the Government began a campaign to wipe out the Holy Spirit Movement and capture or kill its leader. After losing thousands of her followers in suicidal attacks, Miss Lakwena was reported in early November to be wounded and fleeing on a bicycle pushed by the remnants of her army. **********Her whereabouts were unknown until the Kenyan announcement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/busin.main_headline: Schussing Past the Big Guys on the Ski Slopes
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/busin.print_headline: Schussing Past the Big Guys on the Ski Slopes
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/busin.body_text: **********A SIGN hangs over Tom Corcoran's desk, a constant caution about the business he is in, running one of New England's largest ski resorts. **********The signs reads: ''The ski business is an odd little segment of industry that is better left to people who understand it, who deeply care about it, and who are willing to have a less predictable bottom line than most big corporations will tolerate.'' **********''I read that in Fortune magazine about 20 years ago and had it framed,'' said Mr. Corcoran, a 56-year-old Harvard M.B.A. who once raced on the United States Ski Team and is a past chairman of the National Ski Areas Association. Outside his office in Waterville Valley, N.H., a visitor can hear the roar of compressed air and water showering man-made snow onto downhill trails. **********''I can't say that the ski industry has changed much since,'' he said. ''It's a business for entrepreneurs. Large corporations have tended not to do well in it.'' **********Among the corporations that have tried the ski business and then bailed out are 20th Century Fox (Aspen and Breckenridge, Colo.), the Chrysler Corporation (Big Sky, Mont.) and Scott Paper (Squaw Mountain, Me.) Of course, there are exceptions. The Keystone/Arapahoe resort, for example, owned by Ralston Purina and positioned in Colorado, just over the Great Divide, intercepts increasing numbers of skiers before they go on to Copper Mountain, Vail or Aspen. **********But in general, individual entrepreneurs, such as Mr. Corcoran, Alex Cushing of Squaw Valley, Calif. and Dave McCoy of Mammoth Mountain, Calif., have proved to be more successful than the corporate giants. **********''A ski area is not going to produce a stream of uninterrupted earnings that you can rely on for dividends,'' Mr. Corcoran said. ''The business is seasonal. It's a weather-sensitive business, perhaps more so than farming. And it attracts managers who are individualistic and independent, not the kind of people who fit the corporate mold.'' **********Mr. Corcoran is willing to concede that the ski business is perhaps no longer ''an odd little segment of industry,'' as his sign says. Across the country, the resorts have an annual payroll of $350 million. Ski areas are pivotal to the economic health of scores of mountain communities from rural Maine to the High Sierras of California. **********This winter the nation's 600 ski areas are hoping to attract a record number of visitors, surpassing the 1986-87 high of 53.7 million days of skiing. The Winter Olympics - to be held in February in Calgary, Alberta, on the eastern edge of the Canadian Rockies - traditionally help the ski business. **********A growth spurt would be welcome. In the 1960's, the ski industry grew annually by 10 to 15 percent, as the postwar baby boom brought millions of young people to the sport. But in recent years demand has flattened. Nationally, skier visits have hovered just above the 50 million mark for nearly 10 years. And the proportion of frequent downhill skiers - those who ski more than 12 days a season - has declined. **********Those numbers are somewhat deceptive though, masking the fact that the number of ski areas has also declined. Marvin Kottke, who measures skier visits annually for the National Ski Areas Association, said his figures now come from 175 fewer ski areas than existed in 1978-79. In effect, Mr. Kottke argued, the same skier volume shared by fewer suppliers has meant a 20 percent growth in business for ski areas that survived. **********Not surprisingly, the key to running a successful ski area is paying close and continual attention to the quality of the snow. ''Quality snow is what today's customer wants,'' said Jim Branch, president of Sno Engineering, a ski area consultant in Lyme, N.H. ''Areas have to make it, many of them nightly, and they have to groom it once or more than once a day.'' **********But resorts must pay close attention to peripheral details, as well. Tom Leonard, president of Crystal Mountain in the Cascades, outside of Seattle, says he spends a lot of time motivating the employees who put the customers into chairlift seats and serve them food to insure that patrons have ''a fun experience.'' **********At Waterville Valley, Mr. Corcoran emulates the frequent flier programs of the airlines to promote repeat business. A person skiing midweek pays $25 for a full-day ticket and receives a countdown card. On each consecutive day he continues to ski (between Monday and Friday), he pays $2 less until the ticket reaches $10 a day, good for the rest of the season. The discount does not apply on weekends, when areas are often crammed. **********ACCORDING to Mr. Corcoran, a ski resort does not have to be large to make money. The crucial elements, he said, are cost control and marketing, recommending: ''Build and run resorts that attract high attendance and revenues relative to the capital invested.'' **********This formula is getting harder to follow, however, as the cost of improvements increases. Many ski complexes have spent millions of dollars in recent years on snow-making, new lifts, base lodges and wider trails. Many have acquired fleets of $100,000-plus snow-tilling machines that groom the slopes to the creamy, easy-to-ski texture that is so important to customer satisfaction. **********Even more expensive are the recently introduced ''high-speed quad'' lifts, in which the chair detaches from the fast-moving cable and inches along so that four skiers at a time can be seated. The chair then grabs on to the cable again and the skiers are carried uphill at 1,000 feet a minute, or about 12 miles an hour, more than twice as fast as fixed-chair lifts. **********Skiers who ride the new high-speed chairs like them so much that they resent going back to the slower ones. But the high-speed lifts can be more than twice as expensive. One three-quarter-mile-long detachable quad alone can require an investment of more than $2 million. **********Area owners must also widen trails and add snowmaking and grooming to take care of the additional skiers poured onto the slopes by a high-capacity detachable chairlift, which carries passengers at two and a half times the rate of a conventional chair. **********Complicating their financial woes, many areas are still amortizing a huge number of recently built fixed-chair lifts. **********Still, resort operators can't afford to ignore the public's desire to ski more and sit less. One solution may be to devise a premium ''first-class ticket'' to ride the high-speed chairs. **********A long-time industry analyst, Charles Goeldner, of the University of Colorado, believes ski areas need an immediate increase in lift ticket prices of at least 10 percent beyond inflation to compensate themselves for recent investments. **********''The ski areas are delivering a much more valuable product to the skier, but they're not pricing it adequately,'' Mr. Goeldner said. **********The Aspen Skiing Company, for example, has invested $33 million in new facilities over the last four years. After it raised the one-day ticket price to $35, though, townspeople marched in protest last summer. **********The Aspen company ''greatly improved the value of the skiing experience,'' Mr. Goeldner said. ''The hullabaloo about the price increase was totally unjustified.'' **********Vacationing skiers usually buy tickets for five or more days of skiing, and this can lower their costs significantly. A six-day pass at Aspen, for example, means the customer pays just $30 a day to ski. **********Elsewhere this season, daily lift passes are up by about $2 from last winter. Mr. Goeldner estimates the average cost to an American skier for an adult one-day weekend lift pass this winter will probably be $22 to $23. **********STILL, the industry is nervous about raising prices too much, so many resorts are looking at other ways to raise revenues. ''Our real future is in becoming four-season resorts,'' Mr. Corcoran said. ''At one time, ski areas could shut down in the spring and let the staff go. But as the investments have become bigger, the costs can only be recovered with year-round revenue.'' **********As a result, ski resorts are building conference centers and small convention facilities; indoor sports centers; covered ice rinks, golf courses and tennis courts. Construction activity has been hectic in and around ski areas in New England, particularly at Sunday River and Sugar Loaf in Maine, and at Okemo in Vermont. **********South of Loon Mountain, Mr. Corcoran is greatly expanding Waterville Valley, which started in 1966. In the last three years alone, more than $40 million has been spent on new inns and apartments at Waterville. **********Mr. Corcoran and his associates have just broken ground on a new $18 million condominium lodge, the Golden Eagle. Its 138 one- and two-bedroom units sold out in eight days. **********''With time and the evolution toward four-season activity, who knows?'' Mr. Corcoran said. ''We may even be able to make the bottom line of skiing more predictable.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/19/world.body_text: **********A senior official in the West German Justice Ministry testified today that documents used by the prosecution in the trial of Klaus Barbie, the wartime Gestapo chief of Lyons, are authentic. **********The official, Alfred Streim, told the court that the documents showed direct responsibility by Mr. Barbie in two mass deportations of Jews from Lyons to eventual death in Nazi camps. Mr. Barbie is charged with crimes against humanity. **********During the months leading up to the trial, Mr. Barbie's defense lawyer, Jacques Verges, had said in interviews that the documents, seen as key pieces of prosecution evidence, were fake. **********The documents consist of telexes or reports, signed by Mr. Barbie, in which he appears to inform the central office of the Gestapo in Paris of two operations against Jews in Lyons. 'They Are Authentic' **********One is a document reporting the deportation, in February 1943, of 84 Jews, most of them women, children or elderly people, seized in a raid on a Jewish organization. The other is a telex announcing the seizure on April 6, 1944, of 44 Jewish children from the village of Izieu, east of here. All 44 children were killed at Auschwitz. **********''I have studied the documents and I can say that they are authentic,'' Mr. Streim said. He told the court that he was the chief of the German Justice Ministry's department that investigates Nazi crimes, and had studied numerous documents on the German occupation of France. **********During pre-trial interrogations, Mr. Barbie, maintained that while he was head of the Gestapo in Lyons he did not concern himself with actions against Jews. Those, he asserted, were carried out by what he described as an autonomous subsection of the Gestapo. **********Mr. Streim said notations on the reports showed that the operations in question were initiated by the Gestapo in Lyons, a point apparently designed to refute a possible claim by the defense that Gestapo officials here were merely obeying orders of superiors. **********Earlier in today's session, the sixth in the trial, lawyers for civil plaintiffs in the case demanded that the presiding judge use force to compel Mr. Barbie, who withdrew from the trial last Wednesday, to appear in court. The request was denied on the ground that most of the witnesses had a chance to confront Mr. Barbie in pre-trial questioning.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/15/world.main_headline: OUSTER IS SOUGHT AT U.N. FARM UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/15/world.print_headline: OUSTER IS SOUGHT AT U.N. FARM UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/15/world.body_text: **********The United States, Britain and several other nations, most of them Western, plan to open a campaign here this week to replace the head of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization, whom they accuse of mismanaging the organization and pursuing anti-Western policies, according to Western diplomats. **********At a meeting Monday of the F.A.O.'s 49-member executive council, the diplomats say, these nations will press for the replacement of the official, Dr. Edouard Saouma, when his second six-year term expires at the end of 1987. **********In his place, they want to appoint Moise Mensah of Benin, who is deputy director of the International Fund for Agricultural Development, which also aids third-world farmers. **********Dr. Saouma, a Lebanese, could not be reached for comment over the weekend, but an F.A.O spokesman denied the charges, saying that under Dr. Saouma the organization has become more efficient and more oriented toward helping poor countries. **********The spokesman said spending on headquarters posts had fallen from 77.2 percent of the 1974-75 budget to 54.5 percent in 1986-87. At the same time, the spokesman said, Dr. Saouma has created a ''streamlined evaluation service'' designed to test the efficiency of the organization's programs. **********Dr. Saouma has ''strengthened field activities and slashed administrative costs,'' the spokesman added. Asian Food Gains Cited **********In the latest F.A.O. annual report, Dr. Saouma defends himself against Western charges. In particular, he stresses that in Asia, ''food self-sufficiency is close at hand,'' although 20 years ago ''the prospect of that area ever producing sufficient food looked bleak.'' **********The drive to replace Dr. Saouma is the latest move in a campaign by Western and some other nations to deal with what they call inefficiency by the United Nations and a tendency by many of its agencies to pursue policies inimical to Western interests. **********The United States and Britain have withdrawn from Unesco, charging that the educational, scientific and cultural body is badly run and promotes controversial political causes. **********The 11 biggest Western contributors to the United Nations and its agencies have agreed to put a limit on its spending increases. The United States has reduced its 25 percent assessed share of all United Nations spending. **********In recent weeks, the Western diplomats said, the Lebanese Government has pleaded with Western nations for Dr. Saouma's reappointment, saying his replacement would constitute a further humiliation for wartorn Lebanon. **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz was persuaded only with difficulty to endorse the removal of Dr. Saouma, according to the diplomats. **********The nations that want to replace Dr. Saouma are concerting their strategy in secret meetings of what is known as the Camberley Group, after the town in England where the first meeting was held last year. The original members of the group were Australia, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Finland, West Germany, Japan, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland. U.S. Excluded at First **********France, which supports Dr. Saouma, was not invited to the group's meetings. The United States was also excluded at first because its representative to the F.A.O., Millicent Fenwick, a former member of Congress, was believed to support Dr. Saouma. But since her departure a few months ago, the United States has been associated with the move against Dr. Saouma. **********Supporting Dr. Saouma are most Arab and African nations and many other third-world nations, diplomats say. Italy has declared itself neutral. **********With a two-year budget of $420 million and about $1 billion in pledges from donor countries for food programs it administers, the F.A.O. is the second-largest United Nations aid-giving organization, after the World Bank. **********Western governments say it is poorly run, often encouraging grandiose products in developing countries that are not suited to their needs. **********Under Dr. Saouma, the organization is also accused of drawing up contentious guidelines for world farm trade that impinge on other bodies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/world.main_headline: DISTRUST BETWEEN OPPOSING FORCES LEAVES THE GAP UNBRIDGED, THE CRISIS UNCHANGED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/world.print_headline: SEOUL'S GREAT DIVIDE; DISTRUST BETWEEN OPPOSING FORCES LEAVES THE GAP UNBRIDGED, THE CRISIS UNCHANGED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/world.body_text: **********On the first day in two months that he was not under house arrest, Kim Dae Jung never left his house Thursday. **********Mr. Kim, the opposition leader, had plenty of reasons to stay home, including a bad cold and an endless stream of visitors. Still, in a small but vivid way, his decision to impose another day of confinement on himself underlined an inescapable reality in South Korean politics: Just when things seem to change, they don't. **********In fact, Mr. Kim found himself under house arrest once more today to prevent him from attending protest rallies planned by the opposition. **********Through the last two weeks of political turmoil here, nothing has proved more unchanging than the raw fact that the Government and the opposition do not trust each other, never have and probably never will. Closer to the Edge **********That point was reinforced by a closely watched attempt at crisis control on Wednesday, the first meeting ever held between President Chun Doo Hwan and another key opposition figure, Kim Young Sam. Afterward, the two sides talked as though they had attended separate events. The ruling party saw the Chun-Kim meeting as a signal for ''grand compromise.'' The opposition called it a failure. **********Setting aside the questions of whose view was right, the result for now was to push the country closer to the edge. The possibilities for a swift end to the South Korean crisis have shrunk. Worse, there is the bleak prospect of renewed street disturbances today after they had begun to subside in the last few days. **********At Wednesday's session at the Blue House, the presidential residence, Mr. Chun agreed to let National Assembly discussions resume on the central issue in this crisis - how to change the constitutional method for choosing a new national leader. Because the President suspended those talks two months ago, his reversal was a major concession, Government officials said. The opposition did not see it that way. First, its leaders argued, why should they give Mr. Chun credit for undoing an action that in their view should never have been taken in the first place? **********Second, there were never substantive talks because the two sides could not agree even on how to sit at the same table. **********Finally, the opposition said, the passage of time has altered bottom-line demands. Kim Dae Jung insisted Thursday that Mr. Chun now had to declare not only that he was willing to talk about constitutional revision but also that he would not hold elections under the exisiting electoral college system. Anti-Government forces say that system is stacked against them and call for direct Presidential elections. **********That means they want Mr. Chun to drop his cherished plans to hand over the Government next February to his designated successor, Roh Tae Woo, an old ally and a fellow ex-general. ''Unless Chun Doo Hwan makes such a promise, we cannot trust him,'' Mr. Kim said. **********Some analysts saw a measure of posturing in the opposition stand. They argued that all the tough talk did not necessarily eliminate the possibility of later compromise. Brinkmanship, it was noted, is a basic component of Korean politics. Sensitivity Over His Resolve **********In particular, Kim Young Sam may have felt he had to stand firm against Mr. Chun, for his anti-Government resolve has sometimes been questioned in hardline circles, including allies of Kim Dae Jung. ''I think there's great sensitivity about Kim Young Sam being labeled a Government patsy,'' a foreign diplomat said. **********Even if there is an element of posturing on both sides, it is hard to imagine Mr. Chun readily giving up plans to transfer power on his own terms. He has never been interested in revising the system, a point reinforced by a public transcript of what he told Kim Young Sam on Wednesday. **********For its part, the opposition would find it difficult to accept Mr. Chun's political timetable without appearing to be in full retreat. **********Almost immediately after the Blue House meeting, each side began a campaign for public sympathy. The two Kims are counting on widespread dislike of Mr. Chun among South Koreans and their desire for a faster pace of democratic development. The ruling camp is hoping that Koreans will view the President's offer as reasonable, and it has begun to portray the anti-Government forces as being obstructionist at a dangerous moment. **********It is too early to say which way the general public is leaning. But political opinion can be fickle. Many of the same people who were out in the streets a week ago, denouncing the Government as a military dictatorship, could easily turn to accusing the opposition of standing in the way of progress. Students in Spearhead **********Nor are university students, who have spearheaded the recent wave of unrest, immune to public reaction. **********Students, increasingly bold and sensing their power, do not much care about what politicians on either side have to say. But they have shown many times that they are not oblivious to popular moods. **********Perhaps of more immediate concern is whether the army will grow tired of the protesters before the general population does. On the eve of today's scheduled street protests, the question again is how long the Government is prepared to tolerate unrest before it sends in troops to take over from the police. **********Gaston J. Sigur Jr., a high-ranking State Department official sent on a special mission to study the crisis here, left Thursday saying the United States opposed martial law and believed that ''any use of armed forces is unwarranted.'' Another State Department official who was here this week, Edward J. Derwinski, said Wednesday that South Korean officials had assured him the military would not intervene. **********Some experts also question how much stomach the army would have to be called out against South Koreans. Agonized memories of Kwangju, where soldiers gunned down 200 people as then-General Chun consolidated power in 1980, are as fresh as yesterday. Threat From the North **********According to a knowledgeable diplomat, many military men feel that Kwangju ''tarnished their prestige,'' and they do not want that to happen again. They also do not wish, he said, to be distracted from their main duty of defending the country against possible attack from North Korea. That threat is always considered genuine here and is emphasized on a day like Thursday, the anniversary of the outbreak of the Korean War in 1950. **********Nevertheless, there is no guarantee that troops would not be used if disturbances grow and if the Government believes it can convince most South Koreans that it offered fair concessions only to have them rejected by an intransigent opposition. Mr. Chun alluded to possible use of force in his conversation with Kim Young Sam. **********Two weeks ago, Mr. Roh called unrest part of the ''growing pains'' that South Korea must endure on the road to democracy. On Thursday, a Western diplomat agreed, saying he believed the country was headed toward a more open society in a few years. **********But, he added, ''I think we're in for a troubled tomorrow.''
