https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/05/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; Teen-Agers Now Need Tax Planning 101
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/05/busin.body_text: **********STUDENT wage earners who plan to spend the summer flipping burgers or bagging groceries will find their finances have been complicated by the new tax law: More of them may be subject to tax, and the tax bite may be bigger. **********''Students must consider tax planning, which has never been a major factor before,'' said Kevin F. Roach, partner in charge of executive financial services with Price Waterhouse in New York. **********Under the old law, you needed $1,080 of investment income or $3,560 of gross income before you had to file a tax return. Now, dependent children with gross income that exceeds the standard deduction of $2,540 in 1987 ($3,000 in 1988) or who have more than $500 of investment income must file a Form 1040 - even if they ultimately owe no tax. **********While Congress lowered the tax rates and increased the standard deduction for all taxpayers, it changed the law so that children who can be claimed as deductions on their parents' returns cannot take a personal exemption for themselves when filing their own returns. As a result, ''you can't generalize about the overall consequences'' of the new rules for youngsters, Mr. Roach said. **********Once teen-agers are put on a payroll, income tax is automatically withheld from their paychecks unless they claim they have the right to be exempt. **********To be exempt, they must meet two tests. First, they must not have owed any Federal income tax and must have been entitled to a full refund of any tax collected last year. Second, they must not expect to owe any tax this year. If they qualify, they check line six on Form W-4 or W-4A. **********But the recent Tax Act may prevent large numbers of teen-agers from checking that box, because they can no longer claim a personal exemption on their tax returns. Under the old rules, families got two cracks at the personal exemption: Parents claimed their children as dependents on their tax returns and children counted themselves as exemptions on their own returns. To prevent double-dipping, the new law eliminates the exemption -worth $1,900 this year - for dependent children who may be claimed as dependents by their parents. **********At the same time, the Tax Reform Act hedged the standard deduction with new limits, so many youngsters may find it ''more difficult under current law to be exempt from withholding than under prior law,'' said Richard J. Shapiro, national director of taxes for Oppenheim, Appel, Dixon & Company. **********For children who are eligible to be claimed as dependents by their parents (whether they actually are or not), the standard deduction is limited to the greater of two figures: either $500 or their earned income up to the maximum amount. They (or their parents) must struggle with complex calculations that allocate the deduction between earned and unearned income. The allocation is required for two reasons: Only $500 of the standard deduction can be used to offset unearned income, and unearned income of a child younger than 14 in excess of $1,000 is taxed at the parents' higher rate. **********For example, a teen-ager who has $850 of earned income and $950 of unearned income claims a standard deduction of $850, of which $500 is allocated to unearned income and the $250 balance to earned income. This leaves net unearned income of $450 and earned income of $500 subject to tax. **********To illustrate the interplay of the new rules, assume that a student earns $1,500 in trust income and $4,000 from a summer job, for a total adjusted gross income of $5,500. Under the old law, he could claim one personal exemption, reducing his taxable income to $4,420 ($5,500 minus $1,080). The $2,480 standard deduction or zero bracket amount reduced his income even further, leaving him with a $221 tax liability under the old rates. **********Under the new law, however, he cannot claim a personal exemption. So his taxable income equals $2,500 - $4,000 earned income plus $1,500 unearned income, less the $3,000 standard deduction. (The rates for 1988 are used to avoid the problems of ''blended'' rates in 1987, but the results differ by only a few dollars.) Only $1,000 of the unearned income is taxed because the remainder is offset by $500 of the standard deduction; the $2,500 balance of the standard deduction reduces his taxable earned income to $1,500. **********His total tax bill equals That is the sum of $225 tax on earned income ($4,000 less the $2,500 standard deduction, taxed at the 15 percent rate); plus $150 tax on $1,000 of unearned income, according to Mr. Roach. If the child is younger than 14, however, $500 of his unearned income would be taxed at his parents' rate, assumed to be 28 percent; this would raise his total tax bill to $440. **********Besides income tax, students must pay Social Security tax on their summer earnings. This year's rate is 7.15 percent, and the tax is due without exception on all earnings up to $43,800. **********ONE way to reduce taxes is to put children on the family business payroll for the summer. **********Tax revision took the shine off most other family income-shifting devices, so ''I've been receiving more calls than ever before from people who want to know how to put their kids to work in the family business,'' Mr. Roach said. **********Say you need someone to fill in for vacationing workers, and you offer your teen-ager a job at the rate of $6 an hour for 40 hours a week during July and August. The bulk of the teen-ager's $1,920 of earnings is taxed at the 11 percent rate, and you can deduct that amount as a business expense. Children under 21 who are employed by parents who operate their business as a sole proprietorship or partnership reap another benefit: Their earnings are exempt from Social Security tax.  FRILLS FOR THE HOME OFFICE **********The Internal Revenue Service has repeatedly tightened up on the popular home-office deduction. A welcome change for taxpayers is a recent ruling that broadens the scope of that deduction. **********In the ruling, a taxpayer, a dentist whose home office occupied one-sixth of the square footage of his residence, was permitted to depreciate that fraction of the purchase price and deduct a portion of the monthly maintenance cost of his new home security system - expanding the definition of ''ordinary and necessary'' business expense. (A taxpayer who used his home office to manage his investment portfolio was denied the same deduction, however, because his activities were not a ''business'' for purposes of the home office deduction.) The ruling is a reminder that ''anyone with a deductible home office should look for other items'' such as central air-conditioning or fire alarms that might also be partly deductible or depreciable, said Gene Linett of Deloitte, Haskins & Sells. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/busin.main_headline: Not Only the Budget Worries Money Managers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/busin.print_headline: Not Only the Budget Worries Money Managers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/busin.body_text: **********Even if the budget negotiators in Washington agree to a compromise, the stock market may only get a temporary lift from the money managers whose purchases had been such a propellant this summer. **********While they have said for weeks that the budget deficit is the stumbling block to a rebound in stock prices, many of these managers are now citing other reasons for not buying stocks. Beneath it all is a more wary attitude after watching their clients' portfolios decline sharply since mid-October. **********Money managers have billions of dollars in cash waiting to be invested. There is no precise number, but the average cash position of 600 money management firms representing $131 billion was 7.7 percent at the end of last week, according to the Indata Corporation, a division of Gordon, Haskett & Company in Stamford, Conn. **********That is roughly one percentage point higher than the average cash position this year, but it is still well below the level before the bull market began in 1982, when the cash level was 14 percent, said Larry A. Ciccarelli, manager of equity research at the firm. Trade and Dollar Are Factors **********While the budget deficits have become an obsession with some portfolio managers, there are additional factors keeping them away from stocks. They are nervous about the trade figures the Government will release today. Additionally, many fund managers will not move their clients' assets into stocks until they see evidence that the dollar has bottomed. **********They are also nervous that an international event, such as a collapse of the Japanese stock market, could lower the value of stocks sharply. And some portfolio managers believe that by December there could be heavy tax-related selling by individuals. Managers expect that the stocks of small-capitalized companies that fell the hardest in October will be sold as individuals take capital losses. **********Furthermore, some portfolio managers are waiting to buy stocks until they see the Federal Reserve Board cut the discount rate. These managers believe that the economy is weakening and that the Fed should not wait for more evidence before it lowers rates. Pointing to ''lousy home sales, lousy auto sales and a worldwide correction in stock prices,'' Steven A. Kroll, executive vice president of E. F. Hutton & Company, said, ''That's about as much evidence as you need.'' Waiting for Bargains **********Moreover, some managers such as Michael Holland, president of First Boston Asset Management, are not buying stocks because they do not think prices are cheap enough. They want bargains. **********''We don't feel we have to use up that cash in a week or two,'' said James H. Farrell Jr., a partner of Cashman, Farrell & Associates, a Wayne, Pa., investment firm that has $200 million of its clients' funds set aside in short-term investments. ''Bear markets generally don't bottom in a few weeks.'' **********As a result, his firm is barely nibbling at stocks. **********A move to cut the budget deficit obviously would be encouraging. But some money managers would like to see budget cuts larger than the $25 billion to $30 billion now under discussion. One of them is Mario Gabelli, head of Gamco Investors, which has $450 million of its clients' $2 billion parked in money market securities. But he doubts deeper cuts will be made because he does not think the budget negotiators have the ''guts'' to do so. Calls for Zero Deficit **********Some institutional investors want to see Congress and the Administration agree to reduce the deficit to zero within the next five years. **********''It's maddening,'' said Jonathan Berg, founder of New York's Berg Capital, which has half its clients' assets in cash. ''When they raise our taxes, they expect us to adjust our personal budgets, but they're unwilling to cut spending enough. Obviously they're unwilling to address the problem.'' **********Many portfolio managers privately argue that Congress should make cuts ''across the board.'' They want to see cuts in Social Security, the military budget and the cost-of-living adjustments in Federal pension funds. 'No Time to Be a Hero' **********Money managers are also skittish about buying stocks because of concerns about their own business. If they spend what little cash they have on stocks and the market drops further, they worry that their clients will accuse them of being risky and dismiss them. **********''We don't have enough confidence to take action,'' said the head of one firm that manages several billion dollars. **********Conversely, if money managers sell stocks in their portfolios and the market moves higher, their clients will dismiss them and hire better-performing money managers. **********''This is no time to be a hero,'' said one manager.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/28/busin.body_text: **********Bowing to political reality, Japan announced today that it would continue its curbs on automobile exports to the United States for a seventh year. The decision is part of an effort to head off mounting American protectionist sentiment. **********Hajime Tamura, the Minister of International Trade and Industry, said that the quota for auto exports would be 2.3 million cars, the same level as in the previous two years. He added that the ministry believed that, without restraints, auto exports to the United States would have increased and exacerbated trade frictions. **********The car exports accounted for more than a third of Japan's trade surplus with the United States, $16.8 billion out of a total of $43.3 billion in the fiscal year from April 1985 to March 1986, the trade ministry said. **********The Reagan Administration's official stance has been that, in keeping with its free-trade philosophy, it would not ask the Japanese to extend the quotas. But some American auto makers and the United Automobile Workers union, pointing to the $51.5 billion trade deficit with Japan, had called for a cut in the number of cars shipped to the United States. **********This proposal set off a heated debate within the Tokyo Government, according to reports here, with some officials arguing that a cut in auto exports would be a dramatic gesture that might avert further friction and others arguing that to do so would hurt the auto industry, which is already suffering from a strong yen. **********Mr. Tamura said that a reduction had been considered but rejected. **********''Japan is neither a subject country nor a colony of the United States,'' Mr. Tamura added. ''Considering that the Japanese economy is in a recession because of the strong yen and foreign cars are entering Japan, I am sure that the United States Congress and the United States auto industry will welcome this decision.'' Desire to Act Quickly **********The announcement that the restraints would continue came early this year - the ''voluntary'' restraints do not actually expire until March 31. The timing of the announcement shows the Government's desire to act quickly to put a difficult issue behind it. Two years ago, the announcement that Japan would allow auto exports to grow by 24.3 percent touched off what may have been the most severe trade crisis between the two nations since World War II. **********''We have decided to expedite the whole process since it would be counterproductive to both our countries if rumors and speculation should arise,'' Mr. Tamura said. **********The early decision also reflected a broad agreement among Japanese auto makers that continuing restraints were not only inevitable but in some ways desirable. Even before the decision was made, a number of top auto executives said they believed it would be impossible to end the restraints this year, in light of the large American trade deficit with Japan and a Democratic majority in Congress resolved to pass some kind of trade legislation this year. 'It Can't Be Helped' **********''There is nothing that can be done,'' Kenichi Yamamoto, president of the Mazda Motor Corporation, said a few days ago, using a traditional Japanese phrase indicating resignation to fate. ''I don't want to accept it, but it can't be helped.'' **********Indeed, those familiar with the negotiations between the trade ministry and the auto industry said that, this year, some auto makers actually supported continuing the restraints. **********In the past year, the rapid rise of the yen against the dollar has sharply reduced the profits of several auto makers. Profits at Mazda, for example, dropped more than 70 percent from last year, and Nissan reported its first loss since World War II in the first half of this fiscal year. **********Japanese auto makers have been forced to raise prices in the very year that they faced new competition from South Korea, which began shipping cars to the United States last year. In recent months, inventories of Japanese automobiles in the United States have been increasing. Fears of Smaller Makers **********Japan's smaller auto makers, in particular, feared that without quotas, in which the number of cars each company can sell in the United States is set by the trade ministry, they might suffer from severe competition from their Japanese counterparts for the United States market. **********For many auto makers, the quotas have proved profitable. While they restricted total sales in the United States, they allowed auto makers to sell higher-priced, more profitable models. Analysts believe that, except for Toyota, Japanese auto makers rely on exports for profits and do not make money on sales within Japan. **********One executive familiar with the positions of the major auto companies said he believed that the trade ministry would change the allocation of exports this year to include exports from Daihatsu and that it would increase the allotment for smaller companies. He added that he expected that the Honda Motor Company would probably give up some of its share of the quotas because it is producing the most cars in the United States.  COOL U.S. RESPONSE  WASHINGTON, Jan 27 (Special to The New York Times) - American officials responded coolly today to Japan's decision. **********They noted that it would neither deflect Reagan Administration pressure on Tokyo for more market-opening moves nor influence the course of trade legislation this year. **********Senior American trade officials are in Tokyo this week pressing Japan to allow American companies to bid on construction work for the Kansai Airport project in Osaka Bay and taking up pharmaceutical, semiconductor and other sectoral trade disputes. **********American automobile industry officials said they were disappointed that Japan kept the limitations at 2.3 million units. Harold A. Poling, president of the Ford Motor Company, had urged Japan to cut shipments to below two million units as well as to increase the percentage of American product content in Japanese vehicles built in the United States. **********The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said the United States had not asked Japan to extend the restraints. He added that the only real answer to ''our bilateral trade problems'' was ''for Japan to open its markets further.'' **********Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, said the quota extension will have ''zero chance'' of heading off trade legislation this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/24/busin.main_headline: SALES OF U.S.-MADE CARS FELL 37.1% FOR JAN. 11-20
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/24/busin.print_headline: SALES OF U.S.-MADE CARS FELL 37.1% FOR JAN. 11-20
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/24/busin.body_text: **********Sales of new domestically made automobiles plunged 37.1 percent in the second 10-day sales period of the year, the nation's eight major auto manufacturers reported yesterday. **********The drop continued a new-year slump, attributed to large sales incentives and unusual buying ahead of the change in the tax law on Jan. 1. **********Meanwhile, the General Motors Corporation, whose sales have dropped the most sharply of the Big Three, announced a round of division-by-division sales incentives. The inducements include rebates of up to $1,000 by Chevrolet and discounts on options packages by Pontiac, Oldsmobile and Buick. No incentives were offered by Cadillac. **********The seasonally adjusted selling rate for the Jan. 11-20 period was 5.3 million, down from 9.3 million in the same period in 1986 but up slightly from 5.1 million in the early part of the month. There were eight selling days in the period in both years. **********Analysts attributed the sagging sales to the aftereffects of advance buying last year, but some cautioned that underlying demand might also be softening. ''We're going to come in about a million below our forecast on an annualized basis,'' said Michael Luckey, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ''If it goes on like this for a few more periods, we may have to rethink our assumptions.'' **********G.M. reported that it sold 67,549 cars in the period, a decline of 42.2 percent, while Ford Motor Company reported sales of 33,838, a drop of 31.8 percent. The Chrysler Corporation was off 33.6 percent, with sales of 16,306, and the American Motors Corporation was down 47.2 percent, with estimated sales of 810 cars. Volkswagen of America reported sales of 842 cars, down 48.6 percent. **********The only sales increases were reported by Japanese companies that are receiving additional supplies of cars from plants in this country. Sales by the Honda Motor Company increased 41.3 percent, to 4,018, while the Nissan Motor Company's sales increased nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 2,027. The Toyota Motor Corporation, which was not manufacturing cars in this country at this time last year, reported sales of 384 in the period. **********Sales of light trucks declined as well in the period, but by a lesser amount than autos. Truck sales, which include mini-vans and sports utility vehicles, totaled 69,945, down 18 percent. **********Chrysler recorded a gain in trucks in the period, with sales of 11,191, up4.7 percent. But G.M.'s total of 23,817 was off 33.7 percent, and Ford's sales of 27,539 were down 11.9 percent. Jeep Sales **********A.M.C's sales of 5,500 Jeeps equaled last year's level, while Nissan's 1,844 were down 12.1 percent. **********For the year to date, light-truck sales were down 21.2 percent. Car sales in the first two selling periods were off 37.9 percent. **********G.M. lost car market share in the period, declining to 53.9 percent, from 58.7 percent a year earlier. Ford gained, however, climbing to 26.9 percent from 24.9, and Chrysler was up to 13.0 percent from 12.4 percent. **********A.M.C. was off slightly, to six-tenths of 1 percent from eight-tenths of 1 percent, while Volkswagen was also down, to seven-tenths of 1 percent from eight-tenths of 1 percent. But Honda gained, to 3.2 percent from 1.4 percent, while Nissan was off slightly, to nine-tenths of 1 percent from 1.0 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/world.main_headline: Crisis in Haiti Leaves the Neighboring Dominicans Worried
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/world.print_headline: Crisis in Haiti Leaves the Neighboring Dominicans Worried
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/03/world.body_text: **********Although the violence that shook Haiti over the last week has not spilled over into the neighboring Dominican Republic, the border between the two countries remained closed today and Dominican troops in the area were on alert. **********Long-awaited national elections in Haiti, scheduled for Sunday, were canceled after an outbreak of attacks by gunmen apparently tied to the military Government and the deposed regime of Jean-Claude Duvalier. **********In the Dominican Republic, Government leaders and private citizens expressed shock and concern over the events in Haiti. But officials were reluctant to break diplomatic relations or take other steps that some fear could lead to conflict between the two countries. **********''Haiti is our only neighbor,'' Foreign Minister Donald Reid Cabral said in an interview today. ''Any problem in Haiti affects us in many ways. Up to now, however, we see no reason to break relations.'' Outside Intervention Opposed **********Mr. Reid said that while the Dominican Republic favored democracy in all countries, it opposed calls for outside intervention in Haiti. ''The Dominican Republic does not interfere in the affairs of other nations because we do not want others to interfere in our affairs,'' he said. **********Emotions ran high in some circles, however, fueled in part by outrage over the killing of a Dominican television cameraman, Carlos Grullon, by anti-election terrorists in Haiti. Mr. Grullon, 24 years old, was buried here Tuesday after his body was flown home from Port-au-Prince. Tearful friends and relatives shouted condemnations of the Haitian regime. **********As they watched the upheaval in Haiti, some people here saw parallels with the history of their own country, which was ruled by the dictator Rafael Trujillo for three decades and was convulsed by violence for several years after his assassination in 1961. **********Bishop Roque Adames Rodriguez of Santiago, a city near the Haitian border, said he had warned Haitian friends that the overthrow of a dictator does not necessarily end a nation's trouble. **********''I told them not to be enthusiastic about the simple exit of Duvalier,'' the Bishop said. ''We had a very clear experience when Trujillo fell.'' Stronger Action Urged **********Jacobo Majluta Azar, a leader of the opposition Dominican Revolutionary Party, was among politicians calling for stronger action against Haiti. **********''If this inhuman and criminal barbarity is not condemned by all countries, and especially by our country since we share the island, we will not only be denying justice to the Haitian people but also encouraging tyrants who rule other nations,'' he said. **********In Santo Domingo's central market area, there were far fewer Haitians on the streets than usual. Many traveled home to vote and have been unable to return. **********Several hundred thousand Haitians are believed to live in the Dominican Republic, many of them working as street merchants, field hands and factory laborers. Most are here illegally, but they are tolerated and generally get along well with the Dominicans. **********Stores that sell goods to visiting Haitians reported business down by 50 percent or more. Brightly painted buses owned by Haitian peddlers stood in parking lots; they have remained idle for days. **********''No one likes to live in a foreign country, but what is happening in Haiti is so sad we cannot go back now,'' said Louis Antonio Simeon, 31, a Haitian who does odd jobs in Santo Domingo and sends money home to his family. ''We have had dictatorship for too long, and we want to be free. When will God let it happen?'' **********Newspapers in Santo Domingo this week strongly condemned the Haitian Government. ''The general impression is that what happened was not anarchy, but terror organized by the authorities themselves,'' said an editorial in Listin Diario. Effects Across Border Feared **********The tabloid El Sol warned that the Dominican Republic could not hope to remain unaffected by turmoil in Haiti. ''If there is no democratic outcome in Haiti, we will have to prepare ourselves to expect revolutionary outbursts that will have incalculable consequences for our country,'' it said. **********Although Haiti and the Dominican Republic share the same tropical island, the presence of so many Haitian refugees here attests to the different fortunes of the two countries. While Port-au-Prince is perhaps the most wretchedly impoverished capital city in the Western Hemisphere, much of Santo Domingo is modern and bustling with commerce. The levels of health care and education are much higher here, life expectancy is considerably longer and employment opportunities are far greater. **********The current crisis seems likely to widen the gap even further. A report published here this week said at least six companies that maintain assembly plants in Haiti are planning to move their operations to the Dominican Republic so they can function in a climate of political stability.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/world.main_headline: PRESS VS. PALACE: AQUINO WIELDS A SWORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/world.print_headline: PRESS VS. PALACE: AQUINO WIELDS A SWORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/world.body_text: **********The word ''media,'' a spokesman for President Corazon C. Aquino said in the early days of her Government, is the plural for ''mediocre.'' **********Right from the start, something seemed to go wrong in relations between the palace and the local press, which was glorying in its newfound freedom, sometimes with more exuberance than accuracy. **********The number of daily newspapers in Manila jumped to more than 20, and political columnists became celebrities as they stirred fact, gossip and rumor into a colorful daily mix. **********''If you want unverified gossip passed on as truth, it is there,'' wrote one of the more careful columnists, Francisco S. Tatad. ''If you want a person's private fault reported as public fact, it is there, too. If you want the most inconsequential nonsense blown up into an earthshaking event, you will find no shortage of it.'' **********Another columnist, Sylvia Mayuga, said the press had come to deal in ''political pornography,'' offering perverse thrills that distort realities and values. Censorship Is Charged **********Now, as the Government tightens its grip before a constitutional plebiscite, the press has put itself in the spotlight, accusing the Government of censorship. **********When the Government television station refused last week to broadcast a discussion forum with an opposition figure, former Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile, journalists who had been jailed or dismissed during the martial law he administered rose angrily to his defense. **********''Can one no longer criticize the Government?'' wrote Ninez Cacho-Olivares, who was one of the most daring critics of President Ferdinand E. Marcos in the final months of his rule. **********The Aquino Government, she wrote, ''seems to have gone the way of Marcos and has violated the constitutional guarantee of freedom of the press.'' **********Both the writers and the readers of such criticism are aware that the Aquino Government is far from duplicating the press censorship of the Marcos years, when all but a few ''crony'' newspapers were closed and hundreds of journalists were jailed. **********The stridency of the criticism illustrates both the degree of freedom that is permitted today, and the flamboyance with which it is often exercised. Dress Code for Reporters **********The Government has often reacted with what its critics like to call ''onion skin,'' only to provide new grist for Manila's hungry newspapers in their circulation war. **********At one point the palace banned a photographer who had violated guidelines by photographing Mrs. Aquino in the act of eating. **********At another it issued a dress code for reporters covering the President that required them not only to look presentable but to smell good. **********Most delicious for her press critics was the President's own joke, received by political columnists with high dudgeon, that ''perhaps it was my mistake that I restored the freedom of the press.'' **********Mrs. Aquino had to back down a few days later, saying, ''From now on I just have to keep reminding myself that now that I am President, I am not supposed to give jokes.'' Press 'Is Too Free' **********But genuine irritation did seem to be behind her quip. **********Her former spokesman, Rene Saguisag, the man who said he found the media mediocre, seemed to reflect her views when he said last summer, ''We are for a free press, but it is too free.'' **********''Every day when I read the papers, I find out that I did or said or thought things that I did not do, say or think,'' he said. **********Of the President, Mr. Saguisag said, ''I don't think she jumps for joy'' when she reads the morning papers. **********Her problems with the press have come not only from the wild competition among the proliferating newspapers, most of which analysts here believe will eventually lose the war for readership and close down. **********She has also lived for nearly a year with several hostile newspapers that remain in the hands of close Marcos associates, and with dozens of radio stations that broadcast strident pro-Marcos propaganda. **********Now, Ms. Cacho-Olivares suggested, the Government ''seems to be bent on doing away with the opposition media.'' **********Last week, the National Press Club expressed ''grave concern over the deepening involvement of the Government in the media.'' Newspaper to Close **********There are reports that the Government may not renew the licenses of several radio stations, and it has announced the closing at the end of this month of The Philippines Daily Express, which is owned by a close Marcos associate, Roberto Benedicto. **********The Government says the newspaper, which was taken over by a commission investigating Mr. Marcos's holdings, is being closed because it is losing money, and not for political reasons. **********The commission has also assumed control of two other pro-Marcos newspapers, and there are reports that the Government is supervising two independent television stations. **********In addition, the President has not dismantled Mr. Marcos's propaganda apparatus as she promised to do during her campaign, but has attempted to improve and reorganize it. **********The Government television station, once named for Mr. Marcos's World War II guerrilla unit and now renamed People's Television, frequently broadcasts film montages and other programs that celebrate the new Government. Broadcast Is Canceled **********Months ago, it committed itself to broadcast a weekly coffee-shop forum at which opposition figures often took part even during the later months of Mr. Marcos's presidency. **********But last week it canceled its broadcast of the forum at which Mr. Enrile was the guest. Both the cancellation and the Government's explanation for it have disturbed several Philippine journalists. **********''Do not confuse a Government entity with the private and commercial media,'' said Mr. Saguisag's successor as spokesman, Teodoro Benigno. ''Freedom of the press is very much in practice in the commercial media.'' **********If given air time on People's Television, he said, Mr. Enrile would simply ''rant, fume, rage and criticize the Government without giving the Government a chance to present its side.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/31/busin.main_headline: WHY A LOW SAVINGS RATE ISN'T ALL BAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/31/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM; WHY A LOW SAVINGS RATE ISN'T ALL BAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/31/busin.body_text: **********PERSONAL saving is the part of your paycheck that is left over after taxes and all the bills are paid. For most Americans struggling to make ends meet, it will come as little surprise that saving amounts to a small share of income. But the 2.5 percent of after-tax income it represented in 1986 was well below the average of 6.6 percent for the last five years and the lowest level in the postwar era. **********This abysmal performance, especially in comparison with Japan's saving rate of more than 25 percent, has raised serious questions about our national policy on saving. Should we save more? Why does a country like Japan save so much, and should we be more like it? The answers are far from clear cut. **********The American attitude about saving is schizophrenic. Saving is considered a virtue, so failing to save must somehow be unvirtuous. Then again, we are subjected daily to a barrage of ads claiming, ''You can have it all, now,'' suggesting that somehow our every need and wish should be instantly gratified. **********Historically, the United States achieved enormous gains in living standards without a high level of raw saving and capital accumulation. It did this by avoiding major wars on its soil (except, of course, the Civil War) and through technological ingenuity that raised the productivity of the resources already at hand. Still, unless we want to gamble on some new frontier to sustain our living standard, the low savings rate should concern us. **********There is one bright spot: The stock market boom of recent years has probably distorted the measured saving rate, making it look much lower than it is. Technically, the savings rate also includes corporate contributions to pension funds, which make up a large part of personal saving. Funding formulas for defined benefit pensions call for reduced contributions when the stock market and real interest rates are high. Both events have coincided in the 1980's and probably have had a significant negative impact on the measured personal saving rate. (See accompanying chart.) We should not find absolute solace in this pension-related drop in personal saving, however. When the market drops, the same pension-funding formula would call for increases in pension contributions. While those additional payments would show up as a sharp increase in the personal saving rate, many companies would find themselves strapped for cash to meet the contributions. **********Moreover, we should not lose sight of a major cause of the low savings rate - the effort to maintain a high level of consumption during the 1980's, a period of sluggish growth that averaged 2.5 percent or below instead of the 4 percent we had counted on. This living beyond our means finds its most obvious expression in the Federal budget deficit, which continues to draw down savings. **********But none of this weighs particularly heavily on Americans, perhaps because they continue to prosper despite a low savings rate, conventionally measured. Accordingly, economic policies seem to be contemptuous of the notion that saving ought to be encouraged. **********Our tax policy, which subsidizes borrowing and penalizes lending, is the reverse of that in high-saving countries like Japan. The rush toward consumption accelerates in inflationary periods, when borrowing expands because inflation-bloated interest rates are fully deductible for borrowers but fully taxed for lenders. This effect was only mildly muted by the Tax Reform Act of 1986. **********A look at nations with high rates of personal saving is informative, but is also a little discouraging. Japanese real per capita income was halved by World War II. The result was a ferocious commitment to elevating future consumption by saving one-quarter to one-third of income, rather than leaving things to chance or technological breakthrough. **********Although contemporary Japan is a newly rich country, its citizens do not enjoy a rich standard of living. The Japanese work six days a week and save nearly a third of their income. That pool of savings is augmented by the ingrained saving habits of Japan's elderly and the scarcity of leisure time. ALSO, instead of using its limited areas of open land for ample and comfortable housing, Japan has chosen to allow farmers to use the land to grow rice, even though the direct cost of growing rice in Japan is eight times the world price. The indirect cost is far higher.  Agricultural protection forces Japanese consumers to spend an extra $60 billion yearly on food and to pay dearly for substandard housing. The average Japanese spends 10 times annual family income for housing, compared with an already hefty four times income spent by Americans. Most of the difference is due to the astronomical cost of land in a mountainous country that devotes most of its habitable terrain to agriculture. **********The recent link-up between Tokyo and the international capital markets produced a mutual attraction between Japan's megasavers and America's superconsumers far stronger than anyone had imagined. But now that America's Japanese-financed spending spree has been under way for a few years, there are signs of strain in the marriage. Americans are increasing their debt to Japan at a rate of $60 billion a year and running a $60 billion trade deficit in the process. **********Before long, both America's extravagant spending and Japan's high saving rate will have to change. Americans are already getting nervous about debts to foreigners, while the Japanese, especially those who have seen the homes and life styles of Americans, are beginning to wonder what they are saving for. **********A major inhibitor of saving in the United States is the tax system, which taxes saving twice - when the money is earned and when it pays interest. A consumption tax or national sales tax, in place of income taxes, would eliminate that bias and encourage more saving. **********If Japan changed land use and tax policies to increase the supply of land for housing, the resulting surge in housing construction would fuel an economic boom. Japanese producers could turn their attention to supplying the builders who would rehouse the nation, instead of producing exclusively for export. Trade tensions would be sharply reduced. **********We are a rich nation, well able to afford a consumption binge. But at current saving rates and barring major technological innovations, the living standards of our children and grandchildren will at best only match those we are now enjoying. While this would be no great hardship by historical standards, it would be the first time a society has chosen to lower the living standards of subsequent generations. If that is what we propose, perhaps we should warn our children and ask ourselves why America in the late 20th century should be different from most other societies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/10/busin.body_text: **********Three of New York's most prominent securities lawyers told a panel of the House of Representatives today that proposed tender offer legislation would have small effect on hostile takeover activity. **********The proposed legislation, which would restrict a number of tactics frequently used in hostile takeovers, including ''greenmail'' and ''golden parachutes,'' is being considered by the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance. **********''I think all of the bills as presently drafted will essentially have no impact on hostile takeover activity,'' said Martin Lipton, a partner in the New York firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz. ''And the takeover frenzy that we have been in the last decade will continue in a somewhat different form.'' **********Two other lawyers - Joseph H. Flom, a partner with Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, and Arthur Fleisher Jr., a senior partner at Fried, Frank, Harris, Shrive & Jacobson - testified that the proposed legislation would have little effect on takeovers by increasing the time necessary to complete a transaction. The bill would increase the number of calendar days a tender offer can remain open, to 60 from 20.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/17/busin.body_text: **********Jaime Ongpin, Finance Minister of the Philippines, will formally ask bankers to reopen talks on their completed debt-restructuring accord with his country, people familiar with his plans said yesterday. **********''He will tell the banks he is only willing to pay 13/16 over Libor,'' one of these sources said, requesting anonymity. A spread of 13/16 percentage point above the London interbank offered rate would match that won by Argentina this week and by Mexico last year in their debt negotiations. **********''If the banks think we are going to sit still after they had sworn to us that the Mexican debt package would only be repeated over their dead bodies and then gave the same deal to Argentina, they are mistaken,'' Mr. Ongpin said in Manila, Reuters reported. ''I now see no moral or legal obligation to honor our commitment.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/busin.body_text: **********Ending a fierce, two-month takeover battle, the Dutch publisher Wolters Samsom Group N.V. said it had won control of rival Kluwer N.V., successfully fighting off a competing bid from another Dutch publisher, Elsevier N.V. The merger of Kluwer and Wolters Samsom, valued at $540 million, will create a new Dutch publishing giant and replace Elsevier as the second-largest publisher in the Netherlands. The combined publishing houses are expected to have yearly revenues of about $850 million. **********Elsevier, a leading international scientific publishing house that already had a 30 percent stake in Kluwer, wanted a merger to strengthen its position as one of the publishing world's leading houses. Its bid for Kluwer expires Monday, but stock market analysts said it had little chance of succeeding.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/12/world.main_headline: NORTH POPULARITY WON'T CURB PANEL, LEGISLATORS SAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/12/world.print_headline: NORTH POPULARITY WON'T CURB PANEL, LEGISLATORS SAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/12/world.body_text: **********Members of the Congressional select committees say the favorable public reaction to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's testimony does not lessen their determination to conduct an aggressive investigation into his activities and the Reagan Administration's policies on Iran and Nicaragua. **********In interviews Friday night and today, after four gripping days of testimony, senators and representatives from both parties said they did not believe the public regard for Colonel North translated into support for his policies or disapproval of the committees. **********''It's not that they agreed with the colonel,'' said Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii and chairman of the Senate panel, adding that ''it's that people hated to see him hung out to dangle in the wind'' by the Administration. Reagan Suffers in Poll **********That position was borne out by a New York Times/CBS News Poll taken Thursday that showed favorable public views of both Colonel North and the committees and unfavorable opinions of President Reagan's policy on Latin America and his handling of Iran-contra matters. **********Moreover, the legislators said that by the week's end they sensed a shift in momentum. The committees' mail, according to a spokesman, was heavily critical of the investigation early in the week, but by Friday it had turned around. Several legislators said they had seen a similar shift in their personal mail. No 'Evil Wizard' Found **********Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, the Republican vice chairman of the Senate committee, said that for months the White House had depicted Colonel North as ''the evil wizard,'' and he was often portrayed that way in news accounts. One reason for the favorable response to his testimony, Senator Rudman suggested, was that the public was surprised to find him such an attractive and sympathetic witness. **********''I am totally convinced,'' the Senator continued, ''that when this all sinks in, the American people will have a lot to be concerned about.'' **********Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, agreed with that assessment. ''This week was overshadowed by the force of his personality,'' he said. ''But in the long term, the focus will be on the policy.'' **********Many lawmakers today were preparing questions they intend to ask Colonel North on Monday, and the staffs were preparing for the appearance of Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter on Tuesday or Wednesday. **********Democrats and Republicans alike said Admiral Poindexter, the former national security adviser who was Colonel North's immediate superior, would be the crucial witness of the investigation. He is the only one with intimate knowledge of what was being done on Iran and Nicaragua who met regularly with the President. **********''All roads now bypass North and lead to Poindexter,'' said Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois. ''What he is going to say now is the mega-question.'' **********Republicans and Democrats both said they had been impressed by Colonel North's sincerity and believed his testimony that the secret operations he ran from the White House were conducted only under orders from his superiors. But they said they were skeptical of many aspects of his testimony. **********None of the more than a dozen lawmakers interviewed supported the central point in Colonel North's testimony - that it was acceptable to lie to Congress and others in the Government to protect clandestine foreign policy initiatives and to finance those operations with secret funds raised outside the Government. Some Testimony Not Believed **********Moreover, many of the senators and representatives said they found particular elements of the colonel's testimony unbelievable. For example, they said they doubted that he shredded his files last fall because, as he said, he knew he would be leaving the White House and feared his successor would not have his ''same values'' or ''perspective.'' Surely, they said, the main reason for the shredding was to hide from Congress and perhaps from prosecutors what had happened. **********Another part of the testimony many found unbelievable was the Marine colonel's assertion that he needed to use money from the Iran arms sales to pay for a security system for his home because the Government would not provide him with protection. They said they would try to show on Monday that he had not made a serious effort to obtain official protection. **********But the legislators said the testimony would be valuable in the attaining their main goal of determining and explaining to the public, in the words of Senator George J. Mitchell, a Maine Democrat, ''what happened and how and why these policies developed.'' **********Colonel North, for instance, was the first witness to describe the influence in the Administration of William J. Casey, then the Director of Central Intelligence, and Mr. Casey's interest in having a secret fund he could draw on that was not accountable to Congress or the rest of the Government. What Mr. Casey wanted, Senator Rudman said, was ''a C.I.A. outside of the C.I.A., thus avoiding the oversight any democracy has to have.'' **********The lawmakers were also especially interested in his testimony that top Administration officials like Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger were muted in their opposition to trading arms to Iran for American hostages. Mr. Shultz and Mr. Weinberger, who have said they argued strenuously against the deals, will testify later. **********Representative Ed Jenkins, one of only two legislators who questioned Colonel North this week, made a point of criticizing the secret fund. ''There is not a single official elected by the people of this great nation that had any knowledge of that,'' he declared. **********When Mr. Jenkins asked the colonel if that statement was correct, he replied that it was. ''That is current knowledge, Congressman,'' he said. Respectful Challenging **********In his questioning, Mr. Jenkins, a Democrat from rural north Georgia, politely challenged the colonel on such matters as his lying to Iranians with whom he was trying to arrange a long-term understanding and his justification for the profits Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord and his business partner, Albert Hakim, stood to make from the arms deals. **********Mr. Jenkins's demeanor and line of questioning were ''masterful,'' Senator Rudman said. Others said that if that caliber of interrogation was maintained, it might somewhat diminish the public's perception of the colonel. **********''Remember,'' said Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, ''General Secord looked pretty good at first, but at the end, he didn't look so hot.'' **********The legislators have no doubt that Colonel North did himself a great deal of good with his testimony this week. Senator Howell Heflin, a Democrat who was once Chief Justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, said, ''He has such a winning way that it will be very difficult for any jury to convict him.'' **********Senator James A. McClure, an Idaho Republican, said he was advising people not to form conclusions yet. ''Every witness,'' he said, ''shifts the focus to someone else.'' **********The investigation, he added, would not ''run off its track and blow up,'' and people should let it ''run its course'' before reaching judgments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/23/world.main_headline: Lebanese Hijacking Suspect Is Denied Bail at Hearing in U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/23/world.print_headline: Lebanese Hijacking Suspect Is Denied Bail at Hearing in U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/23/world.body_text: **********Appearing with both his forearms encased in plaster, Fawaz Younis, a Lebanese terrorist suspect, was denied bail today at a pretrial hearing. He was charged last week with hijacking a Jordanian airliner in 1985. **********The casts were placed on Mr. Younis several days ago because he had suffered ''small fractures in each wrist,'' said Pat Korten, a Justice Department spokesman. Mr. Korten said law enforcement officials had not yet determined whether the fractures occurred while Mr. Younis was in their custody. **********Francis D. Carter, the Washington lawyer who is representing Mr. Younis, said the fractures ''definitely'' occurred after he was trapped in a sting operation while on vacation in Cyprus. **********Officials from the F.B.I. and the Justice Departments have refused to give details of the operation that led to the arrest, in which the suspect was lured into international waters by American authorities. Arrested by F.B.I. Agents **********But one Government official said of Mr. Younis's fractures, ''It appears that it could only have been accidental.'' He said he was not aware of any struggle. **********This official added that after Mr. Younis was captured on board a private yacht off Cyprus where he was arrested by F.B.I. agents, he was transferred to a Navy vessel where he was interrogated for three days. **********''When he was brought aboard the U.S. naval vessel, his wrists were swollen,'' the official said. **********Much of today's hearing was taken up with a video-tape recording of a speech given by a man whom Government prosecutors identified as Mr. Younis. He gave the speech while standing on the steps of an airliner. **********In a four-page transcript provided to reporters, the man identified as Mr. Younis said the hijacking was undertaken as an expression of protest over an Arab League meeting that week. The Arab nations adopted a resolution calling for an immediate cease-fire in and around the Palestinian district besieged by Shiite militiamen on the outskirts of Beirut and for the withdrawal of the Shiites. 'We Are Not Terrorists' **********''We would like to clarify,'' the transcript recorded Mr. Younis as saying, ''we are not terrorists, killers or criminals, nor are we shedders of blood.'' **********He continued: ''We would just like, through our operation, to make it clear to the people and to world opinion as a whole what is really going on within some of the repressive right-wing Arab regimes - especially in the Arab League conference, that was held to save Yasir Arafat and his acts and to save his false slogans.'' **********Mr. Younis, who is a Shiite Moslem, was arraigned last Thursday in Federal District Court here on charges that he was a leader of the 1985 hijacking of a Jordanian airliner with four Americans aboard. He pleaded not guilty in the brief hearing before being returned to custody.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/06/world.main_headline: FURY AND TURMOIL: DAYS THAT SHOOK KOREA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/06/world.print_headline: FURY AND TURMOIL: DAYS THAT SHOOK KOREA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/06/world.body_text: **********On Friday, June 19, after a night of violent demonstrations that saw riot policemen lose control of the streets to anti-Government protesters, President Chun Doo Hwan was ready to call troops into Seoul and other embattled cities. **********Orders to move were issued that day to army units, and some began to take up positions outside the capital, knowledgeable politicians and foreign diplomats say. **********They discussed the military threat in painting a fuller picture of the events that ultimately produced the startling announcement last Monday in which Roh Tae Woo, the chairman of the ruling party, altered the face of South Korean politics. 'Very Close' to Using Troops **********What was contemplated on June 19, the politicians and diplomats said, was not martial law but a lesser action known as a garrison decree. It would have authorized the use of soldiers to maintain order, but would also have left the Government and all its agencies in civilian hands. **********The country, several well-informed people said, had come much nearer to military intervention than most South Koreans realized at the time. ''We were very close,'' a diplomat said. **********But a few hours before troops were set to move, Mr. Chun suddenly shifted direction, as he often had done in his seven years in power. His instinct is to deal quickly and forcefully with dissent, people familiar with his thinking say. But he is also prepared to sheath his temper, they add, if that seems the wiser course. **********From moderates within his Government and ruling party, Mr. Chun heard warnings that military action would jeopardize the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, would anger the United States and other countries important to South Korea, and perhaps would even have made it impossible for the President to transfer power next February, as planned, to his hand-picked successor, Mr. Roh. **********Besides, several officials said, many commanders did not want to get involved, in the belief that the military's reputation had been sullied whenever it was called out against South Koreans in the past. **********Instead of immediate action, Mr. Chun pulled back and settled for a stern warning. On the night of June 19, his figurehead Prime Minister, Lee Han Key, went on television to threaten unspecified ''extraordinary'' measures if the protests did not end. Drastic Compromises **********That decision, well-placed analysts said, may have turned the tide in South Korea's political crisis, for it affirmed the Government's commitment to seek a political solution to end the most sustained street violence in seven years. It led senior officials and ruling-party leaders to consider drastic compromises that they had rejected out of hand before. **********Ultimately - although it took 10 days - it produced the decision by Mr. Roh to capitulate to major opposition demands for direct presidential elections, release of political prisoners and restoration of civil rights to dissidents, including the best-known political figure, Kim Dae Jung. Two days later, on July 1, Mr. Chun gave his approval. **********Suddenly, Mr. Roh must run for a presidency that he had expected to have handed to him. Just as suddenly, the opposition is forced to prepare not only for an election that had seemed improbable but also for the possibility that it might actually take office next year. **********How Mr. Roh reached his decision is still not fully clear. Although he said in an interview on Saturday that he had discussed the political situation with many Koreans of varied backgrounds, he made his intentions known only to close advisers. **********Even before then, pressure for decisive action had been building within the governing Democratic Justice Party. Still, when his final announcement was made to the party's executive council, it was a true bombshell. **********He was looking, Mr. Roh said in the interview, for ''sweeping, epoch-making, bold measures.'' **********It appears that he had no face-to-face meetings with President Chun between June 24, when he says he made up his mind, and June 29, when he publicly disclosed his plans. In the interview, Mr. Roh would not directly discuss any conversations that may have taken place at the Blue House, the presidential residence.  A Pair of Old Allies, But Sometimes Also Political Rivals **********But party officials and diplomats say they believe that Mr. Roh kept Mr. Chun fully informed through third parties about his thinking. The President may not have known in advance about every detail of what would become an eight-point plan, these officials said, but he understood the critical details, especially those involving direct presidential elections and political freedom for Kim Dae Jung, a man openly loathed in the Blue House. **********''Mr. Roh knew the President's mind,'' a National Assembly member from the Democratic Justice Party said. **********Some analysts also discerned a calculated attempt to enhance Mr. Roh's political stature, which had begun to wilt in the crisis. This maneuvering was not without complications. **********On one hand, Mr. Chun and Mr. Roh are old allies, fellow graduates of the Korea Military Academy, class of 1955, and partners in a mutiny of generals that brought them to power in late 1979. But they have also fallen into rivalry on occasion. This may have been one of those times, political analysts said. **********Mr. Chun had announced publicly that he was leaving all political matters to Mr. Roh, concentrating himself on defense, economics and national security. As the crisis wore on, some analysts said, the President grew increasingly irritated with his friend. **********There were reports that Mr. Roh might even be sacrificed as his party's presidential candidate, the hope being that that would be enough of a conciliatory gesture to the opposition to ease tensions. At one point, Mr. Roh himself implied that he was prepared to give up his ambitions for higher office if that was what it would take. **********But when the decision was finally reached to offer concessions, several knowledgeable people said, it was also agreed to protect the Roh candidacy. Only the boldest possible move would work, Mr. Roh and his advisers. **********Among Mr. Roh's problems was that many South Koreans regarded him as a phlegmatic carbon copy of the President. During recent protests, some of the attacks were brutal. In one chant, Mr. Roh was called ''the bald man with a wig,'' meaning Mr. Chun in disguise. **********''By taking these steps he shatters his image as an indecisive man,'' a diplomat said of Mr. Roh. ''My hunch is that they agreed in principle to some sort of dramatic gesture to establish a break with Chun.'' **********There is no evidence that Mr. Roh cleared his proposals with senior military officers, to check whether the prospect of a wide-open presidential campaign would make them nervous. Twice in the past - Park Chung Hee in 1961 and Mr. Chun in 1979 - South Korean generals have stepped in when free-for-all politics became too disorderly to their liking. **********Still, as a former general, Mr. Roh is widely presumed to have taken informal soundings from the army. Several politicians said they had heard that he had help in this effort from his brother-in-law, Kim Bok Dong, also a retired military man. The purpose, they said, was not so much to obtain the army's approval as to determine if there was active disapproval. **********For his part, Mr. Roh said in the interview that ''consulting with active-duty military officers on this political subject would be inappropriate.'' Nevertheless, he added, ''I also felt quite confident that the military would fully support my proposal.'' **********The wave of protests began on June 10, a few hours after the ruling party certified Mr. Roh as its presidential candidate before a much-criticized electoral college that is now to be discarded. **********It had been generally assumed that street rallies scheduled for that day by a coalition of anti-Government groups would be large but easily contained, like others that had come before. There was ample precedent to show that riot policemen were capable of stopping demonstrators cold before they could even gather. **********This time, things were different. It was not just that the rally was bigger than previous ones. For the first time, there were also undeniable signs of solid middle-class support for college students, who by long tradition are the shock troops of protest in South Korea. **********People of all ages and backgrounds were obviously dissatisfied with the slow pace of political development. All they had was Mr. Chun's promise that he would step aside next February, thereby becoming the first South Korean leader to leave the Blue House voluntarily. The President had argued that his departure, of itself, would be the single greatest stride toward democracy in the country's 39-year history. **********It quickly became clear that South Koreans wanted more. **********Their protests reached a fever pitch the night of Thursday, June 18. Downtown Seoul looked like a war zone as tens of thousands of demonstrators took control of the streets, overpowering entire units of riot policemen who had run out of tear gas. **********Battles erupted in cities across the country, including places not accustomed to street fighting, such as Taejon, 85 miles south of the capital. That night in Taejon a protester, who turned out to be a drunken ex-convict, commandeered a bus and drove it into a line of police officers, killing one of them. **********From that moment, the mood of the police turned dark. They were overworked and undermanned, and discipline was in danger of breaking down. ''There were police units that began to ask for military help,'' a Western diplomat said. **********They were turned down the next day, however, as Mr. Chun reportedly first endorsed involving the army, then backed away. ''In a sense,'' the diplomat said, ''that has been Chun's saving grace - his unpredictability. That's part of his mystique. You don't know what he'll do.'' **********Even before the June 19 decision to withhold military force, a political solution was being demanded in many quarters. Religious leaders, notably the influential Roman Catholic Primate, Stephen Cardinal Kim Sou Hwan, called for direct election of the next president. **********That same week, President Reagan sent a letter to Mr. Chun, urging discussions and cautioning the South Korean leader against an overreaction to the protests. **********In the meantime, adverse reaction overseas to the civil unrest raised serious questions about whether South Korea could hold a trouble-free Olympics next year; this created its own pressures for a peaceful settlement. **********Few things are more important to South Koreans -supporters and opponents of the Government alike -than the 1988 Games. For them, the Olympics amount to a coming-out party attesting to their arrival as a global economic force.  In the National Assembly, The Ruling Party Suddenly Switches **********Perhaps the surest sign that change was afoot came from National Assemblymen in the ruling party. Suddenly, they were clamoring for concessions to the opposition, arguing that democratic changes were long overdue anyway. And some of these Assemblymen, such as Lee Jong Chan and Hyun Hong Choo, were advisers to Mr. Roh. **********The turnabout of the politicians was startling. For seven years most of them had served as unquestioning minions to Mr. Chun, providing him with a political framework that he lacked as a career army officer. Now, worried about their country's future and no doubt their own as well, they became vigorous advocates of reform. **********A caucus of party lawmakers held on Sunday, June 21, showed the depth of feelings within the Democratic Justice Party, especially among politicians from Seoul and other big cities. Their remarks were reported in uncommon detail by the South Korean press, which has long been shackled by the Government but which in recent weeks has gone out of its way to test the outer limits of official tolerance. **********One Assemblyman, Hong Sung Woo, a former television actor, was quoted as saying: ''People want direct elections. People are fed up with the military running politics.'' **********Other comments from unidentified lawmakers were, ''We should get rid of the smell of military barracks from our party,'' and, ''We should regain the confidence of people to escape from being an object of hatred.'' **********People who were on hand said that the overall anti-Chun tone was even harsher than the newspapers suggested. **********According to Korean officials familiar with Mr. Roh, opinions of this sort had already begun to influence his thinking. **********They say that six years out of the army - and after more than two years as chairman of the ruling party -he has become ''civilianized.'' Forced into the rough and tumble of politics, colleagues say, he has learned to respect diversity of opinion, especially when compared with Mr. Chun, who went straight from the barracks to the Blue House and is said to have minimal patience for disagreement. **********In conversations, if not in print, Korean journalists who follow political affairs have raised the possibility that Mr. Roh's surprising announcement was an attempt to strike at Mr. Chun. They say he had been unhappy over reports that his presidential candidacy was in jeopardy, and in effect tried to save himself with a bold move that would back the President into a corner, leaving him no alternative but to go along.  Growing Signs of Change: Hard Line Eases in the Blue House **********But it seems more likely that there was some sort of coordination between President Chun and Mr. Roh. **********In late May, even before the crisis began, Mr. Chun bolstered his old friend's standing by reorganizing his Cabinet and removing two serious rivals - the Prime Minister, Lho Shin Young, and Chang Se Dong, head of the National Security Planning Agency, formerly known as the Korean Central Intelligence Agency. **********Moreover, President Chun, having abandoned his initial hard line, suddenly showed little public hesitation himself about accepting changes. **********An important sign was his willingness to meet for the first time with Kim Young Sam, head of the main opposition force, the Reunification Democratic Party. At that meeting - held on June 24, the day Mr. Roh said he had made up his mind to act - Mr. Chun reversed an order he had announced in April, and agreed to a resumption of talks on amending constitutional provisions for electing the president. **********That was not good enough, Mr. Kim said later, and he announced that his party would join new street rallies scheduled nationwide for June 26. Once more, the mood turned ominous. Many Koreans approached June 26 with unmasked dread, for it seemed that troops might be summoned if the violence of June 18 was repeated. **********While the numbers of protesters were large, sweeping across more than 30 cities, the rallies were peaceful for the most part. It was increasingly evident that the momentum of conciliation was well under way. **********By then, demands for change were louder than ever within the ruling camp. On June 26, the Democratic Justice Party's Secretary General, Lee Choon Koo, said openly that it was now impossible for Mr. Chun to transfer power to a designated successor using the existing Constitution and its electoral college. **********Still, most party members were talking about relatively moderate overtures to the opposition, such as holding a national referendum on a new form of government, or calling quick elections for the National Assembly, with the winning party having its way on constitutional revision. A few people called for direct elections, but they were a distinct minority. **********Almost no one in the party - or in the Government, for that matter - was prepared for how far Mr. Roh would go when he walked into the party's executive council session last Monday with a text that had been written over the weekend by an aide, Lee Byong Ki. **********He asked reporters and photographers to stay, and then, for 17 minutes, he laid out his plan for direct elections and other changes. As he spoke, some party members closed their eyes and concentrated. **********''This country belongs to us,'' Mr. Roh said. ''It is our historic duty to both exert our efforts and exercise restraint and wisdom to more successfully develop the country, which was founded and nurtured with the blood of our forefathers and the lives of the patriots, and to proudly hand it over to the next generation.'' **********He added, ''I sincerely hope that national wisdom will be pooled to demonstrate to the world that the Korean people will not go backward, but will go forward to make a contribution to world history.'' **********At that, the room burst into applause. Mr. Roh shook hands with senior party officials, apologizing for not having provided advance warning. **********''What do you think of my plan?'' he asked a Korean reporter as he left. ''You have done well,'' the reporter replied. ''You saw that I have abandoned everything,'' Mr. Roh said. And then, using a Korean expressing for taking a big gamble, he added, ''Now, I am really naked.''
