https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/25/busin.print_headline: Advertising; New Monthly Is Aimed At Owners of VCR's
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/25/busin.body_text: **********Some experienced magazine and direct-marketing people are involved in the planning for a new monthly, controlled-circulation magazine that will bring readers news of the world of video cassettes and advertisers an opportunity to sell the readers those cassettes by mail. **********The publication is V, The Mail-Order Magazine of Videocassettes, which will bow in January with a circulation of 400,000 taken from a list of affluent VCR owners compiled by the publisher, the Fairfield Publishing Company of New York. The people on the list are not only affluent but also people who have bought by direct mail in the past. **********Behind the magazine are John R. Purcell, its chairman and chief executive, most recently chairman and president of SFN Companies and formerly president of CBS Publishing. His president is David H. Soskin, previously of SFN and former president of Soskin/Thompson, the direct-marketing subsidiary of J.Walter Thompson. **********Richard Wien is vice president and editor in chief.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/26/world.main_headline: In the War Crimes Archives: Rifts on Prosecutions
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/26/world.print_headline: In the War Crimes Archives: Rifts on Prosecutions
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/26/world.body_text: **********A former West German state official and a fugitive former minister of pro-Nazi Slovakia who was admitted to the United States are among 35,000 suspected war criminals named in recently unsealed United Nations files, a first review of the vast archive has disclosed. **********The cases involve Wilhelm Kopf, the first Premier of the West German state of Lower Saxony, who was accused of heading the Germans' property expropriation program in a part of occupied Poland, and Ferdinand Durcansky, a Slovak minister who was accused by the postwar Czechoslovak Government of ordering the deportations and killings of Jews. Both men are dead. **********The 8,178 files, collected by the United Nations War Crimes Commission and closed for more than 40 years, include harrowing litanies of World War II atrocities against Jews and others by German forces and their collaborators, including Italians, from fjords in Norway to mountain villages in Yugoslavia. The files also include accusations against 363 Japanese. Files Mirror Cold War Tensions **********The files, stored in a Manhattan office building and recently opened for the first time to outside researchers, also shed new light on some of the cold war tensions that split Eastern and Western members of the commission, impeding efforts to prosecute some of the accused. **********Historians say it would require extensive research to determine how many the accused have not been previously linked to war crimes or, for that matter, how many are still alive and can be found nearly half a century later. **********Some historians have also compared the archive to raw police files, replete with inaccuracies and untested allegations. In one case, a renowned anti-Nazi writer and resistance figure, Eugen Kogon, who had been forced to work in the human experiments laboratory at the Buchenwald concentration camp, has been listed as wanted for mass murder, with no further details. **********Hermann Langbein, a co-author and longtime associate of Dr. Kogon, said from Vienna this week that Dr. Kogon had saved many prisoners at Buchenwald at great personal risk, and that the commission's listing was a tragic error. Dr. Kogon, who is 85 years old and has Alzheimer's disease, is the author of ''The Theory and Practice of Hell,'' a classic treatise on the concentration camps, and many other writings on the evils of Nazism. He lives in West Germany. **********The United States and the 16 other nations that made up the commission agreed in October to open the files after a long dispute following the disclosure that the former United Nations Secretary General, Kurt Waldheim, was listed as wanted for murder by Yugoslavia. Mr. Waldheim, who had served with a German Army intelligence unit and was elected President of Austria last year, has denied taking part in any atrocities. His wartime role is being studied by an international commission of historians. No New Data on Waldheim **********Beyond what has already been disclosed, there is no further information on Mr. Waldheim in the United Nations war crimes files. **********Earlier this month, The New York Times became one of the first news organizations permitted to review the files, stored on two floors of a 12-story commercial building at 345 Park Avenue South, at 25th Street. The files were turned over to the United Nations in 1949, a year after the London-based War Crimes Commission voted itself out of business after four years of work and as the cold war made adversaries of wartime allies. The Soviet Union never joined the commission. **********The commission did not have investigators or hold trials. It also did not list citizens accused by their own government of aiding the Nazis. **********The files show that Mr. Kopf was listed by the commission for having served during the war as chief of the Nazis' ''trusteeship'' office in Chorzow, confiscating Polish property for the Third Reich. Allegations From Poland **********Witnesses alleged in statements submitted by the Poles that Mr. Kopf, backed by the Gestapo, had taken over their homes and shops and had been seen with furniture taken from deported Jews. One account said he had struck or beaten a farm worker. The Poles also said they had a German photograph showing Mr. Kopf in command of a deportation transport in Krzepice. **********After he was listed by the commission in 1947, Mr. Kopf was identified through a newspaper photograph as the British-appointed head of Hanover Province who became the first Premier of the new state of Lower Saxony. **********Embarrassed by the disclosure, the British and the Americans moved in the commission's last days in 1948 to remove Mr. Kopf from the war crimes list, on the ground that he had already been investigated by the British. **********In his statement, Mr. Kopf said: ''Naturally a normal day's work was expected and action was taken against idleness, cruelty to animals and theft. In some cases I boxed the ears of anybody caught red-handed, whether a Pole or a German.'' **********The panel's deputy chairman, Sir Robert Craigie of Britain, commented: ''It was characteristic of the Germans as a whole that they do box the ears of young people at slight provocation. That, however, was not a war crime.'' The dismayed Poles were outvoted and Mr. Kopf's name was taken off the list. He died in 1961.  Dispute on Slovak Official A similar dispute engulfed the case of Dr. Durcansky, Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of the Nazi puppet state of Slovakia in 1939 and 1940. According to Czechoslovak charges accepted by the commission in 1946, he had been on the payroll of the Nazi secret services and had promulgated anti-Jewish laws in Slovakia. Most of the country's 88,000 Jews perished. Slovakia's President, Josef Tiso, a Roman Catholic priest, was later hanged as a war criminal. **********The commission listed Dr. Durcansky in 1946, and the Czechoslovak Government tried him in absentia the next year and sentenced him to death. But the Czechoslovaks said they learned that he had escaped to the French zone in 1945 and, with a suspicious freedom of movement through the West, remained at large plotting against postwar Czechoslovak leaders. **********Dr. Durcansky turned up in the United States in 1959, speaking to anti-Communist Slovak groups. According to the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, which investigated the case at the time, the State Department granted Dr. Durcansky an immigrant visa with the explanation: ''Membership in or affiliation with the defunct Nazi Party in itself no longer constitutes a ground of ineligibility.'' He died in Munich in 1974. **********Commission files show that the Poles also complained of the refusal of Western occupation authorities to honor requests for the extradition of other accused war criminals. **********The Poles also grew aware, commission files show, that the Americans were searching for selected German scientists and technicians to recruit them for military research. **********Commission papers show that members realized that only a small proportion of those accused would ever be brought to trial. Short of checking each case against other records in archives all over the world, there is no way of knowing who was caught and prosecuted.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/busin.body_text: **********Sales of new domestically assembled cars fell 25.8 percent in the middle 10 days of February despite rebates, subsidized financing and other incentives, the nation's eight major manufacturers reported today. **********The decline, to 188,310 units, was led by the General Motors Corporation, whose sales were off 38.1 percent, at 91,716. All other companies reported lesser drops, except Honda of America, which gained. **********On a seasonally adjusted basis, sales ran at a 6.8 million rate, well below the 9.1 million rate in the 1986 period and the 7.8 million rate in the first 10 days of February. Bad Weather a Possible Factor **********Analysts said bad weather may have been a factor in the most recent period, but they added that the apparent inability of incentives to spur sales could mean production cuts and layoffs for the Big Three companies. **********''There are substantial incentive campaigns out there to move the market,'' said John Hammond, a sales analyst with J. D. Power & Associates. ''If they are not enough, what do the manufacturers have left for the spring selling season that begins in mid-March?'' G. M. is offering a variety of incentives on about half its model lineup, and other manufacturers have competing programs. **********Others noted that the 1986 period was very strong, distorting year-to-year comparisons. But they pointed out that G. M. has been losing market share almost since the beginning of the model year last October. #10-Point Loss Seen for G. M. ''They've lost about 10 percentage points of market share in that time,'' said David Healy, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. **********Mr. Healy estimated that G. M. dealers would have a 100-day supply of cars by the end of March if sales continue at the present rate and production schedules do not change. Since a 60-day supply is considered the most desirable, G. M. will have to decide whether to cut production and make layoffs or offer incentives like the 2.9 percent financing program that started last August but that contributed to an operating loss in the third quarter. **********Aside from cars, sales of light trucks also fell sharply at G. M., while the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation had slight increases. G. M. sold 23 percent fewer light trucks, at 36,987 units, in the 10 days. That drop pulled the industry down 10 percent from last year, to 96,774 units. Ford Off 7.9%, Chrysler 14.8% **********Ford's car sales in the mid-February period totaled 59,225, down 7.9 percent, while Chrysler's were 26,716, off 14.8 percent. **********The American Motors Corporation was down 64 percent, to 725, and Volkswagen declined 23.5 percent, to 1,522. Honda of America, however, was up 55.4 percent, at 6,208, and the Toyota Motor Corporation, which had no domestic cars last year, reported sales of 684. Sales of the Nissan Motor Corporation, which had reporting difficulties, were estimated at 2,100 based on previous periods, down 25 percent. **********G. M.'s domestic car market share in the period declined to 48.7 percent from 58.3 percent. The beneficiary of the slippage was Ford, which gained to 31.4 percent, from 25.3 percent. Chrysler was up to 13.8 percent, from 12.1 percent, but A.M.C. declined to three-tenths of 1 percent, from eight-tenths of 1 percent, and Volkswagen of America was constant at eight-tenths of 1 percent. Jump in Honda's Market Share **********Rising production at its Marysville, Ohio, plant increased Honda's market share to 3.3 percent, from 1.6 percent, while Nissan was constant at 1.1 percent. Toyota accounted for three-tenths of 1 percent of the domestic market. **********The mid-February sales slump further sank sales for the calendar year, to 26.5 percent below the 1986 period, at 786,122. Once again, the largest decline was reported by G.M., whose sales of 414,875 are down 33.5 percent. Ford's totaled 213,890, down 16.6 percent, while Chrysler's total of 101,327 is off 22.6 percent. Honda is up 62.5 percent, at 33,645, while A.M.C. is down 60.7 percent and Volkswagen is down 46.5 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/04/world.body_text: **********A parade of witnesses will go to Capitol Hill beginning tomorrow and continuing into the summer to testify in public hearings on the Iran-contra affair. The Senate and House investigating committees have not announced a witness list, except to say that Richard V. Secord will be the opening witness, to be followed by Robert C. McFarlane. Here is a list of some of the people likely to testify. The Congressional committees have given some potential witnesses limited immunity, or immunity from prosecution based on their testimony.  Elliott Abrams  Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs. **********He may have accidentally deposited money from the Sultan of Brunei meant for the Nicaraguan rebels, known as contras, in the wrong Swiss bank account. Mr. Abrams has acknowledged that he was given the number of the account by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North.  Charles Allen  The C.I.A.'s national intelligence officer for counterterrorism. He received intercepted conversations from Iran and was one of the first to sound the alarm about problems in the covert action.  Carl R. Channell  A professional fund-raiser who runs several conservative organizations. He pleaded guilty last Wednesday to charges of conspiring to defraud the Government by raising tax-exempt funds to arm the contras. He named Colonel North as a co-conspirator.  Duane Clarridge  Chief of the C.I.A.'s European division. He helped Colonel North arrange a flight by a European airline connected to the C.I.A. that carried arms to Iran in November 1985.  Col. Robert C. Dutton  A retired Air Force officer and associate of General Secord. He helped oversee the contra supply effort and was instrumental in an arms shipment to Iran last fall. Given limited immunity by the Congressional committees.  Lieut. Col. Robert Earl  Colonel North's deputy on the counterterrorism unit at the National Security Council until late 1986. Given limited immunity.  Col. Richard B. Gadd  A retired Air Force officer and business partner of General Secord. He reportedly helped provide aircraft and recruit pilots to fly supplies to the contras. Given limited immunity.  Robert M. Gates  In the first months of the Iran initiative, he was the Deputy Director for Intelligence, the C.I.A.'s senior analyst. Last year he replaced John N. McMahon as Deputy Director of Central Intelligence. On March 2, President Reagan withdrew his nomination of Mr. Gates to be Director of Central Intelligence.  Albert Hakim  An Iranian-born arms dealer and businessman who is now an American. He is a business partner of General Secord. Given limited immunity.  Fawn Hall  Colonel North's secretary on the National Security Council staff. She has reportedly testified that she helped destroy documents and alter some memorandums when the details of the Iran-contra affair were first being disclosed. Given limited immunity.  Michael A. Ledeen  A part-time consultant to the National Security Council. He first broached the Administration's hope for better relations with Iran in meetings in 1985 with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel.  Robert C. McFarlane  National security adviser until Dec. 4, 1985. He continued to assist the Administration through December 1985 and secretly went to Teheran in May 1986 at President Reagan's request.  Edwin Meese 3d  The Attorney General. He advised President Reagan on the legality of not informing Congress in advance about the arms sales. He conducted his own investigation of Colonel North's activities before calling in the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Last Nov. 25 he announced that profits from the arms sales to Iran had been diverted to the contras.  Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North  A National Security Council aide until he was dismissed last Nov. 25. He is said to have been the central figure in arranging the secret arms sales to Iran and diverting profits to the contras. The Congressional committees have agreed not to vote on immunity for Colonel North before June.  Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter  Resigned as national security adviser last Nov. 25 after it was disclosed that he knew about the diversion of profits in the Iran arms sales to the contras. **********Given limited immunity.  Donald T. Regan  Resigned as White House chief of staff on Feb. 27 amid intense criticism of his handling of the Iran-contra affair.  Richard V. Secord  A retired Air Force major general and an associate of Colonel North. General Secord is reported to have arranged logistics, worked on negotiations and helped develop a channel for the Iran arms shipments. He is also believed to have been involved in running a private supply network for the contras.  Theodore G. Shackley  A former top C.I.A. official. He met with Manucher Ghorbanifar, an Iranian middleman, in late 1984 to discuss possible arms sales to Iran in return for the release of American hostages in Lebanon.  George P. Shultz  The Secretary of State. He disapproved of the covert Iran operation and has said he was not informed about key aspects of the arms sales.  Caspar W. Weinberger  The Secretary of Defense. He repeatedly objected to the arms sales, but ordered his subordinates to make the weapons available.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/14/busin.main_headline: U.S. Takes New Tack On Japanese Dumping
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/14/busin.print_headline: U.S. Takes New Tack On Japanese Dumping
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/14/busin.body_text: **********In an action that could speed up price increases on products imported from Japan, the Commerce Department has found that two Japanese companies have been selling roller bearings at illegally low prices. **********The case was brought because many Japanese companies have put off raising prices to compensate for the much higher value of the yen against the dollar. Instead, they preferred to absorb costs resulting from a strong yen and even sell at a loss, rather than lose market share. **********This is the first time Washington has moved in a significant way to penalize Japan for following this course. Higher Duties Possible **********The yen has risen against the dollar by more than 60 percent since February 1985, which should mean that Japanese products would cost much more in the United States than before. **********But some bearing prices failed to rise at all during the investigation period, between March 1 and Aug. 31 of last year. **********Should the ruling be affirmed, it would result in higher customs duties on the imported bearings, which have a variety of industrial uses, especially in transportation equipment. **********But many analysts said the case could set a precedent for other industries in which the dollar's decline has failed to improve their ability to compete against the Japanese. **********The decision comes as the trading relationship between the United States and Japan has been strained by the Toshiba Machine Company's sale of sensitive military goods to the Soviet Union and a disagreement between Washington and Tokyo, now partially settled, over the dumping of computer chips. Looking for 'Fair Value' **********Koichi Haraguchi, information counselor at the Japanese Embassy, said it was ''not appropriate'' for his Government to comment because this was an ''internal action taken in accordance with U.S. dumping law.'' **********The duties are intended to raise the Japanese selling prices to what the Commerce Department has determined to be ''fair value.'' This is computed on the basis of the exporters' home market price, his selling price in other markets outside the United States, his cost of production and other factors including a margin of profit. **********The department singled out two Japanese companies for sales of tapered roller bearings. It said that the Koyo Seiko Company was selling bearings at 70.44 percent below the computed fair value and that the NTN Toyo Bearing Company was selling bearings for 47.05 percent less. **********The decision, which was announced late Wednesday, came on a complaint filed by the Timken Company of Canton, Ohio, the leading maker of bearings in this country. It involves imports valued at more than $100 million last year. Commerce 'Is Waking Up' **********''This is a shot across the bows of the Japanese that currency changes ultimately have to be reflected appropriately in product prices,'' said Representative Nancy Johnson, Republican of Connecticut, whose district contains companies making roller bearings, machine tools, computers and other products affected by Japanese competition. **********Representative Helen Delich Bentley, Republican of Maryland, who is a member of the Congressional steel caucus, said she was happy the Commerce Department ''is waking up and starting to pay attention to dumping resulting from currency changes.'' **********The finding will become final if the International Trade Commission, another Federal agency, determines that the domestic roller-bearing industry has suffered from low Japanese pricing. The I.T.C. has already made a preliminary finding of injury. Its final ruling must come within 45 days.  If the I.T.C. makes an affirmative finding, the Commerce Department will issue an order instructing the Customs Service to collect duties determined by the dumping margins announced yesterday. **********Commerce Department officials declined to speculate on which industries might be the next to seek higher dumping margins. 'Likely to Be More Cases' **********S. Bruce Smart Jr., the Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade administration, said only that ''given the major shift in exchange rates and the lesser shift in prices of Japanese goods in the U.S. market, there are likely to be more cases of dumped goods than we are accustomed to seeing.'' **********The ruling drew reaction from the steel industry. A spokesman for the American Iron and Steel Institute, Sheldon Wesson, said, ''The steel industry has expressed concern over the fact that the lower value of the dollar has not been reflected more than slightly in the prices of imported steel, leading to the conclusion tht a very large proportion of the steel sold in this country is at dumping prices.'' **********Auto industry officials have also been following the case closely. **********Robert A. Perkins, vice president of the Washington office of the Chrysler Corporation, observed, ''This will be a strong indication to the Japanese, and anybody else, that if they're selling below cost they had better look to their pricing.'' **********Some analysts suggested that Japanese pickup trucks might become one of the next targets. On top of the currency changes, they have had to absorb a 25 percent duty imposed as an offshoot of a trade conflict in the mid-1960's. Inflationary Impact **********If Japanese companies, which account for about 20 percent of the total imports of the United States, dramatically raise the prices on their products, that could result in considerable inflation. **********Barry N. Bosworth, senior fellow at the Brookings Institutition and one of the top economists of the Carter Administration, said he expects prices of imported goods from Germany and Japan will rise by 20 percent by the end of next year. **********Already, he said, import prices are having an effect on the Consumer Price Index, which measures the rate of inflation. His studies show that while domestically produced costs are rising by 4 percent annually, the overall index this year will show a rise of 5 to 5 1/2 percent because of import price increases. **********As for the roller-bearing decision, Mr. Bosworth said, ''this sort of thing will put pressure on the Japanese to get their prices up.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/busin.body_text: **********ECONOMIC forecasters have been attacked in recent years for their apparent inability to predict many of the things that matter most - the continued growth in the trade deficit, say, or the stock-market plunge. Some businesses have closed their economics departments, partly for such failures. **********Yet, with a new round of predictions upon us - it is the season of computers spewing out ever-increasing quantities of numbers - this judgment seems harsh. Professional score-keepers say that forecasters have performed relatively well of late. **********''Contrary to the popular opinion that forecasting has deteriorated, it has not,'' said Victor Zarnowitz, a professor at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business and research associate for the nation's semi-official business-cycle arbiter, the National Bureau of Economic Research. In his view, forecasters have managed to more or less keep pace with a job that in the 1980's has grown progressively harder because of frequent economic swings. **********Professor Paul A. Samuelson of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a close student of forecasting, agreed. ''I think that the general state of the art has improved a little but at the same time the world that needs to be forecast has deteriorated,'' he said. ''You used to be able to be pretty sure of getting things qualitatively right,'' even if the magnitudes were wrong, he added, ''but even that has disappeared.'' **********Last year's forecasts, in fact, seem to have been respectable. ''I think we hit it pretty well on the head,'' said Robert J. Eggert, who edits Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a monthly newsletter of economic forecasts. He estimates that his consensus of about 50 economists is likely to be within one tenth of a percentage point of actual 1987 gross national product and inflation. The prediction for unemployment, however, is likely to be too high by about half a percentage point. The Zarnowitz group also seems to have performed well. Of course, the tallying of 1987's economic activity will continue for months after year-end. **********If forecasts have their limits, they can nonetheless help in thinking about the economy. Specialists such as Professors Zarnowitz and Samuelson, along with Lawrence R. Klein of the University of Pennsylvania and Stephen K. McNees of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, offer some propositions to help in evaluating the crop of forecasts for 1988 listed in the accompanying table. ***********The consensus of a group of forecasters will, by mathematical certainty, be more accurate over time than the predictions of most individuals. ***********Forecasts of physical outputs tend to be more reliable than forecasts of prices or markets. ***********Full-time and long-established forecasters do better than newcomers and those who forecast only periodically. ***********Predictions for full years tend to be more accurate than for shorter periods. ***********Errors at the peak of a business cycle tend to be greater than those at the bottom. **********Some of today's frustrations over the limits of forecasting date back to the early 1960's, a period in which the economy seemed to behave according to the rule books. That created unrealistic expectations. Economists have worked at improving their forecasting skills, but have found that simply adding computer power to macroeconomic models does not necessarily improve results. Moreover, even the best economic insight is no match for a single bad assumption about policymaking in Washington. **********What should nonprofessionals do when confronted with the latest array of forecasts, which this year reflect an unusually high degree of uncertainty because of the stock market plunge? **********''For most households and businesses,'' Mr. McNees said, ''I'd advise them to pay attention to the consensus so they will have some idea about employment and spending prospects.'' **********But investors stand to gain much less from the forecasts, Mr. McNees added. ''There's very little evidence that anyone can give you or sell you useful financial advice.'' AN ARRAY OF ECONOMIC PREDICTIONS **********A selection of current economic forecasts from about 50 monitored monthly by Robert J. Eggert for Blue Chip Economic Indicators and about 30 monitored annually by Victor Zarnowitz for Economic Forecasts: A Worldwide Survey.

Volcker, the Fed chairman, favored tightening credit. [ Page D1. ]  A Fed member, Wayne D. Angell, said Mr. Volcker was not at odds with the panel's Reagan-appointed majority about whether rates should be raised to support the dollar and head off higher inflation.  [ D23. ] **********An opening rally in the stock market was cut short by the sharp rise in interest rates and by higher gold and silver prices. After seesawing through the afternoon, the Dow Jones industrial average closed with a 5.39-point drop, at 2,270.60. Only 139 million shares were traded, reflecting the Easter Monday holiday in Europe.  [ D12. ] **********The dollar dropped in thin U.S. trading after rising against the yen in Tokyo. European markets were closed for a post-Easter holiday. In New York, gold rose $9.25, to $452.50.  [ D30. ]  Silver, gold and platinum futures surged as the dollar declined. Schmidt, apparently lost favor with the company's board because of his difficulty in persuading the I.C.C. to approve a merger of the Santa Fe and Southern Pacific rail systems. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/world.main_headline: REAGAN'S TOP AIDES ARE LOOKING TO NEW MEETING WITH GORBACHEV
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/world.print_headline: REAGAN'S TOP AIDES ARE LOOKING TO NEW MEETING WITH GORBACHEV
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/14/world.body_text: **********White House officials said today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz was likely to agree in Moscow on another meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********Raising the stakes for the Moscow discussions, the officials also said that progress was being made in Moscow on arms control and that they were optimistic about an agreement. **********The officials, Howard H. Baker Jr., the chief of staff, and Frank C. Carlucci, the national security adviser, sought to provide a White House assessment of Mr. Shultz's talks. **********While leaving open the possibility of snags, they were unusually sanguine, with Mr. Baker saying: ''There is a historic opportunity for an arms control agreement. I think the atmosphere is right. I think the leadership is right. I think the issues are right.'' **********Mr. Shultz, who began three days of talks today, is expected to meet with Mr. Gorbachev on Tuesday and to hand over a letter from Mr. Reagan. **********One official said the letter might contain a request for a summit meeting, which would be the first since a meeting in Iceland in October. Positive Comments on Arms Mr. Baker said he ''would not be surprised'' if Mr. Shultz discussed the summit meeting with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and if there was ''some sort of decision.'' **********At another point, he said, ''I think there is a good prospect that it may occur.'' **********The comments on the possibility of an arms control agreeement were among the most positive to date. An official said the optimism was focused on the subject of medium-range missiles, where the United States reportedly plans to press for a total ban. **********''I am convinced that this President wants an arms control agreement,'' Mr. Baker said. ''I am convinced that the proposals he has made are realistic and forthcoming and I am convinced, based on the information we have at hand, that the Soviet Union appears to be moving in the direction, a more favorable direction in that field.'' **********Similarly, Mr. Carlucci said arms negotiations were focusing on a reduction of 50 percent in long-range, or strategic, missiles and the elimination of medium-range forces. **********''And never has the Soviet Union been brought to that position,'' he said. ''So we think good progress is being made.'' Permission to Negotiate A White House official said Mr. Shultz had been sent to Moscow with permission to negotiate, but that he would be able to receive additional guidance from Mr. Reagan. Before Mr. Shultz's departure, there were conflicting accounts on how much latitude he would have in his discussions. **********Although the White House officials here would not comment on the instructions that Mr. Shultz received from the President, Mr. Baker said the instructions ''can lead to the construction of a framework for meaningful negotiations.'' **********Mr. Shultz is believed to be carrying instructions that back away from some understandings reached in at the Iceland summit meeting. At that time, the two sides agreed not to withdraw from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty for 10 years and to eliminate all ballistic missiles during that period. **********But under the latest American posture, Mr. Shultz is expected to suggest that each side promise not to withdraw from the treaty only until 1994. **********Explaining the shift, Mr. Carlucci said the 10-year period was in connection with reducing ballistic missiles to zero, which he said the Soviet Union had opposed. Without the total ban, he said, the United States favored a shorter period of adherence to the ABM treaty and would focus on a 50 percent reduction in ballistic missiles. **********Mr. Carlucci said the Administration was still insisting that any accord on medium-range nuclear weapons also deal with constraints on shorter-range forces. He said any freeze that did not give the Americans the right to build up to the Soviet level of 133 shorter-range missiles would be unacceptable. **********But displaying some flexibility, he said the United States could accept either parallel or follow-up negotiations on the shorter-range issue, so that it would not block an agreement in terms of medium-range forces. **********In a speech in Prague on Friday, Mr. Gorbachev proposed a freeze on shorter-range nuclear systems and an immediate start of negotiations aiming first at reduction and ultimately at elimination of these systems. **********Mr. Shultz is expected to travel here this week to report to the President on the Moscow talks, Mr. Baker said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/18/busin.body_text: **********The Haft family of Washington offered yesterday to pay $6 billion for the 95 percent of the Dayton Hudson Corporation it does not yet own. **********Dayton Hudson, with head offices in Minneapolis, owns one of the nation's leading department store chains as well as highly profitable discount operations. **********The company, which is considered the main beneficiary of a new Minnesota law to discourage unfriendly takeovers, did not respond to the Haft offer yesterday but is expected to resist it strenuously. To placate stockholders interested in a profit on their shares, Dayton Hudson is expected to devise some alternative plan. **********In a move to gain sympathy in Minnesota, Herbert H. Haft, the 67-year-old chairman of the Dart Group Corporation, and his son, Robert M. Haft, 34, who is president, said they would donate any profits they made on their stock to Minnesota charities if shareholders rebuffed them. The Hafts - among the original discount store operators - are thought to have a net worth of $400 million. The Value to Shareholders **********The Hafts propose to pay $65 a share for 95 percent of the shares, and stock worth an estimated $3.25 in the new Dayton Hudson in exchange for the other 5 percent of the shares. They said stockholders would get 20 percent of the new company under the proposal. **********The offer came after the 4 P.M. close of the New York Stock Exchange, where Dayton ended the day at $52.875, up only 50 cents. But Jefferies & Company of Los Angeles, dealing in the stock after hours, said last night that the stock was trading at $60. **********The move by the Hafts had been in the works for some time. In late July the company said it had received a letter from the Hafts disclosing their intention to buy as much as 50 percent or more of the company. Anti-Takeover Law Passed **********To help Dayton Hudson fight off the Hafts, whose interest in the company was widely known, Minnesota had already passed an anti-takeover law preventing the payment of greenmail to buy off an unwelcome suitor after next March and prohibiting for five years the sale of any assets to pay off debt. The law also requires that shareholders approve anything proposed by a stockholder with more than 20 percent of the stock. **********Robert Haft said last night that Dart now owns about 4.9 percent of Dayton Hudson, at a cost thought to approach $250 million. **********He said that the shares were not for sale and that Dart had ''no intention to sell them to the company or anyone else,'' maintaining that the Hafts ''will make every effort to purchase the company.'' **********In the past, analysts have sometimes suggested that the Hafts might be more interested in making a profit by putting a company in play than in actually buying the company. **********Mr. Haft noted that last fall, when Kenneth A. Macke, chairman of Dayton, introduced a poison pill plan to make the company extremely expensive, Mr. Macke stressed that the plan was not intended to prevent all takeovers. **********Mr. Haft said that the pill was, in Mr. Macke's words, ''to encourage a potential acquirer to negotiate with the Dayton Hudson board.'' **********''This,'' Mr. Haft said, ''is an effort to do that.'' **********Analysts said they thought that the Hafts were interested in Dayton Hudson primarily for its value if broken up and sold in pieces. But under Minnesota's new law, this could not occur for five years. **********Dayton Hudson's Target discount chain, with more than $4 billion in sales; its Mervyn's apparel chain, with sales of $2.8 billion, and its Dayton's and Hudson's department stores, with sales of $1.6 billion, are all imposing subjects for divestiture. **********Unlike other chains that have sold weak divisions only when they became takeover targets, Dayton Hudson took the initiative by selling B. Dalton, its book chain, to Barnes & Noble; closed its faltering Plum's discount division, and sold other stores. **********The offer - proposed to Mr. Macke and other Dayton Hudson directors -was conveyed in a letter dated and hand-delivered by a Haft attorney yesterday. Late yesterday Dayton Hudson said that it had received the letter and that the proposal would be ''considered by our board of directors in due course.'' **********The letter noted that Dart, known since the 1950's for its Dart Drug stores, since sold, has been in the retail business for more than 30 years. **********The younger Mr. Haft said in an interview that through Dart and a real estate company the Hafts operate they would put up $750 million for the deal, with unidentified bank lenders arranging senior bank financing amounting to about $3 billion. **********In their letter, the Hafts told the company that their financial adviser, Paine Webber Inc., had assured them that if Dayton Hudson approved their offer and senior bank financing could be arranged, it was ''highly confident'' it could arrange the balance in unsecured and subordinated debt. Mr. Haft said this might be in junk bonds. **********Based on its past opposition to the Hafts, Dayton Hudson is expected to resist the takeover, possibly by buying back stock or selling the company to someone else. **********The Hafts' letter argued that their offer represented a 50 percent premium over the stock price less than six months ago and about 2.8 times the company's book value. **********In a special plea to the residents of Minnesota, the Hafts said they would continue the company's current policies, including those with the community and charities. They said they would not only keep current management but would give it an ownership interest, and would keep Dayton Hudson's headquarters in Minneapolis. The offer, they said, was subject to the board recommending it to stockholders and to the elimination of the poison pill plan. **********The Haft family made nearly $160 million last year in an unsuccessful takeover bid for Safeway Stores and an estimated $40 million this year in a bid to buy the Supermarkets General Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/05/busin.main_headline: Tax Watch; Fighting I.R.S.: Uneven Match
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/05/busin.print_headline: Tax Watch; Fighting I.R.S.: Uneven Match
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/05/busin.body_text: **********THIS is the time of year when many taxpayers begin to worry that the income tax return they just filed will come under scrutiny and someday bring the Internal Revenue Service knocking at their door. And there is reason to worry: Disputes between the I.R.S. and a taxpayer are not an even match. **********With fresh allegations of I.R.S. abuses pouring into Congressional mailboxes, lawmakers are beginning to question whether the revenue service has too much unchecked power and taxpayers too few protections. The dilemma Congress faces is whether it can afford to give taxpayers greater rights at a time when it is raising I.R.S. collection quotas to help reduce the Federal deficit. **********The I.R.S. is empowered to take extraordinary measures to go after money it thinks the Government is owed. Yet taxpayers lack some of the same basic rights of due process that the judicial system affords accused criminals. **********The burden of proof in most types of tax disputes is on the taxpayer, not the Government. Revenue agents are not required to read taxpayers their rights before interrogating them. When taxpayers are represented by an attorney or accountant, the I.R.S. still reserves the right to question the taxpayer directly. And with little notice, or in some cases no notice, the I.R.S. can seize a taxpayer's bank accounts, car, house and other assets to cover the taxes owed. **********This situation, in the view of some members of Congress, has left taxpayers vulnerable to abusive tactics by overzealous collection agents and victim to the honest mistakes that a mammoth and overburdened tax bureaucracy can sometimes make. **********Taxpayer ''horror'' stories of run-ins with the I.R.S. are nothing new. But Congress has grown concerned about the continuing flurry of documented cases in which an I.R.S. agent has used aggressive collection tactics even before the taxpayer has had a chance to work out a settlement, to raise the necessary funds or to prove that the revenue service made a mistake. **********While lawmakers are convinced that such instances are isolated, they worry that, without a legislative remedy to give taxpayers greater due process rights, the situation will get worse as the I.R.S. enforcement arm undergoes a rapid expansion. In the next few years, the I.R.S. is to hire thousands of new enforcement and collection agents with orders from Congress to collect billions of dollars more in delinquent taxes. **********Not surprisingly, the taxpayer rights legislation, known as the Taxpayers' Bill of Rights, has been politically popular. After all, no taxpayer ever liked a tax collector. The taxpayer horror stories recounted at recent Senate hearings were widely publicized on nightly news broadcasts. Both Democrats and Republicans are co-sponsors of the legislation, which has been introduced in both the Senate and the House. **********But some legal experts fear that some of the provisions contained in the bill could seriously undermine the nation's tax-collection system, as well as prospects for passage of the bill itself. Of particular concern is the proposal to shift the burden of proof in civil court and administrative proceedings from the taxpayer to the I.R.S. **********Such a shift might seem long overdue in a country where a person is considered innocent until proved guilty. But Michael Graetz, a professor at the Yale Law School, said civil tax cases had to be treated differently because the tax system was structured as a self-assessment system where only the taxpayer had access to all the information to show whether the return was filled out correctly. **********''Under the self-assessment system, the taxpayer's duty is to report to their best judgment the taxes they owe the government,'' he said. ''And in a self-assessment system it doesn't seem to me unreasonable for taxpayers to show that their assessment is correct.'' **********If the burden of proof was shifted to the I.R.S., he said, taxpayers would feel comfortable taking more aggressive positions on their tax returns, feeling the I.R.S. would have difficulty proving them wrong. **********Also controversial is a proposal that would require the I.R.S. to offer most delinquent taxpayers an opportunity to pay in installments. Installments are appropriate in hardship cases, Mr. Graetz said, but providing others an opportunity to defer taxes is likely to be perceived as unfair by taxpayers who pay on a timely basis. **********Gerald Portney, a former associate chief counsel at the I.R.S. who is now a principal at Peat Marwick Main, thinks the legislation would help prevent collection agents from rushing too quickly to seize a taxpayer's property. The bill would extend to 30 days, from 10 days, the waiting period before the I.R.S. could seize property after notification to the taxpayer was made. (The I.R.S, however, will still have the authority to seize property without notice in extraordinary cases where it suspects the collection may be in jeopardy. Jeopardy assessments are common in cases involving taxpayers suspected of being drug dealers, taxpayers about to flee the country or those suspected of preparing for an imminent sale of their property.) The legislation would also provide taxpayers with channels for appeal on such collection actions. Under current law, Mr. Portney said, taxpayers have avenues for appealing a proposed determination of how much is owed, but not for appealing a decision on when or how it is to be collected. **********Regardless of legislative prospects, Mr. Portney said, improved relations between the I.R.S. and taxpayers will require a change in attitude by revenue agents. ''The attitude of revenue officers is that the people they deal with are all deadbeats,'' he said. ''They just can't differentiate between the person that is a deadbeat and other people.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/15/world.main_headline: Aide Says U.S. Planes Carried Contra Arms
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/15/world.print_headline: Aide Says U.S. Planes Carried Contra Arms
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/15/world.body_text: **********The official who headed the United States humanitarian aid program for the rebels in Nicaragua said today that he twice ordered his planes to shuttle weapons for the contras in Central America at the direction of Elliott Abrams, an Assistant Secretary of State. **********The shipments involved weapons the contras had stockpiled in the region that needed to be transported to their troops, said the official, Robert Duemling, former head of the State Department's Nicaraguan humanitarian assistance office. **********He said the flights took place early in 1986, when the Government was giving nonmilitary assistance to the contras but when a Congressional ban on military aid was in effect. **********The office was in charge of buying and delivering such goods as food and nonmilitary supplies. Mr. Duemling said that none of the money was spent to buy weapons, but that it was decided that weapons owned by the contras could be ferried by the aid planes in some cases. **********He said he was directed by Mr. Abrams to fly the ''mixed loads'' after the Administration ''policy people'' consulted extensively with the Congressional intelligence committees as to whether that would be permitted. He said he sat in on at least one such meeting and that the committees did not veto the idea as far as he knew. **********Mr. Duemling said he got ''policy guidance'' from Mr. Abrams that ''did permit a degree of latitude'' with the flights. But he said he and Mr. Abrams agreed that because the loads would be politically controversial, ''It was only something we would have to do if sorely pressed, not something we would do as a first choice.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/01/world.main_headline: AS TRUDEAU ENDS SILENCE, STORM BEGINS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/01/world.print_headline: AS TRUDEAU ENDS SILENCE, STORM BEGINS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/01/world.body_text: **********A month ago, in a single day and without public debate, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and the premiers of Canada's 10 provinces agreed on a far-reaching re-drafting of Canada's Constitution that would recognize Quebec as ''a distinct society'' and grant broad new powers to all of the provinces at the national Government's expense. **********Because the deal included Quebec's agreement to sign the Canada Constitution Act of 1982 after a five-year holdout, it was enthusiastically received. Mr. Mulroney, who had been in the worst slump that opinion polls have recorded for a Canadian leader, saw his standing begin to rise. **********And then something happened that few had foreseen. **********On Wednesday, Pierre Elliott Trudeau ended the three-year-long silence on public affairs he had maintained since retiring as Prime Minister in April 1984. With a newspaper article that described the accord as a ''total bungle'' and Mr. Mulroney as ''a weakling'' for agreeing to Quebec's demands, he sent the kind of shock waves across the country that characterized his 15-year tenure as Canada's leader. 'Balkanized' Country Feared **********Mr. Trudeau, 67 years old, said he had stepped back into public debate because he despaired of anybody else's ''sounding the alarm.'' He has kept campaigning against the accord with radio and television interviews. His theme has been that Mr. Mulroney is turning away from the Trudeau vision of a strong federal state, with equal rights for French- and English-speaking Canadians, and moving toward a newly ''balkanized'' country with an ''impotent'' national Government, in which French Canadians would have to look to Quebec as their homeland. **********Since his article was published in La Presse of Montreal and The Toronto Star, the former Prime Minister has insisted that he has no intention of returning full time to political life. ''I'm an elder statesman now,'' he told the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, with what sounded like a self-mocking laugh. But Mr. Trudeau, once known as the the man with the shaprest tongue in Canadian politics, has become the most talked-about figure in the country all over again. **********Mr. Mulroney has called his predecessor's invectives ''a bit of low-level comedy'' and predicted that Mr. Trudeau would change his stand on the Meech Lake accord, named for the placed in Quebec where it was worked out. ''In about six months he's going to be saying that the Meech Lake accord was terrific, he's been in favor of it all along, and I'm a great Prime Minister just like him,'' he said. **********Other critics have been less sparing. Lise Bissonnette, a Quebec-based columnist for The Globe and Mail of Toronto, described Mr. Trudeau as a ''sore loser'' raging against ''his vanishing dreams.'' Marcel Prud'homme, a Montreal politician who was made a Cabinet minister by Mr. Trudeau, drew a withering analogy to another powerful figure. ''John XXIII was a great Pope, but he's dead too,'' he said. **********Behind the polemics, however, there was a widespread sense that Mr. Trudeau had done the country a service by provoking a debate about a deal that might have proceeded to ratification in virtual silence. Newspapers this weekend were packed with articles examining the accord, and influential voices were demanding that its adoption be delayed to permit a full examination. Liberal Split Develops **********In Mr. Trudeau's Liberal Party, now in opposition, a split has developed that threatens to undermine John Turner, Mr. Trudeau's successor as party leader. Mr. Turner has given qualified approval to the agreement. **********The country's foremost constitutional expert, Senator Eugene Forsey, has called for a delay in ratification. So has a group of leading artists and intellectuals, among them Farley Mowat, the writer, and Ramsay Cook, a noted historian. While these and other opponents share Mr. Trudeau's concern that the agreement may have laid the groundwork for a renewed separatist drive in Quebec, nationalists like Pierre-Marc Johnson, leader of the Parti Quebecois, once the standard-bearer for separatism, have condemned the pact as not going far enough. **********Undaunted, Mr. Mulroney has scheduled a meeting with the premiers for Tuesday to sign the agreement. If they can resolve last-minute problems in the wording, the pact will go forward for ratification by Parliament and the provincial legislatures. Mr. Mulroney has said he would like to have the process completed by the fall. **********Having accomplished his purpose in stirring a debate, Mr. Trudeau has said he intends to return to his former, almost invisible life as a partner in a Montreal law firm, as a world traveler and as father to his three sons, the oldest of whom is now 15. **********''I'm like Garbo,'' he told a CBC interviewer. ''I like to be alone.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/28/busin.body_text: **********Goldome Federal Savings of Buffalo, which is planning a public offering, will herald the event with $1 million worth of advertising in 30 days. **********The campaign aimed at depositors and other individual investors along the Northeast Corridor will have the theme line ''Stake Your Claim In Goldome.'' It was created by David Ross Palmer & Associates of New York and Chicago. **********Ads will run in daily newspapers in 11 Eastern markets, spot TV in New York State and Florida, business publications and on the Cable News Network in five states. All will be trying to get consumers to call an 800 number for a subscription offering circular. Some in Buffalo will be waiting in a telemarketing center for the calls. **********Additionally, there will be a direct mail drop of 2.5 million pieces The advertising is scheduled to start tomorrow, but it is dependent upon permission from New York State to go public, according to Robert B. Rakoczy, vice president, product management and market development.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/23/world.main_headline: THEORY OF BHOPAL SABOTAGE IS OFFERED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/23/world.print_headline: THEORY OF BHOPAL SABOTAGE IS OFFERED
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/23/world.body_text: **********Union Carbide Corporation investigators, nearing the end of a 16-month inquiry, say they have found new witnesses, documents and scientific evidence proving that the 1984 Bhopal toxic gas disaster was caused by sabotage by a company employee. **********Company investigators also say they have found altered logs and documents. Carbide says these indicate that several employees at its Bhopal pesticide plant knew about the start of the accident earlier than they have acknowledged, and then tried to cover up this knowledge. **********Company representatives say Union Carbide has scientific proof that the gas leak could not have happened the way the Indian Government says it did, which is that water from the washing of a pipe 350 feet away got into a tank containing the lethal chemical methyl isocyanate and caused a toxic chemical reaction. **********The disaster, the worst industrial accident in history, occurred the night of Dec. 2-3, 1984, when clouds of toxic gas spread through the central Indian city of Bhopal, killing at least 2,000 people and injuring another 200,000. Indian Government Disagrees **********Indian officials and former Indian employees of Carbide's Bhopal plant vehemently dispute the company's assertions of sabotage. These officials and former workers say the company has failed to offer any proof of its charges and is maligning the people on whom it once relied to run the plant. **********Talk of sabotage has figured in talk about the Bhopal disaster almost from the moment it started. Legal experts have been highly skeptical about the Carbide's claim because the company's legal strategy has been to try to avoid paying hundreds of millions of dollars in damages by proving that the gas leak was caused deliberately. **********But in recent interviews, company representatives said that much of the evidence had only recently come to light and that it buttressed the case for sabotage in a way that has not been disclosed in public. Company officials, however, repeatedly refused to allow themselves to be quoted by name. **********India is suing the Union Carbide Corporation of Danbury, Conn., for $3.3 billion in damages, charging that the plant was badly designed and that its managers were negligent. The plant was run by the company's Indian subsidiary, Union Carbide India Ltd., 50.9 percent of which is owned by the American corporation. Question of Liability **********Union Carbide says that the subsidiary is solely liable for damages, that its plant was well-designed and managed, but that no plant can be protected against employee sabotage. **********''We are 100 percent certain that this accident was caused deliberately,'' said a person close to the company's investigation. ''The problem is that people don't believe our story because it is highly complicated. But when you look at the evidence, you can come to no other conclusion.'' **********The company also maintains that 10 to 15 employees, including three to five supervisors in the Indian subsidiary, are conspiring to cover up details of the case in cooperation with Indian Government investigators. Most of these employees have left Carbide and are working for the state government of Madhya, of which Bhopal is the capital. **********As for who might have sabotaged the plant, Union Carbide representatives say they think they know but are not prepared to identify him yet. A source said suspicions rested on a plant operator on duty that night who was unhappy with a transfer to a separate part of the plant. Confession Might Not Help **********The representatives said they recognized that even a confession would be greeted with skepticism and that the company would have to make its case using documents, logic and evidence, rather than on personal testimony. **********India denies all of the Carbide charges, including any suggestion that it is helping to cover up details of the investigation. **********''The whole talk of sabotage is impossible,'' said an Indian official involved in the case, adding that specific company findings were suspicious because they been raised only recently. He said Union Carbide might be fabricating the evidence. **********India maintains that even if the disaster was caused deliberately, Union Carbide would still be liable for damages. Indian officials say sabotage is enough of a ''foreseeable'' act that the corporation must still be held responsible. Safety Mechanisms at Issue **********India also insists that the plant's safety mechanisms were either poorly designed or not working the night of the gas leak, turning what could have been a minor accident into a catastrophe. In fact, India is hoping to win its damage claim without even proving how the gas leak occurred. **********The lawsuit over the Bhopal disaster has been bogged down in Indian courts since September 1986, when India first filed the claim. **********In Bhopal, thousands of gas victims are receiving Government subsistence help and medical care, but they have not been compensated for lost income or other damages. Experts say it could take years for them to win any major compensation in court. **********India has rejected Union Carbide's offers to settle out of court for $300 million to $350 million. Meanwhile, with the Government suit taking precedence, lawyers representing individuals are still pressing for their right to sue. One Point of Agreement **********The only assumption on which Union Carbide and the Indian Government agree is that the disaster happened when a half ton to a ton of water got into one of three tanks containing methyl isocyanate, a chemical used to make a pesticide known as carbaryl, marketed under the brand name Sevin. **********The water is believed to have started a chemical reaction that raised the temperature and pressure in the tank. That reaction is said to have caused particles of iron from the tank to break off, mix with the chemicals inside, and create a second violent reaction, sending toxic gas past safety devices into the atmosphere. **********Indian Government analysts have concluded that the disaster started when workers were washing some equipment 350 feet away from the tank, and that the water leaked through one or two feeder lines into the tank. Most independent investigations, including one by The New York Times in 1985, reached the same conclusion. **********In making a case for sabotage, the Carbide experts are trying to prove that this could not have been the cause, partly because of evidence that the feeder lines were sealed off and partly because of the pipes' configuration. 'A Theory It Can't Prove' **********''There are only two theories, and the Government is wedded to a theory it can't prove,'' said a person close to the Carbide investigation. ''We can disprove the water-washing theory seven different ways from Sunday.'' **********The company maintains, for example, that when Indian investigators opened the feeder lines to the tank, they were ''bone dry.'' **********A lawyer for the Indian Government said that even so, Carbide could well have tampered with them itself. He said there were other reasons India was certain of the water explanation, but he declined to detail them. **********The Carbide investigators also calculated that given the amount of water flowing in from the washing, it would have taken 12 hours for the 6,000 to 7,000 pounds of water in both the methyl isocyanate tank and the feeder pipes to accumulate, making it impossible for the accident to happen when it did. Water in Only One Tank **********The company investigators are also said to insist there is no physical explanation of why the water leaked into only one of the three tanks. **********The company investigators said there was minor sabotage at the plant before the gas leak. For example, during some labor troubles in 1982, they said, nuts and bolts were thrown into some reactors, and four employees suspected in the incident left the plant. **********The company also says logs had been tampered with before the gas leak to cover up mistakes at the plant. **********The company says that plant employees knew that water mixed with methyl isocyanate would create a solid mixture that would damage the plant. But, it said, no one knew this would also create the reaction with iron particles and that the action would create such havoc. Pressure Gauge Called Key **********According to company sources, among the most significant evidence of sabotage is testimony that Union Carbide says it has about a pressure gauge that was missing the night of the disaster. The gauge was supposed to be on the tank containing methyl isocyanate. **********The company says the missing gauge left an opening through which the water was deliberately put into the tank. The company also says several people recall seeing a water hose near that opening the day after the accident. **********In interviews last year, former plant employees told The New York Times that Union Carbide lawyers had questioned them closely about a hose near the tank, and whether they suspected sabotage. They said they had seen no hose and suspected no one, and accused the company of fabricating the sabotage story. **********But the Carbide investigators maintain that one employee, Sunder Rajan, told them casually in February 1986 -nearly 15 months after the accident -that he had noticed the pressure gauge was missing but had never mentioned it to investigators. **********Carbide maintains he did not think it was important at the time, and that he simply replaced the gauge the morning after the accident. Worker Files a Complaint **********In a statement filed in a Bhopal court, Mr. Rajan accused Indian investigators of trying to intimidate him and make him change his story. **********The company sources also showed what they said were altered logs and documents. They said these were proof that the supervisors and employees at the plant were aware of the start of the accident earlier than they have said. **********The evidence, according to the company, is that initially the employees tried to drain off water from the tank. The company says this means that the workers immediately knew the source of the problem and that the only way they knew so quickly is that workers saw the hose feeding the water into the tank. **********The Carbide representatives said that shortly after the night shift arrived at 10:45 P.M., someone walked to the back of the storage tank to an alley, and hooked one end of a rubber hose to a water tap. They said the person removed the pressure gauge on the tank, hooked up the hose and turned on the water. **********''Five minutes to get to the tank, and five minutes to hook up the hose to the tank,'' the person said. ''That''s all it would take.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/16/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Adminstration today ordered officials to complete their narrowing of a list of Japanese electronics products that will be subject to the tariffs expected to be imposed on Friday. **********A senior trade official said the Cabinet met for ''a review of what's been said over the last few days.'' He reported that there were no objections to proceeding with the sanctons. **********President Reagan is expected to issue a proclamation on Friday setting duties of up to 100 percent on $300 million in annual imports of specific Japanese products. A preliminary list published on March 27 represented $1.8 billion of annual imports. **********The original list included computer tape and disks, television sets, electric motors, air-conditioners, refrigerators, calculators, hand tools, pumps and measuring devices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/30/busin.main_headline: Gold Contracts Falter As Inflation Fears Ease
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/30/busin.print_headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS; Gold Contracts Falter As Inflation Fears Ease
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/30/busin.body_text: **********Gold futures prices came under renewed pressure today as traders, taking into account the dollar's recent gains, squared their positions before the weekend. **********Inflationary pressures have abated in recent weeks because of the dollar's recovery against other currencies, and precious metals have taken the brunt of the selling in the commodity markets. **********But silver futures firmed after a recent decline, with many traders feeling that the plunge had gone too far. This week, silver prices dropped $2 from the highs of the previous week. Analysts said silver outperformed gold today on fresh buying from managed commodity funds. **********Wheat futures prices tumbled at the Chicago Board of Trade as the market's speculative element exerted selling pressure. Sizable sales by two large trading houses early in the session set the tone, and technical analysts said price charts had suddenly turned bearish. **********With the Soviet Union's wheat needs temporarily satisfied, analysts said there were few other countries likely to buy American wheat in the near term. They added that the United States wheat harvest was expected to produce a bountiful crop that may not find an export outlet. **********Corn prices finished mixed. Contracts calling for delivery after the fall harvest closed slightly higher on talk that important parts of the central Corn Belt have been missed by recent rains. **********Similarly, distant months of soybean futures gained on the nearby months, as traders unwound spread positions. **********At the New York Mercantile Exchange, trading in energy futures was sluggish. ''Energy futures opened lower, violated support areas, then rallied to close above those levels,'' said Carol Denicolo, energy specialist at GPR Inc. **********Speculators dominated the coffee futures market as trading in the cash market was light and the July contract finished with a loss. Weather reports scuttled talk of a cold spell in Brazil's coffee-growing regions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/25/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Conseco Markets Debt and Equity
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/25/busin.body_text: **********Conseco Inc., a holding company that acquires, owns and operates life insurance companies, yesterday priced a $300 million offering of debt and equity through underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds. **********A $255 million issue of speculative-grade 12 3/4 percent senior subordinated notes due in 1997 was priced at 98.622 to yield 13 percent. Noncallable for five years, the notes yield 4 3/4 percentage points more than Treasury securities of similar maturity. **********The notes are rated B-1 by Moody's and B by Standard & Poor's. Conseco, based in Carmel, Ind., increased the offering from a planned $250 million. **********The company is also selling 1.8 million shares of $1.875 convertible preferred stock at $25 a share. The stock is convertible at any time into the company's common stock at an initial price of $17.50 a share. **********Proceeds from sales of the notes and preferred stock will be added to funds from Conseco's recently completed offering of 2 million shares to finance the $275 million acquisition of the Western National Life Insurance Company from the Beneficial Corporation and to repay bank debt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/06/busin.main_headline: PARADYNE PLEADS GUILTY, SETTLING FRAUD CHARGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; PARADYNE PLEADS GUILTY, SETTLING FRAUD CHARGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/06/busin.body_text: **********The Paradyne Corporation pleaded guilty today and was fined $1 million for scheming to defraud the Social Security Administration to obtain a $115 million computer contract. **********Under a plea-bargaining agreement, Robert S. Wiggins resigned as chairman, president and chief executive officer, the company announced, and was replaced by Jerry Kendall, the vice president. As part of the agreement, the prosecutors dropped six other counts of bribery and making false statements. **********The company pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to defraud and agreed to pay the fine and $200,000 in costs during a hearing before Federal District Judge William Castagna. **********The charges stemmed from attempts by Paradyne, a data communications products manufacturer based in Largo, Fla., to win the contract - the largest ever awarded by the Social Security Administration - to revamp the agency's computer system in 1981 and 1982. Demonstration Called a Fake **********The prosecutors accused Paradyne of faking a computer demonstration during the bidding process. When Paradyne could not develop the computer in time for a demonstration, it used one made by another company and represented it as its own, the prosecutors said. **********The Government said a conspiracy began in June 1980 and continued until the indictment was returned in December 1985. **********Paradyne maintained a contract to service the field-office computers, but the company was suspended from bidding on other Government work. The settlement ends the suspension, Paradyne said, and enables it to resume business with the Government. **********The 45-page fraud indictment charged Paradyne and eight executives with conspiracy, bribery, false statements, perjury and obstruction of justice. **********During proceedings today the Government dismissed conspiracy and false statement charges against four former and current executives. Four others, including Mr. Wiggins, were put into a program that defers prosecution. If they successfully complete one year in the program, the charges will be dismissed. Mr. Wiggins had been accused of conspiracy, making false statements, obstruction of justice and perjury. **********In September 1985, two days before trial, Paradyne settled separate fraud charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which accused the company of lying to get the lucrative contract.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Purolator Bid Sends Stock Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/02/busin.body_text: **********Wall Street greeted a new bid for the Purolator Courier Corporation by raising the price of its stock by $5.50 a share, to $40.375, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Late Tuesday the Emery Air **********Freight Corporation had announced its bid, which was valued at $40 a share in cash and subordinated debt, or about $306 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Emery said that it would help to pay for the bid by selling or leasing Purolator's air hub in Indianapolis, and by divesting itself of Purolator's Stant Inc. subsidiary. Kevin Murphy, an analyst at **********Morgan Stanley & Company, said those sales could raise $202 million. ''That leaves a net purchase price of $104 million for Purolator's trucking division,'' Mr. Murphy said. ''But Purolator also has $75 million of debt on its books.'' **********Purolator directors met yesterday at Basking Ridge, N.J., to consider the offer, which came a little more than a day before a $35-a-share leveraged buyout offer was due to expire. **********As expected, the leveraged buyout group did not immediately increase its bid, but it said its offer had been extended to midnight, April 6. **********Purolator lost $57.6 million on revenues of $841 million last year. Emery, which is based in Wilton, Conn., lost $5.4 million on revenues of $887.5 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/09/busin.main_headline: A Quick Fix That Would Be Harmful
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: SHOULD SOME LATIN DEBT BE FORGIVEN?; A Quick Fix That Would Be Harmful
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/09/busin.body_text: **********THE search for a quick fix for the Latin American debt problem has generated numerous proposals for concessional debt relief. But a close analysis suggests that, except for some extreme cases (Bolivia, for example), such relief is not needed and actually would be counterproductive. **********The best single measure of the debt burden is the ratio of interest payments to exports. In part because of the decline of world interest rates, this ratio has fallen from 47 percent to 34 percent since 1982 for non-oil exporting countries in the region. After a setback from lower oil prices last year, the oil exporters should resume their improvement this year. Since 1982, debtor countries have sharply cut their external deficits, reduced their budget deficits and devalued their exchange rates to spur exports. After a severe recession in 1983, the countries re-established positive economic growth, and last year growth in non-oil Latin countries averaged 6.5 percent. **********None of the four key debtor countries - Mexico, Brazil, Argentina or Venezuela - can be described as insolvent and in need of bankruptcy treatment. Brazil's current suspension of bank payments results not from external shock but from internal mismanagement last year. Exports are now recovering and new economic measures taken in June will reduce the budget deficit. Mexico has shown a dramatic external-sector recovery after last year's collapse of oil prices. The banks have just completed a new lending package for Argentina, and Venezuela has large foreign reserves. **********Smaller countries such as Chile that have adopted proper policies have achieved impressive results in growth and exports. Most of the countries in the region can manage their debt and still achieve politically acceptable domestic growth of some 4 to 5 percent annually or higher. **********International economic conditions must of course be adequate for continued progress. A threshold of perhaps 2 1/2 percent annual growth in industrial countries is required for sufficient expansion of debtor-country exports. In addition, a new explosion of interest rates and new trade restrictions in industrial countries must be avoided. Commodity prices have been an area of disappointment, although there are emerging signs that they are recovering, particularly in the metals. The partial recovery of oil from its 1986 low is helping to stabilize conditions for Mexico and other oil exporters. **********Not only is there no immediate need for widespread debt relief, but its long-term benefits are also doubtful. Debt forgiveness is incompatible with improving the debtor country's creditworthiness and returning the country to normal access to international capital markets. Any improved capacity to service reduced debt would tend to be more than offset by the deterioration in creditors' perception of the country's willingness to pay - especially if they thought the country was capable of meeting its obligations while achieving satisfactory growth. Credit reputation is crucial in sovereign borrowing, where physical collateral is absent. **********Forced forgiveness would tend to isolate the country not only from capital markets but also from export markets, because the two go hand in hand. Peru illustrates the point. Its exports and foreign reserves have fallen as foreign banks have cut off trade credit in response to President Alan Garcia's unilateral ceiling on payments, and its favorable growth of last year is unlikely to be sustained. **********SENATOR Bill Bradley has proposed that banks forgive three percentage points annually on both interest and principal - over three years - with agreed policy reform. For Mexico, this program would raise national income by at most one-half percentage point annually during the period. This benefit would seem too small to risk the potentially large long-run costs associated with impairment of creditworthiness. **********Another proposal in Congress would create a new debt entity to buy bank debt at the secondary market price and convey the discount to the countries. If such a program is voluntary, few banks would enlist. If forced on the banks, such mechanisms would severely damage the long-term credit relationship between the banks and the countries. **********It is true that the risk to the international banking system from developing country debt is much lower today than in 1982 because of increased bank capital and the sizable loan-loss reserves set aside after Brazil suspended bank payments in February.
