The central point, however, is that even judged solely by the debtor country's own interests (especially longer term), arrangements for new borrowing usually will be superior to forced forgiveness of debt. President Miguel de la Madrid reached this conclusion one year ago at the depths of Mexico's crisis. **********The proper policy on debt remains a strengthened Baker Plan, which envisions coordinated resumption of capital flows to the debtor countries in return for policy reform. Renewed capital inflows will be necessary for investment revival and sustained growth, especially as export expansion begins to exhaust idle capacity. The banks must fulfill their part of the Baker Plan, and will come closer to doing so this year with large new lending to Mexico, Argentina and possibly Brazil. The Export-Import Bank should expand lending more rapidly, as a positive way to harness Congressional concerns about export recovery. Lending through the World Bank and the regional banks should rise faster than under Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d's original formulation. **********But the fundamental premise of the Baker Plan remains sound: It is far better for the debtor countries themselves - and for the international financial system - to keep debt management on a track that points back to re-establishment of normal access to capital markets. Forced debt forgiveness would jettison the hard-won progress in that direction that has already been achieved.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; ORDERS FALL 4% AT U.S. FACTORIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/busin.body_text: **********Orders received by American factories in January fell 4 percent, the steepest one-month decline in almost seven years, the Commerce Department reported today. Analysts said the change in the tax law was part of the reason. **********Civilian orders plunged by a record 5.2 percent in January, eased by a leap in military equipment orders. **********Orders totaled $194.46 billion in January. This was down $8.16 billion from December, when orders had risen 1.6 percent. **********The advance in December orders, which followed an even stronger 3.6 percent November rise, had fueled hopes that American manufacturers were finally beginning to see improvement after two and a half years of sluggishness resulting from the nation's trade deficit. **********But analysts attributed the year-end strength to a rush by American consumers and businesses to buy big-ticket items while they could still qualify for more lucrative tax benefits under the old tax law. Foreign Competition Noted **********Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities in New York, said the January plunge showed American factories still facing intense foreign competition. **********''If trade were improving, you would expect to see it in these orders numbers, and that isn't happening,'' Mr. Yardeni said.  Overall economic growth, as measured by the gross national product, slowed to 2.5 percent last year, the weakest showing since the last recession, with American manufacturing one of the hardest-hit sectors. **********The Reagan Administration has forecast a substantial rebound in growth this year, to 3.2 percent. But Mr. Yardeni predicted today that the G.N.P. would expand only 1 percent to 2 percent. He said trade would fail to improve enough to offset expected declines in business investment and consumer spending. View of Ordering Pattern **********Jay Levy, head of Levy Economic Forecasts of Chappaqua, N.Y., said the January decline essentially showed that the big jump in orders that occurred in December was borrowed from the early part of 1987. **********The 4 percent drop in factory orders in January was the largest since a 4.5 percent drop in May 1980. **********Business capital spending in January fell 17 percent, the most in a year. **********Orders for military equipment shot up 49.7 percent in January, to $6.55 billion, after an even bigger 57.7 percent decline the month before. Wide swings in this category often occur. **********The decline in January orders was concentrated in durable goods -items that are expected to last three or more years. Those orders totaled $103 billion in January, 6.7 percent below the December level. **********Orders for nondurable goods edged down eight-tenths of 1 percent in January after rising 1.7 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/world.main_headline: SHAMIR ASKS INQUIRY IN SECURITY CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/world.print_headline: SHAMIR ASKS INQUIRY IN SECURITY CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel formally requested today that the Supreme Court president, Meir Shamgar, appoint a judicial commission to examine the conduct of agents of Shin Beth, Israel's internal security service. **********The Cabinet voted Sunday to establish the commission. The actions come after the Supreme Court freed a former army officer who was convicted of treason and espionage in 1980 based on testimony by Shin Beth agents that the Government admitted to be false. The former officer, Izat Nafsu, who said he was forced by agents to make a false confession, had served seven years of an 18-year prison sentence. **********Shin Beth, whose domestic intelligence assignment is roughly similar to that of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was once highly revered for helping prevent terrorist acts against civilians, but it has been rocked by scandal ever since its cover-up of the killings of two captured Palestinian bus hijackers in 1984 was discovered last year. Police Inquiry Is Resisted **********On Friday, Attorney General Yosef Harish ordered a police investigation into the perjury accusations that were raised in Mr. Nafsu's successful court appeal. But today the right-wing Likud bloc called for a halt to that investigation, and Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of the Labor Party praised Shin Beth's efforts to prevent terrorist acts. **********''I want to express deep appreciation for the quality of its people, their skills and their achievements in the war against terrorism,'' Mr. Rabin told Parliament today. ''I know that here and there some irregularities have taken place, but we must be cautious, for this is a unique instrument for fighting terrorism.'' **********Mr. Nafsu, a 32-year-old member of Israel's tiny Circassian Moslem minority who was a lieutenant in the Israeli Army, said Shin Beth agents had used physical and psychological harassment to force him to confess. He also said Shin Beth agents lied in the military court that heard his case. Fear for Agency Morale **********Shin Beth officials have said they fear a police investigation would badly hurt the agency's morale and effectiveness. Shin Beth figures told Israeli newspapers they would prefer a judicial inquiry. **********While the police are investigating criminal charges, the inquiry commission's task will be to examine Shin Beth's investigation methods, work procedures and internal organization, experts have said. **********Today, Shin Beth agents told the mass-circulation newspaper Maariv that they are confused about how to continue with their work, and do not know whether to continue interrogating suspects with the methods they have used until now.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/22/busin.body_text: **********New World Entertainment Ltd., defeated in its hostile attempt to acquire Kenner Parker Toys Inc. earlier this month, said it was extending its $47-a-share tender offer another week, until Friday. It is the second time New World has extended its offer since it was outbid by the Tonka Corporation, which on Sept. 5 agreed to buy Kenner Parker for $51 a share, or $622 million. The move is apparently a precautionary one that would permit New World to revive its bid if Tonka failed to complete its merger or if New World, still in litigation over its offer, won a favorable court ruling.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/02/world.body_text: **********Afghanistan's Soviet-backed Government announced today that starting Jan. 15 its forces would observe a cease-fire in their battle with Moslem guerrillas. **********Najibullah, the Afghan leader, described the move as a step toward national reconciliation in the seven-year-old war, the Kabul radio reported. **********But the first reaction from guerrilla leaders appeared to be negative. **********According to Reuters, a spokesman in Islamabad, Pakistan, for the seven guerrilla groups known as the Mujahedeen said they had rejected Mr. Najibullah's move. **********According to reports today by the Kabul radio and the Soviet press agency Tass, Mr. Najibullah disclosed the cease-fire on Tuesday in a speech to the Central Committee of the ruling Communist Party of Afghanistan. He was reported to have said the cease-fire would be temporary but could be extended if rebel groups honored it and reconciliation began. Warns Against Attacks **********''National reconciliation begins with a cease-fire,'' the radio quoted Mr. Najibullah as having said. ''At the national level, the cease-fire will be effective from Jan. 15.'' **********He warned, however, that ''if someone continues to fire, he will get the response that will be satisfactory.'' **********The cease-fire would be followed, he said, by a discussion with the opposition groups, including exiled leaders of the former monarchy. **********''We don't want to exclude different political groups, moderates, monarchists and heads of armed anti-Government bands active abroad, from national reconciliation,'' Mr. Najibullah said. ''I have spoken before about the creation of a coalition government of national unity.'' **********No further details on the cease-fire were provided by the Kabul radio or by the Tass report. The Kabul broadcast was monitored by United States Government listening posts, translated and transmitted to Washington. State Department Doubtful **********State Department officials said that as far as they knew, the announcement had not been preceded by any discussions between the Afghan Government and the guerrilla groups. Because of this, they said they doubted the cease-fire would win guerrilla backing. There was no official comment in Washington pending the return of senior officials from the New Year's holiday. **********The analysts said the cease-fire was consistent with the Soviet effort over the last year to widen the political base of the Afghan leadership and to put the onus on the guerrillas for the continued fighting. About 120,000 Soviet troops are stationed in Afghanistan. **********In December 1985, Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, called for including genuine opposition figures in a national reconciliation government. This theme has been repeated by Soviet and Afghan spokesmen since then. **********In addition, the Soviet side has given signs of being concerned about the negative effect of the drawn-out guerrilla war on its own population and on Soviet standing in Moslem countries. A token withdrawal of about 8,000 troops was undertaken last October and was given wide publicity in the Soviet Union to suggest that Moscow was eager to end its involvement once the proper conditions were met. Took Over in May **********Mr. Najibullah, a former secret police chief, took over control in May after the Soviet Union forced Babrak Karmal to step down as party leader. He has repeatedly called for a reconciliation government. **********In November Mr. Karmal was forced to give up his remaining Government and party posts, increasing Mr. Najibullah's power, although experts contend that there remain serious differences within the Kabul leadership. **********Last month Mr. Najibullah and almost all the key members of his leadership spent several days in Moscow meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and other high officials, apparently to plot strategy for coming months. The Soviet leaders were believed by American political analysts to have called for an end to divisions in the leadership and for a more credible effort to persuade some opposition figures to join the Government. **********Negotiations to try to end the war have been held under United Nations auspices between Pakistan and the Afghan Government. Those talks will resume in Geneva on Feb. 11, with the main unresolved issue being a timetable for the withdrawal of Soviet forces. The Soviet Union has offered in the past to leave within four years, but the Pakistanis and Americans want a withdrawal in three to four months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/23/busin.main_headline: Budget Plan Expected To Leave Investors Cold
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/23/busin.print_headline: Budget Plan Expected To Leave Investors Cold
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/23/busin.body_text: **********Investors are expected to be unimpressed with a tentative agreement to trim the budget deficit by $76 billion over two years, Wall Street experts said yesterday. **********The reason, they said, is that the plan provides for only $7 billion more in cuts this fiscal year than would have been made automatically under existing legislation. **********''There's no home run in this plan, so I don't expect anything dramatic,'' said Lawrence A. Kudlow, an economist at Bear, Stearns & Company and formerly chief economist in the Office of Management and Budget under David A. Stockman. ''By the slimmest of slim margins, it's possible that the markets may be up. But I think they have already reacted to the news through last week.'' **********On Friday the Dow Jones industrial average rallied after the announcement of the plan, closing up 18.24 points, to 1,913.63. But for the week it was down 21.38 points. Price Decline Seen **********Jay Goldinger, a California investment broker, was more skeptical than Mr. Kudlow, and predicted that investor confidence might be shaken by the limited agreement and that stock prices might decline slightly. **********''It's like getting a birthday cake where the icing looks great, but the cake is really hollow,'' said Mr. Goldinger, who works for Cantor, Fitzgerald & Company in Beverly Hills, Calif. ''There's a relief that the discussions are over with. But the result doesn't seem to be much. I think the markets may be selling off.'' **********Architects of the plan said it was intended to allay fears at the major exchanges and stabilize the volatile trading on the major currency and stock exchanges during the last month. **********But Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, said investors had already lowered their expectations and the decline last week of the dollar and of leading market indexes reflected most of the reaction to the process of reducing the deficit. **********David Schafer, president of Schafer Capital Management Inc., which manages $600 million in pension, retirement, and mutual funds, said he did not foresee a strong reaction to the plan, although the markets may go up slightly. **********''It might be a mild positive because something got done and cuts will be made,'' Mr. Schafer said. ''But I wouldn't expect anything extraordinary.'' **********Traders will be unable to get an early clue from Tokyo because the markets there are closed for a national holiday. Share prices in London, however, could provide an early indication of the overseas reception of the news. **********''The key is not the deficit reduction, but rather the renewed potential for an internationally coordinated drop in interest rates,'' said Robert Giordano, chief economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/08/world.main_headline: 'PEOPLE USED TO WALK UP TO TELL ME WHAT A GREAT JOB I DID'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/08/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS: 'I CAME HERE TO TELL YOU THE TRUTH'; 'PEOPLE USED TO WALK UP TO TELL ME WHAT A GREAT JOB I DID'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/08/world.body_text: **********Under questioning by John W. Nields Jr., the House committee's chief counsel, Lieut Col. Oliver L. North insisted yesterday that he believed his superiors knew about his actions. This exchange occurred during questioning about a false chronology. **********Q. By putting out this false version of the facts you were committing, were you not, the entire Administration, to telling a false story? **********A. I'm not trying to pass the buck here. O.K., I did a lot of things, and I wanted to stand up and say that I'm proud of them. I don't want you to think, counsel, that I went about this all on my own. I realize there's a lot of folks around that think there's a loose cannon on the gun deck of state at the N.S.C. That wasn't what I heard while I worked there, I've only heard it since I left. People used to walk up to me and tell me what a great job I was doing. **********And the fact is there were many, many people to include the former Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs, the current National Security Adviser, the Attorney General of the United States of America, the Director of Central Intelligence, all of whom knew that to be wrong. **********Q. We understand that, Colonel, and I take it one of your functions was to give people above you in the hierarchy advice? A. That is correct.  Q. And by putting out this story, you were committing, among other people, the President of the United States to telling a version of the facts which wasn't true? **********A. Counsel, I think I've answered the question as best I can. I'm not too sure who you want to blame for committing who. If you want to blame me for committing others, that's fine. **********Q. No one has suggested that, sir. My question to you is this: Isn't it true, and I'll put it that others above you, by putting out this version of the facts, were committing the President of the United States to a false story? A. Yes, that's true.  Q. Did you ever say, to any of those people, you can't do that without asking the President? A. No, I did not.  Q. Did you ever say, you can't do that, it's not true and you cannot commit the President of the United States to a lie? **********A. I don't believe that I ever said that to anyone, no. **********Q. Did anybody else, in your presence, say that? A. No.  Q. So none of these people, Director of Central Intelligence, two National Security Advisers, Attorney General, none of them ever made the argument, it's not true, you can't say it? **********A. No. And in fairness to them, I think that they had a darn good reason for not putting the straight story out and their reasons might have been the same as mine. They may have been different. You'd have to ask them. The fact is, I think there were good and sufficient reasons at that time. Q. Did anybody ask the President? A. I did not. Q. Do you know if anyone else did? A. I do not.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/world.main_headline: At a Trial in Sierra Leone, a Script for a Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/world.print_headline: At a Trial in Sierra Leone, a Script for a Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/world.body_text: **********On paper, Francis M. Minah is an African steeped in the Western traditions of law. **********He trained in law at King's College, London. When he came home to this former British colony, he donned the black robes and white wig of a Sierra Leone solicitor and argued cases in the grand Edwardian-era Law Court Building here. **********Soon, the young lawyer was elected to Parliament, the first step in a political career that led to the nation's second-highest post, First Vice President. Feeling passed over for the presidency, he is said to have resorted earlier this year to a traditional African route to the top - a coup. Prosecutors say that Mr. Minah was the primary instigator of a plot to overthrow the Government, and that other men carried out the specific actions. **********About half of Africa's leaders owe their jobs to coups. Many others, fearing that they will be overthrown, minimize their international travel. The latest coup victim was Jean Baptiste Bagaza of Burundi, who was overthrown while attending a conference in Quebec in September. **********Those who are victorious in their coups rarely divulge their secrets. Those who fail rarely live to tell the tale. **********But hewing to their legal tradition, Sierra Leoneans are putting the coup plotters on trial. The testimony - the A B C's of a coup plot - has captivated this intimate capital on the west coast of Africa - an overgrown town that was the setting for Graham Greene's novel, ''The Heart of the Matter.'' **********The heart of a successful coup is often murder. **********Everyone in town knew that every weekday morning, Sierra Leone's President, Joseph S. Momoh, drove down the Hill Cot Road from his official residence to his office. **********Gabriel T. Kaikai was particularly aware of this fact. The chief of presidential security until Mr. Momoh demoted him last year, Mr. Kaikai is thought to have taken part in the coup by planning the killing of Mr. Momoh. **********Mr. Kaikai's memory appears to have focused on a hairpin turn where cars have to slow down to pass over a bridge. Prosecutors say he selected a weed-choked, red clay bluff as the spot to ambush the presidential motorcade. **********The hairpin turn had another advantage. From there, a fast driver could arrive in five minutes at the broadcast studios of the national radio station -another key element in a successful coup. In African countries, where few people read newspapers, the success or failure of a coup can depend on the impression created on national radio. Prosecutors say Mr. Kaikai spent several hours at home with a tape recorder, polishing his coup speech. ''My dear people, you can safely call this coup as your coup, 'the peoples' coup,' '' his recorded voice was heard to say in the courtroom. **********The plotters were actually limited to a small group of Government employees - largely from Mr. Minah's Pujehun district - who lost influence when Mr. Momoh became President in November 1985, the prosecutors said. **********Without access to the army arsenal, the plotters won backing from Jamil Said Mohamed, who was then the richest man in town, court documents say. Mr. Jamil, who now lives in London, denies any involvement. **********The conspirators' downfall came when they tried to enlist the help of a man whose brother had been dismissed from the army because of a denunciation by Mr. Kaikai. On March 23, the night before they were to act, the police raided Mr. Kaikai's two residences. **********They uncovered large weapons caches, including two AK-47 rifles, one Uzi submachine gun, six cases of bombs, two rocket launchers, 12 cases of ammunition, 19 submachine guns, six rockets and 12 hand grenades. **********The trial of the 18 co-defendants is expected to go to the jury for a verdict in late December. **********''The whole thing is pretty hollow,'' Garvas Betts, one of Mr. Minah's defense lawyers, said. ''I don't think you can connect some of the characters.'' **********Mr. Minah, on trial for treason, has not taken the proceedings well. Newspapers reported that he wept as he was led handcuffed for the first time into the old colonial Law Court Building.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/28/world.main_headline: WEST BANK STUDENTS MARCH IN SUPPORT OF FATAH FIGHTERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/28/world.print_headline: WEST BANK STUDENTS MARCH IN SUPPORT OF FATAH FIGHTERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/28/world.body_text: **********Hundreds of students at Al Najah University in Nablus, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, defied warnings from Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin and demonstrated today in support of Al Fatah, Yasir Arafat's guerrilla organization. **********Witnesses said about 500 students at Al Najah, the largest Palestinian university in the West Bank, carried portraits of Mr. Arafat, sang Palestinian nationalist songs and chanted denunciations of Syria, Jordan, Israel and the Shiite Amal militia, which is fighting the Palestinians in Lebanon. **********Israeli troops surrounded the campus to prevent hundreds of other students and youths from joining the demonstration, but no violence was reported. The demonstration was called to commemorate the 22d anniversary of the founding of Al Fatah, the main guerrilla group operating under the umbrella of the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********Since it is technically against Israeli law to express support for the Palestine Liberation Organization, the demonstration today was highly unusual. It was also something of a challenge to the Israeli authorities, who have been tacitly working with Jordan to erode Mr. Arafat's widespread backing in the West Bank, particularly among educated youth, and to build support for the more conservative King Hussein. Warning From Rabin **********Last week, Mr. Rabin warned the heads of Palestinian universities and colleges that he would not tolerate their schools' becoming centers of Palestinian activity. **********Beginning last month, when Israeli troops killed three Palestinian students who threw stones at them during demonstrations in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, the tension between the Israeli occupation authorities and Palestinian youths has been steadily increasing. In recent weeks, there have been several confrontations between the Israelis and Palestinians. **********An Israeli Army spokesman announced today that a senior officer had been ordered to investigate allegations that two Israeli officers and eight soldiers had beaten and degraded Palestinian prisoners at the Ansar-2 prison camp outside of Gaza last month. **********The commander of Israel's southern front, Maj. Gen. Yitzhak Mordechai, dismissed the allegations when they were first brought up last month by Palestinian lawyers. The army spokesman said grounds have now been found for an inquiry. Allegations of Ill Treatment **********The Palestinian prisoners were arrested during a demonstration. One of them, Suhayl Abdel Ata, 21 years old, said at a news conference that he and two colleagues were forced by Israeli soldiers to strip, salute an Israeli officer and then kiss each other's buttocks. Later, he said, the three of them were bound and beaten and given virtually no food for three days. When they requested water they had to drink it from their shoes, he said. **********Last week, Mr. Rabin barred a former Hebron Mayor, Mustafe Natshe, and a Palestinian lawyer, Faiz Abu Rahme of Gaza, from attending an international conference in San Diego on the Arab-Israeli conflict. The two Palestinians are known for their relatively moderate views and had planned to go to the conference with Israeli peace campaigners, such as Abba Eban, a member of Parliament. The conference was called off because of the travel ban, which baffled even many Israelis. **********''There is no escaping the conclusion that Rabin's decision is emblematic of an unnecessary and inexplicable act of oppression,'' wrote Zeev Schiff, the widely respected military editor of the Haaretz newspaper. ''The truth is that in everything regarding the Palestinian issue, Rabin holds extremist positions and follows a zig-zag policy.'' **********In the last two years, the Israeli Government has revived the practice of expelling Palestinians suspected of supporting the P.L.O. No trials are held and lawyers trying to appeal the deportations cannot see most of the evidence against their clients because the information is gathered by security services through covert means and from informers. **********On Monday, Mohammed Dahlan, 26, of the Gaza Strip, was expelled to Jordan after being accused by the Israeli authorities of leading Al Fatah's youth movement. A Palestinian newspaper editor, Akram Haniye, was deported last month, also on charges of being a Fatah organizer. **********Thirty-seven Palestinians have been deported since the practice was reinstituted under the national unity Government in July 1985. The policy was halted by Prime Minister Menachem Begin in 1982. **********Stone-throwing at Israeli cars in the West Bank has also become a daily occurrence in recent weeks. **********The army said today that it was investigating whether an Israeli civilian, whose car was hit with rocks while driving past the Balata refugee district near Nablus on Monday, was responsible for shooting a Palestinian youth from Balata who was taken to a hosptial in Nablus with a gunshot wound. **********Last, month a 12-year-old Palestinian boy from Balata was shot and killed, reportedly by an unidentified Israeli West Bank settler whose car was stoned while driving by the camp. No one was arrested in the shooting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/22/busin.main_headline: TECHNICAL FACTORS HELP AS CRUDE OIL TOPS $19
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/22/busin.print_headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS; TECHNICAL FACTORS HELP AS CRUDE OIL TOPS $19
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/22/busin.body_text: **********The price of crude oil surged yesterday, topping $19 a barrel for a near-month futures contract, as crude oil and petroleum products advanced across the board. **********Oil analysts said, however, that the gain did not foreshadow any long-term trend in the oil market. Rather, they said, it resulted from technical market factors and anticipation of a report that showed a decline in inventories of crude oil and refined stocks. **********The crude oil futures contract for May closed at $19.03 a barrel, up 38 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. More moderate gains were scored in the London-based spot market: West Texas Intermediate crude, the major American grade, rose 25 cents, to $18.90 a barrel, and Brent North Sea crude, the major British grade, rose 10 cents, to $18. **********Petroleum products gained less than a cent. The near-month futures contracts for heating oil and unleaded gasoline rose to 48 cents a gallon and 51 cents a gallon, respectively. **********Peter C. Beutel, assistant director of Elders Futures Inc., said a typical last-minute squeeze on the May crude oil contract developed yesterday, the last day it was available. Along with heavy demand by traders seeking to take delivery, this was largely responsible for crude's price surge, he said. **********Nauman Barakat, an oil futures analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said technical factors helped lift the price. ''In terms of fundamentals, it's hard to justify a $19 price now,'' he said. **********Traders may also have anticipated ''good numbers'' from the American Petroleum Institute, he said. **********In its weekly report, issued after trading ended, the trade group said distillate fuel stocks fell 712,000 barrels from last week, to 104.5 million, and crude oil stocks fell 5.5 million barrels, to 323.7 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/31/world.main_headline: IN COLUMBIA, RISING VIOLENCE BREEDS NEW DOUBTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/31/world.print_headline: IN COLUMBIA, RISING VIOLENCE BREEDS NEW DOUBTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/31/world.body_text: **********Within the space of a few days this month, the leader of Colombia's main leftist party was assassinated, the country's best-known sculptor was kidnapped and several prominent writers and artists were forced into exile by death threats. **********That was not all. A bomb damaged the Defense Ministry in Bogota, 16 people were killed one afternoon by feuding emerald-smuggling rings and gunmen of the left and right added several dozen to the estimated 1,200 political killings here so far this year. **********Even for Colombia, a country long accustomed to levels of violence that would be considered intolerable elsewhere, the events of recent weeks have proved too much to ignore. **********The immediate response of many Colombians has been to blame the Government for the breakdown of law and order and to complain that President Virgilio Barco Vargas has failure to provide strong leadership. **********There is also new recognition that, while Colombia is in no imminent danger of being taken over by leftist or rightist extremists, uncontrolled violence is seriously undermining the country's democratic institutions. **********But perhaps most of all, the crisis has exposed a deep sense of powerlessness. Violence affects some regions and social groups more than others, yet not one person can say that he or she really knows what is going on, who is responsible and what should be done. **********''The population is perplexed,'' said Enrique Santos Calderon, a leading newspaper columnist. ''People ask, 'Why is this happening?' and 'Who wants to destabilize the country?' and then they answer according to their intuitions and passions.'' **********Trends nonetheless exist. While at different times this year violence has come principally from leftist guerrillas and narcotics traffickers, there is now strong evidence that extreme rightists are waging a ''dirty war'' against nonviolent leftists. **********The killing of the leader of the leftist Patriotic Union, Jaime Pardo Leal, on Oct. 11 served as the catalyst for the latest soul-searching, but it was in no way an isolated incident. Over the last 18 months, close to 500 other party members have been killed. **********Death threats sent out to a number of priests, academics, lawyers, journalists and artists have in turn spread terror to groups outside the Patriotic Union. Several of those threatened had denounced the rightist campaign. But in other cases, the motive was unclear. **********For many, in fact, the severity of the crisis became apparent only when they learned that many prominent people - among them, the actress Vicki Hernandez, the musician Sergio Acevedo and the journalist Daniel Samper Pizano - had fled the country. **********Yet while the leadership, structure and activities of the country's leftist guerrilla groups are well known, no one has so far been able to identity the members of what is apparently an active and well-organized extreme right. **********There is well-documented evidence of the direct participation of some army officers in rightist death squads. Before he was killed, Mr. Pardo even asked the Attorney General's Office to investigate several officers who, he said, were involved in killings. **********But despite chants at Mr. Pardo's funeral accusing the Defense Minister, Gen. Rafael Samudio Molina, of responsibility for his death, to date there is no proof that the army as an institution has adopted ''dirty war'' tactics. **********The Patriotic Union contends that in many troubled regions, the extreme right includes cattle ranchers, narcotics traffickers and rightist politicians as well as army officers. Yet those who are coordinating what leftists call the ''extermination campaign'' at a national level have not been identified. **********Bernardo Jaramillo Ossa, the 33-year-old lawyer who succeeded Mr. Pardo as head of the Patriotic Union, said the extreme right's objectives at least are clear. ''It wants to drive us out of the political arena, to force us to abandon the democratic struggle, to make us boycott next March's municipal elections,'' he said. ''We're not going to give it that pleasure.'' **********Many politicians in fact specifically link the latest wave of violence to the elections, scheduled for March 13, because for the first time in this country's history mayors will be elected rather than appointed by the central government. Thus, where the Patriotic Union might win, it is coming under attack.  Colombia's Crisis: Not Easily Stereotyped **********While warnings are heard that Colombia is sliding irrevocably toward the kind of chaotic polarization that has convulsed El Salvador in recent years, this country's crisis still somehow escapes easy stereotyping. **********The economy, for example, is growing strongly. The battle lines between left and right are not clearly defined; many conservatives are anxious to dissociate themselves from the extreme right and some leftists are openly critical of guerrilla tactics. And while violence in Central America is mainly political, things are complicated enormously here for many reasons. **********The kidnapping last week of the sculptor, Rodrigo Arenas Betancourt, was a case in point. He was grabbed in Medellin, a city where leftist guerrillas, narcotics traffickers, paramilitary gangs and common criminals all operate with apparent impunity. None took responsibility for the crime. **********There were more than 11,000 killings in Colombia last year, making for a per-capita rate almost five times higher than the rate in the United States. Many killings are attributed to personal vendettas and crimes of passion, particularly since even minor disputes are routinely settled with guns. **********Further, violence has undergone a qualitative change here this decade with the introduction by major cocaine traffickers of the macabre figure of the paid assassin, invariably a young man in his late teens or early 20's who has been specially trained to kill. **********Known locally as ''sicarios,'' or ''assassins,'' these gunmen over the last three years have killed a Justice Minister, some 50 judges and more than a dozen journalists who dared challenge the power of the billionaire drug barons who form the so-called Medellin Cartel. **********Yet since mid-1987, when terrorized judges and politicians finally abandoned efforts to either jail major traffickers or extradite them to the United States, drug-related violence has sharply diminished. **********''The drug bosses now feel relaxed,'' one foreign narcotics expert said. ''They don't need to kill anyone because they have gotten their way. They're exporting more cocaine than ever and there aren't even arrest warrants out for them.''  A Grim Legacy: Mobsters and Justice **********In the process of intimidating society, the drug mobsters have effectively destroyed Colombia's system of justice, which now seems incapable of confronting an array of other criminal or paramilitary groups. **********The mobsters' grim legacy also includes assassins, now underemployed, who will kill for as little as $70 a victim. The Government announced last week that 403 ''sicarios'' had been arrested and another 38 killed in gun battles since 1984, yet others have quickly taken their place. **********One consequence of this insecurity is that many senior officials and politicians now drive in bulletproof cars accompanied by heavily armed guards. The security police force, which is roughly equivalent to the F.B.I., is forced to assign 70 percent of its 2,000 agents to personal protection, and has few available for investigations. **********Only last month, the Minister of Government, Cesar Gaviria, stunned Congress by providing a list of 138 paramilitary groups that are active in the country. **********Some are believed to be gangs of criminals and assassins. Others are so-called self-defense groups formed by cattle ranchers with army encouragement to combat rural guerrillas. A few, such as the Colombian Anti-Communist Association and Death to Revolutionaries, appear to be rightist bands. **********But the list also included groups named Rambo, Terminator, Love for Medellin and the Clean-Up Squad of Cali, which have taken responsibility for killing several hundred homosexuals, transvestites and petty criminals over the last year. **********A recent report from Colombia's Roman Catholic Bishops complained that ''private justice has imposed itself as a generalized method, with armed bands and paramilitary groups operating under the slogan of 'cleaning up society' and escaping the vigilance of authorities, military or civilian.'' **********The culture of violence is deeply ingrained here. Throughout the 19th century and again during a period known as La Violencia between 1948 and 1954, when some 300,000 people died, it pitted Liberals against Conservatives. The two parties made peace in 1958, but then the partisan struggle gave way to ideological warfare as new leftist guerrillas appeared. **********First in the countryside and later also in cities, rebels carried out attacks on police and army units and financed themselves through kidnappings and extortion. The armed forces, in turn, were frequently accused of killing innocent peasants and of torturing suspected guerrillas. **********But after the country had been under a state of siege for more than 30 years, with the suspension of many constitutional rights, a consensus began to emerge that neither side could win a military victory. When he took office in 1982, President Belisario Betancur therefore decided to gamble on negotiations with the rebels. **********''There was extraordinary support for the idea,'' a former Government official recalled. ''Everyone was exhausted by the futility of the violence. Many thought the guerrillas should be given a chance to join democracy.'' **********When cease-fires were finally signed with the Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces, or FARC, and three other groups in 1984, they were not required to surrender their weapons. Theoretically at least, the way was opened for them to take part in politics.  Fighting Is Renewed: Charges, Countercharges **********Within a year, however, all but the FARC had resumed guerrilla warfare. The April 19 Movement, or M-19, for example, said the Government had broken its promise to carry out social and economic changes. The Government said the rebels had used the truce to recruit and re-arm. By early 1986, the violence was widespread as ever. **********The FARC, the largest rebel force with some 6,000 men spread over 38 fronts, persevered in the cease-fire. In alliance with the Communist Party, it formed the Patriotic Union, which won 14 seats in Congress - as well as some 300,000 votes - in elections last year. **********Thus, even in an atmosphere of violence, the Patriotic Union demonstrated that political participation was possible. But its very success immediately converted its leaders into targets for assassination, particularly in regions where it expects to do well in municipal elections next March. **********The crisis touched off by Jaime Pardo's killing, therefore, not only focused attention on the murder campaign against the Patriotic Union, but also prompted different political groups to urge the Government to resume the peace process with other guerrilla groups. **********Many politicians of both the left and the right believe that only peace talks can keep Colombia from sliding into a more open civil war. The Roman Catholic Church has offered to mediate, while both the Patriotic Union and the opposition Social Conservative Party have called for negotiations. **********''At the moment, everyone in the country is in favor of a dialogue except the Government,'' said Misael Pastrana Borrero, a former President who now heads the Social Conservative Party. ''But a dialogue without the Government is meaningless.'' **********The Barco administration, however, has insisted that the guerrillas must agree to disarm before negotiations are possible. Further, after the FARC joined five other groups in a new Simon Bolivar Guerrilla Coordinating Committee last month, officials said the rebels were preparing for all-out war.  [ On Wednesday, apparently in response to criticism of the Government's failure to respond to calls for talks, a senior presidential adviser, Carlos Ossa Escobar, traveled to the headquarters of the FARC for the Government's first direct contact with the rebels since last April. It was not immediately known if any progress had been made. ]  Many politicians have blamed the immobility of the Government for the deepening crisis. After only 15 months in office, President Barco's image is that of a weak and indecisive leader who is holed up in the palace and out of touch with the rest of the country. **********A respected former Foreign Minister, Alfredo Vazquez Carrizosa, complained that Colombia had ''an executive branch that doesn't decide, a Congress that doesn't legislate and a judiciary that doesn't apply the law.'' **********Even the Defense Minister, General Samudio, has warned that ''a demented society is leading the country to anarchy and chaos,'' while a former President, Carlos Lleras Restrepo, said he could remember ''no moment of such anguish for Colombia.'' **********For Patriotic Union leaders, however, a primary objective is simply to stay alive. Although the party's new leader is now guarded around the clock, he and others continue to receive death threats. **********''They at least prove we're growing,'' Mr. Jaramillo said. ''If we were weak, no one would bother with us.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/12/busin.body_text: **********The stock market continued its leisurely rally yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 6.52 points, to 2,360.13. But the pace of stock trading, which had picked up in the previous two sessions, settled down. Still, the Dow is now only about 45 points below its record high. **********The Dow, which had a nondescript May - it started the month at 2,312.22 and ended it at 2,332.37 - is doing somewhat better so far in June. The average has moved higher in six of the last seven sessions - although many traders would like to forget about Wednesday, when it eked out a gain of 0.91 point after being up nearly 30 points. **********The market headed higher at the opening yesterday and held on all day, as investors apparently shrugged off the jolt of Wednesday's discouraging selloff, which came in the last hour of trading. On the New York Stock Exchange, 891 issues moved higher and 627 fell; 138.9 million shares changed hands, compared with 197.4 million on Wednesday. **********The Big Board's composite index rose 0.71, to 168.24, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 1.26, to 298.73. The Dow transportation index rose 5.05, to 1,028.37, yet another record, on the back of the still-strong airline issues. Bullish Signs **********''The internal strength of this market is impressive,'' said Peter G. Grennan, who heads the stock index futures department at Shearson Lehman Brothers. He said he was picking up bullish signs from both the cash and futures markets in stock indexes. ''It looks as if we will be looking to test the highs'' on the Dow, Mr. Grennan said, adding ''there is a lot of cash around,'' in a reference to money managers who are playing a wait-and-see game with the market. ''That's the scary part'' to anyone who might want to short the market, he said. **********The stock market was supported somewhat by the bond market, which had modest gains yesterday, despite some concern about a rise in the Commodity Research Bureau's futures index. That created some inflationary jitters in both the credit and equity markets, which are also nervously watching oil prices. **********Despite yesterday's stock gains, the relatively low trading volume is a sign that institutional investors are sitting on the sidelines, awaiting today's Government figures on merchandise trade and producer prices. If anything, some analysts say, Wall Street has too much on its plate. Both investors and analysts are having a hard time digesting the various indicators of the economy's direction. **********The Government reported yesterday that retail sales fell six-tenths of 1 percent in May, the biggest decline in four months. That raised new concerns about a possible recession; since February, retail sales have been essentially flat as consumers, burdened with debt, have curtailed their purchases. Japanese Issues Are Strong **********Japanese stocks that are traded on Wall Street rose strongly after the Tokyo stock market reached new highs. Honda Motor gained 8 3/4, to 113 3/4; Kyocera 4 3/8, to 75 3/4; Matsushita 4, to 133, and Hitachi 2 5/8, to 75 7/8. **********Dayton Hudson, which has been surging on takeover rumors, fell back 3/4, to 54 1/2, in very heavy trading. Some analysts noted that a takeover or leveraged buyout of the company at its current stock level might cost $6 billion. That would be beyond the capabilities of many likely suitors. **********Waste Management, which was recently recommended by analysts despite antitrust troubles, gained another 1 3/8, to 39 3/4, in heavy trading. **********International Business Machines lost 1/8 to 157 5/8. The company has denied rumors that it is experiencing problems with its new line of personal computers. **********Procter & Gamble, which on Thursday announced an $800 million restructuring and consolidation, rose 1/4, to 95 5/8. Although the restructuring will hurt earnings this year, the company said cash flow would be enhanced and its dividend would be maintained. **********In over-the-counter trading, Maxtor, fell 5 1/4, to 23 3/4. The company, a maker of disk drives, had said its first-quarter earnings would be disappointing. **********The Nasdaq O-T-C index rose 0.56, to 423.37. The American Stock Exchange index gained 0.66, to 333.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/30/busin.body_text: **********Thorn E.M.I., a British consumer products company, said today that it had agreed to buy the Rent-A-Center chain in the United States for $594 million. **********Rent-A-Center, which is based in Wichita, Kan., owns 270 stores and 168 franchises in 38 states. It rents household goods such as televisions, appliances and furniture. **********Thorn, which owns rental businesses in Britain and 12 other countries, said the merger would create one of the world's largest buyers of household products. The increase in purchasing power should result in lower costs for both companies, it said. **********The British company said in a statement that it was offering $27 for each share in the American company. Thorn said two of Rent-A-Center's principal stockholders, including the chairman, Thomas Devlin, had given it options to buy 50.6 percent of the shares.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/02/busin.body_text: **********The Government index designed to predict the course of the nation's economy climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in July. This rise, analysts said, confirms the likelihood of more months of restrained business expansion. **********It was the sixth straight advance in the index of leading economic indicators, the longest streak since the period from December 1985 through May 1986. **********''This is generally consistent with continued moderate gross national product growth of about 2 1/2 percent,'' commented Stephen S. Roach, principal senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. But he also noted that much of the July advance reflected higher stock prices and inflation and that therefore the data were ''not a real source of encouragement.'' **********Nonetheless, the Reagan Administration cited the leading index as yet another in a series of mostly favorable recent statistics while asserting that September would mark the 58th straight month of economic growth, tying a modern peacetime record. Administration Comment **********''Reaganomics gets better with age,'' declared Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, at the Western White House. **********Four of the nine indicators available for July accounted for the five-tenths of 1 percent advance. **********The biggest contribution came from a rise in the proportion of companies, to 62 percent from June's 57 percent, reporting slower deliveries from suppliers. This indicator points up production bottlenecks and possible inflationary pressures. **********The other significant contributors to the advance were a second straight sharp increase in stock prices and a rise in the price of various materials that are sensitive to the business cycle. The value of contracts and orders for new plant and equipment showed a negligible increase. **********The three elements that weakened the leading index were a decline in manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods and materials, a decline in building permits and a tiny decline in the M-2 measurement of the nation's money supply. **********Two components - initial claims for state unemployment insurance and the length of the average work week - were unchanged in July. **********The July increase, which was in line with expectations, brought the index to 191.8, or 6.6 percent higher than in July 1986. Revision of June Figure **********Meanwhile, the increase for June was raised today to a full 1 percent from the eight-tenths of 1 percent initially reported, with inventories accounting for the additional strength. This made the June increase the biggest since a jump of 2.1 percent in December. **********Today's report also showed that the index of coincident indicators - those that tend to track current economic activity - climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in July after averaging no change for May and June. **********But the index of lagging indicators fell five-tenths of 1 percent following declines of two-tenths in both May and June. It is the first time this index has fallen three straight months since mid-1983. **********Although declines in the lagging index are not in themselves bullish, such declines do tend to push upward the coincident-lagging ratio, a gauge that many economists consider a useful supplementary predictor. **********The coincident-lagging ratio climbed above 1.3 at the July reading as it registered its third straight advance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/19/busin.body_text: **********The Falstaff Brewing Corporation was ordered yesterday to pay Best Brands Beverage Inc. nearly $46 million for overcharging the company. **********Falstaff, based in Vancouver, Wash., and its Texas affiliate, the Pearl Brewing Company, violated antitrust law, according to a Federal court jury. The case was heard before Judge Richard Owen in the Southern District of New York. **********Best Brands, which is based in Hamilton, N.Y., has a contract to distribute Falstaff beer and ale in seven states in the Northeast. It accused Falstaff of illegally raising the price of its beverages by as much as 20 percent for Best Brands, but not for other distributors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/busin.body_text: **********The Senate deleted a provision in the trade bill today that would have allowed the President to impose an oil import fee to reduce dependence on foreign oil. **********The 55-to-41 vote generally pitted oil-state senators against those from consuming states, especially in the Northeast, Midwest and Northwest. A broad coalition - from the United States Chamber of Commerce and the Sierra Club to the Farm Bureau and the United Automobile Workers - had opposed the provision, as had the Reagan Administration. **********The debate revived many of the energy dependence and independence arguments of the 1970's and the early 1980's. It also touched on the danger to oil supplies posed by the Iran-Iraq war and the resulting attacks on oil tankers in the Persian Gulf. **********Supporters of the provision, led by Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committtee, argued that the proposal would force the White House and Congress to work to develop a national energy policy. Opponents said the proposal was a ''backdoor'' way to impose an oil import fee, which has been rejected overwhelmingly in the Senate the last two years. 'Plasma' of Economy **********''It's a straightforward response to one of the most urgent and important problems facing America today -our dangerous drift toward dependence on OPEC oil,'' Mr. Bentsen said, adding that ''oil is really the plasma of the American economy.'' **********Speaking against the plan, Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, called it ''special-interest legislation at its worst,'' adding: ''It seeks to prop up the domestic oil industry at the expense of everyone else. It's a backdoor way to ram through an oil import fee.'' **********Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, also opposed the Bentsen provision. He argued that most imported oil comes from countries that are not likely to cut off supplies, such as Mexico, Venezuela and Canada. And he said that the economic consequences - and increase in oil prices - would be the same if there were a disruption in the supply of oil, regardless of how much oil the country was importing. **********For Mr. Bentsen, the defeat was his first setback in managing the trade bill, which the Senate will continue debating next week, after the Fourth of July recess. He said that he was working on a new version of the proposals that he hoped would pick up more votes. Other Issues Unsettled **********Senate leaders hope to complete action on the trade bill next week. Among the major proposals still to be debated are a provision requiring notification of employees before plant closings and mandatory retaliation against unfair competition. **********Under the Bentsen proposal, the Administration would have had to set a ceiling of 50 percent or less of total consumption for imported oil. If oil-consumption projections prepared by the Administration showed that this ceiling would be exceeded within a three-year period, the President would have been required to submit to Congress a plan for reducing dependence on imports. **********The legislation did not set out what steps could be taken, but opponents argued that they would most likely be an oil import fee or oil import quotas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/20/busin.body_text: **********LESS than four years ago, William Dean Singleton had no newspapers and no money to speak of - only a yearning to own a newspaper chain. By the end of this year, if all goes according to plan, the newspaper chain the 36-year-old Texan runs will be worth an estimated $1.2 billion, with Mr. Singleton owning roughly one-third of that. **********Though he has been building his chain since 1984, Mr. Singleton marched into newspaper publishing's big league over the last 10 days with the announcements that Media News Group Inc., the umbrella corporation for his privately held group of papers, plans to pay $95 million for The Denver Post and $150 million for The Houston Post. It will add these two major dailies to its chain of nearly 60 newspapers, weeklies and dailies, including The Dallas Times Herald, which it bought last year for $110 million. **********Mr. Singleton either owns, or is committed to buying, 28 dailies and 28 weeklies from Connecticut to California. **********By combining his volcanic entrepreneurial drive and his tough management style with the financial clout of others, Mr. Singleton has now assembled one of the nation's largest newspaper groups. He has come a long way from his days as a poor boy in west Texas who went broke trying to found a newspaper chain when he was in his mid-20's. **********His partners, Richard B. Scudder, a third-generation New Jersey newspaper owner, and Media General, a communications conglomerate based in Richmond, have provided the cash. The only money Mr. Singleton has invested personally is the $200,000 he borrowed from Mr. Scudder in 1983 to start his chain, a loan he says he has not yet bothered to fully repay. **********Mr. Singleton has exhibited a voracious appetite for acquisition and a willingness to pay top dollar for newspapers. With the Houston and Denver papers, Media News, with total circulation of more than 1.3 million, will become the nation's 11th-largest newspaper group, according to Morton Research, which also figured the group's breakup value of $1.2 billion based on annual revenues it estimates at about $600 million. **********A man who works non-stop - a habit that cost him his first marriage - Mr. Singleton has emerged as one of this generation's premier newspaper empire builders. Among the nation's hungriest newspaper entrepreneurs, his biggest rival is Ralph Ingersoll Jr., a man of similar age and driving ambition, whose Princeton-based chain now has 38 dailies and 159 weeklies. Mr. Singleton unabashedly embraces the role of newspaper magnate. ''I want to die and at the funeral have a lot of people stand around and say, 'Dean Singleton built a hell of a newspaper company,' '' he said last week at his corporate headquarters at The Times Herald. He added that he also wants his papers to be good and that he will do all he can to encourage his son, William Dean Singleton Jr., now 18 months old, to run the company after him. **********His reputation of being one of the tightest, toughest managers in newspapers, holds little appeal for him, he said. His nightmare is for his mourners to say, ''God, that Dean Singleton, he sure knew how to make money - he made 40 percent,'' referring to the profit margin sometimes commanded by the smaller, monopoly newspapers that Mr. Singleton owns. **********Journalists and others in the newspaper industry have mixed feelings about Mr. Singleton and the papers that bear his mark. Some argue that he saves jobs by saving the newspapers themselves, and that his publications are as good as their markets allow. Others say his papers are editorially undistinguished and rarely reflect any priority beyond tight management aimed at insuring high profitability. But with his three recent big-daily purchases, Mr. Singleton has in a sense demonstrated that the assurance of big profits is not the only reason he will buy a newspaper. **********At a time when virtually all the big chains shun competitive markets, he is brazenly challenging the belief that it is financial folly to buy the second-ranked newspaper in a two-paper town. His papers in Dallas, Houston and Denver all trail their rivals in circulation and advertising market share, although he says only the last is a money-loser. **********Some newspaper analysts are skeptical that these papers can survive in the long term, arguing that Mr. Singleton is fighting some strong evidence that only one paper can prosper in even the largest cities. They point, for example, to Detroit's two dailies, which are among the nation's 10 largest, and are seeking Government permission to merge all non-editorial departments into a joint operating arrangement because they say they cannot be profitable independently. **********Aggravating the problem for Mr. Singleton is that Dallas, Houston and Denver are all economically depressed because of the flagging energy industry. He must generate cash from these local economies to pay for his papers, since his company has financed most of their combined $355 million purchase price with debt. **********But Mr. Singleton, who sleeps about five hours a night and who went back to work two hours after marrying his second wife, Adrienne Casale, is unperturbed. Though his face is cherubic and his nature personable, he has an enormous confidence in what he calls his ''killer instinct,'' an entrepreneurial drive for success that he strives to instill in his publishers. **********Despite his hope that he will leave a legacy that goes beyond the bottom line, once he runs a paper, his management code dictates that profitability must precede all. It is a lesson, he says, he learned the hard way.  An Entrepreneur at 8 **********Dean Singleton grew up in Graham, Tex., a small town 110 miles west of Dallas, whose fortunes waxed and waned with the price of oil. His father worked the oil rigs as a pumper, and there wasn't much money for the Singletons' five children. **********Mr. Singleton says his father - whom he spoke to almost daily until the older man's death in 1982 - always pushed him and loved to hear about his latest deal, though he wound up living in a different world from that of his son. ''The year he died, he bragged to me that for the first time in his life he'd made $20,000,'' Mr. Singleton said, with a bit of melancholy in his voice. **********Even at a young age, Mr. Singleton, the next-to-youngest in the family, was ''a little hyper,'' said Pat Robinson, his sister and, since last year, his secretary. His instincts were entrepreneurial, his dealmaking talents apparent. **********At 8, he was a chubby little boy who sold mail-order Christmas cards door-to-door. He remembers laboriously drafting a letter to the Cheerful Card Company in Scarsdale, N.Y., to persuade the company to extend him credit. Based on his letter, it did. **********The town of Graham was divided into the rich - cattle barons and old oil money - and the poor. Early on, Mr. Singleton noticed the difference. ''I always admired people who had a little more than I did,'' he said. **********At 14, he took a part-time job at The Graham News, one of the town's two twice-weekly papers. He started in the mailroom, though he was soon covering sports and city hall. **********But the person in town he most admired was Edward B. Harris, publisher of The Graham Leader, the rival weekly. ''He was the man in town because he owned the newspaper,'' Mr. Singleton recalled. **********Often, after finishing his work at The News at 3 A.M. on days of publication, Mr. Singleton would go to The Leader and talk for hours with Mr. Harris about his ambition to own a newspaper someday. (He bought The Leader from Mr. Harris last year.) His friendship with the older man was only the first of many such relationships for Mr. Singleton, who found little in common with his peers and who considers his 74-year-old partner, Mr. Scudder, to be his best friend. **********After three years at three different colleges, when he also worked full time at several newspapers, Mr. Singleton quit school and became a copy editor at The Dallas Morning News, the city's dominant paper and now Mr. Singeton's bitter rival. (See box) While at The Morning News, Mr. Singleton, then 21, was approached by Edwin M. Eakin, who invited him to run a weekly paper he wanted to start in Clarendon, a small town in west Texas. Mr. Eakin and his partner put up the $5,000 to finance the paper, and Mr. Singleton was offered half-ownership for operating it. He accepted, and the first issue of The Clarendon Press was printed in May 1972. **********Mr. Eakin remembers Mr. Singleton as very energetic, but also as a self-promoter. ''He can convince people he can go to the moon,'' he said. **********A few months after starting the Press, Mr. Singleton married a girl from an old Clarendon ranching family who never adjusted to Mr. Singleton's frenzied devotion to work. ''She didn't understand, and I wasn't going to change,'' he said. The couple divorced three years later. **********By then, Mr. Singleton had put Clarendon's other paper out of business, and had acquired a few other small papers, with his partners putting up the money. **********He also embarked on a venture that left him devastated and changed his life. **********In August 1975, with different partners providing the cash, Mr. Singleton tried to revive The Fort Worth Press, an afternoon tabloid that had recently been closed by its owners, Scripps-Howard. **********Mr. Singleton restarted it as a morning broadsheet paper, but by mid-October, the board of directors had ousted him as publisher in favor of his general manager, an older, more experienced man. Three weeks later, on Nov. 5, a date Mr. Singleton cites from memory, the paper closed. ''I had personally signed a lot of bank notes, and had to sell everything I had,'' he said.  Profits Come First **********The experience taught him what he considers to be the fundamental lesson of newspaper publishing: ''While your total dedication may be to the news product and causes you can fight, if you don't have a solid profit base, all else is meaningless.'' **********Feeling a failure, he nonetheless went looking for another paper to buy. He found one in Westfield, Mass., that was losing money. Joseph L. Allbritton, the entrepreneur who then owned The Washington Star and who wanted to acquire more papers, was also interested in the Westfield paper. Over lunch, the two men struck a deal: Mr. Allbritton would buy the newspaper, and Mr. Singleton would run it. **********Soon he was acquiring other papers for Mr. Allbritton. In fact, during the next eight years, Mr. Singleton was the hungry and apt student of Mr. Allbritton, whom he describes as his mentor. ''I worshipped the ground he walked on,'' Mr. Singleton said. ''He was tough, tough as nails, but a gentleman,'' and superb at figuring out creative deals. **********It was during this time that Mr. Singleton, in his late 20's, began to earn a reputation as a henchman for Mr. Allbritton and a union-buster - because, he says, Allbritton Communications acquired unprofitable newspapers that needed severe cuts to become profitable. **********When production unions struck the Allbritton paper in Paterson, N.J., Mr. Singleton immediately replaced union workers, and most of the strikers lost their jobs permanently. **********At The Trenton Times, which Allbritton Communications bought from the Washington Post Company in 1981, he slashed the staff by a third. **********He also created a flap when he dismissed a Times business reporter who, when asked to limit an article about an advertiser to its press release, added unfavorable information about the company. At the time, Mr. Singleton was quoted as saying, ''We don't have a situation where the newsroom is autonomous.'' He denied, however, that advertisers controlled news coverage, and said the reporter was fired for ''insubordination.'' **********Though Mr. Singleton said he sometimes throws up after announcing the layoffs that often have accompanied his proprietorship of a newspaper, he always makes the necessary cuts. **********The cuts at The Trenton Times did not provoke a strike, he added, because the bitter Paterson strike had demonstrated how tough he could be. **********Drastic action was needed at The Times, he said. The money-losing paper ''was a journalistic masterpiece in many ways,'' but too weighty for Trenton and too fat to make money. **********To compete better with the Trentonian - the town's leading paper, owned by Ralph Ingersoll - Mr. Singleton went beyond job cuts, ordering lots of short articles, flashier design and a local focus. He also came up with advertising discount plans to lift revenues. **********The result: As with other papers Mr. Singleton has managed since his Fort Worth debacle, red ink turned to profits. As a lagging paper in a two-paper town, The Trenton Times served as a kind of laboratory for Mr. Singleton, who now faces that situation with his three biggest papers.  A Paper of One's Own **********By 1983, Mr. Singleton was itching to own papers himself, and when Mr. Allbritton declined to make him a partner - ''Joe Allbritton never has partners,'' said Mr. Singleton - he forged an alliance with Mr. Scudder and struck out on his own. Mr. Scudder had been publisher of The Newark News, his family's paper, and had also founded the Garden State Paper Company, a newsprint manufacturing company. **********Characteristically, Mr. Singleton first met Mr. Scudder over a deal: When it was acquired, The Paterson paper owed Garden State for newsprint, and Mr. Scudder threatened to cut the paper off unless the new owners paid the debt. But, Mr. Scudder said, Mr. Singleton persuaded him ''to keep shipping paper, and for every ton shipped, he would pay for one-and-one-third tons.'' Soon the two men had a standing Friday lunch date.  Mr. Scudder, who had sold his paper and paper company to Media General in 1970 - though he continued to manage them for a while - had some cash. And in late 1983, he and Mr. Singleton formed Gloucester County Times Inc. and acquired The Gloucester County Times, a daily in Woodbury, N.J., with a circulation of about 26,000. **********Mr. Scudder lent the new company $2.5 million, and put up $300,000 for his 60 percent equity of the company. He also lent Mr. Singleton the $200,000 he needed to acquire his 40 percent stake. Neither man has ever had to put any more personal money into the business, according to Mr. Scudder. **********The company borrowed the rest of the $10.5 million for The Times from Rhode Island Hospital Trust, a Providence bank later acquired by the Bank of Boston. The two banks have remained the principal lenders to the chain. **********Mr. Singleton quickly demonstrated that he could run his own daily. ''In two years, The Gloucester Times tripled its cash flow,'' to about $2.5 million, Mr. Scudder said. The new partnership also quickly acquired several other papers, all with money from friendly bankers. **********Along the way, Mr. Singleton married a second time, and though he wedged the ceremony between deals, he says he loves his understanding wife, his child and his business equally, which he considers the highest accolade. **********By this time, Mr. Singleton and Mr. Scudder realized that, even with good profits, their credit would not be great enough to build the major chain of which Mr. Singleton dreamed. **********So in 1985 they created another company, Garden State Newspapers Inc., with Media General as a partner. Media General agreed to provide all the cash for down payments on newspaper acquisitions - usually 20 to 30 percent of the purchase price - in exchange of 40 percent of the ownership of the papers. Mr. Scudder and Mr. Singleton equally divided the remaining 60 percent. **********They also formed Media News, an operating company that managed all of the papers, with Mr. Scudder as chairman of all three corporations and Mr. Singleton as president. **********With Media General's financial power behind him, Mr. Singleton began buying papers furiously. In 1986, he acquired 35 dailies and non-dailies, many of them from Harte-Hanks Communications, a media conglomerate. In fact, he has acquired most of his papers from other chains. **********But it was with the purchase of The Times Herald in September 1986 that Mr. Singleton began to be recognized as a significant player among newspaper entrepreneurs. **********When he acquired The Times Herald from the Los Angeles-based Times Mirror Company, the paper had become unprofitable after years of a bruising and expensive newspaper war. Media General, which has first refusal on all of Mr. Singleton's acquisitions, decided not to be a partner in this one because, as a public company under pressure to keep earnings at a maximum, it felt the No. 2 paper in Dallas was too risky. **********Instead, Mr. Scudder and Mr. Singleton bought the paper through Gloucester County Times, their other partnership. Of the $110 million purchase price, Gloucester County put up $20 million in cash and borrowed $30 million from banks. Times Mirror, the seller, financed the remaining $60 million, with no interest or principal to be paid for four years, according to a source close to the transaction who asked not to be identified. **********Times Mirror agreed to similarly generous terms in its agreement to sell The Denver Post for $95 million, but this time Media General was a partner. **********Media General provided $25 million to Garden State, to be used for the down payment, with Times Mirror financing the rest. John Morton, of Morton Research, characterized the deal as very good for Mr. Singleton, because he will be getting a $56 million plant, 45 acres of land near Denver and highly favorable financing terms from Times Mirror. The terms are so good, he says, that he estimates the low-cost loan effectively lowers the price by about $25 million. **********Media General will have an option on 40 percent ownership for its $25 million. Mr. Singleton said that about $20 million more would be needed to acquire presses, and that the money would come from Garden State's earnings. **********Mr. Scudder and Mr. Singleton will acquire The Houston Post from the Toronto Sun Publishing Company through Gloucester Times, financing nearly all of the $150 million price with bank debt - Mr. Singleton says he has never had to use high-yield, high-risk junk bonds to raise money.  'Warm and Fuzzy' **********The Toronto Sun had sought bids for The Post, and accepted Mr. Singleton's proposal. His proposal did not offer the most ready cash - instead, Mr. Singleton agreed to pay the Post's owners a sum equivalent to 1.25 times the increase in annual revenues in 1992 over that of 1987. **********''Pretty creative, wasn't it?'' Mr. Singleton said, with the delight of a man who acknowledges that dealmaking makes his heart jump. **********Even with the new acquisitions, Mr. Singleton says there is more than enough money to pay the interest on the loans. Mr. Morton estimates that Media News's annual cash flow, the money available to pay down the debt, is between $80 million and $90 million. Mr. Singleton says that the company's cash flow-to-debt ratio will remain near its present level of between 5:1 and 6:1. But Mr. Singleton still has to make his No. 2 papers successful. In Dallas, he commissioned a survey - which he plans to do in Houston and Denver - and decided that The Times Herald was too much like The Morning News, the city's newspaper of record. **********Mr. Singleton also hired David Burgin, a man respected for journalistic creativity and reknowned for a volatile nature. Mr. Burgin had been Mr. Singleton's editor in Paterson before going on to larger papers. Mr. Singleton once fired him in Paterson, after an argument in which Mr. Singleton insisted that a story on the Middle East did not belong on the front page. He said, ''Damn it, we don't sell any papers in Cairo,'' Mr. Burgin recalled. Mr. Singleton quickly rehired Mr. Burgin. **********Mr. Singleton still gives strong policy guidance, though he said he does not interfere with day-to-day decisions. Though he sits on The Times Herald's editorial board, he has one vote, and yields to the majority, even in political endorsements when his more conservative choices are sometimes overruled. **********At Mr. Singleton's direction, Mr. Burgin said, the new Times Herald has tried to become ''more warm and fuzzy'' with a ''heavy dose of stories that are emotional, practical, and analytical.'' Mr. Burgin's first move was to frame the nameplate on page one with flags of Texas and the United States. He also added a cheery ''Good Morning'' to the front page. **********Mr. Singleton cut the news staff to about 250 from 320, and eliminated bureaus in El Paso, Tyler, and Lubbock, as well as New York. The Sunday magazine also went, along with expensive weekly fashion and society sections that were printed on high-quality newsprint. **********As a result of these and other economies, Mr. Singleton says, The Times Herald is once again making a profit. Its coverage, he claims, now suits all but the most upscale reader better than before. While staff members say the breadth of coverage may have suffered, the paper competes with a sort of guerrilla journalism, with scoops that editors at the more conservative Morning News say they find questionable in some cases. For instance, when the Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation began their investigation of fraud and corruption in thrift institutions in Texas last month, The Times Herald published the names of all those subpoenaed. **********But The Times Herald still dramatically trails The Morning News in advertising and circulation, and such gaps in other cities have led to dizzying declines for the weaker paper. **********At The Houston Post, which is profitable, Mr. Singleton has the advantage of having a sophisticated printing facility and the morning slot, although his rival, The Houston Chronicle, has a commanding advertising and circulation lead. The Post is also far leaner than The Times Herald, giving Mr. Singleton less room to cut expenses. **********The Denver Post leads The Rocky Mountain News in Sunday circulation, but trails during the week.
