The two papers are also quite close in advertising share, but The Post is losing money. Mr. Singleton says that, despite recent layoffs by Times Mirror there, he still thinks the paper has room for significant economies. **********To Mr. Singleton, the Dallas, Houston, and Denver acquisitions make sense because the markets have traditionally been dynamic. He is confident they will be so again. And, he says, none has significant competition from suburban papers, which makes more room for two papers.  Joining the Club **********As Mr. Singleton surveys the future, he sees a growing - but not a public - company. He says he has no intention of taking his company public, given the attendant pressure for high earnings every quarter and the scrutiny of analysts. **********Mr. Singleton now is molding himself to fit comfortably in the courtly, small world of newspaper publishing, which is often compared to a gentleman's club. **********His goal, says this toweringly ambitious and competitive man, is to behave like a gentleman. For instance, even though his partners need him more than he needs them now, he says, he will not seek to alter the arrangement to his advantage. **********Even being the No. 1 paper in Dallas, Houston and Denver, while nice, is not essential. ''I'm not going to hang my head if I'm a strong No. 2,'' he said.  TAKING CIRCULATIONTO COURT **********IN Dallas, the rivalry between The Times Herald and The Dallas Morning News has long been fierce. Now it has turned ugly. **********In November 1986, two months after Dean Singleton took over The Times Herald, he filed suit in Federal court against The Morning News, charging it with fraudulently padding its circulation records and seeking damages for advertising lost because of the alleged misrepresentations. **********''I've never seen the arrogance of it,'' said Mr. Singleton of The Morning News and the A.H. Belo Company, its parent. **********Soon after, The Morning News filed a countersuit, charging similar circulation fraud by The Times Herald, and branding Mr. Singleton's lawsuit a gimmick to discredit The News and gain market advantage. Both papers have denied wrongdoing. The Morning News has shown steady circulation gains in recent years, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. Mr. Singleton has also sued the A.B.C., charging that the bureau, aware of Morning News circulation irregularities, did not stop the paper from publishing those figures. **********According to Mr. Singleton, the dispute began when Morning News circulation employees approached the Times Herald, claiming they were disturbed by circulation irregularities at their newspaper. Mr. Singleton instructed his law firm, Baker & Hostetler of Cleveland, to investigate and its report - citing allegations of inflated circulation numbers - was presented to the A.B.C. **********The Times Herald reported some of those allegations on its front page in October, prompting an investigation by Texas Attorney General Jim Mattox. He eventually served notice on The Morning News that he was considering bringing charges of deceptive trade practices against the paper, which Morning News executives branded political opportunism. Mr. Mattox's action now awaits an audit of both papers by the A.B.C., expected by Christmas. **********Last month, The Times Herald charged a junior Morning News circulation manager with perjury in depositions for the Federal suits. The Morning News has reprimanded the circulation manager, but Morning News executive vice president Jeremy Halbreich said the incident was ''absolutely not representative of a pattern.'' **********''Our circulation numbers are very solid and will hold up under anyone's scrutiny,'' he said. **********Unaudited publishers' reports issued by the A.B.C. for the six months ended September 1986 claimed the Morning News had a daily circulation of 391,000 and 531,000 on Sundays; The Times Herald had daily circulation of 246,000 and 339,000 on Sundays.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/20/busin.body_text: **********The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said today that it lost $18.3 million in the fourth quarter, coming back from a $107.8 million deficit a year earlier. **********The latest net loss included an after-tax loss from continuing operations of $38.9 million, and $20.6 million in net income from discontinued lines. A year earlier, the loss from ongoing operations totaled $110 million, and the company earned $2.2 million from discontinued operations. **********Fourth-quarter sales rose 6.3 percent, to $544.6 million from $512.5 million, Kaiser Aluminum said. **********For the full year, Kaiser Aluminum lost $32.7 million, down from a loss of $186.5 million in 1985. **********Annual sales rose 9.4 percent, to $2.22 billion from $2.03 billion. **********Kaiser Aluminum recently reached an agreement with Alan Clore, a British investor and leader of an investor group that owns 30 percent of Kaiser Aluminum, under which Mr. Clore would gain control of the company in return for a $140 million cash infusion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/22/world.print_headline: MEXICO TO BAN SALE OF BLOOD
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/22/world.body_text: **********The Mexican Government announced today that it would prohibit all commercial dealings in blood and blood byproducts, saying the rapid spread of AIDS among the Mexican population made the measure ''urgent and imperative.'' **********Health Minister Guillermo Soberon said the number of AIDS cases discovered so far in Mexico ''is few in relation to other countries.'' But he said ''the character of the disease obliges us to take measures of a preventive nature'' before conditions worsened. **********As of April 1, there were 407 ''clinically proven'' cases of AIDS reported in Mexico, but Government estimates made public at a news conference here today said that figure was likely to climb to more than 32,000 by 1991. **********The measure will affect 110 private blood banks, many of them operating along the northern border with the United States. The selling of blood has sometimes been a source of income for poor Mexicans, including many seeking to cross illegally into the United States. **********Health officials said the commercial blood banks would be allowed to continue operating only if they turned to voluntary blood donations, The practical effect of that decision will be to close many of the banks. **********Jaime Sepulveda Amor, a Health Ministry official, said the measure was being taken because Government studies had determined ''that the donation of blood for money has a close association with an extremely high risk of positive results'' in tests for the presence of the AIDS virus antibodies. **********AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, is an incurable disease that cripples the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and some cancers. It is caused by a virus spread through sexual intercourse or exchanges of blood. **********The presence of AIDS antibodies in blood means that a person is infected with the AIDS virus; it does not tell whether that person will go on to develop the fatal disease, but the blood is presumed infectious. **********Another Health Ministry official, Jose Luis Dominguez Torix, said Mexican law ''prohibits the export of blood and related products.'' For that reason, he added, ''we have no reason to believe there is any kind of traffic or commerce in blood'' to the United States or other countries. **********Nevertheless, there have been press reports over the years of a black market in Mexican blood.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/07/world.main_headline: SENATE TO SET UP IRAN INQUIRY PANEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/07/world.print_headline: SENATE TO SET UP IRAN INQUIRY PANEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/07/world.body_text: **********Without significant partisan rancor, the Senate voted 88 to 4 today to create a special committee to investigate the Iran-contra arms affair. **********The House of Representatives, meanwhile, unanimously took the first step toward setting up a companion committee. A House vote on the matter was scheduled for Wednesday. **********At the Justice Department today, officials agreed to turn over responsibility to the independent counsel, Lawrence E. Walsh, for any current investigations he considers necessary for his inquiry. **********Party leaders in the Senate continued to disagree over the decision by the Senate Intelligence Committee on Monday night not to make public the findings of its three-week investigation last month into the arms sale to Iran and the diversion of funds to the Nicaraguan rebels. **********But Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, consented to an arrangement under which the Intelligence Committee would turn over its findings and a list of unresolved questions to the new select committee. The select committee was given the authority to make public whatever parts of the Intelligence Committee report it felt should be disclosed in the ''public interest.'' Damage to Presidency Feared **********The actions today left open the question of whether the Congressional investigations, which are expected to take most of the year, would be conducted in a bipartisan fashion. **********The four senators who voted against the creation of the select committee were Jesse Helms of North Carolina, Chic Hecht of Nevada and Gordon J. Humphrey of New Hampshire, all Republicans, and Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, a Democrat. **********The three Republicans argued that an extended investigation would be damaging to the Presidency and to American foreign policy. Senator Hollings contended that the entire matter could be cleared up without an investigation if President Reagan would come forward and tell all he knew. **********The agreement on the scope of the special prosecutor's inquiry was reached today at a meeting between Mr. Walsh and senior Justice Department officials. 'He Was Shown the Store' **********Reagan Administration officials said that the officials, including Associate Attorney General Stephen S. Trott, told Mr. Walsh that they would turn over any Justice Department investigation involving Iran arms smuggling, support for the contras, or both. **********''Everything was made available to him,'' one Federal law-enforcement official said. ''Anything he wants, he gets. He was shown the store and told he can take anything off the shelf that he wants.'' **********In a court order announcing his appointment, Mr. Walsh, a former Deputy Attorney General, was given power to investigate not only the links between Iran arms sales and the contras, but also any illegal financing for the contras since 1984. **********As a result, Government officials have said that Mr. Walsh was expected to take over at least three Justice Department investigations involving contra financing, including a year-old inquiry now being handled by the United States Attorney's office in Miami. **********Senator Dole, a likely candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, appeared eager today to dispel any notion that he might be trying to exonerate President Reagan prematurely in the Iran-contra affair. Bipartisan Effort Needed **********''It is necessary that we start off on a totally nonpartisan, bipartisan basis,'' the Kansas Senator said in his opening remarks to the Senate as the new Congress convened. **********On the other hand, Mr. Dole said, a good deal of information is already available to Congress because of the Intelligence Committee's investigation. ''The President of the United States,'' he added, ''is entitled to have that made public at the earliest possible date.'' **********''We may never have all the facts,'' Mr. Dole said. At the same time, Senator Dole said the Iran affair should not dominate the new Congress. ''There are too many other problems, domestic and foreign, that are not going to go away,'' he said. ''They cannot, and should not, be swept aside because of an obsession with the Iranian affair.'' **********At Senator Dole's suggestion, the target date for completion of the Senate investigation was moved forward to Aug. 1 from Oct. 30. But procedures were aproved that would allow the Senate to vote later to extend the investigation until the end of October. Restoring Public Trust **********Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Democratic leader, also attempted to put forth a bipartisan air. **********In his opening statement to the Senate, Senator Byrd said that ''the Iran misadventure has hurt the Presidency,'' and he added, ''Our first duty in this new Congress is the restoration of public trust in the formulation of American foreign policy.'' **********Mr. Byrd went on to say he had ''every faith'' that the Senate investigation would be conducted ''in a statesmanlike and bipartisan fashion.'' **********Mr. Byrd said he objected to making public the Intelligence Committee's findings now because that panel's report was ''filled with gaps'' and had been ''sanitized'' by the White House. **********He said that ''as of now'' he knew of no evidence that President Reagan had broken any law. But he added, ''Nobody is served by making available to the public part of the record.'' 'Devastating Effect' Is Seen **********One of the Republicans who opposed creation of the committee, Senator Hecht, said it would allow the controversy to ''drag on and on and on into the next year.'' **********That, Mr. Hecht said, would have a ''devastating effect on present and future intelligence operations around the world.'' **********But most senators who spoke today expressed confidence in Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, who was named chairman, and Senator Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire, the vice chairman. **********Mr. Inouye promised a careful investigation today and said he had reached an arrangement with the chairman of the House select committee, Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, to share information and avoid a ''situation where each side is trying to outdo the other, rushing for headlines.'' **********The two panels, he said, will alternate hearings, with one committee in session one week and the other holding hearings the next. The hearings may begin as soon as next month. **********For his part, Senator Rudman also promised a ''fair, thorough, bipartisan, careful inquiry.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/01/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices plunged yesterday amid continuing concern over the apparently unbridled fall in the dollar. **********The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 76.93 points, to 1,833.55, or 4.03 percent. While that was the Dow's eighth-biggest point loss ever, it represented a slight comeback from midsession, when the Dow was off by more than 110 points. **********At that time, when the Dow fell briefly below 1,800, traders began recalling other recent Mondays, particularly Oct. 19, when the Dow plunged an unprecedented 508 points, and Oct. 26, when it fell 156.83. Treasury Securities Bought **********With yesterday's drop, the Dow lost 159.98 points for November. The 30-stock blue-chip index now stands 888.87 points, or 32.6 percent, below its record high of 2,722.42 reached last Aug. 25. And the Dow is just 94.81 points above the Oct. 19 closing level of 1,738.74. **********As stock prices tumbled yesterday, worried investors flocked into fixed-income investments, pushing up the price of Treasury securities, especially short-term issues, in a ''flight to quality.''  [ Page D19. ]  Gold prices also rose, to their highest levels since 1983, as many investors also scurried into that traditional safe haven. But while many gold and silver mining issues at first bucked the Wall Street trend, they, too, were sold off in the general rout of stocks. **********''Nobody wanted stocks at all,'' said Bernard Spilko, managing director of Bank Julius Baer. **********Yesterday's stock selloff was broad, particularly in the early going. Traders in New York got little comfort from the Asian stock markets, which closed sharply lower before Wall Street opened. At one point on the New York Stock Exchange, 25 stocks were down for every advancing issue. Not one Dow stock managed a gain. No Panic Selling **********But despite the inevitable comparisons, there was none of the panic selling that characterized some recent Mondays. Trading was heavy, especially when compared with the moribund level of late last week, when many traders and investors took off Wednesday and Friday to stretch out the Thanksgiving holiday. **********While a hefty 268.9 million shares changed hands on the Big Board yesterday, that figure was misleading. More than 61 million shares of that volume was in only five utility stocks - Ohio Edison, Texas Utilities, Union Electric, Detroit Edison and Pacific Gas and Electric. Those stocks were traded by big institutions as part of specialized strategies designed to capture dividends. **********Some market experts said that a bad day for Wall Street was probably inevitable yesterday. Indeed, many analysts said on Friday that it was a strong possibility, citing the inflation concerns raised by recent rises in commodity prices and the uncertainty generated by a falling dollar. **********So when the dollar fell in European and United States trading, after plummeting to a new low in Tokyo, stock traders in New York braced themselves. **********Mr. Spilko, whose bank is the securities arm of the big Swiss banking house, said, ''You need to have a stable dollar.'' He said that foreign investors, particularly the Japanese, were loath to buy stocks in the United States while the dollar eroded, making their investments worth less after currency translation. Confidence Erodes **********The Federal budget-cutting accord reached recently in Washington between the White House and Congress had firmed the dollar somewhat. But market experts said that the confidence of the currency and stock markets started to erode last week with the realization that it might be some time before Congress voted on the package. **********Noting that many foreign investors had lost heavily during the dollar's slide, Mr. Spilko said: ''And now we're asking them to invest more. Who would put money up?'' ''I feel that there will be a stable dollar,'' Mr. Spilko said. ''I feel that confidence will be restored.'' But he added that Wall Street might be in ''for a tough couple of days'' because yesterday's selling might precipitate a new round of margin selling and mutual fund redemptions. Moreover, he added, the Dow's performance yesterday was ''psychologically disappointing.'' **********In Asian markets, stocks sagged badly yesterday. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Nikkei index of 225 blue-chip stocks fell 365.45 points, to 22,686.78, and in Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index fell 55.79 points yesterday, to 2,138.39. In Tokyo, traders said that, while the loss itself was not so large, the fact that stock volume was comparatively light indicated bearish sentiment. Program Trading a Factor **********The Dow's latest rout was worsened by program trading in the morning. When brokers noted that stock index futures contracts opened the day at wide discounts to cash stock prices, they predicted the Dow would drop 50 points, which turned out to be conservative. Program traders bought the ''undervalued'' futures and sold actual stocks to lock in so-called riskless profits. **********''There was a continuation from Friday, when discounts widened,'' said Donald M. Selkin, head of stock index futures research at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''The programs came late Friday and early today.'' **********Program trading, in which arbitragers and others try to profit from unusual disparities that arise between the value of stocks and the value of the futures contracts that are tied to certain stock indexes, was temporarily banned after the big stock selloffs that started on Oct. 19. But now they are unrestricted. ''I don't know if that's what the market needs,'' Mr. Selkin stated. **********Stock prices fell sharply in the over-the-counter market, although a late rally there trimmed most 3- and 4-point losses to only 1 or 2 points. **********''The whole market is beat up, across the board,'' one O-T-C trader said in midsession. ''The rest of the world doesn't think we're serious about budget cutting.'' **********Some analysts said they were concerned by certain technical indications in the stock market. For example, last week the stock market broke with tradition and closed sharply lower on the day after Thansgiving -breaking a 22-year string of gains. **********And the 33.29-point drop in the Dow transportation average yesterday, to 695.14, was seen by some as a sign that the cyclical rail and air stocks were ''predicting'' a recession. Big Board Composite Off 5.47 **********On the Big Board yesterday, the composite index fell 5.47 points, to 129.69, and the S.&P. 500-stock index dropped 10.04, to 230.30. At the close, 1,576 stocks were down, and only 201 up. **********Among the blue chips, I.B.M. lost 4 1/8, to 110 3/4; Digital 6 1/2, to 119; Merck 5 1/2, to 170; General Motors 2 1/8, to 56 3/8; Du Pont 3 3/8, to 78 1/8, and Phelps Dodge 4 7/8, to 40. Elsewhere, CBS lost 9, to 155 3/8.  Brokerage stocks were very weak. Merrill Lynch lost 2, to 20 1/2.  Even Paine Webber Group fell 2 1/8, to 16 1/2, despite the company's announcement that it had agreed to sell an equity stake of up to 25 percent to Yasuda Mutual Life Insurance, one of Japan's biggest life insurance concerns. **********The Nasdaq composite index of O-T-C stocks fell 11.31, to 305.16, and the American Stock Exchange's market-value index declined 8.58, to 242.39.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/17/world.main_headline: New Attitude of Arabs a Challenge, Eban Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/17/world.print_headline: New Attitude of Arabs a Challenge, Eban Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/17/world.body_text: **********Abba Eban, the former Foreign Minister, says Israel is failing to understand, or take advantage of, a revolutionary change in the Arab world. **********In an interview today on the eve of the 10th anniversary of Anwar el-Sadat's visit to Jerusalem, Mr. Eban asserted that it was a ''tragedy'' that at a time when the Arab world appears increasingly willing to come to terms with Israel, a deadlocked national unity Government is keeping the country from recognizing or exploiting the opportunity. **********''We have gotten so used to the idea that the Arabs were immobilized and frozen in their antipathy to Israel that when they do finally change we do not know how to take 'yes' for an answer,'' said Mr. Eban, a member of the Labor Party and chairman of the Parliament's Defense and Foreign Affairs Committee. Restoration of Relations **********Mr. Eban pointed to the Arab League summit meeting last week in Amman as the best indication yet that the Arabs ''may be on their way to changing their struggle with Israel from one about legitimacy to a pragmatic argument about interests and territory.'' The meeting, he said, cleared the way for a restoration of relations between Arab countries and an Egyptian Government that has diplomatic relations with Israel and approved the idea of an international Middle East peace conference. **********The Arab summit meeting resolutions were also important symbolically, said Mr. Eban, because they referred to the ''Arab-Israel'' conflict, using the sovereign term for Israel and not the old language of ''Zionist entity.'' They also placed the threat from Israel as secondary to that from Iran. **********''All of this does not mean the Arab-Israel conflict will be easy to solve, but it does mean that there is an opportunity,'' Mr. Eban added. ''We should look at Sadat's visit to Israel a decade ago as the beginning of something and the Amman summit meeting as the continuation of it.'' Israelis Misread Arabs **********As examples of an Israeli failure to read changes in the Arab world, he cited Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's rejection of an international peace conference, and the insistence of other ministers that Israel should support Iran in the gulf war because the Khomeini revolution is only ''temporary.'' **********''The notion that Khomeini is a passing episode is nonsense,'' Mr. Eban said. ''Those who have studied the history of Iran would be more inclined to believe that it was the Shah's regime which was the passing episode.'' **********Mr. Eban argued that Israel's support for the Maronite Catholics in Lebanon, its decision to sell arms to the so-called pro-Western ''moderates'' in Iran and its ability to ignore the meaning of the Amman Arab summit meeting, which most Israeli officials did, are all rooted in the same outlook. **********Israel, he explained, has historically lived in a very isolated state from its immediate neighbors. He said it made Israelis very vulnerable to offers from anyone in this hostile neighborhood who ''winked'' at them, such as the Maronites or the so-called moderates in Iran. He said that when the Iranians or Maronites approached Israeli officials and said that with a little Israeli help they could reverse the tide of history in their respective countries, and make them more pro-Israeli, normally savvy and sober Israelis bought it. **********The isolation, he continued, has also prompted Israel to look for friends outside its immediate neighborhood to the non-Arab and sometimes non-Moslem nations on the periphery of the Middle East, such as Iran, Ethiopia and Turkey. **********''The result was an Israeli tendency to say that in any confrontation between an Arab and a non-Arab, we must support the non-Arab,'' Mr. Eban said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/01/world.main_headline: Uprising Casts a Shadow on Philippine Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/01/world.print_headline: Uprising Casts a Shadow on Philippine Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/01/world.body_text: **********A week ago, the economic news in the Philippines was good. **********In the first six months of this year, the country's growth rate rose to 5 percent and the stock market was on the upswing. Investment, the key to a sustained recovery, was also climbing. **********Today, financial markets reopened for the first time after a military rebellion Friday - a revolt that had followed a leftist-inspired general strike two days earlier. And it was evident that much of what the administration of President Corazon C. Aquino had achieved was thrown into confusion. **********Economic growth is crucial to the political stability of the Philippines. This is particularly true in rural areas, where the Communist New People's Army looks for recruits, and where Government-sponsored development programs had just begun to work. Too Early to Judge **********Diplomats, economists and Government officials say it is too early to make a judgment on the long-term economic effects of the latest attempted coup, led by a disgruntled colonel with few if any apparent policies of his own beyond an aversion to politics and a preference for military rule. **********''I am still bullish,'' Jose Concepcion, Minister of Trade and Industry, said today in an interview. ''There might be a temporary review of the situation by some investors. But the President has certainly sent a clear signal not only to foreign investors but also to domestic businesses, and to the army, that she is Commander in Chief.'' **********He told a tale of a Australian investment team who happened to arrive in the southern city of Davao when the radio station was blown up and then made it into Manila in time for the street battles Friday. After all that, he said, they turned up in his office asking how they could speed up their proposed deal. **********But today, stocks that had risen on aggregate by 4 to 5 percent in value last week dropped across the board on the Manila and Makati stock exchanges by 3.9 percent, nearly erasing the recent gains. G.N.P. Prediction Lowered **********Effects on investment and economic growth will take more time to measure, although hopes of 6.5 percent increase in gross national product this year are already being scaled back to about 5.8 percent, The Business Chronicle, a Manila newspaper, reported today. **********Investment, foreign and domestic, is considered by many to be the key factor in determining whether the Philippines can hold on to the place it was beginning to achieve among the faster-growing countries of Southeast Asia. **********Foreign economic analysts point out that the growth rate reached by Manila in the first six months of this year puts it in a league with Singapore and Thailand, and ahead of Malaysia and Indonesia. Those countries are all partners in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. **********The construction industry has boomed, with cement plants running at capacity and imports required for the first time in many years. The city of Manila has begun to take on a slightly more upbeat air, as long-delayed improvements are made. Several Rural Projects **********In the countryside, diplomats say, Government-sponsored work projects have created jobs while building needed roads, bridges and other structures that enhance rural life. **********Mr. Concepcion said that People's Economic Councils were beginning to operate at the province level, advising the national Government of local needs. Small industries were beginning to be established. **********Diplomats and foreign economic analysts say that rising commodity prices have also contributed to improved conditions, often measured here by increased consumer demand. **********For instance, the price of copra, dried coconut meat, has doubled in the last year, with most of the profit going to farmers, a diplomat said. Under President Ferdinand E. Marcos, crony monopolies would have reaped the rewards, many here say. Major Problems Remain **********There are still major problems facing the rural economy, however. With land redistribution now bogged down in Congress, farmers are finding that agricultural development loans have dried up, as banks anticipate the breakup of holdings larger than 15 or 20 acres. **********Despite record foreign and domestic investment figures for July - an increase of more than 1,000 percent from the year before, Mr. Concepcion says - cash is not flowing into rural or urban areas at the rate economists had hoped. The economic revivial has been almost entirely fueled by consumer demand. **********To further complicate the outlook, there have been calls in the newly elected legislature for a selective repudiation of the Philippines' international debt, now about $27 billion. **********But trends are positive in industrial centers, Mr. Concepcion said, with the 40 percent plant utilization of a year ago increased to 90 percent or more now. He said the textile industry, with plants going seven days a week, could absorb a billion dollars in investment at this point. Toys and electronics are also growing sectors, he said. Some Existing Benefits **********The Philippines, if finally free of political tensions, could benefit from several factors, officials and foreign economists say. The work force appeals to Western nations because it is easy to train and English-speaking. **********Diplomats and other analysts also suggest that coups do not necessarily drive investors away, as Thailand, with more than a dozen coups or coup attempts, has demonstrated in the last 20 years. The deciding factor, they say, is whether these outbreaks threaten the country's basic policy directions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/10/busin.body_text: **********The stock market held its recently gained ground yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average adding 1.06 points to close at 2,352.70. Airline and semiconductor issues were strong. **********On Monday the Dow gained 25.49, and the key blue-chip indicator, which has been moving higher, is within striking distance of its 2,405.54-point high set on April 6. Volume picked up a bit, as did optimism among some traders and analysts. **********In recent weeks, market watchers have pointed at the relatively modest volume as a sign of investor uncertainty. Big institutional investors, they said, are obviously on the sidelines. **********But more traders and analysts now say the stock market is poised for a sharp move higher, because the lack of volume has not been accompanied by any real erosion in stock prices. Normally, they argue, the stock market tends to trend downward when trading slows - and it has not. **********''I hate this market, but you can't fight it,'' one trader said. ''I can see the Dow popping 50 or 60 points higher from here.'' Transportation Index Up **********The Dow transportation index continued its climb yesterday, rising 11.92 points, to a record 1.013.34. The Big Board's composite index was up 0.25, at 167.38, and the S.&P. 500-stock index gained 0.56, to 297.28. **********Jack Salomon, a technical analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company, suggested that the continuing surge in the transportation average, bolstered by higher airline fares, is a sign that the overall market - and the Dow industrials - may be headed higher. **********''By virtue of its composition, the transportation index usually anticipates an improvement in the economy, as reflected in the movement of goods and services,'' Mr. Salomon said. ''The Dow transportation made a new high, and everybody is waiting to see if the industrials will confirm it.'' Institutional Money Expected **********Other market experts noted that with interest rates and the dollar holding fairly steady - and little in the way of jolting news expected from the economic summit in Venice - institutional money may now start coming into the market. **********''This market is putting beads of sweat on the brows of institutional money managers who are sitting on big piles of cash,'' commented a major stock trader who deals with many money managers. ''They are scared they will lose clients to the index funds.'' **********The trader, who asked not to be identified said the money managers may thus start buying stocks. If they do, he predicted, they will concentrate on big capitalization stocks, including, perhaps, the oils, which offer liquidity ''so that they can get out easily.'' **********Other analysts, however, say that big investors may still act cautiously ahead of the figures on the American trade deficit that are due Friday. **********Yesterday, advancing issues outpaced decliners by about 8 to 7 on the Big Board, with 848 issues advancing and 712 declining. Volume moved up; 164.2 million shares changed hands, compared with 136.4 million Monday. **********The surging transportation stocks were led by AMR, which added 1 3/8, to 59 1/2; Delta, which gained 1 1/8, to 57 1/8; NWA, up 1 1/8, to 71 1/4. But the sector was up across the board, as analysts started raising earnings estimates based on fare increases. Texas Instruments Up 6 **********An industry report indicating robust orders spurred the semiconductor stocks. On the Big Board, Texas Instruments jumped 6, to 175 3/4; Motorola added 1 1/8, to 54 3/4, and National Semiconductor gained 5/8, to 13 5/8. In over-the-counter trading, Intel gained 2, to 43 1/4, and Xicor added 1, to 12 1/2. **********Dayton Hudson advanced 1 7/8, to 52 1/4, in heavy trading amid rumors of a possible bid for the retail chain. **********Among other actively traded issues, Pacific Gas and Electric, which went ex-dividend, was down 1/8, at 20 1/8; New England Electric was up 1/8, at 27 3/8; A.T.&T. declined 1/4, to 26, and G.E. eased 1/8, to 53 7/8. Waste Management Fall **********Waste Management dropped 1 7/8, to 38. One of its subsidiaries was indicted in California with two smaller companies on price-fixing charges. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 1.17, to 331.53. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq index rose 2.26, to 421.67. **********One O-T-C issue that has been badly battered recently, Genentech, which recently lost ground in its fight to get its heart-attack drug approved, gained 2 1/2 points, to 42 1/4.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/21/busin.main_headline: BRAZIL TO SUSPEND INTEREST PAYMENT TO FOREIGN BANKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/21/busin.print_headline: BRAZIL TO SUSPEND INTEREST PAYMENT TO FOREIGN BANKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/21/busin.body_text: **********The Brazilian Government, struggling to protect its rapidly diminishing supply of hard currency, tonight suspended the payment of interest on its debt to foreign banks. **********In a 15-minute address to the nation, President Jose Sarney said the Government was not adopting ''an attitude of confrontation.'' Instead, he said, he hoped that ''a definitive and lasting solution'' to Brazil's debt problems would emerge from negotiations with creditor banks, which are expected to begin next month in New York. **********''We want to negotiate a formula to meet our obligations without compromising our development,'' he said, ''a formula that avoids the political instability that will inevitably follow a new recession, unemployment or social crisis.'' Open-Ended Moratorium **********Brazilian officials said that Mr. Sarney had originally planned to announce a suspension of interest payments for 90 days but that he was persuaded by his financial advisers to make it open-ended. The suspension will presumably last until coming negotiations with commercial banks are completed. **********The action by the largest debtor in the developing world seemed certain to create worry in banking circles. Of a total foreign debt of $108 billion, Brazil owes about $81 billion to private banks, including $24 billion to American banks, led by Citicorp, Chase Manhattan and Bank of America. **********The buildup of the crisis within a few weeks has taken bankers and Brazilians by surprise. Bank stocks fell in New York today, but bankers acknowledged that Brazil had little choice but to halt the interest payments. They said the nation needs to undertake fundamental economic changes. (Page 33.) At current interest rates, American commercial creditors would normally receive about $500 million from Brazil each quarter. If the suspension of interest payments extends beyond 90 days, it would hurt banks' quarterly earnings because banks in the United States would then be required by law to account for the payments that are overdue. **********In the last four years, banks have grown accustomed to almost continuous restructurings of the debts of Latin American nations, but Brazil's problems are causing particular worry, not only because they involve such an important debtor but also because any special deal worked out with Brazil could serve as a precedent in other negotiations. **********Nonetheless, the banking community is less vulnerable today to a debt crisis than it was when the region's problems began with Mexico in August 1982. Since then, many American and European banks have taken measures, such as increasing their capital and making reserve provisions, to protect themselves against suspension of interest payments and even an outright default by any single debtor nation. Healthy Trade Surplus **********Brazil, which has paid no principal on its commercial debt since the country's last financial storm in 1982 and 1983, appeared to have resumed its traditional dynamic growth rates in 1985 and 1986. A healthy trade surplus more than covered annual interest payments of between $9 billion and $11 billion. Both local officials and foreign bankers had predicted that Brazil would soon resume normal borrowing operations. **********But a price freeze imposed last February increased purchasing power and stimulated an unprecedented boom in consumer spending. Consequently, exports slumped and imports rose. The country's foreign exchange reserves then tumbled, bringing on the debt crisis. **********From monthly trade surpluses of more than $1 billion in mid-1986, the surplus fell to just $129 million in January this year, the lowest in four years. Similarly, in barely 12 months, reserves dropped from $11 billion to less than $4 billion. Inflation has also soared again in the last three months and is now running at an annual rate of more than 700 percent. $3.96 Billion in Reserves Tonight, President Sarney said he acted to protect Brazil's reserves, but dismissing rumors that they were close to zero, he disclosed that they stood today at $3.96 billion, enough to cover imports for several months. ''For reasons of sovereignty and national security, our reserves have to be preserved,'' he said. **********Brazil is known to want both new credits and a reduction of its current payments, but the details of its negotiating position are reportedly incomplete. The Finance Minister, Dilson Funaro, is expected to present the Government's proposals at a meeting with a 14-bank advisory committee representing about 600 creditors in the first week of March in New York. **********Tonight, Mr. Sarney noted that the country's political and military leaders had unanimously endorsed his measures, and he said it was the moment for ''responsible patriotism.'' He added, ''We need to negotiate with the authority of a sovereign country and a Government supported by the people.'' **********But he also promised that domestic austerity measures would be taken to complement the external action. He pledged that for the next six months, the Government would spend only as much as it received, that state companies would not invest more than their revenues and that the whole range of subsidies would be reviewed. He once again emphasized that the program would be aimed at maintaining growth and employment. **********Since March 1985, when he became Brazil's first civilian President in more than two decades, Mr. Sarney has committed himself to a strategy of economic growth, and he has consistently pledged that the Brazilian economy would not fall into recession. The country's majority party, the Brazilian Democratic Movement, has warned that it would not endorse any cutbacks in social spending. **********While Mr. Sarney's announcement seemed aimed at stirring nationalistic feelings, it was criticized by opposition leaders of the right and left. 'Incompetence and Imprudence' **********Senator Roberto Campos, Planning Minister under the former military regime, lamented Brazil's unilateral move, which, he said, was the result of ''management incompetence and imprudence.'' Noting that world interest rates as well as Brazil's oil import bill fell last year, he added, ''There was no external factor to justify Brazil's insolvency.'' **********The prominent labor leader, Luis Inacio Lula da Silva, whose Workers Party has frequently called for a total halt to Brazil's debt payments, was also critical. ''A moratorium works when you announce it from a position of strength, when you have money and decide to invest it domestically instead of paying it abroad,'' he said. ''But in this case, I think the moratorium is just bankruptcy. Brazil is simply recognizing that it has no way of paying.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/world.main_headline: 5 KILLED BY BOMB AT BEIRUT AIRPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/world.print_headline: 5 KILLED BY BOMB AT BEIRUT AIRPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/world.body_text: **********A bomb hidden in a suitcase exploded in a crowded passenger terminal at Beirut International Airport today, killing at least 5 people and wounding 70 others, the police said. **********The police said they believed that the bomb, which weighed about two pounds, was carried by a woman who died in the blast.  [ The woman was posing as a departing passenger, the police said, according to The Associated Press. **********She was identified as Soraya Sahyouni, a Sunni Moslem Lebanese. The other dead were reported to be Lebanese, and most of the wounded were Lebanese and other Arabs bound for Persian Gulf nations. ]  First Explosion This Year The explosion, for which there was no immediate claim of responsibility, was the first in the airport this year. At least 62 people have been killed in 18 explosions in Lebanon this year. **********The airport reopened Tuesday after a five-day general strike by Lebanese protesting the country's economic crisis and the 12-year-old civil war. **********Witnesses said thousands of panic-stricken residents who feared for their relatives rushed to the airport, about four miles south of Beirut and near the mainly Shiite Moslem southern suburbs. Area Is Sealed Off **********Lebanese Army and Syrian soldiers sealed off the area. About 7,000 Syrian soldiers arrived in Beirut last February in an attempt to curb three years of violence caused by battles between rival militias. **********The bombing at the airport came as a Frenchman was shot in East Beirut, the predominantly Christian sector of the capital. **********The police said the Frenchman, identified as Richard Genpel, a 46-year-old engineer, was driving his car on Jounieh Highway when another car intercepted him and a gunman got out and shot him in the head. The police said Mr. Genpel was in a critical condition in a hospital in East Beirut.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/22/busin.body_text: **********Assets of the nation's 381 money market mutual funds increased by $3.69 billion, to a record $239.31 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/05/world.main_headline: Ugandan Cult Carrying Out Suicide Raids
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/05/world.print_headline: Ugandan Cult Carrying Out Suicide Raids
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/05/world.body_text: **********If your faith is strong, the rebel priestess teaches her soldiers, enemy bullets will turn back in midair and kill those who fired them. **********Armed mainly with such beliefs, a barefoot army called the Holy Spirit Movement has marched out of northern Uganda to confront government forces at the head of the Nile. **********They have lost hundreds dead in suicidal assaults along their route, but hundreds of others have survived the 400-mile trek to threaten roads and railways that are vital to this landlocked east African nation of 15 million. **********President Yoweri Museveni has said the movement poses no threat to his government, although it has engaged his forces in fierce battles. Goal of Uniting Ugandans **********''The Spirit says he is going to fight and overthrow Museveni and unite all the people of Uganda,'' the rebels' priestess leader told reporters who crossed the front in late October to find the rebel force in a banana grove at this village east of Jinja. **********''The war is supposed to get rid of all wrong elements in society, so in the end peace is enjoyed by all Ugandans.'' **********She is ''Mama Alice'' to her devotees, Alice Lakwena to outsiders. Lakwena means ''messenger'' in the Acholi tribal language and is the name of the spirit through whom Alice says she receives her messages from God. **********Alice is 27 years old and the daughter of an Anglican Sunday school teacher. She says she became a Roman Catholic when she began receiving guidance from her Holy Spirit two years ago. **********Her cult combines a form of Christianity with beliefs and rituals drawn from African tradition. **********New members of the army, the Holy Spirit Mobile Force, go through initiation ceremonies that include spitting into the mouths of a black chicken, a ram and a pig. The movement treats illness by proxy through small clay figures in human form. Purge of Mankind Is Seen **********The movement says a purge of mankind like the Biblical flood will take place soon. **********Seated barefoot on a straw mat to meet her visitors, the short-haired priestess wore a military-style green jacket and a plastic crucifix and rosary around her neck. **********''If you go into battle with faith and if you are not evil, then you come out successful and without injuries of any sort,'' she said through a translator. **********Many of the rebels share these beliefs, even the educated among them, like a former university professor who was once Minister of Education.  [ The former official, Isaac Newton Ojok, surrendered to Government forces last Friday, and one of the movement's most experienced officers, Lieut. Col. John Kennedy Kilama, was captured on Sunday. They said clashes in recent days had reduced the movement to a hard core of 500 men sharing 100 to 150 guns. ]  Alice's army is composed mainly of Acholi, a Nilotic tribe culturally distinct from the Bantu peoples of southern and western Uganda. Acholi were the backbone of Ugandan armies under previous governments and an underlying cause of the rebellion is resentment of President Museveni's southern-dominated administration. **********Pax Ochieng Otur, a rebel officer, told reporters that when the movement began last year, many joined because of resentment of government forces in Acholiland.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Smooth Transition Seen for Rockwell
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.body_text: **********There were no surprises yesterday at the Rockwell International Corporation as the big military contractor announced plans for changes at the top. Robert Anderson, who will be 67 years old next month, recommended to the board at a meeting in Atlanta that he step down as chairman and chief executive in February and be replaced by Donald R. Beall. **********Mr. Beall, 48, has been Rockwell's president and chief operating officer since 1979. He will continue as president once the management changes are complete. **********''We worked out this transition two or three years ago,'' Mr. Anderson said yesterday. ''We started a new fiscal year in October, and we thought it was a good idea to announce what our plans were. Since Don and I have worked closely for almost 20 years, I think it will be a smooth transition.'' **********Rockwell, which has headquarters in Pittsburgh and Los Angeles, is winding down its B-1 bomber program and clearly has some choices to make under a new chief executive. **********''It's a time of transition and new opportunities for Rockwell, with the caveat that it also leaves the company with uncertainty over where it is to go next,'' said Wolfgang H. Demisch, aerospace analyst at the First Boston Corporation. **********Mr. Anderson tenaciously pushed the B-1 program through to its completion - the 100th and final bomber is scheduled to roll off the production line this spring. **********The program represents about a third of Rockwell's business, and the company has no similar blockbuster military program to take its place, Mr. Demisch said. But Rockwell has ample cash and few threats on its horizons, he said, adding that the management team has been successful in the past and that Mr. Beall ''is a guy who can make very tough choices on where he goes at this point and what he wants to focus on.'' **********Rockwell two years ago moved into the commercial market in a big way with the purchase of the Allen-Bradley Company, a maker of factory automation products. In addition, it has aerospace, automotive and commercial and military electronics businesses contributing to its $12 billion annual sales. **********Mr. Beall and Mr. Anderson joined Rockwell in the same year - 1968 -and both came from the auto industry. Mr. Anderson had spent 22 years at the Chrysler Corporation, where he headed the Chrysler-Plymouth division. Mr. Beall came from the Ford Motor Company, where he was an engineer. **********Mr. Anderson has spent much of his time lately speaking on such topics as the need to improve America's competitiveness. He will remain chairman of the board's executive committee and will be a consultant.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/02/world.print_headline: AFGHANISTAN TO OBSERVE A CEASE-FIRE; Soviet Intentions Cited
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/02/world.body_text: **********The temporary cease-fire announced by Mr. Najibullah appears to be part of a Soviet effort to lay the groundwork for an eventual reduction of its military presence there, Western diplomats said today. **********If carried out, the plan for national reconciliation would reduce internal tensions and make Afghanistan's domestic policies more acceptable to Western governments, the diplomats said. **********Mr. Najibullah told a special meeting of the Central Committee of the Afghan Communist Party on Tuesday that Government forces would begin a cease-fire on Jan. 15 if Western-supported guerrilla forces refrained from attacking, Tass said today. **********He also encouraged opposition elements, including Moslem clerical leaders, to join the Government and broaden its base of support, according to the Tass report. **********Western diplomats said Mr. Najibullah, who visited Moscow in December, appeared to be taking the initial steps in a Soviet-inspired plan to give Afghanistan at least the appearance of greater autonomy and democracy. Goal of Troop Reduction **********Mr. Gorbachev has said the Soviet Union wants to withdraw its forces from Afghanistan. Increased stability in Afghanistan and enhanced credibility for its Government could smooth the way for a reduction of Soviet troops, according to the Western diplomats. **********Mr. Gorbachev has said a Soviet withdrawal would be contingent on the reduction of outside aid to the guerrillas. **********Soviet officials and Western diplomats said last month that the presence of more than 100,000 Soviet troops in Afghanistan, while not a serious drain on Soviet resources, was damaging to Moscow's international image and an impediment to Mr. Gorbachev's effort to give Soviet foreign policy a new look. **********Mr. Gorbachev, who visited India in November, has tried to increase Soviet influence in Asia and the Middle East but has been thwarted to some extent by Moslem anger over the Soviet role against the Moslem guerrillas in Afghanistan. **********The problem for Moscow, according to the diplomats, is that it cannot accept a pro-Western Government in Kabul, but that such a government would probably take power if Soviet troops were not present. **********Although there have been reports of progress in the United Nations-sponsored negotiations on Afghanistan, a political settlement appears unlikely in the near future, the diplomats said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/05/world.body_text: **********Riot policemen raided two industrial complexes today, arresting about 200 striking workers in the biggest roundup since the current wave of labor troubles began two months ago. **********The Government said it had arrested workers who were responsible for burning cars, smashing windows and furniture and seizing company executives in Ulsan and in the industrial city of Pupyong. **********In Seoul, the Home Affairs Minister signaled that an official decision had been made to pursue a two-track approach to South Korea's labor unrest. He pledged that peaceful walkouts would not be suppressed, while also warning that violence would be dealt with harshly from now on. **********''The Government will arrest and severely punish those who carry out violent activities such as arson, destruction of property and hostage-taking,'' said the Minister, Chung Kwan Yong. ''Official forces will intervene inside and outside the work place to end such incidents, even without a request from the company.'' Crackdown Is Widened **********The police raids today widened a crackdown on militants that has grown increasingly intense in recent days, leading to the arrest of dozens of student leaders, lawyers and other dissidents. **********In Ulsan, a southeastern industrial center, riot officers stormed into the dormitories of Hyundai Heavy Industries, where 20,000 shipyard workers have been on strike since Wednesday in a wage dispute. Early this morning, the police arrested 70 men suspected of violence, and later in the day they took away about 30 more. They included 10 strikers who had seized a police officer, touching off a brief scuffle at the main shipyard entrance. **********In Pupyong, 18 miles west of Seoul, the police arrested 100 workers in a Daewoo car plant who had taken over the administration building and had held company executives as virtual hostages for a while. According to the authorities, the strikers had gasoline bombs and were threatening to set fire to the building. **********At both Daewoo and Hyundai, workers did not inflict any damage that would affect mechanical operations once work resumes. Ulsan strikers confined most of their damage to the city hall, where they burned cars and broke windows and furniture, angering local officials and some residents who do not work for Hyundai. Request of Authorities **********A Hyundai spokesman said today's arrests came on the authorities' own initiative and without a company request for help. Daewoo, on the other hand, did ask the police to intervene. **********The Government had apparently sensed that labor violence was an issue that could be used to its advantage. A hard line, political analysts said, improves the chances for blunting any unhappiness about the unrest that may exist within the powerful South Korean military. **********In addition, some said, the Government may sense that it enjoys popular support in this matter. ''There are people who say that you can't have workers running amok,'' a foreign diplomat said. ''There is a conservative streak in Korea that goes beyond strikes.'' **********Government and ruling-party officials insisted that the military would not be used to end the labor strikes, which affected about 700 companies nationwide, most of them small. **********''What the Government is trying to do is not to suppress workers' demands but to have an orderly settlement process - it won't go beyond that,'' said Hyun Hong Choo, an influential National Assemblyman from the ruling Democratic Justice Party. **********Ulsan and Pupyong were both quiet after the arrests. Through the day, striking workers kept announcing that they wanted nonviolence, sometimes invoking the name of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/05/world.main_headline: AQUINO IS WELCOMED ON CAMPAIGN TRAIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/05/world.print_headline: AQUINO IS WELCOMED ON CAMPAIGN TRAIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/05/world.body_text: **********With well-organized fanfare, Corazon C. Aquino embarked this weekend on what amounts to a presidential campaign, one year after what had seemed an improbable bid for office against Ferdinand E. Marcos. **********In contrast to last year's makeshift campaign, in which pro-Marcos officials sometimes denied her a stage from which to speak, local officials now crowded close to be seen with her, calling her ''the most beautiful President we ever had.'' **********The issue this time is a draft constitution, which faces a nationwide plebiscite on Feb. 2 and which both sides agree will amount to a test of confidence in Mrs. Aquino's Government. **********This time the underdogs are her opponents, many of whom have rallied behind Juan Ponce Enrile, who has admitted rigging his region's vote against her a year ago, when he was Mr. Marcos's Defense Minister. He was dismissed as Mrs. Aquino's own Defense Minister in November. Inept, He Says of Aquino **********He, too, opened his campaign this weekend, calling her both a dictator and weak and inept, and urging the nation to ''rise as one'' to reject her presidency with a no vote. **********Speaking in Zamboanga City in southern Mindanao, he belittled her role in toppling Mr. Marcos, saying she had not been present at the military revolt, which he helped lead, that forced Mr. Marcos to flee the country two weeks after the election. **********Attacking Mrs. Aquino in harsher language than he used before his dismissal, Mr. Enrile said: ''The people are strong enough to compel anybody to come down. If we had done it before, we can do it again.'' **********The older politicians of Mr. Marcos's own party, those who have not abandoned it for one of the more vital alternatives that have appeared to take its place, also opened a campaign of opposition to the constitution this weekend. **********At the same time, the country's first leftist party, the Party of the Nation, which had at first indicated support for the charter, appeared to be moving for tactical reasons toward an opposition stand. New Election Is Aim **********Few analysts here believe that the constitution can be defeated. But its opponents on the right say they hope the vote will be close enough to reinforce their calls for a new presidential election. **********The President's own spokesman, Teodoro Benigno, has said only an ''overwhelming'' vote of at least 65 percent will be considered a victory. **********The presidential palace announced that Mrs. Aquino would make campaign appearances in different cities each weekend this month. Her strategists have said they are consciously tailoring the campaign to emphasize her personal popularity rather than any aspects of the long and complicated constitution. **********''I know you still love me,'' Mrs. Aquino said as she opened her campaign Saturday in the southern Luzon region of Bicol, where she received strong support in the presidential election last February. **********Although the crowds were smaller than predicted, they showed the same fervor they had last year, when the nation became aware of the ''Cory phenomenon,'' the unexpected star quality of an inexperienced, untried candidate. A Promise of Help **********As they had a year ago, thousands of supporters stood for hours in the burning sunshine, waving yellow banners and clamoring for a glimpse of the candidate. Once again they raised the campaign chant, ''Cory, Cory, Cory,'' that had so disconcerted Mr. Marcos's confident strategists. **********This weekend Mrs. Aquino showed she had learned some politics during her months in office, promising, as Mr. Marcos had in his campaign, more money for local schools, irrigation projects and highway construction. **********In the city of Legaspi, she announced a 33 percent increase in economic aid to the region, with a grant of 2.4 billion pesos, or $120 million this year. **********An economic consultant to the Government said a major job-creation program would be introduced just before the February vote for maximum political effect. **********''It's patronage politics, but a more enlightened kind of patronage politics,'' he said. ''It's more enlightened because they don't like to do it.'' A Vote 'for Our Children' **********On stage, Mrs. Aquino sounded some of the themes of her earlier campaign, talking of her husband, Benigno, an opposition politician whose assassination in 1983 began a series of events that led to Mr. Marcos's downfall. **********She seemed at times almost apologetic in asking for support, reminding her audience that they had voted her into office for a six-year term and recalling her pledge not to run for re-election when that term ends in 1992. **********''This yes vote is for democracy and economic recovery,'' she said. ''This is also for our children, so that they can live in freedom at all times and so that no dictator can ever rule over us again.'' **********Politicians on both sides agree that passage of the constitution will mark a new chapter in her presidency, giving it a legal basis and laying the foundation for a democratic government that will include a two-chamber legislature.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/01/world.body_text: **********The Kuwaiti authorities said today that they had arrested 11 men for bombing the emirate's oil installations on the eve of the Islamic summit conference held here this week. **********The names of two members of the purported terrorist cell - five more men were still being sought - suggested that they were Shiite Moslem Kuwaitis of Iranian origin, sources here said. The men were also accused of starting a series of fires in the oil fields last June. **********Iran boycotted the meeting of the 46-member Islamic Conference Organization over Kuwait's support for Iraq in the Persian Gulf war. Several Islamic fundamentalist groups, including the shadowy Islamic Holy War, threatened reprisals if the meeting was held. **********The Islamic summit conference went ahead as scheduled under tight security, including roadblocks in the downtown area, banning fishing boats from going into the Gulf, sealing mailboxes and halting the shipping of parcels from the post office. Underlying Tensions **********But the arrests pointed up the underlying tensions in this tiny nation, a boom town surrounded by desert, only 40 percent of whose population of 1.6 million are Kuwaiti citizens. **********The ruling Sabah clan, along with a network of other important families, are mostly Sunni Moslems. But about a third of the population are Shiite Moslems, along with an expatriate community that does much of the work, including about 300,000 Palestinians and an estimated 60,000 to 90,000 Iranians. **********Tens of thousands of these expatriates have been deported in the last two years as part of a security crackdown, and because of cutbacks in the economy due to falling oil prices. **********The surnames of two of those implicated in the purported plot - Behbahani and Dashti - are the same as two of the half-dozen leading Shiite families of Iranian origin who came here around the turn of the century. Those families are regarded as the peers of the network of influential, largely merchant, Kuwaiti families at the pinnacle of influence. 'Kuwaiti High Society' **********''These are Shiite families of Iranian origin who are very integrated into the feudal structure,'' a diplomat said tonight after hearing the names. ''This is happening right in the middle of Kuwaiti high society.'' **********There have been a number of terrorist incidents in Kuwait in recent years, including the suicide truck bombings of the American and French embassies by Shiite Moslems in December 1983. **********American and French hostages have been seized in Lebanon in demand for the release of 17 men who have been imprisoned, with 3 under death sentences, for those bombings. The 17 are mostly Iraqi Shiites, but include several Lebanese. **********In addition, a Kuwaiti airliner was hijacked to Iran a year later, a suicide car bomber attempted to blow up the ruling Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah, and a series of bombs went off in popular coffeehouses along the seafront. Oil Platform Damaged **********On Jan. 19, three days before the foreign ministers of Islamic states gathered here to draw up the agenda for the summit, explosions went off simultaneously at three oil installations. **********One of the bombs reportedly caused considerable damage to Kuwait's offshore oil-loading platform at Sea Island, knocking one of the two berths out of service. **********Responsibility for the explosions was claimed in Beirut by a previously unknown group calling itself the Revolutionary Organization - Forces of the Prophet Mohammed in Kuwait, which declared, ''We threaten people who do not want to look at the right of the oppressed in Kuwait and tomorrow in Palestine.'' **********The Kuwaiti television tonight showed extensive footage of what it said were caches of arms and explosives seized along with the terrorists. Arrests Hinted During Summit **********The piles of weapons included more than a dozen handguns, machine pistols and automatic rifles; hand grenades; detonating devices including alarm clocks, fuses and electrical wires, and, according to the narrator, TNT and C-4 explosive. **********The dates Jan. 27 and 29 appeared superimposed on some of the film of the weapons, suggesting they had been found, and the terrorists arrested, during the Islamic summit. **********The announcement of the arrests quoted a source at the Interior Ministry who ''praised God for protecting Kuwait and thanked the Almighty for helping Kuwait's security forces to arrest those responsible for the fires that broke out in oil installations last June and last Jan. 19.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/05/world.main_headline: Reagan and Aides Prepare Offers on Future Arms Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/05/world.print_headline: Reagan and Aides Prepare Offers on Future Arms Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/05/world.body_text: **********President Reagan and senior officials met today to review what arms control proposals the United States should make at the summit meeting next week. **********Administration officials said there was no basic change in many key elements of the American position. **********But American and Soviet officials expect intense negotiations on how to reduce long-range nuclear arms and on the related issue of what commitment should be made to the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. **********Administration officials also said they expected to wrap up remaining minor issues at talks in Geneva on the new treaty to ban medium- and shorter-range missiles in time for the signing Tuesday by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. Soviet Expects Resolution **********Col. Gen. Nikolai F. Chervov, the head of the arms control directorate of the Soviet General Staff, said in an interview that the two sides would try to resolve several key issues next week here on a future agreement on long-range arms and anti-missile systems. **********On reducing long-range arms, General Chervov said the two sides should be able to resolve the question of what missile ceilings or ''sub-limits'' should be set by the new agreement. ''There is every reason now to believe it could be done,'' he said. **********General Chervov also suggested that the two sides should be able to make progress on how long to adhere to the ABM treaty. **********The Soviet Union has proposed that the two sides should pledge not to withdraw from the treaty for 10 years, while the United States has proposed a commitment not to withdraw before the end of 1994. **********''As to the duration of that period of time it could be 10 or 15 years or less than that,'' General Chervov said. ''Anyway, it is up to the heads of our two countries to decide and agree upon.'' **********General Chervov also said that Mr. Gorbachev and President Reagan would have a ''significant conversation'' on the ABM treaty. Strict Interpretation **********General Chervov and other Soviet officials here have left the impression that Moscow believes that the critical issue of interpretation of the ABM treaty is too difficult to deal with resolve at the summit meeting. But he asserted that there was no change in the Soviet position that the ABM treaty must be interpreted strictly. **********He said that the Soviet position was similar to that of senators who have endorsed the traditional, restrictive intepretation of the treaty. The Reagan Administration has developed a ''broad'' interpretation that would allow expanded testing of a space-based defense against missiles - known as ''Star Wars.'' **********General Chervov also suggested that a treaty reducing long-range arms could not go into effect until the two sides resolve what the ABM treaty means and its period of observance. He said a ''50 percent reduction in strategic nuclear offensive arms can only become a reality'' if all the ABM provisions are strictly observed and complied with. Resistance From Hard-Liners **********Before today's meeting, several compromise proposals on the ABM issue had circulated in the Administration but had run into strong resistance from Administration hard-liners. **********Some Administration officials had suggested that the United States agree not to withdraw from the treaty until the end of 1996 - instead of 1994 - as the United States has proposed. **********Another suggestion involved the Soviet radar at Krasnoyarsk in central Siberia, which the Reagan Administration says is a violation of the ABM treaty. Under this idea, the Russians would satisfy American concerns by eliminating the radar's power source instead of tearing down the radar, as the United States had demanded. **********Under another suggestion, the United States would try to address Soviet concerns by agreeing to negotiate the meaning of key terms of the ABM treaty after a new treaty reaching long-range arms goes into effect. **********For the treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range weapons, the Soviet Union earlier this week provided its final package of required missile data, Officials said that the data appear to be in line with American estimates. **********An American official said today that the two sides were still trying to work out differences on monitoring outside of Soviet and American missile plants. But he said he expected this issue to be resolved very soon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/06/world.body_text: **********Two senior Administration officials encountered heated, skeptical cross-examination today from Democratic senators about the military effectiveness of the Nicaraguan rebels and the Administration's commitment to a negotiated settlement in Central America. **********These two issues, rather than the reported diversion to the rebels of profits from weapons sales to Iran, seemed to dominate the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's concerns as it met to consider a bill to cut off aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, known as contras. **********''In my judgment,'' said the committee's Democratic chairman, Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, ''the military strategy represented by the contras is headed for disastrous results which offer the stark prospect of deepening U.S. military involvement. We need to redirect our policy toward exploring every political and diplomatic path available, which I frankly do not believe the Administration has done.'' 'Political Slavery' Feared **********The two officials, Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, and Philip C. Habib, special envoy for Central America, argued that the obstacles to a negotiated solution had been erected by the governing Sandinistas. The Administration remained committed to the Contadora process, Mr. Habib said, under which a 21-point tentative settlement has been worked out. **********But Mr. Abrams contended that without military pressure, the Sandinistas would not be induced to negotiate or permit democracy. He denounced the bill to halt aid as guaranteeing ''political slavery for Nicaragua.'' **********The bill was introduced by Connecticut's Senators, Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat, and Lowell P. Weicker, a Republican. It would deny the contras the $40 million that remains of the $100 million appropriated this year. **********The measure's prospects for passage are uncertain. Since it would undoubtedly be vetoed by President Reagan, sponsors would need two-thirds of both houses to override the veto. Some Democrats would rather confront the White House on next year's appropriation request, which could be defeated by a majority of the legislators. Goal of 'Political Victory' **********Under close and often hostile questioning, Mr. Abrams said it was not the Administration's goal to build up a conventional force that could march into Managua. ''If the question is, can they win a straight-out military victory such as what we won in World War II,'' he declared, ''nobody is thinking about that.'' He stressed that the contras were fighting a ''guerrilla war'' and that the goal was ''political victory.'' **********He predicted that with continued aid, the rebels could force the Sandinistas to permit democracy in Nicaragua in two to four years. He said that with the $100 million appropriated this year for the contras and $105 million or more next year, the pace of guerrilla warfare would increase, and Nicaraguan troops would lose control of some territory. **********He also said the Administration was moving toward a decision to sell F-5E jet fighters to Honduras, which recently declared it would stop allowing the contras to use its territory as a staging area. Most of the 15,000 to 18,000 rebel fighters are now in Nicaragua, Mr. Abrams contended, although he declined to give precise figures. **********Senator Dodd questioned the assumption that the contras could force the Sandinistas to permit free elections. ''How do you get a force strong enough to force a government to change fundamentally but not strong enough to overthrow the government?'' he asked. **********Mr. Abrams replied simply that the Sandinistas had to be convinced that ''down the road lies ruin.'' **********''They don't believe that yet,'' he said, ''but when they believe that, we have the potential for a settlement.'' **********Mr. Habib faced tough questioning on the Administration's refusal to conduct negotiations with Nicaragua. **********''We are ready to resume bilateral talks as soon as the Sandinistas enter into a dialogue with their opposition,'' he said. ''We believe that until the Sandinistas come to terms with its own people, there is no point in resuming bilateral talks with the Sandinistas.'' **********The only Senator to express clear support for the contras was Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. Noting that some claim that the contras cannot win, Mr. Helms asked: ''How do we know that? They have never had a fighting chance. Of course they cannot win without our help.''
