https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/12/world.main_headline: PANAMA CALLS STATE OF EMERGENCY AFTER 4TH DAY OF VIOLENT PROTESTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/12/world.print_headline: PANAMA CALLS STATE OF EMERGENCY AFTER 4TH DAY OF VIOLENT PROTESTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/12/world.body_text: **********After the fourth consecutive day of protests and political violence, the Panamanian Government today imposed a ''state of urgency'' under which many civil and political rights were suspended. **********The National University and all high schools in the capital were ordered shut to prevent students and teachers from joining marches against the military-backed Government. **********Through the night on Wednesday and into the pre-dawn hours, Panamanians gathered to block streets with barricades of rubbish, tires and burning automobiles. Today protest caravans snaked loudly through the city as citizens gathered to cheer, beat pots and pans and wave white handkerchiefs. Troops Patrol Streets **********Troops dressed in camouflage uniforms and armed with tear gas and automatic rifles patrolled city streets, and most stores and businesses were closed. Public transportion was all but paralyzed. Military helicopters circled over the city all day. **********The United States Ambassador, Arthur H. Davis, today paid a visit to the head of the Christian Democratic Party, Ricardo Arias Calderon, a leading opposition figure who has called for General Noriega's resignation. Asked if the Ambassador brought a message of support, Mr. Arias Calderon replied, ''I think the visit itself was a message.'' **********The crisis, considered the most serious Panama has faced since the military seized power in 1968, erupted on Sunday with the publication of dramatic charges by Col. Roberto Diaz Herrera, who until his retirement last week was the second-ranking member of the Panama Defense Forces. Allegations Against Leader **********Colonel Diaz said he had collaborated with the top military commander, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, in electoral fraud in 1984, and said General Noriega had directed the 1985 slaying of Dr. Hugo Spadafora, a leading critic of the Government. **********In addition, he said General Noriega had planned the killing of Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, Panama's leader, who died in a plane crash in 1981. General Torrijos is a hero to many Panamanians and is regularly invoked by General Noriega and other officers as their mentor. **********Amado Martinez, one of a group of more than 100 people who gathered in the San Cristobal section of the capital to block streets by building barricades and setting them afire, said: ''We are not organized by anyone, we are just the people of Panama, and we are fed up. Everyone wants to get rid of Noriega and to return to democracy.'' **********In an interview with a radio station from neighboring Colombia, General Noriega said today that he would not resign his office because doing so would not resolve the country's problems. He blamed this week's turmoil on ''groups of businessmen stimulated by opposition politicians.'' **********Under what the Government called a state of urgency, which limits personal freedoms and resembles a state of emergency in other countries, police may arrest citizens without charge and hold them for indefinite periods without informing them of charges against them or presenting them to the judicial authorities. Constitutional guarantees of free speech, peaceable assembly and free transit were also suspended. The Government prohibited independent radio news programs. Stations not broadcasting music were required to join a national network that broadcast appeals for calm and condemnations of ''evil men who have always been ambitious for power.'' **********Even before Colonel Diaz's charges last weekend, there had been widespread reports that General Noriega was involved in vote fraud and the killing of Dr. Spadafora. Colonel Diaz added hitherto unknown details, identifying officers he said were involved and specifying the electoral district in which he said vote counts were altered to provide a victory margin in 1984. New Charges on Torrijos Death **********But the allegations surrounding General Torrijos's death were not widely heard before, and few Panamanians or foreigners had seriously questioned the official conclusion that the general's death in the plane crash was accidental. Colonel Diaz said a bomb disquised as a radio transmitter was placed aboard the plane on orders of General Noriega, who was then the country's second-ranking military officer. **********Today, Colonel Diaz was gathered with his family and supporters behind the walls of his luxurious home, which he said he bought with money he earned from bribes paid by Cubans seeking Panamanian visas. **********In an interview, the 49-year-old colonel said he was moved to speak out by a growing sense that God would punish him if he did not. Like some other leading Panamanians, including General Noriega, Colonel Diaz is in regular touch with psychics and spiritualists. **********''I have confessed, and it would be best for Panama if General Noriega also confesses,'' Colonel Diaz said. ''Our war is psychic, mystical and religious.'' Priests Gather With Colonel **********Among those gathered with Colonel Diaz today were several Roman Catholic priests. One, the Rev. Juan de Dios Antolines, said the church had intervened to protect the ''physical and spiritual life of Colonel Diaz and his family.'' **********The colonel has rejected suggestions that he seek asylum in a foreign embassy, but indicated he would consider an invitation from Archbishop Marcos Gregorio McGrath that he and his supporters move from their home to a church to conduct a ''permanent vigil.'' He also acceded to the Archbishop's request that he surrender all firearms that supporters had brought into his house in recent days. **********Colonal Diaz, who was the first chief of the army's Office for Psychological Operations, said he was not seeking power for himself. He said the man who should legally be president of Panama is Dr. Arnulfo Arias Madrid, who was proclaimed the loser in the 1984 elections. **********Dr. Arias was wildly cheered as he took part in a downtown motorcade on Tuesday. But he has not joined the call for a national strike, which several private groups support.  U.S. Warns Travelers WASHINGTON, June 11 (Special to The New York Times) - The State Department warned Americans today to avoid traveling to Panama, and the Pentagon ordered American military personnel to restrict their movements there because of the clashes. **********The measures came as the Reagan Administration stepped up its public criticism of the Panamanian Government. Phyllis Oakley, the State Department spokeswoman, read a statement urging the authorities to respect human rights and endorsing ''the goal of free and untarnished elections and the full development of an apolitical professional military institution.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/13/world.body_text: **********In a blow to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, the Indian Defense Minister resigned today under pressure from politicians unhappy with his attempt to investigate possible kickbacks in the awarding of an overseas defense contract. **********The move by the Defense Minister, Vishwanath Pratap Singh, followed weeks of discord within Mr. Gandhi's Government and heated accusations by opposition politicians that Mr. Gandhi was trying to cover up various scandals. **********Opposition leaders accused Mr. Gandhi tonight of letting Mr. Singh be ''hounded out'' of the Government. The National People's Party said he had been forced to resign as ''punishment for exposing corruption.'' **********The resignation is certain to pose a serious test to Mr. Gandhi at a time of rising criticism of his performance and deepening divisions in his party. Aggressive Tactics Criticized **********The dispute began in March, when Mr. Singh came under attack for having hired an American investigative agency, the Fairfax Group of Annandale, Va., to look into illegal activities overseas by Indian businesses. The agency was hired last year while Mr. Singh was Finance Minister; he moved to the Defense Ministry in January. **********Then, last Thursday, Mr. Singh said he had begun a separate inquiry into payments to an Indian who served as an overseas agent in a $300 million defense contract. **********The contract was for purchase of submarines from West Germany. The commission awarded was said to have been about $25 million. **********No additional details were available, including the name of the recipient of the commission. But the payment was widely seen as evidence of a possible kickback to Mr. Gandhi's ruling Congress Party. **********Many political experts have asserted that the party raises funds by skimming money from overseas contractors in both the West and the Soviet Union. But no evidence has surfaced. **********Mr. Singh's dramatic announcement of the investigation in Parliament on Thursday stunned his fellow party members. He had not cleared the action with the Prime Minister or any appropriate Cabinet committee. Accusations of Disloyalty **********Publicly, the criticism by Mr. Singh's colleagues centered on his failure to notify them and on charges that he had jeopardized the inquiry by making it public. But leading allies of Mr. Gandhi were reported to have denounced Mr. Singh at a closed meeting of Cabinet members Friday night, suggesting that he had sought to embarrass the Prime Minister, improve his own image and save his job. **********Mr. Singh responded by promising to resign as an act of ''loyalty'' to Mr. Gandhi. He said today that he gave his resignation to the Prime Minister after a ''heart-to-heart talk'' late Saturday night. **********The Prime Minister's own role remained unclear tonight. It was not certain whether he asked for the resignation, encouraged his colleagues to press for it, or tried to dissuade the Defense Minister. **********The resignation was accepted today by the Indian President, Zail Singh, and Mr. Gandhi transferred K. C. Pant, the Steel and Mines Minister, to the defense post. **********In a statement, Mr. Singh continued to proclaim his loyalty to the Prime Minister, saying he had begun his investigation with the best intentions. **********''It is honor enough to belong to the Congress family and work with its leader, Rajiv Gandhi,'' he said. ''It is now for the people to decide whether I am over-ambitious or my critics are wrong.'' Criticism From Opposition **********George Fernandez, a leader of the People's Party, said tonight that ''Mr. Singh should put the country's security above loyalty to his party and let the people know the truth behind the dirty deal.'' **********Mr. Fernandez said the resignation confirmed that for seven years an ''illegitimate fortune'' had been made out of arms sales to India. **********Mr. Singh, a 56-year-old politician from a princely family in the populous northern state of Uttar Pradesh, created a splash by resigning as the state's Chief Minister in 1982. The issue then was his admitted failure to contain a crime wave. **********But as Finance Minister and then Defense Minister, Mr. Singh rose to become one of the most popular politicians in India, with a reputation as an honest and effective administrator. **********In the finance post, he was the architect of India's policy of lowering taxes and easing Government regulations and earned an international reputation for his understanding of economics. **********But Mr. Singh also rankled businessmen and politicians by authorizing investigators to pursue cases of tax fraud by raiding the homes and offices of leading industrialists. Many of his targets were longtime allies and contributors to the Congress Party. Heavy-Handed Investigations **********Mr. Gandhi transferred him to the defense post amid widespread reports that the Prime Minister felt Mr. Singh had become too aggressive. For example, it was reported that Finance Ministry inquiries had forced key businesses to shut down while being investigated, costing them much of their export trade. This in turn was said to have damaged India's balance of payments. **********Then last month, it was disclosed that Mr. Singh had hired the Fairfax Group to look into the overseas accounts of a leading Indian textile industrialist. **********The industrialist, Dirubhai Ambani, chairman of Reliance Industries, had been accused in the press of smuggling in machinery and chemicals for synthetic fabrics in collusion with the Government. He denied the charges. **********Mr. Singh's critics became angry, however, when it was alleged that Fairfax Group fees may also have been paid by a rival textile company, Bombay Dyeing. **********In the view of many, this tainted the Government's investigation and raised the charge that Mr. Singh had thrust the Government into a private-sector dispute.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.main_headline: Kuwaiti Hanging of 3 Shiites Is Reported in Beirut's Press
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.print_headline: Kuwaiti Hanging of 3 Shiites Is Reported in Beirut's Press
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.body_text: **********The Beirut press reported today that Kuwait had executed three convicted Shiite Moslem bombers whose release had been demanded by people claiming to hold American hostages here.  [ Kuwait denied that the three men had been executed. Kuwait's Interior Ministry, in a statement carried by the Kuwait News Agency, said, ''There is no truth whatsoever to these claims.'' ]  The Beirut press, in its reports today, quoted a newsletter published in Teheran by Iraqi political exiles. The report said the three men, two Iraqis and a Lebanese, were hanged at Kuwait's central prison in May. The Teheran newsletter named the Iraqis as Hussein Kassem Hassan and Bakr Ibrahim, and the Lebanese as Elias Saab. **********They were sentenced to death by a Kuwaiti tribunal in March 1984, four months after they had been arrested after bomb attacks against the American and French embassies and Kuwaiti Government buildings. **********Fourteen other suspects were given prison sentences ranging from three years to life.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/21/world.main_headline: As the Inquiry Unfolds, Pitfalls for Lawmakers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/21/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS: CONGRESS IN THE LIMELIGHT TOO; As the Inquiry Unfolds, Pitfalls for Lawmakers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/21/world.body_text: **********Even as the House and Senate Iran-contra committees train the spotlight on the Reagan White House, more than two months of joint hearings have at times caught the panels themselves in the glare. **********They have thrown into harsh relief the pitfalls as well as the promise of a full-scale Congressional inquiry into the Administration of a popular President. **********A few years after the Senate Watergate investigation turned him into a folk hero, Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. wrote that a Congressional investigation could become either ''an instrument of freedom'' or ''freedom's scourge.'' **********Had he lived to see the Iran-contra investigation, the North Carolina Democrat might have added a third possibility: that the investigation could become the scourge of Congress as well. A Sympathetic Figure **********Critics of the Administration both inside and outside Congress watched in dismay as Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the witness whose advance notices had cast him as the probable villain of the drama, became a sympathetic figure to much of the public by skillful use of the platform the hearings provided. At the most crucial point in their work, the committees appeared off stride, scrambling to regain momentum and public credibility. **********In interviews over the last week, veterans of earlier Congressional investigations, as well as members of Congress not directly involved in the current inquiry, indicated general, if tentative, agreement on several aspects of the committees' work so far. **********They said the Iran-contra investigation was a more difficult one for Congress than the Watergate inquiry, and that the chairmen, Senator Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii and Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, deserved credit for maintaining a dignified, nonpartisan tone despite the size of the group - 26 members compared with 7 on the Watergate committee. **********But they added that the high-profile role of the committees' lawyers, while probably necessary, nonetheless had hurt the panels' public effectiveness. Some Things Done Better **********Fred D. Thompson, who served as chief minority counsel to the Senate Watergate committee, said the public now forgets that the committee was widely criticized for its leaks and open partisanship. **********''There were days when people said that maybe Nixon's a crook, but these guys are out to lunch, too,'' he said. ''The facts bailed us out.'' Indeed, a Gallup poll in August 1973, as the Watergate committee was in the midst of its work, indicated that a bare majority, 52 percent, thought the hearings were ''good for the country.'' **********''These committees are doing some things better than the Watergate committee did,'' said James Hamilton, who was assistant majority counsel to the Watergate committee and the author of a book, ''The Power to Probe,'' about Congressional investigations. **********''They have controlled leaks, they have prevented partisan staff wrangling,'' he said, but added: ''The committee members have not been as dominant as those on the Ervin committee, perhaps because the staff lawyers have played such a large role. This may have worked to North's advantage, since it is difficult even for superior lawyers to weigh in with moral rectitude like Sam Ervin did so effectively.'' On the Defensive **********Those interviewed said that the dominance of Arthur L. Liman, the chief Senate counsel, and John W. Nields Jr., chief counsel to the House panel, have given the proceedings a prosecutorial tone that has created public sympathy for the witnesses. **********''You have all the standard courtroom theatrics,'' said Mark Helmke, who until earlier this year was press secretary to Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana. ''Prosecutorial staff counsel, brilliant defense attorneys. The problem is that in a trial, there is a judge. That's a role that members of Congress don't play very well. They've been miscast. They look bad.'' **********Mr. Helmke added that the sheer size of the committees ''makes it look like a bunch of Congressmen and hired guns are ganging up on the witnesses.'' **********''Having counsel do the questioning, so that it is coherent and consistent, is basically a sound idea,'' said Representative David E. Price, a freshman Democrat from North Carolina. Mr. Price, a political scientist and academic specialist in the Congressional committee process, said his studies of Congressional oversight hearings had shown that questioning by members was often ''sporadic and segmented.'' He added, ''You put counsel in that role for good reason, running the risk that they come on too strong.'' **********Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat, put it another way. ''The lawyers are doing what good lawyers do in a court of law,'' he said. ''They're building a case brick by brick. But these pieces have to be bigger. The public has to see a 100-piece jigsaw puzzle, not 1,000 pieces. It's not a jury of 12 but of 100 million.'' **********By permitting the ''detective story'' to dominate the hearings, the committees have not focused adequately on the public policy part of their mandate, said Jerome Levinson, who served as a counsel to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. **********''In allowing the issue to be framed as a detective story - whether Reagan knew - the committees miss the boat,'' he said. ''The real question is the role of covert action in a democracy. How often do you have the chance to get the attention of the nation on a fundamental question like that?'' **********But Mr. Levinson said ''tremendous institutional pressures'' make it difficult to focus on the larger issues. ''It's just so easy to be pulled into the facts and lose sight of what it is you want to accomplish,'' he said. **********Mr. Thompson said there were inherent political risks for members of Congress in pursuing any sustained, high-profile investigation. **********''Whether the members like it or not, this is essentially a broad policy debate,'' he said. ''There's an inherent weakness in the committee process. You can try to bear down on the factual side, but a real strong witness who's got sympathetic points to make and who can deliver those points effectively can make the policy debate jump out. All of a sudden the ground is shifting out from under you.'' **********Senator Terry Sanford, Democrat of North Carolina, said: ''It's not a perfect system. But I hope we don't have these investigations often enough to develop a perfect system.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/18/busin.main_headline: Japan's Efforts to Soften U.S. Anger on Toshiba
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/18/busin.print_headline: Japan's Efforts to Soften U.S. Anger on Toshiba
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/18/busin.body_text: **********In its desire to quell American anger over a Japanese company's sale of militarily sensitive technology to the Soviet Union, Japan is taking steps that may seem extraordinary to Americans, but make perfect sense to Japanese. **********The action has been rapid-fire this month: *********** On July 1, the top two officials of the Toshiba Corporation resigned, even though they said that the company had not known about the illegal export of propeller-milling equipment to the Soviet Union by the Toshiba Machine Company, of which it owned a majority interest.. *********** On Tuesday, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone accused Toshiba Machine of betraying Japan. *********** On Wednesday, the Toshiba Corporation sent a contrite letter of apology to members of Congress. *********** On Thursday, Japan's trade minister told American officials that his Government would seek harsher penalties for future violators and would work to toughen Japan's export control system. **********While some of these steps might strike Americans as degrading, they have not occasioned much comment in Japan. Their logic is clear to most Japanese - Japan cannot afford to risk losing access to its most important foreign market. Moreover, gestures such as public apologies or the resignation of top corporate executives are accepted - and expected -here as a proof of sincerity. They are considered not humiliating but honorable. **********''The resignation doesn't mean that the executives say they are guilty,'' said Naohiro Amaya, executive director of a research center called the Dentsu Institute for Human Studies and one of the architects of Japan's postwar trade policies. ''The company was put in a disastrous situation, and it's common sense in Japan for the president to take a serious action that may help to solve the problem. But Americans may find this puzzling - Chrysler was involved in some scandal, and Lee Iacocca's reaction was quite different from Toshiba's.'' **********Moreover, unlike numerous past disputes with the United States, many here acknowledge that Japan was in the wrong this time. **********''We are saying one thing - We are responsible,'' said Yoshifumi Matsuda, a spokesman for the foreign ministry. ''Toshiba Machine committed an illegal act.'' He added that the Government was also responsible ''because of a rather loose framework of export controls and a shortage of manpower'' to supervise these exports. **********A senior Japanese executive of a major corporation agreed. ''I don't think anyone was surprised'' by the measures taken, he said, adding: ''Since Toshiba Machine did something against the law, how do we fight back against American accusations?'' **********Nonetheless, many Japanese are puzzled and resentful about the depth of American fury over the Toshiba affair. **********For most Japanese, the incident has not loomed nearly so large as it has in the United States. Mr. Nakasone's charge of betrayal did not stir much comment here, although he may well have understood how his comments would be received in the United States. **********Nor was there much comment about the pledges made in Washington by Hajime Tamura, Japan's Minister of International Trade and Industry, to toughen export controls and stiffen penalties. One foreign ministry official said today, however, that some of Mr. Tamura's promises ''are not fully endorsed by other ministries.'' Mr. Nakasone, however, endorsed some of the proposals in testimony today before Japan's parliament. **********These remedial measures came after the United States delivered two shocks that jolted the Government and the public into recognizing the high stakes of the Toshiba affair. One was the Senate proposal to ban imports made by the Toshiba Corporation. The other was the picture of Congressmen smashing a Toshiba radio in front of the Capitol. What appeared a mere photo opportunity in the United States received prominent coverage in Japan. **********Just a few hours after the Senate proposal, Toshiba's chairman and president resigned. A ban on Toshiba exports to the United States - which accounts for 10 percent of Toshiba's annual sales - would have a devastating effect on the company. **********Indeed, it was American pressure that played a key role in prompting Japan to consider toughening its export controls, said one foreign ministry official who helps supervise the controls. ''Of course, if there was no United States pressure, it would be very difficult to take measures which by Japanese standards are very drastic,'' he said. Trade Curbs Feared **********Many here also fear that the furor will further poison trade relations with the United States - and insure the passage of harsh trade measures under consideration in Congress. Last year, the United States accounted for 38.5 percent of Japan's exports and a third of Japanese trade. **********''Japanese don't want a protectionist trade bill,'' said Clyde Prestowitz, a former United States trade negotiator. ''They want the semiconductor sanctions lifted. They don't want to be locked out of Strategic Defense Initiative research. They have enormous stakes in the United States. They are trying to save this at the cost of having someone go over and bow low and apologize - that's a pretty low cost.'' **********At the same time, however, many Japanese are troubled by the intensity of the American reaction. **********''There is a sense here that the American Congress is making a witch hunt without substantial evidence,'' Mr. Amaya said. ''It's rather interesting that the Congress didn't smash Norwegian sardine tins, only the Toshiba radio.'' A Norwegian company, Kongsberg Vaapenfabrikk, was also involved in the illegal sale. U.S. Charge Questioned **********There is widespread skepticism here about the American charge that the Toshiba Machine equipment was used to make Soviet submarines quieter. Military experts, some politicians and many ordinary Japanese have questioned whether a direct link really exists. In several days of questioning in Japan's parliament, Government officials have provided conflicting accounts on the evidence of such a link. **********The result, said Mr. Matsuda, the foreign ministry spokesman, was that many Japanese remained doubtful about the evidence of a linkage. That, he said, was ''very regrettable.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Quadrex President Takes Kidder Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/busin.body_text: **********John M. Liftin, president of the Quadrex Securities Corporation, will be joining Kidder, Peabody & Company as senior vice president and general counsel. The position is particularly sensitive since Kidder was rocked by an embarrassing insider-trading scandal last year, not long after it was taken over by the General Electric Company. **********Mr. Liftin, who is 44 years old, has been president of Quadrex, a small New York investment banking firm, for the last two years. Before that, he practiced law in Washington as a partner in the firm of Rogers & Wells. He replaces Robert A. Krantz Jr., who retired from the firm in June. **********Mr. Liftin, who will assume his new position on Sept. 8, will report to Silas S. Cathcart, chief executive of Kidder, Peabody. **********In an interview, Mr. Liftin said that he found the offer from Kidder, Peabody more attractive than his present post because ''the legal content was minor in this job, and I missed it.'' He added that he considered the scope of Quadrex rather limited. ''Quadrex has only two business areas: Eurobonds and mergers and acquisitions,'' Mr. Liftin said. ''Kidder has everything. There is an awful lot of diversity there.'' **********Mr. Liftin said that the insider-trading scandals, involving such prominent Wall Street figures as Ivan F. Boesky, Martin A. Siegel and Boyd L. Jefferies, had added to the importance of the legal staffs of investment firms. Kidder, Peabody itself agreed to pay a record $25.3 million to settle insider-trading charges. **********''There is an upgrading of the legal function at a number of firms,'' he said. ''And the signals were clear to me that they were doing that at Kidder, Peabody. If this were just any other in-house legal job, it certainly would not have been attractive to me.'' **********Between 1971 and 1974, Mr. Liftin worked at the Securities and Exchange Commission, first as special counsel to the chairman and, later, as associate director of market regulation. Before joining the S.E.C., Mr. Liftin was an associate with the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell. **********Mr. Liftin is a 1964 graduate of the University of Pennsylvania. He received his law degree from the Columbia Law School in 1967.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/27/busin.body_text: **********The Mesa Petroleum Company said it had purchased 15.5 million Mesa Limited Partnership common units for $263.9 million, in accordance with its previously announced plan of liquidation. The plan was approved by shareholders in December 1985. The units will be distributed Feb. 2 to Mesa Petroleum shareholders of record Jan. 26. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/11/busin.main_headline: Icahn Setback on USAir Bid Is Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/11/busin.print_headline: Icahn Setback on USAir Bid Is Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/11/busin.body_text: **********Carl C. Icahn may have overreached in his effort to acquire the USAir Group and may find it difficult to end it without paying a price financially and legally, some analysts and sources close to the takeover effort said yesterday. **********Mr. Icahn, a takeover specialist who is the chairman and owner of Trans World Airlines, was busy meeting with his legal and financial advisers yesterday reassessing whether he should continue his battle for USAir. **********Mr. Icahn, who controls 15 percent of USAir's stock, received another of a series of legal blows when United States District Judge Maurice Cohill Jr. extended a temporary restraining order preventing Mr. Icahn and T.W.A. from buying more USAir stock until after a March 23 hearing. **********The court order was issued as a result of a USAir suit, which charged that Mr. Icahn had violated several Federal laws and had made misleading statements to Government agencies and stockholders because he wanted to break up USAir's deal. **********Some analysts said the judge's order greatly increased the odds against Mr. Icahn because it gives USAir time to gain support among its stockholders and Piedmont stockholders for its $1.59 billion tender offer of $69 a share for Piedmont. The offer is set to expire April 3. **********Analysts said the judge's order also took away Mr. Icahn's most potent weapon to put pressure on USAir management: the ability to increase his stake in the carrier. **********''Time is now in USAir's favor,'' said Hans Plickert, an airline analyst at E. F. Hutton & Company. ''It is not in Icahn's favor.'' **********Even if Mr. Icahn decides to end his effort, analysts said, he still could face substantial losses in disposing of his four million USAir shares. They said that USAir's stock price could drop further if Mr. Icahn ends his bid. **********USAir shares fell 62.5 cents, to $47.125, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday after trading as high as $51.125 last week. **********Some analysts speculated that Mr. Icahn's tactics in the USAir bid could draw more attention to his activities on the part of the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********And Mr. Plickert said the climate that Mr. Icahn was operating in had changed as a result of Wall Street's insider-trading scandal. ''Takeover games have gotten a bad name,'' he said. ''When someone violates a regulation in the process, that's a lot more negative today than it was six months ago.'' **********Emerging from yesterday's court proceedings in Pittsburgh, Edward I. Colodny, the chairman of USAir, who has so far helped build a strong defense against Mr. Icahn, told reporters that however Judge Cohill ruled in the future, ''USAir is in this thing to win.'' **********T.W.A.'s reaction to the court order was a short statement by Mark A. Buckstein, the airline's senior vice president and general counsel. Mr. Buckstein said, ''T.W.A. is reassessing its strategy relating to its investment in USAir stock.'' **********Mr. Buckstein, reached later in the day, said that he would have no further comment on whether Mr. Icahn would withdraw his offer or about possible legal problems from increasing his holdings in USAir last week. **********USAir's suit charged that Mr. Icahn's takeover offer violated provisions of the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act. Under that law, his ownership in USAir would have been limited to $15 million worth of stock unless the Transportation Department assumed jurisdiction over the takeover effort. **********But the agency, with the Justice Department's backing, rejected his takeover application last Friday, the same day that Mr. Icahn disclosed he had lifted his USAir stake to 15 percent and the day that the USAir and Piedmont boards approved the merger. **********USAir also said that Mr. Icahn violated the Federal Aviation Act, by acquiring more than 10 percent of USAir stock - a stake that gave him control of the carrier under the act -without the Transportation Department's approval of a voting trust to hold the stock. **********The USAir suit said that if Mr. Icahn had filed under the Hart-Scott-Rodino law, ''he would have been forced to delay his purchases of USAir stock by many weeks.'' **********''He chose to circumvent those requirements,'' USAir's suit said, ''because they conflicted with his need to prevent the formation of another strong national carrier in competition with T.W.A.'' **********USAir's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission and sources involved in the takeover effort, including a source close to Mr. Icahn, suggest that Mr. Icahn was seeking to stop the USAir-Piedmont merger because the two carriers were prime candidates to either merge with T.W.A. or buy out his huge stake in T.W.A. **********The documents and sources indicated that Mr. Icahn was concerned that after the merger, it was unlikely that the Department of Transportation would allow T.W.A. to merge with the combined USAir-Piedmont because of competitive concerns. **********In addition, the industry's rapid consolidation had diminished the number of carriers to which he could sell his T.W.A. holdings. **********''His options became very limited,'' said a person close to the takeover effort. **********According to documents filed by USAir with the S.E.C., Mr. Icahn contacted Mr. Colodny several times to discuss a merger, from last September to this month. Last September, he also called Piedmont executives to inquire if they wanted to buy T.W.A. or to have T.W.A. acquire Piedmont, according to the court papers. **********According to the USAir suit, Mr. Icahn called Mr. Colodny on Feb. 21, saying that a merger between USAir and Piedmont would put T.W.A. in a tough competitive position and that he ''couldn't watch that happen.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/world.main_headline: POLAND ANNOUNCES BIG ECONOMIC SHIFT WITH RISE IN PRICES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/world.print_headline: POLAND ANNOUNCES BIG ECONOMIC SHIFT WITH RISE IN PRICES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/world.body_text: **********Poland's Government announced a package of far-reaching governmental and economic changes today mixing capitalism and socialism. It said the measures would bring higher prices and increased unemployment but would also create the conditions for advance. **********The measures appeared destined to change Poland's centralized Communist economy drastically, and many economists and officials say they pose a crucial test for the Government of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. **********It remained unclear how the Government would accommodate apparently conflicting elements of the program, elements that raised the specter of renewed social unrest. Effect on Living Standards **********The Government announced that fundamental changes in the price and wage system would entail broad price increases. Yet it pledged there would be no drop in the standard of living. **********The program foresees expansion of the rules for bankruptcy proceedings, which would entail the liquidation of uneconomical state-run companies and raise the likelihood of wider unemployment. Yet the Government pledged not to budge from its commitment to full employment for all Poles. **********Prime Minister Zbigniew Messner said that as a result of the economic crisis, society was growing impatient, and that there was ''tiredness with everyday life hardships.'' Evokes Gorbachev's Efforts **********As he laid the measures before Parliament, the Prime Minister evoked the spirit of the changes in the Soviet Union under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, which have been referred to as glasnost, or openness, and perestroika, or restructuring. **********''The rightful character of the direction that we selected is confirmed by processes now under way in other member states of the socialist community,'' he said. ''Soviet perestroika has become a symbol here.'' **********If carried out over coming months, the measures would enable Poland to challenge the role of Hungary as the most daring economic innovator in the East bloc. Last month, Budapest announced a series of austerity measures, telling Hungarians they would have to tighten their belts for an indefinite period if better economic times were to follow. **********In an apparent effort to gain a measure of popular support for the Polish changes, Parliament agreed to a national referendum Nov. 29 to determine the pace and extent of the program. **********It was made clear that the Government would not ask the population whether it desired the changes, but merely how quickly and with what intensity. **********The Government also announced it intended to introduce fundamental changes in the political system. But it did not elaborate, saying only that they would be discussed at a special session of the Communist Party's Central Committee in November. **********Within several months the Government plans to break up the monolithic state banking system, allowing competing commercial banks to operate, and to create the East bloc's second securities market, after Hungary. **********There was litle excitement and no applause in the Parliament building as Mr. Messner, in a voice free of emotion, announced that the Government would scale back its commitment in an area once sacred to Communist governments by requiring citizens to pay a larger share for health services, entertainment and cultural events. **********The Government laid before Parliament its economic program through the end of 1990. It described the program as the second stage of reform following efforts begun in 1981, after martial law was imposed to crush the Solidarity labor movement. Speaks Candidly of Economy **********While Mr. Messner said the first stage had enabled Poland ''to accumulate a number of valuable experiences,'' he spoke candidly of current economic conditions. **********''There are bureaucratic overgrowths, erroneous motivational systems, shortcomings in the organization of labor, lack of respect for social property,'' he said. Then, borrowing a witticism common to the streets of Communist countries, he added, ''In extreme cases, the people pretend to be working, and the enterprise pretends to pay them.'' **********The Prime Minister said the program was designed to meet conditions set by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank for initiating aid to Poland. ''The fund's stance is that solutions in the sphere of incomes and prices should be quick, firm and profound,'' he said. **********Indeed, the keystone of the measures incorporates a drastic overhaul of the centralized system of prices and wages, which officials said could yield markedly higher prices for basic goods and raise the possibility of social unrest. The idea is to link wage levels more closely to company profitability as a spur to efficient operation. 'Negative Effects for Some' **********Wieslaw Sadowski, the Deputy Prime Minister and architect of the program, said, ''It is quite clear that serious restructuring is not possible without negative effects for some groups.'' **********''We cannot secure wages to anybody, except minimum wages,'' Mr. Sadowski said. **********The Government, however, evidently fearful of the potential for unrest, announced a wide-reaching system of family grants, apparently designed to offset the removal of price subsidies. **********''In keeping with the general assumptions of the income policy of the Government, the standard of living of the population would not be lowered,'' Mr. Messner said. More Self-Management Seen The Government package contains three sets of measures, one designed to stimulate productivity and supply, the second to change the currency system and the system of prices and wages, and the third to restructure the management of the economy. **********The central Government's administration of the economy would be scaled back - Mr. Sadowski said the number of high-level bureaucrats would be cut to about 100 from 194 - accompanied by ''gradual reduction of the scope of detailed substantive planning.'' **********Productivity would be stimulated through introduction of a large measure of self-management and self-financing into state-controlled industries. **********But the Government also said it would seek to broaden the activities of the economy's private sector by dismantling the hurdles to operating private companies, particularly in the areas of retail trade food services and the production of building materials. **********The program generally consists of the enunciation of goals and principles, without expounding in detail how they would be put into effect. **********Thus, though the program made a strong commitment to stirring the private sector, it made little mention of the liberalization of markets for materials, equipment and capital, which until now have posed formidable obstacles to private entrepreneurs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/25/busin.main_headline: About Real Estate; Renovators in Greenpoint Tackle New Construction
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/25/busin.print_headline: About Real Estate; Renovators in Greenpoint Tackle New Construction
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/25/busin.body_text: **********For as long as anyone there can remember, the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn has functioned as a stable blue-collar community with large Polish and Italian populations living in small houses and apartment buildings. In the last five years, however, artists and young professionals have flooded into the area looking for affordable housing and willing to pay prices that are out of reach for long-time residents but a bargain for people moving from Manhattan. **********Michael D'Annunzio, born and reared in Greenpoint, and his wife, Elina Gonzalez-D'Annunzio of Brooklyn Heights, have scrambled to fill the niche. As a development team, these principals of South Heights Construction have renovated four small vacant apartment buildings - one in Williamsburg and the others in Greenpoint - with the apartments renting for $600 to $800 a month. **********Now they are undertaking their first new construction, a 14-unit condominium building at 102 Guernsey Street, between Norman and Nassau Avenues, a mixed block of residential and commercial buildings. The development is next door to the home of Mr. D'Annunzio's parents and a few houses from his own home. Mr. D'Annunzio's father, Emidio, provided the 6,500-square-foot site, which used to be a parking lot. **********Work on the foundation began last week. The four-story red brick building will be called Florence Courts, after Michael D'Annunzio's mother. **********''We know all the ins and outs of renovation, but this is a new phase for us,'' Mrs. Gonzalez said, pointing at the foundation with its pools of muddy water, as her two young girls skipped on the sidewalk. ''Condos seemed too big time for us. We were small contractors. We're excited, nervous.'' **********The project, apparently the first new condominium building in Greenpoint, is scheduled for completion next summer. Four one-bedroom apartments, eight two-bedrooms and two three-bedrooms, measuring from 600 to 1,000 square feet, will cost from $135,000 to $175,000. The architect is Paul Draskovic of Manhattan. **********The D'Annunzios expect the condominium buyers to have roots in the community. ''Ten years ago my friends didn't want to live here when they moved out of their parents' houses,'' said the 36-year-old Mr. D'Annunzio. ''They moved to suburbia, but when their wives had babies the fact was they couldn't afford to stay there. Now they want to come back, but you can't buy a house here. It's all word-of-mouth, and the cheapest one is $165,000.'' **********Last year the couple finished their most elaborate renovation so far. The four-story turn-of-the-century building at 125 Guernsey Street between Norman and Meserole Avenues (a half block from the condominium site) had been heavily damaged by a fire a few years ago. When their company, South Heights Construction, bought the tan brick building for $25,000 through a request for proposals issued by the Department of Housing Preservation and Developments, the building lacked a roof, stairs and part of the cornice. **********As in their other renovations, they replaced all the mechanical systems, installed new windows and erected new walls, besides restoring the roof and cornice. Today a bright red door leads to a carpeted stairway, off which are eight apartments - four one-bedrooms and four twos with monthly rents ranging from $600 to $800. The building is now full. **********''It's a very young building, and I know almost everyone,'' said Charles Redguard, 22, a pharmaceutical salesman. ''This is ideal for me. I could never find a $600-a-month one-bedroom in Manhattan.'' **********The developers also did the nearby renovation of a four-story brick building at 57 Norman Avenue, at the corner of Guernsey Street, into eight rental units in 1984 and the rehabilitation of a four-story building at 296 Nassau Avenue, off Hausman Street, into nine apartments in 1985. **********Financing for the condominium, as well as 296 Nassau Avenue and 125 Guernsey Street, came from the Community Preservation Corporation, which does market-rate lending in neighborhoods that have a hard time attracting major creditors. The D'Annunzio project represents the 13-year-old company's first new-construction financing. **********''Michael and Elina have demonstrated an ability to take on new challenges,'' said Mary A. Brennan, a Community Preservation vice president. ''It's fair to say that he's a little bit nervous about his first new construction project, and so are we. But the two of them have excelled at bringing projects in ahead of schedule and under budget.'' **********The D'Annunzios are now negotiating with the city's housing agency for development rights to a major site in Williamsburg. The three vacant buildings there, at 28-32 Havemeyer Street off North Seventh Street, would probably yield 32 units - either condominiums or rental apartments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/28/busin.body_text: **********The Economy **********The U.S. suffered a $14.8 billion trade deficit in January as imports flowed at nearly twice the level of exports. The showing was much worse than in December, though not nearly as bad as November's revised $15.4 billion trade gap. Some prominent private economists said the January results were a warning signal that the nation's trade deficit will be hard to turn around, and legislators said the figures were bound to increase the momentum for protectionist legislation. But Reagan Administration officials insisted that their forecasts of a $30 billion to $40 billion reduction in this year's deficit were still possible.  [ Page 39. ] **********The Consumer Price Index jumped 0.7 percent in January, the biggest increase in four and a half years. The rise in the most widely followed inflation gauge exceeded general expectations and prompted some experts to express uneasiness about price trends. However, other economists remained unperturbed by the upturn; they noted that much of the gain reflected higher oil prices, which have turned down again, and a rise in the volatile food sector.  [ 39. ]  The Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose a sharp 0.8 percent in January, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported.  [ 41. ] **********The prices paid to farmers for raw products were unchanged in February from a revised January index, according to the Agriculture Department.  [ 40. ] International **********Brazil's troubles have spurred moves by international banks and Western governments to prevent similar problems from spreading throughout Latin America's debtor nations. Venezuala and Chile have signed debt-restructuring accords, Argentina has gained a $500 million short-term loan and Mexico is expected to sign a $7.7 billion loan package.  [ 39. ]  Brazil's Finance Minister called for smoother arrangements with lending organizations to insure long-term capital flows to debtor nations. The minister, Dilson Funaro, is seeking to turn Brazil's suspension of debt payments into broad intergovernmental discussions on debt reform.  [ 42. ] Markets **********Stock prices rose slightly in quieter trading. Although Wall Street largely ignored the Reagan Administration's troubles, investors seemed distracted. The Dow Jones industrial average, coming off a losing session on Thursday, rose 7.31 points, to 2,223.99. The Dow fell 11.25 points for the relatively quiet week.  [ 43. ] **********Interest rates slipped as prices edged up in the credit market, despite the fact that consumer prices and the trade deficit for January showed stronger-than-expected increases. The discount rates on Treasury bills were essentially unchanged, while prices of notes and bonds showed moderate gains.  [ 42. ] **********The dollar inched higher in a narrow trading range. Dealers shrugged off negative reports on the nation's trade deficit and inflation but continued to worry about possible central bank intervention. In New York, gold dropped 75 cents, to $405.25 an ounce.  [ 48. ] **********Cattle futures rallied strongly with the nearby live cattle contract advancing the 1 1/2-cents-a-pound limit for daily trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. On other markets, grain and soybean futures advanced, while energy futures were lower.  [ 48. ] Companies **********Purolator disclosed it was weighing an acquisition bid, but it declined to name the bidder or the size of the bid. For months, the company's chief executive has been seeking a good offer.  [ 40. ] **********Tri-Star ended talks on the possible purchase of movie theaters owned by United Artists Communications. The deal would have been worth $500 million.  [ 40. ] Today's Columns **********More small investors are shifting money to real estate pools from such traditional products as stocks, bonds and money market funds. At least four mutual fund management companies are offering the pools, although some fund managers contend that they will not necessarily benefit investors. Your Money.  [ 40. ] **********A compact fluorescent lamp can be used in an ordinary incandescent light bulb socket with an adapter patented for North American Philips. Patents.  [ 40. ]

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/10/busin.body_text: **********TUESDAY, MARCH 10, 1987  Companies **********Chrysler will acquire American Motors for about $1.5 billion. Although the struggling A.M.C. is a tiny company by auto industry standards, it could bring Chrysler a chance to expand its market share by a few important percentage points. The deal would also give Chrysler the highly profitable Jeep off-road vehicles to broaden its lineup. Chrysler will buy the 46 percent of American Motors held by Renault and offer to buy the remaining shares from the public. The A.M.C. deal represents a milestone in the remarkable comeback by Chrysler, which averted bankruptcy in the late 1970's.  [ Page A1. ]  Renault is selling its A.M.C. stake so it can put its assets to better use in Europe.  [ D9. ] **********The Haft family offered to buy Supermarkets General for $1.6 billion in cash, or $41.75 a share. The food and drug chain, with more than 300 stores in the East, operates under the Pathmark and Purity Supreme names. The company is expected to oppose the bid vigorously. Last year, the Hafts made nearly $160 million in an unsuccessful bid for Safeway Stores.  [ D1. ] **********Harper & Row received an unexpected $190 million bid from Theodore Cross, a lawyer and editor. Mr. Cross said $170 million would come from the First National Bank of Boston and he would put up the rest. The 170-year-old publisher is on the best-seller list with ''The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe.''  [ D1. ] **********USAir agreed to acquire Piedmont for $1.59 billion, ending a three-week-old contest for control of one of the fastest growing and most profitable carriers in the deregulated airline industry. The pact appears to strengthen the ability of USair to resist an unwelcome takeover advance by Carl C. Icahn, chairman of T.W.A.  [ D1. ] **********A hostile tender offer for Caesars World was begun by Martin T. Sosnoff, a New York investor and money manager. Caesars said its board would study the $735 million bid from Mr. Sosnoff, who has twice failed to gain a seat on the company's board. Some analysts said his $28-a-share bid was too low.  [ D1. ]  Donald J. Trump will buy 73 percent of Resorts International for $79 million, apparently ending the bidding for the gambling and hotel concern.  [ D5. ] **********Allegheny International agreed to a leveraged buyout for $500 million by a First Boston affiliate. The buyout is part of a continuing trend in which major investment banks are investing their own capital to facilitate deals.  [ D4. ] **********Walt Disney agreed to acquire a Los Angeles television station, the independent KHJ-TV, in a complex deal.  [ D4. ] Markets **********Takeover stocks soared in wild trading, helping to offset somewhat a broad decline in the overall market. The overall weakness in the market was attributed by many to Robert Prechter's prediction of an approaching downturn. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.11 points, to 2,260.12.  [ D1. ] **********Interest rates were little changed in the credit markets as traders and dealers were unconvinced by forecasts calling for higher or lower rates.  [ D23. ] **********The dollar turned higher against most major currencies except the British pound in a narrow range of trading. In New York, gold dropped $1.25, to $404.50.  [ D21. ]  Prices of crude oil and petroleum products sagged a bit, after having climbed nearly $2 in a week. Oil analysts attributed the decline to profit taking.  [ D21. ] The Economy **********States have broad power to restrict underground mining to protect the land above the mines, the Supreme Court held in a 5-to-4 decision. The ruling upholds a Pennsylvania law that requires mining companies to leave millions of ton of coal in the ground.  [ D2. ] **********Interest rates on mortgage loans continued to drop in February, reaching the lowest levels in almost nine years, according to two Government surveys.  [ D7. ]  Americans took out $536 million more in consumer debt than they paid off in January, up only slightly from an extremely small December increase.  [ D7. ] Today's Columns **********Price stability in the troubled steel industry appears likely for the rest of this year, according to Walter F. Williams, chairman and chief executive of Bethlehem Steel. Talking Business.  [ D2. ] **********The stock market is luring a great deal of I.R.A. money, with mutual funds the No. 1 attraction. The big concern among fund managers is the effect of the expected shrinkage in fresh I.R.A. contributions after the April 15 tax deadline. Market Place.  [ D10. ]

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/23/busin.main_headline: Wall St. Phones Were Kept Busy
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/23/busin.print_headline: MARKET TURMOIL; Wall St. Phones Were Kept Busy
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/23/busin.body_text: **********On Monday the New York Telephone Company reported that telephone traffic in the Wall Street area remained the same as for any normal business day. But Monday was anything but a normal business day with the stock market taking a record-breaking plunge. **********Now, after reviewing its figures, New York Telephone said yesterday that the number of phone calls in southern Manhattan, which includes Wall Street, rose 8.8 percent Monday. **********Tina Gimas, a company spokeswoman, said that the area originated 11.1 million calls on Oct. 19, compared with 10.2 million calls on Oct. 5, which she called a ''typical'' Monday. **********Telephone calls from the Upper East Side and Upper West Side residential areas of Manhattan rose 4.5 percent during the day, with calls from the East Side increasing 6.8 percent Monday evening, the company said. It took phone company engineers a few days to determine the exact increase in calling volume, Ms. Gimas said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/03/busin.body_text: **********THE turnover in presidencies and other executive positions at the nation's colleges and universities has grown rapidly in recent years. **********Heidrick & Struggles, a management recruiting firm that began finding presidents for colleges 10 years ago, says the business now constitutes about 10 percent of its gross revenues. **********Looking back at its first effort, when it found a president for Brown University, William J. Bowen, a vice chairman of Heidrick & Struggles, recalled, ''We were reluctant to do the search because we had no experience finding college presidents.'' **********Now the firm is so deeply involved in finding presidents, deans, private school principals and other academic officials that it has published its first academic survey. Released last week and titled ''The University and College President,'' it offers a profile of the position. **********The typical president is a white Protestant male, 53 years old, with a doctoral degree; is married and has not been divorced; has an academic background, but not necessarily as a tenured professor, and has held the post about six years. That merely reflects what is, of course. Many universities would be happy to fill openings with qualified candidates from more diverse backgrounds. **********Mr. Bowen cannot recall when there were so many openings for college presidents. ''The tenure of many in office - 40 percent - now is about three years,'' he said. At many schools, however - the Ivy League, the Southwestern conference, and women's colleges including Bryn Mawr, Mount Holyoke, Smith and Wellesley, presidents tend to stay on the job longer than average. **********Some of the most recent comings and goings: Colin Campbell, president of Wesleyan University, announced last week that he was leaving; James O. Freedman left the University of Iowa to head Dartmouth, replacing a lawyer, David T. McLaughlin. **********In addition, George D. Langdon stepped down at Colgate University, and Oakes Ames at Connecticut College. Daniel Berg has left the Rensselaer Polytechnic presidency to return to a tenured professorship. There is also the former president of Princeton University, whom Mr. Bowen of Heidrick & Struggles calls ''the other Bill Bowen.'' Princeton's William G. Bowen resigned to head the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, and has been replaced by Harold T. Shapiro, former president of the University of Michigan. Dr. Howard Swearer is leaving Brown University. **********''I am not sure why so many presidents have stepped aside, but I think it might be a burnout factor, but not the same problems like the sit-ins and riots of the Vietnam period,'' Mr. Bowen said. He explained that independent colleges and universities and a growing number of state-supported schools ask their presidents to be fund-raisers. **********''They don't like to do it year after year,'' he said. ''They become drained.'' **********Facing six dinners this week, Dr. Edward Lewis, president of St. Mary's College, a state-supported liberal arts college in Maryland, agrees about the burnout factor. ''Furthermore, social interaction can be painful for some academics,'' he said. ''Also, we are robbed of time to think.'' **********He said he thought that the opportunities for women presidents were growing but added that there ''has been a belief that fund raising involves working the old-boy network, which cannot be done as well by women as by the typical 53-year-old male president.'' **********He pointed to Dr. Hannah Gray, president of the University of Chicago, as a woman who made the jump to a presidency recently. ''Also there is Dr. Patricia Plante, a former dean at another college, who now is president of one of the University of Maine's units,'' he said. **********Fund raising aside, the life of a college president can be quite pleasant. They usually occupy a mansion on or near campus rent-free. A staff is also provided, which means instant help when entertaining. **********The pay is good, too. The survey indicates that college presidents average $89,450 a year, with some large Eastern universities paying more than $100,000. **********College presidents who responded to the survey said they worked 67 or more hours a week. While faculty members often can take the summer off to travel, or just think, college presidents average less than three weeks of vacation. **********More than 87 percent of the presidents have doctorates, an indication that most institutions are still headed by academics despite reports that some successful businessmen would like to assume the presidencies of some schools. **********Presidents have to serve several constituencies, including contentious faculty and difficult trustees, which makes them often feel as if they are skating on thin ice. **********According to the survey, 87 percent of the presidents named as their first objective ''recruitment, promotion and retention'' of high-level personnel. In other words, care and feeding of faculty egos takes precedence over the trustees, who win the next highest consideration, and the students, for whom the education is intended. **********For the survey Heidrick & Struggles reached 971 presidents of four-year degree-giving institutions with 1,000 or more students. They received a response of more than 33 percent, which is considered a good return.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/01/world.main_headline: AFGHANS SUGGEST SOVIET TIMETABLE FOR WITHDRAWAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/01/world.print_headline: AFGHANS SUGGEST SOVIET TIMETABLE FOR WITHDRAWAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/01/world.body_text: **********The Afghan leader, Najibullah, proposed a 12-month timetable today for the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan, where they have been fighting Islamic guerrillas for eight years. **********''This is the summit proposal,'' a western diplomat said tonight, referring to the coming meeting between Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and President Reagan in Washington, at which Afghanistan is expected to be a topic of talks. **********''That is why he said it,'' the diplomat said. ''This is the timetable they are offering.'' All-Powerful Presidency **********Mr. Najibullah said his proposal had ''already been negotiated with the Soviet side.'' Previously, the Afghan Government had set a 16-month withdrawal plan in United Nations sponsored talks in Geneva. Pakistan, which is the host to leaders in an alliance of seven Islamic guerrilla groupings, as well as nearly four million refugees, has called for an eight-month withdrawal period.  [ At a Washington briefing, speaking in response to a general question, Michael H. Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, said: ''If they indicate a reasonable time frame for getting out, then there are perhaps ways in which we can help. But the fundamental problem is the occupation, and that requires a timetable for withdrawal.'' ]  Mr. Najibullah's proposal - delivered this evening as he assumed the all-powerful office of president under a new constitution - prompted considerable diplomatic speculation in the complex military and political tangle here. The offer, according to terms the Russians have previously outlined, would be on the condition of a halt to American aid to the guerrillas. Sullying International Image **********Even as Mr. Najibullah was speaking of peace this evening, Government artillery pounded away in the darkness at suspected rebel positions in the mountains surrounding the capital. **********''People in the various capitals are going to have to look at this with some care,'' a European diplomat said. ''You should note that this is the same figure Pravda wrote was a realistic timetable.'' **********Mr. Gorbachev has said he would like to pull the 115,000 Soviet troops out of the impasse here, which has caused difficulties for the Soviet Government at home and abroad. Soviet troops moved into Afghanistan in December 1979, as the Soviet Government said its soldiers had been asked by the Kabul Government to help quell fighting there. A Moscow Protege **********But the quandary for Moscow, diplomats here say, is that the withdrawal of Soviet troops would inevitably mean the collapse of the regime they have sponsored. **********The Russians installed Mr. Najibullah as the local party leader in May, 1986, and he is regarded as a Moscow protege. **********For the last two days, Mr. Najibullah has been holding a gathering of tribal chiefs and elders, in this case dominated by party loyalists - to adopt a new constitution billed as an instrument of ''national reconciliation.'' **********The most salient feature of the constitution, unanimously approved this afternoon, is the creation of an all-powerful president, who is supreme commander of the army and posesses sweeping emergency powers. **********After hours of speeches extolling his virtues, Mr. Najibullah was unanimously elected president by the gathering this evening. He was the only candidate. **********At one point today one delegate, a tribal chieftain, got into a gun battle with security men who refused to let his armed bodyguards accompany him into the meeting hall. Five tribesmen and three soldiers were reported killed in the clash. **********The chieftain, Esmatullah Muslim, who defected from the rebels two years ago and was named an army general and member of the ruling revolutionary council, escaped the initial clash. **********At midafternoon, Government forces besieged his walled compound, which was defended by more than a hundred armed followers. **********The Afghan leader said the 12 months for withdrawal could be further reduced if the seven-party guerrilla alliance accepted a Government cease-fire. **********Diplomats here said it was almost inconceivable that the guerrillas would accept the Government offer. **********And with Mr. Najibullah holding sweeping presidential powers, they said, it was unlikely that opposition groups would join a coalition government. **********Mr. Najibullah addressed by name eight guerrilla leaders operating in Afghanistan, including one of the best known, Ahmed Massoud, who controls most of the northwest sector. Mr. Najibullah said he would pull Soviet troops out of their areas if they would agree to peace. **********''He is trying to split them from the leaders in Pakistan,'' a diplomat said of the proposal. ''He is saying 'if you want to rule your area, I will get these people, the Russians, off your back.''  U.S. Expects Pullout Date **********WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (Special to The New York Times) - Mr. Armacost said in a summit briefing today that he hoped the meeting in Washington next week between President Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev ''would provide a date certain for the completion of withdrawal, and that's the critical point.'' **********Mr. Armacost gave no indication that he was aware of Mr. Najibullah's offer. **********The Reagan Administration has taken no public position on previous reports that the Soviet Union was willing to withdraw its 115,000 troops from Afghanistan within a year. **********It is not clear whether this period would be short enough to satisfy American concerns. The Administration does not want the Afghan rebels to become vulnerable after their military support is ended under agreements negotiated by the United Nations between Afghanistan and Pakistan. **********A State Department official said recently that some officials in Washington were not entirely happy with Pakistan's proposal for an eight-month withdrawal, but wanted a shorter period.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.main_headline: Political Lot of Reagan And Gorbachev Linked
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.print_headline: THE SUMMIT; Political Lot of Reagan And Gorbachev Linked
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.body_text: **********Two days of summit talks have demonstrated how closely President Reagan has tied his political fortunes to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the leader of the nation that Mr. Reagan has spent his entire career denouncing, according to political experts inside and outside the White House. **********As Mr. Reagan approaches his final year in office, he has only a few possibilities for major accomplishments. Heading the list are winning Senate approval of the treaty banning medium- and shorter-range nuclear weapons signed on Tuesday and reaching another agreement with the Soviet Union next year that would reduce long-range missiles. **********The way in which Mr. Reagan's future has become interwined with Mr. Gorbachev was symbolized today when the President invited the Soviet leader into his private study, just off the Oval Office, for a conversation outside the earshot of aides and notetakers at the outset of the meeting. **********''It was primarily a personal gesture,'' noted Marlin Fitzwater, the spokesman for the President, ''to set the tone and establish the nature of the relationship right off the bat this morning.'' Overnight Poll Taken **********Indeed, White House aides point out, Mr. Gorbachev has linked his own success at home to progress in arms-control talks with the United States. Accordingly, they say, both leaders are now dependent on each other. **********But if Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev have developed a personal rapport, and a common political interest, this summit has also demonstrated that they remain rivals in basic ways: for public attention, for press coverage and for influence and prestige around the world. **********The White House is keenly aware of this rivalry, and directed Richard Wirthlin, the President's pollster, to take overnight soundings of public reactions to the first day of the summit talks. One White House aide boasted that ''the President is coming off tremendously'' in the battle for public approval, but that view is not universally shared in the political world. **********Before the summit meeting began, Mr. Reagan joked that he was not worried that Mr. Gorbachev would steal the scene. After all, he noted, he had worked in films with Errol Flynn, the late actor known for his scene-stealing. But some White House aides admit that the Soviet leader has looked more vibrant and animated than Mr. Reagan, particularly in televised discussions with groups of Americans. President Looks Bored **********Mr. Reagan, who uses notecards to prompt his memory for even the most casual remark, would never engage in such an open and wide-ranging discussion. But one White House aide complained that Mr. Gorbachev is being held to a lower standard of performance than Mr. Reagan. **********''It's pretty easy to come in here and make general statements for two hours,'' he said. **********Some guests at the White House dinner Tuesday night thought Mr. Reagan looked bored and distracted at times, sitting silently with his hands in his lap. And the 76-year-old President, 20 years older than the Soviet leader, has kept a much more private schedule during the summit talks, husbanding his strength and energy for the intense exchanges with Mr. Gorbachev. **********The White House is clearly irritated with talk around Washington that Mr. Reagan cannot cope with the demands of the summit. 'Sort of a Touchy-Feely Summit' **********The President's advisers are bothered by the memory of the Reykjavik meeting last year, when Mr. Reagan seemed unprepared for the new arms control proposals advanced by the Russians. **********''The President gets tired of people asking, is he prepared, is he up for this,'' said one of the President's senior advisers. ''There are some in this Administration who are trying to create the impression that the President can't do anything unless they're out there, plowing the ground.'' **********Mr. Reagan's most important problem comes from his longtime conservative supporters, who are openly alarmed at the sight of their longstanding hero bargaining with the leader of what he once called the ''evil empire''. **********One White House official with close ties to the conservative movement, said: ''I hear from people outside who are very, very upset. This is Carter-like, sort of a touchy-feely summit, instead of being specific about the major differences that divide the two countries.'' **********To those conservatives, the aide added, Mr. Reagan is ''too concerned with his place in history,'' and has thus ''gotten soft'' in his views toward the Russians. 'Sober, but at Ease' Approach **********The more common view in the White House, however, is that the summit is going as planned, and that Mr. Gorbachev's strong presence works to enhance Mr. Reagan's as well. In fact, the White House wanted the Soviet leader to meet with Congressional leaders, as he did today, because they thought he would be an effective advocate for the treaty, which must still win Senate approval. **********As for the President's own performance so far, Mr. Reagan's aides said he was doing what he set out to do in his pre-summit planning. **********One aide described his approach as ''sober, but at ease,'' and noted that Mr. Reagan sprinkled his remarks with folksy humor and stories. **********Another aide said Mr. Reagan was effectively conveying the message he wanted to convey. As that adviser put it: ''It's important to make the point over and over again. This shows that peace through strength works.'' **********White House aides are also delighted with the personal chemistry between the two leaders, which has showed itself in humorous public exchanges, as well as in their private chat this morning. **********''These are two superpower leaders,'' said Mr. Fitzwater, ''who know how to sort out the wheat from the chaff. And they know the tough bargaining, and they know the tough talk. But they also know how to deal on personal, friendly relations, and this meeting was part of that.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/14/busin.main_headline: A Top Treasury Officer Is Going to Law Firm
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/14/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A Top Treasury Officer Is Going to Law Firm
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/14/busin.body_text: **********J. Roger Mentz, the Treasury's top tax officer and the point man on the Netherlands Antilles controversy, will join the Washington office of Cadwalader Wickersham & Taft, the New York law firm, in September. His deputy, O. Donaldson Chapoton, will probably succeed him. **********Mr. Mentz, 43, was active in last October's overhaul of the tax system. He joined the Treasury as deputy assistant secretary just as the tax issue was beginning. Made assistant secretary the following December, he became the Administration's full-time shepherd of the plan that Congress enacted. **********However some elements of the tax laws escaped the bill's objectives of fairness, simplicity and loophole-closing. Prominent among them was the tax treaty with the Netherlands Antilles, which is used by American corporations to sell debt in the Eurobond market and by some Americans to avoid taxes. **********On June 29, Mr. Mentz decided to cancel the treaty, effective at the end of the year. But the announcement caused such upset in the markets, that the Treasury watered down the plan. ''But I'm very glad to have it resolved,'' he said. **********None of this figured into Mr. Mentz's departure plans, he said. ''The timing of all this had been planned for several months.'' He said, correctly, that assistant secretaries for tax policy rarely last beyond two years. **********Mr. Mentz is an alumnus of Princeton and the University of Virginia Law School. He joined the Treasury after 19 years with Mudge, Rose, Guthrie, Alexander & Ferdon in New York. At Cadwalader, he is expected to specialize in international tax issues.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/16/busin.body_text: **********Assets of the nation's 407 money market mutual funds grew $1.16 billion, to $247.18 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 107 institutional funds fell $30.5 million, to $65.08 billion. The 207 general purpose funds rose $763.2 million, to $74 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds rose $424.2 million, to $108.1 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/05/world.main_headline: G.O.P. to Report on Iran Deal Special to The New York Times
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/05/world.print_headline: G.O.P. to Report on Iran Deal Special to The New York Times
