https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/05/world.body_text: **********Republican members of the House committee on the Iran-contra affair have concluded that President Reagan did not know about the diversion of profits from the Iran arms sales to Nicaraguan rebel groups, Congressional officials said today. **********They said a draft of the report, scheduled for release this month, also asserts that Congressional restrictions on aid to the contra rebels did not apply to the National Security Council. **********The report's conclusions, some of which were first disclosed today by United Press International, are intended to refute a majority report that is said to leave open the question of whether President Reagan knew about the diversion of millions of dollars to the contras. Vote Due on Final Report **********The House and Senate committees investigting the affair are scheduled to vote today on a final report of their inquiry. **********Congressional officials said the majority report would also argue that restrictions on contra aid under the Boland Amendment did apply to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and other National Security Council staff members. **********The 1,000-page majority report is expected to be signed by all Democrats on the House and Senate committees, and by at least three Senate Republicans. **********Republican members on the House panel, who have vigorously defended the President's actions in the Iran-contra affair, had long planned to release a separate report. In an appearance today before a Federal grand jury investigating the affair, Colonel North testified briefly, frequently leaving the jury room to consult with his lawyers. **********Legal figures with knowledge of the testimony would not discuss details of Colonel North's appearance, but said it was largely ''technical.'' **********The appearance, which lasted less than 30 minutes, followed a shouting match in a hallway of the Federal District Court here between Colonel North's chief lawyer, Brendan V. Sullivan, and a prosecutor in the case. **********At one point Mr. Sullivan was overheard yelling, ''We've always followed the law.'' **********Under grand jury rules, Colonel North could not bring counsel into the jury room but was allowed to leave when necessary to consult with Mr. Sullivan and another lawyer, Barry Simon. After Colonel North's testimony, he and Mr. Sullivan left the courthouse, refusing to comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/11/busin.main_headline: Get Business on the Government's Side
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/11/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: ADVICE FOR MRS. AQUINO; Get Business on the Government's Side
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/11/busin.body_text: **********NEARLY a year after the defeat of Ferdinand Marcos, the Philippine economy remains capital-starved and in trouble - per capita economic growth fell for the second straight year in 1986. Frightened by political instability, both American and Philippine executives continue to withhold new investment. Unfortunately, with the future of the Aquino Government hanging on the performance of the economy, this reluctance has itself become a major source of instability. **********Why the inaction? After all, segments of the Philippine business community proved their daring by taking an early and outspoken stand against the Marcos regime. And American executives murmured in enthusiastic response when President Corazon Aquino called for renewed investment during her triumphant tour of the United States a few months ago. **********Moreover, this is a country wealthy in agricultural lands and natural resources. Its currency has stabilized and the rate of inflation is below that of the United States. Capital flight has slowed. Labor is abundant, competent and inexpensive. Finally, the United States Government, in word and deed, has emphasized its continuing support of the Aquino Administration in its struggle to shape a viable, moderate political mandate. **********Despite these promising aspects, many business leaders apparently fear that the process of political rejuvenation is still incomplete; that, like the storming of the Bastille on July 14, 1789, the Peoples Power drama of last February signaled the beginning and not the end of the revolution. This reasoning is clearly evident in the actions of the ''Filipino-Chinese'' community. **********In the Philippines, as in other Southeast Asian countries, Chinese immigrants and their descendants play a signal role in the economy. The Filipino-Chinese business community is highly sensitive to potential tremors, which accounts for the anomaly of capital flight out of the Philippines peaking in the months before, and not after, the murder of Benigno Aquino in 1983. Regrettably, their fears have yet to fade. Respected members of the Filipino-Chinese community told me recently that funds were not yet returning for direct investments. **********The general concern over instability translates into the specific worry that President Aquino is ill-equipped to deal with the serious and violent threats from both ends of the political spectrum. Perhaps this is a valid anxiety. However, in November Mrs. Aquino clearly demonstrated that she was more the dragon-lady than the housewife when she dealt with the challenge of former Defense Minister Juan Enrile. And it now appears that she would not succumb to accommodations with the Communists, which could lead to their infiltrating and eventually dominating the country's political institutions. **********However, the investment drought may have less to do with politics than with the failure of the Aquino Administration to demonstrate a unified commitment to the private sector and to foreign investment. Mrs. Aquino may sincerely believe in the contributions foreign investors can make to the Philippines. And her competent Ministers of Finance and Trade, Jamie Ongpin and Jose Concepcion, may firmly support a dynamic private sector. But the words and actions of others in the Government make a different impression. For example, the number of strikes in 1986 may exceed by 50 percent those in 1985. A majority of these were instigated by the Communist-controlled Kilusang Mayo Uno, the largest union in the Philippines. But many observers also point a finger at the Minister of Labor, Augusto Sanchez, for his statements attributing economic problems to the private sector and for his criticisms of foreign investors. With an unemployment rate surpassing 30 percent and with underemployment even higher, a Minister of Labor should be more interested in urging businesses to create new jobs than in engaging in irresponsible confrontations. A FURTHER example is provided by the Presidential Commission for Good Government. Established to recover the wealth stolen by President Marcos, his friends and relatives, the commission sometimes appears vengeful and arbitrary, interested more in ''getting even'' than getting money. Assets of targeted companies have been sequestered, apparently to force them into quick cash settlements and to avoid a drawn-out legal process during which the sequestered assets would diminish in value. These actions are destructive of the business climate, not to speak of the companies in question and their thousands of employees. **********While the alleged billions of dollars stolen by Mr. Marcos would go far in reviving the crippled economy, the Government cannot look upon the money as a quick fix. Legal and administrative roadblocks in the Philippines, the United States, Switzerland and other foreign countries make recovery a frustrating, long-term task. **********As bleak as the economic situation may seem, there are several immediate steps the Aquino administration can take to regain the initiative. **********First, her administration should speak in a single voice in defining the moral and operational terms in which foreign investors can function in the Philippines. Business can live with constraints and risks, as long as they are clearly stated. It is Mrs. Aquino's prerogative to have Cabinet ministers openly hostile to the private sector or to foreign investors certainly, but such voices are a costly luxury at a time of great unemployment and economic stagnation. **********Second, realizing that the Marcos wealth will not be recovered quickly, the commission should concentrate its recovery efforts overseas. Its activities in the Philippines should be limited strictly to instances where there is clear and promptly confirmable evidence that the Marcos family and cronies were hidden owners. **********Lastly, the Government should open talks about the United States military bases. The rental price for the facilities at Clark Field and Subic Bay Naval Station should be determined on the basis of ''market value.'' Just what are the Russians paying for Camranh Bay in Vietnam and for secret airfields in Cambodia? If their rental is $1 billion a year, then the United States should be asked to pay $1 billion a year for its bases in the Philippines (we are now paying $900 million over five years). These funds could be applied in part to the retirement of the $26 billion Philippine foreign debt. Moreover, management of the non-military aspects of the bases should be transferred to a civilian corporation, which would be a joint venture of American and Philippine companies. **********Foreign investment in concert with a confident domestic private sector has been a winning combination in many Asian countries and could work in the Philippines. However, President Aquino must demonstrate a commitment to this approach. Meanwhile, American and Filipino businessmen will watch and wait.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/world.main_headline: SHULTZ MEETS WITH LEADER OF REBELS IN SOUTH AFRICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/world.print_headline: SHULTZ MEETS WITH LEADER OF REBELS IN SOUTH AFRICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/world.body_text: **********Oliver Tambo, the head of the African National Congress, called on Secretary of State George P. Shultz today to use American influence to press other Western countries to impose economic sanctions on South Africa at least as strong as those enacted by Congress over President Reagan's veto. **********Emerging from a 50-minute meeting with Mr. Shultz, Mr. Tambo said he had also urged a broadening of the American sanctions. **********The meeting marked the first time any Secretary of State had met with Mr. Tambo, whose organization, which advocates voting rights for blacks and an end to apartheid in South Africa, is banned by the Pretoria authorities. It also was an indication that the United States recognizes the A.N.C. as a central factor in the South Africa struggle and is willing to engage in discussions with the organization. **********The State Department did not allow news photographers into the session, although an official State Department photographer took pictures. Mr. Redman said that it was not customary for news photographers to be present during meetings that did not involve foreign ministers or other officials of a foreign government. But it is not unusual for photographers to take pictures before or after such sessions. **********Mr. Shultz held the meeting amid criticism from conservatives, who have condemned the Congress as a pro-Soviet terrorist organization. The Secretary addressed these two issues at the outset of the discussions, according to Charles E. Redman, the State Department spokesman. He said that Mr. Shultz had ''laid out our concerns about the degree of Soviet influence in the A.N.C.'' and the group's use of violence. 'Very Serious' Meeting **********Mr. Tambo, who makes his headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia, called it ''a very serious and substantive meeting,'' and Mr. Redman used the same characterization. **********''We found there was a large area of agreement on the nature of the apartheid system, on the need to abolish it, and we are considering together the ways of achieving this,'' Mr. Tambo said. He criticized the Administration's ''constructive engagement'' policy, under which Washington has sought to exert quiet pressure on South Africa, as ''unhelpful'' in combating apartheid. **********Although Mr. Shultz's stated purpose was to explore the possibility of an American role as a broker in the South African conflict, State Department officials acknowledged that the meeting was largely symbolic and, in part, an effort to defuse criticism of American policy by black African leaders. **********Mr. Redman emphasized the Secretary's desire ''to work with all of the parties, to bring them together so they can start talking.'' The South African authorities have refused to negotiate with the African National Congress. Relations at a Low Point **********The session with Mr. Shultz comes at a time when relations between Washington and Pretoria are at a low point and American influence with the South African Government appears practically nonexistent. **********In an unusual show of force, dozens of uniformed policemen were stationed in and around the diplomatic entrance to the State Department, and the adjoining street was closed to traffic along the full length of the building. **********Mr. Shultz's decision to meet with Mr. Tambo drew strong criticism from the Conservative Caucus, which condemned the A.N.C. for both its use of violence and its ties to the Soviet Union. Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, said yesterday that he feared that the session would be seen as showing approval for terrorism. Use of Violence Endorsed **********During his visit to Washington, Mr. Tambo has endorsed the use of violence in the struggle against apartheid. **********''Apartheid is inherently a practice of violence,'' he said yesterday in a speech at Georgetown University. ''We choose not to submit but to fight back, arms in hand. We have no alternative but to intensify our armed resistance because, as your Declaration of Independence says, in the face of systematic tyranny, it becomes a duty and a right to take up arms.'' **********He told reporters that the A.N.C. was indebted to the Soviet Union for providing arms, but he stressed that non-military assistance had also come from Norway, Sweden, Italy, the Netherlands and other Western countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/26/world.main_headline: U.S. to Send Official Delegation To Observe Haiti's Voting Sunday
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/26/world.print_headline: U.S. to Send Official Delegation To Observe Haiti's Voting Sunday
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/26/world.body_text: **********President Reagan will send an official delegation to Haiti this weekend to observe its first presidential election in 30 years, the White House announced today. **********The delegation, which includes members of Congress and representatives of labor, business, education, churches and the law, will observe the election at polling places around the country. **********The decision, which has been expected for some weeks, puts Haiti's military on notice that the United States is firmly behind a free and fair election and will support the civilian government that emerges. **********The observers ''carry with them my hope and confidence in Haiti's success,'' Mr. Reagan said in a statement issued by the White House. ''After February's inauguration, my Government will work closely with the newly elected president of Haiti and his government to move towards the prosperous and happy future Haiti so richly deserves.'' **********Mr. Reagan expressed concern for ''the all-too-frequent violence which has marked the process, especially that which was directed at electoral authorities and candidates.'' Runoff Vote to Follow **********Although Administration officials foresee some logistical and communications problems in the election Sunday and acknowledge that there could be violence, they say they are confident it will successfully narrow the field of candidates and set the stage for a definitive second round of voting, which is scheduled for Dec. 20. The runoff for the legislature is scheduled for Jan. 3, and the new government is scheduled to assume power Feb. 7. **********The Administration has taken pains not to publicly criticize Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, head of the provisional Government, although he has been portrayed in Haiti as unresponsive to appeals to support the presidential elections fully. General Namphy took over after the fall of the Duvalier family's rule 22 months ago. **********Officials here say they are worried that if they criticized the Government too forcefully, Washington would be accused of meddling in Haiti's internal affairs and the election would be tainted as American-imposed. **********While praising the Administration for sending observers to the election, Walter E. Fauntroy, who is one of the observers and a founder of the Haitian Refugees Task Force of the Congressional Black Caucus, chastised the Administration for not criticizing the Haitian Government more strenuously. **********''The President could have made a stronger statement,'' said Mr. Fauntroy, a Democrat who is the Congressional Delegate for the District of Columbia. ''I had hoped he would have signaled those responsible for the violence that their efforts to disrupt the elections will not go unpunished.'' **********These are the members of the official American delegation: Roger Allen Moore, general counsel of the Republican National Committeee, who will serve as chairman  Representative Benjamin A. Gilman of New York, a senior Republican member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee  Mr. Fauntroy  Jaime B. Fuster, Puerto Rican resident commissioner **********Paula Dobriansky, Deputy Assistant Sectretary of State for Human Rights  William Doherty, executive director of the American Institute for Free Labor Development  Ladonna Lee, of the International Foundation for Electoral Systems  Erns Exceus, managing director of the Latin American Bureau of the Americas Society  Msgr. William Murphy, an aide to Bernard Cardinal Law, Archbishop of Boston  Bruce McComb, deputy director of Freedom House  Thomas C. Reed, former Secretary of the Air Force  Kathleen Lawrence of Heron, Burchette, Ruckert & Rothwell  Fred Brooks, chief executive officer of MacGregor Sporting Goods  George T. Benston, professor at Emory University  Mario Paredes, executive director of the Northeast Regional Pastoral Center for Hispanics

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/29/world.main_headline: U.S. MARINE GUARDS LEADING LONELY, ISOLATED LIFE IN SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/29/world.print_headline: U.S. MARINE GUARDS LEADING LONELY, ISOLATED LIFE IN SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/29/world.body_text: **********A United States Embassy guard, shaken by reports that two of his fellow marines helped Soviet agents infiltrate the embassy last year, turned to a diplomat on Friday and said, ''Everyone is going to think we are a bunch of Communists.'' **********The remark, as recounted by the diplomat, reflected a mixture of anger and depression among the 29-man Marine security contingent at the embassy. **********The allegations that two Marine guards allowed Soviet agents to inspect sensitive areas of the embassy, has thrown a spotlight on the marines and prompted questions about whether they are particularly vulnerable to Soviet influence. **********Security procedures at the embassy were tightened this week to prevent a recurrence of the breaches, American diplomats said. They said that embassy staff members were assigned to watch sensitive areas at night to supplement the marines. Least Prepared for Soviet Stay **********Of all the Americans here - diplomats, military officers, business executives, journalists, students and scholars -the marines seem least prepared for their stay in the Soviet Union. They are generally in their early 20's, unversed in Russian and unfamiliar with the nation's culture. Unlike most Americans, who at least try to interact with Soviet society, the marines focus exclusively on embassy affairs. **********They are discouraged from mixing with Russians, instructed to travel in pairs and obliged to turn for entertainment to the English-speaking community. **********While most seem to adjust and make the best of their circumscribed world, some become bored and lonely, developing a tendency - for sheer excitement, if nothing else - to deal with the very world they are told to avoid. **********That is apparently what happened in the spy case, where one marine, Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree, was reportedly seduced by a woman who was a Soviet agent engaged in custodial work at the embassy. **********The marines guard the embassy's main entrance and the ninth floor with its sensitive areas, patrolling the grounds and serving as firefighters. The unit is headed by a gunnery sergeant, who reports to the civilian security officer at the embassy. **********Other Western embassies use experienced security forces, often drawn from the ranks of intelligence services, and consider the American system less reliable. **********''No one has all the answers, but it invites trouble to turn over security to a group of young men who are more suited for combat than for guard duty,'' a Western European diplomat said. **********The marines, while not mixing socially with senior diplomats, seem well integrated into the younger community of diplomats and students. **********Their social world revolves around a cluster of Western nightspots, including ''Uncle Sam's,'' an informal bar and discotheque set up evenings in the embassy snack bar, similar operations at other embassies and, on Saturday nights, the foreign currency bar and discotheque at the Cosmos Hotel. **********For female companionship, they turn mainly to ''nannies,'' a British term used here for young foreign women who are employed by Western residents to take care of their children. **********Since last fall, the marines have been housed in a barracks in a new embassy compound, and have access to recreational areas in the compound, including an indoor pool, gymnasium and bowling alley. Past Black Market Problems **********The espionage case is not the only trouble to strike the Marine contingent. American diplomats said that four marines were sent home this year after they became involved in trading money on the black market. In a separate case, two marines were withdrawn when a Western woman said they had raped her. **********Several nannies said that Marine parties often turned wild and that they were frightened at times by the aggressive behavior of the Americans. **********Diplomats who knew Sergeant Lonetree described him as an isolated figure who never seemed comfortable in the embassy. **********They said the man arrested as his accomplice, Cpl. Arnold Bracy, was friendly with many members of the American community and displayed curiosity about Soviet life, sometimes joining other Americans for dinner at restaurants. **********''Arnold was one of the first marines here who ever wore a Russian fur hat,'' a friend recalled. **********A British nanny said that Marine drills had increased and that access to the embassy was restricted for a period on Friday evening as the marines conducted a security exercise. **********''There are not any Marine parties this weekend,'' she said. ''It is pretty quiet over there.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/24/busin.body_text: **********Spain's banking community speculated that Banco de Bilbao might revise its takeover offer for the nation's second-largest bank, Banesto, which Friday rejected its first offer. In announcing that the bid by the smaller bank had been turned down, a spokesman for Banesto, whose formal name is Banco Espanol de Credito, said that the bank was prepared to consider another offer if one were made. Spanish banks are dwarfed by foreign competitors, and a merger of the two banks would create Spain's largest bank and one that would rank within the top 20 in Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.print_headline: HOW INDUSTRIES WILL FARE IN 1987; Rural America's Absentee Landlords
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.body_text: **********THE outlook for the economy in 1987 looks all-too-familiar: another sluggish year with worries about too much debt and too little growth to drive the unemployment rate much below today's 6.9 percent. **********But behind the standard forecast for another standard year is an American economy still churning with change. The merger wave is continuing to roil key industries. Slow, or non-existent, growth and falling prices are forcing some sectors into a new pragmatism. **********In oil, commercial real estate and agriculture, owners are becoming more willing to sell out at what seem to be fire-sale prices. In entertainment, hard-nosed business executives are cutting costs. **********With all this, short-term interest rates are likely to dip even further as the Federal Reserve pours money into an economy limping into its fifth expansionary year. **********What follows is a look at what could prove to be some of the more interesting sectors by business and economic correspondents of The New York Times. **********AS the farm crisis forces more and more farmers to give up their land, the turmoil is producing an unexpected twist: growth in absentee ownership. Investment-minded doctors in Des Moines and lawyers in Chicago, hoping that the agricultural cycle has bottomed out, are buying up land. **********While they wait for land prices to rise, these investors are renting out the land to farmers, some of whom already have their own farms, some of whom are merely tenant farmers. ''Iowa land that once sold for $2,500 an acre now goes for $800, which enables these investors to make a decent rate of reurn,'' said John A. Schnittker, a former Under Secretary of Agriculture. **********Overcapacity in rural America is making this absentee ownership possible. With the nation's grain exports having plummeted since the glory days of the 1970's, agricultural overcapacity has resulted in dismally low grain prices. This is slowly and painfully squeezing out marginal operators. The shakeout will cause the number of commercial farmers to fall to 450,000 in five years, down from 600,000 now, says Mr. Schnittker. **********If there is a silver lining to all this, it is that the upheaval will force American farm goods, helped by the weaker dollar, to become more competitive on world markets: Farmers who survive will be able to produce at lower prices. **********Still, no one expects agricultural America to make great strides over the next few years in regaining lost market share in the global grain trade - unless there are major commodity shortages in China, the Soviet Union or elsewhere. Much capacity has been added in competing countries like Brazil and Australia. And many nations are heavily subsidizing their farm sectors, though there will be stepped-up pressure to reduce those subsidies in future trade talks. **********Says John K. Hosemann, senior economist with the American Farm Bureau: ''We built this mess we're in over six to eight years, and it will probably take six to eight to work it out.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/06/busin.main_headline: ANALYSTS URGE CAUTION IN WAKE OF MARKET SURGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/06/busin.print_headline: ANALYSTS URGE CAUTION IN WAKE OF MARKET SURGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/06/busin.body_text: **********Although the stock market ended the week on a very high note after beginning it on a sour one, individual investors should remain cautious in their buying, according to analysts interviewed over the weekend. **********''One should not panic during a decline or grow overly euphoric during advances,'' said Larry Wachtel, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''When all is lost, buy. And when all is wonderful, don't buy. Don't be dictated by the pressure.'' **********Some market professionals have been expecting a significant correction in the market and had thought that the 57.39-point decline in the Dow Jones industrial average last Monday might have been the start of one. But they were hopeful even then that the market would recover to go even higher. After Friday's climb of 69.89 points in the Dow, other analysts also predicted that stock prices would rise to new heights. **********''I am expecting at least another boom this year and possibly more,'' said Greg Smith, chief investment strategist at Prudential-Bache. Stable Rates Cited **********As long as the economy continues to show modest growth and the dollar and interest rates remain relatively stable, the stock market will not suffer a damaging plunge, at least not without some significant warning, the analysts said. **********The market tumbled early last week on fears that the falling dollar would decline even further and that interest rates would rise as a result, but as those tensions subsided by week's end, the relieved market soared. **********Investors tracking the ebb and flow of those tensions should not limit themselves to just strong stocks or stay too long in one group, the analysts said. They said investors should also consider cyclical and emerging growth stocks, such as drugs, paper, chemicals and technology, and not just the insurance and utility stocks that are the staples of many portfolios. Flat Second Half Possible **********Many securities analysts have adopted the view that the current uptrend in the stock market will not stop simply on a random day or in response to a single news event. Instead, they said, stock prices will probably flatten in the second half of the year, when the current season of liquidity changes. **********It is this liquidity factor, which stems from increased foreign buying, as well as investors pumping money into Individual Retirement Accounts and mutual funds, that has helped fuel the market. Analysts predicted that this situation will not change until later in the year. **********Analysts also predicted an overall improvement in corporate profits this year, which should help stock prices. This improvement will be mainly the result of a decrease in foreign competition as the weaker dollar makes foreign products, particularly Japanese items, more expensive. **********In addition, the weaker dollar makes American goods cheaper, which should allow American manufacturers to set up or recapture markets overseas. Domestic operations have also been improving their efficiency, increasing the potential for higher profits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.main_headline: THE FINAL WEEK: REAGAN SILENCE MAY HAVE UPSET VOLCKER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.print_headline: THE FINAL WEEK: REAGAN SILENCE MAY HAVE UPSET VOLCKER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.body_text: **********When Paul A. Volcker met last Tuesday with Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, he delivered a message without equivocation: After two terms, he wanted out as the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. **********But no one, including Mr. Baker and President Reagan, thought he was serious. That conclusion prompted several days of behind-the-scenes drama that ended today when Mr. Reagan announced that Mr. Volcker would not stay on when his term expires in August. **********White House officials replaying the drama provided these details: *********** While Mr. Volcker had reason to think that Mr. Reagan would reappoint him, he never heard this directly from the President. Mr. Volcker apparently interpreted the President's unwillingness to make a direct appeal as a sign that, while Mr. Reagan did not want to dismiss the central banker, he did not really want him to stay on. *********** The process leading to the selection of a new Federal Reserve chairman, which had been a source of speculation for months, took place in less than a week. Mr. Baker had the key role, first in trying to dissuade Mr. Volcker from leaving, then in the selection of the New York economist Alan Greenspan over two other candidates - John Whitehead, the Deputy Secretary of State, and Beryl W. Sprinkel, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. The only other top Administration official actively involved was Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d. *********** Mr. Reagan chose Mr. Greenspan nearly on the spot after his name was put forward by Mr. Volcker as his first choice. The President offered the job to Mr. Greenspan, a former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, about an hour after receiving Mr. Volcker's resignation. **********Officials said the first indication of Mr. Volcker's intentions came last Tuesday when he met with the White House chief of staff to discuss his plans. At the private meeting, Mr. Volcker said he did not want to stay past August, a decision that had not been tipped to senior White House officials, one Reagan aide said. **********But the aide said that Mr. Baker had nevertheless already consulted the President on Mr. Volcker's reappointment and that the President had supported it. Thus, he conveyed to Mr. Volcker the message that Mr. Reagan planned to ask him to stay on and that he should rethink his decision. **********However, people close to Mr. Volcker suggested that attempts at persuasion were minimal and that no offer came directly from the President. **********Nonetheless, as Mr. Volcker went off on a four-day fishing trip to think about what he would do, White House officials said they were convinced that he would reconsider. They expected him to tell the President that he would accept a third term. **********Adding confusion to the events, The Wall Street Journal reported on Monday that a senior White House official said he would not lead reporters ''off'' predicting reappointment. An Administration official made a similar point in an article in The New York Times today. **********But Mr. Volcker's intentions became clear when he met with the President in the Oval Office at about 4 o'clock on Monday afternoon. Howard Baker and James Baker were also at the session, which lasted about an hour. Mr. Volcker arrived with a letter that indicated he did not want to be reappointed, one official said. **********''I want to make it very clear that the President would have been very, very pleased had the chairman's decision been otherwise,'' Secretary Baker said today. ''And it's quite clear, I think, that this is what the chairman wanted to do and thinks he should do.'' **********But officials familiar with the meeting said Mr. Reagan made no effort to persuade Mr. Volcker to remain after he announced that he did not want a third term. Mr. Reagan then elicited advice from the chairman on possible successors. **********By the account of the officials, Mr. Volcker said his first choice was Mr. Greenspan, regarded in financial circles as a ''pragmatic ideologue,'' who served as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Ford Administration. The Fed chairman's second choice was Mr. Whitehead. **********According to one official, Howard Baker put forth Mr. Sprinkel's name, but only as a courtesy. In the end, Mr. Reagan decided on Mr. Greenspan and called him at about 5 o'clock. **********The Volcker development is reminiscent of the situation involving Howard Baker when he was considered recently for the position of Director of Central Intelligence before the selection of William H. Webster. **********At that time, associates of Mr. Baker had said he would have accepted the post had he been asked by the President. However, Donald T. Regan, the chief of staff at the time, had informed Mr. Reagan that Mr. Baker was not interested, and no Presidential appeal came.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/01/world.main_headline: DEFENSE AIDE REJECTS CONCEPT OF A WORLD FREE OF ATOMIC ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/01/world.print_headline: DEFENSE AIDE REJECTS CONCEPT OF A WORLD FREE OF ATOMIC ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/01/world.body_text: **********A senior Pentagon official today called suggestions that the world could some day be free of nuclear weapons an absurd folly. President Reagan has often said a nuclear-free world is his goal. **********The Pentagon official, Richard N. Perle, an Assistant Secretary of Defense, speaking in Munich, West Germany, dismissed the idea of total nuclear disarmament as ultimately envisaged at the Soviet-American summit meeting in Iceland in October. **********''The foolishness of a nuclear-free world is in no way mitigated by the conditions that Western statesmen routinely attach to its achievement in order to avoid dismissing the idea as the empty propaganda that it is,'' Mr. Perle said. **********In the days after the summit meeting, the Soviet Union said the United States had agreed to the principle of total nuclear disarmament, while the White House said this was President Reagan's ''ultimate goal.'' **********A White House synopsis of the arms talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev said, ''The President was reflecting his willingness to discuss the details, including timing, of a plan to eliminate all nuclear weapons, in conjunction with a plan to reduce conventional arms to assure conventional force balances.'' **********Mr. Perle, according to the text of his speech made available here, was contemptuous of such explanations. **********''To argue that eliminating all nuclear weapons is a good idea but the year 2000 is too soon, or to suggest that it must proceed by steps or stages, or that it must await a more favorable conventional balance or the settlement of regional disputes is a self-defeating obfuscation,'' he said. **********''These arguments - rationalizations, really - are deployed by officials and politicians who fear that the public would not support them if they simply rejected outright Mr. Gorbachev's beguiling maneuver.'' **********Mr. Perle said his comments represented his own views.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/18/world.main_headline: Unesco Director Withdraws Bid For Re-election
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/18/world.print_headline: Unesco Director Withdraws Bid For Re-election
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/18/world.body_text: **********Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, whose 13 years as Director General of Unesco have split the organization, announced tonight that he wanted to withdraw from his race for re-election. **********Western and Soviet-bloc diplomats said this would likely mean that Federico Mayor Zaragoza, a former Spanish Education Minister, would become Unesco's next director general. **********In a letter to Unesco's executive board, Mr. M'Bow, of Senegal, said he had asked the Organization of African Unity, which had sponsored his candidacy, to withdraw his name. Two and a half hours later, the executive board received a letter from Senegal's President requesting that Mr. M'Bow's candidacy be withdrawn.  [ In Washington, a State Department spokesman said the department had no comment either on Mr. M'Bow's plan to withdraw or on his tenure at Unesco.  [ The spokesman, Benjamin Justesen, also declined to say whether the American position toward the organization might be reconsidered in light of Mr. M'Bow's action. ''We are not currently members of Unesco,'' he said, ''and I will not speculate on what we might do in the future.'' ]  Although several Unesco delegates at first thought Mr. M'Bow's withdrawal might be part of a strategy to rally African support, others said the two letters together made clear that Mr. M'Bow's candidacy was dead. **********His withdrawal would end the tenure of one of the most controversial, tough-minded leaders of any international organization. During the administration of the 66-year-old Director General, the first African to head a major international agency, the United States and Britain quit Unesco, asserting inefficiency in the agency's operations and ideological squabbling. **********Several diplomats said Mr. M'Bow's departure could open the way for the two countries to rejoin. Clear Support for Rival **********Over the last few days, several African and Soviet-bloc delegates had urged Mr. M'Bow to withdraw gracefully in order to reduce the contentiousness within Unesco, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. **********Several delegates said Mr. M'Bow decided to request that his name be withdrawn only after it became clear that a majority of the 50-member executive board supported Mr. Mayor, 53 years old. Mr. Mayor, is a native of Barcelona and a biochemistry professor. A member of the European Parliament, he was Unesco's Deputy Director General under Mr. M'Bow from 1978 to 1981. **********On the executive board's fourth ballot, taken on Wednesday, Mr. M'Bow received 21 votes and Mr. Mayor 19 for the $170,000-a-year job, which has a term of six years. Mr. M'Bow was backed principally by Arab and African nations. Mr. Mayor had the official support of Japan and most European and Latin American nations and the unofficial backing of the United States and Britain. **********Many delegates predicted that in the fifth ballot, scheduled for tonight, Mr. Mayor would pick up most of the 10 votes that had gone to three other minor candidates. By Unesco rules, the fifth ballot is limited to the top two candidates in the fourth round of voting. **********At midnight, board members were still arguing over procedure and had still not cast the fifth ballot. **********The United States and Britain have long said that even if Mr. M'Bow is succeeded by someone more to their liking, they would not automatically rejoin Unesco. Funds Eroded **********The United States quit Unesco in 1984 and Britain left the next year. Their withdrawals, combined, slashed Unesco's funding about 30 percent. **********American and British officials have said they would only rejoin the organization if there were substantial changes in Unesco's programs and structure. Among other things, they contend that the countries that contribute more of Unesco's budget should have more of a say in shaping the organization's activities. **********In addition, West Germany, Canada, Switzerland, Denmark, Japan and the Netherlands have threatened to resign if substantial changes were not brought about within the organization. Their withdrawals would reduce the organization's $159 million annual funding another 30 percent. **********Mr. Mayor has pledged to restructure Unesco in an effort to woo back the countries that quit the organization. **********In his withdrawal letter, Mr. M'Bow protested that some member nations had ''perverted the democratic process'' by threatening to quit or not pay their annual contributions. Speculation on New Candidacy **********Several Western delegates interpreted Mr. M'Bow's letter as intended to protest the executive board's nomination process, perhaps in the hope of overturning its recommendation when Unesco's 158-nation General Conference, its highest body, meets in early November. **********As the executive board meeting continued late Saturday night, several delegates said they expected Mr. Mayor to win enough support within the board so that he would have little problem obtaining the General Conference's backing. **********However, many delegates did not rule out the possibility that despite his withdrawal letter, Mr. M'Bow might seek somehow to revive his candidacy. They remember Mr. M'Bow's statement last year that he would not stand for re-election if his candidacy were to prove divisive - a statement that led many to believe he would not run for an unprecedented third term. Thus, Mr. M'Bow surprised many Unesco observers when he became a candidate last month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/25/busin.body_text: **********Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks totaled 282,177 units in the second 10 days of November, down 2.1 percent from the comparable 1986 period, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today. **********Light-truck sales were up 19.0 percent, to 109,625 units, while car sales fell 12.0 percent, to 172,552 units. The reporting period, Nov. 11-20, had nine selling days, the same as it did last year. **********Domestic cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.0 million, down from the rate a year earlier of 6.7 million. But analysts said last year's annual rate was inflated somewhat by changes in the Federal tax law, which induced many consumers to buy big-ticket items before the end of the fourth quarter while they still could deduct the sales taxes. 'The Numbers Are Not Great' **********David Healy, an auto analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert, said the tax law changes would make year-to-year comparisons hard to interpret for several months. **********''Last year, annual rates bottomed in late October, then rose in November and peaked in late December with more than a 10 million rate,'' he said. ''Then, in January, it dropped almost to five million.'' **********Mr. Healy cautioned against attributing the sales slowdown to the stock market collapse. **********''The numbers are not great, but I think they would have been sluggish anyway,'' he said. ''It looks like the market had no effect on Middle America. The average car buyer is sitting on his hands because he's waiting for new incentive programs.'' **********The Ford Motor Company last week announced selected discounts on cars and extended others on light trucks. Mr. Healy said the move should put more life into the market. **********Edward A. Sullivan, an analyst with Wharton Econometrics, said he expected car sales to edge up only slightly because of the modest extent of the existing sales incentives. **********''These aren't big incentives,'' Mr. Sullivan said. ''Who's going to buy a car now, without them?'' **********Among the Big Three, the General Motors Corporation took 43.1 percent of the market for cars and light trucks, down 3.6 percentage points from a year earlier. Ford had a 34.4 percent share, up 4.3 points, and the Chrysler Corporation's share edged up one-tenth of a point, to 17.7 percent. **********General Motors sold 121,586 domestic vehicles, down 9.8 percent from last year. Its sales included 80,628 cars, down 18.0 percent, and 40,958 light trucks, up 12.4 percent. **********Ford sold 97,006 domestic vehicles, up 11.9 percent from a year earlier. Its sales included 54,442 cars, down 1.6 percent, and 42,564 light trucks, up 35.7 percent. **********Chrysler, which acquired the American Motors Corporation in August, sold 50,261 domestic vehicles, down 1.4 percent from the two companies' sales a year earlier. Its sales included 23,777 trucks, up 6.7 percent, and 26,484 cars, down 7.7 percent. **********Among the foreign-owned American manufacturers, Honda of America sold 6,676 cars, down 22.2 percent. The Nissan Motor Company sold 1,505 cars, down 47.5 percent, and 2,326 light trucks, up 13.5 percent. The Toyota Motor Corporation also sold 1,505 cars, up 98 percent. Volkswagen of America sold 1,149 cars, down 29.3 percent. The Mazda Motor Manufacturing Corporation, which recently began production, sold 163 cars.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/31/busin.main_headline: HOME STATE EX-OWNER GOES TO JAIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/31/busin.print_headline: HOME STATE EX-OWNER GOES TO JAIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/31/busin.body_text: **********Marvin L. Warner, the former owner of the Home State Savings Bank, was sentenced today to three and a half years in prison for his role in the thrift institution's collapse, which touched off a state savings and loan crisis in 1985. **********Mr. Warner, 67 years old, was also ordered to pay $22 million in restitution to the state. Common Pleas Judge Richard Niehaus ordered Mr. Warner jailed immediately unless he could post the amount in cash and securities, but Mr. Warner's lawyers said their client could not meet the bond. Taken to County Jail **********Within minutes Mr. Warner, a Cincinnati millionaire who was Ambassador to Switzerland in the Carter Administration, was taken to the Hamilton County jail. A deputy said he might be placed in a section occupied by a co-defendant, Burton Bongard, a former Home State president. **********William Jeffress, Mr. Warner's chief attorney, said lawyers would argue for Mr. Warner's release on Tuesday before a three-judge state appeals panel. **********Mr. Warner was also placed on five years' probation, to be served after the prison term. He was also fined $250,000. **********David Schiebel, another former president of Home State, was sentenced to three 18-month prison terms, but Judge Niehaus said he would reduce the actual time served to six months if Mr. Schiebel later served five years' probation. Mr. Schiebel was also fined $25,000.  Warner Guilty on Nine Counts On March 2, after a 14-week trial, Mr. Warner was found guilty of six counts of unauthorized acts and three counts of securities violations; Mr. Bongard, 46, of New York, was convicted on 41 counts of unauthorized acts and 41 companion counts of misapplication of funds, and Mr. Schiebel, 57, of Cincinnati, was found guilty of three counts of securities violations. **********Mr. Bongard's sentencing was delayed until Tuesday because of what Judge Niehaus described as confusion over a change in the law concerning penalties on the charges for which Mr. Bongard was convicted. **********Mr. Warner dabbed at his eyes with a handkerchief as his lawyers presented character witnesses, including former Ohio Governor John J. Gilligan. ''I would not recommend to any public official that you do other than what is proper, what is right,'' Mr. Warner told the judge. ''My suffering is unimportant, compared with the depositors in the case.'' **********Mr. Warner, a former chairman of the Ohio Board of Regents and the Ohio Building Authority, added: ''There never has been any question about my honesty or integrity. My request would be that you give me the same justice that you would to any individual.'' Depositors Had Urged Punishment **********Former Home State depositors, who were cut off from their money for three months by the March 1985 failure of the Cincinnati-based thrift institution, had written letters to Judge Niehaus, urging him to punish the three men. **********All three have said they will appeal their convictions. Mr. Warner and Mr. Bongard face trial on May 5 on Federal charges of conspiracy and wire fraud in the matter; Mr. Schiebel is not a defendant in that case. **********Mr. Warner and Mr. Bongard were convicted of transferring Home State investments to E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., without authorization from Home State's board of directors. Other Securities Charges **********The securities charges against Mr. Warner and Mr. Schiebel accused them of failing to give a true financial picture of Home State in documents advertising the sale of the savings bank's debentures. **********Prosecutors said Mr. Warner and Mr. Bongard conspired to send the Home State money to E.S.M. to prop up the failing securities firm, in return for guaranteed profits on their personal securities accounts at E.S.M. **********The defendants said they had been duped by E.S.M. executives, who they said had issued audits that hid the company's huge losses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/14/busin.body_text: **********South Africa's wholesale prices were up moderately in May from a year ago but remained lower than the previous month's level, the Government said today. The producer price index rose 14.6 percent in May.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/03/busin.body_text: **********AS you all know by now if you watched the evening news, ''The Cosby Show,'' ''Family Ties'' or ''Cheers'' last night, most of the M*A*S*H team has re-enlisted under the I.B.M. banner. **********Seven of the well-known characters from the popular TV series have now leaped into the International Business Machines Corporation's effort to introduce its Personal System/2 computers. The stars will be in TV, newspaper, magazine and radio, and will probably also show up in direct-mail and point-of-sale materials. **********Trade sources are calling it a $50 million campaign. I.B.M., as is its wont, is not commenting. **********The commercials have the characters playing white-collar workers, as I.B.M. appears to be trying to distance itself from the M*A*S*H show. No doubt some legal ramifications there. **********The advertising is being done by Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, which started as the corporate agency in 1979 and took on the additional assignment for personal computers in 1981. It was the shop that came up with the engaging, though elaborate, ''Little Tramp'' spots. **********Bert Reisman, assistant group executive of the I.B.M. Marketing Group, explained that the job of the Charlie Chaplin character was to demonstrate a little man coping and prospering with high technology. The advertising helped the company sell about three million units last year. The character will probably continue to be used overseas to sell the new products. **********The reason for the assembly of a group of celebrities to act as part of the white-collar work force in a manufacturing plant is that they are supposed to communicate the idea of interconnected, interrelated productivity, and that, Mr. Reisman said, ''is not a concept for one little lonely tramp.'' **********''And,'' he added, ''we want it done in a friendly, light, familiar way and in a more realistic business setting.'' **********Five 30-second commercials have been produced. The seven stars are Harry Morgan, who was Colonel Potter in M*A*S*H and is still the boss in the commercial; Gary Burghoff, who was Radar; Loretta Swit (Hot Lips Houlihan); Larry Linville (Frank Burns); William Christopher (Father Mulcahy); Wayne Rogers (Trapper John), and Jamie Farr, who was the always beautifully dressed Klinger. **********Mr. Reisman said they had all signed multiyear contracts. Asked about the pay scale for such talent, Lloyd Kolmer, a talent broker, said all of them are probably in the low-six-figures category. **********Missing from the cast are Alan Alda, who was Hawkeye, and David Ogden Stiers, who was Maj. Charles Emerson Winchester. However, according to Richard J. Lord, chairman of the agency, negotiations are in progress with Mr. Alda, who might very well show up in future spots. Wasn't it in 1983 that it was reported here that Mr. Alda had signed a five-year contract to be the spokesman for Atari? **********Other highlights of the I.B.M. campaign will be a five-page layout in The Wall Street Journal, with a two-page adaptation appearing in 50 local newspapers. **********A bigger play is saved for magazines, 17 of which will carry a 24-page insert in mid-April, while a five-week effort will begin then on nine radio networks. **********The magazine schedule includes Business Week, Forbes, Fortune, Time, Newsweek, the blue-chip demographic edition of U.S. News & World Report, and several computer trade publications. **********Meanwhile, mister, will you buy my apple?

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/09/busin.main_headline: Ex-Officer of Times Co. Will Join Rothschild Inc.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Ex-Officer of Times Co. Will Join Rothschild Inc.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/09/busin.body_text: **********Sydney Gruson, a former vice chairman and director of The New York Times Company, plans a new career in investment banking. On March 2, he will join Rothschild Inc. as a senior adviser. **********Mr. Gruson is expected to help build Rothschild's business in the communications industry. ''He's going to be working with the corporate finance department and reporting directly to me,'' said Robert S. Pirie, Rothschild's president and chief executive. ''I don't know anybody who knows newspapers, magazines and communications better than Sydney.'' **********Mr. Gruson, he said, has been involved in every acquisition made by the Times Company in the last 15 years. Rothschild is not a major player in investment banking activities for newspaper acquisitions and the like, but hopes to build a business around Mr. Gruson, Mr. Pirie said. **********He added that he expected mergers and acquisitions to continue in the communications industry. ''You still have a tremendous shakeout taking place,'' he said, in such industries as cable television and independent television stations. ''And there are still a tremendous number of small family-owned newspapers. The pressures of age, tax problems and inheritance are causing these businesses to come into the marketplace. Many are regional monopolies and highly profitable.'' **********Mr. Gruson was on vacation and unavailable for comment on his new post. He resigned his Times Company positions last November in anticipation of his required retirement under company policies for directors. He reached the mandatory retirement age of 70 on Dec. 16, but remained with the company until January. **********Mr. Gruson, who was born in Dublin, started his 50-year career in journalism with a job as an office boy with the Canadian Press news service. He joined The New York Times as a war correspondent in London in 1944. **********Beginning in 1971, when the Times Company acquired Family Circle magazine, WREG-TV in Memphis and three newspapers in Florida, Mr. Gruson played a major role in the company's expansion program. That year he was named director of the affiliated companies. In 1972, he became senior vice president and a year later executive vice president. He was named vice chairman in 1979.  Rothschild Inc., which is based in Manhattan, is the United States operation of the French and British Rothschild banking groups.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/world.main_headline: Where Plastic Is a Passion and the Polar Ice Is Hot
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/world.print_headline: TOKYO JOURNAL; Where Plastic Is a Passion and the Polar Ice Is Hot
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/18/world.body_text: **********This country has grown so rich so fast that its people sometimes have trouble devising ways to spend their money. **********The Japanese have, as a result, developed a habit of latching onto expensive fads faster than they can say ''$1,300 waterbed.'' Trends have rushed in this summer with more force than a mid-August storm. **********One of the hottest consumer items is a small electronic bread maker that costs about $250. It is being snapped up by a rapidly growing number of people who, despite the traditional rice culture, feel that breakfast is incomplete without a freshly baked loaf of bread. **********Other Japanese, unfazed by high import duties that push the price of a quart of imported Scotch to $50 or $60, are willing to pay extra for special ice to pour their liquor over. One company has turned a neat profit this summer with polar ice, shipped from Antarctica and sold for $2.40 a pound. **********Connoisseurs say they like a distinctive crackling of the ice as it melts. Frenzy Over Telephone Cards **********But for depth of passion and breadth of numbers, nothing compares with a telephone-card collecting frenzy that has become an expensive mania involving millions of people. **********The card, a magnetized piece of plastic about the size of a credit card, can be inserted into the slots of special pay phones. With a 500-yen card, a customer gets 50 units of 10-yen phone calls. Ten yen, or about 6 cents, is the basic charge for a local call, which makes it one of the few items one can get in Japan without having to contemplate bankruptcy. **********When a card is used up, it is to be thrown away. But suddenly, sensing that there is money to be made, more and more of the millions of Japanese card buyers are holding onto these bits of plastic. **********About 500,000 Japanese have become serious collectors of the cards, trading them like stamps and paying many hundreds of dollars for any card considered especially valuable. #40,000 Different Types Telephone cards are not unique to Japan. But other countries usually have only one basic design. Here, with money to burn for such frills, the variety seems endless. **********By one expert count, at least 40,000 different types have gone into circulation since the first card was issued in December 1982 by Teleca, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation. Hundreds of new cards flood the market each week as businesses and individuals design their own for advertising purposes or for sheer vanity. **********Cards bear company logos and store names and addresses. There are cards with pictures of just about everything: pets, pop stars, Mount Fuji, sumo wrestlers, Tokyo Bay, the Princess of Wales, plum blossoms, samurai figures, pornographic models, political slogans and James Dean. **********Politicians issue cards bearing their photographs as fund-raising gimmicks. Unions produced special cards recently to help promote their annual organized campaign for wage increases. Antismoking groups did the same. **********Even organized-crime groups like the cards. Police officials in Nagoya were dismayed not long ago when a local crime clan issued a telephone card bearing its name and symbol. Collectors Form Associations **********Collectors have decided that for one reason or another - relative scarcity, unusual designs, printing errors - some of these cards are worth far more than the basic 500 yen. To trade with one another, they have banded together in at least five asssociations in Tokyo alone. Some are specialists, such as the fellow who collects nothing but pictures of hotels and inns. **********Japan's King of Cards is a slight, bookish-looking man named Hidetaka Matsuda, who says that when he last counted he had 5,000 of the cards. Operating out of an apartment in northern Tokyo, he writes a column for a monthly magazine that collectors use as a guide to the latest hot items and their prices. **********Mr. Matsuda's own prize is a rare card bearing the photo of a pop singer named Yuki Saito. He bought it a year ago for the equivalent of $660 and figures that its value has since doubled, making it probably the most expensive card in Japan. Other pop stars also sell for $1,000 or more. **********''We never imagined that things would get like this,'' said a senior phone company official, Koichi Fujisawa. ''The reason we came up with telephone cards was to provide better service to our customers. We never thought they would lead to manic collectors.'' Rich Source of Additional Profits **********Not that he is complaining. For Nippon Telegraph and Telephone the cards have proved a smashing success, worth $620 million in sales in 1986. **********The company expects to sell 200 million cards this year, compared with 148 million last year, 60 million the year before and only 9.4 million the year before that. That means there will be roughly two cards sold for every Japanese, including those too young to reach the dial on a pay phone and those too lonely to have anyone to call. **********While there is no end in sight for the card-collection fad, it could slow down. But it is a safe bet that something new will turn up, perhaps $1,300 waterbeds, which suddenly have caught on even though most houses are too small to accommodate them comfortably. **********Some businessmen found this summer that people are not beyond spending money on air. One company does a brisk business selling oxygen in a can - $16.60 for a five-minute supply. And the oxygen does not last as long as a tumbler of crackling polar ice.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/22/busin.main_headline: Small Investors Seize the Moment, Hunt for Deals
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/22/busin.print_headline: MARKET TURMOIL: THE INVESTORS; Small Investors Seize the Moment, Hunt for Deals
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/22/busin.body_text: **********As the stock ticker flashed by at a crowded discount brokerage firm in Los Angeles yesterday afternoon, Ray Bachar studied the numbers for several minutes, trying to decide what to do. **********''I'm looking for an opportunity within the volatility,'' said the 41-year-old resident of Huntington Beach, Calif, who settled on a small investment in the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. In his opinion, the company's stock had been undervalued by the market's decline last week and its free fall on Monday. **********Like Mr. Bachar, millions of small investors were looking for opportunity in the midst of volatility. With so many people aggressively seeking bargains, there was little sign of the kind of panic selling that some had feared would develop, analysts said. 'Vastly More Confidence' **********''The realities are that the small client is testing the waters, and confidence does appear to be coming back,'' said Philip Waxelbaum, national sales manager for Prudential-Bache Securities. ''There was vastly more confidence in the system today than there was on Tuesday.'' **********To be sure, many small investors remained somewhat shellshocked by the events of the last few days and sat tight on their holdings. ''Right now, I'm not doing anything - the market's just too crazy,'' said Joe Polimeni, a 33-year-old photographer for United Press International, who checked the ticker at lunchtime at Olde Discount Brokers in Detroit. **********But the fact that even nervous investors were choosing to take no action at all, rather than to sell - to ''take the shot and hang tough,'' in the words of one investor - seemed to reflect confidence in the market. 'Large Sigh of Relief' **********''There seems to be a large sigh of relief, for the moment,'' said Bill Sullivan, director of individual financial services for Merrill Lynch. **********''The average small investor did not panic,'' Mr. Waxelbaum said. ''Interestingly enough, a very large number of them have been nonchalant. They're saying that something like this was to be expected as a correctional action.'' **********Moreover, the perception that there are bargains to be had led many people to brokerage firms to place buy orders - some for the first time. **********Some observers even wondered whether a few small investors were overdoing it. ''We see a large increase in greed here - we're seeing people throwing money fast and hard, and maybe without thinking,'' Thomas J. Czech, first vice president for research at Blunt Ellis & Loewi Inc., a Milwaukee-based firm, told The Associated Press. **********Whether they were buying, selling or just watching, people at brokerages across the country expressed fascination with the week's events. **********Many people complained that they had effectively lost money because their orders had taken so long to execute, because of the extremely high market volume this week, and others said they were waiting for confirmations on orders they had placed as long ago as Friday. Conversely, the question of timeliness had other investors praying that their orders had never been processed at all. No Bullish Stampede **********Despite the more optimistic mood that was prevalent yesterday, many analysts said they did not expect a sustained bull market anytime soon. **********''There's still a lot of concern out there. The average investor is not rushing back into the market, and we're not suggesting that they rush back into the market,'' said Mr. Sullivan of Merrill Lynch. **********Indeed, there was perhaps more preoccupation with the economy in general than with particular stocks, and several investors said they were heartened by indications that the Federal Reserve Board would act to prevent a recession - by encouraging lower interest rates - rather than fight inflation. **********''I'd rather be employed and have inflation than be unemployed,'' said John Hawley, a real-estate manager for an oil company in Los Angeles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/14/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Pennsylvania Conducts Postponed Bond Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/14/busin.body_text: **********The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, which delayed a proposed debt financing on April 21 because of unfavorable market conditions, sold about $154 million of bonds yesterday through the First Boston Corporation. **********The bonds, rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, were offered with yields ranging from 5 percent in 1988 to 5.90 percent in 1992, 6.70 percent in 1997, 7.40 percent in 2002 and 7.60 percent in 2006 and 2007. **********Interest rates on long-term tax-exempt bonds are now equal to or higher than what they were when the state postponed its sale. But at that time, analysts noted, bond prices were dropping sharply, causing losses at securities firms and making them bid very cautiously for new bond issues. Yesterday, amid more stable prices, the state drew five bids - more than it might have received in April, one dealer said.

The commission named the consultants last September to investigate the prudence of Public Service's Seabrook investment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Allied Bancshares To Combine Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/21/busin.body_text: **********Allied Bancshares Inc. said that it would combine its 20 subsidiaries within Harris County, which encompasses Houston, into a single institution. The new bank, to be called Allied Bank N.A., is expected to have assets of about $7.12 billion and deposits of $5.5 billion, according to Jay C. Crager, Allied's chief financial officer. **********The parent company, the sixth-largest banking concern in Texas, currently has $9.8 billion in assets and 51 banking units statewide. The move, partly intended to shore up its weakened units in the Houston area by combining assets, is the largest consolidation of its kind in Texas since the adoption of a new state law on Dec. 4 allowing limited branch banking within county lines.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/06/busin.body_text: **********Officials of the Ford Motor Company said the company's six-year and 60,000-mile powertrain warranty would be extended to light trucks and vans as well as cars. The warranty is retroactive to the beginning of the 1987 model year. ''The warranty war is over,'' said Louis E. Lataif, Ford's vice president for sales. With all three major domestic auto makers now offering warranties of six or seven years, and because most cars are traded in before then, warranty has been removed as a key element in decision making, he said. **********Ford also announced prices for the small imported cars it will begin selling in the American market this year. The Mercury Tracer, a Japanese-designed car that will be assembled in Hermosillo, Mexico, will be priced at $7,926. The Ford Festiva, a smaller car with a less-powerful engine that is made in South Korea, will have a sticker price of $5,765.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/20/world.body_text: **********As the bloody conflict in the Persian Gulf enters its eighth year, Iran is moving to alt an effort to impose international sanctions if it does not heed the United Nations Security Council's call for a cease-fire with Iraq. **********Iran hopes to deflect the push for sanctions, which the United States championed, by dissuading other members of the Council, especially the Soviet Union and China, from participating, according to Iranian officials and experts. **********But interviews with Iranian officials and experts suggest that Iran's objective is not to end the war. While United States officials concede that the Iranians are softening their tone, they say they would be astonished if Iran accepted a cease-fire. Iranian to Speak at U.N.  To press Iran's case, President Ali Khamenei, one of the four highest-ranking Iranian leaders, will address the United Nations on Tuesday. **********According to Iranian officials, Mr. Khamenei will seek to show what an Iranian official described as the ''human face of Iran,'' emphasizing that his country is a victim in a war that destroyed cities, killed and maimed hundreds of thousands of Iranians and made many more refugees. **********Iranian officials say Teheran has been careful not to attack Western naval vessels in the gulf and has toned down its demands for the overthrow of the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein. Among other efforts, the Iranian President, who is a severe hard-liner, will meet American reporters privately and publicly and appear on television news shows in the United States - the country Iran refers to as the Great Satan. **********But Iranian officials and independent experts say that a ''war lobby'' in Iran makes it hard for the country's leadership to turn abruptly to peace. **********Gary Sick, an Iran expert formerly on the National Security Council, said the growing domestic Iranian weapon industry, which supplies from 60 to 75 percent of Iran's needs, and the militant Revolutionary Guards, who are fighting the war, have an interest in carrying on with it. Iranian officials note that the most important influence of this war lobby is nurtured by the estimated three million to five million people making up the families of the ''martyrs,'' who have been killed in the war, and by the thousands of refugees. **********''Ours is a heavily politicized population,'' said an Iranian official who asked not to be identified. ''Part of our leadership legitimacy is that it promised to extract revenge for those who have suffered.'' **********For its part, Iraq has been politically unable to admit it blundered into the conflict, or to allow the United Nations to say so - as Iran is demanding. **********The government in Baghdad fears that conceding its responsibility for the war would risk giving a green light to domestic opponents - from Communists to Arab nationalists - to challenge the right of the Baath Party to continue to rule Iraq. Many Iranian officials and American experts say the United States is also championing the sanctions effort partly for political reasons. They say the Reagan Administration is seeking punishment of Iran because it perceives that such a move would be widely approved by Americans and by pro-American governments in the Persian Gulf region. **********''Iran's position has changed,'' said Shireen Hunter, deputy director of the Middle East Project at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. ''They have softened their tone and are mindful that this emotional thing against Iran in this country is blotting our vision.'' **********Equally worrisome for Iran is the perception that the Soviet Union, which until recently had moved toward closer cooperation with Teheran, is putting up only token resistance to the effort for sanctions, and that China may be intimidated into slowing its weapons sales to Teheran. **********''If there isn't any change in the Iranian position towards a cease-fire, it will be very difficult for the Soviets not to go along with the sanctions,'' said Paul Jabber, a Mideast analyst with the Council on Foreign Relations. ''From the U.S. point of view, it is imperative that the war be brought to a speedy conclusion, otherwise a naval clash between the U.S. and Iran in the Gulf is likely and, worse, a breakthrough on the ground by the Iranian armed forces might threaten an Iraqi defeat.'' **********A Security Council resolution in July, clearly aimed at Iran, calls for the imposition of sanctions on any party to the war that refuses an end to hostilities, a return to recognized borders and the exchange of prisoners. The conditions favor Iraq, which has lost territory. **********The Iranian leadership's, whose cardinal condition is that the international community at least condemn Iraq for initiating the war. **********Iranian officials said, the Iranian leadership continues to believe that a war of attrition against Iraq, which has one-third the population of Iran, will eventually lead to a collapse of Iraqi morale and a military breakthrough by its numerically superior army.  U.N. LEADER CALLS FOR IRAN EFFORT **********UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 19 (Special to The New York Times) -For the first time, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar expressed impatience today with Iran's attitude in peace negotiations, calling for ''real action'' to prove Iran's determination to end the war.  IRAN AND IRAQ REPORT RAIDS **********MANAMA, Bahrain, Sept. 19 (AP) -Iraq and Iran reported new air raids and artillery attacks today. Iraq said Iranian shelling of seven cities killed at least 12 civilians and wounded more than 30., It reported coordinated raids by two squadrons of Iraqi warplanes raided against oil-pumping stations at Zaneh and Razan, western Iran, at noon today. **********A Cypriot-flag supertanker bound for Iran, the Aktinia, was hit by an Exocet missile in an apparent Iraqi attack on Iranian oil targets in the Persian Gulf, according to gulf-based marine salvage executives.
