https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/busin.main_headline: OTHER VOICES: Martin Marty; Everywhere, Paper Cities
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/busin.print_headline: OTHER VOICES: Martin Marty; Everywhere, Paper Cities
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/busin.body_text: **********Excerpts from an interview with Martin E. Marty, a professor of history of modern Christianity at the University of Chicago: **********IN recent years I've had a funny feeling in any city, Houston, anywhere. You go past 15 or 20 miles of aluminum and steel and glass and you find people doing things in those buildings with paper. And they're doing it in an economy in which fewer things are being produced than 30 years ago. They're not building transistors or forging steel. They're advertising transistors and steel products manufactured elsewhere. **********I'd often get the feeling that we really have invented a marvelous fiction that we're all very very serious and very grim but there's really not a lot to it. We get up early in the morning, compete like mad, drive around the country, as if we were really producing something, and yet if you take an ironist's view you could almost say it is a game and it is based on a fiction. We take it seriously, just as we take the rules of pro football seriously, as if it were real. **********This week I've had the sense that people feel they've changed the rules - or that it was a game. When people play the horses or buy a lottery ticket they expect to lose. But in the stock market people are gambling and betting all the time. And when they lose, they feel cheated instead of waking up and saying life should normally cheat you. **********After Monday I don't know of any people saying they are going to put their money only in a coffee can. People are easily assuaged. We have all the props that were invented since 1929. But in a sense you have a different perspective on life, less sense of security, a feeling that you can't rely on things. **********From the viewpoint of someone who studies religion and culture, my interest is in the games we invent, the facades behind which we live, the subtle contracts we make to ward off chaos, which is what religions are. **********And Monday was chaos. Suddenly all these things we think we have ordered and channeled and domesticated impinge on each other. **********There's a funny side to it. It was unstoppable. Program buyouts were in the computers and you couldn't introduce human rationality to stem it. All of us were trying to reach our brokers, the frantic people on the floor. If you came from another culture you'd have to say they have a funny game in America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/26/busin.main_headline: A Time to Settle Up With Uncle Sam
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/26/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; A Time to Settle Up With Uncle Sam
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/26/busin.body_text: **********THE Internal Revenue Service is putting the pressure on taxpayers to settle continuing disputes. In late May, the I.R.S. began a formal program to clear up a backlog of tax-shelter cases by offering 75,000 investors a one-shot chance to settle. And in all cases, taxpayers are finding it is increasingly expensive to fight: Last year the penalty for substantial understatement of tax jumped to 25 percent of the tax owed from 10 percent. The fraud penalty has risen to 75 percent from 50 percent. ''The growth of penalties, in number and size, is putting a premium on resolving problems more quickly,'' said Gary K. Shelton, a San Francisco attorney. **********Last year's Tax Reform Act provides an additional settlement incentive by phasing out the deduction for personal interest. While all interest on overdue taxes could be deducted in 1986, only 65 percent can be written off this year, and the deduction will be phased out completely by 1991. **********Higher price tags notwithstanding, ''disputes have become more frequent,'' said Leon Nad, a partner with Price Waterhouse. At the same time, both the agency and taxpayers are becoming ''more litigious'' and showing ''less inclination to settle'' than in the past, he said. **********One exception is carved out for tax-shelter cases. ''The new tax act put most tax shelters out of business, which makes it psychologically easier,'' for the I.R.S. to settle existing disputes, knowing they will not recur, said Sheldon S. Cohen, a partner with the Washington law firm of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius. **********Growing numbers of disputes are prompted by bills appearing in taxpayers' mailboxes. Now that the much publicized I.R.S. computer snafus of a few years ago have largely been corrected, the system automatically kicks out bills when, for example, dividends or interest paid by banks and mutual funds, or amounts on a W-2, do not match the income reported on taxpayers' returns. **********But most tax controversies still begin with audit notices. Taxpayers receive a form letter, asking them to meet with an examiner. The main function of I.R.S. auditors at this level is to establish facts - whether an expense should be treated as investment interest or personal interest, for example - but on occasion they will negotiate a compromise settlement. **********Auditors are least likely to negotiate a settlement on items that require documentation - the allocation of business and personal use of an automobile, for instance, or the value of property donated to charity. Experts say this trend may be attributable to the tough new documentation requirements written into the recent tax law. Other unlikely candidates for settlement: recurring items that will turn up on a taxpayer's return in future years - depreciation, for example - or issues for which the national office has not yet set up a formal policy. **********Does it pay to hire a professional to represent you at an audit? Around New York, accountants' hourly fees average $75 to $125; lawyers may charge $100 to $200 an hour or more. Mr. Shelton advises using accountants for cases worth less than $5,000, and estimates that it takes about eight hours to review the papers and handle the interview. His rule of thumb: Pay a professional if the fees will not exceed 25 percent of your potential tax liability. (These fees are combined with other miscellaneous itemized expenses and may be deducted to the extent they exceed 2 percent of adjusted gross income.) Taxpayers who fail to settle with an examiner may take their cases to the I.R.S. appeals office. Appeals officers are senior employees who have more discretion to settle cases and may take into account a taxpayer's chances of success in court. Thus, an appeals officer who estimates that the I.R.S. would have a 60 percent chance of winning in court might offer to settle a $5,000 dispute for $2,000. **********While about 85 percent of disputes are settled at this level, ''the appeals office is not a bargain basement,'' advised Laurence Keiser of Hanigsberg, Stern & Keiser, a New York accounting firm. To discourage nuisance cases, the I.R.S. has an unwritten 80/20 rule, Mr. Keiser says, so if you estimate you have ''less than a 20 percent chance of winning in court, forget it.'' **********PROFESSIONAL fees rise as you move through the system. Mr. Keiser estimates that an average appeals case costs $1,500 to $2,500, to pay for a lawyer to evaluate the case, review the file, prepare a written protest (required where the disputed tax exceeds $2,500) and attend the conference. But ''if the appeals officer has the sense that the lawyer handling the case will litigate, that will be worth a couple of points in the settlement negotiations,'' he said. **********The costs of refusing a settlement offer may be substantial. ''Interest and penalties used to be a minor consideration,'' Mr. Shelton said. ''Now, they could almost double your payment on a longstanding problem.'' **********Tax reform also phases out the deduction for personal interest, impelling cost-conscious taxpayers to settle now instead of next year. In 1987, top- bracket taxpayers pay 38.5 percent. Since 65 percent of interest is deductible this year, each dollar of interest paid reduces the Federal tax bill 25 cents. In 1988, that will drop to a maximum tax savings of 11 cents on the dollar. **********Some people may want to hedge their bets by paying the disputed tax as they negotiate a settlement. This stops interest from running and creates an interest deduction. A word of caution: before paying, ask the I.R.S. to formally assess the tax. If you don't, you get the money back if you win the case - but without interest. **********Be aware that it may simply be uneconomical to litigate. While a special small-claims procedure lets tax-court litigants handle their own cases, the costs in time can be heavy. Those who hire lawyers can run up a $10,000 to $15,000 bill, experts say. **********Finally, consider the human element. ''At some point, you may get tired of living with an audit,'' said Sheldon Ganis, a partner with Oppenheim, Appel, Dixon & Company. ''It may be worthwhile to take the settlement and say enough is enough.''  MONEY IN THE MAILBOX **********Even taxpayers who waited until April 15 to file their returns should have received their refunds by now: Checks are mailed out 10 to 12 weeks after the return is filed, said Robert Kobel, an I.R.S. spokesman. If the agency is dragging its feet in your case, you can check the status of your refund by calling 1-800-554-4477. And take heart: When the refund is received more than 45 days after the return was filed, you receive interest - now at 8 percent - on the money.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.main_headline: Gunmen in the Punjab Kill 6; Independence Day Toll at 13
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.print_headline: Gunmen in the Punjab Kill 6; Independence Day Toll at 13
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.body_text: **********Two gunmen raided two villages in Punjab state today and opened fire at random, killing six people and wounding at least three, the Press Trust of India said. **********The killings, coinciding with the 40th anniversary of India's independence, raised the death toll in the 24-hour-period to 13. **********Extremists had stepped up their attacks ahead of independence day celebrations, and security in New Delhi had been tightened. **********In the attacks today, two men believed to be Sikh extremists raided the town in Kapurthala district, indiscriminately firing on villagers from a motorscooter. **********On Friday, five people, including four members of a family, were shot dead near India's border with Pakistan. **********Two other killings were reported from the Punjab, where the death toll for August stands at 79. More than 700 people have been killed this year. **********Militant Sikhs are fighting for an independent homeland.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/30/world.main_headline: AQUINO DEMANDING ARREST OF LEADERS IN MILITARY REVOLT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/30/world.print_headline: AQUINO DEMANDING ARREST OF LEADERS IN MILITARY REVOLT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/30/world.body_text: **********The leaders of an attempted coup were still at large today and the military remained on alert after Government forces put down the most serious armed challenge to the presidency of Corazon C. Aquino. **********''I want them arrested,'' Mrs. Aquino told reporters Saturday. ''It's not a question of forgiving. It was not only done against me but against the entire country. You saw how many innocent civilians were killed.'' **********Mrs. Aquino's tone Saturday was in sharp contrast to her expressions of leniency in the past against those involved in actions against her Government. **********The Government said 40 people had died in the fighting, most of them civilians. Hundreds were reported to have been wounded, including the President's son, Benigno S. Aquino 3d, who said he was fired on by troops he mistook for friendly forces.  [ Page 9. ]  Roadblocks Set Up There were reports, which were difficult to confirm, that some rebellious soldiers might still be moving toward Manila. The military set up tight roadblocks on the northern and southern approaches to the city. **********Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, the armed forces Chief of Staff, estimated that 800 to 1,200 soldiers had taken part in the uprising and that 705 were in detention aboard a 300-foot-long naval landing craft. He said the military lacked other facilities for holding them. **********House Speaker Ramon Mitra said he had ordered the arrest of the entire 200-man House security detachment, which he said had joined the mutiny and left the Congressmen unprotected. Complaints About Government **********Although the mutineers did not draw significant support from civilians, some of their complaints about the pace and style of the Aquino Government echoed a growing restlessness often expressed among middle-class Filipinos. **********A nationwide strike to protest fuel price increases, held two days before the attacks last Friday, appeared to reflect a larger discontent with a Government that is often described as indecisive and lacking direction. **********An officer close to Col. Gregorio Honasan, the leader of the rebels, said Colonel Honasan had ''gone underground.'' The officer said of the uprising, ''I see it as a beginning.'' **********A source close to renegade forces loyal to the former president, Ferdinand E. Marcos, said it was possible that Colonel Honasan, now that he had failed on his own, could join forces with them. **********Senator Juan Ponce Enrile, Colonel Honasan's mentor, denied on radio today that he had been involved, though some members of government said publicly they suspected him. **********Five other middle-grade officers identified as commanders of the mutineers were also being sought. Call for Punishment **********''The full force of the law will have to be meted out to the ringleaders,'' said the President's spokesman, Teodoro Benigno. ''Many of those on a lower level might not have known what was going on.'' **********Some captured enlisted men said they had thought they were going on a training mission, or were heading into battle with Communist guerrillas. **********As for the leaders, Mr. Benigno said, ''They might have hypnotized themselves into thinking they are the saviors of the country.'' Luzon Soldiers Said to Be at Large **********Some soldiers who had prepared to join the rebels in Manila from camps in southern and central Luzon were reportedly still at large. **********The military said that to avoid a shootout, about 400 mutineers were allowed to leave a police garrison they had captured in San Fernando, 40 miles north of Manila, taking their weapons with them. **********In Legazpi, 210 miles south of Manila, some 100 soldiers were reportedly allowed to escape serious punishment and return to their units after taking over an airport with plans to fly to the capital. **********The roadblocks on the outskirts of Manila were heavily manned, with tanks deployed at some points, and all traffic entering and leaving the city was being stopped. Roadblocks at Other Towns **********Other towns near the capital were reported also to have set up strict roadblocks. **********Cadets at the Philippine Military Academy, where Colonel Honasan enjoys wide support, issued a statement warning the Government to ''exercise justice and good sense'' in dealing with captured mutineers. **********The leaders of the rebellion, the same men who had organized a number of coup threats last fall, represented a deep strain of discontent in a divided and politicized armed forces. **********Mr. Benigno said: ''The country is moving forward. This is not a banana republic.'' He added, ''There's one thing you can say about the Aquino Government that you can't say about other third world governments: its capacity to withstand coups.'' Rebel Called Urban War Expert **********Colonel Honasan's friend, who declined to be identified, said that the rebellious soldier was an expert in urban guerrilla fighting and that he might begin his own small insurgency. **********Colonel Honasan, when planning a coup against Mr. Marcos that developed into the revolt that helped bring Mrs. Aquino to power in February 1986, is said to have planned to escape to the mountains if the attempt failed. **********''Look forward to interesting urban-type warfare because that's what Greg excels in,'' his friend said. **********In a statement Saturday, Communist rebels said the mutiny had enhanced their own position. They called the uprising a ''panic reaction'' to their own growing strength. Statement From Communists **********''The current situation is undoubtedly excellent for the Filipino people to victoriously advance their revolutionary struggle on all fronts,'' said the statement, issued by the Communist-dominated National Democratic Front. **********The last small pockets of armed resistance were neutralized Saturday, one day after pro-Government forces waged vigorous ground and air attacks on their positions. The headqauarters building at Villamor Air Base, where a small group appeared to be holding out, was sealed off to the public. President and Son Attend Mass The President and her son, whose arm was in a sling, attended a mass Saturday for five slain members of the presidential security command, including three who died in the attack on Mr. Aquino. **********The rebels failed in an attempt to seize Malacanang palace shortly after midnight Friday morning and later were driven from four television stations, after broadcasting a brief message calling for popular support. **********The armed forces general headquarters building stood blackened and gutted Saturday after a fire that began when rebels were forced from the building in fighting that raged through Camp Aguinaldo. **********Cebu City, the nation's second largest urban center, returned to normal Saturday after local military forces put civilian leaders under arrest and forced most radio and television stations off the air. **********The local commander, Gen. Edgardo Abenina, was dismissed by General Ramos. As the mutiny in Manila collapsed, he accepted his removal without resistance.  REAGAN PLEDGES U.S. SUPPORT **********LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28 (Special to The New York Times) - President Reagan today pledged the ''wholehearted support'' of the United States for the presidency of Mrs. Aquino, and said he was determined to work closely with her to spur democracy in the Philippines. **********In a statement issued here shortly before Mr. Reagan's departure for his ranch near Santa Barbara, Calif., Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said, ''The President is gratified and relieved that President Aquino has resolved the crisis faced by her Government over the past two days.''  AQUINO AND THE MILITARY: AN UNEASY ALLIANCE  President Corazon C. Aquino has withstood several challenges from the military since she came to power in February 1986. Here are several of the most significant incidents.  July 6, 1986: A group of military officers supporting the deposed President Ferdinand E. Marcos takes over the Manila Hotel and declares Arturo Tolentino, who had run for vice president on a ticket with Mr. Marcos, the president. The officers surrender two days later.  Nov. 23, 1986: The Government says Lieut. Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, Chief of Staff, has blocked a coup plot by disaffected military officers linked to Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile. Mr. Enrile is dismissed.  Jan. 27, 1987: Marcos loyalists and mutinuous troops try to seize military and press installations in the capital. The mutineers hold a radio-television station for 61 hours before surrendering.  July 13, 1987: Four army officers are arrested in Manila in connection with a coup attempt.  Aug. 27, 1987: Mutinous soldiers begin attacks on the presidential palace to try to overthrow the Government. By the next day, the uprising, the most serious assault on the Aquino Government, has been crushed, but the military remains on alert and the coup leaders remain at large.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/15/busin.body_text: **********NOBODY had built a better mousetrap, but there were plenty of other ideas among the inventors who gathered last weekend in Arlington, Va., for the Seventh Annual National Inventors Conference. Under the aegis of the United States Patent and Trademark Office, more than 50 inventors from around the country displayed their newly patented creations - ranging from a fortune-cookie folding machine to a shoe that allows its wearer to virtually walk on water - in hopes of attracting some commercial interest. **********Some 75 inventors attended meetings at the Sheraton Hotel across the street from the Patent Office, to learn how to raise the money or entice the big company that would get their invention onto the market. The advice they got was general and sometimes contradictory, but the emotional support was strong. ''You are perhaps this nation's most valuable resource,'' Donald J. Quigg, Patents and Trademarks Commissioner, told them in his speech. Inventiveness has always been viewed as a peculiarly American trait. But according to the Patent Office's statistics, that is rapidly changing. Last year, foreigners accounted for 44 percent of the 76,000 patents granted by the Government; 20 years ago, the figure was only 16 percent. ''And when a foreigner gets a patent, it's a good bet that he or she plans to enter our market,'' said Mr. Quigg, who added that it is no coincidence that the nation's trade deficit has grown along with the number of foreign patent-holders. **********In fact, in some of the most important technological fields, such as fiber optics, electrical equipment and sound reproduction, the lion's share of United States patents is now going to foreigners. **********An explosion of patents in a given area, however, does not necessarily mean an explosion of ground-breaking inventions. As Jacob Rabinow, an inventor who holds 221 patents ''and a couple more pending,'' explains it, many patents simply reflect the incremental advances being made in a given technology. ''It means that a lot of people are working in that field,'' he said. **********But the crowd at last weekend's convention was not thick with corporate engineers or research and development technicians. There were engineers - some with doctoral degrees - but mostly they worked for small companies or ran their own. And there was a sprinkling of individuals with no corporate affiliation and no academic credentials. **********At this gathering, the inventions tended to be more eccentric. A few even seemed to challenge the Patent Commission's modest criterion that a new device be ''useful'' to be patented. And most of the devices exhibited had only the slimmest commercial prospect. But for all that, their involvement was no less passionate: **********''You're from Miami?'' said one man, reading the other's tag. ''Yep.'' ''What do you do there?'' **********''Invent.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/02/busin.main_headline: M/A-Com Picks Leader From Its Own Ranks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/02/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; M/A-Com Picks Leader From Its Own Ranks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/02/busin.body_text: **********M/A-Com Inc., an electronic equipment manufacturer that has been undergoing a restructuring, announced yesterday that it had named Thomas F. Burke as president and chief executive. **********Mr. Burke, 57, replaces Richard T. DiBona, 53, who suffered a stroke a year ago. Mr. DiBona continues as a director. **********Mr. Burke has been with M/A-Com for more than 25 years. He was chief financial officer when Mr. DiBona suffered his stroke and in November was named chief operating officer. A committee set up by the board chose Mr. Burke for the top job after looking inside and outside the company. **********As chief executive, he succeeds Frank A. Brand, 63, who has been acting chief executive. Mr. Brand ''will be staying with the company,'' Mr. Burke said, adding that he planned to announce a management reorganization shortly, at which time he will disclose Mr. Brand's role. **********M/A-Com, based in Burlington, Mass., also said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to five million of the company's common shares. In September, it received approval to repurchase 12 million shares. **********Mr. Burke said the company had sold two businesses last year for $300 million and was using the proceeds for the stock buyback and to retire debt. **********M/A-Com, which employs 8,500 workers, derives $400 million of revenues from electronics components and $250 million from communications systems. The components are used in such applications as radar, navigation and electronic countermeasures and the company is also strong in military encryption technology. **********The company said it had abolished the position of board chairman. Mr. Burke said he would act as chairman at the meetings ''but under the bylaws the board does not require a chairman.'' Irving J. Helman, who has been acting chairman, will continue as a director. **********Mr. Burke is a graduate of Boston College with undergraduate and master's degrees in economics. Before joining M/A-Com in 1961 he was employed by a paper comany, Hollingsworth & Whitney, and CBS's electronics division.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/busin.main_headline: The Big Board Battle to Contain the Damage
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/busin.print_headline: The Big Board Battle to Contain the Damage
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/busin.body_text: **********BY noon Tuesday a groggy John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, had come to his wit's end. The tiny pool of ''buy orders'' on hand at the opening had dried up. And temporarily closing the Big Board seemed like the only way to prevent the market from another debilitating tailspin on top of Monday's 508-point decline. **********Yet a shutdown, however temporary, would be the option of last resort. At a late Monday night brainstorming session beneath the stained-glass ceiling of the exchange's boardroom, three dozen leading brokers had cringed at the thought of interrupting trading. Howard H. Baker Jr., the President's chief of staff, telephoned to say the White House did not care much for the idea. The Securites and Exchange Commission and officials of the trading pits in Chicago did not like the idea either. **********Ultimately, Mr. Phelan did not exercise his final option. ''We decided to let it bounce around and see what happened,'' he said Tuesday afternoon. **********The market continued to struggle through the day. And while trading continued on the floor, nervous officials worked closely with the financial community, with corporations and with Government experts to make sure that Monday's free fall did not recur. **********All through the week, the Big Board jawboned its members, urging them not to trade stock-index options and stock-index futures, in an attempt to contain the market's unsettling volatility. And market officials fine-tuned trading hours, hoping to lift some of the oppressive volume from their backs. **********When the Federal Reserve said it would try to promote easier credit, many banks lowered their prime rates, some by as much as three-quarters of a percentage point, in a dramatic retreat from increases made as recently as the previous Friday. And several companies quickly said they would buy back millions of their own shares to support their sagging stock prices and at the same time strengthening them against takeovers. **********Indeed, those corporate buybacks became a significant factor in the market. Early Tuesday, David Roderick, chairman of the USX Corporation, said USX would ''take advantage of current market conditions'' to buy up to 20 million of its shares. **********Donald Peterson, chairman of the cash-laden Ford Motor Company, then said Ford would accelerate its scheduled repurchase of 45 million shares. **********''Those announcements brought buyers back and allowed some stocks to re-open,'' said Leo Melamed, who introduced financial futures contracts at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. ''They brought a great deal of confidence back to the market.'' **********By the end of the week more than 100 companies announced buybacks, including Honeywell, ITT, General Motors, Chrysler, McGraw-Hill, MCA, IC Industries, Allegis, Citicorp, Merrill Lynch, Shearson American Express and Bristol-Myers. **********''They wanted to make a demonstration of their confidence,'' said Stanley Abel, the chairman of Abel/Noser, a Wall Street consulting firm that specializes in buybacks. ''That's all part of calming the troubled waters, reassuring the public that the panic on Monday was unjustified.'' **********Calming the volatility proved more difficult that soothing the public. And many experts and voices in Washington blamed that on the impact of trading in stock-index futures and options. Both products give investors the right to purchase or sell a bundle of securities at a specified price at some point in the future. **********Since these ''derivative products'' became popular a half-dozen years ago, brokerage houses have recruited mathematicians and physicists to join their ranks. These so-called ''rocket scientists'' have devised intricate formulas and complex trading programs that measure both the market value of certain stocks and of futures on those stocks, and then rapidly execute trades when the market values are out of synch. The technique is known as program trading. **********By Tuesday morning, the New York Stock Exchange forbade brokers to use its electronic data system for program trading, saying the system was about to overload. **********''What we wanted to do was take it out of our system,'' Mr. Phelan explained. ''We wanted to make sure our system was clear for people who wanted access to it.'' **********BEHIND the scenes a debate raged on program trading, and whether it was indeed a culprit in the remarkable volatility. Members of Congress and the S.E.C. said they would investigate. The Chicago exchanges, perpeptually on the defensive about stock-index trading, felt the most pressure. Facing the possibility that they would become scapegoats if the market dove again, the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the Kansas City Board of Trade, the New York Futures Exchange and options pits of the American Stock Exchange decided to shut. **********The executive committee of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange huddled in special session, thinking that the New York Stock Exchange was about to close, too. The members voted to shut down. Then came a call from New York. **********''We were advised by Mr. Phelan that they were going to try to tough it out,'' said Mr. Melamed of the Merc. After 40 minutes of eerie silence, the Chicago exchange reopened. **********By Thursday afternoon, the Big Board had decided to close two hours early on Friday, as well as tomorrow and Tuesday. Other exchanges took the cue and followed. Mr. Phelan said the 2 P.M. close was intended to give the exchange a breather, allowing the staff and the member firms to catch up on paper work. **********Because of the paucity of buy orders, the market frequently ran out of gas late in the trading session during the week. Many brokers said they expected that the shorter work day would lead to a less volatile market. **********The cooperation between Wall Street and the Federal Government was echoed within the financial community. Goldman, Sachs & Company established a loan fund of $1 billion for cash-strapped mutual funds that had been hit by heavy redemptions. Stock exchange executives monitored the finances of shaky firms and directed them to sources of ready capital. **********When A. B. Tompane & Company, one of the specialist firms whose job it is to maintain orderly markets in selected stocks, was overwhelmed by the crushing volume, Merrill Lynch & Company helped forestall panic by quickly agreeing to acquire it. **********But all the gyrations have taken their toll. For example, two seats on the exchange, sold by distressed brokers trying to raise cash, brought $750,000 and $760,000 respectively late in the week. A week earlier, a seat sold for $1.25 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/12/world.main_headline: AQUINO IS THE KEY IN PHILIPPINE VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/12/world.print_headline: AQUINO IS THE KEY IN PHILIPPINE VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/12/world.body_text: **********Three rival political rallies competed for crowds here one recent humid night amid the smoke of frying squid and the tinkling bells of ice cream vendors. All three claimed the support of President Corazon C. Aquino. **********Some candidates slipped quietly from stage to stage in an attempt to secure alliances and avoid open splits. At each rally they danced, sang and shook their fists in the Philippine style. **********Elections for a new Congress are a month away, and the political scramble that is now under way demonstrates the new wide-open atmosphere Mrs. Aquino has restored. **********Future members of Congress - and people who consider themselves potential presidents - seem to be everywhere now, more than a year after the end of two decades of authoritarian rule by Ferdinand E. Marcos. A Thousand Candidates **********Early soundings have caused unexpected concern among Mrs. Aquino's strategists over the possibility of a strong showing by her opponents. **********Nearly 1,000 candidates from as many as 70 parties are campaigning for the 24-member Senate, whose members are elected nationwide, and the 250-seat House of Representatives, whose members are elected from districts. **********In this jostling crowd, getting name recognition has become the main challenge. Most candidates are focusing their energies on simply trying to get voters in the May 11 election to remember who they are. **********Leticia Ramos Shahani, for example, a normally sedate former United Nations official who is running for the Senate, dances the cha-cha on stage to her theme song, ''Sha-Sha-Shahani.'' The Popularity of Aquino **********After the overwhelming endorsement of a new Constitution in a referendum in February, it is Mrs. Aquino who is indisputably the country's most popular politician. **********Pro-Government candidates, who are expected to dominate both houses, compete to share in her popularity. A photograph of the President holding up a candidate's hand can mean victory. **********Her opponents, including former Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile, who once tried to force her from office, now play down their opposition to her, saying they want to help her form a democratic legislature. **********For the same reason, few politicians have dared attack the President directly. Instead, accusations of corruption have been aimed at some relatives. **********Some former Marcos supporters have come over to the Aquino camp, and it is a measure of the Government's concern about this election that it has welcomed support from the stronger vote-getters among them. Warning to Opposition **********Mrs. Aquino herself is on the stump each weekend. She has aroused some controversy with a declaration, in the Marcos style, that she needs no opposition in the legislature. **********Her Secretary of Local Government, Jaime Ferrer, has ordered all local officials, who are appointed by the Government, to campaign for Mrs. Aquino's candidates or be dismissed. **********Most of the leading figures now on the campaign trail are familiar faces from within the Government or the opposition of the past, including loyal Marcos functionaries who withered in his shadow and dissidents who marched against him in the streets. **********The major alliances supporting or opposing the President differ little in their social backgrounds or political programs, however, except for a handful of issue-oriented activists. Political alliances take precedence over issues. No Aquino Party **********The President has refused to form a political party, and her supporters have put together a fractious alliance known as Laban. She has endorsed 24 candidates for the Senate but has chosen to leave many of the House races open, and confusion and acrimony have resulted in many places. **********Her senatorial candidates, traveling the country in four groups of six, have canceled appearances in some towns to avoid embarrassment of the kind encountered in Cebu. **********The major opposition parties have formed an equally tenuous grouping known as the Grand Alliance for Democracy, which includes a number of men closely associated with Mr. Marcos. **********Other Marcos men have kept alive his political party, the New Society Movement. Although it is now very much a minority party nationwide, the structure still exists in many places. A Threat to Aquino Program **********These opposition groupings are expected to present a stronger challenge in the House than in the Senate. A strong opposition here could seriously slow the President's program. **********Meanwhile, the left wing has started an experiment in mainstream politics with a coalition called the Alliance for New Politics, which is expected to win only a symbolic presence in the legislature. **********The core of the alliance is the Party of the Nation, a legal group that was formed under the sponsorship of Jose Maria Sison, the founder of the Communist Party of the Philippines. **********The alliance's seven senatorial candidates are radical organizers and former leaders of the leftist underground. They support Mrs. Aquino while putting forward their own political agenda, which includes the immediate dismantling of American bases and free redistribution of land to peasants. **********Mrs. Aquino's supporters have not stressed issues, in part to avoid splits in their disparate alliance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/busin.print_headline: BAKER TO PICTURE DECLINE OF DOLLAR AS ECONOMIC BOON
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/busin.body_text: **********Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d is expected to tell President Reagan Monday that the two-year fall of the dollar that accelerated late last month has been good for the economy, an Administration aide said today. **********The aide, one of a score or more who have reviewed the briefing papers and charts and graphs prepared for a meeting to brief the President on the economy, said Mr. Baker and Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, are also expected to say that the tumult in the stock market Friday causes them little worry. **********A White House spokesman, Dale Petroskey, confirmed the meeting, set for 2 P.M. Monday, but he declined to discuss what the President would be told. Volatile Stock Market **********Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average, apparently benefiting from prospects that a cheaper dollar would increase the profits of American industries by helping them sell more goods abroad, embarked on its longest rise in history - 13 consecutive day that pushed it up more than 200 points. It turned on Thursday though, and in a wildly gyrating market Friday, the Dow swung back and forth by more than 100 points before plunging 44.15 points to close at 2,101.52. Market analysts are predicting that the wild swings will continue, while carefully distinguishing between the surge in the market earlier in the month and the pandemonium on Friday.  [ Page 22. ]  The event brought expressions of concern from the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, John S.R. Shad. **********Mr. Petroskey said today, ''We have no comment on the stock market,'' but the Administration aide said Mr. Baker and Mr. Sprinkel would tell Mr. Reagan that Friday's turmoil was an aberration and that the more important trend was the long-term rise in stock prices that began in 1982. **********The Baker-Sprinkel briefings are usually given every two or three months to top White House officials and typically cover broad economic trends. **********The Administration aide, who insisted on anonymity, said that this time the briefing papers of the two men dwelled heavily on the volatile events in the stock and currency markets, which have aroused calls for regulation from some of Congress's new Democratic leaders. **********The dollar, declining steadily for two years under a carefully orchestrated effort by Mr. Baker and the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, began falling sharply against the West German mark and the Japanese yen after the Administration reported late last month an unexpectedly large, $19.2 billion November deficit in the nation's foreign trade. The fall continued with reports that the Administration favored a further decline. **********The Administration's indifference to the volatility in the stock market developed last year with the proliferation of computer-driven ''program trading,'' a complex strategy involving the interplay of stocks and related investments, stock index futures. Resisting Calls for Regulation **********The official added that Mr. Sprinkel, in presenting charts showing the performance of the Dow, was likely to urge the Administration to resist attempts in Congress to regulate the activity. He is also planning to present historical material showing that stock prices often embark on sustained climbs after periods when the Federal Reserve helps stimulate the economy's growth with declining interest rates. With the Federal Reserve's help, interest rates have been declining steadily since 1980, leveling off in mid-1986. **********Commenting on the long-term trend in stock prices, one Administration official said today, ''Obviously, we're pleased.'' **********Regarding the dollar, the Administration has made its satisfaction known in recent days. At the White House Mr. Petroskey said again today, ''Our position on the dollar remains unchanged. We don't intervene unless there's a disruption in the market.'' **********In Japan, by contrast, the decline has caused dismay because it is undermining the profits of that country's giant export industries. Japan's finance minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, was so concerned that he paid an emergency visit to Mr. Baker Wednesday seeking help to arrest the dollar's fall. But he left without any public assurances, at least, that such help was imminent. **********West Germany has been affected in much the same way, and on Thursday, the country's central bank cut interest rates, partly in response to pressure from Mr. Baker. Cutting interest rates was designed to help stabilize the dollar, but the mark rose anyway. Fears of Recessions **********The dollar, though it stabilized Friday, has also largely shrugged off comments by Mr. Volcker that it had declined about enough. The aide and other officials said they did not know whether Mr. Baker would also express some concern that the fall of the dollar against the yen and the mark might become counterproductive. Too sharp a fall, a senior Administration official said in an interview last week, could slow the West German and Japanese economies so much that they could slip into recessions. **********They would then be unable to buy increasing quantities of American goods and thus help reduce the American trade deficit, which the Reagan Administration now sees as the No. 1 problem facing the economy. The deficit reflects difficulties and job losses in American manufacturing and agriculture and has led to widespread pressure in Congress to enact protectionist legislation against foreign imports. **********But the decline of the dollar to date, the aide said of Mr. Baker's views, ''has been good for America and good for the economy.'' While the trade deficit reached a record of an estimated $175 billion last year, the falling dollar, in pushing up the prices of imports and depressing those of American exports, will soon show a reversal. **********To demonstrate that the dollar still has some room to fall, Mr. Baker has prepared charts showing its performance where decline has been slight, against currencies other than the yen and the mark. These are the currencies of South Korea and Taiwan, which are now tied to the dollar and rise and fall with it. **********This largely protects their exports to the United States, which now account for a sizable share of the American trade deficit, from the fall of the dollar against other currencies. For months, the Treasury has been urging those countries to readjust their Government-fixed exchange rates to take account of the deficit but has so far won only token adjustments. ''They've done diddily-squat,'' the aide said. **********Some economists find less to fault in the Administration's hands-off attitude toward the stock market than in a similar attitude as yet toward the currency markets. With respect to the yen, the mark and several other European currencies, especially, they say the dollar's decline should stop for now because they see widespread signs that it will soon show it has succeeded in reducing the trade deficitmarkedly. **********Lyle E. Gramley, a former governor of the Federal Reserve Board who is chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association, said that in dollar terms the American trade deficit with Japan had reached another record. But in volume terms, in the quantities of goods involved in the two nations' trade, Japan's exports here fell about 3 percent last year. He said the volume of Japanese imports, meanwhile, is rising.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/26/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: ARGENTINA'S BASIC ECONOMIC PROBLEM; When an Economy Goes Underground
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/26/busin.body_text: **********For years, Latin American economists have attributed underdevelopment to ''dependency'' and the unfair ''exchange terms'' of third world primary goods for manufactured products from the advanced nations. **********Although these theories looked good on paper, they scarcely helped developing nations progress. Luckily, an unconventional but more practical and self-reliant approach to economic growth is taking shape in Latin America: the ''informal'' approach. **********Just as expert Persian rug dealers look at the reverse of carpets to find their true value, some Latin American scholars, such as the economists Hernando de Soto in Peru and Marcos Victorica in Argentina, are looking at the underside of their economies to find out why they resist working effectively. The results are astonishing. **********Argentina is a good case study. The seventh most prosperous nation in the world in gross national product per capita before World War II, Argentina today finds itself 40th. **********For decades, perplexed analysts have searched in vain for ways to explain the drastic decline. But two years ago, Mr. Victorica, who directs the Institute for Contemporary Studies (I.D.E.C.), sensed the clue lay in the irregular practices that permeate Argentina's economy: standard double accounting, uncontrolled tax evasion, what is thought to be the highest level of capital flight in Latin America (as high as $31 billion annually, according to one study) and a habit of under-reporting payrolls and understating revenues and profits. **********Mr. Victorica and his colleagues delved into the mysteries of the informal economy and concluded that three out of every five Argentines today work full or part-time in the unregistered sector, producing as much as $42 billion a year in goods and services, equal to 60 percent of G.N.P. None of this shows up in official accounting. A comparable underground economy in the United States would account for as much as $1.8 trillion in economic activity. **********Although at first glance this would suggest the Government is simply too lenient, the institute's investigation suggests that ''informality'' spreads because the state is too intrusive. **********According to Adrian Guissarri, an I.D.E.C. economist, Argentines have kept out of the official system about 33 percent of the total wealth produced since the late 1940's, when this country's free-market economy became largely state-controlled. Argentina's economic decline began at about that time, too. **********Today, the state controls enterprises that account for more than 50 percent of G.N.P. The Government not only owns monopolies in oil, railways, telephone, electricity, postal service, gas, water and airlines, but also runs more than 520 deficit-ridden companies. Last year, by the calculation of economist Rodolfo Rossi, the state monopolies were responsible for 84.1 percent of the public sector's consolidated deficit. **********The import restrictions, export taxes and price, wage, interest rate and exchange controls that today straitjacket the economy have been standard practices - with nuances - under all Governments, even those that advocated free-market theories. But the most alarming aspect of this all-encompassing bureaucracy is its suffocating inefficiency and total disregard for the public interest it claims to represent. **********Retired people, who were forced to pay mandatory retirement dues to the state welfare system while working, receive miserable pensions of less than $100 a month. A year ago, when they sued the state for its failure to pay them the equivalent of 82 percent of their last salary, as established by law, the Government declared a ''state of social emergency'' and refused to pay, claiming the money was ''gone.'' **********THE state telephone system is another example of what people are forced to tolerate. At a time when communications are erasing national borders and gathering the world into one network, Argentines have trouble reaching their neighbors by telephone. Until last year, people suffered through unconscionable waits - 40 years in one case - to obtain a telephone. **********But thanks to a much publicized program, people with a desperate need for telephone service - primarily businesses and individuals who have been waiting many years for a phone - have been allowed to place ''special'' orders that the state monopoly promises to fulfill within 66 months. Such special-order telephones cost $2,500, a little more than twice the typical fee of $1,200 for a residential line and $2,000 for a commercial line. **********Another victory of spendthrift bureaucrats has been the final outcome of the anti-inflationary Austral Plan introduced in June 1985 to stop a monthly inflation rate of 30 percent. Though President Raul Alfonsin promised to reduce bloated Government expenditures, which, he admitted, were causing rampant inflation, public deficits and inflation were lowered through price and wage controls and higher taxes, not by significant public sector cuts. **********The extremely low payoff of this state-run system is pushing Argentines to boycott the voracious bureaucracy and enter the vast and ever-expanding underground economy. This explains why the unregistered sector here is not restricted to marginals, dropouts or outcasts, as in most countries, but includes many of the most ambitious working people from all social, economic and professional backgrounds. Most agree that informal transactions are the only defense against price controls, astronomical interest rates and high taxes. **********Tax evasion has been the curse of all Argentine administrations - last year, only 130,000 out of three million people who were supposed to pay the three main taxes actually did. When tax agents hit the streets in search of evaders, they found that 40 percent of the people registered had declared false addresses, including one who claimed to live in the middle of the River Plate, another in a church and a third in a soccer stadium. **********Such scandalous levels of tax evasion and under-the-counter operations were explained, until recently, as an Argentine genetic or cultural penchant for civic indiscipline. A legacy of the Italian and Spanish immigrations, analysts said. **********Today, however, they are beginning to be taken for what they really are: A symptom of the dramatic divorce between Argentina's authoritarian economic rules and most people's freer attitudes and preferences. **********The informal economy is a symptom of Argentina's economic woes, not a solution to them. Its presence suggests that growth will begin to recover only when people believe that the state is serving, rather than robbing, them. Only when taxes are lowered to realistic levels, wages and prices are set by the market, and major industries are returned to the private sector will Argentines bring money back from foreign banks, take it out from under the mattress and out of unregistered businesses and invest in renewed growth at home.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.main_headline: No Room in Outer Space For Private Launchers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.print_headline: HOW INDUSTRIES WILL FARE IN 1987; No Room in Outer Space For Private Launchers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.body_text: **********THE outlook for the economy in 1987 looks all-too-familiar: another sluggish year with worries about too much debt and too little growth to drive the unemployment rate much below today's 6.9 percent. **********But behind the standard forecast for another standard year is an American economy still churning with change. The merger wave is continuing to roil key industries. Slow, or non-existent, growth and falling prices are forcing some sectors into a new pragmatism. **********In oil, commercial real estate and agriculture, owners are becoming more willing to sell out at what seem to be fire-sale prices. In entertainment, hard-nosed business executives are cutting costs. **********With all this, short-term interest rates are likely to dip even further as the Federal Reserve pours money into an economy limping into its fifth expansionary year. **********What follows is a look at what could prove to be some of the more interesting sectors by business and economic correspondents of The New York Times. **********IN the year following the Challenger disaster, the question facing the commercial space industry is whether there will be a commercial space industry. **********Until Jan. 28, 1986, the day of the accident, the only thing clear about the nation's space-commercialization policy was that it revolved around the space shuttle. The shuttle was to serve as the primary means of getting commercial satellites into orbit. And its payload bay was the experimentation center for companies trying to make everything from perfect ball bearings to drugs in the weightlessness of space. **********At various times, entrepreneurs announced plans for private launching services. But most were grounded by their big competitor - the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. NASA, fearful of losing business for a shuttle system that was just barely cost-effective, kept the prices it charged for lofting payloads artificially low. **********Now, for the private-launching industry, it looks like the only thing worse than the presence of the shuttle is the absence of the shuttle. **********President Reagan's new space policy, which bars NASA from putting most commercial payloads on shuttle flights, would appear to give a green light to private launching efforts. But with no domestic launching capability in place, major satellite owners -like Comsat, Intelsat and Western Union - have been scrambling to get aboard Europe's Ariane flights. **********''If there is room for an American competitor, and we think there may only be room for one, it could be whoever wins the MLV contract,'' said Brad Meslin of the Cambridge-based Center for Space Policy, referring to the Air Force's new medium-launch vehicle. The multibillion-dollar contact should be awarded in the next few months. And the winner - the contenders include Martin Marietta, Hughes Aircraft and McDonnell Douglas - will wind up with a production line in place, making it far cheaper to sell variants of the rocket for private satellite launchings. **********There is also a race on for another unmanned rocket: The Pentagon's ''heavy lift'' vehicle to take very large ''Star Wars'' payloads into orbit. Boeing has already proposed a craft that uses many of the features of the shuttle's propulsion system. **********Just how quickly American aerospace companies should jump into the fray, however, is unclear. Some are afraid of getting burned on Government programs that are later cut by Congress. And the demand for private launching services may decrease by 1993 as the sky fills with more than enough communciations-satellite capability, say several experts, making many wonder whether it is worth the investment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/15/world.body_text: **********A long-simmering dispute between Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and President Zail Singh of India erupted in public this week, creating an embarrassing new political crisis for Mr. Gandhi's Government. **********The unusual rift between two former allies threatened to undercut the Prime Minister's authority and deepen divisions within the ruling Congress Party at a time when Mr. Gandhi's political difficulties were already on the rise. **********On the surface, no major issues were at stake. But the controversy was said to have derived partly from strains between the two leaders over the handling of Sikh demands in the northern state of Punjab. President Singh is a Sikh. **********Politicians now speculate that Mr. Singh may run for re-election as President this July without Mr. Gandhi's support, seeking votes from Congress Party dissidents and opposition politicians. This could pose a serious challenge to Mr. Gandhi's political strength. **********The President is elected by a vote of Parliament and India's 24 state legislatures. Normally, he is little more than a figurehead who attends ceremonial functions at home and abroad. But as chief of state, he can wield influence at decisive moments. Ties to Gandhi's Family **********For example, it was Mr. Singh who decided in 1984 to swear in Mr. Gandhi as Prime Minister after the asssassination of his mother, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, instead of waiting for Parliament to make the choice. **********At the time, it was said that Mr. Singh was acting out of political loyalty to Mrs. Gandhi, who had backed him for the office of President in 1982 in an attempt to heal the disaffection among Indian Sikhs. **********The President's devotion to the Gandhi family has given an ironic edge to reports in the last year that Mrs. Gandhi's son had snubbed him. **********It was widely reported, for example, that Mr. Gandhi had stopped briefing and consulting the President, had barred him from foreign trips and had permitted his allies to criticize him in Parliament. **********The strains began to come into the open this winter when President Singh refused to sign a bill approved by Parliament to give the Government sweeping powers to intercept mail. A Letter to Gandhi **********Then, this week, the President wrote a letter to Mr. Gandhi, charging that the Prime Minister had refused to keep him abreast of the issue, as required by the Constitution. **********The letter was prompted by Mr. Gandhi's earlier assertion that he had treated Mr. Singh appropriately. ''There is no question of keeping the President outside,'' Mr. Gandhi had told Parliament. ''We keep him fully informed on all major national issues.'' **********The letter, which was published in the newspaper Indian Express on Friday, created a furor in Parliament. **********Addressing the Prime Minister as ''My Dear Rajiv,'' the President said he appreciated Mr. Gandhi's desire to avoid an ugly controversy but added: ''As you are aware, the factual position is somewhat at variance with what has been stated by you.'' **********''Even on certain important domestic issues, I have not been kept informed,'' the President wrote. Blame for Punjab Tensions **********The Prime Minister has never made public his complaints about the President, but senior aides have let it be known that it derives partly from the issue of Sikhs in the Punjab. **********Mr. Singh was a former Chief Minister of the state of Punjab and later Home Minister under Mrs. Gandhi, and Mr. Gandhi is said to have blamed him for letting the situation deteriorate into one that cost his mother's life. Mrs. Gandhi was assassinated by two Sikh security guards. **********Mr. Gandhi's supporters also cite reports that Mr. Singh had once been friendly with Sikh extremists in order to undercut rival Sikh politicians in the Punjab, and that he still has links with some extremists. **********Other analysts say the rift is partly cultural. At the age of 71, Mr. Singh is an affable and shrewd politician who is uncomfortable speaking English and proud of his humble rural upbringing. **********When Mrs. Gandhi backed him for President in 1982, the choice was widely criticized, especially when Mr. Singh declared facetiously that he would have been happy to take a broom and sweep the floor if that was what his leader wanted of him. **********In any case, Mr. Singh's background contrasts with those of the Oxford- and Cambridge-educated people around Mr. Gandhi. Squabbles in the Past **********There have been cases in the past of Indian prime ministers squabbling with presidents. But the confrontation with Mr. Singh poses a serious political challenge for Mr. Gandhi at a time of rising criticism of his style in office. **********Even some of those sympathetic to the Prime Minister regard his behavior toward the president as petulant and high-handed. **********In still another twist to the controversy, federal policemen on Friday raided the residence of Ram Nath Goenka, one of India's leading industrialists, who is a longtime foe of the Gandhi family and owner of the Indian Express. **********The raid appeared to be a part of the Government's crackdown on tax evaders, but Mr. Goenka's associates said it could have been a retaliation for the publication in The Express of Mr. Singh's letter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/12/world.main_headline: 2d Seoul Opposition Leader Set to Run
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/12/world.print_headline: 2d Seoul Opposition Leader Set to Run
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/12/world.body_text: **********Although stopping short of a formal declaration of candidacy, South Korea's most prominent opposition figure left virtually no doubt at a public rally here today that he was running for president. **********''The great majority of the people will want me to run,'' the opposition figure, Kim Dae Jung, said in his clearest indication that he would enter the race. **********''I am the one who is needed today,'' he said. **********Mr. Kim's remarks before tens of thousands of supporters capped a troubled weekend for South Korea's political opposition. It has suffered a severe split despite previous promises to stand united against a Government that it denounces as a military dictatorship. A Growing Rivalry **********On Saturday, another dissident politician, Kim Young Sam, announced that he was running for president, saying he was tired of weeks of fruitless wrangling and it was time for action. **********Kim Dae Jung is considered likely to follow with an official declaration of his own later this week, barring a switch in position that seemed hard to imagine after his statements today. **********For weeks, South Koreans have been riveted by the growing rivalry between the two Kims and their obvious inability, despite frequent pledges of allegiance, to set aside old rivalries and long-frustrated ambitions to become president. **********Many of their supporters have been openly dismayed by the split, believing that only a united opposition led by a single candidate can guarantee victory against the ruling party in elections expected in mid-December. **********Acknowledging that he, too, was concerned, Kim Dae Jung told the crowd today that the ultimate goal was to defeat not Kim Young Sam but the Government party and its candidate, Roh Tae Woo. He suggested, moreover, that it was conceivable that either he or Kim Young Sam might ultimately drop out of the race if it looked like victory was beyond reach. 'Sacrifice' Is Expected **********''Kim Young Sam and I will cooperate in the face of military dictatorship,'' he said. ''At the last minute, if it is needed to defeat the military dictatorship, we will make whatever sacrifice is necessary to make sure that the ruling party cannot win.'' **********Echoing charges made the day before by Kim Young Sam, Kim Dae Jung accused the Government party of having tried to buy votes by handing out gifts during a long holiday season that ended today. It was the first clear signal that the opposition would charge fraud should it lose to Mr. Roh. **********This working-class city, 15 miles south of Seoul, is a natural constituency for Kim Dae Jung, and an enthusiastic crowd filled an open field to hear him speak for an hour. Many people chanted his name over and over, and shouted, ''Run, run, run!'' **********And that is what Mr. Kim essentially said he would do, despite the absence of a formal statement. ''I think I'm the strongest candidate to solve the problems that our nation faces,'' he said. Risk of Army Intervention **********He was even more unequivocal in a written statement distributed earlier to reporters and translated into English by his aides. In it, Mr. Kim bitterly denounced the contention, raised by Kim Young Sam and others, that he should not run because strong opposition to him within the South Korean Army created a risk of military intervention. **********If Koreans accept the idea of a military ''veto group,'' Kim Dae Jung said, ''it only means that we have given up democratization.'' **********He added, ''I am convinced that we absolutely cannot change our position because of a certain attitude taken by a small number of politically minded soldiers.'' **********In the written statement, Mr. Kim also touched on a point that he does not often tackle head-on - the sense among some South Koreans that for all his talk about democracy he is really, in his own words, ''seized with the desire for power.'' **********''Even though there may be a temporary misunderstanding among the people,'' he said, ''I believe I cannot neglect the ardent popular expectations of a large number of people, support being given me by dissident leaders and my own sense of a mission to perform. **********''For that reason, I am positively examining various factors in the direction of running for the presidency.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.body_text: **********Wendy's International Inc. said it would eliminate 160 positions, or 20 percent, of its nationwide administrative staff. About half of the cuts will be made at its headquarters here. The company said the action would improve profitability by streamlining its administration and reducing restaurant development expenditures. It said it would open 175 to 200 restaurants this year, down from the 260 originally planned. Of the almost 3,800 Wendy's restaurants worldwide, 1,300 are operated by the company. Sales in 1986 were nearly $2.75 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/23/world.main_headline: It's Gloom And Glitter For Manila
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/23/world.print_headline: It's Gloom And Glitter For Manila
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/23/world.body_text: **********The mile or two that separate the glittering hotels of Manila from the garbage-strewn North Harbor docks of the Sulpicio Shipping Lines measure the distance between two Filipino nations. **********On Sunday, one of Sulpicio's interisland passenger ships, the Dona Paz, sank in flames with at least 1,500 people on board - survivors say the figure may be twice that - after a collision with a small oil tanker. There were only 26 confirmed survivors. **********Today, decomposing bodies began washing ashore on Mindoro Island, and there were reports that fishermen had found a 4-year-old boy alive on a piece of timber. **********President Corazon C. Aquino called the accident one of the worst in maritime history, ''a national tragedy of harrowing proportions.'' **********She called on the more fortunate to help the families of the Dona Paz victims, most of them poor. **********''Our sadness is all the more painful because the tragedy struck with the approach of Christmas,'' Mrs. Aquino said in a statement read by her press secretary. **********Christmas is a holiday of immense importance in the Philippines, the only predominantly Christian nation in Asia. Rich or poor, Filipinos head for Manila to spend the holiday with their families. The well-to-do travel by plane, the poor by inter-island ship. The Two Philippines **********In the better seafront neighborhoods of Manila, there are string orchestras, women in pastel gowns and choirs singing carols as this city swings into its peak social season. Wide-bodied jets disgorge thousands of revelers home from abroad, bearing cartons of electronic toys and other expensive gifts. **********Farther north along the harbor, past some of Asia's worst slums, Rupa Narido waits mutely in her worn housekeeper's clothes at Sulpicio's waterfront office. As she sits under the glare of neon lights, the only sounds around her are sobs. Her sister is missing. **********''We had a telegram saying she was coming on the Dona Paz,'' a relative said of Mrs. Narido's missing sister, Consolacion Narido Garcia. ''We came two hours on a bus to meet her.'' **********In 48 hours, the shipping line had managed to post the names of only 122 of the more than 1,500 passengers and crew members known to have been on the Dona Paz. A separate, computer printout of 26 survivors was also taped to a wall outside the Sulpicio office. It drew no crowd. **********Five Coast Guard ships and two commercial vessels searched today in the area where the 2,215-ton Dona Paz and the 629-ton tanker, Victor, were reported to have gone down. Frogmen joined the operation. Leaping Into a Flaming Sea **********Government television showed pictures of the survivors, who were being treated for burns in a Manila hospital. Most of those who could talk described leaping into a flaming sea and swimming past the bodies of victims. **********No survivor was able to give a broader account of what happened on that moonless night. Crew members of passing ships said there had been a collision and an explosion. They said that both ships had lights on. **********Many Filipinos, officially and unofficially, assumed that the Dona Paz had been dangerously overloaded. Survivors said extra passengers had been picked up after the vessel was full. Passengers were crowded into metal bunks or slept on decks. **********Up at the Sulpicio pier, where a bigger sister ship, the Philippine Princess, was preparing to sail to Cebu, a young man who would not give his name, asked suddenly, ''What can you think of Filipinos?'' **********''My parents - my mother - was on the boat and is maybe dead,'' he said. ''I loved them. But this is life. Filipinos live in permanent insecurity.'' **********He said the disaster recalled a bygone era of unsupervised ships teeming with too many passengers. ''This accident came from the 19th century,'' he said. ''It should not happen now.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/29/world.main_headline: South Koreans Arrest 3 High Police Officials
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/29/world.print_headline: South Koreans Arrest 3 High Police Officials
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/29/world.body_text: **********Three senior police commanders were arrested today on charges that they covered up information on the torture death of a student, officials said. **********A Government spokesman, who declined to be named in keeping with official practice, said the three commanders were arrested for trying to conceal how many officers were involved in the Jan. 14 killing of the student, Park Chong Chul. **********The death and subsequent revelations of a police cover-up have created a national furor. President Chun Doo Hwan dismissed his Prime Minister and seven other key ministers this week in an attempt to ease the crisis. **********Three junior officers, who were arrested last week, were formally indicted today on charges of ''brutal acts'' for their role in the death, the spokesman said. Their names were not disclosed. Two other junior officers had already been charged in connection with the killing. **********Officials identified the police commanders arrested today as Gen. Park Cho Won, deputy chief of the National Police, Yu Chong Bang, chief of the Fifth Department of the Anti-Communist Investigation Division No. 2, and Park Won Taek, Mr. Yu's assistant.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/11/busin.main_headline: Ex-Armco Chief Is Chosen to Fill Commerce Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/11/busin.print_headline: Ex-Armco Chief Is Chosen to Fill Commerce Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/11/busin.body_text: **********President Reagan today named C. William Verity Jr., retired chairman of the steelmaker Armco Inc. and a strong advocate of expanded trade with the Soviet Union, as his choice to head the Commerce Department. **********''I know he shares my commitment to free and fair trade,'' Mr. Reagan said. He added that Mr. Verity ''supports our efforts to prevent any move toward protectionism that would bring immediate retaliation and reverse the recent progress we've made in correcting the trade imbalance.'' **********As Secretary of Commerce, Mr. Verity would fill the Cabinet post left vacant by the death of Malcolm Baldrige, who was killed July 25 in a horseback riding accident. Pressing Trade Issues **********Mr. Baldrige was popular in both the business community and on Capitol Hill, and his death has left the White House without a key player at a time that trade legislation is pending in Congress and trade tensions with Japan are running high. **********Republican and Democratic aides on the Senate Commerce Committee predicted that Mr. Verity, who is 70 years old, would win confirmation from the panel with little difficulty. **********But he is expected to face difficult questioning about his outspoken views on the handling of American-Soviet trade. From the late 1970's until the mid-1980's Mr. Verity was co-chairman of the U.S.-U.S.S.R Trade and Economic Council, a private organization of American companies and Soviet trading agencies. **********In that job, Mr. Verity urged Washington to separate trade from politics in its commercial dealings with the Soviet Union. He warned that America was ''shooting itself in the foot'' by imposing export controls against nations of the Communist bloc. **********In 1984 Mr. Verity complained that American companies were losing at least $10 billion a year in sales to the Soviet Union through export curbs. **********In his introductory remarks today, President Reagan noted that Mr. Verity ''supports ongoing efforts to keep vital technology from falling into the hands of our adversaries.'' **********According to several of Mr. Verity's business associates, he and Mr. Reagan struck up a friendship in 1981 when Mr. Verity was chairman of the President's Task Force on Private Sector Initiatives. That panel was charged with recommending ways in which corporations, religious groups, charitable foundations and local governments could supplement social programs at a time that Federal spending on them was being cut. **********Although industry groups in Washington had urged the White House to seek someone already within the Commerce Department - particularly S. Bruce Smart, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade Administration - business leaders today hailed Mr. Verity's nomination. Mr. Verity is a former chairman of the board of the United States Chamber of Commerce. **********''Bill Verity is an outstanding choice as the new Commerce Secretary,'' said Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation. **********Richard Lesher, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, described Mr. Verity as ''a good friend of the business community who really understands that the trade deficit is partly of our own making and partly the result of how our trading partners play the game.'' **********Mr. Verity made only brief remarks today at the White House, saying it would be inappropriate to answer questions from the press before his Senate confirmation hearings. **********''I'm just happy to have this opportunity at what I think is a historic time in international trade,'' he told Mr. Reagan. ''I look forward to trying to help you in the job of making this country more competitive.'' **********Mr. Verity is a native of Middletown, Ohio, where Armco has its headquarters. The company, founded by Mr. Verity's grandfather in 1900, is the nation's No. 5 steel producer. **********Mr. Verity joined the company, then known as the Armco Steel Corporation, in 1940, a year after he graduated from Yale University. He stepped down as chief executive officer in 1979 and as chairman in 1982. As head of the company, he criticized the Government for not doing more to diminish steel imports. **********Mr. Verity is married and has three children. **********Friends say he has two distinctive habits: He never wears a watch, and he never wears dress shoes. ''It's true,'' said Mr. Lesher of the Chamber of Commerce. ''I never saw him in anything but penny loafers.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/08/world.main_headline: Mecca Pilgrims Say Iranians Concealed Weapons
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/08/world.print_headline: Mecca Pilgrims Say Iranians Concealed Weapons
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/08/world.body_text: **********Moslem pilgrims returning from Mecca said today that Iranian demonstrators who rioted there carried knives and fire bombs concealed in their clothes and that hundreds of people were trampled to death in a stampede as the Iranians attacked the Saudi police. **********The accounts of the rioting on the eve of the annual pilgrimage in which more than 400 Moslems died described a belligerent Iranian march on the Grand Mosque. It swiftly turned into a scene of noise and chaos as hand-to-hand fighting broke out in the dense crowd, according to the accounts. **********''It was a big tragedy,'' Ali el-Dimildash said, arriving on one of the first special pilgrimage flights at the Cairo airport tonight. ''Here we are people who had gone there to say, 'There is no God but God,' and this is supposed to be a place of peace.'' **********''The Iranians were carrying under their clothes, knives, sticks - all kinds of weapons, even bombs,'' he said. ''They started hitting people trying to get them to join their demonstration. The security forces came, and they started throwing things and then they were chasing the Saudi soldiers. It was a mess.'' 'Iranians Were Very Tough' **********''The Iranians, they were very tough,'' said another returning pilgrim, Ibrahim Saeed. **********''Wherever they went, it was in a big group,'' he said. ''Nobody could interfere with them. They went after the people from the gulf and started chasing them. They surrounded the police and took their weapons away and started chasing the police.'' **********Saudi officials said 402 people were killed in the clashes outside the Grand Mosque, adding that the death toll included 275 Iranians, 42 pilgrims of other nationalities and 85 Saudi citizens and security officials. **********Iranian officials said today that 322 of their citizens had died in the clashes.
