Saudis Say No Shots Were Fired **********Saudi officials say that no shots were fired and that the victims were trampled. Iranian officials say the police opened fire on a ''peaceful demonstration.'' **********There were emotional scenes and huge demonstrations in Iran today as 50 more coffins of the Iranian dead arrived at the Teheran airport. They were paraded through the main Friday prayer meeting at Teheran University, and then carried to the Cemetery of the Revolutionary and War Dead south of the city, marked by a bright red ''fountain of blood.'' **********''Death to America!,'' the crowd chanted. ''Death to the fascist Saudi police!'' **********''We will fight to the last breath,'' the Iranian Chief Justice, Abdul-Karim Ardebili, said in the sermon. ''Once we could not sleep for fear of America. Now America cannot sleep for fear of our volunteers.'' A Violation of Traditions **********The carrying of weapons during the pilgrimage would be a violation of Islamic traditions, which hold that the area, known as the haram, is a sacred place where violence is forbidden. **********Pilgrims arriving in Cairo and in other Arab capitals gave similar accounts of an apparently premeditated Iranian march on the Grand Mosque, which contains the black square Kaaba with its chunk of rock that is the most sacred Islamic shrine. **********The witnesses spoke of Iranians' pulling weapons from under their clothes, including bottles filled with gasoline and charging the police until their ranks broke. **********In the noise and confusion, several said, it was impossible to hear if any shots were fired. A few thought they had heard shots but, Mr. Dimildash said, ''I could not tell you where they came from.'' 'Lots of People Trampled' **********The witnesses, however, agreed that the large majority if not all of the people who were killed died from being trampled by the crowd. **********''Lots of people were trampled,'' said Moustapha Hammoud, one of the first passengers off the flight. **********What should have been a joyous occasion was somewhat subdued as relatives crowded around the old airport terminal, many with their cars bedecked with white flags for the pilgrimage, or hajj. Most of the arrivals had brought boxes of electric fans, vaccuum cleaners or other appliances from the duty-free shop in Jidda. **********''The Iranians gathered in a central place behind the Kaaba, and in the beginning it was a peaceful demonstration,'' said Issam Abdul-Azziz. **********''They were shouting and waving banners. Then all of a sudden, they started chasing the police. They were hitting them with knives and short swords. A lot of people were killed. There was shooting. A lot of Saudis were killed.'' **********Witnesses said that after the rioting the streets were littered with bodies, burnt-out cars and debris. The witnesses said it appeared that most of the victims died when they fell under the feet of the panicked mob. **********''Most of the Moslems who were there, we were so angry,'' Mr. Dimildash said. ''You are not supposed to be carrying any weapons in that holy place.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/12/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Wellcome's Bet On AIDS Drug
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/12/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Wellcome's Bet On AIDS Drug
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/12/busin.body_text: **********BETTING on the ''AIDS market'' promises to be an up-and-down affair - a point driven home last week to investors in Wellcome P.L.C., whose share price jumped almost 15 percent through Thursday and then fell back more than 7 percent on Friday. The Wellcome swings illustrate the speculative excitement generated by companies working on AIDS drugs. **********The British pharmaceutical maker's American subsidiary, the Burroughs-Wellcome Company, has developed azidothymidine, or AZT, as a treatment for patients with acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Recent Government-monitored trials have shown that AZT prolongs the life of AIDS patients. **********On Jan. 16, Food and Drug Administration experts are scheduled to hold public hearings to discuss whether AZT should be approved as a prescription drug, with formal F.D.A. approval expected soon afterward. The F.D.A. has already given AZT a special 1AA classification, meaning that the drug is deemed to be of vital importance. Accordingly, AZT could win approval in record time and be on the market by March or April. **********News of the F.D.A. meeting prompted a wave of Wellcome share buying last week, with most of the interest coming from American investors. About a dozen Wall Street houses make markets in the British company's shares. There is no way to invest directly in Burroughs-Wellcome, the American subsidiary that accounts for roughly 70 percent of the parent company's earnings. **********But that has certainly not deterred United States investors recently. ''The surge in buying interest in Wellcome has been just phenomenal,'' said Jonathan Gelles, an analyst for Wertheim & Company in New York, whose firm rates Wellcome a ''speculative buy.'' Market makers estimate that the American trading volume in Wellcome jumped as much as fourfold some days last week, with millions of shares changing hands. **********Indeed, the American buying was the main reason for the sharp runup in the company's share price last week, from a 236-pence-a-share closing price the previous week to 271 pence last Thursday. (There are 100 pence to a British pound, and a pound is worth $1.48 at last Friday's exchange rate.) But last Friday, Wellcome's share price dropped 21 pence, to 250. **********The reason for the fall in Wellcome shares was that on Friday an American company, ICN Pharmaceuticals, of Costa Mesa, Calif., reported that its drug, Ribavirin, appeared to be effective in preventing people exposed to the AIDS virus from developing the disease, based on clinical trials. **********The Ribavirin results, while promising, are preliminary. ICN has not yet had its antiviral agent tested in Government-regulated experimental treatment programs, a stage already completed by Wellcome's AZT. In addition, the two drugs have been tested on different groups, with AZT going to seriously ill patients, while Ribavirin was given to people with a pre-AIDS condition. Wellcome has done some work on AZT's effectiveness in retarding the progression from AIDS-related complex to full-blown AIDS, but the results have not yet been released. **********The Friday retreat shows the vulnerability of Wellcome's shares to competing AIDS-research announcements, not to mention competing breakthroughs. But Wellcome's enthusiasts stress that hopes for AZT as an AIDS treatment merely add to the company's allure, but is not the main reason Wellcome is an attractive investment. **********Wellcome is already ''the world's commercial leader in virology,'' says Samuel D. Isaly, an analyst for S. G. Warburg & Company in New York. For the next few years, Zovirax, an anti-herpes drug, is expected to be the key element in corporate growth. **********A high growth rate became evident in the second half of the company's fiscal 1986 year, which ended last August, when pretax earnings increased 20 percent. Warburg, which is also Wellcome's investment banker, says the rapid growth in earnings should continue. **********In a new report, Warburg states, ''We identify Wellcome as our single-most-attractive major capitalization recommendation of pharmaceutical companies based anywhere in the world.'' Last Friday, Mr. Isaly stressed that the Warburg recommendation still held, despite the ICN announcement. **********However, Wellcome's stock is now selling at roughly 30 times most analysts' estimates of fiscal 1987 earnings, a rather lofty multiple. There already appears to be a fair degree of what one analyst called ''AIDS hope'' in Wellcome's stock price. **********It could be justified. For example, if AZT were sold to 20,000 AIDS patients and had an annual treatment cost of $5,000, it would be a $100 million-a-year drug, according to Ian White, an analyst for Greenwell Montagu Securities in London, which as a ''hold'' recommendation on Wellcome shares. Last year, Wellcome had pretax profits of $185.4 million on sales of $1.4 billion at current exchange rates. **********Some analysts remain skeptical. ''Wellcome is a high-risk, high-reward speculative stock now,'' said Elie Gibson, an analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company in London. ''I worry about recommending a stock on the back of public excitement about a drug that will not contribute much to earnings for two or three years.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Della Femina Clarifies Lifestyles Resignation
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/busin.body_text: **********Although Jerry Della Femina, chairman of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, announced last Friday that he had resigned the Ansell Americas account for Lifestyles condoms, he said yesterday that he actually delivered the letter of resignation last Wednesday. And he offered a copy of his letter dated ''18 February'' to prove it. He said he was concerned lest anyone think he quit a day after the brand had been assigned to Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss, which said it was informed of the appointment on Thursday. **********As previously reported, Mr. Della Femina said that he had resigned because of a quote attributed to John H. Silverman, president of Ansell, in Time magazine: ''AIDS is a condom marketer's dream.'' **********Mr. Della Femina made available a copy of a letter from Mr. Silverman dated Feb. 19 that was in response to the resignation. Mr. Silverman, who in interviews contended the quotation in Time had been out of context, wrote of how he had been trying to no avail for two months to get an appointment with Mr. Della Femina. **********''We were wondering,'' Mr. Silverman wrote, ''if your disappearance had to do with our rebuke of your appearing - supposedly in behalf of the Lifestyles campaigns - on a number of TV interviews with no advance notice to Ansell, your client. We have pointed out repeatedly that you owe that to us, and that Lifestyles is the crusader, not Jerry Della Femina.'' **********In a letter personally delivered to this column yesterday, Mr. Della Femina said that getting condom advertising accepted by magazines and televison ''is the most important thing he has done in this business.'' That was his mission, he said, and he was not ''flacking'' for any one brand.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/world.main_headline: 20,000 Dismissed at Mines; Pretoria Curbs Press Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/world.print_headline: 20,000 Dismissed at Mines; Pretoria Curbs Press Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/world.body_text: **********South Africa's largest mine owner dismissed 20,000 striking black miners today in response to the rejection Wednesday by leaders of 300,000 strikers of the employers' latest offer. **********The mining companies also issued dismissal notices to 22,500 more miners, while 3,000 workers staged an underground sit-in at the world's deepest gold mine. The moves came on the 18th day of a nationwide miners' strike against six major mining companies that has crippled most gold mines and a fifth of the coal pits. **********Also today, the South African Government announced that it was assuming new emergency powers to censor the press and to close for up to three months newspapers that it believes are promoting acts of civil disobedience and boycotts or promoting the image of radical groups. **********The stringent new curbs, which supplement existing restrictions under a 14-month-old emergency decree as well as over 100 laws restricting the press, will apply to all newspapers and publications, although they are directed specifically at the so-called alternative press, a category including low-budget, mainly weekly newspapers, news agencies, journals and specialist publications concentrating on anti-apartheid politics, education, labor and economic issues. Curbs Are Condemned **********Opposition and anti-apartheid spokesmen condemned the curbs as another bid to crush legitimate dissent and warned that, in addition to their effect on ''alternative'' news outlets, the new regulations would increase already high levels of self-censorship by more established news organizations. **********In the miners' strike, the Anglo American Corporation, the biggest mining company and the one worst hit, adopted a tougher stand by carrying out threats to dismiss 20,000 miners at seven gold and coal pits. **********Employers, grouped under the Chamber of Mines, have refused to improve a wage increase ranging between 15 and 23.4 percent since talks broke down six weeks ago. Leaders of the National Union of Mineworkers on Wednesday reduced their demand for a 30 percent across-the-board increase to a 27 percent raise. Employers' Offer Rejected **********Miners voted Wednesday to reject an offer by the employers that would have doubled death benefits to the families of miners killed in mine accidents and increased the holiday leave allowance. **********Employers, clearly shocked by the union's rejection of their offer, have vowed to take a hardline against strikers in a bid to restore their disrupted mines to full production. The strike is estimated to have cost the mining companies $100 million so far. **********Miners at Anglo American's Western Deep Levels mine said today that they had begun a sit-down strike when they were forced at gunpoint by security staffs out of their hostels and down the mine shaft. Intimidation Is Denied **********An Anglo American spokesman denied the intimidation charges. **********Today's dismissals brought to 31,000 the number of striking miners who have lost their jobs. **********It remains unclear whether the dismissals announced so far in the strike will be permanent. Mining companies and other employers in South Africa have engaged in mass dismissals in labor disputes in the past, only to rehire some or all of the dismissed workers later. However, in the current strike, the mine owners have accompanied dismissals with closures of mine shafts in some cases, raising the possibility that strikers may not be re-employed when the dispute is settled. **********In announcing the new press restrictions, Home Affairs Minister Stoffel G. Botha, said publications would be closely monitored and those deemed to be dangerous would be served with a warning that their coverage was ''a threat to the security of the public.'' **********If the newspaper failed to heed the warning, the Minister could appoint a Government censor to clear all reports or ban it for up to three months. **********Mr. Botha said existing restrictions were inadequate to deal with what he called the ''unconventional revolution-supportive press.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/22/busin.main_headline: Talking Deals; Using ESOP's In Buyouts
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/22/busin.print_headline: Talking Deals; Using ESOP's In Buyouts
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/22/busin.body_text: **********ON Wall Street, where financing fads for acquisitions seem to rise and recede with almost the same volatility as the stock market, one of the latest innovations is a hybrid technique. It combines an old idea, employee stock ownership plans, with a newer one, leveraged buyouts. **********In the leveraged employee stock ownership plan, the buyers borrow money to pay for the company in a deal that leaves employees with a majority of the stock. In a typical deal, the employees usually get around 70 percent of the stock. **********Both new financing methods and Federal tax advantages have encouraged a number of these deals this year. And if stock prices remain depressed as a result of this week's volatility, the deals could become even more attractive because they will be cheaper for the buyers, said Eugene J. Keilin, general partner at Lazard Freres and a specialist in this area. **********Last week's $750 million bid by 17 unions to take control of their own railroad, Southern Pacific, is the latest. Another example is the proposed $1.2 billion management-driven buyout of the Charter Medical Corporation, a large provider of psychiatric care. The deal will leave the management of the Macon, Ga., company in charge, but also confer an undisclosed amount of ownership on Charter Medical's employees. In addition, there is the proposed $1.8 billion buyout of Avis Inc., which is being financed in part by an employee ownership plan. **********Investment bankers often praise these deals, citing the advantages of self-ownership. But some plans have drawn harsh criticism. The Charter Medical deal provides a case in point. The company and its adviser, the Bankers Trust Company, are tight-lipped about the specifics, but many on Wall Street, believe the plan could leave employees with a minority voice in the board room despite being the majority owners. **********Critics say that deals in which the employees effectively end up with only minority control are merely financing schemes that offer tax advantages for managers, whose primary interest is not employee ownership or a democratic workplace. **********In some of the deals, employees are given shares that carry less voting power than the stock that management receives. In other cases, the managers could receive warrants or other convertible instruments that could give them greater power after the deal is consummated. **********One investment banker, calls these plans typical management-driven buyouts with ''ESOP qualities'' thrown in simply for the tax breaks. Management essentially gets a leveraged buyout at a discount. The key tax advantage is that principal and interest on the debt are deductible. Bankers Trust, which has pioneered a new security, called floating- rate ESOP's, to finance such leveraged deals, has been sharply criticized for the structure of some of their deals because of the diluted power left in the hands of employees. Bankers Trust executives, however, staunchly defend their plans. **********''Is management ripping off'' the employees? asked Kim M. Chandler, a vice president at Bankers Trust. ''No. Employees shouldn't be brought in on the day-to-day decisions. You still need management to run the company.'' She added: ''Remember, the employees get ownership free. It's a free gift. It's manna from heaven.'' **********Though they might have diluted control, she argues that employees should still benefit from the self-ownership and all the commonly promoted advantages, including greater motivation. **********Ms. Chandler concedes, however, that some leveraged ESOP's were made simply to provide management with attractive tax credits, deals possibly conceived in the ''wrong spirit.'' **********But not all leveraged ESOP's are the same. Employee or union-driven ownership deals are also common. The bid by United Airlines' pilots to win control of the carrier, is a case in point. And the bid for Southern Pacific by the unions is the creation of the employees, whose motivation stemmed mainly from a fear of anti-union purchasers, according to sources working on the deal. The deal is said to include the current management as well as the employees. **********Although most analysts agree that these plans will probably become more common, Mr. Keilin of Lazard Freres thinks the management-driven leveraged employee ownership deals will come under added regulation. **********''These tax advantages are potentially costly to the Federal Government,'' Mr. Keilin said. ''I think everybody is predicting you're going to see more. You'll also see more scrutiny by Congress.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/01/busin.body_text: **********The Pacific Telesis Group restated its first-quarter results today, citing a California Supreme Court ruling on telephone rates. **********The court denied a stay of an earlier decision by the California Public Utilities Commission, which reduced the 1987 rates for the company's Pacific Bell unit by $191 million a year. **********Pacific Telesis said it would petition the court for a review of the decision. **********The earnings were revised to $265.9 million, or 62 cents a share, on revenues of $2.2 billion. On April 16 the company had said it earned $293.3 million, or 68 cents a share, on revenues of $2.24 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/10/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********''The Price of De-Powering'' (Prospects, Feb. 22) fails to reflect the actual broad consensus on the relative costs of power plant decommissioning. The $700 million price tag quoted is inconsistent with almost all other careful estimates. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has very conservatively concluded that the cost will not exceed $200 million. **********The cost to dismantle all existing plants would only be 2 percent of the accumulated savings from nuclear-generated electricity. Whatever minor rate increases the cost of the final disposal of nuclear plants may cause, they will be more than offset by the value of the power produced during their operating life.  THEODORE M. BESMANN  Oak Ridge, Tenn., March 3

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/13/world.main_headline: 4 Killed and 13 Wounded in Philippine Fighting
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/13/world.print_headline: 4 Killed and 13 Wounded in Philippine Fighting
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/13/world.body_text: **********Four civilians were killed and 13 wounded today when Communist rebels raided a village and bombed a police station, the military said. The deaths raised to 42 the death toll in rebel-related violence reported since a 60-day cease-fire ended Sunday. **********A military spokesman said a village official and three residents were killed when guerrillas of the New People's Army attacked a village in Capiz Province, about 250 miles south of Manila. **********Farther south, 10 civilians and a police sergeant were wounded when guerrillas on a minibus threw two grenades at the door of a police station in Davao, the spokesman, Maj. Wilfredo Garcia, said. **********Major Garcia said two of the eight rebels were wounded in a gun battle with traffic policemen who tried to block their bus, but six escaped. The driver was captured later. Summary Executions Reported **********Meanwhile, the Government-run Philippine News Agency quoted a witness today as saying that two soldiers killed in a guerrilla raid Wednesday on a power plant in Pangasinan were ''summarily executed'' after rebels disarmed and beat them with rifle butts. The 60-day truce that ended last weekend was part of an effort to reach a peaceful settlement of the insurgency, in which fighting has cost more than 17,000 lives in 18 years. Last weekend, guerrilla envoys refused to extend the cease-fire and return to the talks, from which they had withdrawn, contending that the Government ''was not serious'' about negotiating peace. On Wednesday, President Corazon C. Aquino said the army would resume operations against the rebels. **********Alan Jasminez, secretary general of the leftist People's Party, said Mrs. Aquino's action was provocative. Leaders of the party, which the military has accused of being a Communist front, said at a news conference today that they favored an extension of the truce. **********''It will make the other side prepare for a counteroffensive and this may bring the country to the brink of war,'' he said. **********The People's Party also announced plans to field candidates in legislative elections set for May. Many of its members are former political prisoners freed by Mrs. Aquino after she took power a year ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/07/busin.main_headline: Bond Prices Mixed to a Bit Off
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/07/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Bond Prices Mixed to a Bit Off
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/07/busin.body_text: **********After surging for two consecutive days, bond prices ended mixed to slightly lower yesterday. **********Experts said investors took a wait-and-see attitude in the absence of any economic news. Tomorrow, consumer borrowing figures will be released while, on Friday, employment figures and producer price statistics will be disclosed. **********''The bond market reacted apathetically to an eventless news day after some early profit taking, said Gary Ciminero, chief economist at the Fleet Financial Group in Providence, R.I. Further Rate Drop Seen **********Wayne Nordberg, head of the investment policy committee of Cleveland-based Prescott, Ball & Turben Inc. said that, even in the face of a weakening dollar internationallly, the bond market continued to give a good account of itself. ''The expected lethargy in the U.S. economy should produce a further decline in interest rates in the first quarter,'' he added. **********Mr. Ciminero said that further wariness in expectation of Friday's economic data served to suppress bond prices. ''An increase in December payroll employment in excess of the 250,000-plus jobs recorded in each of the prior three months would certainy dampen bond prices but I expect an even bigger December job gain, perhaps as much as 350,000,'' he added. **********The benchmark 7 1/2 percent, 30-year bond, due in 2016, opened unchanged at 101 15/16 yesterday and, by late in the day, it was bid at 101 26/ 32, down 7/32, to yield 7.35 percent. **********At the same time, the Treasury's 7 1/4 percent, 10-year bonds were bid at 101 10/32, off 3/32 for the day, to yield 7.06 percent. Bill Rates Slightly Lower **********Yesterday, rates on short-term Treasury bills edged a bit lower from Monday's close. The three-month bill rate ended the day at 5.49 percent, off five basis points; the six-month bill ended at 5.51 percent, off four basis points, and the one-year bill finished at 5.52 percent, off three basis points. **********''Short-term interest rates had shot up toward year-end, which was expected because of traditional seasonal influences,'' Mr. Ciminero said. ''The Fed funds rate remains at 6.50 percent, well above its recent lows, which indicates either a subsiding pace after the traditional seasonal spurt is slow or that the Fed may in fact be sneaking in a tightening move.'' The Federal funds rate eased from 6.85 percent on Monday. **********Dealers also said yesterday that retail participation was light as many investors continued to ponder strategy for the months ahead. Sentiment was bullish in the belief that the economy will weaken in the first quarter and prompt the Federal Reserve Board to further ease credit. **********''Over the last few weeks, Federal Reserve policy has taken a dramatically easier turn,'' said James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer. ''What remains to be seen is how much of that accommodation is purely technical and how much, if any, is intended to be permanent. For the time being, at least, there's plenty of money around.'' **********There was little impact from the $2.5 billion in customer repurchase agreements conducted by the Federal Reserve before noon. Traders said the size of the operation was sufficient to offset potential disappointment that the Fed did not add reserves directly through more aggressive system repurchase agreements, as many analysts had expected.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/19/busin.body_text: **********In a sign of continuing expansion of the financial services industry, Shearson Lehman Brothers has leased 215,000 square feet of office space in a new 14-story building at 75 Park Place to house some of its data processing and commercial paper operations, the company said yesterday. Shearson plans to vacate 100,000 square feet at nearby sites. **********The action comes less than two years after the American Express Company, Shearson's corporate parent, moved into new headquarters three blocks away and a year after the company occupied a computer center nine blocks north. The new tower, developed by **********Jack Resnick & Sons, fills the block bounded by Park Place, Greenwich Street, Murray Street and West Broadway. **********The lease was not disclosed, but real estate analysts estimated it at $8 million a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/15/busin.main_headline: HBO Buying Rights To Paramount Films
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/15/busin.print_headline: HBO Buying Rights To Paramount Films
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/15/busin.body_text: **********Home Box Office has signed an exclusive agreement for the pay-television rights to Paramount Pictures films released after mid-1988. The deal, which includes 85 films, is expected to last at least five years. **********The rights to films from Paramount, currently the nation's most successful movie company, had been aggressively sought by Home Box Office, the nation's largest pay television service, and Showtime, which is No. 2 and which has had an exclusive deal with Paramount. **********No price was disclosed, but some industry experts estimated that the deal was at least $500 million. One knowledgeable pay television executive said an actual price was hard to determine because Home Box Office generally buys films at prices based on their box office performance as well as on the number of HBO subscribers. **********Nevertheless, the deal appears extremely lucrative for Gulf and Western, Paramount's parent company. Paramount's hits include ''Beverly Hills Cop II,'' ''The Untouchables'' and the ''Star Trek'' series. **********One industry expert who declined to be named said he thought the deal could be a programming coup for Home Box Office, which is a unit of Time Inc. **********Home Box Office, with 19 million subscribers, already owns the exclusive rights to films from Columbia Pictures and Tri-Star Pictures. Through a complex agreement, it effectively has the exclusive rights to Warner Brothers films as well. **********Showtime/The Movie Channel, with eight million subscribers, is owned by Viacom International, which was recently acquired by the theater owner Sumner M. Redstone. Although it is losing its right to Paramount films, Showtime still has an exclusive contract with the Walt Disney Company's Touchstone Films, as well as with Orion Pictures. **********Dennis Leibowitz, a media analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, speculated that despite the defeat, Showtime might ultimately benefit. He said that if cable and movie industry companies believed Showtime had severe problems, they might take equity positions in the service. That would insure its survival and help Mr. Redstone pay down the debt he incurred in the buyout. **********Paramount and Home Box Office also entered into an agreement through which they will jointly finance a number of original films made for pay television.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/19/busin.body_text: **********Competitive Labor Costs **********The record level of May imports reported last week is probably an aberration and hides a ''fundamental improvement in the trade deficit,'' said Lawrence A. Veit, international economist at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. ''I predict that in June the monthly trade deficit will fall to below $12 billion, from the $14.4 billion reported for May,'' he said. This would mean three successive quarters of declining trade deficits in nominal terms. **********One of the factors in closing the gap, Mr. Veit says, is the increasing competitiveness of American labor costs. Two years ago, unit labor costs in the United States were $12.82 an hour, much higher than Japan's $6.45 an hour or Germany's $9.60 an hour. This year American manufacturing labor costs should be about $13.70 an hour, but thanks to the falling dollar, Germany's comparable costs will be $16.30 an hour and Japan's $11.44 an hour. **********Even if the dollar rises, American labor costs should remain competitive in the near future, Mr. Veit says. The reasons: Wages are rising slowly, and American companies are investing in new equipment to raise worker productivity. **********The footnote to all this, Mr. Veit said, is that in 20 years or so, the figures on industrial labor costs will become almost useless in determining American competitiveness. With the industrial sector shrinking, he said, there won't be much manufacturing labor to keep track of.  Shrinking Surpluses **********The nation's economy may get little help from the states over the next 12 months. While the states appear to be in good shape this year, Federal spending cuts and an anticipated $3 billion decline in Federal grants-in-aid will reduce their revenues, said James S. Fralick, senior economist at Morgan Stanley. **********This will cause state surpluses to shrink this year, according to Mr. Fralick - to about $54.8 billion from an estimated $63 billion in 1986. Some states can be expected to make up any resulting revenue gap by raising income taxes, excise taxes or sales taxes, said Mr. Fralick. ''One survey shows that 29 states have already proposed sales tax increases,'' he said. **********But even if the states overcome their own fiscal problems, Mr. Fralick said, they will be saving less. This hurts the economy over all, because money that the states salt away is figured into the national savings rates. **********''Retrenchment at this level of government,'' Mr. Fralick said, ''represents a removal of a significant source of support of an already sluggish economy.''  Ideas That Venture Out **********Corporate executives who normally scour the business landscape for startup companies their corporation might want to invest in are increasingly looking inside their own walls. ''Major corporations are becoming the source of high-potential venture capital opportunities,'' said Mark L. Radtke of Venture Economics in Wellesley Hills, Mass. **********According to Mr. Radtke, companies are beginning to see that some of the ideas and products they develop internally might provide the basis for new companies. As a result, they are using their venture capital to start up the businesses that can market - or further develop - these products. **********This approach is not just a way to find new companies to fund, said Mr. Radtke. It is also a potentially profitable way to develop products that ''might have been shelved'' because they didn't fit with a large corporation's overall strategy. **********Monsanto has already funded four small start-ups to commercialize their own technology, he said. So have Tektronix, Kodak and 3M. In the future, he said, this will increasingly ''be a mechanism to maximize the productivity of corporate R.&D.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/28/world.main_headline: The Great Conciliator: Howard Henry Baker Jr.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/28/world.print_headline: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: MAN IN THE NEWS; The Great Conciliator: Howard Henry Baker Jr.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/28/world.body_text: **********Howard H. Baker had always said that when the President asks you to do something, it's hard to say no. **********It is no secret that he had hoped to be tapped for Secretary of State or to fill a Supreme Court vacancy. He did say no to Donald T. Regan, who sounded him out about succeeding William J. Casey as Director of Central Intelligence. **********But Mr. Baker's friends were not surprised that when the President himself telephoned the former Senate Republican leader at a Florida retreat Thursday and asked him to run the White House, there was little hesitation before the acceptance. Mr. Baker flew to Washington today for a meeting with his new boss. **********As recently as two weeks ago, Mr. Baker told friends that he planned to run for President and had commissioned a report on how to raise $10 million for his campaign. Now those friends say the Presidential campaign is probably over. **********''You have to assume that when you're taking this job you're taking it for the remainder of the term,'' a Baker confidant said. A Career as a Conciliator **********An informal, rumpled, unthreatening man, the 61-year-old former Senator made a career out of being a conciliator, bringing together disparate factions and cajoling them into agreements that led to legislation. It was this quality that led to his election in 1977 as Senate Republican leader and his elevation to majority leader in 1981, when the Republicans won control of the Senate. **********His skills were sorely tested. Mr. Baker reconciled the liberal and conservative wings of his party and then reconciled the President's goals with those of the Senate Republicans. At the same time, he won the respect and affection of Democratic leaders of both the House and Senate. He was fond of putting opponents in the same room for all-night sessions and was instrumental in orchestrating the President's many victories on the Hill. **********''He's a genius at finding the compromise point and pushing it through,'' said Senator Jim Sasser, Mr. Baker's Democratic colleague from Tennessee. **********President Reagan frequently acknowledged Mr. Baker's role. ''I'm frank to say that I don't think we could have had the successes that we've had up there without his leadership,'' the President once told a reporter. **********Although the two men were not socially close, Mr. Baker considered himself the President's lieutenant on Capitol Hill. He said today that he made a conscious decision ''that I would be Ronald Reagan's spear carrier in the Senate.'' **********''Anytime there was a matter on which we disagreed, where I felt very keenly, as a matter of conviction and philosophy, I let him know that, and someone else handled it,'' Mr. Baker said. ''But that was very rare.'' **********Indeed, although Mr. Baker's gave the impression of being politically moderate, his voting record was conservative even before he became President Reagan's man on the Hill and helped arrange the curtailment of dozens of social programs. **********Mr. Baker was never the most organized man in the world, nor the most driven, despite his wish to be President. His managerial skills also were the subject of occasional good humor, if not hilarity, on Capitol Hill. He often seemed distracted and preoccupied with matters other than the affairs of state. **********Mr. Baker was both participant and observer, casual and calculating. An avid photographer, he rarely is without his camera. He took it to White House meetings, frequently photographing the President and Vice President as well as many of the staff members he will now manage. **********He acknowledged that the camera reflected his own view of himself as an outsider. Asked once if he felt like an outsider at the White House, he said, ''I am, and always have been.'' Then, gesturing at his Senate surroundings, he added, ''And sort of an outsider here.'' **********Howard Henry Baker Jr. was born to politics on Nov. 15, 1925, in Huntsville, in the eastern, Republican part of Tennessee. His paternal grandfather was a judge; his maternal grandmother a county sheriff, and his father a House member from 1951 until his death in 1964. His stepmother then took over the House seat. **********After high school at the McCallie Military Academy in Chattanooga, he enlisted in the Navy and studied engineering, receiving his Navy commission just in time for the Japanese surrender. Mr. Baker went on to the University of Tennessee Law School, where he was elected president of the student body after running on a platform of - what else? - ''mending fences'' between fraternity members and the independents. It was an early example of Mr. Baker's lifelong devotion to coalition politics. **********He married Joy Dirksen, the daughter of Senator Everett M. Dirksen of Illinois, the Republican leader. ''His marriage could not have been better politically arranged if it had been made in the courts of Europe,'' Prof. John Bakke of Memphis State University observed. The Bakers have two children, Darek, 34 years old, and Cissy, 31. On Watergate Committee **********After a legal career in which he specialized in handling the defense in murder cases, Mr. Baker ran for the Senate in 1964 and was buried in the Lyndon Johnson landslide. Two years later he became the first Tennessee Republican ever popularly elected to the Senate. He easily won re-election in 1972 and 1978 and received national exposure because of his habit of helping Presidents, regardless of party. **********As a member of the Senate Watergate committee, he sought to separate President Nixon from the actions of his underlings, pounding away at an artful question, ''What did the President know and when did he know it?'' **********Senator Baker eventually grew bored with the Senate, however, and retired in 1984, to spend more time with his wife, who was suffering from cancer, as well as to earn some money and to run for President. ''I make no bones about it,'' he often said at that time. ''I want to be President.'' 'Happy as a Bug' **********Mr. Baker joined the Washington office of Vinson & Elkins, a Houston law firm, proclaimed himself ''happy as a bug'' and, when asked how it felt to be making $500,000 a year, told a visitor, ''You vastly underestimate me.'' **********Old friends and colleagues enthusiastically greeted his new appointment, but most considered it a political and financial sacrifice. **********''I can see his interest in terms of meeting a public responsibility,'' said former Senator Edmund S. Muskie, who served with Mr. Baker in the Senate. ''I don't see any political advantage to his doing this. He's a man who enjoys challenges.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/12/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Prices Rise in Light Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/12/busin.body_text: **********Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday, although market participants said the gains were based on light volume and accompanied by a great deal of uncertainty. **********Although the decline in retail sales for May and the weakness in non-auto sales over the last two months indicated that the American economy is growing only modestly, such domestic news continues to be overshadowed by worldwide developments. **********Late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds due in 2017 were offered at 100 30/32, up 21/32 of a point, to yield 8.66 percent. Two-year notes were yielding about 7.60 percent and five-year notes were at 8.10 percent. **********Much of the recent uncertainty in the bond market centers on how the currency market will react to the American trade statistics for April, which are to be published today. Some analysts said yesterday that a deficit of $14 billion or less would encourage a stable to stronger dollar and higher bond prices, while a larger trade deficit would have the opposite effect. They also noted that foreign exchange traders in Tokyo are becoming impatient with the restrictions placed on them by Japanese regulators. These restrictions have helped stabilize the dollar in recent weeks. But when they are lifted, the dollar might decline again. Slow Growth Worldwide **********Economists expect that sluggish economic growth in Japan, Germany and Latin America points toward a slow reduction in the American trade deficit, which will keep alive the threat of renewed weakness in the dollar. **********''World economy is still dominated by a lack of growth, and nothing that came out of the summit is likely to alter that,'' said Georges F. Rocourt, chief economist at the Mercantile-Safe Deposit and Trust Company in Baltimore. **********Although slow economic growth worldwide suggests that inflation is not likely to surge and put pressure on interest rates, Mr. Rocourt said that bond investors still have good reason to be nervous. Another decline in the dollar might mean that higher interest rates would be required to attract money from overseas. He added that the Federal budget deficit might emerge as a new worry this summer. Although the deficit is expected to shrink this fiscal year to about $170 billion, from more than $220 billion, the outlook for 1988 is not as bright. Much of the decline in 1987 was a result of the change in the Federal income tax law. **********The Federal Reserve's report late yesterday on the nation's money supply had little impact on short- or long-term interest rates. As expected, the Fed figures showed that the money supply measures known as M-2 and M-3 had grown more slowly in May than April, and remain below the bottom of the Fed's 1987 growth target of 5 1/2 percent to 8 1/2 percent. The Fed's Criteria **********Although slower-than-targeted growth in the money supply would in the past lead to expectations of a more stimulative monetary policy with lower short-term rates, the Fed's policy today is guided by other criteria. Traders remember that in April, when M-2 and M-3 were also below their annual growth targets, the Fed moved to a more restrictive monetary policy with higher short-term interest rates. **********The Fed's motive for pushing rates higher in April was to keep the dollar from declining further by making it a more attractive currency and to demonstrate to the credit markets that it was willing to oppose the inflationary expectations that resulted from increased commodity prices. **********Analysts at Ried, Thunberg & Company concluded yesterday that ''unless the commodities and financial markets turn rambunctious, it looks as if American monetary policy will be on automatic pilot,'' for at least the next few months. **********The nation's basic money supply measure, M-1, consisting of checking accounts and currency, fell $4.4 billion, to $753.7 billion, in the week of June 1. Although the Fed does not set a target for M-1 growth because its links to changes in the economy are unreliable, analysts still follow its growth pattern to measure to extent to which liquidity is building in the economy. Since the fourth quarter, M-1 has grown at an annualized rate of slightly more than 10 percent, well below the 1986 growth rate of more than 16 percent. **********The more broadly defined money supply measures, which the Fed is watching closely enough to publicly set growth targets, are also expanding more slowly than last year. M-2, which rose $900 million in May, to $2.838.9 billion, has grown at a 4.5 percent rate since the fourth quarter. M-3, which grew $14.3 billion in May, to $3,555.1 billion, has grown at a 4.3 percent rate since the fourth quarter.

BUSINESS FORUM: HEADLIGHTS AT HIGH NOON;
A SILENT SPRING IN EASTERN EUROPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/26/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM: HEADLIGHTS AT HIGH NOON;
A SILENT SPRING IN EASTERN EUROPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/26/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: ACCORDING to Marxist theory, environmental problems cannot occur in Socialist countries because man and nature are inherently in harmony. Unfortunately, the trees, rivers and air of Eastern Europe do not understand Marx. **********ACCORDING to Marxist theory, environmental problems cannot occur in Socialist countries because man and nature are inherently in harmony. Unfortunately, the trees, rivers and air of Eastern Europe do not understand Marx. **********Across Eastern Europe, pollution - as well as general economic decline - are the Grim Reaper of the l980's. In East Germany, according to a West German environmental research group, 90 percent of the trees are sick, dead or dying. The human mortality rate has increased sharply in Hungary, Poland, Russia and Bulgaria, and environment-related illnesses such as cancers and skin and heart diseases are soaring in all Eastern bloc countries. **********In Czechoslovakia, health threats have become so ominous that the Government, according to internal documents, considered a mass evacuation of its industrial region in early 1986. In Poland, experts predict that all plants in Krakow could be dead by the year l990, and the Polish Academy of Science estimates that pollution damage is already costing Poland an amount equal to 10 percent of its gross national product. **********In Leipzig, once one of the prettiest cities in Germany and now a chemical-industry center, the windward sides of monuments and buildings look like they were scorched in a fire, while the leeward sides are smooth and clear. In Molbis, a town downwind of Leipzig, the air is so dirty with the emissions of chemical plants that drivers sometimes must turn on their headlights during the day. Neighbors cannot see each other's houses, and visitors often vomit after a night of breathing the air. **********In Prague, mothers are advised not to give their babies tap water - even after boiling it. In northern Bohemia, the most heavily industrialized area of Czechloslovakia, life expectancy is up to l0 years shorter than elsewhere in the country. Rates for skin disease, stomach cancer and mental illness are twice as high or higher than in the rest of the country. According to Dr. Zdenek Badura, a Czech environmental expert, ''new viral illnesses are emerging. The activity of viruses has grown and they are assuming new forms unknown to us.'' **********Sections of northern Bohemia suffer with permanent near-zero visibility. The Erzgebirge mountains along the Czech-East German border are rapidly becoming a huge tree cemetery, the world's best showcase of the effects of acid rain. The higher one travels up the mountains, the worse the forest carnage. At the top of some mountains, not a single tree survives - just barren landscape with a few remaining stumps. **********In Krakow, the Polish National Lawyers Association reports that cancer, heart disease and artery problems are between two and eight times higher than in the rest of Poland, and the infant mortality rate is more than three times the national average. A 1985 report by the Polish Academy of Sciences noted an ''appalling increase'' in the number of retarded school-age children in Upper Silesia. **********And Poland faces a catastrophic water shortage. Only 1 percent of the country's water is clean enough to drink, and almost half the water is so polluted that it is unfit for any use. Temporary water shortages now reportedly affect l20 cities and l0,000 smaller towns. The Academy of Science report warned that if present trends continued, ''in five years there will be no more water.'' Why is pollution so terrible in Eastern Europe? One reason is that, since 1980, when the Soviet Union sharply reduced oil deliveries, East Germany, Poland and Czechloslovakia have increasingly turned to brown coal. It takes five tons of soft brown coal to produce the energy of one ton of black coal, and brown coal has a very high sulfur content. And East European plants often use antiquated machinery with no filters. Thus, the air is increasingly cloudy and poisoned. BUT THE problems are deeper than that. In East Europe, the governments are both protector and polluter - and this conflict of interest is almost always resolved by maximizing production at the expense of the environment. Some governments have tried until recently to deny that any environmental problem exists. East Germany blames its dying forests on storms and heavy snow. One Czech Communist Party ideologist attributed environmental problems to ''non-Socialist individuals still surviving in the country.'' **********In most countries, environmental policy consists largely of praying for strong winds. In Czechoslovakia, factories are often exempted from pollution regulations when their output is declared to be ''in the interests of the entire community.'' In Hungary, more than half the factories hit with pollution fines have done nothing to reduce their pollution. Pollution controls in Polish factories are frequently turned off to save energy. **********Pollution can be reduced substantially only with expensive Western pollution control equipment. But Eastern European nations cannot come up with a few score billion dollars to overhaul factories, clean up rivers and install catalytic converters. **********Thus, Socialist poverty will likely be destiny - and doom - for East Europe's environment. East Europe is a land of declining productivity, increasingly antiquated machinery and collapsing infrastructure. The only East European country not suffering falling living standards is East Germany, and most of its ''prosperity'' comes from its handouts from West Germany, and from extracting $15,000 from the the West German Government for each citizen that is allowed to emigrate. **********As the world economy becomes more integrated and the pace of technological change quickens, East Europe is becoming an economic ghetto. The only advantage in international trade that Eastern Europe had in recent decades was skilled labor and low wage rates. But now that the newly industrialized countries are rapidly raising their technological levels, Eastern Europe has lost its final advantage. **********In all of these countries, pollution is getting worse and will continue worsening for at least the next several years because of the increasing reliance on brown coal. Severe environmental problems helped create the Solidarity movement and continue to fuel the opposition in Poland. In Czechoslovakia, Hungary and East Germany, dissident organizations are spreading the news of health threats and urging governments to reform. Governments have arrested environmentalists but it is a little difficult to hide tens of millions of dying trees. **********Eastern European governments face a Catch-22 situation. They must soon either make expensive pollution control investments or face a public health catastrophe and possible revolts. To afford the necessary investments, however, the governments will have to cut living standards sharply - another potential provocation. **********Pollution could be the final nail in the coffin of East European Socialism. Unfortunately for Eastern Europe, there is no export market for brown snow and dying trees.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/04/busin.main_headline: Dollar Closes Mixed; Precious Metals Drop
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/04/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS; Dollar Closes Mixed; Precious Metals Drop
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/04/busin.body_text: **********The dollar turned in a mixed performance yesterday, firming against the Japanese yen but setting new three-month lows against the West German mark in active trading dominated by rumors. **********Meanwhile, precious metals prices fell in a round of profit taking following the previous day's strong advance. Gold futures closed lower on the Commodity Exchange in New York, with the December contract down $1.70, to $471.70 an ounce. The December silver contract dropped 9 cents, to $7.94 an ounce. **********The dollar began the day stronger in Tokyo, helped by corporate orders and reports of an attack on a Japanese tanker in the Persian Gulf. **********''That is the first time we have seen corporate buying in Japan in quite a while,'' said Paul O'Gara, chief foreign exchange dealer for Midland Bank in New York. Rumors of Secret Talks **********However, as trading shifted to Europe, and later to New York, dealers pushed the dollar lower on rumors that finance ministers from the five leading industrial nations - the United States, Japan, Britain, West Germany and France - were planning to hold a secret meeting over the weekend to negotiate a lower trading range for the dollar. **********An official from the West German Finance Ministry denied the rumors that the nations, known as the Group of Five, would meet, and the Treasury Department refused to comment. But traders apparently thought the reports were credible enough to warrant pushing the dollar down to its lows for the day. **********A round of profit taking in other currencies brought the dollar up later in the afternoon, and New York dealers said activity fell off sharply after 2 P.M. **********By late in the day, the dollar was bid at 141 yen, below its high of 141.66 for the day, but slightly above Wednesday's close of 140.85. That was the highest level for the yen seen in New York since late May. **********The dollar failed to hold its own against the mark, as it slipped to another three-month low. In late trading, the dollar was quoted at a bid of 1.7920 marks, down slightly from Wednesday's New York close of 1.7973. Shortly after the Group of Five rumors hit the market, the dollar was bid as low as 1.7880 marks. Lack of Guidance Seen **********''Sentiment seems to be growing in the market that the G-5 feels that since there has been no improvement in the U.S. trade statistics since the Louvre meeting last February, the dollar should be lower,'' said John Prout, senior vice president and head of the foreign currency options department at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. **********Traders remain uniformly bearish about the dollar, not only because of America's continuing trade problems, but also because of a lack of guidance from top officials in Washington about the currency's appropriate level.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/01/busin.body_text: **********ONCE upon a time, there were mostly stocks, bonds and bank accounts, and it was a much simpler age. **********Welcome to the 1980's. In these go-go years, the geniuses of high finance have been busy inventing a new world in which billions of dollars ride on stock maneuvers that few people really understand. Financial futures are swapped for stocks and back again in space-age strategies that sometimes send the markets reeling. Big investors play one market against another, believing - until the market brutally teaches them otherwise - that it is possible to buy one's way out of risk. **********While the system was working, hardly anybody paid attention. But, suddenly, as the market avalanches on the last two Mondays have shown, it isn't working. Now, the experts are beginning to ask whether all that cleverness may have helped push the country to the brink of economic disaster. Did the markets, in effect, try to commit suicide? **********That question is kicking off a debate that is one of the most fundamental that can take place in a capitalist system. What is the role of markets? How much of their function is to raise money for businesses? How much is to satisfy the urge to gamble? How much should government regulate a free market? **********Conditions were ripe for an end to the aging bull market, most everyone agrees. But the speed and depth of the recent dives sent a everyone agrees. But the speed and depth of the recent dives sent a chill through the country. And they put a spotlight on the relatively new futures and options markets. Demands are building for regulations tear the system apart. ''There is an element of underlying risk that was never perceived,'' said Salomon Brothers' chief economist, Henry Kaufman late last week. **********Critics charge that the market's collapse was amplified by the unusual ways in which the futures markets sometimes interact with the stock markets. The futures market was designed partly to shift the risks of price drops away from the equities markets. But when the markets turn sour, the huge institutional traders who dominate both markets play them both - with the aid of computers that can preside over the destruction of billions of dollars faster than people can figure out how to stop them. Rather than limiting risk, critics say, those computer strategies actually contribute to the market decline. **********Through history, futures and options have been spurned because they were often viewed as mere speculation. Thomas A. Russo, a securities lawyer who wrote one of the leading texts on commodities law, says options on commodities have been so controversial that they have been banned entirely in this country at least seven times since the early 19th century. **********But in this era of deregulation, they have come into their own. The first financial futures contract on securities, Mr. Russo said, was offered in 1975. Since 1982, one particularly novel instrument, a futures contract that mimics the price of Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, is the most widely used of the new ''shadow stocks. It is a high flier: The amount of money riding on stock futures contracts now dwarfs the amount in the New York Stock Exchange. **********Options are the right to buy or sell stock for a certain price on a certain date. Futures contracts represent the obligation to buy or sell stocks on a certain date. Like stock purchases themselves, both are bets on the future. But they are cheaper because fees are lower. That is because they do not require the complex documentation of real stock purchases and they can be bought with much lower ''margin'' deposits. Although, in theory, futures represent the right to have actual stock delivered on the final date of the contract, this seldom happens and most contracts are settled in cash. Rather than being a destructive force, as some critics charge, futures and options were supposed to be the magic potions of the new financial world. Used properly in conjunction with purchases and sales of stocks, their salesmen said, futures and options could prevent portfolio losses, making them the perfect hedge. The promise of lower risk helped draw money into the stock market. **********So grand was the feeling of invulnerability that someone named this new strategy portfolio ''insurance,'' a label that seems sure to win an ironic footnote in accounts of the billions of dollars quite uninsurably lost in the collapse of '87. **********WHILE the fever of the bull market built, however, the new hedges won plenty of followers and the futures' zealots were not shy about pointing out an apparent correlation: As trading in futures contracts surged, so did the number of shares traded on the stock exchanges. That, they said, was proof that the new instruments were performing the useful function of encouraging investment. The more money hedged in the stock market, the argument went, the more money would come into the market and the country would be richer. It was not an argument anyone felt much like puncturing while the Dow Jones industrial average was climbing skyward. **********Many of the future-markets critics acknowledge that the ability to hedge helped spur the bull market. But they charge that the futures markets whipped what might have been a gentle downdraft into a frenzy of selling, adding to the 508-point loss on Black Monday and the second big loss a week later. **********The ''portfolio insurance'' strategies essentially involve alternate bets in the markets. Most of the portfolio insurance programs are run with the aid of complex computer programs - so-called program trading - that can automatically initiate trades in multimillion dollar lots. In the equity markets big investors bet heavily that their stock will move up. In the futures market, for a small premium, they hedge against the chance that those same stocks will move down. If the markets move up, they take the gain from the increase in value of their stock minus the small cost of buying futures to cover themselves against loss. **********When the stock market begins to fall, however, the situation gets more complicated. As the value of stocks falls below the value of the matching futures index, program traders and portfolio insurers begin selling stocks and buying futures. This action, in turn, depresses stock prices further, and a vicious cycle begins that sends both markets into a downward spiral. **********IN an interview last week with New York Times reporters, the New York Stock Exchange's chairman, John J. Phelan Jr., said there was a flaw in the way the financial futures market fed on falling equities prices. Portfolio insurance, for example, was designed so that stockholders could shed some of the risk of owning shares, he said. ''But there's a chink in the system, so that instead of protecting itself against a crisis, it had created more risk in the system,'' he said. ''Some way has to be found so that once risk is transferred out, it won't come flying back into the system.'' **********It is not universally agreed that the financial futures markets contributed to the market's collapse. The day after Mr. Phelan's interview, Leo Melamed, chairman of the executive committee of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the nation's largest futures exchange, said efforts to pin the blame on futures trading for the stock-market collapse amounted to a witch hunt. **********Some critics worry that, without new regulation, the cannibalization of the main market by the futures markets may injure the economy permanently. The country's ability to raise capital could be in jeopardy if people fear investing in stocks, critics say. Some investors may stay out of the market, fearing the increased volatility that many attribute to the futures markets, said Roberta S. Karmel, a former Securities and Exchange Commission member and a member of the board of the New York Stock Exchange. ''The questions is: Are these products having the effect of destablizing the equities markets?'' she asked. **********Some who are concerned about the effect of the futures markets on the economy suggest such adjustments as limiting the amount of futures any one player can control. Some contend that reforms must be more extreme. Markets have always provided havens for the sometimes incompatible goals of investment and gambling, said the economist Robert L. Heilbroner. **********He worries, however, that the severity of the market's fall appeared so unrelated to corporate health that it represents the sudden deflation of a vast speculative bubble. The bubble, in turn, he fears, may have been inflated by futures markets - markets more divorced from productive enterprises than the stock market. **********The recent fall of the Japanese stock market, he said, can be explained with traditional measures of corporate performance. Since the action in the American markets cannot be explained the same way, Mr. Heilbronmer said, ''I can't think of another reason except that the gambling function overloaded the markets.'' **********President Reagan appointed Nicholas F. Brady, head of Dillon, Read & Company and a former United States Senator from New Jersey, to study the market collapse. His commission is expected to look into whether the futures markets increase volatility in the stock markets. The New York Stock Exchange is expecting a report in two weeks on the same subject from former Attorney General Nicholas Katzenbach, requested by the exchange several months ago. Other official investigations are also underway. **********The Commodities Futures Trading Commission, which regulates futures contracts, says it is studying the market's huge drop. But one of its commissioner, Robert R. Davis, said previous studies had indicated futures markets could affect how quickly equities markets move, but not how far. ''We have a problem of unsubstantiated allegations,'' Mr. Davis said. **********The fact that the Commodities Futures Trading Commission is responsible for financial futures is one issue certain to get a lot of study. The agency is small and, some critics say, unsophisticated, compared to the S.E.C., which regulates stocks. But a major issue likely to emerge is not who regulates financial futures, but how they are regulated. One key difference between treating financial futures as securities rather than commodities is the amount of money a player must ante up. Options, less popular among institutional money managers, are regulated as securities. **********Since the Depression, Federal law has set a 50 percent ''margin'' requirement for stocks. That means an investor may borrow no more than half the purchase price. In the world of grain and hog-bellies where commodities rules were born, margins were intended merely as a good-faith deposit that signaled to the seller that he was dealing with a person of honor. Those margins were much smaller. **********When financial futures came along, those same rules were applied and the result - until two weeks ago, when the financial futures exchanges temporarily raised their margin requirements during the financial panic - was that people could control millions of dollars of ''shadow stock'' with relatively small investments. Many critics believe there should be a margin requirement for futures equivalent to the one applied to the securities that set futures' prices. **********Those low margin requirements, critics say, multiply vastly whatever negative effects might come from the existence of a shadow market. Until the market collapsed on Oct. 19, investors could control portfolios worth tens of millions of dollars with an actual investment of as little as 7 percent of that amount. **********''The country learned a lesson about margins after 1929 and unfortunately, it's a characteristic of human beings that the farther they get from the past, the more they forget,'' said James M. Stone, who was chairman of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission under President Carter. ''These financial instruments opened the back door to 5 percent margins, 50 years after the front door had been closed.'' **********The debate about the role of futures is not new. Mr. Stone, a member of the commission for the first few years of the Reagan Administration, said the futures market had accelerated the recent market collapse. In 1982, he voted against allowing their sale. ''These are very dangerous instruments and their benefits are not commensurate with their dangers,'' he said. **********Some business experts say they think the recent episode has demonstrated that there may be a need to increase margin requirements or limit the amount of financial futures that any one trader can control. **********Some experts argue, however, that the investment world will never again be a simple place. Walter B. Wriston, the former Citicorp chairman, said that the stock market's increasingly rapid movement had more to do with the rapid flow of information and the increasing globalization of markets than with other financial developments. In any event, he said, it be unrealistic to think that those markets were going to disappear. Even if they were outlawed in this country, he said, they would move abroad and draw investments with them. **********The new markets were born, he said, because computer systems can calculate the value of vast portfolios and communicate information in a flash. ''That system,'' Mr. Wriston said, ''wasn't built by economists. It was built by technology and it isn't going to go away.'' As long as there are financial geniuses around, they will find a way to test the limits of that technology.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/02/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Gold Tiptoeing Back Onstage
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/02/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Gold Tiptoeing Back Onstage
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/02/busin.body_text: **********THIS week Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d proposed to lay another brick in the foundation of a new world monetary system - a gold brick. The United States, he told the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, is ready to consider using, as an ''additional indicator'' for guiding the coordination of national economic policies, ''a basket of commodities, including gold.'' **********Although his proposal caught most of the delegates by surprise, a few American economists and a few foreign officials, including the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, and the West German Finance Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, knew it was coming. The one thing unsure the night before Mr. Baker's address was whether he would actually mention gold in the basket. **********Indeed, Mr. Lawson, speaking ahead of Mr. Baker on Wednesday, proposed that, as a policy indicator, ''special attention'' be given to ''the trend of world commodity prices'' - but without naming gold. Nor was there any reason to think that the Briton was concealing his interest in a return to the gold standard, which would require a country losing gold to tighten its monetary policy to defend the value of its currency, even at the cost of recession. **********On the contrary, Mr. Lawson said that ''we have put a lot of effort into developing performance indicators for individual countries'' and that he had ''considerable doubts whether we can usefully take that exercise much further.'' It would be far better, he thought, to monitor ''the group as a whole.'' **********But Mr. Baker's reference to gold as an indicator, along with economic growth rates, external imbalances and exchange rates, thrilled the champions of gold, such as Representative Jack Kemp of upstate New York. He hailed it as ''a victory for those of us who have been working to restore a sound dollar and low long-term interest rates.'' **********Was Mr. Baker's mention of gold simply throwing a political bone to the conservatives - or did it have genuine economic and financial significance? **********The markets reacted as though it did: The dollar rose briskly after his speech. And the price of gold fell, implying that traders thought a reinforced commitment to an anti-inflationary policy would make gold a less attractive speculation. **********Gold advocates, such as Robert A. Mundell of Columbia University, believe that gold should stabilize within a range of $500 to $600 an ounce. Gold, now near the middle of that range, offers investors little prospect of capital gains - and no yield. **********Professor Mundell believes that stabilizing the dollar against gold would also increase the flow of capital, especially Japanese capital, into this country's stock market as anxieties about further dollar depreciation recede. In a conversation on the eve of Mr. Baker's talk, he predicted that it would lift the Dow Jones industrial average to 3,000, with American equities looking better than ever, particularly in relation to Japanese equities. He forecast that stabilizing the dollar against gold would bring Japan's overvalued stock market crashing down. **********Further, he said, belief in a stable dollar would bring more capital into the American bond market, lifting prices and pushing down long-term interest rates. The premium required to lure capital because fears of dollar depreciation and inflation result in very high real rates would no longer need to be paid. Lower interest would spur growth in this nation and ease the third world's debt burden. **********However, this heavy inflow of capital, as Mr. Mundell sees it, would perpetuate the American trade deficit, which he considers the inevitable result - and the mirror image - of the heavy volume of capital that the Japanese and other foreigners want to invest in the United States. **********But many American economists stress that this game cannot continue indefinitely as the United States becomes engulfed with foreign debt. **********However, unlike the majority of American economists who consider the dollar still overvalued, as indicated by the persistent trade gap, Mr. Mundell considers the dollar undervalued in terms of what American assets are really worth and roughly right in relation to the current gold price. **********It is such thinking that now appears to be playing a role in the Reagan Administration's changed exchange-rate policy and its cautious flirtation with gold. It also looks like a new element in Federal Reserve monetary policy under Alan Greenspan, a longtime conservative and cautious friend of gold. **********All of this may shock many American economists, disciples of John Maynard Keynes who, in a 1930 essay, said, ''Gold has become part of the apparatus of conservatism.'' He warned that ''the friends of gold will have to be extremely wise and moderate if they are to avoid a revolution.'' **********The revolution did occur, but now gold is tiptoeing back - floating exchange rates having caused more instability than the world can stand. Yet the movement toward gold looks hesitant and uncertain. Mr. Mundell would call it only a step in that direction. More important now is the move toward stable exchange rates and the defense of the dollar.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/24/world.main_headline: GENERAL SEES MISSILE PLANS AS A MISTAKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/24/world.print_headline: GENERAL SEES MISSILE PLANS AS A MISTAKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/24/world.body_text: **********The NATO alliance's departing military commander said today that he now accepted as ''inevitable'' a projected arms control agreement removing Soviet and United States medium-range and short-range nuclear missiles from Europe. **********But in an interview at his headquarters here, the commander, Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, made it clear that he considered the emerging agreement a mistake. **********He said he had always opposed such an accord and asserted that his concerns were shared by all his subordinate military commanders in the 16-nation Western alliance. **********Warning that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization could resist a Soviet attack only for ''days, not weeks,'' without nuclear arms, General Rogers not only criticized the Reagan Administration's willingness to remove United States and Soviet nuclear missiles from Europe but also set out three conditions for maintaining the credibility of Western defenses. **********Although General Rogers, who is 65 years old, is leaving military life, many officials say his views could have an influence on the fate of any new medium-range arms control treaty when it comes up before the Senate for ratification. Pressure on Europeans **********General Rogers, whose views command considerable respect in Western Europe, implicitly criticized the Reagan Administration for seeming to rush European governments into accepting an arms control plan that some have doubts about. **********''I think the pressure was there,'' he said, adding that some members of the Administration wanted an American-Soviet summit meeting this fall and ratification of the arms pact ''before the President leaves office.'' **********Many European leaders, General Rogers went on, consider the agreement ''foolish.'' But he said they were ''hoist on their own petard,'' since, as a condition of deploying United States missiles in the first place, they had agreed to remove them if the Soviet Union offered to withdraw its equivalent missiles. **********''Which is more important, political credibility or the credibility of deterrence?'' General Rogers asked. **********General Rogers, who will hand over his command to Gen. John R. Galvin on Friday, cited three steps he believes NATO must now take to keep ''the credibility of our deterrence as high as possible'' after the medium-range missiles disappear. **********First, he said NATO must resist ''sliding any further down the slope of denuclearization.'' He called for a halt in new nuclear disarmament negotiations with the Soviet Union while ''we look at the long-term implications for Western Europe.'' **********''Let's not sacrifice the long-term security of Western Europe on the altar of political expediency,'' he said. Concern Over German Missiles **********In particular, General Rogers insisted that NATO resist Soviet pressure to include West Germany's 72 aging Pershing 1A missiles in the proposed ban and press ahead with plans for modernizing them. **********He also urged NATO members to resist expected Soviet pressure to cut back on very short-range tactical nuclear weapons in Europe and start eliminating aircraft capable of carrying atomic bombs. **********''I'm convinced the Soviet Union is going for the denuclearization of Europe,'' he said, adding that this would leave Western Europe vulnerable to
