''intimidation and blackmail'' from the Warsaw Pact's superior conventional forces. **********Second, General Rogers said NATO must ''follow through'' on its 1983 decision to reduce, but also improve, its stock of such tactical or battlefield nuclear weapons. **********General Rogers said the alliance had already cut the number of these warheads below the ceiling of 4,600 that it set itself to reach by 1988. **********But he pointed out that the Nuclear Planning Group also agreed in 1983 to develop a new longer-range version of the Lance missile and a new nuclear missile that aircraft can fire at ground targets 200 miles away. **********Finally, General Rogers called on the Atlantic alliance to hasten development and deployment of high-precision rockets with conventional explosive warheads capable of striking at enemy reinforcements moving up well behind the front line. **********If all this is done and NATO allies press ahead with current plans to strengthen other aspects of their conventional forces, General Rogers said, then the alliance's present dependence on nuclear deterrents will be reduced. **********General Rogers asserted that he is not bitter about the NATO governments' decision to press ahead with the zero-option disarmament plan against his advice. **********But he insisted that the proposal to trade United States Pershing 2 and cruise missiles against Soviet SS-20's and to ban shorter-range systems as well is fundamentally flawed because the military need for the United States missiles will still be there after their Soviet counterparts are gone. **********General Rogers described the Pershing 2 as the European missile the Russians ''fear most'' because it can strike military targets in Soviet territory as well as in Eastern Europe, with pinpoint accuracy in just 13 minutes. **********General Rogers contended that a zero option agreement appears to run counter to the new political guidelines NATO countries approved last year for the use of nuclear weapons. **********These guidelines, he said, require the alliance commander to be able ''to strike with certainty'' at enemy targets and possess ''an escalating series of options'' in response to any threats. ''We are losing options,'' General Rogers said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/29/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Bond Prices Decrease Modestly
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/29/busin.body_text: **********Note and bond prices declined modestly in light trading yesterday, with little participation by institutional investors or speculators outside the major securities firms. **********Although prices of some long-term Treasury issues fell three-quarters of a point, analysts warned that the price changes were not indicative of any trend among institutional investors but rather were the result of short-term trading strategies. **********By late in the day, the closely watched 8 7/8 percent Treasury bonds due in 2017 were offered at 98 26/32, down 23/32, to yield about 8.99 percent. Drop Followed Dollar's Fall **********The drop in bond prices followed the dollar's decline on foreign exchange markets to new lows of about 123.3 yen and 1.58 marks. Although declines in the dollar are still worrisome to the bond markets - because they suggest more inflation, stemming from higher prices for imports and more leeway for American producers to raise their prices - analysts noted that those fears have not prompted significant investor selling of bonds. **********''The dollar helped bring on lower bond prices, but I think the statement from the White House and the widespread intervention are reasons to believe that the dollar is beginning to reach its bottom,'' said John L. Hickey, executive vice president at Swiss Bank Corporation International Securities. Accepting the idea that the dollar may not decline much further ''gives good value to the bond market at this time,'' he added. **********The White House issued a statement yesterday saying that further declines in the dollar were not desirable. At the same time, central banks in the United States, Japan, West Germany and other countries opposed the dollar's decline by intervening in foreign exchange markets to buy dollars or sell their own currencies, currency traders said. Interest Rate Rise Not Seen **********Analysts noted that the latest declines in the dollar had not revived old fears that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates to help make the American currency more attractive. Concerns about higher short-term interest rates were allayed by a statement last week by Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, that an increase in American interest rates was not part of an agreement by leading industrialized countries to promote stable exchange rates. **********Economists also doubted that the Fed would be willing to raise short-term rates at a time when the momentum of economic growth seems to be waning as consumer spending slackens. **********One additional sign that consumers are more circumspect about spending was evident in the National Association of Realtors' report yesterday that prices and resales of existing homes fell during November. Sales fell 4.5 percent during the month, to an annual rate of 3.41 million units, 11.4 percent lower than a year ago. The median sales price slipped $600, to $84,200, but was still $3,800 above the price a year ago. **********John Tuccillo, chief economist at the National Association of Realtors, said the drop in the median sales price ''was caused by a change in consumer behavior with more emphasis on the lower end of the market.'' He said the lower sales prices did not imply that homeowners were suffering a loss of wealth because of declining values of their homes. ''We estimate that home prices rose about 6 1/2 percent this year, or a bit more than inflation,'' he said. Bill Rates Drop **********In the Treasury bill market, interest rates declined at the regular weekly auction. The average rate for three-month bills fell to 5.73 percent, from 5.96 percent, while the new six-month rate dropped to 6.32 percent, from 6.48 percent. **********Traders said the lower rates were a result of greater-than-normal demand because the maturity of the new issues coincides with the end of the first and second quarters in 1988. Others said yesterday's steep drop in the stock market might have encouraged securities dealers to bid more for the new bills in anticipation of stronger demand from investors who might pull money out of the stock market. **********Elsewhere in the short-term market, commercial bankers in charge of liability management and securities dealers in charge of financing their inventories are hoping there will be no surge in borrowing costs over the New Year's weekend comparable to last year's, when rates rose above 30 percent in some cases. By borrowing in advance to cover their end-of-year needs - even if it means paying a slightly higher interest rate - they hope to avoid a similar crunch this year. Securities dealers yesterday paid about 6.5 percent for overnight financing of their Treasury securities, compared with about 7.4 percent for one-week financing. **********The combination of advance planning and the Federal Reserve's willingness to supply ample funds to the banking system caused analysts at Griggs & Santow, an economic advisory firm, to conclude that ''the chances of anything resembling the late-in-the year tightness of 1986 are slim.'' **********In the tax-exempt market, the year-end turmoil caused securities dealers temporarily to offer an abnormally high 8 percent yield for a few issues of variable rate demand bonds. ''At the end of the year, there are relatively few buyers, so dealers end up setting an interest rate that reflects their cost of financing,'' one New York banker noted. ''By this time next week, the rates will be back down to 5 percent or 5 1/2 percent.'' **********Following are results of yesterday's auctions of three- and six-month Treasury bills:  (000 omitted in dollar figures)             3-Mo. Bills   6-Mo. Bills        Average Price   98.552   96.805        Discounted Rate   5.73%   6.32%        Coupon Yield   5.91%   6.64%        High Price   98.567   96.820        Discounted Rate   5.67%   6.29%        Coupon Yield   5.85%   6.60%        Low Price   98.549   96.800        Discounted Rate   5.74%   6.33%        Coupon Yield   5.92%   6.65%        Accepted at low price   54%   54%        Total applied for   $23,158,365   $20,095,310        Accepted   $6,403,270   $6,401,310        N.Y. applied for   $20,881,005   $17,702,650        N.Y. accepted   $5,730,910   $5,761,150        Noncompetitive   $798,015   $657,570       Both these issues are dated Dec. 31, 1987. The three-month bills mature March 31, 1988 and the six-month bills, June 30, 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/23/busin.main_headline: A Speedy Way to Encode Material
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/23/busin.print_headline: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER; A Speedy Way to Encode Material
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/23/busin.body_text: **********MOST people even vaguely familiar with computers are aware of two varieties of disks, hard and floppy, on which programs and data are stored. But the lesser-known cartridge disk has lately been gaining popularity with computer users. **********The cartridge is a hybrid that combines the floppy's ease of switching and the storage capacity of hard disks. **********The most widely used cartridge-disk system is probably the Bernoulli Box, whose patented technology employs ''superfloppies,'' each capable of storing 20 megabytes, encased in a hard covering. Like a hard disk, the Bernoulli and other cartridge systems can be installed as either an internal or external drive. The recent substitution of a Bernoulli drive for a hard disk in Leading Edge's Infinite Memory System should increase the prominence of this medium. **********Unlike the Bernoulli Box, however, most cartridge drives contain a hard disk in their removable cartridges. Their backers contend that hard disks have a longer life, because they are less prone to wear than the softer, flexible floppy. Personally, I've experienced no wear problems with Bernoulli cartridges, and I know of at least one insurance company that has been using them for two years without any difficulties. **********Putting a hard disk in a cartridge introduces two areas of potential difficulty: The disks may be too sensitive to shock damage to be altogether practical and the cartridge - which is not hermetically sealed, as the traditional hard disk is - may be too easily affected by smoke and dust particles. **********Lately, however, I've been using just such a cartridge drive, and again I can report that I've had no problems. Given that I usually manage to bring considerable difficulties upon myself whenever I deal with a new product, this failure to encounter any obstacles speaks rather highly for both versions of cartridge technology, hard and soft. **********The cartridge hard-disk unit I have been using is the Diskit 2 Plus ($3,595 from Ideassociates Inc., Billerica, Mass. 01821, tel. 800 257-5027). The only part I'm unhappy with is its price. It's hard to justify spending as much, if not more, for an external hard-disk cartridge system than you would for a computer itself. I also find it difficult to justify spending $1,000 more than what I'd pay for a dual-drive Bernoulli Box, each of whose cartridges has a 20-megabyte capacity, compared with the Diskit 2's 10 megabytes. **********Yet there is one application that can justify the additional expense. That's when you must deal with sensitive data best stored in encrypted form. **********Diskit 2 Plus offers the standard advantages of the removable cartridge medium: limitless data storage away from the computer, the flexibility of being able to have separate hard disks for separate applications or functions and fast backup. But its real edge lies in the rapid encryption system that it offers. Instead of the computer encrypting the material in a batch after you have completed a file entry, Diskit 2 Plus encodes the material as you work. Because the process is hardware-based rather than a function of the software, the encryption is much faster. **********THE manual provided with the cartridge provides very little background on the actual encryption method that Diskit 2 Plus employs. You are limited to a key ''word'' no longer than eight characters, whether they be letters, numbers or keyboard symbols, and each character in the key word must be typed twice. **********Only X's appear on the screen as you enter the key word. Such hidden verification makes unauthorized entry, or access to the systems data, marginally more difficult, at least for amateurs. For pros, I'm not sure how troublesome it would be to break the encryption. Then again, since its primary function is to secure such information as financial data or sales figures, would-be scrutinizers are not likely to be professional cryptographers. **********The bad side of this security system is that if you happen to forget the code you chose, you can forget the data, too. The manual stresses, ''There is no method of recovery if you forget the key used.'' **********But should you want to change the key word, that is easily done. First you copy the contents of an encrypted cartridge to a cartridge in an unencrypted drive and then recopy the information to the cartridge in a newly encrypted drive with a fresh key word. It sounds a bit clumsy, and it is time-consuming. But that is the price one must pay for the speed that hardware encryption offers. **********The Diskit 2 Plus hardware includes a drive unit the size of a small telephone book that fits unobtrusively between the monitor and the console. There is also a controller board that must be installed inside the computer, and on that board is a jumper to be set to either the encryption or the non-encryption mode. **********None of the installation maneuvers are any more difficult than those for other boards, although setting the jumper might be intimidating to some, since it requires actually fiddling with the board itself. A simple, sturdy toggle switch at the end of the board, accessible from the back of the computer, would have been a preferable design. **********THE software for Diskit 2 Plus, which comes on a standard floppy disk, installs automatically and includes a diagnostic program. My biggest problem lay in the seemingly innocuous insertion and removal of the cartridge for the first time. The drive doors of Diskit 2 Plus are very stiff, and you must wield more force with them than you are likely to be accustomed to using when dealing with a computer. The extra force is required because of the tight seal around the cartridge, which is designed to minimize contamination. **********Similarly, when you open the drive door, the cartridge seems unwilling to be ejected. Here too you must use more force than you expect to use in computing, pushing the door down beyond where it first stops. **********I asked several people to try to remove the cartridge, and all of them failed. They were afraid of breaking the drive as they wrestled with it. But in the process of getting over such misgivings, you learn how rugged the drive actually is. **********The cartridges are surprisingly sturdy, considering that they contain a sensitive hard disk. I dropped one a number of times from table height, and it continued to function without faltering. **********About all you could wish for is that Ideassociates would do with the price what I did with the cartridges.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/03/busin.body_text: **********American lawyers for the Toshiba Corporation met with Pentagon officals today to discuss steps the company will take to improve its export control procedures. **********Administration officials said the Pentagon had assigned an expert on export controls to work with the lawyers in drafting a compliance program for Toshiba. **********The meetings come amid a clamor from Congress for retaliation against the Japanese company and Kongsberg Vaapenfabrikk, a Norwegian state-owned concern. A Toshiba subsidiary and Kongsberg sold technology to the Soviet Union that helps its submarines run quieter, evading detection. **********Toshiba's two top executives resigned Wednesday following Senate action Tuesday that would ban American imports of Toshiba and Kongsberg products for two to five years. The Senator who introduced the measure acknowledged that it might prove to be unconstitutional. **********Retaliatory legislation has also been proposed in the House. And a House appropriations panel today directed the Pentagon to withhold a $100,000 contract for lap computers from Toshiba until the import-ban issue is resolved. **********Toshiba is represented by the Manhattan law firm of Mudge, Rose, Guthrie & Alexander. The firm has hired Leonard Garment, the Washington attorney and one of its former partners, as special counsel. **********Mr. Garment said Administration officials he spoke with seemed to approve of what Toshiba had said about its intentions and to approve of the resignations. Toshiba has maintained that it was unaware of its subsidiary's sales to the Russians. **********''Just to be sure there is no confusion about the resignations, there is no claim by the United States of complicity by the parent company,'' Mr. Garment said. ''The resignations were a matter of a cultural tradition that considers senior executives of the parent company responsible for what occurs on their watch.'' **********Administration officials, declining to be identified, said only that the Japanese Government's investigation of the sales was still in progress and that the departing executives would be Toshiba consultants. **********''A senior Japanese trade official called us this morning to discuss the Senate vote and wanted to know what to do,'' one Administration official said. ''We tried to explain that this was a political problem and that it was going to take more than those resignations to mollify Congress.'' **********The Administration has asked the Japanese Government to toughen its export controls to reduce leaks of high technology to the Eastern bloc. **********The Administration, according to Commerce Department officials, is hoping that if Congress insists on an import ban the wording might be changed in conference to give the President the ultimate decision on whether to impose sanctions. **********''The Administration doesn't want any legislation,'' Malcolm Baldrige, the Secretary of Commerce, told a business group after a speech on Wednesday. ''But the measure adopted by the Senate was the least worst among the various Congressional proposals.'' **********The main sponsor of the import ban, Senator Jake Garn, noted when he offered it that there could be a question about its constitutionality because such a ban would be retroactive - imposing punishment for an action that occurred before the legislation was adopted. The Utah Republican said he separated his bill into sections so that if the Toshiba-Kornsberg part were declared unconstitutional, the part covering future violations would remain in force. **********Richard B. Rivers, a former general counsel for the United States trade representative and now head of international practice at the law firm of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, said he had been studying constitutional implications of a ban. **********''It clearly raises some constitutional issues,'' he said. For example, he noted, an American importer of Toshiba products might assert that its property had been taken in violation of the Fifth Amendment. **********Another possibility, Mr. Rivers said, is an argument that the ban would violate the constitutional protection against bills of attainder. These are legislative actions that pronounce a designated person guilty of some crime without a trial.  ----  TOKYO ACCEPTS MOVE **********TOKYO, July 2 (AP) - The Japanese Government said today that it would not interfere with an American ban on Toshiba Corporation products. It also promised a closer watch on exports to Communist countries. **********Yukio Okamoto, director of the Foreign Ministry's national security affairs division, said the Government felt that ''we should never allow these things to happen again.'' He said it would not ''protect Toshiba from American Congressional action.'' **********Atsushi Iwaai, director of the export control office in the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, said more export license inspectors would be added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/world.main_headline: Vietnam More Optimistic About U.S. Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/world.print_headline: Vietnam More Optimistic About U.S. Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/world.body_text: **********United States and Vietnamese negotiators looking for ways to resolve the issue of 1,776 Americans still listed as missing in this country met briefly twice today. **********Vietnamese officials were more optimistic after the talks this morning than they were on Saturday at the outset. **********At a break between the sessions today, Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach told reporters the two sides had reached ''a better understanding'' on the issues. **********Diplomats here say the talks will indicate how a new Vietnamese leadership under Nguyen Van Linh, the Communist Party general secretary, will be able to deal with Washington. **********Mr. Thach, now also a Deputy Prime Minister, is thought to be one of the more influential members of the new administration. **********The American delegation, led by John W. Vessey Jr., a retired Army general and former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, declined to comment on any aspect of the talks, except to say there was more work to do. **********This morning, when asked if a planned news conference would still be held on Monday, General Vessey, who is President Reagan's special envoy, brushed aside the question. **********''I don't know if you can expect one,'' he said brusquely. He also canceled plans for sightseeing in Hanoi today. **********A previously unscheduled meeting of technical advisers was called for this afternoon. Technical meetings have in the past usually planned crash-site excavations or the returns of war dead. **********There has been no decision about whether the higher-level talks will continue on Monday, when the American team is due to leave Hanoi. **********''The talk will resume when we are ready to resume,'' General Vessey said. **********Remains of American war dead were last returned to the United States last fall. A resolution of the issue was interrupted, in part, by preparations for the change in Vietnam's leadership. **********Many American officials, including most, if not all, on the team now in Hanoi, believe that Vietnam is holding several of the American war dead to be doled out as talks move toward what the Vietnamese hope will be eventual diplomatic recognition. **********Few United States officials - and no Hanoi-based European diplomats -believe that any Americans are being held captive in Vietnam. But the Reagan Administration is under pressure from those who claim to have knowledge of such captives and say the Government is doing nothing to free them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/14/busin.main_headline: When the Doorbell Is a Fan Blowing
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/14/busin.print_headline: WHATS NEW IN THE HEARING BUSINESS; When the Doorbell Is a Fan Blowing
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/14/busin.body_text: **********JERALD JORDAN cannot hear regular alarm clocks. In college, his roommate created a gadget that sent a weight reeling onto his metal bedpost when the alarm sounded. The bang startled him out of bed and into class. **********Today's devices are not quite so primitive. **********Early in the morning, before the sun has risen, Mr. Jordan's Signalman - a transmitter attached to his clock and a nearby lamp -causes the light to blink in the still-darkened room. ''No more weights shattering the morning,'' said Mr. Jordan, 57, a registrar at Gallaudet University. ''It's a peaceful way to start the day.'' **********Strange things are happening in the homes of the hearing-impaired. Lights flicker, beds vibrate and fans start to blow when doorbells, alarm clocks or phones ring. That may be a bit spooky for the unaccustomed, but the devices that trigger such effects are making life easier for the hearing-impaired. **********''People do not have to live in isolation anymore,'' said Pauline Davies, a sales representative of Hearing Instruments. ''They don't have to say 'What?' all the time or worry about how they're going to get up in the morning.'' **********Listening and alerting devices account for less than 5 percent of the industry's $650 million in annual sales, but manufacturers expect them to rise to 20 percent by 1990, said Tad Zelsky, president of Sehas Inc., a distributor of hearing aids and personal devices based in the Southeast. **********Listening devices include telephone amplifiers, infrared or FM units, and portable microphones that a hearing-impaired person can place close to a subject, just as television reporters do. Alerting devices include the Signalman, a small transmitter that is attached to two electric appliances and can send signals from one to the other. **********Costs range from $25 for the Signalman to $850 for a vibrotactile wristwatch/pager, a complicated device that makes use of bells and vibrations. The device is connected to appliances and, for example, when a faint timer bell on the oven sounds, a signal is sent to the watch, which vibrates on the wrist. **********Many products are usually available only through the manufacturers. But some department stores and electronics stores carry the Signalman as well as television decoders, which make specially designed captions visible and cost approximately $250, and a pocket talker, the portable microphone that costs about $100. **********The popular phone amplifier -A.T.&T.'s National Special Needs Center handled 340,000 calls for it last year - increases sound by 30 percent and is available for about $170, according to Susan Decker, the company's manager of sales development. **********For Jerald Jordan, whose home is fully equipped with hearing devices, life is much easier today. ''I never really enjoyed television before I got my decoder,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/14/world.main_headline: Wright Says Award for Arias Dooms Aid for Contras
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/14/world.print_headline: Wright Says Award for Arias Dooms Aid for Contras
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/14/world.body_text: **********Representative Jim Wright, the House Speaker, said today that the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica today insured that Congress would not approve the Reagan Administration's request for new aid for the Nicaraguan rebels. **********''I can't conceive of providing any military aid in a time of peace,'' said Mr. Wright, a Texas Democrat. **********He said it was his view that the Administration's proposal to provide $270 million in new aid for the rebels, known as contras, was probably destined to fail anyway. But, he added, the symbolism of the award to Mr. Arias meant that ''there will be no support for the contras at this time.'' **********Nonetheless, Secretary of State George P. Shultz told the House Foreign Affairs Committee later in the day that President Reagan will demand that Congress provide new aid to the contras before Thanksgiving. 'Necessary' for Agreement **********Mr. Shultz argued that the aid would enhance the prospects of the agreement for which President Arias was given the award. The $270 million, he said, was ''necessary to support the agreement and insure that it endures.'' **********At the same time, some Republicans grumbled about the award to Mr. Arias. Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, said it remained to be seen whether the Arias plan would bring peace and freedom to Nicaragua. **********''The award may be premature,'' said Mr. Michel, who has often spoken for the Administration on the issue. **********Representative Newt Gingrich, a Georgia Republican, was even harsher. He said the Peace Prize decision was ''premature and saddening.'' Mr. Gingrich compared it to 1973, when the Peace Prize was awarded to Henry A. Kissinger, then the Secretary of State, and Le Duc Tho of North Vietnam, for negotiating what was supposed to be an end to the Vietnam War. Military and Nonmilitary Uses **********''This is the same committee that gave the award to Le Duc Tho two years before he turned South Vietnam into a Communist prison,'' he said. **********Under the Administration plan for aid to the contras, the money would be available for both military and nonmilitary uses. Mr. Shultz said the money could later be applied solely to nonmilitary purposes if the peace plan were proceeding. **********Democratic leaders in Congress have said that they might later appropriate a smaller amount of money to help in resettling the contras. But they have been adamant in their opposition to the Administration's proposal for $270 million in aid. **********Under the peace accord, of which Mr. Arias was the chief architect, five Central American Governments - Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras - are to carry out cease-fires with rebel groups by Nov. 7. Other Provisions **********At the same time, each of the Governments is to insure that several other provisions are in place, including freedom of the press and amnesty for political opponents and insurgents. The agreement also calls for an end to all outside aid to insurgent groups. **********In an appearance in Washington last month, Mr. Arias urged Congress to refrain from providing new aid to the contras while the peace process was under way. There was widespread agreement today that the naming of Mr. Arias as the Peace Prize recipient enhances his prestige and his request to suspend contra aid. **********''Now people will pay more attention to the request from Central America that aid to insurgent forces should be ended,'' said Guido Fernandez, the Costa Rican Ambassador to Washington. Congratulations From U.S.  The White House and the State Department offered congratulations to Mr. Arias today, but the event signals a shift in the Administration's fortunes on the issue. Administration officials have complained with increasing frequency that the Arias plan favors the Government in Nicaragua. **********In his testimony today, Mr. Shultz seemed to be setting out the conditions to allow the Administration to declare that Nicaragua has failed to comply with the accord by Nov. 7. **********He criticized President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua for saying he would not negotiate a cease-fire with the leadership of the contras. Mr. Ortega said last week that he would seek to comply with the peace accord's requirement for a cease-fire by negotiating with contra field commanders. **********''He should negotiate directly with the resistance for a cease-fire,'' Mr. Shultz said. ''The Ortega regime has so far refused, trying instead to divide the fighters from their political leaders.'' **********At another point in his testimony, Mr. Shultz said of the peace plan: ''If any part fails, the entire structure fails. If no cease-fire is negotiated, if no full amnesty is implemented, the other measures are in abeyance.'' **********Representative Dante B. Fascell, a Florida Democrat and chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said it appeared that the Administration was setting conditions difficult to meet by insisting that everything be accomplished by Nov. 7. **********Earlier, Mr. Wright told reporters that the Nov. 7 date should not be considered a true deadline. ''I don't think you set up an arbitrary time limit,'' he said. ''It's not like a football game.'' ---- Nicaraguan Copter Shot Down MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 13 (AP) - Contra forces have shot down a Soviet-made MI-17 helicopter providing ground support to Sandinista troops, the Defense Ministry said Monday night. There was no word on the fate of its four crew members. **********The ministry said the helicopter was shot down Sunday by a United States-made Redeye ground-to-air missile about 11 miles west of a military training base in Jinotega Province, about 200 miles north of Managua. **********The site lies outside three war zones where the Sandinistas on Oct. 7 called a 30-day unilateral cease-fire as part of the Central American peace plan. **********The Government declared a fourth cease-fire zone today, in a 240-square-mile area in central Zelaya province, 165 miles northeast of the capital.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Search Service Stresses Fixed-Income Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/busin.body_text: **********Joseph S. Crisanti, a co-founder of a credit rating company well known on Wall Street, is starting a new business. **********This time, Mr. Crisanti has begun a search service that will specialize in finding jobs for executives in the fixed-income markets, an area that Mr. Crisanti knows well. **********''We will try to provide a broad service that will cover the investment area in general,'' he said, ''but our real forte is in fixed-income. Other search firms have people within the firms that concentrate in this area but I don't know any firm that specializes in it.'' **********Mr. Crisanti, 52, was with Paine Webber as a corporate institutional bond salesman when in 1975 he joined with Paul McCarthy, Philip Maffei and Robert Ried to start the bond-research firm. **********Mr. Ried dropped out early on to start his own economics firm in Connecticut. McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei gradually established itself with reports on bond ratings of some 500 companies, and in the early 1980's it was recognized by the Securities and Exchange Commission as a statistical rating organization, joining Moody's, Standard & Poor's, Fitch and Duff & Phelps. **********''Surprisingly,'' the S.E.C. recognition ''was a non-event,'' Mr. Crisanti said, adding, ''It's more of a prestige type of thing, and it didn't do an awful lot to get us business.'' **********Nevertheless, the firm had built a following and caught the eye of the Xerox Corporation, whose financial services group bought the company in 1985. Mr. Crisanti left the firm in May 1986, while his partners stayed. He took some time off and now is anxious to be back in business. ''We always wanted to be on our own, and once I left the firm I wanted to continue to be on my own,'' he said. **********Mr. Crisanti grew up in Manasquan, N.J., seven miles south of Asbury Park, where his family had a resort hotel. He went to Cornell University's School of Hotel Administration and worked in the family business until he was 30. ''It was one of those businesses that there was no home life all summer,'' he said. ''That's what drove me out of it.'' **********He went to Wall Street and worked for Smith Barney before joining Paine Webber and going out on his own. Mr. Crisanti lives with his wife and three children in Holmdel, N.J.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/20/world.main_headline: IN SOUTHERN RUSSIA, A GLIMPSE OF DEMOCRACY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/20/world.print_headline: IN SOUTHERN RUSSIA, A GLIMPSE OF DEMOCRACY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/20/world.body_text: **********As the ritual of a Soviet political campaign drew to a close this week, the citizens of this agricultural center on the Russian steppes faced an unfamiliar predicament in their local elections: a choice. **********On Sunday, for the first time since the Soviet authorities began direct elections to government offices 50 years ago, the residents of Surovikino county and other select districts - in all, 5 percent of the country's 50,000 villages, towns, cities and counties - will be handed ballots listing more candidates than offices. **********Despite some confusion about the new procedure, and despite an occasional grumble that the old way was just fine, most voters seemed to view the experiment as a good first step into the murky waters of democracy. **********Initial worries that Surovikino politics would turn into the sort of unseemly free-for-all that people here associate with American democracy proved unjustified. **********It caused a stir when one candidate from the nearby town of Nizhny Chir flew into a jealous rage and beat his wife severely a week before the election, but the embarrassed work collective that nominated him organized a quick withdrawal. **********By today, when two American reporters paid a visit to a campaign meeting in the local agricultural high school, the dose of competition had evidently aroused unusually keen interest among the county's 26,600 voters. **********''There are difficulties at first; we are accustomed to the old system,'' said Ala Gritsoyenko, a judge in the local People's Court, after sitting through an hour of dispassionate speeches in the high school auditorium. ''It is complicated, deciding how to give out our votes. We are now obliged to cross out names, and that is difficult.'' **********But she concluded that the system ''will take root'' and be instituted across the country for the next local elections in early 1990. Effort to Shed Complacency **********The competitive election experiment grew out of a call in January by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, for a measure of ballot-box accountability to break the complacency of an utterly predictable political system. **********Competition is being imposed on a style of politics that, by tradition, shuns all signs of conflict in favor of collective harmony. **********It is considered bad form for a candidate to boast of his own virtues, so an associate, known officially as the ''trusted person,'' accompanies the candidate to public appearances to do his bragging for him. **********There are no brass bands or bunting, lawn signs or television advertisements. The only campaign posters are grainy, black-and-white handbills that could be mistaken for wanted posters. **********When Nikolai M. Selivyorstov, a lanky first-time candidate who works at the Surovikino grain elevator, was asked why anyone should choose him over Boris K. Sovranski, the manager of the cement factory, he seemed shocked by the question. **********''I don't feel any spirit of competition,'' he said, adding that he would quite likely cast one of his votes for Mr. Sovranski. The Issues Are Familiar **********Nevertheless, local politics in the Soviet Union are recognizable to a Westerner. Everyone knows everyone else. The issues are the everyday problems of poor telephone service, missing sidewalks and spotty garbage pickup - issues that the local councils have some power to affect. **********Even without competition, Soviet elections have traditionally been an opportunity for citizens to demand apartment repairs or other favors when the nominee is most likely to pay attention. **********The Communist Party still maintains a firm monopoly on the making of broader Government policy, and a central role in the screening of candidates, assuring that no election will become a referendum on, say, Mr. Gorbachev's anti-drinking campaign. **********Whether under the old system or the experimental one, candidates for the unpaid, part-time jobs as local representatives - deputies - are nominated at public meetings, usually in workplaces, and screened by election commissions dominated by the party. **********Local ward-heelers, called agitators, shepherd the voters to the polls, where the ballot normally bears the name of a single candidate. **********Voters may cross out the proferred name, and in a handful of districts each year a majority of voters reject the nominee. But to scratch out the name, a voter must detour to a voting booth, signaling his intentions and his questionable loyalty in full view of the presiding officials. Surplus Candidates Offered **********In the experimental areas, election districts have been combined and a surplus of candidates nominated, usually four nominees for every three offices. **********On Sunday, every voter will enter a booth and scratch off names until the number of candidates listed equals the number of offices to be filled. The runners-up become reserve deputies who can move up in case of an emergency. **********The campaign meeting at the Surovikino high school was to consider candidates for District 18 of the county council, and voters interviewed afterward said it was fairly typical, although subdued somewhat by the conspicuous presence of foreign guests. **********Eight candidates had been nominated for six seats that represent the eastern portion of the town, including the hospital, the high school, the automotive repair shop and the milk can factory, amid weathered wood houses and gray brick apartment blocks. More than 200 voters had been excused from work to attend. **********The meeting began with presentations by the ''trusted persons,'' usually co-workers, who took the stage to describe the background and work habits of the candidate. **********''First of all, he has a businesslike approach to work,'' said the proxy for one candidate, Viktor N. Yerokin, principal of the high school. ''He not only fulfilled, but overfulfilled the planned enrollment of children to our school.'' **********The spokesman for another candidate, the chief doctor at the hospital, told the voters, ''We can assure you on behalf of our collective that he will spare no effort to preserve your health.'' **********Vyacheslav V. Antonov, who works at the gasoline station, was praised for saving the station 150 gallons of grease last year. Sweeping Promises **********Then came a period of comment from the voters. Citizens arose in the audience and stated their demands. One complained of infrequent garbage pickup; another called for sidewalks along the eastern end of Lenin Street, and a third wanted better bus service to the hospital. **********Finally, the candidates were invited to speak. Only two came to this meeting, the doctor and a young investigator for the prosecutor's office. The voters seemed not to mind, saying they had plenty of chance to hear the candidates at other meetings or accost them on the street. **********The election speeches, on this occasion, were marvels of brevity, camaraderie and commitment. **********''On behalf of all the candidates, thank you for being here today,'' said Mikhail I. Selevanov, the doctor. ''I promise to bring to life all of your requests.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/10/world.body_text: **********With democratic trappings but also the mass arrest of dissidents, the ruling Democratic Justice Party convened in a Seoul gymnasium today and nominated the man almost certain to become South Korea's next president. **********Roh Tae Woo, the party chairman, was chosen by 8,600 delegates in a secret ballot, to be the party's presidential candidate. **********The result had been virtually certain since last week, when President Chun Doo Hwan designated Mr. Roh, a close ally since they were classmates at the Korea Military Academy, to be his successor. After that, no one else considered seeking the nomination. **********With opposition forces planning vast demonstrations in Seoul and other cities, the country's 120,000-member police force went on maximum alert.  [ Reuters reported clashes at universities across the country, with protesters hurling stones and gasoline bombs at riot policemen, who fired tear gas. Scores were arrested, Reuters said.  [ Hospital officials in Seoul said a Yonsei University student hit in the head by a police tear gas canister was in a coma and being kept alive artificially, Reuters said. ]  By Tuesday afternoon, at least 2,600 people had been been rounded up in nationwide police sweeps. While half of them were quickly released, others received summary trials for ostensible breaches of public security. **********In the ruling-party scenario, an electoral college of 5,000 or more members will vote Mr. Roh into office when it meets in December. He will take over officially from Mr. Chun in February. Milestone in Politics **********Despite the inevitability of the outcome, the party convention was treated by the Government as a milestone in what is intended to be the first peaceful transfer of presidential authority in the country's stormy postwar history. **********In a speech prepared for delivery at the convention, Mr. Roh pledged to pursue democratic reforms and to seek political dialogue with opposition leaders. **********Among the changes that he mentioned, without providing specifics, were greater press freedom and local political autonomy. However, he warned that ''radical leftist ideologies coupled with violent activities'' threatened democratic advances in South Korea. **********In a speech of his own, President Chun bluntly warned that civil disorders would be ''resolutely dealt with, no matter what sacrifice may be necessary.'' Opposition Leaders Detained **********Police officials said they would put 200 dissident leaders under house arrest, but it was not clear how successful they were. About 15 opposition figures sought sanctuary in an Anglican church, a rallying point for protesters, and many others have stayed away from their homes since last weekend to avoid confinement. **********In the meantime, thousands of police officers in riot gear and in plain clothes took up positions along downtown streets to block demonstrations that top Government officials claimed were inspired by ''impure elements'' trying to ''create extreme social confusion.'' **********The opposition, a loose network of politicians, clergymen, labor leaders and students, denounce Mr. Chun as a ''military dictator'' and say that Mr. Roh will not be much different. ''He's a second Chun Doo Hwan,'' said Kim Young Sam, head of the main opposition force, the Reunification Democratic Party. **********Indeed, Government officials agree that Mr. Roh, who is 54 years old, is likely to continue the present emphasis on military preparedness, economic growth and tough tactics against dissenters. But politicians and diplomats regard Mr. Roh as more willing to listen to other views than the aloof Mr. Chun, and say he may prove more conciliatory. Boycott of December Elections **********In an interview, Mr. Kim reiterated his party's intention to boycott the December elections, and demanded that the Government resume suspended talks on revising the constitutional method of selecting a leader. **********Opposition leaders insist on direct presidential elections, contending that the present electoral college - or even a parliamentary system proposed until recently by the ruling party - offers them no chance for victory. **********By refusing to take part in the electoral college, the opposition intends to handicap Mr. Roh in his search for legitimacy, a problem that ruling-party members acknowledge they must solve. ''If there is only one candidate,'' Mr. Kim said, ''what is the difference between our system and the Communist North Korean system?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/12/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Sea-Land Deal By CSX Approved
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/12/busin.body_text: **********The Interstate Commerce Commission voted unanimously to approve the CSX Corporation's planned $803 million acquisition of the Sea-Land Corporation, the first merger between a railroad and an ocean shipper. The merger means that Richmond-based CSX would operate 27,000 miles of railroad tracks, along with barges, pipelines, trucking and global shipping. **********The commission delayed CSX's acquisition of two Sea-Land trucking subsidiaries, even though CSX already operates a trucking unit. The commission said it needed to study the effect of a new trucking law on the merger. Sea-Land ships freight around the world and also operates truck lines within the United States. The company, based in Menlo Park, N.J., has been hurt by the worldwide slump in the ocean shipping industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/21/busin.main_headline: Bank Ties Savings Plan To Rise in College Costs
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/21/busin.print_headline: Bank Ties Savings Plan To Rise in College Costs
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/21/busin.body_text: **********As a partner at Lazard Freres & Company, Peter Roberts was a bond market whiz who used sophisticated mathematics to squeeze profits out of small irregularities in the futures and options markets. **********But all that expertise in high finance was of little help four years ago when his brother asked for advice about how he could insure that he would have enough money for his three young children's college educations. **********Mr. Roberts had no ready answer then, but he does now. He is the guiding force behind the College Savings Bank, a new institution based in Princeton, N.J., whose sole line of business is to sell certificates of deposit with interest rates that will change annually to keep pace with the rising costs of a college education. Filling His Brother's Needs **********Recalling that discussion with his brother, Mr. Roberts said: ''We sat over the dinner table and talked about the whole range of investments. When I suggested zero coupon bonds, my brother asked what would happen if inflation was to rise sharply from current levels. I had to admit that zeros might not be the answer. As it became clear there was no investment then available to satisfy my brother's needs, I decided to develop a specific product for that purpose.'' **********Even if the new product falls short of Mr. Roberts's claim of being ''the single most important financial product of this century,'' his hyperbole is close enough to the mark to attract attention from educators and financiers who are looking for alternatives to Government loan programs that leave students or their families heavily in debt. **********''Should the same generation that is bequeathing its children an extra $1 trillion in national debt hand its offspring a bill of upwards of $25 billion a year for their own college educations?'' asked Michael S. McPherson, chairman of the economics department at Williams College. **********Because 30 percent to 40 percent of the $25 billion spent annually on college comes from savings, the potential market for the College Savings Bank's product looked lucrative enough for Mr. Roberts to leave a job at Lazard Freres that he modestly described as ''very well paying'' and to attract four Lazard partners as investors and directors. One of Several New Plans **********At a time when the average cost of tuition, room and board for one year of college is up to $11,312, from about $5,800 in 1980, and rising much faster than the overall inflation rate, the College Savings Bank program is one of several new plans to encourage savings by families. Many families are already aware of the heavy burden they are facing. One recent survey by the Opinion Research Corporation found that 82 percent of Americans expect college expenses will soon be beyond the means of the average family. **********In an article published by the Brookings Review last autumn, Mr. McPherson estimated that college costs are likely to continue rising faster than the overall general inflation rate, though not faster than family incomes. **********Some states and a handful of colleges have responded to rising costs by developing tuition prepayment plans in which a specified payment today guarantees to pay college costs in the future. There are some drawbacks to these plans. For one thing, there is the possibility that the interest earnings in such early-contribution plans might be subject to Federal income tax. **********But the major problem with these plans is that they limit the student's choice of schools. If the student decides not to attend one of the schools in the plan, the amount prepaid is returned but the interest on it is forfeited. In contrast, the College Savings Bank imposes no restrictions on which college the student may attend. Costs Vary Widely **********One College Savings certificate, called a College Sure C.D., is based on the average cost at a group of 500 independent schools, as compiled by the College Board, the educational testing and information company based in Princeton. But college costs vary widely - at current prices it would take 1.49 College Sure C.D.s to pay for four years at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, but 6.36 C.D.s to pay for four years at Bennington College in Vermont. **********The bank advises families how to buy C.D.s with maturities that will coincide with their childrens' college years and how to make periodic contributions if they are unable to buy one C.D. with a lump sum. **********If paid in a lump sum, a College Sure C.D. that would cover one year of average college costs in the year 2000 can be bought now for about $14,750. Assuming college costs rise 10 percent a year, the C.D. would be worth $39,052 in the year 2000. **********Like other bank deposits, interest on College Sure C.D.s is subject to income tax. To ease the tax burden, there are proposals in Congress that would either exempt from taxes the interest on savings earmarked for college or allow some tax deduction for the savings. The proposals are supported by educators but are worrisome to Government officials concerned about reducing Federal tax revenues. Not Always the Best Rate **********To provide the College Savings Bank with a profit margin, the price of a College Sure C.D. will be greater than the average cost of one year at college as measured by the index. Because of that premium, the effective interest rate for depositors will be roughly two percentage points less than the college inflation rate, Mr. Roberts said. **********Since 1983 when Federal interest ceilings for bank time deposits were lifted, data compiled by the Bank Rate Monitor, an industry newsletter, shows that the national average for one-year time deposits has been higher than the rate that would have been paid by the College Savings Bank. **********''Our interest rate will often be lower than what could be earned at other banks, though at times we might pay more,'' acknowledged John D. Finnerty, executive vice president at College Savings. ''But we are not trying to offer the best investment. The important thing we are offering is a guarantee that over time the value of your C.D. will keep pace with college expenses.'' **********For the bank itself, there is a risk that its investments will pay low interest rates even though college costs are rising rapidly. ''I expect our earnings to be volatile and show some years red ink,'' Mr. Roberts said. Insured Deposits **********The bank's investments will be limited to high-quality securities, he said, supplemented by trading in consumer price index futures contracts and options on those contracts. Other techniques, such as interest rate swaps with conversion from floating to fixed interest rates, or vice versa, might also be used, he added. **********The deposits are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. There are penalties for early withdrawal of principal. **********College Sure C.D.s are currently sold only through the bank, using nationwide toll-free phone numbers. The C.D.s might eventually be sold through securities firms, which, Mr. Roberts said, have expressed ''extremely high'' interest in the concept, The bank is working to broaden its product line with savings programs and cost indexes for law, business and medical school.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/21/busin.main_headline: Pension Plans Say Benefits Are Safe Despite Loss
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/21/busin.print_headline: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE DAY AFTER THE PLUNGE; Pension Plans Say Benefits Are Safe Despite Loss
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/21/busin.body_text: **********Corporate executives sought to assure employees yesterday that their retirement benefits in company pension plans would not be affected by the stock market's plunge. But the executives conceded that pension funds had lost money, and pension managers were assessing the extent. **********''Clearly it's had a negative impact on the value of pension funds,'' said Fred Zuckerman, vice president and treasurer of the Chrysler Corporation. ''But it certainly does not have any impact on meeting pension obligations.'' 'Confusion and Pandemonium' **********Companies generally place about 50 percent of their pension funds into stocks, about 35 percent into bonds and the balance into a combination of real estate and other investments. **********''With the average pension fund being 50 to 60 percent stock, you can see that damage has been done,'' said James F. Beasley, chief operating officer of Rogers, Casey & Barksdale, a pension fund consulting firm in Stamford, Conn. ''There is a lot of confusion and pandemonium right now.'' **********Chrysler had about $4 billion in its pension fund in September, with about $2 billion of that invested in stocks, Mr. Zuckerman said. He was unable to estimate how much the fund had lost after stock prices collapsed on Monday. **********At the Manville Corporation, Charles F. Lemons, who manages that company's pension fund, said he was also unable to determine the value of his fund now. He said the pension fund had a value of about $800 million in September. **********A five-year bull market in stocks had resulted in a proliferation of overfunded pension plans as the investments made by pension fund managers earned more than was needed to pay benefits. But the pensions managers interviewed yesterday said that Monday's selloff eliminated some of those surpluses, reducing the amount by which the pension plans were overfunded. No Lasting Impact Is Seen **********Many worried retirees have been calling companies to ask about their pensions. But Mr. Beasley and others insisted that the market plunge in stock prices should not have long-term impact on the pension funds' ability to make payments to retirees. **********''I don't think this should be perceived as having a lasting impact on companies and certainly should not be viewed as something that would prevent them from handling their liabilities,'' he said. ''After all, a lot of pension funds' portfolios are tied up in bonds and real estate. It just takes away from the surpluses.'' **********For example, Bruce Bunch, a spokesman for the General Electric Company, said that G.E.'s pension programs were still adequately funded. ''But our pension fund was overfunded and this clearly puts a dent into that,'' he said. ''The value of our pension funds is roughly at the same level it was at the end of 1986,'' which was $19.5 billion. **********The toll of the stock plunge varied, however. Many companies said they had anticipated a downturn in the market and had altered the balance of their pension-fund investments. G.E. Shifts Its Strategy **********''Our pension manager has anticipated some market correction for the last 12 months,'' said Craig Martin, a spokesman for the Boeing Company. ''And he has steadily taken action to insulate the pension funds from the effects of a downturn in the market.'' **********Mr. Martin would not elaborate except to say that the company had shifted its investments, placing greater emphasis on bonds and other investments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/busin.main_headline: Schwab Plans Offering Of $14 to $17 a Share
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/busin.print_headline: Schwab Plans Offering Of $14 to $17 a Share
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/busin.body_text: **********The Charles Schwab Corporation, the nation's largest discount broker, filed today for an initial public stock offering, just six months after it was sold off by the ailing BankAmerica Corporation. **********In the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said it planned to offer 7 million new shares at $14 to $17 a share. After the offering, which had been expected, the company will have 24.4 million shares outstanding. **********At the price of the offering, the company would have a market value of $340 million to $415 million, far higher than the $280 million for which the company was bought in a management-led buyout in February. **********The valuation would seem to indicate that BankAmerica sold the brokerage for less than it was worth. However, BankAmerica is still entitled to a second payment from the appreciation in Schwab's equity. That payment could total $40 million, although the bank would not be able to realize all of it at one time. Founder's Stake **********Charles R. Schwab, the founder and chief executive, will own 7.2 million shares after the offering. That amounts to a 29.6 percent stake with a value of more than $100 million. Over all, Schwab executives and their families will still own 53 percent of the stock and will be able to control the board of directors, according to the filing. **********The offering will be managed by Morgan Stanley & Company and the First Boston Corporation, with 6 million shares to be sold in the United States and a million abroad. Some 2.1 million shares are being reserved for Schwab customers and employees. **********The company, which has applied for a listing on the New York Stock Exchange, said that $79 million from the offering would be used to retire debt incurred in the purchase of the company and $6 million would go for the redemption of preferred stock. The rest would be used for operations. Earnings Up Sharply **********Schwab says it has 1.8 million accounts. Because of the bull market, the company's earnings rose rapidly in 1986 and are growing again this year. **********In 1986, the company had net income of $32.2 million, almost triple the $11.4 million of the previous year. Revenue last year came to $308.3 million, up from $202.7 million in 1985. For the three months ended June 30, 1987, the company said it had net income of $12.7 million, or 63 cents a share, on revenue of $113.2 million. **********Mr. Schwab, whose photograph appears almost daily in newspaper advertisements, founded his brokerage in the early 1970's and saw his fortunes soar after brokerage commissions were deregulated in 1985. **********The company tried to go public around 1980 but pulled back. In 1983, it was sold to the BankAmerica Corporation for BankAmerica stock that was valued at $57 million at the time but steadily declined. Mr. Schwab became a BankAmerica director and its largest individual shareholder, but sold his stock and quit the BankAmerica board last year as problems mounted at the bank. **********BankAmerica, needing special gains to offest huge loan losses and fend off a takeover attempt by First Interstate Bancorp, agreed to sell the company back to Mr. Schwab and the management in February. Some analysts said at the time that the bank could have received a higher price from another bidder. However, Mr. Schwab had threatened to leave if someone else bought the firm.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/14/busin.body_text: **********Norway's Defense Minister said today that his Government was taking steps to reorganize a major state-owned company and tighten export controls in the wake of disclosures that the company had illegally sold sensitive technology to the Soviet Union. **********Defense Minister Johan Jorgen Holst offered these assurances in an apparent effort to protect the company against possible retaliation by the United States. **********The technology sold by the Norwegian company, Kongsberg Vapenfabrik, has enabled the Russians to make their submarines more difficult to detect, American officials say. The company also makes military equipment, including Penguin anti-ship missiles that Norway is trying to sell to the United States Navy. A Meeting With Weinberger **********The sale of the Penguin missiles is important to the company and to the Norwegian military, which believes it would help to reduce the unit cost of the missiles to Norway. **********The illegal sales by Kongsberg were the main focus of a meeting today of Mr. Holst and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. Mr. Weinberger is in Norway to attend a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. **********Aides to Mr. Weinberger said that the sale of the technology to the Soviet Union was a serious loss to the West. One aide, who requested anonymity, described the loss as a ''multibillion-dollar problem'' that would require the United States to step up its efforts on antisubmarine warfare. **********This official said the spy ring headed by John A. Walker Jr., a former Navy warrant officer, had provided the Russians with valuable information about the American capability to track Russian submarines. He said that officials at the Norwegian company had sold the Russians ''some of the fixes.'' Exports to Toshiba **********According to American and Norwegian officials, an export trading arm of the Kongsberg company exported computer software and military equipment to the Toshiba Machine Company of Japan, knowing that it would be sold to the Russians along with Toshiba's tooling equipment. Toshiba Machine is partly owned by the Toshiba Corporation. **********The equipment sold by the Norwegian and Japanese companies would enable the Soviet Union to produce quieter propeller blades for its submarines. American officials said today that the propeller blades had already been installed on some Soviet submarines and that, as a consequence, the submarines were harder to track. **********Mr. Holst said that the sales had clearly violated the export restriction set by the Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls for Western nations. **********He said that one employee of the Norwegian company had already been charged by Norwegian police with providing false information in applying for an export license. He said that three other employees were ''under suspicion'' and that investigations were continuing. Information Still Secret **********But Mr. Holst said the investigations had determined that company officials involved in the illegal sale did not have access to secret information about weapons made by the company. **********''The fact that there have been unfortunate incidents in one part of the firm from time to time should not be taken as an indication that the firm itself is unreliable,'' he told a group of American reporters who are traveling with Mr. Weinberger. ''That is manifestly not the case.'' **********Mr. Holst said the branch of the company that exported the technology had been shut down and that the company was being reorganized. ''There is no question that the firm will continue,'' he said. ''But it will continue as a more consolidated firm, concentrating on the production of weapons.'' **********He said the Norwegian Government was making an effort to encourage Norwegian concerns to tighten their export controls and to improve its own licensing procedures. 'Barring the Barn Door' **********Asked about the Norwegian effort, an aide to Mr. Weinberger likened the steps to ''barring the barn door'' after the horses have escaped. **********He said that the two sides had discussed cooperative efforts to deal with the problem of how to improve the United States's antisubmarine capabilities. He said his personal view was that the Norwegians should make some form of restitution to the United States, but added that the Pentagon has not yet taken a formal position on the issue. **********A spokesman for Mr. Weinberger said that the Pentagon did not plan to ban the purchase of arms made by the Norwegian company because of the illegal sales. **********But some members of Congress have threatened to retaliate against the Norwegian and Japanese companies by banning the purchase of their goods by the American Government. **********The Japanese Government has filed charges against Toshiba Machine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/busin.body_text: **********The global push for cutting tax rates, spanning ideological boundaries, has come even to Sweden, home of the world's highest taxes. **********A Swedish worker receiving wages of $35,000 a year or more, for example, faces a stunning marginal, or peak, income tax rate of 78 percent because of the country's generous welfare state. **********The high rates on comparatively modest salaries have made the game of avoiding taxes a national pastime, swelled the underground economy, worsened inflation and squelched incentives to work harder for additional income. 'Just Doesn't Work' **********''The very high level of progressive taxation just doesn't work,'' Kjell Olof Feldt, Sweden's Finance Minister, has acknowledged. **********Earlier this year, Mr. Feldt proposed a sweeping overhaul that would lower income tax rates, reduce tax avoidance and broaden the tax base in Sweden. **********Tax revision - corporate overhaul will be addressed later this year - is a highly sensitive political issue in this country, especially for Mr. Feldt's Social Democratic Party. The Social Democrats, who have controlled the Government for 49 of the last 55 years, have made high taxes a central part of their platform. **********Tax reduction has always been the rallying cry of the non-Socialist opposition. So by calling for an overhaul, the Social Democrats risk laying themselves open to charges, especially from their own left wing, of deserting their Socialist principles. The tax debate will be a central issue in next year's elections, but some overhaul of the system seems certain to be approved. A Global Movement **********While the debate here, as elsewhere, is shaped by domestic politics, it also provides a magnified example of the forces behind the international tax-revision movement. **********In addition to the United States, nations that have adopted or are considering tax overhauls include Britain, France, West Germany, Denmark, Belgium, Australia and New Zealand. The drift of the Swedish proposals -cutting rates and simplifying the tax system - mirrors the global trend. **********Some nations may be acting, at least in part, out of fear that companies and skilled employees will relocate to places with lower taxes. **********In Sweden's case, for instance, IKEA, the country's most rapidly expanding retailing chain, has moved its headquarters to Denmark for tax reasons, and a large community of wealthy Swedes lives in Britain. One of them is Erik Penser, one of the most successful and influential individual investors in Swedish corporations. Swedish tennis stars routinely move to Britain or Monte Carlo as soon as they begin to pile up large earnings on the international circuit. **********But the impetus for tax revision in the industrial world is mainly a drive for efficiency. Ideology, to be sure, has played a role, especially in Britain and the United States, where the Thatcher and Reagan Administrations view high taxes as an infringement on individual freedom and enterprise. But Labor or Social Democratic Governments in Australia and New Zealand in addition to Sweden, have also embarked on tax revision. **********Accordingly, many analysts have pointed to the tax movement as evidence of an international shift to the right in economic policy. That claim is debatable. Yet even in a Social Democratic country like Sweden there is less concern today about income redistribution and more about efficiency. No Welfare Cuts Planned **********Political leaders here say the focus on efficiency is not a departure from its long-held commitment to economic egalitarianism, enshrined in the Swedish welfare system, but is necessary to insure that the nation can continue to pay for its generous social programs. So far, there is no serious talk of paring the welfare state. **********''The Social Democratic Party has to recognize that high taxes, which reduce efficiency and stimulate inflation, slow down growth and ultimately undermine social equity,'' said Mr. Feldt, one of the party's so-called new pragmatists. ''That is a sophisticated argument. But I think we will get it through.'' **********Mr. Feldt's proposal calls for reducing income tax rates to three levels: 60 percent, 45 percent and 33 percent. (Beginning Jan. 1, there will be two main tax brackets in the United States: 15 percent and 28 percent, although some taxpayers will pay 33 percent on part of their income.) In addition, Mr. Feldt's plan would sharply cut back the generous deductions for interest payments on personal loans, insurance fees and other expenditures. Curbing deductions would make up for some of the $4 billion of revenue lost from reducing income tax rates. Curbing Underground Economy **********Analysts here hope that lower rates will diminish underground activity, estimated at up to 20 percent of Sweden's gross national product, and thereby return substantial funds to the taxed economy. In all, the total tax load on the Swedish economy of 52 percent of G.N.P. is not likely to change much., if at all. **********Mr. Feldt's proposals will be debated in party conferences later this year and will be a focal point during the 1988 elections. **********Moreover, a program to revise corporate taxes, expected to include a hefty cut in the nominal rate of 50 percent, will also be introduced later this year. If approved, overall tax revision would probably go into effect over the next two or three years. Approval Expected **********Though details remain to be worked out, a sweeping tax package is all but assured. ''There is a majority in Sweden today, including major interest groups that would lose some of their special benefits, that understands we need tax reform,'' said Bengt Westerberg, head of the Liberal Party, a leading non-Socialist party. **********Indeed, the perceived need to rid national tax systems of decades of growth-inhibiting special deductions, allowances and loopholes is another common thread in the global tax-revision movement. Some economists suggest that tax systems have life cycles and what is occurring around the world today is the death of the postwar generation of tax structures. **********Accordingly, the only means to tax rationalization becomes a drastic overhaul, instead of the piecemeal bartering among interest groups that led to the problem in the first place. In Sweden, the American approach is deemed worth copying. 'You Have to Be Brutal' **********''Politically, you have to be brutal and have a clean sweep, much like in the United States,'' said Gunnar Eliasson, president of the Industrial Institute for Economic and Social Research, a private research group. **********Sweden's combination of high income taxes and proliferation of deductions has made tax avoidance a cottage industry in recent years. A decade or so ago, sidestepping taxes was considered shady behavior. ''But today, how to avoid taxes is one of the most common subjects of social discussion at dinner parties or over drinks,'' said Nils Lundgren, senior economist at PK Banken, a big Swedish bank. **********The 1980's also brought to prominence Roger Akelius, a best-selling author who has been called the ''Dr. Ruth of Swedish tax avoidance,'' dispensing helpful tips on how to outsmart the tax man. **********The inflation of the 1970's focused public attention on ways to avoid taxes because workers were bumped into higher and higher tax brackets. The high taxes, in turn, fueled further inflation. For example, if a company gives workers an increase in take-home wages, it has to pay out three or four times the amount because of the high taxes. **********One result: average wage settlements in Sweden have increased by 8 to 9 percent annually in recent years, compared with annual advances of 1 to 3 percent in West Germany, whose companies often compete with Sweden's. The Corporate Tax Debate **********Still to come is the debate over corporate tax revision. One of the secrets of Sweden's strong economic performance in the postwar years has been the implicit deal struck between the Social Democrats and major corporations. **********Part of the formula has been the tax treatment, which is extremely favorable by international standards. ''The big companies provide exports and jobs, but they are taxed very lightly,'' said Jacob Palmstierna, president of Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken, the nation's largest bank. **********At present, the nominal corporate tax rate is 50 percent. However, given all the allowable deductions for investment and depreciation, the effective rate that Swedish companies pay is 25 percent. (Beginning July 1, the statutory corporate tax rate in the United States drops to 34 percent, from 46 percent.) The Federation of Swedish Industries has recommended that the nominal rate be cut to 25 percent, along with a cut in deductions. Industrialists worry that they could be short-changed in the political negotiations. ''If the corporate rate in the tax reform package ends up above 25 percent, it will be a tax increase,'' said Pehr Gyllenhammar, chairman of A.B. Volvo, the country's largest company. ''And Sweden would not be well served.'' 'Brain Drain' Feared **********Despite reservations, Swedish executives want tax revision. They worry about a ''brain drain'' of people in global industries such as finance and electronics if Sweden keeps its high income tax rates while other nations are cutting theirs.  WHAT SWEDES GET FOR THEIR TAXES  The Swedish social welfare system has worked in a society of shared values, where it might not in a country where different groups have conflicting goals, say experts at the Brookings Institution, who have studied the Swedish economy. Some Swedish tax revenues, unlike many nations' welfare benefits, go to reward those who work. Three examples are:  DAY CARE  Parents must be registered as members of the work force in order to enroll their children in day care.  SUBSIDIZED LUNCHES  Employees may buy coupons for half their face value and redeem them for restaurant meals. Consequently, many Stockholm restaurants are open only at lunchtime.  RETIREMENT BENEFITS  Work incentives are built into the Swedish equivalent of Social Security so that greater work results in greater retirement benefits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Thrift Official Plans to Resign
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/busin.body_text: **********The Commissioner of the Texas Savings and Loan Department, L. Linton Bowman 3d, has disclosed plans to resign at the end of the year. No reason was given. **********Mr. Bowman's decision comes as the state's savings and loan industry has come under intense Federal scrutiny for allegations of fraud at more than 20 institutions. **********Mr. Bowman's plan to step down was disclosed by Gov. **********Bill Clements in an interview today in The Dallas Morning News. Mr. Bowman could not be reached for commment. **********Mr. Bowman, who is 58 years old and has served as the head of the regulatory agency since January 1983, recently drew criticism when it was disclosed that he had held stock in a state-chartered savings and loan in Texas while serving as commissioner. **********He is also a part owner of a small real estate company in Austin with a former chairman of the Vernon Savings and Loan Association. Vernon has been seized by Federal regulators and its former officials have been sued by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. Mr. Bowman, however, has not been accused of any wrongdoing.
