https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/busin.main_headline: Primerica's President Sees a Profitable Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Primerica's President Sees a Profitable Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/busin.body_text: **********Kenneth A. Yarnell Jr., who brought Gerald Tsai Jr. and the American Can Company together, has been named president and chief operating officer of the company, now known as the Primerica Corporation. **********Currently chief financial officer, Mr. Yarnell, 44, will become the No. 2 man to Mr. Tsai, chairman and chief executive at the Greenwich, Conn., company. Mr. Tsai, 58, who will reach the company's mandatory retirement age in seven years, once served as president. **********''Jerry Tsai's vision is to build Primerica into one of the largest and most profitable corporations in the country,'' Mr. Yarnell said. ''We have a good platform on which to build a very major company.'' **********Mr. Yarnell ''will assist me in planning the corporation's future direction,'' Mr. Tsai said in a statement. He will also continue to be involved in the company's acquisitions and financings. **********Twelve years ago, Mr. Yarnell was hired from Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette on Wall Street to form a mergers and acquisition department at American Can when the company was moving from industrial products to financial services. **********He was instrumental in acquiring the Fingerhut Corporation, a direct-marketing company, for American Can. Mr. Tsai, then head of Associated Madison Companies Inc., an insurance company, wrote to William S. Woodside, then American Can's chief executive, suggesting a venture to sell insurance by mail. **********''Mr. Woodside asked me to get in touch with Jerry,'' Mr. Yarnell said yesterday. ''I went down to New York and he and I hit it off very well, as it's so easy to do with Jerry.'' **********The discussions turned to a bigger deal - ''Why didn't Jerry sell us his company and come on board?'' - Mr. Yarnell recalled. That happened, and Mr. Tsai eventually became chief executive after Mr. Woodside retired.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/07/busin.body_text: **********MANAGEMENT consulting, a favorite career with its high salaries, is changing in many ways, a partner of a large accounting firm and the managing director of a consulting firm agree. **********For new graduates with bachelor's degrees or master of business administration degrees, it might be wise to look for jobs at big accounting firms. The fastest-growing part of many accounting firms is management consulting, and they do not want to use accountants for such jobs. **********Michael Bealmer, a Coopers & Lybrand partner with the title of national director of systems services consulting, said last week that 21 percent of the professionals at his firm work in consulting, compared with 12 percent five years ago. **********About 60 to 65 percent of the professionals are accountants in the auditing part of the business, he said, while most of the rest are tax experts. **********''Our numbers have been steadily increasing,'' he said, adding that he expects the consulting sector to grow each year until it reaches about 30 percent of both professionals and billed hours. **********Consulting growth makes sense because the wave of corporate mergers has reduced the number of accounting firms' clients. **********In the 1970's and early 1980's, Mr. Bealmer said, the emphasis was on hiring M.B.A.'s or engineers with about 10 years of experience for consulting. **********''Years ago, management consultants tended to be efficiency experts - an image that has dogged us,'' he said. ''In recent years we have branched away from a soft-product mentality that meant consulting sessions with management and writing reports.'' Now, he explained, the firm wants to present ideas and follow up to make sure they work. **********''So we do take graduates right out of college, and that represents a significant shift - a shift from being just an adviser to being an implementer,'' he said. **********Useful courses that new graduates might offer include management information systems, computer science, mathematics and engineering. **********''As soon as they join, we give them five weeks of a technical program,'' Mr. Bealmer said. About 200 to 250 go through the program each year. **********''In the firm everyone matriculates toward a partnership,'' Mr. Bealmer said. At Coopers & Lybrand about 10 percent of the professional staff are partners. **********Marvin Schiller, managing director of A. T. Kearney Inc., a large management consulting concern, agrees that consulting has changed. **********''When I started in the 1950's,'' he said, ''it was considered a scourge if a company hired a management consultant - an indication that the company could not take care of its own problems. Now it is considered a sign of strength.'' **********He credits the change partly to the fact that many top businessmen, when they were still in college, had professors who did a lot of consulting. **********Mr. Schiller's firm stresses expertise in two areas - logistics and manufacturing. ''We like more experienced M.B.A.'s,'' he said, adding that they need about six to nine years of experience. ''We give them real live training on the job, and they must be able to contribute quickly.'' **********Still another change, he noted, is ''more and more overlapping'' with legal aspects. ''We act as expert witnesses,'' he said. ''Our firm has been hiring persons with background in product libability issues.'' Management consulting these days, he said, also overlaps with public relations and advertising. **********Another trend he described as ''a double-edged blade'' involves consulting firms that develop long-lasting relationships with clients. ''If we become too chummy with clients, a company might let consultants do the management thinking,'' he warned. **********To avoid this and make sure an effective job is done for a client, he said, ''a team of our people determines if our recommendations have been implemented after a year or so and if the ideas have been beneficial.'' **********Kearney operates around the world directly, not through affiliates. **********''There is a good market,'' Mr. Schiller said, ''because Europe is five years behind us in consulting, and Japan is five years behind Europe.'' **********To staff its global operation, Kearney has these criteria for M.B.A.'s from five major business schools: at least two years of experience in the firm's consulting area, fluency in a foreign language and work or residency in a foreign nation. The first four hired were a Mexican, an Italian, a Filipino and an American.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/world.main_headline: Legislators See Accord as Evidence That Reagan Presidency Still Lives
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/world.print_headline: MISSLE ACCORD: MIXED VIEWS IN WASHINGTON; Legislators See Accord as Evidence That Reagan Presidency Still Lives
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/world.body_text: **********President Reagan's agreement in principle on an arms accord won support today from some of his most ardent traditional political opponents, criticism from some of his most loyal allies, and skepticism from some of Capitol Hill's experts on arms control. **********It was seen as a major achievement not only for Mr. Reagan, who made an arms control pact with the Soviet Union the top priority of his second term, but also for Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who negotiated many of the major points in the accord. **********On Capitol Hill, many lawmakers from both parties praised the agreement in principle with the Soviet Union to ban medium-range nuclear weapons, and said the Senate would probably approve by a sizable margin ratification of the treaty Mr. Reagan is expected to to sign later this year. **********Despite a year of political setbacks and physical stress for the President, legislators said today's agreement demonstrated Mr. Reagan's continuing ability to influence events here in his final 16 months in office, particularly in foreign policy. As Senator Carl Levin, a Michigan Democrat, put it: ''This probably slows down the process of lame-duckism.'' Glow Dimmed by Criticism **********But Mr. Reagan's glow of success was dimmed by criticisms from some of his most ardent conservative supporters, who accused him of compromising American security in the face of the Russian military threat. **********''The Soviets haven't complied with any other treaties that they've agreed to,'' said Senator Steve Symms, an Idaho Republican. ''What makes us so sure they'll agree to this one?'' **********Senator Alan Cranston of California, the Democratic whip, predicted that as many as 22 conservative Republicans might oppose the pact, which must be approved by two-thirds of the Senate. That would not be enough to kill the treaty, but Mr. Cranston warned that ''a determined minority can delay things for a long, long time.'' **********Even supporters of the pact cautioned that they wanted to see the ''fine print'' when the actual text of the proposed treaty is completed by technical experts from both countries. Their chief concern is how the bargain will be verified, a problem that has plagued previous attempts at arms control between the two super-powers. Talks on Conventional Forces **********Moreover, defense experts pointed out that today's agreement in principle would leave the Soviet Union and its allies in a stronger military position, given their overwhelming superiority in conventional forces. **********Many lawmakers agreed with Senator J. James Exon, a Nebraska Democrat, who said talks on reducing conventional armies in Europe is ''the next serious problem that needs addressing.'' **********It was a day of political irony for Mr. Reagan, as the staunchest expressions of support for the impending accord came from some of his traditionally fiercest opponents. Senator Cranston, a man that President Reagan tried mightily to defeat last year, said he would lead the fight for approval of the pact in the Senate. ''He may end up glad that I'm here,'' Mr. Cranston said . **********But Democrats today could not resist taking a few jabs at the President and what they called his born-again commitment to arms control. A View to History **********''I welcome these late conversions,'' said Senator John Glenn, the Ohio Democrat, ''even if it came later than a lot of us would have liked.'' **********But few questioned the President's sincerity. Mr. Reagan's support for an arms agreement was said to reflect his determination ''to go down in history as a peacemaker - that's human nature,'' as Senator Exon put it. **********Moreover, many lawmakers said that after more than six years in office, Mr. Reagan had learned a good deal about the terrors of nuclear war, and the economic burden that an unbridled arms race was placing on the country. **********But Tom Griscom, the President's communications director, said that Mr. Reagan has been devoted to arms reduction for a long time, and that he was implementing a proposal first made five years ago. ''People ought to read the speeches he's made,'' the White House aide said. Gorbachev Was Willing **********But Mr. Griscom also acknowledged that today's agreement ''was probably not something people would have anticipated'' from the Reagan Administration. One reason Mr. Reagan has put so much effort into reaching an agreement, he added, is that he found the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a receptive negotiating partner. **********The impending arms pact is also a significant achievement for Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who negotiated the major points during a marathon session on Thursday and will go to Moscow next month to complete the final draft. When he finished briefing senators this afternoon on Capitol Hill, the lawmakers gave Mr. Shultz a rare round of applause. **********Aides to Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, Mr. Shultz's long-time bureaucratic rival, were noticeably absent from several key meetings this week, and some Administration officials said this was done deliberately, out of concern that they would chill the tone of the negotiations. But Congressional officials said the Administration would have trouble securing Senate approval for ratification of any treaty that was opposed by the Defense Secretary or his military advsiers on the Joint Chiefs of Staff. **********Although Mr. Weinberger, as Defense Secretary, played a less visible role than Mr. Shultz in the week's negotiations, Mr. Weingerger was the first in the Administration to champion the kind of proposal announced today by the United States and the Russians. Skeptics on the Hill **********In the weeks ahead, Mr. Shultz is likely to continue his visible role, negotiating the terms of the summit meeting, expected in late fall in Washington. That meeting will also deal with other matters, including human-rights issues and regional problems such as in Afghanistan. **********The skepticism on Capitol Hill came primarily from two camps: from conservatives who distrust any agreement with the Soviet Union, and from arms control experts who worry that today's agreement in principle focuses on a relatively less-dangerous category of nuclear weapon and that it raises potential difficulties between the United States and its European allies. **********Much of the criticism focused on the verification question, and many details about the proposed procedures were not yet available to lawmakers. **********''I am concerned about verification - I have grave concerns,'' said Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a Utah Republican and a leading conservative. Concern Over Verification **********''If verification procedures are airtight - and I mean airtight - then we'll do all right,'' added Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader. **********Many lawmakers, including some leading Democrats, also criticized the failure of the Administration to move forward with efforts to reduce the Soviets' wide lead in conventional forces. **********''We don't have anything on the table that would make any difference in the imbalance of conventional forces,'' complained Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, chairman of the Armed Services Committee and one of Senate's most influential voices on military policy and arms control.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/25/world.main_headline: New Soviet Interest in U.N. Broadens
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/25/world.print_headline: New Soviet Interest in U.N. Broadens
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/25/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union's call for a United Nations naval force in the Persian Gulf is the latest sign of a new interest by Moscow in using the organization's peacekeeping machinery to advance Soviet interests, diplomats say. **********In the 42-year history of the United Nations, Moscow was traditionally aloof or critical of the few times that international forces flying the United Nation flag have been sent into troubled areas. But recently, the Russians have begun paying their share of the costs for peacekeeping operations - to which they had refused to contribute. **********And in his address to the General Assembly on Wednesday, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze for the first time clearly called for a United Nations naval presence in the gulf to insure freedom of navigation there, saying it should replace the United States and other Western navies now protecting civilian ships in the area. **********Last week in an article in Pravda, Mikhail S. Gorbachev also praised the efforts of the United Nations to maintain the peace around the world by sending military forces to supervise truces or to keep antagonistic forces apart. The Soviet leader said the organization should increase such peacekeeping activities in future. New Interest in Command Unit **********Recently, Soviet officials have said Moscow was also interested in reviving a forgotten and almost-defunct United Nations organization called the Military Staff Committee. When the United Nations Charter was drawn up, the Staff Committee was supposed to comprise the armed forces chiefs of staff of Britain, China, France, the United States and the Soviet Union, the five permanent members of the Security Council. **********The Staff Committee was to command joint military operations carried out by the national forces of those countries on Security Council orders and intended to enforce peace. The need for unanimity, however, paralyzed it and prevented the Security Council from ever ordering such an operation under its command. **********Although the United Nations sent forces to repel North Korea's invasion of South Korea in 1950, that decision was made by the Security Council in the absence of the Soviet Union and the United States was designated sole commander of the operation. **********Significantly, the Soviet Foreign Minister coupled his call for a United Nations naval presence in the Persian Gulf with a strong appeal for unity among the Security Council's permanent members, essential for any military intervention in the area. Goals of Russians Questioned **********Western diplomats and United Nations officials are divided over what this new Soviet interest means. **********Some are skeptical, arguing that Moscow is seeking a propaganda advantage over the West by appearing to favor international action to resolve the gulf dispute at a time of public anxiety in the United States and Europe about the involvement of Western navies there. **********In addition, they point out that such a United Nations force in the gulf would probably include Soviet as well as American ships, giving Moscow an internationally sanctioned military role in the area for the first time. **********Today, the Reagan Administration signaled its opposition to the whole idea. A State Department spokeswoman, Phyllis Oakley, said such a United Nations presence would be new and complicated to work out. The Reagan Administration, she added, was also opposed to giving the Soviet Union ''the chance to increase its presence in the region.'' 'It Could Be Propaganda' **********Other officials and experts contend that the new Soviet leadership may now be genuinely interested in using the United Nations' peacekeeping machinery to help resolve the many bitter regional conflicts in which the Soviet Union is now involved, which are increasingly costly for Moscow to pursue. **********''It could be propaganda but it may also reflect Soviet interest in making the U.N. machinery work properly at last,'' said Brian Urquhart, former United Nations Under Secretary General for Special Political Affairs. **********In the past, the Soviet Union has never liked United Nations peacekeeping operations. Moscow seldom agrees to pay for them although it has only once vetoed such an operation in the Security Council. In 1978, after the Camp David accords, the Soviet Union insisted on closing down the second United Nations Emergency Force set up to preserve the peace between Israel and Egypt. **********Part of the explanation, experts say, is that the Soviet Union traditionally favors strict adherence to the United Nations' charter, which clearly states that all military operations should come under the control of the Security Council and the Military Staff Committee. Soviet Hostility Decreases **********But Soviet suspicion of United Nations peacekeeping activities also reflects its resentment at the large United Nations peacekeeping force mounted in the Congo in 1960, which Moscow felt favored the pro-Western factions in the bitter civil war that ravaged the country at independence. **********Soviet hostility to the United Nations' peacekeeping role has been decreasing in recent years, suggesting Moscow is coming to accept that the world body can play a useful role in ending conflicts and preserving peace. **********At the end of the Middle East War of 1973, the Soviet Union allowed Poland to send troops to participate in a United Nations peacekeeping force. And in October of that year, it accepted Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's invitation to send 36 Soviet officers to the United Nations Truce Supervisory Organization overseeing the cease-fire. **********In April 1986, the Soviet Union agreed to start paying its share of the cost of the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon, which first set up in 1978 to oversee the withdrawal of Israel forces from Southern Lebanon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/01/busin.body_text: **********Bolstered by a resurgent I.B.M., the stock market recouped some of the ground it lost last week. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which gave up 70.15 points last week, rose 23.60, to close at 2,662.95. The Dow was basically strong all day; it was up almost 17 at noontime. Its rally yesterday squelched - at least for a day - talk that the long-awaited market correction had arrived. **********International Business Machines, considered a market bellwether, gained 1 7/8, to 168 3/8, and led a strong technology sector in which Digital Equipment gained 2 1/8, to 189 5/8; Cray 2 3/8, to 114 7/8, and Data General 3/8, to 32 3/8. Oil Issues Move Higher **********Oil and precious metals issues also moved sharply ahead. **********Late last week, a weak dollar and rising interest rates cut into the stock market's recent rally, which on Aug. 25 pushed the Dow to a record 2,722.42. After gains in the morning, interest rates closed slightly lower yesterday. The dollar edged higher. **********Oil prices continued their recent surge, and energy stocks reflected this. Mobil rose 2 1/2, to 53 1/2; Exxon 1 5/8, to 99 5/8; Royal Dutch/Shell 1 5/8, to 134 1/2; Chevron 1/2, to 58 1/2, and British Petroleum 1 3/4, to 75 1/8. Renewed fighting and rising tensions in the Persian Gulf as American-escorted tankers again entered the danger zone made an impact. **********And, as is usually the case when oil prices rise, the fuel-conscious airline stocks fell: Delta lost 3/4, to 56; NWA 5/8, to 67 1/4, and AMR 1/2, to 59 3/8. Newmont Mining Up Sharply **********Gold stocks rose. ASA Ltd. gained 1, to 65 1/2. Gold is a traditional haven for nervous investors in times of international crisis. Newmont Mining rose 9 1/2, to 92, but that jump had little to do with international tensions: A group led by T. Boone Pickens offered $95 a share, or $5.7 billion, to acquire the 90 percent of Newmont it does not already own. **********Elsewhere, news that the United Auto Workers had chosen Ford Motor as its strike target in this year's national contract talks apparently helped General Motors. G.M. rose 2, to 92. Ford also gained, however, adding 3/4, to 108. Chrysler was off 1/4, to 44 3/4. A strike against Ford could come as early as Sept. 14. **********Among other blue chips, Procter & Gamble gained 2 1/2, to 102 1/2; Kodak added 1 3/8, to 100 3/8, and Philip Morris rose 1 7/8, to 117 7/8. **********The New York Stock Exchange composite index climbed 1.46, to 184.45, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 2.76, to 329.80. Gainers on the Big Board led losers by a 1,007-to-601 margin; volume was a modest 165.8 million shares. **********Market experts noted that the Dow might have better days yet in store, since the stock market has traditionally performed well in the three days before the Labor Day weekend. ''It's one of the more predictably strong periods,'' said Robert H. Stovall, president of Twenty-First Advisers Inc. Most-Active Stocks **********Two utility stocks, Ohio Edison and Public Service Enterprises, were the most actively traded issues on the Big Board. Ohio Edison gained 1/8, to 22 1/4, on 10.8 million shares, and Public Service gained 3/8, to 25 5/8, on 7.9 million. Both are about to trade without their dividends. **********National Semiconductor gained 7/8, to $15 3/4, after the company announced it had signed an agreement to buy Schlumberger Ltd.'s Fairchild Semiconductor unit for about $122 million in common stocks and warrants. Schlumberger, basically an oil field servicer, gained 3/4, to 47 3/8. **********In over-the-counter stock trading, the Nasdaq index rose 1.68, to 454.97. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 1.60, to 361.35. Bolar gained 2 7/8, to 41; the company has received regulatory approval for a generic drug.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/12/busin.body_text: **********Cannon Group Inc. has agreed to sell its real estate holdings for at least $300 million and lease them back from a company affiliated with a major shareholder. **********Cannon, a leading independent film producer, said on Friday that the agreement was reached with Spanish developer Renta Inmobilaria S.A., which is affiliated with Intercorporation S.A., a Luxembourg holding company that owns about 18 percent of Cannon's common stock. The deal covers almost all of **********Cannon's physical assets apart from its film library and marks the end of the company's ownership of movie theaters. **********The assets include its Los Angeles headquarters, its Commonwealth Theaters chain in the Midwest, its European theaters and the Elstree film studio in England. **********Cannon said in a statement the proceeds would go toward reducing its bank debt, which industry analysts estimate at about $200 million. It also said it terminated a **********December 1986 agreement with Warner Communications Inc., the large entertainment concern, whereby Warner would invest in or acquire 50 percent of Cannon's European theater chain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/world.main_headline: U.S. and Greece Ease Dispute And Open Way to Base Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/world.print_headline: U.S. and Greece Ease Dispute And Open Way to Base Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/world.body_text: **********Greek and American officials indicated today that their countries had overcome a crisis that had reportedly jeopardized the future of United States military bases. **********After a 90-minute meeting between Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and Michael H. Armacost, Assistant Secretary of State for Political Affairs, both sides said preliminary discussions on a new agreement covering the four main and 20 lesser military installations would open in Athens Sept. 4. **********The dispute involved charges that Greece was negotiating with Abu Nidal, the Arab linked to terrorism.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/05/world.body_text: **********The third reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear power station, damaged in an explosion and fire in April 1986, has been repaired and put back in operation, the press agency Tass said today. The fourth reactor at the Ukrainian plant was damaged beyond repair in the accident, which killed at least 31 people. It was entombed in reinforced concrete to prevent radiation leaks. An official said that radiation was still a problem at the plant and there had been three fatal accidents this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/01/busin.main_headline: Raids in Persian Gulf Lift Crude Oil Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/01/busin.print_headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS; Raids in Persian Gulf Lift Crude Oil Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/01/busin.body_text: **********Prices of crude oil and petroleum products rose in heavy trading on world markets yesterday after a weekend in which Iraq broke the informal six-week cease-fire in the Persian Gulf. **********On Saturday and Sunday Iraqi jet fighters bombed offshore oilfields and three Iranian oil tankers, the first attack since the United Nations Security Council called for a negotiated end to the fighting. **********Iraq said yesterday that it had hit two more Iranian ships in the new air attacks. Iraq said it resumed the attacks because Iran had refused to agree to the cease-fire resolution. In addition, Iranian speedboats were reported to have attacked a Kuwaiti-flag freighter near the Strait of Hormuz in Iran's first action in the Gulf since the U.N. resolution. **********In response, the near-month futures contract jumped nearly 60 cents yesterday morning but eased in the afternoon to close at $19.73 a barrel, up 34 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The near-month heating oil contract gained nearly a cent, to 52 cents a gallon. Unleaded gasoline was up one-quarter cent, to 51 cents a gallon. **********Crude oil price gains on the London-based open market were similarly moderate. In that market, West Texas Intermediate, the American benchmark grade, was trading at $19.70 a barrel, up 31 cents, while Britain's Brent North Sea crude, an important international marker, had risen 35 cents, to $18.55 a barrel. **********''The day's movements were keyed to the situation in the Gulf,'' said Peter C. Beutel, assistant director of Elders Futures Inc. **********However, commodity analysts cautioned that the gains were not likely to hold unless a more significant threat develops to the flow of oil through the Gulf. They pointed to the fact that crude oil prices gained less than a dollar and that the run-up actually eased late in the day. **********''It's not being perceived of as a major development,'' said Michael Rothman of Merrill Lynch Futures, Inc, referring to the action in the Persian Gulf. **********Given the substantial output of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in recent weeks, Mr. Rothman said, traders are waiting to see what the demand for OPEC oil will be in September and whether the group will curtail its output.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/01/world.main_headline: GORBACHEV TELLS SOVIET ON NEW YEAR A THREAT OF WAR PERSISTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/01/world.print_headline: GORBACHEV TELLS SOVIET ON NEW YEAR A THREAT OF WAR PERSISTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/01/world.body_text: **********As Mikhail S. Gorbachev delivered a televised New Year's address to the Soviet Union, President Reagan's radio speech could be heard over the Voice of America early today on short-wave radios in spite of some jamming. **********According to American diplomats who monitored Mr. Reagan's broadcast here, it was audible on most of the frequencies used by Russian-language broadcasts of the Voice of America. One diplomat said that on at least two frequencies the broadcast could be easily understood. On other frequencies, the speech was drowned by static. **********Listeners in Leningrad reportedly received the President's message clearly. **********Mr. Reagan decided to beam his message to the Soviet Union by radio over the Voice of America after the Soviet Union rejected a White House proposal for an exchange of televised New Year's messages between Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev. **********Soviet spokesmen said such an exchange would be inappropriate in light of what they described as a poor state of relations between the two countries, notably over the issue of arms control. **********Last year Mr. Reagan appeared on Soviet television, and Mr. Gorbachev spoke on television in the United States. **********In his speech today, Mr. Reagan painted an optimistic picture of progress on arms control and other aspects of Soviet-American relations. **********In contrast, Mr. Gorbachev, in a message to the American people handed to Joseph Kingsbury-Smith, national editor of the Hearst Newspapers, expressed disappointment over the arms control negotiations. Mr. Gorbachev said: **********''People in Washington should finally decide in utter clarity what they want: a runaway arms race or a reduction and elimination of weapons.'' **********In his New Year's speech to the Soviet people, Mr. Gorbachev said: **********''Good wishes alone are now not enough. Good deeds are also needed. Never before has the earth, our home, been subjected to such a danger. There are too many stockpiled weapons in it. These stockpiles should not be allowed to grow further, a catastrophe should not be allowed to happen.'' Deadlock on Arms Control Arms control talks in Geneva have been deadlocked since Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev agreed informally in Iceland in October on a 50 percent cut in all strategic nuclear forces over the next five years and on drastic reductions of Soviet and American medium-range missiles in Europe. **********A formal agreement in Iceland collapsed because the two men could not agree on a formula for limiting the development of space-based missile defenses. **********In the New Year's speech to the Soviet people today, Mr. Gorbachev also criticized the American refusal to join the Soviet Union in a halt of nuclear testing and the American decision to stop adhering informally to the strategic arms limitation treaty of 1979. **********''Deliberately and pointedly wrecking old treaties does not help the conduct of successful talks on new agreements,'' Mr. Gorbachev said. **********Most of his speech was devoted to what he called an encouraging start on efforts to revitalize the economy. **********He said the prospects engendered by the Iceland summit meeting had been set back by ''old conservative thinking'' by Western politicians. **********On domestic matters, he said the Soviet Union had ''laid the beginning for a comprehensive renewal of our society'' through greater openness in the press and in the arts as well as through economic change. **********But he warned that ''the forces of stagnation and complacency are still making themselves felt, some people still hope that everything will return to the old beaten track.'' ----Citizens Have Exchange In a live, four-hour radio program broadcast yesterday by radio stations in the United States and the Soviet Union, citizens of the two nations wished one another ''Happy New Year'' and the Russian equivalent, ''S novym godom.'' **********The program made no mention of the Soviet Union's rejection of an exchange of televised New Year's greetings between President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********Poets, children, singers, and classical, jazz and rock musicians from both countries performed and chatted. At one point, two cooks in New York and Moscow swapped recipes for New Year's specialties. **********The program was broadcast in New York over WBAI radio starting at 7 A.M. and over the Soviet radio network at 3 P.M. Moscow time. It included live broadcasts from other cities in both countries. **********The program, a joint production of the two radio stations, was part of a peace vigil that began worldwide at noon Greenwich time in London (7 A.M. Eastern Standard time).

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/world.main_headline: DEFEAT IS PRECICTED FOR THE GOVERNMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/world.print_headline: IRISH VOTES ARE CAST; DEFEAT IS PRECICTED FOR THE GOVERNMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/world.body_text: **********Irish voters cast ballots in a general election today, with opinion polls forecasting defeat for Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald and his Fine Gael party. **********But commentators said a pessimistic electorate could leave the favorite, former Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey, unable to form a government strong enough to jolt the country out of its economic woes of record debt and unemployment. Coalitions or minority Governments emerged from three previous elections over the last six years. **********Polls opened at 9 A.M. and closed at 9 P.M. A total of 459 candidates were seeking the 166 seats in Parliament. Vote counting begins 12 hours after polls close, and early results were expected by noon Wednesday. **********The Irish state radio reported ''a brisk turnout,'' and state television estimated 75 percent of those eligible voted. In the 1982 election the turnout was 72.8 percent. The Stakes for Leaders **********Absolute control of Parliament would signal a remarkable comeback by the 61-year-old Mr. Haughey and his Fianna Fail party. Mr. Haughey has served two abbreviated terms as Prime Minister, after each of which his political career was written off. **********For Mr. FitzGerald, also 61, an economist, defeat could end his political career. **********He won a place in history through his efforts to make peace in Northern Ireland, crowned by the British-Irish agreement of 1985. The accord for the first time gives mainly Roman Catholic Ireland a voice in running the British province, where Protestants outnumber Catholics 3 to 2.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/03/world.main_headline: Old Scourge Loses Ground In West Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/03/world.print_headline: Old Scourge Loses Ground In West Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/03/world.body_text: **********In the dusty mud brick villages around here, the medieval sight of a small child leading blind men linked by poles is becoming increasingly rare. **********For centuries, farmers here thought it was their destiny to go blind by middle age. **********More recently, scientists penetrating this remote part of West Africa discovered a link between what villagers called ''poor man's disease'' and microscopic parasites carried by river-bred flies. **********The reaction in villages like this one, where up to 20 percent of adult men were blind, was to abandon wide swaths of fertile land along riverbanks. **********Now onchocerciasis, or river blindness, appears to be under control. **********''Today over 90 percent of the program area is under control and the riverine area is safe for resettlement,'' said Ebrahim M. Samba, director of the Onchocerciasis Control Program, which is administered by the World Health Organization in Ouagadougou, the capital. ''Over three million children born in the last decade are fully protected from becoming blind.'' **********In Burkina Faso, the former Upper Volta, the West African nation hit hardest by the disease, the new mastery of the disease commonly known as ''oncho'' is changing the landscape. In a land rush, peasants have returned an estimated 1,000 square miles of fertile farmland to cultivation. Abandoned villages are being repopulated, and food production is climbing. **********Worldwide, varying stages of ''oncho'' affect an estimated 20 to 30 million people - in southern Mexico, the Pacific coastal regions of Guatemala, Colombia and Ecuador, the Orinoco river basin in Venezuela and Brazil, in Southern Yemen and in Africa from Senegal to Ethiopia. **********While malaria spreads largely unchecked through Africa, the successful ''oncho'' campaign involving helicopters, larvacides and extensive laboratory research may serve as an example for other health campaigns in the third world, scientists say. **********Since it was begun in 1974, the program has lifted the threat of river blindness from a core area comprising Benin, Burkina Faso, Ghana, Ivory Coast, Mali, Niger and Togo. Last year, the program was expanded to Guinea, Guinea Bissau, Senegal and Sierra Leone. **********In this village, southwest of Bobo Dioulasso, the country's second-largest city, and half a mile from the River Kou, river blindness is largely an unhappy memory. **********''There are very few blind people here now,'' Adama Sanon, Samandemi's village chief, said recently. **********The infection is borne by a black fly, aptly called Simulium damnosum. The fly's ''damnable'' nature came from its sting and its invisible cargo - larvae. **********In the human body, these larvae develop into threadlike worms. Lumped in nodules, the worms cause an itching so severe that ''oncho'' is one of only a handful of diseases that have been known to drive Africans to suicide. **********Moving through the body, the worms invade the eye. The buildup of dead worms in the eye eventually causes lesions and blindness. **********A new drug, ivermectin, is now undergoing field trials in Burkina Faso and appears to reverse the condition without adverse side effects. But, without controlling the carrier, medication cannot stop new infections. **********Since the black fly was the sole carrier and the worms had an estimated life of 15 to 18 years, scientists reasoned that the disease could be controlled if they could wipe out most of the flies for a 20-year period. **********In a program that has cost $200 million to date, a fleet of aircraft have flown weekly missions during the rainy season, spraying 11,000 miles of West African rivers with larvacides approved by independent ecologists. The fly fought back. New, resistant strains emerged and had to be countered with different larvacides. Winds, blowing across Africa from east to west, brought new flies into previously cleared areas. Scientists discovered that flies can travel 400 miles in a day on the wind. **********To stop reinvasion, the Oncho Program last year was expanded east, from a core area of 295,000 square miles to one of 502,000 square miles. **********While scientists do not talk of eradication, they believe that the problem now is sufficiently under control to start turning over monitoring responsibility to local authorities. **********''In 90 percent of the program area, the transmission of onchocerciasis has been interrupted,'' read a report prepared last year by the United States Agency for International Development. ''An estimated 27,000 cases of blindness have been prevented in Burkina Faso alone over the past decade.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/busin.body_text: **********DR. PETER HOFMANN, who lives in a Manhattan apartment building that was converted into a cooperative, was faced with a task recently that thousands of other apartment dwellers are faced with each year - finding a mortgage. Yet even though the sponsor of the conversion had arranged with one bank to supply mortgages in bulk to all of the tenants, Dr. Hofmann chose another. ''The bulk interest rate was 9 3/4 percent, but I'm only paying 9 percent,'' he said. ''The difference was significant.'' **********Others involved in cooperative conversions have discovered that the bulk mortgages they were offered had lower rates or had benefits that could not be obtained on an individual basis. Those people naturally chose the bank or savings and loan association that the sponsor of the cooperative had selected. **********The choice of a mortgagee is one of the most important made by individuals whose apartments are being converted to cooperative ownership. In most cases, buyers of apartments in new buildings constructed as cooperatives or condominiums must also obtain a mortgage to finance their purchase. **********In those situations, the sponsor will frequently make an arrangement with one or more financial institutions that agree to provide mortgages to anyone living in the building or to those who intend to move there. The institutions normally make a master appraisal and engineering study so that each purchaser will not have to go through this process individually. And while buyers are under no obligation to use that institution, they are generally encouraged to do so. **********''The sponsor or the builder tries to arrange some kind of bulk commitment through a local institution,'' said Paul Havemann, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage research company. ''It's likely to be the same bank that lent him money to rehab the deal. But there's no guarantee that this commitment will contain the most competitive terms.'' **********In previous years - particularly in the early 1980's, when rates were much higher - sponsors who had difficulty selling apartments arranged so-called buy-downs, in which they paid banks to offer more favorable rates to purchasers. But such buy-downs are rare today, when mortgage rates are just about returning to double-digit levels. **********Nevertheless, many sponsors and builders are still anxious to dispose of their apartment inventory and therefore try to make it easier for buyers to get financing through a bulk commitment. And when a rate advantage is not offered, other benefits may be included. **********''The sponsors may smooth the path for the borrowers,'' said Arthur Weinstein, a New York lawyer and vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives. ''They'll negotiate appraisal fees, closing costs and perhaps even points. Then there's the pure convenience of a bulk commitment.'' **********Some bulk mortgages eliminate the need for income or employment verification of buyers, which enables the application-to-commitment procedure to be completed in as little as 15 business days -typically less than half of the usual time. In addition, because of strength in numbers, less documentation may be required and representatives of the lender may be available on the premises to handle details of the transaction. **********''Under a bulk commitment, we offer more aggressive terms than we would offer typically on a walk-in basis,'' added Leonard N. Druger, executive vice president of Citicorp Homeowners Inc. in St. Louis. ''On a loan-to-value basis, we might offer 90 percent up to $400,000 on a bulk commitment, but only 90 percent up to $200,000 on a walk-in.'' **********In certain instances - sometimes by choice, sometimes by necessity - the sponsor will offer its own financing as another alternative to purchasers. This type of financing - known as a balloon mortgage - is often for a short term, perhaps two to five years, and requires a large payment at the end of the period. **********''Only a minority of the sponsors now take back and hold the mortgage,'' said Leslie Plump, a Long Island lawyer who represents a number of banks that participate in bulk mortgage commitments. ''Then they may try to peddle it to a bank or pick up a line of credit.'' **********Bulk commitments can also be obtained by a tenants committee, as well as by a sponsor or builder. **********''It all boils down to legwork by somebody,'' Mr. Weinstein said. ''I recommend that the tenants association stick together even after a deal has been struck and that it put banking on the agenda.'' **********But as Dr. Hofmann learned to his profit, a bulk commitment can at times be bettered by an individual willing to take the time and trouble to shop around. Of course, a careful analysis of the complex loan packages is necessary in order to make a meaningful comparison. Even if the bank offering the bulk mortgage is eventually chosen, you will have the peace of mind of knowing that it had the best terms available when a loan was needed to buy your apartment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/13/world.body_text: **********Two former White House officials involved in the Iran-contra affair have begun cooperating with the investigation by a special prosecutor, according to Federal investigators and people with knowledge of their accounts. **********The officials, Howard R. Teicher and David C. Fischer, have already been interviewed by investigators working for the prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh. **********Mr. Teicher, a former National Security Council staff member, is expected to testify before a Federal grand jury. He recently resigned from the White House and had been the senior director of political-military affairs at the council. **********Mr. Teicher and Col. Oliver L. North were among a handful of officials who traveled to Teheran in May 1986 to discuss the transfer of American arms and the fate of American hostages held in Lebanon. Mr. Teicher later helped brief President Reagan on the trip. **********A Federal law enforcement official said he understood that Mr. Fischer had assisted prosecutors in bringing conspiracy charges against the two Washington fund-raisers, Carl R. Channell and Richard R. Miller, who raised money for the contras. **********Mr. Channell and Mr. Miller recently pleaded guilty to charges involving solicitation of contributions for a nondeductible purpose: arming the rebels. **********From 1981 through March 1985, Mr. Fischer was Mr. Reagan's top personal aide, escorting visitors into the Oval Office to meet with the President and accompanying him on most trips. **********He resigned in 1985 and became a consultant to Mr. Miller's political consulting concern.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/world.main_headline: A CORNER OF INDIA STIRS HOPE FOR UNITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/world.print_headline: A CORNER OF INDIA STIRS HOPE FOR UNITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/world.body_text: **********Christian churches scattered in the hills of this remote corner of India summon their worshipers with a resonant brass gong. Hymns are sung slowly to the beat of old tribal drums. **********But last Sunday, the churches of the tiny territory of Mizoram were filled with prayers of a more urgent nature. Worshipers were asking for a safe and fair election to enable them to be accepted at last by their country. **********For 20 years, the heavily forested mountains of Mizoram were the scene of a secessionist insurgency led by a former government clerk, who spent most of that period in jail, under house arrest, in exile or in hiding. **********Last June, Laldenga, the guerrilla leader, reached a settlement with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi in which the rebels laid down their arms in return for his becoming interim Chief Minister of the territory. Mizoram was also promised elevation to the status of an Indian state. Elected in His Own Right **********On Monday, voters here elected the 59-year-old Mr. Laldenga as Chief Minister in his own right, dealing a blow to Mr. Gandhi's Congress Party but shoring up his hopes for national unity. **********Although there were charges of fraud and vote-buying by all parties before the election, the voting was eventually deemed peaceful by all parties. **********''We are going to have a new state, and we are going to have a new beginning,'' said C. Lawmsanga, a counselor in the tiny village of Muthi, a few miles from Aizawl. ''All of us hope that our lives will be improved.'' **********With its myriad religious, ethnic, linguistic and caste groupings, India faces a constant struggle for national integration. But few of its groups are more disaffected than the 50 million aboriginal tribespeople scattered in remote forests and mountain areas. **********Like tribal people elsewhere, the Mizos and others in the northeast have mixed emotions about their relationship with the rest of India. Feeling neglected, they also fear that development programs could attract outsiders and wipe out their distinctive identities. Protests Began in Famine **********A famine in Mizoram in 1959-60 spurred Mr. Laldenga and others to protest, and their movement became an outright rebellion as Mizos felt increasingly excluded and oppressed by New Delhi. **********In the last decade, the Mizo insurgency died out. But aides say Mr. Gandhi pursued a political accommodation because of an overall strategy to convince Indians that their grievances could be resolved in the framework of Indian unity. **********The approach has led to political accords with leaders of Punjab, Assam and Jammu and Kashmir, some of whom had earlier been jailed on charges of sedition. **********Mizoram, sandwiched between Burma and Bangladesh in India's northeast, is an unfamiliar and untraveled place even for Indians. Since the insurgency began in 1966, it has been closed to foreigners, although foreign reporters were permitted this week to observe the election. **********Isolation has brought certain rewards. Only 500,000 people live in an area roughly the size of Massachusetts. The thinly populated ridges are lush with orchids, teak, thorny bamboo and wild banana trees, and the mist that settles in the valleys makes the mornings serene and beautiful. Headhunting Once Common **********The Mizo people came here a few hundred years ago, perhaps from China or Upper Burma. Headhunting was once common. So were animist religious beliefs holding that the hills, trees, rocks and streams were inhabited by demons who delighted in creating trouble for mankind. **********Somehow, Hinduism passed by these hills as it spread across Southeast Asia. Mizoram was transformed instead by the arrival of Presbyterian missionaries from Wales in 1894. Within a few years, 90 percent of the Mizo people had converted to Christianity. **********The mixed heritage of tribal and Christian influences makes Mizoram and other parts of the northeast an anomaly. In the village of Muthi, a radio was blaring ''Jingle Bells,'' and afterward people were singing it by themselves. Inside another hut of grass and bamboo, a middle-aged man was strumming Western chords on a guitar. **********The Mizos never had a written script until the missionaries introduced Roman letters. Now Mizoram has one of the highest literacy rates in India. **********But it was not always easy to suppress old tribal customs. A certain religious value used to be attached to seducing a woman, for instance, and many tribal chiefs had concubines. Even today, sexual morals in Mizoram and elsewhere in the northeast are considered looser than in the rest of India. But the church has been able to curb promiscuity, largely because Mizos quickly wrested church leadership from the foreign missionaries. **********''In the olden days, people got drunk on rice beer and beat their wives,'' said the Rev. L. N. Ralte, executive secretary of the Mizoram Presbyterian Church. ''It was the Mizo Christians who thought this should be stopped, and it was.'' New Threats to Morality **********Now, Mr. Ralte said, new trends threaten the morality of the Mizo people. Videotapes, films and other materials are regularly smuggled in from Thailand through the jungles of Burma, along with what are considered corrupting Western values. **********Many young men and women here wear jeans and chic-looking blouses and skirts. Drugs and crime are a growing problem for the police, and much of the recent political campaign turned on issues of law and order. **********''The Christian missionaries are doing a very fine job,'' Chief Minister Laldenga said. ''But we have been a troubled area for a long time, affected by violence and corruption. We must have a program of social reformation.'' **********Indians elswhere are expected to be watching Mr. Laldenga's performance in office. Aides to Mr. Gandhi hope the Chief Minister's installation will help convince the leaders of other insurgent groups that they can settle their grievances with New Delhi peacefully. **********That may be a farfetched hope, given the rising violence by Sikh radicals in the northern state of Punjab and by dissidents elsewhere in India. Ban on Immigration Sought **********''After 40 years, our unity is wearing thinner and thinner,'' Mr. Laldenga said, referring to national unity, and he added that certain ''special protections'' should be established for aggrieved regions. For Mizoram, he favors a ban on immigration by Bengalis and other outside ethnic groups. **********The problem of unity remains especially acute in the northeast. In nearby Manipur and Nagaland, a leftist guerrilla organization is said to have at least 2,000 soldiers continuing a rebellion that has been going on since India's independence in 1947. **********Indian officials say that with Mr. Laldenga's ascension, they at least might be able to withdraw army troops from the area for use in suppressing insurgencies elsewhere.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/busin.body_text: **********The bull market in stocks, which five years ago began a climb that is still breaking records, has changed the face of corporate America. **********Since the rise began on Aug. 13, 1982, the market value of all stocks has swelled by $1.8 trillion - or about $1 billion a day, according to the Federal Reserve Board. **********Does this represent actual wealth? According to Franco Modigliani, the professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who won a Nobel prize in 1985, the value of a stock is determined mainly by what the company is expected to earn. **********But whatever causes the stock to rise, the results are quite real. ''The increase in stock prices has created a sense of wealth that has had a major and beneficial effect on the economy,'' said George L. Ball, chairman of Prudential-Bache Securities. ''You've got 40 million people owning stock, and they are feeling richer and spending more freely.'' **********In addition, this bull market - which has advanced faster in its first five years than any other - has brought about a takeover frenzy and led to a significant consolidation of American industries. It has shaken up complacent companies and ousted entrenched managers. And it has helped the economy by encouraging spending by consumers and businesses alike. **********This spending has financed start-up companies and helped to expand existing ones, flowed into the pockets of corporate raiders and made many investors a lot richer. **********''What we are seeing is the largest creation of wealth since the 19th century,'' said Donald B. Marron, chief executive of Paine Webber, Still, past performance is no indication of what will happen in the future. No one can say how long this bull market will last. And many Wall Street experts and economists are uneasy about the risks that seem to be part of today's market. **********In the rash of deal-making, corporations have loaded up on debt - either to fend off raiders or improve performance in the stock market. As money pours to Wall Street from foreign shores, serious questions have been raised about foreign investment in American companies. And while the rising market has enriched many, it has rekindled suspicions about ethics in business and led to cries to re-regulate industry and Wall Street. **********Since August 1982, the Dow Jones industrial average has risen more than 230 percent, to a high on Friday of 2,572.07. This year, the average of 30 major stocks has climbed 36 percent, hitting four consecutive highs last week alone. This bull market has been exceeded only by one that lasted from August 1921 until the crash of September 1929, when the market appreciated 496 percent, and by the run from June 1949 to December 1961, when stock prices rose 355 percent. Better Economic Times **********Today's bull market is the child of better economic times. It began as a recession was ending, interest rates started falling and American business became determined to improve its competitive position. **********When it will end is anyone's guess. Experts say the traditional signs of a dying bull market have not yet appeared: excessive optimism, heavy issuance of new stock and sudden participation by small investors who normally do not buy stock. **********Yet there are storm clouds in the form of an economy that continues to limp along, a Federal budget deficit of $119 billion so far this year and a stubborn trade deficit. Still, the market has continued to climb on improved corporate earnings, a stable dollar and reduced fears of inflation. **********On the popular level, business has captured the imagination of small investors, who are enjoying both real profits from appreciated stocks they have cashed in and paper profits from those they still hold. **********Stock and bond mutual funds - the primary investment vehicle of small investors - have swelled in value from $53.7 billion to $430 billion during the bull market, according to Lipper Analytical Services. At the same time, such businessmen as the Chrysler Corporation's chairman, Lee Iaccoca, and Steve Jobs, who helped start Apple Computer in a garage, have become modern American folk heroes. **********But the quest for wealth has also led to excesses that highlight the differences between rich and poor, insiders and outsiders. The spectacle of a 30-year-old Wall Street M.B.A. earning $300,000 a year and commuting by airplane to a weekend home in East Hampton stands in sharp contrast to the unemployed oil worker in Houston or the Middle Western farm family fighting to keep its land. **********This has begun to create a backlash in the form of anti-takeover legislation now being enacted in many states - particularly those where corporate takeovers have caused a loss of jobs. And it has prompted both social reformers and many on Wall Street to wonder if compensation on Wall Street is out of line. **********''The bull market has sharpened the difference between solid poverty and flamboyant luxury,'' said the Rev. William Sloane Coffin, who recently announced his resignation as senior minister at Riverside Church in New York to become president of a disarmament organization. ''These financiers don't produce anything. They make millions of dollars in a most non-creative fashion. They don't make products. They just shuffle papers very brilliantly.'' **********Many are troubled by rampant greed, especially when it has bred illegality, as in the case of Ivan F. Boesky, once a major player on Wall Street, who admitted last year to using inside information in picking stocks of takeover targets. **********The prospect of more investment from abroad has also created worry. Foreign investors, led by the Japanese, added about $18 billion to their holdings of American stocks in 1986 and $9.6 billion more in the first quarter this year - as a lower dollar made American stocks and other investments a bargain. Effect on Corporate America **********But the bull market's biggest effect has been on corporate America -whose net worth was dramatically increased by the market run-up, enabling it to engage in a variety of business maneuvers. **********This, plus lower interest costs, has prompted huge borrowing by corporations - to fend off raiders armed with equally low-cost debt or to engage in deals that made shareholders or management, or both, richer. In the last five years, corporate debt increased by some $700 billion, according to the Federal Reserve Board. **********Crafty investors and corporate chieftains learned that a rising equity market and reasonable borrowing costs could be a powerful combination. With a small amount of equity financing and a large amount of borrowed dollars, a small investor group could gain control of a company -and the earning power of its assets. **********In this environment, such companies as Beatrice and R. H. Macy & Company went private through multibillion-dollar leveraged buyouts. Revlon was taken over by a well-financed corporate raider. Uniroyal, Storer and Levi Strauss fended off raiders by borrowing heavily to go private, while Union Carbide borrowed to repurchase its own shares. A Shuffling of Assets **********The corporate shuffling of assets has touched every corner of business: from old-line concerns, such as USX, that have been streamlined to become more competitive to whole industries, such as the airline industry, that have been reshaped by mergers to the elimination of such familiar public companies as RCA, General Foods and Gulf Oil, all of which have been acquired. **********Critics say many of these deals have been constructed to reap financial gains for a few and do little to add productive business capacity or expand the nation's industrial base. And, say critics, they have pushed corporations far into debt, which in an economic downturn could transform today's leveraged buyout into tomorrow's bankruptcy. **********''People have taken advantage of an unprecedented opportunity to get a greater hold on the future earning power of corporate assets,'' said Kenneth Lipper, a former deputy mayor of New York and now a private investor. ''Managements have become preoccupied with getting a piece of the action and not in running a company. It's like: 'I build nothing. I own.' History will look back on this period with scorn.'' **********Much of this activity was facilitated by the advent of junk bonds -high-yield bonds issued by companies with low credit ratings. For corporate raiders and leveraged-buyout artists, the $92 billion junk bond market gave them financial firepower. **********Wall Street, meanwhile, has boomed from all this activity. Once an elite collection of private houses, investment firms have become huge public corporations with voracious appetites for capital and the ingenuity to capture it. **********Industry growth has been explosive - from 1.7 million employees at the end of 1982 to 2.3 million today. In the same time, industry capital, the best indicator of health, has increased sixfold, to $30 billion. **********But with size has come risk. The stock market itself has become more volatile with the advent of program trading - sophisticated computerized trading programs that allow big investors to hedge their bets in the stock market with positions in the options and futures markets. **********No less an industry leader than John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, warns that program trading could lead to a ''financial meltdown'' in which the market would drop by hundreds of points. Already, the market has been shaken by a stunning 115-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average in a 70-minute period on Jan. 23. **********Not only is the market riskier, but so is the business of Wall Street. Deregulation has cut margins on stock commissions, and new competition has eaten into the fees that firms earn for acting as corporate financial advisers. As a result, Wall Street houses are now pumping more of their own capital into bigger trading positions, into new offices overseas and into merchant banking activities in which investment houses put money into the deals they arrange. **********And problems have cropped up. Merrill Lynch & Company lost some $377 million on trading in the second quarter and Salomon Brothers, the nation's pre-eminent trading house, lost $100 million in its trading operations in April alone. Some also now feel they have overspent abroad. Shearson is reviewing its London staffing, while Salomon is trying to trim in London too. **********With risk, comes reward - and that is what motivates Wall Street now. But some worry that in light of the investment in buildings, employees and uncharted new businesses, Wall Street is vulnerable if the bull turns around. **********Warns Mr. Lipper, ''You move farther and farther out on the high wire, and when you fall, its a long way down.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/09/world.body_text: **********ISSUE: ARMS SHIPMENT - One of the most important questions facing the committee is the nature of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3rd's weekend fact-finding mission last November. Mr. Meese was present when Colonel North proposed that William J. Casey, the late Director of Central Intelligence, make the false statement to Congress that no one in the Government knew about the Iran arms shipment of November 1985. Colonel North said Mr. Meese knew the truth within weeks.  NORTH'S TESTIMONY - ''I do remember discussions which included the Attorney General subsequent to this event. I believe there was one that Mr. McFarlane referred me to in December... One of the issues that had already come up by then was a draft finding prepared in concert with Mr. Sporkin who was at the time the general counsel of the Central Intelligence Agency. I was led to believe or at least came to believe in 1985 that Mr. Sporkin had gotten the acquiescence or spport - either he or Director Casey - of the Attorney General in that November finding. The November finding specifically referred to prior actions.''  OTHERS' ACCOUNTS: Meese statement, released by his spokesman today - ''As to the arms shipments that took place prior to 1986, he did not learn about these until November 1986. The Attorney General was in no way involved with the November 1985 ''finding'' drafted by C.I.A. general consel Stanley Sporkin. . . . In fact, he did not know of any such November 1985 finding until a year later, in November 1986.''  ISSUE: CHRONOLOGIES - Another key issue is who ordered the falsification of chronologies to be used by the White House in presenting the Iran arms sales story. Colonel North attributes inaccurate statements about the November shipment to Robert C. McFarlane, the former National Security Adviser.  NORTH'S TESTIMONY - ''As I indicated earlier, I had gotten that language from Mr. McFarlane.''  Q. So you got the language from McFarlane. He persuaded you it was appropriate to put it in. You put it in.  A. Who is ''he?''  Q. McFarlane.  A. Yes.  OTHERS' ACCOUNTS - Mr. McFarlane testified that he assisted Colonel North in preparing the chronologies and that he acquiesed in some language prepared by others that he knew was ''technically wrong.'' He said, however, that it was Colonel North who directed the efforts of four to five people. He quoted Colonel North as saying: ''It looks to me like what we're putting together here will assure that the President isn't hurt by this.'' Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary for Inter-American Affairs, said this was because he had made a honest error and had not been told of Colonel North's role in the operation. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/08/busin.body_text: **********THE last frontier for cost-conscious American companies might be to explore maintenance operations, according to Michael Hora, a vice president at A. T. Kearney Inc., a management consulting firm. **********''Manufacturing techniques in this country generally are still at the stage of the early 1970's, and I would say that maintenance techniques are more than 35 years behind the times, dating back to the 1950's,'' he said in an interview. **********In recent years companies have been cutting costs in many areas to improve the bottom line - dismissing managers, trimming expense accounts, increasing productivity on assembly lines, requiring employees to pay a bigger share for benefits and using part-time workers. **********Until recently little attention has been focused on maintenance. Mr. Hora said he believed that more money needed to be spent on upgrading maintenance to ultimately save money through greater efficiency at the plant level. **********Maintenance supervisors are concerned with safety as well as with keeping machinery running efficiently and overseeing utilities. Mr. Hora would like to see their duties enlarged to include community safety with regard to waste disposal, for example. **********They should be constantly suggesting ways to improve maintenance procedures, Mr. Hora believes. But most supervisors do not have a direct link to top management, because for years their importance has been little realized, he said. **********Corporate organization charts vary widely but often the maintenance manager reports to the plant engineer, who reports to the plant manager, possibly a vice president. Generally, the top maintenance people have been engineers with degrees in mechanical, electrical or civil engineering. **********The maintenance manager might supervise groups of project engineers with responsibility for areas like the utility systems, the boilers, waste handling and repairs of machinery. Mechanics, carpenters, electricians, plumbers and others would work for the project engineers. **********Mr. Hora predicted that there would be ''more autonomous work teams with a maintenance person assigned to each.'' **********''I am thinking in terms of a team of operating, quality control, material handling and maintenance persons,'' he said. **********In years past the plant engineer or the maintenance manager often spent a lifetime in the job, with little chance of promotion, except possibly to the post of company engineer. **********Today, Mr. Hora suggested, maintenance engineers might be rotated, which means that they would spend a few years in the job and then move on to other company areas and presumably upward. **********''They do not all need to be engineers,'' he said, ''but could be holders of master of business administration degrees, accountants and even production people rotated through the job.'' They would bring fresh ideas, he explained. **********Indeed, Robert W. Lear, a former chief executive officer and the current executive-in-residence at the Columbia Business School, has long urged more young M.B.A.'s to take jobs working on factory floors at the start of their careers. He calls it a ''logical start on the pathway to top executive positions.'' **********Since so much can be done to improve maintenance, Mr. Hora said, the ideal candidates for top positions might have an engineering background and an M.B.A, along with the ability to sell improvement ideas directly to top management. **********Too much emphasis has been placed on making workers more productive and too little on keeping equipment parts on hand and readily available and on the purchasing of new types of equipment, he added. **********''There needs to be increased capital investment in equipment,'' he said, adding that maintenance people know this but often cannot make themselves heard. **********Mr. Hora has just completed a study for his firm, determining which companies out of 300 large ones have the best maintenance. In doing the study, he ''found no best corporation in terms of maintenance management'' but he did pinpoint seven excellent plants of large companies with regard to maintenance operations. **********The seven plants named for excellent maintenance techniques were: Allied Fibers, Moncure, N.C.; Alumax of South Carolina, Goose Creek, S.C.; Amoco Chemical Company, Decatur, Ala.; Frito-Lay Inc., Beloit, Wis.; Great Southern Paper, Cedar Springs, Ga.; Ore-Ida Foods Inc., Burley, Idaho, and Travenol Laboratories Inc., Marion, N.C. **********At these plants, he said, managements ''have recognized the contribution that maintenance can make to their companies' profitability and they have worked at becoming the best.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.print_headline: CONSUMER RATES; Yield Rise Is Expected
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.body_text: **********Yesterday's increase in the prime lending rates at a number of leading banks and thrift institutions, the second rise in just over a month and the fifth this year, sets the stage for another round of yield increases for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts. **********Yields on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were all up for the sixth consecutive week ended Wednesday. **********At the Treasury's closely watched bill auction, traders said the mixed results were a little misleading as strong investor demand for the new three-month bills resulted in a higher price and lower rate, a development contrary to the prevailing trend. The average discount rate for new three-month bills fell one-tenth of a percentage point, to 6.49, while the six-month bill rate rose 13 basis points, to 6.96 percent. **********Those wanting to defer reporting income until next year were attracted to the 1988 maturity. **********For the current week, The Bank Rate Monitor's national index shows the average yield for six-month certificates of deposit up one-tenth of a percentage point, to 7.19 percent, while the bank money market accounts, which compete with the money market mutual funds, are up 4 basis points, to 5.75 percent. **********For longer maturities, the rates for one-year and two-and-a-half-year certificates were up 11 basis points, to 7.60 percent and 8.03 percent, respectively. A five-year C.D. increased 9 basis points, to 8.55 percent. **********The Bank Rate Monitor said the ratio of increases to decreases grew to 57 to 1, from 36 to 1 last week. **********''With the new jump in the prime, you can expected yields on C.D.'s to rise another one-third point between now and Thanksgiving,'' Robert K. Heady of The Bank Rate Monitor said. Bank money market accounts during that time he added, will gain another 15 to 20 basis points. **********In the funds market, Donoghue's Money Fund Report said the seven-day taxable compounded average yield for a money-market mutual fund rose 11 basis points, to 6.66 percent, while the 30-day compounded average increased by the same amount, to 6.50 percent. **********The average number of days to maturity of securities held in portfolios stood unchanged at 38 days. **********Tax-free assets, Dongohue's said, rose by $514 million, to a total of $63.2 billion, while the assets of taxable money market funds during the same period increased by $337 million, to a total of $230.3 billion. **********In the taxable sector, consumer funds rose by $436 million, to a total $174.7 billion, with institutional fund assets off by $99 million, down to $55.5 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/19/busin.body_text: **********Treasury auctions this week start with today's sales of three-month and six-month bills, continue with a two-year note issue on Wednesday and end with a one-year bill issue on Thursday. **********In advance of today's auction, rates on outstanding Treasury bills were unusually low relative to other securities because of an influx of orders late last week from traders and investors who were seeking safe haven in the midst of plunging stock and bond prices. By late Friday, the outstanding three-month issue was 6.64 percent, down more than four-tenths of a percentage point, compared with 7.37 percent for six-month bills and 7.56 percent for one-year bills. **********In the note market, interest rates also fell on Friday, and the two-year issue was quoted by government securities dealers with a yield of about 9.09 percent. **********Elsewhere in the Treasury market, securities dealers doubt that Congress will increase the Treasury's authority to sell bonds with interest rates of more than 4 1/4 percent in time for the Oct. 28 announcement of details for a major Treasury financing in early November. **********Because the Treasury has the authority to sell only about $4.5 billion of unused bonds, dealers are speculating that the regular quarterly offering of about $9 billion of 30-year bonds in early November will be eliminated, while the size of 10-year note issues would be increased. That possibility has helped cause 30-year bonds and 10-year notes to trade at similar yields recently. In mid-September, before the problem was recognized, 30-year bonds had yields of about two-tenths of a percentage point more than 10-year notes. **********In the corporate market, interest rates are too high for many issuers' comfort. But there were signs Friday of improved investor demand, which could encourage more borrowers to sell debt, especially if they expect rates to continue rising. **********Apart from large underwritten offerings of new bonds, dealers note that investor demand is satisfied by unpublicized sales of medium-term notes, which increasing numbers of companies are offering continuously. This week, for example, the Metropolitan Federal Bank will begin offering up to $300 million of mortgage-backed notes due in 9 months to 10 years through Salomon Brothers Inc. as lead agent. Moody's Investors Service is expected to rate the notes Aaa. **********Local governments are also dismayed at high interest rates. Although three states have scheduled large bond sales this week, dealers remember that Hawaii canceled a similar sale last week because rates were too high. **********The following new debt issues are scheduled for sale this week:  TAXABLE  MONDAY  City of Wichita, Sedgwick County, Kan., $20.95 million of taxable collateralized mortgage bonds series 1987, NR/NR/NYR.
