https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/04/world.body_text: **********Israeli troops foiled an attempt by Palestinian guerrillas to land in northern Israel today. **********Reports from southern Lebanon said two guerrillas were killed and two captured, while a fifth escaped, private radio stations in the capital said. **********The incident took place off the coast of Naqura, a Lebanese town on the border with Israel. The Israelis were assisted by members of the Christian militia of the South Lebanon Army. **********The mainstream Shiite Moslem militia, Amal, said its fighters had foiled an Israeli attempt to land troops south of Tyre, the southern port. A communique said the Shiite militiamen fired at an Israeli gunboat that tried to land marines at a nearby beach.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/28/world.body_text: **********A group of dissidents and freed political prisoners has published the first issue of a new, unofficial journal of news and opinion and has asked the Soviet Government for permission to distribute copies in the Soviet Union and abroad. **********The magazine, called Glasnost, in honor of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proclaimed policy of freer expression, is apparently the first privately controlled periodical to be published openly in the Soviet Union. **********The 56-page inaugural issue, reproduced using typewriters and carbon paper for lack of a printing plant, is being withheld from distribution until early July to give Soviet officials a chance to react. **********Sergei Grigoryants, a literary critic released from prison in February after serving four years for his work on a clandestine human-rights journal, is the editor. He said 50 to 100 copies of the first issue would be distributed next month, whether or not the group received the requested permission. **********''We hope to do it with permission,'' he said. ''But we will do it anyway.'' Inspired by Gorbachev **********What sets the publication apart from ''samizdat,'' or ''self-published,'' newsletters that have long been part of the dissident underground is that the organizers, inspired by Mr. Gorbachev's call for greater openness, have set out to do everything out in the open. **********Mr. Girgoryants has notified the Communist Party Central Committee in writing of each step, including a planned news conference to inaugurate the magazine. On June 19, he sent officials copies of the first issue. **********It includes a reprint of an article by Andrei D. Sakharov, who Mr. Grigoryants said had agreed to appear at the news conference. Dr. Sakharov's article is an appeal for revisions in the Soviet Criminal Code and for release of political and religious prisoners. **********The issue of Glasnost also includes an article describing the growth of unofficial political discussion clubs in Moscow, reports on the Ukrainian Catholic Church and the underground human-rights organization Moscow Trust Group, and an annotated list of prisoners serving in Chistopol Prison, where Mr. Grigoryants was imprisoned until February. Plans for Publication **********Mr. Grigoryants said he and his collaboraters hoped to publish the magazine 36 times a year and would concentrate on problems that the official press overlooks, including human rights, emigration, prison conditions and religious affairs. Political and cultural reports will also be included. **********He said the organizers of the magazine had been offered financial support from both Soviet and foreign investors who wanted to reprint the magazine in Europe and the United States. **********Mr. Grigoryants says he sees the undertaking as a test of liberalization under Mr. Gorbachev. **********In a recent letter to the Central Committee, Mr. Grigoryants proposed to organize his magazine under a new law permitting individuals to start small-scale businesses. The law does not envision publishing ventures, but it does not rule them out, either. **********In addition to the magazine, Mr. Grigoryants said he and several friends planned to begin what he called a press club for free discussion of current events with public officials. In July, he said, the group will invite Soviet officials to discuss cases of would-be emigres who have been denied permission to leave the country because they once had access to secret information. **********Mr. Grigoryants acknowledges that without official authorization to hire printers and to buy paper, it will be extremely difficult to expand Glasnost beyond a limited circulation. He does not seem optimistic about getting active Government support but said,''We do hope that at least we can proceed without persecution.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/27/busin.main_headline: Miller, Tabak Deal For Penn Traffic
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/27/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Miller, Tabak Deal For Penn Traffic
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/27/busin.body_text: **********The Penn Traffic Company said it had agreed to be acquired by Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company. Under the agreement, an affiliate of Miller, Tabak would begin a tender offer to acquire all of Penn Traffic's shares for $31.60 each. There are 4.2 million shares outstanding. After completing the offer, the affiliate would merge with Penn Traffic and the remaining shares would be converted into the right to receive $31.60 in cash. **********Miller, Tabak owns 9 percent of Penn Traffic and was engaged in a proxy battle with the company last summer over defensive amendments the company had adopted. But it had never made an offer for the company, which is involved in supermarkets, dairy stores and shopping centers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/31/busin.main_headline: OFFER SEEN FOR ICHAN'S USX STAKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/31/busin.print_headline: OFFER SEEN FOR ICHAN'S USX STAKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/31/busin.body_text: **********Carl C. Icahn has turned down an offer from a foreign investor willing to pay a premium for the large Icahn holding in the USX Corporation, Wall Street sources said yesterday. **********The sources said that the buyout offer was made about a week ago by a group of small brokerage companies who said they were acting on behalf of a foreign investor. The sources would not say who the investor was. **********They said Mr. Icahn feared that if he accepted the offer, he would lose credibility on Wall Street, where he relies on his ability to raise huge amounts of financing. Greenmail Spurned **********To bolster his $8 billion offer to buy USX, Mr. Icahn stressed that he would not accept what is commonly known as greenmail by selling his stake of 29.3 million shares, or 11.4 percent of the company, at a premium. **********Through this stance, Mr. Icahn was able to persuade a wider group of investors to put up money for his offer, since he was assuring them he would not walk away with a higher profit for himself and his original group of backers. **********But Mr. Icahn was stymied in his bid to take over the huge oil and steel company by stalling actions instituted by David M. Roderick, the chairman of USX, who later also took measures that would make it more expensive to take over the company. Finally, Mr. Icahn withdrew his bid of $31 a share on Jan. 9, although he vowed to continue to seek control. Frustration for Mr. Icahn **********Now, the sources said, Mr. Icahn is frustrated and at a loss about what to do next to extricate himself from what so far has been his first significant defeat in an attempt to gain control of a major company. His most notable success was the acquisition of Trans World Airlines, which was nearly bankrupt when it was purchased and now is posting profits. **********Mr. Icahn is finding it difficult to dispose of his large USX stake, which has tied up more than $670 million. He is also paying interest on the funds borrowed to buy the stock. **********One leading foreign investor who has disclosed a strong interest in USX's shares in the past is Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian financier. He said last August that he intended to spend at least $15 million to buy USX stock and to acquire a stake of up to 15 percent. **********In October Mr. Roderick said that Mr. Holmes a Court has sold his $15 million investment, but Wall Street brokers said later that the investor was buying USX shares again. Little Leverage for Icahn **********Charles Bradford, the steel analyst for Merrill Lynch, said that there was little Mr. Icahn could do to press Mr. Roderick and the USX board of directors to do what he wants. The recent settlement of a strike by steelworkers against USX removes one element that had been seen as helpful for Mr. Icahn's bid. **********On the other hand, Mr. Bradford said that Mr. Icahn was in a good position to profit from his holdings if he was willing to hold on for the long term. **********He projected that USX would earn a modest $1 a share in 1987 from a small recovery in steel operations and that its oil division should also do better because of some firming of oil prices. In addition, he noted that a large part of Mr. Icahn's interest costs was offset by dividends paid by USX on the stock he owned. **********Thus, he concluded, Mr. Icahn could wait to see what developed at USX at small risk to his investment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/14/world.body_text: **********A $10 million donation from the Sultan of Brunei to the Nicaraguan rebels that was sent to the wrong Swiss bank account last August has been recovered by Swiss authorities, a spokesman for the bank said today. **********The bank, Credit Suisse, said in a communique that an investigating magistrate in Geneva last week froze all bank accounts belonging to the recipient of the misdeposited money, a businessman whose identity has not been made public. The magistrate took the action after the bank filed a charge of misappropriation of funds against the businessman, the bank said. **********''As a result, it was possible to recover the amount in question,'' the bank said. ''The decision as to how to proceed rests with the examining magistrate.'' **********Swiss officials have not identified the man, who was described as a wealthy Swiss shipping magnate by Sen. Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, who is chairman of the joint Congressional committee conducting hearings into the Iran-contra affair. **********Officials said privately, however, that the businessman is not Swiss but that he lives in Geneva and has shipping interests. The officials said the man had no previous connections with the Iran-contra affair. No Complaints About the Money **********There are at least seven large shipping concerns handling merchant ships in Switzerland, but officials suggested that the man might be a private shipping broker. **********The $10 million was sent at the request of the State Department and was erroneously deposited in the business executive's account when two of the first three digits of a nine-digit account number were transposed. **********Juerg Neef, a spokesman for Credit Suisse in Zurich, said the bank had had no reason to become suspicious or take any action before last week because neither the Sultan of Brunei nor the holders of the account that was supposed to receive the money had complained. **********The money was intended for deposit in a secret account run by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, then a National Security Council aide, and others in the private arms network. That account has since been frozen by authorities. Bank Became Concerned **********Credit Suisse became concerned, Mr. Neef said, when informed by Congressional investigators that the money might have been sent to the wrong account. On checking the account in which the money had been deposited, the spokesman said, the bank found that the $10 million was missing. **********In an effort to locate the money, Mr. Neef said, Credit Suisse filed a complaint with the investigating magistrate, Vladimir Stemberger, in Geneva and asked him to freeze the holdings of the account's owner. **********After ordering banks holding the individual's accounts to report the amounts, Mr. Stemberger said he interviewed the businessman and found him cooperative. ''He said right away where the money was placed,'' Mr. Stemberger said. ''He gave the information voluntarily.'' 'A Terrible Misunderstanding' **********Mr. Stemberger said the business executive explained that he had placed the money in another bank, believing that the money might have been a payment for the sale of a ship by one of his business partners. In that period, the money earned about $253,000 in interest, which was frozen along with the original deposit, Mr. Stemberger said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/16/world.main_headline: Iraqi Jets Hit at Bases Of Iranian Speedboats
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/16/world.print_headline: Iraqi Jets Hit at Bases Of Iranian Speedboats
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/16/world.body_text: **********Iraqi jets hit tiny islands and offshore oil platforms used as bases for Iran's Revolutionary Guard speedboat fleet for the third straight day today as tensions mounted in the Persian Gulf. **********With only a week remaining until Kuwaiti oil tankers sail under the American flag, bringing the injection of American fighting ships and sailors into the almost seven-year old Gulf war, an Iranian official said, ''We are ready to sink American ships.'' **********The official, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of Parliament, said Iran was ready for confrontation ''if the enemy got crazy.'' **********Four American naval ships, including a helicopter assault carrier and a landing force of 1,800 marines, passed through the Suez Canal this afternoon, but officials in Washington said they were headed for routine exercises in the Indian Ocean. **********The four-ship Marine landing force will arrive in the area simultaneously with the battleship Missouri and three escort ships, adding to a regional force that already includes an aircraft carrier battle group in the Arabian Sea and nine Navy ships to escort American-flag merchantmen, including the Kuwaiti tankers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/16/busin.body_text: **********Output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August, the seventh consecutive monthly advance, the Government said today. **********The Federal Reserve said the August increase was the smallest increase since a one-tenth of 1 percent rise in April. It followed much larger gains of eight-tenths of 1 percent in July and seven-tenths of 1 percent in both June and May. **********Analysts said the moderate August increase indicated that the nation's industrial sector was still recouping losses inflicted over a two-year period by heavy competition from foreign-made products. Rise Is 'Very Positive' **********''The August rise in industrial production is very positive, coming after last month's big increase,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ''The industrial expansion is now widespread and appears to be taking on a life of its own.'' **********And Cynthia Latta, an economist with Data Resources Inc. of Lexington, Mass., said, ''The rise in industrial production is consistent with the fact that the lower value of the dollar is benefiting American industry.'' **********The increase in industrial production in August was held back by an 11 percent drop in output of passenger cars. Autos were assembled at an annual rate of 5.9 million units in August, down from a July rate of 6.7 million units. **********Auto makers have been forced to reduce output and reinstitute incentive sales programs in an effort to reduce a huge backlog of unsold cars. The cut in production of passenger cars was offset, however, by a rise in output of light trucks. **********Output at all United States manufacturing plants rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August, one-third of July's increase of nine-tenths of 1 percent. **********Production at factories making durable goods, items expected to last three or more years, was up five-tenths of 1 percent while output of nondurable goods edged up one-tenth of 1 percent. **********Output of business equipment, which has grown rapidly this year, increased a sharp 1 percent in August. **********Richard Rahn, chief economist of Output at utilities was up four-tenths of 1 percent in August and stands 5.5 percent higher than a year ago. **********Over all, industrial production is 4.5 percent higher than a year earlier, with the index standing at 130.7 percent of its 1977 base of 100.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/busin.main_headline: Tide Is Out for Risky Debt
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/busin.print_headline: Tide Is Out for Risky Debt
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/busin.body_text: **********The last month has been a tough time for the junk bond market as the drop in the stock market and fears of a recession discouraged many buyers. That anxiety culminated Tuesday in the withdrawal of a proposed $1.5 billion financing for the Southland Corporation. **********While many analysts said the Southland financing was plagued by a fundamental problem of too many bonds backed by a company with too little earnings, they agreed that its problems were compounded by the generally negative conditions for the entire market of high-yielding, high-risk issues known as junk bonds. **********When stock prices fell sharply in October, yields of junk bonds rose as investors worried that the stock market decline would lead to a cutback in consumer spending that would, in turn, cause a recession. A recession is the best environment for Treasury bonds, whose prices rise on the prospect of declining inflation and interest rates, but it is the worst environment for junk bonds. Buyers of junk bonds worry more about whether corporations can pay interest and principal on their bonds if revenues weaken in a recession. Most Important Question **********''The most important question for the market is whether the economy is going into a recession or will it muddle along with modest or slow growth,'' said John A. Utter, portfolio manager of the IDS Extra Income Fund, a $1 billion mutual fund specializing in junk bonds. ''If there is nothing worse than a growth recession, then I expect the market for low-grade bonds will bounce back.'' But if there is a full-fledged recession, Mr. Utter said, ''then low-grade issues will underperform the rest of the bond market.'' **********The next economic recession, whenever it comes, will mark the most severe test of the junk bond market since it has grown from a backwater of the financial markets to a $150 billion market whose investors include thousands of mutual funds, savings and loans associations and insurance companies. No one knows how many issues may default, but many analysts expect that the rate of failure for junk bonds will exceed the historical average of about 1 1/2 percent of all outstanding issues. **********But investors have willingly accepted that risk in recent years, lured by the promise of high interest rates. Bond yields vary widely, but many junk issues are now above 14 percent, rising to more than 18 percent for riskier issues. **********According to data compiled by Kidder, Peabody & Company, 10-year single-B rated bonds of industrial companies averaged about 14.83 percent on Oct. 27, up from 13.74 percent just two weeks earlier. Market sources said the Southland financing would have offered even higher interest rates, of 15 1/2 percent and 16 1/4 percent on interest bearing bonds due in 1997 and 2002, respectively. Many Move Back In **********Since late October, analysts noted that many investors have been moving back into the high-yield market, despite their cautious response to the Southland offering. Prices of most issues have recovered from their lowest points and gained more ground after the Southland offering was canceled. **********At Drexel Burnham Lambert, the largest trader and underwriter of junk bonds, a spokesman said that yesterday ''was one of our busiest days in two years, with heavy volume and broad-based buying.'' Besides the demand from investors who were prepared to buy the Southland offering, he said that up to $3 billion of outstanding junk bonds had been retired in the last few weeks, adding to the amount of funds investors have available for buying other issues. **********Solomon Samson, an analyst at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said that ''it's too early to ring the death knell on the junk bond market, or to assume that defaults won't come.'' He stood by a conclusion he reached earlier this year that junk bond issues of the last few years are more risky than earlier ones and ''could translate into higher default rates than in the past.'' **********He also estimated earlier this year that, over all, the performance of junk bonds over time ''will fall short of expectations'' and buyers of junk bonds may eventually return to more conservative investments. **********Donald P. Brennan, meanwhile, head of merchant banking at Morgan Stanley & Company, said, ''I would not read too much into the Southland financing as to the health or sickness of the entire high-yield market,'' 'Deals Have to Be Sensible' **********While the collapse of the stock market has led to a pause in junk bond financing, Mr. Brennan said he expected to see more corporate buyouts financed by junk bonds. ''But the deals have to be sensible, and within the company's ability to service the debt,'' he said. Several institutional investors who declined to buy the Southland bonds said they were not pulling back from all junk bonds, but were just not satisfied with the Southland financing, particularly the $650 million of bonds that would pay no interest for five years or pay interest in the form of other bonds rather than cash. **********Many investors and securities dealers said that the Southland financing was struggling even before the drop in stock prices made investors more wary of junk bonds. **********Raymond E. Neidle, a senior securities analyst at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, a New York credit rating firm, said that ''the company's earnings projections seemed to be on the optimistic side, especially since the interest rates on the bonds were going to be higher than they earlier assumed.'' **********Mr. Neidle noted that Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers, Southland's lead underwriters, did not plan to retain an equity interest in Southland, ''which is a negative factor for many investors who like to see more of a commitment to the company on the part of the underwriters.'' The two firms planned to use proceeds from the junk bond sale to repay $600 million in short-term ''bridge'' loans they arranged for Southland, including about $100 million each on their own books. Investors Being Selective **********While the rise in bond yields is a clear sign that investors see more risks, traders noted that investors were being more selective but were not fleeing the market. In the last few weeks, they have been trying to buy bonds of those companies they think will weather a recession better than others. **********''We see some tiering in the market as investors distinguish between the issues that should fare well in a recession and those which might be harder hit,'' said Robert Levine, head of high-yield bond research at Kidder, Peabody. **********For the issues that investors regard as the least risky in the junk bond category, prices have bounced back sharply from their lows set on Oct. 19. For example, a Colt Industries 12 1/2 percent issue due in 2001 was offered yesterday at 102 1/4, up from as low as 89 3/4 on Oct. 19, when the stock market and all junk bond prices plummeted. In fact, the Colt issue is now higher than before the Oct. 19 decline. **********But other issues are still treated skeptically by investors. Fruehauf, a supplier to the automobile industry and lessor of truck trailers and containers, is among the companies regarded as vulnerable to a recession. Its 13 3/4 percent securities due in 1996 were offered yesterday at a price of 72, up from 68 on Oct. 23 but still below the price of 81 7/8 in trading on Oct. 16. **********Raymond Lemanski, a vice president at Prudential-Bache Securities, said that, despite fears of a weaker economy and the problems of the Southland financing, there were other reasons to expect that corporate takeovers would continue and might still be financed by junk bonds. He said that interest rates on bank loans, which finance half or more of many leveraged buyouts, had declined. At the same time, the drop in the stock market has reduced the purchase price of many companies. Those two factors ''should more than compensate for higher interest rates on the junk bonds,'' he said. **********Even if large public offerings of junk bonds are more difficult now, those bonds may still be issued in exchange for common stock of a takeover target. Investment bankers have already proposed issuing junk bonds as partial payment for stock of the CNW Corporation and the Seaman Furniture Company. **********The risks faced by companies that issued junk bonds in anticipation of asset sales have also been exaggerated, according to many analysts. For example, Mr. Brennan said that Burlington Industries - which issued $1.7 billion of junk bonds before the market collapsed in September to finance a leveraged buyout arranged in April, when the Dow Jones industrial average was around 2,100, had not encountered difficulties in selling assets since the stock market declined in October.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/18/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration will consider policies to block foreign takeovers of companies in security-sensitive industries, officials said today. **********''I think there would be quite a lot of support for that position,'' Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said. **********A Japanese company, Fujitsu Ltd. announced Monday that it had abandoned its proposed takeover of the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation in California, following opposition by the Pentagon, the Commerce Department and the Central Intelligence Agency. **********Japanese officials said Mr. Baldrige's public criticism of the deal contributed to its cancellation. His position appears to mark a movement toward an Administration policy of putting some American companies off limits to foreign investors. Specific Guidelines Sought **********''I just get the feeling it's an idea whose time has come,'' Mr. Baldrige said. He and other officials he declined to name want the Administration to fix specific guidelines for preventing such takeovers, he said, which would apply to only a ''tiny minority'' of the total. **********''Everybody wants an open investment policy,'' he said, ''but there have to be some exceptions for the national interest.'' **********A senior official who asked not to be named but who played a central role in the opposition to purchase of Fairchild said, ''I think there's a strong sentiment here that some industries are not totally up for grabs.'' **********''Two of the most visible are semiconductor and computer companies,'' he said, but there are others as well, including those that use exclusive American technology in making weapons and special components and materials for weapons. Japanese Reiterate Pledge **********Japanese officials, stung by the collapse of the Fujitsu-Fairchild deal, reiterated that Japan was doing its best to enforce the much-debated semiconductor agreement between the two nations. The United States has threatened to scuttle the agreement unless Japan assures that companies are abiding by it.  [ Page D6. ]  In Washington, the Japanese Embassy's economic counselor, Yoshiji Nogami, said, ''We regret that there have been a number of unwarranted criticisms raised by some Administration officials.'' He said Japan favord the unimpeded flow of capital among nations. Administration officials, however, were quick to observe that Japan restricts foreign investment in its economy. **********Mr. Baldrige and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger are expected to bring the takeover issue before a top-level, interagency policy-setting group, such as Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d's Economic Policy Council or the President's National Security Council. **********For the moment, however, the White House said the Administration's official noninterventionist policy remained the same. ''So far as I know, there has been no change in our position,'' said Albert R. Brashear, a spokesman for the President. Advocates of Free Market **********Until the Fairchild takeover was proposed last fall, the Administration had been an unequivocal proponent of foreign investment in the United States, a position consistent with the President's free-market views. Some senior officials, notably in the Treasury and the President's Council of Economic Advisers, still espouse those views. **********No laws prohibit foreign takeovers, and top Government officials had never discouraged one until now. But even without a Federal proscription against some takeovers, the Fujitsu-Fairchild episode shows that jawboning can have the same effect. **********The thwarted deal has a bargaining-ploy dimension: Officials of the Administration are irked by what it sees as Japanese violations of trade agreements, particularly in the area of computers and semiconductors. They could therefore be trying to force compliance by obstructing Japanese investment in American industry and real estate that has made the country one of the biggest foreign investors in the United States. Japanese Predominance Feared **********But beyond such trade matters is the Administration's discomfort over Japan's emerging power in computers, of which Fujitsu is an important producer, and in semiconductors that make all electronic equipment run, from computers and fighter planes to video recorders and digital watches. **********The Defense Department's concern, officials there say, is fear of the loss of an American-owned source of supply. The Commerce Department shares that concern and worries about losing an American position in a major world industry. **********Both are concerned because the semiconductor industry, in particular, has been battered by soft sales and Japanese competition. Depressed prices of the industry's common stocks could make its companies especially vulnerable to takeover.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/15/world.main_headline: Italy's Government Falls as Small Party Quits
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/15/world.print_headline: Italy's Government Falls as Small Party Quits
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/15/world.body_text: **********The 15-week-old Government of Prime Minister Giovanni Goria resigned today after the small Liberal Party withdrew from the governing coalition in a dispute over measures to reduce the huge budget deficit. **********Senior politicians said it was unclear whether a quick solution would be found by forming a new government without the Liberals or whether Italy faced a long political crisis that would produce major leadership changes. **********The Goria Government collapsed just as it was trying to contend with a looming economic crisis, a wave of labor unrest and the establishment of an Italian naval presence in the Persian Gulf. **********The Liberals, who won only 2.1 percent of the vote in national elections in June and hold only 14 seats in Parliament, announced on Friday night that they would withdraw from the five-party coalition. The decision followed a week of negotiations aimed at resolving differences over the Government's finance bill. **********At issue was a revision of the bill that eliminated a proposed income tax cut to help lower the Government's deficit. The Liberals maintained that the coalition's basic agreement on policy envisioned deficit reduction through cutting spending rather than increasing revenues. **********The Government's proposal aimed at bringing the 1988 borrowing requirement to $84 billion, from an estimated $89 billion this year. Italy has the largest official budget deficit in proportion to the size of its economy of any major Western industrial nation. **********In addition to the Liberals, several of Italy's top bankers, leading businessmen and the major trade union federations had all found fault with the limited budget reduction program proposed by Mr. Goria, who was Italy's youngest Prime Minister when he took office July 28 at the age of 44. **********Cesare Romiti, managing director of the Fiat company, said this week that the finance proposal was ''absolutely inadequate.'' Confindustria, an industrialists' association, warned that the budget deficit would speed a ''very deep crisis'' as a result of recent events in the world's stock martkets. And Italy's three major trade union federations called a four-hour general strike for Nov. 25 to protest the elimination of the income tax cut. **********As Mr. Goria, a Christian Democrat, went to the Quirinal Palace today to tender his Government's resignation to President Francesco Cossiga, some politicians speculated as to whether broader political designs were behind the collapse of the coalition of Christian Democrats, Socialists, Social Democrats, Liberals and Republicans. **********Even without the Liberals, who represent conservative views, the four remaining parties could form a government with a comfortable majority in Parliament, but no major party leaders would commit themselves to that option today. **********Senator Nino Andreatta, chairman of the Senate budget committee, said: ''If there are no secret plans, this crisis should be easily overcome. If it is not overcome quickly, it means that from the start there were secret political plans.'' **********On Friday leaders of the five coalition parties agreed to re-examine the finance bill, and the collapse of the Government seemed to have been averted. But a few hours later the Liberals announced that they were withdrawing in any case. **********That turn of events has fueled the speculation that a plan to unseat Mr. Goria involving several political parties lies behind the Government's fall. **********President Cossiga announced today that he would begin the traditional round of consultations with party leaders on Sunday while Mr. Goria remains in office as a caretaker.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/06/world.main_headline: ONE BARGAINING CHIP: A U.S.-SOVIET WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/06/world.print_headline: ONE BARGAINING CHIP: A U.S.-SOVIET WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/06/world.body_text: **********At different points, Albert Hakim was asked about pledges to provide American aid in ousting the President of Iraq and in fighting the Russians if they invaded Iran. **********ARTHUR L. LIMAN. This was the meeting in Germany? **********A. Yes sir. **********Q. Now, if you look at it, it says on one of the points: As I said in Brussels, we will fight Russians in Iran in case of invasion with or without Government of Iran assistance. Who is the I? Is that Secord? **********A. It says U.S., Mr. Liman - **********Q. Oh, that's U.S.? **********A. U.S. will - **********Q. United States will fight the Russians, not - **********A. That's my understanding. . . . **********Q. And the I who is saying this to the Iranians is General Secord? **********A. Yes sir. **********Q. And were you present when he was committing to the Iranians that we would go to war with the Russians if they invaded Iran? **********A. The way I recall this, Mr. Liman, it was a bargaining method that General Secord used to get the attention of the Iranians.  * * * **********Q. And you had warned General Secord and Colonel North that it was important to deal straight with the Iranians. Is that so? **********A. . . . Yes. **********Q. And you were there when General Secord was making these kinds of statements and giving these kinds of assurances to representatives of the Iranian Government? **********A. I was there.  * * * **********Q. And I'm also correct that Secord wrote and said to the Iranians, We will cooperate to depose the leader, the President of Iraq?  * * * **********A. He left these with me to use as ideas for patching up things. **********Q. Was it you who was saying that we will cooperate to depose - **********A. No. General Secord wrote this. **********Q. And it was General Secord who also said it, wasn't it? **********A. I think it was more than Secord . . . it was the attitude of the total delegation.  * * * **********Q. Now is the we - we will cooperate - is that the enterprise or is that again the United States of America? **********A. My understanding is the U.S. **********Q. Did you find it surprising that General Secord, a private citizen and a lieutenant colonel . . . could . . . make these kinds of representations to the leader of the Iranian delegation? **********A. My impression, Mr. Liman, was . . . that the President of the United States was supporting this mission. It was cleared with him. . . . **********Q. But in fairness, you got that impression because Colonel North dropped the name of the President and because he had the kind of access in the White House that he had and because he could deliver the TOW's and the Hawks and the other things that were promised, right? **********A. Yes. **********Q. I mean, it wasn't because General Secord told you that he'd met with the President. Because he's made it clear he didn't? **********A. That's correct, sir.  * * * **********SENATOR SAM NUNN. As an American citizen, did it bother you that a retired general, and a lieutenant colonel on the N.S.C. staff, and a businessman, were holding out to the Iranian delegation that America would get involved in a war . . . against the Soviet Union . . . and that we would also cooperate with them to depose the President of Iraq? . . . **********A. If I believed at the time that Colonel North and General Secord did not have the approval of the higher-ups to attend these meetings, it would definitely have bothered me. But I was continuously under the impression that they had the authority to participate. . . . **********Q. So you thought they were really speaking for the President. . . . **********A. That was my impression.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/12/world.body_text: **********The South African Government published a bill in the white-dominated Parliament today that would give some blacks a chance to vote for a national multiracial advisory organization that would draw up a new constitution. **********The proposed organization, widely criticized as racist by anti-apartheid groups campaigning for universal franchise in a central parliament, would have neither executive nor legislative powers. **********The bill, a revised version of a measure published a year ago, seeks to establish a national council headed by President P. W. Botha. **********It differs from the original draft in that it provides for the election of nine black representatives elected by an estimated 8 to 12 million blacks who fall outside the political jurisdiction of four nominally independent black states and six semi-autonomous tribally defined black homelands. At least half the black population of 25 million would thus be ineligible to vote for the proposed council, a factor likely to insure a boycott of the voting by black nationalists. Outside Tribal Areas **********Under the terms of the bill, every black citizen over 18 who is ''ordinarily resident'' in South Africa, but outside the tribal homelands, will be entitled to vote for the organization. **********South Africa's three million people of mixed race, known as coloreds, and one million Indians have political representation in junior houses of the white-dominated Parliament, where lawmakers elected by the country's five million whites are in a clear majority. **********Blacks are not represented in the central Government. **********The proposed council, presented by Government spokesmen as proof of their commitment to negotiate with those they call moderate black leaders, has so far not attracted any credible moderates. Buthelezi May Participate **********But Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, the leader of six million Zulus, has hinted that he might be prepared to take part in the council if certain conditions are met. **********The most important of these is the release from prison of the jailed leader of the African National Congress, Nelson R. Mandela, who has served 25 years of a life sentence for his role in a bid to overthrow the Government. **********The Constitutional Development and Planning Minister, Jan C. Heunis, said today that the proposed national council would have an ''open agenda'' with the sole purpose of negotiating a new constitutional dispensation. He described the bill as ''one of the most fundamental reform measures'' in the history of South Africa. Congress to Be Excluded **********Analysts said that the outlawed African National Congress would be excluded from participating, but the anti-apartheid United Democratic Front, a coalition of two million members that shares political goals with the congress, would be able to participate if it chooses. **********The Pretoria Government also announced today that it had approved the ending of racial disparity in the wages of an estimated 680,000 public service employees - about 390,000 of them black - by March 1 next year and had published a bill providing for parity in service conditions for 200,000 transport workers, about 110,000 of whom are blacks. **********In the South African-controlled territory of South-West Africa today, a court ordered the immediate release of six leading figures of the guerrilla-backed South West Africa People's Organisation, the black nationalist movement fighting a 21-year-old guerrilla war against South African rule. The six, who included the group's vice president, Hendrik Witbooi; national chairman, Daniel Tjongarero, and foreign affairs spokesman, Nikolaas Bessinger, as well as officials of affiliated trade unions, were detained in a police crackdown last month under a security law that allows indefinite detention for interrogation. **********It was the first time that a court in the territory, widely known as Namibia, had freed prisoners under the Terrorism Act, as the law is known.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/world.main_headline: Saudi King Denounces Iran Stand On Ending the Persian Gulf War
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/world.print_headline: Saudi King Denounces Iran Stand On Ending the Persian Gulf War
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/world.body_text: **********King Fahd told a meeting of Arab leaders from the Persian Gulf today that Iran's conditions for ending its war with Iraq are unreasonable and that prolonging the war could drag their nations into it. **********''Force will not solve the problem because every power will have to defend itself and, what would be worse, some countries might seek help from other powers,'' the Saudi monarch told the opening session of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council summit meeting. **********The leaders of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain, Oman and the United Arab Emirates planned to meet for four days, with the Iran-Iraq war and Persian Gulf shipping attacks at the top of the agenda. **********King Fahd said the seven-year Iran-Iraq war will end one day, ''but why wait till the war annihilates everything?'' **********''It would make better sense,'' he said, ''to end it without delay, rather than wait for it to engulf all in its flames.'' Iran's Stand 'Unreasonable' **********The King said Iran's conditions for ending the war ''are unreasonable and unacceptable.'' Iran has demanded that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq be removed and that Iraq and its Arab backers pay Iran enormous sums in war reparations. **********''Conditions come after the war ends,'' King Fahd said. He praised Iraq, which has said it can accept a United Nations Security Council resolution seeking a cease-fire. Iran has failed to embrace the resolution. **********Syria's Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, arrived in the Saudi capital just before the meeting opened at Riyadh's ornate domed Conference Hall. His country is Iran's main ally among the Arab countries, and the gulf council countries have been pressing Syria to mediate with Teheran for an end to the war. Diplomatic Offensive Sought **********Knowledgeable officials said Saudi Arabia and Kuwait would press the council members for a diplomatic offensive to persuade world powers to support an arms embargo against Iran. They said the United Arab Emirates and Oman preferred to start a dialogue with the Iranian Government. **********Before the Saudi king spoke, other leaders of the council, a group based on a 6-year-old economic integration and defense pact, stressed the need for their combined action to ward off the perils of the war. **********The President of the United Arab Emirates, Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahyan, said the meeting was being held ''under extremely sensitive and difficult circumstances, necessitating prompt action to confront the challenges that have adversely affected our region.'' **********The Emir of Bahrain, Sheik Isa bin Salman Al Khalifa, also spoke of ''enormous challenges'' besetting the Arabs of the gulf region and called for deliberations among gulf allies to face ''these regional and international menaces.'' Half the World's Oil **********Others attending the summit meeting, the council's eighth, included Sultan Qaboos of Oman, and Sheiks Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah of Kuwait and Khalifa bin Hamad al-Thani of Qatar. **********The gulf council nations account for about 50 percent of the world's proven oil reserves. They profess neutrality in the Iran-Iraq war, but Iran accuses them of a bias toward Iraq, singling out Saudi Arabia and Kuwait for purportedly pouring more than $38 billion into Iraqi coffers since 1980. **********The summit is under the shadow of the worst phase of the so-called tanker war in the gulf. At least 26 ships have been raided by Iran or Iraq this month. **********The leadership in Teheran has warned the gulf Arab powers that the region's shipping routes will be insecure unless they can persuade the Iraqis to cease air strikes on Iranian shipping. U.S. Strengthens Presence **********The United States and five Western allies, along with the Soviet Union, have strengthened their naval presence in the region since the summer. **********Kuwait has registered 11 tankers in the United States to gain U.S. warship protection against Iranian attacks. **********The Emirates President, Sheik Zayed, told Saudi reporters that an end to the gulf war could be reached by dialogue. **********He repeated his call for a peace mission by three neutral Arab leaders ''to underwrite the rights of Iran and Iraq.'' **********''If the two sides accept this, then we can demand a cease-fire and a withdrawal of troops back to their barracks. Afterward, arbitrators acceptable to all would begin to define the rights and dues of each side. These rights are to be guaranteed by kings and heads of state, including us.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/30/world.main_headline: AMERICAN DIED IN REBEL AMBUSH, NICARAGUA SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/30/world.print_headline: AMERICAN DIED IN REBEL AMBUSH, NICARAGUA SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/30/world.body_text: **********An American civilian who was killed in northern Nicaragua was a victim of an ambush by United States-backed rebels, the Government said today. **********The report, carried in the official Sandinista newspaper Barricada, contradicted a communique issued late Tuesday by the Foreign Ministry, which said the American, Benjamin Ernest Linder, 27 years old, had been abducted and later executed. **********American diplomats said the version published today was probably correct. **********Barricada quoted a survivor of the ambush as having said Mr. Linder and two Nicaraguans, Paulo Rosales and Sergio Hernandez, died when rebels attacked a Government work crew with grenades and gunfire. **********Mr. Linder was apparently the first American civilian to be killed in the fighting in Nicaragua. Thousands of such volunteers have come here to work on a variety of projects, partly as a way to show their repudiation of United States support for the rebels, who are known as contras. Rebels Awaiting Details **********In a telephone interview from Miami, Marta Sacasa, a spokeswoman for the main contra force, said she had not yet received details of the incident in which Mr. Linder was killed. ''Obviously, the project he was working on was protected by militia or by the Sandinista Army, and we have said in the past that we consider any armed group to be a target,'' she said. **********In Honduras, Mrs. Sacasa's organization, the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, issued a statement saying Mr. Linder had been killed in ''a firefight between one of our patrols and a group of militia of the Sandinista army.' **********The Nicaraguan Democratic Force, the statement said, ''holds the Marxist Leninist regime of Nicaragua responsible for the death of the U.S. citizen by allowing him to enter an area of civil war in our country.'' **********Before dawn today Mr. Linder's body was taken to the city of Matagalpa from the remote part of Jinotega province where he was killed. It was to remain there until the arrival of his parents, who were expected in Managua on Thursday. **********Friends said Mr. Linder had expressed the desire to be buried in Nicaragua if he were to die here. **********More than 100 Americans and other foreigners marched in front of the United States Embassy in Managua today, chanting slogans and carrying signs that read, ''Stop the Spilling of Innocent Blood'' and ''Help Peace Come to Nicaragua.'' **********Six of the protesters were admitted to the embassy and met with Ambassador Harry Bergold for about 40 minutes. ''It went cordially,'' said Laura Enriquez, one of the Americans who took part in the meeting. ''He said it was a tragedy, that he regretted it had happened, and that he was sorry he had to receive us under these circumstances.'' U.S. Is Held Responsible **********Speakers at the demonstration said the United States was responsible for Mr. Linder's death because American funds support the contras. **********Mr. Linder was a mechanical engineer who had been living in the village of El Cua, 30 miles from the Honduran border, while directing a series of rural developmental projects. For five years, rebel activity in the area has been almost constant. **********Three days before the ambush in which Mr. Linder was killed, a group of contras attacked a government dairy project nearby, killing two people. **********Several land mines have exploded under vehicles passing through the area, including one on July 3 that took 34 lives. According to diplomats, the mines were planted by contra squads. **********''If you want to pick the most dangerous area in Nicaragua for Americans to be running around, that would be in for a good candidate,'' said Alfred Laun, a spokesman for the American Embassy here. **********It was unclear whether Mr. Linder or his co-workers had been armed. In an interview in El Cua last year, Mr. Linder said he sometimes carried a weapon or was accompanied by someone who did. **********In several conversations, Mr. Linder said he understood the risks he ran by remaining so long in such an area. He said he believed his training was better used in an isolated and impoverished place like northern Nicaragua than in the United States. **********Mr. Linder lived in a shack on the outskirts of El Cua, which has a population of about 3,000. With his reddish beard and jeans caked with mud, he appeared quite popular in the town. Residents recognized him as the person mainly responsible for the construction of a 100-kilowatt hydroelectric plant that opened in El Cua last May, bringing electric power to the town for the first time. **********''The last time I talked to him, he was talking about starting a forestry project, and he wanted me to come up and work with him,'' said Howard Hiner, an American who lived in Nicaragua. ''He was always coming up with something.'' **********Although there are no official figures for the number of Americans in Nicaragua, officials today gave estimates ranging from 1,500 to 3,000. Dangerous Areas Out of Bounds **********Mr. Linder was the 10th foreign-born civilian to die in the Nicaraguan conflict, according to Government figures. In October, the Government imposed new restrictions intended to keep foreign volunteers out of dangerous areas. But those restrictions applied only to projects officially sponsored by foreign governments, and were not enforced in the cases of individual volunteers like Mr. Linder. **********One of Mr. Linder's American co-workers, Mira Brown of Boston, said today that at the moment of his death, Mr. Linder and his crew were measuring the water flow of a stream to see if it could be harnessed to provide power for the village of San Jose de Bocay.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/16/busin.main_headline: Boesky Use Of Futures Is Cited
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/16/busin.print_headline: Boesky Use Of Futures Is Cited
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/16/busin.body_text: **********Large positions in stock index futures accumulated by Ivan F. Boesky before the announcement in November of his $100 million insider-trading settlement appear to have been used by Mr. Boesky to offset, or hedge against, possible losses on a giant stock portfolio he controlled, according to officials of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission. **********''There is no indication that Boesky was attempting to wildly profit from trading in stock index futures,'' William E. Seale, a member of the commission, told the Senate Agriculture Committee today. ''It would seem that he had some kind of portfolio he wanted to hedge.'' **********Mr. Seale said he doubted that Mr. Boesky had tried to profit from the drop in the stock market that was widely predicted after the announcement of his settlement on Nov. 14, even though Mr. Boesky had a substantial short position in stock index futures. **********''In that case, the rational thing would have been to liquidate all of his positions'' on the Monday following the announcement, which came on a Friday, Mr. Seale said. But in the days after the announcement, Mr. Boesky liquidated only about one-third of his short positions in the indexes. Trading in Index Futures **********According to data submitted by the commission to the Senate committee, which has jurisdiction over all commodity futures trading, Mr. Boesky actively traded in futures contracts on both the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the New York Stock Exchange composite index from at least May 1986 up to and after the announcement of his settlement. **********The documentation indicated that Mr. Boeksy both made profits and suffered losses from his futures positions. For example, on Sept. 11 and Sept. 12, when the stock market plunged a total of 120 points, Mr. Boeksy had a large short position in the S.&.P. 500 stock index future, which would have risen in value. On the other hand, from Sept. 12 through Nov. 14, Mr. Boesky held a large short position on the New York Stock Exchange composite index and would probably have lost money. **********In both cases, however, when he made money on the short positions, he would have lost money in his stock portfolio, and when he lost money in short positions, he would have made made money on his stocks. **********Investors use index futures as a way to bet on the future course of the stock market and to protect gains in stock they own. **********Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who is chairman of the committee, voiced concern that the Securities and Exchange Commission did not get in touch with the commodities commission until one hour before the Nov. 14 announcement and that the S.E.C. did not try to stop Mr. Boesky from trading in stock index futures. **********Gary G. Lynch, director of enforcement at the S.E.C., said the commission had been concerned about ''preserving the confidentiality'' of the Boesky investigation, adding that Mr. Boesky ''was a cooperating witness.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.print_headline: TRUCKER TURNED BUILDER: ARTHUR E. IMPERATORE; Creating Shangri-La On the Hudson
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/busin.body_text: **********ARTHUR E. IMPERATORE, looking imperial, as he always does, nervously drummed his fingers on the table. Smoke seemed about to issue from his ears. He has a famous short fuse. He said stiffly, ''We've got a lot of money sitting around here. I hear the clock ticking.'' **********This meeting - being held at the Manhattan offices of the architectural firm of Schuman, Lichtenstein, Claman & Efron - had been called to discuss details of a crescent-shaped apartment building Mr. Imperatore intends to build on two miles of land he owns that winds through Weehawken and West New York on the New Jersey banks of the Hudson River. It would be the first stirrings of his ideal city, which he plans to call Port Imperial. **********He is basically a novice at real estate development. He has never built anything other than one housing project in Cliffside Park, N.J., and some truck terminals. Still, at 61, Mr. Imperatore sees no reason why an aging but active trucking magnate should not become a master builder. **********The meeting turned to windows. How many should open? How many shouldn't? Views diverged. At one point, Mr. Imperatore interrupted to say, ''You know, we better follow these things up or we're going to be out of time. We can't keep losing a week, a week, a week.'' **********Mr. Imperatore is worth perhaps $200 million. The money comes from his trucking company, the APA Transport Corporation, which hauls everything imaginable along the East Coast. In the mid-70's, Mr. Imperatore fell into doleful spirits. His mother died. One of his brothers was killed in a helicopter crash. His marriage disintegrated. He was creeping up on his 60's and felt it necessary to ponder succession. **********So he removed himself from active duties at his company. Needing a project to absorb him, he bought the big parcel of riverfront land in 1981, when wild dogs roamed on it. He got it cheap - $7.75 million - from the liquidators of the Penn Central holdings, and has already watched it multiply many times in value. Since he bought the parcel, he has been moving to create what he refers to as a Shangri-La with a glorious view of the Empire State Building. People who know him are not surprised. He has never thought small. **********The meeting sputtered along. Mr. Imperatore consulted his watch and announced that he had to get to New Jersey. ''If I said anything insulting,'' he remarked in leaving, ''I meant it.'' **********Buttoning his raincoat, Mr. Imperatore bustled downstairs, jumped into his Oldsmobile and and began careening at a blood-curdling speed through traffic. ''I drive like a truck driver,'' he said. ''I used to be a truck driver. You look for opportunity and move quickly. You have to make time to get productivity.'' **********Racing along, working the horn hard, he said, ''I have an esthetic eye that gives me insight and imposes a demand for high-quality esthetics and symmetry. My eye picks up asymmetry and rejects it. I'm a believer that people are affected by their environment much more than they are willing to admit consciously. I'm constantly fighting the battle of beauty and classicism and trying to compromise between what I feel people should require and have and the age of pragmatism. In my work, I'm always trying to think of how to make the world better - better human conduct, better civility, better efficiency, just a better civilization.'' **********He parked at a small pier on the Hudson River at 38th Street. This was where he had recently begun a ferry service to Weehawken - the first in 20 years - in order to carry commuters to his dream city. He boarded a motorboat, settled behind the wheel and plowed across the river to Arcorp Properties, his Weehawken real estate development company. **********''I'm 61,'' he said on the way over. ''I've worked for 50 or 51 years. I've always had an inner drive to accomplish and get things done with creativity, purpose and honesty, with a strong sense of personal discipline and control.'' **********Mr. Imperatore has a tall, lithe figure, sparse gray hair and a bulbous nose. He often wears a sort of tired, sad look. His voice, which he uses often, is like creaky hinges and his speech is generously laced with swearwords. He treats people well, providing they work harder than they ever thought they could. **********''I have great respect for people,'' he said. ''And I demand respect - because I earned it.'' **********His city, he explained, will be in the ''Greco-Roman tradition.'' It will contain 12,500 housing units, 10 million square feet of office space, a hotel and a cultural center. The cost may reach $6 billion. Construction is expected to span two decades. Mr. Imperatore hopes he'll see it all. **********In doing his planning, Mr. Imperatore dropped in on more than 50 cities to borrow ideas. Slices of Venice, Copenhagen and Paris will reappear on the New Jersey waterfront: a town square reminiscent of Venice's Piazza San Marco, an 800-foot observation tower derived from a Leonardo da Vinci sketch, a boulevard that some refer to as the ''Champs Elysees of Weehawken,'' an entertainment center mimicking Copenhagen's Tivoli Gardens. **********Ask him who will live in the city, and Mr. Imperatore responds firmly: ''The world.'' **********The world must wait, however. Ground-breaking for the first apartment building is not scheduled until September, and Mr. Imperatore faces rabid competition along the waterfront. **********''Even if his proposal can succeed on its own, 10 or 15 years down the line it's going to have to withstand competition from all the other developments on the West Bank of the Hudson River,'' said Martin Bierbaum, assistant professor in the graduate public administration program at Rutgers University. ''That area could turn out to be a total disaster.'' **********''I think that Arthur Imperatore, while he's a wonderful guy, is really a novice at real estate,'' said Joe Barry, a developer in Hoboken. ''What he's proposing is on such a massive scale that he's not going to have much learning time. You have to do more than throw a lot of money at a project.'' **********Donald Trump, in a recent television interview, succinctly summed up Mr. Imperatore's chunk of land as ''garbage.'' **********Mr. Imperatore huffs that anyone who doubts him doesn't know him. He says that he will soon be announcing a joint venture on his property with a large, seasoned developer that will silence a lot of naysayers. **********Arthur Imperatore wasn't always special. That didn't start, he says, until he was at least 2. When he was 10 he decided to become a millionaire. **********That was quite a dream for someone who was one of 10 children of an Italian immigrant who ran a grocery store. There was no money in the Imperatore house. The 10 children shared two drab bedrooms. Meals were taken at an ironing board that teetered across two chairs. (Still, there was a regal tradition: In Latin, the family name means emperor.) This was happening in West New York, where Mr. Imperatore was born on July 8, 1925. At 7, Mr. Imperatore helped his family with deliveries. He mopped floors at a candy store. He was a Western Union messenger. He was a Fuller Brush man. He had a bank account when he was 9. He never went to college. **********''My interest as a kid was in doing something, making money and putting my family on the map,'' he said. **********Trucks gave him the opportunity. In 1947, along with four of his brothers, he established the rudiments of APA Transport with two Army surplus trucks operating out of the Imperatore house. Under Mr. Imperatore's tight-fisted rule, the company flourished as one of the industry's most profitable truckers. The New York-New Jersey area is one of the most miserable in the country for labor-management squabbling (his drivers belong to the teamsters union). Yet APA became legendary for stellar management and profitability. In 1985, he says, the company earned $8.4 million on revenues of $98.7 million. **********APA's stringent hiring policies are perhaps the key to its success. Want to drive an APA truck? You must withstand endless interviews, a drug test, a polygraph test in states that allow it and a week's orientation at no pay. To weed out crooks among new applicants, APA subscribes to 45 daily newspapers, and four people work full-time clipping out stories about arrests. From these, a master roster of dubious names is compiled, which right now lists more than 1.6 million people. **********Mr. Imperatore remains APA's chairman, but the place is run on a daily basis by its president, Armand Pohan, who is Mr. Imperatore's stepson. Earlier last year, in order to grow, the company bought Sanborn's Motor Express, a Maine trucker. There have been problems melding the two together, since a lot of Sanborn drivers who are not up to APA's standards have left or been let go. **********One of the most remarkable things about APA is its reputation for being ''clean'' in an industry that is often dirty. **********''We don't stand for corruption of any people for any reason,'' Mr. Imperatore said. ''I.B.M., Ross Perot -we didn't copy any of those guys in how to be honest. We invented this stuff down here in the swamps. The Japanese didn't teach me anything. We grew up in the worst kind of crud. The teamster influence? Some of those guys are in prison right now. They tried to strong-arm us. But they didn't. We never bought peace.'' **********In fact, even the Teamsters seem to approve of Arthur Imperatore. ''He's fair, he's just, he's tough,'' says Walter Shea, an international vice president with the union, who has known Mr. Imperatore for many years. ''We rarely have a grievance with him. If everyone was like Arthur, we probably wouldn't have unions.'' **********Mr. Imperatore is tougher than nails. But he's also generous to his people. In 1973, for instance, he opened a $1 million recreation center for workers and their families at the APA main terminal in North Bergen. The basketball court is so good that the New Jersey Nets practice on it. **********Mr. Imperatore treats himself well, too. His immense office at APA is a splendid replica of the drawing room of a 17th-century Venetian prince. ''Nice office, huh?'' he likes to say to visitors. ''I deserve it.'' **********Until recently, he lived in a mansion perched on a bluff in Fort Lee, N.J., though now he rents an apartment in Manhattan while quarters are being prepared for him in the Arcorp Properties headquarters. He's still separated from his wife and lives alone; he has a son and daughter, who are both in graduate school. He owns a 141-foot yacht, the Imperator, which contains artwork by Boudin, Monet and Pissarro. He likes to float in the yacht down the Hudson, peering at his acreage and smiling contentedly to himself. **********Mr. Imperatore had to meet someone at the office of a marina that operates on his property. Walking in, he noticed the carpeting was soiled. He barked at the attendant: ''Why is this carpet dirty? That's grease.'' **********The phone trilled. The attendant picked it up. ''Listen to me,'' Mr. Imperatore snapped. ''Tell whoever it is you'll call back. I'm talking. Get someone to come and clean that.'' **********Tidiness is a fanaticism of Mr. Imperatore's. At any given time, his coat pockets are apt to be stuffed with sundry balled-up scraps of litter he has spied on the ground. ''You see how dirty the world is and then you come to my property and it's clean,'' he said. ''People enjoy working in a clean, neat environment. I think people deserve that.'' **********Still fuming about the greasy rug, Mr. Imperatore left the office. He noticed a crumpled Hershey bar wrapper on the ground, picked it up and stashed it in his pocket. **********''I want to show you something,'' Arthur Imperatore said, driving through the streets of North Bergen. He pulled up alongside a nondescript two-story house, swung out of the car and punched the bell. This was the house he was born in. Now he owns it. One of his brothers lives in it with his wife. **********His brother was out, but his wife answered in her bathrobe. **********''Oh, Arthur, why don't you give me warning?'' she said. **********''I didn't have warning,'' Mr. Imperatore said. **********The living room was small, plain, crowded. Mr. Imperatore paced about. ''This was where I started,'' he said. ''Ten kids in two rooms. It was a mess.'' **********''What my project is about,'' he continued, ''is I want to help the milieu in which I built my business. I made my fortune here and I believe in the community. I have an idea of perfecting a piece of the world.'' **********''Some coffee, Arthur?'' his sister-in-law interrupted. **********''No time,'' Mr. Imperatore said. ''Gotta go.'' On a gray, snowy day, Arthur Imperatore's car eased to a halt in front of APA headquarters. The letters in the company's name happen to stand for nothing, though employees quip that they are short for ''Always Please Arthur.'' As he threaded his way to his office, Mr. Imperatore called out effusive greetings to the drivers. Some of them he hugged. He asked after the health of relatives. **********As he mounted the stairs, his eyes were trained on the carpet. ''Look at this,'' he said to one of the vice presidents, and nabbed two pieces of litter. ''You guys let this place go to pot.'' Then he said, ''When I was building the company, I was introduced to a book called 'Acres of Diamonds.' It was about a man who had a great farm but he was restless and greedy and failed to work his farm. So he sold it and the man who bought it worked it and found on the farm the acres of diamonds. The moral is, if you work hard you find opportunities.' **********He plopped down in his office and stared into the distance. ''Men love to work,'' he said. ''They want leadership and to be taught their work, their craft, to make a better world, a small chunk of immortality by their work.'' **********''We bring out the heroism in people,'' he continued. ''I used to do it in a masterful way. I don't know if they're screwing it up now. I think they are, actually.'' **********After a while, he got into his car to circle the snowy yard. A rule is that drivers have 5 minutes to get their trucks on the road. Most made it. A few dawdled. **********Mr. Imperatore pulled up alongside a driver who was still getting his truck ready to roll. ''Get out of here,'' he told him. ''You can talk to the freight, but it won't walk.'' **********''I know, Arthur, I know,'' the driver said. **********''If I weren't in this car, you'd get a snowball,'' Mr. Imperatore said. ''Now get out of here.'' Mr. Imperatore headed for the exit to go to the waterfront. Suddenly, he braked, opened his door and leaned out. He snatched up a gum wrapper and put it in his pocket.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/world.main_headline: GANDHI IS CHALLENGED IN HINDU STATE NEAR PUNJAB
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/world.print_headline: GANDHI IS CHALLENGED IN HINDU STATE NEAR PUNJAB
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's forces face a formidable challenge in an election campaign in the politically sensitive northern state of Haryana. **********The election, on Wednesday, is widely considered a major test for Mr. Gandhi, whose image and base have been eroded in recent months by reports of kickbacks to Indians involved in major military contracts, by defeats in two state elections elsewhere this spring, by an outbreak of Hindu-Moslem rioting and by accusations from critics that his Government lacks firmness and vision. **********Haryana borders both the state of Punjab, on its northwest, and New Delhi, which is situated just east of the state, and Mr. Gandhi's failure to curb atttacks on Hindus by Sikhs in the Punjab has become a major factor in the Haryana election. Opposition leaders accuse Mr. Gandhi of ''selling out'' Haryana's economic interests to the Sikhs in the Punjab. **********The opposition candidate in Haryana, Devi Lal of the People's Party, has pledged to investigate corruption charges against leaders of Mr. Gandhi's Congress Party in his state if he is elected. Like many parties in India, the People's Party is organized less around an ideology than around the interests of a group, in this case Hindu peasants. 'An Even Battle' **********A senior aide to Mr. Gandhi acknowledged that Mr. Lal was staging ''a great assault on our bases'' and described the election as ''an even battle.'' But he added that he and other leaders were as worried about the possibility that dissidents within their own party would try to sabotage the Congress campaign as they were concerned by Mr. Lal's challenge. **********''The rebels are one of the biggest dangers that we face and they are defying us openly,'' said the Gandhi aide, who is a senior Cabinet minister in New Delhi. He said the national Environment Minister, Bhajan Lal, was upset because Mr. Gandhi had ignored a demand that his followers be given more electoral races to contest in the 90-seat state legislature. Mr. Lal, no relation to the opposition leader, was Chief Minister of Haryana until last year. **********The Congress Party has announced that it is expelling 29 rebels from the organization for running against its official candidates, and it has threatened to oust more. Shrinking Base **********Mr. Gandhi is said to be concerned about the Congress Party's shrinking base. Eight of the country's 22 states are controlled by opposition groups, including the entire south and much of the east. A Congress Party defeat in Haryana would bring Mr. Gandhi's foes to power at New Delhi's doorstep and would make a major inroad into an area considered the Hindi-speaking heartland of central and northern India, which the Congress Party has controlled for decades. **********Most of India's 780 million people live in this belt, and it has been the traditional foundation of national political power. A setback in Haryana would raise questions about how effectively the Prime Minister can govern during the rest of his five-year term, which is half over. **********But Mr. Gandhi's aides insist that the Government will serve its full term, and they point out that the Prime Minister still controls 402 of 542 members in the national Parliament, despite some disaffection within the ranks, Relations With Sikhs at Stake A victory for Mr. Lal of the People's Party would also mean that prospects for an accord with Punjab's Sikhs, already severely set back by the dismissal last month of a moderate Sikh government there, would become even more distant. Mr. Lal said today that a 1985 accord between Mr. Gandhi and the moderate Sikhs was ''as good as dead'' and that he would not compromise on Haryana's demands for more irrigation water, more territory from the Punjab and a new capital. **********Today, a crowd of perhaps 5,000 waited patiently in this farming village in the shade of a large tent, or outside under a blistering sun, for two hours to listen to Mr. Lal. Mandkaula is about 60 miles south of New Delhi. **********Mr. Lal, who is 73 years old and towers over his followers at 6 feet 3 inches, was received here by village leaders with garlands of marigolds and was presented with a turban and a bundle of crisp rupee notes. **********His audience responded gleefully to mild abuse of Mr. Gandhi and sharper criticism of local Congress Party leaders, whom Mr. Lal likened to ''thieves and crooks.'' **********But the crowd reserved its strongest support for Mr. Lal's declaration that he would write off all loans to farmers if he became Haryana's chief minister, its top elected official. **********''If the central Government can forgive capitalists who apologize for tax fraud worth billions of rupees, if it can permit crooks to smuggle out billions of rupees and stash the money into Swiss banks, then I can, with a stroke, free my fellow farmers of all outstanding loans,'' he announced. The audience cheered and applauded noisily. **********The reference to the Swiss banks was to an International Monetary Fund report that said that Indians held more than $1 billion in secret Swiss bank accounts. The Indian Government also has a policy of dropping cases against industrialists who apologize for past tax fraud and pledge good conduct in the future.

It is intended to prevent accidents caused by the loss of cooling water, as occurred at the Three Mile Island nuclear generating station in **********A GAUGE that monitors the level of coolant in nuclear power reactors was patented this week by five inventors in the Pennsylvania State University's nuclear engineering department. It is intended to prevent accidents caused by the loss of cooling water, as occurred at the Three Mile Island nuclear generating station in Pennsylvania. **********Patent 4,639,349 was granted to Anthony J. Baratta and four fellow scientists. It is assigned to the Research Corporation, a foundation with offices in Tucson, Ariz., and New York, which is granting licenses to industry.
