https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/04/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********As a certified public accountant and a bank regulator, I take issue with William B. O'Connell's article on the Financial Accounting Standards Board (A History of Defying Public Policy, Forum, Sept. 6). **********Mr. O'Connell's main premise is that a non-elected body is setting (or thwarting) public policy, a role that is reserved for the Congress. Congress does set public policy, and that policy is often carried out through various regulatory bodies, including the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency. In the area of financial institutions, the basic Congressional policy, and that of the Comptroller's Office, is to promote the safety of the financial system for the public benefit. **********Where Mr. O'Connell's perception is distorted, however, is his focus on the role of the F.A.S.B. in public policy. The board's role is to assure the reporting of accurate financial information to the investing public. **********Congress and the financial institutions regulatory authorities have a public policy goal to protect the financial system and its depositors. The Securities and Exchange Commission and the F.A.S.B. have a responsibility to assure that the investing public has a clear understanding of the financial condition of a financial institution. These are two different public policy goals addressing different audiences. DANA H. COOK  Special Advisor to the Comptroller of the Currency  Washington, Sept. 18

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/08/world.body_text: **********A Polish court threw out a suit today that accused the chief Government spokesman of slandering four Poles. The spokesman had declared that the four had espionage links with an official of the American Embassy. **********It was the first time Polish citizens had availed themselves of a right of legal appeal against what were once held to be unchallengeable activities of the Government. The case appeared to set the narrow limits within which the Government will allow itself to be legally contested. **********The case involved assertions by the spokesman, Jerzy Urban, at a news conference this year that four Polish professors held secret meetings with an American diplomat whom the authorities had accused of espionage. **********The Chief Judge, Edmund Sadkowski, giving the grounds for refusing the suit, acknowledged that Mr. Urban's assertions might constitute invasion of privacy, but said the spokesman had no duty to determine whether information supplied him by Government agencies was true or not. **********The plaintiffs deny the charges. The American diplomat, Albert Mueller, later left Poland, and no formal action was taken against him. **********One of the plaintiffs, Magdalena Sokolowska, a sociologist at Warsaw University, said after the brief hearing that she was ''deeply offended and deeply disappointed.'' **********The other plaintiffs are Klemens Szaniawski, a logician; Bronislaw Geremek, a historian, and Janusz Onyszkiewicz, a mathematician. **********They are expected to appeal. A final ruling would rest with the Supreme Administrative Court or the Constitutional Tribunal, bodies created after 1980 to permit citizens to challenge governmental actions. **********Mr. Urban did not attend the hearing, but was expected to comment at a regular news conference Tuesday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/07/busin.body_text: **********President Reagan will appoint M. Peter McPherson, the Administrator of the Agency for International Development, to succeed Richard G. Darman as Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, Administration sources said yesterday. An announcement is likely today, they said. **********Mr. McPherson, 46, once a tax lawyer, and a Peace Corps volunteer in Peru, has supervised the agency since February 1981. He has been associated with Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and Mr. Darman off and on for years and is considered unlikely to seek significant changes in the Baker-Darman policies on the dollar, developing world debt, taxation, trade and other major issues. **********The appointment requires Senate confirmation. Officials close to the Senate Finance Committee said they did not expect serious opposition but said they doubted Mr. McPherson would be cleared before May. Mr. Darman assumes his new job as a managing director of Shearson Lehman Brothers next Monday. **********Mr. McPherson, whose probable appointment was disclosed yesterday by The Wall Street Journal, worked closely with Mr. Baker and Mr. Darman as counsel to the President-elect's transition team in 1980 and as acting counsel to the President until joining the aid agency. Their association goes back to the Ford Administration, when Mr. McPherson was a special assistant to the President and deputy director for personnel. **********In his current position, he has served as an Administration emissary to developing countries, promoting the Baker Plan through which countries are granted easier lending terms in return for adoption of Baker-prescribed, growth-oriented economic policies. **********Early in his term at the agency, he established a Bureau for Private Enterprise to encourage private business development in third world countries as an alternative to direct foreign aid. ''He has been a strong advocate for economic policy reform,'' an associate said. **********These policies have aroused some opposition from the poorer countries, which see them as meddlesome. At the same time, Mr. McPherson has come under criticism from conservative groups for extending aid to countries the groups consider hostile to the United States. **********Mr. McPherson also has expertise in tax law, having once served as an expert on international taxation for six years in the Internal Revenue Service. In the years of the Carter Administration, he was head of the Washington ofice of a Ohio law firm.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/12/busin.body_text: **********A late Easter is usually good for business: Balmy weather helps retailers sell their spring merchandise. But this year's late Easter won't be enough to get overall consumer spending to bloom. **********While Americans may be interested in buying bonnets, baseballs and bedspreads, they are not purchasing big-ticket items like cars or houses anywhere near the rate of a year ago, says Burton Zwick, senior economist at Kidder, Peabody & Company. This spring, overall spending by debt-burdened consumers has slipped to a 2 percent real annual rate of growth, down from 4 percent in 1986. ''If this level is maintained, it will be the slowest year for spending since this recovery began in 1983,'' he said. **********This is not necessarily bad news, says Mr. Zwick. Among other things, lower spending means less demand for imported goods - and that helps to narrow the nation's trade gap. In fact, he said, getting trade back in balance may mean that ''spending growth may have to slow to 1 percent beyond 1987.'' Utilities: On the Prowl **********Electric utilities have been borrowing less and less to build new plants. Next year they will internally generate 84 percent of their new-construction costs - up from 30 percent in 1980, says Mark D. Luftig, a vice president at Salomon Brothers. **********There are a number of reasons that utilities have the cash to carry out construction under their own steam. Power companies benefit from the lower corporate tax rates in the new tax law. **********And some of their construction projects are exempt from provisions in the new law that repeal the investment tax credit as of January 1986. **********What's more, with 35 percent overcapacity in their industry, they are not building much. ''The only projects are nuclear plants that are not yet finished,'' said Mr. Luftig. **********Until they need to build more capacity - in the early 1990's - power companies are on the prowl for other investments, including acquisitions, Mr. Luftig says. Those that have the go-ahead from their public service commissions have already bought banks, cable television businesses and insurance companies. **********But utilities won't invest in buybacks of their own stock, as they have in the past. The reason: Shares are too expensive. According to Mr. Luftig, utility stocks are selling at 140 percent of book value in this raging bull market. Professional Power **********While labor unions will continue to face tough times, professional associations of white-collar workers could gain considerable clout. **********Given the recent problems in downsizing and other kinds of corporate restructuring, ''activist professional associations could grow in both membership and influence,'' said Richard Belous, a labor economist at the Conference Board. **********Most professional groups cannot yet match the power of the American Bar Association or the National Education Association, says Mr. Belous. But as they grow, white-collar organizations - representing engineers, computer technicians, even economists -will be more aggressive with Congress and corporations. The trend has reached even the smallest groups. The American Association of Textile Chemists and Colorists, for example, is rallying its 8,000 members around the issue of foreign competition. **********All this means increasing competition for unions that also represent professionals. ''If professional organizations thrive, said Mr. Belous. ''it's going to be a lot harder for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to recruit.'' Fashionable Fingernails **********Fashion's current emphasis on femininity is reaching all the way to the fingertips, says David A. Weiss, president of Packaged Facts, a retail research firm. And sales of nail-care products point up the trend. Mr. Weiss expects sales of nail polish, removers, dips, creams, hardeners and decorative decals - to top $1 billion next year, up from $875 million in 1986. ''Apparently, once consumers start purchasing one type of nail-care product, they expand their purchasing to other types,'' he said. **********The key to this industry's growth, says Mr. Weiss, is a change in consumers' attitudes. ''In the 1970's, the effect of feminism and the new role of women in the workplace deemphasized the use of cosmetics,'' he said. But these days, he said, ''Once a woman has proven she is an iron-fisted executive, it doesn't matter if the iron fist has frosty pink nails.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; A.M.C. ABSORPTION BY CHRYSLER SEEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/17/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation plans to absorb and dismantle the American Motors Corporation by the end of the year if its proposed buyout of the ailing auto maker is completed on schedule, the trade journal Automotive News reported. Chrysler agreed last week to purchase Renault's 46.1 percent interest in A.M.C. and to buy all other outstanding A.M.C. shares. **********Under the buyout, A.M.C. would remain as an independent subsidiary, but not for long, Chrysler's vice chairman, Bennett E. Bidwell, told Automotive News. ''The free-standing subsidiary concept will only be transitory,'' he said. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/22/world.main_headline: WALSH SEEKING ALL IRAN RECORDS OF JUSTICE DEPT.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/22/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS; WALSH SEEKING ALL IRAN RECORDS OF JUSTICE DEPT.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/22/world.body_text: **********The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair has asked Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to turn over thousands of documents related to the Justice Department's inquiry last fall into the sale of American arms to Iran, Federal law-enforcement officials said today. **********They said the special prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh, had greatly expanded his investigation of the Justice Department and was seeking a broad range of department records, from investigative files to private notebooks and telephone-message slips. Request 'Absolutely Massive' **********A senior official said the request for the documents had been delivered to the department in the last two weeks and was ''absolutely massive - every scrap of paper from Meese and anybody else in the department'' who took part in the Attorney General's much-criticized investigation last November. **********The broad scope of Mr. Walsh's request appeared to be more bad news for the Attorney General, who is expected to come under harsh questioning next week during testimony before the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair. **********Mr. Meese is also under scrutiny by another special prosecutor for his involvement with the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx defense contractor that has been linked to a wide-ranging scheme to obtain Government contracts through influence-buying. **********The Attorney General and the Justice Department have repeatedly and specifically denied wrongdoing. Staff Secluded From Testimony **********While recent Congressional testimony of Col. Oliver L. North and Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter has focused at times on the Justice Department investigation of the Iran-contra affair, Mr. Walsh and his staff insist that their investigation is not being influenced by the recent disclosures in Congress. **********In fact, Mr. Walsh has ordered his staff not to read about, watch or listen to testimony from witnesses who received immunity from prosecution, including Admiral Poindexter and Colonel North. Congress granted limited immunity to several witnesses to compel their testimony. **********Under immunity rules, Mr. Walsh cannot bring criminal charges against such witnesses based on information obtained from their Congressional testimony. **********According to law-enforcement officials, Mr. Walsh and his staff are puzzled by strategic errors made by Mr. Meese and his investigators that permitted White House officials, including Colonel North, to destroy critical documents about the Iran arms sale. Report to Congress Awaited **********Mr. Walsh's intentions are not entirely clear, although one official with knowledge of his inquiry said the special prosecutor would seek to determine whether Justice Department officials aided the White House in a criminal cover-up of the Iran-contra affair. **********Aside from looking for criminal violations, Mr. Walsh is known to be gathering Government documents and conducting witness interviews for use in a detailed report to Congress on the Iran-contra affair. **********Recent testimony before Congress has raised questions about whether Mr. Meese had advance knowledge that the Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, was preparing to deliver false testimony to Congress last November about the Iran arms sales. The Attorney General has denied it. According to one official, Mr. Walsh asked in his document request for any material that made reference to Mr. Casey's testimony and any Justice Department involvement in its preparation. **********In a letter outlining the document request, officials said, Mr. Walsh asked the department to turn over documents related to the Iran-contra affair that were dated from October through December of last year. **********''It's everything from that time period,'' said a Federal law-enforcement official. 'Nothing to Hide' **********He said Justice Department prosecutors were ''uncomfortable'' with the scope of the document request because ''it makes it look like the department has some sort of smoking gun in the files when, I assure you, there isn't one.'' **********Another official said he believed that Justice Department prosecutors were ''unconcerned'' by Mr. Walsh's request. ''There's absolutely nothing to hide,'' he said. **********During an investigation late last November, Mr. Meese and a small team of his close aides turned up evidence that profits from the Iran arms sales were diverted to Nicaraguan rebel groups. A Three-Day Delay **********After discovering a National Security Council memorandum outlining the diversion plan, Mr. Meese waited three days before obtaining White House files and seeking the help of experienced criminal prosecutors and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. **********The delay permitted Colonel North and others to destroy documents related to the Iran arms sale. The colonel has testified that he was shredding documents even while Mr. Meese's investigators were going through files in a nearby room in the White House. **********Admiral Poindexter, the former national security adviser, told Congress in recent days that he destroyed a Presidential decision memorandum on the arms sale within hours of learning that Mr. Meese had begun an investigation. The admiral said he was seeking to avoid ''political'' problems for the President. **********On Capitol Hill, members of the Iran-contra committees have described the Justice Department's investigation as inept.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/30/world.main_headline: REGAN TESTIFIES TODAY ON ROLE IN 'BATTLE ROYAL'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/30/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS; REGAN TESTIFIES TODAY ON ROLE IN 'BATTLE ROYAL'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/30/world.body_text: **********When Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff, begins testifying before the Iran-contra committee on Thursday, committee members hope he will be able to explain how a ''battle royal'' erupted in the White House over the sale of arms to Iran. **********Until he resigned early this year, Mr. Regan was one of the President's closest aides, and his testimony could be important because he may be able to explain how Administration officials came to lie to and deceive each other over important aspects of the Iran arms sales. **********Both George P. Shultz, the Secretary of State, and Edwin Meese 3d, the Attorney General, have acknowledged in their testimony that other officials misled them. No New Disclosures Expected **********But beyond the glimpses of the inner workings at the White House he can offer, associates of Mr. Regan and commitee staff officials say that they do not expect him to offer much in the way of new disclosures. Like the President, he has denied knowledge of the diversion of profits from the arms sale to the contras. Most of what he has already told Congressional investigators in private about the Iran initative has already been made public. **********''I see him mainly tying down the facts,'' said one associate of Mr. Regan. ''There's not much new in that.'' **********An Iran-contra committee official said: ''How many times can you ask one guy and have him say, 'I don't know; I wasn't told'?'' **********Mr. Regan was one of the most powerful men in the White House through most of the period the Iran initiative was conducted. But in the weeks of the televised hearings, he has been the odd-man-out, seldom mentioned by the others who have testified. Questions to Be Raised **********Still Mr. Shultz's testimony about a a ''battle royal'' within the Administration over control of foreign policy makes Mr. Regan's account especially important. **********Among the questions Mr. Regan is expected to be asked are these: *********** Why did he he fail to tell the Secretary of State of a retroactive Presidential finding, signed in December 1985, allowing the arms shipment to Iran? *********** Why did he shift from opposing the arms sales in December 1985 to supporting the policy a month later, according to Mr. Shultz's testimony? *********** Did he lead White House attempts to effectively punish Mr. Shultz for not supporting the arms sale? The Secretary testified about what he believed was retaliation against him when he had difficulty gaining access to Government planes and meetings with the President. *********** What was he told about efforts in May 1986 to establish a channel for providing arms to Iran by using arms merchants, Adnan M. Khashoggi and Manucher Ghorbanifar? Mr. Shultz said he raised questions about such an arrangement and said Mr. Regan told him he would take the matter up with the President. *********** Why he was unable to persuade the President to turn over the Iran initative to Mr. Shultz in November? Mr. Shultz testified that he wrote a note to the chief of staff with that request, only to be told by Mr. Regan that ''I can't make it.'' Regan Denies Coverup **********Associates of Mr. Regan believe the most combative line of questioning could center on how he managed the White House, particularly in the critical period when the arms sales to Iran were disclosed last November. The committees have been trying to determine whether a coverup was attempted. The former chief of staff has adamantly insisted that there was no such attempt. **********But in a sharp rebuke, a Presidential commission that reviewed the Iran initative in February said that Mr. Regan shared the ''primary responsibility for the chaos'' that descended on the White House when the policy initiative was first disclosed. Mr. Reagan disagreed with that. **********The panel, headed by former Senator John G. Tower, also said Mr. Regan was partly to blame for the failure of the National Security Council staff to follow ''an orderly process'' that would have provided more internal scrutiny of its activities. **********Aides to Mr. Regan say that the testimony by Mr. Shultz, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and others validates the chief of staff's key response to the Tower Commission: That the staff of the National Security Council operated as a separate entity that kept him in the dark, much as it did Mr. Shultz. Access to the President **********The Tower Commission's assessment was based on the fact that Mr. Regan enjoyed access to meetings by senior officials in which the initative was discussed and that he also attended daily briefings for the President by Admiral Poindexter and his predecesor, Robert C. McFarlane. **********This picture of an involved Mr. Regan is reflected in a computer note, dated Feb. 27, 1986, from Mr. McFarlane to Colonel North released by the committee. The chief of staff is described as wanting to go all out for ''the wrong reasons'' on the Iran initative, while Mr. Shultz and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger are portrayed as opposing it. **********Mr. Regan will be testifying with legal representation, but his attorney will sit behind, not beside him. Thus, like Mr. Shultz and Attorney General Meese, he will be picture as facing his interrogators alone. **********The former chief of staff first talked to committee staff investigators in March and was interviewed again about 10 days ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/09/world.main_headline: U.S. Reported to Thwart a Marcos Coup Plot
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/09/world.print_headline: U.S. Reported to Thwart a Marcos Coup Plot
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/09/world.body_text: **********The United States Government has uncovered information that Ferdinand E. Marcos was planning to instigate an armed insurrection in the Philippines this Friday in hopes of returning to power, officials said today. **********After learning of the plans, senior State Department officials traveled this week to Honolulu, where Mr. Marcos is living in exile and warned him that he was in danger of violating American law as well as the terms of the agreement by which he came to the United States in February 1986. State Department officials said Abraham D. Sofaer, the State Department legal adviser, warned Mr. Marcos in talks on Monday and Tuesday that he could not leave the island of Oahu, where he is living in exile, without permission. **********The plot apparently never advanced very far because the people from whom Mr. Marcos was seeking to obtain financing and arms shared their information with Manila, the Justice Department and Congress. **********The State Department spokesman, Charles E. Redman, said: **********''The United States is seriously concerned about indications that Mr. Marcos apearred to be seeking to destabilize the Aquino Government and was contemplating a return to the Philippines without the express permission of the Philippines Government.'' **********While Mr. Redman would not give details of the allegations, other officials said that the Government was in possession of tape recordings of conversations betweeen Mr. Marcos and a lawyer for a member of the Saudi royal family and the lawyer's aide. Mr. Marcos, they said, was seeking a loan from the Saudi Arabian to finance his insurrection, and believed the lawyer's associate to be an international arms dealer. The tapes, which officials say they believe are authentic, show that Mr. Marcos was planning to spend about $18 million to purchase tanks, rocket launchers, recoilless rifles and antitank and antiaircraft missiles. **********The plot also called for Mr. Marcos's forces to kidnap President Corazon C. Aquino and to hold her hostage. **********Mr. Marcos was planning to pay back the loan with a cache of gold still hidden in the Philippines worth about $14 billion. **********Officials said the insurrection was scheduled for July 10. **********In one of the taped conversations, which were made available by officials, Mr. Marcos said he was seeking 8,000 recoilless rifles. At other times, officials said, he spoke of 10,000 people who would take up arms. **********The tapes were of conversations made on the telephone and in person between Mr. Marcos, a man identified as Richard Hirschfeld, a Virginia lawyer, and Robert Chastain, an associate who posed as an arms dealer. Their motive for dealing with Mr. Marcos was unclear. **********Last January, the Reagan Administration foiled what it said was a plan by Mr. Marcos to return to Manila and rally his supporters. **********At the time that plot was disrupted, dissident soldiers had seized a television station in Manila and Mr. Marcos had a plane ready to fly him home. **********Representative Stephen J. Solarz, a Brooklyn Democrat and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific, said today that he would hold hearings Thursday on the new allegations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/world.body_text: **********Afghan troops have begun a major offensive against some 9,000 Moslem rebels in southeastern Afghanistan near the Pakistan border, Moscow television said today. **********The television showed film of the troops shelling what a Soviet reporter said were rebel strongholds and arms supply routes in a snow-capped mountain range in the Khost district of Pakhtiya province. **********The reporter said the operation had both military and political objectives and was under the command of the Chief of Staff of the Afghan Army, Lieut. Gen. Shah Nawas. **********In an interview translated into Russian, the general said the action was begun after efforts to find a peaceful solution to the fighting in the area had failed. **********The Soviet reporter, Mikhail Leshchinsky, said armed rebels from the local Jadran tribe had been in control of the region for a long period of time. **********''For nine years the population of the district has been held hostage by the counterrevolution,'' Mr. Leshchinsky said. **********General Nawas said the Jadran tribe had apparently rejected peace proposals under pressure from Pakistan and Western countries. **********''The blockade of Khost will now be lifted by military means,'' the general said. **********The report made no reference to participation by Soviet forces in the operation and there was no sign of non-Afghan troops in the film shown. **********The Soviet Union is estimated by Western analysts to have about 115,000 troops in Afghanistan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/busin.body_text: **********The business of running local governments is getting ever more businesslike. **********Fairfield, Calif., for example, is an equity partner in a large regional shopping mall; Cincinnati has a stake in a Westin hotel, and New York City is a partner in an office building with Morgan Stanley & Company. **********Long accustomed to being passive regulators of business, local governments are becoming entrepreneurs as a way of raising revenue, developing blighted areas and acquiring specific projects, such as luxury hotels. Profitability Is Uncertain **********The investments are not without risk, or critics. The projects are still young and their profitability not certain. And some experts think the governmental entrepreneurship could lead to charges of antitrust violations and conflicts of interest. But others argue that, for most municipalities, the total amount of dollars involved is small and that public scrutiny of government actions should help keep any project in line. **********Most experts agree that entrepreneurial government has its roots in the taxpayer revolts of the late 1970's, when voters approved Proposition 13 in California, Proposition 2 1/2 in Massachusetts and similar measures elsewhere. These initiatives put limits on property tax increases, reducing revenues for local governments. Those governments, in turn, developed innovative approaches to doing business. **********''It's taken 10 years, but the fruits of Proposition 13 are just being harvested,'' said James B. Hudak, a partner in the San Francisco office of the accounting firm Arthur Andersen & Company. **********''For the first couple of years the state bailed out cities and counties,'' Mr. Hudak added. ''Then cities implemented salary freezes, sold surplus land, employed creative accounting. But now they've run out of things to do and are forced to look at more creative alternatives.'' **********Fairfield, a city of about 73,000 that is halfway between San Francisco and Sacramento, was one of the first and most aggressive practitioners of government entrepreneurship. A Quick Profit on Land **********When Gale Wilson, the city manager, was approached by Ernest W. Hahn Inc. in 1976 for permission to build a small shopping center, he proposed a large regional mall. The city purchased the land for $1.25 a square foot and sold it to Hahn for $2.25 - a quick $1 million profit. In return, the city expedited zoning variances and building permits. **********Fairfield negotiated the deal to get increased revenue in property and sales taxes. But after Proposition 13 was passed in 1978, the city worked out a new deal with Hahn to compensate for the revenue cut. Under that arrangement, Fairfield will receive in perpetuity 10 percent to 17 percent of net cash flow after expenses from the merchants in the one-million-square-foot mall. Despite initial reservations, the company says it has had no problem with the arrangement and has made similar deals since then. **********Fairfield sold Hahn only half of the land it bought, and Mr. Wilson expects to realize far greater profits from the 66 acres surrounding the mall. The first tenant of a new development there, a Toys ''R'' Us store, has agreed to give the city 50 percent of its net cash flow in return for the right to locate on that land. **********Mr. Wilson's staff is taking a similarly aggressive posture in acquiring land and negotiating leases for an automobile dealership center. When the United States Postal Service turned down the city for a new post office, Fairfield built one anyway, and now leases it to the Postal Service. **********''I tell developers, 'You have to do things our way,' '' Mr. Wilson said. '' 'Yes, we'll make you pay, but you will make money.' '' Motivations Other Than Revenue **********Mr. Wilson said his efforts had been aided by Fairfield's size, location and rapid growth. But similar projects are under way across the United States, and the motivation often goes beyond generating revenue. **********In Cincinnati, the city will get 17 percent of the profit from a project that includes a Westin hotel and a new home office of the First National Bank of Cincinnati. **********The main objective of the deal, in which the city assembled the land and handled the financing, was to rebuild a blighted area and get a luxury hotel in the city's center. But sharing in the profit ''helps keep up with inflation and helps to sell a project to the public and the city council,'' said Nell Surber, director of redevelopment in Cincinnati. **********San Antonio is a partner in a Sheraton hotel with the Encore Company of Dallas and China's national bank, which was approached when American banks showed no interest in the project. The city's principal goal was to get more hotel rooms to make the city more attractive for conventions, but this and other investments are expected to provide it with an additional $5 million a year in revenue. ''The city is now taking a position that we have something of value, and we want something in return,'' said Louis J. Fox, San Antonio's city manager. Alarm Systems for Sale **********In Pasadena, Calif., the city plans to market telecommunications and office alarm systems. Judith Weiss, the assistant city manager, said the communications systems were expected to ''make offices in Pasadena more competitive,'' while the city hoped the alarm systems would lower the cost of providing police and fire protection. **********If some deals appear to open the door to cronyism, kickbacks and unfair competition, proponents of entrepreneurial government say the mere appearance of corruption has tended to have such a chilling effect on development that cities have gone out of their way to avoid it. **********''Cities doing this successfully are finding that they have to be cleaner than Caesar's wife,'' said John J. Kirlin, a professor of public policy at the University of Southern California's Sacramento Public Affairs Center. **********Some experts fear that not all local governments have the savvy to handle such deals. ''Some will be mesmerized by the talk of easy cash flow and will do something they'll later regret,'' said David E. Dowall, associate director of the Institute of Urban and Regional Development at the University of California at Berkeley. ''Some very sweet deals have been negotiated for the private sector.'' **********Critics of governmental entrepreneurship also question whether the supposed safeguards of public accountability are really effective. In Fairfield, some residents said they thought Mr. Wilson had too much power, and they contended that the city staff had been too secretive and too concerned with making deals. A Conflict Is Seen **********Indeed, many cities find an inherent conflict between the privacy that fosters good deal-making and the desire for an open local government. **********''In some ways there is a lot to be said for working out these deals efficiently; in principle, that makes a great deal of sense,'' said Michael Wheeler, director of education at the Center for Real Estate Development at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ''The difficulty is: How can you have that kind of flexibility and still be consistent so that people are treated fairly?'' **********Professor Wheeler also noted the potential for antitrust problems. In a hypothetical situation where a city would give approval to a shopping mall in which it held an equity stake and then reject other malls, he said that ''city power would have been used to create a monopoly.'' **********A 1984 Federal law exempts local governments from damages in antitrust actions, but plaintiffs could seek an injunction to block a project. Development Entities Set Up **********Cities are circumventing conflicts by establishing separate entities that are treated like any developer. **********The largest of these, the New York City Public Development Corporation, was formed in 1966 and has grown rapidly since 1980. It has more than 100 projects under way with a total value of close to $13 billion. These include the $130 million Morgan Stanley office building in Brooklyn in which the city has invested $12 million. It will receive 25 percent of the net cash flow. **********The Public Development Corporation has been accused of being power-hungry and ramming its projects through the regulatory red tape. However, its president, James P. Stuckey, said the corporation faces the same review as any developer. **********The corporation has a staff of 160, including lawyers, planners and engineers - an advantage that few purely private developers possess. Rather than compete with local developers, Mr. Stuckey said, his organization helps them by offering low-interest loans for projects that banks would not finance. Major Players Are Cities **********While cities remain the major players in entrepreneurial government, states, counties and even transit districts are realizing they can combine their regulatory powers and real estate to generate income. **********Los Angeles County recently granted a 66-year lease for a 26-acre parcel to be called the Long Beach/ Signal Hill Business Center. A development of Goldrich, Kest & Appel, the project is expected to bring the county $1.3 billion in revenue over the life of the lease, on property currently valued at about $11.8 million. **********In Washington, the Metropolitan Area Transit Authority has developed seven revenue-producing sites above or around station entrances. These included office buildings, retail facilities and parking structures. **********Experts say that given the revenue pressures some governments face, participation in private enterprise is likely to increase, even without further limitations on taxation. **********In most cases, the governments involved are passive stakeholders, taking a share of profits but having little role in the properties' management. **********One contrary example shows the pitfalls a city can face in trying to run a business. St. Petersburg, Fla., bought a motel for $2 million and operated it from 1978 to 1985, never earning more than $100,000 in a year. **********But the meager profits were not the only problem. When local citizens arranged for guests to stay at the motel, ''if they didn't like the color of the sheets or had a problem with a waitress, they would complain to the city council and the council would complain to us,'' said Robert Obering, the city manager. ''For all the agony we went through, it just wasn't worth it.'' **********Projects in other cities have been stalled in the planning stages by jurisdictional battles, miscalculations and inadequate resources. But the advocates of entrepreneurial government say such risks are inevitable and surmountable. **********''Entrepreneurial management says you can get into and out of any business,'' said Ted Gaebler, former city manager of Visalia, Calif., which owned and operated a minor-league baseball team for several years. **********Mr. Gaebler, now a consultant to cities and counties, said the task that remained was to re-educate the public about the role of government. ''Private companies going through a restructuring don't hesitate to educate the public about what the new nature of their business is,'' he said. ''The American public is very receptive if someone takes the time to explain changes.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/27/busin.main_headline: Dingell Bill Would Curb Hostile Takeover Moves
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/27/busin.print_headline: Dingell Bill Would Curb Hostile Takeover Moves
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/27/busin.body_text: **********Representative John D. Dingell plans to introduce legislation Monday that would outlaw or restrict a host of tactics frequently used in hostile takeovers, including ''greenmail,'' ''golden parachutes,'' ''poison pills'' and open market purchases of a target's stock. **********The Michigan Democrat's bill would also triple the time required for a tender offer to remain open, require much faster reporting time for accumulations of 5 percent of a company's stock, and ban nearly all dual classifications of stock, thereby requiring that all common stock have equal voting powers. **********Some securities experts said they had expected a more restrictive bill from Mr. Dingell. ''The legislation is not intended to stop constructive merger activity but rather to restore stability to our financial markets by curbing abusive and unfair tactics employed by both raiders and managements,'' said a statement by Mr. Dingell and Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat who is co-sponsoring the bill. **********Mr. Dingell and Mr. Markey are considered the most influential members of the House on securities matters, since they preside over the committees responsible for all securities legislation. Mr. Dingell is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee and Mr. Markey heads the telecommunications and finance subcommittee. **********The legislation follows by more than two weeks a more restrictive bill introduced by Senator William Proxmire, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee. **********Among the measures in the Dingell-Markey bill that would affect management defense tactics is a ban on greenmail, specifically prohibiting a company from purchasing its securites back from a major stockholder at a price above the ''average market prices of these securities during the 30 preceding trading days.'' The only exception would be if the purchase were approved by shareholders or offered to all shareholders. **********The bill would also prohibit managements, during a hostile takeover battle, from adopting large severance bonuses if they lose control of the company. Such payments, called golden parachutes, could, however, be adopted during the ''normal course of business'' provided they were disclosed to shareholders. **********Included is a limit on poison pills, which are provisions that foster accumulations of huge amounts of debt or other measures that make a takeover excessively costly. Any poison pill adopted during a tender offer would require shareholder approval. The bill also bans other defensive takeover measures that are not approved by shareholders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/busin.body_text: **********The dollar's value is likely to continue to decline for at least the next few months, many economists and participants in the foreign-exchange markets say. **********''I'm sure about the trend for the dollar - it's going to be down,'' said David C. Redding, a vice president and money market economist at the Bankers Trust Company. ''The only question is whether the decline will be gradual or pronounced.'' **********Economists and traders attributed the widespread pessimism to the large Federal budget deficit and the stubborn trade deficit. **********But they say the dollar might show some strength if the September trade figures, being issued today, are better than expected or if the budget negotiations yield concrete results. Some traders warn that the dollar could plummet if the talks break down. Budget Negotiators Busy **********That seemed unlikely yesterday. White House and Congressional conferees were reported near agreement on a plan to reduce the deficit by $25 billion to $30 billion, but the details are not yet worked out. **********Japan's big corporations are basing their planning on the yen's reaching 120 to the dollar by next year, according to Jay N. Woodworth, also a Bankers Trust vice president and economist, who recently returned from a trip to Japan. For the dollar, that would be a steep drop from yesterday, when there were 135.10 yen to the dollar. Further, the Japanese companies that Mr. Woodworth visited expect the dollar to fall even further in 1989, to 100 yen to the dollar. **********The bank's own economic model projects a drop in the dollar to 115 yen by the fourth quarter of 1988. The model also predicts a sharp dollar decline against the West German mark, to 1.50 marks to the dollar. Yesterday there were 1.6760 marks to the dollar. Fluctuations in Value **********On a day-to-day basis, currency dealers say, the dollar might turn, perhaps sharply, either up or down because of short-term events. **********For instance, the dollar might shoot up for a day, or even just for minutes, because of an off-the-cuff remark by President Reagan, as it did Tuesday when Mr. Reagan, in response to a question, said he thought the dollar had fallen far enough. **********In doing their job, foreign-exchange traders tend to think less about economic issues in terms of years and more about outguessing their competitors in terms of minutes. **********''No one believed the President, but what else is he going to say when asked about the dollar?'' said a leading New York trader who asked not to be identified. Despite his skepticism about Mr. Reagan's comments, the trader bought dollars as soon as he learned what the President had said. The trader explained that he expected other traders to buy dollars on the news, driving up the currency's price, and he hoped to sell later in the day after the price had risen. **********Stephen Leach, a vice president and foreign-exchange expert at the Chemical Bank, said he thinks that despite Mr. Reagan's remarks the Administration wants a weaker dollar, making American products more competitive abroad. He thinks the Government's strategy is to encourage the dollar to go lower now so that when when the major nations try to stabilize currency relationships, the Americans would be in a better position to seek a lower-value dollar. Strategy Could Change **********But that strategy could change dramatically, Mr. Leach said, if the stock market started to decline because of fears about a weak dollar. **********The fight between the Administration and Congress over how to narrow the budget deficit has been feeding the market's perception of the United States as a spendthrift nation. **********''The deficit is truly where it starts,'' said Burt R. Clark, treasurer and executive vice president of the treasury group at the National Westminster Bank USA. ''What we have is the fear that the richest coutry in the world can't control expenditures. Americans will have to take a cut in their real standard of living.'' **********Mr. Clark said he expects the yen to strengthen to 133 to the dollar within the next week or two. But he said he could not say whether he thought the dollar would collapse completely. **********''If you sell the dollar, what will you buy?'' Mr. Clark asked. ''At some point the fall has to stop.'' But like other foreign-exchange dealers, Mr. Clark wants to see action. ''The more the Administration tries to jawbone the dollar up, the more the market will test the downside,'' he said. **********A trader for a large Swiss bank, asking not to be identified, agreed. ''The main reason the dollar can't go up is that the people in charge are only talking,'' he said. ''They don't do anything but talk. It's too late. People are too disappointed.'' Focus on Budget Talks **********This trader described the dollar's recent decline as a ''collapse'' and said he thought it would fall further. **********At Morgan Stanley & Company, J. David Germany, senior economist, said that ''there will be tremendous focus on the budget negotiations'' because a reduced deficit would lead to a sounder economy in the United States, making it easier to create a more stable relationship between the dollar and other currencies. **********But some economists blame the Europeans and the Japanese. **********''With the stock market crash worldwide, the expectation of inflation has been dramatically reduced,'' said Alan Reynolds, an economist at Polyconomics Inc. of Morristown, N.J. ''It's fairly clear it's deflation abroad rather than inflation in the United States that's turning the exchange rate,'' he said. ''Our monetary policy is not too easy; theirs is too tight.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/11/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices fell on Wall Street for the third straight session yesterday as the weakening dollar once again gave investors an excuse for converting some of their paper profits into cash. **********The dollar actually closed higher yesterday, but only after a zigzag session that saw the currency rise in the early going, fall sharply in the middle of the day, and later climb slightly. **********In the end, the Dow Jones industrial average, recovering only somewhat from its lows of the day, lost 18.70 points, to 2,158.04. The blue-chip average is now down more than 43 points since last Friday. **********''When the dollar is oozing down, that's wonderful,'' one market analyst said. ''When the dollar's in a free fall, that's another thing.'' **********Most stock market professionals, while seeing clear-cut benefits from the lower dollar, are privately worried that the currency's slump could prevent interest rates from going any lower. Others, however, fear that the dollar's decline, left unchecked, could have a detrimental impact on the worldwide economy. **********''It's particularly bad lately, because it adds an element of uncertainty to the global economy when we don't need that uncertainty,'' said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities. He said the financial markets lately seemed to be ''pleading with the policy makers of the world to do something.'' **********Ironically, the lower dollar has been widely credited with helping the Dow rise 300 points in just the first month and a half of 1987. If sentiment on the dollar should change, traders think at least some of those gains could erode quickly. **********Some erosion did occur yesterday. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.65 points, to 157.18, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 3.09, to 275.07. The average share lost 43 cents on the Big Board, where there were twice as many losing issues as gainers, 1,095 to 544. **********Volume picked up slightly, but only to a modest 168.3 million shares, compared with 143.3 million Monday. **********Some investors think the three-session downturn is good for the market, especially since it gives reluctant investors a chance to get into the action. ''There are a lot of people out there hoping that stocks will come down,'' said Jon Groveman of Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company. **********But traders say that, unlike earlier this year, the bond market is reacting negatively to the dollar's decline, and that is bothering Wall Street. ''If the dollar goes into a free fall, the bond market will follow,'' Mr. Groveman said, and that ''will be too much for the stock market to handle.'' **********Fannie Mae, which is sensitive to rising interest rates, dropped 1 1/2, to 45 3/8, as the Big Board's most active issue. **********The American Stock Exchange's market-value index fell 3.01 points, to 313.64, while in over-the-counter trading the Nasdaq composite index declined 2.28, to 403.50.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.main_headline: Frost in the White House for 2 First Ladies
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.print_headline: THE SUMMIT; Frost in the White House for 2 First Ladies
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.body_text: **********Raisa Gorbachev paused for a moment on her tour of the White House today when a reporter asked whether she would like to live in such a place. **********''It's an official house,'' she said. ''I would say that humanly speaking a human being would like to live in a regular home. This is a museum.'' **********Before she could say much more, Nancy Reagan interrupted, taking her elbow and steering her toward the imposing marble mantelpiece in the State Dining Room. Mrs. Reagan actually lives upstairs in the cozier family quarters, but she showed no inclination to apologize for the stately quality of the mansion's public rooms. ''I want to show you something I really like,'' Mrs. Reagan said. A Verbal Tug-of-War **********It was Mrs. Reagan's day to be hostess and Mrs. Gorbachev's day to be the gracious guest. This guest did not seem shy about appearing to upstage her hostess. **********While their husbands were smiling and already calling each other ''Ron'' and ''Mikhail,'' their strong-willed wives remained locked in a verbal tug-of-war that even official interpreters could do little to disguise. **********From the first stop on the White House tour, when Mrs. Reagan pointed out a rather ethereal portrait of Pat Nixon, Mrs. Gorbachev made it clear that she wanted to set the agenda. Changing the Subject **********Swinging away toward a portrait of Lady Bird Johnson, the former professor of Marxist-Leninist theory assumed a schoolteacher tone and asked: ''This picture that we face, to what century does it belong? I would say it's a typical picture of the 20th century.'' **********Undaunted, Mrs. Reagan explained that the Nixon portrait was painted by Henriette Wyeth Hurd, Andrew Wyeth's sister, which prompted Mrs. Gorbachev to note that an exhibition of paintings by the Wyeth family was recently shown in Moscow. **********The two women were careful to dismiss reports that they disliked each other. 'It Seems Smaller Today' **********Before the tour began, Mrs. Reagan told reporters she found such reports ''so silly, so silly,'' adding, ''I assume she feels that way.'' **********But Mrs. Gorbachev, whose main home is believed to be an apartment in downtown Moscow, was just assertive enough to give some listeners the impression that she was sparring. **********''This is where we were last night,'' Mrs. Reagan said when they entered the State Dining Room. ''It seems to be smaller today,'' Mrs. Gorbachev replied. **********When Mrs. Reagan showed her the Red Room, Mrs. Gorbachev replied: ''Yes, we were in this room yesterday. Mrs. Shultz was quite an active guide for me.'' She was referring to a brief tour of the room by Secretary of State George P. Shultz's wife, Helena. **********When Mrs. Reagan acknowledged that an Albert Bierstadt landscape was difficult to see because of the television cameras, Mrs. Gorbachev readily agreed, adding, ''I see the light here is a problem.'' **********Peppering Mrs. Reagan with questions as if the First Lady were a graduate student facing an oral examination, Mrs. Gorbachev at times seemed to test Mrs. Reagan's composure. 'What a Big Help I Am' **********Asked when the White House was built, Mrs. Reagan apparently could not give an answer, leaving it to Betty Monkman, the White House assistant curator, to tell Mrs. Gorbachev the dates - between 1792 and 1800. **********''What a big help I am,'' Mrs. Reagan said to reporters with a sigh. **********Several times during the 45-minute tour, Mrs. Reagan let Ms. Monkman do the talking. **********At times, Mrs. Gorbachev seemed more interested in the television cameras than in the tour or her hostess. She greeted reporters with a cheery ''Good morning,'' the only English she used during the day. **********Turning toward the cameras, she told Mrs. Reagan, ''I invite you to come to Leningrad and to Moscow because you know how rich those cities are.'' Snapping at Reporters **********She did not invite Mrs. Reagan for a reciprocal visit to the homes she shares with her husband, which include their main Moscow apartment, another in the Kremlin and a dacha in the country. **********Mrs. Reagan, perhaps unwilling to show displeasure with her guest, lost her patience instead with the reporters who kept asking Mrs Gorbachev personal questions and delaying the tour. **********When one reporter asked Mrs. Gorbachev whether she would go shopping, and Mrs. Gorbachev said no, Mrs. Reagan snapped, ''I'm not going to be able to show her the rest of the house.'' **********And when Mrs. Gorbachev spoke at length about Soviet education after a reporter asked whether she had studied American history and English before the trip, Mrs. Reagan interjected, ''Regrettably, we have to move on.'' **********An unstoppable Mrs. Gorbachev refused to budge. 'I've Answered This 5 Times' **********At one point, in the East Room, Mrs. Gorbachev interrupted Mrs. Reagan in mid-sentence, telling her how much the pianist Van Cliburn, who played at the State Dinner Tuesday night, is liked in the Soviet Union. **********''Well, he is very much liked here,'' Mrs. Reagan replied. When Mrs. Gorbachev was asked again during a visit to the Blue Room whether she got along with her hostess, an exasperated Mrs. Reagan turned to the reporter and said: ''Oh, I've answered this, I think, five times.'' **********In a moment of solidarity, Mrs. Gorbachev replied: ''Well, everything is all right. It seems to me Mrs. Reagan gave the answer, and that was her word.'' Discussion of Problems **********And the two women apparently had a fruitful discussion about the drug problem in the United States and alcoholism in the Soviet Union, over coffee in the Red Room. **********By the end of the morning visit, however, White House aides were so miffed by Mrs. Gorbachev's performance that they were reduced to sniping about her clothes. **********''A bit cocktailish, don't you think?'' said one White House aide about Mrs. Gorbachev's outfit: a black crepe dress with satin collar and cummerbund and rhinestone buckle, black suede stiletto shoes and clutch bag and rhinestone applique on her baggy hose. **********Mrs. Reagan wore an understated Oscar de la Renta Glen plaid dress and a simple gold collar necklace and earrings. The Patient Husbands **********Mrs. Gorbachev's comments took so much time that President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, had to wait in the Diplomatic Reception Room for 10 minutes after their morning meeting while their wives finished coffee. **********While they were waiting, Mr. Reagan told a group of reporters later in the day, he and Mr. Gorbachev planned a little joke. **********''I suggested something to him,'' the President said, ''and we both did it -that when finally they came around and through the door, he and I were both looking at our watches. We got a laugh.'' **********Mrs. Gorbachev then went to visit the National Gallery. **********Tonight, as the President and Mrs. Reagan entered the Soviet Embassy for dinner, Mrs. Reagan was asked what she discussed with Mrs. Gorba-chev were as good friends as their hus-bands seemed to be, Mrs. Reagan said, ''I never said we weren't.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/14/world.main_headline: LEGISLATORS MOVE TO TAKE SPOTLIGHT AT IRAN HEARINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/14/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS; LEGISLATORS MOVE TO TAKE SPOTLIGHT AT IRAN HEARINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/14/world.body_text: **********The Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair reached out today, in full view of a national television audience, and tried to take back control of their hearings from the man who so dramatically dominated them last week. **********Today it was the Senators and Representatives who made the speeches, not Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. Legislators from both parties seemed determined to show that they had thought just as deeply about the conflict between the executive and legislative branches and about patriotism, freedom and democracy as had the Marine officer who lectured them last week. Senator Sets the Tone **********Senator George J. Mitchell, a Maine Democrat, set the new tone at the outset. ''Of all the qualities the American people find compelling about you,'' he told Colonel North, ''none is more impressive than your obvious deep devotion to your country. Please remember that others share that devotion, and recognize that it is possible for an American to disagree with you on aid to the contras and still love this country just as much as you do.'' [ Excerpts, pages A10 to A12. ]  Mr. Mitchell continued: ''Although He's regularly asked to do so, God does not take sides in American politics, and in America, disagreement with the policies of the Government is not evidence of lack of patriotism.'' Colonel North had urged Congress to maintain aid to the contras ''for the love of God and for the love of country.'' Constitution Is Cited **********Answering questions from the committee today, Colonel North said the plan to make him the ''fall guy'' for the Iran-contra operations was first suggested by William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, as early as 1984. He had previously testified that he had discussed such a plan with Mr. Casey last fall. It was also announced today that Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, would be the next witness, testifying again at his own request.  [ Page A10. ]  If not as dramatic as last week's ses-sions, today's offered an unusual chance to hear legislators stating their governmental philosophies and reaching back into history to buttress their arguments. The political stakes were considerable, with many committee members believing themselves in danger of seeming like a hanging jury that cared little for the broader questions of the national interest. **********The same theme as that of Senator Mitchell was sounded later by Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, who argued that ''the essence of our constitutional system is that it gives us a process by which we can resolve these sharply held differences among ourselves.'' **********''The substantive goal does not justify compromising the means.'' **********Looking straight at Colonel North, who sat solemnly as the lawmakers delivered their homilies, the Maryland Senator quoted Justice Louis Brandeis to the effect that ''the greatest dangers to liberty lurk in insidious encroachments, by men of zeal, well meaning, but without understanding.'' **********But Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, cited the Constitutional Convention of 1787 and the Israeli-Egyptian conference at Camp David in 1978 to demonstrate that ''secrecy has its uses.'' **********Nearly every one of the questioners praised Colonel North for his testimony - even those who also criticized what he did while working at the White House. Mr. Hyde declared that everyone remembered Brig. Gen. Billy Mitchell for his advocacy of air power, but almost no one remembered the prosecutor at his court-martial in 1925. **********Another defender, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, told Colonel North: ''I don't want you prosecuted. I don't. I don't think many people in America do. And I think there's going to be one lot of hell raised if you are.'' **********But tempers frayed later in the afternoon, and Representative Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas, a cigar-chewing former marine, told Brendan V. Sullivan Jr., Colonel North's relentlessly aggressive lawyer, to quit telling the committee how to conduct its business. **********The committee chairman, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, who had expressed the intention to complete the colonel's testimony today even though that would have meant continuing well into the evening, changed his mind after the shouting match between Mr. Brooks and Mr. Sullivan and ordered an adjournment shortly after 5 P.M. **********Earlier, in a long monologue, Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, came closer than anyone else to summarizing the questions that will have to be resolved at some point. as a result of Colonel North's activities and testimony. Among them were these: *********** Can any Administration avoid compliance with the law by simply launching a covert operation? If so, can a President decide, ''in his sole discretion,'' to delay notifying Congress as long as he likes? *********** Should deception ''be practiced upon Congress by deletion, or official documents reduced to confetti, while false statements are given to public officials,'' even in covert activities? *********** Can the executive branch ''authorize the sale of United States assets, inflate the prices to be paid, and then fund programs that were either not known or authorized by Congress, and in fact, had maybe even been rejected by Congress?'' *********** Should Congress ''adopt policies that deal as severely with members of Congress who reveal our country's secrets as they would with those who lie'' about those secrets? **********But it was Mr. Hyde, the white-haired legislator from the Chicago suburbs, who seemed to some in the room to best sum up the background to the whole effort to divert funds from arms sales to the contras. **********''When you have a liberal Democratic Congress,'' he said, ''God bless them all, the people elected them and that's democracy and all that good stuff, and you have a conservative Republican President, you've got a recipe for gridlock. Nothing will happen. And that is the problem we have to deal with here in our Central American policy.'' **********Senator Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire, who is the vice chairman of the Senate committee, rounded out the day by delivering his own speech to the witness because, he said, ''everyone else has had something to say to you.'' Himself a supporter of contra aid, he cited poll figures and the views of his own conservative constituents to support his contention that ''people in this country just don't think'' that contra aid ''is a very good idea.'' **********''The American people have the constitutional right to be wrong,'' he said. ''What Ronald Reagan thinks or what Oliver North thinks or what I think or what anybody else thinks makes not a whit'' of difference ''if the American people say, 'Enough.' And that's why this Congress has been fickle and has vacillated - that is correct.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/29/world.body_text: **********South Africa's authorities, who have used this disputed territory as a constitutional laboratory for a decade, now find themselves unexpectedly wrangling with a Government that they created. **********In this sparsely populated and mineral-rich territory, South Africa has experimented with refining apartheid and finding ways to transform its system of segregation and white dominance into a more sophisticated form - but one that would retain current controls - on the way to what Pretoria calls power sharing. **********And it is here in South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, that the leaders of a Government created by South Africa have challenged Pretoria in a battle over a proposed new constitution. **********The political wrangling revolves around whether a new constitution should retain the system of ''minority rights'' - Pretoria's euphemism for political apartheid whereby whites maintain segregation in schools and health facilities here. Calls for Individual Rights **********Most politicians in the so-called transitional Government argue that minority rights are best safeguarded by the protection of individual rights. **********Although there have been three interim governments since local rule was established in 1980, South Africa continues to rule the former German colony - in defiance of a United Nations independence plan dating from 1978. **********The interim governments have had no real leverage on Pretoria other than reminding President P. W. Botha of his public commitment to allow the territory's people to determine their own future without outside interference. **********Blacks have majorities in the interim Cabinet, the Constitutional Council and the National Assembly, but their political power is academic. The real power rests in segregated authorities that represent 11 racial or ethnic groups, one of which represents whites. Whites Run Institutions **********Each of these authorities technically has the power to block Government moves that would effect them. But the white authority is the most powerful since it runs most of South-West Africa's institutions, such as schools and hospitals. **********South Africa also maintains an Administrator General in Windhoek, the capital, who has limited veto power over legislation. **********The 16-member Constitutional Council was assigned to draft a constitution that did not discriminate on the basis of race. **********The proposed constitution, whose provisions have not been published, is reportedly based on a system of one person, one vote, with a bill of rights. But it is said to omit any specific reference to minority rights, a phrase President Botha regards as essential to protect the white minority in a country where 87 percent of the population is black, 7 percent white and 6 percent of mixed race. The Guerrilla War **********Pretoria's plan for South-West Africa has included a series of constitutional provisions over the years to bolster the position of so-called internal leaders who are willing to cooperate with Pretoria at the expense of the South-West Africa Peoples Organization, or Swapo, the biggest opposition party. **********Swapo, which is recognized by the United Nations as ''the sole and authentic representatives of the Namibian people,'' has a military wing that has been fighting a 21-year guerrilla war from bases in Angola, more than 450 miles north of Windhoek. **********President Botha installed the territory's latest interim Government amid much fanfare two years ago, and since then it has been promoted by a $2 million-a-year international public relations campaign. **********But now the appointed leaders of the multiracial but mostly black coalition Government are once again at loggerheads with Pretoria over its preoccupation with retaining absolute control here. This preoccupation has insured that the constitutional experiment has merely eliminated racial discrimination on the periphery, while leaving political apartheid's fundamentals intact. Segregation Remains **********Laws outlawing interracial marriage, restricting black labor mobility and demarcating racially segregated residential areas for South-West Africa's 1.2 million people have been abolished. **********But schools and medical facilities remain segregated on the insistence of the Windhoek Government's white authority, which is controlled by the South-West Africa National Party, an offshoot of South Africa's ruling National Party. **********Windhoek's Finance Minister, Dirk Mudge, who has been a top leader of the pro-Pretoria forces, has had increasingly strained relations with President Botha in recent months over the proposed constitution and other issues. **********Mr. Botha recently cut South Africa's vital annual contribution to the recession-plagued economy from $254 million to $154 million - reportedly after a clash with Windhoek leaders over the ''apartheid-free'' constitution. Afterward, Mr. Mudge warned that ''the road to constitutional and political independence would be accompanied by greater economic and financial self-sufficiency.'' 'A War Economy' **********A truly independent South-West Africa would also remain heavily dependent on the South African-trained security forces and civil service. **********Pretoria retains control of the military and the police and the responsibility for foreign affairs. The interim Government is not allowed to negotiate beyond the territory's borders on the international status of South-West Africa or send diplomatic representatives abroad. **********''Namibia is effectively a war economy,'' an economist said. ''If the military was to withdraw, the economy would collapse.'' **********Even if the proposed constitution is approved by the interim Government, after public comment, it still would face formidable hurdles. The document would have to be approved by voters. Then it could not form the basis for true independence until it was approved by all the parties to the United Nations independence plan. The Question of an Election **********Overshadowing the constitutional debate, the central question in South-West Africa remains whether President Botha is prepared to move toward an internationally supervised election. Swapo would almost certainly emerge from such an election with an outright majority because it is drawn largely from the territory's biggest ethnic group, the Ovambos, and has the prestige accruing from leading the visible struggle against Pretoria. **********Analysts of South African politics say the swing to the right in South Africa's whites-only election in May makes Mr. Botha less likely to risk a white right-wing backlash by endangering white control in South-West Africa. They also say he would be stoking the fires of black resistance in South Africa by allowing a liberation struggle to be won on Pretoria's border. **********There have been signs that three years of heightened black resistance in South Africa - including the efforts of the African National Congress, the main guerrilla group fighting to end apartheid there - have brought the constitutional laboratory closer to home. **********There are also signs that Mr. Botha is likely to continue playing for time in South-West Africa, as he has done since he took office in 1978. **********''We may yet have to ask an African National Congress government in Pretoria for our independence,'' a Swapo official joked.

Although the United States imports only 3 to 5 percent of its oil from gulf producers, the region is still a major supply factor, he said at a news conference. ''We learned from the 1970's that severe dislocations in supplies and prices affect us immediately,'' Mr. Herrington said.
