https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/19/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Is a short-term surge in interest rates good or bad for companies tied to the housing industry? As long as rates do not climb too fast - or too far -some analysts argue that the rise actually can spur business. ''People seeing rates rising will panic and buy a home quickly,'' said Jay Charles Goodgal, a Paterson, N.J., money manager. **********Is a short-term surge in interest rates good or bad for companies tied to the housing industry? As long as rates do not climb too fast - or too far -some analysts argue that the rise actually can spur business. ''People seeing rates rising will panic and buy a home quickly,'' said Jay Charles Goodgal, a Paterson, N.J., money manager. That is why Mr. Goodgal still feels comfortable buying the First American Financial Corporation, a California-based title insurance concern that has expanded into the New York metropolitan area. **********He also likes the numbers. First American was trading last week at about $61 a share, over the counter. That is less than six times the company's 1986 earnings. First American has only about 2.75 million shares outstanding, and Mr. Goodgal cautioned, ''It's very thinly traded, with a large spread'' between bid and asked prices. ''I won't pay more than a point spread,'' he said. The first quarter will get a one-time boost this year from a $9 million tax credit, according to Mr. Goodgal. That is equivalent to about $3.27 a share and could lift earnings toward $4 a share. For the year, he expects First American at least to match 1986's results, before the tax credit, and perhaps do much better. ''They're in the best markets possible, one of the biggest title insurers in California, with limited exposure to Texas,'' he said. ''And their business in the Northeast is dramatically increasing.'' **********The biggest risk? That a sustained, sharp increase in rates knocks the props from under housing demand. But a rate rise that does not stall the industry can bolster the insurer's results by lifting yields on its investments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/01/busin.body_text: **********''FRED, I think we've got a sissy here,'' said Duke Rudman to his chauffeur, Fred Washington. At the time, Mr. Rudman, clad in peach-colored jogging pants and a gray hooded sweatshirt, was digging in his toes and traipsing across an interviewer's back to demonstrate the Oriental acupressure massage therapy he had learned in Japan. **********This session in Mr. Rudman's den did not seem to be a run-of-the-mill opening for a discussion about the oil industry, but very little is run of the mill about Mr. Rudman, from his remarkable vigor to his contrarian instincts to his eye-catching attire. At 77, he is a legend in the oil industry, a maverick who has made his fortune by following his instincts. And now that exploration efforts have slowed to a virtual standstill in the depressed oil patch, the venerable oilman is once again moving against the crowd, spending millions of his own dollars to drill new wells. **********Mr. Rudman, whose career dates to back the 1930's, is an independent operator in a field increasingly dominated by corporate behemoths, a health food devotee in a world more attuned to t-bones, an aficionado of plumed hats and red velvet tuxedos in an industry that prefers conservative suits or blue jeans. And as unremitting gloom shrouds his fellow oilmen, he also stands out as an optimist. **********''I've been waiting 56 years for this,'' said Mr. Rudman. ''It's the greatest opportunity that has ever existed in my lifetime. The way I figure is that if the price of oil is 50 percent of what it was and your drilling cost is 50 percent of what it was, you're in the same situation only the deals are so much better now.'' During the boom years, he said, too many investors were crowding each other out of the best opportunities. ''Right now, I figure I'm going to go at it as hard as I can. I'm spending every dime of my income on drilling wells.'' **********Other oilmen maintain that Mr. Rudman's optimism should be taken with a few grains of salt. He can afford to be enthusiastic, they say, because he scored a remarkable coup in 1981, at the height of the oil boom, by selling off all his producting wells to the Petro-Lewis Corporation. In a debt-ridden industry, he is one of the last of an endangered species, a cash-rich oilman. He said he is investing millions of his own dollars in approximately 70 wells this year. **********Mr. Rudman bases his optimism on the lowered costs of drilling wells in a depressed industry. With the number of active oil rigs in the United States down to 839 from a peak of 4,530 in 1981, rigs can sell for 10 cents on the dollar. Promoters who once charged fat fees for oil deals are now desperate for investors. Most of the wells that could be drilled for $1 million to $3 million a few years back can be done for half that now. Mr. Rudman figures he has more chance of getting in on a deal that could turn into a major find, and he is certain the current carnage in the industry will eventually lead to shortages and substantially higher prices. **********His colleagues in the industry take a somewhat different view. ''As far as timing, I agree with Rudman,'' said George Mitchell, a Houston oilman. ''But it's going to take two or three years for the industry sentiment to change. Most oilmen are stressed, the banks are stressed, the participants are pulling back because of the new tax law. They don't feel this is the time to move in the oil business. Most people are too busy battling debt and a downward price spiral.'' **********In fact, Mr. Rudman's optimism may be as much a matter of temperament as of economics. It is not easy to find much romance in the oil industry these days, but Mr. Rudman is a throwback to an earlier era when any young man with enough moxie could turn himself into a wildcatter. Those days seem long gone, and independent oilmen have been among the worst casualties of the current oil price collapse. As such, his perspective may have as much to do with where the industry has come from as where it is going. **********''A lot of people ask me why I'm still drilling wildcat wells,'' Mr. Rudman said. ''Well, the older guys in the business have a feeling of living by the sword and dying by the sword. Living a little recklessly when all the odds are against you. It's something you can't feel unless you've done it. It's like playing football and running through 11 guys the entire length of the damn field. You got 11 guys trying to tackle you and no one gets you. You have to do it to know how it feels.'' **********Mr. Rudman, whose full name is Mayer Billy Rudman, was born in Bonham, Tex., in 1909, the son of a Russian clothier who arrived in Galveston near the turn of the century. His mother, Rose, who will turn 100 this year, was born in St. Louis. Eventually, his father got into the oilfield supply business, and the family spent Mr. Rudman's youth living in a series of Oklahoma oil towns, alighting over the years in such places as Drumright, Okmulgee, Okemah and Henrietta. **********He learned at an early age how to box, he said, because it was not easy being the only Jewish boy in a small Oklahoma town. Growing up, he worked in the oilfields every summer. After high school he spent a year at the University of Oklahoma, but soon grew restless. He dropped out after his freshman year and started hustling up oil exploration deals in southern Oklahoma and East Texas, living for a time in a pipeyard to make ends meet. Back then you could drill a well for as little as $5,000, so he was able to put together deals giving him a small share of wells financed with other investors' dollars. IT was not an auspicious beginning. He says he drilled 29 dry holes before he finally hit his first one, around 1932, at a time when oil was selling for about 10 cents a barrel. He went back and forth between Texas and Oklahoma, but spent most of his time in East Texas, where the late H. L. Hunt and thousands of other would-be tycoons were plying the 80-mile-long field that would turn out to be the richest ever found in the United States. **********By the age of 30, he had interests in 175 wells, and $5,000 in monthly income to plow back into new ventures - a relatively modest sum even then for a player in the high-stakes oil business. Mr. Rudman slowly built up his activity until 1951, when he became the first independent to drill successfully in the Williston Basin, kicking off two fields with combined production of 188 million barrels of oil and 484 billion cubic feet of gas. The strike made him, at age 42, a major independent player. ''You can say it took me out of the jerk class,'' he said. **********His best move after the Williston Basin probably came on June 30, 1981, when he sold all his producing properties to Petro-Lewis, the aggresive Denver-based oil and gas company. Mr. Rudman declines to specify how much the sale was for, saying only, ''It was enough to get my teeth fixed, and dentists are pretty expensive.'' But it included properties he had accumulated over 50 years, and industry gossip puts it in the neighborhood of $150 million. At the time he sold, oil was selling for about $36 a barrel, having peaked a few months earlier at $38, and has since skidded to a current price of less than $17. Petro-Lewis has spend much of the last year trying to stave off bankruptcy proceedings. **********Along the way, Mr. Rudman has come to be known as much for his exotic wardrobe and oratorial skills as for his business success. He was first nicknamed ''Duke'' back in the 1930's, a tribute to his sartorial splendor even in those early years when his budget was limited. In the 1960's, when his taste tended toward spats and Edwardian suits, he won some international fashion awards. These days he still dresses for work with the care most people reserve for major evening outings, picking one of his favorite Lord's San Franciscan hats off pegs on his bedroom wall before leaving for his office in a chauffeur-driven Lincoln limousine. At night, he turns up at social and sporting events ranging from charity balls to the Dallas Mavericks' basketball games. **********Outside oil and fashion, he has been an active anti-smoking crusader since 1935. He and his wife, Josephine, have been married for 53 years and have two sons, Wolfe, a former antiques dealer who recently joined his father's oil company, and Michael, a director with the National Theater in London. **********Over the years Mr. Rudman has been acquainted with most of the legendary names in the oil business, and says the best of them all was the late H. L. Hunt. ''He was one of the most brilliant men I ever met,'' Mr. Rudman recalled. ''He would have been successful at anything. A lot of people begrudge him his success, but they shouldn't. He was brilliant. He was a hard worker. Even when he was worth a fabulous amount of money, you would find him at every strike. He was always ahead of everybody.'' In 1969 Mr. Rudman decided that oilmen were not getting the recognition they deserved, so he founded the All-American Wildcatters Association, an informal oil industry fraternity that meets one weekend a year to hear a speaker and swap industry gossip. Its membership roster includes T. Boone Pickens, Bunker and Herbert Hunt, Pennzoil chairman Hugh Liedtke, former Exxon chairman J. K. Jamieson, Kerr McGee's Dean McGee and other industry giants. There are about 105 members in all, although with the passage of time there are fewer independent wildcatters and more oil industry potentates, reflecting the shift in the industry. ''I knew the public would never honor us, so I figured we could at least honor each other,'' Mr. Rudman said. ''I felt we were heroes, and I still do.'' **********That is a common refrain in the Southwest, but it is recited with particular fervor these days, in light of the current economic carnage in the industry. Like most of his fellow oilmen, Mr. Rudman is convinced that today's low energy prices must eventually lead to shortages, as American producers continue to go out of business. A recent study by the National Petroleum Council predicted that severe price shocks could be only a few years away, and that by 1995 as much as 60 percent of the nation's oil needs would have to be supplied from foreign sources, up from 27 percent in 1985. **********''Sooner or later there is going to be panic, and I mean real panic,'' Mr. Rudman said. ''Eventually people are going to get down on their hands and knees to the oilmen. It's either us or the Arabs, and I guarantee they can reason with us a lot better.'' **********Mr. Rudman's operations are now relatively simple. He buys shares in promising oil drilling activities around the nation, including some in frontier areas where no oil and gas have been found. He does not travel to do the drilling himself, but solicits and evaluates the deals that are brought to him. He is doing fewer deals than he did at the peak of the boom, when he participated in as many as 170 wells in a year, but often he is taking a larger share of them. **********Mr. Rudman says that one great discovery - like the East Texas field or Williston Basin - can make up for dozens of dry holes, particularly at today's relatively low drilling costs. **********But few of his peers in the industry or the All-American Wildcatters Association share his optimism. Most oilmen are more worried about servicing debt at a time of collapsing prices than expanding in hopes of a big hit or an eventual price rise. More important, although individual deals can be done cheaper now, the oil industry's future lies either offshore or in remote areas where only the biggest players can compete. **********Last week Conoco Inc. announced a $400 million offshore venture, adding that the industry's future will increasingly be found in deeper waters offshore. Roy Huffington, a Houston oilman and current chairman of the wildcatters' group, said it can cost as much as $150 million for one wildcat well and $1 billion in acreage to become a player in the Alaskan frontier. **********''The rewards in the business are no longer commensurate with the risks,'' Mr. Huffington said. ''You spend that kind of money and the odds are maybe one in 10 you'll find something. It takes a lot of economic staying power to play in a game like that. It was more fun when you could roll the dice with $50,000 and maybe find an East Texas field. Now you can spend $1 billion and find absolutely nothing. That stings a little bit.'' EVEN the more modest plays are less accessible to an aspiring operator than they were in Mr. Rudman's youth, because the fields are likely to be smaller and the oil found at deeper levels. ''There was just a lot more oil to be found back then,'' said Steve Schneider, a Dallas oilman and a founding member of the wildcatters' organization. ''If you have an Easter egg hunt with ostrich eggs and hummingbird eggs, you're going to find the ostrich eggs first. Then it dwindles down to the smaller things. If you found an East Texas field that was 80 miles long and 15 miles wide, a lot of people could get in on it. Nowadays a big field might be 300 to 500 acres, and it might be pretty well buttoned up before anyone can drill on it.'' **********Mr. Rudman both agrees and disagrees. He figures times are tough now, but no tougher than in the Depression era when oil was selling for 10 cents a barrel. He has seen enough booms and busts to figure there is light at the end of the tunnel. Whether the industry will ever again be a place where a boy with no money can drill 29 wells before hitting on one is open to question. But no one makes it in the oil business without being a believer, and Mr. Rudman figures the big hits are still there for those who can manage to keep looking for them. **********''If you find enough oil, price doesn't matter,'' Mr. Rudman said. ''I guess that's something that's ingrained in guys like me. We're still looking for that big one. Of the thousands of wells I've participated in, I've only been involved in five or six major fields, but if you don't have the guts or the fortitude to keep going after them, the chances of staying in this business are very slim.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.main_headline: THATCHER CALLS JUNE 11 ELECTIONS, BUOYED BY A BIG LEAD IN THE POLLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.print_headline: THATCHER CALLS JUNE 11 ELECTIONS, BUOYED BY A BIG LEAD IN THE POLLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today called a general election for June 11, a year ahead of schedule, and thus tied her political fortunes to an improving economy and her rising position in public-opinion polls. **********The Conservative Prime Minister ended weeks of increasingly feverish speculation shortly after noon when she went to Buckingham Palace and formally advised Queen Elizabeth II to dissolve Parliament. **********Under the schedule announced today, Parliament will have until next Monday to wind up its business. At that point, the parties will publish their manifestoes for the campaign in the 650 parliamentary constituencies in England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. Thatcher Ahead in the Polls **********According to the public-opinion polls, Mrs. Thatcher is positioned to lead her party to another substantial majority. Consolidated figures from the 10 most recent nationwide surveys put the Conservative Party at 41.7 percent, Labor at 30.4 percent and the Alliance parties at 25.5 percent. If evenly distributed throughout the country, that popular vote would give her a majority of about 90 seats. Her majority now is 138 seats. **********The Labor leader, Neil Kinnock, said today, ''This election is about saving our country from industrial decline, social division and the destruction of community services.'' **********The Alliance, a union of the Social Democratic and Liberal parties that is bidding to emerge as a centrist third force, condemned Mrs. Thatcher for catering to wheeler-dealers. But David Steel, the Liberal leader, said voters would also reject the ''state socialism which Mr. Kinnock offers.'' **********Another victory would make Mrs. Thatcher, who took office in 1979, the first Prime Minster in this century to win three consecutive terms. With another full term, Mrs. Thatcher would also become the century's longest serving Prime Minister, surpassing Herbert Asquith and Winston Churchill, both of whom served almost nine years. Looking to a Fourth Term **********In interviews after her announcement today, Mrs. Thatcher even raised the possibility of a fourth term. ''I hope to go on and on because I believe passionately in our policies, and I believe they are right for Britain,'' she said. She added, in response to a question: ''A fourth term? I would like to be able to, but we have first to win the third term.'' **********Conservative strategists plan to emphasize the historical shadings of this contest as they lay out two main themes for the re-election campaign. **********First, they will argue that Mrs. Thatcher needs a third term to institutionalize her free-market economic policies and prevent a return to the state ownership and economic control instituted by the Labor Government after World War II. **********Second, the Conservatives will argue that the Prime Minister will use a third term so she can extend what they call the ''Thatcher revolution'' from economics into new areas of social policy, like education, health care and housing. **********The Tory manifesto, for example, is said to include a plan to transfer rental housing from state to private ownership. **********''I think it really is a manifesto to set a course to go up to the next century,'' Mrs. Thatcher said today. ''We ought to set Britain's course for the next century, as well as this.'' Opposition Seems Eager **********The opposition leaders said they were eager to join the campaign debate on the terms outlined by the Conservatives. They see this as an opportunity to hammer at the issues of compassion and fairness and to emphasize Mrs. Thatcher's image as an uncaring ideologue. **********''Will we have a modern welfare state with Labor or end up with a poor law state under the Tories?'' Mr. Kinnock said today, sounding a central opposition theme that Thatcherism has divided Britain's haves against its have-nots. **********Mr. Kinnock said Britain's booming consumer economy, low inflation and declining interest rates had been achieved at the price of an industrial decline and rising unemployment. Although unemployment has decreased for eight months in a row, it is still over three million, or 11 percent, compared with 1.1 million, or 4.3 percent, when Mrs. Thatcher took office. **********Labor is also warning the nation's 43.6 million voters that Mrs. Thatcher's emphasis on social programs amounts to a ''hidden agenda'' to dismantle Britain's elaborate welfare system and coarsen its social conscience, so that savings on social spending can be used to finance tax cuts for the wealthy. The Alliance's Stand **********Mr. Steel's partner in the Alliance, David Owen of the Social Democrats, said the Alliance offered a ''government committed to both the competitive market economy and a concerned, compassionate society which would unite the nation.'' **********Talk of Labor and the Alliance working together in a campaign of ''tactical voting'' to deny Mrs. Thatcher a majority in a ''hung Parliament'' has recently waned as the Alliance has become more frank about its hopes of displacing the Labor Party as the main opposition force. Still, a dip below 38 percent in the total Conservative vote could cost Mrs. Thatcher her majority and open the way for her opponents to form a coalition government. That is regarded as the major risk she takes in calling an election at this point. **********By law, Mrs. Thatcher could have called an election as late as July 7, 1988. But in deciding to go to the voters with 13 months left in her five-year term, she was responding to election fever in Parliament and a series of good political and economic omens. These were capped by a strong Conservative showing in local elections last Thursday. **********Mrs. Thatcher is now Europe's longest serving elected Prime Minister and will be the senior leader at the economic summit meeting of major non-Communist industrialized nations June 8-10 in Venice. Today, advisers said she would interrupt campaigning for a one-day visit to Venice, probably on June 8.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/03/busin.body_text: **********A power struggle has broken out in the Commerce Department under its new Secretary, C. William Verity Jr., over his choice to fill the new job of Under Secretary for Export Administration, Commerce officials said today. **********Seeking to place his own man in the influential position, Mr. Verity has proposed Robert W. Dean, an alumnus of the State Department, the Pentagon and the Central Intelligence Agency. Mr. Dean is now the senior director of international programs and technology affairs at the National Security Council. **********But the choice has upset Senator Jake Garn, senior Republican on the Senate Banking Committee and one of the most persistent critics of the Commerce Department's management of export licensing programs. These programs are aimed at preventing advanced technology and other products that could have military use from reaching the Soviet Union and other unfriendly countries. **********The Utah Senator wants the new job to go to a former economist on his staff, Paul Freedenberg, who for the past two years has been Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Export Administration and is now the Acting Under Secretary. **********Administering the export rules is very sensitive because of opposing positions taken by the business community and the Pentagon. Businessmen say the controls hurt exports, and they assail curbs that bar them from a sale when their competitors in Western Europe and Japan are free to go after the same business. The Pentagon complains that too much American technology has been used in the Soviet military buildup. **********Senator Garn has long feuded with the Commerce Department over what he contended was its laxity in export-control policy. **********It was Senator Garn's 1985 amendment to the Export Administration Act that mandated a reorganization in the Commerce Department effective Oct. 1 in which export controls now get higher priority attention. Previously, management of the controls came under the Under Secretary for Trade Administration. The Garn amendment made export administration an autonomous unit within the Commerce Department and outside the trade administration office. **********''Since the post was created by Garn, and he already had his own man as Assistant Secretary, it was only natural that he would fight to have that man elevated to Under Secretary,'' said an official who asked not to be identified. **********Senator Garn is reported to have written a letter to Secretary Verity urging that Mr. Freedenberg be named. The White House office of personnel is expected to make an announcement soon. The betting is that Mr. Freedenberg will win.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/29/busin.body_text: **********British businessmen are optimistic that output and orders will continue to rise, but they also expect the recent rapid growth to taper off to a more sustainable rate, according to a report from the Confederation of British Industry. Fewer companies are working below capacity now than at any time since 1974, while a shortage of skilled labor is increasingly seen as a problem, the report said. A fourth of the business respondents said they were more, rather than less, optimistic about the outlook for their businesses than they were four months ago. This was slightly below the previous quarter's 29 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/02/busin.body_text: **********In the first phase of the personal computer boom, the industry's two software heavyweights - the Microsoft Corporation and the Lotus Development Corporation - thrived largely by staying out of each other's way. That polite, unspoken arrangement ends next week. **********On Tuesday, Microsoft is planning to introduce Excel, its innovative, graphics-heavy spreadsheet program, specifically designed to exploit the best features of the International Business Machines Corporation's new PS/2 line of personal computers. **********In the minds of many in the industry, Excel may pose the first serious challenge to Lotus's 1-2-3, the spreadsheet program whose longevity has shocked even its creators. **********For Microsoft, Excel is one of the most expensive, and by some measures one of the riskiest, in the company's 10-year history. Lotus, which dominates the spreadsheet market, has sold more than two million copies of 1-2-3. Faithful Customers **********Among numbers-crunching accountants, corporate planners and business school students the program has developed the kind of loyal following usually reserved for Madonna and the Boston Red Sox. **********''We don't expect to make a huge impact right away,'' said Jeff Raikes, who is in charge of marketing applications programs at Microsoft, which is based in Bellevue, Wash. ''But we are heading into a technology transition, and over the long term we have a major opportunity.'' **********In fact, Excel is something of a grand experiment in the software industry. The first major program designed specifically for the power, graphics and memory of I.B.M.'s new machines, it will be an early test of whether I.B.M. personal-computer users are willing to do more than trade up their hardware; it will be a test of whether they are also willing to shake old habits and rethink how they deal with information on their computer screens. **********''This will be the first glimpse of what the next generation of applications will look like,'' said Michelle Preston, an analyst at Salomon Brothers. But the power of familiarity is enormous, Ms. Preston noted. ''So to displace Lotus, this will have to be not just a little better but a lot better,'' she said. The Natural Look **********Lotus's approach seems natural to anyone who has ever used graph paper to record and tally columns and rows of related numbers, such as an inventory list or a sales projection. What the program does, however, is total the results itself, establishing mathematical relationships between figures that reside in different ''cells'' where the columns and rows meet. **********If the number in one cell changes, the values in related cells are recalculated instantly. Lotus was also the first spreadsheet with the capability to graph the results of its calculations. **********Ever since it was introduced in 1982, Lotus's computer-screen appearance has become a much copied industry standard, and spreadsheet maestros can manipulate a Lotus screen like a master pianist plays a keyboard. **********Excel's approach is different. Originally designed for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh, it makes use of small graphics characters called ''icons'' to establish links between cells and to move data around. **********Unlike 1-2-3, Excel can link multiple spreadsheets - one for each month of regional sales reports, for example, to obtain yearly totals -and make use of scores of colors to distinguish different types of numbers and charts. **********In the lingo of the computer industry, rarely known for coining graceful phrases, this Macintosh-like approach is known as a ''graphical user interface.'' Having learned a lesson from Apple, I.B.M. is wholly adopting that interface in the PS/2 line. **********Most new programs for the PS/2 line will share the same on-screen look, running under a uniform program that I.B.M. calls the Presentation Manager. (In fact, the Presentation Manager is derived from Microsoft Windows, a program that has caught on among I.B.M. PC users only in recent months.) A Popular Feature ''We think this is a case where a competitor's strength is also its greatest weakness,'' said Mr. Raikes of Microsoft. ''In the case of Lotus, the strength is an interface that people are very used to.'' He was referring to the Lotus-like spreadhseet grid and the sequence of keystrokes used to convey instructions to the computer. **********''But the world is moving toward a graphical interface,'' Mr. Raikes said. ''And Lotus is hoping that people won't want to switch.'' **********Lotus, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., and whose sales should hit $375 million this year, is hardly standing still. When Microsoft, with projected sales in the calendar year 1987 of about $400 million, recently displaced it as the largest personal-computer software company, more than a few egos were bruised in Lotus's brick-and-glass headquarters on the Charles River, overlooking Boston. **********So early next year Lotus plans to release the third and totally revamped version of Lotus 1-2-3. Among its features will be three-dimensional spreadsheets, similar to a pad of spreadsheets, many with related data. **********''It will have all kinds of powerful performance advantages,'' said Ed Belove, the head of research and development at Lotus. ''That means better graphics, including features to allow the user to define their own graphic and chart types.'' **********It will also include elements that allow companies and sophisticated users to customize versions of 1-2-3 for their own uses - currently a complex task that has spawned something of a sub-industry in the software business. **********''Remember, 1-2-3 hasn't changed much since it first came out,'' one Lotus insider said recently. ''There's a five-year-long wish list of stuff that's going to get crammed into this thing. Some of it will blow you away.'' Graphics Version to Follow **********By midyear, Lotus plans to follow up with 1-2-3G, a graphics-oriented version of 1-2-3 that will also make use of I.B.M.'s Presentation Manager. ''We aren't complacent and we never are,'' Mr. Belove said. ''But we feel comfortable that the improvements we are making in 1-2-3 will make it the most attractive spreadsheet on the market.'' **********Nonetheless, most analysts feel that Lotus's market share has no place to go but down. It commands a remarkable 80 to 90 percent of all I.B.M. PC spreadsheet sales sold today. The remainder goes to older programs and low-cost alternatives, such as Paperback Software Inc.'s VP Planner, the subject of a copyright-infringement lawsuit between Paperback and Lotus. (Another low-cost spreadsheet, Borland International's $195 Quattro, was introduced earlier this week.) Even at $495, Excel could grab 10 percent almost right away, analysts said, and do better if Lotus stumbles. ''Excel could be a $20 million product in the next 12 months,'' Ms. Preston said. ''That would be a fine performance, and still might not do much to disrupt Lotus's business.'' Powerful Computers Required **********Still, most experts expect Microsoft to face an uphill battle. Excel's heavy use of graphics means the computer's processor must constantly refresh virtually every point on the computer screen, too big a task for all but 5 to 10 percent of the older members of I.B.M.'s line. Thus, the program will only run on computers with an Intel 80286 or 80386 processor -and it will run fast only on computers with more than a million bytes of memory. **********''It's the first program that also tries to get you to buy faster hardware,'' said Steven A. Ballmer, a senior Microsoft executive. In other words, until the PS/2 line begins to infiltrate the corporate marketplace, Excel is likely to make slow progress. **********Lotus could also throw Microsoft some curves. While Excel is compatible with Lotus spreadsheets and small programs called ''macros'' that make Lotus easier to use, most experts expect Lotus to make substantial changes in its new version. That would send Microsoft back to the laboratory to keep up. **********And many analysts question whether corporate customers, who have spent millions of dollars to teach their employees how to use 1-2-3, are willing to change - no matter what hardware they buy. Losing Ground in Japan **********History is little help is judging who will prevail. Microsoft's early Multiplan spreadsheet, now aging and slow, was wiped out by 1-2-3 in the United States and is losing ground in Japan, where it was once the market leader. But the version of Excel that runs on the Macintosh, introduced two years ago, easily defeated Lotus's Jazz - an ''integrated'' program that included word-processing and communications programs, but featured a spreadsheet with too little power and flexibility. **********''One can argue that we mispositioned Jazz,'' Mr. Belove said. ''People were looking for 1-2-3 on the Macintosh, and that is not what we gave them.'' **********While Lotus won't talk about it, 1-2-3 on the Macintosh is expected soon, perhaps next year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/30/busin.body_text: **********Victor Posner pleaded no contest today to charges of evading more than $1.2 million in Federal income taxes by inflating the value of land donated to a Miami Bible college. **********United States District Judge Eugene P. Spellman accepted the plea, ending a legal battle that started in 1979. He set sentencing for Dec. 4. Mr. Posner, who remains free on bond, faces penalties of as long as 40 years in prison and fines of up to $75,000. **********Mr. Posner, a 69-year-old Miami Beach industrialist and pioneer corporate raider whose holdings include controlling interests in Royal Crown Cola, Sharon Steel and Arby's, pleaded no contest to a total of 10 counts. '86 Conviction Set Aside **********A 1986 conviction in the case had been set aside because of jury irregularities, and a retrial had been set for Nov. 2. The charges included one count of conspiracy to evade income taxes, four counts of tax evasion and five counts of making false statements in a tax return. **********His attorney, Edward Bennett Williams of Washington, said Mr. Posner's age was a factor in the plea. Mr. Williams said that if Mr. Posner had been convicted in a new trial he could be before the court for sentencing after exhausting his appeals ''at the age of 73.'' **********Prosecutors opposed the no-contest plea because it might prevent the Government from succeeding in subsequent civil suits against mr. Posner for taxes reportedly owed, according to Neil Cartusciello, with the United States Attorney's office in New York. **********Mr. Cartusciello estimated the amount of back taxes and penalties owed by Mr. Posner could amount to $1.25 million. A No-Contest Plea **********When a defendant enters a no-contest plea, it is not an admission of guilt. Rather, he is stating that he will offer no defense. The defendant is then subject to being judged guilty and punished as if he had pleaded guilty or had been convicted. However, he retains the option of denying the same charge in another legal proceeding. **********''You understand that if you enter this plea, it is a plea of guilty?'' Judge Spellman asked Mr. Posner after the plea was entered. **********''Yes, I understand,'' Mr. Posner replied. **********Mr. Posner, the son of a Russian immigrant, was a high school dropout in Baltimore. He was named the highest-paid executive in the nation by Business Week magazine in 1985. **********But his financial empire has shown signs of stress in the last few years and Mr. Posner sold off holdings to pay company debts. His Evans Products Company and Sharon Steel filed for reorganization of debts under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code. Case Started in 1979 **********Mr. Williams noted that the case started in 1979 with a civil proceeding. Mr. Posner was indicted in 1982 on tax evasion charges and filing false tax returns relating to his Federal income taxes between 1975 and 1979. The government charged that he had evaded $1.2 million taxes by inflating the value of property he donated to Miami Christian College. **********A Miami real estate broker, William Scharrer Jr., was charged in two counts with aiding and abetting Mr. Posner in tax violations. He was convicted in 1984 and sentenced to 18 months, and is appealing. **********Mr. Posner was convicted by a Federal jury on July 18, 1986, but Judge Spellman set aside the verdict and declared a mistrial, later disclosing he had found, among other things, that one juror had driven out to see the property that the Government contended Mr. Posner had overvalued.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.main_headline: Africans Cite War's Toll on Children
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.print_headline: Africans Cite War's Toll on Children
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.body_text: **********Life has become a doubtful proposition for the four million children caught in the crossfire of Africa's wars. **********The death rate of this continent's children, from bullets and preventable diseases, is soaring, and the toll exacted by conflict is felt in other serious ways: Children often lose their homes and clothing and, because of the protracted chaos, cannot attend school. Many have seen their parents killed or have been separated from their families. With anxiety and depression as uncompromising companions, they wander toward a future that seems to offer more despair than promise. **********In an attempt to find ways to ease the plight of these victims, about 100 representatives of African governments, international humanitarian organizations and non-governmental groups met here last week in the first conference on the continent devoted to the impact of war on children. **********The participants recommended, among other things, that the Organization of African Unity work with governments and other bodies to promote the continent as a ''zone of peace,'' where children would be guaranteed access to basic services and protection. They called on governments and international agencies to immediately assess the effect of Africa's various wars on women and children, who were said to be the main victims, with a view toward providing help based as much as possible on resources available locally. Apartheid Condemned **********The conference, sponsored by the United Nations Children's Fund and the Nairobi-based African Network on Prevention and Protection Against Child Abuse and Neglect, identified South Africa's system of apartheid as a ''form of war'' that was particularly destructive to children and urged all countries and humanitarian groups to brng it to an end . **********A conference paper on Mozambique, a southern African country that has experienced one of Africa's grimmest and most prolonged conflicts, reflected the bleak situation in strife-torn areas elsewhere on the continent. The report said that the decade-long war, in which the Marxist Government has been fighting South African-backed rebels, had helped to raise the mortality rate of children under the age of 5 to as many as 375 per 1,000 last year from 182 for each 1,000 in 1980. It said the conflict had resulted in the death of 320,000 children between 1981 and 1986. **********''Normal family and community life in Mozambique is being destroyed,'' said the paper, which was prepared by the country's Ministry of Health in collaboration with humanitarian organizations. **********''The high mortality rate caused by the war, the displacement of millions from their homes, the separations that take place when communities are attacked, are major factors. However, the psychological stress caused by uprooting and insecurity, the lack of essential goods, the overcrowding in urban areas, also contribute to the breaking up of the family structure. The vast majority of families in Mozambique are unable to meet their children's basic needs, not just for food and shelter but for stimulation, love and stability. The consequences of this situation will have to be dealt with over a long period of time.''

Again, the Indian capital is draped with banners proclaiming the country's friendship with Moscow. **********The occasion is a huge Festival of the Soviet Union mounted this week by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Nikolai I. A Master of Balancing **********India, a leader of the nations professing nonalignment, has long had close ties with Moscow. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/24/busin.body_text: **********Oregon and other states plan to invest millions of dollars in the $5 billion fund being raised by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company to finance leveraged buyouts, according to state officials and the New York-based investment firm. **********The Oregon Investment Council, which is responsible for investing state money, has pledged $600 million for the buyout fund, which is believed to be the largest in the business. **********The fund is to provide equity for leveraged buyouts, which are corporate acquisitions that rely mainly on the use of borrowed money. **********The Oregon council made the commitment after being approached by George Roberts, a partner at Kohlberg, Kravis, according to The Oregonian newspaper. Mr. Roberts said nine other states already had made commitments to the fund, including Illinois, Iowa, Massachusetts, New York and Washington. **********He said the new fund was expected to invest in eight to 12 leveraged buyouts in the next five years. **********The state's decision to invest in the fund comes less than a week after Oregon enacted a new law intended to help companies fight off hostile takeovers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/05/world.body_text: **********The special prosecutor in the Iran arms case is expected to assume control soon of a Justice Department investigation in Miami of possibly illegal aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, according to Government officials knowledgeable about the case. **********Their accounts are the first strong indication that the inquiry by the prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh, will extend to cases not necessarily stemming from the arms sales to Iran. **********In another development in the broadening inquiry, legal sources said two New York lawyers, Alan Levine and Guy M. Struve, were expected to be named as assistants to Mr. Walsh, pending a background investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. **********Mr. Levine is a member of the Manhattan law firm of Kronish, Lieb, Shainswit, Weiner & Hellman, and is a former Assistant United States Attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Struve is a member of the Manhattan law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, where Mr. Walsh was a partner from 1961 to 1981. **********The Justice Department's Miami investigation, which apparently will now be handed over to Mr. Walsh, began in October 1985 following news reports that a group of Cuban exiles, including some Bay of Pigs veterans, had shipped six tons of automatic rifles, mortars and other weapons from a Fort Lauderdale airport to the Nicaraguan rebels, known as contras. Law enforcement officials have not indicated that there is a link between these shipments and the Iran arms sales. **********Federal authorities said a grand jury began hearing evidence in the case last fall. **********In the court order announcing his appointment, Mr. Walsh, who is formally known as an independent counsel, was provided with powers to investigate any allegations of illegal support for the Nicaraguan rebels that involved American officials and that took place during or after 1984. **********The court's mandate went further than the Justice Department's original request, which had asked only that the special prosecutor investigate financing of the contras as it related to the Iran arms sales. **********According to the Government, millions of dollars in profits from the arms sales were diverted for use by the contras. **********The Justice Department's request also asked that the investigation study allegations dating back only to 1985. In 1984, Congress barred the Government from spending money in direct or indirect support of the contras. **********Government officials said they believed Mr. Walsh would also take charge of investigations by the F.B.I. and Customs Service into Southern Air Transport, a Miami-based carrier that has been linked to the contra supply network and the effort to sell weapons to Iran. **********The Justice Department recently acknowledged that it delayed the inquiries for several weeks last fall because the White House was concerned that investigators might interfere with delicate hostage negotiations in the Middle East. **********At the time of the delay, the department said, prosecutors were unaware of any connection between arms sales in Iran and events in Nicaragua, except that Southern Air Transport might have been somehow involved in transporting equipment to both nations. **********Mr. Walsh, the officials said, appeared to be moving quickly to begin his investigation and had already tentatively selected several lawyers to serve as his assistants. They said some of the names had been submitted to the F.B.I. for background checks. **********Mr. Levine, 38 years old, served as an Assistant United States Attorney in Manhattan from 1975 to 1980. He graduated in 1973 from the law school at New York University, where he was editor of the law review. **********Mr. Struve (pronounced STROO-vee), who turns 44 on Monday, graduated from the Harvard Law School in 1966 and served as a law clerk for J. Edward Lumbard, former chief judge for the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York. **********Mr. Levine and Mr. Struve did not return messages left with workers at their offices today. **********Government officials said Mr. Walsh, a former Federal judge in New York, was expected to talk this week with Justice Department prosecutors to discuss the scope of his inquiry. **********A department official who asked not to be named said Mr. Walsh would probably ''take over whatever investigations he wants to take over.'' **********It is unclear, the official said, whether Mr. Walsh will seek to take control of a separate Federal investigation in Georgia focusing on Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force major general who has been linked to the contra supply effort. **********Officials said Mr. Walsh might also be entitled to take over several Iran arms smuggling cases that have no apparent connection to the contras. The Justice Department has disclosed several cases in which Americans are charged with smuggling arms to the Teheran Government. **********Mr. Walsh is in contact with the F.B.I. and has been briefed on several aspects of the bureau's investigation into the Iran arms case, officials said. **********They said it had become clear that Mr. Walsh's investigation would not be concluded quickly. ''Look for a year,'' one said. ''Maybe you'd better look for two.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/12/busin.body_text: **********Retail sales fell six-tenths of 1 percent in May, the biggest decline in four months, the Commerce Department said today. **********The decline was mostly a result of weak automobile sales, but the report raised new concerns among economists about the prospects of a recession. **********The Commerce Department said sales dipped to a seasonally adjusted $124.0 billion last month, after increasing two-tenths of 1 percent in April. **********Since February, retail sales have been essentially flat. Consumers, burdened by high levels of debt and weak growth in income, have sharply cut back on purchases of such discretionary items as cars and furniture. **********Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of overall economic activity, has been the driving force behind the nation's recovery from the 1981-82 recession. Recovery Could Be in Danger **********Spending this year is expected to increase by only 2 percent, half the growth rate of 1986. Analysts said that if this scaled-back forecast proved to be too optimistic, the recovery could be in danger. **********''The retail sales report makes me nervous,'' said Sandra Shaber, economist at the Futures Group, a Washington forecasting firm. ''I would have liked to have seen more activity outside of autos, and we just didn't get it.'' **********The weakness last month was led by a 3.8 percent drop in car sales, the largest monthly decline since January. Excluding autos, retail sales would have risen only three-tenths of 1 percent, but analysts said most of this advance resulted from higher prices rather than from greater sales volume. Figures 'Look Pretty Weak' **********''The retail sales figures look pretty weak,'' said Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch in New York. ''Consumer spending will rise much more slowly than it did in 1986 because income growth is very weak and savings are virtually nonexistent.'' **********Deborah Johnson, senior economist at Prudential-Bache Securities in New York, predicted that overall economic growth, as measured by the gross national product, would probably not exceed 2 percent this year. That would be even less than the 2.5 percent growth in the G.N.P. in 1986, a year in which the economy was suffering from a slump in manufacturing. **********''Now we are beginning to see a little bit of an upturn in the industrial sector, but that will probably be offset by a weak consumer,'' she said. ''We are not worried about a recession right now, but if interest rates push up a lot higher, you would have to begin to worry.'' **********The six-tenths of 1 percent drop in retail sales in May was the biggest decline since a record plunge of 7.1 percent last January. **********Sales of furniture and other home furnishings fell eight-tenths of 1 percent last month after declining five-tenths of 1 percent in April. Sales at hardware stores edged up three-tenths of 1 percent in May after dropping 3.2 percent in April. Durable Goods Down 2.5% **********The total category of durable goods - items designed to last three or more years - fell 2.5 percent in May following a tiny gain of one-tenth of 1 percent in April. **********Sales of nondurable goods were up six-tenths of 1 percent in May after a smaller two-tenths of 1 percent increase in April. **********Sales of nondurable goods at department stores and other general merchandise stores rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in May. The sales had risen five-tenths of 1 percent in April. **********Sales at apparel specialty stores were up 1.3 percent, the largest increase of any category, followed by an increase of eight-tenths of 1 percent in sales at gasoline stations. Analysts said both gains were heavily influenced by rising prices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/27/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Bond Prices Move Downward
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/27/busin.body_text: **********Bond prices ended lower in very thin trading yesterday as market participants continued to react to a weaker dollar and lower-than-anticipated retail interest in this week's Treasury refunding. **********Some brokers said the lower prices might represent an effort by bond dealers to stimulate interest in the securities that were auctioned on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. **********''The bond market continues to move in step with the currency market,'' said Theodore Tung, chief economist at the National City Corporation in Cleveland. The dollar was weak in Europe on Thursday night and in New York yesterday morning. Bond Yields Less Attractive **********''A strengthening of the dollar and a lower-than-expected rise in the Consumer Price Index had sustained the bond market's rally until the end-of-the-quarter Treasury mini-refunding,'' Mr. Tung said. He added that bond yields, which have dropped substantially in recent weeks, were now less attractive to many investors, so that a further rally at this time would be more difficult. **********After opening lower, bond prices eroded through the afternoon to the close, hurt by the mixed results of the Treasury auctions. Yields on the three new issues in the $24.25 billion financing have generally risen since the issues were sold. **********The two-year notes, which sold at an average yield of about 7.46 percent on Tuesday, were up to 7.52 percent early yesterday afternoon and by late in the day were at 7.49 percent. The four-year notes, which sold at 7.89 percent on Wednesday, were at 7.93 percent at midafternoon and 7.89 percent late in the day. And the seven-year notes, sold Thursday at a yield of 8.10 percent, ended at about 8.19 percent. **********Dealers said it appeared that the amount of demand expected when the bids were submitted on the new seven-year paper had been overestimated. Demand Overestimated **********Some estimated that bids from Japanese dealers totaled $1 billion to $2 billion. This was in line with what had been expected until just before the auction, when optimistic market talk raised the estimate of the Japanese buying to as much as 30 percent of the refinancing. Others said that an overestimation of domestic retail demand had led some dealers to bid more aggressively than warranted. **********The Treasury is expected to auction $9.75 billion of one-year Treasury bills on Thursday. **********By late in the day, the closely watched long-term bond, the 8 3/4 percent Treasury issue due in 2017, was offered at 102 31/32, off 19/32, to yield 8.47 percent. **********Short-term rates were mixed. Three-month Treasury bills fell four basis points, to 5.80 percent, while the six-month bill rose three basis points, to 6.13 percent. **********In the corporate bond market, prices were lower as they followed the lead of the weaker government securities. **********Among the few new issues priced yesterday was a $200 million speculative-grade financing by the Catalyst Energy Corporation, which offered 7 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2002 at a price of par through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at $25.45 a share.

Lipton Inc.'s best-selling Cup-a-Soup. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/15/busin.main_headline: Jim Walter Stock Rises Above Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/15/busin.print_headline: Jim Walter Stock Rises Above Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/15/busin.body_text: **********Investors pushed the stock of the Jim Walter Corporation slightly above $60 yesterday, on speculation that a higher bid for the company might be forthcoming. **********On Thursday, the large home-building concern agreed to be acquired through a leveraged buyout by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company for $60 a share in cash, or $2.43 billion. **********The bid from Kohlberg, Kravis was sweetened by $10 a share from an offer the firm made in mid-July and appeared to cap a behind-the-scenes bidding war for Jim Walter, a battle that was joined by several financial companies. **********Jim Walter's stock closed at $60.50 in consolidated trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, up 62.5 cents on the day. **********Yesterday's activity in the stock was fueled by a report that appeared in Friday's editions of The Wall Street Journal that one of the bidders, Paine Webber Inc., had made a higher bid for the company than the one it accepted from Kohlberg, Kravis. **********The Journal reported, and Paine Webber officials confirmed, that the investment banking firm had made two offers. The officials said yesterday that the firm was considering whether it would make another bid. **********''We are examining all of our options,'' said Jack Perkowski, director of investment banking at the firm. **********Paine Webber's first offer was presented on Monday to a group that included bankers from Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., Jim Walter's investment adviser, and members of Jim Walter's board who are not part of management. **********That offer was to merge the companies at $69 a share, or $2.8 billion. Of that total, $60 was in cash, $5 in subordinated debt securities and $4 in equity securities. Debt Burden Cited **********That offer was withdrawn after the management at Jim Walter told Paine Webber a merger deal would take too long and would burden the company with too much debt, a disincentive for managers who would participate in a leveraged buyout. **********''There are two pulls on management in a leveraged buyout situation,'' said one Wall Street analyst, who asked not to be identified. ''First, they want to maximize payment to shareholders. But they also want to maximize their own opportunity as participants in the leveraged buyout. The more you pay up front the less you have available later.'' **********The second Paine Webber offer, submitted late Wednesday, was a tender offer of $62 a share, or $2.52 billion. That offer was composed of $52 in cash and $10 in securities. It was rejected in favor of the all-cash offer from Kohlberg, Kravis on Wednesday evening. Proxies and Votes Required **********Tender offers, like the ones made by Kohlberg, Kravis and Paine Webber, can be completed in as few as 20 days. Mergers, by contrast, can take as long as three months to complete because they require that the company send out proxy statements to shareholders and that holders vote. **********Yesterday Mr. Perkowski and Joseph Flom, the firm's outside counsel, went to pains to argue that the offer of $69 a share presented greater value to shareholders than the one from Kohlberg, Kravis. **********But Stephen Waters, co-head of mergers and acquisitions at Shearson Lehman Brothers, said yesterday that the $69 offer was not a viable one when the final deliberations began. ''We specifically asked them if the $69 offer was on the table,'' he added. ''They said no, it is withdrawn, and we have a $62 proposal.'' **********Meanwhile, Jim Walter was busy preparing tender documents that will go to shareholders on Wednesday. ''A document will go out to shareholders in less than a week laying out the particulars of how this transpired and the facts of the agreement,'' David L. Townsend, a spokesman for Jim Walter, said. ''Until that time we cannot comment.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/23/busin.main_headline: Big Board, Amex Set Shorter Hours
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/23/busin.print_headline: MARKET TURMOIL; Big Board, Amex Set Shorter Hours
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/23/busin.body_text: **********The New York and American stock exchanges, responding to the frenzied pace of trading, announced yesterday that they would shorten their hours today, Monday and Tuesday, halting at 2 P.M. instead of 4 P.M. **********The Chicago Board Options Exchange also said it would close two hours early on those days. Other markets are expected to follow, including the over-the-counter market. **********The crush of business this week will also mean that workers at the New York and American exchanges will be called in over the weekend to help clear out the paperwork that backs up each trade. **********The decisions were an enormous relief to Washington and to many of the investment houses, which had been under heavy strain from the wild fluctuations plaguing the market and the avalanche of trading activity. Since Friday, volume on the Big Board alone has topped 2.3 billion shares, nearly as much as was traded in all of 1967, and leading indexes of the markets have closed lower on five of the last seven trading days. **********''The system needs time to catch its breath,'' said John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, at a hastily arranged news conference yesterday. He said any further decisions to curtail trading later next week would be made ''on a day-to-day basis.'' **********While the market was open, the New York Stock Exchange also announced that it had curbed certain program trading. Requests of Members Cited **********Mr. Phelan said that the markets ''behaved extraordinarily'' in the face of unprecedented trading activity but that during the past few days member firms had requested shortened trading days. He said Thursday's trading had shown signs of ''being less volatile.'' But he also said there were ''at least three or four Congressional investigations under way'' on the origins of the selloff and that the Securities and Exchange Commission would also explore trading problems. **********Major brokerage houses also announced that they expected their staffs to report to work on Saturday to help with the backlog. **********Merrill Lynch & Company, E.F. Hutton Group Inc. and Shearson Lehman Brothers said they would also extend the hours of their branch offices this weekend to respond to investor inquiries. **********''I asked that the exchanges be closed,'' said Nathan Gantcher, president of Oppenheimer & Company. ''I just think the people physically cannot take what's happening. The system is not built to handle the things that have happened in the past few days. At the rate it was going, it was going to kill people. Those people it did not kill, they would be making a lot more mistakes.'' **********One problem pointed out by Mr. Phelan concerns what traders call making comparisons. The so-called back-office procedure works when buyers and sellers of the same trade compare notes on what each side did. But problems can arise, for instance, when one trader thinks that he has sold 10,000 shares of Exxon, while the buyer from a different firm assumes he has bought 10,000 shares of American Express. **********Despite some feeling that the shorter hours should not be allowed to continue too long, money managers endorsed the move. **********''I think it's a great idea,'' said Charles R. Utoft, trading director of I.D.S. Financial Services, the mutual fund arm of the American Express Company. ''Everybody kind of needs a rest.'' **********Still, Jefferies & Company of Los Angeles, which provides a ''third market'' for trading when the exchanges are closed, said it would offer that service as usual today, Monday and Tuesday. A Balancing Act **********Directors of the New York Stock Exchange met yesterday morning to decide how best to handle the enormous volume and volatility of the market in the past week. **********''The board felt that it had a certain amount of balancing to do,'' said Roberta S. Karmel, one of the directors. ''There is always a fear that given the general nervousness of the world, that this could somehow trigger a greater nervousness. But we had to balance that with the orderly settlement of these transactions.'' **********Mr. Phelan, who ultimately made the decision to curtail trading, has been in touch with Government officials at the Federal Reserve, the Treasury Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission. He is also said to have discussed curbing hours with senior officials at the White House. **********At his news conference last night, President Reagan said he had approved the move. And immediately after the exchange's announcement was made, it was endorsed by the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********The move to curtail hours is not without precedent. In the 1960's, the New York and American exchanges and the National Association of Securities Dealers, which is responsible for the over-the-counter market, cut trading time and, during the summer of 1968, even closed the markets for four days to clean up logjams. Saturday paperwork sessions were introduced in the 1980's during periods of heavy volume. The New York exchange also shortened trading days in the 1970's, when it suffered problems while it changed to a computerized system. Problems Seem Even Worse **********But this week's problems seemed worse. At certain points the market reporting system was two hours late. Many investors have complained that they have been unable to reach their brokers. And once brokers had been reached, the investors said, it was exceedingly difficult to execute trades at prices that had been requested. **********Mr. Phelan said that the New York Stock Exchange did not count the number of complaints it had received in recent days. At the American Stock Exchange, complaints against brokers doubled in the past week. S.E.C. officials said that they had received a higher volume of complaints from shareholders than normal, although the precise number will not be known until next week at the earliest. **********The wild gyrations of Wall Street have also begun to spawn scores of lawsuits and arbitration claims, many directed against brokers and dealers who have had difficulty in executing customer orders. **********Since Monday afternoon, clients in increasing numbers have contacted lawyers to try to recoup losses, and brokerage houses have been bracing themselves for a potential tidal wave of legal actions, according to lawyers and executives who insure financial institutions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/28/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Stone to Purchase Southwest Forest
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/28/busin.body_text: **********The Stone Container Corporation, one of the nation's largest producers of corrugated container and paperboard products, said today that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Southwest Forest Industries for $32.25 a share, or $441.8 million. **********The announcement caps a year in which Stone has increased its production capacity and broadened its product line through acquisitions and other investments. Last February, Stone paid $510 million for the Champion International Corporation, which makes corrugated containers and strong brown wrapping paper. In October, Stone acquired a 49 percent interest in the Seminole Kraft Corporation for $7.5 million. **********In the Southwest purchase, Stone said it would also assume $264 million in long-term debt and $57 million of redeemable preferred stock. **********The purchase will increase Stone's presence in the Southwest and will give the company a foothold in the newsprint industry. Southwest is the nation's 10th-largest newsprint producer. **********Stone also said it had received new loan commitments for $1.1 billion. It said $800 million of that would go toward the Southwest acquisition, and another $100 million would redeem an earlier letter of credit. An additional $200 million, in the form of an ''evergreen'' revolving credit, will be avaiable for general corporate purposes. **********The acquisition will raise the Chicago-based company's debt-to-capitalization ratio to 73 percent, from about 58 percent. While Stone officials concede this is substantially above the industry average of roughly 50 percent, they said they expect strong cash flow to help them lower it to that level by 1988. **********Southwest, which is based in Phoenix and operates paper mills in Florida and Arizona, reported a loss in 1986 of $1.7 million, resulting from the conversion of 36.2 million debentures into common stock. Sales had reached $631.5 million. **********For the first nine months, Stone reported net income of $10.7 million on sales of $1.46 billion. **********Southwest's stock rose $7.50 a share today, to $31.125, with 2.7 million shares changing hands, making it one of the biggest gainers and most active stocks on the New York Stock Exchange. Stone Container closed at $74.50, up $2.
