https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/world.body_text: **********The people of this single-belfry village, about a 90-minute drive from Paris, say that from time to time they saw Nathalie Menigon doing her shopping in town. But as the local butcher put it, nobody could have been expected to recognize her. **********''Sure,'' a local policeman said, ''we were instructed to be on the lookout'' for Ms. Menigon and Jean-Marc Rouillan, two of France's most wanted terrorist suspects, ''because it's well known that the forests around here would be ideal hiding places. But, you know, it's not easy. For us they seemed to be just another couple from Paris with a country house.'' **********Ms. Menigon and Mr. Rouillan, the two leading members of the French urban guerrilla group Direct Action, were captured here Saturday night along with two other members. The arrests were carried out in a police raid on an isolated farmhouse on the edge of Vitry-aux-Loges, where the couple had lived for three years. **********In the end, according to investigators, Mr. Rouillan and Ms. Menigon were turned in by an informant who telephoned the police, giving them the exact location of the farmhouse here. The investigators said the informant received a reward, posted some months ago, of nearly $180,000. **********Perhaps more surprising than the arrests was that Ms. Menigon and Mr. Rouillan - objects of one of France's most intense police searches - were able to live more or less openly here as long as they did. The village, 20 miles east of Orleans, is not far from some of the Loire valley's noted chateaus, although it is relatively obscure itself. **********The villagers say Mr. Rouillan and Ms. Menigon, who called themselves Robert and Nadine, blended in so well that nobody, including the members of the local gendarmerie, ever suspected them of being fugitives. **********''There are 5,500 country houses in the township,'' said a local police officer, standing across a pasture from the long, low-slung farmhouse, backed by clumps of trees, where the couple lived. ''And there are only 10 policemen.'' The local butcher said of Ms. Menigon: ''I think I saw her once or twice, but I didn't know it was her. She doesn't look like her picture.'' **********Somewhat faded black-and-white photographs of Ms. Menigon and Joelle Aubron, who was also arrested on Saturday, have been posted in some 80,000 public places in France since November, after Direct Action took responsibility for the slaying of Georges Besse, the chairman of Renault, in front of his home in Paris. The two women are suspected by police of having carried out the killing. **********The identity of the informant who telephoned the police has not been disclosed, but he is assumed to have been in the small circle of friends and supporters that have surrounded Direct Action since it emerged in 1979. **********After the informant's call, an anti-terrorist squad observed the farmhouse with binoculars from across fields and surrounding woodland. After 36 hours, when two other members of the group, Georges Cipriani and Ms. Aubron, turned up on Saturday night, several dozen officers moved in to capture all four without firing a shot. **********Both Mr. Rouillan and Ms. Menigon have been in police hands before. The two were arrested in May 1980 when the police lured them into a trap after Direct Action had carried out several bomb attacks against Government and corporate buildings. Mr. Rouillan gave up without a struggle, but Ms. Menigon, shouting ''I am Direct Action,'' emptied two .45-caliber pistols in the direction of the police. She missed. #16 Freed Under Amnesty A year later, as part of a general amnesty, the newly elected Socialist Government freed 16 imprisoned members of Direct Action, including Mr. Rouillan. Ms. Menigon, because she had shot at the police, was not included, but she was released several months later after a three-week hunger strike. **********Two reasons were given for the amnesty: the group's attacks had not at that point caused any casualties, and the Socialists believed that a gesture toward radicals would deter them from resuming terrorist activities. **********But investigators say Mr. Rouillan has told his interrogators that he resumed his activities almost immediately because he preferred the life of a guerrilla to legal political activity. **********Mr. Rouillan, who is 34 years old, has long been a radical leftist. In the early 1970's he founded the Internationalist Group for Revolutionary Action, which carried out bomb attacks in Paris. **********In 1977, after three years in jail, he met Ms. Menigon, a bank clerk with radical political views. They formed Direct Action in 1979, bringing together several underground splinter groups. A Close Call in Belgium **********In 1982, after their release from prison, the Government formally banned Direct Action and the two went into hiding. In early 1984 the police spotted them crossing into Belgium. The Belgian police picked up the trail, but Mr. Rouillan and Ms. Menigon escaped by taking a policeman hostage. **********In the meantime, Direct Action's attacks became more deadly. In addition to the killing of Mr. Besse, it took reponsibility for the killing of a French Army general, Rene Audran, in January 1985, and a bombing at a Paris police headquarters last July that killed an officer and wounded 22 others. **********According to residents of Vitry-aux-Loges, including two farm families who lived within sight of the farm where Mr. Rouillan and Ms. Menigon lived, the two of them were quiet and polite but distant and little seen. **********Neighbors say Ms. Menigon, 29, raised two goats and several hamsters. At one point she helped to care for the aging grandmother of one of her neighbors. She told them that she was a Belgian citizen and had worked as a Government researcher. They rented the farmhouse for $600 a month from its owners, who lived in Paris. **********''She was adorable with Grandma,'' a neighbor told Le Monde. ''She liked animals. I would never have thought her capable of killing. She had me sign a paper saying I would take care of her two goats, Lucy and Nova, if anything happened to her.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/busin.snippet: LEAD: It is more fitting than it might seem that a three-acre site in Yonkers once occupied by a secondary school should be developed as an apartment complex for the elderly.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/busin.main_headline:
ABOUT REAL ESTATE;
'CONGREGATE-CARE' PROJECT IN YONKERS FOR THE ELDERLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/busin.print_headline:
ABOUT REAL ESTATE;
'CONGREGATE-CARE' PROJECT IN YONKERS FOR THE ELDERLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: It is more fitting than it might seem that a three-acre site in Yonkers once occupied by a secondary school should be developed as an apartment complex for the elderly. **********It is more fitting than it might seem that a three-acre site in Yonkers once occupied by a secondary school should be developed as an apartment complex for the elderly. **********River Towers, a $35 million, 208-unit luxury apartment house that is to be constructed on the site, has been designed for healthy old people who are active and young at heart. **********What Noah Berley, a Brooklyn developer, has in mind for the property, which is on Riverdale Avenue and meanders over the New York City line into Riverdale, is a residence for people in their 70's who wish to live independently in their own apartment but have central dining facilities and on-site opportunities for recreation and social events. **********Such ''congregate-care'' projects have become popular housing alternatives for older people elsewhere in the country. But River Towers will be one of the first of its kind in the metropolitan area. A similar luxury complex is under construction in Plainview, L.I., by Darren Enterprises of Plainview, and others are planned in Brookhaven, L.I. **********''We expect to fill a vacuum in the market, by appealing to people who want the companionship of their contempories and who are interested in doing and learning and participating,'' Mr. Berley said. ''This is not a nursing home. You have to be capable of independent living.'' **********Construction of the building is expected to start in the spring and will take about 18 months to complete. Because it is an as-of-right project, requiring no variances or city assistance, it will not be affected by a Federal court order that has postponed other Yonkers real estate projects. **********One reason that developments of the kind Mr. Berley is planning have lagged has been the difficulty of finding suitable sites, he said. Proximity to transportation and location in a good neighborhood are essential. **********''This is the best kind of location because it's full of activity, young people, life, and a sense of neighborhood,'' he said, indicating with a sweep of his arm the campus of the College of Mount St. Vincent, a small liberal arts college adjoining his property. **********The new residential tower will sit on a hill overlooking the Hudson and Palisades, shielded from urban congestion by a greenbelt of trees and small public park to the west and by the college campus to the south. But it will also be in the mainstream. At its doorstep will be Riverdale Avenue, with shopping within walking distance, and public bus service to midtown Manhattan. **********The L-shaped, 12-story building will have a red brick facade with precast concrete trim. It will contain a mix of studios and one- and two-bedroom apartments. The units will vary in size from 378 square feet for a studio to 938 square feet for a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment. **********Rents will start at $2,500 monthly for a studio and will range up to $3,800 monthly for a two-bedroom unit. The price will include two meals a day, social activities including trips, housekeeping services and some laundry service. A couple would pay an additional $350 a month. To meet those rents, tenants would need an annual income of $35,000 to $45,000. **********The architects are Samuel and David J. Paul of Forest Hills, Queens. What they want to achieve with their design, David Paul said, is a dynamic flow between common areas that will encourage residents to mingle. **********The focus of the building will be toward a landscaped rear garden with paths and sitting areas. Terraces will lead to the garden from the dining room and lounges, which will be on the first floor adjoining the main lobby. A card room and a snack bar will also be on the main floor. Each of the upper floors will have a lounge area. Apartments, on the second floor will be reserved for people who may need help with dressing and personal care. **********A 23,000-square-foot lower level will be the center for social and recreational activities. It will contain an auditorium, library, rooms for arts and crafts and an exercise and physical therapy center. There will also be a beauty salon, a convenience store and a bank branch. **********On Long Island the Greenbriar in Plainview is similar in concept to River Towers. The Greenbriar is already under construction, with occupancy to begin early next year. Rents have not yet been established, said Donald Monti, the president of Darren Enterprises. The 150,000-square foot building will contain 100 studio and one-bedroom apartments. Amenities will include and indoor pool and an outdoor pool. **********Other such projects are in the early planning stages in Brookhaven, after new zoning was adopted last summer by the Long Island town. **********''There is a real need out here that we want to encourage developers to meet,'' said Thomas Cramer, the town's deputy commissioner of planning, environment and development. **********Developers of projects that provide congregate facilities and meet Brookhaven's guidelines will be permitted a density of 20 units to the acre, almost double the density allowed under other zoning categories.

Ershad resign, opposition leaders said today. Government officials acknowledged that 519 people had been detained. **********Opposition parties have called for a ''siege of Dhaka'' on Nov. 10 to bring down the Government, which oponents say has destroyed the economy and militarized administration. **********President Ershad siezed power in a military coup in March 1982. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/08/world.main_headline: EVESDROPPING ON EMBASSIES IS A HIGH-TECH BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/08/world.print_headline: EVESDROPPING ON EMBASSIES IS A HIGH-TECH BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/08/world.body_text: **********Security experts say the access that Soviet agents apparently obtained from Marine guards to the United States Embassy in Moscow provided the Russians with a wide range of espionage opportunities. **********''You have to figure a worst-case scenario,'' said Kevin D. Murray, who operates an electronic security service bearing his name in Clifton, N.J. ''You have to suspect that they found everything they wanted to know.'' **********The Russians' first priority would probably have been to photograph the surroundings and available documents, and to try to figure out what coding devices were being used. **********''In short, the first thing you would do would be to go after everything that eavesdropping cannot get you,'' Mr. Murray said. **********Nevertheless, Mr. Murray and others in his field believe that Soviet agents would also have exploited their access to plant surveillance devices. 'There Are Thousands of Ways' **********''There are thousands of ways to bug a building like the embassy,'' a Pennsylvania security expert said. ''The two sides are close technologically speaking, but the war is not won electronically. It depends on the ingenuity and sneakiness of the spies. By letting them get such a clear picture of where to focus their efforts, we have given them a huge advantage.'' **********The simplest bugs act as microphones or tiny transmitters and can be attached to equipment, furniture or decorations. These devices, which can be attached to wires thinner than a human hair, have been miniaturized to the point that the naked eye would be unlikely to notice them. **********''You are talking about things the size of a pinhead or grain of rice,'' said William Sharek, spokesman for Communication Control Systems Inc. of Portchester, N.Y., which has made debugging sweeps at embassies. **********A bug can be a simple passive device, such as a thin metal, glass or plastic membrane that vibrates with the sound of voices or typewriter keys. The device can be read by an outside power source, which might be anything from a microwave beam to laser light. A Mixture of Energy Waves **********The beam reflected from the bug is a mixture of the waves of energy from the power source and the pattern of vibrations caused by sound waves in the room. When the signal is received. computers break it down into its parts and enhance anything unusual for further study. **********Such passive systems have drawbacks. The information can be garbled by competing noises, for instance, by equipment that randomly bangs water pipes. And laser systems fail when window shades are drawn. **********The windows themselves vibrate with conversations, but the patterns are often disrupted by outside sounds and by deformities in the windows, which are often made with deliberate bulges. Moreover, sensitive embassy activities are transacted in specially shielded interior rooms. **********Some techniques rely on bugs with their own power source. Some have miniature batteries. Others tap into the building's power sources. The bugs broadcast a signal on a radio or microwave frequency on which sounds in the room are superimposed. But the smallest bugs tend to have limited range and all are vulnerable to discovery. Advanced Detector Described **********The most advanced detector, known as a nonlinear junction detector, is a box attached to a boom and antenna and is used to beam microwaves at surfaces that may have been bugged. The bug's transmitter echoes back with a signal at twice the frequency when struck. **********The detector can be countered by covering the transmitters with copper shielding or, more recently, by switching to fiber optics. The microscopic filaments of glass fiber can be connected to an infrared transmitter on an outside surface. **********''It could be disguised as a brick,'' said Samuel W. Daskam, president of Information Security Associates of Stamford, Conn., a manufacturer of nonlinear junction devices. ''It is a real pain to detect.'' **********Another twist is to equip the bug with the ability to record information, perhaps in digital form, and to transmit it only when told to do so by an external signal or an internal program to minimize discovery. **********Such short-burst transmissions are used by American and Soviet embassies to communicate with satellites and are described by security experts as all but impossible to intercept. Typewriter Episode Recalled In previous Moscow bugging episodes, in 1984, the Americans discovered that the Russians had mounted bugs inside the hollow frames of IBM typewriters and that the bigs magnetically recorded what was being typed and transmitted the information through electrical wires in bursts. **********The bugging apparently occurred when the typewriters were being delivered to the embassy as ordinary cargo, either by actually installing devices in the typewriters or by substituting bugged typewriters for those orderd by the embassy. **********In gaining access to the embassy in the most recent episode, the Russians would have been able to form a clear picture of which objects would be the best targets for such switching operations. They also would have had the opportunity to design bugs for them that would be hard to detect unless debugging experts knew where to look. **********For example, one counterintelligence expert said he had encountered a thin receiver capable of picking up telephone conversations embedded between plastic layers in the casing around a telephone jack. Debuggers would need X-rays or some other technology for subsurface probing to discover such bugs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.main_headline: THE 99-WORD STATUTE THAT MAY TRIP OFFICIALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.print_headline: THE 99-WORD STATUTE THAT MAY TRIP OFFICIALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.body_text: **********Buried in the hundreds of pages of the Federal Criminal Code is a 99-word conspiracy statute that law enforcement officials say may become the principal legal instrument in unraveling the Iran-contra affair. **********The law, which makes it a crime to conspire ''to commit any offense against the United States,'' will probably form the basis of new indictments brought by the special prosecutor in the case, Lawrence E. Walsh. **********The statute, labeled ''Conspiracy to Commit Offense or to Defraud the United States,'' is so broadly worded and has been so liberally interpreted over the last half-century that many current and former Reagan Administration officials are believed to be vulnerable to criminal charges. **********Two Washington fund-raisers who sought donations for the Nicaraguan rebels have already pleaded guilty under the conspiracy statute and agreed to cooperate with investigators. They named a co-conspirator: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the former National Security Council aide. Inquiry Is 'Accelerating' **********The statute was used to prosecute more than two dozen officials involved in the Watergate scandals, including President Nixon's two chief White House aides, John D. Ehrlichman and H. R. Haldeman. Mr. Nixon was named as an unindicted co-conspirator in covering up the Watergate break-in. **********Mr. Walsh, formally called an independent counsel, has talked very little about his legal strategy, although his aides have described the investigation as ''accelerating and expanding.'' **********Officials with knowledge of Mr. Walsh's plans say he is considering a variety of criminal charges, including perjury, obstruction of justice and theft of Government property. **********More important, they say, Mr. Walsh is apparently trying to prove that Administration officials joined in a conspiracy to violate Federal tax laws and Congressional restrictions on foreign arms sales and aid to the rebels, including the Boland Amendment. **********The amendment, named for Representative Edward P. Boland, Democrat of Massachusetts, barred American intelligence officials from offering aid of any kind to the rebels, known as the contras, from October 1984 to October 1986. No Criminal Penalties **********While the amendment carried no criminal penalties, prosecutors could charge that the officials misused Government authority by joining - conspiring - to undermine the will of Congress. **********Recent evidence suggests that Reagan Administration officials did seek ways to provide possibly illegal military aid to the contras. **********Asked to speculate what could happen under the wide scope of the conspiracy law, legal specialists said even President Reagan and Vice President Bush had reason to fear criminal charges in the Iran-contra affair. (There is no indication that Mr. Walsh is considering action against either man.) ''The fact is that once you start out on a conspiracy strategy, a lot of people can be brought in by connection or reference or statements of a co-conspirator,'' said Samuel Dash, a Georgetown University law professor who was chief counsel to the Senate committee that investigated the Watergate affair. Law Called Too Broad **********There has long been criticism that the conspiracy law is too broad and can be used unfairly. **********Under the statute, suspects can be prosecuted for joining in a conspiracy even if little was done to carry it out. Penalties under the law can be tough: up to five years in prison for conviction on each felony count. **********Mr. Dash noted that the statute's origins are in English common law. ''Back then,'' he said, ''you didn't even have to prove that what people were conspiring to do was a crime, so long as it was somehow harmful to the public good.'' **********The law can still be broadly applied. In a conspiracy case today, prosecutors need to show that at least two people joined and agreed to violate Federal law or misuse Government authority, and that some action was taken to carry out the plan. The act itself need not be criminal. **********Prosecutors appreciate the law's flexibility. The acts of one conspirator can be used as evidence of the guilt of any other conspirator. Two Implicate North **********Colonel North has been named as part of a tax conspiracy that helped funnel illegal military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. **********He was implicated by the two fund-raisers, Carl R. Channell and Richard R. Miller, who have already pleaded guilty. Mr. Channell and Mr. Miller confessed that they had sought millions of dollars in tax-deductible contributions for the entirely nondeductible purpose of arming the contras. **********If prosecutors can prove that Colonel North was part of the agreement to violate tax laws, it is possible that he could be convicted strictly on the basis of acts by Mr. Channell and Mr. Miller. **********''Mr. Walsh has a lot of freedom in this,'' said Philip B. Heymann, a law professor at Harvard University who oversaw the Justice Department's criminal divison in the Carter Administration.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.main_headline: FRENCH JETS BOMB AIRFIELD IN CHAD HELD BY LIBYANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.print_headline: FRENCH JETS BOMB AIRFIELD IN CHAD HELD BY LIBYANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.body_text: **********French warplanes bombed a Libyan-held airfield in northern Chad today, in retaliation for Libyan air raids in the country, the Defense Ministry here said. **********The French planes ''neutralized'' Libyan radar intallations at Wadi Doum, north of a line at the 16th parallel that divides Chad into northern and southern halves, the ministry said. **********Several hours later, Libya was reported to have bombed the town of Kouba Oulanga, 40 miles south of the 16th parallel. The French Defense Minister, Andre Giraud, said on French television that the report of the new Libyan raid was ''plausible,'' but he did not confirm that it had taken place. Shifting Alliances in Civil War **********The Libyan raid and the French response today represent the latest sharp flare-up of international hostilities in the Chadian civil war, which has been raging off and on for 20 years. The conflict has long been characterized by shifting alliances and a persistent effort by France to prevent Libyan influence from spreading into the southern half of the country. **********The balance of power shifted in recent weeks when the main anti-Government rebel group, led by a former Chadian President, Goukouni Oueddei, broke with their Libyan supporters and joined forces with President Hissen Habre. Fighting between Chadian troops and Libyan forces broke out on Dec. 20 in the extreme north of the country, apparently when Libya tried to take over territory in the region of the Tibesti Mountains. **********Both France and the United States provided emergency military aid to Chad in the fighting last month, leading to some gains by the Chadian forces. Libyan Raids in South **********The French raid today was in retaliation for Libyan air attacks on Sunday against two towns south of the 16th parallel, also known as the Red Line, which was proclaimed by France in 1983 to prevent Libyan-backed rebels from marching to Ndjamena, the Chadian capital, in an effort to overthrow the French-supported Habre Government. The Defense Ministry gave no details of the raid beyond saying that it was carried out at midday today by detachments of the 1,200-member ''deterrent force'' maintained by France in southern Chad. French radio said that the attacks were speadheaded by four Jaguar fighter-bombers based in Ndjamena. **********''We had to find a riposte that was precise, significant, and that did not represent an escalation, but that would demonstrate that we would not let ourselves be pushed around,'' Mr. Giraud said. **********The airfield attacked by France today has been used by Libya as a staging area to supply pro-Libyan rebels fighting against the French-supported Government of Chad. It was hit in a French air attack last February after what the French called Libyan-supported attacks south of the Red Line. **********The Libyan raids on Sunday, which were reported to have killed one person and wounded four, were militarily insignificant, French analysts said. They were termed a ''mosquito bite'' by Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, but there were nonetheless seen here as a provocation by the Libyans in defiance of warnings by France that it would reply to any military moves south of the Red Line. **********In a radio interview here Tuesday, Mr. Chirac said the Libyan raid on Sunday ''could not remain without a response from France.'' He called French policy ''neither hesitation nor a wish for escalation,'' but he said ''France will be respected by Libya.'' **********Mr. Habre's Government, capitalizing on the rupture between Libya and the former rebels led by Mr. Goukouni, launched an offensive roughly three weeks ago in an effort to put the northern half of the country under Chadian control. Government spokesmen in Ndjamena claimed earlier this week to have captured the northern oasis town of Fada from the Libyans, although there was no independent confirmation of this. **********Government officials in Ndjamena have claimed that about 100 Libyan soldiers have been captured in recent fighting, and yesterday in Ndjamena 22 captives were paraded before angry crowds who pelted them with stones. **********Libya's raid on Sunday south of the Red Line was seen as a response to its losses on the ground to Chadian forces. **********France has rejected requests by Mr. Habre that it join in the offensive but both France and the United States have supported the move by airlifting military supplies to the Chadian forces. **********Agence France-Presse reported here today that two American C-141 transport planes loaded with jeeps and trucks took off from an airport in the western French city of Nantes and were believed to be headed for Chad. **********Mr. Goukouni and Mr. Habre were originally allies in the Chad National Liberation Front, a northern-based Arab rebel group known as Frolinat that had Libyan support, but broke with each other in 1976. U.S. BACKS FRENCH RAID **********WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) - The White House expressed support today for the retaliatory French air strike. **********''We have expressed general support for the French role in Chad, and we continue to do so in this case,'' said the White House spokesman, Larry Speakes. **********He said the French had ''made it clear they would retaliate'' for the Libyan raid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/11/world.main_headline: A Haiti Vacation Ends in Plane Crash at Sea for 4 Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/11/world.print_headline: A Haiti Vacation Ends in Plane Crash at Sea for 4 Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/11/world.body_text: **********Francis Randall, a 55-year-old history professor at Sarah Lawrence College, remembers that the light plane crashed into the darkened ocean with a ''terrific jolt.'' **********A door popped open and Professor Randall, his 14-year-old daughter, Ariane, and two American women climbed out on a wing. The pilot appeared to be dead. **********Within seconds, Mr. Randall recalled, the plane was swallowed by the water late Saturday night and ''we were four people alone in the sea.'' Battled the Thrashing Sea **********For the next 36 hours, Mr. Randall and his daughter, who live on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, battled the thrashing sea, an unrelenting tropical sun and their own fears before Haitian villagers caught sight of them bobbing, battered and delirious, a few hundred yards off the southwestern tip of Haiti. **********United States Coast Guard rescue crews have been unable to find the two women, Anna Rivera, 41, of Manhattan and Delia Clarke, 38, of Ledyard, Conn. The Coast Guard stopped searching late Thursday afternoon, but resumed its efforts this morning after an inquiry from a member of Congress. **********As night fell last Sunday, a wild storm blew up, tearing Mr. Randall and his daughter apart, with her floating in the lone life jacket they had been sharing. It was the last they saw of each other until they were fished out of the sea 15 hours later. Mr. Randall said he had thought his daughter was dead. Vacationing at Club Med **********The girl, a sophomore at Hunter College High School, was more hopeful. **********''I figured he was somewhere out there,'' she said Wednesday, her face and neck swollen with sunburn, ''and that he'd want me to swim to Haiti. I tried to do that.'' **********The four Americans had been vacationing at the Club Med in Haiti - it was a birthday trip for Ariane - and when their American Airlines flight to New York on Saturday was canceled because of anti-Government protests, they decided to charter a small twin-engine plane to the Dominican Republic. The pilot, Elias Katime, became disoriented and flew west instead of east toward Santo Domingo. Eventually, they ran out of gas. Reluctant to Question Pilot **********Mr. Randall, whose wife, Laura, an economics professor at Hunter College, was researching a book in Mexico, said he could see the constellations in the dark sky and realized the plane was going the wrong way. But he said that he believed the pilot spoke only Spanish and that one of the women who knew the language was reluctant to question the pilot. **********For the first seven hours in the water, the four Americans clung together. As the plane was going down, the pilot tossed his life jacket to Mr. Randall, who strapped it on his daughter, hoisted her onto his lap and held onto her. There was one other jacket for the two women. **********Somehow, Mr. Randall said, they managed to contain their hysteria. No one screamed or cried. Ariane got seasick. Sea Snails Left Welts **********They were all terrified of sharks and they agreed, Mr. Randall said, ''not to mention fins.'' **********They never saw any sharks. The worst creatures they had to contend with were sea snails that left welts on their legs like horsefly bites. **********As dawn broke the first morning, at sea, the four Americans saw a strip of land on the horizon that proved to be Haiti. One of the American women was a poor swimmer. The other had suffered a broken arm and a concussion. **********''We had a terrible decision to make,'' Mr. Randall said. ''Could two of us swim and try for the coast or should all of us try and stay together and hope that some one would find us?'' **********''If two of us went,'' said Ariane, ''we would come back with a boat. We thought the land was a lot closer.'' **********Finally, father and daughter decided to go. They had the blessing of the two others, Mr. Randall said. But, he added of one of the women: ''I can't say she really wanted us to go. She said she would feel very uncomfortable if we left.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/29/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Another Bid For Storehouse
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/29/busin.body_text: **********A small British engineering concern, Benlox Holdings P.L.C., has started a $3.35 billion bid for Storehouse P.L.C., a huge British retailing group that owns the Conran household-goods chain. **********Storehouse, which is headed by the wealthy British entrepreneur Sir Terence Conran, brusquely dismissed the unsolicited offer, the second bid in a week. ''We don't want to be distracted by unreal propositions,'' the finance director of Storehouse, Jim Powers, said. **********Storehouse last week spurned a hostile takeover offer from Mountleigh Group P.L.C., which valued the company at $2.95 billion. **********Benlox has said that if its all-stock offer were successful, it would take Storehouse apart and create smaller, specialized chains. Benlox is offering 11 ordinary shares for every two ordinary Storehouse shares, valuing them at $8.22 each. **********Storehouse stock jumped to $6.48, from $5.72 at Friday's close, after the second bid was announced. Market sources suggested Benlox might be exploiting resentment among shareholders that the company did not consult them when it rejected Mountleigh's offer. **********Benlox, which is worth about $74 million, is 21.7 percent owned by the Egyptian financier Dr. Ashraf Marwan. Other stockholders include the publisher Robert Maxwell.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/11/world.main_headline: CAMPAIGN OVER, BRITAIN VOTES FOR A NEW PARLIAMENT TODAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/11/world.print_headline: CAMPAIGN OVER, BRITAIN VOTES FOR A NEW PARLIAMENT TODAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/11/world.body_text: **********Britain today reached the end of a general election battle in which Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was tested by predictable attacks on her vision of the nation's future and by a surprisingly erratic performance by her own troubled campaign organization. **********In her final news conference in the contest, Mrs. Thatcher brushed aside Labor Party charges that she envisions a Britain ''divided by privilege.'' She appealed for a ''large majority'' from what she described as a country newly united in middle-class prosperity by her ''popular capitalism.'' **********''Home ownership, second pensions, share ownership, choice in education -all these were once the privileges of the few,'' she said. ''They are now being extended to the many.'' **********The polls indicate that there is enough potency in this message - and enough nervousness about Labor's plan to scrap Britain's nuclear weapons - to give Mrs. Thatcher a third consecutive term as Prime Minister when Britons vote Thursday in 650 parliamentary constituencies. Reduced Majority Predicted **********The latest poll, by Robert M. Worcester of MORI, put the Conservatives at 44 percent, Labor at 32 and the Alliances parties at 22. Such a breakdown in the popular vote would give Mrs. Thatcher a reduced majority in the House of Commons, down to about 100 seats from the 144-seat majority she gained in 1983. **********Other late polls have put Mrs. Thatcher's lead at only half that, and Neil Kinnock, the Labor leader, predicted today that late shifts in the marginal constituencies would yield ''massive gains for the Labor Party, which will be enough to give us government.'' In a typical finale to his energetic campaign, Mr. Kinnock said Mrs. Thatcher's claims of prosperity amounted, in the face of 11 percent unemployment, ''to the self-deluding vanity of a fading empress and her courtiers.'' **********Both major parties asserted today that the election could deal a crippling, perhaps deadly blow to the Alliance, a centrist political coalition formed by the Liberals and the Social Democrats in 1981. Capping a dispirited campaign, David Steel of the Liberal Party, held out hope of a ''very late'' surge toward the Alliance. But analysts agreed that the Alliance performance had exposed strains in its dual leadership - Mr. Steel and Dr. David Owen of the Social Democratic Party - and raised questions about its ability to continue. **********But the main area of speculation today had to do with the conduct of the Tory campaign. It is a question of such sensitivity that when it arose today, Norman Tebbit, the Conservative Party chairman, who joined Mrs. Thatcher at her news conference, reacted like a man trying to stamp out a fire on an expensive carpet. **********''Shall we assess the campaigns on Friday?'' he said sharply, maintaining that the expected Thatcher victory would answer all criticism. But a variety of Conservative officials and independent commentators disagreed, saying that the unevenness of the Thatcher campaign has raised questions about her heretofore unassailable dominance of the British political scene and about the viability of her dream of going ''on and on'' until the end of the century. **********Two influential columnists, Peter Jenkins of The Independent and Geoffrey Smith of The Times of London, concluded today that this campaign had dimmed rather than enhanced Mrs. Thatcher's prospects of a fourth term. ''The Conservatives have run a rather lackluster campaign,'' acknowledged Robert D. Waller of Harris Research, a poll taker for the Conservatives. ''Mrs. Thatcher hasn't come out of it too well.'' **********Conservative Party circles were buzzing today with speculation about the assigning of blame and the changes Mrs. Thatcher would make if she wins. **********A purge of the senior staff at Conservative Central Office seems certain. 'Too Many Cooks' **********In any event, accounts from several sources provide a behind-the-scenes glimpse of a Conservative organization that saw itself as hobbling unhappily toward victory and being second-guessed every step of the way by an anxiously autocratic Mrs. Thatcher. **********''The truth is we've had too many cooks,'' said one official. ''It's not been a happy campaign.'' According to several people, the trouble began early, when Mrs. Thatcher got cold feet about the ability of Mr. Tebbit, a believer in the ideological bludgeon, to manage a nuanced campaign. **********On Mrs. Thatcher's orders, Lord Young, the Employment Secretary, was sent into Conservative Central Office to oversee the Prime Minister's campaign schedule. John Wakeham, the Tory whip and a rival of Mr. Tebbit to succeed Mrs. Thatcher, was assigned to oversee television. **********Another problem was late-night telephone calls to Mrs. Thatcher from outside advisers that put her into a ''frenzy'' of unhappiness over management of her campaign. At one point, she personally ordered three recuttings of a campaign film within 72 hours. **********Mrs. Thatcher's rating in the polls stayed remarkably steady despite the disarray behind the scenes. But Mrs. Thatcher seemed to sense that what was supposed to be a stroll to a third term was coming across as a struggle.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/world.main_headline: LINK IN CONTRA SUPPLY GETS IMMUNITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/world.print_headline: LINK IN CONTRA SUPPLY GETS IMMUNITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/world.body_text: **********The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair has granted full immunity to Lieut. Col. Richard B. Gadd, a key participant in the affair who helped direct the private network supplying weapons to the Nicaraguan rebels, according to a Federal law-enforcement official and the colonel's lawyer. **********They said Colonel Gadd, who had been under intensive investigation by prosecutors, could be a critical prosecution witness in any case brought against Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, a longtime friend and colleague, and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. **********Defense laywers in the case said the decision by the special prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh, was another sign that indictments in the case would be returned soon. **********''If someone as important as Gadd is getting immunity, Walsh must clearly have already made some important decisions'' about the investigation, one said. 'An Abundance of Caution' **********The colonel, retired from the Air Force, has told Congress that General Secord recruited him in 1985 to transfer weapons and other supplies to the rebels, also known as contras. **********According to Colonel Gadd, he was later asked by Colonel North to oversee construction of a secret airfield for the contras in Costa Rica. **********Colonel Gadd's lawyer, Kenneth A. Lazarus, confirmed reports that his client had received immunity. The colonel accepted immunity, Mr. Lazarus said, ''only out of an abundance of caution; I don't believe that Colonel Gadd had committed any crimes.'' **********Mr. Lazarus said Colonel Gadd had received immunity in early July. **********After Colonel Gadd's retirement in 1982 from the Air Force, in which he had been a covert operations specialist, he created a group of companies that won lucrative military contracts for secret assignments throughout the world. Closing the Circle **********According to law-enforcement officials, Mr. Walsh is expected to seek indictments charging Colonel North and others with conspiring to violate Federal restrictions on contra aid. **********One law-enforcement official said that by obtaining Colonel Gadd's cooperation in the inquiry, Mr. Walsh had ''pretty much closed the circle'' of witnesses who could implicate Colonel North. **********According to law-enforcement officials, Mr. Walsh has granted immunity to several witnesses: Robert C. Dutton, another retired Air Force officer involved in the contra supply network; Robert W. Owen, a former Senate aide who served as Colonel North's link with the contras; and Fawn Hall, Colonel North's White House secretary. **********Earlier this year Congress granted limited immunity from prosecution to Colonel Gadd in exchange for his cooperation with the Congressional inquiry. Under that immunity grant, testimony from the colonel could not be used against him. Outlook for Criminal Charges **********Mr. Walsh's decision to grant full immunity means that it is virtually certain Colonel Gadd will not face criminal charges from the Iran-contra affair. **********In a deposition provided last May to the House and Senate committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, the colonel said he had known General Secord since 1980, when they were both working on Defense Department plans to rescue American hostages held in Iran. **********Five years later, the colonel said, he was recruited by General Secord to participate in the contra supply effort and was asked to obtain planes to transfer arms from Portugal to Central America for the contras. **********General Secord, he said, ''indicated to me that this type of activity should be conducted very discreetly.'' Colonel Gadd added, ''I was told to protect both his name and the White House.'' **********In October 1985, Colonel Gadd said, he met with Colonel North and was asked by the White House aide to study the feasibility of creating a secret contra airfield in Costa Rica. Also at that meeting, the colonel said, were General Secord and his business partner, Albert Hakim. **********According to his account, Colonel North asked General Secord to arrange a $150,000 advance to Colonel Gadd to cover the initial expenses for building the airfield. Colonel Gadd said he later did oversee construction of the facility. **********Through 1986, Colonel Gadd said, he oversaw the transfer of weapons to the contras.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/world.main_headline: NICARAGUA EXTENDING THE STATE OF EMERGENCY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/world.print_headline: NICARAGUA EXTENDING THE STATE OF EMERGENCY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/world.body_text: **********The Sandinista-controlled National Assembly voted Monday to extend the five-year-old state of emergency for another year. **********The vote, which came after a long debate, means that many rights guaranteed in the Constitution adopted last month will remain suspended. They include the right to strike, the right to hold outdoor public meetings, the right to publish uncensored news and the right to be presumed innocent until proved guilty. **********Sandinista legislators described the measure as essential to public security in the face of continuing activity by rebel groups backed by the United States. **********''The state of emergency is made necessary by the war situation in our country,'' said Rafael Solis, secretary of the Assembly and a senior Sandinista legislator. ''The guarantees are suspended only for those who plot against the security of the state, not for common citizens.'' Danger From U.S. 'Is Real' **********The president of the Assembly, Comdr. Carlo Nunez Tellez, who is a member of the all-powerful Sandinista National Directorate, told the Assembly, ''The danger of United States military intervention is real.'' He warned the opposition not to ''assume defiant attitudes in order to test whether the Government is or is not willing to apply the state of emergency.'' **********The outcome of the debate was not in doubt since Sandinista legislators were certain to vote for the measure. Nonetheless, the debate was lengthy and frank. **********Opposition leaders insisted that the emergency decree was unconstitutional, and several walked out of the session when their protest was rejected. The final vote in the 96-member Assembly was 60 to 15. **********A Conservative Party leader who was formerly a member of the governing junta, Rafael Cordova Rivas, cited recent statements by Sandinista leaders that rebel groups had been dealt fatal blows. ''If the contras have been strategically defeated, if they are wiped out,'' he asked, ''then why does there have to be a state of emergency?'' Territorial Limits Urged **********Antonio Jarquin of the Popular Social Christian Party said that if emergency rule was necessary, it should be limited to war zones and not be enforced in cities. **********Legislators from every opposition party spoke against the emergency decree. Several said it had been used to repress workers and peasants. **********The Socialist leader, Domingo Sanchez, said he knew of many cases of peasants who had been forced to supply contras with food and were later jailed by authorities on charges of collaborating with the enemy. **********''The peasants are suffering injustices, and their blood is flowing,'' he said. ''It is our moral responsibility, as their representatives, to correct this.'' **********Sandinista legislators accused critics of minimizing the threat Nicaragua faces. **********''When the bombs fall, it isn't only Sandinistas who die,'' said one, Rosario Altamirano. ''The bombs don't have names and addresses on them. All Nicaraguans suffer.'' **********The state of emergency was the first matter debated by the Assembly when it convened Monday for its 1987 session. The Assembly had never before taken up the matter, since before the adoption of the new Constitution emergency rule could be imposed by the President alone. Minor Changes Adopted **********Some minor changes in the presidential decree were accepted. Public meetings may now be held if the police give prior authorization, and authorities must now notify the families of detainees. But a suggestion that all prisoners be brought before judicial authorities within 30 days of their arrest was rejected. **********Also under the decree, the privacy of mail and telephone conversations as well as the right to travel abroad may be suspended when authorities deem it fit. **********Sandinista officials have indicated that they consider the state of emergency a vital legal tool and a principal weapon to prevent the contras from building what Commander Nunez called ''an internal front.'' According to officials with access to Western intelligence reports, Nicaraguan security policemen operating with emergency powers have foiled various contra efforts at urban warfare. **********''They have rolled up everything the contras have tried to do in the cities,'' one ambassador said. But Clemente Guido, who was the Conservative Party's presidential candidate in 1984, said Monday that the continued state of emergency ''leaves the citizen without defense from security police.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/16/world.body_text: **********Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, the head of the provisional Government, has disavowed all responsibility for the massacre that disrupted Haiti's presidential elections two weeks ago and disparaged the Roman Catholic Church, Haitian political leaders and the civilians who organized the election. **********In an interview published in a French newspaper today, General Namphy referred to the competing political forces in Haiti as a ''basket of crabs'' and charged that ''foreign countries'' had ''financed the disorder here.'' **********Except for a formal communique, the general's remarks in the left-of-center French daily Liberation were his first on the abortive election in which thugs in civilian clothes and soldiers attacked polling places and at least 34 people were killed. **********In the interview, conducted last Friday at his walled home north of the capital, General Namphy seemed to confirm that regardless of who wins the second attempt at elections, which the general has scheduled for Jan. 17, the army will remain dominant. Names Himself Commander **********''The armed forces will guarantee in the future the setting up of the pedestal for democracy,'' General Namphy said. ''That is why for three years we will assume the position of Commander in Chief of the armed forces as the Constitution provides.'' **********Many Haitians said they believed the intent of the Constitution was to give a newly elected civilian President the authority to choose his chief army officer and that General Namphy was presenting an insuperable challenge to the next chief of state. **********General Namphy accused the nine-member civilian council that organized the elections of responsibility for the violence that forced the halting of the elections, partly because, in keeping with the Constitution, the council had rejected the presidential candidacies of 12 former associates of the Duvalier dictators. **********These candidates ''reacted,'' he said, ''and everyone pretends to be astonished and blames the army.'' **********He said that ''foreign countries'' had tried through the electoral council ''to designate the President of Haiti.'' **********At one point he asked rhetorically, ''What did Haiti do to the United States to deserve this?'' **********The United States took the lead, among several countries including Canada and France, in supporting the elections and provided more than $10 million in financial help. **********A United States official denied General Namphy's charges, adding: ''The disorder seems to have been caused by persons opposed to the electoral process. We supported the electoral process.'' **********General Namphy also accused the Catholic Church in Haiti, which had encouraged broad participation in the election, ''of meddling with politics.''
