https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/21/world.main_headline: SRI LANKAN GUERRILLAS SAID TO KILL 15
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/21/world.print_headline: SRI LANKAN GUERRILLAS SAID TO KILL 15
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/21/world.body_text: **********At least 15 Sinhalese villagers were killed early today, apparently by Tamil guerrillas, in the same northeastern district where terrorists killed 127 people in an ambush last week, the Government said today. **********A police officer died in a separate attack on a security post in the northeast, according to the Government. **********The Government spokesman, Tilak Ratnakara, said a curfew had been reimposed on the Trincomalee district after an attack before dawn today on the village of Wan Ela. Victims Were Sleeping **********According to the Government, the 15 villagers killed today - 5 men, 5 women, 4 girls and a teen-age boy -were asleep when the guerrillas struck. Paramilitary Home Guards were called in, Mr. Ratnakara said, and the guerrillas escaped after an exchange of fire.  [ The Associated Press quoted Government sources as saying at least 18 people were killed in the attack. ]  Officals speculated that the attack today was carried out by Tamil guerrillas running ahead of troops who are trying to block their access to the sparsely populated east coast. Guerrillas, who maintain seaside outposts, have in the past frequently evaded the military by boat. **********The latest attacks represent an escalation by separatist forces of their guerrilla campaign on behalf of Sri Lanka's Tamils, a largely Hindu group that makes up 18 percent of the country's 16 million people. The guerrillas want to establish an autonomous state in the north and west where Tamils would not be dominated by the island nation's Sinhalese majority, which is predominantly Buddhist. **********The conflict between the two groups has long dominated political life in the country, a former British colony once known as Ceylon, and has become a full-fledged guerrilla war in the last four years. The most recent violence has prompted the Government to cancel a cease-fire in the conflict, in which 5,000 people have been killed. Troops Encircling Area **********Mr. Ratnakara said in an interview today that Government troops were trying to encircle a 250-square-mile inland area where four or five guerrilla bands of 40 to 50 fighters each were thought to be hiding. The wilderness straddles the road between Habarana and Trincomalee, along which the ambush occurred Friday. **********As funerals began taking place all over Sri Lanka today the Government has continued to reject calls for revenge from Sinhalese nationalists. **********President J. R. Jayewardene, a Sinhalese, who is trying to negotiate a settlement that would give Tamil areas some autonomy, set the tone Saturday in a speech in the central hill town of Nuwara Eliya. **********Speaking to tea plantation workers, who form a separate Tamil population not closely related to the separatist Tamils of the north and east, the President recalled anti-Tamil riots four years ago that left hundreds dead and much Tamil property in ruins. **********''The Sinhala people acted foolishly by creating trouble in the country in July 1983, when some army personnel were killed,'' the President said in remarks quoted by a Sri Lankan newspaper, The Sun. ''Hereafter, if persons comitting such acts are detected they will be sentenced to death. **********''The whole world fell out with Sri Lanka on account of those actions,'' he said. U.S. CONDEMNS THE VIOLENCE **********WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) - The State Department issued a statement today condemning the recent violence in Sri Lanka. ''We call on all parties, especially the Tamil militants, to enter into meaningful negotiations without delay,'' said the department spokesman, Charles E. Redman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/08/busin.body_text: **********Jorge Diaz Serrano, the former head of the Mexican state oil monopoly Pemex, has been sentenced to 10 years in jail on charges of personally enriching himself during his tenure. **********The sentence handed down Wednesday also ordered Mr. Diaz Serrano to pay the Government $54 million to cover losses it suffered because of an embezzlement scheme that was said to have netted him $34 million. **********Mr. Diaz Serrano headed Pemex during the 1976-81 oil boom years and was once considered a potential candidate for the presidency of Mexico. He has maintained his innocence since his arrest in July 1983 and has said he would appeal the verdict.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/01/busin.body_text: **********The dollar opened at a record low today for a second straight day, but its fall was checked by intervention by the Bank of Japan. **********As the dollar fell, stock prices plunged more than 360 points in early trading on the Tokyo exchange before recovering. Yozo Asai of Yamaichi Securities said that Monday's sharp drop in stock prices on Wall Street was a factor in the Tokyo market's shaky opening. **********The dollar opened at a record low of 132.28 yen, down from Monday's close of 132.45 yen. The currency had dipped as low as 132.10 yen in early trading, its lowest level since the late 1940's. **********Shortly after the market opened, Japan's central bank began buying dollars, and the currency stabilized, traders said. The dollar closed the day at 132.42 yen, down 0.03 yen, and traders said that sentiment toward the dollar remained bearish. Drop of 362.92 in First Hour **********On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average dropped 362.92 points after the first 45 minutes of trading but later recovered to end the day at 22,832.89, up 146.11, or 0.64 percent The day's volume was 400 million shares, against 270 million the previous day The decline in the leading index, which fell 365.45 points Monday, was led by export-oriented issues such as Sony, Toyota Motor and Hitachi. **********Traders said the yen's appreciation against the dollar had raised the possibility of a further erosion of price competitiveness for major Japanese exporters and weighed heavily on blue-chip stocks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/world.main_headline: India's Boom Leaves One State in Dark Ages
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/world.print_headline: India's Boom Leaves One State in Dark Ages
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/world.body_text: **********About 300 million Indians are said to be living below the poverty line, but Government statistics still portray a trend in which poverty is gradually being reduced. Such hopeful projections run up against a harsh reality for millions of people here. **********To experts involved in development problems in India, the northeastern state of Bihar is in a class by itself. After five years of economic growth in the country, no other state remains so ridden with poverty, caste bigotry, illiteracy, crime, corruption and lawlessness. **********''Ah yes, Bihar,'' said Ashok Mitra, a Marxist economist and former Finance Minister for the neighboring state of West Bengal. ''It is back in the Dark Ages. Where do you begin to solve the problems of Bihar?'' **********Because of rising violence between lower-caste groups and feudal landlords, Bihar's stubborn problems are lately receiving more urgent attention here in the state capital and in New Delhi, where economic assistance is being increased. **********The state's unusually severe handicaps - its floods and droughts, and the exploitation of lower-caste peasants by feudal landlords here - persuade some experts that without basic changes in land and labor policies, Bihar can never achieve progress. Bihar Recalls Debate **********But to others, the state symbolizes the debate over India's general strategy to lift its most downtrodden people into the mainstream, where they can take part in the economic boom in the country at large. **********With 80 million people packed into an area the size of Washington State, Bihar has a per capita income of $111, less than half the national level. A quarter of its people are from the poorest and lowest castes and aboriginal tribes. **********In India, nearly 40 percent of the people are said to have incomes below the official poverty line of $500 a year for a family of four. But at least half the population of Bihar falls into that category. **********Southern Bihar, blessed with coal and iron deposits, has become India's mining and steel center. But in a practice criticized in the West, where India's Socialist system is often regarded as a drag on growth, India uses these industries as employment generators, sometimes making the end product too expensive to be sold on international markets. India's Poverty Belt **********Bihar is actually the center of a large area in India's northeast where poverty is the most severe. Hunger and malnutrition are rampant also in Orissa and West Bengal states, as well as in the eastern part of Uttar Pradesh. **********For this entire area, India's antipoverty strategy under Prime Minister Gandhi is twofold: to rely on the private sector to create jobs, and to use increasing Government revenue for investment in poverty programs and infrastructure in places like Bihar. **********Since 1980, India has achieved an economic growth rate of 4 percent to 5 percent, its highest since independence in 1947. The industrial growth rate is now nearly twice that rate. Indian officials say that means money will be available to help the poorest of the poor. **********The current five-year plan calls for $4 billion in investment in Bihar. But this year, that translates into only a $12 investment per person. At this rate, progress in building irrigation projects and employment programs is going to be slow, officials say. **********But some economists here wonder if the Government's policies aren't making things worse. They say a huge budget deficit is spurring inflation, eroding the standard of living of the people of Bihar. **********Some statistics show that despite what the Government says about their conditions improving, the poor are consuming less grain, lentils and beans than they used to. **********Moreover, in the agriculture area, critics say the Government should be investing much greater sums to make the area more productive, rather than rely on food grains brought in from other parts of the country.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/10/busin.body_text: **********The TLC Group, a New York investment firm, has agreed to buy the Beatrice International Food Company from the parent of the Beatrice Companies for $985 million, TLC officials said yesterday. **********The international food unit, based in Chicago, comprises 64 companies in 31 countries. It reported $2.5 billion in sales last year and operating income of $147 million. The company manufactures confectionaries, snacks, processed meats, beverages and other food products and is engaged in wholesale and retail distribution of food, groceries and household products. **********TLC will own 55 percent of the business, which would make it the largest black-owned company in the country in annual revenue. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which is providing financing for the leveraged buyout, will own most of the balance, a Drexel official said. In a leveraged buyout, a company's cash flow is used to repay the debt taken on to finance its purchase. **********People familiar with the transaction said the management of Beatrice's international food business would have a small stake in the new company. Started With $1 Million **********The deal with BCI Holdings, the parent of Beatrice, is a coup for Reginald F. Lewis, chairman of the TLC Group. In three years, TLC has grown from an investment group with $1 million in equity to majority owner of one of the largest international food businesses. **********Mr. Lewis formed the TLC Group to acquire other companies. Its most notable deal previously was the purchase of the McCall Pattern Company, a maker of sewing patterns. TLC purchased McCall for $1 million in 1984 and sold it last month for $90 million to the John Crowther Group, a British textile conglomerate. **********The Beatrice transaction makes Mr. Lewis a much more prominent player on Wall Street. **********Before selling McCall, TLC was ranked sixth on Black Enterprise magazine's list of the nation's largest black-owned companies. With the acquisition of a controlling interest in Beatrice's international food business, TLC would far outpace what has previously been the nation's largest black-owned business, the Johnson Publishing Company. That Chicago-based media and consmetics concern reported revenues last year of $173.5 million. Canadian Unit to Be Sold **********TLC Group said it had agreed to sell the company's Beatrice Foods Canada Ltd., one of Canada's leading diversified dairy and food products companies, for about $230 million. That deal would also be structured as a leveraged buyout by the Onex Corporation, Canada's largest leveraged buyout group, and the management of Beatrice Canada. TLC will retain a 20 percent interest, the companies said. **********The Canadian company had 1986 sales of $367 million and operating income of $27 million, accounting to about 18 percent of Beatrice International Food's operating profit. **********Mr. Lewis's group said it planned to sell other units of Beatrice International Food, possibly those in South America and Australia. TLC said it would retain Beatrice's core businesses in Europe, which last year accounted for $1.7 billion in sales and $98 million, or about 67 percent, of the food company's operating earnings. **********Completion of the sale, which TLC and Drexel said was expected by Oct. 1, is subject to approval by the Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission and some foreign governments in countries where the company operates. **********BCI Holdings will use the proceeds from the sale to reduce the debt it incurred last year from its acquisition of the Beatrice Companies, which went private in a $6.2 billion leveraged buyout organized by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. Brand Names Kept Private **********Beatrice has since said it would spin off a consumer products and specialty foods company to the public while keeping its brand-name foods company private. **********In May, Beatrice said the new public company, to be called E-II Holdings Inc., would consist of its nonfood operations, including Samsonite luggage and the Culligan water-treatment service, as well as its specialty-foods businesses, such as Aunt Nellie's pickles. **********E-II Holdings is expected to have sales of $1.57 billion, compared with Beatrice's total sales of $8.93 billion in the fiscal year ended Feb. 28. **********There had been much speculation about what the company would do with its international food business. A year ago, Beatrice said it was considering spinning off its international food group into a separate corporation and offering stock to the public. But so such plan materialized. Billions in Assets Sold **********Beatrice officials said later that they had held discussions with several parties, including the Pillsbury Company, but talks broke down. **********Since it went private in April, Beatrice has sold more than $3.6 billion of its assets, including the Avis Inc. car rental unit, Coca-Cola bottling operations and International Playtex Inc.. **********After the spinoff and the sale of the international food business, BCI Holdings will consist of most of Beatrice's current domestic and international food businesses. Its brands include Tropicana fruit juice, Peter Pan peanut butter and Orville Redenbacher's popcorn. **********Mr. Lewis began searching for acquisitions after the sale of McCall, which left him with an abundance of cash. **********''The things he was able to do at McCall, coupled with his creativity, made it easy for us to decide to participate in this with him, '' said Dean C. Kehler, a managing director at Drexel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/06/busin.body_text: **********The first witnesses were called yesterday in the insider-trading trial of Israel G. Grossman, a 34-year-old lawyer charged with tipping off six relatives and friends about a corporate restructuring that his law firm was working on. **********Mr. Grossman, whose case is not related to the broader insider-trading scandal on Wall Street, was arrested in February. He was indicted on 38 felony counts that contend the group he tipped off about a restructuring of Colt Industries illegally earned $1.5 million in less than two weeks by buying $33,000 worth of Colt options. The options soared in value last year after Colt announced its restructuring. **********Mr. Grossman had worked at Kramer, Levin, Nessen, Kamin & Franke a a law fm m that woeked for Colt. Grossman did not work on the transaction himself, but learned of it through a colleague, the Government charged. **********Michael Nassau, the Kramer, Levin partner in charge of the firm's work on the deal, testified yesterday about the timing of the transaction and what work Kramer, Levin performed. **********Martin Fleisher, who was an associate at Kramer, Levin, then testified that it was he who told Mr. Grossman about the Colt deal. **********The Government has said that telephone records show Mr. Grossman began to call his relatives late on the same day, and that they bought Colt options shortly afterward.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/14/world.main_headline: ELECTION UNLIKELY IN '87, NICARAGUA OFFICIAL SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/14/world.print_headline: ELECTION UNLIKELY IN '87, NICARAGUA OFFICIAL SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/14/world.body_text: **********The Nicaraguan Vice President says local elections will probably not be held this year as previousy announced. **********''For logistical rather than political reasons, I believe it is most probable that the elections will be held in 1988,'' the official, Sergio Ramirez Mercado, said in an interview Monday. **********During debate over the new Constitution, a Sandinista leader, Carlos Nunez Tellez, president of the National Assembly, said the Government would call local elections in 1987. The statement was carried under a banner headline on the front page of the official Sandinista newspaper, Barricada, last Nov. 20. **********Reacting to that announcement, opposition leaders began preparing for a campaign. Among other steps, they have discussed the possibility of forging an electoral coalition that would support single candidates against the Sandinistas in important cities. 'The Political Event of 1987' **********''Everything we have is going into the local election campaign,'' a Social Christian leader, Azucena Ferre, said less than a week ago. ''It will be the political event of 1987.'' **********But Mr. Ramirez said Monday that many administrative tasks remained before local elections could be held. He said the National Assembly would have to formulate and enact a law defining the rights and responsibilities of local governments, and would also be asked to redraw some municipal boundaries. Then, he said, the electoral commission would have to draw up procedures and train personnel. **********''Maybe in May or June of 1988 we could set up the machinery for voter registration, which needs to be done all over again,'' he said. ''The election has to be next year.'' **********News of Mr. Ramirez's statement took supporters of the opposition by surprise. 'We Are Ready' **********''It is perfectly feasible to have an election this year if they want one,'' Mario Rappaccioli of the Conservative Party said. ''Depending on the rules of the game, we are ready whenever they are.'' **********Mr. Ramirez said voters would elect councilors by direct vote. He said it was not certain whether mayors would be directly elected or chosen by councilors. **********Mr. Ramirez said the Sandinistas would present candidates in every municipality. **********''In local elections it is important to have candidates who are respected, and we are going to consider each case separately,'' he said. ''We expect to come up with good candidates.'' Sandinista Victory Predicted **********''As a member of the Sandinista Front,'' he added, ''I would have to predict that the Sandinista Front is in a position to win the large majority of municipalities.'' **********Whenever local elections are held, much attention would certainly focus on the campaign in Managua. Mr. Ramirez for the first time suggested that the current Sandinista Mayor, Moises Hassan Morales, a former mathematics professor who holds a doctorate from North Carolina State University, was likely to be the party's standard-bearer in the capital. **********''I personally think that Moises Hassan is a good candidate, a person known for leadership,'' the Vice President said. ''I don't see how we could lose in Managua.' **********Municipal governments have been run by appointed officials since the Sandinista takeover in 1979, and Mr. Ramirez said a change was needed. **********''The system of hand-picking people from Managua has unfortunately led to a reduction in the authority of local governments and their ability to get things done,'' he said. **********On another matter, Mr. Ramirez dismissed recent statements by American officials portraying rebel groups as growing in strength to the point where they may be able to topple the Government. **********''The counterrevolutionaries are having trouble finding recruits and are not doing well,'' Mr. Ramirez said. ''There is no possibility of them making a chalenge that would alter the military balance.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/16/busin.body_text: **********Although the raw numbers show little improvement in the nation's trade deficit, Reagan Administration officials and other analysts paint a more more optimistic picture. They note, for instance, that the import totals have been swollen by price increases that conceal an underlyingshift favorable to the United States. Over the last 12 months, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, import prices have risen by 14.5 percent while export prices have gone up a much more modest 3.3 percent. **********Thus, if the $15.7 billion deficit reported on Wednesday had been calculated with 1986 prices for imports and exports, the number would have been a much improved $12 billion, said Robert Ortner, the Commerce Under Secretary for Economic Affairs. **********''Trade has already begun to contribute to real economic growth and jobs,'' Mr. Ortner said. ''The darned trouble is that price increases are still very big in imports, covering up the underlying shift and disturbing financial markets.'' Slow Economic Growth **********Nonetheless, persistent problems are still holding back the faster export growth that will be needed to solve the trade problem. For one thing, economic growth in many world markets is just too slow to generate a thirst for American goods. For instance, austerity programs have cut demand in the debt-strapped developing countries that normally take a third of American exports. **********Moreover, West Germany and Japan have placed their priorities on cutting inflation and reducing fiscal deficits. These moves have weakened consumption, causing a decline in American exports despite more competitive pricing. So far this year, American sales to Japan have fallen by 4 percent. This weak consumption comes on top of persistent regulatory problems in penetrating Japan and other protected markets. **********As part of its strategy to reduce the trade deficit, the Administration engineered a sharp drop in the international value of the dollar, causing imports to rise in price and making American exports more competitive. **********The dollar, as measured against many major currencies, is now 40 to 50 percent below its level when it started on its downward course in February 1985. In theory, that much devaluation should have spurred export sales because the dollar price of American goods has become cheaper when calculated in foreign currencies. Both Imports and Exports Rise **********But the lower-priced dollar has not yet had the trade impact that many experts expected. To be sure, overall exports are higher than they were last year. They have rested on a plateau for the last six months at slightly more than $20 billion. But imports are higher as well, averaging around $35 billion in recent months. **********The dollar has not fallen much, however, against the currencies of some very important trading partners. In fact, the trade deficit has worsened most with the countries that have been the biggest markets for American exports. These include such newly industrialized Asian countries as Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore and Hong Kong. **********American exports to these countries rose by 16 percent this year, but imports from them are up by 19 percent. **********One reason why their products are selling so well in the United States is that these countries have refused to permit their currencies to rise significantly against the dollar. As a result, their prices have not gone up dramatically in the United States. Displacing the Japanese **********Analysts said these countries' exports to the United States are displacing products from Japan, whose yen has appreciated against the dollar by about 50 percent in the last two years. **********A similar trade situation exists in Mexico, where exports are up 12 percent, but imports have risen by 14 percent. **********In other Latin American countries, exports are down from last year's levels because of new financial problems associated with their crushing debt burdens. **********In the oil-exporting countries, American exports have been hurt by falling demand, while American imports are rising in dollar terms primarily because of increased oil prices. In the first half of 1987, the deficit with these countries worsened by $2 billion. **********In a report to the National Association of Manufacturers, Stephen L. Cooney, an N.A.M. economist, predicted that the United States would improve its trade balance with Canada and Europe. But, he said, the American trade balance would remain stable with Japan and worsen with other regions. Rising American Exports **********Despite the disappointments, economists report that in volume terms American exports so far this year have risen by about 12 to 15 percent, or about three to four times the growth rate for world trade. **********''That's not a bad record,'' said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, ''but considerably more is needed.'' **********He has called on both Europe and Japan to stimulate domestic demand by 2 percent over where it is now. Should such action be taken, he said, it would reduce the American trade deficit by $40 billion a year. **********Many analysts say that the most effective way to redress the trade deficit is by increasing exports of American manufacturers. **********In 1980 the United States ran a $5 billion surplus in manufacturing trade, while last year the deficit was around $125 billion. **********''There is no way the trade deficit can improve without a pickup in manufacturing,'' said C. Michael Aho, an economist with the National Foreign Trade Council.

Hurwitz said today that the stock market's steep decline since the beginning of October had resulted in $33.8 million in losses, which would adversely affect both concerns' fourth-quarter results. **********The Los Angeles-based concerns are Maxxam Group Inc., parent of the Pacific Lumber Company, and MCO Holdings Inc., an oil and gas exploration company. **********In the third quarter, Maxxam earned $73.6 million, or $5.39 a share, compared with a loss of $2.4 million in the period a year earlier.
