https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/16/world.main_headline: Witness Is Principal Target Of Grand Jury Investigation
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/16/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS: AN ADMIRAL AT RISK; Witness Is Principal Target Of Grand Jury Investigation
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/16/world.body_text: **********Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's lawyer said today that his client had been named the ''primary target'' of a Federal grand jury investigating the Iran-contra affair and that there was an ''imminent threat of prosecution.'' **********In testimony before Congress, the lawyer, Richard W. Beckler, said he had recently been informed that Admiral Poindexter was a target of the special prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh. **********In the jargon of Federal prosecutors, the word ''target'' is carefully chosen and often refers to someone who will soon face indictment. Additional Criminal Charges **********Mr. Beckler's disclosure about his client, the former national security adviser, was the clearest public statement by any defense lawyer in the case that Mr. Walsh would seek additional criminal charges. **********Lawyers with knowledge of the case said at least one other participant in the Iran-contra affair had received a so-called ''target'' letter from Mr. Walsh and that some other suspects were now trying to work out plea bargains with the special prosecutor's staff. **********Prosecutors usually send target letters shortly before indictments are issued. The letters are both a courtesy and a threat - a courtesy to defense lawyers and a final threat to their clients: cooperate now or face charges. Whether indictments may come within days, weeks or months is not clear because different prosecutors send target notices at different points. **********Law-enforcement officials have said previously that Admiral Poindexter, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and others were under investigation on charges that they conspired to violate a host of Federal laws, including statutes involving obstruction of justice and aid to Nicaraguan rebel groups. The restrictions on aid to the contras do not carry criminal penalities, but law enforcement officials have said violating them could subject some present or former officials to conspiracy charges. **********Others under investigation, officials have said, include Elliott Abrams, an assistant secretary of state, and Richard V. Secord and his business partner, Albert Hakim, who helped run the Iran arms sales and the contra supply operation. **********Lawyers for Colonel North have refused to talk with reporters and did not return telephone calls today. Attempt to Block Interrogation **********In announcing that Admiral Poindexter was a target of prosecutors, Mr. Beckler was trying to block the interrogation of his client by the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair. The committees denied the lawyer's request. **********''I have never seen a situation where the primary target of a criminal investigation has been forced to testify before a nationwide audience and have that testimony dissected over and over and over,'' Mr. Beckler told the lawmakers. **********Lawyers with knowledge of the investigation said there was good reason for Mr. Walsh to notify Admiral Poindexter now that he was a target of the grand jury. **********The admiral is testifying before Congress under a grant of limited immunity, meaning that his testimony cannot be used against him. **********By issuing the target warning now, Mr. Walsh may be able to argue after an indictment that he had intended to bring criminal charges long before Admiral Poindexter appeared on Capitol Hill and that prosecutors were not influenced by his testimony. **********Law-enforcement officials with knowledge of Mr. Walsh's investigation say he is focusing on conspiracy indictments. Obstruction of Justice **********The conspiracy laws allow prosecutors to bring charges when two or more people agree - conspire - to violate Federal laws, even if those laws do not themselves involve criminal penalties. **********The officials say that Mr. Walsh is studying charges based on violations of several laws, including the Boland Amendment, a statute that limited military aid to the contras. While the Boland Amendment carried no criminal penalties, conspiracy to violate the amendment could be a crime. **********Defense lawyers and law-enforcement officials say that Admiral Poindexter and Colonel North are also threatened with more obvious criminal charges, such as obstruction of justice. **********The Admiral acknowledged today under questioning that he had destroyed a critical White House document about the Iran arms sales last November, shortly after he learned that the Justice Department was investigating the arms sales. **********Colonel North has admitted that he shredded related material at about the same time, raising questions whether he was trying to obstruct the investigation by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/23/busin.body_text: **********The Union Carbide Corporation said today that its third-quarter operating income rose 76 percent, to $74 million, thanks to a strong performance by the company's chemicals and plastics divisions. **********The company, based in Danbury, Conn., said earnings rose to 57 cents a share, from 43 cents, or $42 million, a year ago. Sales rose 11.6 percent, to $1.73 billion from $1.55 billion. The 1986 figures do not include gains from asset sales and pension accounting changes. **********''The fundamentals for our major businesses are good,'' the company's chairman, Robert D. Kennedy, said. **********Excluding the sale of a distribution facility in 1986, operating earnings from chemicals and plastics rose 49 percent. Industrial gas earnings were up 9 percent. **********Union Carbide became heavily indebted in January, when it bought large blocks of its own stock and incurred as much as $5.5 billion in debt to fend off a takeover attempt by the GAF Corporation. The restructuring also included the asset sales and staff cutbacks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/26/world.main_headline: Hurricane in Bermuda Causes Minor Injuries
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/26/world.print_headline: Hurricane in Bermuda Causes Minor Injuries
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/26/world.body_text: **********Hurricane Emily ripped roofs off many houses, damaged boats and cars and left 16 people injured as it raced across Bermuda and into the Atlantic today with gusting winds of up to 112 miles per hour. **********No deaths were reported and most of the injuries were minor, said a Bermuda Government spokesman, Bryan Darby. **********Power was cut off over about 90 percent of the island but by early afternoon workers had restored electricity to Hamilton, the capital. Mr. Darby said he expected the entire island to have full power by Saturday. the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla., reported that Emily was moving northeast at 40 to 45 m.p.h., then weaken as it moved over the colder waters of the North Atlantic. **********The roof of the airport terminal was blown off and the airport was closed, Mr. Darby said. The authorities received 230 reports of torn roofs, boats lost, uprooted trees and other damage. **********The cruise ship Atlantic, with about 700 passengers aboard, slipped its mooring in the strong winds and had to be towed back to dock, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/10/world.body_text: **********What the newspapers called ''The Crockford's Mystery'' did not last long. But in the space of a few days, it forced into public view the angry divisions within the Church of England over theology and clerical promotions. **********On Monday, Dr. Gareth V. Bennett, a conservative Anglican priest and Oxford don, killed himself. Twenty-four hours later, church officials reluctantly confirmed that Dr. Bennett was the author of an anonymous attack on the Archbishop of Canterbury that was published last Thursday as the preface to the new issue of Crockford's Clerical Directory, the church's who's who. **********On Thursday, the church's powerful policy committee will convene to try to sort things out. Church officials say they may reprimand two high-level lay employees for allowing Dr. Bennett to use a church publication to criticize the Archbishop, Dr. Robert Runcie, and a ''liberal establishment'' that Dr. Bennett said was leading the church astray on issues like homosexuality and ordination of women. **********Also up for debate at the meeting on Thursday will be the longstanding custom of printing an anonymous essay on the state of the church in the opening pages of the church directory. Some priests, deeply shaken by the 58-year-old bachelor's suicide, see the practice as tainted because it has brought death and division to the church. Hailed by Traditionalists **********But no one expects a quick resolution to the deeper questions of why Dr. Bennett killed himself and what his death means for the power struggle in the Church of England between his fellow Anglo-Catholic traditionalists and the dominant modernist wing of the troubled church. **********Traditionalists today hailed Dr. Bennett as a martyr who killed himself in despair over being unable to halt the decline of a state church that now claims only 5 percent of the British population as communicants. **********''He was one of those people who manifestly ought to be a bishop and who has been passed over in favor of very, very inferior people,'' said John Gummer, who holds the No.2 agricultural post in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Goverment and is a lay member of the church's governing General Synod. ''He was a saintly, gentle figure. It was his friends who were bitter about his being passed over for people who had not his conviction in the faith of the church.'' **********A Labor member of Parliament, Frank Field, another lay Synod member, said Dr. Bennett was ''an example of the blackballing'' of conservative theologians by ''the Runcie group.'' Only seven or eight of Britain's 43 bishops are regarded as reflecting conservative theological positions and social values. Defeat for Anglo-Catholics **********As an adherent of the Anglo-Catholic wing of the Church of England, Dr. Bennett emphasized its Roman Catholic roots on issues such as an all-male priesthood. But the Anglo-Catholics suffered a defeat in February when the General Synod approved preliminary steps that could lead to the ordination of women by 1991. **********Liberals privately cited Dr. Bennett's thwarted ambitions to be a bishop and the defeat on ordination as the reason for his attack on Dr. Runcie, the head of the Anglican Church. His preface described the Archbishop as a practitioner of ''elitist liberalism'' who lacked sound theological training and avoided tough issues by going with the crowd. **********''His influence is now probably at its height,'' Dr. Bennett wrote. ''It would therefore be good to be assured that he actually knew what he was doing and had a clear basis for his policies rather than taking the line of least resistance on each issue.'' **********The harsh tone of the article caused a storm of controversy. There were charges of ''back stabbing,'' and before Dr. Bennett's authorship was disclosed, the Archbishop of York, Dr. John Habgood, denounced the article as ''scurrilous, sour and vindictive.'' Today, Dr. Bennett's friends said he might have killed himself because of this critcism from Dr. Habgood, widely regarded as the leading candidate to succeed Dr. Runcie, and because of the growing ''witch hunt'' for the author by the press. Coroner Insisted on Knowing **********Those eager to make a hero of Dr. Bennett have been trying to excuse his repeated false statements to reporters and priests who asked him if he was the mystery author. The Rev. Philip Ursell, an Oxford colleague, said today that Dr. Bennett believed that ''the fulfilling of a contract to remain anonymous is not the telling of an untruth'' and he likened what some have labeled Dr. Bennett's ''lies'' to protecting the confidentiality of a confession. **********In the end, church officials were forced to reveal Dr. Bennett's role because of pressure from the Oxford coroner, who considered the question of authorship germane to his inquest into the cause of death. **********There is an underlying political motif to the entire episode. Anglican traditionalists are generally regarded as supporters of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, and she is sympathetic to their effort to hold the church to traditional values. In the British system, Mrs. Thatcher selects from a list of two nominees each new bishop to be appointed by the Queen. **********In September Dr. Bennett was appointed to the six-member selection committee that picks the nominees for Mrs. Thatcher's consideration. In killing himself, Dr. Bennett seemingly missed a chance to use this powerful position to seed the nomination lists with conservatives. **********But Mr. Gummer suggested that Dr. Bennett may have despaired because the liberal domination of the selection committee itself meant that Mrs. Thatcher would never have the opportunity of choosing conservative bishops. ''If you put up two liberals or one liberal and one impossible you soon make sure that the hierarchy is entirely liberal,'' Mr. Gummer said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/30/world.main_headline: New Clash in Jerusalem on Films on Sabbath
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/30/world.print_headline: New Clash in Jerusalem on Films on Sabbath
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/30/world.body_text: **********Israeli riot policemen broke up demonstrations at dusk today by hundreds of rigorously Orthodox Jews protesting the showing of movies on Friday nights. Bursts of tear gas fired by the police wafted through Jerusalem from the clashes. **********Crowds of strictly religious men, women and children gathered at 12 intersections leading out of Mea Shearim, the Orthodox quarter of Jerusalem. They shook their fists, spat and shouted ''Sabbath, Sabbath'' at passing motorists, who were driving before the end of the Sabbath at sundown. At each intersection police officers -armed with tear gas, nightsticks and water cannon - stood guard, making certain that the protesters, led by their rabbis, did not try to move out of Mea Shearim. 'Get Out of This Country' **********But at several interesections groups of 300 to 400 demonstrators surged into the streets and began throwing stones and screaming ''Nazis'' and ''Get out of this country'' at the police. **********Whenever the police seemed to fear that the crowd was about to get out of control, they opened up with tear gas and hoses, which sprayed water mixed with a green dye not easily removed from clothing. **********Each time the police let loose with the hoses the crowds scattered into side streets. At one intersection, a small crowd of nonreligious Jerusalemites gathered behind the police barricades and cheered each time tear gas was fired. **********Some of the rigorously Orthodox from Mea Shearim came out individually and engaged the spectators in sidewalk debates. **********Most of these involved observant men demanding to know why the others were defiling the Sabbath. The spectators asked why the strictly religious did not serve in the army. **********Today's clashes were the latest in Jerusalem's ''Sabbath War,'' which began several months ago when two movie houses, later followed by two more, defied a city ordinance and opened for business on Friday night. **********The demonstrations tonight seemed to be dying out after a few hours. ''We have mobilized hundreds of policemen from all around the country,'' said Maj. Avraham Zalba, a police spokesman. ''We have everything under control.'' Mobilizing Public Support The main complaint of the police officers on the scene seemed to be that for the third or fourth week in a row they had been robbed of their own Sabbath by the Sabbath demonstrations. **********The leaders of the rigorously Orthodox called today's demonstrations as part of an effort to mobilize public support against the movie showings, which, they believe, desecrate the Sabbath and violate the traditional balance of secular and religious relations in the holiest city of the Jewish people. **********On Friday night, some 2,000 nonreligious Israelis demonstrated against what some described as ''religious coercion,'' and attended films at four movie houses that were open. **********Rabbi Nissim Zeev, a prominent religious politician, warned in a newspaper interview last week that the theaters could be burned down if they continued opening on Friday nights. **********Most nonreligious Jerusalemites do not seem to favor widespread restaurant and movie openings on Friday nights, because of the historic religious character of the city. **********However, many say they would like to see a few places open in non-Orthodox areas where their teen-age children could go. Moreover, they say, they resent being told by the religious that they have to behave in a certain way. Barricaded Neighborhoods **********Rigorously Orthodox Jews make up 25 to 30 percent of Jerusalem's population. Their own neighborhoods are blocked off with barricades from Friday night to Saturday night to prevent cars from driving through. **********Israel operates on a six-day workweek, with Sunday being a normal workday and Saturday the only day off. For Jerusalemites, this means that nothing is open on Friday nights. During the summer, when the sun sets very late, movie houses and restaurants cannot open until 9:30 P.M. on Saturday, after the Sabbath is over.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/03/busin.main_headline: RIVAL AIDS CAMPEAU IN ALLIED DEAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/03/busin.print_headline: RIVAL AIDS CAMPEAU IN ALLIED DEAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/03/busin.body_text: **********The Campeau Corporation, in a struggle to complete its $3.6 billion purchase of the Allied Stores Corporation, got financing help from a rival bidder for Allied, two of the parties said yesterday. **********Also, Allied has decided to sell by June 16 of its retail chains that provided 38 percent of its sales. They include Bonwit Teller and Garfinckel's. The 16 divisions generated 12 percent of store profits during 1985. **********The Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation, which sided with Allied to prevent Campeau's takeover, will get a 35 percent interest in what remains of Allied at a cost of $210 million. **********The financing deals give analysts more reason to question whether Campeau stretched itself too thin to acquire the larger Allied Corporation, which has 691 department and specialty stores in 46 states. Campeau, a Canadian-based builder and shopping center developer, agreed to acquire Allied in November. **********The Campeau-Allied plans were disclosed in a prospectus filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and in a joint release from Campeau and DeBartolo. **********Under bank agreements, Allied is required to sell the divisions ''as soon as possible'' to pay off $300 million in debt. Allied said it would not sell other retail units, including Brooks Brothers, Ann Taylor and the Jordan Marsh department stores. It did not specify all 16 divisions that it would sell. **********The S.E.C. filing also shows that Allied plans securities offerings that would raise more than $1 billion for additional financing. These offerings include $600 million in senior subordinated debentures, $200 million of senior notes and 10 million shares of cumulative exchangeable preferred stock. **********The company said that besides 16 divisions, it might be forced to sell other assets to meet loan payments. **********After the June payment, the company said it owes $500 million by Dec. 31 and a total of $1.1 billion by December 1988. **********Edward J. DeBartolo, the Ohio developer whose bid for Allied was exceeded by Campeau, is lending Campeau $150 million to help finance the purchase. **********In their joint news statement, the two companies said that Mr. DeBartolo would have the option of making an additional $60 million payment to Allied and converting his loan into a 35 percent equity interest in Allied, the nation's third-largest department store operator. **********Moreover, they said the agreement included ''certain benefits to DeBartolo'' that will enable the developer to ''participate directly in the business development of Allied.'' **********Financial analysts said that Campeau had hurried in order to complete the Allied deal to save millions of dollars in tax benefits that would be lost under the new tax law, which took effect Thursday. **********Meanwhile, the two developers said that Mr. DeBartolo had agreed to purchase the five regional shopping centers owned by Allied for $400 million, but Campeau has an option to purchase back a 50 percent interest for $200 million by March 31. That would leave Mr. DeBartolo with a 50 percent interest in the shopping centers. Originally he was to purchase a 25 percent interest for $112.5 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/30/world.main_headline: Sentences Are Reduced In Polish Priest's Death
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/30/world.print_headline: Sentences Are Reduced In Polish Priest's Death
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/30/world.body_text: **********Four former officials of the Interior Ministry, who were convicted of murdering a priest who supported the Solidarity labor movement, have been given shorter prison sentences, Government officials said today. **********The four men who killed the priest, the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, are benefitting from a general amnesty that freed hundreds of Solidarity supporters interned during martial law. **********Former Capt. Grzegorz Piotrowski, who received the maximum term of 25 years for leading the attack on the priest, will serve 15 years. The term of one accomplice, former Col. Adam Pietruszka, was reduced from 25 to 10 years. **********The sentences of the other two men, former Lieut. Leszek Pekala and former Lieut. Waldemar Chmielewski, were shortened to six and four and one half years respectively, from 15 and 14 years. All four men have already served three years. **********Father Popieluszko was abducted in October 1984. He was tortured and killed and his body was thrown into a reservoir.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/06/busin.main_headline: ARCHIVES OF BUSINESS: The Toy Industry; Under the Tree, in Christmases Past
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/06/busin.print_headline: ARCHIVES OF BUSINESS: The Toy Industry; Under the Tree, in Christmases Past
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/06/busin.body_text: **********CHRISTMAS was a lot easier on parents before toys came along. When children played with wooden spoons or pots, their parents not only didn't have to spend any money but, more important, didn't have to make any choices. (They also didn't have to squirm around under couches and beneath dish washers, days later, rooting for mislaid pieces from the Erector set.) By the late 1800's, the toy business was in full swing. Besides dolls and stuffed animals, stores were offering Jack-Straws, the Roaming Turtle, the Jester, the Electric Experiment Box and the Tom Stout Marble Game. **********These days, upward of 4,000 new products annually come wobbling and whirring and squishing out of toy factories, many of them just in time to find a spot under the Christmas tree. The country's 800 toy makers engage in pitched battles to try to get their products under enough trees to win a bigger piece of the $12.5 billion toy market. No wonder guards patrol Mattel's R & D building in Hawthorne, Calif., as if it were a missle silo. **********Over the decades, a plenitude of toys has been put on the market - about 150,000 different toys now clog store shelves. Some sell well for years and are known as classics - Lionel trains, Crayola, Play-Doh, Barbie, G.I. Joe, Tinkertoys, Cabbage Patch dolls. Others never sell and are known as just plain duds. **********In the end, of course, it doesn't matter what the toy designers or the parents think about a toy. Its success comes down to the whims of the children who play with it, and there's no predicting what they'll like. **********Here's a look at a few of the toys that, over the years, a lot of them did like. *********** Hot day. Nothing much to do. A restless John Lloyd Wright, the son of Frank Lloyd Wright, was in Tokyo, accompanying his father on a business trip. This was 1916, when John Wright was 24. While his father was tied up with a client, he watched workmen move timbers into place for the Imperial Palace Hotel, intended to be an earthquake proof building. As he watched, he drifted off and dreamed of a toy that children could use to build little versions of some of the structures of America's past - the log cabins, the forts, the bridges. **********Returning to his home in Merrill, Wis., John Wright worked out the details for a construction toy, and, in 1918, he put Lincoln Logs on the market; the name was meant to bring to mind the logs in Abraham Lincoln's old home. But there wasn't much interest. Not until 1924, in fact, did children really nag their parents to buy them the logs. **********By the 1930's, however, children all over the country were building log cabins. In 1943, Playskool acquired the rights to Lincoln Logs from Mr. Wright, immediately making the company a very large housing developer. The logs continue to be steady sellers, Playskool said; this year, it expects that more than 500,000 sets will be bought. In fact, it takes four train carloads of Ponderosa pine from Oregon every month to make enough Lincoln Logs to satisfy demand. *********** While Richard James, a marine engineer, was aboard ship in 1943, a torsion spring - a coiled, circular spring - fell off a table and begin rolling around the deck. Its wild gyrations amused him. When he came home, he told his wife, Betty, that he thought a nifty toy could be made out of a spring. Mrs. James went on with what she was doing. **********For two years, Mr. James tinkered with various metals, thicknesses and proportions, before he perfected a coiled steel spring (80 feet long if stretched taut) that could quiver its way down a flight of stairs. His wife flipped through a dictionary to come up with a name for it and stopped when she arrived at ''slinky.'' **********Motionless in the store, Slinky looked like something misplaced from the hardware department. ''It looked like nothing sitting there,'' Mrs. James said. ''You had to see it move.'' The Jameses persuaded the Gimbels store in Philadelphia to allow them to set up a sloped board in the toy department where they could let Slinky ''walk.'' Within 90 minutes, all 400 Slinkys in stock were sold. **********In 1945, the Jameses started a company, James Industries, and they were pretty happy. But how long could a coil of steel sell? Mrs. James figured Slinky was good for a few years, at best. Year after year, though, Slinky kept selling. In the last few years, it has sold at an annual rate of more than two million springs. **********Beginning in the late 1970's, the line has been extended to include a Slinky Junior, a Plastic Slinky, a Slinky Cater-Puller and Slinky Eyeballs. The original steel version, though, still outsells the others. **********In 1960, Mr. James apparently had seen enough Slinkys for one lifetime. He left the business - and Mrs. James - to join a religious cult in Bolivia (He died in 1974.) Mrs. James continued to own and run the business, as she does to this day, in the small town of Hollidaysburg, Pa. Now 69 years old, Mrs. James rides around town in a car bearing the license plate: ''SLINKY.'' *********** The thing should never have been invented. During World War II, scientists at General Electric were searching for a rubber substitute to make tank treads and G.I. boots. No luck. They discovered a pink, taffy-like goo that was good for absolutely nothing. **********G.E. people used to take it to cocktail parties and joke about it. It was at one of those parties in 1949 that Peter Hodgson, a Connecticut marketing man, saw it. He noticed the delight people took in stretching it and bouncing it off walls, and decided it might make a good toy. He ordered a batch, stuck it in a toy catalogue he was writing for a local store and called it Silly Putty. **********It did well enough that Mr. Hodgson formed a company in New Haven in 1950 so he could make and market the blobs himself. Millions of half-ounce dabs of Silly Putty, packaged in plastic egg-shaped containers, sold every year. People found they could bounce it like a ball. They could stretch it like taffy. When they struck it with a hammer, it shattered like glass. **********At first, Mr. Hodgson marketed Silly Putty as an adult toy. It moved slowly, until it began to pick up some free publicity. Steve Allen started to play with it on his nightly Tonight show, and ''The Big Story,'' a detective series, built a murder mystery around it. **********In 1957, hoping to expand sales, Mr. Hodgson began a television advertising campaign aimed at children. They especially liked the fact that the stuff would pick up pictures from comic books. In time, it became mainly a children's toy. **********In 1977, Binney & Smith, a Pennsylvania toy maker, bought the rights to Silly Putty. Sales had been tapering off, though increased distribution by Binney & Smith helped rebuild them. Of late, two million eggs of Silly Putty are sold each year. **********Silly Putty is one of those toys that lend themselves to versatility. Parents use it to strip lint from their clothing. Others scrub typewriter keys with it or stick it under table legs to stop the wobbling. In 1981, the Columbus Zoo selected it to take hand and foot prints of its gorilla population. Receivers for the New England Patriots football team squeeze it to strengthen hand muscles. Silly Putty even went into space; the Apollo 8 astronauts used it to hold tools in place. **********Peter Hodgson died in 1976. He left an estate of $140 million. *********** John B. Tigrett was an executive of a Chicago bus company, and, as a sideline, he took flings with novelties. He did okay with a dunking duck that squatted on the edge of a glass of water and kept dipping its beak in and out of the water. In 1950, however, he found a toy that got him out of buses for good. **********Sitting on a plane, he began talking to the man next to him. The passenger mentioned that a salesman in Rutherford, N.J., had invented a toy for his little girl out of adding-machine paper. Mr. Tigrett contacted the man and arranged to license the product. The salesman had already thought up a name - Zoomerang. **********The Zoomerang consisted of tough red, white and blue paper wrapped around one end of a stick that was a bit smaller than a pencil. Holding on to the other end of the stick, you flicked your wrist and whipped the coil out in a spiral for a distance of up to eight feet. The paper then sprang back into place. In another version - endorsed by Hopalong Cassidy - the paper spiral shot out of the barrel of a plastic revolver. **********When Mr. Tigrett introduced the Zoomerang, it didn't sell. He wrote to Arthur Godfrey, who mentioned it on his radio show, and that did it. **********By 1954, Mr. Tigrett had sold about 20 million Zoomerangs. It was the biggest-selling toy in America. ''The surprise element did it,'' Mr. Tigrett said. ''That's what sold everything then.'' **********After about four years, the zoom was about gone from the Zoomerang. By then, Mr. Tigrett was pretty well off. He had another big hit with a bird that wallked up and down walls and then he got into the boat business and other things. In 1964, when Zoomerang sales were virtually gone, he sold everything and moved to Europe. **********He has since acted as a financial consultant to such people as the Hunt brothers and J. Paul Getty. For the last 20 years, he's been a partner in business ventures with Sir James Goldsmith, the European financier. Today, at 75, he lives in Memphis, Tenn., and London. It amuses him that his Zoomerang still shows up, made by some company or other in Taiwan. ''I bought one in New York the other day,'' he said. ''It didn't work well at all.'' *********** Mr. Potato Head has never been content to be just a toy. He has always insisted on a full-fledged life. **********Perhaps that's because television went to his head. Mr. Potato Head, according to toy industry lore, was the first toy ever advertised on television; that happened when he starred in some local commercials in California in 1952. (The first toy to hit national TV is thought to be the Mouse Guitar, which was put on the air in 1955.) In 1953, a year after Mr. Potato Head was introduced - as a set of metal-tipped eyes, ears, noses and mouths that could be stuck onto a real potato - he met Mrs. Potato Head. According to the fanciful publicity distributed by Hasbro, Mr. Potato Head's manufacturer, they had an incredibly fast courtship, were married and spent their honeymoon, logically enough, in Boise, Idaho. **********Hasbro was one of the first companies to recognize the value in endowing a toy with a fantasy life, a practice that has become increasingly commonplace. Every few years, it seemed, consumers received some more details on what the Potato Heads were up to. In the early 1960's, Mr. Potato Head went on a buying binge. He bought a convertible, boat, trailer, airplane and locomotive. **********In 1966, after the company started selling plastic bodies along with the appendages, Mr. Potato Head became drawn to recreational activities. A wind-up spring was installed inside him so he could jump, fish, play with a jackhammer and fly kites. Mrs. Potato Head started jumping, too. She could move a feather duster, floor polisher, dinner bell and vacuum cleaner. (This was before female potatoes were liberated.) In 1974, Mr. Potato Head was getting older. He couldn't jump and, worse, he had doubled in size. (He still hasn't lost the weight.) In February 1985, the Potato Heads had a child. Even with Baby Potato Head around, Mr. Potato Head soon found time to campaign (unsuccessfully) for mayor of Boise. Ads billed him as the first vegetable to run for public office, ''a man of the soil.'' The publicity hasn't hurt. Hasbro estimates that 40 million heads have been sold, with about a million kits bought each year. **********Mr. Potato Head still makes news. At a press conference last month he announced that, after puffing on a pipe for 35 years, he was giving up smoking. ''It's a bad influence on the kids,'' he said, ''let alone what it must be like for my wife, a non-smoker. *********** If you can do more than one thing with a toy, it helps. If you can do a few trillion things, it really helps. **********That's what the Christiansens figured. Ole Kirk Christiansen ran a carpentry shop in Denmark. It began in 1916, making ladders and ironing boards, then toys. In the 1930's, Mr. Christiansen sold an awful lot of Yo-Yo's, until the Danes got Yo-Yo'd out. He switched to toy trucks and then, in 1949, came up with little plastic building bricks with round studs. **********In the 1950's, his son, Godtfred Kirk Christiansen, took over the company, now known as Interlego A/S, and bet everything on the bricks. He named them the Lego System of Play. Lego arrived in this country in 1961. The bricks lend themselves to the imagination. Just six bricks, the company says, can be combined in 102,981,500 ways. If you've only got three bricks, you can fit them together in 1,060 ways. A statistican once figured out that every year European children spend five billion hours playing with Lego bricks. **********Initially, the bricks were designed for 5-year-olds, but with time the age range has been expanded. There are also Lego people and all sorts of items to make a whole Lego city. Larger bricks are made for 3-month-old babies and the upper range is listed at 14 years. However, plenty of people several decades older get a kick out of them. Norman Mailer, when he was 37, built a 15,000-brick ''city of the future'' in his Brooklyn living room. **********Lego Systems, the Connecticut-based American division of Interlego, sells the bricks in this country, the toy's largest market. Lego doesn't give out dollar numbers, but estimates have put annual sales in this country at as much as $115 million. More than half the households with children under 15 are thought to own the bricks. **********All sorts of things have been built out of Legos, by people at home, for contests or displays: the U.S. Capitol, Mount Rushmore, Sitting Bull, Ronald McDonald, the Port of Copenhagen and quarterback Joe Montano. *********** It was really disgusting. It was a pea-green blob. One look at it made you want to throw up. **********It was Slime. **********For whatever reason, kids were ready for a drippy, clammy piece of yechhh in 1977. Within months of its introduction by Mattel, which developed it in one of its Hawthorne, Calif., labs, Slime had become one of the country's 10 biggest selling toys. **********The stuff was 95 percent water; the rest was sugar and a bunch of secret ingredients that Mattel executives wouldn't divulge even if you pointed a Zoomerang at them. Slime could be messy, but Mattel assured parents that water ought to get it out of clothing. Still, in one publicized case, a Chicago mother had to cut some of her son's hair out after she couldn't extract Slime from it. **********Some adults liked to spill Slime on co-workers' desks. Down in Washington, Jim King, the White House personnel chief under Jimmy Carter, once poured some in Hamilton Jordan's office. **********Slime did nicely for a few years before fading. Then, in 1980, Mattel tried to give it a lift by offering two new versions: Rainbow Slime, streaked with different colors, and Slime It's Alive, with plastic eyes. Neither went over big. Slime disappeared from the market in 1981. **********There's no keeping a yucky blob down. In 1986, Slime reappeared as an accessory for Mattel's Master of the Universe action figures. Any warrior who isn't careful might be snatched by the fearsome claw of the Slime Pit, which then pours gruesome Slime all over him. Even a brave warrior doesn't like that.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/21/world.main_headline: ELECTION EVE TALK WITH KOHL: SURE OF VICTORY AND ALL SMILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/21/world.print_headline: ELECTION EVE TALK WITH KOHL: SURE OF VICTORY AND ALL SMILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/21/world.body_text: **********Snugly ensconced in one chair, Helmut Kohl reached out with a long arm and dragged an empty one to him in a kind of half-embrace. ''I have been underestimated for decades,'' the West German Chancellor said with a big smile. ''I've done very well that way.'' **********Five days before national parliamentary elections, Mr. Kohl seemed to have good reason for his contentment. Every polling organization in the country has found that his center-right coalition is headed for re-election on Sunday - the Chancellor predicted with 54 to 55 percent of the vote - confirming him in the stewardship of West Germany for four more years. **********In Bonn, a small city where the large and restless Mr. Kohl has never felt at ease, the scent of imminent victory is especially sweet. For it has been here above all that he has been derided as a bumbling, inarticulate and pratfall-prone provincial. Dramatic Shift in Mood **********Yet as he and others struck the balance of his four years and five months in power it was difficult to avoid the conclusion that West Germany's national mood had dramatically shifted from torment and doubt to satisfaction and mild optimism. **********A visitor to his spacious office overlooking a snow-covered park remarked that the winter election campaign had been dull and issueless. ''What you call boring,'' the Chancellor retorted, ''is that we have a good record in office. And the people see it.'' Quite consciously, Mr. Kohl has presided over a calming of West Germany's political life, which in 1983 was acutely polarized over the deployment of American medium-range nuclear missiles and an agonizing debate about sovereignty and a German national identity caught between East and West. **********Wolfgang Bergsdorff, one of the Chancellor's closest advisers, said of his chief: ''He has two visions, and they are both covered by the word 'normality.' The excited climate in the country should be calmed down, and he has certainly accomplished that.'' **********''The other part is our relationship to our history,'' continued Mr. Bergsdorff, ''and with what happened in the German name between 1933 and 1945. His feeling is that the German memory should not be occupied solely with this period and that we should overcome our troubled relationship with ourselves.'' **********It is not certain that Mr. Kohl has achieved this second goal, which has kindled controversy. The world still associates this country with such gestures as President Reagan's wreath-laying at the military cemetery at Bitburg, where members of the SS are buried, or with the Chancellor's off-the-cuff comment that Kurt Waldheim, now President of Austria despite a searing investigation of his war record, was a ''great patriot.'' Holds to His Position **********Klaus Hofmann, a journalist who has known Mr. Kohl for almost four decades, said that even more than West Germany's first Chancellor, Konrad Adenauer, Mr. Kohl was determined to cement the alliance with the United States. ''He has held to this position even when opinion polls and other fashionable indicators have been against it,'' said the journalist. ''I think he will go into history as a big integrator of the Federal Republic in the West.'' **********This is a friendly judgment. Yet even Mr. Kohl's foes concede that his great political strength lies in his unchallenged command of the Christian Democratic Party apparatus, which he patiently built up during nine years as an opposition leader. As Chancellor he has kept his doors open to the likes of county-level party treasurers, who return to the provinces convinced that the man at the top cares. **********It is suggestive of Mr. Kohl's populist style that he has drawn up a little-known testament stating that should he ever be taken hostage he does not want the state to be put in a situation where it could be blackmailed to secure his freedom. **********The Chancellor horrifies his bodyguards by his determination to be seen moving normally among his countrymen. It is not unusual to see him strolling about Bonn or, at home in Ludwigshafen, attending a local Roman Catholic church with hardly any protection. Comparisons to Truman **********Michael Sturmer, a historian who has occasionally advised the Chancellor, speculated that Mr. Kohl might one day be put in the category of Harry S. Truman, ''a vastly underrated politician who almost came through the side door and left the stage having accomplished a lot.'' **********''His real strength,'' said Mr. Sturmer of the Chancellor, ''is touching the ground and having that feeling of the ground - and appealing to the man who wants simple home truths. In this way his petit bourgeois background, and even his gaffes, help him. He is regarded as a real human being, authentic.'' **********Reading a speech to Parliament or on television, Mr. Kohl looks stiff and uncomfortable stumbling through someone else's words. But election campaigns appear to have an almost liberating effect, allowing him to abandon the persona of the statesman for that of the politician and to speak his own folksy idiom. **********At a rally in Wurzburg on Saturday, Mr. Kohl appeared shortly after 8 P.M. at the rear of a big hall and picked his way down the aisle, reaching into the crowd and grabbing hands. On the speaker's dais, a young protester with a sweater rushed the Chancellor with a petition and was violently hustled off the stage by bodyguards. **********''That's no cause for excitement!'' the Chancellor boomed into the microphone as a group of Communist hecklers, who have been disrupting his campaign regularly, sounded a chorus of boos and whistles. Mr. Kohl drowned them out with a one-liner: ''If they were real Marxists they would know the famous sentence of Rosa Luxemburg - that freedom is always the freedom of the other!'' **********The set Kohl speech is an extended homily on the virtues of hard work (''The future is more important than leisure''), freedom and traditional Christian values that he sees leading to ''a renaissance of the family.'' **********''All the principles that are valid for private life must be valid for public life,'' he said in his speech, ''and this must be German politics.'' **********He vowed continuity in foreign policy and discussion with the Soviet Union and its allies, but, as he has recently, struck out harshly at East Germany for holding political prisoners. ''The decisive reality is that we are part of the Western world and we will not accept Soviet or Communist hegemony over the Federal Republic,'' he declared to loud cheers. An Hourlong Conversation **********An hourlong conversation in German with Mr. Kohl in Bonn at the tail end of the campaign was in some ways like a continuation of his speech, with some of its themes, such as the need for West Germany to embark on more basic research, being developed in quieter tones. **********The Chancellor noted that this was the first January election ever held here, a wintry variable that might reduce the turnout. But he said he would be ''fully satisfied'' if his coalition of Christian and Free Democrats won 54 to 55 percent of the vote. **********''I have never believed this fairy tale about the absolute majority,'' he said, referring to earlier speculation that his party might get an overall majority of Bundestag seats. ''Absolute majorities are very unpopular with us.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/14/world.main_headline: 18 Reported Dead as Troops Clash With Salvador Rebels
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/14/world.print_headline: 18 Reported Dead as Troops Clash With Salvador Rebels
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/14/world.body_text: **********Eight soldiers and 10 rebels died in a seven-hour night battle for the town of Delicias de Concepcion in eastern El Salvador last night, the armed forces press office said today. **********In a statement it said 12 soldiers and 3 civilians had been wounded. The rebels later said on their clandestine Radio Venceremos that 25 soldiers were killed and 24 wounded. **********It was the second major rebel attack in two months in the area and military sources said it produced the fiercest fighting of the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/26/busin.main_headline: Tax-Exempt Bond Sale The Largest in Months
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/26/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Tax-Exempt Bond Sale The Largest in Months
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/26/busin.body_text: **********In the largest tax-exempt bond sale since March, the Louisiana Public Facilities Authority is offering $1.3 billion of bonds through underwriters led by Lazard Freres & Company. **********Proceeds from the sale will be used to repay about $780 million the state owed a Federal unemployment trust fund and to bolster the state's own unemployment trust fund. The bonds are not backed by the state, but they are secured by collections of a recently approved tax on employers equal to 1.4 percent of the first $15,000 of wages paid to each employee. **********Several other states are considering bond sales to refinance the money they owe the Federal trust fund, but none of those issues is expected for at least a few months. As economic conditions have improved in recent years, states' borrowings from the fund have fallen, from $14 billion at the peak of the last recession, to $3.9 billion in June and a projected $1.3 billion by the end of 1988. **********Underwriters tentatively offered the bonds with yields ranging from 4.75 percent for issues due in 1988 to 6.35 percent in 1992, 7.47 percent in 1997 and 7.76 percent in 1999. **********The financing sets a new standard in the tax-exempt market for extensive use of ''super sinkers,'' a category of bond that is expected to be retired long before its stated maturity. By using excess funds to retire super sinker bonds as soon as possible, the authority reduces the average maturity of its debt, thereby allowing it to pay lower interest rates. **********The six issues of super sinker bonds in the Louisiana financing total $392.7 million and have stated maturities in 2000 to 2002. But assuming the state collects as much in employment taxes as projected, the bonds' average lives will range from slightly less than one year to 6.6 years. Yields range from about 6 percent for the super sinker with an estimated life of 0.95 year to 6.875 percent for a 2.85-year issue and 7.66 percent for the 6.6-year issue. **********Because the bonds are backed by seven-year letters of credit from a group of four Japanese banks, led by Fuji Bank Ltd., they were rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/05/world.main_headline: LEBANESE PRIME MINISTER RESIGNS, CITING DEADLOCK
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/05/world.print_headline: LEBANESE PRIME MINISTER RESIGNS, CITING DEADLOCK
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/05/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Rashid Karami resigned today after three years in office, saying that his Cabinet, which was half Moslem, half Christian, had failed to resolve political and economic problems. **********Although the 10-member Cabinet had been virtually inactive, it served as a symbol of a legitimate Government in a country torn apart by 12 years of civil war. **********The announcement by Mr. Karami, a 65-year-old Sunni Moslem, raised concern that it might not be possible to form a new government under the prevailing conditions. **********Moslem politicians, including the Prime Minister, have boycotted all dealings with President Amin Gemayel, a Maronite Christian, who, under the Lebanese political system, would have to choose another Moslem as Prime Minister. Christians Want Syria to Leave The boycott came after the President had rejected Syrian-backed Moslem demands to give Moslems a larger share of power. **********The Christians want Syrian peacekeeping troops to leave and to be replaced by a United Nations force. About 7,000 Syrians patrol the western, Moslem part of Beirut, and 25,000 Syrian soldiers are deployed in the north and east of Lebanon. **********Mr. Karami said he decided to step down on the ground that the continuing political and economic deadlock was against Lebanon's interests. He mentioned two recent occurrences. **********One was a Cabinet meeting 10 days ago, the first in seven months. He said the meeting confirmed that Moslem and Christian members could not agree on any issue. The other incident, last Friday, was the presentation by various factional leaders of contradictory proposals and demands that Mr. Karami said generated even more fears about the nation's course. Jumblat's Remark Recalled Newspapers said Mr. Karami had been angered in particular by remarks by Walid Jumblat, the Druse leader. At a May Day rally on Friday, Mr. Jumblat called Mr. Karami, President Gemayel, and Hussein al-Husseini, a Shiite Moslem who is Speaker of Parliament, ''cheaters and murderers.'' **********The Druse leader has been Minister of Public Works in the Cabinet, which was labeled ''government of national unity'' when formed in 1984. **********Mr. Karami, in making his announcement, declined to say what he thought might happen next. **********In the last two decades Mr. Karami has headed nine governments. President Gemayel was elected to a six-year term in 1982. **********Within an hour of Mr. Karami's announcement, artillery fire broke out along the Green Line, which divides Beirut into Moslem and Christian sectors. Radio stations said shells and rockets struck residential areas on both sides of the line. There were no immediate reports of casualties. **********Under the Constitution, the outgoing Cabinet will be expected to stay on as a caretaker until the President appoints a new Prime Minister to form an administration.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/22/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Testing and reporting for syphilis has been mandatory in virtually all states for many decades. Gonorrhea, German measles, and other nonlethal diseases are legally reportable by physicians to health departments in most states, but AIDS, a lethal disease, is not. **********This is basing public policy on political cowardice and strained law rather than technical and medical realities. Bad medicine and science always prove to be bad public policy. **********The answer to the insurance dilemma is straightforward. Most life insurance policies contain, typically, a two-year suicide clause. Since it would be entirely reasonable, with what we know today, to regard promiscuous homosexual or heterosexual activity and sharing intravenous needles as courting suicide, insurance carriers might well consider a clause that invalidates life insurance or limits the payment upon death to the aggregate of premiums by making an ''AIDS suicide clause'' five years or longer. The actuarial unpredictability of the disease will then become irrelevant.   DR. JOEL J. NOBEL   Plymouth Meeting, Pa., March 2

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/13/busin.main_headline: The Monthly Trade Figures: A Closely Watched Barometer
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/13/busin.print_headline: The Monthly Trade Figures: A Closely Watched Barometer
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/13/busin.body_text: **********The monthly trade figures have become a litmus test of sorts for the health of the overall United States economy. This is why investors and traders in all the financial markets pay so much attention to the report - and, correspondingly, why the prices of stocks and bonds and the value of the dollar in relation to other major currencies can rise or fall, depending on how the actual figures stack up against expectations. **********For instance, a ''good trade figure'' - one (like September's) that is on the low end of what economists had been expecting or even lower - instills confidence in the economy. **********Why? For one thing, it indicates that American corporations are becoming more competitive in world markets, a development that itself has broad implications. By indicating that the devaluation of the dollar that already has taken place is working to improve the competitiveness of American companies, favorable trade figures reduce protectionist sentiment in the United States. In addition, by indicating that the rate of dollar outflow because of imbalances between exports and imports is being reduced, they decrease the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will have to raise interest rates to attract money from abroad. **********How the trade figures affect the various financial markets, though, is even more complicated. At least as important as the actual numbers, is how the figures jibe with expectations. Explaining yesterday's rise in the stock and bond markets and the increase in the value of the dollar, some analysts said that reports of progress in the Washington negotiations to cut the Federal budget deficit played at least as important a role as the trade figures did. **********But even though the trade report was not a big surprise and was not good in absolute terms - a $14 billion monthly trade deficit is still extremely large - it was better than many experts had been predicting. **********''The overriding common denominator in the markets was that the trade number came in on the optimistic end of the spectrum,'' said Jay N. Woodworth, vice president and economist at the Bankers Trust Company. **********If the statistics released yesterday turn out to be a new trend (which no one can know for sure at this time) the effects could be salutory for the economy for a variety of reasons. **********First, it would mean that the United States would not feel compelled to drive the dollar's value down further to make American goods more competitive. That would bode well for holders of dollars who would feel less compelled to sell them out of fear that they would drop further in value. **********Second, with a smaller merchandise trade deficit, fewer dollars flow out of the country. Thus, the nation's foreign debt would grow more slowly, which means that the United States would be perceived to be financially stronger. **********Foreigners, feeling more confident, thus would be more willing to hold dollars. **********''This country is a debtor nation,'' said Burt R. Clark, treasurer of the National Westminster Bank USA. ''Increases in the trade deficits will increase those debts. How much credit will the world give you, and with what do you repay those debts?'' **********Third, if the dollar maintains its relative strength, it would reduce pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to prop up the dollar. High interest rates encourage foreigners to buy dollars that can be invested in American securities, driving up the value of the dollar. One major reason why the Federal Reserve does not want the value of the dollar to decline too far is that it makes imports more expensive, and that leads to inflation. **********But although raising interest rates might shore up the dollar, it can also cool, or even cripple, the domestic economy - and that could cause corporate earnings and stock prices to drop. **********On the other hand, if the Federal Reserve does not have to worry about the dodlar's value, it can keep money readily available at low rates. That would stimulate economic growth, keep corporate profits strong and, in turn, encourage higher stock prices. **********Fourth, because higher exports create more jobs for Americans, continued improvement in the trade balance would reduce pressures for adoption of protectionist policies. Many economists believe that such policies were largely responsible for the Great Depression of the 1930's. The smaller trade deficit ''shows that a decline in the dollar could help stop the erosion of American jobs to foreigners,'' said Stephen Leach, a foreign-exchange expert at the Chemical Bank. ''We are seeing a turnaround. It's taken a long time, but there is solid improvement.'' **********Finally, just the sense that progress is being made creates a more buoyant mood among investors, in both stocks and bonds. That was reflected in the financial markets yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/25/world.main_headline: RAIDS BY CONTRAS ON THREE TOWNS CALLED HARD BLOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/25/world.print_headline: RAIDS BY CONTRAS ON THREE TOWNS CALLED HARD BLOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/25/world.body_text: **********A rebel attack on three towns in northeastern Nicaragua last Sunday was the contras' largest and most successful military operation of the war, according to evidence seen by a reporter and the accounts of Government soldiers and townspeople. **********''They really hit us,'' said Juan Rodriguez, a 25-year-old Government soldier. ''It was a hard blow.'' He said he fought ''hundreds'' of contras in a pitched battle in Siuna for most of Sunday morning. **********He estimated that as many as 40 soldiers were killed in the fighting here, a higher figure than that given by the Government. Civilian Toll Is High **********But the overall effect of the rebel attack was greatly influenced by the number of civilian casualties. As many as 19 civilians appear to have been killed and more than 100 wounded in the three towns, according to doctors and Sandinista officials. Almost all appeared to have been hit by mortar and small-arms fire, a doctor here said. **********In addition, although the rebels carried out their most extensive sabotage of the war, some installations that they claim to have destroyed were not damaged. They also failed to attack major military and economic targets that were easily accessible to them. **********For most of Monday, Tuesday and today, Sandinista planes and helicopters ferried reinforcements, weapons, ammunition and wounded, a great many of them civilians, across the thick green jungle of this nearly inaccessible region of northeastern Nicaragua, darting to and from the battlefield in an effort to recoup and pursue the departing rebels. Dead Buried in a Trench **********A bulldozer and men wearing gauze masks dug a trench in Siuna today to bury four dead rebels. The army dead had already been removed, but the civilian hospital remained full of wounded villagers and militiamen. **********The combined offensive began without warning at 5 A.M. Sunday when the rebels, probably numbering 2,000 to 3,000, swept into the towns of Siuna, Bonanza and Rosita, several witnesses and army soldiers said here. **********The rebels occupied Siuna and Bonanza, where they engaged Government troops and destroyed an important radar station, a large arms and munitions warehouse, an electrical plant, a police station and a militia barracks among other targets, according to Sandinista officers and residents. They said the rebels began to withdraw from Siuna and Rosita on Sunday night and from Bonanza on Monday. Mine Works Not Destroyed **********The three mining towns, all in Zelaya Department, produce gold and silver, which is economically important to Nicaragua, and hold significant military installations. The rebels damaged the mine works in Bonanza but not, as they asserted, in Siuna, according to evidence seen by reporters and accounts by Sandinista officials and residents. **********The coordinated raids indicate a new level of military sophistication, a will to fight and the ability to use what appears to have been highly accurate intelligence. The attacks also indicate that the guerrillas have largely neutralized the threat from Sandinista helicopter gunships with American-provided missiles. **********The rebels now appear to be able to strike targets at a time of their choosing in this rugged country of few roads and then set up ambushes against Sandinistas sent in as reinforcements. Rebel Claim Is Denied **********This is the second successful major attack since October by the rebels, who claim to have killed or wounded more than 200 Government troops. **********Maj. Ramon Sosa, the Sandinista army commmander for this region, disputed the contra claim in a briefing here today. He contended that 49 soldiers had been killed and 76 wounded and that 137 rebels had been killed. In addition, he said, 19 civilians were killed and 93 wounded. He said also that several civilians had been seized by the rebels. **********The figures given by both sides were impossible to verify by reporters, who did not see bodies to back up the claims. **********Major Sosa showed only a few rifles that he said had been captured from the rebels, a seeming anomaly if more than 100 guerrillas were killed. But the fighting occurred in a dispersed area and it is possible that not all weapons were collected for reporters to see. **********The Government did not allow reporters into the battle area until Wednesday, when they were permitted to enter Siuna for a few hours but not Bonanza or Rosita. **********In Siuna, Major Sosa gave an account of the battle that was contradicted by several soldiers, by villagers and by the evidence of fighting. Other reporters were allowed to fly briefly over Bonanza and Rosita. They reported seeing heavy damage in Bonanza, where the rebels fought for almost two days. **********Major Sosa asserted that the rebels had not occupied Siuna, that Sandinista ''crossfire'' had destroyed the radar site here and that a arms warehouse that was blown up held only antiquated weapons. Town Reported Bombed **********But 14 separate army and civilian witnesses said that the rebels had occupied Siuna so completely that the Sandinista air force bombed the town in an effort to rout them. The bombs were apparently defective; two sat in their craters today, unexploded. **********Several witnesses, including four soldiers, also contradicted Major Sosa by giving convincing accounts of how the rebels blew up the radar station. They also said the destroyed warehouse was full of new, not antiquated, weapons and ammunition. **********Accounts by soldiers and villagers indicate that the guerrillas dominate this zone of Zelaya Department. Reporters were taken to Siuna in Sandinista air force planes that flew at treetop level - to avoid rebel rocket fire, a pilot said. **********Several eyewitness accounts gathered in Siuna indicate that more than 1,000 rebels struck from five directions before dawn, catching about 360 government defenders by surprise. They almost immediately destroyed the radar station and arms warehouse, according to local residents, soldiers and evidence seen by a reporter. Trucks Not Destroyed **********But for reasons that are not clear, they did not destroy several heavy trucks and the mine works here. They also failed to attack or shell the headquarters of the 366th Sandinista Army Brigade, even though it was immediately in front of them. **********One villager, Nelson Antonio Giron, said townspeople gathered in the church had implored the rebels not to destroy the mine works, a major source of work here. Ten residents said in separate interviews that the rebels held the town for about eight hours and walked around the center talking to townspeople. They said there was no looting or abuse of civilians. **********Dr. Klaus Helber, a West German who is head of the hospital and who has lived here for two years, said the rebels refrained from entering the hospital when asked not to, even though wounded Sandinista soldiers were inside. **********Dr. Helber, who described himself as a Government supporter, said the contras told two nurses at the hospital: ''We don't want to hurt civilians. We know you are suffering hunger and we are here to bring you liberty.'' **********The rebels then told people not to join the militia, warning that they would attack again soon, townspeople said. One villager said the rebels had taken away four local residents, but Dr. Helber, who knows the town well, made no mention of villagers' being missing. Help From Local Peasants **********The rebels say that they have extensive support in this area and that local peasants provided them with key intelligence and helped guide their surprise approach on the towns. Those claims appear credible. ''It is clear the contras know very well where to eat and where to sleep,'' Dr. Helber said. ''There are people who help them.'' But the rebels appear to have won few friends in the towns by causing so many civilian casualties. It is not easy to prove whether civilians were hit by rebel or Sandinista weapon fire since part of the battle took place inside the towns. **********Most of the more than 70 wounded civilians whom Dr. Helber said he treated appeared to have been hit by shrapnel. The wounds strongly indicate that the civilians were struck by poorly controlled mortar fire that the rebels used to open their attack. **********This reporter saw several women and young children who had been hit by shrapnel while taking cover in their homes. Many were wounded only lightly, but a number were severely hurt, including a 6-year-old girl, Kenia Rodriguez Martinez, who lost both of her feet to a mortar round in Siuna. ''A bomb hit my house - I was trying to hide,'' she said, lying quietly on a stretcher before being evacuated by plane. **********Maria Aguilar Jarquin, whose 4-year-old daughter, Lijia, was hit by shrapnel, said: ''They said they were fighting for a free fatherland and that they don't want to hurt civilians. But they scare me - this is dangerous.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.body_text: **********Charles A. Atkins, the New York financier accused of engineering one of the largest illegal tax shelter conspiracies in history, was described by prosecutors yesterday as a man who descended into a ''world of fraud'' because of his own ''greed and lies.'' **********But lawyers for Mr. Atkins, the managing partner of the Securities Groups, an umbrella organization for several investment partnerships, said that their client had never made a transaction without the approval of lawyers and that much of what the Government said was a conspiracy was nothing more than the normal course of business for modern investment houses. **********Mr. Atkins is charged with 31 counts of conspiracy and fraud to produce what the Government says were more than $350 million in fraudulent deductions for wealthy investors. He is being tried along with William S. Hack, president of Kale Holding Corporation, and Ernest M. Grunebaum, who headed a division of the securities group. They were both indicted on several charges. **********Yesterday's opening session of the trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan included an explanation of Wall Street jargon by Federal District Judge Edward Weinfeld and the presentation of charts by defense lawyers to explain Government securities trading. A Crucial Difference **********The gradual exposure to the words and world of Wall Street underscored a crucial aspect of the trial - differentiating for the laymen on the jury between the complex, but perfectly legal, financing of tax shelter deals and the crimes of which Mr. Atkins and his associates are accused. **********The case has attracted particular notice because of the well-known people who invested in the company's deals, including Laurence A. Tisch, chief executive of CBS Inc.; Preston R. Tisch, the Postmaster General of the United States; Andy Warhol, the artist, and the actors Lorne Greene, Michael Landon and Sidney Poitier. None of the investors are charged with any crime. **********In opening statements for the Government, Stuart E. Abrams, the chief of the major crimes unit in the United States Attorney's office, described the case as being about ''greed and lies.'' **********''Once Mr. Atkins turned to fraud, success came very easily,'' Mr. Abrams said. Prosecutor's Comments **********Mr. Abrams spoke of secret tape recordings that a partner of Mr. Atkins had made in the summer of 1982 in which, the Government contends, Mr. Atkins discussed the scheme; of five outside accountants who refused to issue statements or sign the partnership's tax returns in 1983, and of the company's growing revenues being rolled forward each year to escape paying taxes. **********''Securities Groups became a full-service tax fraud operation,'' Mr. Abrams said. **********The lawyer for Mr. Atkins, James A. Moss, denied that Securities Groups paid fees to individuals in outside companies to provide documentation of ''bogus'' losses that could be used for deductions by the firm's investors. **********''There were fees,'' Mr. Moss said. ''For any broker or dealer the payment of fees is common.'' **********Lawyers for Mr. Hack and Mr. Grunebaum both denied that their clients had done anything improper. Mr. Grunebaum's lawyer, John H. Doyle, stressed that his client had not been in the inner circle of Securities Groups. Government's First Witness **********In the afternoon session, the Government called its first witness, Steven Hageman, a former partner in a subsidiary of the Securities Groups. **********Mr. Hageman, who pleaded guilty to conspiracy and income tax evasion this year in connection with his work with Securities Groups, testified that officials of the company knew that it had sent false information about transactions to investors and that tickets verifying transactions were sometimes backdated to gain tax benefits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/29/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********While E. L. Doctorow may be correct in describing stock speculation as a trivial use of time, he is surely wrong to include the game of chess in the same category. Certainly he must realize that many people regard a brilliantly played chess game as a work of art. Indeed, many of the games Paul Morphy produced over 100 years ago are still studied and appreciated as such; further, provided Western civilization is still operative, they will continue to be a hundred years hence. Would that Mr. Doctorow's works similarly survive.  JAMES J. REILLY Bellport, L.I., Oct. 25

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/05/busin.body_text: **********A group led by the Australian investor Alan Bond today offered $38 a share for the G. Heileman Brewing Company, the nation's fourth-largest brewer. **********But Heileman's stock soared $8.25, to $42.125, an indication that Wall Street expects a higher bid. **********The cash offer by Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. was valued at $1.2 billion. Heileman issued a statement urging shareholders to do nothing about the bid until the board and management have decided whether to accept it. No National Brand **********George Dahlman, an analyst with Piper Jaffray & Hopwood, of Minneapolis, said Heileman is worth as much as $45 a share. He praised the company's performance and its management, despite a 4 percent drop in earnings in the first half of the year. **********''The only thing they haven't done is to get a national brand,'' Mr. Dahlman said. **********Heileman, a regional brewer whose brands include Old Style, Colt 45 and Henry Weinhard, has about 8 percent of the nation's beer market, according to Jerry Steinman, editor and publisher of Beer Marketer's Insights, a New Jersey newsletter. **********The beer business is dominated by the Anheuser-Busch Companies, maker of the top-selling Budweiser brand. The company has 38.5 percent market share of the market. Trailing Anheuser-Busch are the Miller Brewing Company, a subsidiary of the Philip Morris Companies, with a 20.3 percent share, and the Stroh Brewing Company, with a 12 percent share. 'He's Buying Distribution' **********Paul Shain, a beer industry analyst with Dain Bosworth Inc. of Minneapolis. speculated that the Bond Corporation, which owns the Swan Brewery, the second-largest beer manufacturer in Australia, might want to use Heileman as a distributor for its own brands. **********''He's buying distribution,'' Mr. Shain said of Mr. Bond's offer. ''Beer is sold through wholesalers, distribution is highly unionized, and it's not easy to break in with a new product. With Heileman, you've got product slots, you've got shelf space.'' **********However, Mr. Steinman said, new brands face extraordinary difficulties and $1.2 billion is a high price to pay just to enter the market. He said Australian beers, largely the Foster's brand, represented only 1.7 percent of imports and one-hundredth of a percent of the total American market. **********The Bond Corporation, which also has interests in energy, broadcasting, films and property in Australia, Hong Kong and elsewhere, bought its first American beer company in 1986, when its Swan Brewery subsidiary paid $28 million for the Pittsburgh Brewing Company. Mr. Bond said in a statement that the acquisition of Heileman would create the world's fourth-largest brewer in the world, after Anheuser-Busch, Miller and Heineken N.V., a Dutch company. Heileman Chief 'a Fighter' **********Don Deaton, a spokesman, said Mr. Bond personally presented the buyout bid to Russell G. Cleary, Heileman's chairman and chief executive. **********Mr. Steinman of Beer Marketer's Insights said he thought Mr. Cleary would struggle to stay independent if he could. ''I think of him as a fighter,'' Mr. Steinman said. Bond Corporation's Amber Acquisitions Corporation conditioned the offer on Heileman's removing its so-called ''poison pill,'' a legal mechanism installed two years ago to discourage takeover bids, and on the tender of 75 percent of Heileman's outstanding common stock. **********Clare Zempel, an analyst with Robert W. Baird, in Milwaukee, said the poison pill goes into effect within 10 days of a hostile offer and essentially dilutes the equity of shares the buyer might acquire. **********A Bond spokesman said the 75 percent stock requirement was included to overcome takeover restrictions in Wisconsin. Small Brands, Big Business **********Heileman, which earned $48.3 million on sales of $1.3 billion in 1986, itself has a reputation as an aggressive acquirer of small brands. It has done well with Henry Weinhard's Private Reserve, a beer aimed at an upscale market on the West Coast, and Colt 45, a malt liquor. But success in the national market has eluded it. **********Antitrust considerations helped thwart two Heileman bids for the Pabst Brewing Company and one for the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, now part of Stroh. Nor could the company push its biggest beer into the big leagues by sheer promotional effort. **********''They attempted to take Old Style national, and it just didn't work,'' Mr. Shain of Dain Bosworth said. **********Mr. Bond, a native of Britain, is a self-made man. He is famous for his sponsorship of an Australian yacht that won the America's Cup. In the year ending June 30, his Bond Corporation had an operating profit of $116 million on revenues of $1.8 billion. **********Bond Corporation said it would raise the cash for the deal from its own reserves as well as from financing provided by a group of banks and by Salomon Brothers Inc.  THE HOUSE OF HEILEMAN  The company, headquartered in La Crosse, Wis., has become the nation's fourth largest brewer through aggressive acquisitions of regional brewers.
