https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/23/busin.main_headline: Advertising; McCaffrey Forms Unit For Films
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/23/busin.print_headline: Advertising; McCaffrey Forms Unit For Films
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/23/busin.body_text: **********McCAFFREY & McCALL has formed a McCaffrey & McCall Entertainment unit that will mainly serve the needs of United Artists. **********It will be run by Norman S. Freedman, the chairman and chief executive, and Daniel Stern, the president and creative director. **********According to the agency and to Andrew Fogelson, president for marketing worldwide at United Artists, the agency and client will have a ''true marketing partnership,'' with the agency making some kind of creative contribution on every United Artists movie. **********This relationship is unusual, the client and agency agree, because most agencies working for movie production companies are only media buyers, with the actual advertising being done by any one of a multitude of boutiques and creative freelancers that flourish in the Hollywood smog. **********Mr. Freedman explained that the agency had prepared to start the new unit by gathering a myriad of marketing information from its client on MGM movies in wide release over the last six years. (United Artists is a subsidiary of the MGM/UA Communications Company.) From it, they developed data on 440 variables affecting profit and fed it all into a computer. **********''As a result, we have been able to increase profits without increasing marketing funds,'' Mr. Freedman said. **********''Given the big sums of money used to promote movies, I think we are going to revolutionize the business,'' added David B. McCall, the parent agency's chairman. **********Mr. Fogelson, reached by telephone at his California home, said, ''I think they were the first to do an analysis and come up with a process to help improve our business in a very dramatic way.'' **********He said that beginning with the July 31 release of the new James Bond movie, ''The Living Daylights,'' United Artists plans to bring out eight movies in the next 12 months and then go to a 10-movie-a-year schedule. The average media advertising budget for each film should be about $6 million, he said. **********Other films on the schedule include ''Real Men,'' with James Belushi and John Ritter; ''Baby Boom,'' with Diane Keaton, and ''Bright Lights, Big City,'' with Michael J. Fox. **********''The movie business is changing dramatically because of the cassette business and the percent of revenues coming from the cassettes,'' Mr. Fogelson said, ''so we have to increase the number of releases to supply the market.'' **********He described the ''windows of opportunity'' as theaters, cassettes, televisin and libraries. **********The Bond movie will be the first from United Artists since it merged with MGM. Lee Rich, a former Benton & Bowles man in New York, is now chairman of MGM/UA Communications. **********McCaffrey & McCall Entertainment, whose parent is a Saatchi & Saatchi company, has a staff of about 12. Mr. Freedman, 50 years old, comes to its leadership from the account management side of the agency where he was an executive vice president. He is ready for a show business assignment after six years of running the ABC-TV Network account. **********Before coming to McCaffrey & McCall, Mr. Freedman worked as a researcher at Grey Advertising and then switched to account handling and did a stint on Procter & Gamble. Afterward, he went to Masius Wynne-Williams and was an account man on Colgate-Palmolive. He is a native of Brooklyn and has bachelor's and master's degrees from New York University. **********Mr. Freedman's associate, Mr. Stern, was born in Manhattan but grew up in the Bronx. He graduated from the prestigious High School of Music and Art and, instead of going to college, went on the road with his cello. He made it as far as the Indianapolis Symphony and even without a degree was welcomed as a visiting professor at Wesleyan University in Connecticut. **********Besides creating advertising, Mr. Stern creates novels, nine so far, and the latest, published in 1982 by Simon & Schuster, is ''An Urban Affair.'' Does it have movie potential?

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/15/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********There are about 100 million workers in the United States who average about $13 an hour. One of our important perks is the ability to buy better quality automobiles at lower prices from Japan than are available from domestic manufacturers. **********However, Harold A. Poling wants to limit imports of cars because of the trade deficit (''Counting Cars From 'Immigrant' Plants,'' Forum, Feb. 1). What he wants is protectionism.  Whatever Mr. Poling's objectives, they are hardly in keeping with our democratic process. Should $13-per-hour workers be required to subsidize the domestic automobile and allied industry workers making $23 per hour, in addition to the enormous salaries of the managements? He should learn to make better quality at lower cost or step aside for the imports.  CHARLES D. REICH   Shaftsbury, Vt., Feb. 3

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/world.main_headline: MANAGUA WARMS TO NEW PEACE PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/world.print_headline: MANAGUA WARMS TO NEW PEACE PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/world.body_text: **********President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that Nicaragua was now willing to consider a regional peace plan proposed last month by President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica. **********Mr. Ortega's comments marked a reversal from earlier Nicaraguan statements condemning the plan as a ruse designed by the Reagan Administration. **********In a speech today opening the 1987 legislative session, Mr. Ortega said he supported the principle of ''Central American dialogue.'' **********''Understanding and coexistence among brothers is possible when national and regional interests prevail, not the interests of the hegemonic power,'' he said. **********Mr. Ortega's comments came one day after he told foreign diplomats that he was prepared to attend a meeting scheduled for mid-May at which Central American presidents are to discuss the Arias plan. Key Issue Is State of Emergency **********When the peace plan was first put forward in Costa Rica last month, Nicaraguan officials portrayed it as an attack on their Government. The Foreign Ministry called the plan ''truly lamentable'' and said countries that backed it were becoming ''neo-colonies of the United States.'' **********The Arias plan would require all Central American countries to guarantee ''full observance of civil rights'' and ''real pluralistic and democratic processes,'' including free elections overseen by foreign teams. **********Diplomats said that to comply with these clauses, Nicaragua would have to lift its state of emergency, which restricts many civil liberties. Nicaraguan leaders consider the state of emergency essential to the maintenance of public order and security. **********Today, Mr. Ortega said the state of emergency could be lifted only ''if the Reagan Administration stops its war of aggression against the people of Nicaragua.'' In the past, the Sandinista Government has also rejected the presence of official foreign election monitors. **********But despite these reservations about the Arias plan, Nicaraguan leaders apparently have come to believe that it may contain positive elements. 'Something They Could Live With' **********Under the Arias plan, all outside funding of rebel groups in Central America would be forbidden. Unlike the Contadora peace proposal, which has been in negotiation for more than four years, the Arias plan would not require any Central American country to reduce the size of its army or arsenal. **********American officials have privately expressed strong reservations about the proposal, according to diplomats. The diplomats said the Reagan Administration is not prepared to halt aid to Nicaraguan rebels without major concessions from the Nicaraguan Government. **********''The Sandinistas now understand, as they did not a week ago, that this plan was not made in Washington by any means,'' said one ambassador. ''The more they look at it, the more they think they may be able to fix it so that it becomes something they could live with.'' Contra Threat Dismissed **********Much of Mr. Ortega's speech was devoted to the military threat from the rebels, known as contras. He said the Nicaraguan Army was prepared to contain any new contra offensive, but warned that the United States had ''more sinister options'' in case the contra effort failed. **********Groups of contras have recently been moving into Nicaragua from bases in Honduras in preparation for what is expected to be increased fighting. Mr. Ortega today put the size of the rebel force at 6,000 fighters, about half the number used by Western military experts, and said American funds would not be sufficient to topple the Sandinista Government. **********''Reagan cannot buy his victory in Nicaragua,'' Mr. Ortega said. ''It is not simply a matter of writing a check for a larger amount.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/19/world.main_headline: U.S.-INDIA RELATIONS ARE WORSENING, MOSTLY OVER PAKISTAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/19/world.print_headline: U.S.-INDIA RELATIONS ARE WORSENING, MOSTLY OVER PAKISTAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/19/world.body_text: **********A series of major and minor disputes have sent relations between the United States and India skidding to the lowest level since Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi took office in 1984, American and Indian officials said today. **********The officials said friction and bitterness had replaced the friendliness of a year or two ago, when Washington was hopeful that Mr. Gandhi would break with precedent and be more sympathetic to American interests. **********Indian leaders say the United States appears to have abandoned its newly professed sensitivity to New Delhi's concerns and is instead seeking a long-term relationship with Pakistan as an American surrogate in the region. **********''It is clear that Washington is looking to Pakistan as a replacement for the Shah,'' a senior Indian official said, likening the situation to that in Iran before the 1979 revolution. ''That raises the temperature here.'' Foreign Minister Cancels Trip **********A measure of Indian anger was the recent cancellation of a trip to Washington by the Indian Foreign Minister, N. D. Tiwari. His deputy, K. Natwar Singh, then had to defend his own earlier visit to the United States against bitter questioning in Parliament. **********The new tension has not blocked other efforts to improve relations, officials said, but some of these efforts were said to have stalled. ''This is a very delicate time,'' an American diplomat said. **********At the center of the stir is the Reagan Administration's determination to provide Pakistan with a new military aid package, including an advanced air surveillance system, despite indications that Pakistan is developing a nuclear bomb. **********American military aid to Pakistan, which has fought three wars against India, has long been the major irritant in Indian-American relations, but officials say several other issues have aggravated the problem. Among them have been snags in the proposed sale to India of a sophisticated American computer and a move in the House of Representatives to cut American aid to New Delhi. Citing the Afghan War **********American officials say Pakistan needs protection against the 115,000 Soviet troops in neighboring Afghanistan. But this has also led to doubts in Pakistan about Washington's reliability, with rising fears there that the United States would cut off aid if the Afghan war were somehow resolved. **********To reassure Pakistan, Washington has lately said that it would continue to provide military help even if the war is settled. India charges that these assurances show that Washington is looking for a long-term military ally. **********American officials, meanwhile, are irritated because Mr. Gandhi has begun blaming his domestic problems on a plot by ''foreign forces'' to discredit him and undermine Indian democracy, as he did in a speech Saturday. Although not mentioning the United States by name, he has made it clear that he was accusing Washington of being part of an attempt to destabilize the country. **********''This is the kind of thing we used to hear from Indira Gandhi,'' an American official said, referring to Mr. Gandhi's mother and predecessor, who often angered the United States with talk of a ''foreign hand'' working against India. Mrs. Gandhi was assassinated in 1984. 'Purely Political Reasons' **********''It's not what we expected from Rajiv,'' the official said, noting that earlier under Mr. Gandhi cooperation with the United States, even in the military area, had risen to its highest level in 20 years. ''I don't even think he believes this stuff. He is doing it for purely political reasons.'' **********Mr. Gandhi has been under fire lately because of a feud with the Indian President, Zail Singh, as well as charges that his Government took payoffs from West German and Swedish arms contractors and accusations connected with trying to protect a Bombay textile concern against charges of business fraud. **********His Congress Party issued a statement last month warning against a conspiracy of multinational corporations and unnamed Western countries to destabilize India. American officials were understood to have conveyed their displeasure to Mr. Gandhi's aides and asked him to stop using such language. **********Instead, the Prime Minister repeated the charge in a fiery speech before 200,000 supporters on Saturday. The crowd roared in approval when he vowed to teach a lesson to Pakistan and ''its patrons.'' **********''We're going through lean times now,'' an Indian diplomat said. But he and others cited a recent speech in Parliament by Deputy Foreign Minister Singh in which he said India hoped to ''further promote, deepen, strengthen and widen'' its relationship with Washington. Good Ties in Some Respects **********Indian and American officials say the relationship remains strong in other respects. The United States is still India's largest trading partner, and Indians still flock to the United States to live and work. The United States also wins praise here for its efforts to arrest Sikh terrorists. **********Cooperative ventures are also continuing in education, technology and health as part of an improvement in relations that began in 1982 and increased after Mr. Gandhi took office in late 1984. India also remains interested in American military technology and plans to send a team of experts to investigate possibilities of buying electronics for a proposed Indian jet fighter. **********But Indian officials said that although they expected Washington to continue to help Pakistan, its efforts to rush ahead with highly sophisticated equipment, such as a possible air warning defense system, violated what they considered to be pledges of a new sensitivity to Indian concerns. **********Officials agree that relations worsened after the visit last October of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, which an American official called ''a disaster.'' Mr. Weinberger infuriated India by not warning Mr. Gandhi or his aides that, on the next stop of his trip, he was going to come out in favor of sending Awacs radar planes to Pakistan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/07/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge dismissed a lawsuit today that contended the arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky was liable for investment losses suffered by two people because of his illegal insider trading. **********The suit, filed under Federal civil racketeering statutes on behalf of Isabel Sterber of New Jersey and Aline K. Halye of Connecticut, contended that Mr. Boesky's activities had artifically inflated prices of certain stocks and options purchased by the women. Those activities included insider trading in takeover-related stocks and illegal payments to others for inside information. **********The suit said the women lost unspecified sums because of stock price declines when the Securities and Exchange Commission announced Mr. Boesky's role in the insider-trading scandal last November. The suit sought unspecified damages. **********Mr. Boesky, formerly one of Wall Street's leading speculators in stocks of potential takeover targets, agreed last Nov. 14 to pay a record $100 million in civil penalties to settle S.E.C. insider-trading allegations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/busin.main_headline: Opening a Window on the Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/busin.print_headline: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER; Opening a Window on the Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/busin.body_text: **********NO personal computer could have prepared an investor for the wild ride the markets took last week. Even the Big Boys, using their Big Computers, were stunned by the magnitude of the tremors that shook Wall Street. **********But an investor with a PC and the appropriate programs could have avoided the sense of helplessness that many people felt as the markets moved swiftly and vital news about them seemed to slow down. **********Before making a trade, investors want information. Using a modem and communications software, personal computers can tap much of what is available to brokers and big institutions - and they can do it from a home, office or pay phone. This can be particularly soothing when your broker vanishes behind a barrier of busy signals. **********The PC user can get up-to-the-minute stock quotes, detailed financial information on any public company, data on interest rates, foreign exchange rates, futures prices and other economic indexes, current assessments from a wide range of analysts and wire service reports that won't appear in the newspapers until the following morning. And when it's time to execute a trade, the computer can file the order with a broker. **********For calmer moments, there are programs that allow the average PC user to chart and analyze both individual stocks and broader markets with a surprising degree of sophistication. It would be a mistake, however, to rely exclusively on these programs for an investment strategy. If they all did what they were advertised as being capable of, everybody would have been smiling last week, right? **********Many analysts blame a technique called program trading for the wild plunges and rocketlike increases in the Dow last week. The computers Wall Street uses for program trading are brutes that allow pension plans and other big institutions to make thousands of calculations and, simultaneously, to hurl millions of dollars into the market, playing the futures against the actual stock prices. Program trading is no place for sissies. **********In a sense, though, these institutional computers are not doing anything that the humble PC cannot do. If you want to fight fire with fire - even if it is a match against an inferno - you can run similar programs and see the same signals that the technical analysts use. **********Analysis programs are also available that evaluate individual issues, and they might have told you, for example, that I.B.M. was at $170 but a bargain at $103, or that the Dow had skated onto thin ice the instant it crossed above 2,250. If nothing else, learning to use these programs will make an investor more knowledgeable about the market. **********While there are an estimated 50 million investors nationwide, there are only about 10 million PC's in use. Thus the computer can be a tool that gives you an advantage over the unequipped. What follows is an examination of some of the software available for stock analysis. Next week we'll look at the PC as an information tool about the markets and underlying economic conditions as well. **********There are, in general, two classic techniques for following the market: fundamental analysis and technical analysis. **********Fundamental analysis tries to identify companies that are undervalued or fairly valued, with good prospects for long-term appreciation. It looks at companies not as quick-profit possibilities, but as the sort of businesses you would want to own and pass on to your children. **********TECHNICAL analysis is for investors who want to get in and out of the market quickly, taking profits based on split-second timing, using a collection of complex market indicators. Technicians love charts. **********Dr. Fred Shipley, a professor of finance at DePaul University in Chicago and the editor of the newsletter Computerized Investing (published by the American Association of Individual Investors), said he believed that fundamental analysis could help most investors, and he was particularly keen on two programs. **********His choices were Stockpak II from the Standard & Poor's Corporation ($275 to $1,010 for a year, depending on how many stock exchanges you want to monitor and whether you want your data updated once or twice a month, for I.B.M. and Apple II's; 25 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10004, 800-852-5200), and Value/Screen Plus (a two-month trial is $39, which rises to $169 quarterly and $309 a year for monthly data updates, or $1,500 a year for weekly electronic delivery of updated company information, for I.B.M.'s, Macintoshes and Apple II's; Value Line Inc., 711 Third Avenue, New York N.Y. 10017, 212-687-3965.) Dr. Shipley said Value/Screen Plus was somewhat easier to use, but it is limited to tracking the 1,600 most heavily traded stocks on all the exchanges. Stockpak, on the other hand, has access to everything in the S.& P. register, so if you're interested in obscure securities, this might be a better choice. **********''I'm not a strong believer in technical analysis,'' Dr. Shipley said, ''and I don't feel that most people will benefit from a lot of trading.'' But, he said, the reviewers at Computerized Investing have been impressed by a new technical analysis package called Criterion STS ($688, Criterion Software Inc., 916 Southwood Blvd., Incline Village, Nev. 89450, 800-332-2999). ''It does basically what it says it will do,'' he said. **********CRITERION just introduced a somewhat different program at half the price, known as Criterion MTS. On Oct. 1, Criterion MTS suddenly flashed an alert: on a 1 to 100 scale, with 100 being, in effect, ''sell everything and head for the life rafts,'' the program signaled a 99. As of Thursday, it was not advising investors to return to the market. **********Membership in the American Association of Individual Investors (612 North Michigan Avenue, Chicago, Ill. 60611, 312-280-0170) is $48 a year; a subscription to Computerized Investing is $24 extra. **********Another group of interest to those who want to combine computers and investment is the Microcomputer Investment Association (902 Anderson Lane, Fredericksburg, Va. 22405, 703-371-5474). Dr. Jack M. Williams, administrator of the group, said that the majority of commercially available stock analysis programs ''are not worth the disks they come on.'' **********''Be very careful, be extremely careful when you buy software and trust your funds to it,'' he said. ''You can go broke quickly.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/04/busin.body_text: **********The  Markets **********The stock market lurched downward as volatility returned. The Dow Jones industrial average fell sharply from the onset, was off as much as 115 points around 1 P.M., then rose somewhat to close down by 50.56 points, at 1,963.53. The apparent lack of progress in Washington on reducing the deficit and profit taking by investors who bought at recent low prices were cited as factors in the selling.  [ Page A1. ]  Democrats proposed and Republicans rejected a $31 billion deficit-reduction package. Democratic leaders said they would move ahead on their own.  [ A15. ]  The New York Stock Exchange relaxed its curb on program trading, saying major brokerage houses could execute such trades for their own accounts, under certain restrictions.  [ D11. ]  Tokyo stock prices fell in early trading this morning.  [ D11. ]  A sharp decline is expected in hiring on college campuses by investment banks.  [ D11. ] **********The dollar rallied on world markets after traders had pushed it to new lows against the mark and the yen. Central banks that intervened in recent sessions to smooth the dollar's fall stayed out of the markets, traders said. Dealers described the rally as largely technical and said they were pessimistic about the dollar's prospects. **********Gold prices dropped by $1.70, to $468.40, in New York.  [ D1. ] **********Treasury bond prices rose nearly a point, cutting the yield of the 30-year issue to slightly above 9 percent.  [ D23. ] **********Price swings bloodied some traders in another wild day in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures pit in Chicago.  [ D24. ] Companies **********Olympia & York may bid for Santa Fe Southern Pacific, heating up a takeover battle that could be the largest ever outside the oil industry. The Canadian real estate and investment company said it was considering a cash bid of $63 a share. Henley has offered $63 in cash and securities.  [ D1. ] **********Four unions at Pan Am will support a takeover effort by Kirk Kerkorian, the West Coast investor, union officials said. Their backing is considered crucial to Mr. Kerkorian.  [ D1. ] **********U.S. airlines fared poorly in a survey of 30,000 passengers who fly often. Swissair and Singapore Airlines led the list of the top-rated airlines, which was dominated by foreign carriers.  [ D5. ] **********I.B.M. will introduce its new operating software in December, a few months ahead of schedule. The system, known as OS/2, will be licensed to hardware manufacturers for $325 for each package; an extended edition will ship in July for $795.  [ D5. ] **********Telex cannot use an Oklahoma law to block a takeover bid by the New York financier Asher B. Edelman, a Federal judge ruled.  [ D5. ] International **********Brazil and its creditors appeared close to agreement on a plan for the resumption of interest payments on Brazil's $100 billion foreign debt, nearly nine months after the Government suspended payments. Banking officials said the banks would in effect provide much of the money to pay the interest due them.  [ D1. ] **********A Federal jury indicted two Japanese businessmen and two Hungarian diplomats, charging them with diverting an American-made laser system used in making semiconductors to Hungary in violation of United States export control laws. Elsewhere, four men were indicted in a scheme to sell designs for a supercomputer to the Soviet Union.  [ D2. ] Technology **********Brighter and more lifelike movies are possible with a film-making and projection system called Showscan. To adopt Showscan, however, the industry would have to abandon two historic standards.  [ D10. ] **********Little slips of paper stuck to a telephone inspired the creation of Lotus's latest software, Agenda, which has been described as a spreadsheet for ideas. Advances.  [ D10. ] Today's Columns **********What ails the market may be, at root, the inability of nations to respond to crises. There is a need for national leaders to reconcile differences in their efforts to stabilize currencies and rescue the dollar. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene.  [ D2. ] **********The new-issue market has come to a virtual standstill. Prices are off sharply for corporations that made initial offerings just before the market collapse. Market Place.  [ D12. ]

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/busin.main_headline: RESEARCH-COTTRELL SALE TO INVESTOR GROUP SET
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/busin.print_headline: RESEARCH-COTTRELL SALE TO INVESTOR GROUP SET
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/busin.body_text: **********An investor group headed by Odyssey Partners, Allen & Company Inc. and First Chicago Venture Capital has signed an agreement to buy Research-Cottrell Inc. in a leveraged buyout for $43 a share, or $293 million, the builder of water, air and waste treatment plants said yesterday. **********The three firms are to share ''roughly equally'' in the venture, insiders said, and Peter J. Gianacakes, who is 62, will remain chairman and chief executive. Some company officers, including Mr. Gianacakes, have been invited to invest in the venture. **********The stock movement, however, seems to indicate that Wall Street expects a new bidder to emerge and push the offering price higher. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Research-Cottrell jumped $5.25 yesterday, to $44. It was the third-most-active issue, with 1.54 million shares changing hands. **********Jeremiah P. Cronin, Research-Cottrell's chief financial officer, said that, after a board meeting Friday evening, the company endorsed its sale to the Odyssey-Allen-First Chicago group as the highest bidder after its adviser, the First Boston Corporation, arranged a bidding contest among several potential buyers. **********Mr. Cronin said the company was originally approached with a pair of buyout offers a couple of months ago but ''the board decided it didn't want to look at just those two.'' They were not identified. Mr. Cronin stressed, however, that management had not initiated the sale. **********According to the Value Line Investment Survey, Research-Cottrell has been revamping its operations over the last four years to enter the lucrative business of upgrading waste water and waste management systems and to work with the Government in converting such services as municipal waste plants to private interests. Last year more than half the company's new business came from such growth areas. **********The deal would be the second investment of this kind for Odyssey Partners, formerly called Oppenheimer & Company and still headed by Leon Levy and Jack Nash as senior partners. Last year Odyssey bought control of Gundle Environmental Systems of Houston, a producer of heavy-duty plastic liners to contain toxic wastes. It has since sold some of the Gundle stock through Drexel Burnham Lambert. **********One person close to the bidders described Research-Cottrell as ''part of a growth industry.'' But he noted that ''it also has some risks'' because the company must bid for jobs and could bid too low. Also it has to post large performance bonds for some projects. **********Research-Cottrell has been bidding on jobs for 75 years, the company pointed out, and is familiar with the process. None of the company will be sold to finance the venture, it added. Novel Financing Twist **********In a novel twist to its role as financial adviser to the buyers, Drexel will provide its own funds for the deal on a temporary basis - known as bridge financing - which it will subsequently replace with new money to be raised through the sale of high-yield securities generally called ''junk bonds.'' **********Drexel has long been the unquestioned leader in raising money through junk bonds, but other Wall Street houses have devised bridge financing to compete with Drexel. Now Drexel, in turn, has adopted bridge financing itself to prevent the loss of clients. **********When junk bonds are involved, Drexel typically gives lenders a letter saying it is ''highly confident'' it can raise the money. With bridge financing, it issues a commitment letter guaranteeing to provide the money. Safer Procedure Sought **********Bridge financing is being used in this instance, it is understood, because the parties insisted on it as somewhat safer, though more expensive because of the commitment fees that borrowers have to pay. **********Under the terms of the definitive agreement, the investor group will ''shortly'' make a tender offer of $43 a share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/02/busin.body_text: **********An environment of generally steady, low interest rates proved fertile for securities underwriters in the first quarter, and the volume of bonds and stock issued by corporations soared to a record. **********A total of $87.7 billion in corporate securities was issued from January through March, the largest sum ever in a three-month period and up 29 percent from $68 billion in the first quarter of 1986, according to IDD Information Services. **********Most of that gain came from an increase in the amount of corporate bonds sold. Volume of this nonconvertible debt rose 29.4 percent, to $67.7 billion, from $52.3 billion a year earlier, according to IDD. Rate Drop Is Impetus **********The impetus for bonds was the drop in interest rates from levels of the last several years. Many corporations used the proceeds of their bond offerings to repay higher-rate bonds issued several years ago. They were also enticed to issue long-term bonds at rates with which they were comfortable, analysts said. **********''There's nothing like low interest rates to bring out the issuers,'' said James A. Stern, co-head of the primary markets group at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., adding, ''There was also tremendous demand by investors who wanted the long-term securities.'' **********The unusually heavy flow of stock offerings was the result of the bull run in the stock market. A total of $11.5 billion in stock was issued during the quarter, IDD said, up 32.2 percent from $8.7 billion. **********Even with such big increases, competition intensified among underwriters. Salomon Brothers Inc. hung on to its position as the biggest underwriter, but just barely. According to IDD, Salomon underwrote $13.26 billion in securities, down 19.6 percent from $16.5 billion a year earlier. **********More important, the firm's share of the market fell to 15 percent in the first quarter from 24 percent the year before. Salomon's underwritings of both debt and stock slipped, according to IDD. A Last-Minute Rush **********The firm did report a strong increase in underwritings of mortgage-related securities, but still gave up market share. Those numbers were bolstered by a flurry of offerings of mortgage-related securities late Tuesday, the last day in the quarter, in an effort to maintain its lead over First Boston Inc. **********First Boston also released a late rush of mortgage-related securities, but it could not catch its rival. First Boston finished with $12.63 billion in underwritings overall, according to IDD. **********There were some big shifts in the rankings. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets jumped to third from fifth, and Bear, Stearns & Company leaped from 16th to ninth. Drexel Falls Two Places **********Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. slipped to sixth place from fourth but maintained its dominant position in the market for higher-yield, lower-quality ''junk bonds,'' in spite of being the subject of a Government investigation. Drexel's junk bond underwritings jumped 59.5 percent, to $3.35 billion, from $2.1 billion during the first quarter of 1986, IDD said, giving it a 50 percent share of that market. **********The market for municipal securities also jumped. The total new offerings of municipal securities rose 119.5 percent, to $29.2 billion, from $13.3 billion, according to IDD. Sixty-three percent of these municipal bonds were used in refinancings to replace older, higher-rate bonds, IDD said. **********Most of that was accounted for by tax-exempt bonds. There was also a fourfold rise in underwritings of taxable municipal bonds, to $907 million, IDD said. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/28/busin.body_text: **********E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical company, said today that results in the energy sector again hurt its profits, causing first-quarter earnings to fall 3.2 percent even though chemical and specialty businesses were up sharply. **********Du Pont earned $391 million, or $1.62 a share, on revenue of $7.20 billion, compared with profits of $404 million, or $1.67 a share, on revenue of $7.29 billion in the 1986 quarter. **********Du Pont's chairman, Richard Heckert, said in a statement, ''Results for our chemical and specialty products businesses were up sharply; however, total company earnings were down slightly from last year's strong first quarter because of weakness in the petroleum sector.'' **********Du Pont said after-tax operating income from the petroleum segments dropped 64 percent from a year ago, to $55 million in the latest quarter. Coal earnings were down 27 percent. First-quarter results benefited, however, from improved worldwide demand and lower energy and feedstock prices, earlier restructurings and efforts to improve productivity, Mr. Heckert said. **********After-tax operating income for the company's chemical and specialty products businesses was $393 million, 55 percent ahead of the quarter last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.main_headline: Gunman Gets Life Sentence In Quebec Legislature Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.print_headline: Gunman Gets Life Sentence In Quebec Legislature Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/world.body_text: **********A former army corporal who sprayed machine-gun fire into the Quebec legislature in 1984, killing three people and wounding 13, was sentenced today to life imprisonment after pleading guilty to reduced charges of second degree murder. **********The former corporal, Denis Lortie, 27 years old, will be eligible for parole in 10 years. **********He showed no emotion when Justice Gaston Desjardins of the Quebec Superior Court passed the sentence and told him, ''You committed a serious crime but the circumstances were not loathsome.'' **********Three legislative employees were slain in the attack, which was motivated by Mr. Lortie's hatred of the Parti Quebecois Government then in power, according to evidence at his trial. **********Mr. Lortie was convicted originally of first-degree murder and sentenced to life in prison with no parole for 25 years, but the Quebec Court of Appeal ordered a new trial on the grounds that the judge improperly instructed the jury. **********In the interim, Lortie changed his plea to guilty and the charges were reduced.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/27/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Uneasiness on Fed and Dollar
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/27/busin.body_text: **********Uneasiness about the future of the dollar and the possibility of a credit-tightening move by the Federal Reserve caused Treasury notes and bond prices to decline modestly yesterday. **********At the regular monthly auction of two-year Treasury notes, the average yield was 7.86 percent, up from 7.66 percent at the previous auction in late July. Securities dealers said the higher yield was needed to compensate investors for the risk that short-term interest rates would rise if the Fed sent clear signals that it had tightened monetary policy a notch. **********Although there is no clear-cut evidence that the Fed has tightened policy, traders have worried that the Fed might act to defend the dollar. They remember that in April and May, the Fed raised short-term rates to prevent a buildup of inflationary pressures that would result from too steep a drop in the dollar. **********In yesterday's trading, a slight improvement in the dollar and the Fed's move to supply reserves temporarily helped alleviate fears of a tighter policy. But the fears were not eliminated, as overnight rates for bank loans remained above 7 percent most of the day. 5-Year Auction Today Elsewhere in the government securities market, the five-year Treasury notes to be auctioned today were offered by securities dealers with a yield of 8.35 percent, up from 8.30 percent. In the long-term market, the 8 7/8 percent bonds due in 2017 were offered at 98 29/32, down 17/32, to yield 8.98 percent. **********Although the steep drop in bond prices since late March has dismayed many portfolio managers, institutions such as pension funds and insurance companies continue to accumulate funds that must be invested. Many, such as the California State Teachers Retirement System, are shifting their funds away from active managers whose records in the last five years suggest they cannot consistently predict the direction of interest rates and bond prices. **********Instead, these institutions are hiring index-fund managers who design bond portfolios that will match some index measuring the bond market. **********''There is still a widespread feeling that fixed-income securities are a reasonable asset class to be invested in,'' said Thomas E. Klaffky, a managing director at Salomon Brothers. But he added that some investors have been dissatisfied with indexes that merely duplicate the mix of maturities and types of securities that are outstanding. ''Investors are asking why they should buy the mix of securities that issuers want to sell,'' he said. Indexes matching the mix of outstanding debt securities are especially inappropriate, he added, for investors whose liabilities have a longer duration than the duration of a market index. The Latest Product **********For investors who like the low cost of an indexed portfolio and are convinced that over time it will offer a better return than one that tries to outguess the market, Salomon Brothers yesterday introduced a new wrinkle called the Targeted Index Matrix. **********In effect, the new product is a formalized version of what many investment managers have been doing informally - creating a special index that matches the needs of a particular investor. For example, the pension fund of a new high-technology company with no retired workers ought to emphasise longer-term securities becaue its liabilities are much more distant than those of a steel company with many retired workers. **********The matrix offered by Salomon allows each investor to select a mixture of corporate, mortage and Treasury securities that matches the desired duration of the portfolio (which will vary depending on the duration of the liabilities of the investor). **********After the investor selects how much is to be held in a core portfolio of corporate and mortage securities, which currently have a duration of about five years, a portfolio of Treasury issues is designed to create the desired duration for the entire portfolio. Because the Treasury market is the largest and most liquid part of the credit markets and offers securities with durations ranging from one day to 30 years, it is the sector of the market best suited for the frequent transactions needed to keep the portfolio in balance. **********Although Salomon Brothers is not an investment-management firm, it hopes that institutions using its indexes will end up doing their trading through the firm. Because index-fund managers must pay close attention to the changing composition of an index and often adjust the mix of their holdings,''there is opportunity for a lot of dialogue that can mean business'' for the bond-trading and underwriting activities that are Salomon's bread and butter, one executive at the firm said. **********Following are results of yesterday's auction of two-year Treasury notes: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures)  Average Price 99.800  Average Yield 7.86%  Low Price 99.800  High Yield 7.86  High Price 99.873  Low Yield 7.82%  Accepted at low price 79%  Total applied for  $31,414,400  Accepted  $9,807,105  N.Y. applied for  $27,005,905  N.Y. accepted  $7,869,015  Noncompetitive  $1,251,000  Interest set at 7 3/4%  The two-year notes mature Aug. 31, 1989.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/19/busin.body_text: **********What seemed destined to be a historic day on Wall Street turned into only a slightly memorable one as the Dow Jones industrial average rose above 2,300 for the first time but did not stay there. **********When the session was over, the Dow was at its highest closing level ever, but the gain was only 2.13 points, to 2,286.93. The blue-chip index peaked early yesterday around 2,302 before profit taking sent it in reverse. **********''It's lost its compass,'' said Harvey Deutsch, a market analyst with Purcell, Graham & Company, trying to explain the market's erratic behavior. Witching Hour Looms **********Most of the unpredictability, market experts said, is the result of tomorrow's ''triple witching hour,'' when stock index futures, index options and regular stock options all expire and when the stock market has been subject to dramatic swings and extremely heavy trading. **********Some experts still think tomorrow's session could bring wild swings in prices. But most are coming to the opinion that this triple witching hour could turn out to be dull. **********''I think you are getting a little bit of premature unwinding'' of option and futures contracts, Mr. Deutsch said. ''Friday could be a bit of a non-event.'' **********Yesterday was not very eventful either, in spite of the fact that various important indexes inched their ways to new highs. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.23, to 166.64; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.31, to 292.78; the American Stock Exchange index was up 1.80, to 337.04, and in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq index climbed 0.37, to 435.16. All of the closing levels were records. **********The average share gained 16 cents a share on the Big Board, where advancing issues edged out losers by a slim 810 to 767. Trading volume, with the help of a pickup in interest from European investors, jumped substantially, to 198.1 million shares from Tuesday's 177.3 million. European Influence **********''Europeans got excited in the morning, and they were buying stock,'' said John Havens, head of the trading desk at Morgan Stanley & Company, who said stock index futures prices at one point were high enough to pull Wall Street along. **********Soon afterward, however, programs to buy large amounts of stock turned into programs to sell. ''The buyers,'' Mr. Havens said, ''just pulled away.'' **********Oil stocks, however, continued to interest investors who believe that the recent rise in crude prices might benefit the industry. Phillips Petroleum, for instance, led the consolidated active list, gaining 5/8, to 15 3/8, on volume of 4.4 million shares. **********USX, which is deeply involved in the oil business, rose 1 1/4, to 27 7/8, and was the second-most-active issue. Its volume was 4.1 million shares. Other energy-related issues on the active list were Occidental Petroleum, up 1 1/8, to 33 1/4, and Schlumberger, up 5/8, to 40. Management of Schlumberger's Fairchild Semiconductor unit plans to acquire that business. Gencorp Gains 18 **********The biggest gain of the day was turned in by Gencorp, which rose 18, to 106, in busy trading. A group led by AFG Industries and two Texas investors made a $100-a-share tender offer for Gencorp stock. Speculators are obviously expecting higher offers and bid the stock past the offer price. **********American Express, an active issue, rose 1, to 78 5/8. The stock was moved in part by speculation that the company would soon sell a stake in its brokerage unit to a Japanese insurance company. American Express declined comment. **********Bristol-Myers gained 4 5/8, to 107. The company said it would seek approval from the Food and Drug Administration to test an AIDS vaccine in humans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/08/world.body_text: **********France began a roundup of several dozen members of a leftist Iranian opposition group today in what appeared to be part of an agreement to improve relations with Iran. **********The Interior Ministry announced that dozens of members of the Iranian group, the People's Mujahedeen, would be expelled from France for ''taking part through this organization in militant actions that seriously disrupt public order.'' **********The Government has come under severe criticism in the United States, Britain and much of the Arab world over the accord with Iran that emerged after the release of two French hostages by pro-Iranian forces in Lebanon last month. The accord included, among other things, partial repayment by France of a large debt to Iran and the eventual restoration of diplomatic relations between the two countries, which have been severed since July. Ransom Is Denied **********At the European summit meeting in Copenhagen Friday and Saturday, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac assured Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher that no ransom was paid for the release, and the British leader said she accepted the assertion as true. **********In an interview here today, a senior French diplomat denied that the deal included a pledge to withdraw the French fleet patrolling the Persian Gulf to guard against Iranian mining and attacks on neutral shipping. **********''We have not polluted French foreign policy,'' the diplomat said, pointedly adding that France, unlike the United States, had not agreed to supply Iran with weapons. **********The diplomat said that contrary to recent press reports, a payment of $330 million to Iran had not been made, but would be soon. As for the expulsion of the Iranian dissidents, the source went on to say that this was ''a small price to pay, especially that the only thing they are good at is propaganda, not real opposition.'' **********The group's leader, Massoud Rajavi, was himself induced to leave France in June 1986, abandoning his headquarters at the village of Auvers-sur-Oise, a distant suburb of Paris, as part of an earlier deal to release hostages. A short while later, two French hostages were released from Beirut by pro-Iranian groups holding them. Altogether, 7 French hostages have been released from Lebanon since Mr. Chirac came to power in the spring of 1986. **********Mr. Rajavi lives in Iraq now, but many members of his group were allowed to maintain operations here, essentially limited to demonstrations and propaganda against Iran. **********Iranian opposition figures said the roundup began quietly 4 days ago, but came into full force at dawn today when plainclothesmen raided houses where Mujahedeen members live in Auvers-sur-Oise. Paris homes of Mujahedeen members were also raided, the dissident figures said. At Least 20 Are Held **********Habib Naweb, a spokesman for the group, said that at last count at least 20 members had been arrested. He said they were held in detention centers at police stations and the police headquarters here. ''It is another phase of the normalization of relations between Khomeini and France,'' he said in an interview. ''This isn't of any benefit to France. Khomeini will only ask for more. The French are paying a heavy ransom to the Iranian regime.'' **********According to the New York office of the group, the Mujahedeen members who were arrested in France began a hunger strike to protest the action. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/11/busin.body_text: **********A leveraged-buyout group led by Morgan Stanley Group raised its bid for Burlington Industries yesterday by $2 a share, to $78. **********The new bid by the group, which has been trying to take the textile giant private since May 22, exceeds a hostile $77-a-share offer made jointly by the investor Asher B. Edelman and Dominion Textile Inc., which is Canada's largest textile concern. The latest sweetener adds roughly $64 million to the Morgan group's $2.5 billion deal. **********Earlier in the day, Burlington's stock closed at $74.875, down 37.5 cents. Morgan Stanley's lenders said they would not provide financing for the deal if Burlington posted a $500 million bond in keeping with a ruling, issued last Friday, that grew out of a suit brought by Burlington in Federal District Court in Greensboro, N.C. $500 Million Bond a Prerequisite The bond is a prerequisite for a preliminary injunction that would bar the Edelman-Dominion team from buying shares under its offer. **********Burlington has charged the investors with misappropriating inside information by relying on the help of a former Burlington executive, James J. Ammeen, in preparing a raid on the company. The bond would compensate the investors in the event that the court later determines that the charges have wrongly kept the Edelman-Dominion group from buying the company. **********Burlington has returned to Federal court to challenge the size of the bond, and the rival bidders have appealed the decision to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in Richmond. Former Employee Speaks Out **********In an interview yesterday, Mr. Ammeen, who had left Burlington in November 1985, responded to questions raised about his work with the Edelman-Dominion group in the early stages of the takeover fight. Mr. Ammeen said he had not violated confidentiality agreements he signed with the company.  [ Page D4. ]  Meanwhile, the litigation has clouded both bids. Shareholders are concerned that Mr. Edelman might be hamstrung by the injunction at the same time that Morgan Stanley is having trouble soothing its lenders' fears about a huge potential liability if the lawsuit is dismissed. **********By raising its offer, Morgan Stanley still leaves open the question of why its lenders would welcome a $78-a-share bid when they previously had concerns about a $76-a-share offer. **********A Morgan Stanley spokesman said the company was confident it could get the bond reduced in court. But the announcement suggested at least to some outsiders that Burlington had chosen not to post the bond -rather than upset Morgan Stanley's financing. Edelman Group in Study **********''At first glance, it would appear that they're not posting the bond,'' said Corey Horowitz, a partner of Mr. Edelman, ''and if they don't post the bond, that means we're not enjoined, and that means we could raise our bid.'' **********The takeover battle began on May 6, when the Edelman-Dominion group offered to buy the remaining Burlington shares for $67 a share. Since then, the group has raised its offer three times, first to $72 and then to $77. In a defensive move before the Morgan Stanley proposal, Burlington said on May 11 that it would buy back up to eight million of its common shares at $80 a share. **********Representatives of Mr. Edelman and Dominion, who own 3.4 million shares altogether, or about 12.3 percent, have met in the past with their counterparts at Morgan Stanley to discuss a possible settlement of the battle. The question now is whether the outside bidders will settle for the $6.8 million in additional profit that the newest bid would give them, or press their fight. **********One person close to Burlington said he expected the Edelman-Dominion team to accept the latest proposal. ''Edelman was talking about expenses that were a much bigger number, but that was before he had all the trouble he has now,'' he said, referring to the preliminary injunction.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/25/busin.main_headline: PRICES INCREASED 0.4% IN MARCH FOR CONSUMERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/25/busin.print_headline: PRICES INCREASED 0.4% IN MARCH FOR CONSUMERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/25/busin.body_text: **********The Consumer Price Index, the most widely followed indicator of inflation, climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Labor Department reported today. On an annual basis, the increases so far this year translate into an inflation rate of 6.2 percent. **********Although the overall rise in the index was the same as in February, several economists pointed to other figures that suggest, they said, that price increases are a source of concern. **********''I'm getting a little uncomfortable,'' commented Robert G. Dederick, a former Commerce Department official who is now executive vice president of the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. ''This is going to have to be closely watched.'' **********Prices in the New York and northeastern New Jersey area rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March.  [ Page 39. ]  Economists said that even when food and energy, two of the most volatile components, were excluded, the index advanced in the first quarter at an annual rate of 5.2 percent, up from 3.7 percent in the quarters ended last Sept. 30 and Dec. 31. **********The Reagan Administration said that inflation remained well under control and that the increases this year have resulted mainly from a rise in oil prices, which had fallen to unsustainably low levels. **********Asked about today's report, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d declared, ''In our view, that reflects primarily what we have been saying would be the case for quite some time, and that is an increase in oil prices.'' **********The price of gasoline and heating oil rose in March, though at a slower pace than in February. But there were also substantial price increases for a broad array of goods and services. **********The index for apparel and such related services as dry cleaning, for example, leaped 1.7 percent last month, the biggest jump since August 1974. **********The Labor Department said the introduction of new, higher-priced spring and summer merchandise, particularly women's clothing, was mainly responsible. Private analysts noted that the increase for clothing also reflected the dollar's weakness against foreign currencies. **********Clothing is imported in large quantities, and the low value of the dollar allows domestic producers to raise prices, too. The price of infants' and toddlers' apparel soared 5 percent last month while women's and girls' clothes climbed 2.4 percent. Footwear was up 1.7 percent. 'Disturbing' Figures **********Today's report prompted an economist at one New York bank to say he would ''have to rethink'' his prediction that consumer inflation would climb no higher than 3 1/2 to 4 percent this year. A 1.1 percent rate was recorded in 1986, with the aid of collapsing oil and gas prices. **********This analyst, who asked not to be identified, said he was still evaluating the report, but he called the figures ''disturbing.'' **********The rising cost of imports has clearly become an important factor in assessing inflation trends. Thursday's report on the gross national product disclosed that the price of imports, which includes a substantial amount of oil, climbed at a 13.5 percent rate in the first quarter. **********''I'd keep an eye on that area,'' Daniel Friel, economist at the North Carolina National Bank, said. Transportation Costs Up **********Prices in the important transportation sector rose six-tenths of 1 percent last month. The price of gasoline was up 2.3 percent; used cars rose 2.1 percent, and automobile insurance rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, bringing its 12-month increase to 9.5 percent. The rise in used-car prices was the third in a row, after 11 monthly declines. Prices of new cars were essentially unchanged after falling 1 percent in February, the department said. **********The cost of housing rose four-tenths of 1 percent, the same as the month before, as the prices of heating oil and electricity rose while natural gas declined. Charges for cable television, which jumped 1.2 percent last month, are now 4.5 percent higher than in December. Only Decline Is for Food **********Food and beverages made up the only one of the index's seven main components to show a price decline, minimal though it was. The cost of food in grocery stores fell four-tenths of 1 percent after rising by that amount in February. Declines for fruits and vegetables, dairy products and other items more than offset small rises for cereal and bakery products and meats, poultry, fish and eggs. Restaurant meals rose at a rate of four-tenths of 1 percent. **********The indexes for medical care, entertainment and other goods and services all rose by either four-tenths or five-tenths of 1 percent, the Labor Department said. **********The C.P.I.-U, which covers all urban consumers, now stands at 335.9, which means that a basket of goods and services that cost $10 in 1967 now costs $33.59. The ''old'' index, using 1972-73 expenditure patterns instead of the new 1982-1984 patterns that were introduced in February, also rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month. **********The C.P.I.-W, which covers urban wage earners and clerical workers, rose five-tenths of 1 percent, the Government said. **********Today's C.P.I.-U report also showed no acceleration in the price of services, which rose by four-tenths of 1 percent for the third consecutive month. Commodities rose by five-tenths of 1 percent for the second month. **********Upward pressure on prices was most evident in the Northeast and North Central states. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/21/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Jones industrial average set records yesterday - but just barely. After an up-and-down day, the popular yardstick of 30 blue-chip stocks finished with a small gain for a 13th consecutive advance, its longest string ever. **********The 1.97-point rise in the Dow, to a record 2,104.47, masked a day of price swings and bouts of heavy profit taking that left most other indicators signaling that the extraordinary market advance might be running out of steam. **********One signal was the lack of clear direction. The market's direction turned several times during the day and the Dow was down by as much as 10 points early in the afternoon. Advances led declines only slightly on the New York Stock Exchange, with 849 issues up and 811 down. Also, the Dow transportation average, which often serves to confirm the trend in the industrial average, fell 4.72 points, to 877.79. Turnover soared to 224.8 million shares, from 162.8 million shares Monday, when the Dow jumped 25.87 points. **********The market ''sort of has lost some of that sharpness, that sense of relentlessness,'' said Monte Gordon, director of research for the Dreyfus Corporation. ''It seems to be struggling a little bit to keep its momentum.'' Other money managers agreed, saying they expected to see the market pull back for one of its classic corrections after a fast march upward.  [ Marketplace, Page D8. ]  Also holding back the Dow average yesterday was the downturn of one of its key components, International Business Machines, which fell 2 1/2, to 122 3/4. The company announced fourth-quarter earnings early in the session that were considered slightly worse than expected. **********The failure of the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks to advance to a new high ''indicated to us that even the issues that have been carrying the market are now tired,'' said John M. Blin, who heads a company bearing his name that designs trading programs. The S.&P. 500 declined 0.30 point, to 269.04. **********But the ''flashing red light'' to Mr. Blin was the uncommonly sharp drop in the prices of stock index futures after the Big Board closed. Stock index futures trading ends 15 minutes after the exchanges close at 4 P.M. New York time.  ''In that 15 minutes, many big institutions were heavy sellers of index futures,'' Mr. Blin noted. ''It could mean that the institutions believed the market will break Wednesday and were eager to hedge their portfolios with index futures. If the market does break, they hope to balance their portfolio losses with the gains from the shorting of futures.'' Selling short in the futures market involves a promise to deliver a certain number of contracts at a specific price at a future date. If the contracts are priced lower at the time of delivery, the seller makes a profit. **********But if the market opens sharply higher, Mr. Blin expects that the hedgers will quickly buy out of their index futures contracts and move more cash into actual shares, at least for another day. **********Donald. M. Selkin, Prudential-Bache Securities' head of stock index futures research, agreed and pointed out that the two key index futures, the S.&P. 500 and the Major Market Index, were so heavily sold short after the stock exchanges closed that their normal premiums over their underlying indexes had shrunk to abnormal levels. Those levels typically attract speculators who sell stocks and buy futures to lock in a profit. ''Wednesday could witness an abrupt end to the current market advance,'' Mr. Selkin said.  Newton D. Zinder, senior vice president and analyst at E.F. Hutton & Company, was also cautious about yesterday's market because it was clearly influenced by investors taking profits. ''If the market moves any higher, these bouts of profit taking will become more frequent and cause more volatility,'' he said. **********While the debate over whether the market was poised for a correction or further advance preoccupied analysts, prices of many shares that move the averages continued to respond to earnings and other fundamentals. **********Salomon, for instance, the giant investment banking house, dropped 5 1/8, to 39 1/4, on prospects for poor fourth-quarter earnings, and led the Big Board's most-active list on a turnover of 7.8 million shares. **********Auto stocks were in demand, with G.M. up 1 1/8, at 71 1/8; Ford 1, to 71 1/4, and Chrysler 1/8, at 45 3/4. Other active issues included Navistar, up 3/8, to 6 3/8, and General Electric, up 1 3/4, to 96 5/8. **********The American Stock Exchange's market-value index rose 0.51 point, to a new high of 294.48. But the Amex had 330 declining stocks and 250 gainers on a volume of 18.7 million shares, up from 14 million on Monday. Home Shopping Network, trading ex dividend, soared a further 5 3/4, to 38 1/4, on the Amex. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index dipped 0.53 point, to 392.06. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/world.main_headline: Libyans Said to Bomb Planes Seized by Chad
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/world.print_headline: Libyans Said to Bomb Planes Seized by Chad
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/world.body_text: **********Daily bombing raids by Libyan jets have destroyed or damaged half of the Soviet-made aircraft seized intact by Chadian troops when they captured the Libyan base of Wadi Dum two weeks ago, a French military officer said today. **********''The Russians must have put a lot of pressure on the the Libyans to wipe out all this equipment before we got hold of it,'' the officer said. **********Some of the equipment abandoned by the Libyans at the base was new and highly advanced and had never been seen in the West, the officer said. **********Aircraft seized intact by the Chadians at Wadi Dum included three Mi-24 armored attack helicopters, nine L-39 ground support planes, two Sukhoi fighter-bombers and an An-26 transport plane, as well as three Italian-made Marchetti light planes. **********In addition to airplanes and helicopters, the Libyans abandoned at least three batteries of the latest model of SAM-6 missiles, which have never been inspected in the West. **********The continued bombing by Libyan planes is believed to have provoked a warning issued today in Paris by Defense Minister Andre Giraud. He said France, which has 2,500 men and a squadron of Jaguar fighter-bombers in Chad, might be forced to intervene in northern Chad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/17/world.body_text: **********Boris N. Yeltsin, the former ally of Mikhail S. Gorbachev who was dismissed last week as head of the Moscow Communist Party organization, has been hospitalized, the editor of the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia was quoted as saying today. **********The Austria Press Agency reported from Innsbruck that the editor, Ivan D. Laptiev, told reporters that Mr. Yeltsin's health had suffered during the recent political upheavals in Moscow. However, Mr. Laptiev was quoted as saying Mr. Yeltsin had not suffered a heart attack. **********Mr. Laptiev said Mr. Yeltsin, 56 years old, was resting at an unidentified hospital, the Austria Press Agency reported. **********He went from the hospital to last week's Moscow Communist Party meeting that decided on his dismissal and then returned to hospital, Mr. Laptiev was quoted as saying. **********The Austria Press Agency reporter who attended the news conference told The Associated Press by telephone that despite repeated questions Mr. Laptiev declined to give further details about Mr. Yeltsin's health.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/01/busin.main_headline: TRADE BILL IS PASSED BY HOUSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/01/busin.print_headline: TRADE BILL IS PASSED BY HOUSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/01/busin.body_text: **********Despite the opposition of the Reagan Administration, the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a sweeping trade bill that demands America's trading partners open their markets to American products and requires retaliation if they refuse. **********The bill was approved with 290 votes in favor, exactly the total needed to override a Presidential veto, and 137 opposed. The vote on the bill, whose retaliatory provisions would fall heavily on Japan, came as Japan's Prime Minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone, met with President Reagan and Senate leaders. **********The strong vote reflects the political pressure to act on trade, not support for some of the bill's main provisions, over which members are split. **********''Regardless of the substance, everyone knows where the politics are,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn. ''The political pressure is all in one direction on this.'' **********Nonetheless, some members said that if the proposal were not moderated, they would not vote to override a Presidential veto. **********The legislation goes to the Senate, where the Finance Committee is working on a less retaliatory version. The full Senate is expected to debate a bill in June. Many members supported the House bill while hoping that changes will be made in the Senate or in the eventual House-Senate conference. Gephardt Amendment Included **********The trade bill includes the amendment offered by Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, that requires retaliation according to a rigid formula against countries that have built up large trade surpluses and are found to have shut out American products. **********That amendment was narrowly approved Wednesday, by a vote of 218 to 214, and House Speaker Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas, acknowledged today that the close vote means the amendment will be modified in the Senate or in conference to ease its retaliatory effect. **********But there is much more to the trade bill. The overall legislation is a broad list of remedies, many of which are opposed by the Reagan Administration, that supporters say would bring a new tough stance to American trade policy even if the Gephardt amendment is weakened. **********''I think it sends a strong signal that the House is determined to respond to the demand of the American people for an assertive trade policy,'' Mr. Wright said.  The vote on the Gephardt amendment in the House reflects a division about both the substance of trade policy and the political strategy needed to approve a bill the President could eventually accept. The main disagreement is over how strong retaliation should be against unfair trade practices. **********Today's vote closely followed party lines, as only 43 Republicans voted for the bill and only 6 Democrats voted against it. But Republicans and Democrats in the House are more in agreement on trade than the vote shows. In an alternative they offered today, Republicans endorsed most provisions of the bill that was ultimately approved. **********The Reagan Administration is opposed to most of the bill's major provisions, including those endorsed by the Republican legislators. The opposition was outlined in a letter signed by the President's Cabinet secretaries Wednesday. **********This means it might not be as easy as the Administration thinks to use the split over retaliatory policy to win major changes in the bill, as the Senate acts and the two versions go to a conference where a compromise will be worked out. Congress, therefore, could approve a trade bill that the Administration still opposes, setting up a major confrontation this summer. **********''From the Administration's point of view, the split is not meaningful,'' Mr. Gephardt said of the votes on his amendment and the overall bill. ''It isn't much of a division that the Administration can exploit.'' The Republican Alternative **********Before final approval, the House defeated the Republican alternative on a party-line vote of 268 to 156. The provisions that it dropped included the Gephardt amendment, registration of foreign investments, mandatory exchange rate negotiations and a ''Buy America'' ban on Government purchase of goods from countries that discriminate against American suppliers. **********But the Republicans did keep a provision, which the Administration opposes, that requires some mandatory retaliation against the unfair trade practices of countries with large trade surpluses. The retaliation, in tariffs or quotas, would equal the dollar amount of American trade lost because of closed markets. **********The Republicans did drop the Gephardt portion, which is a second step of retaliation against nations with ''excessive'' surpluses. It requires reduction of these trade surpluses if the unfair trade practices persist. **********In votes on other amendments today, the House, by 232 to 183, approved revoking most-favored-nation status for Rumania, meaning that imports from that nation would no longer be subject to the lowest tariffs possible. While current law prohibits most-favored-nation status for countries that do not allow their citizens to emigrate, Rumania has received annual Presidential waivers. **********Supporters of the amendment argued that the vote would send a message to Rumania to pay attention to human rights. Opponents said it would make it more difficult for Americans to help people in Rumania. **********An effort to delete the provision in the bill requiring disclosure of foreign investment in the United States was defeated, 230 to 190. Opponents of the disclosure argued it would discourage foreign investment. **********An amendment to strike the ''Buy America'' provision lost on a standing vote of 17 to 8.  Major Provisions of Trade Bill  Following are the main provisions of the omnibus trade bill approved in the House of Representatives yesterday:  RETALIATION  Requires mandatory retaliation against unfair trade practices on a case-by-case basis and gives the Administration discretionary power.  Separately, requires retaliation against countries whose large trade surpluses with the United States are based on unfair trade practices. If negotiations to remove the practices fail, the Government first imposes tariffs or quotas equal to the value of U.S. trade lost. If the unfair practices persist, the Gephardt amendment requires the Administration to take action, through import bans or cancellation of trade agreements, to reduce the country's trade surplus by 10 percent a year.  IMPORT AND EXPORT AID  Establishes an Industrial Competitiveness Council to promote U.S. competitiveness and productivity.  Expands the existing Trade Adjustment Assistance program for retraining workers displaced by foreign competition.  MARKETS  Pressures Japanto open its financial markets to U.S. firms. If not, Japanese firms in U.S. lose their primary dealership, which allows them to buy and sell Government bonds.  Bans Government purchases from countries that discriminate against American products.  Tightens laws to protect against foreign infringement of U.S. trademarks, patents and copyrights.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/25/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor:  Plastic is prominent in litter not only because it is non-biodegradable (''Plastic Falls to Pieces,'' Prospects Jan. 11) but because of its lightness. The wind carries plastic everywhere while metal and glass, which are also non-biodegradable, stay put. Similarly, metal and glass sink to the bottom of streams while plastic floats. Visible or not, all are there to clutter and clog. **********That's because too few consumers care and because adequate solid waste management does not yet exist. These problems won't be avoided by littering the environment with materials that spontaneously degrade. **********As for shopping bags that shatter when exposed to ultraviolet light, would housewives only go to the supermarket on cloudy days?  JEROME S. SCHAUL  Caldwell, N.J., Jan. 12

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/19/busin.main_headline: Business and the Law; Speech Rights Of Companies
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/19/busin.print_headline: Business and the Law; Speech Rights Of Companies
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/19/busin.body_text: **********VIEW the world of corporate law from the perspective of the First Amendment and it could look dramatically different, a former senior lawyer with the American Civil Liberties Union told an audience of Federal judges and lawyers here last Friday. **********At the annual conference of the Second Judicial Circuit, Burt Neuborne, who until last year had been the national legal director of the A.C.L.U., said that many laws regulating the marketplace probably could be successfully challenged on the ground that they violated the First Amendment. **********''In the securities area, for instance, it's about time that the system is regulated in an economically efficient way,'' said Mr. Neuborne, ''and the First Amendment would be a good prism through which to look at these issues.'' **********Mr. Neuborne, a professor at the New York University School of Law, explained that there was no compelling reason, for example, why statutes had certain specifications for the ''tombstone'' advertisements that are placed in newspapers to announce the sale of stocks and bonds. Such requirements ''are almost certainly unconstitutional,'' he said, adding that the time has come to challenge the constitutionality of aspects of decades' worth of other corporate regulations. **********He also said that, unlike political speech, the First Amendment did not and should not protect false or misleading statements by businesses. **********One Federal judge in New York, who not too long ago ruled in a landmark case involving the constitutionality of a Federal securities law, took Mr. Neuborne's position a step further. ''I don't see any reason why a corporate issuer of securities has to be silent during the period between a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the time in which the sale is approved,'' said the judge in an interview, speaking on condition that he not be identified. Federal securities laws limit what an issuer of a stock or bond may say between the date the offering is filed with the S.E.C. and the date it becomes effective. **********''I think that amounts to an improper prior restraint,'' the judge said. ''That's not to say that officers shouldn't be punished for committing fraud or being deceptive or something like that. But there is a strong tradition in the law that it be used to punish someone after they've acted wrongly, not to chill them beforehand.'' **********But Kenneth J. Bialkin, a corporate lawyer at Willkie Farr & Gallagher, disagreed. He said the limitations before a stock offering were not really restrictions on speech, but an effort to prevent the sale of a security before a registration statement with the S.E.C. becomes effective. **********In a direct response to Mr. Neuborne, Prof. Frederick Schauer of the University of Michigan School of Law said that those who advocated the use of the First Amendment in order to deregulate the marketplace might be seriously undermining free expression in other areas. **********''Burt wants less paternalism,'' said Mr. Schauer, ''and the economic analysts want more of a free market. Those views ought to be argued about in the political arena and perhaps under other constitutional provisions.
