I do not see the First Amendment as the appropriate lever for general views about Government regulation. If we do use it as that lever, we may discover that it snaps.'' **********The Supreme Court only began shaping the constitutional guidelines on the speech rights of companies about a decade ago, during the Burger Court. The area has become known as commercial speech, and a majority of the cases have concerned the manner in which businesses can advertise. **********The Court has struck down laws restricting advertisements for drugstores, lawyers and abortion clinics. It has also upheld restrictions on advertisements by casinos in Puerto Rico and a law that required The Pittsburgh Press to print certain classified advertisements. **********Congress is considering measures that would restrict the speech of some companies. House and Senate committees have held hearings on proposals to either ban or tax cigarette advertisements. **********At the judicial conference, which ended yesterday morning, Floyd Abrams, the noted First Amendment lawyer at Cahill Gordon & Reindel, said that it was only a matter of time before free speech arguments would be used by top corporate officials involved in takeover battles. **********''Elections of company leaders, like political elections, involve some of the most important choices that are made in society,'' said Mr. Abrams. ''I think it's not too far off to foresee a case in which there is a corporate takeover and one side will claim that the other is providing less than full information, and the other side will step up to the plate and say that the S.E.C. has no authority to demand all this information.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/16/busin.main_headline: Cadillac's Allante Is Struggling to Find Its Niche
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/16/busin.print_headline: Cadillac's Allante Is Struggling to Find Its Niche
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/16/busin.body_text: **********The two-seater, $55,000 Allante model was billed as the ''new spirit of Cadillac'' when it was introduced last March. But judging from sales thus far, the spirit may still be willing, but consumer interest is weak. **********Cadillac officials concede that they are disappointed by the sales figures, but insist that the Allante is accomplishing its primary goal: re-establishing the Cadillac brand as the equal of European models like Mercedes-Benz, BMW and Jaguar. **********The success or failure of the Allante may have important implications for Cadillac and its parent, the General Motors Corporation - both of which have been suffering from lackluster sales and a declining market share. First Move In a Larger Plan **********The introduction of the Allante marked the first move in a larger plan to push all Cadillac models up into the highly profitable, ''ultra luxury'' segment. Sticker prices range from about $40,000 to $75,000 in this segment, which is now dominated by the Europeans and is soon to be invaded by the Japanese. **********Unlike most Cadillacs, which have been known for their plush interiors, soft rides and gas-guzzling engines, the Allante was intended to be a taut, European-style roadster. Indeed, Cadillac bypassed its own designers and signed up Pininfarina, the Italian company best known for its Ferrari designs, to do the exterior styling and actually build the bodies for the new car. **********Cadillac officials confidently predicted they would sell 6,000 Allantes a year, or about 500 a month. Early sales did not reach this target, but were respectable, ranging from about 250 to 280 a month. But in September sales plunged to 107 cars and rebounded only slightly in October and early November, raising questions outside G.M. about the model's long-range prospects, particularly since the stock market's collapse has thrown the outlook for all high-priced cars into question. Customers Balk at Price **********Dealers generally praise the car, but say customers are having trouble accepting the Allante's stiff price. ''It is going to take awhile for American buyers to get used to paying over $50,000 for a domestic car,'' said David A. Banks, a Cadillac dealer in Concord, N.H. **********Rob Mancuso, a Cadillac dealer in the Chicago area, agrees. ''There does appear to be price resistance to a Cadillac in this range,'' he said. ''If it said Maserati on the side of the car, there would be no problem.'' **********General Motors once defined automotive luxury in this country, with its big, chrome-bedecked Cadillacs, Buicks and Oldsmobiles. But younger, affluent buyers have shown a preference for cars with nimble handling, like Mercedes and BMW. In recent years these brands, despite their costs, have stolen sales from G.M.'s more expensive models and contributed to the company's lackluster earnings, according to analysts. **********''The main objective of Allante is, and always has been, what it can do for Cadillac as a whole, not mass production,'' said John O. Grettenberger, the general manager of the division. **********With just two seats, a 130-mile-an-hour top speed and removable soft and hard tops, the Allante is clearly patterned after the Mercedes-Benz 560SL roadster, which sells for $61,000. ''It is accomplishing the image effects we hoped for,'' Mr. Grettenberger said. ''Dealers are proud that we have a car of that caliber.'' **********But some outsiders disagree, saying the Allante does not make a bold enough statement to set a new tone for the division. ''The Allante did not proclaim anything new, interesting or different,'' observed Leon Mandel, a columnist with Autoweek magazine. ''But nothing else would have gotten approved. It had to adhere to G.M. orthodoxy.'' **********Despite the recent sales slump, Cadillac is taking a long view toward the Allante, Mr. Grettenberger insists. ''My No. 1 objective is to establish the car as a credible competitor in the ultra luxury segement. We are intending to establish it and grow and enhance our position in the marketplace through only the highest-level promotion and refinements to the car,'' he said. G.M., he added, would not try to increase sales by means of special promotions or incentives that might undercut its image. Incentive Leasing Campaign Set **********Nevertheless, Cadillac has quietly mounted an incentive leasing campaign to clear out the unsold 1987 models. The incentives include 6.5 percent financing on 48-month leases, compared with 10.6 percent on standard leases, and payments of $100 to sales managers and $100 to $1,000 for salesmen for each Allante moved out of the showroom. **********To reassure prospective buyers, Cadillac is considering adopting a program intended to guarantee the resale value of the car - just as the Ford Motor Company did when it introduced its German-made Merkur Scorpio model earlier this year. **********The Ford program ties the value of used Scorpios to Mercedes-Benz 190's of the same vintage. If the Scorpio sells for less, Ford has pledged to make up the difference. The Allante's value would be tied to the Mercedes Benz 560SL, if such a program is offered, Mr. Grettenberger said. **********The Allante has been a learning experience not only for the division but for the Cadillac dealers who are faced with the task of luring customers in and getting them to pay $50,000 for a domestic car. ''It's not something people just walk in and order,'' Mr. Grettenberger said. ''In many cases the sales are being consummated in their offices, restaurants and homes.'' Buyers Are Often Fussy **********Cadillac officials have also found that buyers in this price class are much more fussy about color than the average consumer. At introduction, the car came in white, silver, gold and maroon. White and silver sold well, gold moderately well and maroon hardly at all. Most of the leftover 1987 models being offered under the incentive are maroon. **********For 1988, Cadillac dropped the maroon and added red and black as colors. As Maryann N. Keller, an auto industry analyst observed, ''After all, people who spend $55,000 for a car want to be noticed.'' **********Most Allante buyers so far have been men who live in large cities and have an appetite for the new and unusual and the income to indulge their interests. ''We're taking exotic cars in trade, things like Merkurs and Jaguars,'' said Bill Symes, a dealer in Pasadena, Calif. He described the buyers as ''car nuts'' who feel compelled to drive the latest model. Because the car has two seats, ''it's not very practical as a family car,'' he noted. **********Cadillac officials say they intend to refine the Allante gradually in the European fashion to broaden its appeal. In addition, plans are being considered to expand the line. **********''Cadillac deserves to be in the ultra luxury segment,'' Mr. Grettenberger said. It remains to be seen, however, whether consumers agree with him.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/20/busin.body_text: **********The Exxon Corporation's petrochemicals business is enjoying good times. Profits are rising, demand is brisk and most of its plants are operating nearly flat out. **********In days gone by, Exxon would have almost automatically built a new plant or two so that impatient customers would not be tempted to take their orders elsewhere. **********No more. Instead of expansion, Exxon is squeezing additional production from existing facilities through small and inexpensive steps such as installing pipes with wider diameters, reducing maintenance downtime and teaching staff to operate high-tech equipment more efficiently. **********Investing billions of dollars in new capacity on the basis of forecasts of significant growth ''has proven to be a terribly painful experience'' for the chemical industry, said Kenneth N. Robertson, a vice president of Exxon Chemical, whose overcapacity forced it to sell one plant and close another in 1985. A Reluctance to Build **********If Exxon is more cautious about capital investment, so are many other manufacturers. In industries ranging from autos to electric utilities to appliances, there is a reluctance to build factories or replace the equipment used in production. **********That reluctance, if it persists - and there is strong evidence that it will -could hobble the economy for years. Capital spending has been a powerful engine of economic growth in the postwar years, and the stimulus it can provide is especially needed now. With so much concern that the other engine, consumer spending, is cooling off, capital spending or the lack of it could determine whether the economy continues to grow or slides into recession. **********Many economists and business executives are convinced that the years of robust capital investment are over for a while. ''Long term, the trend is slowly down, not up,'' said Irwin Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover Bank. Even Paul A. Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economics who considers himself an optimist on capital spending, does not look for a rapid expansion. ''I do not see a collapse,'' Professor Samuelson said, ''but I don't see a new era either. In fact, I'm quite surprised that we are doing as well as we are.'' **********Capital spending climbed a hefty 17 percent in 1984 and another 9 percent in 1985 as the nation worked its way out of a recession. That provided a mighty contribution to growth early in the current recovery. Modest Growth Is Forecast **********This spending surge, however, followed a two-year period of decline. And the recovery was short-lived: Last year, capital spending fell by 3.1 percent in inflation-adjusted dollars, and the Commerce Department, in a survey of capital spending plans released last week, forecast a rise of only 1.8 percent for this year. **********While spending is increasing in paper, textiles, and food, some big guns of capital investment - auto, steel, computer and utility companies, for example - are shrinking their outlays, and the oil industry has no plans to increase spending significantly. **********Most forecasts see capital spending increasing again in 1988. After next year, however, it is expected to subside. Neither the Commerce Department nor such private forecasting services as Wharton Econometrics and McGraw-Hill's Data Resources Inc. hold out hope that capital investment will grow at more than a 4 percent average annual rate before the mid-1990's. **********That would keep it just ahead of the expected annual increase in the gross national product - hardly the stimulant that spending has been in the past, when it climbed at two or three times the rate of economic expansion. A Range of Roadblocks **********But too many obstacles are piling up for history to repeat itself: *********** The chief obstacle is the emergence of the global marketplace. With efficient, low-cost producers in such countries as Taiwan, Korea, Brazil and Japan competing against them, American corporations are under intense pressure to lower their prices. For that reason, American executives are demanding that a given investment reduce their companies' manufacturing costs. They also insist that such projects generate higher financial returns. The upshot: Fewer capital-spending projects are winning approval. *********** Worldwide production overcapacity in many industries is taking its toll. Because of the overcapacity, American business has abandoned a traditional reason for capital investment: Having enough factories on hand to stay a step ahead of the seemingly insatiable market. ''The thinking that prompted us to buy three machines instead of one, to allow for growth, is gone'' said John Hackett, chief financial officer at The Cummins Engine Company. *********** The growing tendency to buy parts and components abroad, rather than make them in-house, is cutting into capital spending, particularly in the auto, steel and electronics industries. *********** The volatile dollar and the big trade deficit add to the risk of capital investment and inhibit it. A plant that might be cost-competitive in the world market with the dollar at its current low level could easily become a money-loser if and when the dollar rebounds. Optimists assume American companies will capture a larger share of both domestic and international markets because of the weak dollar and therefore will expand production. Others, such as Robert Ortner, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, are not sure that foreign competitors will be so easily dislodged. ''There has been some pickup in manufacturing activity from an improvement in our trade position,'' he said, ''but not enough yet to justify much capital investment.'' *********** After a decade of disappointing productivity gains from automating their factories and offices, companies are much more wary about investing in high-tech equipment. High-tech equipment accounted for more than 30 percent of capital expenditures last year, up from a 12 percent share in the early 1970's. But this spending is now being cut. *********** The expanding service sector does not require as much capital outlay as manufacturing because its principal tool, the computer, is not as costly as heavy machinery. *********** The new tax law is hurting capital spending - although it is still unclear what the ultimate impact will be. Executives in the steel and paper industies, for example, argue that their cash flow, upon which capital investment depends, will be hit hard by the elimination of such measures as the investment tax credit. **********One doomsayer, the Harvard economist Lawrence H. Summers, said the new law would raise the effective tax rate on most types of investment by 20 percentage points, which means an investment's yield would have to be higher to offset the tax bite. ''In the long run, this may well reduce the stock of plant and equipment by 10 to 15 percent,'' Professor Summers wrote in the current issue of the Harvard Business Review. **********Four examples follow of the sea change in capital spending: Cummins Engine A maker of diesel motors for heavy trucks, Cummins is disillusioned with high-tech investment. Partly as a result, its capital spending will decline this year to $150 million, from $280 million in 1986. **********''Earlier, we jumped too quickly into robotics on the assumption that the way we got productivity was to eliminate employees,'' Mr. Hackett said. ''Now we think in terms of work flow: how to reduce the handling of material so that we don't need so much hardware.'' **********Work-flow improvements, in fact, permitted Cummins to close a components plant in Columbus, Ind., its headquarters city, without reducing the company's overall production. **********The key was the elimination of a number of unnecessary procedures. ''We found, for example, that we were machining parts, moving them to a warehouse for storage, then bringing them back to complete the motor assembly,'' Mr. Hackett said. ''We've eliminated the warehousing.'' **********Cummins is also eliminating high-based stackers - expensive, computerized, vertical storage bins that automatically deliver parts for assembly. ''It was a good idea in the 70's but an inefficient use of capital today,'' Mr. Hackett said. ''Just-in-time delivery is better.'' Ford Motor **********A tougher emphasis on profitability to get through periods of slack demand is causing Ford to forgo capital-spending projects it once would have undertaken. **********For example, it has given up manufacturing paints for its vehicles after deciding that the return on the investment required to upgrade its paint factory in Mount Clemens, Mich., would be too low. **********So last August, the paint factory, with 500 employees, was sold to E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, which already has a paint-making business and could absorb the Mount Clements plant with less of an investment than Ford would have had to make, said William Selover, an executive in Ford's diversified products and components division. **********Like so many other big companies, Ford is also going abroad for parts. It entered into a joint venture in Mexico in 1982 to manufacture plastic dashboards, mostly for cars sold there. Now Ford draws on the Mexican plant for nearly all the plastic dashboards installed in vehicles made in the United States. Champion International **********A major goal of Champion, the nation's largest paper company, is to get more production - and thus more profit - from existing equipment. Although most of Champion's paper mills are running at more than 90 percent of capacity, the company is resisting plant construction. **********At its Bucksport, Me., white-paper mill, the strategy has meant a $100 million investment to improve the paper-coating process and to rebuild the existing machinery. The incremental new tonnage is the most profitable because it comes with little additional operating cost. **********In a similar vein, more than $500 million in new machinery or improvements to existing equipment are under way or under study for plants in Upper Michigan and Canada. Champion's last new mill came on line more than a year ago, and the company, which acquired St. Regis in 1984, has no plans for more. Goodyear Tire **********Capital spending is seen as a bigger risk at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, which amassed a mountain of debt to shake off Sir James Goldsmith, the British raider. To ward off his takeover attempt last year, Goodyear bought back half its stock at a cost of $2.6 billion. **********The outlay more than doubled the company's debt, to $4 billion. The considerable cost of servicing this debt means that Goodyear, based in Akron, Ohio, cannot afford to take a chance on any project that might lose money, said Mark Blitstein, its director of investor relations. **********''We have to be more conservative than ever about capital investment and also research spending,'' he said. The downside, he acknowledged, is ''that companies that can't afford risk don't make the breakthroughs'' in technology and productivity. **********Goodyear's capital investment fell last year to $582 million, from $619 million in 1985, and will continue to decline slowly through 1989, Mr. Blitstein said. While Goodyear has completed a $250 million conversion of its Tyler, Tex., plant into a state-of-the-art radial tire manufacturer, it is not likely to undertake a similar endeavor before the 1990's, executives said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/10/world.main_headline: Israelis Who Met With P.L.O. Deny Aid-to-Terrorists Charge
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/10/world.print_headline: Israelis Who Met With P.L.O. Deny Aid-to-Terrorists Charge
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/10/world.body_text: **********Four Israeli leftists who met with members of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Rumania in November pleaded not guilty today to breaking a law banning unauthorized contacts with ''terrorist organizations.'' **********Scuffles erupted outside the courthouse between leftist protesters calling for the charges to be dropped and right-wingers demanding heavy sentences for the peace campaigners. **********The trial is the first under a new law adopted by Parliament in August providing up to three years' imprisonment for Israelis who meet representatives of guerrilla movements. The defendants were among 29 Israeli leftists and pacifists who met low-ranking leaders of the P.L.O. at a meeting organized by the Rumanian Writers' Association in November. **********Judge Avraham Baiser rejected defense lawyers' motions for dismissal and adjourned the trial until mid-June.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/05/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II is scheduled to take part in an ''encounter with the world of labor'' here Sunday morning. But the fishermen of this gritty port city, like many other workers in the economically depressed south of Chile, have had to send their regrets. **********''We would like to be able to attend the papal festivities, but we cannot afford to,'' said the president of the Federation of Fishermen here, Juan Salazar. ''Those of us who are fortunate enough to have jobs are having to work double shifts, even on Sunday, just to be able to make ends meet.'' **********The workers' move, a product of their economic plight under the Government of Augusto Pinochet, will contribute to Concepcion's determined effort that the Pope get his wish ''not to remain solely in abstract considerations, but to descend to very concrete problems,'' as the local Archbishop, Jose Manuel Santos, put it in an interview on Friday. **********For months, church, labor and human-rights groups here have been eagerly preparing for John Paul's arrival, which they view as a rare opportunity to state their case against the military rule of General Pinochet. 'A Panorama of Fear' **********Aware of the Pope's reputation as one who is devoted to the Virgin Mary, and presuming he will have special affection for a city named after the Immaculate Conception, they plan to present him with a locally made image of the Virgin of Czestochowa. **********But residents have also readied numerous documents describing what they call a ''panorama of fear, repression, misery and exploitation.'' **********''The Pope cannot solve our problems for us, and we should not expect him to,'' said Alejandro Sepulveda, a leader of the local teachers' union, a thousand of whose members have been dismissed since January in cutbacks. ''But through him we can make others aware of the human problems that have poisoned the soul of this nation.'' **********Chileans have come to expect such frankness from the one million residents of the country's second-largest urban area. Concepcion's people have a reputation for independence that goes back to the days of Bernardo O'Higgins, who led Chile's struggle for liberation from Spain. Anti-Government Sentiment **********More recently, Concepcion has been recognized as a hotbed of anti-Pinochet sentiment and the birthplace of the armed leftist underground. Residents of the suburb of Penco take pride in reminding visitors that theirs was the only place in Chile recorded as having voted down the 1980 plebiscite that formalized General Pinochet's rule. **********In the last six years, political, labor and religious leaders here say, opposition to the military regime has hardened. The reasons have as much to do with the Pinochet Government's economic policies as anything else. **********A major industrial, mining, fishing and forestry center, Concepcion in the years before General Pinochet's seizure of power was a strong union town with a flourishing Communist Party. **********But new laws handed down in 1981 ''without consulting us have crippled the labor movement by denying us the right to collective bargaining and favoring employers,'' said the president of the local dockworkers' union, Roberto Redondo Fierro. Strikes 'Cruelly Repressed' **********In a letter sent to the Pope last month, workers here charged that strikes to raise ''starvation wages'' and to protest ''unjust'' labor laws had been ''cruelly repressed.'' **********The economic crisis afflicting Latin America has also been strongly felt here. The number of employed miners has dropped by 50 percent under General Pinochet, and workers in the textile industry by 67 percent, according to a church study.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/09/busin.body_text: **********If Texaco Inc., which is fighting a multibillion-dollar legal battle with the Pennzoil Company, were to file for bankruptcy protection, it would be the largest company ever to do so. The action could impede Texaco's ability to operate and could cause hardship for creditors, customers and shareholders, bankruptcy experts and analysts said yesterday. **********By virtue of Texaco's size and the scope of its operations, the possibility of bankruptcy is ''shuddering,'' said Robert Weiss, an analyst at the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********Texaco is the third-largest oil company in the United States and does business in about 150 foreign countries. At the end of last year it had nearly 52,000 employees worldwide. According to court papers filed by the company, Texaco pays suppliers more than $1 billion a month. **********Texaco's chief executive, James W. Kinnear, reiterated on Monday that the company would file for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code if its efforts in the courts and discussions with Pennzoil ''fail to provide Texaco with the reasonable relief it requires to continue its appeal on the merits of the case.'' **********The statement followed a ruling by the United States Supreme Court that reversed a Federal court's decision exempting Texaco from posting an $11 billion bond while it appeals a damage award that Pennzoil won in 1985. On Tuesday, a Texas appeals court barred Pennzoil from seizing Texaco assets until a hearing could be held next Monday in Houston. **********If Texaco and Pennzoil do not settle the case or come to an agreement on the bond, action by the Texas appeals court could induce Texaco to choose to file for bankruptcy if it could not win more time from the courts. Effect on Day-to-Day Operations **********If Texaco should file for protection, its day-to-day operations would continue under the supervision of a bankruptcy judge, with input from creditors. Analysts said the company would then face trouble dealing with some suppliers, who would ask for guarantees that their bills would be paid. For example, shipments of crude oil are often financed with letters of credit from banks, and lenders would be reluctant to issue such credit with Texaco in bankruptcy proceedings, analysts said. **********Some of Texaco's drilling and exploration activities may also be halted or delayed while the company, the bankruptcy judge and creditors work out a plan to keep the company running. Analysts said the company's stock dividend would almost certainly be suspended, as would interest payments on its debt. **********A number of businessmen, government officials and politicians have filed affidavits in the case, saying that Texaco would be severly damaged if it had to file for bankruptcy. **********But since Texaco is in sound financial health except for the uncertainty of the Pennzoil battle, most analysts think the company would eventually settle into something approaching business as usual. While it would have problems in the credit markets, the suspension of the dividend and of interest payments would free large amounts of cash to help keep the company running, analysts said. **********''The problems Texaco would face would be of a short-term nature until the judge works things out,'' Mr. Weiss said. Rapid Filing Possible **********Texaco has hired a bankruptcy lawyer to represent it, and bankruptcy experts said Texaco would undoubtedly be prepared to make the necessary filings in the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York virtually instantaneously if it decided to enter Chapter 11 proceedings. The chief judge of the district is Charles L. Brieant, the judge whose ruling was overturned by the United States Supreme Court on Monday. **********Texaco's suppliers and creditors are jittery about the situation, and their relationships with the company would only worsen in bankruptcy. **********Manufacturers Hanover and Bank of America have informed Texaco in the last two months that they would not lend to the company on an unsecured basis, and Security Pacific has said it would not undertake foreign currency transactions pending an internal credit review of Texaco. Southern California Edison is demanding weekly payments for electricity. **********Other suppliers, however, remain calm about the possibility of Texaco's entering bankruptcy. **********Ron Turner, a spokesman for the Baker International Corporation, the oilfield services concern that is merging with the Hughes Tool Company, said the company's business with Texaco was ''quite meaningful'' in financial terms. But he said the company was not terribly worried about losing Texaco's business if it enters bankruptcy because the first priority of the judge and the creditors will be to keep Texaco's oil flowing to insure that its cash flow will remain healthy. **********''Suppliers and vendors like us who help Texaco keep its oil flowing will not be cut off,'' Mr. Turner said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/world.main_headline: Iranian Vessels Said to Fire on Chemical Tanker
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/world.print_headline: Iranian Vessels Said to Fire on Chemical Tanker
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/world.body_text: **********Two Iranian patrol boats fired at a Liberian-registered chemical tanker today just outside the Persian Gulf, smashing a porthole with a bullet, shipping officials reported. **********They said the first information was that the tanker, the 20,578-ton Osco Sierra, had been hit by a missile. This report alarmed shippers in the gulf, where tension has been high because of mined waters and the presence of United States warships to escort Kuwaiti tankers. **********The attack occurred in the Gulf of Oman 45 miles off the United Arab Emirates port of Fujaira, where shipping sources say Iranian gunboats regularly challenge vessels they suspect of carrying war material for Iraq. **********Iraq, which has conditionally accepted a United Nations resolution for a cease-fire in the seven-year-old war, urged the United Nations to force Iran to accept the cease-fire. Teheran has neither accepted nor rejected the call. **********Earlier today in Kuwait, the Defense Ministry said a mine had been spotted and detonated near four Kuwaiti tankers, under United States flags, waiting to join a United States-escorted convoy. **********Shipping sources said the United States amphibious assault ship Guadalcanal, bearing minesweeping helicopters and escorted by two warships, appeared to be scouting the route. **********Shipping sources said the departure of the convoy would not be made public for fear of alerting the Iranians. **********In the air war, Iraq said it stepped up attacks today on Iranian oil centers with raids on oil-pumping sites and a power station.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/world.main_headline: ADVISER REBUKED BY WHITE HOUSE FOR ARMS REMARK
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/world.print_headline: ADVISER REBUKED BY WHITE HOUSE FOR ARMS REMARK
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration today rebuked Edward L. Rowny, one of its senior arms advisers, for criticizing its arms control strategy, and said his comments could complicate talks with the Soviet Union. **********''It is somewhat difficult, and there's no sense denying that,'' Marlin Fitzwater, President Reagan's spokesman, said of Mr. Rowny's comments. ''I think it is fair to say that there are people who are somewhat upset about it and would rather he didn't make those comments, but I have not heard of any efforts to change his status as a negotiator.'' **********In an interview with six newspaper reporters today, Mr. Reagan was less critical of Mr. Rowny, saying, ''I expect diverse opinions in the shop.'' Conventional Forces Issue **********But he did take issue with Mr. Rowny's suggestion that the Administration was not doing enough to reduce the Warsaw Pact's superiority in conventional forces while it was seeking reductions in medium- and short-range nuclear missiles in Europe. **********Mr. Reagan insisted that this superiority ''would have to be taken into account'' in any agreement between Washington and Moscow on medium- and short-range missiles. **********As the President spoke, Western European officials expressed ''serious concern'' at the Soviet superiority in shorter-range missiles in Europe but failed to adopt a common position on their elimination. The State Department rejected a Soviet demand that American warheads for West German missiles be destroyed as part of an accord. And a Soviet negotiator said Washington was taking an ''unconstructive'' attitude toward the latest Soviet arms proposals, but he said an agreement remained possible this year.  [ Page A10. ]  Reaction to Newspaper Article Mr. Rowny, a retired Army lieutenant general who has spent the last 15 years in arms control work, prompted the debate on Monday when he praised a commentary by former President Richard M. Nixon and his Secretary of State, Henry A. Kissinger, on the need to link a missile treaty with reductions in Soviet conventional forces. The article was published Sunday in The Los Angeles Times. **********Mr. Rowny did not endorse their position, but he said the Administration's negotiations with Moscow should not be focused solely on the issue of medium- and short-range missiles and should also deal with such matters as conventional arms, regional conflicts and human rights. **********He said the Soviet offer on medium- and short-range weapons was a ''pretty good deal.'' But he added: ''That's the small picture. We have to look at the big picture.'' **********''We don't have a consistent strategic policy,'' said Mr. Rowny, who underscored that he was talking about policy of recent Administrations and not just that of President Reagan. A White House Meeting **********Mr. Rowny is scheduled to meet Wednesday with Howard H. Baker Jr., the President's chief of staff. An aide to Mr. Rowny said today that ''The Ambassador will have no comment until he returns and meets with Senator Baker.'' **********Mr. Reagan did not state explicitly how the conventional weapons problems would be addressed. But White House officials have said the Administration would probably try to attach an ''understanding'' to any arms pact, asserting that both sides will make a special effort to negotiate a reduction in conventional arms in separate talks. **********Mr. Rowny has been one of many figures in recent days warning that the Administration had not been sufficiently concerned about the Warsaw Pact's sizable advantage in conventional military forces. This advantage, the critics say, would leave Western Europe vulnerable to attack if nuclear missiles stationed there now are removed as part of an arms accord. **********''We recognize that we must keep in mind the conventional balance,'' the President said today, ''and as a matter of fact, ever since I've been here we have been, as you know, in negotiations with the Soviet Union on that matter of conventional weapons. So it's wrong to assume that we're not aware of that and we're not dealing with it.'' **********Mr. Reagan said he was impressed with the Soviet willingness to discuss actual reductions in arms. ''If you look back in history, this has never been true of them before,'' he said. **********Asked why the Soviet Union, which he once denounced as an ''evil empire,'' now seemed willing to negotiate seriously, the President said of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader: ''I think it is very obvious that he is faced with a tremendous economic problem, and a great deal of that problem has been aggravated - made worse - by their military buildup.'' 'Practical Ends' Emphasized **********Both sides, he said, are taking a realistic, unemotional view of the talks. ''If it suits their practical ends to have some arms reduction,'' the President explained, ''and it suits our policies also, then let's get together.'' **********The United States and the Soviet Union have tentatively agreed to remove all medium-range missiles from Europe, with each side retaining 100 warheads outside the continent. Earlier this month, Moscow also proposed removing from Europe all short-range weapons, those that can travel 300 to 600 miles. **********The Administration is considering its response to the Soviet offer, and consulting with both its European allies and with Congressional leaders. **********One of Mr. Rowny's criticisms was that the Administration seemed overly eager for an accord and overly optimistic about the chances for achieving one. **********The President replied that ''most of us have have tried to keep from expressing an optimism,'' and that his Administration has been ''expressing a hopefulness, rather than optimism.'' Shultz Shows Enthusiasm **********In recent days, the Administration has been playing down its enthusiasm for the Soviet offer and stressing the hard bargaining still ahead. But when Secretary of State George P. Shultz first returned from Moscow, Administration officials made no attempt to hide their enthusiasm for the latest turn in the arms control negotiations. **********Mr. Baker, the chief of staff, said that ''big things are in the offing,'' and added, ''I remain optimistic that we've got an historic opportunity to get meaningful arms control agreements with the Soviet Union.'' **********Soviet and American leaders have said that a summit meeting in the United States could be held this year if an agreement on arms control, can be worked out in advance. **********Mr. Rowny, who was the chief negotiator on strategic arms at the beginning of the Reagan Administration, was replaced in 1985 and since then has served in Washington as a senior adviser to President Reagan. He has been popular with conservatives in Congress and has been an ally of Secretary of Defense Caspar W, Weinberger and others in the Administration less disposed to compromises with the Russians. **********The Administration has long insisted that different parts of the arms control debate should not be linked. In their view, such linkage would make any deal too complicated and unwieldy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/24/busin.body_text: **********An angry political confrontation has developed in Canada over a bill that would give foreign drug companies - many of them American - protection against widespread copying of their products by Canadian-based competitors. **********The legislation has been demanded by the Reagan Administration, and the outcome could affect trade talks between the two countries. **********At issue is Canada's practice of allowing companies that make generic drugs to produce copies of patented drugs. These drugs are sold in Canada under the condition that a minimal 4 percent royalty fee be paid to the patent holder. Canada has argued in the past that the practice helps control drug prices, but the developers of the original drug say that the practice leaves them without adequate protection for the profitable sale of their products. A Result of Talks **********The present impasse is an outgrowth of a promise Prime Minister Brian Mulroney made to President Reagan in March 1985, when the two met in Quebec City. At their meeting, the Canadian leader acknowledged that an arrangement that has existed here since 1969 was ''unfair'' and should be changed. **********Of the top 30 drug companies in Canada, only two are Canadian-owned. The others, including the top 22 companies, are subsidiaries of international drug companies, most of them American. Measured by 1986 sales in Canada, American Home Products was the leading company with sales of $168 million ($125 million United States.) It was followed by Merck Frost Canada, $159 milllion; Glaxo Canada, $136 million, and Johnson & Johnson, $130 million. **********In recent days, Prime Minister Mulroney has vowed not to back down on the Government's bill, first introduced last November, which would give major drug manufacturers 10 years of patent protection from generic drug manufacturers. But it is not clear that the legislation can get through the Canadian Senate, which rejected the Government's version last week. Criticism in Canada **********Because some people believe the bill will hurt Canadian consumers, it has been strongly criticized by the two opposition parties in Parliament and has been opposed by large majorities in public opinion polls. At the same time, Reagan Administration officials and powerful figures in Congress (including Bob Dole of Kansas, leader of the Senate's Republicans) have said that better patent protection for American drug companies is a priority in the free-trade talks that are under way between the two countries and that no trade agreement should be reached if the drug issue is not satisfactorily resolved. **********In recent remarks, Mr. Mulroney defended the patent bill on the ground that major drug companies have promised to spend $1.4 billion (Canadian) in additional spending on research and development at their Canadian plants, mostly in Montreal, Mr. Mulroney's political base. But the 1,300 jobs that the Prime Minister says this would produce may be a less important factor than the pressures in the trade talks, which are widely regarded as crucial to the Ottawa Government's hopes of winning re-election in 1989. Nader Takes a Stand **********A letter from Ralph Nader, the American consumer advocate, provoked the Prime Minister's ire last week. In the letter, Mr. Nader urged that the Canadian bill be scrapped as ''anti-consumer,'' and he said it would be a bad precedent for people in the United States who are fighting for lower drug prices. **********In response, Mr. Mulroney said: ''We do Canada's business. Mr. Nader is an American whose life's work is to protect American interests, and he's done that quite well.'' **********In the bill that emerged last year, the major feature was a 10-year patent arrangement for new drugs, followed by compulsory licensing, on a 4 percent royalty payment, to companies wishing to copy the drugs. Features that offset the patent provision, including removal of patent protection for any company found to be overcharging for its products, were removed after pressure from the Reagan Administration. In Ottawa the bill finally reached the Senate, in what was expected to be the final step to its enactment, earlier this month. **********To the Government's surprise, the opposition Liberals defied a tradition of not rejecting major Government bills by cutting the 10 years of patent protection to 4 years. As a compensating measure, the Senate voted to raise the proposed royalty payments to 14 percent, but the Government and major drug companies were not mollified. Some companies renewed threats to cease manufacturing and selling their products in Canada or to cut research and development expenses, already sparse, still further. A Legacy of Trudeau **********The law permitting the drug copying was passed by the former administration, led by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, which had decided that major drug manufacturers were overcharging Canadians for their products. The removal of the patent protection led to rapid growth among so-called generic drug manufacturers, who were able to copy brand-name products in Canada and sell them for as much as 50 percent less than the originals. **********A study done a few years ago for the Government by a University of Toronto economist, Harry Eastman, found that the savings to Canadians on their drug bills amounted to a minimum of $211 million (Canadian) a year. Other studies have shown that drug prices on average are 20 percent lower in Canada than in the United States, a reversal of the situation that existed before the law was changed in 1969. **********The lower prices being paid by Canadians represent a loss to foreign drug companies, mainly American, that account for 80 percent of the Canadian market. But more than that, from the drug companies' viewpoint, the existing Canadian legislation, with no effective patent protection, has undercut efforts to gain better patent protection in the huge markets in developing countries. **********Government officials have said that the patent protection is necessary not only to raise the amounts that multinational drug companies spend on research here but also to remove the ''bad boy'' image that they say Canada has developed in many parts of the Western world as a result of offering less protection to so-called intellectual property rights than is available elsewhere. According to the officials, most Western European nations offer 10 to 15 years of patent protection to drug companies. In the United States the figure is 17 years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/busin.main_headline: Kidder, Peabody Fined $300,000 by Big Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Kidder, Peabody Fined $300,000 by Big Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/busin.body_text: **********The New York Stock Exchange fined Kidder, Peabody & Company $300,000 yesterday on charges that the firm violated exchange rules and Federal regulations. **********According to the exchange, the violations included improperly computing net capital, filing inaccurate reports to the Government and mixing customers' securities with its own as collateral for loans. **********The exchange also penalized two Kidder, Peabody executives. John T. Roche, executive vice president, and Gerard A. Miller, former operations director, were fined $25,000 each for failures of supervision. Kidder, Peabody Statement **********The firm and the executives agreed to be censured without admitting or denying the findings. Kidder Peabody said that it consented last October to the settlement, which covered ''highly technical and complex aspects of control of customer securities and related accounting and reporting procedures.'' The complaint involved actions from 1982 to early 1986. Kidder, Peabody said that the charges were similar to others it settled with the Securities and Exchange Commission more than a year ago. **********Both the exchange and the firm said the disciplinary step was unrelated to the Government's insider-trading investigations of Martin A. Siegel, Timothy L. Tabor and Richard Wigton. Mr. Siegel, a former Kidder executive, has pleaded guilty to insider-trading charges. Mr. Tabor, a former Kidder executive, and Mr. Wigton, a longtime Kidder executive, have said they plan to fight insider-trading charges filed against them. **********The exchange said that $300,000 fines had been levied by it only twice before - against Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis in 1980 and A.G. Becker in 1983. The highest fine, $400,000, that the exchange has imposed was against Bache, Halsey, Stuart, Shields Inc. in 1982 for endangering the firm when the Hunts of Texas were trying to corner the silver market. Avoiding Litigation **********In an announcement to its 7,000 employees, Kidder, Peabody said that it had accepted the censure to avoid extended litigation. It added that ''at no time was any customer at risk of losing money'' and ''the firm did not profit or seek to profit'' from any of these activities. **********In an unrelated penalty, the exchange fined Sprague & Nammack, a former member firm, $200,000, and two of the firm's partners, Jerome W. Nammack Jr., $60,000, and Harold E. Mercil, $25,000. The exchange said that the firm had caused fake transactions to be printed on the ticker tape to influence prices. All three accepted the censure, without admitting or denying the charges. Mr. Nammack also agreed to a six-month suspension.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.body_text: **********Richard B. Wigton, whose indictment on insider trading charges was dismissed by a Federal District Court on Tuesday, will not be reinstated at this time in his old job at Kidder, Peabody & Company, officials of the firm said yesterday. Mr. Wigton was suspended without pay as head of arbitrage and over-the-counter stock trading at Kidder when he was indicted on April 9. While the indictment has been dismissed, the United States Attorney's office has said that it will file an expanded indictment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/busin.main_headline: Southland Stock Edges Up After Tuesday's Slide
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Southland Stock Edges Up After Tuesday's Slide
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/12/busin.body_text: **********Shares of the Southland Corporation edged up yesterday by $2.50, to $54, after plummeting $16.25 on Tuesday. **********Southland, which owns more than 7,000 7-Eleven stores, said Tuesday that it had been forced to put on hold its plan to become a private company because Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers Inc., its investment bankers, were unable to find buyers for all bonds needed to finance the deal. **********Yesterday's modest recovery came on rumors that an investment company not previously involved in Southland's plan would sell the $1.5 billion in high-yielding bonds that Southland needs. **********Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the dominant firm in junk bond financing, and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. were the most frequently mentioned rescuers, but traders and people close to both firms discounted the rumors. **********One trader noted that similar debt-financed buyouts in which Drexel played a role were also in doubt in the wake of the markets' tumble last month. **********The fortunes of the junk-bond market are closely tied to the health of the economy because companies partly financed by high-yield bonds need to maintain consistent profits to continue paying the comparatively high yields. **********Yields on junk bonds rose sharply after the collapse in the stock market over rising fears of an economic slowdown, or recession, in the coming months. **********''We still have confidence that the transaction will get done,'' said Gerald Rosenfeld, chief financial officer of Salomon Brothers Inc., the securities unit of Salomon Inc. **********Dennis Telzrow, an analyst with Eppler, Guerin & Turner, a brokerage in Dallas, where Southland is based, said the Thompson family, which founded Southland and owns 72 percent of its shares, would probably wait several weeks before trying to sell the junk bonds. **********Southland is attempting to sell assets valued at $1.2 billion as part of the refinancing package. The only agreement signed so far involves the sale, for $80 million, of 270 7-Eleven stores in its Houston division. **********Southland's holdings include the High's Dairy Stores and Chief Auto Parts chains and 50 percent of the Citgo Petroleum Corporation. **********Edward G. Gagnon, a retailing analyst with Rauscher, Pierce, Refsnes Inc., in Dallas, said Southland would step up its efforts to find buyers for all its assets on the auction block. **********Cash obtained from those sales would give a clearer picture of current market values for the more than 6,000 convenience stores Southland intends to retain, he said. That, in turn, should make it easier to find buyers for the high-yield bonds, he said. **********Mr. Gagnon said he did not believe the turmoil in the stock and junk bond markets would have much impact on prices Southland could obtain for the properties up for sale. **********''Rates are lower and maybe some deals can be cut,'' he said. **********Goldman and Salomon are each carrying bridge loans to Southland of $100 million that are to be repaid when the buyout plan is completed. Several banks hold an additional $400 million in bridge loans. **********Mr. Rosenfeld of Salomon said his firm's potential exposure in the Southland transaction ''is in no way any risk to the financial well-being of the firm.'' A spokesman for Goldman, Sachs said officials of the firm were not available. **********In the early stages of the buyout offer, Southland's outside auditing firm, Touche Ross & Company, had prepared a document in which it officially agreed that Southland had the assets and prospects to afford the $4.9 billion refinancing. **********Richard H. Murray, executive director of Touche Ross International and the firm's former general counsel, denied a report published yesterday in The Wall Street Journal that Touche Ross could be judged liable to the banks if Southland was unable to repay money provided by the banks to finance the buyout. **********Mr. Murray said the specific terms of the letter, which he declined to disclose, did not now apply to the transaction because of the volatility in the junk-bond market. ''We are confident we have no liability here,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/18/busin.snippet: LEAD: BARRETT N. SINOWITZ, a studious-looking, barrel-chested stockbroker in the Prudential-Bache Securities office near Grand Central Terminal, was trying to reassure a client about his drug-stock holdings, which had plunged more than 20 percent ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/18/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: BARRETT N. SINOWITZ, a studious-looking, barrel-chested stockbroker in the Prudential-Bache Securities office near Grand Central Terminal, was trying to reassure a client about his drug-stock holdings, which had plunged more than 20 percent in the market's two-week blood bath. **********BARRETT N. SINOWITZ, a studious-looking, barrel-chested stockbroker in the Prudential-Bache Securities office near Grand Central Terminal, was trying to reassure a client about his drug-stock holdings, which had plunged more than 20 percent in the market's two-week blood bath. **********''Look,'' he said on Thursday, staring at the computer screen in his 12-foot by 12-foot private office, ''just because the market is down doesn't mean that people are going to stop taking medicine. In fact, with the market going down this fast, people are probably going to take more medicine, not less. You want to own drug companies - particularly the ones that make tranquilizers.'' **********It was hardly a rollicking joke. The cataclysm that hit Wall Street last week shook investors all around the country and made even the staunchest bull wonder if the five-year joy ride had come to an end. While the 17.5 percent decline thus far from the August high of 2,722.42 might be viewed as just a monstrous correction in an ongoing bull market, many investors may be unable to think of it as anything but a reminder of an earlier October massacre - the Crash of 1929. **********The Dow plunged 108.36 points on Friday, 57.61 points on Thursday and 95.46 points on Wednesday, losing 10.4 percent in those three days - a number which put the fall within range of the one-day performance of Oct. 28, 1929, when the market swooned 12.8 percent. Rightly or wrongly, many investors picked last week to panic - and they swarmed into the market with sell orders, sending the volume well past previous records. **********On Thursday, the day sandwiched between the two largest one-session point declines in market history, a visitor sat in on Mr. Sinowitz's calls to see how clients were coping with the carnage. Surprisingly, most seemed to handle the slaughter with something approaching equanimity. Or at least stunned silence. Only 30 of his 500 clients bothered to call. **********To be sure, there were some hysterical calls - one woman thought she had a 50 percent loss in Syntex, the drug company, because she forgot the stock had split 2-for-1 - but over all, Mr. Sinowitz succeeded in convincing his flock that the week represented a buying opportunity, albeit a terrifying one. **********On Thursday, while the market zig-zagged nervously before plunging to a 57-point loss, most of it in the final half-hour, Barry Sinowitz bought $132,000 worth of stock for clients and sold not a single share. Some clients called to sell, then wound up buying or standing pat after hearing the broker's soothing words. It was a day for practicing the ancient art of hand-holding. **********In the past two weeks, Mr. Sinowitz's clients have poured almost $2 million into the market. ''Of course,'' he said on Thursday, ''as it stands now I was wrong. I should have sold all these stocks. That's why I'm going to go jogging and try to forget.'' **********With hindsight, it is easy to say that Mr. Sinowitz should have abandoned his bullish stance several weeks ago - at least temporarily. As it happens, the anguish some of his clients felt during the recent market debacle was made more extreme by his very basic market strategy. Mr. Sinowitz does not believe in stop-loss orders, or in buying puts as insurance. He says such techniques rarely work. **********On Friday, when the market was spiraling downward, Mr. Sinowitz's phone rarely rang. He spent a lot of time reading the newspaper. Just before the close, he said he might change his strategy a bit on Monday and suggest that some of his clients sell call options as a hedge. He was starting to worry. **********But all through Thursday and Friday, his clients were bravely - or foolishly - buying stock as the market continued its vicious decline. On Friday, though, one client had the audacity to override Mr. Sinowitz's protestations and sell. ''He'll regret it, '' said Mr. Sinowitz.  In many ways the 50-year-old Mr. Sinowitz is an old-fashioned broker. He is relatively conservative and has little interest in quick trades, options or futures. He is proud to point out that not one of his clients owns stock on margin. **********Arriving in the office at 6:30 most mornings, he does much of his own research, as he has throughout his 14 years as a broker. He got into the business after being an international management consultant and running his family's plumbing and electrical supply business. **********Today most of his clients are upper-middle-class professionals, although the size of his accounts ranges from $500 all the way up to $2.5 million. Almost all are long-term investors. The advice he gives directly affects the allocation of $30 million and this year his efforts will net him a bit over $200,000. **********A passionate jogger, Mr. Sinowitz finds that he runs more when the markets are volatile. ''This has been an absolutely wonderful year for jogging,'' he said. ''I'm now doing so much that I've entered the Marathon for the first time.'' **********That sweat-inducing volatility - which of late has been primarily in the wrong direction - had clearly spooked Mr. Sinowitz's first lunch-time caller on Thursday. The man wanted to sell his 200 shares of a leading entertainment company, which had slumped 15 percent from their high. **********HEARING doubts about this stock, Mr. Sinowitz acted like a man who had heard America besmirched and must rise up to defend it. ''No,'' he said firmly. ''Don't sell. Nothing has changed. Nothing has changed.'' **********He was almost shouting. ''This isn't a time to panic; this is a time to buy. Before you sell, at least let me ask you something. Why does a stock go down?'' The client, apparently, didn't know what to make of the question, so Mr. Sinowitz repeated it, then answered. **********''It goes down because a company's prospects are bad or because they have worsened. Now let me read you something.'' **********He called up the company's latest quarterly report on his computer screen and read off the glowing numbers. Revenues up 26 percent, profits up 61 percent, margins improving dramatically. ''Does this sound like a company in trouble? So why would you want to sell it?'' **********The answer: Because Robert Prechter, the reigning market guru, had said earlier this month that Dow might drop as low as 2,300. ''That's only 4 percent more,'' said Mr. Sinowitz, a statement which, alas, was true at the time. ''Hang in there.'' **********It was more an order than advice, and the man did as he was told. ''He thinks he would get back in at a lower price,'' Mr. Sinowitz said, ''but in practice that rarely happens.'' **********THE other problem with the ''follow-the-seer'' strategy, he said, is that all forecasters are stupendously wrong eventually. ''You're a lot better off watching quarterly earnings statements than listening to some star-gazing guru.'' **********Mr. Sinowitz doesn't think much of anyone's market forecast, although he is willing to predict that the selling will cease in a week or less. What he truly believes in is the value of good stocks, top companies in leading industries like drugs and pollution control. He does not think one should sell such worthy equities until the fundamentals change significantly. (It is worth pointing out that most of these good stocks are 20 to 30 percent lower than they were earlier in the month. Mr. Sinowitz is of the opinion that they now have added goodness.) With the market off 10 points, another would-be seller called, and the defender of the faith again responded. ''Last quarter's write-off was a one-time thing for Banc One,'' he said. ''Rollins Environmental just came through with excellent numbers and it's a very recession-proof company. I'm writing out four buy orders as we're talking. Yeah, things don't look so good now, but eventually they will, once all this emotionalism disappears. When will that happen? If I knew exactly when I wouldn't need you as a client.'' **********And then came the clincher. ''Look, it's to my benefit to call you up and ask you to sell and then get you back in later, but I'm not doing that.'' **********She found this so convincing that she decided to add 100 shares of Syntex, the drug maker, to her holdings. **********''Please buy 200,'' Mr. Sinowitz said, in a tone clearly indicating he would be personally wounded by anything less. ''And 100 more shares of Banc One.'' She did. MR. SINOWITZ swayed clients with surprising ease, illustrating that they really do rely heavily on his opinions. They have remained bullish partly because he has told them the party will be over only when inflation truly kicks up - and he insists it hasn't yet. **********As soon as he expressed this upbeat view of inflation, naturally, the market plunged again. ''Wow,'' he said, like a little kid. ''It's down 15 points and it was just up 5 two minutes ago. Gosh, that's fast.'' **********''Gosh'' is not quite what clients said on Jan. 23, the day the market sank 114 points in little more than an hour. That's when clients were most frantic and most eager to make telephone contact. (Bullish for Nynex.) ''They really worried that it was all over,'' he said, ''but I think that day - and the market's rise immediately afterward - taught people that they're going to have to live with volatility. It's part of the game.'' **********Again, as if on cue, a call came from a client who cannot cope with the volatility. ''I'm not worried about the companies we're in,'' he told her. ''I'm worried about your psyche.'' No dice.  ''If I were you I wouldn't sell here,'' he said with a big sigh. He had told her this the day before - and on many other occasions. She suggested that calamity was just around the corner. ''What can I tell you, I just don't think the world is coming to an end.'' **********Bingo. He had hit the hot button - the global perspective. Her personal storm passed. **********For most of the day, however, it was business as usual for Mr. Sinowitz. Sometimes he was on two phones at once, but there were lulls when the phone did not ring for 30 or 40 minutes. He told a first-time buyer a few basics about the market, bought him an $11,000 investment in three companies, and then bought some four-month CD's and some two-and-a-half-year municipal bonds for other clients. (By midday Friday, that first-time buyer wanted to sell and take his $500 loss. Mr. Sinowitz convinced him to hold on - and the loss mounted.) What Mr. Sinowitz also did Thursday was play host to his regular lunch-hour visitor, Gabriel Torre. Mr. Torre is a dapper, 80-year-old lawyer with a portfolio that totals more than a half-million dollars. He comes by to get the feel of the market, and what he felt this day was mostly positive. ''You know,'' he said, ''my father and I got wiped out by the Crash, but I don't think anything like that will ever happen again. There are too many safeguards.'' **********Mr. Sinowitz seemed comforted by his client's view that we have learned from history. **********After the market's close on Thursday, while Mr. Sinowitz was changing clothes for his evening run to his Upper East Side apartment, the voice of Hildegard Zagorski, Prudential-Bache's associate vice president, came over the squawk box next to Mr. Sinowitz's computer. ''Well,'' she said, ''at least today's agony is over. We think the market is searching for a bottom here.'' She sounded as if she could use some hand-holding herself. As for Mr. Sinowitz, he made about $600 net on Thursday and became even more convinced that the devastation would help shake out some weak holders of stock. ''Right now,'' he said, ''many people are concentrating on panicking and not on the opportunities they have, and that's too bad.'' **********When more desperate phone calls come in the next few days, Mr. Sinowitz will continue to offer reassurance. He will try mightily to keep people in their stocks, but he knows he will sometimes cave in. ''If a person is really going over the edge, I'll say, 'Look, if it makes you feel better, sell. But 12 months from now you'll be sorry.' '' **********That was what Mr. Sinowitz said on Thursday. When he said it again the next day, however, there was a great deal more doubt in his voice.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/12/busin.main_headline: PURCHASING CHIEF EXPECTED TO QUIT AT DEFENSE DEPT.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/12/busin.print_headline: PURCHASING CHIEF EXPECTED TO QUIT AT DEFENSE DEPT.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/12/busin.body_text: **********Richard Godwin, the Under Secretary of Defense for acquisition, will resign because he is frustrated with the working of his year-old office, Government and arms industry officials said today. **********Appointed as a procurement ''czar'' with centralized and sweeping powers over Pentagon purchases, Mr. Godwin reportedly now feels that his authority was not adequate and that the Pentagon has failed to streamline the labyrinthine bureaucracy that develops and buys weapons. **********His resignation marks the latest of several times during the Reagan Administration that the job of supervising the military's purchases, which cost about $170 billion a year, has changed hands - usually amid disagreement over how much authority to place in what part of the bureaucracy. Major Issues Unsettled **********Mr. Godwin will leave office when several major procurement policy issues, notably the appropriate levels of profits to be earned by military contractors, remain unsettled. **********Mr. Godwin could not be reached for comment today, but associates said that he informed Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger of his plans this week and that he would hand in his resignation next week. The Armed Services Committees of the House and the Senate both plan to ask him to appear as a witness in hearings that could lead to new legislation clarifying the responsibilities of his office. 'Disturbing Development' **********''It is a very disturbing development,'' said Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the House Armed Services Committee. **********Another influential committee member, Larry J. Hopkins, a Kentucky Republican, said Mr. Godwin's departure called into question the commitment of the Pentagon to the organizational reforms enacted last year. ''I knew that the family had been arguing,'' he said. ''I'm sorry it is leading to divorce.'' A former executive of the Bechtel Group Inc., Mr. Godwin was named to take the high-level post, nominally one of the four most powerful assignments in the Pentagon, after it was created by Congress last year in answer to weapon procurement scandals. **********But since taking office, he has lost a number of policy disputes, and members of Congress and the Packard Commission on procurement reform have complained that he did not have enough authority. One industry wit tagged him ''Under Secretary for acquiescence,'' in the belief that he was not aggressive enough in defending his prerogatives. **********''Turf and personality have nothing to do with it,'' one of his associates said in describing Mr. Godwin's departure. ''It's how you run the company. The company ought to be run like a business.'' **********Congress created Mr. Godwin's office last year as part of a sweeping package of legislation reorganizing the Pentagon. Advocates of a streamlined system of acquisition said that, by naming a single executive in the top ranks of the office of the Defense Secretary, the Pentagon would be able to build weapons more quickly and cheaply while avoiding costly duplication of efforts by the individual military services. **********Before the new position was established, there were as many as eight senior officials in the Defense Department with some responsibility over various aspects of acquisition - and none who worked full time on the task. Findings Endorsed **********The Packard Commission was a Presidentially appointed panel of experts headed by David Packard, a former Pentagon official and chairman of the Hewlett-Packard Corporation. Last year, the commission recommended establishing Mr. Godwin's post and streamlining the bureaucracy, and the Pentagon endorsed the panel's findings, which were enacted into law. **********A year after the commission made its recommendations, though, Mr. Packard reviewed the progress to date and wrote to President Reagan that Mr. Godwin ''has not been given adequate authority.'' For example, he said, auditors responsible for reviewing the performance of military contractors had not been put under Mr. Godwin's control. **********People involved in military procurement said today that Mr. Godwin's ascendancy on the crest of a reform wave backed by a large majority in Congress and by a Presidential blue-ribbon panel of experts may, in the end, have cost him leverage inside the Pentagon. **********''This place is not attuned to taking on the reforms,'' said one Pentagon official who asked not to be named. **********Mr. Godwin's authority was undermined when the individual service secretaries, who control weapons procurement for the Army, the Air Force and the Navy, continued to argue that they should be in charge of their respective weapon projects. His role, they argued, should be limited to supervision and policy formulation. Influence Was Restricted **********At the same time, Deputy Defense Secretary William H. Taft 4th, the department's No. 2 official, restricted Mr. Godwin's influence over procurement expenditures by making himself responsible for key decisions, relegating Mr. Godwin to an advisory role in the budgetary process. **********''It's just clearly not going to work,'' one of Mr. Godwin's associates said. **********The vacancy comes at a time when the Pentagon is having difficulty winning Senate confirmation of several nominees to serve as assistant secretaries, the level of authority one notch below Mr. Godwin's. Nominees for these positions would be in charge of policies ranging from arms control to commando warfare. The Pentagon has expressed continuing frustration at the delay in confirming the appointments. **********Mr. Godwin will depart just as the Senate begins consideration of next year's military spending bill, which was held up for several months in a dispute over arms control policy. **********It is possible that senators who favor changes in the military bureaucracy will seek to toughen last year's legislation to force the Pentagon to give Mr. Godwin's successor more power over procurement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/busin.main_headline: BONANZA AT THE TOP OF DISNEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/busin.print_headline: BONANZA AT THE TOP OF DISNEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/busin.body_text: **********The Walt Disney Company has proved a magic kingdom of incredible proportions for its chairman, Michael Eisner, and its president, Frank Wells. **********Stock in Disney is currently trading near $80 a share, and has climbed $16, or 25 percent, since early May. By comparison, the Dow Jones industrial average has gained 400 points, or about 16 percent, in that time. **********The run-up in Disney stock is simply more icing on the cake for Mr. Eisner and Mr. Wells, who together hold options to buy roughly 3.9 million Disney shares. They received the options in the fall of 1984 when they joined the company. Valued at $250 Million **********If fully exercised now, their options would net them at least $250 million, based on a current market value of more than $300 million for the Disney shares they would obtain, minus their cost of some $50 million. **********The options enable the executives to acquire shares at a predetermined price, but there are limits on the number of options that can be converted to shares at any one time. There are also restrictions on the sale of the shares obtained. Neither Mr. Eisner nor Mr. Welles has exercised a significant number of his options. **********Still, the two executives are obviously in a highly lucrative situation. ''The numbers are absolutely staggering,'' said one Wall Street executive who asked not to be named. **********There is no doubt that Disney's performance has been among the most stunning in the entertainment industry. Since the end of 1983, annual net income tripled to more than $257 million, on $2.5 billion in revenues, for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30. That profit was easily surpassed in just the first nine months of this fiscal year, with net income at $309.4 million, on sales of $2.3 billion. **********Adding to the momentum, Disney's two newest films, ''Stakeout'' and ''Can't Buy Me Love,'' are both doing well, following a series of other hits. **********Disney's stock has reflected its earnings performance. Adjusted for a 4-for-1 stock split in 1986, Disney stock has risen from $15 in September 1984, when Mr. Eisner and Mr. Wells joined the company. The shares closed yesterday at $78.75, down $1.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. An Unusual Situation **********The situation is clearly a bonanza for Mr. Eisner and Mr. Wells, and to a lesser extent for Gary Wilson, the chief financial officer, who joined the company in July 1985 and holds an options package valued at $74 million. Their situation reflects both Disney's turnaround and the unusual deal they were offered, in which they received a more substantial opportunity to obtain stock than is typical in such programs, according to consultants on executive compensation. Envy of the Industry **********Inevitably, their deal is the envy of other executives. As Gerald Roche, the chairman of Heidrick & Struggles, an executive search firm, put it, ''Everybody else is looking at them and saying, 'Wow, how can we do that, too?' '' **********Several compensation consultants agreed that the potential gain for the Disney executives might be a record. But Pearl Meyer, the executive vice president of Handy Associates, a search firm that also acts as consultants on executive compensation, pointed out: ''This was a turnaround situation. Partially the numbers look obscene because the company has done so well.'' **********The Disney executives, Mrs. Meyer added, ''are getting entrepreneurial rewards without the commensurate financial risks of starting a company themselves.'' **********Erwin Okun, a Disney spokesman, said that roughly 7.4 percent of Disney shares had been allocated to Disney management as options or stock grants. Over all, 500 executives participate in the option program. But nearly half the allocated equity, 3.6 percent, is in the hands of Mr. Eisner, Mr. Wells and Mr. Wilson. **********The percentage of equity allocated to management is higher at some companies, even as high as 16 percent, Mrs. Meyer said. But in cases where it is higher, such as at Johnson & Johnson or the Data General Corporation, the equity is generally spread among several hundred executives. **********What is unusual at Disney, Mrs. Meyer said, is that the three top executives control such a huge share. **********''Normal stock options for people in the Fortune 500 are not that high,'' said Louis Brindisi Jr., chairman of the Management Compensation Group, a firm that analyzes executive pay and benefits. ''It can only be related to the shareholder value they helped create.'' **********Both Mr. Eisner, who was president of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, and Mr. Wells, a former vice chairman at Warner Brothers Inc., are highly regarded in the entertainment industry. The dismal earnings performance of Disney at the time they were hired helps explain the leverage they had in negotiating their contracts. **********According to the 1986 proxy, Mr. Eisner was granted options to buy 510,000 shares at $57.43 a share when he agreed to join Disney in September 1984. Mr. Wells received 460,000 options. On Jan. 13, 1986, Disney declared a 4-for-1 stock split. That brought the option price to $14.36. There had been at that time about 32.4 million shares outstanding. The split and several adjustments changed that number to about 131 million shares. Salaries and Bonuses **********Mr. Eisner was given an annual salary of $750,000 and Mr. Wells, $400,000. In addition, Mr. Eisner received a cash bonus last year of $2.6 million, the result of an incentive formula that gave him 2 percent of the amount by which Disney's net income exceeded a 9 percent return on stockholders' equity. Disney's return rose to 19 percent in the 1986 fiscal year, from 8 percent in 1984. Under the formula, Mr. Wells got 1 percent. **********Mrs. Meyer believes that the Disney plan has adequate safeguards for shareholders. The hurdle rate of a 9 percent return on equity is relatively high for such compensation packages, she said. **********Mr. Okun, the Disney spokesman, noted that only 20 percent of the options could be exercised each year for five years. Also, the shares obtained cannot be sold for six months. **********High salaries are not unknown in the entertainment industry. Steven J.
