Ross, for example, the chairman of Warner Communications Inc., has a complicated contract that could bring him cumulative compensation of as much as $142 million by 1996. His salary is $1.2 million annually and the bonuses are dependent on the company's performance. **********But situations within the industry are difficult to compare. For one thing, Mr. Ross was the architect of Warner Communications as it exists today, making him in essence the founder of a company. Warner has a number of directors whom he brought on the board, and they are the people who approved his contract. **********In the case of Mr. Wells and Mr. Eisner, they were in effect hired from the outside. Disney, which was generally regarded as a sleeping giant, had such properties as Mickey Mouse and Sleeping Beauty waiting to be exploited.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/20/world.body_text: **********The father-in-law of a young Hindu woman who was burned to death when she placed herself or was placed on her husband's funeral pyre was arrested today pending charges of murder and abetting a suicide, the United News of India reported. **********Three of the man's relatives were taken into custody on the same grounds, the news agency said. **********The woman, Roop Kunwar, 18 years old, died Sept. 4 in the flames of her husband's cremation pyre in a tiny village in the northwestern state of Rajasthan. Her husband, Maal Singh, 24, had died of gastroenteritis a day earlier. **********The Hindu rite of immolation by a widow, called sati, has been outlawed in India since 1829 but is still practiced occasionally - perhaps once or twice in a decade - in a remote village. Pilgrims Visit Site **********Since the death, thousands of pilgrims have visited the village of Deorala to worship at the cremation site. The village is about 100 miles southwest of New Delhi. **********According to Hindu tradition, such deaths are supposed to be voluntary and guarantee that the wife is reunited with her husband in the next life. **********There have been several newspapers reports, however, that Roop Kunwar may have been coerced or forced by relatives to take her own life. Women's groups have condemned the action as barbaric and as evidence of the continued subjugation of women in Indian society. **********The Indian Express reported from Rajasthan today that the district magistrate and superintendent of police in the area where the sati occurred had been transferred. Three policemen were also removed from the district, it said. **********United News said those arrested had been identified as Roop Kunwar's father-in-law, Sumer Singh, and three of his relatives, Ranjit Singh, Ranajit Singh and Bhupendra Singh. The Singhs all are Hindus. **********The police earlier had arrested Maal Singh's 15-year-old brother, who is said to have lighted the funeral pyre. He has been held in a juvenile home pending charges.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/29/busin.body_text: **********International **********The dollar plunged to new lows against major currencies, prompting a strong statement from the White House that it opposed any further drop in the currency's value. The pressure on the dollar's value became so intense that the Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan and other central banks bought dollars to support the currency, according to traders. Officials admitted that the dollar's weakness reflects both confusion by traders over the Administration's commitment to stopping any further decline and the realization that any policy tools the White House could employ to buttress the dollar are, at best, modest.  [ Page A1. ]  In light trading on the currency markets, the dollar slid to new lows, and gold rose in New York to $487.75 an ounce, up $1.25.  [ D14. ] **********The dollar's slide shows how hard its stabilization will be no matter how coordinated the policies of the seven trading partners. And huge differences remain about what the proper level of the American currency should be.  [ D17. ] **********Japan approved a budget of $461 billion for 1988 that provides the biggest spending increase in six years. Senior officials said the overall 4.8 percent increase was evidence that they were responding to demands from overseas to stimulate the economy.  [ D1. ] **********Angola is shifting to free markets, as part of a wider move toward the West by a Government that only a few years ago tried to become the first African member of Comecon, the economic union of the Eastern bloc.  [ A6. ] Markets **********The Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 56.70 points, to 1,942.97, its biggest decline since Dec. 3, when it fell 72.44 points. Analysts attributed the drop primarily to the dollar's fall. Broader market indexes also fell sharply.  [ D1. ] **********Note and bond prices declined modestly in light trading, with little participation by institutional investors or speculators outside the major securities firms. Analysts said the price changes were not indicative of any trend among institutional investors but rather were the result of short-term trading strategies.  [ D12. ] **********Cattle futures advanced the 1 1/2-cents-a-pound daily limit before losing part of their gains.  [ D14. ] Companies **********Santa Fe Southern Pacific accepted a $1.8 billion offer from Rio Grande for its Southern Pacific railroad. The deal must be approved by the I.C.C., but not by stockholders, some of whom were very unhappy. Santa Fe had turned away a competing bid of at least $2 billion from Kansas City Southern and an offer from its unions to match any other bid. Railroad analysts forecast that the merger plan would precipitate much litigation, a major proxy fight for control of Santa Fe and widespread opposition from a number of fronts. Six months ago, the I.C.C. had ordered the company to sell one of its two major lines.  [ D1. ] **********Rorer sweetened its offer for A. H. Robins, the pharmaceutical company with $2.48 billion in liabilities to thousands of women who claim they were injured by its Dalkon Shield birth control device. Robins's board received the news as it met to consider bids from Rorer, American Home Products and Sanofi.  [ D1. ] **********First Chicago and Wood Gundy ended their agreement to form a partnership amid questions about the health of the Canadian investment firm after the October stock market plunge.  [ D1. ] **********Computervision will consider Prime Computer's takeover offer of $390 million. Computervision's stock jumped on news of the offer, which was made Sunday, and closed up $4.25, at $13.25.  [ D4. ] **********Trustcorp will pay nearly $200 million for Summcorp, a bank holding company in Fort Wayne, Ind.. Trustcorp is a financial services company based in Toledo, Ohio.  [ D4. ] **********Computer Memories will merge with DIC Animation City, the producer of such television cartoon shows as ''Alf'' and ''Real Ghostbusters,'' in a $75 million stock deal.  [ D4. ] Today's Columns **********Medical-evacuation methods perfected in Vietnam and neurosurgery in hospital trauma centers have helped tens of thousands of Americans survive brutal accidents. A fast-growing industry is springing up to serve these survivors. Business and Health.  [ D2. ] **********Avon Products has paid a $2 annual dividend since 1983. Most analysts think the dividend is secure for now, but its safety is like a shadow that keeps lingering over the stock. Market Place.  [ D6. ]

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/04/busin.body_text: **********The Sherwood Group Inc. has disclosed that several of its executives are the targets of a grand jury investigation into possibly illegal securities practices and that the brokerage firm could be harmed if they were to be indicted and convicted. **********The individuals under investigation are former officials of First Jersey Securities, whose branch system was acquired by Sherwood late last year. **********Sherwood, owner of Sherwood Capital, a securities firm that specializes in the sale of over-the-counter stocks, made the disclosures in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing related to a public offering of its shares last week. Sherwood sold seven million of its 13 million shares outstanding at $8.50 a share. S.E.C. Filing Subpoenaed **********The S.E.C. required that Sherwood amend the filing twice to make full disclosure of the extent of the investigation into Sherwood and some of its officers before it allowed the offering to take place. **********Sherwood disclosed that the offering document itself had been subpoenaed as part of the Federal grand jury investigation in Manhattan. **********The disclosures have raised questions about whether Sherwood's shares will be accepted for trading on a stock exchanges. The American Stock Exchange earlier had approved the shares for a listing. But an exchange official said yesterday that it was ''seeking clarification of some of the material in the prospectus'' before making a decision. **********Sherwood inherited part of its problems. It agreed last December to acquire 33 of the retail offices of First Jersey Securities, which is currently fighting S.E.C. civil charges that it manipulated stock prices, creating excessive markups. Previous Settlements **********First Jersey settled a similar set of charges with the S.E.C. in 1984 and last year settled other charges filed by the National Association of Securities Dealers. In that settlement, a number of First Jersey's senior executives were fined and suspended, including its chairman, Robert E. Brennan. **********In addition, Mr. Brennan agreed earlier this year to pay $10 million to settle a class-action lawsuit by First Jersey customers who had contended that they had been defrauded through manipulative pricing practices. **********Some of the grand jury subpoenas relate to activities that had taken place in the branches while they were still owned by First Jersey. However, Sherwood's filing also says that the grand jury is looking into some activities that took place after the branches became part of Sherwood. **********''The key element here is that Bob Brennan is no longer involved in the company,'' said Fredric Rittereiser, First Jersey's former chief executive and now Sherwood's chief executive. ''We've gotten away from the old scenario,'' he added, referring to First Jersey's sales practices, which were the subject of the earlier S.E.C. charges. Sherwood Executives Named **********Sherwood's stock-offering document said that among the individuals involved in the grand jury investigation are John E. Dell, the former president of First Jersey and now head of Sherwood's retail system, and several branch managers. **********The document notes that their ''contribution to Sherwood Capital is significant,'' indicating that the loss of these executives could have an ''adverse'' impact on the firm. **********Mr. Rittereiser called Mr. Dell ''very important'' to the firm, but said of the grand jury investigation, ''It remains to be seen what will happen. We're still early in the process.'' **********When First Jersey sold its branches to Sherwood, neither brokerage firm would disclose the price. But the offering document said that Mr. Brennan was paid $19 million in the form of 10-year notes paying an interest rate of 8 percent. It added that a note of $3.7 million and a second note for $10.1 million would be paid off from the proceeds of the stock offering in Sherwood.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/23/busin.body_text: **********The volatility of the international monetary system was severely criticized today by many of the 200 leading bankers gathered here for the International Monetary Conference. The bankers urged their governments to take stronger action to stabilize exchange rates. **********Although a number of the officials complained about the floating exchange rate system, they presented only a few ideas on how to improve it. One proposal was to set up a huge multinational institution that would periodically intervene in financial markets to reduce volatility. **********''We have an international monetary system that doesn't serve us very well,'' said Willard C. Butcher, chairman and chief executive of the Chase Manhattan Bank. ''We've had persistent currency misalignments - not for a day, not for a month, not for a year, but for periods of five, six and seven years - that have severely damaged, perhaps in some cases even mortally damaged, many of our basic industries.'' Monetary 'Mechanism' Sought **********Mr. Butcher is chairman of the 33-year-old annual conference, which brings together bankers from more than 100 of the world's leading banks. He said that the current international monetary system was not going to correct itself and that the search for a more satisfactory system ''must be intensified.'' **********In the speech that received most attention today, Toyoo Gyohten, Japan's vice minister of finance for international affairs, proposed establishing ''some international mechanism'' to cope with unpredictable emergencies or unjustifiable volatilities in the monetary system. He said that the huge size of international money flows would require this mechanism to have at least several hundred billion dollars in order to influence the financial markets. **********Mr. Gyohten said that floating-exchange rates did not cause distortions, but instead reflected distortions created by the mismatch of governments' policies. He noted that a huge policy mismatch made the dollar extremely strong in the early 1980's, when the United States adopted a tight monetary policy and a loose fiscal policy while most other leading industrial nations were pursuing tight fiscal policies. **********Several officials here said one problem with the monetary system is that while the dollar is becoming more important as an international currency, the United States economy is playing a less important role in the world economy. This, they said, makes regulating the dollar's behavior more difficult for American Treasury officials and central bankers. U.S. Urged to Diversify **********At the same time, several officials noted that Japan and West Germany had not been willing and able to make their currencies play a sufficiently important role as their economies grew in importance. **********To reduce these imbalances and to help stabilize currencies, Mr. Gyohten said the United States should diversify its official monetary reserves and allow more of its foreign debt to be denominated in currencies other than the dollar. He also urged the use of foreign currencies for United States trade. **********Mr. Gyohten also called for Japan and West Germany to encourage the international use of their currencies through financial deregulation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/12/world.main_headline: U.S. AND SOVIET LEGISLATORS ARE PLANNING TO DEBATE ON TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/12/world.print_headline: U.S. AND SOVIET LEGISLATORS ARE PLANNING TO DEBATE ON TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/12/world.body_text: **********The first public dialogue between members of Congress and the Supreme Soviet, the nominal Soviet Parliament, will be televised in both nations this month in six broadcasts on such issues as arms control, human rights, regional conflicts, health and environment. **********Three hours of satellite time have been booked for April 25 in the first of the series, which is called ''CongressBridge.'' The program is expected to be broadcast by a major American network, yet to be announced, and on Soviet television, which is operated by the Government. **********''For too long we have seen each other only as warmongers,'' Representative Claudine Schneider, Republican of Rhode Island, said. ''The time is ripe for new ways of thinking.'' Last Details Being Worked Out Representative Schneider and Representative George E. Brown Jr., Democrat of California, lead a six-member Congressional group that has been working on ground rules. They left for the Soviet Union on Thursday to work out final details. **********The impetus for the project came in an exchange of letters last year between Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., then the Speaker of the House of Representatives, and Lev N. Tolkunov, chairman of the Soviet of the Union, one of the two chambers of the Supreme Soviet. **********The Supreme Soviet is chosen every five years from a single slate of candidates handpicked by the leadership. Unlike the Congress, the Supreme Soviet does not formulate policy, but endorses policies decided by the ruling Communist Party. **********Representative Brown said, ''We have made it clear on both sides that the purpose is not to try to get anyone to give up his belief in his own system - we each think we have the best system in the world.'' **********But for good or bad, he said, ''we are going to have some impact on the Soviet people.'' **********''Their leadership has continued to portray the United States as some kind of an ogre dominated by Wall Street capitalists,'' he said. ''If we can begin to ease that image, if they can see that we are real people, that we have some desire to understand their system, that may help to accelerate the process of change over there.'' **********The organizing group, which also include Representatives Thomas J. Downey of Long Island and Charlie Rose of North Carolina, Democrats, and Jim Leach of Iowa and E. Clay Shaw of Florida, Republicans, discussed the project here in December with a visiting Supreme Soviet delegation. **********Under the guidance of Prof. William L. Uri of Harvard, they negotiated the broadcasts in exhaustive detail. It was a day, said Representative Schneider, of ''getting beyond posturing.'' Editing May Be a Problem **********One concern, Representative Shaw said, was that of the editing process. **********''In order not to put everyone to sleep,'' he said, ''the two-and-a-half-hour talks are going to have to be edited down, so we have agreed on a joint editing body. We will just have to see how it works. If they turn it into a progaganda tool to twist what we say and just make them look good, we will have to take another look at it.'' **********The series, co-produced by the Soviet Government's State Committee for Television and Radio, and Internews, a nonprofit television production company, are expected to have different formats and may include some live broadcasts, but the first one, on differences between the two political systems, will be taped. **********The second broadcast, planned for May, will take up arms control, with later programs focusing on human rights and regional conflicts. **********Mr. Brown said he believed it was possible to have a dialogue on such divisive issues without resorting to grandstanding or polemics. **********''They don't want to talk about human rights and we don't want to talk about Nicaragua,'' he said, ''so we have compromised, and we are going to talk about both.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Picking Stocks After the Selloff
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Picking Stocks After the Selloff
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/busin.body_text: **********THERE'S nothing like a record-sized crack in equity prices to send Wall Street's research departments back to the drawing board for a fresh set of stock selections. **********And now, after the huge selloff in late October, two dominant themes have emerged. First, there is a flight to quality, or an emphasis on companies with strong managements, healthy balance sheets and liquidity, or large equity capitalizations. Second, many of the new favorites are viewed as benefiting from the lower interest rates and slower economic growth generally envisaged for 1988 as an aftermath of the stock market slump. **********A popular choice at several investment firms is American Telephone and Telegraph, which repeatedly has been viewed as a safe haven in times of market distress.  Prudential-Bache Securities came up with a list of equities that, in the opinion of its analysts, is ''mostly likely to outperform the market during difficult times.'' The firm expects a slowdown in economic growth for 1988 - but no recession. **********Recommended to Prudential-Bache's customers as ''some first-class tickets for your flight to quality'' were 37 stocks. In electric utilities, the choices were Public Service Enterprise Group, Southern California Edison and General Public Utilities. Packaged-food favorites were Campbell Soup, Kellogg and Kraft. The drug selections were Bristol-Myers, Schering-Plough, Squibb and Upjohn Recommendations in other groups ranged from Ford Motor, Anheuser-Busch and American International Group to Mobil, Dow Chemical and Rite Aid. **********E. F. Hutton & Company also revised downward its expectations for the economy. Looking ahead to next year, Jeffrey M. Applegate, Hutton's chief investment strategist, said, ''Quite simply, we are now looking for lower everything: growth, inflation, consumer spending and corporate profits.'' **********As a result, the firm emphasizes companies that should fare better in a slow-growth economy and said it also ''is taking a step back'' from companies that would benefit from speedier economic growth. **********Along with A.T.&T., Hutton added these stocks to its emphasis list: Bankers Trust, Bell Atlantic, Consolidated Natural Gas, Golden West Financial, J. P. Morgan, Panhandle Eastern, Parker-Hannifin, Procter & Gamble, Schlumberger, Sonat, Union Camp, CPC International and Kellogg. **********In a move away from the more cyclical, or economically sensitive, stocks, the firm deleted numerous former selections. These included Carter-Wallace, Caterpillar, Charming Shoppes, Great Northern Nekoosa, Kennametal, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, Motorola, Reynolds Metals, TRW and Union Carbide, among others.  For its model balanced portfolio, Hutton also changed the asset allocation. It reduced the equity exposure from 60 percent to 50 percent, raised the bond portion from 25 percent to 35 percent and left the cash segment unchanged at 15 percent. **********The stock market's vicious October decline also has caused Alex. Brown & Sons in Baltimore to emphasize interest-sensitive issues for the first time in about a year, according to William L. Paternotte, director of research. Now the firm looks with favor upon insurance stocks, regional banks andsavings and loan institutions - sectors that benefit from lower interest rates. **********''Examples of the kinds of stocks we are recommending,'' Mr. Paternotte said, ''are Hartford National, First Union Corporation, Rouse Company, USF&G Corporation and Northwestern National Life.'' **********While some firms made changes last week in their recommended lists, Salomon Brothers took a positive stance the night of Monday, Oct. 19, after the Dow Jones industrial average fell a record 508 points, or 22.6 percent. Adding nine stocks to its recommended list, the firm described these choices as ''buying America at a discount.'' The new recommendations - which still remain in force - were A.T.&T., Conrail, Ford, Gillette, International Business Machines, Masco, Schlumberger, Snap-On Tools and Trinova. More recently, the firm added USX and General Cinema to its list.  While conceeding the likelihood of slower economic growth ahead, Robert S. Salomon Jr., director of equity research, believes that ''the economy will show a good deal of resilience in 1988.'' He added: ''In our judgment, slower growth is not necessarily a negative for the stock market, since it may well extend the horizon of recovery.'' **********Last Friday, Advest Inc. recommended for purchase a list of what Richard Schmidt, director of research, described as ''fallen angels.'' The selections met certain criteria: minimum market capitalization of $1 billion, stable earnings growth, balance sheet quality - and sharp price declines between Sept. 30 and Oct. 28. **********Ranging across a wide spectrum, Advest's choices included Walt Disney, Telerate, Toys R Us, Rohm & Haas, Compaq Computer, Maytag, Sherwin-Williams, Loews and The Limited.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/world.main_headline: Guerrillas Report Defection Of Brother of Afghan Leader
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/world.print_headline: Guerrillas Report Defection Of Brother of Afghan Leader
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/27/world.body_text: **********A Pakistan-based Afghan guerrilla party said today that the younger brother of Afghanistan's Soviet-backed leader had defected to the guerrillas. **********A spokesman for the party, Jamiat-i-Islami, said the defector, Sidiq, and his wife were with its field commander, Ahmad Shah Masood, in the strategic Panjshir Valley north of Kabul, the capital. Mr. Sidiq is said to have been at odds with his brother Najibullah, the Afghan leader, for some time. **********The New York Times, quoting American intelligence reports and foreign diplomats, reported Tuesday that Mr. Sidiq had defected. At the time, Jamiat-i-Islami officials had not announced the defection. **********A spokesman for the party, Najibullah Lafraie, said a message had been received from Commander Masood saying Mr. Sidiq defected on Oct. 29. **********Mr. Lafraie said Mr. Sidiq was in his 30's and had been a vice president of a Government-run bank. He was also a member of the ruling People's Democratic Party.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/busin.main_headline: Prices Paid To Farmers Fell in July
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/busin.print_headline: Prices Paid To Farmers Fell in July
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/busin.body_text: **********After rising for six consecutive months, the prices that farmers get for raw products dropped 2.3 percent in July but still averaged 2.4 percent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today. **********Lower prices for oranges, corn and wheat more than offset higher prices in July for lettuce and calves, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report. **********John Buche of the department's National Agricultural Statistics Service said the decline in the index was the first since a 3.2 percent drop from last November to December. **********Beginning in January, he said, the ''prices received'' index increased each month, including a 1.6 percent increase in June. **********Prices for livestock and livestock products as a group were unchanged from June but averaged 4.9 percent more than a year ago. However, the all-crops price index dropped 4.5 percent in July from the level a year earlier, the report said. **********The preliminary July figures were based mostly on midmonth averages and are subject to revision. **********New quarterly figures showed that prices paid by farmers to meet expenses increased 1.2 percent from April and were up 3.1 percent from July 1986. **********Prices of food grains dropped 6.2 percent in July but still averaged 1.1 percent above a year ago, with declines reported for both wheat and rice. **********July commodity prices averaged 128 percent of a 1977 base used for comparison, according to the preliminary figures, down from 131 percent in June. A year ago, the July index was 125 percent. **********Consumer food prices are expected to continue rising, perhaps averaging 2 percent to 4 percent higher than in 1986, when they gained 3.2 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/06/busin.main_headline: Advanced Steel Mill Planned by Nucor
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Advanced Steel Mill Planned by Nucor
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/06/busin.body_text: **********The Nucor Corporation, the nation's ninth-largest steelmaker, said yesterday that it was building a $200 million mill to produce flat-rolled products using a new thin-slab process. The company said it expected the new plant to be completed in early 1989. **********The plant would produce sheet steel from two-inch slabs. The company said the process would be more efficient than methods used by its larger competitors, which produce steel from thicker slabs and require greater use of energy. **********''This would be the first thin-caster plant that has been attempted,'' said F. Kenneth Iverson, chairman of Nucor, which is based in Charlotte, N.C. ''So we don't anticipate things going without some problems initially.'' **********Mr. Iverson said that the company had purchased equipment for the continuous-casting plant, but that a site had not been selected. He said the plant would probably be in the South. **********Under the new process, steel coils would be made without the reheating functions of conventional mills. ''We will have big savings in energy costs with this new plant,'' Mr. Iverson said. ''Also, our labor costs should be lower because the production method will take fewer employees.'' **********Nucor's stock rose $2.625 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $33.875. **********Nucor has in recent years pushed to develop technologically sophisticated production methods, and it has achieved rising market penetration. **********The company produces bar, structural and specialty steel products using a continuous-casting method. The company's steel-making plants are exclusively in rural areas and its workers are not union members.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/09/busin.main_headline: International Report; Swiftly Rising Prices Alarm China's Leaders
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/09/busin.print_headline: International Report; Swiftly Rising Prices Alarm China's Leaders
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/09/busin.body_text: **********There is a new ugly word in China: inflation. **********China's leaders debated what to do about it at the recent Congress of the Communist Party. Newspapers have been running editorials about it. And people, aware of the increased supply of food and goods that accompany the higher prices, are discussing the pros and cons of inflation in markets and shops throughout the land. **********Inflation has begun to take root as China adapts to a wide range of free-market reforms introduced over the last few years. By one of the best measures available, prices rose more than 9 percent in the first six months of this year - a very large increase for this nation, which until two years ago had experienced annual inflation of only 1 percent or less for more than 30 years. **********Lately, however, prices have been rising so fast that they have brought charges of profiteering, consumer complaints and official action, such as price controls. Like punching a down-filled pillow, however, suppressing prices in one place merely seems to plump them up elsewhere. **********The current issue of the monthly China Statistical Reports shows that food prices in cities were 19.5 percent higher in the first six months of 1987 than a year earlier. Some commodities showed particularly dramatic increases. For instance, grain products were up 46.4 percent, while fresh vegetables rose 26.9 percent. **********Several Western diplomats who watch China's economy believe its inflation has been understated. ''They don't have an index for such things as intermediate goods, things like motors for washing machines,'' said one economist with a Western embassy. ''The in-house statistics of the People's Bank of China show a higher rate of inflation.'' **********The problem of rising prices has so alarmed China's leadership that the matter was one of the major topics at the 13th Congress of the Communist Party, which ended Nov. 1. **********In his opening address to the Congress on Oct. 25, Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang called for the eventual deregulation of virtually all prices. ''We should gradually establish a system under which the state sets the prices of a few vital commodities and labor services while leaving the rest to be regulated by the market,'' he said. **********While the party's Congress - the body that formally approves policies for the country - ratified Prime Minister Zhao's position, the degree to which deregulation is put into effect will depend greatly on his ability to overcome political opposition. **********Prices are seen as the key to whether economic reforms will succeed in this land that has been undergoing a dramatic economic upheaval under Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, who has just retired from the Central Committee of the Communist Party. Many Western economic analysts - and many Chinese, too - believe that China's economy must shift to a system in which prices more realistically reflect supply and demand if the nation is to overcome the inefficiencies of bureaucratic planning. **********But to this Communist nation's ideological purists, who are still a strong force, the alarming inflation rate is a sign of creeping capitalism. **********For some of the more rigid Marxists who have retired from the Central Committee but are still expected to influence policy - including Chen Yun, the 82-year-old craftsman of China's Soviet-style economy in the 1950's - ballooning inflation gives them rhetorical ammunition to attack the methods of reformers. Complaints About Prices **********''The old guys may not understand the relationship between the money supply and prices,'' a Western diplomat said, ''but they sure understand the complaints from the people.'' **********China's people like the wider availability of many foodstuffs and goods, but that does not mean they are happy about paying higher prices. ''Trying to sell inflation to the Chinese people is tough,'' one Western analyst said. ''Needless to say, they're skeptical of this.'' **********However, the Government has managed to protect most workers by raising wages. According to the overseas edition of Liaowang (''Outlook''), a general interest weekly, wages have risen 120 percent in the last eight years. A Western economist in Beijing estimates that wages climbed 20 percent in urban areas last year and are up as much as 17 percent this year. **********Even such entrenched reformers as Mr. Deng and Prime Minister Zhao have been willing to tolerate a temporary tightening of consumer price controls as a way of marshaling their forces, allaying consumer complaints and mollifying some of the hard-line party members. Control of Basic Factors **********The reformers also have called for more sophisticated control over elements of the economy that can fuel inflation, such as the money supply. Major banks, in both urban and rural areas, have announced tighter control over loans. **********Indeed, no matter what people think of the economic reforms, they see inflation as a matter of national concern. Deputy Prime Minister Yao Yilin has spoken with urgency about surging prices. ''Price fluctuations are still a problem which is caused by an imbalance between supply and demand,'' he said bluntly at a meeting on national planning last month. ''We could face big problems in China's economic development and reform if we fail to solve this problem.'' **********But a sizable and growing number of younger party people, committed to reform, are distressed by the price controls that the Government has imposed. They reason - correctly in the eyes of Western economists - that the controls do nothing but forestall the need to address broad economic adjustments. **********All reformers agree that economic growth is not possible in the long term without deregulation of prices throughout the economy. Increase Called 'Inevitable' **********Prof. Xiao Zhuoji, a member of the economics faculty at Beijing University, said China's inflation rate, while too high, is a natural consequence of reshaping the economy. ''The increase in prices is inevitable,'' he said, ''because of the unreasonable pricing in the past. It is normal, and it promotes production. In the past, prices were stable, but people couldn't find what they needed.'' **********For this reason, the Government seems to be having some trouble enforcing its price controls. If it is a choice between paying higher prices or having nothing to buy, consumers, shopkeepers and market managers all seem to prefer higher prices. **********On the first day of September, Yao Wenhuan posted fixed prices for tomatoes, cucumbers, garlic and corn on a notice board in the center of the Yonganli market that he manages. But the prices were so low that farmers just stopped carting in their produce to sell. Only near the end of September, after Mr. Yao had torn down the price list, did the vegetable growers reappear.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/14/busin.body_text: **********Business sales, aided by a year-end spurt of car buying, jumped 2.9 percent in December and inventories fell five-tenths of 1 percent, the largest decline in more than three years, the Commerce Department said today. **********The department said that inventories held on shelves and in backlots dropped to $587.17 billion in December, after adjusting for normal seasonal variations. This decline was the largest since a fall of six-tenths of 1 percent in March 1983. **********Business sales rose to $448.31 billion, posting the best monthly gain since a 3 percent rise in September. Sales were unchanged in November. Auto Sales a Factor **********The big gain in sales and the steep drop in inventories were both tied to automobiles, analysts said. **********Auto sales jumped sharply as consumers rushed to make purchases while they still qualified for sales tax deductions, a tax advantage eliminated under the new tax law. An Optimistic View **********Normally, such a steep fall in inventories would lead to hopes for increased production and higher employment in coming months. But analysts said the big December drop was less meaningful because January statistics had already indicated a big decline in auto sales for that month. **********''We are seeing little strength in the economy,'' said Michael Evans, head of a Washington forecasting firm. ''Consumer durables and spending for business equipment, two key sectors of the economy, are weak, and I think they will remain weak.'' **********But Doug Handler, chief forecaster for Wharton Econometrics of Philadelphia, said the inventory figures were showing no unwanted buildup of goods and should translate into higher production figures. **********He noted that the ratio of inventories to sales took a sharp dive in December, to 1.31 months, meaning it would take that long to exhaust existing inventories at the December sales pace. This was down from an already low 1.35 months in November. **********''Usually a drop in the inventory-to-sales ratio is a very clear signal that strong economic expansion is coming down the road,'' Mr. Handler said. **********The decline in inventories was led by a 1.2 percent dip in stockpiles held by retailers. Inventories at the manufacturing and wholesale level were down two-tenths of 1 percent.  BUSINESS INVENTORIES AND SALES  Billions of dollars, seasonally adjusted              Dec.   Nov. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/24/world.print_headline: 7 Skiers Killed in Avalanche In Wilds of British Columbia
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/24/world.body_text: **********Seven members of a ski party were killed by an avalanche today in the remote mountains near here, authorities said. **********Ten people, including a guide, had been on a tour run by Mike Wiegele Helicopter Skiing, according to a Royal Canadian Mounted Police spokesman in Clearwater, about 60 miles south of this tiny community. **********The guide and two others managed to escape the avalanche in the rugged Monashee range, about 260 miles northeast of Vancouver. **********Mr. Wiegele, whose company arranged the trip, said the skiers were traversing a run single file when a wall of snow about 3 feet thick and up to about 500 feet wide rolled toward them. **********Constable Pat Pearce of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said the avalanche dragged the skiers about a half mile down the mountain. The bodies were found by the survivors and another ski group about three hours later, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/18/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Issues Rise Slightly
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/18/busin.body_text: **********Strength in the dollar continued to spill over into the bond market, where prices of Treasury issues rose modestly in light trading yesterday. **********By late in the day, the closely watched 8 3/4 percent Treasury bonds due in 2017 were offered at 103 29/32, up 17/32, to yield 8.39 percent. It was the highest closing price in New York for the new 30-year issue, though slightly below the peak level set yesterday in Tokyo. As recently as May 21, the 8 3/4 percent issue was trading around 97 with a yield of 9.05 percent. **********Improved investor demand and falling interest rates have encouraged more corporations to sell corporate issues. Although activity remains below the level of March, when nearly $16.8 billion of new issues were offered, at least six new issues totaling $765 million were offered yesterday. Another $500 million of collateralized mortgage obligations were also offered. Federal Reserve Purchases **********Besides hopes that the dollar's strength will attract more foreign buyers, market participants said Treasury prices were supported by purchases by the Federal Reserve of notes and bonds for its own account. The Fed's purchases were anticipated and did not signal any change in monetary policy. **********The Treasury's announcement of a three-part note financing next week also buoyed the markets. The size of each issue was reduced $250 million from the similar financing three months ago, and was a reminder that the Treasury's borrowing needs have been greatly reduced by the drop in the budget deficit to around $170 billion in the current fiscal year from more than $220 billion in the fiscal year 1986. **********The Treasury said it would auction $9.75 billion of two-year notes next Tuesday, $7.5 billion of four-year notes on Wednesday and $7 billion of seven-year notes on Thursday. Late yesterday, securities dealers offered the new two-year issue at about 7.37 percent, the four-year issue at 7.70 percent and the seven-year at 8.03 percent. **********''The new supply is a hurdle for the market, but a lot of institutions, including some Japanese, see it as a buying opportunity, though they will try to be quiet about their intentions,'' said Philip Braverman, a vice president at Irving Securities Inc. Fears of Inflation **********The Irving analyst said that the dollar's stability ''is not just a short-term phenomenon'' and that market participants are recognizing that their earlier fears of inflation are overstated. As data accumulate showing that the economy is not continuing to expand at the brisk pace of the first quarter, he said, the Federal Reserve might eventually encourage a modest drop in overnight interest rates. **********Not all experts share Mr. Braverman's optimism, especially regarding the future of the dollar. **********Rainer Gut, chairman of Credit Suisse, said in a speech to the National Press Club in Washington that the dollar might remain stable, or even strengthen for the next few months. But he said the American trade deficit remains so large that ''the basic trend of the dollar over the next couple years is down.'' **********While activity in the corporate market has increased recently, interest rates are still uncomfortably high for many potential borrowers. **********The Pacific Gas and Electric Corporation, for example, yesterday postponed a $250 million sale of 30-year bonds. In May, Pacific Gas and Electric delayed a similar financing, only to reappear a week later after interest rates had dropped about 1/4 percentage point. **********In the mortgage market, officials at Salomon Brothers said they had placed with investors a two-part $127 million mortgage financing divided into senior and subordinated pieces. Mortgages have previously been used to back packages of senior and subordinated securities, but the issuers were required to retain the subordinated portion, at least initially. **********The new financing by the Residential Funding Corporation was the first of its kind where both the senior and subordinated portions were sold to investors. The ability to divide a pool of mortgages into various classes of securities was hailed by securities dealers as one of the primary benefits of legislation last year that created real estate mortgage investment conduits. Selling a subordinated class of securities is an alternative to purchasing mortgage pool and special hazard insurance, analysts said. Home Mortgage Pool **********Holders of the subordinated securities will bear the loss from delinquencies and defaults on the pool of conventional 15-year home mortgages up to the amount of their investment, which was $6.35 million, or 5 percent of the mortgage pool. Because of that risk, the subordinated issue, which was not rated and was privately placed with thrift institutions and life insurance companies, was sold with an interest rate of around 13 percent. The 95 percent of the pool consisting of senior securities was sold two months ago, is rated double A, and trades in line with other high-quality mortgage pass-through securities. **********Elsewhere in the mortgage securities market, officials at the First Boston Corporation offered $500 million of collateralized mortgage obligations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/10/busin.body_text: **********Finance Secretary Jaime Ongpin hinted he would resign if the Philippine Congress repudiated any of the country's foreign debt. **********''I don't want the responsibility for a debt repudiation policy on my shoulders, because in my judgment the consequences would be beyond the ability of this Government to control,'' Mr. Ongpin said Saturday. **********He told reporters that a debt repudiation would isolate the country in the international financial community and cripple the Government's economic recovery program. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/09/busin.body_text: **********Repeatedly over the last seven years, the Reagan Administration has expressed hopes of creating a North American common market that would link the United States and its neighbors. But in concluding a bilateral commercial accord here on Friday, Mexico and the United States showed that an enormous gap remains between that dream and current reality. **********The agreement, signed by the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, and his Mexican counterpart, culminates six years of negotiations between the two countries. It establishes a nonbinding mechanism to resolve trade and investment disputes and calls for annual Cabinet-level consulations between the two Governments. **********The pact with Mexico comes a month after the United States and Canada signed a sweeping trade agreement that, if approved, would end tariffs by the end of the century. As Mr. Yeutter, speaking in Spanish, noted Friday, the two accords are ''very different'' and illustrate what he called ''the many obvious barriers'' that stand in the way of continent-wide economic integration. Gap in Economies Cited **********Mexico's Minister of Commerce and Industrial Development, Hector Hernandez Cervantes, addressed that point directly when, after signing the trade accord, he pointed out that the American and Canadian economies are ''at the same level'' of development. ''But with Mexico, in relation to the United States, that is not exactly so,'' he added. **********The result of that gap is that Mexico is ambivalent about the benefits of closer and more formal commercial links with the United States. On one level, the American agreement with Canada ''gave the Mexicans a great deal of heartburn,'' one diplomat here said, because ''it reinforced their preoccupation with a North American common market from which they would be excluded.'' **********But the burst of optimism that followed the Canadian agreement has also reawakened traditional Mexican suspicions that the United States has designs on its natural resources and productive capacity. For the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, which presents itself as a defender of ''national sovereignty,'' the issue is especially delicate and potentially explosive with an election year looming. New Common Market Sentiment **********In fact, when initial reports from Washington following the Canadian accord indicated a resurgence of common-market sentiment, the reaction in the press and in political circles here was so strong that Foreign Minister Bernardo Sepulveda Amor was compelled to assure the Mexican Congress that no such arrangement was in the works. He said the Mexico agreement was modest in scale and limited in scope. **********''This is not, I repeat, an agreement that will lead to a free trade plan between the United States and Mexico, nor is it an agreement that will lead to the establishment of a North American common market.'' Mr. Sepulveda said. ''It is merely and exclusively an understanding that contains principles to begin consultations on matters of trade and investment.'' **********Traditionally, Mexico has been the third-largest trading partner of the United States, after Canada and Japan. Mexican exports to the United States reached $17.7 billion in 1986, while Mexican imports amounted to $12.5 billion, according to American Embassy statistics. **********A little more than two thirds of all Mexican imports are supplied by the United States, and 62 percent of Mexico's exports go to the American market. The United States is also the largest foreign investor in Mexico, with $10.1 billion, or 60 percent of all foreign investment as of 1986. Resistance to Change **********When talks on the trade agreement first began, the United States had hoped Mexico would ease restrictions on foreign investment and make its regulations more flexible and ''transparent.'' But Mexico proved resistant to fundamental changes, and the matter has been deferred to the next round of trade consulations, scheduled to begin in 90 days. **********''We are not ready for such an arrangement,'' said one Mexican official who deals in trade issues. ''It is somewhat precipitate to be talking of such things, given the differences that exist.'' But Mexico is not alone in its reservations on the subject of a common market. While the Reagan Administration favors free trade, it is more reluctant to open up some other areas of interest to Mexico. **********As Mexican officials point out, a true common market implies free movement of labor as well as of investments. The United States, they contend, pointing to recent legislation aimed at curbing flows of illegal immigration, is simply not prepared to accept millions of Mexicans crossing the border to work in American factories, offices and farms. Some Progress Made **********Some progress, however, has been made toward integrating the two economies. The most notable and promising example is a program that permits American companies to assemble materials in Mexico and then send them back across the border for final processing, avoiding high duties while making use of cheaper Mexican labor. **********More than 1,000 such plants now operate in Mexico, mostly along the northern border. But officials of both countries now seem to recognize that the United States and Mexico are decades away from achieving the relationship of mutual confidence and equality that the United States maintains with Canada. **********''This is something that must evolve,'' Mr. Yeutter said of closer ties with Mexico. ''It is necessary to study, evaluate and analyze this year by year.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/20/world.main_headline: CAPTAIN OF STARK AND TWO OTHERS RELIEVED OF DUTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/20/world.print_headline: CAPTAIN OF STARK AND TWO OTHERS RELIEVED OF DUTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/20/world.body_text: **********The captain of the frigate Stark and two other officers were relieved of duty today because of their performance during an attack on the ship last month by an Iraqi jet in the Persian Gulf. **********The Pentagon said the senior military commander responsible for the region, Gen. George B. Crist, had taken the step ''based on his lack of confidence'' in the men. **********General Crist, who is a Marine officer, also forwarded to the Navy and the Defense Department the report of a naval board of inquiry into the episode, in which the Stark took no action to defend herself and 37 sailors were killed. **********The action today left open the possibility that the officers, who had been named as ''interested parties,'' or subjects, of the investigation, will be court-martialed by the Navy. No Action on 4th Officer **********The officers who were relieved of duty were Capt. Glenn R. Brindel, the ship's skipper; Lieut. Cmdr. Raymond J. Gajan Jr., the executive officer, or second in command, and Lieut. Basil E. Moncrief Jr., the tactical action officer, who was in charge of the ship's combat functions during the episode on the night of May 17. **********No action was taken against a fourth, unidentified officer, who was responsible for some of the ship's weapon systems and had also been named as a party to the investigation, conducted by Rear Adm. Grant Sharp. **********In the board's investigation, which took place in Bahrain, where the badly damaged Stark is under repair, the Navy learned that Captain Brindel left the bridge a few minutes before the Stark was struck by two Exocet missiles, in what was described by Iraq and the United States as an mistaken attack. Failed to Maneuver Ship **********In the captain's absence, the other officers in charge of the ship's operations failed to take a series of actions that might have prevented the attack or allowed the Stark to use her sophisticated anti-missile weapons to defend herself. For example, they waited too long before signaling the ship's identity to the approaching Iraqi plane, and they failed to execute standard air-defense maneuvers such as turning the ship to give her guns a clear shot at the missiles. **********As these facts were disclosed in recent weeks, Navy officers have privately commented that the ship's captain and other officers might be found culpable. The Navy traditionally holds ships' officers directly responsible for everything, including accidents, that occurs under their command. **********The decision to relieve the officers of duty was made today, the Pentagon said, after General Crist arrived in Washington to discuss the matter with qother senior Pentagon officials. As commander in chief of the Central Command, which is responsible for deploying military forces to the Persian Gulf region, where the United States has no permanent installations, the Marine general is based in Florida and has authority over units drawn from all the military services. Courts-Martial Up to Navy **********General Crist has decided to leave up to the Navy the question whether to press court-martial charges against the officers he relieved. If the Navy decides to press charges, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger will personally review the recommendation, officials said. **********Captain Brindel, who has been an officer for almost 22 years, had commanded the Stark for just over two years. He was due to be given a new assignment soon, but the announcement today made clear that his replacement was a rebuke. He will be replaced as skipper of the Stark by Cmdr. John B. Noll, the Navy said. **********The three officers affected by the action today are now in Bahrain. Captain Brindel's previous orders to join a testing organization in Norfolk, Va., have been postponed until resolution of his case. In the meantime, he has been assigned to the staff of the Atlantic Fleet in Norfolk. Commander Gajan and Lieutenant Moncrief have been assigned to staff positions in Mayport, Fla., the Stark's home port.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/29/world.main_headline: Haitians Voting Today on a New Way of Life
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/29/world.print_headline: Haitians Voting Today on a New Way of Life
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/29/world.body_text: **********In the most decrepit slums of this impoverished country and in the cool hills where the rich live in luxurious villas, there was a rare mood of ebullience today as people prepared to vote Sunday on a constitution that defines a new way of life in Haiti. **********The new constitution contains dozens of specific measures creating obstacles to any future dictatorship and promising personal liberties and such previously nonexistent features as the right to free education, decent housing and a fair day's pay. **********It creates an independent commission to conduct presidential elections, scheduled for November, and bars from participation in the elections anyone in the armed forces as well anyone closely associated with the Duvalier family dictatorship, which ruled Haiti with an iron hand for nearly 30 years. **********The constitution may not be able to deliver all it promises in a poor country with no democratic tradition. But in contrast to the timid interim Government that has presided since street protests brought down President Jean-Claude Duvalier in February 1986, the new constitution has given voice to the Haitians' most passionate hopes and is expected to be approved by a wide margin. **********''People like it because it embodies the spirit of the revolution,'' a foreign diplomat said. **********''It is a useful healing document,'' he said. ''It may not be a useful operating document.'' **********The most influential political groups have given their endorsement, and the Roman Catholic Church, a key shaper of public opinion, has issued a veiled statement that is being widely interpreted as supportive. **********Eighteen small nationalist and leftist groups are urging abstention from voting, and at least two leftist organizations have threatened protest demonstrations. There have been reports that some of those who were close to the deposed dictator have been campaigning against the constitution, warning that its approval would open the way for a Communist takeover of Haiti. **********But Leslie Manigat, a former professor of political science and one of the leading candidates for president, said he believed approval was a certainty. **********''I don't see how anybody can change the overwhelming trend toward a yes vote,'' he said in an interview at his headquarters. **********The most common objection to the constitution is that in their zeal to protect Haiti from the evils of the past, the authors may have created a government so hobbled with checks and balances that it cannot govern. Power is distributed among a president, a prime minister, a chamber of deputies and a senate. How they will relate to each other is not entirely clear. **********Many political leaders said they were temporarily putting aside the question of how the government would work and accepting the constitution as a tool for guiding the country through the transition to an elected president. **********The provisional Government suspended the last Duvalier Constitution and has been governing by decree. **********''Without this constitution there are no rules of the game,'' Mr. Manigat said. ''We just leap into the unknown.'' **********Some oppose the constitution because it formally establishes the provisional administration as the official government until Feb. 7, 1988, when the next president is to be inaugurated. This, critics say, further entrenches a de facto government. The constitution also, for the first time, recognizes the universally spoken Creole as an official language, along with French, and eliminates a widely ignored curb on the practice of voodoo, the blend of Catholicism and African beliefs unique to Haiti. **********Fair elections have been rare in Haiti's history, and the referendum is regarded as a learning exercise. **********Last October, in the country's first election since the fall of the dictatorship, there was great skepticism and little publicity, and fewer than 10 percent of those eligible voted. **********But excitement built as the 40 people who were chosen then, along with 20 appointed by the interim Government, worked for several months on drafting the constitution in sessions that were broadcast live over national radio.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/12/busin.body_text: **********Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company will take their tangled, three-year-old legal dispute before the United States Supreme Court on Monday. **********At issue is whether lower Federal courts acted correctly last year in ruling that Texaco did not have to put up a $12 billion bond before proceeding with its legal battle with Pennzoil in Texas. Texaco has said that if it had to put up the bond it would be forced into bankruptcy. **********The Supreme Court is not expected to rule on the issue for six months or more. The Monday hearing will be closely watched for any indication of how the justices may be leaning in their views on the highly publicized case. If there is any indication of how the case may be decided, it could increase or decrease pressure on the two companies to negotiate a deal. Suit Filed in 1984 **********Pennzoil sued Texaco a month after Texaco reached an agreement to acquire the Getty Oil Company in January 1984. Pennzoil argued that Texaco's action breached a previous, verbal agreement Pennzoil had to merge with Getty, and asked for $15 billion in damages. **********After a trial lasting more than four months, a jury in Houston unanimously ruled in favor of Pennzoil on Nov. 19, 1985. Three weeks later, a Texas district judge entered a judgment of $10.53 billion against Texaco, the nation's third-largest oil company, after Exxon and Mobil. **********It was the biggest damage award in history, causing many Texaco supporters to question the fairness of the Texas judiciary. With interest mounting at $2.6 million a day from its effective date of Jan. 5, 1985, the total judgment facing Texaco is now approaching $12.5 billion. **********Under Texas law, Texaco was required to post a bond in the amount of the judgment, plus interest, to appeal the ruling. But Texaco, arguing that a bond of that magnitude would push it into bankruptcy before it could press its appeal, avoided possible calamity when a Federal judge in White Plains, Charles L. Brieant, ruled that Texaco did not have to post the bond. Instead, he required security of $1 billion, which Texaco posted on Feb. 5. Court 'Intrusion' Cited **********The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Manhattan, agreed with Judge Brieant on Feb. 21. Pennzoil then asked the Supreme Court to review the decision, arguing that the Federal courts made ''an unprecedented intrusion'' into the procedures of Texas courts by eliminating the Texaco bond. **********In its brief, Texaco countered that it was ''within days of bankruptcy,'' and therefore unable to exercise its right to appeal, before the bond requirement was lifted. It argued that Pennzoil's request for a Supreme Court review was mainly an effort to increase pressure on Texaco to settle the case. **********Although the two companies have discussed settling the case without further court action, Baine Kerr, a Pennzoil director and former president, said late last week that no serious talks were now under way. He said officials of both companies had talked by telephone recently, but no meetings had taken place. A Texaco spokesman, Lois Johnston, said the company's policy was not to comment on its dealings with Pennzoil in relation to the case. Texas Ruling Awaited **********Meanwhile, the two companies are awaiting a ruling from the Texas First Court of Appeals on Texaco's effort to have the verdict against it and the $10.53 billion judgment overturned. A source close to the case said the Houston appellate court had informed both sides before New Year's Day that a decision was imminent. **********Texaco has said it would appeal the case to the Texas Supreme Court and the United States Supreme Court, if necessary. **********Still, a ruling against Texaco by the Texas appellate court would likely increase Texaco's incentives to settle the case, Wall Street analysts said, adding that Texaco probably would not fare better with the Texas Supreme Court. There was little agreement, however, on the likely size of a settlement, with estimates varying from as little as $1 billion to as much as $5 billion. **********Kathryn Cox, clerk of the First Court of Appeals, said Friday that a ruling could be issued any day. The court ''is trying to get it out,'' she said. **********The appellate court has had the case since August, and had been expected to rule as early as October. The months of waiting have prompted speculation about the possibility of unresolved disputes among the judges, and the prospect that they may want to review Monday's hearing for any sentiment by the Supreme Court justices. **********One source close to the case said that if the justices express skepticism about the verdict against Texaco and the size of the damages, the appellate court might decide to reconsider its position. On the other hand, a tough questioning of Texaco's position might suggest an acceptance of Pennzoil's arguments. **********Laurence H. Tribe, a professor of constitutional law at Harvard, will be the sole representative speaking for Pennzoil. David Boies, a prominent trial lawyer with Cravath, Swain & Moore, in New York, will argue Texaco's position. **********The stock prices of both companies continue to reflect the legal battle. Texaco's shares closed Friday at $38, up $1.25 for the week, on the New York Stock Exchange. Pennzoil closed at $68.50, off 25 cents for the week. **********Barry C. Good, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company, said James W. Kinnear, who became Texaco's president and chief executive on Jan. 1, may want to move quickly ''to get this settled'' after the Texas Court of Appeals rules. **********At Pennzoil, J. Hugh Liedtke, chairman and chief executive, reaches his 65th birthday on Feb. 10. The company has made no statement about a change in leadership, and Mr. Liedtke said last year he planned to stay active until the litigation was resolved.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/24/busin.body_text: **********Yesterday's record stock market activity left brokers breathless - and eagerly hoping for more. **********The New York Stock Exchange said it had no trouble handling the unprecedented volume, and said stockbrokers had also apparently weathered the storm. **********''Based on the soundings we're hearing, there are no problems,'' Richard A. Grasso, executive vice president, operations and capital markets, said of the stockbrokers. **********While there may have been few glitches with the computer system, some traders reported that some specialists, whose responsibility it is to maintain a smooth market in specific stocks on the floor of the exchange, were swamped by the violent price swings. If problems from the price fluctuations were severe enough, it might strain the capital of these small firms. **********Unlike yesterday's trading of 302 million shares, less than 20 years ago, a sudden 16-million-share day was enough to force exchanges to close one day a week for several weeks at a time, so that overwhelmed clerks could catch up on their paperwork. **********Explaining the smooth handling by brokers nowadays, Mr. Grasso said: ''Much of the problems of 1968-1971 dealt with the movement of paper. But in the last 15 years, we've had two major changes: a significant investment in technology and the immobilization by institutions and brokers of more than $400 billion in stock certificates.'' **********As for the exchange itself, Arthur W. Samansky, spokesman, said the Big Board had invested more than $200 million in technology in the last seven years to handle heavy volume. **********''Our system has been tested at a volume in excess of 400 million shares - without a problem - and it worked today at over 302 million shares with absolutely no technical problems,'' he said. **********The exchange said the volume of trading yesterday alone soared to more than 302 million shares, shattering the previous record of 253.1 million shares set only eight days earlier. **********Volume for the week set a new high of 1.06 billion shares, breaking the record established a week earlier when it reached 1.04 billion shares. That was the first time in history that trading volume crossed the 1-billion-share barrier for just one week.

Salorio, both executive vice presidents, for finance and law, respectively. **********Additionally there is a new managment committee approved by the board. Its chairman is also Mr. Johnston and its members are Mr. Cronin; the two new members of the office of the chief executive; Michael Cooper Evans, a former member of the office; of the chief executive; Michael Cooper Evans, a former member of the office; Stephen G. Bowen Jr., president of the domestic company; Ronald S. Burns, president in Canada; Lee Pavao, president in Latin America, and Don Thompson, president in the Asia-Pacific region. **********The last two men have just replaced W. Lee Preschel, who departed the company last week after 30 years and had held both of those titles. **********Mr. Cronin, 55 years old, will be chairman of two new committees, the Creative Standards Group and the Planning Standards Committee, which will monitor the company's approach to planning and creative advertising.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/21/world.main_headline: Reports of Psychiatry Abuse Counter Talk of a Soviet Shift
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/21/world.print_headline: Reports of Psychiatry Abuse Counter Talk of a Soviet Shift
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/21/world.body_text: **********A political dissident recently released from a Soviet psychiatric hospital said today that the habitual use of punitive psychiatric treatment in the Soviet Union remained unchanged despite recent criticisms of such practices in the Soviet press. **********''There are no changes,'' said the dissident, Vladimir Titov. ''On the contrary, it's getting nastier.'' Mr. Titov was released Oct. 9 from the special psychiatric hospital in the Russian city of Oryel. **********Mr. Titov said his most vivid recollections were of two strong psychotropic drugs that caused fever, pain, slurred speech and left him unable to lie, sit or stand comfortably. He also spoke movingly of dissidents still inside, while other human rights advocates at the news conference played a tape of another patient, Sirvard Avakian, an Armenian dissident, asking in a trembling voice for Western help in releasing her from what she described as the abuse of her doctors. **********This account of the dark side of the Soviet psychiatric system - which differs hardly at all from the horror stories told a decade ago by a dissident psychiatrist, Anatoly Koryagin, and other human rights advocates - comes just as Soviet medical authorities seem eager to rehabilitate their image. **********Two events of the last year seemed, to some observers, to offer Soviet doctors a chance to end their five-year ostracism from the world psychiatric profession. A Series of Articles **********The first was Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, or openness, which this year produced a series of articles in the Soviet press detailing unsanitary and crowded conditions in psychiatric hospitals, and revealing the practice of doctors' accepting bribes from criminals in return for a diagnosis of mental illness - saving the criminals from serving sentences in labor camps. **********Most surprising was an Izvestia article that described with outrage instances of local police and bureaucrats who tried to force the psychiatric commitment of two women who had simply argued too long with authorities. One was committed and one evaded it by barring herself in her bedroom while the family fended off doctors and their aides. **********''Although the subject of the article isn't dissidents,'' the Soviet historian Roy A. Medvedev said in a recent interview, ''the mechanics of psychiatric abuse become perfectly clear because in these articles the diagnoses are disputed.'' **********''And if this sort of thing can be done to an average woman who complains about simple matters, it's all the easier to do it to a dissident,'' he added. **********Another article, in the weekly ideological journal Arguments and Facts, said that in 1985, 1,923 of every 100,000 Soviet citizens were registered as having psychiatric disorders, indicating that more than 5 million in the country have such disorders. **********The other supposed opening for changes in Soviet psychiatry came with the death last summer of Andrei V. Snezhnevsky, the Soviet psychiatrist widely seen as being responsible for designing and defending a system of diagnosis that equated nonconformity with illness. **********To some experts, Dr. Snezhnevsky's death offered Soviet doctors a chance to repudiate his legacy and construct a new theoretical underpinning for Soviet psychiatry. There has even been a recent suggestion, during Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's recent visit to the United States, that Soviet psychiatrists might strike from their textbooks a key Snezhnevsky diagnosis. **********This diagnosis, called ''sluggish schizophrenia,'' is said to manifest itself in obsessive desires ''to seek social justice'' and said to be camouflaged by seemingly normal behavior. It was this diagnosis that was made in the case of Mr. Medvedev's twin brother, Zhores, during his brief forced commitment in the early 1970's, and also in the cases of the women profiled in the Izvestia article. **********Leading doctors who have long defended Soviet psychiatry took umbrage at the Izvestia article, responding in an interview with the Novosti press agency that both the women in question were indeed ill. **********''In the instances described, the two women were in conflict with many people,'' said Marat Vartanyan, a corresponding member of the Soviet Academy of Medical Sciences. ''They suffered themselves and caused suffering to others. They not only made unsupported complaints but accused others of conspiracies.'' **********''Psychiatrists have a duty to safeguard society from disorganizing and sometimes dangerous steps by the insane,'' Dr. Vartanyan added. Transfer Is Considered **********Dissidents assert that the K.G.B. runs the system - an accusation supported by the fact that the Ministry of Internal Affairs controls the 18 special psychiatric hospitals. However, there have been reports in the Soviet press that authorities are considering transferring this responsibility to the Ministry of Health, already responsible for the management of ''ordinary'' psychiatric hospitals and clinics. **********And the doctors interviewed by Novosti said a new law was being formulated to delineate mentally ill persons' rights to housing and employment, and to clarify procedures for involuntary examinations and hospitalization. **********But Mr. Titov and members of the Frankfurt-based International Committee on Human Rights, whose Moscow branch sponsored today's press conference, argue that management or theoretical changes will have no effect on curbing psychiatric abuse, any more than the recent release of several dozen dissidents in psychiatric hospitals. **********''The structure doesn't have to be changed,'' said Aleksandr Podribinek, who has written a book on Soviet psychiatric practices. ''Psychiatric abuse is the result of bad politics, not bad psychiatry. To stop abuse we have to change the politics.'' K.G.B. Came to Hospital **********If the diagnosis of ''sluggish schizophrenia'' were eliminated, he said, ''this might be taken as a sign of some change - but a very unreliable one -and they're committing healthy people using other diagnoses as well.'' **********Mr. Titov said that when he was released from the hospital Oct. 9, ''it was the K.G.B. who came to the psychiatric hospital to talk to me and to try and persuade me to give up my convictions.'' **********Mr. Titov, whose 1982 reports of convict labor on the Siberian gas pipeline were cited as partial justification of the American-led embargo on pipeline equipment, said he was freed on condition that he immediately emigrate to Israel. Mr. Titov, who is not Jewish, has no relatives in Israel. **********In general, Mr. Titov and other members of the committee said Monday, dissidents evoke particular ire on the part of authorities and are often given harsher punitive ''treatment,'' in the form of injections, than the other inmates of the country's 18 special psychiatric hospitals. **********Mr. Titov spent the last five years in psychiatric hospitals as a result of the pipeline revelations, and in total has spent 12 of the last 18 years in such confinement. **********Sergei Grigoryants, the editor of the magazine Glasnost, said yesterday he could not estimate the scope of psychiatric abuse in the Soviet Union, but added that anecdotal information about recent commitments led him to believe the system is still widely abused. **********''We're not doctors,'' added Vladimir Pimonov, a member of the human rights group. ''We can't say that all these people who are committed are healthy. But to shut them in a special psychiatric hospital is inhuman. They're not murderers or terrorists. Their only crime is speaking their minds.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/03/world.body_text: **********Hundreds of people demonstrated against the military-dominated Government here today, and armed men set fire to a building owned by the publishers of the opposition newspaper La Prensa while riot police watched. **********It was the second day of protest since Tuesday, when the Government lifted a state of emergency. **********A few hours later, the authorities ordered an opposition radio station to be closed down indefinitely, asserting that it had incited public disorders. **********A spokesman described broadcasts by the station from June 8 to 10 as anti-Government and said they were believed to have violated the country's penal code. **********Riot police officers had clashed with students earlier today near the University of Panama. Witnesses said that several students were injured and that the police took others away. **********Hundreds of Panamanians turned out for a noon demonstration in the banking district. Riot squads dispersed the crowds, but stood by while about 30 men arrived and set fire to a building owned by the publishers of La Prensa.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/11/busin.body_text: **********After long anticipation, shares of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone began changing hands on Japanese stock exchanges today, trading at about 1.6 million yen a share, or $10,460.93. **********For nearly two days, the shares of the former Government telecommunications monopoly remained unquoted because so few people wanted to sell them and so many wanted to buy. N.T.T. is considered a strong participant in the expanding telecommunications market, and analysts predict a continuing price rise. **********The price of 1.6 million yen was nearly 34 percent higher than the amount paid by individual investors who were allowed to buy the shares before they were listed on the nation's three major stock exchanges. **********To spur trading, the Ministry of Finance released an additional 100,000 shares today, and the Tokyo Stock Exchange forbade dealers to place sell orders without naming a price. **********Today's trading in N.T.T. totaled 217,209 shares.
