https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; NEW MCI STRATEGY: DEREGULATE A.T.&T.
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/06/busin.body_text: **********The MCI Communications Corporation yesterday called for full deregulation of its chief long-distance competitor, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which has been forced by the Government to cut its rates drastically. **********In a filing to be made today with the Federal Communications Commission, MCI said competition had developed to the point that A.T.& T. no longer needs to be regulated to prevent monopoly pricing. **********Analysts said MCI was hoping that A.T.& T., if it were deregulated, would use more of its long-distance profits to develop other areas of its business, rather than cut long-distance rates. **********''They are trying to make A.T.& T. less aggressive,'' said Joseph Bellace, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company. ''They are dealing with such paper-thin profit margins that any relief they can get will improve their earnings outlook.'' Long-Distance Costs Down 30% **********The F.C.C. has estimated that the average cost of making a long-distance telephone call has declined about 30 percent since A.T.& T. was forced to sell off its local phone companies in 1984. **********MCI's filing represents a sudden change of thought for the nation's second-largest long-distance company, which has long supported the F.C.C.'s regulation of A.T.& T., the industry leader. **********Analysts who follow MCI said they were not surprised by the move, considering the heavy losses the Washington-based company has suffered in the last year. They tie the losses in part to the drastic price-cutting that was spurred by the F.C.C.'s decision last year to lower the rate of return it would allow A.T.& T. on its long-distance business. **********To remain competitive, discount long-distance companies such as MCI and the U S Sprint Communications Company have consistently undercut A.T.& T., which still controls about 80 percent of the market. Competing with A.T.& T., however, has proved a growing strain on the carriers, which are making large investments to modernize their networks. MCI lost $448.4 million on $3.59 billion in sales last year. Long-Distance Rates Could Rise **********Bert C. Roberts Jr., MCI's president and chief operating officer, said yesterday that the price of long-distance services could increase if the F.C.C. freed A.T.& T. from rate restrictions. He added, however, that the F.C.C. could limit such increases by setting price ceilings as a transition to total deregulation. **********''It's time to let the market manage A.T.& T.,'' Mr. Roberts said. He added that the last major barriers to market deregulation had been eroded, and cited MCI's recent entry into the 800-number long-distance service market and its increasing presence in the international market. **********A.T.& T., in a statement, called the MCI proposal ''right on target,'' adding that ''it had been our position all along.'' **********Bert Halprin, who heads the F.C.C.'s common carrier bureau, said yesterday that the agency was particularly interested in comments from long-distance competitors such as MCI, but that the agency's primary responsibility was to the public. ''A.T.& T. is still the dominant firm, and it is our opinion that without regulation they would raise their prices,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/08/busin.body_text: **********Inventories and Inflation A stronger economy and growing exports will encourage businessmen to slowly build up inventories, says Morris Cohen, president of Morris Cohen & Associates, a Hackensack, N.J., consulting firm. He expects the increase in non-farm inventories to be $12 billion higher this year than in 1986. **********That is generally considered a modest rise, but a ''turnaround from the second half of 1986,'' Mr. Cohen said. Last year the swings were extreme, reflecting the rise and then the fall of auto inventories and the effect of a weakening dollar on the demand for American goods. In the first quarter, non-farm inventories built up at an annual rate of $37 billion, but by the fourth quarter they were falling at an $8 billion rate. **********This year the widespread use of Japanese inventory techniques - in which goods are ordered at the last minute - will help to moderate inventory growth, Mr. Cohen said. In addition, if inflation remains low, there will be no need to stockpile goods in anticipation of higher prices. A danger signal would be rapid inventory buildup. ''That means inflation,'' he said. A Non-Existent Nest Egg? American consumers could collectively save nothing at all this year. **********''It's never happened before,'' said Edward Yardeni, senior vice president of Prudential- Bache Securities. ''But if consumption exceeds disposable income, the savings rate would be negative'' - and Americans are getting close to that point, he said. **********The nation's personal savings rate, he points out, dropped to only 2.5 percent of disposable income in the fourth quarter of 1986. For all of 1986, it was 3.8 percent, down from 5.1 percent in 1985. ''And the trend continues downward,'' Mr. Yardeni said. **********He cites several reasons for the decline. A large percentage of America's population is under 40, an age group that saves relatively little. What's more, the recent appreciation of stocks and real-estate, whose values are not calculated in disposable income, has created a sense of wealth, encouraging spending. **********Perhaps more important, the new emphasis on low-interest home-equity loans has prompted more consumers to borrow a portion of their real estate appreciation, and spend it. ''If everybody starts to tap the market value of their homes by taking out a homeowners' equity loan,'' said Mr. Yardeni, ''spending could, in theory, exceed income.'' Switching to Methanol **********Methanol, an alcohol made from natural gas, was widely considered a good alternative to gasoline or diesel fuel when the prices of those two fuels were at record levels a decade ago. And now that petroleum prices are rising again, methanol is back in the news. **********But even without higher fuel prices, Environmental Protection Agency emission rules that go into effect in 1988 and 1991 favor methanol over diesel fuel, says Karl Springer of the Southwest Research Institute in San Antonio. That's because ''it may not be practical to adapt some high-emission diesels to meet the 1991 particulate limit,'' he said, adding that in anticipation of the new standards, methanol-powered buses are being tested in northern California. In many cases, gasoline is not an alternative, because it is more expensive than methanol and not as pollution-free. **********But methanol has its drawbacks. It provides about 60 percent less power per gallon than diesel fuel or gasoline, and this requires a larger tank for the same performance. On the other hand, methanol is relatively cheap: It costs only 30 to 52 cents a gallon, whereas diesel fuel has only recently slipped below $1 a gallon and gasoline costs roughly the same.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/04/busin.main_headline: Telex Set Back In Legal Fight
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/04/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Telex Set Back In Legal Fight
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/04/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge issued a temporary restraining order today that prevents the Telex Corporation from using a state anti-takeover law to block the New York financier Asher B. Edelman's $65-a-share bid for the company. Judge David L. Russell of the **********Federal Court for the Western District of Oklahoma issued the order restraining for 10 days the use of the Oklahoma Control Shares Acquisition Act, which restricts tender offers for companies that have a sizable portion of their assets in the state. Telex has most of its assets in Oklahoma, although it is incorporated in Delaware. The ruling was a victory for **********Mr. Edelman. His $872 million tender offer for Telex expires on Friday. **********Under the Oklahoma law, the tender offer would have to remain open for another 30 to 50 days after the closing to allow the company to call a stockholders' meeting to vote on the acquisition. **********Telex shares rose $1.25, to $57.125, on the New York Stock Exchange today. **********Separately, another group led by Mr. Edelman said it was no longer interested in acquiring the Rexham Corporation after Rexham agreed to be bought by Bowater Industries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Pitney Bowes Inc. said yesterday that Thomas F. Loemker had resigned as president of its largest operating unit, Pitney Bowes Business Systems. The board named James L. Bast to succeed him. **********Mr. Bast, 51 years old, has been president of the company's smaller Dictaphone subsidiary since 1982. The business systems unit had sales last year of $1.1 billion, while Dictaphone's sales were $234 million. Over all, the Stamford, Conn., company's annual revenues were $2 billion. **********The company gave no reason for the resignation of Mr. Loemker, who is 56. **********Marc C. Breslawsky, 44, was named president of Dictaphone, and Carmine F. Adimando was named vice president for finance and administration of Pitney Bowes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/06/busin.body_text: **********The Moseley Holding Corporation said yesterday that it would quit the retail brokerage business and seek a buyer for that part of its operations because of mounting trading losses. **********Though the Boston-based firm did not say so, the likely buyer is thought to be Gruntal & Company, a New York brokerage. Gruntal was acquired in June by the Home Group, parent company of the Home Insurance Company. **********Moseley's retail operations were losing money even before the stock market collapse. They contributed heavily to a $7.9 million loss in the quarter that ended Sept. 30 and to the previous quarter's loss of $7.3 million. **********In over-the-counter trading yesterday, Moseley shares fell 31.25 cents, to $1.5625. **********''The thinking was to take a pre-emptive move ahead of other firms that may be in more precarious situtations and which could crowd the channels for funds,'' Jeffrey A. Sonnenfeld, a Moseley director, said of the decision. **********In recent quarters, the retail brokerage unit provided just under half of the firm's revenues. About 325 of the firm's 870 employees are retail brokers. After a sale, Moseley would remain an institutional brokerage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/world.main_headline: PERES'S STAFF, IN ISRAELI INFIGHTING, BARS SHAMIR MESSAGE TO EMBASSIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/world.print_headline: PERES'S STAFF, IN ISRAELI INFIGHTING, BARS SHAMIR MESSAGE TO EMBASSIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/world.body_text: **********The fighting inside the Israeli Government reached a new level today. **********Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's staff asked the Foreign Ministry to tell Israeli embassies that the Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, no longer had a mandate to pursue an international conference on the Middle East. **********Mr. Peres's staff canceled Mr. Shamir's message and instead sent out its own cablegram saying the idea was still alive, Government sources said. **********The Foreign Ministry cable, according to Government sources, notified Israeli embassies that in a meeting of the policy-making inner Cabinet on Wednesday, ''no vote took place; we repeat, no vote took place.'' As a result, the cable went on, there was no change in the official position that Israel should try to negotiate directly with its Arab neighbors through an international conference. 'This Is a War' **********When a senior Foreign Ministry official who supports Mr. Peres was asked by a reporter how a message from the Prime Minister's office could be canceled and a different one substituted, the official said: ''How can you ask me such a question? This is a war.'' **********Indeed, the factions of the Israeli Government may soon need of a peace conference as much as the countries of the region. Matters reached a point today where Mr. Peres and Mr. Shamir were having a disagreement over what they disagreed about. **********Mr. Peres, the leader of the Labor Party, insisted that he was free to continue pursuing the conference since the 10-member inner Cabinet was deadlocked over whether the Government should endorse his proposal and since no vote had been taken. **********Mr. Shamir, the head of the Likud bloc, argued that the conference idea was dead since Mr. Peres had refused to bring the conference issue to a vote - because he knew the Cabinet was deadlocked 5 to 5 and a tie vote would legally be a rejection. **********Yosef Ben-Aharon, the director general of Mr. Shamir's office, now visiting Washington, said in an interview on Israeli radio today that he had ''met people in the White House and, in the name of the Prime Minister, I informed them that following the debate in the Cabinet, the subject of an international conference is finished.'' Mr. Shamir declared on Israeli television Wednesday night that all officials and world leaders who speak to Mr. Peres about the proposal ''will know that Mr. Peres does not speak in the name of the Government.'' **********Mr. Peres responded: ''The Prime Minister can dismiss me if he likes. This does not frighten me. I am acting for peace. I took over a Government with 600 percent inflation, with an army in the Lebanese mire, with tremendous civil hatred and without a peace policy. Am I eating the bread of charity? Was I not elected lawfully?'' **********Mr. Peres was Prime Minister in the national unity Government for two years, beginning in September 1984, before exchanging positions with Mr. Shamir last October. Peres Leaving for U.S. Mr. Shamir's assertion that Mr. Peres does not speak for the Government was timed to coincide with the Foreign Minister's trip to the United States, which begins Friday. **********Mr. Peres said before departing that he would meet with Secretary of State George P. Shultz and other senior American officals to discuss ways to ''keep the peace process alive.'' Mr. Peres emphasized, however, that he had no intention of dragging the Americans into the internal Israeli political fray by seeking any kind of endorsement from them. **********Mr. Peres is clearly going to Washington in a low mood, judging from people who saw him today. Despite his insistence that the question of the conference is still open, political commentators here feel that Mr. Shamir adroitly outmaneuvered him, at least in this round. **********Mr. Peres hoped at first to win over some Likud members of the Cabinet to his proposal, as he had done in previous votes about Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon and economic policy. But Mr. Shamir blocked this path by maintaining a united front. **********Then Mr. Peres planned to call for new elections by putting together a 61-seat majority in the 120-seat Parliament to force Mr. Shamir into dissolving the coalition Government. But Mr. Shamir beat Mr. Peres to the punch and put together a bloc of 62 seats, upsetting Mr. Peres's demand for new elections. Mr. Shamir, whose term runs until November 1988, opposes new elections. The Price of Victory **********Mr. Shamir's victory comes at a price, however. **********Political analysts say that Mr. Shamir may have quashed Mr. Peres's conference plan in the Cabinet but that he did so without ever presenting a realistic alternative peace proposal. The Labor Party will now seek to portray Mr. Shamir, both at home and abroad, as being more interested in holding on to the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip than in bringing about peace with the Arabs. **********Nonetheless, Mr. Shamir's staff was in a celebratory mood at his office this morning, while Mr. Peres was counseling patience. Mr. Peres is said to believe that all he needs to put together a majority in Parliament for new elections is to win over either the small Shas religious party or the National Religious Party. Labor officials say it is only a matter of time, and of offering the right price, before they build a majority to topple Mr. Shamir.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/busin.main_headline: CORN SALE TO SOVIET STIRS LITTLE HOPE OF ANY MORE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/busin.print_headline: CORN SALE TO SOVIET STIRS LITTLE HOPE OF ANY MORE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/25/busin.body_text: **********American and Soviet officials confirmed yesterday that the Soviet Union had bought 39.3 million bushels of corn, its first purchase of American grain since last summer. **********But the sale, representing just a fraction of the huge United States surplus of corn, wheat and soybeans, raised little hope that Moscow would again become a major customer of American farmers. **********In Chicago, where the sale of one million metric tons of corn had been rumored late last week, prices of grain futures were little changed yesterday. The price of the nearest corn delivery contract, for March, dropped 1.5 cents a bushel, to $1.47. March wheat rose 1.25 cents, to $2.805 a bushel, and March soybeans fell half a cent, to $4.875 a bushel. **********''Given our low price of corn, which no foreign supplier can beat, the Soviet Union, which doesn't really need corn, would have been fools not to buy some anyway,'' said Melvin S. Sjervin, senior markets editor of Milling and Baking News, the leading journal of the grain trade. **********But Mr. Sjervin, who met with Soviet officials in Washington Monday night, said they indicated they would not buy any wheat unless they received the same favorable treatment as other customers. Complaining About Terms **********''That is why they stopped buying last August,'' Mr. Sjervin said. **********The Russians then were offered a ''bonus'' of about $15 a ton for purchases of American wheat, he said, but they complained that it was less than other foreign buyers were getting. The bonuses, granted under the Export Enhancement Program, vary in size and are paid in grain. **********''The Soviets were also upset about being required to take whatever grain they bought within a specified period of time, while other buyers are under no such constraints,'' Mr. Sjervin said. **********Vladislav Malkevich, First Deputy Minister of Foreign Trade, is the highest ranking Russian at the semi-annual American-Soviet grain meeting in Washington. Mr. Malkevich said Monday night that more corn might be bought ''as long as American prices are competitive.'' **********But the Soviet official also said in an interview with the Reuters news service that Agriculture Department officials had not made any export bonus offer on wheat during the meeting. Wheat is expected to be high on the Soviet shopping list because the Russians are having an uncommonly difficult winter. With only a light snow cover over their main crop-growing areas, their winter wheat, which is planted in the fall, has been exposed to severe frosts. **********Sherman L. Levin, a Chicago consultant to the grain trade, said 50 percent of the Soviet wheat crop was planted in the fall, compared with 75 percent in the United States. **********''That the Soviets will need to import grain is certain,'' Mr. Levin said. ''What is not is where they will get it. Their 1985-86 grain harvest was estimated at 192 million tons, which forced them to import about 20 million tons, and if the winter reduces the wheat crop, they may have to buy much more.'' In a metric ton, there are 36.7 bushels of wheat, the same of soybeans, and 39.3 bushels of corn. U.S. Called Logical Supplier **********With supplies of grain from Australia, Canada, Argentina and Western Europe either sold out or contracted for, the United States has become the biggest potential supplier, Mr. Levin said. **********''When our statistical wheat year ends May 30, we will have 1.1 billion bushels of wheat left over from past harvests,'' he noted. ''By the end of the corn year, Aug. 31, the surplus should be 5.7 billion bushels, and on the same date we should have 615 million bushels of soybeans.'' **********Given this supply situation, the news that the Soviet officials were coming to Washington for grain talks and the reports of the corn purchase helped to lift grain and oilseed prices in Chicago and Kansas City, Mo., last week to their best gains since the Soviet Union's Chernobyl nuclear accident in May 1986.  IMPASSE IN GRAIN TALKS **********WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (Special to The New York Times) - American and Soviet agricultural trade officials today completed two days of talks without resolving their differences on a five-year bilateral grain pact. They discussed supply, demand and market situations for grain and reviewed prospects for sales. **********The Soviet Union had timed its new corn purchase to coincide with the consultations in Washington. Such talks are scheduled to take place twice a year under the terms of the agreement, but last fall the Russians refused to participate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/busin.main_headline: LAST-MINUTE MANEUVERS CAN REDUCE TAX BILLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/busin.print_headline: LAST-MINUTE MANEUVERS CAN REDUCE TAX BILLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/busin.body_text: **********This time of year, as April 15 draws closer, is when the motivation to find ways to trim income tax bills is greatest, though the options available for legally outwitting the tax collector are the smallest. **********There are, however, a few 11th-hour strategies that can shrink the size of a tax bill by hundreds or even thousands of dollars. **********Depositing money into a personal retirement account is the most notable and typically the most lucrative way to cut tax bills at the last minute. But considerable savings can also result from the way people fill out their tax returns, including how they choose among the various options for calculating tax benefits and the effort spent searching through personal records for overlooked deductions. **********Even the Tax Reform Act of 1986 has created a new last-minute tax saving opportunity for people who bought a computer or some other piece of business equipment. **********For this filing season, the new tax law safeguarded what has been a sacred and valuable ritual for millions of Americans scavenging for last-minute tax-cutting maneuvers - contributing to an Individual Retirement Account. Although the new law imposes restrictions on I.R.A. deductions, the restrictions do not affect 1986 returns. **********As a result, every worker has until April 15 to make a deposit of up to $2,000 to an I.R.A. and claim a deduction for the amount contributed on their 1986 tax return. One-income couples can contribute up to $2,250. Two-earner couples can contribute up to $4,000. **********For millions of middle- and upper-income Americans who are covered by a company pension plan, this will be the last chance to claim a full I.R.A. deduction because of the new law's curbs covering 1987 returns. **********Although the new restrictions raise questions as to whether I.R.A.'s will remain a worthwhile investment in the future for those no longer eligible for the deduction, tax advisers are encouraging their clients to take full advantage of I.R.A.'s this filing season as a way to save hundreds of dollars in taxes. **********''This year the answer is clear,'' said Peter Elinsky, a tax partner at the accounting firm of Peat Marwick. ''Even if you have to borrow, you probably want to contribute to an I.R.A. this year.'' **********The tax-saving opportunities are even richer for the self-employed, including workers with sideline businesses. In addition to making contributions to an I.R.A., they can make tax-deductible deposits to a Keogh retirement plan of up to 13.043 percent or 20 percent of their self-employment earnings, depending on the specific type of Keogh plan they have. In either case, the maximum contribution is $30,000 a year. Requirement on Timing **********The one proviso is that the Keogh plan must have been set up by last Dec. 31 in order for a contribution made this year to qualify for a deduction on 1986 returns. **********Yet there is salvation for people who did not make such advance arrangements. They can establish a Simplified Employee Pension Plan. These plans, which tax professionals often refer to as SEP's, are not as well-known or as widely used as Keogh plans, but they are similar in many respects. A key advantage of a SEP is that self-employed individuals can establish one any time until April 15 and still qualify for a deduction on their 1986 tax return. **********''A SEP is not for everybody, but it's good for the self-employed individual who wanted a Keogh plan but didn't get around to setting one up,'' said Mr. Elinsky. The maximum tax-deductible deposit that can be made to a SEP is 13.043 percent of self-employment income, up to $30,000. **********Investors who sold stocks at a profit in the closing days of 1986 have the unusual tax-saving option of reporting the gain on either their 1986 or 1987 return - whichever the taxpayer finds more beneficial. This special option applies only to stock sold between Dec. 24 and Dec. 31. As a rule, long-term gains from such stock sales should be reported on 1986 returns and short-term gains delayed until 1987 returns. Use of Income Averaging **********For investors and others who had an exceptionally large increase in income last year, the ''income-averaging'' method of calculating tax liability may prove of help in reducing their tax bill. Income averaging, which becomes extinct after this filing season, effectively spreads last year's income gain over a period of four years. **********Similarly, various options exist for calculating a number of deductions. **********For example, individuals have the option of figuring the size of their state and local sales tax deduction either by adding up all their sales tax receipts or by claiming a fixed allowance set forth in I.R.S. tables. Taxpayers who bought a lot of merchandise last year and saved their receipts might well get a bigger deduction by adding up actual sales taxes paid rather than claiming the I.R.S. allowance. **********In the same vein, people who used their car for business have the option of deducting actual operating expenses or a fixed I.R.S. mileage allowance. In most cases, actual operating expenses will provide a bigger deduction than the mileage allowance. **********If you purchased a computer or other equipment for your business, there are a few choices to figuring the write-offs, some better than others. Some Write-Off Choices **********For a computer, the cost can be written off over a period of five years, using the old law's depreciation formula. As an alternative, taxpayers are allowed to start taking advantage of the new tax law's depreciation schedules for writing off business equipment placed in service between last Aug. 1 and Dec. 31. In the case of computers, this option can provide larger deductions in the early years than the old formula. **********Still another alternative is a provision that allows taxpayers to immediately deduct up to $5,000 of the cost rather than depreciate the expense over a period of years. **********Tax savings can also be found by poring through personal records, including checkbooks, monthly credit card statements, receipts, appointment calendars and bills. The objective is to find deductible expenses that may have been overlooked. **********A glance through monthly phone company bills, for instance, will often uncover business calls made from home, a deductible expense. Last month's credit card statement will show the total amount of finance charges paid last year, which is fully deductible as interest expense on 1986 returns. And rummaging through canceled checks will often uncover such deductible items as dues paid to professional associations and subscriptions to professional or investment publications. Finding Arcane Benefits **********''Little things like that add up,'' said Albert Ellentuck, national tax partner at the accounting firm of Laventhol & Horwath. **********There are also some arcane benefits buried in the labyrinth of the tax code. For example, taxpayers who bought a new diesel-powered automobile can claim a one-time tax credit of $102 by filing Form 4136. **********If time permits, wait a few days after going through your personal records before sending in the completed return because some other deductible expenses may come to mind, recommends Stuart R. Josephs, a tax partner at the accounting firm of Seidman & Seidman. ''A week later people often remember something they didn't think of before,'' he said. **********Many of the tax benefits uncovered in plowing through personal records are available only to those who itemize deductions. But the point at which it pays to forsake the standard deduction and itemize is easier to reach than many taxpayers think. Homeowners often pay enough mortgage interest to make itemizing advantageous. And residents of high tax states will often find itemizing worthwhile just because of the deduction for state and local taxes. For 1986 returns, the point at which itemizing becomes beneficial is when itemized deductions exceed $2,480 for individuals and $3,670 for married couples filing a joint return. Fairly Liberal Deadlines **********For taxpayers who were working up until the closing hours of 1986 trying to maximize their deductible expenses, the tax law provides fairly liberal deadlines. If payment was by check, the expense qualifies for a deduction on 1986 returns so long as the check was placed in the mail by midnight Dec. 31 - regardless of when the recipient received it or cashed it. If payment was made by credit card, the deduction qualifies on 1986 returns as long as the charge was made by midnight Dec. 31 - even if the charge did not show up on your credit card statement or was not paid for until this year. **********Filing the return at the right time can also save a few dollars. As a rule, if you expect to receive a refund, file early. The earlier in the season your return is filed, the quicker the I.R.S. is able to process the refund. And the earlier the money is in your own hands, the earlier you can put it to work earning interest. **********On the other hand, if you owe the I.R.S. money, procrastination can pay. By waiting until the last minute to send in the check, you can keep the money profitably invested in your own account. **********Next: Personal deductions. **********PHONING THE I.R.S.  The Internal Revenue Service operates a telephone assistance program to answer taxpayer inquiries about Federal income tax returns. The New York Times is not equipped to handle personal tax questions and asks that they be directed to the I.R.S. Phone numbers for the metropolitan area are:  Manhattan/Bronx/Staten Island - (212) 732-0100  Brooklyn/Queens - (718) 596-3770  Nassau - (516) 222-1131  Suffolk - (516) 724-5000  Westchester/Rockland - (914) 997-1510  If you live in neighboring states, or in other areas outside the above, call the general toll-free number: 1-800-424-1040

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/02/busin.print_headline: MARKET PLACE; Medical Goods Look Profitable
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/02/busin.body_text: **********Numerous companies in the medical supplies industry have good prospects, according to an analysis by the Value Line Investment Survey. **********''A weaker dollar should stimulate sales abroad, while a more stable hospital admissions rate augurs well for domestic performance,'' the investment advisory service said. ''Quality should remain the principal selling feature of products serving specialty health care markets, so most companies probably will enjoy healthy margins. And a lower corporate tax rate will give profits an extra lift.'' **********Long-range prospects are also considered favorable. ''Changes in the health care markets over the next few years will probably offer new opportunities for innovative products,'' Value Line said. ''Notably, the burgeoning home health care market will require equipment that will enable patients to be treated under limited supervision.'' **********Within the medical supplies category, the advisory service has selected 11 stocks that are expected to outperform the market over the coming year. **********Carrying the highest ''timeliness'' rating are five issues: C. R. Bard, Biomet, Intermedics, Medtronic and Puritan-Bennett. In addition, stocks regarded as having ''a better-than-even chance'' of beating the market during 1987 are Abbott Laboratories, Bausch & Lomb, Johnson & Johnson, R. P. Scherer, Stryker and United States Surgical. **********In discussing specialty product niches, the report noted that ''growing acceptance of angioplasty for treating obstructed blood vessels of heart attack patients is helping C. R. Bard to post record earnings.'' **********Medtronic and Intermedics are benefiting from increasing sales of cardiac pacemakers, the survey said. Scherer is counting on a nutritional approach to the cardiovascular field, offering fish oil supplements that are said to reduce blood cholesterol levels. **********Puritan-Bennett is seen extending its home health care product line, ''while it launches a computer-based data collection system that should improve the efficiency of respiratory therapy departments in hospitals.'' Tobacco Stocks Favored **********Tobacco stocks have consistently been one of the equity market's most profitable groups during the 1980's and Salomon Brothers expects this pattern to continue in 1987. **********For the five years ending in 1985, for example, the tobacco industry showed the highest return on equity of all groups in Standard & Poor's 400-stock industrial index. During this period, the industry's return on equity averaged 20.3 percent. The drug industry ranked second with a return on equity of 19.2 percent, followed by the publishing group with 18.6 percent. **********The average showing for 29 industries was a return on equity of 12.1 percent for the five years. **********''We believe that the tobacco industry will continue to be one of the leaders in profitability, based on projected earnings growth of 16 percent in 1986 and 26 percent in 1987,'' said Diana K. Temple, who follows tobacco issues for Salomon Brothers. ''This would compare with the flat earnings we expect for the S.& P. 400 in 1986 and the 22 percent expansion - before write-offs - we look for in 1987.'' **********According to the firm's investment coding, stocks of four tobacco companies are expected to outperform the general equity market during the next 6 to 12 months. These are the Loews Corporation, Philip Morris, RJR Nabisco and U.S. Tobacco. Two other issues - American Brands and Universal Leaf Tobacco - are expected to match the market's overall performance. Merrill Turns Cautious **********Merrill Lynch suggests a cautious approach to investing as the new year begins. **********''We sense that 1987 will be a year of change and greater risk but not the end of the bull market for financial assets,'' said Robert J. Farrell, Merrill Lynch's chief market analyst, in assessing prospects last week. ''We think it makes sense to move cautiously at the outset and hold reserves, even though we think a good rally to start the year, as stocks rebound from tax selling, could be appealing to traders.'' **********Mr. Farrell has an extensive list of stock groups that he favors for the new year. The sectors include electrical equipment, airlines, auto accessory, chemical, paper and forest products, containers, pollution control, computer software and services, tires, mobile homes, office supplies, telephone, natural gas and selected drugs. **********Recently, Merrill Lynch market analysts have cited the likelihood that the Dow Jones industrial average could decline to as low as 1,700 or 1,750 -possibly in the first quarter of 1987 - before the bull market moves to new highs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/world.main_headline: DELHI'S POOR GET 2 BLANKETS BUT LITTLE ELSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/world.print_headline: DELHI'S POOR GET 2 BLANKETS BUT LITTLE ELSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/world.body_text: **********Shivering in the biting evening cold, hundreds of poor and ill-clad men, homeless and anonymous, slip every night into the warmth of a huge concrete dormitory next to the Delhi railroad station in the old walled sector of the capital. **********Inside, they stand in lines to collect their quota of two blankets apiece from the dormitory supervisor and then look for a sleeping place. **********When they find a space that is unoccupied by a huddled, prostrate form, they quickly settle down, putting down their blankets and making themselves as comfortable as possible. They receive nothing else - no food or medical assistance. **********For many poor but able-bodied men, it provides an alternative to sleeping in the open. Already, more than 100 people are reported to have died in a cold spell sweeping the plains of northern India. #5,000 People Every Night There are six such shelters run by the Delhi Development Authority, a sprawling Government construction concern in the capital. They take in about 5,000 people every night in the winter, although social workers familiar with the problem say this is only a fraction of the homeless population. **********''We have no families or homes in Delhi,'' said Ram Prasad, from the Garhwal district in the state of Uttar Pradesh. ''We come from far away to earn our living and, very often, until we find a steady job and a place to stay, we live in this shelter.'' **********Mr. Prasad, a cheerful, short man with a quick laugh, says he works as a cook. **********The shelter is just off the main road that cuts across part of the walled city. Painted a Dirty Yellow **********But the noise of the outside world is muted in the shelter, which is painted a dirty yellow outside and is open all year long. The air inside is thick with cigarette smoke and the murmur of conversation. The seekers of shelter are men working in the tiny restaurants of the city, rickshaw drivers, pushcart vendors, construction workers and some beggars, too. **********They are young and old and come from around India, seeking hope and work. Some have deserted their families; others want to go back. They speak the many languages of this diverse land. **********A color television set entertains them, but most are too far away to see the programs clearly. A small group mostly of younger men sits before the set, watching with rapt attention as a bharat natyam dancer goes through her intricate paces. **********There are lights that stay switched on throughout the night and grimy ceiling fans. There are no windows, only a series of ventilators and exhaust fans to let in fresh air. The burly, mustached guard at the gate says the door is never locked at night so that people can enter. 'No Drinking or Gambling' **********''Any poor person can come in, but we don't allow drinking, gambling or women,'' the guard, Ram Kanda, said. **********The shelter near the railway station can take about 2,000 people and is the biggest in Delhi. There are other shelters, including places run by private agencies, but they are much smaller. **********According to Surrender Saini, the chief of the Bharat Sevak Samaj, a voluntary social welfare group, the shelters were begun in the 1950's when the Samaj took Jawaharlal Nehru around some of the workers colonies in the city. Nehru, the country's first Prime Minister, supported the idea of homes for the homeless. **********At that time, Miss Saini said in an interview, the number of people who slept on Delhi's sidewalks was estimated at 100,000. That figure is believed to have increased by three times, social welfare experts say. Increasing Number of Shelters **********The Delhi Development Authority is also increasing the number of shelters to take care of the influx of newcomers into the city from the countryside, who come in search of jobs and hopes of ''making it big,'' as Miss Saini says. **********Most of the homeless say they have few complaints. ''We get a place to sleep, and that is a blessing,'' said a man in black trousers and shirt, who identified himself as Satish Kumar. But Mr. Kumar, who talked with a visitor as a crowd gathered, said that they wanted cleaner toilets. **********He also said sweepers would allow them the use of the toilet only if they were paid 25 paisa (about 2 cents) each time. ''That is not right, it is unjust,'' said Tapan Kumar, a youth. **********He and others also said they were woken up around 6 A.M. and asked to leave, although the official closing time is 7 A.M. ''It is very cold at that time, and we don't get work until the markets open several hours later,'' said Mr. Kumar, who wore a scarf across his head. **********Delhi officials said they had not heard about the allegations. **********Mr. Kumar, who is barely 18, left his home in Calcutta after a quarrel with his father eight years ago and has lived every night at the shelter. **********He works as a helper at the messy, roadside cafes that proliferate here, but says he would now like to go back to Calcutta. ''I have never written to them, and they have never asked me to return,'' the youth said. ''But if I can save enough money, I will leave this place and go.'' **********Most of those interviewed said they earned five to nine rupees every day (about 40 to 70 cents) if they got work.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/busin.print_headline: REAL ESTATE; Renovating Buildings For Offices
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/busin.body_text: **********WHEN commercial condominiums appeared on the market about five years ago, the first to be developed were designed for medical professionals seeking to avoid escalating office rents. **********Then condominium developers began putting together projects for manufacturers and industrial companies. Now the appeal is to a much broader spectrum of office space users, as exemplified by two current projects in lower Manhattan in which old buildings are being recycled as condominiums. **********In TriBeCa, at the corner of Hudson and Harrison Streets, a development company, Rockefeller Properties, is turning the 101-year-old former Mercantile Exchange Building into six full-floor condominium units. **********A few blocks to the north and east, at 121 Sixth Avenue, at Broome Street, a warehouse building is being converted into condominium spaces for nonprofit organizations. The developer of that project is the Center for Alternatives, a nonprofit group in Manhattan that operates programs for disadvantaged youths. **********''It was a matter of finding a long-term solution to our space problems or maybe being forced to close,'' said Charles D. Terry, executive director of the Center for Alternatives. The group draws financial support from more than 100 foundations, corporations and government agencies. **********The organization's office space and center, known as The Door, are currently situated in the former Cooper-Siegel department store at Avenue of the Americas and 18th Street. From that 55,000-square-foot space the organization offers a spectrum of after-school programs that include health care and career counseling. **********When the organization signed its lease in 1975 the space cost $2 a foot. But that was when the neighborhood had little appeal for most office tenants. Now the stretch of Avenue of the Americas below 23d Street is undergoing a transformation. Owners of the grand old department store buildings there are turning them into luxurious office and showroom spaces. **********A renewal of the Center for Alternatives lease, Mr. Terry said, would have required a rent increase of more than 300 percent. Late last year the organization paid $8.5 million for the building at 121 Avenue of the Americas where the city's Board of Elections stores voting machines. About $5.5 million will be put into renovations for the building. **********Steven Schwartz, who is serving as developer for the project, said the purchase of the building and the renovation job had been made possible by a package of grants and low-cost loans from various foundations, corporations and government agencies. **********The center received $1.5 miliion in grant money and $3.5 million in low-cost loans. Mr. Schwartz put the overall cost at about $150 a square foot. **********The center will occupy the space from the basement level through the fourth floor and will sell the top two 15,000-square-foot floors. **********When work on the Broome Street building begins next month, restoration of the former Mercantile Exchange Building will be nearly done. The six condominium units there range from 7,000 to 12,870 square feet. **********Meile Rockefeller, president of the company that is developing the condominium project, said the high cost of the restoration and renovation work meant that if the space had been offered for lease the rents would have been higher than for the space in other renovated buildings in the area. **********''We decided that the project was much more viable as a condominium,'' Ms. Rockefeller said. ''But office condos are not for every company. They are generally more suitable for private or closely held companies that are asset-based and do not have to answer to shareholders concerned with bottom-line reports.'' Ms. Rockefeller is a granddaughter of Nelson A. Rockefeller, the late Governor and Vice President. **********So far two of the six units have been sold. Saks International, a commodity trading company, has signed a contract for the third and fourth levels of the building. The developers are close to making a deal for the fifth floor. The space that remains is the former trading floor, a two-story space with a mezzanine that costs $250 a square foot, and the sky-lit attic unit where the asking price is $175 a square foot.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/02/world.main_headline: Afghan Proposal Inadequate, U.S. Aides Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/02/world.print_headline: Afghan Proposal Inadequate, U.S. Aides Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/02/world.body_text: **********Reagan Administration officials today described the Afghan Government's proposal to have Soviet troops withdraw over a period of 12 months as inadequate. **********They said they expected Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, would discuss a formal withdrawal proposal when he meets here with President Reagan next week. **********Afghanistan's proposal, made in a speech Monday by the Afghan leader, Najibullah, contains conditions that are unacceptable to the United States and Pakistan, the officials said. **********The unacceptable conditions include a cutoff of American and Pakistani aid to the Afghan guerrillas and the creation of a coalition government of Afghan and insurgent officials before any withdrawal begins, the officials said. In addition, the proposal does not give a starting date for the withdrawal of the estimated 115,000 Soviet troops in Afghanistan. **********''We don't see anything exceptionally fresh in Najibullah's speech,'' said an Administration official who closely watches Afghanistan. ''If what he has to offer reflects the Soviet position, it doesn't look very encouraging.'' Other Administration officials characterized Mr. Najibullah's speech as the most recent in a flurry of statements suggesting flexibility on the withdrawal timetable, but offering nothing concrete. **********Mr. Reagan has said he will press the Russians to agree to a reasonable withdrawal timetable free of unacceptable conditions, which Under Secretary of State Michael H. Armacost said Monday was ''the sticking point'' in United States-Soviet talks on a settlement. **********Mr. Gorbachev, for his part, said in an interview with NBC News broadcast Monday that if the United States wanted a political solution to the problem, ''it could be done very quickly.'' **********In recent months, as the guerrillas have increased their military ability, the Russians have sought to deflect attention from the troop withdrawal issue and focus on the need for an end to ''outside interference.'' Mr. Gorbachev may seek American cooperation in urging the Afghan insurgents to work with the Afghan regime for a political solution, according to interviews with Soviet officials, a position the rebels and the Administration have rejected outright. **********''The only stumbling block now is for the United States to pressure its friends to make a choice in favor of the national reconciliation process,'' a Soviet official said. **********In Moscow today, Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia said at a news conference that Mr. Gorbachev had told him that he was considering a shorter timetable than 12 months for a withdrawal. Mr. Hawke quoted the Soviet leader as having said that he had been in contact with Mr. Najibullah in the last 24 hours and that ''there might be the possibility of an earlier withdrawal than contemplated.'' **********A Soviet official in Washington declined comment on Mr. Hawke's remarks, but said that if the United States used its influence to push the guerrillas into negotiations with Kabul, ''the timetable could be shorter.'' **********Administration officials said that the United States would be adamantly opposed to such a gesture, adding that the Russians were mistaken if they believed that Washington could order the fiercely independent Afghan rebels to behave in a certain way.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/16/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices dropped broadly yesterday as weak currency and credit markets sent the Dow Jones industrial average plummeting to below 2,600. **********The Dow plunged 46.46 points, or 1.78 percent, to 2,566.58, after having gained 67.92 points in its rises over the previous four sessions. Yesterday's drop was the biggest in the pivotal indicator since it plummeted 51.98 points on Sept. 1. **********Among the blue-chip stocks hit hard yesterday were International Business Machines, which fell 4 1/2, to 157 1/2; Philip Morris, which dropped 1 3/4, to 114 1/4, and Digital Equipment, which declined 3 1/2, to 187 1/2. **********Broader barometers than the Dow also were substantially lower. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 5.34 points, to 317.74, while the New York Stock Exchange's composite index declined 2.56, to 177.98. **********Volume on the Big Board contracted to a lackluster 136.2 million shares, from 154.4 million on Monday. A total of 1,159 stocks declined while 430 advanced. **********Yesterday, the dollar edged lower, with traders attributing the drop to a belief that the currency was overvalued after its strong recovery from its slump late last week. In the credit markets, apathy toward Treasury debt issues among dealers and investors resulted in a decline of more than a point in the bellwether 30-year bond. **********As the stock market slipped below 2,600, it broke through a psychological barrier as well, some analysts said. But Brian Luedtke, a technical analyst at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. in Minneapolis, said he believed the 2,500 and 2,700 levels on the Dow appeared to be more critical as support levels than 2,600. ''The 2,600 level appears to be showing a lack of conviction,'' he added. **********Mr. Luedtke said he expected the Dow to vacillate within a 75- to 100-point trading range on either side of 2,600 in the next several weeks. **********''Anyone buying stocks now is playing interest rate roulette,'' said Kenneth S. Hackel, president of Systematic Financial Management Inc. in Fort Lee, N.J. ''The yield spread between stocks and bonds is greatly in favor of bonds. Additionally, with the economy showing renewed vigor, there is the fear of further interest rate increases to come.'' **********''Stocks have followed bonds lower as trade worries continue to pressure the dollar and the bond market,'' said David Wood of Boston-based Fidelity Investments. ''The possible inflationary implications of a huge trade deficit are proving a drag on the financial markets while the initiial reaction to last week's trade figure was one of relief that the deficit was not even higher. Investors are realizing that the trade problem remains a significant hurdle.'' **********The Commerce Department reported on Friday that the United States had a record $16.5 billion trade deficit in July. **********Mr. Wood added that overhanging the stock market was the possibility that the Federal Reserve might feel compelled to tighten credit further. In addition, he said, investors are looking ahead with some caution to Friday's ''triple witching hour,'' with expirations in stock options, stock index futures and index options occurring simultaneously. **********Among individual issues yesterday, Marshall Industries rose 1 1/4, to 20 1/4. Electronic industry analysts cited its stronger-than-expected first-quarter earnings. **********Singer rose 3 3/4, to 52, and Watkins-Johnson went up 1 5/8, to 37 1/4. Both electronic concerns have been rumored to be possible takeover targets. **********Among chemical and pharmaceutical issues, Eli Lilly fell 3 1/2, to 101 1/8; Du Pont dropped 3 1/4, to 114 3/8, and Squibb declined by 2 7/8, to 98 7/8. Newmont Mining Up 5 5/8 **********Newmont Mining was the Big Board's biggest dollar gainer, rising 5 5/8, to 101 1/8. Ivanhoe Partners raised its bid for Newmont to $105 a share from $95. **********Foster Wheeler was the most active stock, falling 1 1/8, to 22 5/8, on a volume of more than 2.4 million shares. A company group led by Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, said it might consider a bid for control of the engineering concern. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index fell 1.72 points, to 353.47, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index declined 3.55 points, to 441.94.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/23/world.main_headline: SOLDIERS OF SYRIA MOVE INTO BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/23/world.print_headline: SOLDIERS OF SYRIA MOVE INTO BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/23/world.body_text: **********Syrian troops poured into Beirut today and began taking control of the capital's predominantly Moslem western sector in an effort to restore order among warring militias. **********Helmeted soldiers dressed in black-and-red combat fatigues first assembled with tanks and armored personnel carriers at the eastern runway of the International Airport in Beirut's mainly Shiite Moslem southern suburbs. **********From the airport, which is closed, they advanced into the city, where the fighting has largely died down. One group moved into the public stadium, until now a stronghold of the Lebanese Army's mainly Shiite Sixth Brigade. Another contingent entered the Tarik al Jadidah district, where the latest wave of fighting broke out a week ago. **********The exact number of Syrian troops in West Beirut was not known, but officials here said there were 3,000 to 4,000, backed by about 100 Soviet-built T-54 and T-62 tanks. Militias Allies of Syria **********The police said 200 people were killed and 500 wounded in six days of combat between Shiite militiamen of the Amal movement and Druse warriors of the Progressive Socialist Party supported by armed members of the Soviet-backed Lebanese Communist Party. All the factions are allied with Syria.  Under the agreement for entry of the Syrians, the militias are to lay down their weapons, disband their forces and close their offices in West Beirut. **********As residents awaited the arrival of the Syrian contingents, an uneasy calm hung over West Beirut as civilians ventured out to inspect damage to their homes and to stock up on food. **********The chief of Syrian military intelligence here, Brig. Gen. Ghazi Kanaan, said the Syrian troops would be fully deployed in West Beirut on Monday. He ordered the militiamen to get off the streets and assured West Beirut residents in a radio message that, ''Your ordeal is over.'' **********The Syrian troops drove from their barracks in the Bekaa region of eastern Lebanon through the Shuf Mountains and then along the coastal highway to Khalde, at the southern edge of the capital. The Syrians, who already had a token force in West Beirut, were to link up with Lebanese regular troops at positions guarding public buildings and foreign embassies. **********A report early on Saturday by a Lebanese source in Damascus that the Syrian troops ''are already rolling'' was misinterpreted to mean they had already reached West Beirut. Hundreds Cheer **********In the initial deployment today, Syrian contingents secured control of the roads leading to the airport, which was closed at the beginning of February after Christian militiamen threatened to bombard it. **********Hundreds of people cheered the Syrians as they arrived at Khalde. Lebanese police and army officers and militia commanders were also on hand to greet them. **********The request for Syrian troops was made by Prime Minister Rashid Karami; the Speaker of Parliament, Hussein al-Husseini; Nabih Berri, the head of the Shiite Amal movement, and Walid Jumblat, the Druse leader. Both Mr. Berri and Mr. Jumblat are members of the Lebanese cabinet. **********The Syrian move was condemned by Lebanese Christian leaders. President Amin Gemayel, a Maronite Catholic, said the request was unconstitutional. The Lebanese Front, an alliance of mainly Maronite Catholic figures, called for intervention by the United Nations Security Council and the superpowers to stop the Syrians. **********The overall commander of the Syrian task force in Lebanon, Gen. Saeed Bairakdar, arrived here with the advance contingent. He immediately met with Moslem commanders from the Lebanese Army and then with militia chiefs. Israeli Planes Watch **********The progress of the Syrian troops was monitored by Israeli reconnaissance aircraft, which crisscrossed the sky over the Syrian columns. The Syrians did not not seem to have an air escort. **********Prime Minister Karami and other Government officials were working on details for the deployment. It was agreed that the joint Lebanese-Syrian force will have one commander, who is to be chosen by Mr. Karami. **********Despite the quiet here, sniper fire made crossing streets in many sections dangerous. General Kanaan, in his latest warning to the militiamen, ordered them to release any Lebanese hostages they might hold and clear out of buildings in which they barricaded themselves during the fighting. U.S. OPPOSES OUSIDE TROOPS  WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (Special to The New York Times) - The State Department said today that Lebanon's problems would not be solved by the addition of outside troops. **********''The United States continues to support Lebanon's unity, sovereignty and independence and the withdrawal of all foreign forces,'' Sondra McCarty, a State Department spokeswoman, said. **********In an implicit reference to the Syrian troops, she said in a statement that ''the past 12 years in Lebanon provide ample proof that no external force can impose political or security arrangements in Lebanon.'' **********The United States ''deplores the tragic suffering of the past week,'' the statement added, and supports bolstering the central government as a way to achieve unity in Lebanon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/19/busin.body_text: **********Benjamin V. Lambert, the independent real estate deal maker who last year sold half his company, Eastdil Realty Inc., to Nomura Securities and then disappeared from the marketplace, has come out of hibernation. **********After nine months of total submersion in Japanese ways of looking at real estate, Mr. Lambert has returned to New York armed with a longer perspective on the market and a hoard of cash from Japanese investors eager to acquire assets in the United States. **********His first deal as a Nomura affiliate, a $325 million mortgage on an office building on Third Avenue at 55th Street, is vintage Lambert with an Asian flavor - complex, innovative and long-term. It provides the investors, who are clients of Nomura, with a favorable fixed rate of return for 10 years and a chance to make a killing in 1997 by converting a portion of the mortgage into a 49 percent share of the building at today's price. **********The deal, which closed last month, symbolizes the increasingly sophisticated methods being used by Japanese investors to acquire real estate in the United States. After drawing widespread attention in 1986 for the record prices they were paying for property in New York and elsewhere, the Japanese have increasingly turned to American partners to guide the placement of their real estate investments through more indirect channels. **********Though they have drawn far less attention this year than last, Japanese buyers have doubled their rate of investment in American real estate. After pouring $6 billion into the market in 1986 - and then watching its value erode as the dollar continued to decline against the yen - the Japanese are expected to invest more than $10 billion in the United States before the end of this year, according to several industry estimates. It will be the fourth consecutive year that the Japanese investment has more than doubled. A Shift in Investors **********As the scale of investment has grown, the nature of it has changed. The first Japanese entrants into the American market in 1984 and 1985 were the giant institutions: major banks, insurance companies and trading organizations. The next, the wave that started arriving in the middle of last year, was represented by private family corporations with mountains of cash reserves and access to low-interest financing. Their investments ran to the hundreds of millions of dollars each, usually in prime office properties that were fully leased. **********In New York, Japanese institutions bought the Exxon Building and the Tiffany Building on Fifth Avenue, among other properties, at prices nearly double those that had prevailed two years earlier. In Los Angeles, another buyer set a record for a single property with the purchase of the ARCO Towers for $620 million. Other deals forced up market prices in Atlanta, Washington and Boston. **********While those institutional and large private investors are still in the market, they are not alone. The tier of investors tapped by Nomura for Mr. Lambert's deal includes those prepared to buy units of $10 million each but who wish to have no direct involvement in negotiating the deal or managing the property. These players, generally private business operators, prefer to treat real estate as just another asset in a portfolio. 'That Makes a Good Fit' **********''Because there is plenty of capital available in Japan, the interest rates are very low,'' Mr. Lambert said. ''As a result, Japanese investors are often satisfied with a yield of less than 9 percent.'' For American borrowers, by contrast, a mortgage interest rate at that level is a bargain. ''That makes a good fit,'' Mr. Lambert said. **********The debt-for-equity option also takes advantage of the long-term view of real estate held by many Japanese investors. Property owners in Japan tend to hold on to their real estate for generations. ''Add to that the expanding population and the scarcity of land on which to build and you have an inflation rate for property of 50 percent a year,'' Mr. Lambert said. ''Given their perspective, they don't mind locking in the price at the present level and then waiting for as much as a decade to take ownership.'' **********The new wave of Japanese investors has as its primary focus the same market as its predecessors, Manhattan. The sales materials prepared by Nomura to interest its clients in Japan featured the skyline of midtown with the 47-story skyscraper at 919 Third Avenue circled in red. ''Manhattan Real Estate'' read the cover, in English. **********In many ways the arrangement resembles the real estate syndication deals of the 1970's, in which private investors, primarily Americans, poured billions of dollars into property deals put together by finance specialists. As the popularity of syndication deals spread, the money fueled a speculative boom in real estate that was driven by tax advantages rather than demand. **********The syndication business collapsed in 1986 as outlines of changes in the Federal income tax laws emerged, and it became obvious that Congress intended to eliminate many of the tax advantages of real estate investment. **********The Nomura syndication deal, however, is not tax-driven. Its economics are based on the interest from the mortgage and the ownership option that will allow the investors to cash in on any rise in the value of Manhattan real estate. Owners Also Gain **********The agreement also offers advantages to the owners of the building, a private limited partnership whose members include partners in Lazard Freres & Company and Lazard Realty Inc. They will gain access to the value that had been tied up in the 17-year-old tower without paying income taxes and without relinquishing ownership, at least for now. If the market continues its bullish climb for another 10 years, they will still own more than half of the building. **********While the deal opened up the Manhattan market to a new tier of Japanese investors, it also opened up the capital base of Nomura, the world's largest stock brokerage house, to Mr. Lambert, fulfilling a dream he envisioned 20 years ago when he created Eastdil. **********''I always wanted to operate an independent investment banking organization focusing on real estate,'' he said, ''and I wanted to do it with other people's money.'' Large Financing Role Sought **********If all goes according to plan, Eastdil will complete at least an additional $700 million worth of deals with Nomura clients in the next 12 months and will double that pace in 1989. By then, Mr. Lambert said, he expects Eastdil to have leaped back into the forefront of real estate finance, alongside of Goldman, Sachs & Company and Morgan Stanley & Company, the American investment banks. **********Mr. Lambert helped create such now-common financing mechanisms as sale-lease-back deals, in which a company sells its property and then leases it back from the new owner. He talked other companies into joint venture deals with real estate developers, giving the companies a stake in the completed project. **********In the process he earned a reputation on Wall Street as the dean of real estate, not so much for his age (he is 49 years old) as for his imagination, his mastery of the business and his courtly approach. **********In the last few years, however, he had been overtaken by the larger Wall Street houses whose emerging real estate departments could draw on the capital, the broad client base and the sales abilities of their organizations. **********To many in the industry, his sale last December of half of Eastdil to Nomura for $50 million represented Mr. Lambert's decision to take his winnings and run. Run he did, to Tokyo, where he huddled with Nomura's senior staff to plot a new assault on the American market. **********''There is no shortage of capital,'' Mr. Lambert said. ''It's just a matter of putting together the right structure for the right piece of real estate.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/world.main_headline: MILLIONS OF ZAMBIANS HIT BY ECONOMIC HARDSHIPS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/world.print_headline: MILLIONS OF ZAMBIANS HIT BY ECONOMIC HARDSHIPS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/world.body_text: **********The realities of economic misery are increasingly menacing this dusty town, which is in a tug-of-war against poverty. **********Thieves break into residents' homes, stealing food and nothing else. Intruders boldly uproot vegetables from the private gardens in this bedroom community of Lusaka as soaring prices make the purchase of food impossible. **********''The thieves have stopped fearing arrest,'' said Theresa Katepa, standing in her garden as dusk gently shoved aside daylight. ''They say, 'If I don't steal from you, where do you think I will get food?' It is very common now because of the changes in the economy. These are some of the worst times.'' **********The lament is echoed throughout this southern African nation of 6.5 million people, where President Kenneth D. Kaunda, under pressure from the International Monetary Fund, has instituted what are considered some of the toughest economic measures in Africa. Copper-Dependent Economy **********The program is intended to pull from the brink of collapse an economy that is almost totally dependent on copper and long snared in a bramble bush of sharply falling prices and production. It is also intended to improve the neglected agricultural and manufacturing sectors. **********In a country that once generated the highest per-capita income in black-ruled Africa, the measures are creating greater hardships for millions of Zambians. **********Economists here say that the guidelines are also having the far-reaching effect of pushing this socialist-oriented society, where centrally planned policies have failed yet capitalism remains a dirty word, toward a free-market economy. **********The initiatives have included cuts in the civil service, the decontrol of interest rates, the slashing or elimination of price subsidies and the bolstering of agricultural prices to producers. The centerpiece of the program is a weekly auction of about $9 million of Zambia's meager foreign exchange reserves, attended by business executives, importers and others in need of hard currency. Vital Imports Increased **********The auction has increased the availability of vital imports to industry, heightened the volume of nonmineral exports because of more attractive prices and made access to foreign exchange more equitable. **********Prices for basic commodities have skyrocketed - inflation is running at 50 percent - and the price of food is out of reach for many. One resident said it was increasingly difficult to buy ground up bones for dogs at the market. These days, people are eating the bones. **********Crime has become a constant threat. Motorists, fearing that they will be mugged, have taken to running through red traffic lights at night. The police, aware of mounting attacks, look the other way. Creed of 'Humanism' **********Fundamental questions being asked here include to what extent President Kaunda can carry out the economic measures without shelving his personal creed of ''humanism,'' a blend of Christian principles and African socialism that puts man at the center of development and advocates a classless society. **********In addition, can President Kaunda, chairman of the so-called front-line states neighboring South Africa, go ahead with his pledge to impose sanctions against South Africa, which would undoubtedly cause even greater economic suffering here? **********And in a nation of a tiny elite and so many poor, can Zambia put in place such a sweeping program of change without ripping apart the country's fragile social and political fabric? **********The fabric began to tear last month after President Kaunda abolished certain food subsidies, resulting in a 100 percent increase in the price of high-grade breakfast meal, the staple diet of urban Zambians. Riots in Copper Belt **********The decision led to three days of riots in the industrial copper belt of northern Zambia, where the average miner makes about $16 a month. The riots left at least 15 people dead in some of the worst street violence since this former British colony known as Northern Rhodesia became independent in 1964. **********The President, leader of the most peaceful and politically stable country in the unsteady southern African region, was clearly shaken by the riots. He restored the subsidies. **********Mr. Kaunda's decision caused concern among Western donors over how seriously the move could hurt economic initiatives. By introducing the subsidies, according to economists, the Government would add about $13 million a year to a deficit already far above the International Monetary Fund's target. Finance Ministry officials said last month that the budget deficit would be more than $240 million, about 30 percent of gross domestic product. The I.M.F. target was 9 percent of gross domestic product this year, economists said. Copper Slump a Factor **********Zambian and Western economists say the economic initiatives are all the more critical because of the sustained slump in the copper industry, which provides Zambia with at least 90 percent of its export earnings. Experts predict that the nation's copper reserves will be virtually exhausted in 15 to 20 years. **********Western donors say that Zambia's long-neglected agricultural sector, plagued by lack of capital and expertise, is the short-term salvation for the economy once copper reserves are depleted. Zambia, with rich arable land and reasonable rainfall, has tremendous agricultural potential. **********''People were being killed, so Kaunda had to do something,'' said one Western economic specialist. ''This does not mean that he is ending the reform effort, because he is still extremely committed to it. People have to keep in mind that the subsidies are just one component of a broad array of reforms taking place.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/17/busin.body_text: **********Buoyed by strong sales of core products and gains in overseas sales, the two leading personal computer software companies - Microsoft and Lotus Development - reported record revenues and earnings today. **********Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash., had third-quarter net income of $19.1 million, or 69 cents a share, up 80 percent from $10.6 million, or 42 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues rose 95 percent, to $98.4 million, from $50.5 million a year ago. **********Microsoft said its profits would increase more if proposed accounting changes go into effect regarding incentive stock options. Under those changes, net income for the quarter would be restated as $28 million, or 99 cents a share. **********Lotus, based in Cambridge, Mass., reported first-quarter net income of $13.7 million, or 31 cents a share, up 20.2 percent from $11.4 million, or 23 cents a share, a year ago.
