https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/13/busin.main_headline: CONTINENTAL IS BUYING PRESIDENTIAL AIR'S GATES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; CONTINENTAL IS BUYING PRESIDENTIAL AIR'S GATES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/13/busin.body_text: **********Continental Airlines said yesterday that it was aquiring all the gates and airport facilities of Presidential Airways. **********The small airline will become a feeder carrier for Continental flights at Dulles International Airport near Washington. **********For the Texas Air Corporation, which owns Continental and last year acquired Frontier, Eastern and People Express, the latest move brings dominance over another East Coast hub. Even though Texas Air is not buying any equity in Presidential, it will own its valuable gates and control its flights to serve the Continental system. **********Presidential, which began service in October 1985, will have 15 gates at Dulles when a new building is completed. It operates eight Boeing 737-200's and five smaller BAE 146's. It flies primarily to cities in the East. **********Jeffrey Crowley, a senior vice president of Presidential, said that Continential in combination with Presidential might have about 150 flights a day out of Dulles by the summer. United Airlines is also planning to make Dulles a major hub on the East Coast, and a fierce battle is expected between the two big carriers. **********Mr. Crowley said that the 10-year marketing agreement resembled an acquisition in many ways even though the current management would continue to run the airline and Texas Air would not own any Presidential shares. He said that Presidential decided to find a partner after Continental and United made major expansions at Dulles. ''We opened talks,'' he explained, ''rather than continue to flail away against the giants.'' **********The wave of mergers and acquisitions has become of increasing concern to those who supported deregulation, some of whom have called for greater vigilance from the Department of Transportation, which reviews all acquisitions and mergers. The absorption of upstart carriers such as People Express and Presidential is of particular worry since it was hoped these carriers would bring down fares and keep the larger carriers from monopolizing markets. **********Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Texas Air, said in an interview that the Justice Department would be asked to review the marketing agreement with Presidential to determine if there were any antitrust problems. **********Presidential has acquired two smaller carriers. They are Colgan Airlines, a commuter airline out of Dulles, and Key Airlines, a charter carrier, which will also feed Continental's flights. **********Continental said that it had paid $13 million for the 10 existing Presidential gates and that it had assumed construction obligations of $8.7 million for five more gates. **********Continental yesterday staged an elaborate news conference in a ballroom of the Marriott Marquis Hotel at which Mr. Lorenzo; Tom Plaskett, president of Continental; Donald C. Burr, president of People Express, and Douglas C. Birdsall, president of New York Air, held wads of bills from a pile, said to be of $5 million in cash, stacked around the podium. The $5 million, Mr. Lorenzo said, symbolized what travelers would save daily when they flew Continental after Feb. 1, when the carrier will absorb People Express and New York Air. **********But Mr. Plaskett acknowledged that fares to some People Express destinations would rise after it was absorbed and most of its operations were transferred to Terminal B at Newark International Airport. **********Continental, in a bid to attract new customers, said it would offer a 2-for-1 ticket sale in January for flights in February from New York City area airports.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/04/busin.main_headline: VAN STUDY SET BY FORD AND NISSAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/04/busin.print_headline: VAN STUDY SET BY FORD AND NISSAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/04/busin.body_text: **********The Nissan Motor Company and the Ford Motor Company have agreed to study a joint venture to develop and produce in North America a version of the popular mini-van. **********The feasibility study, announced Friday by Nissan, could lead to a joint venture between the two companies and eventual production of a mini-van line by the early 1990's. The two companies will discuss the location of a plant, whether to build a new plant or use an existing Ford plant, and parts procurement. A final decision on the venture will be made next spring, when the feasibility study ends. **********The project could help Nissan, which has been suffering from the strong yen and losing market share to Japanese rivals. Nissan has long been eager to link up with one of the Big Three American auto makers because of the Toyota Motor Company's relationship with the General Motors Corporation. Moreover, analysts see a huge potential mini-van market. Joint Design Cited **********Nissan executives said that, because the two companies would jointly design a new mini-van and assemble it in North America, the scope of the project could exceed that of the ambitious joint venture between G.M. and Toyota. In that venture, G.M. and Toyota are assembling cars based on an existing Toyota design at G.M.'s former plant in Fremont, Calif. **********''The depth and scope of this cooperative project in North America between the U.S. and Japanese auto industries is unprecedented,'' said Yutaka Kume, Nissan's president. ''We sincerely hope that the feasibility studies will produce satisfactory results for both companies, making it possible to go ahead with the project.'' **********Yukihito Eguchi, a spokesman for Nissan, said that the company envisioned yearly production of about 200,000 mini-vans. Nissan and Ford would produce a new, larger version of the existing mini-van, a scaled-down van that has become popular for shopping, family trips and commuting. Nissan already markets a version called the Stanza Wagon, and Ford sells a model called the Aerostar. Mr. Eguchi said that Nissan expected demand for mini-vans to increase to at least one million models, compared with 630,000 sold last year. Effect on Competitive Position **********Benjamin J. Moyer, an auto analyst for Merrill Lynch's Tokyo branch, said that Nissan could benefit from the venture by learning new technology about the mini-van from Ford, as well as bolstering its competitive position against Toyota. **********''Nissan is interested in strengthening its ties with one of the Big Three, which would help balance the relationship G.M. has with Toyota,'' he said. ''The market is a promising one, and it's a lot easier for Nissan to enter that market with help from Ford than to enter it on its own.'' **********Mr. Moyer said, however, that he had reservations about whether it was best for Nissan to extend itself and spend more money on a new project at a time when it is suffering from financial losses and struggling to cut costs and improve its market share in Japan. ''Perhaps Nissan might be able to use the money in a more productive way,'' he said. **********Nissan is expected to report a loss for the fiscal year that ended March 31, its first since the postwar recovery. The strong yen has hurt Nissan more than other auto maker, coming at a time when Nissan was losing market share in Japan and the United States and producing less-innovative, less-stylish new models. Mr. Moyer said that he expected Nissan to lose 30 billion yen, or $214 million, in its fiscal year. In September, Nissan reported a $121.9 million loss for the first half of the year. **********But Mr. Moyer said that Nissan had moved very rapidly to restructure its dealerships and cut costs, so rapidly that he reduced his previous estimate of Nissan losses. The company has stopped overtime work, cut utility costs, reduced bonuses to its dealers and wrested large price reductions from its parts suppliers, he said. **********Ford also has a long relationship with Mazda, in which it owns a substantial stake. Calls to Mazda's head offices in Hiroshima were not answered Friday. Many offices were closed for an extended Japanese holiday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/13/world.main_headline: U.S. DROPS ITS CASE AGAINST A MARINE IN EMBASSY SPYING
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/13/world.print_headline: U.S. DROPS ITS CASE AGAINST A MARINE IN EMBASSY SPYING
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/13/world.body_text: **********Charges were dropped today against a second Marine guard accused of spying at the United States Embassy in Moscow. The move amounted to an acknowledgment that the Government could not prove that a crippling security breach occurred at the embassy. **********The 21-year-old Marine corporal, Arnold Bracy of Queens, was freed from the Marine brig in Quantico, Va., and immediately accused investigators of coercing his confession and misusing the results of a lie-detector test. **********Charges similar to those against Corporal Bracy were dismissed last month in a case against another Marine guard, Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree, although he still faces a court-martial on other espionage counts. Guards Worked as a Team **********Sergeant Lonetree, who set off the spying investigation last year when he confessed to an affair with a Soviet woman, is still accused of providing Soviet agents with secret American documents, including embassy blueprints and the names of American intelligence officers. **********The two guards, who worked as a team, were originally charged with allowing Soviet agents to roam through the United States Embassy. **********The charges, now dismissed, accused them of turning off embassy alarms as the Soviet officials rummaged through some of the most sensitive areas of the American compound, including the communications room and the military attache's office. **********Those charges were considered the most serious because such actions could have compromised United States intelligence sources within the Soviet Union. 'Feeling Pretty Good' **********The Marine Corps said it had dropped the case against Corporal Bracy because it was unable to corroborate the purported confession he later recanted. **********At a news conference this afternoon at Quantico, however, Corporal Bracy said he had been coerced into confessing and denied allegations that he had sexual contact with a Soviet woman who has been linked to the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence agency. **********He asserted that Naval Investigative Service agents had forced him into a confession by threatening that he would otherwise lose his rights as an American citizen and as a member of the Marine Corps. **********''They told me my life would be over at 21 years old,'' Corporal Bracy said. ''I wouldn't have a decent job, wouldn't eat a decent meal.'' **********''I'm feeling pretty good right now,'' Corporal Bracy said. ''I knew I didn't do it.'' **********He added: ''I didn't feel the Government was going to just drop it. I was figuring they were going to push it as hard as they could to save face.'' **********The decision today prompted expressions of concern about the quality of the investigation against the two Marines. **********American officials said they were unsure of the extent of espionage in the embassy. 'Horrifying Confusion' **********Although senior Administration officials pointed to the original confessions and said they still believed Soviet intelligence agents entered the embassy, prosecutors reportedly were convinced that the charges would not hold up at court-martial. The Marine Corps left open the possibility that Corporal Bracy might face charges in the future. **********A Federal law enforcement official said that although there was now ''horrifying confusion'' about the facts of the case, embassy officials in Moscow ''should continue to assume a worst-case scenario.'' **********''They just have to assume that the Soviets ransacked the place,'' the official said. **********Another Federal official, however, said investigators had found no evidence that Soviet agents had placed bugs on American communications equipment in the embassy, as was originally feared. **********Based on the confession that Corporal Bracy later recanted, the two Marines were charged with escorting Soviet agents through the compound in early 1986. Sergeant Lonetree was charged in January and Corporal Bracy in March. No Physical Evidence **********A Pentagon officer said today that investigators had been unable to find any physical evidence to back up Corporal Bracy's original confession that Soviet agents had roamed through the embassy in Moscow. **********''When Bracy recanted, we had nothing left to go on,'' the officer said. **********A law-enforcement official said equipment from the embassy's communications room had been brought back to the United States. Bracy's Account **********At his news conference today, Corporal Bracy said he was approached in June 1986 by a Soviet cook who worked in the Moscow embassy and was apparently trying to recruit him as a spy. He said he immediately rebuffed the woman and later reported the incident to his commander. **********About three weeks after the original encounter with the cook, the corporal said, he went to a diplomat's home, where the cook worked, to tell her he was angry that Soviet officials would even consider him as a potential spy. He said he failed to report that incident to his commander. **********''I made my mistake when I tried to act on my own,'' Corporal Bracy said. **********It was his former partner at the embassy, Sergeant Lonetree, who set off one of the largest espionage investigations in the nation's history. **********Last year Sergeant Lonetree went to Marine commanders and acknowledged having had an affair with Violetta Seina, a Soviet woman who worked as a secretary at the Moscow embassy. **********According to records detailing the confession, the affair had evolved into an espionage relationship with her purported uncle, who called himself Sasha. Lie Detector Tests an Issue **********After Sergeant Lonetree made his statements, Corporal Bracy was called in for questioning. He said the two guards had allowed Soviet agents to enter sensitive areas of the embassy - a statement he has since recanted. **********At the news conference today, Corporal Bracy's chief defense lawyer, Lieut. Col. Mike Powell, contended that naval investigators improperly used lie detector, or polygraph, tests to coerce the confession last March. **********Defense lawyers have asserted that polygraph examiners mislabeled the results of tests administered earlier this year to Corporal Bracy. **********The lawyers said that the device showed the Marine guard was truthful when he denied espionage activities, but that the test results described him as deceptive. **********The Naval Investigative Service, which handles criminal inquiries for the Navy and Marines, declined comment today. Concern About Inquiry **********Military officials said privately that there was concern that the spying investigation had been mishandled. They would not be specific. **********In a written statement, the Marine Corps said that the investigation ''was conducted in a correct and professional matter'' and that Corporal Bracy remained a suspect in the investigation. **********According to military officials, Corporal Bracy was found deceptive on some, but not all, questions asked during polygraph tests. Under Defense Department polygraph rules, they said, if a suspect is found deceptive in answering one major question, all of the answers are considered deceptive. **********The Marine Corps said it was unclear where Corporal Bracy would be assigned within the service.  MARINES IN MOSCOW: HOW THE CASE HAS EVOLVED  Jan. 7 1987: The Marine Corps discloses that a former embassy guard in Moscow, Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree, 25 years old, is being held; he is said to have confessed in December that he gave secrets to a woman who was a K.G.B. agent who had a custodial job at the embassy and reportedly seduced him.  Jan. 31: The Marines formally charge Sergeant Lonetree with having given the Russians the names and photographs of C.I.A. agents in the embassy and floor plans of the embassies in Moscow and Vienna.  March 24: The Marines announce the arrest of a second former embassy guard, Cpl. Arnold Bracy, 21, on suspicion of espionage as a result of the investigation of Sergeant Lonetree.  March 26: A second espionage charge is lodged against Sergeant Lonetree, based on information supplied by Corporal Bracy. Administration officials say women who were K.G.B. agents trapped them into providing secrets.  March 27: The Marines charge that Sergeant Lonetree and Corporal Bracy allowed Soviet agents to roam through sensitive sections of the embassy on ''numerous occasions'' in 1986. Sergeant Lonetree is also accused of allowing Soviet agents to enter a room where classified messages are decoded. The Marines assert that Sergeant Lonetree paid Corporal Bracy $1,000. There are reports, however, that Corporal Bracy has recanted his confession.  March 30: The Marines announce that all 28 guards at the embassy will be replaced in April. William Kunstler, the defense lawyer, makes public a record of the questioning of Sergeant Lonetree in which the sergeant says he cooperated with a Soviet agent because he was interested in ''knowing what the K.G.B. wanted to know,'' but found himself in over his head.  March 31: The Marine Corps arrests Staff Sgt. **********Robert S. Stufflebeam, who served as a guard at the embassy, on suspicion that he violated regulations against social contacts with Soviet women. He is later charged with socializing secretly with Soviet women and his case is given to a military inquiry. Pending a decision on whether to prosecute, he is assigned to a unit at Quantico, Va.  April 8: The Marines announce that Sgt. John J. Weirick, 26, who was a guard at the United States Consulate in Leningrad before returning to the United States, is being detained on suspicion of involvement in espionage. He is held for questioning at Camp Pendleton, Calif., but is not charged.  April 22: Corporal Bracy is offered immunity from prosecution but rejects the offer.  May 10: Corporal Bracy says the incriminating statements he made were coerced by agents from the Naval Investigative Service.  May 15: The Marines announce that they are dropping the most serious charge against Sergeant Lonetree - that Soviet agents had been allowed inside the embassy - but that espionage charges involving the passing of documents have been upheld. Sergeant Lonetree is still to be court-martialed and remains in the brig at Quantico, but no longer faces the death penalty. The Marines say the charges that were dropped were based on hearsay.  May 20: The Marines announce they are releasing Sergeant Weirick because military law does not permit prosecution for an espionage offense more than two years old.  June 12: The Marines dismiss espionage charges against Corporal Bracy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/21/world.main_headline: Senate, Split on Gulf, Debates Compromise on War Powers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/21/world.print_headline: Senate, Split on Gulf, Debates Compromise on War Powers
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/21/world.body_text: **********Amid deep divisions over how to formulate policy on the Persian Gulf, the Senate began debate today on a compromise approach to the War Powers Resolution. **********The Senate took up the bipartisan compromise after voting 67 to 28 to cut off debate. Those on both sides of the debate had expected the cloture motion, which requires 60 votes, to fail because of a filibuster threat by some Republicans who oppose any assertion of Congressional authority over the President's conduct of foreign policy. **********The Senate was then scheduled to turn to the debate over the confirmation of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court. **********Instead, 17 Republicans joined 50 Democrats in voting for cloture, and the Bork debate was put aside. Senators attributed the unexpected success of the cloture vote to growing concern over recent events in the gulf. The measure is expected to come to a vote Wednesday. Measure of Senate Unease **********This evening, the Senate voted 92 to 1 in favor of a resolution supporting the President's retaliation against Iran on Monday. The only vote against was that of Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon. **********The compromise War Powers legislation is itself a measure of the Senate's unease over how far to assert itself in the face of the Reagan Administration's refusal to comply with the 1973 law. The legislation is sponsored by the Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, and the ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee, John W. Warner of Virginia. **********Under the War Powers Resolution, American military forces that are deployed in ''hostilities or into situations where imminent involvement in hostilities is clearly indicated'' must be withdrawn after 90 days unless Congress declares war or extends the deadline. The Reagan Administration regards the law as unconstitutional. **********The Byrd-Warner compromise does not itself mention the War Powers Resolution. Nor would it require Congress at this time to decide what it wants to do about the Persian Gulf. Rather, the measure would guarantee a vote, 90 days from now, on a resolution to be submitted at that time. **********The measure does not specify the nature of the resolution, which could range from an invocation of the full War Powers Resolution at its most sweeping to a much narrower expression of congressional concern. Partnership in Policy **********In effect, the measure would simply guarantee that Congress in January would have a legislative vehicle, if it wished to use it, for insisting on some sort of partnership in formulating policy in the gulf. **********''If we're going to put lives at stake in a conflict, we do that much better as one nation than as one man,'' said Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Connecticut Republican. **********Mr. Weicker has tried and failed several times to persuade the Senate to invoke the full War Powers Resolution. On the Senate floor today, he described the Byrd-Warner compromise as ''watered down,'' an ''evasion'' of the law on the books. Nonetheless, he said he would support it. **********''I suppose half a loaf is better than none,'' he said. ''At least it can get passed, and around here there is much merit in that.'' **********The measure would also require the President to make a full report, in classified and unclassified form, on the situation and American policy in the Persian Gulf. **********It also contains two statements of policy: an expression of Congressional support ''for a continued U.S. presence in the Persian Gulf,'' and an expression of ''reservations about the convoy and escort operations of U.S. naval vessels'' in support of the Kuwaiti oil tankers now flying the American flag.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/15/world.main_headline: U.S. Grand Jury Indicts 2 Men On Smuggling to South Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/15/world.print_headline: U.S. Grand Jury Indicts 2 Men On Smuggling to South Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/15/world.body_text: **********Two California men have been charged with trying to smuggle sensitive military manuals to South Africa in an indictment that asserts they were given their orders by the naval attache at the South African Embassy in Washington, officials said Friday. **********The indictment, issued Wednesday by a grand jury in Los Angeles, charges that the California men, George M. Posey and Edward J. Bush, were trying to smuggle the manuals to South Africa in violation of the Military Export Control Act as well as the economic sanctions enacted against South Africa by Congress last year. **********It appeared to be the first time that the anti-apartheid legislation has been used as a basis of criminal charges. **********''We wanted to make it clear we were enforcing the act,'' a Government attorney said, adding that the operation appeared to be part of a larger effort to deliver contraband military equipment to South Africa. **********The attache, Capt. Nicholas Vorster, was also named in the indictment. He returned to South Africa at the end of February. State Department officials said he had been recalled to prevent his expulsion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/17/world.body_text: **********Rescue workers today put the death toll at 30 in a flash flood that devastated a vacation compsite here Tuesday. **********Pierre Ravanat, deputy director of civil protection, said the likely death toll was 30, but could reach 35. He said nine people remained hospitalized. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/13/busin.main_headline: Financial Man Elevated At Cincinnati Milacron
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/13/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Financial Man Elevated At Cincinnati Milacron
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/13/busin.body_text: **********Cincinnati Milacron Inc., the nation's largest machine tool manufacturer, said yesterday that Daniel J. Meyer, the company's vice president for finance and administration, had been elected president. **********Mr. Meyer fills a post that had been vacant for nearly two years, since the retirement of Clifford R. Meyer, who is not related to the new president. **********Mr. Meyer comes to his position amid much turmoil within both the company and the machine tool industry. The company recently reported a third-quarter operating loss of $3.9 million, on revenues of $214.3 million, compared with net income of $5 million, on revenues of $229.5 million, a year earlier. **********The industry has been battered in recent years by increased foreign competition. Milacron officials say that their business has not rebounded significantly despite the weakness of the dollar, which they had expected to make imports less attractive to machine tool purchasers. Also, Cincinnati Milacron has suffered from a reduction in capital spending in the automobile industry that has hurt sales of its robotics products. **********Mr. Meyer was said to be in meetings and was unavailable to be interviewed. **********Mr. Meyer joined the company as director of corporate accounting in 1969. He was named comptroller in 1972 and elected treasurer in 1976. He became vice president of finance in 1977 and was promoted to executive vice president in 1986. **********He holds a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering from Purdue University and an M.B.A. from Indiana University. Before coming to Cincinnati Milacron, he was a manager of management service for Touche Ross & Company. **********William E. Buchholz, vice president and treasurer, was named to fill Mr. Meyer's position.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/10/busin.main_headline: JWT STOCK UP ON TAKEOVER RUMORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/10/busin.print_headline: JWT STOCK UP ON TAKEOVER RUMORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/10/busin.body_text: **********The stock of the JWT Group jumped yesterday as takeover rumors surrounded the advertising company. **********Britain's WPP Group, a publicly held advertising company, is expected to announce today that it plans to attempt an unfriendly takeover of the company, parent of the J. Walter Thompson Company, according to a former agency executive. WPP, headed by Martin Sorrell, was said to be planning to offer $46 a share. **********JWT stock climbed $3 yesterday, to $39.25, as 386,400 shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Don Johnston, chairman and chief executive of JWT, was reportedly out of the country yesterday on client business. Don Deaton, a JWT spokesman, said, ''It's all news to us.'' **********He noted that hostile takeovers were rare among agencies and could be damaging to client relationships. **********Mr. Sorrell reportedly has a $460 million war chest. At $46 a share, JWT would be worth $444 million. Mr. Sorrell, WPP's founder, was once group financial director of Saatchi & Saatchi, the advertising giant. **********In recent months JWT, which has lagged financially behind some of its publicly held rivals, has seen a surge in buying of its stock and Wall Street has been waiting for a potential buyer to emerge. **********In January, dissension at JWT burst into the open when Mr. Johnston dismissed Joseph W. O'Donnell as chairman of J. Walter Thompson after Mr. O'Donnell had held that job for less than a month. Mr. O'Donnell had tried to involve an investment banker in taking the company private through a buyout.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/31/world.main_headline: FRENCH SAY BARBIE'S AILMENT ISN'T EXPECTED TO DELAY TRIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/31/world.print_headline: FRENCH SAY BARBIE'S AILMENT ISN'T EXPECTED TO DELAY TRIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/31/world.body_text: **********The hospitalization of Klaus Barbie, the former Gestapo chief in Lyons, is not expected to further delay his long-awaited trial, French judicial officials said today. **********The officials said the trial would probably be scheduled for the spring or early summer despite the hospitalization of Mr. Barbie on Thursday. **********''There is nothing very worrisome about his illness,'' a judicial official said. ''He is being examined by doctors.'' Barbie Admitted to Hospital **********Mr. Barbie, who is viewed here as the last major Nazi official likely to stand trial, was admitted to a hospital in Lyons after reportedly complaining of difficulties in urinating. **********A medical bulletin issued at Mr. Barbie's hospital in Lyons today said his health was ''not disturbing, given his age.'' The bulletin said Mr. Barbie's condition ''requires some special examinations that will allow a quick determination of the necessity and the nature of a treatment.'' **********Since Mr. Barbie was extradited to France from Bolivia in 1983, many people have said they believed a trial would never take place. They have asserted that Mr. Barbie's lawyer, Jacques Verges, intends to try to turn the trial into an expose of members of the Resistance whom Mr. Barbie is expected to name as collaborators with the Nazis. **********Figures close to the trial said today that the preparation for the case, which has taken four years, was not unduly long in the French judicial system.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Aiwa to Sell Digital Recorders
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/13/busin.body_text: **********The Aiwa Company of Japan became the first concern formally to announce a marketing date for a consumer digital tape recorder - a controversial high-fidelity product that could swing customers away from compact disks. Aiwa will begin selling its digital recorder in Japan March 2, but has no plans now for marketing overseas, a spokesman, Kazuhiro Hoshi, said. The list price will be 188,000 yen, or $1,225. **********Although Japanese electronics companies set a common standard more than a year ago for digital recorders, marketing has been delayed because compact disk makers and record companies protested that introduction of digital tapes would enable consumers to make nearly perfect copies of compact disks, thereby cutting into sales of the young, booming compact disk industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/17/busin.body_text: **********The Veterans Administration said today that it would lower the maximum interest rate on federally backed V.A. mortgages to 8.5 percent, the lowest level in almost nine years. **********The reduction, which will take effect Monday, is the eighth cut in the last 21 months and marks the longest sustained rate decline in the 43-year history of the program, the agency said. The last half-point cut, to 9 percent, occurred on Nov. 21. **********The rate has dropped 4.5 percentage points since April 1985 and now is at the lowest level since February 1978. The peak rate, 17.5 percent, was reached in September 1981. **********The new 8.5 percent rate translates into a $25 reduction in the monthly payment for a $70,000 mortgage, decreasing it to $538.24, the agency said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/14/busin.body_text: **********The Great Western Financial Corporation said today that it was discussing the possible sale of its insurance operations to the Celtic Group Inc., a closely held insurance group based in Chicago. No agreement has been reached. **********Great Western, parent of the nation's third-largest savings and loan association, said in November that it might sell the John Alden Life Insurance Company and a commercial leasing unit and reinvest the proceeds into its core business. **********John Alden, which had a book value of $200 million at the end of 1986, posted earnings of $14.7 million for the year and has about $2 billion in assets. **********The unit was acquired in 1983 along with Blazer Financial Services, a consumer lending unit, for a total of $165 million. **********Joe Reed Jr., a thrift industry analyst with Morgan, Olmstead, Kennedy & Gardner in Los Angeles, estimated the unit would sell for between $200 million and $250 million. **********Ian Campbell, a Great Western spokesman, said any proceeds from a sale might be used to expand Great Western's presence in other states. **********A new California law would allow the company to expand its business later this year into other states with similar laws.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/busin.main_headline: Viability Is Stressed At L.F. Rothschild
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Viability Is Stressed At L.F. Rothschild
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/busin.body_text: **********In the midst of last week's market tensions, Andrew L. Berger was quietly named president of the brokerage firm of L. F. Rothschild Inc., which is a unit of L. F. Rothschild Holdings Inc. **********Mr. Berger, who is 40 years old, has been head of the firm's retail division for the last three years. His ascension to president, a post that had been vacant, gives him more of a hand in running the firm along with its two co-chief executives, Francois J. P. Mayer, 46, and Robert Schoenthal, 44, Mr. Berger said. **********L. F. Rothschild, which is unrelated to Rothschild Inc., another securities firm, was one of the first firms last week to report losses in the market plunge, announcing that it had suffered a $44 million net loss. As a result, it got its fair share of mention in articles about shaky brokerages. **********Mr. Berger said L. F. Rothschild's announcement was an ''attempt to restore the confidence of the investing public,'' and added: ''We felt that, by being the first, knowing full well that others also had problems, that we would be in the forefront of the industry in laying out the impact on securities firms.'' **********But the frankness only appeared to hurt confidence in L. F. Rothschild and raise questions about its future. Wall Street sources said that the firm was looking for a buyer or a substantial injection of capital to bolster its financial health. **********L. F. Rothschild has now been joined by other brokerage firms in disclosing losses, and Mr. Berger is attempting to show that its experience has been no worse than others. ''Our house is in order,'' he said. ''We are a viable firm, a strong firm. Basically we are here to stay.'' **********Mr. Berger added that L. F. Rothschild has ''a balance sheet of more than $5 billion and capital of more than a quarter of a billion, after the losses we announced.'' **********He acknowledged that the company was continuing to review business and financial plans, including possible additions to capital, but added that ''we are not in a capital crisis.'' **********Mr. Berger, a lawyer, joined the firm in 1981 to start a legal department and became involved in other aspects. He built the retail division substantially in terms of business and the number of account executives. **********Mr. Berger is a graduate of Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa., and the Columbia Law School. He joined the law firm of Cravath, Swain & Moore after graduation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/14/busin.main_headline: Once Again, the Sound of Music
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/14/busin.print_headline: WHATS NEW IN THE HEARING BUSINESS; Once Again, the Sound of Music
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/14/busin.body_text: **********FLORENCE HOBERMAN, 75, stopped going to the theater when her hearing diminished. ''With the price of tickets, it just wasn't worth the money to miss every other line,'' she said. **********Today Mrs. Hoberman hums showstoppers from ''Les Miserables'' and ''Me and My Girl'' and gives rave reviews to a wireless transmitting method called the infrared system. **********For $2 at most theaters, she can rent a headset that receives the sound from emitters installed throughout a theater. That allows her, she says, to hear well ''even in the rear mezzanine.'' **********Often nicknamed ''binoculars for the hearing-impaired,'' group listening systems were first installed in Broadway theaters in 1980. Since then, more than 20,000 regional theaters, auditoriums, sports arenas and houses of worship have added them. **********According to a study by Hearing Instruments, a trade magazine, the market is expected to double by the beginning of the next century. Congress is considering legislation that would require all publicly financed buildings to provide for the hearing-disabled. **********Sound Associates, based in Manhattan, first imported the infrared system seven years ago from Sennheizer, a West German company that invented it in the late 1970's. **********To test the system, Sound Associates contacted the New York League for the Hard of Hearing, asking volunteers with varying degrees of hearing loss to see a performance of ''Peter Pan'' at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre, in which the system had just been installed. The volunteers said they could hear every lyric Sandy Duncan sang. **********All Broadway theaters, Lincoln Center and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington are now using the systems. **********And when ''Children of a Lesser God,'' a play that deals with a deaf woman, left Broadway for a national tour, an infrared system was installed in each theater at which it played, from Buffalo to Alaska. **********Sound Associates now controls the infrared market, according to Pauline Davies, sales representative at Hearing Instruments. A few small companies have sprung up this year, but they are still testing their systems. **********The price a theater pays to install the system depends on its size, said Rose Jaffe, director of project development at Sound Associates. In 1,096-seat Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center, for example, it cost $13,000 to install four emitters. Each receiver, a panel box with volume control and headsets cost an additional $125. Most theaters own their own systems, although the Shubert and Nederlander houses rent theirs for $300 per week. **********Infrared systems may also bring hearing-impaired people back to the movies. Some Kansas City movie theaters, for example, are now testing them. **********Another technique to help the hearing-impaired is the FM system, which works in a manner similar to that of infrareds but is portable and less expensive. **********FM systems are now mainly used in churches and auditoriums because they require only a single transmitter attached to a speaker's lapel. The listener uses a wireless headset. **********In a 1,000-seat auditorium, a system costs approximately $750, according to Lee Shough, market manager for Phonic Ear, a hearing technology manufacturer headquartered in Mill Valley, Calif.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/24/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has asked the leading New York banks to be prepared to make additional loans to brokerage firms whose credit lines are being cut by regional and foreign banks, according to banking industry experts. **********Although the banks were said to have agreed o the rquest, it appeared that no crisis had emerged and that no emergency credit was required. In part, bankers said, that was because most securities firms had sharply reduced the volume of securities they were holding. The reduced need for credit by the securities firms also reflected the lower value of stocks held by firms for their own account as well as in their customers' margin accounts. **********One banker described the Fed's move as ''an abundance of caution.'' Primary Concern of Fed **********The Federal Reserve usually is very subtle in its relations with banks and does not direct them to make particular loans. Its primary concern is to insure that the overall system does not break down because of a shortage of credit. **********''We were in close contact with banks and other institutions through the week,'' said Peter Bakstansky, vice president of the New York Fed. ''In the circumstances, appropriately prudential extensions of credit and liquidity to the securities market has been of great importance,'' he said. **********''That is the role of the Fed and the commercial banking system,'' said a New York banker, who asked not to be identified. **********Some bankers said they were worried about whether they could afford to continue to carry out such a role because the size of many market transactions - not necessarily loans to the securities industry - were becoming so large that even the biggest commercial banks would be unwilling to accept the risks involved. **********One banker suggested that the only way to overcome the problem would be to allow the creation of ''megabanks'' by allowing big banking companies to be acquired by huge non-financial corporations. Only that way, he said, could a bank amass the kind of capital needed to support such risks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/busin.main_headline: CHIP MAKERS IN ACCORD ON PLAN FOR CONSORTIUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/busin.print_headline: CHIP MAKERS IN ACCORD ON PLAN FOR CONSORTIUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/busin.body_text: **********The nation's semiconductor makers agreed today to form a consortium in an effort to revive American manufacturing technology in the production of computer chips. They appealed to the Reagan Administration for financial support. **********The consortium is a dramatic move by the semiconductor makers, usually an intensely competitive group, to pool their resources in the bruising war with Japan's electronics giants. **********The announcement ended weeks of frantic negotiations over the form and the goals of the prototype plant, called Sematech, for Semiconductor Manufacturing Technology Institute. Cost Is Uncertain **********Supporters of the venture conceded that in their rush to achieve consensus about the formation of Sematech, they left unanswered some important questions. For example, they could provide no estimate of the overall cost of the project, although participants in an industry meeting here quoted figures of $300 million to $400 million a year. **********Sematech's organizers said they had yet to establish with the Justice Department that the project does not violate antitrust regulations. ''It is conceivable that there is a major antitrust issue here,'' said Charles E. Sporck, the chief executive of the National Semiconductor Corporation, who played an influential role in the formation of the effort. **********Irwin Federman, the chairman of the Semiconductor Industry Association, a trade group that has been lobbying heavily in recent weeks for Federal assistance in the venture, called the project critical to saving ''an industry vital to this nation's economy, national security, and its role as a technological leader.'' **********''Our problems today result from the fact that we are individual companies engaged in a battle against nations,'' he said. Choice for Administration **********Government officials involved in talks with the industry's leaders said the consortium plan could force the Administration to choose between its desire to hold down spending and its concern with national security. **********The Defense Science Board, a Pentagon advisory group, recently urged the Government to contribute $200 million a year for chip-manufacturing development, saying the failure to act would threaten national security. Semiconductors are critical components in computers, weapons and sensor systems. However, the proposed Pentagon budget for 1988 sets aside only $50 million for semiconductor technology initiatives. **********Some officials outside of the Pentagon are hesitant to provide direct support to a project they believe is too late and perhaps doomed. And such involvement would appear to run counter to the Administration's view, at least until now, that the industry should revive itself. **********The goal of the prototype plant, according to industry officials, is not to produce semiconductors. Rather, it will develop advanced manufacturing techniques and equipment that can be transferred back to the member companies - an area where Japan has excelled. The plant is expected to be running within 18 months. Emphasis on Manufacturing Sought ''We have tended to put a higher prestige on the engineers who have done chip design that on those who have done the nitty-gritty of manufacturing,'' said Robert Noyce, a founder of the Intel Corporation, at a news conference here today. ''That has to change.'' **********While the Semiconductor Industry Association's board provided few details of their negotiations on Sematech, the plan appeared to mark a defeat for Intel and a victory for the International Business Machines Corporation, which owns about a quarter of Intel. **********Intel officials had argued that in addition to developing manufacturing techniques, Sematech should produce chips in high volume in order to verify that the techniques had industrial applications. But I.B.M. was fearful that it might face pressure to buy any chips produced in volume at the plant, even if other chips of higher quality or lower cost were available. The prototype facility, I.B.M. said, should only make samples of the chips, as ''a vehicle to test our manufacturing skills.'' **********In the end, I.B.M. prevailed. That appears to pave the way for it to contribute heavily to the project, and some speculate it will provide the design of one or more advanced chips to speed the facility's start. **********''We're quite happy with the result,'' said Paul R. Low, the president of the company's general technology division. He said it was too early to say what I.B.M. would contribute, because operating plans for Sematech will not be prepared until June 1. **********The consortium may be too late to save some of the industry's most vulnerable members, Mr. Low said. ''But wringing one's hands over the past is not all that useful,'' he said. ''With great hindsight it would have been better to start two years ago.''
