https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/jobs/.main_headline: Making a Living Is Now A Family Enterprise
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/jobs/.print_headline: Making a Living Is Now A Family Enterprise
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/jobs/.body_text: **********PURSUING a livelihood in America is increasingly a family enterprise, where success is no longer measured by the earning power of a single job. **********Most families who reach the upper levels of national income today are getting there by combining the pay of two and even three jobholders. Family income, rather than the particular achievement of a husband or wife, then, is becoming the key to making a living and to job success. **********''The spotlight is on the two-earner family, in which the husband and wife are highly committed to the labor force,'' says Gordon Green, a Census Bureau official. Audrey Freedman, a labor specialist at the Conference Board, a business-research organization in New York City, added: ''One of the first things to do is to get married, or remarried, and stay that way.'' **********The statistics tell the story. After more than a decade of stagnant incomes, only 17.7 percent of the 115.8 million Americans employed last year earned $30,000 or more, despite an unemployment rate that has fallen to its lowest level in this decade. Those who broke the $30,000 barrier were mostly corporate executives, or doctors, engineers and lawyers, or in banking and finance. But about 36 percent of the nation's jobholders brought home between $15,000 and $30,000. And the types of jobs they held - as salesmen and clerks, craftsmen, medical specialists, television and computer repairmen and paraprofessionals - are among those multiplying most rapidly in the American economy. **********While most American workers appear to be stuck in jobs that pay below $30,000, family incomes are another matter. There were 64.5 million families, people who are related and live together, in the United States last year, accounting for most of the nation's population, according to the Census Bureau. Some 26 million of these families, or 40 percent, had incomes above $35,000, which many experts consider a sort of minimum level today for entry into the middle class in most parts of the nation. **********The great majority of these families - 21.6 million in all -were grouped in the range of $35,000 to $75,000, and nearly 80 percent of the families had two or more wage earners. **********In the postwar years until 1973, two wage earners were not so necessary, though women had begun to enter the work force in large numbers. The median family income, adjusted for inflation, grew steadily from 1947 until 1973, when it reached $28,200 (as measured in 1984 dollars). After that watershed year family income reversed course, declining steadily until 1983 and rising modestly since then, but only to $27,906 last year. Meanwhile, home ownership, one of the great definers of the middle class, became ever more costly. **********''If you were earning in this median range, with two kids and college ahead, you would be scratching your head and wondering if you were in the middle class,'' said Frank Levy, a University of Maryland economist and the author of the recent book ''Dollars and Dreams,'' a study of American income distribution. ''That's because there is no longer the income growth that characterized earlier periods and gave people a sense of improving their lot. You have to be a two-earner family today to qualify for the middle class.'' **********A recently announced Labor Department survey illustrated the point. It showed a dramatic increase in the number of working women with children under a year old. Only 31.6 percent of these mothers held jobs in 1977. But the percentage rose to 43.3 in 1982 and 51.9 as of last March. **********''These families need the money to maintain what is perceived as the ideal life style,'' said Howard Hayghe, a Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics economist. ''In a sense, the wife brings along a dowry to the marriage, and the dowry is her job.'' **********That job, however, usually brings in less than the husband's. Only rarely does a blue-collar husband - a man working in construction or in a factory or as a craftsman or supervisor -find himself married to a woman employed as an executive or as a doctor or lawyer. In most cases, to reach the high end of the $35,000 to $75,000 income spread, one spouse, usually the husband, often is a corporate executive, or the owner of a business, or a doctor or a lawyer, Mr. Hayghe said. **********Roughly 20 percent of men in this top managerial category are married to women in similar work, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports. But in the majority of cases, the wives are teachers, nurses, secretaries, clerks, receptionists, travel agents and computer operators. **********Aside from having a second wage earner in the house, income potential today is affected more by education than it was a decade ago. In the early 1970's, baby boomers were still entering the labor force and there was an oversupply of workers, which damped wages. As a result, the spread between the incomes of a high school and college graduate were not that great, Mr. Levy noted. Both had roughly an even chance of climbing into middle-class incomes. **********But today, the much smaller post-baby-boom generation is just coming of age and young workers are in short supply. College graduates are particularly sought after in an economy dominated by service-sector jobs, and the unemployment rate among the college-educated is almost zero, labor experts say. The changing dynamics are reflected in the growing income gap for high school and college graduates. The median income of men with five years or more years of college was $34,731 last March, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports, and that for women with the same education was $26,399 - making a total of $61,130. By comparison, the median incomes of a man and woman with only high school degrees totaled $36,888. **********But a middle ground is beginning to develop - one occupied by people who can be trained at community colleges as paraprofessionals, or as skilled office personnel who can be assigned to a variety of administrative jobs and data-processing tasks. **********The paraprofessional is a particularly promising trend, according to Richard Belous of the Conference Board. ''If you go to Harvard and became a brain surgeon, you are obviously in,'' he said, ''but for the people who don't go to Harvard, there can be relatively good careers as paraprofessionals in law, medicine, accounting, even engineering.'' **********As Mr. Belous sees it, the paraprofessional is coming into his own because American companies, facing stiff global competition, are seeking less-expensive ways to get work done. Many high-priced lawyers, for example, spend a great deal of time filling out forms and doing other routine work that can be handled by paralegals, Mr. Belous said. **********''The same is true in accounting, where bookkeeping is a big factor, and in medicine,'' he said. ''The model for the future, in fact, is the visit to the dentist, where five minutes is spent with the receptionist, twenty with the hygienist and only five with the dentist. Similarly, in law, you will come to see the senior partner, but the paralegal will do the work.'' (As an accompanying listing shows, the percentage gain in openings for paralegals is expected to be the highest among all occupations during the rest of the century.) Already in Washington, paralegals in top law firms earn more than $15,000. And the salary range for paraprofessionals in various fields might in time rise to between $15,000 to $20,000 a year in various parts of the nation, ''once American companies accept the concept of the paraprofessional,'' Mr. Belous said. **********That is not the level of income generally associated with middle-class status. ''But it does not take very exalted jobs, if two people hold them, to get above the $35,000 level,'' said Gary Burtless, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. **********It does, however, take patience. Hundreds of thousands of two-earner couples are holding jobs that might start at $15,000 or so and climb over the years to the mid-$20,000 level. This slow progress is reflected in the age breakdowns of wage earners in multi-income families. **********''The key is stability,'' said Stephen J. Rose, an economist with the Washington State Senate and an expert on income distribution. ''Even without a high level of professional training, if you move up the seniority ladder as a salesman or a factory worker or a school teacher or a paralegal, and stay with your family, you can make it into the upper income levels.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/10/world.main_headline: SAUDI BUSINESSMAN IN IRAN AFFAIR TELLS OF 'PLAYING GAMES' WITH U.S. AIDES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/10/world.print_headline: SAUDI BUSINESSMAN IN IRAN AFFAIR TELLS OF 'PLAYING GAMES' WITH U.S. AIDES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/10/world.body_text: **********The Saudi businessman who helped finance the sale of arms to Iran, Adnan Khashoggi, says he played ''games within games'' with William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, and with other American officials involved in the Iran-contra affair. **********Mr. Khashoggi, accompanied by a business associate, Roy Furmark, described some of these ''games'' that resulted in the deception of United States officials and agencies in a long interview in his apartment here over the weekend. **********Mr. Khashoggi's account of his role in the sales of American arms to Iran differed in some respects from his previous public statements. The Saudi financier's shifting stories, given in rare interviews, are as complex as the layers of corporations and financial transactions that financed the arms sales, and the subsequent diversion of some of the profits from those sales to the Nicaraguan rebels. **********According to the interview and a review of some documents provided by Mr. Khashoggi, these were some of the ''games'' he played: *********** Mr. Khashoggi said he masterminded a deliberate deception of Mr. Casey last fall, when Mr. Casey was still head of the Central Intelligence Agency, by inventing a group of angry Canadian investors who were supposedly threatening to disclose the Administration's secret arms sales to Iran unless they were immediately reimbursed for a $10 million contribution to a $15 million arms sale to Iran last May. *********** Mr. Khashoggi said he toyed with F.B.I. officials by telling them that his financial records were buried in the sand under seven hills in the Saudi Arabian desert. Mr. Khashoggi said the F.B.I. took him seriously and wrote to the Saudi Ambassador in Washington to try to recover his records. *********** Mr. Khashoggi said that he had quietly bankrolled the Iranian middleman, Manucher Ghorbanifar, throughout his involvement in the secret arms deals and that he had also introduced Mr. Ghorbanifar to the Israelis. They, in turn, passed Mr. Ghorbanifar on to American officials, who used him as an intermediary in the arms sales. Mr. Khashoggi disclosed that at one point he had taken out a short-term insurance policy on Mr. Ghorbanifar's life. *********** He said Federal investigators had been able to find and freeze only six of his bank accounts, totaling $60 million in assets. But he said investigators had not been able to locate all of his accounts and did not even know the names of all the accounts. **********The interviews with Mr. Khashoggi and Mr. Furmark in Paris this weekend came after the release of the Tower Commission report, which said the United States used unreliable individuals to plan and carry out the sale of weapons to Iran.  AN ATTEMPT TO MISLEAD IS LAID TO KHASHOGGI **********There was no independent means of confirming Mr. Khashoggi's account of the deception of Mr. Casey or of the other ''games'' he says he played with American officials. Federal investigators confirm, however, that Mr. Khashoggi tried to mislead them about the location of his financial records. **********Mr. Furmark arranged Mr. Khashoggi's meeting with a reporter from The New York Times, asserting that the two men were motivated by a desire to be open about their roles in the Iran-contra affair. **********The F.B.I., conforming to its normal procedures during an investigation, declined comment on Mr. Khashoggi's remarks about his records. But a Federal law-enforcement official with knowledge of the Iran-contra investigation understood that there had been communication between the Justice Department and the Saudi Embassy in Washington regarding permission to seek the records in Saudi Arabia. **********He declined to elaborate, but he added that Mr. Khashoggi had presented ''pretty wild stories'' about the location of his financial records and assets. **********''As best we can tell from Khashoggi,'' the official said, ''his records might be in the dunes of Arabia, and they might be on the dark side of the moon.''  TRAIL OF MONEY TAKES CIRCUITOUS ROUTE **********The interviews here and a review of some selected documents that Mr. Khashoggi and Mr. Furmark permitted this reporter to examine indicated that the flow of money in and out of Lake Resources, the Panama-registered shell company used by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the former National Security Council aide, and his associates, are far more complicated than previously known. **********The records show that a number of previously unpublicized Khashoggi companies were used to transfer money to both Lake Resources and Mr. Ghorbanifar. **********Documents in the report of the Tower Commission, which was appointed by President Reagan, indicate that Mr. Khashoggi was at the same time receiving money from both Lake Resources and Mr. Ghorbanifar. **********Mr. Khashoggi said Mr. Ghorbanifar asked him in 1986 to raise $100 million for the contras from the Saudi royal family so that he and Mr. Khashoggi could gain ''influence in Washington.'' Mr. Ghorbanifar made the suggestion when the Administration was quietly seeking alternative funding for the contras, after Congress had declined to authorize $100 million in aid. **********Mr. Khashoggi said he rejected Mr. Ghorbanifar's proposal, but that the two men later planned to split a $100 million sale of American missiles to Iran with the guerrillas fighting the Soviet-backed Afghan Government. Mr. Khashoggi said that under the scheme, which never came to fruition, half of the missiles would have been delivered to the Afghan guerrillas and half to the Iranian Government. **********The information provided by Mr. Khashoggi indicates that Saudi money was the principal source of funds for the Iran arms sales, and that the money from the Iran sales in turn supported private operations by Colonel North and his associates, including support for the contras. Both Mr. Khashoggi and Mr. Furmark continue to deny any knowledge of the diversion of proceeds from the Iranian arms sales.  A CASEY FRIEND PLANTED FALSE STORY **********Crucial questions about the money from the Iran arms deals remain unanswered. What, for example, were the sources and amounts of funds available for diversion and where did they end up? **********During the interview, Mr. Khashoggi seemed to revel in the games he had played with American officials, portraying the complicated series of financial transactions and occasional mistatements to Americans as good financial sport. **********In his discussion of the way he said he misled Mr. Casey, Mr. Khashoggi said the story about the angry Canadian investors who wanted their $10 million back was planted last fall with Mr. Casey by Mr. Furmark, a longtime friend of Mr. Casey. **********Mr. Khashoggi said the story was intended to increase pressure on the Reagan Administration to reimburse the $10 million to Mr. Khashoggi, so he could repay an associate. **********Mr. Furmark was not aware that there were no Canadian investors when he met with Mr. Casey, Mr. Khashoggi and Mr. Furmark asserted. The money came not from Canadians, Mr. Khashoggi said, but from a Saudi business associate, whom Mr. Khashoggi declined to identify. **********Mr. Furmark's discussion with Mr. Casey about the Canadian investors helped start inquiries by the C.I.A. and Congressional investigators of the Iran-contra arms sales. **********Two Canadian associates of Mr. Khashoggi's, Ernest Miller and Donald Fraser, administer a Cayman Islands company through which the $10 million in Saudi funds passed. Their names were the ones mentioned when Mr. Furmark made his disclosures last fall.  GRACIOUS HOST SHOWS ANGER OVER THE TOWER REPORT **********Mr. Khashoggi, who likes to parry with those seeking to unravel his finances, seemed relaxed throughout the evening of interviews, a gracious host who showered his guests with nuts, condiments, Perrier and arak, a strong Middle Eastern alcoholic drink. **********He was repeatedly interrupted by aides, telephone callers and other visitors. After meeting with a visiting oil minister from the Persian Gulf, Mr. Khashoggi slipped away to change from a finely tailored Western business suit into a long, flowing, white caftan that is Saudi Arabia's national dress. **********Some of Mr. Khashoggi's angriest comments were reserved for the Tower Commission. He denied a finding in the commission's report that he had billed both Mr. Ghorbanifar and Lake Resources for $20 million in payments for the arms sales. **********He said he was not aware that ''personal'' funds from the Saudi royal family had been the largest source of financing for the rebels in Nicaragua over the last two years, a conclusion that is hinted at in the Tower report. After the report was released, sources familiar with testimony before the commission said the third country referred to as being the largest source of contra financing was Saudi Arabia. **********Mr. Khashoggi has enjoyed a close relationship with various members of the royal family. The role of Mr. Khashoggi and Saudi officials in arms sales by American companies to Saudi Arabia prompted many investigations in the 1970's, though Mr. Khashoggi was never accused of a crime. **********He characterized his current relationship with the Saudi Government, as well as with other Arab nations, as ambiguous, warm when his efforts at private diplomacy succeed and cool when they do not. **********Mr. Khashoggi said he had made King Fahd aware of his intentions to improve relations between the United States and Iran from the beginning, but that the King did not want to get involved because it was too risky and sensitive.  A FABLE ABOUT RECORDS BURIED IN SAUDI SANDS **********Mr. Khashoggi said he was pleased that ''my country did not issue a statement saying we don't know you'' or take back his passport after it became publicly known that he was dealing with Israel and Iran, both officially shunned by Saudi Arabia. **********In the case of Iran, evidence in the Tower Comission report and elsewhere shows that Saudi Arabia was quietly improving its relations with Iran, at least partly in tandem with the secret United States initiative. **********Now, Mr. Khashoggi said, the United States had asked his country for help in getting information on his role in the Iran arms sales. Federal officials, he said, had asked Prince Bandar, the Saudi Ambassador in Washington, about gaining access to his records, a request that Mr. Khashoggi suggested may have been prompted by a jest he made to an F.B.I. agent. Mr. Khashoggi said he had told the agent that his records were buried in the sand under seven hills in Arabia. **********Mr. Khashoggi said the remark had been a joke, but he also said he had been ''mean'' to the F.B.I. agent who interviewed him. **********Some of Mr. Khashoggi's bank accounts have been frozen in Switzerland at the request of the United States - six accounts containing some $60 million, he said. Mr. Furmark said other related accounts in the United States may also have been blocked. Mr. Khashoggi complained that the two-month freeze had forced his American companies to petition for restructuring under Federal bankruptcy statutes. **********But, he added with a smile, Federal investigators had not been able to locate all of his accounts since they do not know their whereabouts, or even the names of all of his companies. **********''Some we were lucky, some we were not so lucky,'' Mr. Khashoggi said of the requests to freeze assets.  A BEWILDERING BLUR OF BANK TRANSACTIONS **********Some of Mr. Khashoggi's records are stored in Geneva, at Management and Control Inc., a Khashoggi-controlled company that handles his accounting and banking records. Sammy Fadel, the head of the company, which occupies an entire floor of a downtown office building, declined to discuss any of Mr. Khashoggi's financial affairs or to make available any additional records. **********The records made available by Mr. Khashoggi at the interview, compiled by Mr. Fadel and his associates, reveal an almost indecipherable series of transactions. They show that Mr. Khashoggi transferred $25 million into the Lake Resources account in the Credit Suisse bank in Geneva in 1986. **********The transfers came from various personal accounts, as well as from corporate accounts called Trivert and Garnet, some at Credit Suisse and at other banks in Monte Carlo, where the United States does not enjoy the kind of access to banking records that it has with Switzerland. **********The records further indicate that Mr. Ghorbanifar paid $20 million to Mr. Khashoggi, apparently repayment for $25 million Mr. Khashoggi had advanced to Lake Resources; $8 million to the accounts that funded Lake Resources; issued one $3 million check, whose recipient was not specified; and wrote three other checks totaling $9 million to two other companies, Kremdale and Galliot. **********Mr. Furmark, who tried to explain the recorded transactions to this reporter, said Mr. Khashoggi had told him that Kremdale, Trivert, Garnet and Galliot were all Mr. Khashoggi's companies. **********''Who knows how many companies he has?'' Mr. Furmark said in an interview on Saturday. **********The documents also show that Mr. Khashoggi paid money directly to Mr. Ghorbanifar. For example, a check for $533,250 drawn on the account of Garnet on April 16, 1986, was described by Mr. Furmark as reimbursement of Mr. Ghorbanifar's expenses. Mr. Khashoggi said, moreover, that he had bankrolled Mr. Ghorbanifar, and that last May he had taken out a $22 million short-term life insurance policy on the Iranian, whom he described as his partner and ''contact.''  DISAVOWAL OF THREAT TO KILL GHORBANIFAR **********The Tower report reproduced a memo by Colonel North dated July 30, 1986, suggesting that if the Iranians didn't receive an expected shipment of weapons, ''Ghorbanifar will be killed by his creditors (they are the beneficiaries of a $22 million life insurance policy).'' **********Mr. Furmark and Mr. Khashoggi denied this suggestion as well as many other statements contained in the Tower report. Mr. Khashoggi said, for example, that he knew nothing about $40 million to $59 million that the commission said had been paid to Mr. Ghorbanifar for an aborted missile sale in November 1985. **********Mr. Khashoggi said that he had spoken in recent days with Mr. Ghorbanifar, Mr. Furmark and Amiram Nir, the Israeli adviser involved in the Iran sales, and that they all agreed that the Tower Commission and the Senate Intelligence Committee had erred in stating that millions of dollars in profits from the American arms sales to Iran had moved through Mr. Ghorbanifar to Mr. Nir and Mr. Khashoggi. Mr. Ghorbanifar could not be reached for comment. **********Mr. Khashoggi, said by Mr. Furmark to have few records of the affair, said he considered Mr. Ghorbanifar ''the most fascinating man I've ever known,'' except, he joked, for himself.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/16/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY NEWS; CONGRESS AMENABLE TO FURTHER DROP
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/16/busin.body_text: **********As the value of the dollar stabilized today, leading members of Congress said they would welcome a further decline to help shrink the nation's trade deficit - if it came in an orderly way. **********Meanwhile, West German officials said they were considering reductions in their nation's taxes. That might accommodate the Reagan Administration's urgings that the Germans spur their economy. Faster growth would increase the German demand for imports and help reduce the American trade deficit. **********The Federal Reserve Board reiterated Paul A. Volcker's view that the dollar had fallen enough, but Wall Street traders said they had found no evidence that the Fed chairman was trying to stop the dollar's fall by buying dollars and selling other currencies in the open market. **********''We need to use caution and bring it down carefully because there's always the risk it could fall precipitously, and that wouldn't be good for anyone,'' said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee. **********An aide to Robert H. Michel, Republican minority leader of the House of Representatives, said Mr. Michel ''has been extremely gratified by the decline,'' adding, ''I don't think it has reached the point in his mind where he thinks it has gone too far.'' **********Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, said, ''I am very satisfied with the decline of the dollar so far, and I would be satisfied with more.'' **********Senator William Proxmire, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the Banking Committee, said: ''I welcome the decline. No question about it.'' Like Senator Bentsen, he said the Administration should now try to put pressure on Canada, South Korea and Taiwan, whose currencies have changed little against the dollar, to let it fall in relation to them. **********Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, introduced legislation this month directing the Administration to force a dollar decline by negotiating reductions in the currency with such countries and by selling $30 billion in the foreign-exchange market over three years. An aide said Senator Moynihan said the drop in the dollar made little difference to the proposal. ''He thinks the dollar should go lower,'' the aide said. **********The sharpest declines have occurred against the Japanese yen and the West German mark. **********Views in Congress seemed generally at odds with those of Mr. Volcker and consistent with those of the Administration - that the Government should not feed a decline by selling dollars or appealing for a lower dollar but that it also should not try to halt erosion of the currency. **********Today the White House declined to comment on its apparent differences with Mr. Volcker, which have arisen periodically throughout the retreat from the dollar's peak of two years ago. ''It's a longstanding policy that we don't try to tell chairman Volcker how to run his business,'' Albert R. Brashear, a spokesman for the President, said at a briefing with reporters. Analyst's View of Conflict **********The conflict between Mr. Volcker and Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d may be less acute than it has sometimes appeared, and it may even be intended to assure that the decline of the dollar does not run out of control, said Rimmer De Vries, chief international economist at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. **********Mr. De Vries said the two had been playing a harmonious duet, with one supporting a lower dollar and the other objecting but working together to guide the decline in an orderly way. ''This is a beautiful game they're playing,'' he said. **********An economics official at the West German Embassy here, Dietrich von Kyau, said he thought Bonn would decide how to deal with Mr. Baker's appeals for a more vigorous economy soon after the Jan. 25 national elections in West Germany. **********''The Government will decide what it should do for the world economy,'' Mr. von Kyau said. In the past, Mr. Baker has urged West Germany to reduce interest rates, which would stimulate its economy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/24/world.main_headline: Jordan Plans to Revive Its Relations With Libya
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/24/world.print_headline: Jordan Plans to Revive Its Relations With Libya
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/24/world.body_text: **********Jordan decided today to restore diplomatic relations with Libya, broken since crowds burned down the Jordanian Embassy in Tripoli in February 1984, the official press agency, Petra, reported. **********Petra said the decision to renew ties with Libya was in line with ''Jordan's firm commitment to the higher interest of our Arab nation.'' **********Petra said the decision was made at a Cabinet meeting led by King Hussein. The Cabinet discussed preparations for an Arab summit conference to be held in Amman on Nov. 8 to discuss the Iran-Iraq war. **********Jordan has been a staunch ally of Iraq throughout the seven-year-old Persian Gulf conflict. **********Libya at first aligned itself with non-Arab Iran, but has recently restored ties with Iraq and called for a cease-fire in the conflict. **********Jordan's Tripoli Embassy was burned down in 1984, apparently in response to King Hussein's attempts to find a peaceful, negotiated settlement to the Arab-Israeli conflict. **********Libya was also angered by his call for the rehabilitation of Egypt, shunned by the Arab League since its 1979 peace treaty with Israel. Jordan renewed ties with Cairo in September 1984.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/05/world.main_headline: WHITE HOUSE WILL BE ASKED IF 3 ARE LINKED TO IRAN AFFAIR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/05/world.print_headline: WHITE HOUSE WILL BE ASKED IF 3 ARE LINKED TO IRAN AFFAIR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/05/world.body_text: **********The chairman of a House subcommittee said today that he would ask the White House to reveal the duties of three Small Business Administration employees working at the White House without the consent of their agency. **********Requests from both the General Accounting Office and the Small Business Administration for interviews with the employees have been turned down by the White House. The only information Congressional investigators have on the three employees is in a letter from a White House aide who resigned after he was linked to the Iran-contra affair. **********Representative John Conyers Jr., a Michigan Democrat who heads the Subcommittee on Criminal Justice, said he would request specific information on the status and duties of the employees and on their relationship with Johnathan S. Miller, former Assistant to the President for Administration and Management. Linked to North **********Mr. Miller resigned after testimony in the hearings on the Iran-contra affair identified him as having helped transfer cash from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to Nicaraguan rebel leaders. **********Mr. Conyers said he would ask the White House specifically if the three employees were involved in illegal activities related to the Iran-contra affair. He said he also planned to contact the office of the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair about the employees, who have been identified as Gina Kormanik, Karol Anne Lamos and Ramona Ely. **********A recent inquiry by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, found that the three Small Business Administration employees have no contact with, and perform no work for, the agency that pays them. The G.A.O. called that and the White House's failure to inform Congress about the employees violations of Federal law. A Promotion for Employee **********Spokesmen at the White House declined to answer questions about the employees, other than to say that the S.B.A. would be reimbursed for their salaries. **********In the only communication with the General Accounting Office about the employees, Mr. Miller, before his resignation, said all three were assigned to the Office of Presidential Personnel and confirmed they had no contact with the Small Business Administration. A similar letter was sent by Mr. Miller to the Small Business Administration. Both letters were in response to requests from those agencies. **********One of the employees, Ms. Kormanik, was promoted three Civil Service ranks, from GS-8 to GS-11, in 1985 after less than nine months on the job. An ''approval to waive qualification requirements'' form signed by Robert A. Turnbull, Associate Deputy Administrator for Management and Administration, justified the promotion by saying that Ms. Kormanik was performing ''important assignments that are confidential in nature'' for the head of the Small Business Administration.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/23/busin.body_text: **********An advisory committee that issued a widely praised report last year, in which it urged Japan to restructure its economy, is now calling for faster, more profound changes to placate Japan's trading partners and raise Japanese living standards. **********The committee's new report, to be submitted Thursday to Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, comes amid mounting criticism both at home and overseas over Japan's slowness to act on last year's recommendations. Committee members acknowledged that they had no guarantee the new proposals would be put into effect. **********Last year's Maekawa report, named after the committee's chairman, recommended that Japan trim its huge trade surplus by stimulating its economy, buying more imports, phasing out inefficient domestic industries, reducing working hours and changing its tax system to cut income taxes and discourage saving. **********According to a committee member and Japanese press accounts, this year's follow-up report outlines more concrete steps to achieve these goals within the next three to five years. Some Committee Proposals **********The proposed steps include spurring housing construction, stimulating Japan's domestic economy, easing import restrictions, allowing foreign companies to particpate in Japanese construction projects and cutting the workweek to less than 40 hours. **********The report takes aim at several sacred cows: Japan's food supply system, which sets production levels and prices for such staples as rice; the distribution system, which has been blamed for hindering the sale of foreign goods and keeping prices high; Japan's austere fiscal policy, a pillar of the Nakasone administration that critics assert has slowed economic growth; the tight regulation of Japan's petroleum industry, which has set low prices for home heating oil and high prices for gasoline, and Japan's land policy, which contributes to expensive housing by keeping taxes low on farmland. **********Many of these proposals run up against politically powerful vested interests in Japan, and they are bound to encounter spirited opposition. **********''There is no guarantee whatsoever as to whether there is a consensus to implement these measures or not,'' said one member of the committee who asked to remain unidentified. Comment by Panel Member **********''I am not satisfied with the implementation of the Maekawa report,'' said Isamu Miyazaki, a committee member who is also chairman of the Daiwa Securities Research Institute. ''It was too little, too late.'' For its part, the Government released a report Tuesday citing progress in shifting the Japanese economy away from reliance on exports. The Government, this report noted, acted to spur housing investment by reducing interest rates on Government housing loans and proposing tax revisions that would allow some deductions for mortgages, submitted a bill proposing a reduction of working hours, eased cumbersome import regulations, established the Tokyo offshore market, cut the official discount rate five times in an effort to stimulate Japan's sluggish economy and announced plans to increase foreign aid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.body_text: **********MARKET TURMOIL  The world's central banks allowed the dollar to slide a notch, apparently fearing that further efforts to maintain its value would rattle the stock market and undermine economies around the world. Throughout the day, the central banks tempered the currency's decline by buying dollars, although traders said the official buying, though widespread, was modest. Officials said the buying apparently marks a shift in the Reagan Administration's eight-month-old policy of keeping the dollar's value steady.  [ Page A1. ]  Amid fears of a U.S. recession, the dollar's value plunged to its lowest level in seven years against the West German mark. [ D11. ] The stock market faced new pressures but did not lose its balance on the 58th anniversary of the 1929 crash. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.33 point, to 1,846.82. Still, most stocks lost ground and selling of smaller issues continued. Given the dollar's drop, the market's relative calm surprised some experts. [ A1. ] Administration and Congressional negotiators started talks on a budget compromise, but their initial sparring produced few conclusive results.  [ D1. ]  The Thatcher Government backs international demands that the U.S. budget deficit be trimmed, even if tax increases are needed.  [ D1. ]  Bonn thinks the budget deficit is responsible for higher rates worldwide. [ D10. ] The S.E.C. chairman suggested tighter regulation would result if the Government were directly responsible for setting rules on down payments for trading in stock-index futures.  [ D8. ]  The market for S.&P. 500 stock-index futures rallied modestly. [ D20. ] Stocks of U.S. underwriters involved in the British Petroleum offering were hit hard by heavy selling in anticipation they will suffer big losses on the issue. [ D1. ] The volatile Mexican stock market is now suffering the steepest, most rapid slide of any leading exchange.  [ D1. ]  The Tokyo stock market opened sharply lower this morning. [ D12. ] OTHER MARKETS B ond prices slumped for the second straight session, pushed lower by the dollar's decline on world currency markets. Meanwhile, short-term interest rates dropped sharply.  [ D19. ]  Yields declined for C.D.'s and money market mutual funds but rose for money market accounts in the recent week. [ D21. ] COMPANIES  The new management of Continental Illinois will focus on investment banking and strip away most of its commercial banking activities. Thomas C. Theobald, Continental's chairman, said it would sell all its small Chicago-area banks and drop out of the unprofitable municipal securities business. [ D5. ] L. F. Rothschild is seeking a buyer or a large capital injection, according to several Wall Street professionals. According to the sources, the financially troubled firm has been working with its investment banker, Salomon Brothers, to find an acquirer.  [ D4. ]  Primerica said that Smith Barney's recent trading losses would hurt its fourth-quarter results. [ D4. ] Henley Group owns 14.1 percent of Santa Fe Southern Pacific, capitalizing on the weakened stock market. It said it might seek control of the railroad and real estate concern. [ D5. ] LTV and Bethlehem posted profits in the third quarter, rebounding from losses in the 1986 quarter. [ D4. ] Crazy Eddie faces two Federal inquiries: an investigation into its business practices, and a separate S.E.C. examination. [ D20. ] Asher B. Edelman said that a Citicorp unit had joined in his hostile bid for Telex. [ D4. ] THE ECONOMY  The disclosure of credit-card interest rates would be required by a bill approved overwhelmingly by the House of Representatives. The lone opponent was Philip M. Crane, who maintains that only states should regulate credit-card rates. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMN  The leveraged buyout of Southland has been imperiled by the stock market's plunge because of investors' jitters over the ''junk bonds'' used to finance the transaction. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] The new favorites in the equity markets are stocks that benefit from lower interest rates and slower economic growth: utility, food, beverage and tobacco issues. Market Place.
