https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/13/busin.body_text: **********The Economy **********A $1.50 increase in monthly telephone charges was recommended by an F.C.C. board, which also proposed that five million households get a subsidy to help them pay for phone service. The increase in the access charge, to $3.50 from the current $2, was a careful compromise by the commission, which had wanted a larger increase but encountered strong Congressional opposition.  [ Page A1. ]  Looser regulation of the regional Bell companies, which would allow them to offer long-distance service, was opposed by a coalition of communications trade groups.  [ D5. ] **********A toned-down trade bill was approved by a subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee. The bill requires the President to retaliate against unfair trade practices but leaves unresolved one key issue - action against countries that have large trade surpluses with the U.S.  [ D1. ] **********Stronger auto sales gave retail sales a gain of 4.1 percent in February. Increases in other sectors were modest, but autos posted a 14.4 percent rise after a bleak January.  [ D1. ] Markets **********A former top stockbroker at Paine Webber was indicted on charges that he helped clients illegally move large amounts of cash into their accounts. The charges against Gary D. Eder involve a total of about $700,000 that the Government contends he handled in a manner that would avoid reporting the transactions to the I.R.S. Mr. Eder resigned from Paine Webber last month.  [ D1. ]  Merrill Lynch dismissed Nahum Vaskevitch, the London-based investment banker who was charged with insider trading by the S.E.C.  [ D5. ] **********Publishing stocks are attracting investors' money as the bidding for Harper & Row draws attention to the sector. Harper's stock has almost doubled this week and the shares of other publishing houses are posting strong gains.  [ D2. ] **********Stock prices closed mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.64 points, to 2,267.34, but other indexes had fractional gains that lifted them to new records. There were stronger advances on the American Exchange and the over-the-counter market.  [ D6. ] **********The credit markets held firm, as dealers correctly anticipated that the weekly and monthly money supply figures would show no rise. The basic money supply fell $600 million for the week. At the monthly auction of one-year Treasury bills, the average discount rate was 5.68 percent, down from last month's 5.74 percent.  [ D13. ] **********The dollar fell in Europe and was mixed in New York in quiet trading. Gold prices were up $1.90 an ounce in New York, to $408.40.  [ D14. ]  Livestock and meat futures rose vigorously amid increased buying of cattle in the Midwest.  [ D14. ]  International **********An official of Volkswagen has agreed to talk to prosecutors about allegations of foreign exchange fraud that cost the West German auto maker $259 million.  [ D4. ] Companies **********The Houston Chronicle will be acquired by Hearst for $300 million in cash and $100 million in notes. Analysts said the price appeared to be fair. The Chronicle has the largest circulation in Texas, but it has suffered in Houston's poor economy and it faces stiff competition from The Houston Post.  [ D1. ] **********Kawasaki of Japan was chosen to build 200 subway cars for New York City. The decision was a blow to Westinghouse-Amrail, a French-American consortium that has supplied other cars.  [ B3. ] **********Cannon has sold a film library to Weintraub Entertainment for more than $125 million.  [ D4. ] **********Kodak will build a $200 million film lab in Rochester.  [ D4. ] Today's Columns **********Many economists are wary of a search for patterns in economic history. Yet they cannot resist drawing parallels between the pre-Depression era and present circumstances. For several experts, the most frightening similarity is a lack of organization and leadership in the world economy. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene.  [ D2. ] **********The stocks of home builders are surging, especially those that operate in strong regional markets. The share price of Toll Brothers has risen 400 percent since last summer and the stock of Calton Inc. has tripled in recent months. Market Place.  [ D6. ]

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/busin.body_text: **********Beginning today, The New York Times is publishing expanded and improved listings of futures and options contracts among its financial tables. The expansion reflects the growing popularity of many new futures and options contracts created in recent years. **********A future is the obligation to buy or sell a given commodity at a set price at a specified future date. An option, by contrast, is the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell the commodity. In most instances, investors close out their positions by buying or selling an offsetting contract well before the settlement date. **********The biggest area of increased coverage will be options on futures -that is, an option that is settled via a futures contract. Among these options are those related to futures on foreign currencies, agricultural products and financial market instruments, such as the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and Treasury notes. **********Certain index options are also being added - notably, the Financial News Composite Index and the S.&P. 500 index, as are a number of currency options. As the main criterion for inclusion, The Times will use ''open interest,'' or the number of outstanding contracts. **********If the open interest on a future or option drops below 5,000 for a sustained period, that contract will be dropped. If a new instrument is introduced, and it attains that level for a sustained period, it will be added. A few contracts that The Times has customarily carried are now being dropped because they fail to meet that test.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/world.body_text: **********A California protester who was critically injured there last week when he was struck by a train during a demonstration against American support for the Nicaraguan rebels has been embraced by the Soviet Union as the newest in a line of American dissidents. **********The protester, S. Brian Willson, who lost part of both legs when he was hit by a munitions train leaving a naval weapons station in California, has been hailed in the official Soviet press as a hero of peace, offered free medical care in the Soviet Union, and held up as evidence that the United States violates human rights. **********''The bright name of Brian Willson was put down in the chronicle of human nobility and courage,'' Genrikh Borovik, the head of the officially sanctioned Soviet Peace Committee told television viewers Wednesday night. ''His selfless deed is regarded everywhere in the world as a heroic feat in the name of peace.'' **********Mr. Willson joins a pantheon of Americans lionized here, in what Western diplomats view as a notable shift in the Soviet-American debate over human rights. Rights Issues Discussed **********Where Moscow once brushed off Western complaints of rights violations in the Soviet union, officials here now discuss them more openly, while hammering at what they present as mirror-image abuses in the United States. **********Americans relatively obscure in their own country have become official heroes here, featured daily on national television as counterparts of Andrei D. Sakharov or Natan Sharansky. **********These are among Americans who have become well known here in the last year: *********** Leonard Peltier, an American Indian imprisoned in the slaying of two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Peltier is portrayed here as a political prisoner who was the victim of an official frame-up. Soviet diplomats now routinely raise his name as a rejoinder to American diplomats' complaints about Soviet political prisoners. Soviet eye specialists were permitted to visit Mr. Peltier at Leavenworth Prison this summer when he complained of an eye problem. *********** Charles Hyder, who a year ago set up camp in a park across from the White House and announced plans to fast until President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, took steps to end the arms race. Before he ended his fast in May - he said he ate nothing for more than seven months - Mr. Hyder was a nightly feature on the Moscow television news, and the newspapers published pages of letters addressed to him, including one from Gorbachev. *********** Joseph Mauri, the star of a scathing Soviet television documentary last year about the horrors of life in New York. Mr. Mauri is portrayed as a spokesman for the American homeless and unemployed, athough he acknowledged that he had a job as a substitute mailroom worker for The New York Times and lived in a West Side residential hotel. He returned this summer to be greeted by top Soviet officials and to give a press conference on the plight of the homeless in the United States. *********** Arnold Lochshin, a Houston cancer specialist who moved to Moscow last October saying he was seeking asylum because of political persecution. He has been given housing and a job in a research institute, and is periodically featured in the Soviet press. He has said in the Soviet Union that he was a member of the American Communist Party and active in the civil rights movement and received death threats in the United States. *********** Wade Roberts, a black American soldier who defected in April with his West German fiancee. Soviet readers have followed in detail the couple's marriage, Mr. Roberts's enjoyment of his hobby - snake handling - in the Central Asian republic of Turkmenia, and his comments on racism. Right Leg Was Severed **********Mr. Willson, 46 years old and a Vietnam War veteran, had his right leg severed below the knee and his left leg irreparably mangled Sept. 1, when a train leaving the United States Naval Weapons Station in Concord, Calif., failed to stop. He and other protesters had blocked the track to stop what they said were Latin arms shipments. **********The Contra Costa County, Calif., Sheriff's Office is considering whether to file criminal charges against the crew that struck Mr. Willson. Peace groups in the United States have expressed outrage at what happened. **********Coverage of the event here has risen steadily, and has included interviews with lawyers who denounced the failure of the authorities to stop the train and commentaries saying the incident was deliberately arranged by the United States military. **********Tass, citing the American Communist Party newspaper Peoples Daily World, reported that public protests had ''swept'' the United States ''from western to eastern seaboard.'' **********In the Soviet Union, peace groups that are are not officially sanctioned are forbidden, and independent public demonstrations are generally banned. **********Wednesday night Soviet television broadcast a telephone conversation between Mr. Willson's wife, Holly Rauen, and Genrikh Borovik, chairman of the Soviet Peace Committee. **********This morning's edition of Selskaya Zhizn, the national rural newspaper, cited the case of Mr. Willson as an example of ''wild attacks on dissidents'' by American authorities, and said the reason the United States complains about human rights violations abroad is to perpetuate a false ''legend of the United States as a beacon of Western democracy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/busin.main_headline: SEOUL ANNOUNCES A PLAN TO FREEZE ITS SURPLUS IN U.S. TRADE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/busin.print_headline: SEOUL ANNOUNCES A PLAN TO FREEZE ITS SURPLUS IN U.S. TRADE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/busin.body_text: **********In an attempt to forestall the sort of bitter trade dispute that led to United States sanctions against Japan, South Korea today announced a program to freeze its fast-growing trade surplus at current levels. **********By discouraging exports and offering incentives for more imports, the Government said, Korea hoped to keep its 1987 surplus in United States trade near the 1986 level of $7.3 billion. Forecasts were that the surplus, if unchecked, would reach $10 billion this year. **********The Government announcement did not include a detailed program, and to some degree it rearranged in a tidy package various ideas already under discussion. Nevertheless, it represented the clearest signal to date that the Koreans, who have long worried about being treated as a ''second Japan,'' want to blunt American trade anger before it strikes them, too. **********''It is significant in that they've put it down in black and white,'' a United States official said, adding, ''Let's see if it works.'' Baldrige Visit Scheduled **********The timing of the Korean action was important. It came not only on the day that retaliatory American tariffs were imposed on Japanese electronic products but also two days before Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige was scheduled to arrive for trade talks. **********Mr. Baldrige was quoted today in reports from Washington as saying that the deficit with Seoul would persist until there was ''a significant revaluation'' of the Korean won against the dollar. After years in which Seoul allowed its steady devaluation, the won has risen 6 percent against the dollar since the beginning of 1986, and it was fixed today at 839.7 to the dollar. **********But Deputy Prime Minister Kim Mahn Je, who also heads the Economic Planning Board, cautioned that there would be ''no remarkable appreciation'' in the won's value. Exports 36 Percent Higher **********By keeping its currency artificially low, at least in the American view, Korea has begun to elbow Japan aside in some overseas markets. In the first three months of this year, Korean exports were 36 percent higher than in the corresponding period last year. Its current account, measuring financial transactions and services as well as trade, has swung from a deficit to a sizable surplus. **********Increasingly, the United States has expressed its unhappiness with the trade policies of Korea and Asia's other emerging industrial powers, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore. In Korea's case, Washington has demanded over and over that import restrictions be lifted on a range of items, including cigarettes, agricultural products, insurance and banking services, and even movies. **********Despite these exhortations, however, the American deficit in trade with Korea has continued to soar, jumping 60 percent last year above the 1985 figure of $4.6 billion. **********In their worry about being caught in the backlash against Japan, South Korean officials have argued that they should be given special American consideration, both as a struggling junior partner and as a country with a large military burden required by the threat from North Korea. Today's announcement was a tacit acknowledgment by Seoul that emotional arguments alone would not work. Goal of $5 Billion Set **********In a statement, Mr. Kim said, ''The Korean Government is convinced that a growing trade surplus is not only unsustainable but also counterproductive for Korea's long-term economic development.'' A major goal, he added, was to fix the overall current-account surplus at $5 billion. Without interference, it is expected to rise in 1987 to $8 billion. **********Some proposals had been mentioned before, such as shortening the list of 106 products now placed under import restrictions. Specific products were not cited, though. Nor were there details in a pledge that the Government would urge companies to restrain exports to the United States and find markets elsewhere. **********To help Korean companies buy imports, especially American goods, the Government said it would extend $3 billion in special loans. Most of the money would be in foreign currency that was earned through recent trade surpluses. That means, officials said, that they will not be able to devote all the foreign exchange they had intended to repaying the country's large external debt. **********That debt, $44.5 billion at the start of the year, was reduced in the first quarter to $42.8 billion. Expectations were that it would slip below $40 billion by the year's end, but that seems unlikely now, officials said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/01/busin.print_headline: TALKING DEALS; Preservation, With a Profit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/01/busin.body_text: **********WALTER BEINECKE JR. gave himself and his family a $50 million Christmas present this year, when he sold a major portion of the town of Nantucket, Mass., to the First Winthrop Corporation. **********Mr. Beinecke had spent the last 25 years redeveloping the town to keep it from self-destructing. **********Along with his father, Mr. Beinecke had helped organize Nantucket's preservation movement in the 1950's, to save the island's Greek Revival mansions and other landmark buildings. His interest in historic properties eventually led him to the board of the National Trust for Historic Preservation. **********Beginning in the early 1960's, the partnership he managed, Sherburne Associates, bought up much of the rundown waterfront of the old whaling community on the chip of land 30 miles out in the Atlantic Ocean, then fixed it up, building by building, filling in the holes with 18th-century reproductions. **********''If we had taken this beautiful place and allowed the same kind of beachfront motels and pizza parlors that visitors could find on the mainland, there would have been no reason for them to come the 30 miles out here,'' Mr. Beinecke said yesterday. **********But he was never interested in preservation of historic architecture for preservation's sake. He always intended to make a profit - even if it took him a couple of decades to do it. On Christmas Eve, he sold the holdings of the family partnership -160 buildings, including two hotels, the Nantucket Boat Basin, 36 retail buildings and 40 cottages. **********The Beinecke partnership had accumulated the properties gradually, renovating them a few at a time. The partners took advantage of tax rules on depreciation and historic preservation to help shelter income from other businesses. ''In the early years, there was no way to justify the investment based on the returns the properties were generating,'' Mr. Beinecke said. ''But we assumed we were building capital value as the years wore on, and as the economy of the island began to revive.'' **********The revival came slowly. After a century as a whaling port, Nantucket fell into a 100-year depression after a fire burned the town in 1846, Mr. Beinecke said. Then, after World War II, tourists began to find their way to the remote island. **********''The question was whether to provide for it in a way that would save what was worth seeing in Nantucket, or just let the growth happen,'' he said. **********Even after his family had become the largest landholders on the island, Mr. Beinecke often found himself arguing before the local preservation organization for greater restrictions on development. He often contributed money to groups attempting to buy up vacant land to block development. **********Such a strategy helped make existing properties - including the Beineckes' - more valuable, but it also tended to limit the freedom, and sometimes the income, of shopowners and developers. **********Mr. Beinecke also used his control of the commercial real estate of the island to moderate the traffic. He refused to allow one ferry boat to land at his marina, the only one on the island, when the ferry operator declined to reduce the number of passengers he was bringing each day. **********Rents in the shops on the rejuvenated piers soared tenfold, to $6,500 a month, but the customers came and the island's economy boomed. **********Still, as a real estate company, Sherburne was less than a runaway success. ''It was never a free-standing business,'' Mr. Beinecke said. ''Our principal business was Christmas Club A Corporation, which organized savings clubs for banks. We used the depreciation and other tax-related benefits to offset some of the profits from that business.'' **********The only way to realize the increased value of the properties was to sell them, but after playing such a large roll in the revival of the town's economy, the Beineckes were reluctant to let go. ''There was a strong element of family pride,'' Mr. Beinecke said. ''We wanted to find someone who would manage them with the same concern as we had for maintaining the standards of design and quality.'' **********Not until November did First Winthrop learn that the properties might be available. The Beineckes had already gone to contract with another buyer, but then that deal fell through. **********''We were prepared to act quickly,'' said Jeffrey D. Furber, an assistant vice president at Winthrop Financial Associates, the umbrella partnership over First Winthrop. ''The Beineckes were eager to complete the sale before the tax rates went up at the end of the year, and we were already acquainted with the properties.'' **********First Winthrop holds more than $5 billion of real estate around the country and employs 450 people. **********Among the company's largest holdings are a group of 19 buildings in New York City purchased from the MacArthur Foundation of Chicago in 1984. Those buildings include the Gulf and Western building at Columbus Circle and commercial buildings on Fifth and Park Avenues. **********After meetings in Boston, New York and Nantucket between Mr. Beinecke and Arthur Halleran Jr., chairman of First Winthrop, the deal was sealed. ''Mr. Beinecke was looking for a buyer who would hold the properties as a group, not sell them off piece by piece to help pay for the acquisition,'' Mr. Furber said. ''That fit our strategy perfectly. Our view is that if you buy and hold real estate that cannot be duplicated, you will eventually make money.'' **********Buying and holding worked for the Beineckes. Said Mr. Beinecke, ''Whether by the grace of God or inflation, we managed to make a profit in the end.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/12/world.main_headline: A Dissident Returns to Seoul From U.S. With Congressman
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/12/world.print_headline: A Dissident Returns to Seoul From U.S. With Congressman
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/12/world.body_text: **********A dissident who has lived in the United States for more than four years returned to Seoul today with a Congressional escort. **********''Today, I am so proud to be a Korean,'' the dissident, Lee Shin Bom, said, referring to the Government's pledges over the last two weeks to adopt democratic changes, including direct presidential elections. On Thursday, Mr. Lee, who is 37 years old, was one of 2,335 political offenders who were granted amnesty and had their civil rights restored. **********A former student activist who says he was repeatedly jailed and tortured, Mr. Lee was sentenced to 12 years in prison in 1980 for sedition. He was released in December 1982 and allowed to go to the United States a few months later.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.main_headline: U.S. SAYS N.S.C. WILL FACE CHANGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.print_headline: U.S. SAYS N.S.C. WILL FACE CHANGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.body_text: **********The National Security Council will undergo major changes under Frank C. Carlucci, the new national security adviser, including a virtual prohibition against covert operations, a senior White House official said today. **********The official, speaking of Mr. Carlucci's plans, said the new director saw ''no role for the N.S.C. in covert actions'' and believed further that keeping such operations out of the White House allowed President Reagan to maintain some distance from them. **********The changes are apparently meant to prevent the staff of the National Security Council from having a direct role in secret dealings such as the sale of arms of Iran and the subsequent diversion of funds to the Nicaraguan rebels. Those activities are now under investigation by Congress and an independent counsel. **********Mr. Reagan appointed Mr. Carlucci last month to succeed Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter in the aftermath of the disclosure of the diversion. Admiral Poindexter resigned and Mr. Reagan dismissed a key N.S.C. staff official, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, who has been linked to the affair. Other Officials Sought **********The official, who discussed Mr. Carlucci's intentions in an interview with a group of reporters, said he would also try to bring officials from other agencies into policy decisions. Some senior Reagan aides have explained that change as an attempt to prevent the National Security Council staff from secretly conducting major operations unknown to other top Presidential assistants. **********Among the other moves Mr. Carlucci will undertake is the appointment of a general counsel to handle developments related to the Iran affair, the official said. In addition, he will begin several policy reviews, including one of the Middle East that will examine United States policy options toward Iran in the aftermath of the arms scandal. **********Mr. Reagan had banned the N.S.C. staff from taking part in covert operations last month, pending the outcome of a review by a Presidential commission on what the role of the agency should be. Mr. Carlucci's planned prohibition would make the ban permanent even before the commission, headed by former Senator John Tower, a Texas Republican, has completed its deliberations. **********''There is no point,'' said the senior White House official of such operations by the National Security Council staff. ''I see no role for the N.S.C. in covert operations; a procedure is set up for that. 'Better in Other Agencies' **********''We shouldn't be doing as routine matter things that could be done better in other agencies. It's not a useful expenditure of our time and it tends to create friction with those other agencies.'' **********Under the new approach, the agency could still conduct secret diplomatic missions ordered by Mr. Reagan, the official said, but he suggested that they would not include formal covert operations such as the Iranian initiative. **********At the same time, he said steps would taken to assure that Mr. Reagan received all options before making national security decisions, a practice some officials have said was absent in the case of Iran. Mr. Carlucci has ties to the key components of the national security network as a former Ambassador, Deputy Secretary of Defense and Deputy Director of Central Intelligence. **********''Without commenting on this N.S.C. or a N.S.C. 10 years ago, I don't think you'd find anybody in government who feels that the process works as well as it ought to work,'' the official said. ''There are steps that could be taken to improve it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/03/world.main_headline: NO POLICY RETREAT, CHINA TELLS SHULTZ
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/03/world.print_headline: NO POLICY RETREAT, CHINA TELLS SHULTZ
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/03/world.body_text: **********Chinese leaders told Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that they had no intention of retreating from their economic opening to the West or their adoption of some elements of a free-market economy. **********That theme, which an American official said was repeatedly stressed in nearly seven hours of talks with five leaders, was apparently meant to reassure American businesses that are contemplating investment in joint enterprises here. **********It was highlighted by the official New China News Agency, which reported that Deputy Prime Minister Li Peng, whose Soviet economic training has reputedly made him partial to Soviet-style central planning, assured Mr. Shultz that ''China finds no reason to change its policies of reform and opening the country to the rest of the world.'' **********Besides seeing Mr. Li for nearly an hour, Mr. Shultz met with Foreign Minister Wu Xueqian, Defense Minister Zhang Aiping, President Li Xiannian and Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang, who is also Acting General Secretary of the Communist Party. Several Topics Discussed **********An American official said they had discussed the Soviet military presence in Afghanistan and the American and Chinese aid to the Afghan guerrillas, the Vietnamese military presence in Cambodia, military and technical sales to China and the Soviet-American arms negotiations. **********The subject of the arms talks took up a good deal of time, the officials said, especially the announcement Saturday by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, that Moscow was willing to negotiate a treaty eliminating medium-range ballistic missiles in Europe without linking it to an overall strategic-arms accord. **********The State Department spokesman, Charles E. Redman, said there were no plans for Mr. Shultz to visit Moscow soon to hold talks on this. But Mr. Redman would not rule out such a trip if warranted by the progress of negotiations in Geneva. **********Chinese leaders reportedly told Mr. Shultz of their desire to see the elimination of Soviet missiles in Asia, and Mr. Shultz was said to have repeated the American desire to see the number of medium-range missiles cut to zero. No Indication of Shultz Pledge **********There was no indication, however, that Mr. Shultz had given the Chinese any pledge to hold out for such a sweeping accord. The Russians have proposed reducing the deployment in Asia to 100 warheads on their SS-20 medium-range missiles - or to 33 missiles, since the SS-20 has three warheads - which would be a cut of 80 percent. **********On economic matters, Mr. Shultz, in a dinner toast, noted that ''American investment in China, second only to Hong Kong's, now reaches nearly $1.5 billion.'' **********''Important problems remain,'' he said, ''but if they are forcefully addressed so that the investment climate in China improves, the day may come when we will look back on such figures as only a small beginning.'' **********Some Western economic analysts, however, say they see the instability in Chinese politics as raising questions about future economic policy. They said that the progress of the ''reforms'' had been slowed and that although there was no immediate suggestion that the changes be rolled back, serious struggles were taking place in the hierarchy over the best course to take. **********In recent years, China has moved from collectivization in agriculture to household farming, allowing market forces to play the major role in shaping production and income. The industrial sector has not moved nearly as far, and last fall, the leadership decided not to proceed with what is called ''price reform,'' in which many prices would be allowed to rise to market levels. An Anti-Foreign Mood **********In addition, after student demonstrations in December and January and the dismissal of Hu Yaobang as General Secretary of the Communist Party, official criticisms and dismissals of several leading intellectuals have been accompanied by denunciations in the official press of ''bourgeois liberalism.'' This has begun to translate into a new anti-foreign mood, some foreign residents of Beijing say, represented by an increased wariness among many Chinese of befriending Westerners. **********Some Western political analysts say they believe that attacking intellectuals will alienate the very people needed to advance the modernization program. **********Mr. Shultz alluded to this when he said in his toast that each country had gained ''understanding of the differences and similarities between our respective values and traditions.'' **********He seemed to be chiding the Chinese for their expulsion of two Western journalists when he went on to declare that Americans, in their ''respect for human rights and freedom of expression,'' had ''learned the importance of a free press.'' **********''Since the founding of our Republic,'' he said, ''American journalists have sometimes been a thorn in the side of Government officials. But our history has also demonstrated their indispensable importance in safeguarding freedom and justice and in insuring the health of our democratic system. They also have a vital role to play in strengthening mutual understanding between our two peoples.'' **********An American official said the Secretary had also raised the subject in his private talks. Last year, John F. Burns of The New York Times was arrested and expelled, and more recently, Lawrence Macdonald, an American reporter for Agence France-Presse, had his visa revoked. **********Mr. Shultz also asked China to stop selling weapons to Iran, an American official said, arguing that the secret American sales were ''the exception'' and that the Administration's public campaign to halt the arms flow to Iran remained in effect. **********Mr. Shultz is scheduled to meet Tuesday with the Chinese leader, Deng Xiaoping. He is to remain in China until Friday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/busin.body_text: **********The British Government gave the publisher Rupert Murdoch permission to buy the loss-ridden Today newspaper from Lonrho P.L.C. for $:38 million, or about $61 million. Mr. Murdoch's News International P.L.C. announced the proposed acquisition on Tuesday, noting that it required the approval of Lord Young, the Trade and Industry secretary. Lord Young announced the Government's approval in Parliament, saying he would not refer the purchase to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission. Lord Young said the newspaper ''would not have lived'' if he had referred the acquisition to the commission.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/09/busin.main_headline: VIDEO DOGFIGHTING LEADS TO IMPROVED WARPLANES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: ADVANCES; VIDEO DOGFIGHTING LEADS TO IMPROVED WARPLANES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/09/busin.body_text: **********The first test flight of a prototype for the Air Force's new medium-range jet fighter, the Advanced Tactical Fighter, is not expected before 1990. But by the time the prototype hits the tarmac, pilots will have spent months at its controls and will even have engaged in supersonic dogfights with MIG-29's over both land and sea. **********All of this will occur in multimillion-dollar simulators, which reproduce the sights, sounds and feel of aerial battlefield conditions. These elaborate video games are used by designers to identify and correct any deficiencies in the plane's cockpit, which will be jampacked with three times as many electronic readouts as a Vietnam-era fighter. **********The General Electric Company and the Evans & Sutherland Computer Corporation of Salt Lake City are the dominant players in producing simulators, which can cost $20 million or more. **********But such prices are small compared with what is at stake: a $46.9 billion contract to build 750 A.T.F. craft, one of the biggest aircraft projects of the next decade. Two groups are competing: The Lockheed Corporation is prime contractor for the General Dynamics Corporation and the Boeing Company, and the Northrop Corporation is teamed with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. **********Both Lockheed and Northrop have recently upgraded their simulation equipment with powerful models that can simulate entire missions. **********The use of simulators in the design of the new fighter, which will replace the F-15, is particularly important because the Air Force wants a plane that is capable of facing effectively a more sophisticated generation of Soviet missiles and fighters. **********''It used to be, you go out and build a plane and test it and rebuild it,'' said Jack Drewett, manager of flight simulation for General Dynamics in Fort Worth, where the company builds F-16's at $15 million each. Design errors were corrected later, he said. **********''Now, with all the capabilities you put in, you can't afford to do it wrong,'' Mr. Drewett said. **********At first, simulation was limited to pilots practicing night landings or aerodynamic tests in wind tunnels. Older models could not project a realistic scene, nor could they simulate a continuous mission that might involve air-to-air engagements, refueling and low-altitude flights over a array of terrains. Some models had to be stopped to perform different tasks and were often limited to certain speeds, altitudes and attitudes. **********''You had to make a lot of compromises,'' said Robert E. Gunther, manager of Lockheed's $60 million simulation center in Valencia, Calif., 60 miles northwest of Los Angeles. **********Because of their relatively small size, fighters are a difficult assignment for design engineers. Simulation gives the engineers an invaluable assist, Mr. Gunther said. **********An A.T.F. pilot will be bombarded by data from as many as 20 sensors. ''One of the huge challenges is how to present that information to the pilot, to boil it down and put it in a usable context,'' said Terry L. Clawson, a spokesman for Northrop in Los Angeles. ''If you gave him just raw numbers without interpreting them, he'll be dead.'' **********In July, mock combat exercises began inside the 28-foot-diameter dome at Lockheed's lab. About 130 people work in the modernistic, windowless building, sheathed in a porcelain-like material to contain electronic emissions. A second $30 million simulator is planned. **********With a pilot at the simulator's controls, the A.T.F. noses into a cloudless desert sky. One computer controls the flight, determining the plane's aerodynamics, engine propulsion and firepower. **********As the fighter gains altitude, mountains ringing the desert floor shrink away. Two computers create the external world, including enemy planes and missiles. One draws the outline of these objects, based in part on real-world data obtained from classified sources. The other computer colors the panorama and adds texture, such as pockmarks in asphalt or the bolt-pattern of an aircraft wing. **********As the pilot pushes the plane into a steep turn, he even feels the body-crunching force of gravitational pull. Pneumatically powered pumps adjust the pressure of the pilot's suit and seat. **********When the plane's systems detect an incoming missile, the pilot pushes a button to arm a weapon, locks on the target and fires. Yet another computer determines whether the cockpit electronics hampered or helped the engagement. **********The heart of Lockheed's new simulator is a scene creator made by General Electric. **********Assisting G.E.'s scene generator, called the Compu-Scene IV, is a special purpose computer made by G.E. that makes five billion calculations a second, 10 times more computations than the previous model, said Kenneth Kilner, manager of product support for General Electric's simulation department at Daytona Beach, Fla. **********The scene generator's power comes from the use of specialized integrated circuits rather than software, he said. The computer updates the scene 60 times a second, key to faithfully creating the illusion of high speeds without blurring. **********Since virtually every domestic aircraft maker already owns simulators - there are fewer than 30 systems combined - future sales are expected to come from overseas military contractors, Mr. Kilner said. **********Nonmilitary customers of simulators are also emerging. Mercedes-Benz is using them to design trucks. NASA bought one for space station design. And a film maker used one to create a scene for ''The Last Starfighter.'' **********These simulators employ basically the same technology as that used for training pilots, but the nonmilitary market is estimated at $2 billion annually, far great than the $88 million that is expected to be spent on military aircraft simulators this year. **********Simulator developers have become better at selectively applying computing power in critical areas, such as adding the dappled texture of tree leaves in a close-up, but dropping it from the background where it goes undetected and is a waste of computing resources. **********Nevertheless, improvements could come by adding still more power and utilizing more photographic data. Despite the realism of these simulators, some sensitive pilots can detect a lag of about one-twentieth of a second between the time they push the controls and the scenario changes. **********The other weakness of computer dramatizations is probably impossible to fix: the failure to capture the psychological impact of reality. **********Said Lockheed's Mr. Gunther, ''No matter how hard we try - we have sound, we have motion, he's been in the simulator four hours - he knows he can push a little green button that says reset and he's safe.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.main_headline: SOSNOFF RAISES BID FOR CAESARS WORLD
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.print_headline: SOSNOFF RAISES BID FOR CAESARS WORLD
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/03/busin.body_text: **********For the second time since starting a bid to take control of Caesars World Inc. in March, the Wall Street investor Martin T. Sosnoff has raised his offer to the company's investors, to $35 a share in cash and equity securities. **********The package offer includes common stock that would allow current shareholders to end up retaining about a 30 percent stake in the company, Mr. Sosnoff said last night. **********Mr. Sosnoff already owns 13 percent of the Los Angeles casino operator. His latest bid is an attempt to dissuade Caesars World shareholders from accepting a similar offer from management that would give them a $26.25 dividend plus a continuing stake in the company valued by the market at about $8.50 a share. Thus, Mr. Sosnoff's new bid is designed to top the management offer by about 25 cents a share. Three-Month-Old Battle **********The three-month-old battle until now has been especially noteworthy because Caesars World tried to elude Mr. Sosnoff's overtures through the use of a relatively new defensive technique: the leveraged recapitalization. In a ''recap,'' the company pays shareholders a huge one-time dividend in exchange for all but a small, ongoing stake in the company. **********The stocks of recapitalized companies - while they represent far greater risk to both shareholders and the corporations that issue them -have enjoyed a rousing reception on Wall Street, where they have been bid up to reflect investor interest in a continuing equity participation in the company. That strong performance, in part, has made it hard for outsiders to successfully challenge a recap once management has proposed one. **********The challenge has not been lost on Mr. Sosnoff, who is critical of management's plan. ''It's the typical management recap, where they erect so much barbed wire, that if they're successful, no one will be able to touch this company for a hundred years,'' he said. Defeating a Recap **********But Mr. Sosnoff's initiative could be significant in suggesting a way for a hostile raider to defeat a recap after all. Henry Gluck, the chairman of Caesar's World, acknowledged when he announced the recap that he was taking a cue from Mr. Sosnoff by deciding that his company could weather additional debt. Now Mr. Sosnoff, borrowing an idea from the Caesars management, plans to allow other shareholders in Caesars to retain some equity interest in the company if he is the victor. **********''The argument of Mr. Gluck that shareholders still have a stake in the company's future will apply to us as well,'' explained Mr. Sosnoff, who credited his investment bankers at Paine Webber for the idea. **********Mr. Sosnoff first raised his offer last April, to $32 a share from $28. The latest package will not require the investor to raise more than the $930 million in cash and $88 million in preferred stock that he was prepared to pay out before. **********This time, the difference will come from common stock, roughly 30 percent of the equity that Mr. Sosnoff was hoping to own after a successful takeover and that he is now giving back to investors. **********Mr. Sosnoff's plan does not differ dramatically from management's plan in the amount of debt it would require. So if the current stock price indicates what a highly leveraged Caesars would be worth under either plan, Mr. Sosnoff has added $83 million worth of common equity to his previous offer - 9 percent more. **********Ordinarily, offering securities is considered less attractive than cash in a bidding contest. But Mr. Sosnoff was unable to resist increasing the stock portion of the offer when he saw how the market reacted to management's proposal, a source close to him said. The stock of Caesars, on a when-issued basis, closed yesterday at 8 5/8, roughly 16 times projected earnings. **********Mr. Sosnoff admitted he was startled by how well the stock market has responded to Caesars' plan. ''We think it's trading at an enormous premium based on cash flow and earnings projections five years out,'' he said. ''So yes, it surprised us. It surprised us a lot in fact.'' **********Mr. Sosnoff is now offering $35 in cash for 26.5 million shares of Caesars, 84 percent of the 31.7 million shares he does not own. In the event of a merger, the shares not covered by the tender offer get the equivalent value in preferred and common stock. **********Of course, if everyone turns their shares into Mr. Sosnoff, then each share on a prorated basis, would get roughly $29.55 in cash, $2.77 in preferred stock and an equity stub worth about $2.60, in light of where Caesars stock has been trading on the market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/busin.main_headline: PUTTING A PINCH ON MANAGEMENT PERKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN COMPENSATION; PUTTING A PINCH ON MANAGEMENT PERKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/busin.body_text: **********SHOULD companies take from the rich or give to the poor? **********The Tax Reform Act has made it far more difficult to offer tax-favored benefits to highly paid people without making them available to the hoi polloi. Compensation managers, therefore, must decide whether to curtail executive perks, or give them to more employees. ''They just cannot be as stingy with the rank and file,'' said James E. Cheeks, vice president of the Research Institute of America Inc. **********Under the new rules, for example, there is an annual $7,000 limit on the amount anyone can put into a 401-k or other savings plan that qualifies for favorable tax treatment. And the average contribution of employees making less than $50,000 cannot differ by more than 2 percent from the average of those making more. **********Many companies are tinkering with their plans to make the math work out. 3M, for one, will now let employees making less than $50,000 contribute 18 percent of their salary to a 401-k, up from a former 10 percent cap. ''This is solely to meet the discrimination rules,'' said Donald A. Kissack, director of benefits. **********Employer-funded retirement programs cause other problems. Companies must give full pensions to anyone with five years of service. And starting in 1989, companies cannot use Social Security payments to reduce any employee's pension by more than half. **********While those rules serve mainly to increase pensions for lower-paid employees, other rules decimate the pensions of top management. Starting in 1988, companies can only grant pensions on a maximum of $200,000 a year in compensation, no matter how high the actual pay. And the new law puts a heavy tax bite on people whose annual retirement income from all tax-favored sources goes over $112,500. **********''It had been Government policy to forgo tax revenue on pension plans in order to encourage employers to undertake the care and feeding of their employees,'' said Pearl Meyer, an executive consultant at Handy Associates. ''But there has been a shift in policy, along the idea of not giving tax breaks to higher-level employees.'' **********Companies that make heavy use of part-time employees have yet another problem. The new law mandates that by 1989 any employee working 15 hours a week must be offered the same benefits as full-time employees. **********To many companies that represents a no-win situation. ''Offering full benefits at 15 hours could cost a lot, but trying to come up with schedules of less than 15 hours takes away scheduling flexibility,'' said John J. Boyd, senior vice president for personnel at Rich's department store in Atlanta. **********Even companies with few part-time employees, and across-the-board benefits plans, are not escaping trouble-free. ''Most of our plans will probably be unaffected, but going through the measurements to make sure that they are in compliance is a real chore,'' said Thomas E. Burns, manager of employee benefits for the General Electric Company. **********In fact, Mr. Burns already has spotted a potential problem. G.E. has an employee savings plan that lets participants withdraw money after three years. Now, employees who withdraw money before retirement will incur a tax penalty.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/20/busin.body_text: **********''WE'RE out to make hot tea hot,'' exclaimed Susan Read, effusive executive vice president and executive creative director of Lintas:New York, as she turned to the VCR to bring the new campaign for Lipton tea to the screen. It was, she promised, a big idea.  In any event it was big enough to supplant Don Meredith, the one-time Dallas Cowboys quarterback who had been spokesman for the flow-through tea bags for more than a decade. The new campaign, at the moment two 30-second spots and a 60, is shooting at the younger side of the 18-to-54-year-old target audience but will continue to use daytime and prime-time network TV to reach them. **********The spots, directed by Leslie Dektor, largely feature young, with-it adults in a variety of pursuits and all enjoying their Lipton. The point of it all - as the lyrics written and sung by Jake Holmes explain - is to dismiss the fatuous notion that hot tea is the drink for ''little old ladies.'' **********So as Jake, accompanying himself on the piano, sings, ''Look at all those little old ladies drinkin' Lipton tea,'' the young swingers pass in review.  See them rockin'  See them rockin'  Now that's gentility.  Look at all those little old ladies  Drinkin' Lipton tea. **********Joining Ms. Read were David P. Bell, director of product management for regular and specialty teas at Thomas J. Lipton, a subsidiary of Unilever, and Stephen W. Norcia, executive vice president, account services at Lintas:New York. **********All seemed equally turned on to the advertising, urging a visitor to enjoy repeated showings. **********The spots, at least the 30's, will get their first public airing on three soaps on ABC next Tuesday and on prime time Nov. 29 during ''Murder, She Wrote'' on CBS. **********Mr. Bell was not forthcoming with the size of his ad budget. While showing spending of about $16 million for all of Lipton's teas in 1986, Leading National Advertisers, the independent media monitor, recorded only some $3.1 million for tea bags. And that's what we're talking about today. **********The total tea market, Mr. Bell said ringingly, is worth about $1 billion at the retail level, and that includes regular tea, which he calls black tea; special blends; herb teas; ice tea mixes, and all the rest. **********Of the total, he said, black tea sales come to something like $527 million. **********In the area where sales are monitored - supermarket and grocery stores - sales volume is flat. However, Mr. Bell said, sales volume is known to be increasing in a number of newer outlets, including drug chains and mass merchandisers, which are not monitored. **********But - surprise, surprise - hot tea accounts for only 20 percent of the use. So it can use all the help Lipton is about to give it. **********The tea field has been changing quite a bit in recent years, with the increased awareness of herb teas popularized by Celestial Seasonings, and special blends popularized by R. C. Bigelow. **********Their successes prompted Lipton to diversify its own product line. And since Celestial Seasonings was acquired by Kraft a couple of years ago, it has moved into black tea itself. **********The agency, which is one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, began as Sullivan, Stauffer, Colwell & Bayles. It has served Lipton tea for some 29 years. And Lipton is No. 1. But the competition is hot and could easily get hotter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/26/world.main_headline: Mother Russia Makes a Comeback on Births
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/26/world.print_headline: Mother Russia Makes a Comeback on Births
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/26/world.body_text: **********It was almost noon feeding time when the chief doctor, Yevgeny A. Volpin, burst into a dormitory at Moscow Maternity House 27. **********''Our beautiful young mothers!'' he announced, beaming at the five women hastily tucking bared breasts into their hospital gowns. ''How many does this make for you? Two? And you, my lovely? Also two? Good for you! Just like the statistics!'' **********The bemused mothers at this north Moscow maternity ward are part of a reversal with potentially important political and economic consequences: women from the Russian majority in the Soviet Union are having more babies. **********Despite cramped and often overcrowded apartments, dire shortages of such basics as baby clothes, the high divorce rate for Russians and the fact that most women work full-time jobs and bear the brunt of food lines and household chores, the statistics show that Russian women increasingly are having two or three children rather than one or two. **********Demographers here and in the West say the trend is a victory for a strong policy that offers mothers financial incentives to have children, extended leave, improved maternity care and a dose of pro-baby propaganda. **********''The policies have been remarkably successful,'' said Murray Feshbach of Georgetown University, a specialist in Soviet population and health. ''You have to ask how long it will last if they don't solve the housing problem and get better medical care, but they have the beginning of a major improvement.'' **********Western population experts long ago calculated that without a higher birth rate, the Soviet Union would have trouble finding enough workers for its factories and new conscripts for its army. **********Moreover, while the birth rate among Russians and other European ethnic groups has languished, the Asian minorities in Soviet Central Asia have been prolific. **********This has already led to dislocations in the economy that result when people are born in one place and factories are located in another. The high birth rates of ethnic minorities also causes concern about language and cultural gaps, especially in the military, and about the potential allure of Islamic fundamentalism. **********Beginning with a 1981 decree, the Government has gradually increased the inducements for larger families. **********Olga Marozova, interviewed while she waited for an ultrasound examination at the maternity clinic here, is expecting her second child in January. She will remain away from her job as an office worker until the baby is a year old, with a monthly stipend of 35 rubles, about a fifth of her normal wage. **********Mrs. Marozova was paid a bonus of 50 rubles, about $80, for her first child, and will get 100 rubles for the second. The average wage is about 200 rubles a month. **********The benefits are hardly lavish, but Mrs. Marozova said that together with the Soviet system of free medical care and the prospect of a new apartment in five years or so, it was enough to convince her and her husband that they could afford a bigger family. **********Since the first measures to encourage births were introduced in the early 1980's, the birth rate has turned upward and begun to increase at a slightly faster rate, according to official data. **********Last year 19.9 babies were born for every 1,000 people in the Soviet Union, up from 17 a decade ago. (The comparable United States figure is 15.5, but more American babies survive because of superior medical care.) The rate of population increase is rising in 11 of 15 Soviet republics, including Russia, according to the most recent official data. 'Replacement Rate' Lags **********The birth trends are not enough to satisfy demographers. Mikhail S. Bedny, a prominent Soviet specialist in medical demographics, said the national average of 1.94 births a couple still falls short of what demographers call the ''replacement rate'' needed to assure a stable population, about 2.5 births a family. In addition, the rising Russian birth rate is still far outstripped by the rates in Soviet Central Asia. **********Soviet experts concede that by the year 2000 Russians, now 51.5 percent of the population, will become a 49 percent minority in the nation commonly called Russia. **********But the upturn in the Russian birth rate has strengthened the conviction of Soviet policy makers that they are on the right course. A new round of inducements is to be introduced in the new year, including an additional six months of partly paid maternity leave and legislation creating part-time jobs for mothers. **********Mr. Bedny said other factors behind the increase include a slight decline in the use of abortion. Abortion is still the most common form of birth control here, with 10 operations not uncommon for a Russian woman. **********Soviet demographers say they continue to be alarmed at the high rate of infant mortality, despite a steady improvement. Statistics for 1986 show that 25.4 Soviet babies die for every 1,000 live births, compared with 10.4 in the United States. **********The neat brick building where Dr. Volpin presides over 20 births a day is a superior installation for the Soviet Union, featuring American incubators, Japanese ultrasound machines and other imported technology. A Devotion to Superstition **********But doctors readily concede that in a rural setting or less prestigious city the facilities would not be so impressive. The newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya reported last month that it is still common for clinics in many areas to lack blood pressure gauges for infants or feeding tubes for newborns who have trouble eating. The newspaper said some parts of the country have infant death rates comparable to those in Paraguay or Thailand. **********One thing Dr. Volpin's clinic has in common with the most remote villages is a devotion to tradition bordering on superstition. Because of a passionate fear of germs, for example, husbands are not allowed to visit their wives and newborn children for the first four or five days after birth. **********The idea of a husband's being present for a birth provoked embarrassed mirth among the new mothers. **********And newborns are still swaddled like papooses from head to toe in the belief that this makes babies secure, warm and well behaved. **********Dr. Volpin said he believes wrapping babies slows muscle development, but it is clinic policy to swaddle because mothers insist on it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/05/busin.main_headline: Fallon and Chiat/Day Win at the One Show
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/05/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Fallon and Chiat/Day Win at the One Show
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/05/busin.body_text: **********Fallon McElligott of Minneapolis and Chiat/Day of Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York were the big winners at the One Show last night at the Palladium. **********Fallon McElligott, a subsidiary of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, won largely in print, and Chiat/Day's victories were almost exclusively in broadcast. **********During its short existence, the Minneapolis crew has grown accustomed to shaming the New York forces at this sort of gathering. Fallon also made a clean sweep in four categories, taking the gold, silver and bronze prizes. **********The Fallon folks won in the categories of newspaper, trade publications, outdoor and public service. Mike Lescarbeau, a copywriter, was the agency's big winner, taking five of the golds. **********And Chiat/Day San Francisco's single radio spot entry, a California Cooler ad called ''Translation,'' was the highest-scoring entry in the show. All five of the agency's gold awards were for California Cooler ads. **********Among the Chiat/Day writers who turned out advertising for California Coolers, Dave O'Hara was most honored, with five awards, and Dave Woodside won four. **********Unlike the Effies, which were awarded in product categories, the One Show awards are for the best in various media categories. The One Show is put on by the One Club, which has a membership of copywriters and art directors. **********McKinney & Silver of Raleigh, N.C., took three golds for its State of North Carolina accounts. Two were for print advertising for North Carolina Travel and Tourism, and one radio gold award was for the Governor's highway safety program.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/world.main_headline: DEFENSE DEPT. IS REBUFFED ON SOVIET ABM THREAT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/world.print_headline: DEFENSE DEPT. IS REBUFFED ON SOVIET ABM THREAT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/world.body_text: **********The White House has rebuffed a Pentagon suggestion that the United States formally assert that the Soviet Union is preparing a nationwide ABM defense, Administration officials said today. **********Under the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972, the two sides agreed to limit their ABM systems so that they could not become the basis for a nationwide antimissile defense. **********Defense Department officials had proposed that the United States now find the Soviet Union to be moving toward such an defense and that this be noted in the annual report on Soviet adherence to arms treaties. To support its case, the Pentagon cited the start of construction of three new radars on the western periphery of the Soviet Union, among other actions. **********Experts at the Central Intelligence Agency and the State Department contested the Pentagon assessment. Cautious Assessment Is Due **********Officials said the annual report, which is expected to be made public shortly, would offer a more cautious assessment. The United States has previously said that the Soviet Union ''may be'' preparing a nationwide defense, and officials said there would be no basic change in that assessment. **********They said that intelligence did not provide a strong case for the Pentagon view. The experts said that while the Russians were doing research and testing on possible ABM systems, the military implications of some of the Soviet actions cited in the 1986 compliance report had been overstated. **********For example, they said, the United States had expressed concern about a Soviet practice drill in the reloading of ABM launchers near Moscow. The reloading had been conducted in a matter of hours. The ABM treaty has a provision against ''rapid'' reloading, without being specific. **********Government experts noted that the reloading drill was held in 1983, and has not been repeated since then. **********The United States also said last year that the Soviet Union might be trying to improve its SA-12 antiaircraft missile so that it could intercept ballistic missiles. The 1986 report spoke about the interception of a short-range tactical missile, suggesting that the Russians might be able to improve the SA-12 so that it would intercept long-range missiles. Such improvements are probihited by the ABM treaty. **********Today Government experts said the SA-12 had missed most of the time when it was fired at the shorter-range missile. **********One expert said, ''It hit once in about 20 times.'' **********While the Defense Department has cited the construction of the three new radars in the western part of the Soviet Union as signs that the Russians are building an ABM defense of their territory, other experts said that the radars were intended for early warning of an American attack. **********The construction of early-warning radars is allowed by the ABM treaty since they are on the periphery of Soviet territory and oriented outward. Mobile Radars Were Questioned **********In 1986, the United States also voiced concern about the development and deployment of old radars that it considered mobile systems. Mobile components of ABM systems are prohibited by the 1972 treaty. **********But earlier this year, Government experts said, the Russians had only four of these old radars and several of them have since been dismantled. **********Past reports about Soviet adherence to arms treaties also said the Russians are ''likely'' to have violated two treaties of the 1970's that limit the size of underground nuclear tests. **********Since that charge was first made, the Central Intelligence Agency has lowered its estimates of the size of the nuclear explosions conducted by the Soviet Union. And some experts at the United States nuclear laboratories have questioned the earlier allegation. **********A draft of the latest United States report that is soon to be made public says that further study of this question is needed. But the forthcoming report will not withdraw the past allegations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/world.main_headline: U.S., Citing Ecology, Avoids Botswana Loan Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/world.print_headline: U.S., Citing Ecology, Avoids Botswana Loan Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/world.body_text: **********The United States abstained today on environmental grounds from a vote to recommend an international loan to Botswana, a Treasury spokesman said. **********The loan recommendation by the African Development Bank, of which the United States is a member, was approved. The loan would provide $7 million to Botswana to build a slaughterhouse for cattle, the spokesman said. **********The development bank voted to recommend that the Nairobi Trust Fund provide the loan money, the Treasury spokesman said. **********The department abstained after protests from several environmental organizations, according to David Wirth, a senior project lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a public interest law concern. **********It was the first time the United States has not approved a loan to Africa for these purposes, he said. The vote took place in the Ivory Coast. **********Overgrazing is a problem in Botswana, which has three times as many cows as people, and the loan could make the problem worse by encouraging farmers to raise more cattle, Mr. Wirth said. **********The Treasury Department also said the lack of natural grasslands would harm the country's wildlife.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/23/busin.body_text: **********The Times Mirror Company, the large diversified media concern, said today that net income declined 4.6 percent in the third quarter. **********Operating profits for the third period rose 20 percent, to $146.3 million, mainly as a result of a surge in newspaper classified advertising. **********Income in the quarter was $70.6 million, against $74 million a year ago, but the previous year's results were inflated by a one-time gain from the sale of The Dallas Times-Herald newspaper. Revenues rose 12 percent, to $782.3 million, from $697.7 million. **********''As anticipated, earnings growth has slowed in the second half of this year, but we continue to expect 1987 to be another record year in operating earnings,'' Robert Erburu, Times Mirror chairman, said in a statement. **********Times Mirror stock was down 25 cents, at $74.25, in New York Stock Exchange trading today. **********The publisher of The Los Angeles Times said operating profits in newspapers rose 18 percent, to $85.2 million, as a result of strong classified advertising. **********In magazines, books and other publishing, profits were up 29 percent, to $37.1 million. Separately, Knight-Ridder **********Inc., another big newspaper publisher, said today that third-quarter net income rose 6 percent, to $33.4 million, as strong classified advertising offset weak television revenues and newspaper circulation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/31/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Short-Term Rates Up Sharply
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/31/busin.body_text: **********Short-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday as bond traders' concerns about Federal Reserve Board policy intentions and next week's $29 billion Treasury refunding overshadowed interpretations and reinterpretations of the latest trade deficit figures. **********Rates on three-month Treasury bills were up nearly one-tenth of a percentage point, to 5.61 percent, while rates on six-month bills rose 14 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, also to 5.61 percent. The rate for one-year bills was 5.63 percent, up a tenth of a percentage point. **********''People think the Fed may be up to something because it has allowed the Federal funds rate to remain firm,'' one trader explained. That rate, which is what banks charge each other for overnight borrowings to meet reserve requirements, has been above 6 percent for the last two months. It traded between 6 3/16 and 6 3/8 yesterday. Focus on Discount Window **********Robert H. Schumacher, a vice president at Nomura Securities, said speculation about Fed intentions might have taken on an extra dimension because of Thursday's report of a rise in borrowings at the Fed's discount window. ''There's always some new gimmick the market wants to key in on, and the latest, along with trade, seems to be borrowed reserves,'' he said. **********The credit markets initially responded favorably to a smaller-than-expected trade deficit for December and a large downward revision in the November deficit. Some analysts said that the response was actually to the sharp rise in the dollar rather than to the trade deficit itself. **********Either way, the spark faded quickly, and by the end of the trading day the price on the benchmark 7.5 percent Treasury bond was down by 12/ 32 to yield 7.47 percent. Price declines at the shorter end of the market ranged from 6/32 on two-year notes to 12/32 for the 7.25 percent 10-year note, bringing its yield to 7.17 percent. **********Because of next week's refunding, the credit market is more concerned about what the trade deficit means for the strength or weakness of the dollar than about what the trade gap means for growth in the United States economy this year. But interpreting the trade figures on either score has been greatly complicated by the huge revisions in the data. ''The market's concern is whether the numbers we have now are realistic so that we can make a judgment about what the growth of the economy will be and whether the political rhetoric from Washington is going to change,'' Mr. Schumacher said. Likely Immediate Impact **********For the moment, the narrower trade deficit in both November and December should mean that the dollar will strengthen and that foreign investors will therefore be more inclined to buy bonds at the auction. Over the longer term, a narrower trade deficit could be a sign that the domestic economy is strengthening, and a stronger economy would tend to keep the Fed from lowering interest rates. **********''I think the best way to explain what happened in the long end of the market is that buyers simply went on strike after the trade figures came out because it was all too confusing,'' Mr. Schumacher said.  Albert A. Gross, senior vice president at Refco Inc., said that revisions in data were taken for granted among traders, but said revisions as large as those in the trade data were frustrating. ''I think huge revisions like this do help to accentuate volatility,'' he said. Cautioning that it was always hazardous to place too much emphasis on any particular statistic or event in analyzing the market's performance, Mr. Gross said: **********''I do think the common wisdom that the economy will be weaker because of the trade deficit is now in question, and I think that is why the bond futures and Treasury cash market behaved as they did,'' he said. **********Donald J. Fine, a senior vice president and chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank, said trade figures were among the most difficult for private forecasters to predict. **********''By last week, the fourth-quarter gross national product data could give you a conceptual idea of the December trade number, so you would have known it was going to be better than November, but that's about it,'' he said. **********Mr. Fine said the new number and the revision for November suggested to him that the economy remained weak and was not in for a pickup in the first few months of this year. ''The narrowing of the trade deficit is the result of a decline in imports and a decline in exports, which suggests we're talking about lower consumption and lower investment,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/09/busin.body_text: **********The Government Securities Corporation, an aggressive marketer of mortgage-backed securities, has asked to liquidate, Florida's Comptroller, Gerald Lewis, said today. **********State and Federal regulators began investigating the company after it suspended operations on Wednesday. **********Competitors estimated that the firm, one of the largest sellers of government securities in Florida, had sales of between $140 million and $160 million last year. **********Mr. Lewis said that examiners from his office and the Securities and Exchange Commission were determining whether a liquidation would be proper, or whether the firm should be turned over to the Federal Securities Investor Protection Corporation. That agency insures customer accounts of up to $500,000. **********''The company has advised us it has sufficient resources to satisfy all customer accounts, but even if this were not the case, all investors should be protected through the SIPC coverage that Florida law requires,'' Mr. Lewis said. **********No reason was given for the firm's request to liquidate.
