https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/18/busin.main_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM: SORTING OUT THE TRADE PROBLEM;
Business Holds Its Own as America Slips
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/18/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM: SORTING OUT THE TRADE PROBLEM;
Business Holds Its Own as America Slips
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/18/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: FOR most of the last 35 years or so, the United States share in world export markets for manufactured products has been falling, and imports have taken larger and larger shares of United States markets. As the decline in the trade balance accelerated, so too did the debate about its causes. But most analyses miss an important distinction between the export performance of American companies - including all their worldwide operations - and that of the operations within the geographical boundaries of the United States. **********FOR most of the last 35 years or so, the United States share in world export markets for manufactured products has been falling, and imports have taken larger and larger shares of United States markets. As the decline in the trade balance accelerated, so too did the debate about its causes. But most analyses miss an important distinction between the export performance of American companies - including all their worldwide operations - and that of the operations within the geographical boundaries of the United States. That distinction casts the debate in a different light. **********There is no denying that the nation's trade performance has deteriorated badly. We lost about a third of our share of world exports of manufactures between the 1950's and the 1980's. The merchandise trade balance first declined and then, after 1975, turned negative. The deficit grew larger and larger, reaching more than $120 billion in 1985 and surpassing that level in 1986. Then, even the current account balance, which includes services and investment income, after fluctuating between surplus and deficit through the 1970's, slid rapidly into huge and alarming deficits in the 1980's. Finally, in 1986, the Commerce Department announced that, by its calculations, America had become a debtor nation for the first time since World War I. Plenty of candidates have been nominated to take the blame for this decline in our international position: low productivity growth, excessive wage increases in some industries, the neglect of manufacturing in business schools, relatively high taxation of capital, large government deficits and the high exchange value of the dollar. Especially in recent years, more deep-seated causes have been suggested, including a decline in the work ethic among employees and a loss of competitive strength on the part of large companies. The weakness of the companies includes, supposedly, a decline in their technological prowess, partly because they have given up thinking about long-run advantages and now concentrate on the next quarter's profit reports. It also involves increased bureaucracy within the large companies and the loss of their ability to manage industrial operations, perhaps because their executives have been trained in finance rather than in production, or in how to make deals rather than how to make products. **********Some of these problems may be amenable to changes in government policy. But others, such as the decline of the work ethic and the deterioration of American companies, are presumably more deeply rooted and much less subject to manipulation through public policy. **********As a consequence, we have been treated to lectures and sermons describing what we must do to be saved - companies must pull themselves together, learn to manage as the Japanese do, to think about the long run instead of quarterly profit reports, to substitute cooperative relationships with labor and government for the current adversarial ones, and to relearn the arts of production. **********While much of this may be good advice, the diagnosis that it is based on ignores the important distinction we mentioned at the outset - the competitiveness in world markets of the United States as a country is something very different from the competitiveness of American companies. **********The competitiveness of a country depends on what happens within its boundaries to such things as prices, wages, taxes and exchange rates. The competitiveness of a company depends on what happens within the organization but not on what happens to any particular country or locality. A company that is competitive because it has a new or better product or a new or better production process can take advantage of that competitiveness by producing at home or, if events in the United States make such a course unprofitable, by producing in other countries. Thus, American companies could do well in world markets while the country was doing badly. AND this is exactly what has taken place. The share of United States multinational manufacturing firms, including all their worldwide operations, in world export markets held steady or even increased between the late 1950's and the early 1980's, even while the share of the United States as a country fell by 35 percent. The multinationals increased their share of manufactures exported from both developed and less-developed countries. And they increased their shares in exports in most of the countries in which they operated; that is, they increased their exports faster than did other companies in these countries. **********Thus, American multinationals in manufacturing - a class that includes almost all large manufacturng companies - showed no signs of losing their competitiveness. If their technological and management abilities had been deteriorating, they would have deteriorated outside the United States as well as within it. In fact, there is no sign in their export trade of any such deterioration. **********This superior performance in exporting by American multinationals relative to the United States as a country was not an aberration confined to one or two industries. In every major manufacturing sector (foods, chemicals, metal manufacturing, machinery, transport equipment and other manufacturing industries), the multinationals outdid the country. **********How did the multinationals hold on to their export shares when the country's share in manufactured exports was falling so far? They increased their exports from the United States by more than 600 percent in value and perhaps 150 percent in quantity between 1966 and 1983. This was a slightly faster pace than for United States manufactured exports in general but still lagged the growth of exports by other countries. But they increased their exports from overseas production locations by about twice as much. By 1983, almost half of the multinationals' total exports came from their production outside the United States, up from a third or so 25 years earlier. **********American multinationals may be guilty of many of the weaknesses, bad practices and shortsightedness attributed to them. It may be good that they are constantly lectured on their defects and urged to learn from other countries, pay attention to quality and plan for the long-term future. But their worldwide export performance does not show the poor results we might expect from the bad report cards we read. The multinationals have done well as exporters. **********If we wish to explain our national trade problems, we should look for reasons other than the decline of our companies' technology and management. We should be asking whether developments and policies specific to the United States have been making the country less attractive as a location for manufacturing. These might include our slow growth in output and productivity relative to other industrial countries over the last 30 to 40 years and, until recently, the period of extremely high exchange values of the dollar, the effects of which are still with us. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/02/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE: 1986'S NEWSMAKERS IN FINANCE; Economic Crisis Burdened Nakasone
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/02/busin.body_text: **********Trying to make workers work less and savers spend more has put Yasuhiro Nakasone, the Japanese Prime Minister, in an unenviable position. He has proposed measures to those effects in a move to revive Japan's economy, which has been battered by a 40 percent rise in the value of the yen, and to appease the United States, which blames its ally for its staggering trade deficit. **********Japanese manufacturers face the worst slump in more than a decade. Layoffs - almost unheard-of in Japan - have begun, and corporate profits are sagging. Meanwhile, United States officials spent much of 1986 pleading with Mr. Nakasone to encourage domestic growth, with the hope of transforming the Japanese from exporters into importers. **********By using the problems to his advantage, Mr. Nakasone won re-election in July, and in another shrewd move he named his chief party rival, Kiichi Miyazawi, finance minister. **********Mr. Nakasone has forged a bilateral agreement with the United States, pushed for a cut in the discount rate and pressed companies to give workers wage increases, two-day weekends and longer vacations. His tax plan, moreover, ended tax-free savings accounts. **********But while some observers view his policies as extreme steps, others describe them as window dressing aimed at forestalling protectionist legislation in the United States. This latter view gained credence when Japan recently announced its budget, which provided for the smallest spending increase in three decades.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/19/busin.main_headline: Talking Deals; Joint Ventures In Soviet Union
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/19/busin.print_headline: Talking Deals; Joint Ventures In Soviet Union
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/19/busin.body_text: **********PICTURE the sights of Moscow: the Kremlin, Red Square, Lenin's Tomb. And the Pizza Hut. **********This vision may soon come true under the glasnost policy of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. Short on Western expertise, the Soviet Government earlier this year took a major step to opening its economy by permitting joint ventures with Western businesses. Since then, American and European companies have flocked to do business in the Soviet Union. Ten or so ventures have been announced, with at least 60 in the wings. **********The first joint venture involving an American company was announced last week between Combustion Engineering, a Stamford, Conn., concern, and the Soviet state oil company to modernize Soviet oil and petrochemical facilities. Combustion will own 49 percent of the partnership, and the Russians the rest. **********Among other American companies considering joint ventures are Singer, Monsanto, Eli Lilly, Occidental Petroleum and Pepsico, owner of the Pizza Hut restaurant chain. Many of these companies have long done business in the Soviet Union, but never in a joint venture. **********Experts in America see this as a major breakthrough. ''It's a big change and there's a big revolution going on in the Soviet Union,'' said Dwayne O. Andreas, chairman of Archer-Daniels-Midland, who is also chairman of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Trade and Economic Council. ''The Soviets are trying to bring in market-oriented activites to make socialism work better, and the Western companies see the Soviet Union as a big market.'' Jack Brougher, director of Soviet affairs for the United States Commerce Department, added, ''This is a radical departure from previous Soviet practices.'' **********In the past, business between the United States and the Soviet Union has waxed and waned, depending on the political climate. The Russians were instrumental in the development of the Eurodollar market in the the 1950's, when, during the cold war, they pulled their dollar deposits out of New York and moved them to London. In the 1970's, American companies were hired to help build manufacturing plants but generally left once the job was done. Such consumer goods companies as Pepsico have sold their products in the Soviet Union for almost 15 years, but under franchises. **********Joint ventures, for the first time, allow American businesses to have an ownership stake in a Soviet business. This would give them a continuing presence there, greater control and a chance to make bigger profits. Analysts say the Soviet Union is one of the world's biggest markets where Western businesses can operate with little competition. **********''You can't stay out of a country the size of the Soviet Union and stay a major international marketer,'' said Donald M. Kendall, former chairman of Pepsico, which has a Pizza Hut joint venture under study and plans to add 21 bottling plants to the 19 it already franchises in the Soviet Union. **********For the Russians, the impetus for joint ventures is practical. They need the expertise that Western businesses can provide as well as hard currency, now that lower oil prices have cut one source of foreign exchange. The Russians hope that many of these ventures will teach them to build better manufacturing facilities, which, in turn, can build more marketable export products that can bring in needed foreign currency. **********The Combustion arrangement is a model of what others might look like. Combustion's partner, the Soviet Ministry of Oil Refining and Petrochemical Industries, is about double the size of the Exxon Corporation and Royal Dutch/Shell combined. **********The venture's board is composed of three Russians and two Americans. Its director general, or chief executive, is Russian. Two deputies report to the director general - the one in charge of operations is American and the one in charge of administration is Russian. Rank-and-file employees will be both Russians and Americans. Combustion is investing $16 million initially, with all expenses and profits to be split in line with ownership. **********''We understand that success is important to both of us,'' said Charles Hugel, Combustion's chief executive. ''We've had general discussions about profit levels and it is satisfactory to them and to us.'' Mr. Hugel added, however, that in a crunch, the Russians would probably prevail. **********But impediments still remain. With so few Western companies familiar with the Soviet Union, only those that have done business there before have, so far, expressed interest. And even then, such joint ventures are still moving into uncharted waters. American companies must also obtain an export license to make sure that certain types of information and equipment, particularly anything militarily sensitive, is not exported.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/27/world.main_headline: AFGHAN GUERRILLAS IGNORE TRUCE, SAY WAR GOES ON
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/27/world.print_headline: AFGHAN GUERRILLAS IGNORE TRUCE, SAY WAR GOES ON
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/27/world.body_text: **********Eleven days after the Afghan Government declared a cease-fire, guerrilla leaders say that fighting persists throughout Afghanistan and that there has been no trace of a return by refugees to their homeland. **********Spokesmen for the insurgents and American and Pakistani officials said there was also no sign of any willingness by guerrilla leaders to share power with the Communists, as proposed early this month by the Soviet-backed Kabul Government. **********Afghan officials have asserted in radio broadcasts that leaders of some guerrilla groups had recently agreed to work with the Government and some refugees had returned home. **********But all along the Afghan border, guerrilla leaders have been touring refugee camps, making speeches and handing out leaflets to persuade Afghans not to take seriously the Kabul cease-fire initiative of Jan. 15. **********''We've been working day and night to tell them this is a trick,'' said Qaribur Rehman Saeed, chief spokesman for Hisb-e-Islami, the largest guerrilla group. ''Some of the refugees might have been hopeful at first that they could go back, but they now realize, and they are not going.'' **********American and Pakistani officials were nonetheless said to be carefully watching events in Afghanistan after the Kabul initiatives, especially the declaration by the Communist leader, Najib, favoring a political ''reconciliation'' in Afghanistan that would permit the withdrawal of the estimated 120,000 Soviet troops. **********Officials said that Washington was more skeptical of the Government's sincerity than was Pakistan, but that both the United States and Pakistan were interested in continued discus-sions to see how the Communists would carry out their proposals. **********''We have all agreed to probe Soviet intentions with prudence and patience,'' said Deane R. Hinton, the United States Ambassador in Pakistan. He and other officials added that the United States and Pakistan would still insist that Moscow first agree to withdraw its troops within a few months. **********Pakistan is involved in the conflict next door because it serves as the military and political base for the seven Afghan guerrilla groups that receive hundreds of millions of dollars annually in covert assistance from the United States, Saudi Arabia and other sources. **********Lately, Pakistan has stepped up diplomatic contacts with the Russians to discuss the Kabul initiatives, and senior American officials have also accelerated their consultations here. **********With three million refugees in its territory, Pakistan is widely seen as coming under conflicting pressures related to the war. Pakistani leaders strongly back the insurgents' efforts to oust the Russians, but political pressures seem to be rising to get the war settled and let the refugees return. **********Most opponents of Pakistan's President, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, say that he has not tried hard enough to bring the war to a peaceful conclusion. **********In addition to the call for a cease-fire, Kabul invited the leaders of ''armed groups'' to take part in running the country. **********In speeches on the Kabul radio, Mr. Najib pledged to grant amnesty to guerrilla leaders, preserve Islam as the national religion and set up a series of ''reconciliation commissions'' throughout the country with non-Communists in leadership roles. **********Western diplomats said they were impressed that Mr. Najib seemed to be seeking a political end to the seven-year-old war, which spread after Soviet troops swept into Afghanistan in the last week of 1979 to support the Government. **********But a few days after the cease-fire began, the seven major Afghan guerrilla groups held an unusual joint rally here and forcefully rejected all the Soviet-Afghan proposals. **********The insurgent groups, overcoming earlier signs of disagreement over tactics and negotiating positions, vowed to keep fighting until Soviet troops were pushed out and asserted that only they had the right to form an Afghan government. A Threat Against Traitors **********The groups also declared that any Afghan leader who took Mr. Najib's offer would be treated as a traitor and as an agent of the Afghan secret police, a declaration that experts here said had special significance. The declaration was generally seen as a threat by the guerrillas to kill anyone who dared to defect. **********Political analysts here and in Washington point out that although sounding conciliatory, Mr. Najib also made clear his intention to preserve Communist control in Kabul. They noted that in a speech on Jan. 1 he also declared that even a government of ''national reconciliation'' would have to bring about the ''full realization'' of Communist goals and preserve Afghanistan as ''a regime loyal to the Soviet Union.'' **********A senior American official said Mr. Najib made it ''perfectly clear'' that the Communists were ''going to continue to run the place - and that's just not acceptable.'' **********Afghan leaders in Kabul asserted that some local commanders of insurgent groups had already surrendered and agreed to work with the Government. The Kabul radio said recently that 417 ''armed opposition groups'' representing 37,000 people were ''engaged in negotiations'' on sharing power. One Group Said to Defect **********But these claims were vehemently disputed here. Rebel spokesmen said they knew of only one insurgent commander who had defected recently, near the city of Herat. Kabul said he brought 1,500 men with him, but guerrilla leaders said today that there were at most 150. **********Officials in Kabul also said that thousands of refugees had returned from Pakistan in recent days. But Pakistani officials and refugee workers said they had seen no evidence of that. **********Of the major guerrilla organizations, four are Islamic fundamentalists and three are considered moderates, with ties to the old secular power centers in Afghanistan. Experts say that some people in the moderate groups might theoretically be more willing to deal with Kabul to return to power in their areas. **********But so far, the hard line against the Najib initiatives appears to command virtually total support among rival guerrilla groups, whose mutual animosity in the past has sometimes led to fighting between them inside Afghanistan. **********Meanwhile, insurgency leaders said that the fight against the Russians has continued throughout the country, with guerrillas attacking Soviet installations and convoys and Soviet soldiers responding with artillery, shelling and aerial bombardment. Fighting on Edge of Kabul **********''The cease-fire has never been in effect,'' said Syed Bahauddin Majrooh, director of the Afghan Information Center here. He said rebel attacks and Soviet retaliations had increased since Jan. 15 in Paktia Province and near the cities of Jalalabad, Kandahar and Herat, and in the southern outskirts of Kabul. **********Other spokesmen said the insurgents had shot down at least one jet plane and destroyed tanks, and that while the Russians had retaliated they had mounted no major offensives. **********Guerrilla spokesmen generally concede that the war has been difficult for the last two years, particularly in 1986, because of growing sophistication in counterinsurgency by Russian troops. In addition, Soviet aerial bombardment has depopulated key areas, making it harder for the guerrillas to operate. **********In some cases villagers in Afghanistan are said to have demanded that the guerrillas leave their areas to avoid being bombed. Such reports may have led to the Soviet belief that the time is right for a peace initiative. **********The insurgents are believed to have huge stockpiles of weapons and could last perhaps a year or more if their supplies were cut off as part of an agreement on a Soviet troop withdrawal, according to analysts here. **********The Russians are therefore seen as wanting to wait at least two more years before leaving, because this might give them enough time to wipe out the insurgency first.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/24/busin.body_text: **********The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation said yesterday that it would take a $755 million after-tax write-off because of cost overruns at its Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant in upstate New York. **********The power company, based in Syracuse, also said it was cutting its quarterly dividend to 30 cents a share, from 52 cents. **********As a result of the write-off, Niagara Mohawk said it had a net loss for the first half of the year of $569.4 million, compared with income of $238.26 million in the first half of 1986. **********Under a new accounting rule, Niagara Mohawk was forced to write off the cost either this year or next year and all at once. Earnings Capability Cut **********John G. Haehl, Niagara Mohawk's chairman, said the developments ''have reduced the company's future earnings capability despite our efforts to lower our costs by $100 million in 1988.'' He added that the lower dividend rate was ''a level the board believes is sustainable barring unforeseen problems.'' **********The problems occurred on what became the most costly nuclear power plant ever built, at $6.3 billion. Its costs had originally been estimated at $500 million when it was started 14 years ago. **********Some of the cost overruns will be passed along to rate payers of the five New York State utilities that financed the plant, which is operated by Niagara Mohawk and located at Nine Mile Point near Oswego, N.Y. **********The plant received permission to begin full operations on July 1. **********The news came after the market closed. Niagara's stock fell 25 cents, to $15.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Separately, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, lead owner of the troubled Seabrook nuclear reactor, acknowledged that it would have an ''extremely difficult'' time developing financial plans to ward off a bankruptcy filing before year's end. Public Service last week abandoned attempts to raise $358 million for the completed but unlicensed plant and other expenses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/11/busin.main_headline: STOCKS RISE SHARPLY BEFORE TENDER BIDS, S.E.C. STUDY FINALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/11/busin.print_headline: STOCKS RISE SHARPLY BEFORE TENDER BIDS, S.E.C. STUDY FINALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/11/busin.body_text: **********A study of 172 successful tender offers from 1981 to 1985 disclosed that in every case the price of the target company's stock rose abnormally more than three weeks before the bid was announced. **********Average volume in the target stock reached double its historical norm 10 days before the announcement, according to the study, released today by the Securities and Exchange Commission's office of the chief economist. **********The report did not reach conclusions about the scope of illegal insider trading in the examples studied, though it said it was ''unable to explain a great deal of the pre-bid trading.'' **********Three other factors - speculative press reports, market rumors and public disclosures of stockholdings by potential corporate raiders - did spur price and volume increases, the report said. **********The study found that on average in the 172 cases, the target company's stock price gained 39 percent of the total increase caused by the deal by the day before the offer was announced. **********This rise averaged 50 percent when widespread rumors and press reports preceded a tender offer, versus 33 percent when there were no press reports, the study said. If the eventual bidder had filed reports with the S.E.C. about stock positions held, the figure would shoot up to 47.7 percent, versus 26.5 percent if no report was filed. **********''It is possible,'' the study said, ''and logical to many, that illegal insider trading behavior could affect'' the three other factors. For example, speculation in the news media could have originated from the spread of illegal information. **********The report stressed that further information was required to determine the ''ultimate source'' of pre-takeover trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/11/world.main_headline: U.S. BRINGING HOME MARINE GUARD UNIT AT SOVIET CONSULATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/11/world.print_headline: U.S. BRINGING HOME MARINE GUARD UNIT AT SOVIET CONSULATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/11/world.body_text: **********The entire detachment of six Marine guards stationed at the United States Consulate in Leningrad will be replaced in May as a security precaution, the Reagan Administration said today. **********On Tuesday, the Marine Corps arrested a former guard, Sgt. John J. Weirick, on the suspicion that he spied for the Soviet Union while he was stationed in Leningrad in 1981 and 1982. The arrest raised fears that the security of the consulate, like that of the embassy in Moscow, had been compromised by Soviet intelligence agencies with the cooperation of Marine guards. **********Meanwhile, Government officials said one of the marines implicated in breaches of security rules in Moscow had been moved from a previous assignment at another embassy because he had beaten a local woman. **********All 28 guards at the embassy in Moscow are to be replaced as soon as visas are issued to their replacements. The Pentagon said that there was no evidence that the men being recalled from Leningrad and Moscow were implicated in the series of security breaches at the diplomatic missions, but that bringing them back to the United States would aid investigators. **********Staff Sgt. Robert S. Stufflebeam, a Marine guard who was charged this week with improper contacts with Soviet women while stationed at the Moscow embassy, was removed from his post in Harare, Zimbabwe, in 1984 because he had beaten a woman he knew there, according to officials familiar with the situation. **********After leaving Zimbabwe, Sergeant Stufflebeam was moved to a post in Somalia, where he remained nine months, his records show, and in 1985 he was assigned to the guard detachment in Moscow, where he became the deputy commander. **********In Moscow, according to charges filed this week against Sergeant Stufflebeam, he repeatedly met with Soviet women and afterward failed to report the contacts, thus violating rules that govern such meetings. Charges Against Guards **********Sergeant Stufflebeam is not suspected of espionage, but two marines who reported to him in Moscow have been arrested and charged with helping Soviet intelligence agents enter the embassy. **********Sergeant Stufflebeam's military attorney turned down requests to discuss his behavior in Zimbabwe. The sergeant is awaiting court-martial proceedings at Quantico, Va.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/25/busin.body_text: **********Railroad workers across Canada went on strike today, shutting down freight and passenger service and prompting the Government to order an immediate return to the bargaining table to try to end the country's first rail strike in 14 years. **********Labor Minister Pierre Cadieux said he had ordered representatives of Canada's two national railroads and the union representing the 48,000 striking workers to go to Ottawa for a special bargaining session with a federal mediator on Tuesday. Mr. Cadieux said the talks would be the final attempt at mediation and ''if it fails the Government will intervene.'' **********The Government stepped in to end the last railroad strike, a 10-day walkout in 1973, by ordering the unions back to work. **********The strike began early today after round-the-clock talks between the union and the two railroads, Canadian Pacific Ltd.'s CP Rail and the Government-owned Canadian National Rail, stalled on Sunday, apparently over job security. **********Almost a third of Canada's freight is shipped by rail and economists said a long strike, especially as the grain harvest approaches, would hurt exports and weaken the economy. **********''One hundred percent of our grain is moved to market by rail and any downtime is a setback,'' said Mike Chilliak, manager of the Saskatchewan Wheat Pool's Saskatoon division. Mr. Chilliak said Saskatchewan grain elevators could be full by the end of the week, backing up grain throughout the system. **********In addition to the economic consequences, the strike has left thousands of stranded travelers scrambling to find space on already full buses and planes. **********Transport Minister John C. Crosbie said earlier that the Government might seek legislation to send the strikers back to work. But he said later in Parliament that he would let the two sides bargain ''in good faith.'' **********The railroad union contracts expired in December. The talks broke down in January and resumed last week.

Following the merger, Monfort will exist as an independent operating company of Conagra, which also makes Banquet frozen foods and processes Armour meats. **********Last year, Monfort earned $25.1 million, on sales of $1.6 billion. Conagra reported net income of $105.3 million, on sales of $5.9 billion. The companies said they planned to complete the transaction in June. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Conagra's stock closed at $34 a share, up 37.5 cents. Monfort's stock rose $4 a share, to close at $53.50 in over-the-counter trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.main_headline: India's Drought Is Worst in Decades
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.print_headline: India's Drought Is Worst in Decades
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/16/world.body_text: **********Dawn broke in these parched farmlands today with gray clouds, raising a few hopes of rain. But by midmorning the sun was ablaze, once again burning farmers' hopes of relief from India's driest rainy season in decades. **********''I am 75 years old, and I have never seen anything this bad,'' said Naufat Mohammed, a white-bearded farmer, looking at the cracked earth around a well. ''This is God's will, but God is angry with us.'' **********After weeks of false hopes that the summer monsoon rains would come, India faces the prospect of devastation to the national economy, the uprooting of hundreds of thousands of people and the need for a huge relief effort to distribute drinking water and prevent starvation. **********The drought, which Government officials say is unprecedented in intensity, has already spread through most of the country, hitting hardest in the northern grain belts. There wells, reservoirs and water tanks are running at dangerously low levels or are already dry. Rain 75% Below Normal **********Less than a third of the country has received normal rainfall this year, with the hardest-hit areas as low as 75 percent below normal. **********Although the monsoon floods cause many deaths, the rains are normally one of the great life-giving forces in India, central to its culture and the expectations of its people. The monsoon season is incubated as heat in the subcontinent increases while the Indian Ocean to the south remains cool, unleashing a stormy mix of air that then pushes up from the south. **********Almost nothing is anticipated as much as summer rains carried by winds heading northward starting in early June. The failure of the monsoon is a severe blow to Indian morale as well as to the survival of its people. **********There have been no signs yet of death or starvation, but experts say they fear that a large-scale loss of cattle could wipe out the livelihoods of countless families. Milk production has already fallen sharply as the Government struggles to rush fodder such as spoiled wheat or sugar cane to drought areas. Driest in 80 Years **********New Delhi, 50 miles northwest of here, is suffering its driest season in 80 years. Residents of New Delhi and other cities are suffering water shortages and widespread power cuts so electricity can be diverted to farm areas to run hard-pressed wells and irrigation systems. Other cities are experiencing the same thing. **********Agriculture experts say they fear that India's summer grain crop, once expected to be 90 million metric tons, could fall drastically short. This would force India to rush its 23 million tons of buffer grain, now in storage, throughout the countryside. **********Such relief efforts helped to check starvation in the drought of 1979-80, which was described as the worst in this century nationwide. The army was called out to help distribute drinking water by train and military trucks, something many experts think could happen on an even larger scale this year. **********On top of all these problems, the areas in eastern India that are not suffering from lack of rain are experiencing heavy rains and flooding. News reports say that more than 140 people have died in the northeastern states of Bihar, West Bengal and Assam. In neighboring Bangladesh, the death toll has been reported at 350. Emergency Committee Created **********Faced with a crisis that could dwarf all his other political difficulties, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi recently established an emergency committee, of which he is chairman, to oversee drought relief efforts. **********Officials say a food distribution and rural employment program costing about $1.5 billion is about to be announced. A water distribution plan was announced in Parliament today. These and other steps are certain to worsen the national budget deficit and curtail other development programs. **********Aides to Mr. Gandhi say they also fear that bureacratic problems could undercut Government efforts, creating unrest and disenchantment throughout the north. A senior member of the Gandhi Cabinet said he was afraid that on his next visit to his constituency villagers would throw stones at him. **********Officials say that even if the monsoon were to come now at full force it would not save crops in most areas. The biggest fear is that for some reason the rains may never come at all this year. Although most of India depends on the monsoon of July and August, rainfall lingering into the fall is essential if farmers are to recoup this year with their winter crop of wheat. 'Cannot Image the Horror' **********''If the rain fails even in September, we cannot imagine the horror,' said a former Agriculture Minister, Rao Birendra Singh. He said that from all indications so far, the 23 million metric tons of reserve grain should be enough to prevent starvation - ''provided we do not lose our next wheat crop.'' **********The actual reason for the failure of the monsoon is unclear, although meteorologists say it appears to be part of odd global weather patterns this year, including unusually hot weather in Europe and the United States. **********Two-thirds of India's annual grain crop is supposed to be grown during the summer monsoon. The problem is especially acute in the 70 percent of the country's farmlands that have no irrigation and depend entirely on rain. In these areas, fields that are normally iridescent-green with rice are bare, brown or stunted. **********But even the developed farmlands of the north in Punjab and here in Haryana, where irrigation is extensive, are suffering. The Financial Development Commissioner of Haryana said the state had reached ''near-famine conditions.'' Grain Fields Should be High **********A canal running along the main road here was bone dry today. Farmers complained that a 60-foot well was useless because the water it pumped was brackish and salty. **********''This water would destroy any crops,'' said Jivan Singh, whose family members were plowing a nearby field with two oxen in the hope that at some point rain would come and something, perhaps vegetables, could be planted. A few scrubby sprouts of millet grew at his ankles. He said the grain in this field was normally several feet high at this time. **********The drought has been most devastating in the sandy western regions of Gujarat and Rajasthan states, which have had unusually little rain in three or four years. In these areas, recent visitors say, whole village populations have begun moving in search of water for cattle and people.

Rated triple-A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the obligations are backed by 9 and 9 1/2 percent Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation participation certificates, a kind of mortgage pass-through security. **********The floating-rate issue, with an estimated average life of 3.4 years, pays interest at a rate of six-tenths of a percentage point more than the London interbank offered rate for three-month time deposits. Yields on the fixed-rate obligations range from 7.37 percent for an issue with an estimated average life of 3.4 years to 8.37 percent for 7.9 years, 8.66 percent for 11.1 years and 9.51 percent for 17.5 years. **********Yields on the issue range from 1.05 to 2 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/11/busin.body_text: **********AT the top of the MCA black tower, in the office recently vacated by Frank Price, Thomas Philip Pollock is hunched over a pastrami sandwich and a Diet Coke. As the new overlord of Universal movies, Mr. Pollock is at the peak of the Hollywood hierarchy. But his appointment is more than just another executive move in an industry where people change jobs as often as movie stars change cars. **********For Mr. Pollock has never produced or directed a movie, or even worked at a studio. Instead, for the last decade, he has been one of a handful of superstar lawyers who negotiate deals for other superstars - actors, directors, and studio presidents. With his appointment last September as chairman of MCA's Universal Motion Picture Group, Mr. Pollock won the final responsibility for picking the movies Universal will make - and, in the process, became a powerful symbol of the new business forces that have transformed the entertainment industry. **********In an industry dominated in recent decades by ex-talent agents and ex-television executives - Mr. Pollock's predecessor, Frank Price, once ran Universal's television unit - the 43-year-old lawyer's presence in the chairman's office is one sign that this is the era of the Hollywood lawyer, a special breed distinguished more by their savvy in assembling movie deals than their legal skills. **********''There isn't one of the superstar lawyers who hasn't had at least one or two offers to head a studio recently,'' says Bert Fields, the lawyer who represents actors Warren Beatty and Dustin Hoffman. **********Hollywood's top dozen lawyers - those who are now chairmen and presidents of studios and those in private practice who negotiate with the studios on behalf of such clients as Sylvester Stallone or Francis Coppola - are mostly men in their 40's or 50's who have spent several years working in law firms with an expertise in entertainment law. Some are graduates of Ivy League law schools, while others went to school in California. **********Just this week, Fred Bernstein, a 1976 graduate of U.C.L.A. law school, was named president of worldwide production at Columbia Pictures. And besides Mr. Pollock (Columbia, '67), there is Frank Wells, (Stanford, '59) the president of the Walt Disney Company; Sidney Sheinberg (Columbia, '56), the president of MCA; Stephen Silbert, (Berkeley, '67) the president of MGM/UA; Gary Hendler (Harvard, '62) the former president of Tri-Star; J. Victor Kaufman, (N.Y.U., '67) the chairman of Tri-Star; Arthur Krim (Columbia, '32), the chairman of Orion; and a handful of others, including Mr. Fields (Harvard, '52), who represent top talent, and could move into high-level studio jobs at any time. **********Their effect on the industry is not likely to be revolutionary. But the superstar lawyers, with their roots in business, will certainly intensify Hollywood's current obsession with movies not as art, but as products. ''I **********N 1986 America, you cannot run a major studio without a financial/ legal/investment type high up in the hierarchy,'' said Frank Rothman (U.S.C., '51), the former chairman and chief executive officer of MGM/UA. ''It has gotten very expensive to make pictures, and you can't just go to the bank and borrow enough money when pictures cost $14 million apiece. There are new ways of financing - bonds and partnerships and public offerings. So you need lawyers to speak to investment bankers about raising complicated funds.'' **********Mr. Pollock defines the role more succinctly: ''They didn't hire me at MCA for my legal skills. They have fabulous lawyers. Entertainment law is a misnomer. Entertainment lawyers don't talk about law. They talk about business. Entertainment law is about representing people in the entertainment business.'' **********Because the costs of making and distributing movies have always made it necessary to win wide audiences, Hollywood has historically been an uneasy amalgam of art and commerce. But these days, it seems that the emphasis on commerce is greater than ever - and some say that emphasis is lowering the quality of the movies that get made. **********''There's an absolute lack of imagination among the people running studios today,'' said Billy Wilder, a writer/director (''Sunset Boulevard,'' ''Some Like It Hot,'') who won six Academy Awards between 1945 and 1960. ''There's no imagination to do something new, something bold, a movie that is not a sequel. A picture can be in preparation for a couple of years, and a new regime comes in and sweeps it out and starts all over with new projects.'' **********According to Mr. Rothman, studios have no choice but to be concerned with finances, given the cost and complexity of movie deals. A former partner in the Los Angeles law firm of Wyman Bautzer Rothman Kuchel & Silbert, Mr. Rothman was picked by Kirk Kerkorian, the financier who owned most of MGM, to reorganize the studio in 1982, when it was struggling under nearly $700 million worth of debt after its purchase of United Artists. **********After running MGM/UA for four years, Mr. Rothman went back to being a trial lawyer, but one of his ex-law partners - Stephen Silbert -who had also done work for Mr. Kerkorian was named president and chief operating officer of MGM/UA in October. In both cases, the Kerkorian connection led the way to the studio job. ''A lawyer in the entertainment field becomes known to Kirk Kerkorian and becomes a logical choice -not necessarily a better choice,'' said Mr. Rothman. **********Like Mr. Rothman and Mr. Silbert, most of the lawyers who have been enticed into studio jobs first caught the attention of people at the studio while handling business negotiations for clients who are actors, producers, movie executives, or studio owners. **********And even if they go to work for a studio, most lawyers stick to business decisions, rather than purely creative ones. But the two are tightly entangled these days - for, more than ever, the studios must think of a movie as a package of different rights, each of which brings in separate earnings. In some cases, the traditional business of showing movies in theaters is no longer the major source of revenue. **********Tri-Star's ''Flashpoint,'' released in 1984 and starring Kris Kristofferson, is one of an increasing number of movies that has earned more on video cassette than in the theater: $3 million worth of box office tickets, versus $3.3 million, wholesale, for cassette distribution. And Orion's ''Maxi,'' starring Glenn Close, earned less than $2.5 million at the box office, but took in $3.5 million, wholesale, for cassettes. Pay television, syndication and foreign theatrical rights also produce hefty chunks of revenue. And toys and television cartoon series have generated huge profits for movies as diverse as ''The Empire Strikes Back'' and ''Rambo.'' **********''I don't believe you can separate the creative and business decisions,'' says Mr. Kaufman, the chairman of Tri-Star. ''If all your films were low-budget, you could make a purely creative decision. But any high- budget film has to be a consideration of the potential of the film at the box office versus the cost. You have to calculate what you can afford to lose on the films that fail.'' **********Mr. Kaufman said that although he has final approval in choosing movies for the studio, he rarely turns down movie proposals that his president of production is really committed to. Similarly, Mr. Rothman said he almost never made the real creative decisions at MGM, although he had the power to kill ideas he hated. **********Mr. Rothman - who cut MGM/ UA's debt, despite poor to mediocre box office reception for such films as ''The Pope of Greenwich Village'' and ''Oxford Blues'' - said lawyers should not take over the creative function. ''For us to say, 'Make this script or that script' is dangerous,'' he warned. ''There are lots of chips riding on people who are new at making such decisions.'' **********And what makes a lawyer successful in Hollywood is not the ability to choose movies. Rather, it is the ability to put together movie deals - a talent that depends at least as much on having the right contacts as on any specific financial or legal abilities. ''L **********AWYERS, like agents, are important when they have important clients,'' said Mr. Pollock, who got his start representing such talented young film school graduates as George Lucas, and went on to other important movie clients, including Dino De Laurentiis and Ivan Reitman. **********Client relationships were also important to Gary Hendler, who was made president of Tri-Star in February 1983, and quickly convinced his long-time client, Robert Redford, to make a movie for the new company. Tri-Star made its debut with ''The Natural,'' a box office success, but the company poured so much money into making and marketing the movie that it was not terribly profitable. Few of Mr. Hendler's other movies were conspicuously successful, and he resigned in January 1985. **********Superstar lawyers working outside the studios include Bruce Ramer (who represents Steven Spielberg and Clint Eastwood), Barry Hirsch (Goldie Hawn, Jane Fonda), the partnership of Ken Ziffren and Skip Brittenham (Harrison Ford, most major television producers), Mr. Fields, and Mr. Pollock's former partner, Jake Bloom (Sylvester Stallone). **********Their billing arrangements for star clients are generally different from the strict hourly fees that are standard law firm practice. At least one of the lawyers writes contracts for top movie executives for free. Although many Hollywood lawyers now act as all-purpose agent/advisers for their famous clients, some do not feel it fair to charge a percentage of the star's astronomical salary and, instead, settle for a flat fee. SOMETIMES it is the studio, and not the client, that pays the lawyer's fee. Although no one will speak publicly, studio executives and lawyers say privately that when studios really want a particular star, they will often pay both the legal fee and the agent's standard 10 percent. **********Many of the most important talents in Hollywood are now relying more on their lawyers than their agents, and a few - mostly directors, like Steven Spielberg - are eschewing agents altogether. Meanwhile, many of the lawyers are now performing such agent-like functions as reading scripts for their clients. **********''The deals today are so complicated that they can't be done only by an agent or a business manager,'' said Mr. Pollock, who has always read scripts. ''And the reason the deals got so complicated is that the costs got so high. Ten years ago people could afford to take a chance. Now, it's $30 million every time a studio says yes to a movie.'' **********Since it costs $17 million to make a movie and $8 million to market it, plus interest and overhead, Mr. Pollock said, ''studios look for ways to spread their risks, including partnerships. And independent production companies pre-sell pre-sell rights. When cable rights are pre-bought by HBO and video rights by Vestron and foreign rights by Goldcrest, it takes sophisticated deal making.'' **********Many studios are turning to lawyers for that deal-making expertise. But according to Sid Sheinberg, the president of MCA and the man who hired Mr. Pollock, business savvy is not the only hallmark of a movie executive. ''The one single characteristic necessary to success in this business is an affinity and sensitivity to the creative process,'' said Mr. Sheinberg, who started as a lawyer in MCA's television division. ''You can have that and still fail if you're a terrible businessman or irrational. But without it you'll definitely fail.'' **********Some of that affinity may be what gets lawyers to Hollywood in the first place, he said: ''People ask me, 'How did you, a lawyer and a Jewish boy from Corpus Christi, get to this job?' I think there may be something motivating us to go to law school that has an interest in theatricality. Perhaps we veered to law school as a socially acceptable way of dealing with it.''  A HISTORY OF HOLLYWOOD FROM THE MOGULS TO THE LAWYERS **********HOLLYWOOD - Hollywood, and its lawyers, have come a long way since the days of the old movie moguls, mostly uneducated Jewish immigrants who moved to California to exploit the possibilities of a new technology -much like today's young Silicon Valley entrepreneurs. **********Men like Samuel Goldwyn, a former glove salesman, Adolph Zukor, a fur merchant, and Louis B. Mayer, a scrap metal collector, got their start buying penny arcades and showing short silent films to other immigrants for 5 cents a peek. **********For them, lawyers were just tools of the trade, working out the details of their plans. ''The lawyer was always necessary because a picture is a conglomeration of music rights, story rights, all kinds of rights,'' says Samuel Z. Arkoff, a lawyer who in 1954 co-founded American International Pictures. (AIP made such classics as ''I Was a Teenage Werewolf''). ''It's different from a carpenter who makes a table and sells it.'' **********As the theaters got fancier, the moguls began making their own, longer movies to fill them, and in the process, wielded more and more power over the actors, directors and technicians who worked for them. The lawyers, like all the rest, were just tools of the autocratic studio heads who made all the important decisions, including which actors and directors to hire, and, once they had signed the standard seven-year contracts with the studio, which movies they should work on. **********The studios had so much power in the early sound era that the Justice Department brought an anti-trust suit against them to try to break up the industry. And in 1952, the studios were forced to sell off the theater chains in which they showed their movies. **********When the four major studios, Paramount, Warner Brothers, M-G-M, and 20th Century-Fox, lost their captive theaters, they could no longer risk making 40 movies a year - and no longer needed large numbers of actors, directors and producers under contract. And once the actors and directors became free agents, the studios had to make a series of deals to put together a movie. **********''Instead of paying by the week and ordering actors to make five movies a year, the studios hired them picture by picture,'' said Mr. Arkoff. **********By the 1960's, the studios had lost much of their power, and the agents came into their own. Instead of just representing individual talents, they began linking stars with a director and producer, and selling a studio the entire package. ''At one time, MCA had 75 percent of the major talent and William Morris had the rest,'' says Ned Tanen, the president of Paramount's motion picture division. **********By the 1970's, some of the agents had moved into high-level studio jobs, with David Begelman running Columbia, and Alan Ladd Jr. running Fox. But a decade ago the talent agencies began to splinter, as leading agents went out on their own. And the lawyers began to pick up the power. **********''As the Morris office started to decline in power, very bright attorneys smelled a hole,'' said Mr. Tanen, ''The agencies got very weak, and the attorneys rushed in to fill the void.'' **********Said Mr. Arkoff: ''Today almost every producer, every director, every big star has a structure, and more and more those organizations are being headed up by lawyers. Mr. Very Important Producer and Miss Very Important Star are ships, and the lawyers are their barnacles. Being a lawyer was not too popular in 1954. Now when people know you're a lawyer, there's an extra cachet.''

The Job Outlook Across the Nation;
SOUTHEAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/jobs/.print_headline:
The Job Outlook Across the Nation;
SOUTHEAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/jobs/.body_text: **********LEAD: WITH a trade-related upturn in manufacturing, the Southeast is gaining greater economic growth balance between its diversified front-runners, Florida and Georgia, and its industrial states like North Carolina, Tennessee and Alabama, which were hit hard by the trade deficit. **********WITH a trade-related upturn in manufacturing, the Southeast is gaining greater economic growth balance between its diversified front-runners, Florida and Georgia, and its industrial states like North Carolina, Tennessee and Alabama, which were hit hard by the trade deficit. **********In overall growth, according to James N. Young, chief economist for BellSouth Corporation, based in Atlanta, the region's economy in the first half of 1987 was ''relatively sluggish by recent historical standards,'' though the region ''still performed relatively well.'' **********Unemployment fell to 6.2 percent in mid-year, a percentage point below the rate the year before, according to the First Wachovia Corporation, a multi-state bank holding company that has compiled a regional index of business activity. **********Since last December, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, regional employment has grown faster than the nation's - 1.5 percent against 0.6 percent. The gap is even wider since June 1986: 3.5 percent compared with 2.4. **********Mr. Young blamed the absence of vigorous manufacturing growth for the Southeast's lackluster first-half performance. Nevertheless, thanks in part to the weaker foreign exchange value of the dollar, manufacturing employment grew 0.5 percent in the first half and 1 percent since June 1986, to 3.63 million jobs, in the region embracing Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, the Carolinas and Tennessee. **********Textile employment, after reversing a long decline by turning up in 1986, continued to improve in this year - by 8,400 new jobs, or 1.7 percent, in the first half, and 14,200 jobs, or almost 3 percent, since June 1986. **********But the biggest engines of economic growth in the region continued to be business, professional and other services. As a group, these advanced 5.8 percent since June 1986, to 3.58 million jobs, followed by retail trade, up 5.4 percent over the year, to 3.3 million jobs. **********Construction employment, which many economists had expected to slump sharply, actually expanded, though at a slower pace than in recent years - 0.7 percent since last December and 3.1 percent since June 1986 - as absorption of commercial space and home building remained strong in a region that still attracts new businesses and new people. **********The biggest weakness in the region continues to lie along the Gulf Coast, in energy states such as Louisiana, with 10.9 percent unemployment, and to a certain extent in Mississippi, with 9.2, and Alabama, with 7.7 percent. Even here, though, June 1987 jobless rates were significantly improved from levels a year earlier of 13.5 percent, 12.0 percent and 10.2 percent, respectively. **********Looking ahead, James A. Pihera, an economist with Citizens and Southern Corporation in Atlanta, projected employment growth in the Southeast of ''around 3.5 percent,'' compared with last year's 3.4 percent expansion. ''Construction, however,'' Mr. Pihera said, ''will be weaker in the Southeast than it was last year and will temper the lift provided by manufacturing. Economic progress in 1987 is likely to be a little more evenly spread than in years past. Florida, Georgia and Tennessee will have the region's highest job growth at somewhat above 4 percent, but that is not much greater than the expected regional average of 3.5 percent.'' **********The region's fundamental economic disparity remains between fast-growth rates with diversified economies, typically along the Atlantic Seaboard, and those with weaker economies in the Southeast's ''industrial heartland,'' such as Alabama and Tennessee. Regional economists say the effort to improve the industry mix in weaker states, moving away from goods production and toward services, will be a top economic development priority in the next decade.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/17/busin.body_text: **********News with a foreign flavor comes from Foote, Cone & Belding Communications and Grey Advertising. **********F.C.&B. is planning an agency acquisition in Denmark, where it already owns Lockey/FCB. Now it has signed a letter of intent to purchase Hiort, Stenius & Walter. **********What will result will be a $26 million agency called FCB/ Hiort, Stenius & Walter. **********Grey has a new piece of business, Samsonite Europe, the bag-marketing subsidiary of the Samsonite Corporation of Denver. This pan-European assignment will be managed from Brussels and will cover Belgium, Britain, the Netherlands, France and West Germany. The former agency was TBWA Paris.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/02/busin.body_text: **********The K Mart Corporation is offering $200 million of 10 1/2 percent debentures, due in 2017, at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. **********Rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the debentures yield about 1 3/8 percentage points more than bellwether 30-year Treasury bonds. **********The debentures are not refundable for 10 years and are subject to a sinking fund beginning in 1998 that will retire 5 percent of the issue annually. **********K Mart has the option of increasing the sinking fund payments by 200 percent, which would result in an average life of about 13.85 years, compared with 20.5 years if the sinking fund payments were not increased.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/01/busin.main_headline: FROM THE RIGHT: Henry G. Manne; Let the Markets Settle
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/01/busin.print_headline: FROM THE RIGHT: Henry G. Manne; Let the Markets Settle
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/01/busin.body_text: **********Excerpts from an interview with Henry G. Manne, dean of law and director of the Law and Economics Center at George Mason University. **********THERE are many things generating uncertainty about the market - the threat of higher taxes and the threat of taxes on takeovers, for example. **********Then there are trade and international matters. First, the threat of protectionism. Second - and this is very important - the threat of a reversion to managing and regulating currency markets. People still remember that efforts to fix exchange rates don't work - each nation's domestic policy wins out over international collective efforts. **********All of this increased uncertainty, as did the specter raised by David S. Ruder, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, of David S. Ruder, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, of the stock markets being closed during the turmoil. **********There's also this: I think the world perceives the Reagan Administration as weak and in disarray. The President lost the Bork fight, there's the Iran-Contra affair, and there's been continued controversy about how to deal with the deficit. Where do we go from here? A good White House fight against higher taxes and protectionism - and some success in reducing Federal spending - will restore confidence. Apart from that, we should do nothing. Let markets market consider the proper level of the stock market to be. **********In 1929, the Government tightened the money supply - I don't think we'll make that mistake again. But there are other mistakes to be made. The notion of trying to regulate international exchange rates is just one of them. Another is raising taxes. The idea that you can do anything about a market crash and a threatened recession by raising taxes has been discredited. It is what Government did after 1929. **********Increasing protectionism would be devastating: That's what Smoot-Hawley did, and the relationship between Smoot-Hawley and the Depression is clear. **********Right now, there is no real role for Government in dealing with the market crash, except to insure liquidity. Even there, the Federal Reserve should be wary: It must not step over the line to generate inflationary pressures. Of course, I'd hate to be the adviser who is expected to know the exact day that happens.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/17/world.print_headline: Rudolf Hess Back in Prison After 16-Day Hospital Stay
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/17/world.body_text: **********Rudolf Hess was taken back to his prison cell today after a 16-day stay at a British military hospital, a British diplomatic spokesman said. **********The spokesman, Anderson Purdon, declined to give any information about the condition of the last surviving member of Hitler's inner circle, but noted an Allied statement issued Thursday saying his health was improving. **********The 92-year-old Hess has been the only inmate of Spandau Prison since 1966. He was admitted to the nearby British military hospital March 1. His son says he has been suffering from pneumonia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/world.main_headline: INDIA REPORTS GAIN IN SRI LANKA DRIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/world.print_headline: INDIA REPORTS GAIN IN SRI LANKA DRIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/world.body_text: **********India said tonight that its troops had broken into the center of the Sri Lankan city of Jaffna after a 10-day military campaign against ethnic Tamil rebels it had pledged to disarm. **********But there was no independent confirmation of the report, which was issued by an Indian Foreign Ministry spokesman in New Delhi. An Indian Government spokesman in Madras said Indian troops were continuing to advance on Jaffna, but he said nothing about their being in the center of the city. **********Another Indian official in Madras, elaborating on the report from New Delhi, said Indian commandos based in Jaffna Fort had linked up with a column of troops advancing from the northwest of the city along a coastal road. The campaign, which began on Oct. 9, may have already cost 700 civilian lives, local government administrators said in a message today. Operations in East **********Indian forces have also stepped up operations around the eastern ports of Trincomalee and Batticaloa. About 300 to 400 Indian troops came ashore Sunday night on Kalladi Beach at Batticaloa, residents of the area said today in telephone interviews. **********Tonight, policemen in the area told Reuters that Tamil rebels, trying to blow up an Indian convoy at Kalkudah, north of Batticaloa, had instead destroyed a civilian bus, killing 40 people. **********Sri Lankan authorities later said the Tamils on the bus were refugees fleeing the fighting in the Jaffna Peninsula. Most of the dead were university students. Young people reaching Colombo from Jaffna have told reporters that students fear forced recruitment into the guerrilla army. **********Fighting is still apparently going on in Jaffna town, the historical center of Sri Lanka's Tamil community. An Indian Government spokesman called it a ''mopping up'' operation, but Jaffna residents say the town is in a state of near collapse, with casualties high and damage severe. **********None of the reports could be verified on the spot because Indian troops have prohibited journalists from visiting their areas of operation. Today, the daily news briefing at the Indian High Commission here was canceled without explanation. **********Fourteen prominent civil servants in Jaffna today sent a message to Sri Lanka's President, J. R. Jayewardene, asking him to intervene with the Indians on behalf of Jaffna's people. The letter, a copy of which was sent to the Tamil-language Colombo newspaper Virakesari, said there had been ''indescribable bombing and shelling and aerial strafing'' in which ''almost 700 innocent civilians have died.'' **********Some of these local administrators had been tacit supporters of the main separatist guerrilla group, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. **********Relations between local Tamil people and the Indian force appear to be worsening rapidly throughout the Northern and Eastern Provinces of Sri Lanka, where the soldiers are deployed. India says it has 14,000 troops in Sri Lanka, but unofficial estimates here and in New Delhi put the figure at 20,000 to 25,000. **********The Tamils are far outnumbered on the island as a whole by ethnic Sinhalese, who dominate the Government and the armed forces, but they are numerous in Northern and Eastern Provinces. The Tamils are mostly Hindu; the Sinhalese mostly Buddhist. **********The Indians, once advocates of the Tamil cause and critics of the Sri Lankan Government, were at first welcomed as peacekeepers who would underwrite a July 29 accord designed to end a the guerrilla war and bring Tamil militants into the political process in newly created autonomous areas in the north and east. #125 Civilian Bodies Now, Tamil neighborhoods are daily reporting acts of violence against civilians by Indian troops searching for guerrillas or their sympathizers. **********The accord provided that guerrillas would lay down their arms, but the Liberation Tigers resisted the Indian forces' attempts to disarm them, leading to the present violence. **********Eelamuasu, the only remaining newspaper in Jaffna after Indians destroyed printing presses and communications equipment last week, reported 125 civilian bodies claimed after one encounter last Tuesday. The paper is sympathetic to the Tigers. **********There were persistent rumors today that the leader of the Liberation Tigers, Velupillai Prabakaran, was hiding among 25,000 to 40,000 Jaffna residents who are said to be crowded into the historic Nallur temple. **********Tamils in Colombo, have heard that Mr. Prabakaran, still a hero to many, has sent a message to the Indians warning that if they come for him, thousands of Tamil civilians around him would die. **********There were also reports today that the Tigers had made another appeal for a cease-fire, but that the Indians had not found their terms acceptable. **********In Batticaloa, reports are emerging daily about Indian revenge attacks on the Tamil village of Saturagunda after an Indian Army convoy hit a land mine, killing 20 to 25 troops. **********Residents who helped the victims of the retaliatory attacks said that on the morning of Oct. 15, Indian troops burned or ransacked more than 120 homes. Nine people were hospitalized, they said.  Gandhi Says Troops Will Stay **********Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said yesterday in New York that India would keep soldiers in Sri Lanka as long as the Sri Lankan Government continues to allow them. **********''The Indian forces are there strictly at the invitation of the President of Sri Lanka. and they will only be there as long as they are welcome,'' Mr. Gandhi said at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. **********He called on the rebels to ''come out and surrender arms and go along with the peace process.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/28/world.body_text: **********Egypt closed offices of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Cairo and Alexandria today in an angry reaction to harsh criticism from the P.L.O.'s legislative body, which concluded its session here Sunday. **********The move surprised P.L.O. leaders here, who had held the session of the Palestine National Council to reconcile rivalries among the Palestinian guerrilla factions. The Palestinian leaders immediately accused the Reagan Administration and Israel of having put pressure on Egypt to take the action. **********But the Egyptian Foreign Minister, Esmat Abdel-Meguid, after meeting with President Hosni Mubarak, announced that Cairo was acting ''to put an end to this insolence'' by its P.L.O. critics. **********In a statement issued today in Cairo, the Foreign Minister said that ''all P.L.O. offices except those that deal with labor and women's affairs'' would be shut down, ''because of the aggressive attitude of the Palestine National Council.'' A Symbolic Break **********The P.L.O. offices that were closed include a diplomatic mission in Cairo and smaller bureaus that serve Palestinians living, working and studying in Egypt. Although the P.L.O. presence is modest, the move could be a setback for the organization because it carries the symbolism of breaking relations and interrupts the support that President Mubarak has extended to the troubled guerrilla movement for the last four years. **********Egypt, even since signing its peace treaty with Israel, has consistently argued the case for a Palestinian homeland and has supported the P.L.O.'s claim to be the sole representative of the Palestinian people. **********Mr. Abdel-Meguid said today that despite the decision to shut down the P.L.O. presence, Egypt would not stop supporting the Palestinian cause in the peace process. **********The P.L.O. and most Arab countries severed ties with Egypt after it signed the treaty with Israel in 1979. But Egyptian links with the organization were restored after Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. leader, visited President Mubarak in 1983. **********Egypt becomes the second country sympathetic to the Palestinians to retaliate against the P.L.O in less than a year. Last July, Jordan closed the P.L.O. offices there and expelled the senior P.L.O. official, Khalil al-Wazir, who is also known as Abu Jihad, because of P.L.O. criticism of King Hussein. Anti-Egyptian Remarks **********At its final session Saturday night, the Palestine National Council passed a resolution demanding that Egypt renounce the Camp David accords that became the framework of peace between Egypt and Israel. **********The debate included anti-Egyptian remarks, particularly from extremist factions, that prompted a delegation of Egyptian observers to walk out Friday. It was left to the P.L.O.'s Executive Committee to work out the details of future relations with Egypt, a compromise that appeased the more moderate factions led by Mr. Arafat. **********Militant groups attending the conference had made condemnation of Egypt a price of their participation at the unity meeting. **********''The P.L.O. refused to recognize Egypt's great sacrifices for the Palestinian people,'' the Egyptian statement said today. ''The P.L.O. leaders are men out to profit from intrigue and maneuvers. But our decision today won't end Egypt's support for Palestinians. Egypt will continue to support the struggle of the Palestinians.'' A Warning From Mubarak **********President Mubarak had sent an envoy to the meeting to warn that Egypt would react if the resolution were adopted. Mr. Mubarak later called home the Egyptian delegation that walked out. Today, Palestinian delegates and leaders expressed shock and surprise over Egypt's decision. **********''There's no doubt in my mind that pressure was put by the United States and Israel to do it, but it's an overreaction by him,'' said Salwa Abu Khadra, a P.L.O. delegate. ''I didn't expect it.'' **********At a news conference before word of the Egyptian reaction reached here, Nayef Hawatmeh, leader of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a hard-line Marxist guerrilla faction, not only attacked the United States and Israel, but also blamed Jordan and Morocco. He had helped lead the fight for a strong resolution against Egypt. **********Mr. Arafat apparently left town for an undisclosed location, refusing to comment. His spokesmen said Al Fatah, his wing of the P.L.O., would have no comment.
