https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/15/world.main_headline: AS TRUCE BEGINS, AFGHAN CAPITAL SHOWS ITS VISITORS A RELAXED FACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/15/world.print_headline: AS TRUCE BEGINS, AFGHAN CAPITAL SHOWS ITS VISITORS A RELAXED FACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/15/world.body_text: **********For a city surrounded by a war, this arid capital tucked amid the snow-covered Hindu Kush mountains seemed strangely placid today as Government forces prepared to begin a unilateral cease-fire. **********Aside from a teen-age boy holding a bottle of Russian vodka outside a downtown cafe, there were few signs of the Soviet presence that has shaped much of Afghan life since 1979, and few reminders of the fighting against insurgent forces. **********One of those reminders came this evening when the Afghan leader, Najib, appeared on Afghan television to ap=peal for support for a cease-fire beginning Thursday, warning the guerrillas that it would be a final chance for reconcilation. Curfew to Be Shortened **********Speaking his native Pushto, he said: ''Brothers, fathers, please support us. The destiny of the fatherland is in your hands.'' **********He also said that the curfew in Kabul, now from 10 P.M. to 4 A.M., would be shortened by two hours. **********As a full moon rose above the towering mountains and a dusty twilight enveloped the city, thousands of citizens dressed in a dizzying mixture of Western and Moslem garb filled the bazaars. Merchants weighed plump tangerines and mounds of nuts and dried fruits by the light of small kerosene lamps as dilapidated yellow and white taxis, honking loudly, prowled the streets looking for fares. Russians in the Mountains **********''The Russians left a few days ago and moved into the mountains,'' a television repairman said as he worked on a Soviet set. His shop was crowded with Japanese and Soviet models. **********One reason for the calm may have been the arrival of 40 Western reporters from Moscow who had been invited to Kabul as part of a Soviet and Afghan effort to generate favorable publicity for the cease-fire and a peace plan recently outlined by Mr. Najib. **********With encouragement from Moscow, Mr. Najib, who uses only one name, called for the formation of a coalition government, declared a general amnesty, supported religious freedom and, in general, advocated an end to the Afghan conflict. **********The rebels, who receive Western aid, have rejected the Najib proposals as insufficient and several of the groups have said they will not honor the ceasefire. Obstacles to a Settlement **********Moscow has said it will consider withdrawing some of the 120,000 troops it has in Afghanistan if tensions in the country subside and if the West ends its support for the insurgent forces, most of which are based in Pakistan. **********Western diplomats have said a number of major obstacles remain in the way of a political settlement, including the timetable for a Soviet withdrawal and longstanding animosities between Afghan tribes. **********The visit by Western reporters seemed to mark a change in both Soviet and Afghan attitudes toward the war and its effect on public opinion in the West and in Moslem countries, where the Soviet role has been criticized. **********''The main part of your program is devoted to getting you acquainted with the process of reconciliation,'' an Afghan official told the reporters. **********Copies of The Kabul New Times, an English-language paper, were packed with articles about Mr. Najib's proposals. Caviar for Breakfast **********Afghan officials said the visit, which is expected to last until Monday, would include a meeting with Mr. Najib, a talk with Afghan military commanders, a tour of several provincial areas and a chance to watch the Afghan Communist Party and affiliated groups in action at a congress. **********At the Kabul Intercontinental Hotel, the staff was bedecked in native Afghan clothing and signs in the lobby advertised tennis, swimming and saunas. Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, provided first-class service on the flight from Moscow, including caviar for breakfast. **********Several news organizations that had long been denied permission to visit Afghanistan, including The New York Times and The Washington Post, were given visas. **********Restrictions on the movement of the reporters appeared to be less severe than they were during prevous group visits by Western reporters based in Moscow, several returning journalists said. Soviet Has a Hand in Trips **********Western reporters were denied visas to enter Afghanistan from the early 1980's until early last year, Most reporting on the fighting came from correspondents who crossed the border surreptitiously from Pakistan and traveled with guerrillas. **********In 1986, Afghan officials authorized at least three foreign press trips from Moscow to Kabul, including one in October for 90 journalists. In addition, Moscow-based correspondents for The Los Angeles Times, The Baltimore Sun and some European news organizations were given visas to visit Afghanistan individually. **********Althought the tours are ostensibly at the invitation of the Afghan Government, all have been arranged in Moscow with the involvement of the Soviet Foreign Ministry. **********Western reporters invited to Kabul in October to observe the withdrawal of six Soviet regiments, or about 7,000 men, were not permitted to leave their hotel without an escort and were shown only carefully scripted events. **********Today, reporters were free to move about the city on their own, although Afghan escorts accompanied them in some cases. **********A helicopter greeted the arriving journalists over Kabul, lobbing red flares into the sky, apparently to confuse antiaircraft missiles that might be fired at the Soviet passenger jet as it descended steeply in a corkscrew approach pattern, also designed to defeat antiaircraft fire. There appeared to be none. **********Last year the Reagan Administration provided the rebels with Stinger missiles, which they have used to down a number of Soviet helicopters and planes, according to Afghan officials. **********The Kabul airport, which doubles as a major Soviet and Afghan air base, was swarming with cargo planes and Soviet attack helicopters, bristling with guns, that bore Afghan Army markings. Soldiers Along the Route **********But beyond the perimeter of the airport there was little sign of Soviet military activity. Afghan officials said Soviet and Afghan forces had returned to garrisons around the country in preparation for the cease-fire. **********Kabul residents said Soviet forces are usually more visible in Kabul, although they generally limit their presence, apparently in an attempt to reduce tensions with Afghan citizens. **********Afghan soldiers were posted along the route taken by the reporters' motorcade, and other Afghan militiamen stood guard outside government and diplomatic installations, including the United States Embassy and Radio Afghanistan. **********Children and adults, including women who hid their faces behind veils, stopped on the streets to stare at the the passing caravan of police cars and buses. **********In a juxtaposition of urban and country life that is not uncommon in the Middle East and Asia, farm animals wandered near the main roads. At one intersection a man raced down an alley in pursuit of a large black bull. **********Shops and markets were marked by Persian and English signs. A bar was identified in Cyrillic letters. **********Afghan officials said the population of Kabul, currently 1.3 million, had swelled since Soviet troops moved into Afghanistan in December 1979, but they were unable to say by how much.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/busin.main_headline: U.S. WILL STRESS FARM-AID ISSUES IN GLOBAL TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/busin.print_headline: U.S. WILL STRESS FARM-AID ISSUES IN GLOBAL TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/busin.body_text: **********Senior officials of the Reagan Administration say the cost of aiding farmers has become such a burden to so many countries that the United States wants to push the problem to the top of the list of international economic issues to be negotiated this year. **********''They've got to talk about agriculture,'' said W. Allen Wallis, Undersecretary of State for Economic Affairs and the head of the Administration team that is preparing for the seven-nation economic summit conference in June in Venice. **********''I'd say clearly that's the most important economic problem today -more important than trade, debt and so on,'' he said. ''Agriculture has more potential for all sorts of devastating consequences.'' A Sector in 'Absolute Chaos' **********M. Alan Woods, a Deputy United States Trade Representative, said: ''It's a sector of the world economy that is in absolute chaos. It has to be brought under control, and it's not something that one country can do alone.'' **********Such views are common in Europe as well. In a speech here earlier this month, Britain's Agriculture Minister, Michael Jopling, said ''there is a growing consensus about the need for urgent action'' on farm issues. **********Farming worldwide is plagued by overproduction and depressed prices, problems that, most countries agree, are largely the consequence of domestic economic policies. While the battles among the big industrial powers have been dominated again this year by conflicts over growth, currency values, trade, finances and loans to developing countries, agriculture has drawn increasing attention as it has become evident that farm policies to some extent underlie all these issues. **********Traditionally, farm policy has been a matter that countries kept off the table at multilateral negotiations. Successful negotiation presumably would require concessions in the payments, subsidies and restrictions on imports that nations grant their farmers. Elected governments have been unwilling to trade away programs so dear to their politically powerful farm constituencies. **********But in farming, as in many other economic areas, attitudes have been changing. For one thing, spending on agriculture has grown so huge that it is crowding aside the demands of other powerful interests. In the United States, aid to farmers is expected to total $27 billion in a year in which the Federal budget deficit is projected at $180 billion. With Congress and the Administration now committed to cutting the deficit, mostly through reductions in spending, agricultural costs emerge as a highly visible target. **********The problem is similar elsewhere: The 12-nation European Economic Community spent $23 billion on farm-support programs last year; Japan spent $15 billion. **********Pressure for change also arises as the traditionally parochial business of farming becomes caught in the spreading web of economic interdependence among nations. One country's farm-support policies affect world prices and the economies of other countries as surely as do changes in the values of currencies. Initiative From Reagan **********President Reagan put the subject on the international negotiating table last year at the economic summit conference in Tokyo. The other participants agreed with the President that agricultural policies in one country often affect other countries and that talks on the issue are needed. **********That consensus helped put agriculture among the topics that the world's trade ministers listed for negotiation in the round of trade talks that will begin next year. President Reagan now wants to use the summit conference that he will attend in June to broaden the debate and push the trade talks along. The June meeting will also be attended by the leaders of Japan, West Germany, France, Italy, Britain and Canada ''The odds for success increase when we get heads of government sending these kinds of instructions,'' said Daniel G. Amstutz, an Undersecretary of Agriculture. **********The President's commitment to the issue of agriculture makes it central even to those governments that might prefer a different emphasis. West Germany, for example, would give higher priority to dealing with the budget deficit in the United States, which the Germans see as the principal cause of the imbalances in the world economy. **********''But whatever is important to the United States is important to us,'' said Dietrich Von Kyau, economics minister at the West German Embassy here. He said of farm policy, ''If we don't take it into account, we could find ourselves in a trade war.'' Supply and Demand **********The source of the problem is supply and demand. Worldwide farm production has been rising about 5 percent a year, according to Robert L. Thompson, dean of agriculture at Purdue University. In the 1980's, Europe, India and China have become exporters of farm products. **********The surplus of the 1980's now mocks the accepted wisdom of the 1970's - that the world was headed toward critical shortages in food. ''We've got the problem of overproduction in a saturated world market,'' said Derwent Renshaw, an economist at the Washington offices of the European Community. **********With supplies of food outpacing demand, prices have dropped dramatically. The richer countries help their farmers maintain incomes through direct governmental payments, subsidies and restraints on imports. That support has encouraged farmers to produce even more. **********By subsidizing their own production, the richer countries undermine the ability of poorer countries, where production costs are often lower, to sell their goods in the world market. This deprives them of revenues they need to develop their economies and make payments on their loans from developed countries. **********''The basic problem in world agriculture is that the rich nations provide too many incentives for production, thereby creating oversupply and depressed prices,'' Mr. Amstutz, the Agriculture undersecretary, said. Cooperative Effort Favored **********It is generally conceded that the least painful way for nations to reduce their spending for farmers would be to coordinate reductions in aid so that no one country gains at another's expense. But disagreements arise over the precise approach. **********Mr. Woods said some European countries favor a policy that would, in effect, create cartels to insure all countries a piece of world agricultural markets. Others, notably Canada and Australia, want agreement on rapid and concerted reductions by all countries of the subsidies they pay to promote exports. **********The Reagan Administration sees the first approach as a violation of its free-market economic philosophy, but it views the second method as a partial step toward its own goal -comprehensive, step-by-step removal of barriers to trade. **********To encourage others to adopt the American approach, the Administration promises to be flexible about the pace at which farm supports are phased out. ''But we want dates certain for each step of the phase-outs,'' Mr. Amstutz said. Other countries, he said, could thwart the process by resisting such deadlines.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/18/world.main_headline: Reagan Confidant Urged Pardons in Iran Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/18/world.print_headline: Reagan Confidant Urged Pardons in Iran Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/18/world.body_text: **********William P. Clark, the former national security adviser, said today that he wrote President Reagan at the end of the Iran-contra hearings in August asking him to grant pardons to Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. **********He said he urged that the pardons be granted before the independent counsel in the Iran-contra affair concluded his investigation into the secret sales of weapons to Iran and the diversion to profits to the Nicaraguan rebels. **********Mr. Clark, a longtime confidant of the President's, said he would not discuss Mr. Reagan's response, asserting that ''in 22 years, I have never discussed a Presidential communication.'' **********Mr. Clark who was national security adviser from 1982 to 1983, confirmed sections of the letter that were quoted in Wednesday's edition of The Washington Post. But he declined to elaborate. 'In the National Interest' **********''I think the letter stands for itself,'' he said in a telephone interview from his home in central California, where he is now practicing law. ''Beyond that, I feel it's clearly in the national interest that this matter be concluded, that it not go on.'' **********In the letter, Mr. Clark said that Admiral Poindexter and Colonel Northhad undertaken their roles in the affair ''at considerable professional risk'' and ''without consideration for personal gain.'' Admiral Poindexter resigned as national security adviser and Colonel North was dismissed from the National Security Council staff last November. **********The letter asserted that a pardon ''is not necessarily a recognition that any criminal conduct has occurred.'' **********Such an action, it added, ''would simply be an expression of your conclusion that the story has been told, that the people involved have suffered enough, and that neither they, the office of the President, nor the country should be forced to endure an extended criminal trial in which the central issue related to the creation and implementation of your foreign policy.'' **********In addition to the response from Mr. Reagan, Mr. Clark said, Arthur B. Culvahouse Jr., the White House counsel, sent a reply dated Aug. 21 that said in part, ''This is not the time for us to engage in a discussion of pardons.'' **********Colonel North and Admiral Poindexter have been identified as targets of the investigation by Lawrence E. Walsh, the independent counsel in the Iran-contra affair. Mr. Walsh is now presenting evidence to a Federal grand jury. Questions for Reagan **********Mr. Reagan is preparing written answers to questions from Mr. Walsh, the White House said today. **********The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the questions were received Oct. 10 and the President would respond in the next few weeks. He would say little else about the questions. **********Mr. Fitzwater said the President ''was not a subject of investigation.'' There has been no indication that Mr. Walsh will bring any charges against the President.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/25/world.main_headline: Hess Is Buried Secretly by Family; Son Is Reported to Suffer Stroke
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/25/world.print_headline: Hess Is Buried Secretly by Family; Son Is Reported to Suffer Stroke
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/25/world.body_text: **********The family of Rudolf Hess announced today that Hitler's onetime deputy had already been buried in secret, apparently out of fear of neo-Nazi demonstrations and clashes with the police. The family would not disclose when or where the burial had taken place. **********It was also announced that Hess's son, Wolf-Rudiger Hess, 49 years old, suffered a stroke Sunday evening and was taken to a Munich hospital. The younger Mr. Hess has challenged official versions of his father's death that pointed to suicide. **********In West Berlin, British authorities issued a statement today giving more details of Hess's death a week ago, adding that he had hanged himself with an electric cord. Previous statements by the four wartime Allies had said only that Hess was found with the chord around his neck at Spandau Prison, where he had been the only inmate since 1966. Family Orders Own Autopsy **********''All available evidence - including results of a full autopsy and investigations by the special investigation branch of the Royal Military Police -indicates that Hess used an electrical extension cord to hang himself and that the cause of death was asphyxiation,'' the British statement said. **********Wolf-Rudiger Hess and Rudolf Hess's lawyer, Alfred Seidl, have questioned the Allied version and ordered their own autopsy, which was performed last Friday. The results have not been announced yet. **********Hess's funeral was originally scheduled to be held this Wednesday in the Bavarian town of Wunsiedel, where Hess's parents, who had had a summer house there, are buried. The mayor, Karl Walter, had scheduled a news conference for today to announce details of the funeral. **********But once the venue was announced last week and Wolf-Rudiger Hess questioned the Allied version of the death, Nazi sympathizers from West Germany and other Western European countries - including thugs with close-cropped or shaved heads known as ''skinheads'' - began converging on Wunsiedel. So did the police. Tight Security on Roads **********By the weekend, several hundred police and border guards with dogs, riot gear, paddy wagons and helicopters had moved into Wunsiedel and had set up tight security on roads leading to the town, checking for weapons and known extremists. The measures underscored the determination of West German authorities to prevent any manifestation of neo-Nazism, a fringe movement whose antics invariably attract foreign attention and troubling publicity. **********Officials said about 200 neo-Nazis had arrived in the Wunsiedel area by Monday and more than 80 had been detained, most only briefly. **********The prospect of more publicity and confrontations was evidently too much for the Hess family. **********At an afternoon news conference, Mayor Walter announced that the family had already buried Hess. ''He has been buried quietly,'' Mr. Walter read from a statement. ''In view of the developments here - over which the family has no influence - we felt bound to fulfill the wish of Rudolf Hess in the spirit of his will.'' **********''I am surprised, but I am not unhappy,'' added the Mayor, who had expressed growing concern over what was happening to his village. Mr. Walter said the family would not disclose when or where the burial had taken place and no one outside the family could confirm the burial. **********The secret burial was apparently a surprise also for Mr. Seidl, the attorney who had defended Hess at the Nuremberg trials, who said he knew nothing of it when he addressed a press conference this morning in Munich.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/11/busin.body_text: **********Divining the Dow **********As the Dow Jones industrial average passes the 2,000 mark, Laszlo Birinyi Jr. is making the rather precise prediction that it will hit at least 2,073.06 before heading down. Actually, Mr. Birinyi, a vice president and equity market analyst at Salomon Brothers, has been forecasting this figure for the Dow since last spring. **********When the index hits this magic number, he says, it will have grown 90.79 percent since the market rally began in July, 1984 - the same as during the record market rally in the mid-1950's. ''We think we can equal the greatest rally of the post-war period,'' said Mr. Birinyi. **********Will the Dow dip once this record is matched? That depends on how it gets there, he says. ''If it sprints there, it may need to stop and rest. On the other hand, if we have a slow steady gain, as we did through most of 1986, we may not use up a lot of our reserves - and then we could go higher.'' Deeper in Debt **********Consumers are already carrying a record amount of household debt. And they are expected to take on more debt this year, in what Bruce Steinberg, senior economist at Merrill Lynch, calls ''the biggest borrowing binge in history.'' Mr. Steinberg estimates that household debt could grow 9 percent this year from the estimated record $2.61 trillion level reached at year-end 1986. **********The binge will continue, he says, because consumers are confident about the future. They expect the economy to grow, inflation to remain low, interest rates to fall and unemployment to hold steady. **********Though Merrill Lynch expects the 1987 economy to be sluggish, with low income growth, consumer optimism may prove unshakable, Mr. Steinberg says. Those with financial assets, such as stocks and bonds, have done so well that they may feel wealthy enough to go on spending, though at a slower rate. And after a weak first quarter, there will not be enough economic negatives to dissuade consumers from spending or borrowing. In fact, borrowing may become more attractive as rates continue to fall, a trend perhaps assisted by a cut in the discount rate by March. Plastic Falls to Pieces **********Discarded plastic makes up much of the litter that clutters the ground and clogs the streams of America. That's because plastic is non-biodegradable. But now, some new technologies and products offer some promising solutions to the problem. **********One Canadian company is manufacturing a shopping bag made from a plastic film that breaks into tiny pieces when it is exposed to ultraviolet light. A spokesman for the company, which is already selling the bags in Italy, points out that ''one characteristic of litter is that it is exposed to sunlight.'' **********Farmers here at home, meanwhile, may soon have an alternative to the plastic material they use to control weeds, warm soil and retain ground moisture. Chemists at the Agriculture Department's research center in Peoria, Ill., have produced a plastic-and-starch substance that performs the same tasks and can also be broken down by microorganisms. As it crumbles, it can be absorbed into the ground. **********And American consumers will get some new alternatives in packaging. A technology used to manufacture dissolving plastic laundry bags for hospitals is now being applied to some consumer goods: A major consumer-products company is test-marketing a detergent enclosed in a dissolving plastic packet. The packet is not biodegradable, but it is water-soluble. Forsaking Sake **********Sake, the alcoholic beverage made from rice, is losing popularity in Japan. Annual sake sales have dropped to 149 million cases from more than 196 million in 1975. ''I suspect the trend will continue,'' said Frank Walters, research director at M. Shanken Communications, which tracks spirits consumption. **********One reason for sake's decline is the rise of shochu, a distilled spirit similar to vodka and made from barley, corn or buckwheat. Shochu is cheaper, and, though proof percentages vary, generally less alcoholic than sake. ''Sales have exploded,'' said Mr. Walters. Annual sales rose to more than 70 million cases in 1985, up from 21.8 million cases 10 years earlier. **********The sake business, meanwhile, will not get much help from the American market. Sake consumption was off by 15 percent in the United States last year, after a couple of years of healthy increases. ''People here are drinking lighter,'' said Mr. Walters.
