https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/16/busin.body_text: **********Bass P.L.C., a big British brewing concern, said it is buying interests in 178 Holiday Inn hotels from the Holiday Corporation. The $475 million deal would allow Bass to run all the Holiday Inns outside the United States, Canada and Mexico. **********Bass said it is acquiring five wholly owned hotels outside the United States, as well as 13 hotels in Florida, Tennessee and South Carolina. Bass is also acquiring Holiday's interests in 160 other hotels, including 25 under construction, all outside the United States. **********Holiday said it would use the sale proceeds to reduce debt and develop its North American properties. **********Bass said the deal would allow it ''to join the select band of major international hotel companies and enjoy a brand name with worldwide recognition.'' Bass already owns 120 hotels in Britain and continental Europe. Its new deal includes 59 hotels in Europe, 11 in the Middle East, 25 in Africa, 30 in the Far East and Australia and 15 in the Caribbean and Latin America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/14/world.main_headline: Networks May Rotate Their Daily Coverage
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/14/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS; Networks May Rotate Their Daily Coverage
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/14/world.body_text: **********The three network news divisions, faced with intensifying interest in the Iran-contra hearings on the one hand and the loss of millions of dollars in advertising revenues on the other, are planning to cover the remaining weeks of the hearings on a rotating basis, according to several network executives. The alternating coverage could go into effect this week. **********''On this one, it seems to me that it makes sense at some point that we have to be concerned about the overall health and stability of the various companies in the industry,'' said David W. Burke, executive vice president of ABC News. ''And we can serve the public just as well.'' **********By last night, both ABC and NBC had agreed to the plan, and CBS was reported to have agreed in principle. Howard Stringer, president of CBS News, was not available for comment. Coverage Has Been Popular **********The hearings have put the networks in an unusual position. Their gavel-to-gavel coverage of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's testimony has been popular with viewers - more popular, according to preliminary ratings, than their regularly scheduled soap operas and game shows. But the hearings have been carried without commercial interruptions, and that has cost each network between $600,000 (NBC) and $1 million (CBS) every day. **********Each of the networks planned full, uninterrupted coverage of Colonel North's testimony, but none had decided how to cover the witnesses who followed him. The popularity of the North appearance forced the issue. **********Lawrence K. Grossman, president of NBC News, recalled that the networks had collaborated on coverage of the Senate Watergate hearings in 1973, and he retrieved the agreements from that event and proposed that the networks come to a similar arrangement for the current hearings, according to network sources. **********But the collaboration is a delicate matter, not only because the three network news divisions are accustomed to fierce competition, rather than cooperation, but because they are subject to Federal antitrust constraints on such matters. The alternating coverage of Watergate had to be approved by the Department of Justice, and the current proposal has similarly been reviewed by the Justice Department, according to network executives. Cost-Control Measures **********The shift in the fortunes of the three networks has also changed the picture since the Watergate hearings. All three networks are under new ownership and face strict cost-control measures, underscoring the pressure to renew revenue-generating daytime programming. On the other hand, as the network news executives discussed the proposal to alternate coverage, some of them expressed concern that their new owners might see the plan as a means of saving costs on other continuing news stories, such as political conventions. **********But the Federal rules regarding competition between the broadcasters would probably prevent cooperation between the networks except in rare cases, according to network officials. **********If the plan goes into effect, each network would be obliged to carry the hearings either one or two days a week, with the option of providing coverage even on days when another network is the designated carrier. ''That way, one network each day has an obligation or commitment to broadcast, and the others have the opportunity to broadcast,'' Mr. Grossman said. ''The benefit is that the public would be assured of getting it at least from one source at all times, and then we could go in when we thought it was warranted.'' Networks Losing Money **********The benefit to the networks would be three or four days of revenue-earning programming, worth from $2 million to $4 million. CBS, which has the highest-rated regular daytime schedule of programs, has been losing an estimated $1 million each day on its Iran-contra coverage, ABC has been losing about $800,000 a day, and NBC has been losing an estimated $600,000. **********When the North testimony concludes, ''there may be witnesses that no network feels appropriate to have on, because they're technical witnesses,'' Mr. Grossman said. ''It seems crazy for everyone to be there.'' **********The committee hearings are expected to continue until Aug. 7, and among the witnesses expected to appear are George P. Shultz, the Secretary of State; Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Defense, and the Attorney General, Edwin Meese 3d.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/24/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS; Dollar Firm; 7-Nation Plan Is Doubted
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/24/busin.body_text: **********The dollar firmed slightly yesterday in very light trading, as dealers shrugged off the latest affirmation by the United States and its trading partners that they would seek to check a further decline in its value. **********Prices of precious metals fell, reversing Tuesday's rally. Gold was down $1.25 an ounce, to $483.35, in late trading at the Republic National Bank in New York. **********In other markets, stock prices advanced broadly and the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 2,000 for the first time since Nov. 2. Bond prices also rose, and the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond slipped below 9 percent.  [ Pages D4 and D10. ]  Because so many banks and corporations have closed their books for the year and are no longer trading, reaction to the statement by the Group of Seven was muted. But those still in the market were not impressed with what the joint communique had to say. The Group of Seven is made up of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy. **********''I don't think there is a consensus in the Group of Seven that there is a floor to the dollar,'' said Richard E. Witten, a vice president in the foreign exchange department at Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''I don't read in this a commitment to defend the dollar, and I don't think the market is taking this all that seriously.'' **********And Garrett Glass, a vice president in the foreign exchange department at the First National Bank of Chicago, said: ''What the G-7 has done is to renew their commitment to swim up Niagara Falls. It is impossible to stem the decline in the dollar, because the amount of intervention necessary to do that is just too big.'' **********The tendency to discount the importance of the new initiative, which was announced on Tuesday, appeared to be buttressed by comments yesterday by Beryl W. Sprinkel, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. **********Mr. Sprinkel told reporters the statement did not explicitly include a commitment to support the dollar at current levels. **********''That statement pretty much undermined the whole thing,'' said James Hohorts, a managing director in the foreign exchange department at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. **********In its statement, the Group of Seven said, ''A further decline of the dollar, or a rise in the dollar to an extent that becomes destabilizing to the adjustment process, could be counterproductive by damaging growth prospects in the world economy.'' Below 126 Yen Earlier **********The dollar's rally yesterday was largely confined to Asian and European markets. After the communique was issued, the currency, which had earlier slipped below 126 Japanese yen, firmed. **********The dollar also did better in Europe, but traders said comments by Nigel Lawson, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, and West Germany's Finance Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, were more instrumental in creating enthusiasm for the dollar than was the Group of Seven communique. In separate remarks, the officials said the dollar was, at present, undervalued. **********By late yesterday in New York, the dollar was bid at 126.60 yen, up only marginally from Tuesday's late bid of 126.40 yen. The currency did somewhat better against the West German mark, rising to a late New York bid of 1.6330 marks, from 1.6275 Tuesday. **********Dealers said they were particularly disappointed in Tuesday night's communique because it contained no new policy commitments. **********Scott E. Pardee, a vice chairman at Yamaichi International (America) Inc., said he welcomed the Group of Seven's statement. But like his colleagues, he added that he saw little chance that it would prompt a rally in the dollar. **********Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.6335 West German marks, up from 1.6275; 1.3285 Swiss francs, up from 1.3220; 5.5275 French francs, up from 5.5060; 1,202.00 Italian lire, up from 1,197.50, and 1.30695 Canadian dollars, up from 1.30595. **********Gold closed in London at $482 bid an ounce, down from $482.40 late Tuesday. In Zurich it closed at $483, down from $483.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $485.33, up from $482.60.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/world.main_headline: SYRIANS ON PATROL IN EFFORT TO KEEP WEST BEIRUT PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/world.print_headline: SYRIANS ON PATROL IN EFFORT TO KEEP WEST BEIRUT PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/world.body_text: **********Syrian troops went into action today within 24 hours of their arrival in Beirut, trading gunfire with militiamen and setting up checkpoints in an attempt to stop the fighting here. **********Although the Syrians were welcomed as ''peacekeepers'' by some Beirut residents, it was not clear that they could end the fighting in Beirut's streets, as the Americans and the Israelis had failed to do in recent years. **********In the Ain Mirayseh neighborhood, where Shiite Moslem and Druse militiamen have shared influence, Syrian soldiers used rocket-propelled grenades and heavy machine guns to subdue gunmen who refused to surrender. Local radio stations said the gunmen involved were Druse. Four Lebanese Killed **********The report said four Lebanese were killed and two Syrian soldiers were wounded in the clash. The Syrians called in backup units to deal with the situation. There was no immediate report on the direct cause of the shootout. **********In Hamra, where the fighting had virtually destroyed the Commodore Hotel, Syrian soldiers rounded up 60 gunmen, packed them into three trucks and took them away for questioning. **********Syrian reinforcements arrived today, raising the Syrian strength in Beirut and the southern suburbs to 7,000, according to the police. The troops were requested by Lebanese leaders to help enforce a Syrian-brokered cease-fire in the latest round of factional fighting in West Beirut, which began Feb. 15. The police have said 300 people were killed and 1,300 wounded since then. Reports of 100 Kidnappings **********The gunmen had slipped out of sight Sunday night shortly after Syrian Army units began to deploy. But despite warnings from the chief of Syrian military intelligence, Brig. Gen. Ghazi Kanaan, that gunmen would be shot on sight, some reappeared today, wearing civilian clothes instead of their uniforms and trying to conceal their weapons. **********A rash of kidnappings involving armed men was reported. Local radio stations said that as many as 100 people were abducted, but a police source said the number was exaggerated. **********General Kanaan said the abductions were undertaken by lawless elements trying to take advantage of what he called ''security loopholes'' that he promised to close. **********Some banks, offices and shops opened during the day after General Kanaan promised business as usual today. Fear of abduction, however, sent people hurrying home after stocking up on provisions. **********Over the weekend the Syrians, who have kept 25,000 troops in northern and eastern Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate, sent to the Lebanese capital troops equipped with tanks, artillery, rocket launchers, rocket-propelled grenades and AK-47 assault rifles. **********The Lebanese call for help came from Moslem leaders like Prime Minister Rashid Karami, a Sunni; the Speaker of Lebanon's Parliament, Hussein al-Husseini, a Shiite; and the two major militia leaders, the Druse leader Walid Jumblat and the Shiite Amal leader Nabih Berri. **********While the bulk of the Syrian force remained in makeshift barracks in and around the closed Beirut International Airport, vehicles loaded with soldiers patrolled the streets which until yesterday were the scene of large-scale gun battles between Amal, the mainstream Shiite group, and a coalition of leftist fighters led by the Progressive Socialist Party, a mainly Druse group under Mr. Jumblat. **********Mr. Karami announced the establishment today of a seven-man command of Lebanese Army and police officers to coordinate operations with the Syrian task force. **********Headed by the chief of police, Gen. Osman Osman, the command includes Sunni, Shiite and Druse officers. **********Mr. Karami said the new security measures would cover all of West Beirut, including the Shiite-controlled southern suburbs and the Moslem side of the Green Line that separates this part of the city from its Christian-dominated eastern part. Militia Remains on 'Green Line' **********At present, militiamen still control the West Beirut side of the demarcation line, facing Christian contingents of the Lebanese Army and Christian militiamen. **********It was Mr. Karami and other Moslem members of his Cabinet who had requested that Syria rush troops to West Beirut to check the clashes. **********The request was strongly opposed by President Amin Gemayel and other christian leaders, who said Syrian intervention was unconstitutional. **********General Kanaan said there would be more joint Syrian-Lebanese military patrols Tuesday. Police sources here said that all foreign embassies in West Beirut would be given Syrian and Lebanese guards. **********Almost all the Western embassies have been removed from West Beirut after constant abduction of western nationals during the past two years. The embassies remaining mostly belong to the Soviet bloc. **********After four officials of the Soviet Embassy were abducted and one murdered a year ago, the embassy has been guarded by tanks provided by the Progressive Socialist militia, under the Druse leader, Walid Jumblat. Shiite Stronghold Intact **********How soon Syrian troops will fan out in the southern suburbs is not known. The area is a stronghold for the pro-Iranian the Party of God. **********Unlike other groups in West Beirut which put up signs welcoming the Syrians, the Party of God has kept silent. The group is often linked to Shiite extremists holding 28 foreigners, including 8 Americans, hostage. But the Party of God has repeatedly denied it was involved in hostage taking. **********Arab diplomats here said Syrian officers in West Beirut have instructions to search for and rescue the missing Church of England envoy, Terry Waite. **********Mr. Waite, who was involved in efforts to secure freedom for kidnapped foreigners, vanished in West Beirut Jan. 20 after he went to meet with members of the Islamic Holy War organization, which is believed to be holding at least two Americans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/25/busin.body_text: **********International **********West Germany, France and the Netherlands cut interest rates in a show of international cooperation intended to spur economic growth. The reductions follow intense American pressures on Germany's Bundesbank. The action in Europe was interpreted as a sign of approval for Washington's budget-deficit plan. [ Page A1. ] Ford will complete its divestment in South Africa by turning over a 24 percent equity interest in its former subsidiary to an employee trust. [ A10. ] Markets **********Stock prices moved higher after West Germany, France and the Netherlands announced reductions in interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 40.45 points, to 1,963.53. Some analysts were disappointed that the rally was not stronger.  [ D1. ]  Nasdaq said the number of shares sold short and not yet covered fell 9 percent in the month ended Nov. 13.  [ D19. ]  The New York Stock Exchange and the union representing 1,100 employees reached tentative agreement on a three-year contract. [ D15. ] The dollar slipped in active trading in the U.S. after a West German central banker reportedly said that the deficit-reduction plan reached Friday in Washington fell far short of American commitments to its trading partners.  [ D16. ]  Bond prices dropped, hurt by doubts that international interest rates would move much lower and worries about the stability of the dollar. [ D14. ] Precious metals futures closed lower after the end of a rally, which had resulted from forced short covering.  [ D16. ]  The Chicago Board of Trade will set daily price limits for its stock index futures contracts. [ D5. ] The Economy **********The economy expanded faster than had been thought in the months before the October stock-market collapse, while corporate profits surged, the Government reported. The G.N.P. advanced 4.1 percent in the third quarter, a figure revised from the 3.8 percent the Government had reported. [ D1. ] Tax writers face a tougher job than expected in putting together a $9 billion tax-cut package because Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, deleted a $2 billion item favored by House and Senate tax writers. [ D1. ] Sales of American-made cars and light trucks fell 2.1 percent in mid-November. Light-truck sales were up 19 percent, and car sales fell 12 percent. [ D1. ] Companies **********E. F. Hutton may dismember itself if potential buyers come forward with more attractive offers than it receives for the whole firm. And L. F. Rothschild may be considering a piecemeal sale of its operations. [ D1. ] Irving Bank will give all employees substantial benefits in case they are laid off after an unfriendly takeover. The plan is Irving's latest step to fend off a takeover by Bank of New York. [ D3. ] The Pritzkers and Pan Am officials are developing a plan that would allow the family to buy the airline, according to officials of Pan Am's unions. [ D3. ] First Chicago will buy Gary-Wheaton for $136.4 million in stock, in an attempt to build its base in consumer banking. [ D3. ] Technology **********To assemble space shuttle fuel tanks, Martin Marietta developed a 38-foot-tall automated riveter that cost $6 million. Now it is trying to determine what else, if anything, the riveter can do. [ D4. ] ''Machine tools for the mind'' is how one expert describes the new generation of software becoming available to mechanical design engineers. Advances. [ D4. ] Today's Columns **********Did the plunge in stocks put the economy into a black hole? Or was it the bursting of a speculative bubble that did not impair the business outlook? Hopes that the damage has not been ruinous rose yesterday. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Are junk bonds a better deal than ever? The author of a new study on the high-yield high-risk bonds answered with a resounding yes. Market Place. [ D6. ]

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/10/world.main_headline: A TRANSPLANT TRAUMA: IS SOUL-SEARCHING ENDING?
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/10/world.print_headline: TOKYO JOURNAL; A TRANSPLANT TRAUMA: IS SOUL-SEARCHING ENDING?
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/10/world.body_text: **********One sultry summer day in 1968, a teen-age boy drowned in waters off the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido. **********The boy was taken to a hospital in Sapporo where Dr. Juro Wada, a transplant specialist, examined him and pronounced him brain dead. Wasting no time, he removed the heart and implanted it into another teen-ager, who was dying from a congenital cardiac disease. The recipient lived with that heart for nearly three months. **********For his efforts, Dr. Wada was accused of murder. **********Another physician brought legal action, saying that Dr. Wada, of the Sapporo Medical College, had taken the heart while the donor was still alive. Although no formal criminal charges were filed, the case dragged on for six years before the Prosecutor's Office in Hokkaido dropped it completely. Transplants Are Shunned **********Two decades later that heart-transplant operation - the first and last ever performed in this country -continues to cast a long shadow over Japanese medicine and public attitudes about death. No Japanese physician has been willing since then to risk becoming another Juro Wada. **********Recently, however, interest in resuming heart-transplant surgery has revived, amid widening debate over when and how a doctor may declare a patient to be dead. **********Transplant advocates argue that it makes little sense for this medically sophisticated country to deny itself a procedure that is performed routinely in other industrial countries and that could prolong thousands of Japanese lives. **********But opponents, including physicians, warn that patients' rights might be abused by overzealous transplant specialists. This is a special concern in Japan, where the notion of the patient as medical consumer is poorly developed and where attending physicians often act imperiously. **********Further complicating the issue, experts say, are traditional Japanese feelings about the heart as the repository of the soul and thus deserving primacy over the mind. **********In the measured, often elusive way in which Japanese form a consensus on delicate issues, the pro-transplant side gained ground a few weeks ago when a medical group, the Japan Society for Transplantation, recommended that the procedure be approved in cases of brain death. Among conditions that the organization set were that the donor's family give permission and that someone other than the transplant surgeon determine that brain functions had ceased. **********The ethics committee of the Japan Medical Association is expected to announce its views soon, and supporters of heart transplants are looking for a strong favorable statement that may signal a go-ahead. **********According to Isamu Hashimoto, a Kyoto physician who heads the transplantation society, six or seven Japanese hospitals are ready to begin heart operations right away. Liver transplants, which Japanese physicians have also avoided out of post-Wada fear, would also start fairly soon, he said. Legal Definition of Death **********''The most important obstacle,'' Dr. Hashimoto said, ''is that doctors are divided. Some simply cannot accept the concept of brain death.'' **********Neither can many Japanese laymen, even though cessation of brain function is the legal definition of death in most American states and in many other countries. Death is not pronounced here until the heart stops, breathing ends and the patient's pupils become dilated. **********In a poll last year by the Prime Minister's Office, 46 percent of 10,000 people interviewed said they were against all organ transplants in brain-death cases. On this score, the resistance is so strong that another legal case similar to Dr. Wada's is under way. **********Physicians from a group called the Patients' Rights Conference brought murder charges two years ago against a surgical team from Tsukuba University, north of Tokyo, for taking the liver and pancreas from a brain-dead person and inserting them into another patient. **********In their legal action, which is pending, the rights-conference doctors accuse the Tsukuba team of first killing the donor and then causing fatal injury to the recipient, who survived for about a year. **********''I do not understand why some doctors are so eager to transplant any organ whatsoever,'' Dr. Katsunori Honda, a leader of the group, said. ''I would suggest to them that if they dare to transplant they should wait for the heart to stop beating.'' 'An Insult to the Dead' **********Many Japanese have a strong aversion to any mutilation of a body, regardless of the purpose. This a concept that is considered distinct from that of cremation, which is universally practiced here under Buddhist tradition. **********Shusaku Endo, a leading novelist, whose books include medical themes, said that ''taking out a part of the body is seen as an insult to the dead.'' **********''When my older brother died, the doctors wanted an autopsy,'' Mr. Endo said. ''But my sister-in-law refused, saying she didn't want him to feel any more pain. Logically, she knew he was dead. But her feelings were that those knives must be painful for him.'' **********One complication is the fact that, for all the fuss over the heart procedure, kidney transplants are performed routinely in Japan, about 500 times a year. These are mostly from living donors. Even so, according to Dr. Hashimoto, 105 kidneys were taken from brain-dead patients between 1980 and 1985, and for unexplained reasons there has been little public outcry other than in the Tsukuba case. The Final Arbiters **********It is clear on the issue of heart transplants that physicians themselves will be the final arbiters. A special parliamentary committee is studying the matter, but it is expected merely to ratify whatever the doctors decide. **********An important line was crossed 14 months ago when the Health and Welfare Ministry issued a report from a team of neurologists establishing criteria for brain death. They included deep coma, a flat brain wave, loss of spontaneous breathing functions and loss of brain stem reflexes. **********But the report also underlined how slowly change will come. **********The panel stopped well short of saying that brain death is death, and its leader, Dr. Kazuo Takeuchi of Kyorin University in Tokyo, says he could not imagine himself shutting off a patient's respirator. **********''All the doctors in our hospital, myself included, feel that we should wait for the heartbeat to stop,'' Dr. Takeuchi said at a recent symposium. ''There is no question about it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/busin.main_headline: 604 MILLION VOLUME NEARLY DOUBLES RECORD; More About the Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/busin.print_headline: STOCKS PLUNGE 508 POINTS, A DROP OF 22.6%; 604 MILLION VOLUME NEARLY DOUBLES RECORD; More About the Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/busin.body_text: **********Bonn and the United States agreed that the dollar should be stabilized near current levels. Disagreement on currency levels and interest rates had contributed to unrest in the markets. Page D1. **********Small investors searched for news much of the day. Many held on to their stocks, as they tried to determine what really was happening in the stock market. Page D1. **********Washington officials hesitated to offer investors immediate advice. The shouts of panic on Wall Street echoed only faintly in the corridors of the Reagan Administration. The White House maintained that the underlying economy remained sound. News analysis, page D32. **********Investors bought U.S. securities in a search for a safe place to put their money. Some interest rates hovered just below 10 percent. Page D1. **********Tokyo's stock market plummeted to record losses today and the Hong Kong market suspended trading for the week as Asian investors reacted in fright to the collapse on Wall Street. Page D1. **********Business leaders were shaken by the collapse, which wiped out huge amounts of the market value of their companies. And they seemed to have been caught by surprise. But many leaders were confident the panic would pass. Page D32. **********Trading tested computers' ability to handle a volume of trading that had not been expected until the early 1990's. Page D34. **********Wall Street firms are uncertain about the effect the historic drop could have on them, but some analysts fear that smaller and poorly capitalized firms may find rough going in the days ahead. Page D33. **********Mutual funds sold stock shares in huge numbers, feeding the historic drop. Several mutual fund management companies said the number of phone calls from investors was about double the normal volume. Page D33. **********New York City could be affected significantly because of its large number of securities industry employees. Some experts maintain that the city's economy has grown too reliant on Wall Street. Page D32. **********Overseas investors sold actively on Wall Street after years of having poured money into the bull market. Accounts of the volume of foreign selling varied widely. Page D14. **********The dollar closed lower against leading currencies except the Canadian dollar. Analysts said trading was quiet as traders were preoccupied by the jarring news from the stock market. Gold was $486.50 an ounce, up $15.50 from Friday to reach its highest level in over four years. Page D26. **********Democratic leaders called for talks with President Reagan on a deficit-reduction package that would include tax increases. Page D32. **********In politics, two questions loomed: How badly were the Republicans' 1988 chances hurt? How were the Democrats' prospects helped? Political Memo. Page A30.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/world.body_text: **********An arms dealer, free on bail while awaiting trial on charges related to illegal arms exports, has been jailed in New York for violating the terms of his bail, a prosecutor said Friday. **********The prosecutor said the defendant, Solomon Schwartz, 51 years old, had been plotting to sell military parts to Iran and had done unauthorized travel. **********He was ordered jailed until the start of his trial, set for Feb. 17, by Judge Thomas C. Platt of Federal District Court in Brooklyn. **********Mr. Schwartz, of Monsey, N.Y., was arrested Wednesday at La Guardia Airport as he left a plane from Houston, according to the United States Attorney's office in Brooklyn. Mr. Schwartz is an owner of Texas Armament Advisers of Brownsville, Tex. **********An affidavit by an Assistant United States Attorney in Brooklyn, David V. Kirby, said Mr. Schwartz was in Israel from Sept. 28 to Oct. 2. His bail requires that he stay in the New York area. **********Mr. Schwartz and three others are scheduled to stand trial next month on charges of plotting to ship military equipment to the Soviet Union, Poland, Iraq and Argentina. Only one deal, involving night-vision devices for Argentina during the Falkland war in 1982, was carried out, Mr. Kirby said. Mr. Schwartz had been free on bail since 1984, when the original charges were filed. All have pleaded not guilty. **********Mr. Kirby said that according to information obtained from the United States Customs Service, Mr. Schwartz had been involved since September in a plot to sell parts of F-4 fighter and C-130 cargo planes to Iran.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/world.main_headline: REGAN TESTIFIES REAGAN FELT IRAN 'SNOOKERED' HIM
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS; REGAN TESTIFIES REAGAN FELT IRAN 'SNOOKERED' HIM
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/world.body_text: **********Donald T. Regan, who was closer to President Reagan than anyone else who has testified before the Iran-contra committees, said today that the President felt he had been repeatedly ''snookered'' by Iranians into believing that continued arms sales would lead to the release of more American hostages. **********Mr. Regan, the President's chief of staff for two years until he was asked to resign last January after the Iran-contra disclosures, offered a colorful look inside a chaotic White House. **********Using terms from his days on Wall Street and occasional mild oaths, he contributed a good deal of flavor to key episodes and added new insights into President Reagan's thinking. Information Withheld **********He told the legislators that he was not privy to the details of the National Security Council's activities in Iran and Nicaragua, that important information was withheld from him and that he and the President were often misled by Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, then the national security adviser. **********The picture Mr. Regan painted of himself as often unaware of events swirling about him was in sharp contrast with the prevailing image of him as chief of staff - that he was a firm conductor of affairs in the White House who never missed a beat. **********Mr. Regan had been accused of not preparing President Reagan properly for a Nov. 19 news conference on the arms sales in which the President made serious misstatements. Today Mr. Regan blamed Admiral Poindexter, saying the reason for the errors was that the admiral had been ''oblique'' in presenting the facts, and ''this sort of confused the Presidential mind.''  [ Excerpts, page A8. ]  'Startled' by Testimony Mr. Regan also said he had been ''startled'' by Admiral Poindexter's testimony this month that he had personally authorized the use of proceeds from the Iran arms sales to help the contras in Nicaragua. Mr. Regan noted that the admiral had told him, the President and Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d last November that he had only general knowledge about the diversion. **********Asked what he had recommended to the President when no hostages were freed after arms shipments to Iran in February 1986, Mr. Regan said, ''I told him that we'd been snookered again, and how many times do we put up with this rug merchant type of stuff?'' **********What, he was asked, was the President's attitude? ''I think he shared my view that, you know, we'd been had,'' Mr. Regan said. In the final analysis, said Mr. Regan, who was chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company before joining the Government, the Reagan Administration was a victim of a ''bait and switch'' scheme by the Iranians. **********''Did you so advise the President?'' he was asked. ''Yeah,'' Mr. Regan replied. The ''driving force'' in the President's mind for continuing the arms sales, Mr. Regan insisted, was that the United States needed to gain influence in Iran and prevent the Soviet Union from getting a foothold. But he said the President would have stopped the operation at the outset had it not been for his concern about the hostages. 'Down This Garden Path' **********Mr. Regan conceded that he himself had blown hot and cold on the Iran policy, supporting it at times and opposing it at others. In ''20-20 hindsight,'' he said, this is why he thought the arms sales were permitted to continue: **********''A lot of this was plotting by arms dealers to involve the United States in massive arms transfers to Iran. They saw an opportunity here and wanted to keep it alive. I think at the same time, our own people had become so involved in trying to extricate the hostages, and not wanting to fail, that they didn't see they were being misled by these arms dealers. And as a result, they were led down this garden path.'' **********In contrast to Attorney General Meese, who testified this week that he could not remember many consequential developments, Mr. Regan described his ''vivid recollection'' of events last November after the Iran arms sales were disclosed. **********A questioner today noted, for example, that one of the main reasons President Reagan had instructed Mr. Meese last November to begin a fact-finding inquiry into the arms deals was to resolve the discrepancy in Administration officials' accounts of the nature of a 1985 shipment from Israel to Iran. **********Mr. Regan said he and the President knew the shipment contained Hawk antiaircraft missiles and not oil-drilling equipment, as some officials were saying. He said he had been told the true nature of the shipment at the time and had also been told that if it became public, the shipment would be described as oil-drilling equipment as a ''cover story.'' **********But Mr. Regan said Mr. Meese never asked what he or the President knew about the matter. Asked why they did not volunteer what they knew, Mr. Regan said with a half smile, ''We didn't know which facts were true facts.'' Reagan's Reaction Described **********Mr. Regan also recalled that when he and the President learned on Nov. 24 that arms profits had been diverted to the contras, President Reagan ''looked like a guy who was punched in the stomach.'' **********Later that day, he said, William J. Casey, then Director of Central Intelligence, called and asked for an urgent meeting. When Mr. Regan stopped by Mr. Casey's office on his way home that evening, he said, he told the director about the diversion. **********He said he could not tell whether Mr. Casey, a renowned poker face, was surprised or already knew about it. ''You didn't get much facial reaction from Bill Casey,'' he said. ''You wouldn't know exactly how he was taking this news.'' **********Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified that Mr. Casey not only knew about the diversion of funds but had encouraged it. No supporting evidence has been found. Mr. Casey became ill in December and died in May without having been questioned about the matter. A Conversation With Poindexter **********Mr. Regan also gave a vivid account of going into Admiral Poindexter's office on Nov. 25 and telling the admiral, who was having breakfast on a tray, to submit his resignation. **********''I said, 'What's going on, John? What the heck happened here?' '' he recalled. **********The national security adviser, who was then a vice admiral, ''was very careful and deliberate,'' he continued. ''John is a deliberate man. He adjusted his glasses, he dabbed at his mouth with his napkin, put it down. 'Well,' he said, 'I guess I should have looked into it more but I didn't. I knew that Ollie was up to something. But I didn't know what. I just didn't look into it.' **********''I said, 'Why not? What the hell. You're a vice admiral. What's going on?' '' **********The admiral, he said, responded rather lamely that he did not want to know what Colonel North was doing because he was upset by the way Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., then Speaker of the House, was ''jerking the contras around.'' **********Shortly afterward, according to the testimony, Admiral Poindexter went to the Oval Office and, in the presence of Mr. Regan, Vice President Bush and Mr. Meese, submitted his resignation to the President. **********Mr. Regan said the admiral told the President only that ''he was sorry for what had happened and that he probably should have looked into it more, but didn't.'' **********No one asked any questions, Mr. Regan said, and after an ''awkward silence'' the admiral left the room. **********Pressed today by Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, about why the Poindexter account had gone unchallenged, Mr. Regan said he ''never dreamed'' that the admiral might have been ''devious or anything except 100 percent truthful'' last fall. **********Mr. Regan is to continue his testimony Friday. Confusing Aspect of Testimony **********One confusing aspect of Mr. Regan's testimony today and that of Mr. Meese earlier in the week concerns the way Colonel North and Admiral Poindexter left the White House staff. **********President Reagan announced on television on Nov. 25 that Colonel North had been ''relieved of his duties on the National Security Council staff.'' But Admiral Poindexter was said to have ''asked to be relieved of his assignment.'' **********For months, news accounts invariably interpreted the President's words about Colonel North as a euphemism for ''discharged'' or ''dismissed'' or ''fired,'' and his words about Admiral Poindexter as having meant the admiral resigned. The White House has never corrected that impression. **********But both Mr. Regan and Mr. Meese said there was no intention to treat the two men differently. Both had been allowed to return to uniformed military service, Colonel North in the Marines and Admiral Poindexter in the Navy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/07/world.body_text: **********A policeman was killed and 20 people, including a general, were wounded in an attack by drug traffickers Thursday at an airport in the Peruvian jungle, police sources said today. The smugglers reportedly attacked as the police were boarding a helicopter at Tocache, in the cocaine-producing area of Huallaga, 280 miles northeast of Lima.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/18/busin.main_headline: Carbide Settlement On Bhopal Is Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/18/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Carbide Settlement On Bhopal Is Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/18/busin.body_text: **********Lawyers for the Indian Government and the Union Carbide Corporation were scheduled to appear at a court hearing in India today, amid wide speculation that they were close to an agreement on compensation to be paid the victims of the Bhopal disaster. **********A report by The Associated Press, attributed to unnamed sources at Carbide and in the Indian Government, said the chemical company had offered a settlement package totaling $500 million, with most of the money to be paid over 10 years to victims of the 1984 chemical leak, which caused 2,600 deaths and injured more than 200,000 people. **********But officials at Carbide's headquarters in Danbury, Conn., said late yesterday that a final agreement had not been reached. ''We are hopeful that a settlement will be reached, but we cannot predict when,'' Earl Slack, a Carbide spokesman, said. He added that negotiations were ''continuing'' last night, but ''we do not yet have a settlement agreement.'' Government Rejected Offer **********Analysts said Carbide would be able to pay $500 million in damages without jeopordizing the future of the company, particularly if the payments, as rumored, were to be spread over 10 years. Last year, Carbide offered to pay $350 million in damages to Bhopal victims, but that offer was rejected by the Indian Government. **********Activist groups in India, meanwhile, have called for far higher damages, contending that Carbide is taking advantage of the victims of the Bhopal accident, most of whom are poor, have little schooling and, they say, are not aware of the level of cash settlements reached in some American lawsuits. **********One group in India, the Bhopal Group for Information and Action, has suggested that the Indian Government should ask for more than $15 billion in damages from Carbide. 'Fair for All Sides' **********''A $500 million settlement, if that's what they have agreed to, would be fair for all sides concerned,'' said Leslie Ravitz, a vice president of Salomon Inc. He added that, by settling the Bhopal case out of court, Carbide 'would lift an enormous veil of uncertainty'' over its future. **********Mr. Slack, at Carbide, said the hearing today ''is not a settlement deadline,'' and that lawyers for either side could ask for more time to negotiate. **********According to the sources quoted by The Associated Press, Carbide and the Indian Government have reached agreement on a ''working document,'' which specifies that $346.2 million be paid to the Bhopal victims in monthly cash installments over 10 years. The largest amounts, $2,000 a year, or a total of $20,000, reportedly would go to the heirs of those killed. **********In addition, the report said, Carbide might pay more than $153 milliion, bringing the total settlement to more than $500 million. The added money might be eventually used to build a new hospital in Bhopal, if an agreement is reached.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/31/busin.body_text: **********A large New Zealand stockbroker has defaulted and ceased trading, according to an announcement today. It was the second significant failure in a week. **********One of New Zealand's oldest brokerage houses, Buttle & Company Sharebrokers Ltd., of Auckland, told the Auckland Stock Exchange that it was experiencing liquidity problems and might be unable to meet its obligations. **********On Dec. 24 another Auckland broker, Paine Belcher Ltd., defaulted and ceased trading because it was unable to meet its day-to-day liabilities. **********The Auckland exchange said in a statement that Buttle would not be permitted to trade until further capital was introduced.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/03/busin.body_text: **********The Chicago Board of Trade started night-time trading last week, partly to get more trans-Pacific business. With its added 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. schedule, the Board is the first financial market to cater explicitly to foreign clients by being open during hours convenient to them, says Richard L. Sandor, senior vice president at Drexel Burnham Lambert in Chicago. **********But it won't be the last, he predicts. Eventually, financial markets everywhere will go to 24-hour trading, Mr. Sandor says. The Board's trades are limited to Treasury bond and note futures and options on those contracts, ''but one can see this concept expanding into other financial instruments, as well as commodities like soy beans and precious metals,'' he said. **********For now, said Mr. Sandor, the Chicago Board's longer hours ''may reduce the volatility in the markets'' currently fueled by investor jitters about the dollar, inflation and interest rates. The new night-time hours, he says, give American investors additional time to react to events in Europe and Asia. More Pensions Stay Put **********Corporations eager to retrieve excess funds from their pension plans must first terminate those plans under current law. For years, an increasing number of companies have been doing just that - substituting other plans or purchasing annuities to meet their obligations to retirees. Distressed companies, meanwhile, have been able to terminate underfunded plans and pass on their obligations to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, which protects retirees benefit losses. But now, says Frank **********B. McArdle, of the Employee Benefit Research Institute in Washington, there may be fewer of these ''disruptive'' terminations. Last year, he says, the trend slowed, in part because of a new excise tax on the surpluses plucked from the plans. And if Congress passes a pension package proposed by the White House, terminations might decline even more. ''The thrust of the Administration's proposals has been to reduce the number of terminations,'' said Mr. McArdle. **********The proposed legislation does this in two ways: It permits companies to withdraw excess pension funds without terminating their plans. And it requires an underfunded plan scheduled for termination by a distressed company to be supplemented first by any overfunded plans the company sponsors. Homes: Going Once . . . The recent rise in mortgage rates may mean a wave of residential housing auctions this summer -especially in the Middle West - says Joel D. Zegart, president of JBS & Associates, Chicago auctioneers. **********The auctioneer's gavel is seldom heard during the peak spring and summer home-buying season, he says. But the jump in fixed-rate mortgages for new homes could change that pattern. The average rate was 10.37 last week, up from 9.07 a month ago, a time when new-home sales were already slumping. Sales were off 3.6 percent nationwide, 23.7 percent in the Middle West. **********''More sellers will want to dispose of property before interest rates go higher and buyers drop out of the market,'' said Mr. Zegart, who believes that auctions create an ''urgency'' that disposes of homes and condos more quickly than conventional selling methods. But auctions also involve a cost to the seller: New homes sold at auction usually wind up being discounted by at least 25 percent, Mr. Zegart says. Doing Business Abroad **********Just when the dollar may have weakened enough to make American goods attractive in foreign markets, businessmen working abroad might find there is less Government help available overseas. **********Because of State and Commerce Department budget reductions, ''there have been substantial cuts in foreign commercial service,'' said William Archey of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, which has 56 affiliate groups overseas. ''And there has been considerable grousing from our members.'' **********So far, says Mr. Archey, the closing of consulates in Bremen, Nice and Trieste should not affect American business, since many of these consulates do not have commercial offices. But planned closings elsewhere - in Goteborg, a big Swedish business center; in Turin, where Italy's Fiat is headquartered; and in Dusseldorf, West Germany's banking and industrial center - might.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/26/world.main_headline: PAKISTAN APPEALS TO INDIA ON CRISIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/26/world.print_headline: PAKISTAN APPEALS TO INDIA ON CRISIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/26/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Mohammad Khan Junejo called on India today to enter into immediate negotiations to defuse tensions rising from the massing of troops in each country on their mutual border. He declared that Pakistan had no aggressive intentions toward India. **********Speaking at a special session of Parliament summoned to discuss the crisis, Mr. Junejo repeated Pakistan's position that India was unwarranted in placing its armed forces at a high state of alert Friday night. He again denied that Pakistan had done anything to provoke the Indian action. **********The latest tension between the two countries, which have fought three wars since 1947, occurred as both held what they termed routine maneuvers near the border. Each charged that the other's maneuvers were provocative. **********Headlines here and in India have warned of possible war even as leaders of both countries say they have no intention of striking first. **********Pakistani officials said today that despite Mr. Junejo's appeal, no discussions to ease tensions had begun. **********''My Government is prepared to hold consultations at any appropriate level immediately so that normalcy and tranquillity are quickly restored,'' Mr. Junejo said today. ''Irresponsible action would be catastrophic for the entire region and would only bring unimaginable sufferings to its people.'' **********Mr. Junejo said India was being provocative and declared, ''Let nobody be in doubt that every inch of our soil would be defended resolutely.'' **********India began the recent round of recriminations over troop movements when it deployed an unusually large force near the Pakistan border last November. Pakistanis became alarmed despite Indian assurances that the maneuvers were routine. **********Apparently in response, Pakistan held its own maneuvers the next month and, according to India, kept its troops in forward positions longer than necessary. Pakistan denied the charge, but India responded Friday by putting its own troops on a high level of alert.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/04/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN FOOD BANKS; Balancing Blue Jeans and Pinstripes
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/04/busin.body_text: **********IF the first generation of food bankers in the mid to late 70's brought a personal commitment to feeding the hungry, the second generation has combined that commitment with a heavy overlay of professionalism. **********''I don't care how strong your social commitments are; if you don't have an entrepreneurial outlook and management skills, you won't make it in this business,'' said Philip Warth Jr., the president of Second Harvest, who holds a master's degree in city and regional planning. **********A candidate hoping to be hired as the director of a major food bank would not be required to have a graduate degree - but it certainly wouldn't hurt, said Matt Habash, executive director of the Mid-Ohio Food Bank. **********Mr. Habash, who has earned master's degrees in both business and public administration, says his background helps him communicate with senior executives in a language they understand. **********''This job requires things today it never required before,'' Mr. Habash said. He ticked off a few examples: a knowledge of computers, to set up an efficient distribution system; a grasp of accounting and tax law, to understand the problems that donor corporations face in terms of their budgets and their accountability to stockholders and the government; a working knowledge of nutrition, to make sure that a balanced supply of food is offered. **********On any given day, Mr. Habash may solicit donations from a board chairman, negotiate with a contractor building a larger warehouse for the food bank or advise the maintenance crew responsible for keeping up his fleet of trucks. His wardrobe reflects the dual nature of the job: on hand at all times are both a pair of jeans and a business suit. **********Three and a half years ago, Pamela Green, an M.B.A. and computer programmer who had worked as a lending officer for the First National Bank of Chicago's international division, accepted the mandate to get New York City's Food for Survival food bank up and running after others had failed to make the Bronx-based organization work for all five boroughs. **********When Ms. Green joined the bank in 1984, it was distributing 488,000 pounds of food annually, with the help of one consultant and a handful ofvolunteers. Last year, the former lending officer oversaw the distribution of 4,221,000 pounds of food to more than 450 agencies. She is proud that her bank's 35-member staff works closely with an affiliate food bank, Long Island Cares, and New York City's emergency food assistance program. The city buys food in bulk, and Ms. Green and her group oversee its distribution to city-supported soup kitchens and pantries. **********''Food bankers are professionals in every sense of the word,'' Ms. Green said. ''They have come to realize they must be concerned about quality control and equipment and personnel just like any other business. I don't view leaving my job at First National as having been a sacrifice. I've gained a lot and having come from a corporate setting gives me an edge.'' **********Atlanta's Bill Bolling points proudly to the fact that his operation, founded in 1979, is so well run that for every $1 donated, $11 worth of food is returned. **********''You can't beat that,'' Mr. Bolling said. Then he smiled and added, ''You know, my mother always wanted me to be a banker.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/25/busin.main_headline: Southland to Sell Chief Auto Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/25/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Southland to Sell Chief Auto Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/25/busin.body_text: **********The Southland Corporation will sell its Chief Auto Parts division to members of the unit's management and Shearson Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. for $130 million and the assumption of some debt. The sale is part of a plan to repay some of the $4 billion needed for a recent leveraged buyout by Southland, which operates the 7-Eleven chain of convenience stores. **********Chief Auto is the nation's largest retailer of automobile replacement parts, with 470 stores, mainly in Texas and California. Southland said several parties were interested in acquiring the division before it chose the investment group.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/30/world.body_text: **********A general strike to protest a new election decree paralyzed the capital today and was reported successful in other Haitian cities. **********Radio reports said the strike affected the cities of Gonaives, Les Cayes, Jacmel, Petit Goave and St.-Marc.  [ According to Reuters, a hospital spokesman said a man was shot and wounded in the capital. In Cap-Haitien, Haiti's second largest city, another man was shot to death by soldiers dismantling a barricade that residents had erected during protests, Reuters reported. ]  In Port-au-Prince, hundreds of marchers in the downtown area shouted anti-Government slogans, then threw stones at the state radio station. **********The marchers marked the release early today of several union members who were jailed a week ago because they had organized a strike for higher wages that closed down several cities for a day. **********Radio Metropole quoted the union leaders as saying they had been released temporarily. No explanation of why they were freed has been given. **********Marchers shouted ''Down with the National Governing Council!'' and ''Power to the people!'' They threw stones at the Radio Nationale building and at cars parked outside. Four soldiers dispersed the crowd by firing weapons into the air, and no injuries were reported. **********More than 90 political, civic, farm and religious groups organized the strike today to protest an electoral decree, published last Tuesday, giving the three-man military-civilian council led by Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy full control over elections to be held later this year. **********The Government decree took control of elections away from the nine-member Provisional Electoral Council, to which the Constitution gives the authority to organize elections and make the rules for them. It also dismissed two of the board's members. **********Elections for municipal and rural councils are scheduled for Aug. 23. Presidential and legislative elections are to be held late in November.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/world.main_headline: ARGENTINA'S ARMY MOVES TO HEAD OFF OFFICER REBELLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/world.print_headline: ARGENTINA'S ARMY MOVES TO HEAD OFF OFFICER REBELLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/world.body_text: **********The Argentine Army, declaring its loyalty to the Government of President Raul Alfonsin, moved today to end a rebellion by officers opposed to the prosecution of military officers on human rights charges. **********Late tonight, troops backed by artillery began moving into the outskirts of Buenos Aires from bases in towns surrounding the capital, taking up positions around the infantry school at the Campo de Mayo army base where the last of the rebellious officers were holding out. **********Several thousand civilians gathered outside the base on a highway north of the city, chanting their support for democracy for several hours before being ordered out of the area. 'Will Not Vacillate' **********Gen. Ernesto Arturo Alais, who was leading the troops, said he intended to ''retake'' the school, and Defense Minister Horacio Jaunarena said the armed forces ''will not vacillate in the use of force although we will use all the persuasive methods first.'' **********But presidential spokesman Jose Ignacio Lopez said some of the rebellious officers had withdrawn from the school during the evening and that the situation was ''tending to come under the control of the high command.'' **********The president of the lower house of Congress, Juan Carlos Pugliese, said the possibility of declaring a state of siege, which had been under consideration, had been ''diluted.'' **********The two-day crisis began to ease when a cashiered army major who had refused to respond to a court summons fled the barracks in Cordoba where he had sought the protection of sympathetic comrades. His whereabouts tonight were not known. **********A short time later, the Army announced that a group of officers supporting him had given up their action. Journalists in Cordoba, a provincial capital about 400 miles west of Buenos Aires, reported that the Archbishop of Cordoba, Raul Cardinal Primatesta, had played a key role in bringing the episode to an end there. **********However, the second group of rebellious officers continued to hold out at the infantry school at the Campo de Mayo. **********Despite rumors that the rebellious officers enjoyed broad sympathy within the middle levels of the army, Gen. Hector Rios Erenu, the army Chief of Staff, said the majority of the army ''is complying with orders.'' Crisis Began Wednesday **********The crisis began when the fugitive officer, Maj. Ernesto Guillermo Barreiro, refused to appear in a civilian court Wednesday for questioning about abuses committed in an army-run detention center in Cordoba during the mid-1970's. The army leadership responded by dismissing him, and he then holed up in the officers' club of the 14th Airborne Regiment, where he was joined by other officers. **********This morning, a group said to comprise about 50 captains led by Lieut. Col. Aldo Rico occupied the infantry school at the Campo de Mayo. They joined in the demand of the Cordoba officers for an amnesty to cover killings and other abuses committed by the military in putting down the leftist insurgency of the 1970's. **********The officers holding the infantry school were visited during the day by a judge who was reported to have told them he was gathering information for the filing of sedition charges. Colonel Rico told reporters after the judge left, however, that the men with him intended to hold out. Officer Professes Loyalty **********Confusion also surrounded the status of Major Barreiro's immediate superior, Lieut. Col. Luis Nicolas Polo. Earlier in the day, the army announced that he was being removed from command, along with Colonel Rico, because he was assisting Major Barreiro. But later, a military prosecutor took a sworn statement from Colonel Polo saying he had never acted ''as either director or promotor of the rebellion,'' and he was reported to be still in his post. **********While the major's flight and the army leadership's action may have deflated the immediate crisis it did not end the ongoing army unhappiness over having to turn over active-duty officers for possible prosecution by civilian courts in human rights cases. **********The issue has caused a series of crises between the Government and the military, and also within the military, since President Alfonsin took office at the end of 1983. Several analysts called this week's crisis the most serious since then. **********Mr. Alfonsin has supported the principle of human rights trials, and so far 10 officers have been convicted, most of them former military commanders and presidents. But late last year, at Mr. Alfonsin's request, Congress set a deadline for the filing of additional charges. When the deadline passed at the end of February, the courts had accepted cases against an estimated 280 military officers, about one-third of them on active duty. Backing Power of the Courts **********The President has also made a special point of his desire to uphold the power and independence of the courts. Defense Minister Jaunarena, who is close to Mr. Alfonsin, has repeatedly said that the Government would consider the first refusal to appear in court by an active-duty officer as a step toward a coup. **********General Rios Erenu did not allude to the well-known military position about the trials when he left a two-hour meeting between the President and senior officers this morning and announced that he would end the rebellion. **********The army chief, who had been notably quiet for the last two days about the extent to which he would back the President's position, said he had spent the time trying to convince Major Barreiro and his supporters in Cordoba to ''reach the right road through reflection.'' **********General Rios Erenu said the Argentine Army ''is subject to the political power of the nation, it is subject to the mandate of the people of the Argentine nation, it is part of the nation, and it is not going to halt its efforts to make this country respected internationally.''  ---- U.S. SUPPORTS ALFONSIN **********WASHINGTON, April 17 (Reuters) - The United States expressed support today for President Alfonsin against the army rebels. **********''I would like to make note of the United States Government's firm and unequivocal support for the democratically elected government of Argentina,'' said Phyllis Oakley, a State Department spokeswoman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/29/busin.main_headline: Stake in Santa Fe Is Bought
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/29/busin.print_headline: Stake in Santa Fe Is Bought
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/29/busin.body_text: **********Olympia & York Developments Ltd. said today that it had purchased the equivalent of a 6.1 percent stake in the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, for investment purposes only at a total purchase price of more than $465 million. **********In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Olympia & York said that it had received permission from the Federal Trade Commission and the antitrust division of the Department of Justice to acquire up to 25 percent of the Chicago-based holding company with interests in railroads, real estate and energy. **********Olympia & York, the Toronto-based real estate concern, told the S.E.C. that its officials met with Robert D. Krebs, the president and chief executive officer of Santa Fe Southern on Aug. 24. **********At that meeting and afterward, Mr. Krebs and his financial advisers ''indicated that Santa Fe Southern Pacific wished to remain independent and was working on a restructuring program and suggested that the company would not welcome an increase in ownership of the shares by Olympia & York over the 5 percent threshold,'' according to the S.E.C. filing. **********A spokesman for Santa Fe Southern Pacific said that the company had no comment on the filing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/21/busin.body_text: **********Buoyed by strong sales of its ST personal computer and a resurgence in the video game market, the Atari Corporation today reported fourth-quarter earnings of $23 million, or 87 cents a share, up 54.4 percent from $14.9 million, or 64 cents a share, a year ago. Fourth-quarter 1986 results include an extraordinary credit of $11 million. Sales rose 41.7 percent, to $92.7 million, from $65.4 million a year ago. For all of 1986, Atari earned $44.5 million, or $1.89 a share. In 1985 it had a loss of $14.3 million. Sales for the year rose 81.8 percent, to $258.1 million, from $142 million in 1985.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.main_headline: TOUGHER TERMS ARISING ON NEW 3D-WORLD DEBT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.print_headline: TOUGHER TERMS ARISING ON NEW 3D-WORLD DEBT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/21/busin.body_text: **********The decision by Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, to treat $3 billion of its foreign loans as all but uncollectible will probably make the third world debt crisis even more difficult and acrimonious. **********New lending to debtor countries will probably fall, debt reschedulings will become more painful, calls for a governmental solution to the debt problem will grow louder and a divided banking community will become even more fragmented. **********In short, experts on the debt crisis said yesterday, the approach that has long been used to deal with the problem - the banks acting in unison to revise the terms of old loans while providing new money - will be badly undermined. What Citicorp has done, they said, will probably force an entirely new approach to the debt crisis. Future Loan Conditions **********''If there is additional lending, it will be on much tougher terms,'' said Stuart Greenbaum, a banking professor at Northwestern University's Kellogg School. In Latin America, government officials and debt specialists expect future debt talks to be much rockier.  [ Page D6. ]  The biggest casualty of Citicorp's move, according to analysts, will be new lending, which lies at the heart of the plan by Treasury Secretary James A, Baker 3d to deal with the third world's debt burden. The reason: If Citicorp, in as good a position as anyone to assess the climate for lending, says it does not expect $3 billion of its foreign loans to be repaid, other banks will be loath to place their own capital at risk. Reshaping of Portfolio **********Making matters worse, Citicorp has also said it will seek to reduce its loan exposure in the developing world during the next two years by selling some of its loans and engaging in so-called debt-for-equity swaps. **********''You can't be building reserves on your old loans while at the same time making new loans,'' said George M. Salem, the senior banking analyst at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. ''The ability of the banks to extend new credit has been dealt a blow.'' **********The tenor of future debt-rescheduling talks could turn decidedly nastier. A few analysts asserted yesterday that Citicorp's bargaining position had been weakened as a result of its action. According to their line of thinking, now that Citicorp has taken a ''hit'' against earnings to account for its problem foreign loans - and if, as expected, other big banks follow suit - the debtor countries will respond by seeking debt forgiveness, arguing that the loans could be forgotten without any further impact on the banks' profits. **********The prevalent view among debt experts, however, is the opposite. Having taken its lumps, most of these people argued, Citicorp is in a better position than ever to be patient in future debt talks. Other banks that build loss reserves for their foreign loans will be similarly able to take a hard-line approach. And if, as many experts suggest, the debtor countries view Citicorp's move as a direct assault on their creditworthiness, the result could be heated negotiations. ''It is a new era for the debt,'' said Christine Bindert, a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who is now senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ''This is the first time that a bank has recognized that the debt is not a liquidity problem but a basic structural problem. We are finally addressing the real issue after five years of muddling through.'' 2 Citicorp Messages Noted Political ramifications are also expected. At Colgate University, Robert Rothstein, director of the Program in International Relations, said Citicorp was trying to send two messages. **********One, aimed at the developing countries, is that the bank is no longer willing to abide by the status quo of forever restructuring debts so as to allow other, weaker banks to continue reporting profits. The other message, aimed at the governments of the commercial banks' nations, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and other international lending agencies, is that Citicorp expects increased public participation in return for the sacrifice it is making. **********As a result of its decision to add $3 billion to its loan-loss reserve, Citicorp will suffer a $2.5 billion loss in the second quarter, the second-largest deficit ever for a United States corporation. Mr. Reed, Citicorp's chairman, said the move would cost its shareholders ''a year's worth of earnings.'' **********''They have said they have gone as far as they can,'' Professor Rothstein said, ''and that somebody else has got to do something or there will be a substantial crisis. It is a major step toward an outright demand for political intervention.'' Role for Commercial Banks **********But even if additional public money is applied to the debt crisis, participation by the commercial banks will still be necessary. That, in turn, will require more of the cooperation that has allowed American banks at least to work together in so-called loan advisory committees so as to continually restructure maturing third world loans. **********But lately that atmosphere has been eroding as more and more banks, particularly regional banks in the United States, have concluded that the debt crisis is showing no signs of improvement. For some time, moreover, debt experts have spoken of a rift between United States banks and the major lenders of Europe and Japan, which long ago established large reserves for their foreign loans. **********With Citicorp's action, the collegiality among the largest United States banks could very well fall apart. For one thing, Citicorp acted on its own, without consulting any of the other big banks on the advisory committees. But more important, by building its reserve, Citicorp has placed immediate pressure on other institutions to bolster their own reserves. Yet weaker institutions such as Manufacturers Hanover, the Bank of America and some banks in Texas are not in a position to take such a move. Friction With Bank's Rivals **********The resulting resentment toward Citicorp, along with an unwillingness to work side-by-side with the giant bank in future debt negotiations, could run deep. **********At a minimum, debt experts say, negotiations will be hobbled by the friction that will undoubtedly exist henceforth between Citicorp and its rivals. **********''To an important extent, Citicorp has done what is good for it,'' said Stephen Berman, the banking analyst at the Wall Street firm of County Securities Inc. ''It will erode the collegiality somewhat.'' **********Rudiger Dornbusch, the Ford International Professor of Economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, added, ''The more you have episodes like this, the harder it is to keep the cartel of banks together.''
