https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/06/busin.main_headline: Faberge Pays Premium To Buy Elizabeth Arden
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/06/busin.print_headline: Faberge Pays Premium To Buy Elizabeth Arden
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/06/busin.body_text: **********Faberge Inc., which makes Aqua Net hair spray, Brut cologne and other personal-care products for the mass market, has agreed to buy Elizabeth Arden from Eli Lilly & Company for $700 million. **********Whether Elizabeth Arden's cosmetics, which are relatively expensive and sold in department stores, and its chain of beauty salons will fit with Faberge's less-exclusive line, is a question many analysts are asking. **********Faberge was so eager to acquire Arden, which had $400 million in sales last year, that as part of the deal it agreed not to shut any Arden plants or lay off any employees, in addition to paying well above the $500 million to $600 million the sale had been expected to bring. **********''Oooooh, that's a lot of money,'' Allan G. Mottus, an industry consultant, said of the price, which, he noted, was 1.75 times last year's sales. When Yves St. Laurent bought Charles of the Ritz in November 1986, it paid less than 1.5 times sales. **********Arden earned about an $80 million operating profit in 1986. Ritz, Mr. Mottus said, ''was more profitable.'' **********Competitors who had bid for Arden, as well as industry analysts, generally agreed with Mr. Mottus's assessment. They also questioned the soundness of Faberge's strategy. **********''Frankly, we think the pricing is too high,'' said Fumio Hoshino, the executive liaison representative of Shiseido, a Japanese cosmetics giant that been interested in Arden. **********Faberge's chairman, Daniel J. Manella, acknowledged that he was paying dearly for Arden, but he said Arden was the last exclusive beauty business expected to come on the market for a while. **********Eli Lilly closed at $94, up only 37.5 cents, on a day when drug stocks climbed 2 percent on average. Hemant Shah, an analyst with Nomura Securities, blamed the relatively poor showing in the market on a lingering concern over Lilly's Keflex oral antibiotic, whose patent expired in April. It has since lost 40 percent of its market share. 5 Finalists in Bidding About 30 companies had shown interest in Arden. The other finalists were Avon, Warburg Pincus, Moet-Hennessy and Minnetonka. **********Mr. Manella and Arden executives said emphatically that they had no intention of using either company to market the other's products. **********''The two businesses will be run independent of each other,'' Mr. Manella said. ''We have no intentions of trying to upscale our products and for sure, we wouldn't downscale some of theirs.'' Freed From Lilly's Burdens **********Joseph Ronchetti, Arden's president, said he felt Arden would improve its bottom line, perhaps by 10 percent, simply by freeing itself from the corporate burdens that Lilly had imposed. **********''We call it 'de-Lilli-azation,' '' Mr. Ronchetti said. He said Lilly had required Arden to pay a share of the corporate personnel costs even though it has its own personnel director and required Arden to use a corporate distribution center in Dallas when it could ship its products directly from its Roanoke, Va., plant to its customers at less cost. **********''Now all those charges will be removed from our profit-and-loss statement, which will allow us to reinvest in the brands and not in the structure of the company,'' Mr. Ronchetti said. **********That is precisely what outsiders think is badly needed. **********Arden last year spent less than $40 million, or 10 percent of its sales, on advertising and promotion. Faberge spent $78.5 million, or 26 percent of its $307 million in cosmetics and fragrance sales. A Similar Challenge **********In some ways, Arden is a challenge very similar to the one that awaited Mr. Manella when he took over Faberge in 1984. In that year, the McGregor Corporation, a publicly held apparel company, bought Faberge, and then went private. It later changed its name back to Faberge to stress its commitment to the beauty business and is now completely owned by the investor Meshulam Riklis and his family. **********Almost immediately, Mr. Riklis's management cut costs. Their efforts have more than doubled profits while sales have increased 33 percent. **********Mr. Manella eliminated a dozen product lines, including the Farrah Fawcett shampoo, and invested heavily in automation. Packaging and materials can run as high as 70 percent of the manufacturing costs, so where the company had previously relied on outside suppliers for bottles, caps and labels, it began making almost all of them in highly automated factories. **********He also dropped some lavish promotional expenses, including a drag-racing funny car, a ocean-racing boat and an airplane. **********Mr. Manella also eliminated some of the corporate perquisites that had proliferated, such as a shower-for-two and a music room at headquarters, where the former chairman, George Barrie, went to relax every day at 5 P.M. **********''It's unrecognizable compared to what it was a few years ago,'' said Lawrence H. Appel, a consultant with Horvitz & Appel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/21/busin.body_text: **********The Texas Air Corporation, struggling to consolidate People Express, Frontier Airlines, Eastern Airlines and New York Air, said yesterday that it had a loss of $27 million in the second quarter, less than half of the $66.2 million loss it had in the comparable 1986 period. **********Revenues, which reflect the acquisitions, soared to $2.16 billion, from $539.6 million, while operating income rose to $100.9 million, from $29.2 million. **********Texas Air, the nation's largest airline company, gave a breakdown of results at its operating subsidiaries. **********Its Continental Airlines unit, which in April merged with Frontier, People Express and New York Air, had a $71.1 million loss on sales of $948.6 million. Second-quarter 1986 results for Continental were not reported. **********Eastern, meanwhile, earned $27.1 million before a $14.6 million charge for preferred-stock dividends. In 1986, Eastern had a $44 million loss. **********Texas Air said the results at Continental, which largely reflect the continuing impact of integrating several airlines, were disappointing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/06/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; TREASURY RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/06/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates rose slightly in the Treasury market yesterday in very light trading activity, while tax-exempt and corporate bond yields were little changed. **********''The market has been pretty quiet all week,'' one Treasury note trader said, ''and the most often cited excuse is waiting for the employment numbers tomorrow.'' **********By late in the day, the Treasury's bellwether 7 1/2 percent bonds due in 2016 were offered at 100 21/32, down 7/32d's, to yield 7.44 percent, while the new 6 5/8 percent notes due in 1992 were at 99 3/4, down 1/8 point, to yield 6.68 percent. In the Treasury bill market, rates rose a few hundredths of a percentage point, with the three-month issue bid at 5.53 percent. Value of Data Questioned **********Despite the widespread anticipation surrounding the employment report for February, some economists contend that the monthly data will do little to clarify the health of the economy and the likely course of interest rates. They note that economic data for January and February have been distorted by the aftereffects of the year-end buying binge associated with the new tax law. **********One trader said, ''I can imagine it already - the bulls will point to small gains in payrolls as evidence of a weak economy, while the bears will take the average of January and February and say the economy is on the rebound.'' **********In general, signs of weak economic activity are associated with a bullish outlook for bond prices and expectations of lower interest rates, while strong economic data are linked to a bearish outlook for bonds and higher rates. **********In January, when 448,000 workers were added to nonfarm payrolls, some economists were led to revise their growth forecasts upward. But February's gain is expected to be a much smaller 170,000 workers. Fed Vice Chairman on M-1 **********There was no discernible market reaction to a speech by the Federal Reserve Board's vice chairman, Manuel Johnson, to the Eastern Economic Association. Mr. Johnson said that the Fed had not totally abandoned the M-1 money supply measure, even though it has not been closely enough linked to changes in economic activity recently to serve as a guide to monetary policy. **********''The broader aggregates, along with a careful monitoring and assessment of information provided by various financial markets, seem more appropriate as guides to policy,'' Mr. Johnson said. He said that developments in foreign exchange, credit and commodity markets could be useful indicators of inflationary expectations. **********In accord with the diminished status of the M-1 money supply measure, there was little reaction to the Fed's late afternoon announcement that M-1 rose by $1.9 billion in the week ended Feb. 23, and remains below the average level for January. M-1 and M-2 Growth Estimate **********Using partial data reported for February, Donald Fine, vice president and chief market analyst at Chase Manhattan Bank, estimated that growth of M-1 and M-2 would be slightly negative in February, with M-2 growth since the fourth quarter of 1986 barely above the bottom of the Fed's 5 1/2 to 8 1/2 percent target. **********''This doesn't mean the Fed is going to ease,'' he noted, ''but when combined with weak economic data it's a development that could eventually give them more latitude to move in that direction.'' **********Analysts noted that Fed officials indicated at times last year that rapid money supply growth was an impediment to moves toward an easier monetary policy and lower short-term interest rates. Corporate Offerings **********In the corporate market, Holiday Inns Inc. is offering $900 million of 10 1/2 percent senior notes due in 1994 and $500 million of 11 percent subordinated debentures due in 1999. Both issues are offered at par through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. **********Executives at the First Boston Corporation expect to announce interest rates today for more than $1 billion of Allied Stores Corporation's speculative-grade securities. Among new investment-grade issues, Ford Motor Credit Company's $250 million of three-year notes were offered at 6.95 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Company, and Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company's five-year certificates of deposit were offered at 7.28 percent through Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. The Alltel Corporation offered $50 million of debentures due in 2022, at 8.90 percent, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. **********A $500 million issue of collateralized mortgage obligations offered by Salomon Brothers Inc. included an issue with an estiamted average life of 3.4 years at a yield of 7.51 percent and a 7.9-year issue at 8.42 percent. The financing also included a planned amortization class with a more predictable cash flow, offered at 8.23 percent, with an estimated average life of 11.9 years, and a 19.2-year issue that pays no interest until other classes are retired, at a yield of 9.11 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/20/busin.body_text: **********The Marine Midland Bank has begun charging its upstate customers a 75-cent fee for using automated teller machines at other banks. Marine Midland is a member of the New York Cash Exchange, and its customers can gain access to their accounts through the automated teller machines of dozens of banks in several states. **********The fees were imposed by Marine Midland, based in Buffalo, on May 15, but do not affect customers in New York City or on Long Island. **********The Chase Lincoln First Bank, which is based in Rochester, has also announced that it will impose a 75-cent fee on automated teller machine transactions at other banks' machines, beginning Jan. 1. **********The head of New York's consumer affairs bureau, Richard M. Kessel, today denounced what he said was a trend toward such fees, saying, ''I think the banks have taken enough from their customers.'' Mr. Kessel urged the lawmakers here to take into account the new fee, as well as persistently high credit card interest rates, when deliberating the extension of the state's bank deregulation laws. The laws expire at the end of June. **********Lawmakers here said, however, that an agreement in principle to extend the deregulation laws for another six years had already been reached.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/busin.main_headline: SALES OF U.S. CARS UP BY 6.7%
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; SALES OF U.S. CARS UP BY 6.7%
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/05/busin.body_text: **********Sales of new American-made cars increased 6.7 percent in the last 10 days of February, despite a decline in sales by the General Motors Corporation, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today. **********G.M. reported sales of 95,588, a decline of 7.9 percent. **********That evidently prompted three of the company's five car marketing divisions to sweeten the incentives currently being offered on some models. Buick, Oldsmobile and Pontiac said today that they would offer interest rates as low as 3.9 percent on two-year loans as an alternative to the discounts on options previously offered. The new incentives will be in effect until April 30. **********The new incentives raise questions about G.M.'s ability to meet sales targets without costly financing offers that top officials have said they want to avoid. A 7.3 Million Selling Rate **********For the 10 days, the increase in industry sales, to 198,818 cars, put the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate of 7.3 million, slightly ahead of the rate a year earlier of 7.2 million. **********For all of February, domestic car sales were down 9.1 percent, to 556,953, while sales of light trucks, which often substitute for cars, were up 7.5 percent, to 284,835. Sales of imported cars increased four-tenths of 1 percent, to 219,988, while imported truck sales were down eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 66,615. Over all, sales of light vehicles during the month totaled 1,128,391, a dip of 2.9 percent. **********The seasonally adjusted rate for the month was 7.3 million for domestic cars and 2.6 million for imports, for a 9.9 million combined rate. Last February, the domestic rate was 8.1 million and the import rate 2.7 million, for a 10.8 million combined rate. Ford, Chrysler and Honda Gain **********Analysts were generally encouraged by the increase in sales at the end of February, which included strong gains for the Ford Motor Company, the Chrysler Corporation and Honda of America. **********''The sales improvement is a combination of the incentives already offered and tax reform losing its effect,'' said Edward J. Sullivan, an analyst with Chase Econometrics. He said he anticipated domestic sales would climb slightly in the next few selling periods, to about a 7.5 million annual rate. **********While G.M.'s sales were declining in the final 10 days of February, Ford was up 29.3 percent, to 51,411, and Chrysler gained 11 percent, to 30,634. Honda was up 96.1 percent, to 14,104 and the Nissan Motor company gained 35.8 percent, to 3,501. The Toyota Motor Company, which had no domestic production in February 1986, sold 1,082 domestic cars in the 1987 period. A.M.C. and VW Off **********Meanwhile, the American Motors Corporation was down 65 percent, to 926 sales, while Volkswagen of America was off 42.5 percent, to 1,572. **********G.M. did record a gain of 11.4 percent in light-truck sales in the period, to 40,849, while Ford was up 47.7 percent, to 37,559, and Chrysler was up 47 percent, at 16,583. A.M.C.'s Jeep sales were off 4 percent, at 6,132, while Nissan was up 31.4 percent, to 2,701. **********The imports continued to gain in the car market, with their share rising to 28.3 percent, from 26 percent last February. But they lost share in the hotly contested light-truck market, where both import and domestic companies have been offering incentives. The import share fell to 18.9 percent from 20.2 percent. **********G.M. sales problems and the output from new Japanese-owned plants in this country were reflected in changing shares of the total car market for the month. G.M.'s share declined to 36.9 percent from 43.6 percent, while Ford was gaining to 20.3 percent from 17.8 percent, and Chrysler advanced to 11.4 percent from 11 percent. **********Both Honda and Nissan gained in market share, as a result of their domestic output, which allows them to supplement imports limited by trade restraints. Honda's share increased to 7.3 percent from 5.8 percent, while Nissan was up to 6.2 percent from 4.5 percent. Toyota and the Mazda Motor Company, which are both in the process of building domestic plants, lost market; Toyota moving to 4.7 percent from 4.8 percent and Mazda falling to 1.3 percent from 2.3 percent. **********Hyundai, the Korean company that began selling cars last February had a 2.4 percent share of the market last month. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/28/busin.body_text: **********ON July 15, the day that the two Saatchi & Saatchi agencies Ted Bates Worldwide and Backer & Spielvogel, were merged, 40 professionals from each agency were invited to a cocktail party at the Princeton Club in New York to smooth the way. Although the event was scheduled to run from 5 to 6 P.M., it lasted until 8 P.M. and by the end, the feeling of unease began to evaporate, some of those there recalled. **********It did not entirely disappear, of course. There were lingering fears on both sides that the meshing process would be sticky because of pride and varying business cultures. Backer & Spielvogel, the smaller agency, was given frontal position in the new name, Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide Inc., and Carl Spielvogel, B.&S.'s chairman, was named chairman and chief executive of the combined company. Furthermore, the agencies' approaches were different. Backer & Spielvogel was principally noted for its creative efforts and Ted Bates for its development of marketing plans. **********The problem, of course, was to transform separate company spirits into one, often a difficult matter because of rivalries and egos. It was the same problem faced in other recent agency mergers. The trick, it is clear, is to move quickly and decisively and that is what the leaders of Backer Spielvogel Bates say they have tried to do. **********''One initial thing we did was to hold brand reviews of all accounts,'' Mr. Spielvogel said. ''That gave us an opportunity to both see the work and the people in action. When you bring two groups of professionals together, you do get synergy. But the reviews quickly met our objectives of paying attention to key clients and key people.'' **********In an effort to make everyone feel wanted and vital, all employee compensation programs are being reviewed. ''We are also looking to add to all our employee benefits,'' Mr. Spielvogel said. **********On the matter of disparate cultures, it was obvious that at least semantically the merged agencies might run into some confusion. Bates called its primary method the ''unique selling proposition.'' B.& S. called its ''strategy development.'' But, Mr. Spielvogel noted, ''we are now in the process of writing a joint statement on strategy, but we have already decided to use the 'unique selling proposition.' '' **********To merge the staffs physically to best advantage, the agency has appointed study teams of equal numbers of members from each agency to develop the methodology and structure of all the professional disciplines, including creative, account management, research, media, and finance and administration. **********But the knottiest problem the combined agency faced was the dismay that persisted among Bates staff members after when the agency lost almost $300 million in billings last fall because of conflicts and other problems arising from its acquisition by Saatchi & Saatchi. Since then, with the addition of $130 million in new billings at the combined agency, progress has been made in recovering from that loss. **********''And as we get that new business going,'' Mr. Spielvogel said, ''we are giving Bates people made redundant by the accounts' loss first crack at the new accounts. In this way, we are also removing the labels of 'Bates' or 'B.& S.' that they figuratively carry.'' **********What then is the key to running a strong agency? ''You have to remove any superstructure at the top to insure that the top pros aren't doing administrative work but instead working with the clients,'' Mr. Spielvogel said. ''You must be involved in the business of clients.'' A third key, he added, is ''a high degree of professionalism.'' **********Mr. Spielvogel said that he was functioning in the agency as an account executive; William M. Backer, formerly B.& S.'s president and now vice chairman of the merged group, was a copywriter and was also writing a song for the Hyundai auto account, and Donald M. Zuckert, formerly chairman of Ted Bates and now president of Backer Spielvogel Bates, was an account manager. And all other top executives similarly were operating on a hands-on basis with clients. **********Will that personal involvement with clients eventually mean that the agency's top management will miss the forest for the trees? Mr. Spielvogel, 58 years old and a 27-year veteran of the business, smiled and said, ''That's what the advertising business is all about: the trees.''

Charter Medical Gets Bid by Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/17/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Charter Medical Gets Bid by Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/17/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: William A. Fickling Jr., who at 6 foot 4 inches was a star forward for Auburn University's basketball team in the 1950's, said he did not think he was tall enough to be successful in basketball today. **********William A. Fickling Jr., who at 6 foot 4 inches was a star forward for Auburn University's basketball team in the 1950's, said he did not think he was tall enough to be successful in basketball today. **********Mr. Fickling is very conscious of size and its constraints. They have been at the center of his business strategy since 1969, when he combined eight hospitals and several nursing homes into the Charter Medical Corporation, of Macon, Ga., the country's largest provider of psychiatric medical care with 64 hospitals and 8 more under construction. **********Rather than compete with the big players in health care on a broad front, he said, Charter Medical chose to concentrate on psychiatric care. **********''Our corporate strategy was to find a niche in which we could excel,'' Mr. Fickling, Charter Medical's chairman and chief executive, said yesterday. **********The company has created special programs for treating alcohol and drug abuse. It has also increased its revenues to about $1 billion and its work force to about 10,000 people. **********Mr. Fickling took the company public in 1971, and now he and his family want to buy it back. Analysts have said that their initial offer of $860 million, or $40 a share, may be too high to sustain, given the precipitous decline in the company's stock in last month's bear market. **********The 55-year-old executive, citing the admonitions of his lawyers, would not discuss the possibility of withdrawing the offer or submitting a lower one. **********Mr. Fickling and his family own 29 percent of Charter Medical's class A common stock and more than 90 percent of its class B common stock, giving them 75 percent voting control. **********However, the stock's decline - the class A fell $1.25 yesterday, to $25.75, the class B 25 cents, to $27.50 - left the tender offer with no competition. **********Mr. Fickling, a Macon native, graduated from Auburn in 1954. He has worked for the Diversified Development Construction and Insurance Company of Macomb, and served as chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta from 1980 to 1983. His wife, Neva Jane, was Miss America in 1953; they have two sons and two daughters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/17/world.print_headline: POLITICAL GRAFT TRIAL ENDS IN BONN WITH 3 NOTABLES PUNISHED LIGHTLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/17/world.body_text: **********Two former West German Economics Ministers and the former deputy chairman of the giant Flick holding company were convicted of income tax evasion today but cleared of graver charges of corruption. **********The verdicts, coming at the end of an 18-month trial in Bonn, virtually ended a wide-ranging political payoff scandal that had besmirched the reputations of the country's three biggest political parties and preoccupied Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government during much of its first four years. **********Announcing his decision, the chief judge, Hans-Henning Buchholz, said that almost all of the 80 witnesses called in the case appeared to suffer from ''bad memories.'' **********''It is clear to the court that a lot was held back by the witnesses,'' he said. Cleared for Lack of Proof **********Judge Buchholz said the prosecution had been justified in bringing the corruption charges against the three defendants, who he said had been acquitted for lack of evidence against them. **********The verdict was a political blessing for Otto Lambsdorff, who was forced to resign as Economics Minister in June 1984 after being indicted. A senior figure in the small Free Democratic Party and the first West German Cabinet minister to be indicted while in office, Mr. Lambsdorff was fined $100,000 for tax evasion, a punishment that will permit him to seek a cabinet position again. **********His predecessor in the Economics Ministry job, Hans Friderichs, was fined $34,000 for tax evasion while Eberhard von Brauchitsch, the former Flick executive, was fined $306,000 and given a two-year suspended jail sentence for having avoided some $10 million in taxes. **********The sentences were considerably lighter than those demanded by the prosecution, which had asked for a 15-month suspended jail sentence for Mr. Lambsdorff, four years in jail for Mr. von Brauchitsch and a $110,000 fine for Mr. Friderichs, who was chairman of the Dresdner Bank when he was indicted. Graft Charges Dropped **********Mr. Lambsdorff was at first accused of having accepted $50,000 in bribes from the Flick concern in the late 1970's in return for lucrative tax waivers. **********Mr. Friderichs was charged with having accepted $140,000 from Flick for granting similar tax waivers, while Mr. von Brauchitsch was accused of having distributed the bribes. The Flick payoffs were meticulously entered in a ledger that was a central prosecution document. **********Last July, issuing a ''preliminary acquittal,'' the court decided to stop hearing evidence on the corruption charges, which it said it had judged the prosecution could not demonstrate. The corruption charges had been the most serious ones against the three defendants. **********The sharp-tongued Mr. Lambsdorff has treated his trial as an inconvenience and, while gaining re-election to the Parliament last month, has been an active member of the Free Democratic team negotiating the policies of the next Kohl Government. The 60-year-old patrician is his party's spokesman on economics affairs in Parliament. **********Mr. Lambsdorff, a fierce champion of a free-market economy, was one of the moving forces in persuading the Free Democrats to desert their alliance with the Social Democrats in late 1982. The move toppled the Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and brought Mr. Kohl to office. Mixed Views of Verdict **********Martin Bangemann, the Free Democrats' chairman, expressed satisfaction that Mr. Lambsdorff had been acquitted of the corruption charges. But Mr. Bangemann, who succeeded Mr. Lambsdorff as Economics Minister and who is reportedly reluctant to give up the post, did not speculate on Mr. Lambsdorff's political future. **********Offering a contrasting view of the verdict, Otto Schily, a Green Party lawmaker, said the punishments were ''mild and trifling'' considering the ''finesse and criminal intensity'' with which the defendants had deprived the state of ''millions.'' **********''I believe the man on the street will ask how he is supposed to understand this privileged treatment,'' said Mr. Schily, a lawyer who was the most aggressive member of a subcommittee that investigated the Flick payoffs. ''The idea that 'the little ones hang and the big ones go free' will be encouraged.'' **********The Lambsdorff trial was the major legal action growing out of an investigation that started in 1981 and provided a glimpse into a vast network of illegal corporate payments to the three major parties, often through tax-free ''donations'' to dummy charities. The scandal eroded popular trust in West Germany's three established parties and contributed to the rise of the Green Party. **********Virtually every major politician was called to testify before various panels and Chancellor Kohl was separately investigated after Mr. Schily accused him of having perjured himself. At the height of the scandal, Rainer Barzel was forced to resign as Speaker of Parliament after it was disclosed that Flick had paid him a half-million dollars.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/28/world.main_headline: PRESIDENT KEEPS U.S. OPTIONS OPEN ON ATTACK BY IRAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/28/world.print_headline: PRESIDENT KEEPS U.S. OPTIONS OPEN ON ATTACK BY IRAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/28/world.body_text: **********President Reagan, adding to growing uncertainty and concern in the capital, left unclear today what the United States might do if its ships in the Persian Gulf were attacked by Iran's newest land-based missiles. **********''We have to defend ourselves,'' Mr. Reagan said, as he has before. But he refused to be more specific on what type of action the United States might take if attacked by Iranians. **********''I think it's far better if the Iranians go to bed every night wondering what we might do than us telling them in advance,'' he said.  [ Excerpts, page A13. ]  In Brussels today, the NATO allies appeared to rebuff a Pentagon call for military help in protecting oil tankers in the Persian Gulf. The move came at the end of a two-day meeting of the alliance's defense ministers.  [ Page A13. ]  Speculation on U.S. Response A range of possibilities for the American involvement in the Gulf have been a subject of speculation in Congress and in the Administration. It is unclear whether an attack by Iran would trigger retaliation by American forces against the missile bases, or would lead to broader aerial attacks against other Iranian targets. **********Concern in Washington has heightened because of the American decision to allow 11 Kuwaiti oil tankers to sail under the American flag, presumably putting them under the protection of Navy warships in the region. The ''flagging'' of the Kuwaiti ships is to begin perhaps as soon as next week. **********Although Iran has so far avoided any military confrontation with the United States in the Gulf, Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, who returned today from a tour of the region, said it was ''just a matter of time'' before Iran would attack one of the Kuwaiti tankers flying the American flag. Interview With Reagan **********The discussion about the possible American retaliation against Iran arose in an interview with foreign journalists when Mr. Reagan said: ''Now, it is true that the Iranians have placed missiles on shore that can reach targets at sea. That has to be considered with regard to more than just shooting at another vessel or shooting at an airplane.'' Earlier he had said that the United States would attack ships or planes that fired on its ships at sea. **********''I don't see the danger of a war,'' Mr Reagan added. ''I don't see how it could possibly start. As a matter of fact, we are doing everything we can to try and bring about an end to the war that we have.'' **********The President's remarks were the latest in a string of seemingly contradictory statements by Administration officials since an attack by an Iraqi aircraft killed 37 men aboard the United States Navy frigate Stark May 17. Iraq has since apologized for what it said was a mistake. **********Iran and Iraq have been at war since 1980, and although Iraq has attacked many more tankers in the Persian Gulf since then than Iran has, all sides of the debate here have focussed on the threat of an Iranian attack. Kuwait Shipping Main Target **********Of the 30 ships attacked by Iran since last September, 25 were on their way to or from Kuwait, and Administration officials have justified American protection of Kuwaiti tankers as a way to deter further Iranian attacks and keep open the sea lanes in the Gulf. Iranian officials have warned, however, that they will continue their attacks regardless of the American protection. **********Senator Sasser, on the NBC News program ''Today,'' said he doubted that the reflagging of Kuwaiti ships would go forward as scheduled, citing the overwhelming vote by the Senate last week to require that the Administration explain the rules of engagement in the gulf and define security arrangments before the plan to protect Kuwait's ships goes into effect. 'Likely to Be in Combat' **********In another interview today, Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, said, ''We're more likely to be in combat in the Persian Gulf now than we were before.'' **********Last week, after the attack on the Stark, President Reagan said the Navy would defend itself against any hostile aircraft that approached. But his remarks today were Mr. Reagan's first indication that he is considering retaliation in the event of a sea-based or land-based attack from Iran. **********While some officials have called it irresponsible to suggest that the United States might bomb Iran in the event of an attack, others have suggested that the United States would retaliate as it did against attacks attributed to Libya. In that case last year, American forces began by attacking Libyan patrol boats and a missile site and ended by bombing two other military installations. **********Administration officials acknowledge the difficulty in defining the mission of American forces. On the one hand, they have sought to assure Congress and the public that Iran has taken care never to hit an American vessel and does not want a war with the United States. On the other hand, they have characterized Iran as an unpredictable belligerent that poses an increased risk to American forces. U.S. Rules of Engagement **********Because the military rules of engagement are classified, it is unclear, for example, if an attack against a Kuwaiti tanker flying the American flag and primarily manned by foreigners would bring the same American response as an attack on an American naval vessel with American personnel. **********The Iranian threat has become more dangerous since Iran made its batteries of Chinese-made HY-2 anti-ship missiles nearly operational at two sites near Bandar Abbas. Two weeks ago, a second shipment of the missiles, code-named ''Silkworm'' by NATO, arrived. **********In addition, Iranian revolutionary guards, who are less disciplined than the professional Navy and enjoy a certain degree of autonomy in Iran's naval structure, have expanded their authority over the last several months. They have begun to launch hit-and-run attacks on neutral ships in the Gulf from small speedboats. **********Congressional concern was also heightened by new details that emerged today about the American naval escort of two Kuwaiti merchant vessels carrying American-made M-60 tanks, artillery and ammunition to Bahrain last February and again last weekend. The equipment, which was sold to Bahrain, was delivered on Kuwaiti ships at Bahrain's request, the State Department said today. Cargo Is Transferred **********In the first case, an American vessel carrying the arms developed mechanical trouble before it reached the Gulf and had to put into port in Oman, according to a Pentagon official. Its cargo was transferred to a Kuwaiti ship that was accorded the same protection as the American ship. **********Because an escort was provided for the first delivery, the Pentagon concluded that it was appropriate to give the same protection to the second delivery. The Pentagon said in a statement Tuesday that it offered naval escort for the vessels because ''it is important that the United States remain a reliable supplier of defense items to friendly countries.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/26/busin.body_text: **********Indonesia, its economy battered by a plunge in oil and commodity prices last year, said today that it would not reschedule its foreign debts and would neither devalue its currency nor impose foreign currency controls.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/28/busin.body_text: **********In a strongly worded protest, the Japanese Government called on the United States to reverse its decision to impose tariffs on selected Japanese products. **********Although Government officials publicly denied that they would retaliate, one senior official warned that Japan would consider sanctions of its own against American products. **********In a morning news conference, Hajime Tamura, Minister of International Trade and Industry, said the American decision was ''most regrettable'' and called for emergency consultations with the United States. If the tariffs are imposed, he said, Japan will ''take appropriate measures, including those in pursuance of the GATT.'' **********Under the terms of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, Japan could protest the American decision as violating the rules prohibiting members from unilaterally imposing discriminatory tariffs without the approval of the country affected. **********Mr. Tamura also said that Japan would consider canceling the semiconductor agreement that is at the heart of the current trade dispute. **********Mr. Tamura argued that the Japanese Government had done everything it could to uphold the agreement, noting that it had asked Japanese companies to cut production. The production cut was sought to force prices up and curb supplies to a ''gray market'' in which semiconductors are still being ''dumped,'' or sold at prices below the fair market prices stipulated by the accord. 'A Matter of Time' **********''The Japanese Government has taken every measure that Japan can imagine,'' Mr. Tamura said. ''No additional measures for this issue can be considered any more. We firmly believe that our measures will bear significant fruit. The problem now is a matter of time.'' **********Mr. Tamura publicly dismissed the possibility that Japan would impose tariffs of its own. ''Japan has been setting the lowest level of tariffs among industrialized nations,'' he said. ''I do not want to undermine those efforts.'' **********But another senior trade ministry official, who asked to remain unidentified, said that Japan would consider imposing tariffs on American exports, such as agricultural products. 'We Will Raise Duties' **********''If the U.S. resorts to such practices, it is clearly a contravention of GATT provisions,'' the official said. ''This means that we will take equivalent compensatory adjustments. We will raise duties of a similar magnitude on United States products.'' **********Nonetheless, the trade ministry official said he did not believe that the United States and Japan had fired the first shots of a trade war. Rather, he and other trade officials said, there was still time to negotiate. **********The Electronic Industries Association of Japan also sharply criticized the United States action. ''E.I.A.J. believes that it is premature and even irrational to attempt an assessment of the impact of the agreement and our efforts to comply with it only six months after concluding the agreement,'' the association said in a statement. ''We urge U.S. governmental authorities to reconsider the decision made, to evaluate fairly the results of Japanese effors in implementing the objectives of the agreement, and to resist emotional biases.'' **********Industry analysts predicted that the tariffs would hurt the Japanese semiconductor industry, which has already been suffering from an oversupply of chips.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/16/busin.body_text: **********Even by the standards of Alan Greenspan, whose soft-spoken demeanor belies a restless, driven nature, the last five weeks have been hectic. **********There have been dozens of briefings and staff meetings, mounds of unfamiliar documents, get-acquainted dashes to Switzerland and Florida, round trips on the Washington-New York shuttle and one glittery party, at the Swedish Embassy. Not to mention a mini-crisis over the dollar that prompted the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who works a 7:30-to-7:30 day, to push for an increase in the central bank's discount rate for the first time in three years. **********''He did say to me that since he's been on the job, he feels like a VCR on fast-forward,'' said Robert P. Forrestal, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, Mr. Greenspan's host on a whirlwind trip to the South last week. Mr. Greenspan added on another occasion that at his current pace he would serve his four-year term in something like one year, eight months and 47 minutes. **********The 13th chairman of an institution created in 1913, Mr. Greenspan has not been given the luxury of a calm apprenticeship. Since taking over on Aug. 11, he has watched the trade deficit deteriorate and has had to respond to his first test by the markets. While some analysts question aspects of the discount-rate increase that followed, it is widely agreed that he has tackled his new job with uncommon vigor. He is said to be fascinated by the unveiling of monetary mysteries only dimly glimpsed in his years as a private economist. A Do-It-Yourself Type **********With all the activity of the first few weeks, the 61-year-old Mr. Greenspan recognizes that he might be overdoing it, and acquaintances say he is already looking a bit haggard. But he has decided not to appoint a personal assistant. **********For at least the foreseeable future, Mr. Greenspan will operate without such help, traditionally enjoyed by Fed chairman, because he has found that doing things himself helps him reach out to the Fed staff. **********In this, by all accounts within the Fed's white-marble headquarters not far from the Lincoln Memorial, Mr. Greenspan has had early success. Unlike Paul A. Volcker, his predecessor, who was described as often intimidating, Mr. Greenspan is said to be regularly going outside the chain of command to feed his voracious appetite for statistics and other information. Frequently, it is said, he has been stunned at the speed and comprehensiveness of the responses, his status notwithstanding. **********This, as President Kennedy learned by occasionally phoning relatively low-level analysts at the Central Intelligence Agency 25 years ago, can do wonders for staff morale. **********''There is an opening up of things, an openness to views that is refreshing around here,'' said Edward W. Kelley Jr., the newest governor of the seven-member Federal Reserve Board except for Mr. Greenspan himself. ''He wants to know what other people think.'' **********H. Robert Heller, another board member, said the new chairman has produced ''a very collegial atmosphere'' marked not just by dialogue but by ''multilogue.'' Mr. Heller appeared to harbor some misgivings about the decision to raise the discount rate - he was out of town that day and could not vote. Nevertheless, he gave Mr. Greenspan high marks for style. ''It's more of a board instead of just one man,'' Mr. Heller said. ''I find that very attractive.'' **********Martha R. Seger, the board member most critical of Mr. Volcker for his style, said she had been out of town for half of Mr. Greenspan's brief tenure and thought it too early to draw conclusions about him. Learning Journeys **********Mr. Greenspan's almost obsessive urge to learn every fact and meet every colleague took him, over the Labor Day weekend, to a meeting of the Bank for International Settlements - the central bankers' central bank - in Basel, Switzerland, and last week to Jacksonville, Fla., where he helped dedicate a new Fed branch building and participated in a joint meeting of regional directors. **********Mr. Forrestal, who noted that Mr. Greenspan could have ducked out early but did not, said the Southerners were impressed with Mr. Greenspan for making complicated monetary policy and regulatory issues understandable. **********A Fed spokesman, Joseph R. Coyne, said today that Mr. Greenspan had put high priority on visiting all 12 regional banks quickly. **********It has not been decided, however, just how visible Mr. Greenspan will be in public. His first major address, for which he is expected to write the first and last draft himself, is scheduled for Oct. 20 at the American Bankers Association convention in Dallas. Some See a Blind Spot **********Some analysts have suggested that Mr. Greenspan, who in his long career as a private consultant developed a perhaps unrivaled reputation for analysis of the ''real economy,'' is relatively unschooled in the financial markets. **********But those who have seen him in action said this is unfounded. One top Fed official, a protege of Mr. Volcker, declared that he sees in Mr. Greenspan, who had headed his own firm, Townsend-Greenspan & Company, since 1958, ''the same kind of sophistication that Volcker had.'' **********Indeed, some colleagues reported, whenever Mr. Greenspan has been out of touch even for an hour or two, his first question on return invariably is ''How are the markets?'' When he is in his office, they said, he frequently keeps up with market action on a computer screen. **********''What the Fed cannot do is work outside the functions of the market,'' he told an interviewer shortly before being tapped for the Fed in early June after Mr. Volcker resigned, reportedly when the Reagan Administration was lukewarm in its invitation to stay on. Mr. Greenspan thinks that the essence of the Fed's job is to study what markets do - not what market commentators say - and then separate those elements that are temporary and self-correcting from those that demand some policy response. A Key Early Decision **********Market analysts have varying views about both the motivation and timing of the Sept. 4 decision by the Fed to raise the discount rate by one-half point, to 6 percent, to head off what it called inflationary pressures. It was the first increase since April 1984. **********Some thought the move was Mr. Greenspan's unavoidable response to a direct challenge of the new man in the job by the currency and bond markets. Some thought it was a bit hasty - especially because Mr. Heller and Miss Seger, the two governors most inclined to oppose it -were out of town. Others thought a half-point too little. **********Stephen H. Axilrod, vice chairman at Nikko Securities Company International and the Fed's chief staff official on monetary policy from 1952 to 1986, said he regards the discount rate increase as ''a shot across the bow'' to demonstrate that the board remains as committed to fighting inflation as under Mr. Volcker. **********Allan Meltzer, a monetarist professor at Carnegie-Mellon University, called the increase ''a not very promising'' and misguided effort at short-term influence of the level of the dollar. **********Mr. Greenspan, a multimillionaire who was married briefly in his 20's, is paid the same $89,500 salary that Mr. Volcker received. He has moved into the Watergate complex, which is near the Fed headquarters, and is keeping his East Side apartment in Manhattan as well. **********These late-summer days, the goal is to get up to Federal Reserve speed as the new chairman marvels at the quantities of paper that he and his three secretaries must process and watches keenly as the secrets of monetary policy reveal themselves.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/08/world.body_text: **********When President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia recently abandoned stringent austerity measures drawn up by the International Monetary Fund, he fueled the wide-ranging debate over whether the fund's policies represent the best prescription for heavily indebted third world economies. **********At a time when many African countries are adopting I.M.F.-inspired measures, President Kaunda's decision also dramatized the perilous balancing act of developing nations that seek to heal their hemorrhaging economies while maintaining political stability. The decision also called into question the commitment of donor nations in supporting reform-minded governments. **********When Mr. Kaunda announced last month that Zambia was pulling out of its agreement with the I.M.F., many economists and others viewed the move as a decision based on political rather than economic realities, even though Zambia is one of the most politically stable countries in Africa. **********Under pressure from the monetary fund to reduce its $5.1 billion foreign debt, President Kaunda over the last few years undertook an economic austerity program that included major cuts in Government spending and measures to diversify the economy. **********Also included were the lifting of millions of dollars in subsidies for staple foods and the establishment of weekly foreign currency auctions that resulted in the kwacha, Zambia's currency, falling in value in less than two years from 2 to the United States dollar to about 21 to the dollar. Product of Austerity: Wide Complaints But many Zambians, who live in a country that once enjoyed the highest per capita income in black-ruled Africa, complained of soaring prices, widening labor unrest and a dramatic decline in living standards. Last December, after the Government stopped subsidizing corn meal and its price rose at least 100 percent, 15 people died in the fiercest urban violence since the country gained independence from Britain in 1964. **********Mr. Kaunda reluctantly reintroduced the subsidies, but, four months later, announced a 70 percent increase in fuel prices. The increase was canceled a day later amid signs of rising public dissatisfaction in a county where per capita income has fallen from $630 in 1981 to less than $200 today. **********On May 1, President Kaunda rejected the I.M.F.'s conditions for a new financing package of roughly $300 million, which was to be provided after Zambia paid off debts to the fund estimated at $230 million. **********Mr. Kaunda objected to what Zambian officials said were proposals to raise fertilizer and fuel prices, end food subsidies and peg interest rates to the country's 60 percent inflation rate. He instead announced a new economic policy based largely on tight state controls, which some economists viewed as a reintroduction of failed policies of the past. **********Mr. Kaunda ended the foreign currency auctions, establishing a new fixed rate of eight kwacha to the dollar. He also limited payments on the foreign debt, which had been eating up two-fifths of export earnings, to well under 10 percent of such earnings. **********Zambia's scant foreign exchange, Mr. Kaunda said, would be used for necessities such as gasoline, fertilizer and equipment for its vital copper industry. **********While Zambia's Government has blamed the I.M.F. prescription for many recent hardships, economists here say that the lessening of austerity measures could ultimately wreck the economy. Even without the fund, these economists say, Mr. Kaunda can only revamp his economy with strict measures that will no doubt prove unpopular with vast segments of the population. 'The I.M.F. Became Completely Unbearable' **********''It was our genuine desire to work with the I.M.F. and World Bank,'' Mr. Kaunda said, ''and we did so honestly, but it reached a stage where the programs headed by the I.M.F. became completely unbearable. **********''Zambia has not abandoned the restructuring program,'' he said. ''That program will continue, but not on the lines of the I.M.F., which were too demanding on the economy.'' **********The Zambian authorities have refused to grant visas to some foreign journalists, saying frankly that they did not want coverage of their economic crisis. But Zimbabwe-based Western and African diplomats, economists and bankers who are knowledgeable about Zambia's predicament say that it is a classic example of a third-world nation that, because of misguided policies of its own making as well as external economic forces beyond its control, finds itself in an economic quagmire. **********Like other developing economies that are based on exports of raw materials, Zambia's economy remains almost totally dependent on copper and, thus, on the fluctuations of world market prices. **********Copper still accounts for about 90 percent of the country's foreign exchange earnings, and it has steadily lost value during much of this decade. More foreboding for Zambia is that its copper deposits are expected to be virtually depleted by the turn of the century. **********While Zambia failed to diversify its economy or cut spending to compensate for the decline in world copper prices, the price of oil and other vital imports rose. The Government began to incur balance of payment deficits and was forced to borrow from the I.M.F. and other lenders, leading to a foreign debt it can no longer service. **********Some economists say there are few choices available to countries like Zambia that are sagging under the weight of mounting foreign debts, critical shortages of foreign exchange, a lack of capital for investment, chronic shortages of essential goods and spare parts and a dramatic decline in industry. **********These countries are viewed by some economists familiar with the I.M.F. policy as needing money that only the I.M.F. can provide. If the nations accept the fund's measures, economists say, they may face a dramatic drop in living standards and rising public dissatisfaction over the short term but could ultimately experience long-term growth and stability. If they reject reforms, these economists say, they doom themselves to open-ended misery. Kaunda's Action May Be to Buy Time I.M.F. officials have suggested that Mr. Kaunda is aware that he needs the cooperation of the I.M.F. and Western donors. They believe that his break with the fund may be a temporary move to allow his Government to regain popularity before next year's general elections. **********After the elections, Zambian officials reportedly hope to win more favorable terms on an I.M.F. financing package. But if Mr. Kaunda fails to return to the I.M.F., economists say, Zambia will probably continue to receive foreign aid for development projects but lose other sources of funds intended to adjust its balance of payments. **********Yet Western and African critics of the I.M.F. say that its policies conflict with long-term development. They argue that the application of traditional policies of financial austerity and economic liberalization, which demand major sacrifices, fail to bring about positive results and could lead to political chaos. **********These critics say the I.M.F. and Western donor nations want policies that doom third-world countries to low economic status in order to provide the industrialized world with cheap exports and labor and a ready market. **********For example, some economists critical of the fund say the fund urges developing nations to devalue their currency and open trade to international markets - actions, they say, that lock the countries into the continuing export of raw materials at cheap prices and prevent their generally weak national industries from competing with imports from the industrialized world. **********In the view of these critics, the I.M.F. is too inflexible. More realistic approaches are needed, the critics say, including measures that would stretch out payments on Africa's debt and allow the continent to begin sustained economic growth. **********''All of us, African governments, the international community and world markets, are to blame for the situations these countries find themselves in,'' said a Western economist based in this capital city. **********''These countries go to the I.M.F. when they are very sick and that sickness is derived from international and domestic reasons,'' the economist said. ''The I.M.F. has the money but it doesn't have a magic wand, and its mandate is the bottom line. How a country reaches the bottom line is not the fund's concern. Zambia is a perfect case. The Government and outside donors have to have the stamina - it won't happen with I.M.F. quick injections - to bring Zambia and other poor nations back.'' For I.M.F. Policies, Continent-Wide Sway More than 20 nations in sub-Saharan Africa have adopted bold I.M.F.-inspired policies intended to right their economies. All over this vast continent, from Ghana in West Africa to Tanzania in the east, governments are opening up their economies by cutting spending, increasing incentives for agricultural production, devaluing currencies and easing state controls. **********While it does not appear at this point that most will follow the lead of Zambia, economists say, these heavily indebted nations could suspend interest payments on their debts if the international economic climate remains unconducive to sustained growth. **********In addition, many African leaders willing to seek economic changes are under pressure from ideological factions and other groups that benefited from past policies and therefore have a vested interest in preserving them. **********Some economists and African leaders say donor nations have pressed for reforms without providing the resources needed to cover the period between the time a struggling nation begins a restructuring program and the policies begin to reap results. **********While donor nations have poured great amounts of aid into Africa over the years, these critics say, more money is needed to replace the money these countries spend on servicing debt and to insure that the restructuring succeeds. **********If more aid is not forthcoming, some African leaders suggest that the reform measures could set their governments on a collision course with their people. **********''I hope donors will step in and provide gifts or long-term assistance that the African governments need,'' said an economist who is familiar with I.M.F. policies. **********''The governments also have to have the courage to support and stand by their reforms,'' the economist said. ''Too often, African governments bite the bullet because there is no alternative. Their economies are in ruins and the only way they can get money from outside is to agree to conditions that they and their people have no commitment to.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/25/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: THE Boeing Company in Seattle received patents this week for a missile power source, a missile control device and a warhead. **********THE Boeing Company in Seattle received patents this week for a missile power source, a missile control device and a warhead. **********The power source is covered by patent 4,658,588 granted George T. Pinson of Huntsville, Ala. It uses high-pressure gas that is not released until the missile has been fired. When released, the gas can produce electrical, pneumatic or hydraulic power. **********Gas is also employed in the missile control actuator invented by Mr. Pinson and disclosed in patent 4,659,036. The gas is released to position the steering fins on the missile's surface. **********The warhead described in patent 4,658,727, granted Earl F. Wilhelm and Alan B. Zimmerschied of Renton, Wash., can be fired from a missile to aim fragments against an aircraft or another missile.
