https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/08/busin.body_text: **********AMERICANS are paying too much for their financial services. But America's commercial banks are willing, and able, to help lower prices by hundreds of millions of dollars by increasing competition. The missing ingredient is Congressional authority to give banks the capability to move into new markets that will strengthen our banking system. **********Modernization of banking laws is drawing opposition from many members of the securities industry who are using the current volatility of the financial markets to argue against change. But the real purpose behind the opposition is to protect their markets from needed competition. **********The case is clear. Now, more than ever, Congress must strengthen our financial system by reforming out-of-date banking laws, such as the 1933 Glass-Steagall Act. **********Because banks are governed by these old laws, we are not allowed to serve fully and equally. The result is that commerical banking is becoming a declining industry. In 1970, seven of the world's 25 largest banks had their headquarters in the United States. Today, there is only one. Even our largest and strongest banks are not given a competitive posture. **********What products and services do bankers want to offer? The answer is as varied as the communities banks serve. Some banks would like to buy and sell homes. Many banks want to offer mutual funds or underwrite certain securities products like municipal revenue bonds. Others would like to sell life insurance products. **********There are numerous legislative changes that Congress needs to make. The Glass-Steagall Act is just one example of an outmoded law that works to prevent full competition. What does the Glass-Steagall Act do? It insulates Wall Street firms from much-needed bank competition, resulting in a securities industry that is shockingly concentrated. For instance, the same five large securities firms control 95 percent of the commercial paper market, 81 percent of the mortgage-backed securities underwriting market and 72 percent of the corporate debt market. **********If Glass Steagall barriers are removed, banks will provide substantial savings. For example: **********State and local governments, and therefore the taxpayers, could save an estimated $500 million in borrowing costs, according to estimates based on National Governors Association figures, if banks were permitted to underwrite municipal revenue bonds. **********Homeowners could save thousands of dollars in home financing costs with bank entry into the mortgage- backed securities underwriting business, according to the National Association of Homebuilders. **********Business will enjoy lower underwriting spreads and overall funding costs by using bank-offered commercial paper. Further, banks are uniquely qualified to extend the benefits of commercial paper borrowing to smaller companies that are unlikely to have access to Wall Street. **********Small investors would increase their returns through bank-sponsored and distributed mutual funds. Not only would banks' ''no-load'' mutual funds insure that consumers would have more money working for them compared with the vast numbers of ''load'' funds, but bankers can offer expertise in managing unique equity portfolios. **********Lower costs and more services are part of the story but it is also important for the banking system to be safe and sound. For this to happen, banks must be permitted to offer a wider array of financial products to be competitive, maintain profitablity and raise capital. **********Not only will banks have the opportunity to diversify their revenue stream, but they'll have a fighting chance to recapture what were once their best corporate customers, many of whom left when the services they needed couldn't be found in a bank. **********SOME solutions have been generated outside of Washington. More than half the states have approved rules or legislation to give banks wider opportunities to compete in new service areas. Nevertheless, a national solution remains the best means to correct the competitive inequities that tie the hands of banks limiting consumer choices. **********Several proposals that would broaden competition while protecting bank deposits and capital against undue risks are now awaiting Congressional attention. **********Recently, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Comptroller of the Currency, and senior Administration officials offered Congress virtually identical approaches to permit banking institutions to compete by reforming the Glass-Steagall Act. Their testimony demonstrated that any concerns about risks to the deposit insurance system can be met by appropriate regulatory safeguards. **********Obviously, Congress will want to take a close look at the causes of the recent problems in the financial markets, but this should not be used as an excuse to avoid action on modernizing our banking laws, action that is long overdue. Indeed, the recent problems in the securities industry indicate to an even greater degree the need for the stabilizing influence that bank participation would provide. **********Congress has the ability to reverse the decline of the banking industry and insure consumers full competition in the financial services marketplace. In light of banking industry trends and current financial market conditions, continued inaction is the American economy's greatest risk.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/19/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT; AUSTRALIA'S 'LUCK' STARTS RUNNING OUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/19/busin.body_text: **********Once this was known as ''the lucky country,'' and Australians were confident their vast nation would prosper on its abundance of gold, oil, coal and other resources. But a parade of economic difficulties, including a foreign debt that is rapidly becoming one of the world's largest, has eroded that carefree optimism. **********Concern has been building for months, particularly since the plunge of the Australian dollar on currency markets last year, and the much-publicized warning in May by the Federal Treasurer, Paul Keating, that Australia risked becoming ''a banana republic.'' **********Prime Minister Bob Hawke added his own caution a few months later. ''The party's over, finito,'' Mr. Hawke declared, ''and Australians have to understand it, finito.'' **********John W. Howard, the leader of the opposition Liberal Party, said in a recent interview: ''The problems are structural, not cyclical. This is unlike any economic challenge we've faced since World War II.'' Australian Dollar Plunges **********Such bleak assessments are based on plunging commodity prices, a yawning trade deficit and the mounting foreign debt. Australians sometimes refer to the Australian dollar as ''the peso,'' because of its sharp fall over the last year. **********Most economists and bankers strongly doubt Australia's predicament will follow the path of Latin America, where a similar accumulation of debt and plunges in the values of local currencies helped spark a debt crisis in late 1982. But there is no doubt that Australia has suffered an economic decline. **********A century ago, Australia had perhaps the highest per capita income in the world. Today it ranks about 18th, and once-indigent neighbors in the Pacific are fast approaching its level. Singapore, for example, has a per capita income of about $7,000, compared with $10,000 in Australia. **********''It worries the hell out of me,'' said Peter E. Baume, a senior Senator of the opposition Liberal Party, of the rising foreign debt and general economic woes. ''It seems the economy is structurally unsound.'' Larger Debtor Than Argentina **********Australia's growing foreign debt is one of its most vexing problems. At last count, in June 1986, it stood at about $60 billion in United States dollars, up from about $18 billion in 1981. As a debtor, Australia ranks below Brazil and Mexico, each of which owes about $100 billion, but above Argentina, which owes about $50 billion. And Australia has just 16 million people, half of Argentina's population. **********As with the Latin debtors, the majority of Australia's debts are denominated in foreign currencies. In Australia's case, 65 percent of the loans are in United States dollars and another 20 percent in other foreign currencies, with only 15 percent in Australian dollars. **********That means a declining exchange rate makes it more difficult to repay those debts. **********Pessimists sometimes draw a comparison with Argentina, noting that both are resource-rich countries that primarily export minerals and agricultural products. Both protected their domestic producers and suffered rising debt levels and a falling currency. But there are substantial differences as well. Australia's foreign debt, unlike that of most of Latin America, is owed mostly by the private sector rather than the Government. Also, Australia has political stability and it possesses substantial foreign exchange reserves. Pessimism on the Near Term **********''Compared to the Argentinas and Bolivias of the world, Australia's debt is not serious today,'' said John H. K. Brunner, chief economist of Broken Hill Proprietary, a natural resources company that is Australia's largest concern. ''But tomorrow it becomes quite alarming.'' **********Mr. Brunner noted the amount of debt and the interest that must be paid on it are forecast to grow considerably in the next few decades. In the 1986 fiscal year, interest payments swallowed 17 percent of the foreign exchange earned from exports. **********Two American debt-rating agencies, Moody's and Standard & Poor's, recently downgraded Australia's credit rating, but its borrowing costs have barely risen - a sign of continued confidence in the ability of Australian borrowers to repay loans. **********But lenders are fickle, and borrowing could become more expensive if perceptions of the Australian situation worsen. ''You can't keep on increasing your debt without adjustments,'' said Martin Cooper, the managing director of Citibank Savings Ltd. in Sydney. ''Market forces will come to bear.'' Commodities Dominate Exports **********One of Australia's principal problems is that its economy in some respects resembles that of a developing country. More than 80 percent of exports are agricultural commodities, such as wheat or wool, or natural resources, such as oil or coal. The Government aims to lift the manufacturing share of total output to 19.5 percent in the next few years, from its current 17.8 percent level. **********But officials concede that the structure of the economy will remain much the same. Commodities will dominate, and commodity prices are very depressed. **********Prices of agricultural commodities, such as wheat and barley, have also fallen, partly because of trade skirmishes between the United States and the European Community. Australia says that in the present fiscal year, it will lose wheat and barley exports worth $675 million because of trade battles across the Atlantic. **********Donald Horne, a Sydney political scientist, says the problems of Australia's economy are derived from an overreliance on the bounty of the earth instead of on technology and ingenuity. That was why he chose, with considerable irony, the title ''The Lucky Country'' for his classic 1964 study of Australia. Professor Horne's purpose was misconstrued, however, and Australia soon acquired the nickname ''the lucky country.'' Corrective Actions Taken **********While Prime Minister Hawke and his Labor Party colleagues stress the severity of the difficulties that are testing Australia, they also add that important corrective actions have been taken. For example, the flotation of the Australian dollar led to its plunge on foreign exchange markets from $1.16 United States five years ago to 67 cents today. **********Against other currencies, the change is even more startling. A decade ago, the Australian dollar was worth 330 yen; today it is worth about 100 yen. The lower value of the currency should help Australia's balance of trade, making exports more competitive and imports more costly. **********There are already some signs of a turnaround, although economists are awaiting further data to be sure. **********The change in the exchange rate has also sparked a gold boom, particularly in Western Australia. Companies and individuals alike have caught the gold bug, as world gold prices, which are set in American dollars, soar in local currency terms. And there are plans to increase exports of Australian wine, cars, steel and other products. Tourism Is Up **********Meanwhile, tourism is enjoying a boom, as Japanese and Americans flock to Australia, attracted in part by reduced costs resulting from the fall in the exchange rate. **********There are indeed glimmers of better times on the horizon, but for now everyone predicts continued difficulties. Real wages are expected to fall again this year, after declining 5 to 6 percent during the last two years, according to Barry Hughes, an economic adviser to the Federal Treasurer. He expects overall economic growth in 1987 to be 2 percent, and even that will come only from a change in the trade accounts, rather than a gain in living standards. **********''It's going to be a long, hard slog,'' Mr. Hughes said. ''There's no alternative policy worth talking about.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/world.main_headline: From Democratic Leaders in Congress, Cautious Backing for the Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/world.print_headline: From Democratic Leaders in Congress, Cautious Backing for the Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/20/world.body_text: **********Democratic leaders of Congress, anxious to avoid a partisan confrontation over United States policy in the Persian Gulf, offered cautious support today for the strike against the Iranian oil rig. **********''We support what was done,'' Representative Jim Wright, the House Speaker, said at a news conference. ''It was necessary to demonstrate to the Iranians that they cannot willfully and at their whim attack American vessels.'' **********Mr. Wright, a Texas Democrat, was one of five Congressional leaders summoned to the White House Sunday night to be told of the impending attack. **********His Senate counterpart, Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, called the strike ''minimal and appropriate.'' 'Backing Into War' **********But in a statement issued by his office, the West Virginia Democrat said he was ''concerned that we may be backing into war with Iran.'' He added: ''I hope that the President will comply with the requirements of the law, the War Powers Act.'' **********The White House has said it will formally notify Congress of the action within 48 hours, the first step required by the War Powers Resolution. But the Administration does not view itself as bound by the rest of the 1973 law. **********Under the law, American military forces that are deployed in ''hostilities or into situations where imminent involvement in hostilities is clearly indicated'' must be withdrawn after 60 days unless Congress declares war or extends the deadline for 30 days more. **********Congress has been reluctant to invoke the law. Asked today whether he regarded the White House actions as adequate under the War Powers Resolution, Mr. Wright replied: ''I'm not going to get into a quarrel about that. When we face the world at a moment of crisis, we face it as one nation, indivisible, under God.'' **********Senators who believe that the War Powers Resolution was set in motion months ago, when the United States began providing re-registered Kuwaiti oil tankers with naval escorts, have failed repeatedly to get majority support for their efforts to invoke it. Voting on Tuesday **********The Senate will vote Tuesday on whether to cut off debate on the latest compromise measure, sponsored by Senator Byrd and Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia. That measure, which does not refer to the War Powers Resolution by name, would defer until January any vote relating to the policy in the gulf. **********The widespread belief among Democrats that the President was not justified in ignoring the War Powers Resolution appeared to be matched by an equally widespread belief that they had little to gain politically from provoking a confrontation over the issue. **********''The law is the law,'' Representative Dante B. Fascell, the Florida Democrat who heads the Foreign Affairs Committee, said at a news conference. He said Mr. Reagan was ''trying to skirt the entire issue, and I don't think that will be successful.'' **********Some members of Congress said complying with the War Powers Resolution would strengthen rather than weaken the President's ability to conduct policy in the Persian Gulf. 'An Enhanced Position' **********Senator John H. Glenn Jr., Democrat of Ohio, said he supported both the current policy in the gulf and a strict interpretation of the resolution. **********''Think what an enhanced position the President would be in with firm Congressional support, which I think he would get,'' Senator Glenn, a member of the Armed Services Committee, said at a news conference. **********Senator Byrd also implied that Congress, if given the opportunity to debate the matter under the War Powers Resolution, would not undercut Administration policy. **********After United States planes raided Libya in 1986, Congressional leaders complained that they had been consulted only after the operation began. Today Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said Administration aides ''certainly were sensitive'' to that criticism and added, ''We wanted to make it clear that we were consulting with them before the action took place.'' **********Members of Congress were equally sensitive to complaints that they had talked too freely after the raid on Libya, and they were inaccessible after meeting the President Sunday. **********At the meeting, Mr. Reagan, dressed in a casual warm-up suit and slippers, discussed his plans and asked for comments. He told the Congressional leaders that he would report to Congress within 48 hours as mandated by the War Powers Resolution. In response to a question by Senator Byrd, the President said the clock would start running when the attack began this morning. Won't Invoke Rest of Law **********But Mr. Reagan told the lawmakers that he would not invoke the provision of the resolution that could require him to remove forces. **********In recent weeks, the Administration has stressed that the military situation in the gulf does not fall under the definition of war contained in the resolution. But today White House officials shifted gears somewhat, emphasizing that Mr. Reagan considered the War Powers Resolution to be an unconstitutional infringement of Presidential prerogatives. The implication was that the President would not invoke the act under any circumstances. **********''We have decided, like all the Administrations before us since this law was passed, that it is not constitutional,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. ''It unfairly ties the hands of the President.'' **********Asked if the President felt free to ignore any law he deemed unconstitutional, before the courts had ruled on its validity, Mr. Fitzwater replied, ''We believe that we are obeying the law.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/busin.main_headline: U.S. PONDERS MOVE AGAINST JAPANESE ON COMPUTER CHIPS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/busin.print_headline: U.S. PONDERS MOVE AGAINST JAPANESE ON COMPUTER CHIPS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/23/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration appears to be on the verge of imposing sanctions against Japanese semiconductor manufacturers, according to Government officials, Congressional leaders and industry executives. **********The move could result in an acute worsening of the trade friction between the United States and Japan. **********Last week, the Commerce Department confirmed industry reports that many Japanese companies were continuing to sell computer chips below cost in developing countries. This practice, called dumping, hurts American chip manufacturers and violates a recent trade agreement between the United States and Japan. A Specter of Retaliation **********Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, was quoted by the Reuters news agency yesterday as saying the United States was ''very close'' to imposing a ''retaliatory kind of action'' against the Japanese over trade issues, including the dumping of semiconductors. Mr. Yeutter made the comment to reporters in New Zealand, where he was attending a meeting of trade ministers. **********The President's Economic Policy Council is to meet Wednesday to decide what sanctions, if any, should be imposed on the Japanese companies. An announcement is expected before the end of the month. Senate Adopts Resolution **********Last week, the Senate unanimously approved a resolution calling on the President to take retaliatory action against Japanese violators of the semiconductor pact as a necessary step to maintaining a healthy domestic semiconductor industry. The American industry is showing a modest recovery after a long slump. **********Senator Pete Wilson, Republican of California, said it was fairly clear that Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige would recommend sanctions, which could take the form of tariffs on chip imports as well as on electronic products containing the Japanese chips. Mr. Wilson was among a group of senators and industry representatives who met Friday with Mr. Baldrige to discuss what actions the Administration was considering. **********For their part, the Japanese insist that no dumping is going on. Despite this apparent contradiction, however, they concede that some lower-priced ''gray market'' chips are being sold in third countries. These chips were produced two or three years ago, Japanese chip makers say. **********Japanese Government officials apparently are planning to tighten controls over chip shipments to assure that the semiconductor agreement is honored. If Japan acts quickly enough, the new controls could undermine American efforts at retaliation, trade officials in Washington concede. **********The growing pressure for sanctions comes after Administration pressure forced Fujitsu Ltd., the giant Japanese electronics company, to drop its plan to buy the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, an American chip maker. **********''These things are always hard to call,'' said a former Commerce Department official who is familiar with the semiconductor agreement but asked not to be identified. ''But when you consider the protectionist sentiments brewing in Congress, the Fairchild-Fujitsu deal and the fact that the Japanese have consistently broken their promise on this, the Administration will probably whop them one to show that we mean business.'' Trade Group Asks Tariffs **********For months, the Semiconductor Industry Association, an American trade group that played a major role in negotiating the semiconductor agreement, has been pressing the Government for tariffs on products such as video cassette recorders, laser printers and computers containing the dumped chips. The trade group, based in San Jose, Calif., has insisted that the Government act by April 1. **********Under the agreement, reached last July, Washington agreed not to impose trade sanctions against Japanese chip makers in exchange for the Japanese Government's cooperation in enforcing fair-market prices and opening up the Japanese market to American producers. **********The Economic Policy Council, whose members include Secretary Baldrige, has two major options in making recommendations to the President. **********For one, the Administration could impose anti-dumping duties on imports of the computer chips, which are known as dynamic random access memory chips, or Drams, and erasable programmable read-only memory chips, or Eproms. Action Opposed by Industry **********But industry officials strongly oppose this because it would hurt large American companies that use the chips and might force them to move production facilities abroad to take advantage of lower prices. Industry analysts also say there is not enough American production of Drams to supplant the supply from Japan. **********A less protectionist action would be to impose sanctions against so-called value-added products such as laser printers and components for supercomputers that either contain the dumped chips or are produced by the Japanese semiconductor manufacturers found to be dumping them. **********''This seems like the most prudent thing to do because it gets them where it really hurts,'' said Andrew Kessler, an analyst with the Paine Webber brokerage house. **********Before the United States announces what action it will take, however, many industry officials expect Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry to present American trade officials with an anti-dumping plan that would convince them that tariffs on value-added products are not necessary. Steps Taken by Ministry **********Indeed, the Japanese agency acted last week to stem the tide toward sanctions. It summoned representatives of Japan's 10 leading semiconductor companies - including Fujitsu, Hitachi Ltd. and the NEC Corporation - and told them not to dump products in third countries and to step up purchases of American-made semiconductors. The ministry also produced its own evidence that Japanese chip makers were complying with the agreement. **********Nonetheless, American analysts say the trade ministry is working to shut off the flow of all Dram and Eprom chips to third countries such as Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan. **********The ministry now requires export licenses on shipments of semiconductors with a value of 50,000 yen, equal to about $330. Analysts say the ministry, to show it is exercising more control, has lowered that threshold to 5,000 yen, and requires all certificates to show not only the price paid for the chips but also the seller. **********These changes will cause extensive delays in the processing of applications for such licenses and the shipments of the chips. Because of these delays, analysts said, the abundance of low-price dumped chips in third countries would be reduced, causing prices to rise. Then the Japanese trade ministry would continue to monitor chips leaving Japan to make sure they were not being dumped, the analysts said. Plans for Controlling Flow **********A high-level Japanese trade official, who asked not to be named, confirmed last week that the ministry had such plans to control the flow of semiconductors to third countries. **********Adam Cuhney, a Kidder, Peabody analyst in San Francisco, said that if the ministry proposed such a plan to American trade officials, ''it would be hard for them to go ahead with any sanctions.'' **********He said, ''To attach a tariff under these circumstances seems to be an unlikely choice on the part of the Administration, because it would have such a great impact on so many U.S. customers that rely on products produced by the Japanese semiconductor manufacturers.'' **********While these actions would address the problem of dumping abroad, they do nothing about the semiconductor market in Japan itself, which remains closed to American producers. The industry group estimates that American chip makers have more than 50 percent of every semiconductor market in the world except for Japan. **********''The Japanese have to open their market if they plan to abide by the agreement,'' said George Scalise, senior vice president of Advanced Micro Devices Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., and head of the industry association's public policy committee. ''Quality control is no longer a question, and the U.S. industry has earned a right to enter that market.'' **********But analysts say that entrance is unlikely to happen unless Japan exercises tighter control over its companies.  YEUTTTER'S COMMENTS  TAUPO, New Zealand, March 22 (Reuters) - Washington's trade representative said today that the United States and Japan were on the brink of a serious conflict over trade. **********At one point, Mr. Yeutter used the term ''trade war'' in speaking to reporters, but backed off when questioned further at a reception on the eve of a two-day meeting of world trade ministers. **********Mr. Yeutter said the United States and the European Community had come ''very close to a trade war'' over the issue of who should supply cereals to Spain. **********''We are very close to that now with Japan, at least in terms of a potential retaliatory response by the United States over two or three controversial items,'' he said. **********Asked to repeat the phrase, Mr. Yeutter said, ''No, not trade war, but in terms of a potential retaliatory kind of action by the United States.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/18/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: A NEW CABINET DEPARTMENT WOULD HELP; Taming the Economic Policy Monster
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/18/busin.body_text: **********By ALICE M. RIVLIN; **********ECONOMIC policy making in Washington in the last decade has been more frustrating, muddled and confusing than necessary. Some of the fault lies with economists and economics; some with politicians and the political process; some in the interactions. I want to offer some suggestions for modest improvements. **********The main problem, it seems to me, is that our economic policy system has gradually become so complex, diffused and fragmented that it impedes rather than fosters informed choices on major issues. The fragmentation imposes two kinds of costs. **********First, it makes the decision process itself exceedingly inefficient. Decisions are made too often, in too great detail and reviewed by too many layers of decision makers in the executive and in Congress. Too much time is absorbed in procedure and in wrangling over details, not enough on major decisions. It is time to simplify the process, to weed out some of the institutions, and to tip the balance between substance and process back toward substance. **********Second, decisions are made separately that ought to be made together, or at least with attention to their impact on each other. The separation of monetary and fiscal policy is one example; the separation of tax and spending decisions is another. Congress has made a good deal of progress in recent years in putting spending decisions together with their revenue or deficit consequences, but more could be done. I have seven steps to suggest that might make the economic policy process work more effectively. **********First, seek out decisions that should be made less frequently and arrange to do so. This would economize decision-making time and enhance the chances of thoughtful, well-informed decisions. It would free up time and energy for managing the government enterprise more effectively, with a longer planning horizon. It would also reduce the inefficiency and sense of unfairness that goes with frequent changes of the rules. Making the Federal budget every other year would be a major advance. Major revisions of the tax code should occur even less frequently. Big ticket acquisitions, such as major weapons systems, should be reviewed thoroughly at infrequent intervals and then put on a steady efficient track, not constantly revisited. WITH a two-year budget, there would occasionally be major events, such as a sudden escalation of international tension or a sharp unexpected shift in the economic outlook, that would justify reopening the budget in midstream, but the temptation to tinker frequently should be strongly resisted. The argument that economists cannot forecast accurately two years in advance, while quite true, does not undermine the case for a multi-year budget. It simply reinforces the point that discretionary fiscal policy is hazardous and ought to be viewed with great skepticism whether the budget is annual or biennial. **********Second, seek out decisions that need not be made at all and stop making them. Some spending programs could be consolidated into block grants or devolved to the states, not necessarily in the interest of smaller government, but in the interest of greater responsiveness to local needs and a less cluttered Federal decision schedule. In other cases, the responsibility is clearly Federal - as in defense - but Congress would be more effective if it concentrated on major policy issues rather than on details of program management. **********Third, in the executive branch, consolidate authority for tax, budget and fiscal policy in a single Cabinet department. The department could retain the name Treasury, but might better be called the Department of Economic Affairs. The Secretary of Economic Affairs should have a high- level chief economist or economic council with a strong professional staff. The chief economist should work closely with the budget director, who also should report to the Secretary. The purpose would be to bring together economic decisions now made in the Office of Management and Budget, the Council of Economic Advisers and Treasury under one high-level responsible person, to relieve the President of the duty of adjudicating among so many potentially warring power centers, and to increase the chances of building a highly professional permanent economic staff one step removed from the short-run political concerns of the White House. **********Fourth, streamline the Congressional committee structure to reduce the number of steps in the budget process. The authorizing and appropriating functions should be combined in a single set of ''program committees,'' one for each major area of public spending. This would imply a single defense committee, for example, and a social insurance committee. The tax committees should handle the revenue side - not additional spending programs as at present. The budget committees would be charged with considering fiscal policy and putting the spending and revenue sides together into a budget to be passed by the whole congress. The Joint Economic Committee should celebrate the important contributions it made to economic understanding in the days before the budget process and then close up shop. **********Fifth, bring monetary and fiscal policy into the same conversation. This end could be furthered by closer formal links between the central bank and the Department of Economic Affairs to dramatize the need for consultation and interaction. The Federal Reserve chairman should make a report to the budget committees of Congress laying out recommended short- and longer-run economic goals for the nation and discussing combinations of monetary and fiscal strategies to achieve them. The Fed's report should be an important input to Congressional deliberations on fiscal policy. **********Sixth, strive for a Government-wide official economic forecast to be updated on a regular schedule. This would reduce the confusion generated by conflicting estimates and, by the increased interaction between the Department of Economic Affairs, the Congressional Budget Office and the Federal Reserve necessary to create such a forecast, would increase mutual understanding of what is happening to the economy and what the goals of policy should be. **********Finally, bring choices explicitly into the decision process, both in executive branch deliberations and, especially, in Congress. Those proposing spending increases or tax reductions should routinely be required to specify what is to be given up and to offer both the benefit and its cost as a package. In other words, proposals should be deficit neutral. **********The press and politicians often sound as if they are telling economists to work harder: go back to your computers and don't come out until you know how the economy really works and can give us reliable forecasts. But economists know that the economic system is incredibly complicated and that increasing global interdependence and rapidly changing technologies and public attitudes are not making it easier to understand. **********Like the medical profession, which also deals with an incredibly complex system, we economists just have to keep applying our imperfect knowledge as carefully as possible and learning from the results. Both doctors and economists need humility, but neither should abandon their patients to the quacks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/world.main_headline: Chemistry Professor Granted Permission to Leave Soviet
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/world.print_headline: Chemistry Professor Granted Permission to Leave Soviet
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/04/world.body_text: **********Irwin Cotler, a local lawyer, said today that Yuri Tarnopolsky, a Soviet chemistry professor and poet, hade been given permission to emigrate. **********Mr. Tarnopolsky was told Friday that he could leave with his wife and daughter, Mr. Cotler said. Mr. Tarnopolsky spent three years in a Siberian labor camp on charges of anti-Soviet agitation. **********He was released in March and allowed to return to his home in Kharkov. He originally applied for emigration in 1979.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/13/world.main_headline: DAY 2 FOR MCFARLANE: TRACING THE TRAIL OF HELP FOR THE CONTRAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/13/world.print_headline: DAY 2 FOR MCFARLANE: TRACING THE TRAIL OF HELP FOR THE CONTRAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/13/world.body_text: **********In his second day of testimony yesterday at the Congressional hearings in Washington, Robert C. McFarlane faced questions on the National Security Council's involvement with the contras and his understanding of the Boland Amendment. Here, as recorded by The New York Times, are excerpts from his testimony.  INOUYE STATEMENT  DANIEL K. INOUYE. Before we begin our testimony, I'd like to make the following announcement. We have located the $10 million contributed for the contras by the Sultan of Brunei, which was made in August 1986. **********And as all of us are aware, this was the last substantial donation to the contras unaccounted for until this morning. Our discovery was achieved in the following manner: **********Mr. Mark Belnick, the executive assistant to the chief counsel of the Senate committee, with the assistance of the State Department, obtained authorization from the Sultan of Brunei for the Senate committee to act on its behalf in locating the missing $10 million. **********Using this authorization, Mr. Belnick and Mr. John Cronin, one of the committee's senior accountants, pursued the investigation in this country and abroad. Mr. Cronin is presently in Switzerland obtaining the final details. **********What we know now is that the $10 million was transferred into the account of an individual at Credit Suisse, and that this individual withdrew the funds. The money was apparently transferred to this individual's account by mistake. **********We do not yet know whether this mistake was the result of Colonel North giving the wrong account number to Secretary Abrams or whether it resulted from another error during the transaction. Nor do we at present know the identity of the individual, but we have been assured that in about three hours we would know. **********We do know that the bank has filed criminal charges in Switzerland seeking the return of the money. As soon as Mr. Cronin returns from Switzerland, we intend to present the full story through him and Mr. Belnick at these hearings.  . . . **********I suppose the question before us is: Does the Senate Select Committee get a finder's fee?   QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS  RETURN TO COUNTRY 2  JOHN W. NIELDS Jr. Now, Mr. McFarlane, I take it you appeared before a number of Congressional committees, towards the end of last year, one of which was the House Foreign Affairs Committee?  A. That's correct.  Q. And that was, I believe, on Dec. 8, 1986?  A. Yes.  . . . **********Q. I'll ask you whether you were asked the following question and gave the following answer. At the bottom of page 65: ''Mr. McFarlane, I would like to try and understand, as we close, what role if any the National Security Council had in the solicitation of funds for the contras? Earlier this morning Secretary Shultz indicated that there had been success in soliciting and persuading at least one country to provide funding. And presumably it was intended for humanitarian purposes and presumably he was speaking about Brunei. **********''Did you or anyone working with you or for you at the National Security Council at any time make efforts at solicitation of other countries for contributions to the contras?'' **********Mr. McFarlane, this is your response, is it not? ''I did not solicit any country at any time to make contributions to the contras. I have seen the reports that various countries have'' - then there's a word deleted and that's Country 2, isn't it?  A. I don't know.  Q. Well, you can turn to the unredacted version. . . I will represent to you - and you may check it if you wish - that the word deleted there is Country 2. So I will read your answer: ''I did not solicit any country at any time to make contributions to the contras. I have seen the reports that various countries have - Country 2, third countries - and I have no idea of the extent of that or anything else.'' Did you make that answer?  A. Yes.  Q. Now, in fact, you did have a pretty good idea of Country 2's funding of the contras, didn't you?  A. Yes.  Q. In fact, as you've testified yesterday and today, you had a hand in obtaining contributions totaling approximately $32 million from Country 2?  A. Yes.  Q. But you did not tell that to the Foreign Affairs Committee at that time?  A. No. I was trying to use some tortured language - inappropriately, I think. But the comment that I did not know the extent: to be technically accurate, I did not, and do not today. But I take your point, Mr. Nields, it wasn't a full account.  . . .  'PROBLEMATIC' PAPERS  Q. I'd like . . to address the subject again of the contras and particularly the Congressional inquiries in the summer of 1985. I think you've already testified about them but I take it - would it be fair to say that in the summer of 1985 there were some news articles about the contras and the N.S.C.?  A. Yes.  Q. And the news articles were on the subject of where the contras's funding was coming from and whether the N.S.C. was giving them any support?  A. That's correct.  Q. I take it that you then received a letter or letters from several members of Congress and the Senate?  A. Yes sir, I did.  Q. And one of them was from Congressman Barnes?  A. Yes.  . . .  Q. And he states, indeed in the very first paragraph, I am writing in response to recent press reports. And he indicates that they're on the subject of the N.S.C. staff members providing advice and fund-raising support to the Nicaraguan resistance?  A. Yes.  Q. And he asks you to supply information on that subject and also documents. Is that correct?. . .  A. Yes.  Q. And I think you've testified that when you got the letter or learned that it had been received, you asked Mr. Thompson to pull the relevant documents?  A. I think probably Admiral Poindexter, but it was ultimately done by Brenda Rieger, the Freedom of Information Act professional, and given to Admiral Poindexter and in turn to Commander Thompson. . . .  Q. And Commander Thompson is a lawyer?  A. Yes sir. He's in the J.A.G. Corps of the Navy.  Q. And when you returned to Washington he gave you the documents that had been pulled?  A. That's correct.  Q. And told you that some of them were problematic?  A. Yes.  Q. And you, then, made a list of the ones that were problematic?  A. Well, I went through and read them all and had my own judgments about which were of concern and I did make a list of those, yes.  . . .  Q. And it lists six documents by the number in which they were filed in N.S.C. files?  A. Yes sir.  . . .  Q. And this is one of the ones. which you found to be problematical?  A. Yes.  Q. And this is a memorandum from North to you, I take it?  A. Yes.  Q. Dated March 5, 1985?  A. Yes sir.  A WISH LIST  Q. And so this is the second time that you were reading it. August of 1985 was the second time? . . .  A. Probably so.  Q. I take it what Mr. North is trying to do here is to reward a certain Central American country for assistance that it had provided to the contras in obtaining arms?  A. . . . Yes, for me to ask Cabinet officers and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs whether they thought Guatemala was deserving of foreign aid was a reasonable thing to do. On its merits it was worth endorsing. In March, when it came across, I don't recall having gotten, paying attention to it at all. When it came up in August, I do recall saying that this is just one more, kind of, example of hyperbole where innocent propositions are given a rather lurid kind of cast that was just not true.  . . .  Q. And he says so here . . . the real purpose of your memo is to find a way by which we can compensate the Central American country for the extraordinary assistance they are providing to the Nicaraguan freedom fighters?  A. Yes.  Q. Then he goes on to say . . . are end-user certificates which the Central American country provided for the purchase of nearly $8 million worth of munitions to be delivered to the F.D.N.?  A. Yes.  Q. And an end-user certificate, I take it, is a certificate that states the actual final user of munitions?  A. That's correct.  Q. And in this case, this Central American country was not the final user of the munitions?  A. Yes.  Q. So the end-user certificates were false?  A. That's right. . . .  Q. And I take it that North's purpose here is to reward the Central American country for having provided these false end-user certificates.  A. I think that's true. . . .  Q. . . . I take it it's fair to say that Mr. North was in touch with people from that Central American country?  A. Yes.  Q. And indeed he had obtained what he refers to in this memorandum as a wish list from that country?  A. Yes.  . . .  Q. O.K. The wish list is . . . a list of various kinds of military equipment that this country wants?  A. Yes.  Q. And North had obtained that wish list?  A. Yes.  . . .  AID AS REWARD  Q. And what he's writing to, he's asking you if you will make a recommendation to the Secretaries of Defense and State that this Central American country be rewarded?  A. No, I don't think that's quite accurate. He is asking that I ask them for their views on whether this country merits the aid, I believe.  Q. Well, I, it, he's asking you to send a memorandum which recommends that they be given some aid?  A. Yes. And I felt that way. I didn't feel that way because they were giving support to the contras alone, although, gosh, that certainly wouldn't disqualify them from aid.  Q. . . . And you did eventually send that memorandum?  A. Yes.  . . .  Q. And, ah, he says in his memo to you at the top of page 2, your memo does not refer to the arrangements which have been made for supporting the resistance, referring to the Nicaraguan resistance, I take it?  A. Yes.  Q. And, in fact, your memorandum did not make any such reference?  A. No.  . . .  'YOUR BEST SHOT'  Q. I'm going to switch back now to the subject we were on just before we broke for lunch, and this has to do with inquiries that were made of you by various committees of the House of Representatives concerning support of the contras. **********And you've indicated that this subject and episode are not perhaps your favorite, and it is not my intention unnecessarily to have you repeat testimony you gave yesterday, but this is a matter of concern to the House of Representatives which as - A. Listen, Mr. Nields, you're being terribly kind. And during the break, I had the misfortune to turn on the television whereupon a young woman was describing that I was a rather fragile flower that had to be catered to. That's nonsense. Shoot your best shot.  . . .  THE BOLAND ISSUE  RICHARD LEON. I believe we met once before. And by way of reintroduction, I'm the deputy chief minority counsel and this is the opportunity that I have on behalf of the minority to question you. . . . **********I believe you pointed out at the outset of your testimony that you told your aides at the N.S.C. very early on that they were not under any way, shape or form to violate the law. And the law, I believe, that you had in mind specifically when you directed them was the Boland amendment?  A. That's correct. . . .  Q. I believe Mr. Nields just had you point out that you testified this past December . . . upon the questioning of Congressman Cheney, that the Boland amendment applied to the N.S.C.?  A. Yes, that's correct. . . .  Q. Now, let me ask you a few questions with respect to your formation of that opinion, Mr. McFarlane. Because you've testified here today that you thought perhaps you'd been a little too categorical in some of your answers to Congress on other occasions . . . Let me ask you if perhaps your position as the applicability of the Boland amendment to the N.S.C. might also be a bit too categorical . . . You're not a lawyer, are you?  A. No, sir.  Q. And have you ever studied the Boland amendment from a Constitutional perspective?  A. No, sir.  . . .  Q. Was there anybody in your staff at the N.S.C. that you turned to at the time Boland had been adopted to give you a legal analysis of the Boland Amendment from the point of view of its applicability to the N.S.C.?  A. No.  . . .  Q. . . . Between that point in time and your leaving your post as N.S.C. director to the President, did you at any time request from the White House counsel a legal opinion, either in writing or orally, evaluating Boland's applicability to the N.S.C.?  A. No.  Q. Did you ever make a request of that nature to the Department of Justice, in specific its Office of Legal Counsel? . . .  A. No, I didn't.  Q. Are you aware that there are differences of opinion among legal scholars as to the applicability of the Boland amendment to the N.S.C.?  A. Yes.  Q. Have you ever heard those articulated?  A. Yes.  Q. O.K. And is it your position today that you disagree with the position of those who argue that it doesn't apply to the N.S.C.?  A. Mr. Leon, this is a very curious exchange. Now here you are trying to be helpful to me, I can see, but as a practical matter I just answered 20 questions in the negative. And the average viewer assumes that anybody who says no that many times in a row must be evil. Now, in fact, I -  Q. There's no intention to make you look evil, Mr. McFarlane.  A. No. I apologize; I don't mean to be silly. I was accepting that the law applied to the N.S.C. and that we must obey it. Because, I think, in good faith, when you deal with the Congress, you must reach conclusions based upon your own personal dialogue with people who have written the legislation. **********And even though it may not be perfect, if you know because you have been told by Dante Fascell: ''Goddam it, don't raise money'' - you better not raise money.  . . .  THE SECOND GIFT  Q. Now, as I recall your testimony, when you first learned of that country's decision to give more money, double its contribution from the prior year, when you first learned of that, you were the, my understanding of your testimony was you were the first to learn that. Is that correct?  A. That's likely, I think. Yes.  Q. O.K. Before accepting it from that country, in light of the risks that Boland might present, did you decide to find out from anybody in the Administration as to whether or not it should be accepted before first assessing the legal consequences of accepting it?  A. No. At the time, to me, it did seem to be a clear case of a voluntary chipping in or a donation by this party.  Q. So you didn't see any legal, you didn't perceive any legal problem with respect to accepting the gift at that time?  A. No I didn't.  . . .  Q. And you informed the President, with regard to that second gift, again, in writing in a note to his, to his book?  A. Yes, I believe so.  Q. . . . Was the reason why you informed him in that manner in any way because you were concerned about the legality of, of your conduct vis-a-vis that contribution?  A. Not at all. I informed him because I had no way of knowing whether he knew about it or not. I had no reason for knowing whether it came up in the conversation that he had had. And apparently there may have been some ambiguity in what I said yesterday on that score. **********I didn't intend to imply that in that meeting the President raised this issue with the head of state of the other government. I know for a fact he did not.  Q. O.K. And how is it that you know for a fact he did not?  A. Because I had occasion to check on this when I was asked about it six weeks ago during these investigative proceedings. And all I knew, or my basis for knowing, was the debrief that I got at the end of the meeting from the President in which he made no mention of this subject having come up. **********And so, based on that, my own opinion was he did not. But I didn't know whether there might have been something else in his diary and I was informed that there was by a senior White House official but that it had not been raised by the President.  . . .  ACTING AS A SHIELD  PAUL S. SARBANES. Would you say that generally speaking you had a greater respect for the Congress and the need to deal with it in a straightforward way?  A. Senator, I think that's totally self-serving. I think the Director was a man of greater loyalty to his President than anybody I've ever seen, and a man of considerable intellect and skill, and who has done enormous good for his agency and this country, and I think his qualities are not diminished by whatever I say.  . . .  Q. In all of this, who or what were you trying to shield, or protect?  A. Very likely myself, my reputation, my own record of performance.  Q. And only that?  A. Well, I believe, Senator Sarbanes, that President Reagan's motives and direction to his subordinates throughout this enterprise has always been in keeping with the law and national values. I don't think he is at fault here. And if anybody is, I am.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/27/world.main_headline: A President And Glasnost; His Speech on Soviet Reflects a Skepticism
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/27/world.print_headline: A President And Glasnost; His Speech on Soviet Reflects a Skepticism
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/27/world.body_text: **********President Reagan gave a speech without a punch line today - a speech that seemed to be building up to the disclosure of some important new initiative or development in relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, but wasn't. Mr. Reagan's review of **********East-West affairs was far more balanced than those he used to deliver on the subject four or even two years ago. But it reflected ingrained skepticism about the possibility of doing business with the Kremlin, even at a time when arms negiotiations seem to be going well and the new Soviet policy of glasnost, or openness, seems to some Western analysts to offer rich opportunities. **********''While talking about reforms at home, the Soviet Union has stepped up its efforts to impose a failed system on others,'' the President declared. But only a few sentences later he added: ''We are also seeing a new Soviet leadership that appears more willing to address the problems that have divided East and West so long and to seek agreements based on mutual benefit.'' **********Mr. Reagan made only a passing reference to this morning's statement by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, in which Mr. Kohl said that if Moscow and Washington reached an agreement on medium-range missiles, West Germany would dismantle its Pershing 1A missiles. Those weapons have been described by Soviet spokesmen as the principal impediment to a treaty on medium-range missiles, but the President called the issue an ''artificial obstacle'' that was ''without foundation.'' Meeting Not Mentioned **********Nor was there any mention of any early meeting between Mr. Reagan and the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Mr. Gorbachev has reportedly been considering attending the meeting of the United Nations General Assembly next month, and The Los Angeles Times, in a report later denied by the White House, said on Sunday that the two men would meet then. **********It appears that the Administration wants to see further progress at the Geneva arms-control talks before conceding that an agreement is near and before beginning to talk openly about the prospect of a Gorbachev visit, still widely anticipated in Washington, possibly late in November. **********Early this month, a senior Soviet arms negotiator, Aleksei A. Obukhov, said his country would consider a proposal under which the Pershings would be scrapped when obsolete. A Propaganda Victory **********Some Administration policy makers said, however, that they were puzzled and irritated by Mr. Kohl's move, because it appeared to undercut the adamant insistence of the United States that the Pershings were not and could not be part of the Geneva talks because they are not American weapons. Although the West German leader emphasized that agreement would have to be reached at Geneva before he would act, his statement appeared to hand the Russians a propaganda victory. **********Such victories have been coming thick and fast in recent months - so much so that Alton Frye of the Council on Foreign Relations recently compared Mr. Gorbachev to Machiavelli, saying, ''This man is scoring so many points in so many different arenas that it's hard to keep track of them.'' **********Mr. Reagan's entire speech, with its emphasis on the multifaceted relations between Moscow and Washington, appeared to constitute an attempt to regain the propaganda offensive. And in one passage, he overtly acknowledged the problems created by Soviet maneuvering and appealed for help. **********''I think it is vital that Western reporters and editors keep the real record of these negotiations in mind,'' the President said today. ''As soon as the Soviets realize that attempts to manipulate the media on these negotiations will not work, the better the chances are of treaty documents eventually getting signed.'' Official More Optimistic **********In a briefing in Los Angeles before Mr. Reagan spoke, a senior American official sounded a bit more optimistic than the President. He said, for example, that Mr. Gorbachev's steps seemed to suggest that ''he wants some kind of breathing space,'' and this ''does offer opportunities in the arms reduction field.'' The official spoke on the condition he not be named. **********Mr. Reagan, who built his public career as a strong anti-Communist, is said to have become convinced in the last year or so that arms-reduction agreements would earn him a place in history. But old habits die hard, and he began today with a theme that he has used for decades - the alleged perfidy of the Soviet Union in the years after the Yalta agreements. His words were gentler, but the armature of dislike and distrust remained intact. **********The new proposals in the speech were challenges, almost taunts, that no one in the Administration expects the Soviet Union to accept anytime soon. The President suggested to the Soviet leadership that it publish a valid military budget, reveal the size and composition of its armed forces and foster debate in the Supreme Soviet on the issues of military policy and weapons, three steps that not even glasnost is likely to bring about. **********Mr. Reagan acknowledged that ''there is hope'' in the changes in the Soviet Union, which he described, choosing a notably neutral adjective, as ''interesting.'' But he insisted on holding the Soviet leaders to the Western standards they have always rejected, asserting that ''real democracy,'' with elements such as ''orderly debate and meaningful votes,'' remains a distant prospect for the Soviet people.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/28/busin.main_headline: TWO IN JAPAN SEIZED OVER EXPORTS TO SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/28/busin.print_headline: TWO IN JAPAN SEIZED OVER EXPORTS TO SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/28/busin.body_text: **********Two senior executives of a top Japanese machine tool maker were arrested today after being accused of illegally exporting high-technology equipment to the Soviet Union, the police said. **********The executives, Ryuzo Hayashi, 52 years old, a director of the Toshiba Machine Company, and Hiroaki Tanimura, 50, a deputy director, were arrested while being questioned at police headquarters here. **********They are accused of exporting high-technology machine tools capable of making submarine propellers almost silent. The shipments were made between December 1982 and June 1983, the police said. The Government has imposed a one-year ban on any further shipments of goods by the company to Communist countries. **********The machine tools are subject to an export ban by the Paris-based Coordinating Committee for Export Control, which monitors exports of strategic goods to Communist countries. False Statements Reported **********The authorities said that the Ministry of International Trade and Industry had approved the exports after Toshiba gave false statements about the capability of the equipment. **********Toward the end of 1983, Mr. Hayashi and others in the company who were not named had improved cutter heads and other parts made on order from the Soviet Union. The items were shipped from Yokohama on June 20, 1984, without ministry approval, the police added. **********They also modified a computer program manual necessary for operation of the parts and asked an employee of another company to carry the manual in his baggage on a flight to the Soviet Union 10 days later, the police said. The police said the second company and the individual knew nothing about the contents. **********Those arrested also failed to get ministry approval to export the manual, the police said. **********The Toshiba Corporation, Japan's second-largest electric machinery maker, has a 50 percent stake in Toshiba Machine.

Ritter, a company vice president, said. **********''Under the circumstances, we don't feel it is appropriate'' to comment further. **********The company said that it had filled two of the vacancies. Jim Hunter was promoted to vice president of sales and Paul J. Morrissey was named vice president of national accounts. **********Anheuser-Busch said last week that it had completed a 15-week investigation into allegations that payments had been made to some executives by Hanley Worldwide Inc., a St. Louis advertising agency that had worked for Busch.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/07/busin.body_text: **********The broadest measure of Japan's trade surplus fell 21 percent in October from its level of a year earlier, shrunken by the effect of the strong yen, the Finance Ministry said Friday. **********Japan's current account surplus fell from its 1986 level for the sixth consecutive month, dropping to $6.55 billion in October from $8.25 billion a year earlier and $8.38 billion in September. **********The current account measures trade in merchandise and services as well as such transfers as investment income. The numbers are not adjusted to account for seasonal fluctuations. **********The strong yen shrinks Japan's trade surplus by making its exports more expensive and imports cheaper. After allowing the yen to rise against the dollar and other currencies, Japanese authorities have lately been trying to halt the increase, fearing a recessionary impact on the economy. **********Exports grew 6.6 percent from a year earlier, sustained by continued demand for such products as computers and business machines, while imports surged 22.7 percent, as both categories hit records.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/world.main_headline: DOWNFALL OF NAKASONE? IT COULD BE A TAX PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/world.print_headline: DOWNFALL OF NAKASONE? IT COULD BE A TAX PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/world.body_text: **********This rice-growing center in northern Japan is an unlikely place to start a revolt. But if Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone is forced into early retirement, as seems increasingly possible, Morioka and the rest of Iwate Prefecture is where his downward slide began. **********Around the country, Japanese speak of ''Iwate shock,'' a phrase symbolizing the strong, widening opposition to the Prime Minister's plans for a new 5 percent sales tax. Antitax sentiment is so powerful that in local election campaigns that began nationwide today, candidates from Mr. Nakasone's Liberal-Democratic Party are looking nervously over their shoulders to see if the opposition is gaining. Iwate set the tone. Liberal Democrats are not supposed to lose in this conservative alcove of northern Honshu. But on March 8 the party's candidate, Rei Isurugi, failed to succeed her late husband in a special election for Parliament's upper house. **********Mrs. Isurugi did not just lose; she was humiliated. The Socialist candidate, Jinichi Ogawa, won by an unthinkable margin of more than 2 to 1. Tax Plan Is Blamed **********In Morioka, the Nakasone tax plan was immediately blamed. ''The process of creating this tax was arrogant,'' said Tokusuke Kawamura, president of the Chamber of Commerce. **********Since the ''Iwate shock,'' the Prime Minister's political standing has steadily plunged, raising questions about whether he can hang on to his office until his scheduled departure in October. **********''Voter consciousness has changed,'' said Eiichi Sakashita, a Socialist Party strategist in Morioka. ''There's a feeling that they can affect national policy - that they have more control.'' **********Now another campaign has begun, and with it another test for the Prime Minister. This is for local elections to be held simultaneously across Japan on April 12. From early this morning, candidates for Iwate's municipal assemblies rode blaring sound trucks through the rice fields, still brown before the start of the spring planting season. Offsetting Reductions Dangled **********For sure, they talked about local issues, like controversial plans for a new highway. But right behind loomed the tax. **********To make his plan more palatable, the Prime Minister has dangled offsetting reductions in personal and corporate income taxes. No one talks about the cuts, though. Only the tax increases get attention - in Washington as well as here. **********On Thursday, the United States Trade Representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, expressed unhappiness with the Nakasone program on the ground that taxes undercut American wishes for Japan to stimulate its economy. Mr. Yeutter's comments were attacked today by senior Japanese officials, some of whom accused him of interfering in a domestic matter. **********But Mr. Nakasone has displeased people closer to home as well, and in Iwate even fellow Liberal Democrats have abandoned him. **********Just before special election last month, the local party placed an advertisement praising the sales tax in the Iwate Nippo newspaper. Four days after Mrs. Isurugi's defeat, it took out another advertisement, a full-page screamer in huge type that listed five reasons why the tax was a bad idea. 'Voters Seem to Understand' **********''We had to respond sincerely and quickly to voters' attitudes,'' said Masaru Sato, an official in the re-election campaign of the two-term prefectural Governor, Tadashi Nakamura. ''Voters seem to understand us now.'' That brought a polite hoot from Mr. Sakashita, the Socialist official. ''I have a good feeling about this race, more than I ever have,'' he said. **********The tax issue has made an invisible man of Mr. Nakasone. With the Prime Minister's ratings in opinon polls at a record low, Liberal Democrats across Japan have asked him to stay out of their districts during the campaign. **********At Socialist headquarters in Morioka, walls are plastered with posters of the gubernatorial candidate, Setsuro Takahashi, and also of the party's national chairman, Takako Doi, who has campaigned here twice and refers to the Prime Minister as ''Mr. Tax Hiker.'' In Liberal Democratic offices, Mr. Nakasone's picture is nowhere to be seen. Complexity Is a Problem **********A big problem for many Japanese is the complexity of the tax program. There are 51 categories of exemptions, including food and beverages, but details can be puzzling. **********Tickets for traditional Kabuki theater would not be taxed, but performances of rakugo, a venerable story-telling art, would be. Since medical care is excluded, a person can be born tax-free at Morioka's Red Cross Hospital. The same cannot be said for when he finally needs the services of the Fujisawa Funeral Home. **********The tax, intended to bring in $40 billion a year, would affect only 13 percent of Japan's businesses - those with annual revenue of more than 100 million yen, or about $685,000. But those big companies enjoy a disproportionately large share of total sales, and they will pass along the tax to small retailers and consumers. **********Political analysts predict that Mr. Nakasone will eventually get his way, but he will probably first have to modify the tax or delay its effective date. On Thursday, Mr. Nakasone himself hinted as much in Tokyo. **********Meanwhile, Morioka forecasters say that normalcy will return and that the incumbent Governor, Mr. Nakamura, will win again. But no one seems willing to bet on it, and, a newspaper editor said, ''If Nakamura does lose, Nakasone may have no choice but to step down right away.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/world.main_headline: ABRAMS TODAY: WHAT TO LOOK FOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/world.print_headline: ABRAMS TODAY: WHAT TO LOOK FOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/world.body_text: **********Friends of Elliott Abrams, the State Department's combative Assistant Secretary for Inter-American Affairs, say he has an unusual zest for a good argument. **********Those skills are likely to put to the sternest test of Mr. Abrams's State Department career when he appears Tuesday before the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair. **********Members of the committees say they are preparing to ask Mr. Abrams sharp questions about whether he misled Congress, the Tower Commission and the American people over the Reagan Administration's links to a private aid network for the Nicaraguan rebels - and his own. **********Mr. Abrams has insisted since one of the supply planes was shot down last October that he had only a vague idea that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the former White House aide, was involved in the secret aid effort. Today, aides to Mr. Abrams said he plans to stand by that assertion when he testifies under oath. Whether He Lied **********Government investigators have said that Lawrence E. Walsh, the special prosecutor, is already studying previous Congressional testimony by Mr. Abrams to determine whether he lied to Congress or took part in a conspiracy to violate Federal laws. **********Mr. Abrams, 39 years old, is one of the most active defenders of the contra program. Trained as a lawyer, he was named to the senior post on Central America policy in 1985, the third person to hold the position under President Reagan. **********Administration officials say his two predecessors, Thomas Enders, and Langhorne Motley, left because they were too willing to take seriously the Administration's stated ''two track'' policy of both pressuring the Sandinistas and negotiating with them. **********No one has ever made that complaint about Mr. Abrams. Indeed, one issue likely to be raised in the hearings is his zeal for defending the contras, even in the face of more skeptical analyses by the State Department's own Bureau of Intelligence and Research. Name Keeps Coming Up **********Mr. Abrams's name has been mentioned by several witnesses before the committee. Joe Fernandez, the former C.I.A. station chief in Costa Rica who has been identified by the pseudonym Tomas Castillo, said Mr. Abrams was one of the few Government officials who knew about the secret airstrip being built in Costa Rica. **********Lewis Tambs, the former Ambassador to Costa Rica, said he believed his contacts with contras were approved by the Restricted Inter-Agency Group, or R.I.G., that was chaired by Mr. Abrams. Gen. John Singlaub, a retired officer who worked with the contras, said Mr. Abrams encouraged him 1986 when he set out to solicit money for the contras from countries in Asia. **********Moreover, Administration officials say that Colonel North and Mr. Abrams were ideological soulmates who maintained a close personal and working relationship and they wonder how it could be possible that Mr. Abrams did not know about the contra aid network. **********Yet, that is exactly what Mr. Abrams has contended from Oct. 5, the date when a cargo plane carrying the American crewman Eugene Hasenfus was shot down over Nicaragua. As reports appeared in the press suggesting that the Administration had helped organize the supply mission, Mr. Abrams grew irate, and even called senior editors at newspapers asking that his response be printed. He Calls Enterprise Private **********In one interview arising from this effort, he told a reporter that the supply operations were completely private, declaring, ''People are entitled to believe the Government is constantly lying to them, but it isn't.'' **********Testimony before the Iran-contra committees has since demonstrated that American Government officials, including Colonel North and officers in the Central Intelligence Agency were directly involved in the supply network.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/06/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation acquired the American Motors Corporation this afternoon, hours after A.M.C.'s shareholders approved the merger. **********The demise of the smallest of the four American-owned auto manufacturers represented the first consolidation in the domestic industry since 1954, when A.M.C. was created by a merger of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation and the Hudson Motor Car Company. **********Chrysler's cost for the deal, including the assumption of debts, has been estimated at $1.5 billion. Two last-minute lawsuits were filed by shareholders who wanted more than the $4.50 a share that Chrysler offered. But Joseph E. Cappy, the president and chief executive of A.M.C., said that courts would probably reject them. Chrysler Post for Cappy **********Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of Chrysler, announced that Mr. Cappy would join Chrysler as a group vice president for marketing of the Jeep and Eagle, the nameplate that will be applied to A.M.C.'s non-Jeep lines. **********He also said that Francois J. Castaing, formerly a group vice president for A.M.C., would become vice president in charge of engineering of Jeeps and Dodge trucks, and that John P. Tierney, chief financial officer of A.M.C., would be chairman of Chrysler Financial. Mr. Castaing had joined A.M.C. through Renault, which owned a 46.1 percent stake in A.M.C. **********Renault, under pressure in Europe, agreed in March to sell its stake for $200 million in notes and debentures. **********Mr. Cappy said of the merger, ''We're sad about it also, because we would have liked to bring it all the way back, with three straight black quarters.'' After years of losses, A.M.C. registered profits in late 1986 and in the first half of this year. **********Mr. Iacocca said, ''We aren't just combining our strengths, we're increasing them.'' Analysts agreed that A.M.C.'s products would complement Chrysler's lines. **********Chrysler's share of the American car-and-truck market last month came to 11.7 percent. Mr. Iacocca has contended that Chrysler's financial muscle could expand A.M.C.'s 1.5 percent share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/24/world.print_headline: MARINE CORPS CUTS PERIOD GUARDS STAY AT MANY EMBASSIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/24/world.body_text: **********The Marine Corps has shortened to one year the tour of duty for embassy guards in countries such as the Soviet Union where they are considered subject to compromise by foreign agents, the Pentagon said today. **********The chief Pentagon spokesman, Robert Sims, said today that the 15-month tours were shortened because the loneliness and boredom of guard duty had presented ''an obvious opportunity for hostile intelligence to work on our people.'' **********Two marines who worked in the Soviet Union as guards have been charged with espionage for reportedly allowing Soviet agents to enter the American Embassy in Moscow while they stood guard in 1985 and 1986 after becoming sexually involved with a Soviet woman employed at the embassy. Another marine has been arrested on suspicion of espionage in Leningrad in 1981 and 1982, and a fourth, Staff Sgt. Robert S. Stufflebeam, has been charged with violating security regulations by meeting secretly with Soviet women. **********The Marine Corps is carrying out several changes in the way the guards are selected, trained, assigned and supervised, in an effort to prevent similar breaches of security. An investigation has produced evidence suggesting that intelligence agents may have sought to compromise Marine guards in several Eastern bloc countries. **********The Marine Corps shortened the tour for guards in the Soviet Union, the Warsaw Pact countries, China, Lebanon, Nicaragua, and Afghanistan. The marines selected for the posts are always young unmarried men. **********The detachment commanders, who are senior noncommissioned officers and do not stand guard duty, will continue to serve 18-month tours in those countries. **********Other countries have long sought to limit the potential for such breaches of security. A Western European official said today that West German guards are assigned to Moscow for only six months, while the Netherlands posts its guards there for only two months before reassigning them. **********All 28 Marine guards in Moscow are being replaced as a precaution, as are the six guards in Leningrad. The newly assigned marines in Moscow will be supervised by an officer for the time being, the Pentagon has said.
