https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/19/busin.main_headline: Malaysia Opposes Labels on Palm Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/19/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT; Malaysia Opposes Labels on Palm Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/19/busin.body_text: **********The Government of Malaysia has begun a campaign to convince American consumers and politicians that edible palm oil is not a proven health hazard. **********The move comes as the American Congress considers bills that would require the oil to be identified and labeled as a saturated fat in the United States. **********Consumers watching their fat intake generally avoid saturated fats and instead choose unsaturated fats. Cholesterol and Heart Attacks **********Malaysia, which produces about 60 percent of the world's palm oil, regards the Tropical Oils Labeling Bills - which also cover palm kernel oil and coconut oil - as largely an effort by the American Soybean Association, also a producer of edible seed oils, to block competition. **********In the United States, the Center for Science in the Public Interest and other consumer and health groups have also called for the specific labeling of the three tropical oils as saturated fats. **********Saturated fats - which, like butter, are usually solid at room temperature - are important in raising blood cholesterol levels. Unsaturated fats found in most vegetable oils, which are liquid at room temperature, help to lower blood cholesterol. High cholesterol levels in the blood can cause heart attacks and strokes. **********Concerns about the dangers of high cholesterol have been growing. Earlier this month, the American Government and more than 20 health groups issued the nation's first guidelines for identifying and treating people with high blood cholesterol levels. The action could affect more than 40 million people in the United States. 'Fat Fighter' Kits **********In this environment, the Soybean Association has mounted a vigorous advertising campaign against tropical oils. ''Fat fighter'' kits distributed by the association show a portly planter on his veranda and coconuts labeled with health-warnings. Diplomats here describe the association's campaign as crude and clearly aimed against the tropical developing countries. The advertisements provoked a demonstration at the United States Embassy here last month. **********About 13 percent of Malaysia's 16 million people make their livelihood from palm oil, one of more than a dozen edible oilseeds used worldwide. Others are soybean, cottonseed, corn, peanut, sunflower, rapeseed, sesame, olive, linseed, castor bean, coconut and palm kernel. Palm oil and rubber, both plantation crops, cover more than half of Malaysia's arable land and bring in a fifth of the country's non-petroleum export earnings. **********Malaysia, a rapidly developing Southeast Asian nation, hopes to expand its sales of palm oil outside the region as prices begin to rise after a 1986 slump. Most of the exported oil becomes a food additive, used in such products as nondairy creamers. **********Although only about 4 percent of Malaysian exports go to the United States, officials here are aware that American food labeling has a worldwide impact, affecting sales in other countries. The Malaysian Message **********A Malaysian team of experts, headed by Augustine Ong, director general of the country's Palm Oil Research Institute, is now in the United States in an attempt to demonstrate that American health fears about palm oil are based on outdated or incomplete evidence. The delegation also hopes to persuade American researchers to conduct more tests on the oil-palm fruit. Malaysia has limited money for such work. **********The Malaysian message for Americans is that palm oil is ''cholesterol-free'' and has not been conclusively proved to behave like a saturated fat in humans. European research is used to support this claim. **********Malaysian Government officials and diplomats here said that recent testimony in Washington by an official of the Food and Drug Adminstration bolstered their arguments. On Sept. 11, Richard J. Ronk, acting director of the F.D.A.'s Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition, told a House subcommittee that more research was needed on the effects that several major fats and oils in the American diet have on blood cholesterol. According to a transcript of his comments before the Agriculture subcommittee on wheat, soybeans and feedgrains, he also said that tropical oils cannot be classified together because their actions are distinctly different. **********Athough the Malaysians acknowledge that palm oil, extracted from the fleshy fruit of the tree, is a saturated fat - with a 50 percent content -they contend it is not comparable to palm kernel oil, extracted from the nut of the same fruit, which has an 86 percent saturated fat content; or coconut oil, with a fat content of 92 percent. Claims and Counterclaims **********The Palm Oil Research Institute here also holds that the oil palm fruit is a source of carotene and vitamin E, and may in fact reduce blood clotting that can lead to strokes. **********Experts in Malaysia - and the Philippines, a leading coconut oil producer - say they question why heart disease is not unusually high in their countries, where these oils are regularly consumed in larger quantities than in the buyer nations. **********An American Soybean Association position paper, ''Domestic Oils Vs. Tropical Fats'' takes issue with these claims. **********The association contends that palm oil contains four times the cholesterol-producing saturated fat as soybean oil. It also argues that European research showing that palm oil does not elevate blood cholesterol has been discredited. It says that the carotene content of palm oil is destroyed in refining. Changes in the Law **********The Tropical Oils Labeling Bills now before Congress would amend the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act in the following ways: *********** ''Disjunctive'' labeling of tropical oils would be prohibited. It is now permissible for a manufacturer to say that a product ''may contain one of the following,'' and then list a number of fats. *********** The words ''a saturated fat'' would be required to follow palm, palm kernel or coconut oil in a list of ingredients. *********** Foods using tropical oils would be required to have labels identifying them as ''saturated fats'' and list the fat and saturated fat contents per serving. **********The Malaysians have apparently received some support from the Reagan Administration. **********Melvin Searls, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce for East Asia and the Pacific, said recently that the Administration believes the proposals to label palm oil as a saturated fat ''are not desirable from a trade standpoint.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/12/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: DESPITE - or perhaps because of - the fact that the stock market has started edging toward its high-water mark again, many investors who burned their fingers in the increasingly risky ''trading market'' of recent months are turning their attention to secondary issues. **********DESPITE - or perhaps because of - the fact that the stock market has started edging toward its high-water mark again, many investors who burned their fingers in the increasingly risky ''trading market'' of recent months are turning their attention to secondary issues. **********One reason is the stock market's volatility, especially in the blue chips with big institutional followings. Individual stocks can run up or fall 2, 3 even 6 points a day, driven by institutional money managers, who tend to run in packs, and by computer-generated program trading related to arbitrage. **********So, some money managers argue that stock investors who were singed in the first-half market should eschew large-capitalization issues, such as International Business Machines or General Motors, and should instead try to find ''special situations'' in the second half. *** **********''We see the latter half of 1987 as a seesaw market, with the long-awaited move toward small-cap companies finally becoming a reality,'' said Bruce Huber, director of research at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. in Minneapolis. **********There is, of course, no assurance that smaller companies will outperform their bigger brethren. Many such companies are regional niche players, which fill specific needs or sectors of the economy. **********This caveat aside, and also taking into account the fact that investment advisers and research departments are paid to come up with ''special situations'' - and reasons for buying them - here are secondary stocks chosen by four advisory firms: *********** The Society Corporation: Richard Schmidt, director of research for Advest Inc. in Hartford, says that this bank holding company based in Cleveland has been making acquisitions and restructuring for two years. The stock, which trades over the counter, is going for $33.50 a share. Martha G. Locke, the Advest analyst in Boston, who follows Society, said the bank had restructured to absorb its biggest acquisition - and one-time Ohio competitor bank - the Centram Corporation. Society now has $9 billion in assets, $6.9 billion in deposits and branches in Cleveland, Columbus, Dayton, Akron and Cincinnati. In addition to ''a high-quality loan portfolio'' of $5.3 billion, Ms. Locke noted, Society has a conservative management. ''If they err in anything,'' she said, ''it is in possibly being too conservative.'' If Society succeeds in new marketing programs, she added, ''just modest growth in loans should translate into higher income because of strict cost controls.'' Ms. Locke is predicting that Society will earn $3.75 a share for 1987 and $4.14 in 1988 as the bank builds market share and increases lending activity. It earned $3.43 a share in 1986. *********** La Petite Academy: Mr. Huber of Piper, Jaffray said that this large operator of day care centers in 27 states, mostly in the South, Southwest and West, traditionally posts its strongest earnings in the second half. The company, which closed at $17.25 in over-the-counter trading yesterday, earned 48 cents a share in 1986. Saul Yaari, who follows La Petite for Piper, said he expects the company to earn 65 cents this year and 85 cents in 1988. The stock does carry a lofty price-earnings ratio, he acknowledged, but he said its growth rate would justify it. La Petite now has about 550 centers and 50,000 children enrolled. Mr. Yaari said the increasing movement of mothers into the work force, combined with rising insurance costs that will drive ''Mom and Pop and neighborhood'' centers out of the business, will work to La Petite's advantage. And touching on a sensitive subject in the industry, Mr. Yaari said that La Petite's approach of having large, open rooms for its children ''reduces the chance for abuse.'' *** ***********Chambers Development: Thomas Bailey of the Janus Fund in Denver noted that this waste management concern, which owns a landfill in Pennsylvania, recently signed a $50 million contract to handle waste from Passaic County in New Jersey. ''There is a real capacity shortage in the landfill business, especially in the Northeast,'' Mr. Bailey said, adding that he expects Chambers to earn $1 a share in 1987 and $1.75 in 1988. In 1986 the company earned 59 cents a share. Chambers closed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange at $35.75. *********** Circus Circus Enterprises: Roger Engemann, chairman of the Pasedena Growth Fund in California, expects this casino company to earn $1.50 a share in 1988 and $1.88 in 1989. In its latest fiscal year, which ended Jan. 31, the company earned $1 a share. Circus Circus owns five casinos (three of which are tied to hotels) in Las Vegas, Reno and Laughlin, Nev. It also owns the Colorado Belle, a new hotel-casino complex that is scheduled to be operating soon, and its 1,200 additional rooms, Mr. Engemann says, should bolster earnings. Circus Circus closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $29.125 a share. **********Another caveat: Being small, and less well capitalized, such companies might be hard put to maintain their positions in the face of sudden, or unexpected, competition. In addition, as small companies, they might not be able to withstand a severe recession as well as larger companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/15/world.main_headline: MAN SAID TO TAX EARTH'S SYSTEMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/15/world.print_headline: MAN SAID TO TAX EARTH'S SYSTEMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/15/world.body_text: **********The pressures of population growth and economic expansion are starting to exceed the ability of the earth's natural systems to sustain such activity, a new report by the Worldwatch Institute warned today. **********In its report, ''State of the World 1987,'' the Washington-based research group said human use of the air, water, land, forests and other systems that support life on earth were pushing those systems over ''thresholds'' beyond which they cannot absorb such use without permanent change and damage. **********The result has been declining food and fuel production in many parts of the world and, for the world as a whole, contamination of the atmosphere, climatic change, a mass extinction of plant and animal species and the long-term prospect of a decline in the quality of life, the report said. **********''Many of these threshold crossings, which are making the earth less habitable for future generations, are taking society by surprise,'' said Lester R. Brown, president of the institute and director of the study. Three Critical Areas **********''The most threatening globally are the depletion of the ozone layer, climate change and the loss of biological diversity,'' Mr. Brown said. **********The report said that ''so many natural systems becoming unstable within such a short period of time'' could result in economic and political pressures that ''could overwhelm the capacity of governments and individuals to adjust adequately.'' **********The report cited Central America as an area where high population growth, deforestation, soil erosion and high energy costs have led to political instability and social disintegration. **********It said ''a frustrating paradox is emerging'' from global efforts to achieve economic growth. ''Efforts to improve living standards,'' the report asserted, ''are themselves beginning to threaten the health of the global economy. The very notion of progress begs for redefinition in light of the intolerable consequences as a result of its pursuit.'' **********''A sustainable society satisfies its needs without diminishing the prospects of the next generation,'' the report said, adding, ''By many measures, contemporary society fails to meet this criterion.'' Damage From Fossil Fuels **********The report noted that much of the world's economic growth over the last century has been based on the burning of fossil fuels such as coal and oil. But that activity, it asserted, was changing the atmosphere to the point where the global climate was expected to shift drastically in the next century, requiring vast adjustments in agriculture and other activities that will cost billions of dollars. **********The report also said that although overall world agricultural production has been growing, it has been declining in many countries, particularly in Africa, because of soil erosion and the spread of deserts. Even in the United States, fully a sixth of the grain harvest comes from eroding lands or draws on diminishing sources of ground water for irrigation, and so cannot be sustained over the long run, according to the report. **********The destruction of forests, in addition to accelerating the extinction of species, is having a heavy impact on underdeveloped countries such as India that depend on firewood for fuel, the report went on. **********The report also addresses the future of nuclear energy in the wake of the explosion and fire last year at the Chernobyl power plant in the Soviet Union. The report concluded that the accident was pushing many countries to gradually phase out plans to rely heavily on nuclear power for future energy needs - a path some nations had embarked on even before the Chernobyl disaster. **********It also said that the world was becoming divided along demographic lines, with the developed countries having stabilized population growth and most of the underdeveloped nations moving toward explosive expansion. **********Mr. Brown said that the instability caused by many of these trends in areas such as Central America and Africa was of major political significance to the United States. **********The report said the time has come for political leaders at the highest levels to address these problems. ''The course corrections needed to restore a worldwide improvement in the human condition have no precedent,'' it said. **********It added: ''No generation has ever faced such a complex set of issues requiring immediate attention. Preceding generations have always been concerned about the future, but we are the first to be faced with decisions that will determine whether the earth our children inherit will be inhabitable.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/12/busin.body_text: **********Egypt announced a limited reform of its multitiered currency exchange rate today in the hope of satisfying International Monetary Fund requirements for assistance in repaying its $38.6 billion foreign debt. **********The long-awaited move effectively floats a portion of Egypt's currency dealings to the unofficial, but tolerated, street rate. A rotating committee of eight Egyptian banks is to meet daily to determine the going rate, seeking to curb speculation and bring hard currency into official channels. **********Although the official rate for most transactions had been set at 1.35 Egyptian pounds to the dollar, street-corner Pepsi-Cola stands and other informal exchanges were giving 2.15 pounds at the end of last week, before curtailing transactions to see what the change would be. **********The new rate was set by the committee this evening at 2.16. A Condition of Assistance **********Reform of the exchange rates was one of several economic measures called for by the I.M.F. as a condition for granting Egypt standby credits of $300 million. **********Dr. Yusri Mustafa, the Minister of Economy and Foreign Trade, said the new rate would apply to remittances from Egyptians working abroad, which is Egypt's leading source of hard currency. It would also apply to tourism revenue, commercial banks' purchases of foreign currency and some export revenue. **********He added that the new rate would also apply to some imports ''of the type that would not cause too heavy a burden on the consumers.'' **********An official Government bookkeeping rate of 0.70 pound to the dollar will also be maintained, along with the central bank rate of 1.35 for many transactions. In addition, it appeared likely that the street, or black-market, rate would rise somewhat higher than the new rates because of the demand by private businessmen and others for scarce hard currency. 'Unification Will Be Gradual' **********''The new system is the start of setting up a free foreign-exchange market, but unification will be gradual so as not to upset the social balance,'' Dr. Mustafa said. ''We shall be watching the market daily and monthly and act accordingly.'' **********He told a news conference that a fully unified exchange rate would take ''maybe a year, maybe more.'' **********The new rate is expected to affect about 40 percent of official bank transactions, but given the extensive use of the street market, those are a relatively small percentage of all currency transactions here. **********The I.M.F. executive board is to meet in Washington on Friday to approve Egypt's arrangements, and the so-called Paris Club of Western creditor nations is to meet three days later to consider the rescheduling of Egypt's foreign debts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/21/busin.main_headline: Toys 'R' Us Prospers As Holiday Sales Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/21/busin.print_headline: Toys 'R' Us Prospers As Holiday Sales Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/21/busin.body_text: **********Ida and Joseph Gabay may forgo a vacation and otherwise scrimp because of the money they lost when the stock market plunged. But the Gabays have no intention of playing Scrooge when it comes to their grandchildren. **********''What can I do with my four grandchildren but buy them all nice gifts?'' Mrs. Gabay said as she shopped at the Toys ''R'' Us store here recently. **********That seemed to be a widely shared sentiment among the holiday shoppers who filled the Valley Stream store - one of 313 that Toys ''R'' Us Inc. has in the United States. Whether they were worried about the economy, the beating they took in the stock market or their union's pay concessions, not one of the dozen shoppers interviewed was cutting back on toy purchases. Sales Appear Strong **********Of course, toys are historically the last items to be scratched off the holiday shopping list during times of trouble or uncertainty. **********Indeed, predictions that toy sales would decline are now giving way to forecasts of increases, albeit modest ones. Frank Reysen, editor of Playthings, a monthly publication for the toy industry, expects retail toy sales for all of 1987 to be about 3 to 5 percent higher than last year. **********For Toys ''R'' Us, the nation's largest toy seller, this determination to buy, buy, buy comes as especially good news. **********Toys ''R'' Us now has more than 20 percent of the market, up from 17 percent a year ago, according to Cathleen Mackey, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. Wall Street analysts expect the chain to record sales of about $2.24 billion this year, a 30 percent increase from 1986. Its earnings will jump at least 25 percent from its 1986 net of $152 million, they predict. 'The Place Explodes' **********At the 46,000-square-foot store in Valley Stream, eager shoppers were lined up one recent morning even before it opened at 8 o'clock, and continued to flow in until midnight, when it closed. **********''The place explodes,'' said Brian Ehlin, the director of the Valley Stream store. **********Although manufacturers have introduced some new products in recent weeks (including Coleco Industries' Couch Potato and Talking Cabbage Patch doll and Fisher-Price's camera-video recorder), this year has been exceptional for the dearth of exciting new toys. There are no hot new items comparable to the Trivial Pursuit of the 1984 season, the Cabbage Patch of 1985 and G.I. Joe, Lazer Tag and Barbie doll of 1986. **********''Producers did not invest much in new product development this year because of a so-so 1986 and retailer cautiousness in the early months of this year,'' said Mr. Reysen, the editor of Playthings. A Wide Selection **********But rather than hurting Toys ''R'' Us, the lack of superstar toys seems to help it. If consumers are unsure of what they want to buy, they are more likely to go to a Toys ''R'' Us store because of its wide selection, analysts said. **********''The absence of hot items plays into our hands,'' said Charles Lazarus, the chain's chairman and chief executive. **********According to Toys ''R'' Us data, video game machines are extremely popular this year. Two of the biggest sellers are the Nintendo full entertainment system at $139.99 and the Sega system at $99.99. **********Other high-demand items include Big Bird Story Magic, three talking and movie figures that cost $134.99; Couch Potato, a brown stuffed face and head used as a pillow ($28.99); speaking versions of the Cabbage Patch doll ($89.99), and radio- or remote-control cars, trucks and construction vehicles that go for as much as $200. Prices Are Up **********Toys ''R'' Us is using a new electronic-scanning cash register system to keep track of what is selling and to reduce checkout lines. The computerized system, which has been installed in 95 percent of the toy stores, has enabled the chain to increase its checkout speed by more than 30 percent, according to Michael Goldstein, the company's executive vice president and chief financial officer. **********At the Valley Stream store, some customers said that prices this year seemed to be up about 10 percent from 1986. But even higher prices were not causing these consumers to trim their spending plans or to take their business elsewhere. **********''I know that things are overpriced, including toys, but I don't have time to shop anywhere else,'' said Lorraine James of Brooklyn, who was shopping with her 13-year old daughter, Sabrinya. **********William Lee, a bus driver from Ridgewood, Queens, who was in the store with his wife, Elizabeth, added, ''Prices are up but it isn't stopping us from buying what we want.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Sematech Gets $250 Million Budget
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/13/busin.body_text: **********The organizers of Sematech, the consortium of semiconductor companies acting to improve chip manufacturing technologies, said yesterday that a $250 million-a-year budget for the effort had been approved. **********Under the business plan, Sematech would raise about half of the funds from the industry and seek the rest from Federal and state governments. Various bills now in Congress call for giving the consortium between $25 million and $100 million a year. **********Sematech would employ about 800 people when it is in operation, said George Scalise, an official of Advanced Micro Devices Inc., which has been involved in the effort. He said the search for a chief executive and a chief operating officer would begin immediately, and he predicted that both would be hired by September, when a manufacturing site is to be announced. **********The first semiconductors - intended chiefly to test advanced manufacturing technologies -are to be produced in the second half of 1988.

[ D8. ] Sears, Roebuck's net income jumped 47.4 percent. Its retailing and insurance units posted strong gains, but the biggest turnaround involved Dean Witter. Such mutual deterrence needs to be reinforced, in both the economic and military spheres, by accords to enhance stability. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/14/world.main_headline: COLOMBIA ENVOY, A DRUG FOE, IS SHOT IN BUDAPEST
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/14/world.print_headline: COLOMBIA ENVOY, A DRUG FOE, IS SHOT IN BUDAPEST
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/14/world.body_text: **********A former Justice Minister who until recently headed Colombia's anti-drug campaign was shot and seriously wounded today in Budapest in an apparent extension of the country's drug war into Eastern Europe. **********The official, Enrique Parejo Gonzalez, the Ambassador to Hungary, had been assigned to a diplomatic post in a Soviet-bloc country last August in the apparent belief that he would be beyond the reach of Colombian narcotics traffickers who had repeatedly threatened his life. **********The Foreign Ministry here said Mr. Parejo, a 56-year-old lawyer, was shot three times as he left his home this morning by an unidentified gunman who first asked him in Spanish whether he was Colombia's Ambassador. It later said he was in ''satisfactory'' condition after the removal of two bullets from his head. **********The police refused to give further information, and no arrests were reported. **********The assassination attempt against Mr. Parejo, whose predecessor as Justice Minister was killed on orders of cocaine traffickers in April 1984, appeared to confirm a dramatic new escalation in Colombia's drug war. **********This afternoon, the local office of Agence France-Presse said it received a call from a so-called Hernan Botero Moreno Command, which claimed to have shot ''the traitor Parejo'' on behalf of those whose extradition is being sought by the United States. **********Only last month, President Virgilio Barco Vargas ordered a new offensive against the multibillion-dollar narcotics trade after the slaying here of Guillermo Cano Isaza, who was the publisher of El Espectador, Bogota's second largest newspaper, and a strong critic of drug operators. **********Since then, the authorities say army and police units have carried out 1,198 raids and arrested 783 suspects, including three who are on a list of 113 reported traffickers whose extradition has been requested by the United States. None of the half-dozen biggest traffickers, however, has been caught. **********As part of the new offensive and in apparent response to death threats against civilian judges involved in drug cases, the Government has authorized military tribunals to try people charged with drug-related crimes. **********Although the country's former President, Belisario Betancur, declared war against narcotics early in 1984, Colombian operators still supply about 80 percent of the world's cocaine and continue to control much of the distribution network inside the United States. **********As the Colombian authorities have increased their pressure on the cocaine underworld, however, drug-related violence here has increased, with some 30 judges, 20 journalists and numerous police all killed in the aftermath of the killing of Justice Minister Rodrigo Lara Bonilla in 1984. **********But on two occasions, leading traffickers also offered to repatriate several billion dollars to help pay off the country's foreign debt if the Government would renounce Colombia's 1979 extradition treaty with the United States, under which 13 Colombians have already been sent for trial in the United States. **********When the Betancur Government refused to revoke the treaty, the traffickers reportedly focused their threats and offers of bribes on the country's Supreme Court, which reviews all extradition requests. **********In his new post as Justice Minister, Mr. Parejo nonetheless continued to work closely with United States drug enforcement authorities. Having faced numerous threats against his life, he left Colombia for his post in Budapest on Aug. 8. **********Diplomats here said that, while Mr. Barco had promised to continue President Betancur's anti-drug drive, this did not appear to be one of his priorities during his first three months in office. **********Early December, however, in what some political commentators saw as a victory for narcotics traffickers, the Supreme Court declared the extradition treaty with the United States to be unconstitutional since it had not been signed by the President. **********On Dec. 14, Mr. Barco signed the treaty, which immediately went back into effect.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/08/busin.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl today rejected complaints that his country was not doing enough to spur the world's economy and warned against a ''trend toward protectionism'' in the United States Congress. **********American officials have said repeatedly in recent months that West Germany, one of the world's richest nations, should adopt policies to increase domestic spending in order to help lift worldwide economic growth. **********West Germany ''has gone as far as it can without seriously endangering growth at home,'' Mr. Kohl told a meeting of West German bankers. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/17/busin.body_text: **********Prices at the producer level climbed three-tenths of 1 percent in September as higher prices for food and automobiles more than offset a sizable decline in energy costs, the Labor Department reported today. **********Although the moderate increase in the Producer Price Index for finished goods followed a month in which there was no change, economists considered the report somewhat reassuring. The September figure was about what was expected, and, unlike the Government trade report released on Wednesday, seemed to have little effect on the battered financial markets. **********''I think it supports the view that we are not in the early stages of a sustained acceleration of inflation,'' said Robert L. Marks, president of Siff, Oakley & Marks Inc., a New York consulting firm. He said he expects inflation in the prices received by domestic producers of goods to continue at a rate of about 3.5 percent a year. **********Today's report also showed that inflation at the intermediate stage of production rose just one-tenth of 1 percent last month and that prices of crude goods fell nine-tenths of 1 percent. Both these results were the most favorable since December. Some Concern Remains **********Some analysts, however, said they were somewhat disturbed by a surge in prices for finished goods when the volatile food and energy components are excluded. This widely watched special grouping jumped six-tenths of 1 percent last month, compared with three-tenths in August and two-tenths in July. **********Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., said much of this increase seemed to reflect the Labor Department's problem, common in September, of adjusting motor vehicle prices for end-of-model-year liquidation allowances and other factory-financed sales incentives. This year, these incentives were lower than usual. **********As a result, the price of passenger cars jumped 3.6 percent last month after declining 1.8 percent in August. **********Nonetheless, Mr. Harris said that reports by corporate purchasing agents and anecdotal evidence suggested that prices might be rising ''a bit faster'' than the statistics showed and that some producers might be buying raw materials in anticipation of further price increases. **********The three-tenths of 1 percent increase in the finished goods index, often referred to as the P.P.I., represented no substantial acceleration in prices from the average of the first eight months of the year. Food Prices Up 1.1% **********Consumer food prices climbed 1.1 percent in September after falling 1.3 percent in August. Prices rose for fresh fruits and vegetables; pork, beef and veal; eggs and dairy products, and shortening and cooking oil. Processed poultry and roasted coffee prices turned down and the price of fish fell much less than in August, according to the report. **********On the other hand, the price of finished energy goods dropped 3.7 percent after rising 1.5 percent in both July and August. Gasoline was down 6.4 percent while fuel oil was down 11.4 percent. Natural gas prices, however, edged up after two months of decline. **********Prices received by producers of capital equipment spurted seven-tenths of 1 percent, led by increases for heavy trucks and machine tools. **********Among goods at the intermediate stage of production, energy products fell 2 percent, but materials for nondurable manufacturing reversed to an increase of six-tenths of 1 percent. The rate of increase accelerated for paperboard, wood pulp and paper. Precious Metals Down **********Materials for durable manufacturing continued to rise substantially, though the seven-tenths of 1 percent increase was a bit less than in July and August. Prices fell for copper, zinc and precious metals. **********Construction materials recorded a big increase - eight-tenths of 1 percent - for the third straight month, the Labor Department said. **********As for crude goods, which fell for the first time since December, petroleum dropped 5.1 percent and nonfood materials fell 1.8 percent after a rise of six-tenths of 1 percent in August. The price of corn jumped 13.3 percent, the biggest monthly increase in four years, following three straight declines. **********But the price of live chickens fell 18.1 percent, reversing an August increase of similar size. **********The department also reported that the index for the net output of the domestic manufacturing sector eased three-tenths of 1 percent after several months of moderate rises.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/busin.main_headline: FARM EXPORT WEAPON VOTED BY SENATE PANEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/busin.print_headline: FARM EXPORT WEAPON VOTED BY SENATE PANEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/15/busin.body_text: **********The Senate Agriculture Committee today approved a huge export-subsidy program for American farmers that would take effect in 1990 if other food-exporting nations failed to reduce or eliminate their agricultural subsidies. **********The measure, to become part of the omnibus trade bill that the Senate will vote on next month, cleared the panel just one day after an international economic organization, meeting in Paris, called for the dismantling of farm subsidies and the liberalization of agricultural trade. **********The Senate legislation, initiated by two powerful farm state senators, Lloyd M. Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, and John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, amounts to an ultimatum: Either end subsidies worldwide, or the United States will apply them with a vengeance. **********Backers maintain that the American farmer wins either way: If subsidies persist abroad, the legislation would nullify their effects; in a subsidy-free environment, American agriculture, acknowledged to be highly productive, should thrive. **********Initial foreign comment was guarded. ''I can't see it doing world markets much good,'' said Derwent Renshaw, the agricultural counselor at the European Community office here. ''But 1990 is a long way down the road.'' **********Farmers blame foreign subsidies at least in part for the decline in farm exports of $16 billion, or 37 percent, during the last six years - a major factor behind depressed conditions in the farm belt. **********The United States, which for decades complained about export subsidies by the European Community and others, began subsidizing exports of rice, cotton and occasional sales of other commodities in the mid-1980's in response to farm belt pressures. **********The new program would affect the biggest export crops: wheat, feed grains and soybeans. Through a system of marketing loans applied to these crops, farmers would be able to sell them at depressed world market prices and still maintain or even enhance their income. **********''We've bargained long enough for no results,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who is chairman of the Agriculture Committee. ''It's time to send our negotiators to the table with some real leverage to back up our rhetoric.'' **********Marketing loans for rice and cotton were put into effect under the 1985 farm bill and have already created large increases in the exports of these commodities. **********But competing exporters have loudly complained. Thailand, for example, has registered strong protests with the State Department over the subsidized rice sales, which cost the United States Government $1 billion a year and benefit 20,000 American rice growers. There are several million rice growers in Thailand. **********Under the American program farmers sell rice at the current world market price of $3.50 for 100 pounds and collect an additional $8.40 from the Government, bringing their total payment to $11.90, which is the American loan rate, or support price. **********The Reagan Administration has not yet taken a position on the new measure. Administration officials acknowledged that the measure might be useful in negotiations on economic and trade matters, but questioned whether the United States would want to carry out the threat. **********''This would go against what we're preaching'' in the agricultural subsidy talks, one senior trade official said. ''It could also bust the budget.'' **********The legislation would create automatic marketing loan programs for wheat, feed grains and soybeans starting in 1990 unless the President determines that ''significant progress'' is being made in the talks. **********At the Paris meeting Wednesday of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, 24 member governments agreed to ''a progressive reduction of assistance to and protection of agriculture.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/31/busin.body_text: **********The Hadson Corporation, a natural gas distributor, said it planned to merge with Ultrasystems Inc., a developer of cogeneration plants, in a stock deal valued at about $86.9 million. Hadson, based in Oklahoma City, would issue 2.2 shares of its stock in exchange for each of 7.9 million outstanding shares of Ultrasystems, based in Irvine, Calif. Hadson stock closed at $5, up 50 cents, in over-the-counter trading. Ultrasystems shares closed at $8.75, up $2.875, on the American Stock Exchange. **********The blended companies would employ about 1,400 people and would have combined revenues of nearly $550 million in 1987. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/24/world.body_text: **********Soviet and Government troops have killed or wounded more than 1,500 Afghan guerrillas in the first two days of a drive to lift the siege of Khost, a major garrison city southeast of Kabul, the Kremlin said today. **********Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, gave a report on the offensive that began Monday. It was thought to be the first official briefing on war operations in the eight years since Soviet troops intervened in Afghanistan. **********An estimated 115,000 Soviet soldiers are in Afghanistan helping the Communist Government fight Moslem rebels. **********Mr. Gerasimov read a statement on the battle during a regular news briefing for Soviet and foreign journalists. The spokesman brushed aside questions about Soviet and Afghan losses in the offensive. **********Insurgents surrounded the city last spring and halted all supply deliveries, Mr. Gerasimov said. He added that Afghan civilians in or near Khost were starving because of the siege. **********He said the rebels had used American-made Stinger missiles to shoot down several AN-26 transport aircraft in recent months, forcing the Khost airport to close. Supplies and arms for the defenders had been brought in by air.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/25/busin.body_text: **********GLEN W. FORTENBERRY'S Ross Roy Inc. of Detroit has acquired another New York agency. This time it is DiIorio, Wergeles, specialists in product introduction and product repositioning. **********The acquired agency, with 1987 billings estimated at $25 million, will put the parent company into the $500 million arena. **********DiIorio, Wergeles, founded in 1974 by a pair from the deGarmo agency, will continue to operate under its own name and under the direction of its founders, Donald S. Wergeles, the 50-year-old chairman, and Julio DiIorio, 46, president and creative director. **********They will be reporting to Ronald K. Sherman, president of Calet, Hirsch & Spector, New York, which Mr. Fortenberry acquired in January last year. That deal was the fourth acquisition in a year's time, but there had not been another until now. **********When Mr. Fortenberry joined the company in 1980 from J. Walter Thompson, where his executive posts included head of the Detroit office, Ross Roy was billing only about $178 million. The most recent Advertising Age listing puts Ross Roy in 26th place among American agencies with a reported $416 million in billings and $62.4 million in gross revenues. **********Mr. Fortenberry declined to disclose details of the acquisition but did imply that both cash and stock were involved. **********DiIorio, Wergeles has about 20 employees, who work for such clients as Kraft; Quaker Oats, and Laird & Company, a Scobeyville, N.J., distiller. Certainly you've heard of Laird's Apple Jack. **********The agency also repositioned Budget Gourmet, a feat that Marketing & Media Decisions magazine called the most outstanding food marketing success of 1984. **********According to the agency's own statement, it believes that ''every product be positioned like a new product: no myths, no baggage, no assumptions.'' **********''The philosophy,'' the agency says, ''adds rigor and discipline to our work, resulting in innovative marketing and, importantly, fresh, breakthrough creative.'' **********In addition to Detroit and New York, Ross Roy has operating units in Cleveland, Chicago and Toronto.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/21/busin.body_text: **********The Rockwell International Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in its fiscal first quarter, ended Dec. 31, rose 18.8 percent on a 3.6 increase in sales. Rockwell, a major aerospace company based in Pittsburgh, attributed the profit rise mainly to its B-1B bomber program. **********Net income for the latest three months grew to $149.4 million, or $1.05 a share, from $125.8 million, or 84 cents a share, a year before. Sales rose to $2.87 billion from $2.77 billion. **********Rockwell said its backlog fell 26.2 percent, to $10.7 billion on Dec. 31, from $14.5 billion 12 months earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/30/busin.body_text: **********Americans, reassured by the financial markets' steadier performance during November, have not changed their minds about the economy, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll. **********But the poll also found that a sizable number of consumers were going to be more cautious about Christmas spending this year, suggesting that fears might be growing about the economic impact of the stock market collapse last month. This weekend, however, some major retail chains reported sales up considerably as the holiday shopping season began. **********Half of 1,553 respondents polled from Nov. 20 to Nov. 24 said the current condition of the economy was fairly good. Four percent described it as very good, 29 percent as fairly bad and 15 percent as very bad. Asked to look to the future, 41 percent said the economy was getting worse, 11 percent said it was getting better and 46 percent said conditions would be stable. Earlier Responses Noted **********The figures are almost identical to those recorded in a New York Times poll taken three weeks earlier in the wake of Wall Street's mid-October nosedive. These responses suggest that Americans have seen nothing in the past few weeks to change their views about the economy, but their answers to several other questions may give retailers and others who rely on consumer confidence reason to worry. **********Although 30 percent of the respondents said their household financial condition was getting better while 18 percent said it was getting worse, just 17 percent said they planned to spend more on Christmas gifts this year and 32 percent said they would cut back. **********The margin of sampling error in the poll is plus or minus 3 percentage points. Virtually No Link to Turmoil **********The cautious attitude toward holiday spending appears to have little if any direct connection to the turmoil in the financial markets. Only 1 percent of those who said they were going to spend less on Christmas this year cited the stock market's plunge. And 46 percent of those who said they planned to spend more also expressed belief that the stock market's decline would lead to hard times. **********Forty-three percent of the respondents who plan to spend less on Christmas this year said they did not have enough money, 22 percent cited ''life style changes'' such as divorce, retirement or having a baby, and 13 percent said prices were too high. Seven percent blamed unemployment for their belt-tightening plans. **********While few respondents said there was a link between the stock market's woes and their holiday spending, they split evenly on the question of whether the plunge in stock prices would lead to hard times for the economy. Forty-five percent said yes, 45 percent said no and 10 percent either did not answer or said they did not know. **********In response to a more strongly worded question in the earlier poll, taken Oct. 29 to Nov. 3, that asked whether the stock collapse would lead to a ''recession,'' 31 percent said yes, while 50 percent said no. What Americans Expect **********It is not clear whether the bigger yes response in the latest poll is attributable to growing fears about the fallout from the markets' plunge. Some respondents may foresee a slowdown in growth while doubting that the economy will actually experience enough decline in output to be defined as a recession. **********Not surprisingly, many respondents' views about the economy reflect their own situation. Of the 30 percent who said their finances were improving, 16 percent of them said the economy was getting better and 31 percent said it was getting worse - a 15-point gap. Of the 18 percent who said their situation was getting worse, only 6 percent of them said the economy was improving while 58 percent said it was deteriorating - a 52-point gap. **********Blacks were considerably more pessimistic than whites about the future of the economy. Only 2 percent of blacks said the economy was getting better and 53 percent said it was getting worse, while 12 percent of whites saw improvement and 39 percent were expecting it to worsen. Comparisons by Category **********Ten percent of women and 12 percent of men expect the economy to improve. Forty-six percent of women said the economy would worsen, compared with 35 percent of the men. **********The political split was somewhat sharper. Just 8 percent of Democrats predicted improvement and 49 percent said the economy would get worse, while 14 percent of Republicans predicted improvement and 28 percent said the economy would get worse. **********The people most likely to say that the stock plunge will lead to hard times were blacks (66 percent, compared with 41 percent of whites), women (49 percent, compared with 41 percent of men), Westerners (55 percent, compared with 43 percent of people who live in other regions), Democrats (51 percent, compared with 48 percent of political independents and 34 percent of Republicans), and those with family incomes under $25,000 (52 percent, compared with 40 percent for those with incomes over $25,000).  How the Poll Was Taken **********The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Nov. 20 through Nov. 24 with 1,553 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii. **********The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted residential numbers. **********The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephones and to adjust for variations relating to region, race, sex, age and education. **********In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by interviewing all adult Americans. The error for smaller subgroups is larger. **********In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/29/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Marriott Seeks Denny's Chain
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/29/busin.body_text: **********The Marriott Corporation, the big hotel and restaurant operator, said today that it was holding talks to buy Denny's Inc., a 1,200-unit restaurant company, from the investors who took it private two years ago. **********Analysts said the acquisition, if carried out, would make Marriott the leading operator of sit-down, family-style restaurants in America. **********Marriott, which last year paid a little more than $500 million for the Saga Corporation, a food-service and restaurant concern, said in a statement that it was negotiating a definitive agreement with Denny's, based in La Mirada, Calif. **********Marriott would not disclose the proposed price, but James Meyer, an analyst with Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. of Philadelphia, estimated that the deal might be worth at least $800 million. **********In January 1985, in a heavily financed leveraged buyout, Denny's managers paid $753.4 million to take the concern private. But they have since sold off some equity. **********Marriott said it also wanted to buy Denny's 42 percent interest in Winchell's, a chain of about 750 doughnut houses. Marriott shares fell 50 cents today, to $41.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/10/busin.body_text: **********The Cabinet decided today to lift Taiwan's 38-year-old foreign exchange controls, removing a barrier that has kept the nation's massive foreign reserves from flowing to other countries. **********Removal of the controls could have important implications for the United States and other nations with which Taiwan has built up massive trade surpluses. **********Presently, all foreign exchange earned locally must be converted into Taiwan dollars, and individuals can remit only $5,000 abroad annually. **********A Government Information Office statement said the new regulations, decided at a regular weekly Cabinet meeting, will permit the public to buy, hold and use foreign exchange freely.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/05/world.main_headline: SOUTH AFRICA SEIZES 120 AT CAMPUS RALLY By
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/05/world.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICA SEIZES 120 AT CAMPUS RALLY By
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/05/world.body_text: **********South African riot policemen arrested 120 students and fired tear gas at about 50 faculty members at the University of the Witwatersrand here today as the students and teachers protested the whites-only election scheduled for Wednesday. **********The demonstration began after hundreds of armed policemen charged about 3,000 students at the predominantly white school who had gathered to hear a speech by Winnie Mandela, the anti-apartheid campaigner. **********The police broke up the crowd before Mrs. Mandela, wife of the jailed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, could begin speaking. Mrs. Mandela, who is an arts student at the university, was later escorted from the campus by aides as policemen charged the main university hall, where they made the arrests and lobbed tear gas at professors supporting the protest. **********The police, who said they fired tear gas after students began throwing stones, beat several students with whips and rubber batons and dragged students screaming and struggling from the hall to large yellow police vans parked outside the campus. Government Bans Meeting **********The meeting with Mrs. Mandela was banned by the Government 15 minutes before she was to begin her lunchtime address, but students and faculty members defied the ban and met repeatedly throughout the afternoon, regrouping each time the police disrupted the peaceful protests. **********Dancing, chanting students cheered professors wearing academic gowns as a faculty spokesman, Prof. Doug Hindson, said they would back the students' call for a two-day closure of the university to protest the white election. **********Also on the campus, the police arrested at least 13 photographers and members of television crews from major foreign networks and news agencies covering the unrest, including ABC, CBS, Reuters, Time magazine and The Associated Press. The journalists were released after their names were taken and their film confiscated. **********The police said in a statement tonight that they would ignore the provincial court rulings in Natal last week that overturned restrictions on the coverage of violence and actions by the security forces. The Government says that the regulations remain in force while it appeals the rulings. Police Warning on Election **********As tension mounted in anticipation of a planned nationwide protest Tuesday and Wednesday, the Police Commissioner, Gen. Johan Coetzee, warned that the security forces would be out ''in strength'' to handle any attempt to disrupt the elections with work stoppages, boycotts and protest marches. **********President P. W. Botha, whose governing National Party is expected to win the election overwhelmingly, wound up the party's campaign at a lively and well-attended rally in Johannesburg's City Hall behind a heavy security shield. More than 100 policemen armed with shotguns, whips and tear-gas guns cordoned off nearby streets. **********Mr. Botha was heckled by young liberal whites during his speech and faced hostile questioners after the meeting. **********The Government has spent several million dollars in advertising to try to equate a vote for the opposition Progressive Federal Party with a vote for Communism and the outlawed African National Congress, the main nationalist group fighting to end white rule.  2 Blasts Hit Johannesburg **********JOHANNESBURG, Tuesday, May 5 (AP) - Two explosive devices went off at the city's Civic Center early today, causing minor damage but no injuries, the police reported. **********A police official, Col. Frans Malherbe, said one of the devices was believed to have been a limpet mine. He said the blasts, at 12:45 and 1:25 A.M., occurred in a covered outdoor walkway and at a nearby light pole at the Civic Center, which contains municipal offices. He said it was not known who set the devices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/busin.body_text: **********Michael Davidoff, formerly the head trader at a securities company controlled by Ivan F. Boesky, pleaded guilty yesterday to having engaged in bogus stock transactions with a British broker to evade Federal laws requiring brokers to maintain minimum amounts of capital. **********Mr. Davidoff, who worked at the Seemala Corporation, Mr. Boesky's stock-trading vehicle, was charged by the United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York with conducting the scheme with Seligmann, Harris & Company, a London-based brokerage house, and with concealing the scheme from regulators. The bogus transactions took place in the first three months of 1986, according to the court paper. **********Mr. Davidoff, who is 43 years old and lives in New Jersey, is cooperating with the continuing investigation of Mr. Boesky's stock-trading activities, according to Anne Ryan, the Assistant United States Attorney handling the case. Mr. Davidoff faces a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. **********Several sources with knowledge of the investigation said that Mr. Davidoff's cooperation could be vital to the Government, since he would have intimate knowledge of Mr. Boesky's stock-trading activities and relationships with other securities firms and individuals. The sources added that the plea coincided with increased activity among the investigators recently, which could indicate that other charges may be coming soon. Purported 'Parking' Scheme **********Mr. Davidoff helped Seemala engage in a practice known as ''parking,'' according to the charges. This involves creating documents for a phony transaction to make it appear that stocks have been sold, thus allowing the brokerage to report larger cash holdings than it actually has. Later, the appearance of a reversal of the phony transaction is created. **********The effect is to inflate the amount of capital that the broker reports to regulators, allowing the broker to own larger stock positions than would otherwise be permitted. **********Sources close to the investigation said that Mr. Davidoff ''was just an employee'' carrying out Mr. Boesky's instructions in the violations of the capital-requirement statutes. Mr. Boesky's attorney would not comment. **********Mr. Davidoff, according to his attorney, Paul Rooney, did not benefit financially from any scheme. He added that Mr. Davidoff worked at Seemala until earlier this week. A Broader Inquiry **********Sources with knowledge of the Government's investigation have said that the inquiry into Mr. Boesky's activities has moved beyond violations of the insider-trading laws and now involves other kinds of securities transactions. **********The sources have said that several other former employees of Mr. Boesky's firms were subpoenaed last year and that they could face charges similar to those brought against Mr. Davidoff yesterday. **********The investigators are also looking at transactions between Mr. Boesky and several other securities firms, including Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Jefferies & Company, both of which have acknowledged receiving subpoenas in the case. **********In addition, the sources said, investigators have been scrutinizing transactions between Mr. Boesky's firm and Jamie Securities, another firm that specializes in investing in takeover stocks. The sources said that the investigators have been gathering records from both Mr. Boesky's firm and Jamie, and that they are looking at regular billings by Mr. Boesky's firm to Jamie totaling about $500,000. **********The sources noted that Mr. Boesky's firm also handled stock trades for other investors, which might explain the billings. John Mulheren, who heads Jamie, declined to comment. **********Mr. Boesky, who settled S.E.C. charges that he had illegally earned more than $50 million in a year's time by using inside information, will plead guilty to one felony charge, carrying a maximum sentence of five years and a $100,000 fine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/world.main_headline: U.S. PUSH FOR ARMS EMBARGO ON IRAN HITS U.N. DEAD END
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/world.print_headline: U.S. PUSH FOR ARMS EMBARGO ON IRAN HITS U.N. DEAD END
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/world.body_text: **********The five permanent members of the Security Council have failed to agree on an American proposal to impose a global arms embargo against Iran, diplomats in Washington and at the United Nations said today. **********The draft resolution on ending the Iran-Iraq war, which has not been made public, is described as containing the harshest language on the subject put before the Security Council since the Persian Gulf war began nearly seven years ago. But according to diplomats, in its current form it falls short of what Assistant Secretary of State Richard W. Murphy said the Reagan Administration wanted - a resolution ''with teeth in it.'' 'Not Enough Enthusiasm' **********''There is just not enough enthusiasm to push for a resolution that would be what the Americans want,'' a diplomat said. Another diplomat said there might have been more enthusiasm if the United States had not secretly sold arms to Iran. **********As part of their defense of an Administration decision to put Kuwaiti tankers under American protection, Administration officials have repeatedly portrayed the United Nations initiative as an urgent American effort to help bring the war to an end. **********In four months of negotiations with the other permanent members of the Security Council - the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China - American diplomats have taken the lead in pushing for a resolution that would impose an arms embargo on any warring party that refused to cooperate with Security Council efforts to end the war. **********Since it is Iran that remains opposed to a cease-fire, an embargo would in effect apply to Iran but not to Iraq. Degrees of Support **********The four other permanent members have voiced reservations about the United States plan, although they have given it varying degrees of support, according to diplomats. **********The French have argued that an arms embargo might have little effect, since Iran already has a well-developed network of underground suppliers that would continue to function. **********The British, who diplomats say generally support the American initiative, are skeptical of a resolution that could fail or could be used by the Soviet Union to curry favor with Iran. **********The strongest opposition, diplomats said, came from China, which as Iran's largest arms supplier would be unwilling to lose one of its most lucrative markets. The Soviet Union, whose East bloc and other allies are major arms suppliers to Iran, has remained vague, an official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/09/busin.body_text: **********The first offering by a local government of securities denominated in a foreign currency is expected within two weeks by the State of Iowa, Goldman, Sachs & Company announced yesterday. **********The state's $100 million of tax-exempt notes will be offered by Goldman to domestic investors and denominated in Australian, New Zealand, Canadian or American dollars. The exact mix of currencies and the different interst rate that applies to each currency will be announced at the time of sale. **********Based on current market conditions, a Goldman official estimated that one-year notes in Australian dollars would bear an interest rate of about 9 percent, compared with 12 percent in New Zealand dollars, 4 1/4 percent in Canadian dollars and 4 percent in United States dollars. **********Local governments and investment bankers have been studying foreign markets intensely for the last year. An article in CreditWeek, a publication of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said last September that Stanford University, Mississippi, Illinois, Puerto Rico and California's Los Angeles and Orange Counties had considered selling securities in Tokyo or the Euromarket, though they have not yet acted. **********Officials at Goldman, Sachs who have previously sold commercial paper and intermediate-term notes denominated in foreign currencies for corporations, said the financing would reduce the cost of Iowa's borrowing and would not expose the state to risk from fluctuations in the foreign currency market. ''This is the first of what we expect will be several issues for major municipal bond issuers,'' said Gary L. Zwerling, vice president and sales manager at Goldman. **********State governments whose fiscal years begin July 1 are active borrowers about this time of year because they benefit from selling notes as early as possible at the beginning of their fiscal years. Over the next eight weeks, note borrowings are expected by California, Pennsylvania, Utah, Montana, Idaho, Vermont, Rhode Island, Massachusetts and Connecticut, analysts said. **********''There is no currency risk for the borrower,'' said Christian McCarthy, vice president at Goldman. When the interest rate on the notes is announced, he said that Iowa will also sign a contract with Goldman to immediately convert the foreign currencies into dollars and another contract to convert the dollars back into foreign currencies when the notes mature in one year. **********Investors are attracted to foreign currency issues because of their high interest rates, or the potential for currency appreciation. Since early 1986 foreign currency offerings in the United States market total more than $3.5 billion (Australian), $2.5 billion (New Zealand) and $600 million (Canadian).
