https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/busin.body_text: **********The Internal Revenue Service is seeking more than $350 million in taxes from the Hunt family of Dallas in connection with write-offs the family claimed from its buying binge of silver futures in 1979-80. **********In a consolidation of eight cases against the Hunts scheduled for trial in United States Tax Court beginning Monday morning, the I.R.S. contends that Nelson Bunker Hunt and his wife, Caroline, covered millions of dollars of their children's losses when the silver market collapsed in early 1980. **********Mr. and Mrs. Hunt had written off the money as bad loans, but the Government contends that the transfers constituted gifts to their children and that they should be subject to gift and income taxes. **********In 1985, the I.R.S. disallowed $147.6 million that Mr. and Mrs. Hunt had claimed as a short-term capital loss on their 1980 income tax return and is seeking about $100 million in back taxes. The remainder of the taxes sought are charged against three Hunt children and their spouses. **********Mr. and Mrs. Hunt said they loaned the money to help their children cover margin calls on silver futures when the price of silver began to fall. **********The tax court case is a prelude to a silver trading case in which the Commodity Futures Trading Commission alleges the Hunts manipulated the silver futures market through their massive purchases of silver.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/world.main_headline: 'Chronology? I Was the Guy Looking for the Chronology'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/world.print_headline: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS; 'Chronology? I Was the Guy Looking for the Chronology'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/31/world.body_text: **********Donald T. Regan was asked about being the ''fall guy'' in the Iran-contra affair. **********SENATOR HOWELL HEFLIN, Democrat of Alabama. We have heard a lot about fall guys. And we've heard a lot about participants involved in this, who would take the spears in the chest. But as of this stage, not to say that it won't be different at some later date, you appear to be the primary fall guy, that circumstances, in effect, have made you the fall guy. **********Now . . . the Tower Report wasn't very complimentary of you. . . . They said . . . 'More than almost any chief of staff of recent memory, he,' referring to you, Mr. Regan, 'asserted personal control over the White House staff and sought to extend this control to the national security adviser. He was personally active in national security affairs and attended almost all of the relevant meetings, regarding Iran initiative. He, as much as anyone, should have insisted on an orderly process being observed. In addition he, especially, should have insured that plans were made for handling any public disclosure of the initiative. He must bear primary responsibility for the chaos that descended upon the White House, when such disclosure did occur.' **********Now . . . I think you're entitled, in fairness, to respond and to respond here to the committee, to this allegations of the Tower Commission. **********A. I'll be glad to do that, Senator. First of all, I'm not sure I want to educate the committee but at least I educated myself. When I heard all this description of fall guys, coming out in the press from these hearings, I asked my staff, I said what's the derivation of fall guy? Where'd that term ever come from? **********. . . Turns out it's a wrestling expression, dating back from the 19th century, when they had fixed wrestling matches. You recall that in wrestling it's two falls out of three. And one guy would be the fall guy. **********Q. To interrupt you, did you put that in past tense? **********A. I put that in the past tense. Far be it from me to characterize current-day wrestling. But anyway, the fall guy was the guy who agreed to lose. I never agreed to lose. So . . . I'm not sure I'm the fall guy in that sense of the word. **********As far as spears in the breast are concerned, I don't mind spears in the breast, it's knives in the back that concern me. **********Now, as far as chaos is concerned, I'm not sure what could have been done . . . I did try, in all honesty, to get this word out as quickly as I could, to make it public, to let the Congress know, to let the American public know, what we had been doing and that it was a failed policy, that it had not succeeded, make a clean breast of it. . . . **********I think the American public will understand when one of their leaders tries something, with good intentions, and it doesn't succeed, if they know about it and can understand it. What they will not forgive is a desire to hoodwink them, or to conceal something. . . . So I wanted to make it public. But, as I explained earlier, it was decided that we should not do that, for fear of endangering the hostages. **********When the added fillip came, of there being this diversion of funds, then . . . the dam broke loose. . . . And I realized that, I don't care who it was, we just had to get that story out.  * * * **********Well, I submit that I'll take responsibility for the one who urged the President to get it out and get it out now, even though it might be only half the story, as we know it. Get it out. So we did that. **********I have been accused of rigging the chronology. . . . As you know from your own testimony here, I had nothing to do with that chronology. I was the guy that was looking for the chronology, . . . trying to get it straight - rather than sitting up at night trying to get people into some back room somewhere, to rig it. **********There has been a lot said. But I guess that goes with the turf. . . . I'm reconciled to it so, from that point of view, I'll tell my story and let history judge it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/world.main_headline: LAYING DOWN THE LAW AT THE 'CANNABIS CAFE'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/world.print_headline: AMSTERDAM JOURNAL; LAYING DOWN THE LAW AT THE 'CANNABIS CAFE'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/world.body_text: **********A museum dedicated to the lore and enjoyment of marijuana opened on a busy canal-front street here last month and was immediately raided by the police. **********The rare public crackdown was more the news, however, than that such a museum existed in this city, called Europe's drug capital. **********It is a city where a kind of addicts' union helps advise officials, and where heroin addicts routinely get advice and free methadone from a city medical bus that comes quietly around each day like a milk wagon. **********At the same time, marijuana enthusiasts in another part of town daily smoke or eat a dream's worth in cigarettes, cookies and ''space cakes'' on sale at any of the 200 openly tolerated ''cannabis cafes.'' City Gets Tough **********But the raid on the Hash Museum, as it is being called, signaled that this city, where ''flower power'' flourished in the 1960's and which became a sanctuary for Bohemian squatters and drug users in the 1970's, is no longer cooperating in its notoriety. **********Three years ago, the city government enacted tighter controls on dealing in hard drugs, including barring more than three loiterers from gathering in the notorious drug and sex district near the central railroad station. **********It also limited the squatter phenomenon by cutting down on vacant buildings and on official generosity toward transient young people who bumble here like bees to pollen. **********''Like all idealistic movements, it got a bit decadent, and things had to change,'' said Gilbert van Stijgeren, the city's spokesman. **********The change was not entirely reactionary, for at the same time the city concluded that its noncriminal approach to the use of soft drugs like marijuana was working. Increasing Penalties **********The national Government in The Hague, although sympathetic to the laissez-faire local approach, began setting tougher prison penalties for traffickers in heroin, cocaine and other hard drugs who are the main target of the police. The sentence for heroin trafficking was tripled, to 12 years, with little chance for parole. Lately, an increasing number of new prison inmates have been found to be addicted to hard drugs. **********The result is a subtly different Amsterdam, according to city and national officials, even if the busloads of middle-class tourists do not quite realize it as they stare at some of the hollow-eyed addicts. **********Officials note several changes in the drug scene in this still proudly tolerant society. **********For one, the hard-drug problem in Amsterdam is becoming stabilized among an aging group of about 8,000 addicts. There are more than 15,000 addicts nationally, and 50 other communities have introduced methadone maintenance programs to ease withdrawal from heroin, in part because Amsterdam is trying to decentralize its problem and send addicts back home. 'Not So Liberal' **********The average age of drug addicts here has increased from 24 to 27, and Dutch officials envision a ''bridging'' process to see them into middle age and possible rehabilitation. **********''We know our image is still bad in other countries and critics say, 'Oh my God, Amsterdam again,' but we are not so liberal as people think,'' said Eddy L. Engelsman, head of alcohol and drug control in the National Ministry of Health. ''We find that with our integrated policy the drug problem is stabilizing or diminishing.'' **********At the same time, the city has closed 90 marijuana cafes in the last two years for violating the Public Prosecutor's ''expediency'' rule by refusing to stay low-key and avoid the use of hard drugs. **********Officials said the cafe experience showed that it did not invite wider use of soft drugs or evolve into experimentation with harder drugs. 'Reefer Madness' **********According to Government data, the number of marijuana users has remained steady in recent decades at about 3 percent of the population. **********A group of aging, baldish British punk bikers loudly consuming hashish and insulting passers-by this week outside a marijuana cafe called the Bulldog seemed engaged in a parody of the film ''Reefer Madness,'' as if they could not stand the official leniency. The larger, younger surrounding crowd was quietly enjoying beer, wine, pastry and marijuana at sidewalk tables. **********The discouragement of foreign hard-drug users also has helped stabilize the drug scene. A strict ''one for the road'' methadone policy is now in force for alien addicts, who are also required to produce a return ticket home. **********Dutch officials, who are regularly criticized by West Germany, where the drug laws are more Draconian, have found a particular problem with Germans addicted to hard drugs fleeing here. The 60 deaths related to hard drugs in the Netherlands last year included 35 visiting Germans. Only 16 of the addicts were Dutch, from a population of 14 million. **********Police officials and other nations regularly criticize the Dutch policies, saying they invite high-volume world drug traffic. But officials here say data on drug seizures show West Germany, for example, has a far larger problem with its other neighbors. Arrests Rising **********The impression is skewed, Dutch officials say, because this is a traditional shipping nation, and for centuries Rotterdam has been one of the world's busiest transshipping ports. **********According to the city police, arrests for trafficking in hard drugs have steadily risen, to 2,468 last year, along with a 30 percent rise in the amount of heroin seized, to about 450 pounds. **********Cocaine is a growing problem, though not considered comparable to heroin addiction. About 180 pounds of cocaine was seized last year, compared with 11 pounds in 1985. **********''We are taking a pragmatic, nonmoralistic, nonemotional, nonsensational approach to the drug problem,'' Mr. Engelsman said. The Netherlands, he added, is slowly ''demythologizing'' drugs without a melodramatic ''war'' that drives users of hard and soft drugs underground. **********The campaign is not entirely free of hypocrisy. Much like a Times Square vice crackdown, the recent raid on the Hash Museum ended with the place being quietly permitted to reopen five hours later. **********''We were warned not to create publicity in the world press,'' a museum official said, while selling tickets at $2 each. ''Come back in a couple of months and we can talk.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/21/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Price Dip Soon Seen for Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/21/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Price Dip Soon Seen for Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/21/busin.body_text: **********WHENEVER stocks move sharply in one direction or another for a sustained period, the eyes of Wall Street inevitably turn to the giants of the market, the institutional investors, for a reading of what to expect next. **********What they are saying is that, after 13 straight days of moving forward, the market is ready to catch its breath and may well dip in the days and weeks ahead. **********Indeed, the huge gains so far in January have made some money managers turn decidedly cautious. Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average moved ahead 1.97 more points, to 2,104.47, making the total advance nearly 210 points since year-end. **********''I think the market is setting itself up for a correction on the order of perhaps 10 percent,'' said Martin D. Sass of M.D. Sass Investors, which manages $2.8 billion. ''I can still see this move carrying the Dow to 2,150 or 2,200 before the correction comes. But, after that, my ultimate target is only 2,300 by year-end,'' **********One reason for January's stunning advance, he added, is ''panic buying'' by some money managers who entered the new year with too much cash. Most portfolio managers have underperformed the broad market averages for the last two years and, consequently, have an aversion to missing a big rally. **********On the other hand, Forstmann-Leff Associates, a firm with a good performance record, has been raising cash for the last week, even as stock prices continued to advance. ''We simply think the market is fully valued at these levels,'' said William F. Harnisch, president of the firm, which manages $4.6 billion. **********''We went into this year 80 percent invested -and for us, that's bullish. Currently, we are approaching a cash position of 75 percent and we're still raising cash. For example, we sold some of our Price Company stock and also have sold Ralston-Purina. Genentech remains our largest position, and other major holdings include Toys ''R'' Us, General Mills, Eli Lilly, CPC International and Telerate.'' **********Mr. Harnisch also said that any correction in stock prices in coming months was not likely to exceed 10 percent, ''provided there is no big crash in the bond market.'' **********However, David Dreman, managing director of Dreman Value Management, remains resolutely bullish - and keeps the $2.5 billion under his command fully invested. ''I believe it is more dangerous to be out of this market than in it,'' he said. ''Bull markets like this one are few and far between, even though there will be bumps along the way.'' **********As a self-styled ''contrary'' investor, he often picks out-of-favor stocks. At present, International Business Machines is his firm's largest position, to the tune of nearly 2 million shares. **********''I guess this market is going higher, but I really can't judge it for the short term,'' said James S. Martin, chief investment officer of the College Retirement Equities Fund's $27 billion portfolio, the country's single largest. **********As a long-term forecaster, however, Mr. Martin has an excellent record. In June 1983, when the Dow was hovering around 1,200, he told an interviewer: ''I can see the Dow at 2,100 in 1987.'' **********What does he see ahead? ''The ingredients are there,'' Mr. Martin replied, ''for the Dow to reach the high 2,000's over the next two or three years.'' **********One view gaining popularity on Wall Street is that stocks that can respond to a revved-up economy should outperform the interest-sensitive sectors like electric utilities that have benefited in recent years from declining interest rates. ''This market has to be driven by improved earnings in order to go higher,'' Mr. Martin said. **********As a result, some firms such as the College Retirement fund and the Alliance Capital Management Corporation are changing their mix of investments. **********''Our portfolios have been shifting moderately away from consumer-oriented groups like the foods and tobaccos toward sectors that are more economically sensitive,'' said Dave Williams, chairman of Alliance, which manages $30 billion in various portfolios as a subsidiary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society. ''We also favor groups that, in the past, were hurt by the high value of the dollar. These include capital goods, papers, chemicals and technology issues.'' As a matter of policy, Alliance tends to remain pretty fully invested and it does not regard itself as a ''market-timing'' firm. **********Peter Lynch, portfolio manager of the Fidelity Magellan Fund, tends $8.4 billion in assets and, over the last 5, 10 and 15 years, his fund has shown the best performance of any mutual fund. **********Was he surprised by the recent run-up in stock prices?. ''I sure was,'' he admitted. ''I thought the market would go down in January. I'm still waiting to put in my Investment Retirement Account. Where? In Magellan.'' He, too, sees a correction coming. ''But you never know how big or when, until it's over,'' he said. Magellan's two biggest investments are Ford Motor and Federal National Mortgage Association. Other large positions include Chrysler, Kemper Corporation and Middle South Utilities. **********''Eighteen months ago, 20 percent of the fund's assets were in bonds and utility stocks,'' Mr. Lynch said. ''Now that's down to 5 percent. We also have cut back on our investments in foreign automobile stocks.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/22/busin.body_text: **********The levying of tariffs on some Japanese products has set off concern that there might be shortages of popular Japanese laptop computers, prompting retailers and some consumers to accelerate their buying, computer industry executives said today. **********Several retailers said that Toshiba Ltd., one of the two major Japanese laptop computer makers, has said it will have to ration its laptops to them. **********''Toshiba is on allocation,'' said Richard Horan, director of Executive Computers Inc., a Manhattan dealer. ''We're told they have about a month's supply left.'' Toshiba Studies Its Options **********An official for Toshiba, however, said the company was still studying its options and did not know yet how supply would be affected. **********Meanwhile, the NEC Corporation, the other major Japanese laptop computer vendor, said it anticipated being able to meet the demand for its machines, although prices might have to rise. **********Laptop computers are the product in which consumers are expected to most notice the effect of the 100 percent tariffs, which were imposed by President Reagan last Friday. The tariffs are designed to punish Japan for its purported failure to adhere to a semiconductor trade agreement signed last year. **********Government officials and retailers said they expected little change in price or supply of power tools, mid-sized color televisions and desktop computers, the other products that are a target of the tariffs, because these products are also supplied by American companies or by Japanese companies manufacturing in the United States. **********But in laptop computers, the Japanese models made by Toshiba and NEC are among the most popular. **********Most Japanese companies are not expected to continue to import products subject to the tariffs, because a 100 percent tariff is too stiff to swallow. Major questions, then, are how much inventory is already on hand in the United States and how long the tariffs will remain in effect. **********Many experts expect the tariffs to be lifted in three months, but a better indication could come after Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan visits the United States next week. **********If tariffs last only three months, pricing and availability problems should not be severe. Gary Gapp, senior vice president of the Computerland Corporation, the largest chain of computer stores, said the company had a two- to three-month supply of Japanese laptops on hand. **********Retailers said they intended for now to keep prices the same, but if shortages occur or if manufacturers raise prices, retailers would have to follow. If the tariffs were directly passed through to the consumer, it could raise the prices 50 percent or more. **********A few retailers said consumers had flocked to their stores to buy machines ahead of any possible tariff-related price rise. **********''Saturday, there was some panic buying, because no matter what we tell people, they don't believe it,'' said Gene Farb, co-owner of Whole Earth Access, a retailer based in Berkeley, Calif. ''Sales were up 30 to 40 percent that day.'' **********Retailers too, are increasing their orders. Bob Wolff, president of Wolff Computer in New York, said he had ordered a three-month supply, when normally he orders a 20-day supply. Avoiding Product Interruption **********A spokeswoman for NEC Home Electronics in Wood Dale, Ill., said the company had about a 60-day supply of its Multispeed laptop computers, which has a retail list price of $2,000. She said the company believed it could continue satisfying demand for the product without interruption. **********The spokeswoman, Marion Black-Ruffin, said NEC was thinking of shifting assembly of the computer from Japan to one of its existing United States factories. The company is also trying to cut manufacturing costs in Japan so it can keep shipping the product despite the tariffs. Even then, she said, prices would rise. **********A Toshiba official would not say how long inventories would last of the Toshiba 1100, which retails for $2,100, and the 3100, a powerful laptop with a list price of $4,200. John E. Rehfeld, vice president and general manager of the information systems division of Toshiba America in Irvine, Calif., also said the company had not told its dealers that it would be allocating products. **********But retailers and others said they have been told by Toshiba that supplies would be tight. **********''They have said there will probably be a suspension of shipments for some time,'' said John Morgridge, president of the Grid Systems Corporation of Mountain View, Calif., a computer manufacturer that sells the Toshiba 3100 under its own name.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/27/world.main_headline: Another Bicentennial? Next One Is France's
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/27/world.print_headline: Another Bicentennial? Next One Is France's
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/27/world.body_text: **********Just a few days after having marked the 200th anniversary of the United States Constitution, Americans gathered this week to join their oldest ally in preparing for the bicentennial of the French Revolution in 1989. **********Edgar Faure, chairman of the commission planning the Paris celebration, brought to Washington a model of the huge structure that will be the symbol of the French bicentennial. **********The structure, a cube about 330 feet on each side, is being built at La Defense, the high-rise office and residential complex west of Paris, and is dedicated to the study of human rights. ''It is my Eiffel Tower,'' Mr. Faure, a former prime minister, said at a reception at the French Embassy. **********''It will be a good place for having meetings and receptions in 1989,'' he said, ''but I want to go further, to establish it as a foundation for the interdisciplinary study of human rights, to look forward to the next 200 years.'' Americans Aid the Planning **********At the reception, the embassy announced the formation of a committee to help plan American activities during the bicentennial. Among the committee members attending were Warren E. Burger, the former Chief Justice of the United States and chairman of the continuing bicentennial observance of the Constitution; Walter H. Annenberg, the publisher and former United States Ambassador to Britain; Emmanuel de Margerie, the French Ambassador to the United States, and Charles McC. Mathias Jr., the former United States Senator from Maryland. **********Ambassador de Margerie said there would be many French bicentennial events in the United States, including art exhibitions, concerts and academic symposiums. **********There are tentative plans for performances of ''Valis,'' a new French opera by Ted Machover and Catherine Ikam, in Boston and New York, and an exhibition of the French crown jewels and treasures in Washington. Chicago, the favorite of American architects, is to present a show of French architecture. Festival of French Film **********The Houston Grand Opera is to mount a co-production with the Nice Opera and the Aix-en-Provence Festival. The Film Archives of the University of California, Los Angeles, is planning a festival of French films on the French Revolution that might be taken on a national tour. **********Mr. Mathias said that Prof. Stanley Hoffmann, the French historian and chairman for the Center for European Studies at Harvard University, would organize the scholarly activities in the American participation of the French anniversary. **********Ambassador de Margerie, in an interview, commented on ''the intertwining of the American and French revolutions'' as he spoke of the work of Thomas Jefferson and Benjamin Franklin in Paris, and of the support they won from France for the American cause. **********He also mentioned the effect of the Americans on the French - the spreading of revolutionary fervor to Paris and the weakened condition of the French monarchy, partly caused by its financial support of the Americans. **********As guests at the reception looked at the grand arch, designed by the late architect Johan Otto von Spreckelsen, Mr. Annenberg and Mr. Burger chatted at a table away from the crowd. **********''I'm going to do the best I can to get publicity,'' Mr. Annenberg said of his role in the American observance of the French bicentennial, but he lamented that he was slowing down ''as I approach my 80th birthday.'' **********''Don't rub it in, Walter,'' said the retired Chief Justice, who observed his own 80th birthday last week as the nation was observing the Constitution's 200th.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/04/busin.body_text: **********Leading European airlines expect a 40 percent higher profit this year after a ''traumatic'' year in 1986, according to figures released by the Association of European Airlines. The association, which groups 21 major European airlines, said today that the combined profit of its members was expected to rise to the equivalent of about $550 million in 1987, up about 40 percent from $400 million in 1986. Karl-Heinz Neumeister, the association's secretary general, said 1986 was a ''traumatic'' year for European airlines, when the fear of terrorism, the Chernobyl nuclear disaster and the fall of the dollar led to a drop of one million North American tourists.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/15/world.body_text: **********An Iranian opposition group said Friday that its guerrillas had wounded the brother of Iran's President in an attack with hand grenades and machine guns in a northeastern Iranian city. **********The opposition People's Mujahedeen announced in a statement sent by telex from its Paris headquarters that Hadi Khamenei, brother of President Ali Khamenei, had been among about 50 people wounded in the attack. **********It said the guerrillas struck Wednesday in Meshed, firing weapons and throwing hand grenades in Khosravi Street, just off the central Abb Square. **********The Mujahedeen report could not be independently verified. **********Besides Hadi Khamenei, the wounded included a Colonel Mozaffari, a mullah named Samadi and 50 Revolutionary Guards, the statement said. It said the colonel, the mullah and two others wounded were responsible ''for torture and executions'' in Khurasan Province.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/11/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor:  For over 35 years we have closely watched the short- and long-term effects of marketing American technology abroad, mainly through licensing (''The U.S. Giveaway,'' Dec. 7). More than any other nation we have generously offered our technology to outsiders. As a result, the entire world has been able to advance the automation of assembly line manufacturing, as well as the handling and processing of material. **********While the global economy has prospered, a more competitive world has evolved and, at times, has created situations that have come back to haunt many of us. **********The revolutionary process of industrializing the free world continues to this day. I think the American companies involved in that process won't be swayed in their mission by isolated examples of haunting situations. Nothing but good can come from improving the conditions and lives of others. JERVIS B. WEBB  Farmington Hills, Mich., Dec. 11

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/19/busin.body_text: **********THE recent discoveries of materials that lose all resistance to electricity at warmer temperatures than previously thought possible have astonished the industrial world. **********Not surprisingly, these developments have also caused a stir in the modest new office building on the pastoral outskirts of this village just west of Oxford that recently became the headquarters of the Oxford Instruments Group P.L.C. Oxford is the world leader in the commercial application of what are now called conventional superconductors, metals that lose their resistance to electricity when cooled in liquid helium baths to less than 10 degrees Kelvin (about minus 263 degrees centigrade). **********Over the last 25 years, the company has used a curious characteristic of superconductors - the strong magnetic fields they create - to develop a variety of products. It is best known for supermagnets that go into instruments made by other companies to analyze everything from plastics to tumors. The instruments measure the energy emitted by the protons in atoms after they have been subjected to magnetic fields, taking advantage of the fact that different types of atoms emit different levels of energy. **********Peter M. Williams, Oxford's 42-year-old chief executive, acknowledges that the new superconductors, which are brittle ceramics, may one day transform the strategic outlook for superconductivity-based businesses. However, the company, which earned $20 million on sales of $160 million in the year ended March 31, is leaving basic research to others and concentrating on the near-term commercial prospects of using the older superconductors. **********Analysts say that Oxford's most promising opportunity stems from a contract with the International Business Machines Corporation to build a new superconducting device for semiconductor fabrication. **********''It's long-term, but it could be a multibillion-dollar market in the 1990's,'' said Nigel Burton, an analyst who follows Oxford for Robert Fleming Securities Ltd. in London. **********The product is a synchrotron, a machine that accelerates a beam of electrons in a magnetic field to the point where it throws off energy in the form of X-rays. Because X-rays have shorter wavelengths than other forms of light, I.B.M. and other semiconductor makers believe that they can be used to etch finer lines in microchips - and pack more circuits into them - than is possible with today's lithographic processes. **********I.B.M. has turned to Oxford because extremely sophisticated ''supermagnets'' are needed to bend the beam and hold it into an oval circuit small enough to fit into a reasonably sized semiconductor production facility. **********''This is substantially bigger than any project we have ever done,'' said John Pilcher, managing director of an Oxford subsidiary, Oxford Instruments Ltd., that is overseeing the three-year effort that some analysts have estimated to be worth as much as $15 million. **********Oxford is being aided by a $1.5 million interest-free loan from the British Government, which is eager to give the company a leg up in its race with German and Japanese groups that are also developing compact synchrotrons. Government scientists at the Daresbury Laboratory in Warrington, England, provided critical advice on the shape and gradations of the magnetic field the synchrotron would need. **********''Accelerator physicists are rare animals that mainly live in Government labs,'' said Martin Wilson, the project manager. ''We can make it, but we needed help from people who could tell us what to make. The biggest technical problem is that where you would want to put the material to make the magnetic field is precisely where you are not allowed to if you are going to get the X-rays out.'' **********Fortunately for Oxford, the synchrotron project has blossomed just as growth in the company's traditional image-analysis business faltered. Magnet-based image analysis is known as nuclear magnetic resonance, or N.M.R., in the analytical field and magnetic resonance imaging, or M.R.I., in medical diagnostics. It had lifted Oxford from the garden-shed enterprise of Martin Wood, an Oxford physicist who developed his magnetics expertise to meet his research needs, into a publicly traded company with overseas subsidiaries and partners and four divisions. **********Oxford's M.R.I. unit sales were the main growth engine in the early 1980's. But major customers such as the General Electric Company and Siemens of Germany are making more of their own magnets for the analytical and medical diagnostic equipment. And many of the limited number of laboratories and hospitals that can afford the devices now have them. **********In addition, competition is increasing from the Intermagnetics General Corporation, a company in Guilderland, N.Y., near Albany, that stumbled badly when its first products broke down. **********But Intermagnetics later pioneered the concept of magnets that could be housed in mobile units and has since enjoyed an improving reputation. **********The main problem, Mr. Williams said, is that the instrument manufacturers who are Oxford's customers are eager to recoup their heavy investment in M.R.I. and N.M.R. systems and are reluctant to cut prices, thereby reducing their profit margins. Lower prices, he said, might attract a broader range of hospitals and laboratories. **********M.R.I. systems cost anywhere from $1.5 million to several times that, with magnets accounting for 15 percent to 40 percent of the cost. **********''The market needs someone to cut the M.R.I. system price below the $1 million level,'' Mr. Williams said. The company's strategy to stimulate sales as it awaits a price break is to broaden its product line by developing magnets that are more powerful, more compact or better shielded so they can be used in less controlled environments. **********In addition, the company is developing businesses to shield it from the downturn in its medical devices. It markets patient monitoring equipment, including portable devices that monitor heart, brain and stomach activity and devices used in sleep study. In September, it acquired Plasma Technology Ltd., which makes equipment that uses electrical and magnetic fields to control gases from which materials are deposited onto semiconductors. **********''A good market for us at the moment is a $100 million market,'' Mr. Williams said. ''A $10 billion market attracts too many big guys.'' **********Some analysts, including Jack M. Frost, the blunt-speaking American whom Oxford hired to build its patient-monitoring business, see such views as unduly conservative. **********''Our company is still in many ways a hometown company that's reluctant to be in the big leagues,'' Mr. Frost said. **********However, Mr. Williams, whom Mr. Frost described as ''a harder driver than his predecessors,'' does not plan to let anyone take Oxford's place on top of the superconductivity heap without a fight. **********''We hope to grow to the point where we can go up against anybody in a major market by the time the synchrotron is commercialized,'' Mr. Williams said.  BUILDING A BETTER SEMICONDUCTOR **********To produce a new generation of chips with features closer together than current manufacturing processes permit, I.B.M. has contracted with Oxford Instruments to design a synchrotron. The device uses powerful magnets to hold a beam of accelerated electrons in a 4.5-meter-by-1.5-meter oval racetrack while energy is drawn off in the form of X-rays, extremely short-length lightwaves that can be used for high-quality etching.  STORAGE RING  Powerful supermagnets bend the electron beam into an oval circuit. Its stability is maintained with the help of conventional magnets on the straight portions.  1. Linear Accelerator:  This drives a beam of electrons at high speed into the device. Oxford is currently redesigning the system so that this accelerator will be at a 90- degree angle.  2. Injection Transport Line:  This captures the beam of electrons and delivers it into the magnetic field.  3. Radio Frequency Cavity:  This device further accelerates the electron beam once it is injected into the track and adds energy to compensate for that lost when X-rays are drawn off.  4. Lithography Stations:  X-rays are drawn into these stations where x-rays etch chips. The stations may be considerably farther from the synchrotron than depicted. Some stations may be used for monitoring or experiments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/05/busin.body_text: **********Moody's Investor Service said today it had raised Chicago's general obligation bonds to an A rating, reflecting the city's economic growth and its determination to balance its budget. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/18/busin.body_text: **********Italy's wine-doctoring scandal produced a sharp fall in exports last year, the Foreign Trade Institute said today. It said total exports of wine and vermouth fell 35.8 percent, to 242 million gallons in 1986, from 396 million gallons in 1985. Several countries imposed curbs on Italian wine imports following the scandal early last year, when 23 people died after drinking the cheap wine, adulterated with wood-based methyl alcohol. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Britain's Midland Bank P.L.C. is closing its off-shore banking unit in Bahrain in a move to rationalize its operations, a bank official said today. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; EASTERN AIMS TO CUT LABOR COSTS BY 35%
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/22/busin.body_text: **********The president of Eastern Air Lines Inc., Phil Bakes, set a goal yesterday to cut labor costs by $490 million this year as part of a plan to make the carrier profitable. **********In what is believed to be the opening round of a long battle with the airline's unions, Mr. Bakes said that most of the savings would come from reductions in pay. Speaking at a news conference in Miami, he added that the airline would seek $450 million in cost cuts from its three main unions. **********The total reduction would be about 35 percent of Eastern's annual labor costs of $1.7 billion. Some of the pay cuts would be as large as 60 percent. **********Although he did not announce any layoffs from Eastern's 43,000-member work force, Mr. Bakes said that it would be absurd to rule them out. **********The leaders of the three unions -the Air Line Pilots Association, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace workers and the Transport Workers Union, which represents flight attendants - have agreed to pay cuts in the past, but they have usually been temporary and often were traded for giving employees stock in the company and more say in managing the airline. Also, the earlier cuts were generally in the range of 20 percent. **********Eastern's acquisition by the Texas Air Corporation, however, has ceased contacts between management and union leaders, who have lost their positions on the board of directors. **********Mr. Bakes said that the airline would seek $69 million in concessions from its flight attendants, $265 million from its machinists and $114 million from its pilots. **********He estimated that about half of the airline's work force would be designated for pay cuts. Most in the other half were already at levels competitive with lower-cost carriers, such as Continental Airlines, another subsidiary of Texas Air. **********He added that the airline would seek meetings with union leaders to discuss the cost-cutting plans. **********Union leaders could not be reached for comment because the announcement was made after their offices were closed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/10/busin.body_text: **********Japan is urging domestic companies to buy more chips abroad to quell complaints that its market is closed, a spokesman for the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. **********The ministry has asked companies not to discriminate against foreign makers and to sign more long-term chip-procurement contracts with foreign companies, said Junji Yoshihara, deputy director of the ministry's industrial electronics division. **********Japan and the United States are the world's top makers of chips, which are used in a wide range of products, including computers, calculators and telephones. **********In April, Washington put 100 percent tariffs on Japanese-made color television sets, computers and power tools, citing Japanese dumping of chips and lack of American access to the Japanese market. **********Last week, the United States lifted some of the retaliatory tariffs after the Commerce Department said that Japan had stopped dumping computer chips in third-country markets, but tariffs on personal computers and some other products remain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/28/world.main_headline: SOVIET DRAFT ACCORD WOULD COVER U.S. WARHEADS FOR BONN MISSILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/28/world.print_headline: SOVIET DRAFT ACCORD WOULD COVER U.S. WARHEADS FOR BONN MISSILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/28/world.body_text: **********Soviet negotiators said today that American nuclear warheads for West German short-range missiles would have to be eliminated as part of an agreement on missiles in Europe, American officials said today. **********The Soviet position, presented at the Geneva arms talks, was portrayed by some Americans as creating a new obstacle to an accord. **********Some Western Europeans are uneasy about the elimination of American missiles on the ground that it would foster a ''denuclearization'' of Europe. The Americans have sought to allay the concern by saying that an accord would still leave nuclear weapons in Europe, including West Germany's short-range missiles with American warheads. **********Medium-range missiles can reach targets 600 miles or more away; short-range missiles have ranges of 300 to 600 miles. West Germany has 72 Pershing 1A missiles in the short-range class, with the United States controlling the nuclear warheads. **********As the Soviet demand raised a new problem in the negotiations, the White House rejected a suggestion by former President Richard M. Nixon and his Secretary of State, Henry A. Kissinger, that the United States link a settlement on missiles in Europe to an agreement that would reduce Soviet conventional forces. **********Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the United States would seek to reduce conventional forces, but opposed linkage. **********On the West German missiles, American officials say that the Soviet Union did not raise the issue during Secretary of State George P. Shultz's recent trip to Moscow. But today, in presenting a Soviet treaty draft in Geneva, Soviet negotiators said the American warheads for the Pershing 1A's must be destroyed, American officials said. **********Although some Americans portrayed the Soviet move as a setback, one senior official said NATO should consider eliminating the warheads for the Pershing 1A's. He said it was not realistic to expect to keep them under a ban on American and Soviet missiles. **********The Soviet treaty draft pointed up other disagreements. **********The two sides had agreed to eliminate medium-range missiles from Europe, while keeping 100 warheads each outside Europe. The Soviet draft would reportedly bar the United States from deploying its 100 in Alaska, within range of Soviet territory. The United States wants to reserve the right to deploy in Alaska. **********The Soviet draft would also block the United States from converting any of its Pershing 2 medium-range missiles into Pershing 1B short-range missiles. The United States wants to retain this right unless all American and Soviet short-range missiles are eliminated. **********The draft talked about a ''global approach'' on short-range missiles, but did not commit itself on eliminating them from Asia as well as from Europe. The United States says there can be no distinction between short-range missiles in Europe and in Asia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/22/busin.main_headline: Play It Again, Sam - In Color
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/22/busin.print_headline: ADVANCES IN COLORIZATION; Play It Again, Sam - In Color
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/22/busin.body_text: **********It took more than a paintbrush to give Santa Claus rosy cheeks in ''Miracle on 34th Street'' or to create a blue suit for Cary Grant in ''Topper.'' It costs as much as $350,000 per film and requires the help of I.B.M.-PC's, Apple Macintoshes and similar computers, as well as patience and artistic license to transform black and white films and television programs into new commercial video releases for broadcast and pay television, for use in VCR's and for airline licensing. **********The technique has already transformed 63 films, and an estimated 100 will follow this year, casting a green pall over the entertainment industry. Critics of the process profess to be ''sickened'' by the altered classics. Those who wish they had thought of the idea first are envious of the colorization computer wizards -Toronto-based Colorization Inc. and Marina del Rey-based Color Systems Technology Inc. Also, television stations, video cassette producers and the film owners are raking in money. **********Coloring increases a film's revenue producing value many times over. There are more than 17,000 black and white motion pictures and 1,400 black and white television series in this country, which can be colorized much less expensively than a new color film can be made. **********A newcomer, American Film Technologies Inc., has already pounced on the opportunity and expects its first film by August. **********On average a studio movie costs about $16 million, an independent feature $4 million and a television movie more than $2 million. **********The system used by Color Systems Technology works like this:  STEP 1  The original black and white film is transferred to videotape, which is viewed on a high-resolution monitor.  STEP 2  The movie is then broken down into separate frames, scene by scene.  STEP 3  The first and last frames of each scene are studied by an art director, who uses historical records to assign colors to every area of the picture -background, props, clothes, hair, eyes and skin.  STEP 4  With the black and white original on the computer screen, an operator uses a computer palette to assign appropriate colors - transforming the picture on the screen into a colored one. The color can be altered by electronically adding subsequent layers of colors.  STEP 4  With the black and white original on the computer screen, an operator uses a computer palette to assign appropriate colors - transforming the picture on the screen into a colored one. The color can be altered by electronically adding subsequent layers of colors.  STEP 6  Finally, the color values for each frame, thus stored, are combined in the final operation in the patented ''color adder,'' which marries the original black and white material to the color information to produce a colored videotape. Shots are balanced and edited back into their original position.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Rise in Prices Flattens Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/02/busin.body_text: **********The sharp move to lower interest rates that coincided with the Oct. 19 break in stock prices seems to have lost some momentum in the past week as the enthusiasm that carried bond prices straight up last month is being leavened by the skepticism and caution of institutional investors. **********When bond prices were rising 12 points and yields were falling to 9.10 percent by Oct. 23, from 10.45 percent at the start of trading on Oct. 19, the conclusion in the bond market was overwhelming: the stock market decline would cause cutbacks in consumer and business spending that would lead to a weaker economy, lower inflation and lower interest rates. **********Over the past week, however, bond yields edged lower only slightly, closing Friday at 9.03 percent, and securities dealers said demand by institional investors was noticeably weaker than in the previous week. **********Some said the inability of bond prices to continue rising was due to the modest rebound in the stock market last week and diminishing fears of recession. If stock prices recover quickly, some traders worry that note and bond prices could be hit by selling by some fickle money managers who just recently fled the stock market, but are scrambling to get back in. Dollar Still an Issue **********Others pointed to the weakness in the dollar, which discourages purchases by foreigners. Foreign demand for Treasury issues is especially important, analysts noted, as the Treasury auctions $23.75 billion of notes and bonds this week, including 10- and 30-year issues that have attracted strong demand from Japanese investors the last two years. **********The more sedate behavior of bond prices last week seemed to reflect the mixture of views among institutional investors, many of whom remain optimistic that rates will decline further. Others are not so sure, however, and want to see more economic data, while some doubt the recent drop in rates can be sustained. **********''There are lots of silver linings in this whole episode, and I'm more optimistic about the economy and future than in a long time,'' said Marshall B. Front, executive vice president at Stein, Roe & Farnham, a Chicago investment advisory firm. ''We come out of this episode with lower inflation, lower interest rates, enhanced respect for the ability of central bankers to create a stable dollar and some agreement between the President and Congress to reduce the budget deficit.'' **********Mr. Front said further declines in Treasury bond yields were likely, though the extent of the drop would depend on how much economic activity slumps in response to the stock market decline. If inflation remains at the 3.8 percent forecast by Stein, Roe, or lower, Mr. Front said there could be a return of the 7 percent bond yield forecast by many analsyts when the year began. 'Not Much of a Recession' **********''The talk about a really enormous slowdown in the economy is misplaced,'' Mr. Front said. ''We expect a slowdown, but not much of a recession at all'' with a drop in G.N.P. after inflation of about 1 percent in the fourth quarter, followed by growth of one-half of 1 percent in the first quarter, 3 percent in the second quarter and more than 4 percent the next two quarters. **********But Henry J. Gailliot, senior vice president at the Federated Research Corportion, a Pittsburgh-based investment adviser, said he thought that ''people who bought bonds since September will be glad they did two years from now.'' Those bonds offer good yields and value in the face of inflation and the stock market, he said. **********But Mr. Gailliot added that recent euphoria in the bond market did not prove that a long-lived trend for higher bond prices and lower yields was under way and was no reason to abandon the discipline and investment rules learned from past business cycles. **********''The turn in the bond market doesn't come until a recession is started, and sometimes well into the recession,'' he said. ''I don't yet see signs of a recession, so I'm not sure a real bull makret in bonds has begun.'' Preferring the Short Term **********Edward Sporl, a fixed-income portfolio manager at Siebel Capital Management, in Larkspur, Calif., said he continued to keep investments in short-term securities where the risk of loss was low. **********The turnaround in long-term bond prices earlier this month ''is based on some assumptions that I just don't accept,'' he said, noting that forecasts of less consumer spending and more saving are highly tentative. **********''I see what has happened as more of a technical problem in the stock market, and not the direct result of any tight money policy by the Fed or a larger economic phenomenon,'' Mr. Sporl said. **********''We don't know where the economy will be in three or six months, but you do know there will be even more liquidity in the system'' to fuel economic growth and put renewed upward pressure on interest rates, he added. ''I have been in cash since last summer, and I have stayed there through this latest whilrwind,'' he said. **********Questions about the economic effects of the stock market decline are undoubtedly being asked at the Federal Reserve. So far, the Fed has made sure that credit is readily available to securities dealers experiencing a cash shortage and has encouraged a drop in the interest rate on overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market to around 6 3/4 percent Thursday and Friday, from 7 1/2 percent before Oct. 19. **********But analysts noted that the drop in the overnight rate was much less than the Fed could have caused and has not been accompanied by a cut in the discount rate the Fed charges on loans to financial institutions. Warning by the Fed **********Some analysts see an important, but unstated warning in the Fed's reluctance to push down short-term rates more sharply. ''If the Fed doesn't think the economy is going to be so hard hit that they need to cut the discount rate, then maybe the bond market is exaggerating the extent of the damage to the economy from the stock market,'' one securities dealer said. **********In coming weeks, many analysts expect that growth in the money supply will accelerate sharply, as turmoil in the financial markets causes an inflow of money into bank deposits. But they are not sure if the surge in money supply growth will be accompanied by more overt signs of an easing in Federal Reserve monetary policy. **********Those signs might not come, they say, unless there is agreement to increase taxes, a coordinated move with Japan and West Germany to lower rates or clear signs of a weakening in economic activity. **********One result of the mixture of opinions about the rate outlook has been a sharp increase in trading activity in the Treasury securities market. According to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, trading of 40 primary dealers in the Treasury market averaged nearly $173 billion a day in the week of Oct. 21, up from about $114.6 billion the previous week and an average of slightly more than $100 billion earlier this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/07/busin.main_headline: A.T.&T. SEEKS TO LIFT CURB ON PROFIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/07/busin.print_headline: A.T.&T. SEEKS TO LIFT CURB ON PROFIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/07/busin.body_text: **********Seeking to eliminate one of the last vestiges of telephone regulation, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked Federal authorities yesterday to remove limits on what it can earn from long-distance service. **********A.T.&T. also proposed that it no longer have to prove that changes in long-distance rates or services are necessary or reasonable. Instead, the burden of proof would be shifted to competitors and consumers who challenge the changes. **********The company's action, in a filing to the Federal Communications Commission, comes amid evidence that A.T.&T.'s unregulated competitors now feel that long-distance rates have fallen too far, causing them millions of dollars in losses. On Thursday A.T.&T.'s largest long-distance competitor, the MCI Communications Corporation, reversed its stance and endorsed the total deregulation of the telephone giant, apparently in hopes that would lead to general rate increases for A.T.&T. and its rivals. **********Yesterday, A.T.&T. welcomed MCI's move, and said the time had come to remove most remaining regulations on the company, particularly an F.C.C.-imposed regulation that its rate of return on telephone service could not exceed 12.2 percent. 'Only Regulated Game in Town' **********''A.T.&T. is the only regulated game in town, and people are paying a price for that,'' said Larry Garfinkel, the vice president of marketing services for the company, who said F.C.C. regulations had slowed the introduction of new technology. ''If you believe in competition, you have to let the market regulate A.T.&T.'' **********Analysts said they expected the F.C.C. to embrace part, but probably not all, of A.T.&T.'s proposal. **********''It is certainly something we will look at seriously,'' said Albert Halprin, the chief of the F.C.C.'s common carrier bureau. ''But I would look to the end of the year before we will have an answer.'' **********Just two years ago, it would have been unthinkable, analysts note, that A.T.&T.'s competitors would have endorsed a total deregulation of the company. In filings and public statements, they expressed fears that the company could exploit its size and longstanding position in the telephone market to drive smaller competitors out of business. The Major Force **********But now nearly 70 percent of the country's telephone users have chosen a provider for long-distance services, and A.T.&T. has retained about 80 percent of the market. And the two chief competitors, MCI and U S Sprint, seem convinced that the company will not cut prices further to gain market share. **********''The largest constraint on A.T.&T. would be a political one - they can't be seen to be driving competitors out of business,'' said Lee Selwyn, the president of Economics and Technology Inc., a Boston analysis firm. **********But he said that ''the bottom line is that the public, both resident and business users, are worse off'' if A.T.&T. is deregulated. He said, that freed of regulation, A.T.&T. would likely raise rates steeply and double its rate of return, to more than 25 percent. **********At A.T.&T., Mr. Garfinkel disagreed. ''It's truly a competitive marketplace right now,'' he said. ''So if you believe that exists, we are really precluded from raising rates very much.'' **********Christopher Jackson, a communications analyst for the Yankee Group in Boston, agreed that ''any increases would happen gradually, but there is an increasing consensus that regulation is not good for anybody.'' Rates Have Fallen **********Since 1984, when divestiture began in earnest, long-distance rates have fallen about 30 percent. But at the same time, MCI and U S Sprint have spent billions of dollars on equipment and fiber-optic networks, and executives concede that at current rate levels it would be difficult at best to turn a profit. **********A.T.&T. said that it would commit itself to continuing basic long-distance service nationwide, and would maintain uniform nationwide prices, even in rural regions. **********It also said that ''price controls,'' but not profit controls, would be imposed on some basic services. Analysts guessed that if any regulations were retained, they would probably be those protecting smaller customers, particularly in areas not served by other carriers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/world.main_headline: 4,000 Refugees of Civil War Return Home to El Salvador
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/world.print_headline: 4,000 Refugees of Civil War Return Home to El Salvador
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/world.body_text: **********About 4,000 refugees from the civil war in El Salvador returned home today after years in Honduras. **********The refugees crossed into northern Chalatenango Province and were processed by army officials, according to reporters at the scene. They were to be taken to various parts of the country. **********Most of the refugees who have fled the civil war live in camps near the Honduran border. Those returning today were mainly from the Mesa Grande Refugee Camp, run by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, who organized the return. **********Both the Honduran and the Salvadoran governments have in the past accused refugees of collaborating with the leftist guerrillas fighting to overthrow the Salvadoran Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/15/world.print_headline: U.S. Finds It Made Little Progress in U.N. Voting
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/15/world.body_text: **********The United States has made little progress winning votes at the United Nations, despite assertions by Vernon A. Walters, the chief American representative, and other diplomats that the American position is improving, according to a report by the United States Mission. **********The report, an annual feature from the United States Mission since 1983, states that the average member nation voted with the United States 23.7 percent of the time in the General Assembly session last fall, an increase of only one percentage point from the year before. **********Officials at the mission said the statistic does not necessarily contradict assertions that the United States is making progress, because it does not reflect votes considered more important than others. Mr. Walters was not available for comment. **********The mission is working to persuade Congress to resume paying in full its dues to the United Nations. The United States has withheld nearly $300 million in dues because of complaints about the administration of the United Nations and its political slant. **********The report was made public last week without the news conference that has accompanied release of similar reports in the past.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/01/busin.main_headline: Underwritings Shrank 8.7% in Second Quarter By JAMES STERNGOLD
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/01/busin.print_headline: Underwritings Shrank 8.7% in Second Quarter By JAMES STERNGOLD
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/01/busin.body_text: **********A sudden surge in interest rates and unstable bond prices cooled the market for new securities underwritings in the second quarter from the sizzling pace of the previous year. **********A total of $69.2 billion in securities was issued in the second quarter, ended yesterday, according to the Securities Data Company. The total was down 8.7 percent from the $75.8 billion in securities issued by corporations in this country in the second quarter of 1986 and 21.4 percent from the record of $88 billion in the first quarter of this year, according to Securities Data. **********The decline in underwritings provided another vivid example of how difficult the last three months have been for Wall Street. **********The period was marked by a steep rise in interest rates in April that sent bond prices plummeting and handed huge losses to a number of securities firms, including Merrill Lynch & Company, the First Boston Corporation and Salomon Brothers. Those firms have said that they will either report a large decline in overall earnings in the second quarter or a loss. **********''It was really not a bad quarter for us,'' said Geoffrey T. Boisi, co-head of investment banking at Goldman, Sachs & Company, which rose from sixth spot last year to second this quarter in the underwriting rankings. ''But there's no doubt there was some tapering off because a lot of the pent-up demand over the last two years has been exhausted because of the bullish markets we had before.'' **********Reflecting the unsettled conditions that prevailed in the bond market, the amount of debt securities issued by corporations dropped to $52.7 billion, from $58.4 billion a year earlier, according to Securities Data. Common stock offerings declined more modestly, to $13.5 billion, from $14.6 billion a year earlier. **********For the first half of the year, total underwritings rose on the back of a powerful first-quarter surge. According to Securities Data, underwritings in the first half totaled $157.3 billion, up from $144 billion in the first six months of 1986. **********The shifts in the markets in the second quarter led to changes in the underwriting rankings of the securities firms. But Salomon Brothers, the perennial leader, hung on to the premier spot, in spite of an overall drop in its underwritings. According to Securities Data, Salomon Brothers underwrote $10.3 billion in corporate securities in the second quarter, down from $12.3 billion a year earlier. **********The firm's position was bolstered by its grip on the top spot in debt underwritings, with $9.4 billion in the quarter. Elsewhere, Salomon jumped to fourth in underwritings of high-yield, low-quality ''junk bonds'' from ninth the year before. But it tumbled to ninth from second in stock underwritings. **********Goldman's move to the No. 2 positions reflected an increase in its underwritings of both stock and bonds. Merrill Lynch rose to third from fifth. Junk Bond Market Shrinks **********One of the largest moves was made by Drexel Burnham Lambert, which fell from second last year to seventh in the just completed quarter. Drexel continued to hold onto its top position in junk bonds, but that market shrank to $6 billion in new issues in the second quarter from $11.2 billion last year, according to Securities Data. **********Leaping upward was Baltimore-based Alex. Brown & Sons, to 10th position in the rankings, from 18th a year earlier. Most of the difference was accounted for by one underwriting, the huge $1.5 billion Nuveen Municipal Fund, which Brown managed. **********The global securities market, including the United States domestic market and the so-called Euromarkets, also experienced some decline in the volume of underwritings. According to Securities Data, global underwritings fell to $113.6 billion in the second quarter, from $130.7 billion the year earlier. For the first half of 1987, global underwritings rose to $256.6 billion, from $248.2 billion a year earlier. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/16/busin.body_text: **********The military contracting industry, which was riding high only several years ago as the Reagan Administration pursued the largest arms buildup in American peacetime history, is now heading into what may be its most difficult and competitive era. **********Last month's stock market collapse and the new urgency it brought to cutting the Federal budget deficit has put even greater pressure on Congress and the White House to hold down Pentagon spending, which, in inflation-adjusted terms, has been declining at an average annual rate of about 3 percent since 1985. **********Most estimates are that budget negotiations between Congress and the White House will yield a Pentagon budget of between $289 billion and $296 billion for the current fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30. That would be roughly flat or even another decline when inflation is taken into account. Further Cuts Possible **********If the negotiations in Washington fail and the Federal budget were cut across the board under the provisions of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit reduction act, the Pentagon's budget could be pared to as little as $275 billion. **********With budget cutting likely to remain a high priority no matter what happens in the 1988 elections, industry executives now expect the Pentagon appropriation at best to grow only slightly - and at worst to decline steadily, well into the 1990's. Because military pay is unlikely to be cut substantially, the burden of any cuts will fall most heavily on weapons procurement plans. **********The probable cuts come at a time when the major aerospace and arms companies are struggling to adapt to new, more stringent procurement rules that are forcing the industry to take on more financial risk and responsibility. Contractors are paying more of the upfront costs of designing and building new weapons and are generally being paid less - and at a slower rate - for their work. **********''The environment for military contractors right now is dominated by down-trending defense budgets and more difficult contracting terms,'' said Jerry Cantwell, an analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company. ''The returns in the business have come down and at the same time the investment requirements have gone up.'' Gloomier Profit Outlook **********In the short run, the budget squeeze means that some weapons programs will be delayed, scaled back or even canceled, hurting contractors' profits. New programs will be few and far between. Reflecting the new reality, Frank C. Carlucci, President Reagan's nominee to replace Caspar W. Weinberger as Secretary of Defense, told Congress last week, ''I don't think anything can be sacrosanct.'' **********The budget cuts and the new procurement rules also are combining to spawn or accelerate restructuring and diversification plans and the slow consolidation of the industry. **********''A few years ago I would think in terms of it taking three to four years to move from negative cash flow on a program to positive cash flow,'' said Fred Wood, an executive vice president of the General Dynamics Corporation. ''Now I think in terms of 10 years.'' **********Mr. Wood and other industry executives argue that the cash squeeze will weaken the industry and hurt the nation. The squeeze, they say, will force contractors to delay investments in more efficient production facilities. It will also lead to an erosion of their engineering expertise at a time when technological advances are becoming increasingly important to weapons development. Weinberger Departure a Factor **********But that argument is not expected to bear much weight in Washington, especially with the departure of Mr. Weinberger, a hard-core supporter of increased military spending. **********The nearly completed agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union to eliminate intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe has further weakened political support for higher military budgets, despite arguments by some experts that the agreement should lead to an increase in spending on conventional weapons. ''Arms control is seen as a substitute for defense spending,'' Mr. Cantwell said. **********The attitude of Wall Street analysts and investors toward military companies reflects this assessment. Analysts say that while some contractors may suffer more than others, depending on which programs are trimmed, the industry's earnings in general will be lackluster in coming years. The industry's growing problems have long depressed the stock prices of aerospace and weapons companies. Aerospace May Suffer Most **********While the potential cuts could affect everything from ships to tanks, the new reality may hit hardest at the large aerospace companies. Executives of the Grumman Corporation of Bethpage, L.I., for example, concede that their A-6F carrier-based attack plane, an updated version of a venerable Navy aircraft, is in for a difficult fight as Congress seeks spending cuts. **********Similarly, Congress may eliminate from this year's spending bill the $564 million needed for the Marine Corps to acquire 32 more AV-8B Harrier attack jets from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. Development and production money for a number of other missile and airplane programs, including the Advanced Technical Bomber being designed by the Northrop Corporation, is also being trimmed. **********''Things are definitely tougher on the contracting front,'' said Daniel R. Stanley, manager of government programs and business planning at McDonnell Douglas. ''We have to be more competitive. The environment makes it more difficult to make money.'' 2 Monumental Projects Perhaps most worrisome to the industry is the possible long-term effect of sustained budget cutting on the Navy's attack plane of the future, called the Advanced Tactical Aircraft, and on the Air Force's next generation of fighter planes, called the Advanced Tactical Fighter, or A.T.F. Those two programs are not only among the biggest in the works - the Air Force estimates that it will spend $40 billion to build 750 of the A.T.F.'s - they are also the most important examples of the new risks inherent in competing for major contracts. **********Two teams of contractors are competing to build the A.T.F. One team consists of the Lockheed Corporation, the Boeing Company and General Dynamics. The other is made up of Northrop and McDonnell Douglas. The Air Force has awarded each team a $691 million contract to design and build two flying prototypes. But each team is expected to put about $400 million of its own money into the project, a practice known in the industry as cost sharing. **********Even if the A.T.F. program proceeds as planned, the losing team will suffer significant write-offs as its cost-sharing money goes down the drain. But if budget cuts cause the program to be stretched over a longer period or reduce the number of planes ordered, even the winning team might have difficulty making a profit, analysts said. In the worst case, Congress could opt not to pay for any production, leaving both teams in the cold. Optimism for the Short Term **********Despite the current budget environment, industry executives remain hopeful about the program's short-term prospects. ''I don't think it will suffer significantly - maybe marginally but not enough to harm the program through the prototype stage,'' said John C. Brizendine, the president of Lockheed's aeronautical systems group. In the long run, however, the chance that Congress might restrict production of the plane remains ''a hazard and a risk,'' he said. **********Even when a company wins a project unaffected by budget cuts, an automatic, hefty profit is no longer guaranteed, because of stricter procurement and payment rules spawned partly by widely publicized cost overruns and abuses like $400 hammers. **********Progress payments by the Pentagon have been reduced to 75 percent of contractors' monthly expenses, from 90 percent, with payments in many cases made after 30 days instead of 15. Profit margins have been trimmed by a percentage point or so, to about 11 percent, on the average production contract. Tax Changes Also Hurt **********Meanwhile, the new tax law has hit some contractors hard. It significantly tightened a loophole that had permitted them to delay paying taxes on profits until a program was completed. A further tightening of that rule has been proposed. **********The Pentagon is also reimbursing on fewer costs. For instance, the Pentagon used to pick up much of the tab for the costs of marketing a weapon abroad, on the theory that more orders for, say, a plane, would mean greater production efficiency and lower unit costs. No longer. In the same way, the armed services are demanding that contractors pay a greater share of special tooling costs for many programs. **********To cope with the new environment, most major aerospace companies are starting to slim down and cut costs. ''There are a lot of companies that built organizations to go after business that is not going to be there in the amount they had hoped,'' said John N. Simon, an analyst at Seidler Amdec Securities in Los Angeles. **********Some of the companies with the most glaring overcapacity are already consolidating their manufacturing plants and trimming their work forces. Lockheed, whose work force is shrinking as its major production programs wind down, announced in September that it would combine its three aircraft-building divisions. Similarly, General Dynamics is ''trying to take a meaningful percentage of costs out - I'm talking upwards of 30 percent,'' Mr. Wood said. A Loss of Big Projects **********Analysts predict that some companies may well end up being forced out of certain key markets altogether. **********The Rockwell International Corporation, for example, is within six months of finishing the last of 100 B-1B bombers it is assembling for the Air Force. After that, Rockwell, long one of the nation's premier military aircraft builders, will not only lack a major airframe production contract but will have little chance of winning one soon. **********Rockwell, like Lockheed and many other companies, is instead pushing into military electronics by acquiring some of the nation's top companies in that sector. That field has been one of the fastest-growing in the industry because the real improvements in weapons are coming not from bigger or heavier planes, tanks and guns but from more accurate guidance, detection and communications technology. But electronics too has become increasingly competitive, and analysts warn that it is no panacea for companies seeking a haven from budget cutting.
