https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/31/world.body_text: **********President Daniel Ortega Saavedra suggested today it might be possible for his Government to negotiate a cease-fire indirectly with leaders of the United States-backed rebels. **********In the past, the Government has ruled out such contacts. But in comments today, Mr. Ortega appeared to open the possibility that a formula could be found for cease-fire negotiations, using the Roman Catholic Primate of Nicaragua, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, as an intermediary. **********The Central American peace accord signed three months ago requires the Sandinista Government and others in the region to take steps toward a cease-fire by Nov. 5. The Sandinistas have decreed a unilateral cease-fire in four small zones, but critics here and abroad say that is not enough. **********''We have not closed ourselves off from seeking an agreement,'' Mr. Ortega said when asked today about his posture toward the guerrillas, known as contras. **********This week, President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, author of the accord, said the Sandinistas were not doing enough to comply. He has urged that they make use of Cardinal Obando's services as a mediator.  AMERICAN IS REPORTED FREED MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 30 (Special to The New York Times) - A spokesman for the American-backed rebels in Nicaragua said today they had released an American volunteer they had been holding for two weeks. **********The American, Paul Fisher, was detained by the rebels, who halted a bus he was riding in from Chontales Province on Oct. 17.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/03/busin.body_text: **********The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission will recommend that the Washington Public Power Supply System be charged with securities fraud in its record $2.25 billion bond default of 1983, a lawyer for the utility group said today. **********The lawyer, Ron English, confirmed a report in The Wall Street Journal, saying that the S.E.C. staff had advised the utility of plans to seek civil charges against it in connection with defaulted bonds used to finance two proposed nuclear power plants. The supply system is a consortium of 88 utilities in the Pacific Northwest that floated bonds to finance nuclear power projects. **********The five S.E.C. commissioners will be asked to charge the utility group with overstating the demand for power in the region and underestimating the cost of the two plants to promote the bond offering.

They also acknowledged that the 50-cents-a-share increase in the offer for the shares of A.M.C. was that company's price for co-operation in the merger. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/02/world.main_headline: POLISH MAY DAY: SPEECHES, ARRESTS AND AIR OF TENSION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/02/world.print_headline: POLISH MAY DAY: SPEECHES, ARRESTS AND AIR OF TENSION
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/02/world.body_text: **********Polish police officers confronted workers leaving a Warsaw church today, snatching from them a banner with a quotation from the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev: ''We need democracy like we need air.'' **********Elsewhere in Warsaw, the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, declared that Poland was heading down ''the still-bumpy road'' of reform and democratization. **********The events at two May Day rallies, one huge and official, the other small, unauthorized and encircled by the police, reflected the tensions and anxieties that continue to ripple through state and society. At both observances the major themes were improved production and national enrichment. **********At the official rally, the answers stressed discipline and patriotic duty. At the church, the call was for guarantees of the rights of free choice, free expression and free association. Jaruzelski's 'Ideals' **********''To live in dignity, to think creatively, to work assiduously, to effectively manage the economy and to share rewards justly - these are the ideals which will remain on workers' banners forever,'' General Jaruzelski said. **********''We are building a struggle against all that offends the sense of social justice, ignores human suffering and wrongs, breaks the rule of law and discipline and the value of work,'' he said. **********The Polish leader spoke at the start of the parade in which thousands of delegates from factories and offices marched under posters declaring ''Reform Is a Chance for Poland and for All of Us,'' and ''The Work of Poles Guarantees the Power of Poland.'' **********At the same time scarcely two miles away, at St. Stanislaw Kostka Church, a truck driver, Marek Miecznikowski, addressed 2,000 people who had managed to filter through dozens of police checkpoints at which many more people were turned away. No 'Protection of Law' **********''For us, the people of work,'' he said, ''this is still not a real holiday of dignified labor because we do not have the protection of law. We supposedly have the right to free expression of ideas, but we live in a time of police oppression. We have a legal right to our own unions, but those of Solidarity and the other independent unions have been liquidated.'' **********There were attempts to mount demonstrations elsewhere in the country, where, as in Warsaw, military reserves were called up and police leaves were canceled. **********In Wroclaw, 50 people, including a Solidarity supporter, Wladyslaw Frasyniuk, were taken into custody when they tried to march under the banner of the outlawed union. In Poznan, about a dozen people were seized. **********The Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, said almost all of those detained would be released within hours to appear later in magistrates' courts, which usually issue fines. Mr. Urban said 10 million people took part in official May Day parades throughout Poland. Statement by Walesa **********In Gdansk, the founder of Solidarity, Lech Walesa, ignored the shouted urgings of churchgoers who wanted him to lead them in a march. He took note of the tremendous formations of police, saying, ''I don't like to lead losing battles.'' **********He went home, hung a Solidarity banner from his window and issued a statement in which he said: ''The authorities who call themselves workers are ruled by fear. Those who regard themselves as a vanguard of humanity must hide behind cordons of police.'' **********The confrontation with the police at the Warsaw church came two months after a citizens' committee of 160 people had sought to test and expand Warsaw's echoes of the calls for openness and democratization by Mr. Gorbachev. The committee petitioned local authorities to hold an independent May Day march, limiting marchers to 10 slogans that have appeared in official publications. **********The request was denied on the grounds that the slogans were inappropriate and that some members of the committee had in the past provoked violence. Arrests on Way to Church **********Some of the best-known members of the committee, including Konrad Bielinski, Viktor Krulewski, Jan Litynski and Henryk Wujec, were detained on Thursday for 48 hours. Other opposition figures, like Zbigniew Bujak, the former fugitive leader of the Solidarity underground, and Janusz Onyskiewicz, a former Solidarity spokesman, were picked up as they headed for the church today. **********At the end of the religious service, a few dozen people raised banners with the slogans. Before they walked a hundred feet off the church grounds, squads of plainclothesmen darted from behind lines of uniformed policemen to pull down the signs. In several instances, marchers were beaten. Eight people were detained. DEMONSTRATIONS IN MANAGUA **********MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 1 (Special to The New York Times)- Opposition and pro-Government labor unions staged separate demonstrations here without incident today, as May Day was observed with less fanfare than in previous years. **********At the largest rally, a Sandinista official, Victor Tirado Lopez, told several thousand workers that the country's economic crisis could not be resolved while armed conflict continued. **********The largest non-Sandinista march was sponsored by the Confederation for Labor Unity, which is affiliated with the AFL-CIO. More than 1,000 of its supporters chanted slogans and carried anti-Government placards. **********At the Sandinista rally in Managua, relatives of the American engineer killed by rebel fire in the countryside on Tuesday, Benjamin Ernest Linder, expressed support for Nicaragua.''

The progress made was considered satisfactory, it said. **********Cocom examines Western exports to East bloc nations to insure that technology that could improve the bloc's military effort is not delivered.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/23/world.body_text: **********A drug trafficker was killed and a police sergeant wounded in a shootout at a cocaine laboratory in a remote Amazon basin river valley, the Interior Ministry said today. A ministry spokesman said the gun battle erupted when the police burst into the laboratory on Monday in the hamlet of Alto Limon, 275 miles northeast of Lima, and found three Colombian drug traffickers and their Peruvian bodyguards. The police destroyed the laboratory, seizing 880 pounds of liquid cocaine paste and nearly two pounds of refined paste.

Penney Company has made an investment in the Stinu Corporation of Los Angeles, which operates the Units chain of women's specialty stores. Penney would become the largest shareholder in the company. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/25/world.main_headline: A Lament in Bethlehem: 'This Is Not Christmas'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/25/world.print_headline: A Lament in Bethlehem: 'This Is Not Christmas'
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/25/world.body_text: **********Israeli troops in soggy winter coveralls lined streets today and watched from rooftops as a choir sang in the rain to a thin crowd in the biblical birthplace of Jesus. **********Many stores were still closed to protest the Israeli Army's killing of Palestinian protesters in two weeks of rioting in the occupied territories. The Israeli Government has said 21 Palestinians were killed; other accounts have put the toll at 22 or higher. **********An uneasy quiet reigned today throughout the West Bank and the Gaza Strip as Israeli security forces continued making arrests, estimated by an army spokesman to have reached several hundred. **********''Like any wave there is a peak and then it quiets down,'' the army spokesman, Ephraim Lapid, said. ''This is a relative quieting down.'' A Handful of Customers **********But the unrest has already taken a toll on tourism. In Bethlehem, where souvenir-shop windows beckoned with lighted nativity scenes and olive-wood figurines, there were just a handful of customers. ''There are so few people, and there are soldiers everywhere -this is not Christmas,'' a Bethlehem resident said. **********To get into Manger Square, where the activities were concentrated this afternoon, tourists had to stand in line for up to half an hour before being searched by soldiers and policewomen. **********''It's not that I'm scared, but I don't like the atmosphere much,'' a British tourist said. **********Although the religious ceremonies were to proceed as planned, the Mayor of Bethlehem, Elias Freij canceled his annual Christmas cocktail party, usually attended by Israeli leaders and political figures. **********''Today the city will be very quiet,'' Mayor Freij said. ''With all the rain, cold and political tension, people are not in the mood to celebrate.'' **********More than 100 Franciscan brothers, priests and altar boys greeted the Latin Patriarch's procession to Jerusalem, but only a Boy Scout band took part in the march. Other groups, protesting the recent violence, refused. A Darkened Tree in Nazareth **********In Nazareth, an Arab town inside Israel where Christian scripture says Jesus grew to manhood, the City Council decided to leave the town's Christmas tree dark and to take down strings of colored street lights. **********It was difficult to assess the immediate effect of recent events on tourism, but several hotels in the Jerusalem area said at least 10 percent of their guests had canceled reservations. **********The effects will probably be felt most in the spring, travel agents said, because people who have prepaid reservations are unlikely to cancel at the last moment. ''The American market is the most sensitive,'' Garo Garabedian, a travel agent, said. State Dept. Travel Warning **********A State Department advisory warning Americans not to travel in the West Bank, Gaza or East Jerusalem may provoke further cancelations, travel agents said. **********''That was the most damaging thing that could happen to us,'' said Harvey Douglen, the manager of the Ramada Renaissance Hotel. ''If they wanted to punish us, they did a good job.'' **********Some who made the pilgrimage to Bethlehem said they felt no danger. **********''I've been here four times already and every time they've told me not to come,'' an American woman said. ''But it's much more scary when you're sitting over there in the United States -here there's nothing to worry about.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/05/world.main_headline: PRISONER RELEASE IN SOVIET IS LIKELY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/05/world.print_headline: PRISONER RELEASE IN SOVIET IS LIKELY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/05/world.body_text: **********Several imprisoned dissidents have recently been transferred to prisons near their homes in what human rights advocates and diplomats say may be the first stage of a widespread release. **********Yelena G. Bonner, a rights advocate and the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, said today that she had heard of six prisoners' being moved and that some family members had been told they would be freed. **********''Something is happening, we think, we hope, but we are not certain,'' Miss Bonner said. **********The mothers of two prisoners, Aleksei Smirnov and Mikhail S. Rivkin, said their sons, who were serving prison sentences in Chistopol in the Tatar republic for involvement in underground journals, had been moved to Lefortovo prison in Moscow. **********The two women said their sons had been offered freedom in exchange for an agreement to sign some sort of statement with unspecified content. Statement Signed by Prisoner **********The mother of Mr. Rivkin, Inna Golubovskaya, said she had been told by prison officials that her son had signed a statement and would be released within two weeks. She said she had been told that he would be permitted to live and work in Moscow. **********Mr. Smirnov's mother, Yelena Kosterin, said her son had been told he would be set free if he signed a statement acknowledging past wrongdoing. **********Mr. Rivkin, 32, was part of a group of young Muscovites who published a clandestine journal that criticized Soviet policy from the point of view of the Western European Socialists. Mr. Smirnov, 36, contributed to two other underground journals, the Chronicle of Current Events and Vesti. **********The reports of prisoner transfers come a week after the news that two human rights advocates, Anatoly Koryagin and Sergei Khodorovich, had been promised their freedom if they agreed to emigrate. **********Miss Bonner said other prisoners reportedly moved to their hometowns were Valery A. Senderov of Moscow, who was arrested in 1982 for trying to organize an independent trade union, and Genrikh O. Altunyan and Yevgeny M. Antsupov of Kharkov, who were serving sentences for statements critical of Soviet authority. **********According to Miss Bonner and Dr. Sakharov, one and possibly both of two Georgian brothers imprisoned for dissident activities - Tengis and Eduard Gudava - have reportedly been transferred to Tbilisi, the Georgian capital. **********Several of the prisoners were on a list on whose behalf Dr. Sakharov appealed to Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********Mr. Koryagin, one of the two subject to deportation, is a psychiatrist imprisoned for his efforts to expose the abuse of mental hospitals. He was reported today to have been moved to Kharkov. **********According to an emigre group in Munich, West Germany, his wife said by telephone that she had not been allowed to see him and did not know whether he was willing to emigrate. **********Miss Bonner said that Mr. Khodorovich's wife had made the required payment for an exit visa, indicating that the family had accepted the offer to leave the Soviet Union. Emigration is generally severely restricted for all Soviet citizens.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/19/world.body_text: **********A lawyer for three Israelis in the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy case said today that he had advised them not to testify before a Government commission examining the affair. David Libai, the lawyer, said he told Yosef Yagur, former science counsel at the Israeli Embassy in Washington, Ilan Ravid, former science attache at the embassy, and Irit Erb, a secretary, not to appear because anything they said could be used against them later.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/29/busin.body_text: **********The Philip Morris Companies reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings climbed 31.1 percent on a 23.6 percent rise in revenues. **********''General Foods contributed 19 percent to Philip Morris's pretax operating income - income before corporate and interest expense - and Miller Brewing had a good year, contributing about 4 percent to pretax operating income,'' Lawrence Pidgeon, an analyst at Goldman Sachs & Company, said. **********Philip Morris, the largest cigarette producer in the United States, said net income in the latest three months rose to $371 million, or $1.56 a share, from $283 million, or $1.19 a share, in the corresponding 1985 quarter. Operating revenues increased to $6.55 billion from $5.30 billion. **********For the full year, Philip Morris said earnings increased 17.5 percent, to $1.48 billion, or $6.20 a share, from $1.26 billion, or $5.24 a share, in 1985. Revenues soared 59.2 percent, to $25.41 billion, from $15.96 billion. Gains by General Foods **********The General Foods Corporation, which was acquired by Philip Morris in November 1985, showed, for the full year, an increase in operating income of 7.2 percent, to $740 million, with revenues rising to $9.7 billion. **********The company said that full-year operating income from Miller Brewing rose 16.7 percent, to $158 million, on a 4.8 percent increase in operating revenue, to $3.1 billion. Miller's shipments for the year totaled 38.7 million barrels, a 4.4 percent increase over 1985 and the first significant gain in four years, the company said. **********Results for 1986 exclude the Seven-Up Company. Philip Morris sold the international operations of Seven-Up to Pepsico Inc. last July; the American franchise business was sold to a group of investors in November. **********''Both Philip Morris U.S.A. and Philip Morris International had gains in unit volume, market share, revenues, and operating income in 1986,'' Hamish Maxwell, chairman and chief executive of Philip Morris, said. ''Marlboro, the world's largest-selling cigarette, continued to gain worldwide share.'' **********In other areas, Philip Morris said both its real estate and financial services operations posted improved results for the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/busin.main_headline: For Chemcapital Head, New Role, New Risks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; For Chemcapital Head, New Role, New Risks
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/17/busin.body_text: **********Suresh Bhirud, the former chief investment strategist at the First Boston Corporation, is ready to practice what he has preached. ''Instead of just giving advice to other people,'' he said yesterday, ''I will be putting my neck on the line and managing other people's money.'' **********Mr. Bhirud, 38, has become a principal of Chemcapital, a new money management unit of the Chemical Bank. The other half of Chemcapital is Gerald Scriver, 44, who was a partner in Alexander Scriver, a money management firm in Denver, before selling his half to the Chemical Bank and moving to New York. He brought with him about $100 million in assets under management, which provides the base for Chemcapital. **********''We want to manage global portfolios for pension clients, domestic as well as international,'' Mr. Bhirud said. ''We also want to supply some exclusive research products to international ventures.'' **********While Chemcapital is a subsidiary of the Chemical Bank, Mr. Bhirud said it would run basically as an independent asset-management firm, with him as executive vice president and Mr. Scriver as president. **********Mr. Bhirud grew up in Bombay, where his father is a retired civil engineering professor. After graduating from the Regional Engineering College in Durgapur, he left for the Columbia Business School, where he was introduced to the stock market -and grew fascinated with it. **********Mr. Bhirud joined First Boston as a trainee 15 years ago and progressed to writing a regular weekly column on the market in which he selected the stock of the week. **********One article of which he is most proud was entitled ''On a Clear Day You Can See 2,000,'' written in spring 1983, when the Dow Jones industrial average was at 1,200. He predicted correctly, and a year ago he wrote, ''On a Clear Day You Can See 3,000.'' **********Of course, that has not yet happened, but Mr. Bhirud remains bullish. ''Everyone I see around me, from the Harvard Business School graduate to seasoned money managers, is preparing for a downturn,'' he said. ''So it can't occur. It only tells me that the market is going to go much higher.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/20/world.body_text: **********Mario Firmenich, the best-known leader of the leftist guerrillas who fought the Argentine Government in the early and middle 1970's, was found guilty today in a 1974 kidnapping-murder case and sentenced to life in prison. **********But under the terms of an agreement with Brazil, from which he was extradited in 1984, the 39-year-old Mr. Firmenich will serve no more than 30 years. **********Judge Carlos Luft of the Federal Court in the Buenos Aires suburb of San Martin, held that Mr. Firmenich was the mastermind of the kidnapping-for-ransom of Jorge and Juan Born, brothers who had acquired immense wealth as grain traders. **********The kidnappers killed the Borns' driver and a business associate who was with them when they were abducted on Sept. 19, 1974. The Borns were released months later after payment of an estimated $60 million in ransom. **********Mr. Firmenich was the principal leader of the Montoneros, the largest of the Argentine guerrilla organizations, whose actions included bombings, kidnappings and assaults on police and military units. **********The prosecution of Mr. Firmenich was part of a policy announced by President Raul Alfonsin when he took office in December 1983 to bring to justice both the guerrilla leadership and the military leaders who took power in 1976 and oversaw the counterinsurgency campaign in which an estimated 9,000 people died or disappeared. **********Mr. Alfonsin ordered the prosecution of seven people said to be former guerrilla chieftains and of the nine former armed forces commanders who made up the three military juntas that ruled Argentina between 1976 and 1983. **********Of the accused guerrilla leaders, Mr. Firmenich is the second to be found and tried. The first, Ricardo Obregon Cano, a former governor of the province of Cordoba, was found guilty of ''illegal association'' with the Montoneros and is serving a six-year sentence. **********All nine former military commanders were tried on charges of responsibility for deaths, disappearances, torture and other abuses. Five were convicted and are serving sentences ranging to life in prison. **********The Government's campaign against the former military and guerrilla leaders is distinct from the court proceedings initiated by human rights groups and prosecutors against several hundred other military and police officials, some of whom would go free under legislation now pending in Congress. Trials are also under way in at least five other cases involving guerrilla activity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/01/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT; NEW FORCE IN CANADA AIRLINES
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/01/busin.body_text: **********Move over, Air Canada. **********The jaunty commercial announcing the creation of Canadian Airlines International - beamed into Canadian homes during the Stanley Cup hockey playoffs - does not put things quite so bluntly, but the message is the same. **********The carrier, which was formed earlier this year by the $220 million merger of Canadian Pacific Airlines and Pacific Western Airlines, has laid down an unmistakable challenge to Air Canada, the Government-owned airline. **********''From now on, it's Goliath versus Goliath,'' said Murray Sigler, president of the new airline, in the company's 25th-floor executive suite overlooking Vancouver harbor. **********Mr. Sigler, 39 years old, and Rhys Eyton, the 51-year-old chairman of Canadian Airlines International, continue to commute between Vancouver and Calgary, Alberta, home base of Pacific Western. Mr. Eyton had been president and chief executive of Pacific Western and Mr. Sigler had been chief operating officer. Problems of Integrating Carriers **********The two executives, architects of a cost-conscious management policy that made it possible for Pacific Western to acquire the much larger but debt-ridden Canadian Pacific, are still wrestling with the problems of integrating the two airlines. Among other things, they must trim Canadian Pacific's $475 million debt; shed unwanted pilots, flight attendants and ground staff from a combined payroll of 13,000, and negotiate new contracts for the employees who remain. **********But already they have their sights set on a much grander goal: catching up to, and if possible surpassing, Air Canada. Because the Government is talking about selling its airline to private interests, possibly as early as next year, the prospects are for an all-out free-enterprise battle for pre-eminence on Canada's domestic routes, and, if governments permit it, on routes to the United States, Europe and Asia as well. **********In Canada, this marks a significant change. When it celebrated its 50th anniversary this year, Air Canada could look back on a history largely untroubled by competition. Under its parliamentary charter and an elaborate set of rules drawn up by Government regulatory bodies, it has had a monopoly, or something close to it, on many of the country's busiest domestic and international routes. With 22,000 employees, 115 aircraft and revenues of nearly $2 billion a year, the airline ranks as the 12th largest in the world. Protected by Government **********Air Canada's regulatory privileges continued for years after 1978, when deregulation in the United States ushered in an era of no-frills airlines, frequent-flier discounts and $99 coast-to-coast fares. Under rules that limited each of its competitors to 25 percent of its domestic route mileage, outlawed fare discounting and otherwise restricted competition, Air Canada regularly took more than 60 percent of a domestic and international market of more than 25 million passengers a year. **********The biggest loser was Canadian Pacific, which traced its history back to bush plane operations that sprang up in the 1920's. Although the modern airline was founded only in 1942, company histories recall a time when flight times for the smaller operators that preceded it were published as an addendum to the schedule for the Canadian Pacific Railway, and some stops were made only if the station manager at remote airfields waved a flag to indicate there were passengers below. **********But history counted for little after the founding of Trans-Canada Airlines in 1937, that later became Air Canada. Until 1959, when Canadian Pacific was granted its first transcontinental route, from Vancouver to Montreal, Canadian Pacific survived largely as a regional carrier in western Canada and as a pioneer of routes across the Pacific. Other domestic routes followed, and the airline expanded into South America and southern Europe. Still, it remained a weak sister to Air Canada at home. **********''We could carry you from one major center in Canada to another, but if you wanted to go from Spuzzem to Eakum-Seakum, you had to go Air Canada,'' said Peter Golding, employed for nine years by Canadian Pacific and recently named the corporate communications manager in Vancouver for Canadian Airlines International. ''Although we were an officially designated flag carrier, we were conspicuous by our absence from major markets at home.'' A Cautious Deregulation **********The first sign that Air Canada's dominance could be challenged came in 1984, when a ''freedom to move'' air policy was introduced by the Government of the Prime Minister at the time, Pierre Elliott Trudeau. Although more cautious than deregulation in the United States, the policy led to the cancellation of the rule limiting competitors to 25 percent of Air Canada's route mileage and the opening of most of the heavily traveled routes in southern Canada to competition. Service to northern communities continues to be regulated, to insure continuity of service. **********Full deregulation will not come until Parliament enacts legislation, probably next year, and even then the industry will lack some of the freedoms of American carriers. But already, patterns that developed in the United States are being repeated. **********At least 16 new regional airlines have sprung up, many of them selling out to Air Canada and Canadian Pacific as the larger carriers have sought to secure longer-haul routes. Consumers have benefited from fare wars, flight schedules are more full and in-flight service has improved. Merger Forms a Challenger **********But the development of potentially greatest significance came late last year, when the PWA Corporation, parent of Pacific Western, used cash generated by a sale-and-leaseback arrangement on 16 of its Boeing 737 jets to acquire Canadian Pacific. The parent company of the larger airline, CP Ltd., a conglomerate with large holdings in real estate, manufacturing industries and hotels, had become impatient with the cumulative losses of more than $75 million run up by Canadian Pacific since 1981, largely because of an expensive program of aircraft acquisitions. **********The result of the merger, Canadian Airlines International, is smaller than Air Canada, but close enough to pose a serious threat. The new carrier starts with 85 jets and 8.5 million passengers a year, the combined total carried by Canadian Pacific and Pacific Western in 1986. Mr. Sigler, the president, estimates the airline's market share at about 33 percent, slightly more than half Air Canada's, and contends that it is heading into the contest with Air Canada in a better financial shape. **********Joining the two bigger carriers in the contest for long-haul traffic will be Wardair, a privately owned airline founded by a former airline pilot, Max Ward. But despite its success in recent years in moving from its original base as a charter operator into scheduled services, the carrier, based in Edmonton, Alberta, remains a distant third in the overall rankings. Fears of a 'Duopoly' **********Among consumer watchdogs, this has raised concerns that Canada may emerge from the restructuring of the industry with a ''duopoly'' - two large carriers that can set prices and schedules as they wish, to the detriment of travelers. **********To Mr. Sigler, such fears betray a lack of understanding of what lies ahead. Already, the new airline is preparing a challenge to Air Canada's ''backyard'' - Ontario, Quebec and the Atlantic provinces. In addition, it intends to ask the Government to negotiate ''double-track'' rights for the two airlines on services into the eastern United States and Britain, highly profitable routes that only Air Canada flies. Air Canada has responded by saying that it would like a share of its rival's routes in the Pacific region. **********The result, according to Mr. Sigler, will not be a return to the rigidity of the past. ''The whole process of deregulation began here five years later than it did in the United States, and it is ending five years sooner,'' he said, referring to the industry shakeout. ''We'll end up with three major airlines, all of them competitive, offering a better product and more sensitive on pricing than before. How can that be bad for the consumer?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/06/busin.main_headline: Justices Uphold F.D.I.C. On Bank Underwriting
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/06/busin.print_headline: Justices Uphold F.D.I.C. On Bank Underwriting
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/06/busin.body_text: **********In a further breach of the half-century barrier separating the banking and securities industries, the Supreme Court today allowed state-chartered banks that are not members of the Federal Reserve System to underwrite corporate securities. **********The Court, without comment, left intact a regulation, adopted in 1984 by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, authorizing state-chartered banks to engage in underwriting through units physicially distinct from their parent banks. The units could not use the banks' names. **********The decision was seen as another victory for bankers who in recent years have successfully exploited loopholes in Federal banking laws. The decision, however, is more symbolic than practical, because a wide-ranging banking bill passed by Congress last summer puts a moratorium on state-chartered banks underwriting corporate securities until March 1, 1988. **********The Court upheld an April ruling by the Federal appeals court here that the F.D.I.C. did not violate the Banking Act of 1933, known as the Glass-Steagall Act, which separates banking from securities activities. The appeals court said Congress ''clearly intended'' to allow the banks ''to maintain subsidiary or affiliate relationships with securities firms.'' **********Under the F.D.I.C.'s interpretation, the Glass-Steagall Act applies only to national and Federal Reserve member banks. Many of the nation's largest banks are federally chartered and thus outside the F.D.I.C. rule, but the vast majority of medium and smaller banks are state-chartered. **********The Investment Company Institute, representing mutual fund operators, and the Securities Industry Association, which represents securities brokers, dealers and underwriters, appealed the lower court's ruling in the case, Investment Company Institute v. F.D.I.C., No. 87-36. The Reagan Administration supported the ruling. **********The Justices also refused to consider a ruling that the Army Corps of Engineers may block construction, because of water pollution control laws, of dams and power projects previously approved by the Federal Energy Regulatory Agency. In Monongahela Power Co. v. Marsh, No. 86-1642, the Court, without comment, refused to hear an appeal by the Monongahela Power Company. **********The Court agreed to review whether a Mississippi utility is entitled to raise its rates by $626.5 milion to defer costs of a nuclear power plant. Last June, the Justices temporary blocked enforcement of a state court's ruling that disallowed the rate increase for the Mississippi Power and Light Company until they could consider the company's formal appeal. (Mississippi Power and Light v. State of Mississippi, No. 86-1970.) Award to Be Reviewed The Court also agreed to decide whether companies violate antitrust laws when they lobby private organizations that play a role in influencing business legislation. The Justices said they would review a $11.4 million jury award in the case, Allied Tube v. Indian Head, No. 87-157. The Allied Tube and Conduit Corporation, the nation's largest producer of steel conduits, was accused of organizing 230 voters at a National Fire Protection Association meeting to block approval in an electrical safety code of a competing plastic conduit. **********The Court also agreed to consider the appeal by a black woman from North Carolina who charged that she was the victim of on-the-job racial harassment. If it decides in her favor, the decision would effectively broaden the remedy for job-related racial harassment. **********Last November, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit upheld a ruling by a Federal judge in Winston-Salem, N.C., who dismissed a suit by Brenda Patterson against her employer, McLean Credit Union. (Brenda Patterson v. McLean Credit Union, No. 87-107).

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/19/busin.main_headline: TEXACO REPORTED TO REACH ACCORD ON PENNZOIL SUIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/19/busin.print_headline: TEXACO REPORTED TO REACH ACCORD ON PENNZOIL SUIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/19/busin.body_text: **********A tumultuous four-year legal battle that pitted the Pennzoil Company against the giant Texaco Inc. was brought to a conclusion last night when Texaco agreed in principle to give Pennzoil $3 billion, a lawyer for Texaco said. **********An additional amount, about $2.5 billion, would be paid to Texaco's creditors to bring the company out of bankruptcy, the lawyer, David Boies, said. **********A Pennzoil spokesman, Robert Harper, said the company would neither confirm nor deny that an agreement had been reached between the companies. ''We're not commenting,'' he said. Calls to Pennzoil's chairman, J. Hugh Liedtke, were not returned. Icahn Informed **********Carl C. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc. and Texaco's largest shareholder, said he had been informed by Texaco executives that a settlement in principle had been reached and that only a few small issues remained to be worked out before an official statement would be made by Texaco and Pennzoil. **********The agreement settles a case in which a jury awarded the largest judgment in American history. The accord will also allow Texaco, the nation's third-largest oil company, to emerge from bankruptcy in the next few months. **********It also marks the closing chapter of an acrimonious corporate feud that began almost four years ago as a contracts dispute. The fight has been punctuated by thousands of hours of fruitless negotiations, legal wranglings, dashed hopes and charges by executives of both companies accusing the other side of greed, arrogance and duplicity. **********The dispute dates to January 1984, when Texaco acquired the Getty Oil Company for $10.1 billion. Pennzoil, a Houston-based company that thought it had previously reached a binding agreement to buy three-sevenths of Getty, sued Texaco for interference of contract. Huge Bond Required **********In 1985, after a trial that lasted more than four months, a Texas jury awarded Pennzoil $10.53 billion, plus interest, in damages. **********Texaco, saying that it could not put up a bond in that amount, which was required by Texas law during the appeal process, filed for protection from its creditors on April 12 of this year. **********The filing made Texaco the largest company ever to enter bankruptcy proceedings. The Federal trustee supervising the bankruptcy, Harry Jones, then appointed committees to represent the interests of Texaco's shareholders and creditors. **********Last night, Texaco's 14-member board held a telephone-conference call and approved the most important details of the settlement, Mr. Boies said. The two companies are expected to announce the details of the settlement over the weekend. **********Mr. Boies, a partner with Cravath, Swaine & Moore who has been working on the Texaco case as its lead litigator since shortly after it lost the original case in Texas, said the two companies still had to ''iron out'' certain smaller issues in the plan, such as the effect of an earlier confidentiality agreement between the parties that barred them from revealing the contents of negotiations. Mr. Harper, the Pennzoil spokesman, said that no agreement had been signed by the companies and that lawyers ''were still making changes in the words.'' **********The Texaco board conference came after a several days of hectic negotiations among all of the parties. The board had met for more than three hours on Thursday night. **********Alfred C. DeCrane Jr., Texaco's chairman, led the Texaco board discussions from the company's headquarters in Harrison, N.Y. James W. Kinnear, who became Texaco's chief executive and president less than four months before its bankruptcy filing, was at one of the company's law firms, Weil, Gotshal & Manges, on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. **********Mr. Liedtke, who had postponed his retirement earlier this year until the the case was resolved, spent much of the day being advised of developments by a battery of lawyers at a suite at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel in Manhattan. Texaco Canada at Issue **********People who have seen the plan said that it contains no reference to the sale of Texaco's share of Texaco Canada Inc. The parent company and the shareholders and creditors committee had been approached about such a sale by at least one Canadian company, Husky Oil Ltd., a unit of Nova, an Alberta corporation, and other companies were believed interested. **********The sale of Texaco's 78 percent share of the Canadian unit had been proposed as a way of raising more than $2 billion of the settlement. Some one close to Texaco said no decision had been reached about what corporate assets would be used to finance the $5.5 billion reorganization, which consists of the Pennzoil settlement and the money owed to other creditors. **********''We're not interested in a fire-sale sort of thing,'' said a Texaco lawyer, who added that the company might seek loans to finance the arrangement. **********The company had $4.3 billion in cash and marketable securities as of Sept. 30, according to a filing made with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Some of that could be used to finance the plan. **********The plan also does not contain any of the earlier demands by the shareholders committee that it have the authority to make a minority of appointments to Texaco's board. Voice for Shareholders **********But it may contain a separate provision, having no impact on the plan itself, which gives the shareholders an opportunity to voice their views on the corporate structure of Texaco. **********The reorganization plan and settlement will require the approval of Texaco's shareholders, who can be expected to vote on it by March. The month-long vote will occur after the plan is filed in a Federal court in White Plains and an appropriate disclosure statement detailing the effects of the plan on Texaco is approved by a bankruptcy judge. **********Two-thirds of the shares voting must consent before the plan becomes effective. **********News of the settlement came after the stock markets had closed, but traders had anticipated a dramatic development. Pennzoil's stock jumped $4.125, to $79.375, on the New York Exchange. Texaco shares, the seventh-most active issue, with 2.1 million shares changing hands, rose $2.50 to $38.50. On the American Exchange, Texaco Canada increased 50 cents, to $23.625. **********People involved in the discussions said that the last major issue centered on the interest to be paid on the $3 billion. Mr. Liedtke insisted that 9 percent or 10 percent interest be paid from last April, when the Chapter 11 papers were filed, until next spring, when the company is expected to emerge from bankruptcy. **********Texaco lawyers said, however, that Mr. Liedtke backed off from that demand, especially after the creditors and shareholders had supported Texaco's contention that no interest be paid. Pennzoil executives would not comment on the interest issue. **********Earlier in the day, the parties decided not to haggle about who should bear the tax liability of the settlement, but would instead each take a position and let the Internal Revenue Service decide. **********Yesterday's settlement came about in large part because of two recent events that radically changed the dynamics of years of negotiations: the intervention of Mr. Icahn and an innovative ruling by a bankruptcy judge in White Plains. **********Mr. Icahn said last night that he was glad to see a settlement emerge but that he was unhappy that it failed to remove corporate bylaws that would make an unfriendly takeover difficult. **********Asked who deserved credit for reaching the deal, he said, ''It doesn't matter. In the final analysis, what counts is the bottom line.'' **********Last month, Mr. Icahn stepped into the fray by buying a large block of shares from Robert Holmes a Court, an Australian industrialist. Mr. Holmes a Court, who sufffered large losses in the October stock market plunge, sold his stake with an after-tax loss of $42.6 million. **********Mr. Icahn paid $348 million for 12 million shares of Texaco stock and the voting rights of an additional 12.1 million shares. Combined with the 5.8 million shares he owns from earlier transactions, Mr. Icahn controls 12.3 percent of Texaco's stock, making him the largest shareholder. **********He also owns a substantial block of Pennzoil, believed by Pennzoil executives to be about 2 percent. He stands to make a substantial profit from the settlement. **********He declined last night to say whether he would sell his shares soon. A Novel Ruling **********After Mr. Icahn announced his acquisition of Texaco shares, the Federal bankruptcy judge, Howard Schwartzberg, issued a novel ruling that strengthened Mr. Icahn's bargaining ability and also put enormous pressure on all sides to reconcile their differences. **********Judge Schwartzberg granted Texaco 40 additional days - until mid-January - to have the exclusive right to file a reorganization plan. But the judge also said that if two legally recognized committees in the proceeding - which represent Texaco's shareholders and its creditors -could agree with Pennzoil upon a reorganization plan, he would allow it to be filed and brought to a vote of Texaco's shareholders, even over the objections of Texaco's management. **********The ruling fueled a furious round of negotiations and shifting alliances among all of the parties. Advancements toward a settlement were made almost daily. **********Last Friday, for instance, the shareholders committee, Pennzoil and Mr. Icahn announced an agreement to a $3 billion all-cash settlement as part of the bankruptcy plan. Three days later, the creditors' committee accepted the $3 billion figure. **********Faced with the possibility of an accord among the three groups, Texaco resumed discussions with Pennzoil executives and with representatives from the two committees. **********But the alliance between the creditors and shareholders and Mr. Icahn was not solid, and grew tenuous at points when the two committees tried to advance their own interests over a unified plan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/31/world.main_headline: The Hills Are Not Alive With the Swoosh of Skis
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/31/world.print_headline: The Hills Are Not Alive With the Swoosh of Skis
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/31/world.body_text: **********In Chamonix, they are playing golf and tennis. In Gstaad in the Swiss Alps, they are hiking and riding mountain bikes. **********The extraordinary lack of snow has made it a frustrating winter for skiers in the Alps. Instead of finding 50 inches of snow to schuss down, skiers are finding 50-degree temperatures to sunbathe in. Many ski operators are saying it is the worst winter for them in a quarter century. **********''It's a catastrophe right now,'' said Alain Boyelle, director of the office of tourism in St.-Gervais, in the French Alps. ''Lift operators are being hurt. Ski instructors are hurting. Ski shops are hurting.'' **********What is more, many towns are worried that mild winters like this will hurt Europe's image as a skiing capital that attracts people from as far away as Arizona and Australia. Today, for example, the International Ski Federation said a shortage of snow was forcing it to reschedule a Jan. 9 women's World Cup downhill race that was going to be held at Les Diablerets in Switzerland. Too Warm for Snow Machines **********''We can't even use snow-making equipment because it's too warm,'' complained Francis Richard, Mayor of Morzine, a skiing village in the French Alps. **********Morzine is typical of many ski resorts. Only 5 of the 70 lifts are in operation. Many skiers are canceling hotel reservations, and about half the ski instructors are out of work. **********Indeed, because of the warm winds coming up from North Africa, which have kept temperatures between 40 and 50 degrees, ski officials estimate that 6,000 of France's 10,000 ski instructors have been out of work so far this winter. Many ski resorts below 6,000 feet in altitude cannot operate. And some ski operators who invested millions of dollars in new lift equipment last year are worried about whether they will be able to repay their debts. Holidays a Major Time **********Officials in many ski towns estimate that between 15 percent and 20 percent of their revenues come the week between Christmas and New Year's Day. **********''Christmas week is usually one of the best weeks of the year, and that's been lost,'' said Mayor Richard, whose town has 30,000 beds to accommodate skiers. ''It's a disaster, and things will get very serious if it doesn't snow by next week.'' **********With many skiers having shown up anyway, the snow-less ski resorts are doing their best to provide other distractions. They want to make sure the skiers go away as happy as can be expected under the circumstances. **********For example, Chamrousse, a town in the French Alps, grabbed Antoine Montero, a French boxer, to put on an exhibition. Other towns have organized hikes and aerobics classes and have reopened golf courses. **********''We have people hiking around the glacier and we have jazznastics classes,'' said Hans-Ulrich Tschanz, director of tourism for the Swiss resort of Gstaad. ''It really isn't so bad. People are eating lunch in the sun out on the terrace.'' **********Ski resorts that are accustomed to boasting how great they are as ski towns, now boast that they are more than ski towns. They boast of fine dining and fascinating shopping. Restaurants Doing Better **********''Because people aren't spending time on the slopes, the restaurants, bars and movie theaters are doing far better than usual,'' said an official in one ski town. ''They are spending their money on food.'' **********The problems of the towns that do not have enough snow have also translated into problems for towns that have enough snow. Val-Thorens, at 7,000 feet one of the highest ski spots in the French Alps, is having to turn away skiers. Tour organizers that originally intended to send their tour groups to other towns have steered them to Val-Thorens. Normally the town, which has 30 of its 31 lifts in operation, has the capacity to accommodate 15,000 skiers. So far this week it has squeezed in 20,000, resulting in long lift lines and angry skiers. **********''We have too many people,'' said Christian Portello, director of tourism for Val-Thorens. ''Starting tomorrow, we will have to start turning some people away.'' **********Many ski resort officials say this year's problems will push them to increase their publicity next year to make sure they do not lose any skiers. **********''We don't want people to start thinking the lack of snow is just a French problem,'' said Philippe Bertoli, director of the Christiania Hotel in the French resort, Val d'Isere. ''It's a European-wide problem.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/02/busin.body_text: **********Argentina's chief debt negotiator said today that he was confident that a prompt accord could be reached with international creditor banks for rescheduling the country's foreign debt. **********''I'm quite optimistic about carrying out a serious and quick negotiation,'' said Mario Brodersohn, the Treasury Secretary, as he returned from talks in New York with United States Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d; Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Michel Camdessus, head of the International Monetary Fund.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/14/busin.body_text: **********The St. Paul Companies of Minnesota, which has made a bid for the British insurance broker Minet Holdings P.L.C., is aiming to become the first insurance company to win a place at the Lloyd's of London insurance market. Lloyd's had previously argued that there would be a conflict of interest if insurance companies owned its insurance-broker members, whose task is to shop around among insurers for the best policy for their clients. But last month, Lloyd's proposed dropping the rule that bars insurance companies from owning more than 26 percent of a broker. **********St. Paul, which owns 26 percent of Minet, offered to buy the rest for about $515 million, or $8.50 a share. Another American company, the New York-based insurance broker Corroon & Black, holds a 29.9 percent stake in Minet.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/23/busin.body_text: **********The Gulf Canada Corporation, a Canadian holding company, announced its restructuring into three companies in a move that is expected to strip debt from its oil and gas business and increase its shareholder value. Gulf Canada proposed to spin off its oil and gas division into a publicly traded company that will resume oil exploration off Canada's Arctic coast. **********Subject to legal review and shareholder votes set for the spring, Gulf Canada will also split off its 83 percent holding in the forest products company Abitibi-Price Inc. The remaining holding company will change its name to GW Ltd. and will offer to buy back its shares.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/13/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Jones industrial average moved higher yesterday, as the overall market was mixed in nervous trading. **********The Dow, which was up and down all day, ended 15.30 higher, after a sudden burst of trading near the close. The key blue-chip indicator finished at 2,322.60. But on the New York Stock Exchange 842 stocks fell and 725 gained. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange slowed to 155.3 million shares, from 203.7 million on Monday. **********Broader stock market gauges than the Dow also moved higher: The S.&P. 500-stock index added 1.73, to 293.30, and the Big Board's composite index edged up 0.69, to 165.39. **********Many traders and investors had their eyes glued to other markets. And despite some encouraging news about interest rates and inflation -bond prices rose and commodity prices fell - the stock market was skittish all day, and at times seemed headed for its third straight retreat. The last-minute surge helped the Dow to recoup the 15 points it lost on Monday. **********Once again, many blue chips posted good gains. **********I.B.M. gained 2 3/8, to 165 3/8, and thus traded higher than Digital Equipment, which closed at 165 1/4, down 1 3/4. ''It's been a long time since the price of I.B.M. has been higher than Digital Equipment,'' one trader said. He recalled that in early January, when many analysts lowered their opinions of I.B.M., the stock fell to 115 - at the same time Digital, which picked up analyst recommendations, went to 119. ''Everybody thought Digital was the new computer leader,'' he said. ''Now, the one that was the favorite is not performing as well as the one that was hated.'' Drug Issues Stronger **********Drug issues were generally stronger. SmithKline was up 2 1/8, to 112; Merck gained 2 1/8, to 153; Squibb added 5, to 165, and Upjohn was up 1 3/4, to 42 3/4. **********The airlines, like the Dow, made a late spurt. Delta added 1 3/8, to 51; Allegis, parent of United Airlines, was up 1/2, to 67 3/4, and AMR, parent of American Airlies gained 2 3/8, to 56 1/2. **********Among the Dow stocks, Exxon gained 1 1/2, to 90; Kodak added 1 1/2, to 80 1/2; G.E. was up 1 1/8, to 103 1/2, and Du Pont added 3/4, to 118 7/8. **********Another Dow stock, Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing, which declared a 2-for-1 stock split, picked up 3 to close at 129. **********Both Texaco and Pennzoil lost ground. Each of the stocks had been strong recently as rumors swirled about a possible settlement of the two companies' legal tangle or a takeover of Texaco. Some people on Wall Street professed to being tired of the whole thing. ''They have become trading vehicles,'' one trader said. ''There may be less there than meets the eye.'' In any case, Texaco lost 1 1/4, to 36 3/4, and Pennzoil fell 1 7/8, to 84 3/8. **********In the over-the-counter market, Seagate Technology jumped 3 1/8, to 41 1/8, after the company won a disk-drive contract from I.B.M. Another O-T-C technology company, Microsoft, continued its pullback from a recent high of 126. Microsoft fell 4 1/2 points, to 118 1/2. The stock has been hot; a year ago it was initially offered at $21 a share. Some analysts said that Microsoft had been in the running for the I.B.M. award and sold off on the disappointment. **********Another O-T-C issue, Stater Brothers, jumped 3 1/4, to 20 1/4, after reporting higher earnings. Stater is a California supermarket chain. **********The Nasdaq index of O-T-C stocks fell 1.63, to 420.53. On the American Stock Exchange, the market index edged 0.29 higher, to 335.01.
