Between Dec. 11 and Jan. 14, Brookehill bought 5,500 Holly Sugar shares for prices ranging from $97.62 to $104 a share, raising its stake in Holly Sugar to 11.8 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/25/world.main_headline: They Map the Arctic to a Finer Scale
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/25/world.print_headline: They Map the Arctic to a Finer Scale
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/25/world.body_text: **********On the last frontier in North America, in a land of snowy mountains and ice-covered fjords, a group of Canadian soldiers is close to completing a job begun by some of the most famous names in Arctic exploration. **********Their work is the detailed mapping of the Canadian North, and they expect to have finished - taken the last scientific reading, checked the final elevation and packed for home -sometime early next month. When they do, it will be the end of an effort the army began 40 years ago. **********Making the maps will take another year or two, but the mapping of the North American land mass to a 1:50,000 scale - roughly an inch to a mile, the ''tactical scale'' that suffices for most military purposes and for recreational activities such as hiking - will be complete. Next year, the Canadians will turn to the still more exhausting business of charting the waters of the Arctic Archipelago. **********At a ceremony on a windblown ridge near here, Defense Minister Perrin Beatty unveiled a cairn commemorating the soldiers' work. The cairn was built of the same rough granite blocks that mark the passage through the Arctic - and in many cases, the deaths - of the discoverers who ventured ''north of 60'' before helicopters and radios and all the paraphernalia that sustains a modern mapping party. #700 Miles From the Pole Although this outpost lies barely 700 miles from the North Pole, on the western shore of Ellesmere Island, the closest that the soldiers here come to the extreme hardships experienced by men like Roald Amundsen is in the explorers' accounts that some brought for reading in the permanent daylight of the Arctic summer night. **********Still, a summer at 80 degrees of north latitude is not for the fainthearted. Even in summer, gale winds can blow and temperatures can plunge. Men flown by helicopter to mountain peaks for two days of sighting can be isolated in small tents with survival rations for two weeks before fog and winds recede. In a part of the Arctic that has an annual snowfall of barely 18 inches, summer dust storms can rival those of the Gobi Desert. **********''Small mistakes here can be disastrous,'' said Lieut. Col. George Focsaneanu, commander of the 29-man unit that arrived here in early June. As he spoke, a wind howled around the mess tent so strongly that the Huey helicopters used to carry visitors up the ridge flew with their skids barely clearing the rocky outcroppings ringing the airstrip. **********Like many military outposts in Canada's far north, this one owes its beginnings to the United States. In 1947, a joint Canadian-American weather station was established here at the urging of an American, Col. Charles J. Hubbard, who died in the crash of a Canadian aircraft making a mail drop here in 1950. The station still operates year-round as one of the most northerly inhabited sites on earth. Tame Wolf Visits Camp **********It is a land of musk oxen and polar bears, and of an Arctic wolf pack so tame that one of the wolves, nicknamed Scruffy, is a frequent visitor to the camp. But with barely 60 days on site each year, the Canadian mappers have little time for recreation, working 16 hours a day throughout the week when weather permits. **********When the Canadians started their detailed mapping of the Arctic, in 1947, vast areas of the map showed coastlines and features noted by early explorers but otherwise little but white space. Over 20 years, working with dog teams and pack horses at first and helicopters only later, the mapping parties produced a complete set of 1:250,000 scale maps, showing four miles to the inch. In 1967, they began again on the finer-scale project now nearing completion. **********The 1:50,000 scale maps, when finished, will round out a collection of 13,000 maps that cover all of Canada, an archive weighing one and a half tons. Col. David T. Carney, the head of the army's Mapping and Charting Establishment, acknowledged ruefully that many in the Arctic series were not things of beauty by cartographic standards since the colors that brighten more southerly maps -red for man-made features and green for vegetation, for instance - are mostly absent. **********Little has been disclosed about the mapping unit's future work, charting Arctic waters. This is apparently because the charts themselves are likely to be secret, at least for some channels, since the principal users of them will probably be nuclear submarines. Ever since the American submarine Nautilus sailed under the polar icecap in 1958, the Arctic has been a strategic area for United States and Soviet submarine fleets. **********The Canadian Government has acknowledged that it does not know when submarines operate in what it regards as its internal waters, notably the Northwest Passage, the 1,000-mile channel that provides the only passage across the archipelago for surface ships. Since Canadian charts of the Arctic are crude, it is assumed that the United States Navy, at least, has more accurate maps. Names From an Expert **********Some charts go back to the voyages of Sir John Franklin, discoverer of the Northwest Passage in 1845. For the new series, the Canadians will abandon the leadline used until well into this century and use aerial equipment. One feature to be carefully noted are the ''pingos'' - undersea hills, often ice-cored, that rise as much as 70 feet above an otherwise uniform sea floor. Historians believe that pingos, as much as the ice pack, may have accounted for some of the Arctic's most famous wrecks. **********After the mapping and charting are completed, the work of naming features and places across the vast Arctic will remain. The task has been entrusted to Randolph Freeman, an expert on place names working for the territorial government in Yellowknife, who estimates that as many as 100,000 names will have to be found over the next decade. **********Until this year, many of the 64 populated communities in the Arctic had names imposed by outsiders. But since Jan. 1, many of the better-known communities have begun reverting to the names given to them by Eskimos and Indians thousands of years ago. The first such change was at Frobisher Bay, which became Iqaluit, meaning ''place of the fish.'' **********Mr. Freeman spends at least six months a year traveling across the region, speaking to native people and recording traditional place names. Although most places in the southern Arctic are expected to have native names, places like Eureka in the far north, well beyond the area of Eskimo habitation, are likely to retain names given to them by explorers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/busin.main_headline: Seeking Clues to the Market's Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/busin.print_headline: THE '29 CRASH; Seeking Clues to the Market's Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/27/busin.body_text: **********WHERE is the stock market headed? That question has been topmost in many minds since the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 22 percent to 1,738.74 on Oct. 19. **********As 1987 draws to a close, the market is in a rally of sorts. Yet the Dow is still below the level, 2,027.85, that it regained two days after the plunge. And many investors, both individuals and professionals, fear that the Dow has yet to bottom - and may still fall below the Oct. 19 close. **********One place investors have looked for possible clues to the market's future course is the 1929 stock market. As they did in 1987, stocks took a sharp dive in October 1929; the Dow fell 23 percent in two days. Both plunges were followed by two-day recoveries: in 1929 the Dow regained 63 percent of its loss; in 1987 it regained 57 percent. **********But the 1929 crash was just a prelude. After a five-month climb, the market started falling in earnest. Market participants would later recall that while the October 1929 crash got the headlines, causing severe distress to the average investor, it was the rally in the spring of 1930 that hurt many Wall Street professionals. **********Before the 1929 crash, many market professionals had pared back their exposure in stocks. The 1924-1929 bull market was then 63 months old, one of the longest on record. And the increasing public participation, particularly by new and inexperienced speculators, scared many brokers out of stocks before the crash. **********But by the spring of 1930, when the Dow had very nearly recovered to its pre-crash level, many Wall Street professionals thought that the market had merely had a shakeout and that it was safe to own stocks again. **********They were wrong. By July 8, 1932, the Dow had plummeted to this century's low point - 41.22 - for a loss of 86 percent from the post-crash high reached in April, 1930, and a loss of 89 percent from the Dow's record of 381.17 on Sept. 3, 1929. **********But there are important differences between 1929 and today. For one thing, the Government has introduced many more safeguards. For another, there is the opportunity to learn from past mistakes, including the Federal Reserve System's ill-timed tightening of credit in the early 1930's. **********Another key difference is the strength of the economy. In 1929, the economy had already turned down - in August 1929 - before the market embarked on its prolonged crash. Today, if there is to be a recession, mild or otherwise, there is still no sign of it. **********To be sure, economists, chastened by the market's October plunge, hastily began revising their projections downward, almost before the stock ticker finished chronicling the Dow's 508-point fall. But by December, some of these same economists were in the process of rebuilding their recently reduced estimates of economic activity. For the moment, the outlook for 1988 is good, but not great. In the aftermath of the plunge, many investors would be happy to settle for similar performance from the stock market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/04/busin.body_text: **********Dusty fields and backyard vegetable plots are being replaced by rows of thriving factories here, as tiny Hong Kong ''colonizes'' a belt of southern China. **********While American and European companies agonize over unprofitable businesses in China, Hong Kong concerns are nimbly and profitably transferring more and more production to that nation. Already, parts of southern Guangdong province are virtually subcontracting centers for the British territory. **********''They like to work, and they don't like to take holidays,'' Rickie P. K. Yu, the Hong Kong-based manager of Wisegroup Investment Ltd., said of the 62 people in his knitted-garments factory in Shenzhen, just across the border from Hong Kong. Mr. Yu's employees work 10 hours a day, seven days a week, for the princely wage -to them - of almost 30 cents an hour. Once a month or so they take a day off. Better Than the Farm **********''Everyone wants to come here,'' said Li Laikam, a 20-year-old worker in Mr. Yu's factory who moved to Shenzhen two years ago from her native village 260 miles to the southwest. ''It's better here because you don't have to endure the wind and the rain in the fields.'' **********Hong Kong is grappling with a worsening labor shortage, the result of a slow-growing population and a rapidly increasing demand for its toys, televisions and clothes. Unemployment has dropped to just 1.8 percent, and so waves of Hong Kong manufacturing companies in search of workers are shifting production north of the border. **********Hong Kong now supplies 79 percent of the foreign investment in China, and the Hang Seng Bank in Hong Kong estimates that in Guangdong province alone there are 2,000 factories partly owned by Hong Kong interests. **********In addition, the bank calculated, Hong Kong concerns have signed some 60,000 subcontracting agreements with companies in Guangdong, spawning 8,300 factories. Many Hong Kong companies prefer subcontracting agreements because then they need not make an equity investment but can still usually supervise the manufacturing process. 1 Million Jobs Affected More than one million workers in southern China depend on manufacturing arrangements with Hong Kong, the bank reported. In 1978, when China began to open to the West, there were virtually no manufacturing links between Hong Kong and China. **********Many managers and economists say that Hong Kong will increasingly become the managerial center for the region - the site of companies' headquarters and of marketing, engineering, accounting and shipping operations - while the factories themselves will be in China. **********Gordon Wu, the managing director of one of Hong Kong's biggest companies, Hopewell Holdings Ltd., put it this way: ''Hong Kong will be the storefront, and the Pearl River delta of China will be the factory.'' **********Raymond K. Hung, the chairman of Applied Electronics Ltd., a Hong Kong company that manufactures talking dolls, remote-controlled cars and other products, said: ''About 90 percent of our production is being moved to China. As far as toys go, without China you're not competitive at all.'' Labor Far Cheaper **********Applied Electronics has nearly 5,000 employees in China, compared with just 280 in Hong Kong. Although the Chinese workers are not as proficient as those in Hong Kong, the lower labor costs make the shift worthwhile. The company pays assembly line workers in China the equivalent of $77 a month, compared with $333 a month in Hong Kong. **********''They already are at 80 percent of Hong Kong's efficiency,'' Mr. Hung said. ''But I expect they will catch up because turnover is five-tenths of a percent per year, compared with about 20 percent in Hong Kong.'' **********Yet Hong Kong managers certainly do not find manufacturing in China to be trouble-free. Like their American, Japanese and European counterparts, they complain about China's bureaucracy, poor infrastructure and inattention to quality. A Different Work Ethic **********''It's very frustrating to be a manager here,'' said Eddy K. W. Yip, a manager in China for the Hong Kong-based Luks Industrial Company, the one-third owner of an enormous television factory in Shenzhen. ''Workers are very sloppy here, and there is no tradition of a work ethic in China. In Hong Kong, if you don't work, you're out the door.'' **********Other common annoyances of doing business in China are the difficulty of converting local currency into dollars, and the sometimes outrageous cost of raw materials. In one famous example, a foreign company that set up a factory to make orange juice concentrate discovered too late that the price it was expected to pay for oranges was the highest in the world. **********Yet Mr. Yip noted that for all the frustrations, his company's labor cost in Shenzhen - including wages, taxes and room and board - is $162 a month per employee, compared with at least $300 a month in Hong Kong. So the Luks Industrial facility in Shenzhen, which employs 1,100 Chinese workers under 22 Hong Kong managers, doubled production in May and plans further increases so it can manufacture 500,000 televisions a year in 1988. An Acceptance in China **********Shenzhen's labor costs are rising as more Hong Kong companies open factories in the region, but workers are also streaming into the area from other parts of China. While critics point out that Shenzhen has attracted less investment than planners had hoped for, the workers' enthusiasm and the Communist Party's increasing flexibility in employment matters reflect China's drift toward free markets. **********Hong Kong companies are more profitable and successful than other companies in dealing with China for several reasons, analysts say. Among the most important: *********** They have less at risk because frequently they do not invest their own capital. They simply place orders for products and work closely with the Chinese supplier to insure high quality. *********** They usually operate on a small scale. That reduces the layers of bureaucracy and allows more flexibility. Often a Hong Kong businessman hires relatives in China to supervise a ''factory'' of perhaps only a dozen workers. *********** They are mostly interested in the export market rather than in manufacturing for China. That fits neatly with China's own desires and reduces the problem of how to convert revenue in Chinese money into hard currency. *********** Their managers speak the local dialect, know the customs and can often bargain more effectively with officials. 'We Know China Better' **********''We know the tricks,'' said Vincent H. C. Cheng, chief economist of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation. ''We know how to get around the problems. We know China better than the Japanese or Americans.'' **********And, the chief executive of one Hong Kong bank said, the local Chinese know when a ''gift'' to a Chinese official will make a difference. **********Roderick W. MacNeil, a Hong Kong-based consultant to companies considering the China market, said that when the Hong Kong Chinese tackle a venture similar to those American or European corporations pursue - something on a large scale and aimed at the domestic market -they face the same problems as other foreign companies. **********Hong Kong executives say that the key to successful manufacturing in China is to oversee the production as closely as possible and to make the labor force as flexible as possible. Even when Hong Kong companies are simply buying from a factory in China, their executives are always on hand, ready to reject goods that are not quite right. **********''You really have to do your own supervision,'' said David C. W. Yeh, the managing director of Universal Matchbox Ltd., a Hong Kong toy manufacturer. ''If you let them do it, you end up with disaster.'' Lower Quality Standards **********The problem seems to be that some Chinese workers are unaccustomed to the standards that foreign markets demand and see no reason not to sell a shirt just because one sleeve is longer than the other. **********In addition, although workers in China are prepared to stay on the job for many hours, there is little tradition of working hard. Even at the most successful factories in Shenzhen, employees on an assembly line pause to chat, leaving those down the line with nothing to do. **********Yet Hong Kong managers say they are slowly succeeding in speeding up production. They test workers' speed before hiring them, and sometimes pay by the piece instead of by the hour. Increasingly, they are also getting the right to fire those who steal or perform poorly. **********The workers come from all over China to work in Guangdong province. Indeed, Shenzhen was only a village eight years ago and has no indigenous labor force. They are lured by wages two or three times higher than they could get anywhere else. In their eagerness for money, long hours are usually an advantage. Workers often try to switch to a factory that promises ''O.T.,'' as overtime is known in the local Chinese dialect. Lower Rents **********Manufacturers are turning to China not just because of low wages and plentiful workers. Rents in Shenzhen are less than 8 cents a square foot, compared with nearly 60 cents a square foot in Hong Kong. Over all, Wisegroup says, the cost of production at its knitted-garments factory in Shenzhen is about 75 percent below that of production in Hong Kong. **********Other companies say the savings are much smaller. For example, Gartex Manufacturing Ltd., which makes woven trousers and shirts, puts the overall savings at 20 percent. **********As companies in China become more efficient and quality-conscious, they might be able to bypass Hong Kong managers, some executives say. Already some companies in China export directly and handle their own design and marketing. But their efforts usually are not as successful as those run by Hong Kong concerns. **********''It may take 5 or 10 years for China to establish its own reputation,'' said Thomas M. H. Chan, a specialist on business in China at Hong Kong University, ''so for that time period at least it must depend on Hong Kong.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/30/world.main_headline: 'AW SHUCKS' PREMIER FOR ITALY: GIOVANNI GUISEPPE GORIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/30/world.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; 'AW SHUCKS' PREMIER FOR ITALY: GIOVANNI GUISEPPE GORIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/30/world.body_text: **********Giovanni Goria likes to recall that his first big move into national politics, his appointment as Treasury Minister in 1982, came so unexpectedly that he had to borrow a friend's dark suit for the swearing-in ceremony. **********Dressed in slightly informal bluish-gray this morning, Mr. Goria took an oath that made him Prime Minister of Italy's 47th postwar Government. The man who describes himself as ''an accountant who's also a politician'' still expresses surprise at his own success, but by now a certain ''aw shucks'' modesty has become a well-developed part of Mr. Goria's political personality. **********Mr. Goria has retained the image of an outsider in Rome, although he has been in Parliament since 1976 and is a well-established player in the corridors where deal are made here. Behind a salt-and-pepper beard, Mr. Goria radiates an earnest lack of pretension, yet he is also one of the most effective and most visible television performers on the political scene. Youngest Leader Since War **********Mr. Goria, who will turn 44 years old on Thursday, is already the youngest man to lead Italy since the fall of Fascism. Now commentators are wondering whether he might also be the first to take full advantage of what is portrayed here as a gradual Americanization of politics, in which image has grown in importance at the expense of party machines. **********After he had finished reading the names of his Cabinet members in a live broadcast on Tuesday night, Mr. Goria added, under his breath, a slang expression that might translate as ''Oh Lord, wish us luck.'' **********Mr. Goria is going to need all the clever gestures, good luck and blessings he can get, according to most analysts. In a front-page editorial today, the Milan newspaper Il Giornale said: ''Goria clamorously blundered his entry on stage. It was not all his fault, but he is the one who lost face.'' **********Twice on Tuesday evening he had to postpone announcing the formation of his Government while the members of his five-party coalition haggled over the distribution of Cabinet posts. At one point, his aides suggest, the whole enterprise looked as if it was going to collapse after two weeks of negotiation, forcing Mr. Goria to announce that he had failed to form a consensus. **********The messy display of power brokering is being widely described today as a sign of the fragmented and highly combative political situation that Mr. Goria will have to manage. Born in the Piedmont **********Born on July 30, 1943, in Asti, the Piedmont town famous for its sparkling wines, Giovanni Giuseppe Goria is the son of a civil servant and a shopkeeper. He studied economics and worked at a local savings bank, but was already a card-carrying member of the Christian Democratic Party at age 17. His career advanced under the patronage of Ciriaco De Mita, now the party secretary, and he quickly became the Christian Democrats' most authoratative voice on economic matters. **********His wife, Eugenia, and their two children, ages 15 and 11, have remained in Asti. Mr. Goria, meanwhile, has kept a studio apartment in Rome, and he has become a familiar figure in the capital's fashionable restaurants and chic salons. He confesses to being ''a fugitive father,'' seeing his family only on some weekends. **********First as budget under secretary and then as Treasury Minister, Mr. Goria has played a central role in developing eonomic policy during a period that has seen Italy enjoy a boom in productivity and a sharp decline in inflation. Opinions are sharply divided over how much credit he deserves. **********Cutting the Government deficit at a time when Italy's boom appears to be leveling off is going to be as much a challenge for Mr. Goria as keeping the peace among his bickering coalition partners. **********The talents he brings to his new job were summed up by Indro Montanelli, editor of Il Giornale, who wrote: ''The man is certainly not a Bismarck or a Metternich. But he has a clean face, full of energy; he stirs up maternal instincts in women, and he also pleases men because among so many matadors he stands out with his air of a somewhat clumsy rustic.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/13/world.main_headline: CAMPAIGN SEEKS GENOCIDE TRIAL OF KHMER ROUGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/13/world.print_headline: CAMPAIGN SEEKS GENOCIDE TRIAL OF KHMER ROUGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/13/world.body_text: **********A New York-based human rights organization has started a campaign to have the Khmer Rouge tried for genocide before the International Court of Justice. **********The Khmer Rouge rule of Cambodia from 1975 to 1979 is blamed for more than a million deaths. **********The rights group, the Cambodia Documentation Commission, said last week that it believed it had assembled evidence to prove the Khmer Rouge actions were genocide as defined by the 1948 Genocide Convention drafted by the United Nations. The commission estimated that the Khmer Rouge had caused two to three million deaths. **********The commission's director said the group hoped to gain recognition for the Cambodians' suffering and put pressure on the Cambodian guerrilla coalition fighting the Vietnamese-backed Government to eject and punish Khmer Rouge factions. **********The case would mark the first ever considered by the World Court under the convention, which obligates governments to punish genocide offenders. Called 'Ongoing Violation' **********''The United Nations has never recognized the Khmer Rouge human rights violations, and the Cambodians want recognition for this terrible tragedy,'' said the director, David Hawk. **********''Those who were primarily responsible for perpretrating those acts remain active in international and Cambodian life,'' he said. ''This is an ongoing violation of the articles of the convention that require those who commit genocide to be punished.'' **********Two hundred Cambodian survivors of Khmer Rouge camps, as well as survivors of genocide campaigns in other parts of the world, attended a news conference at the New York Public Library on Tuesday announcing the campaign. Members of the commission include Representative Stephan J. Solarz, Democrat of Brookyln; Max M. Kampelman, the Reagan Administration's arms negotiator; the Nazi-hunter Simon Wiesenthal, and Dith Pran, the New York Times photographer whose experiences in Cambodia were portrayed in the movie ''The Killing Fields.'' **********Under the 1948 convention, only governments can bring a genocide complaint before the World Court, and the commission this week sent letters to 70 heads of state asking them to consider pressing the case. **********The convention defines genocide as ''acts committed with intent to destroy in whole, or in part, a national, ethnical, racial or religious group, as such.'' It requires signers to punish those the Court or relevant United Nations bodies find have committed genocide. U.N. Recognizes Coalition **********If the World Court decides against the Khmer Rouge, it could also rule against the Cambodian guerrilla coalition for not punishing Khmer Rouge offenders, Mr. Hawk said. **********A Vietnamese-backed Government has ruled most of Cambodia since Vietnam's invasion in 1979, but the United Nations recognizes a Cambodian coalition government that includes the Chinese-backed Khmer Rouge, democratic factions and groups loyal to Prince Norodom Sihanouk. **********There is no precedent for enforcing the convention, but the commission believes the case would bring diplomatic pressure on the Cambodian coalition to ''get those most responsible for genocide out of their current positions, and out of the jurisdiction of democratic Kampuchea,'' Mr. Hawk said. **********A letter sent to President Reagan stressed that the group did not support the Vietnamese occupation or seek to weaken opposition to it. **********While the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, as the treaty is known, was signed by the United States, the Senate refused to approve it until October of last year for fear it was poorly drafted and might allow other governments to intervene in United States affairs. CONTROVERSY OVER TOLL **********BANGKOK, Thailand, April 12 -Controversy still surrounds the human toll the Khmer Rouge took during its years in power. **********David P. Chandler, an American scholar of Cambodia now at Monash University in Australia, said in an interview last week that most of his colleagues settled on ''about a million -up to a million and a half - regime-related deaths.'' **********Research by Ben Kiernan, a colleague of Mr. Chandler's and the author of ''How Pol Pot Came to Power'' provides similar figures. Michael Vickery, who wrote the first standard contemporary history of the period, ''Cambodia: 1975-1982,'' accepts a slightly lower figure. **********Stephen R. Heder, a Khmer-speaking historian of Cambodia who is now on the Amnesty International staff in London, has in the past been quoted as accepting a figure of about 1 million to 1.5 million ''policy-related'' deaths, among them at least 100,000 executions. **********Speaking by telephone from Australia, Mr. Chandler, who is completing a history of Cambodia since 1945, acknowledged that other figures had been given, ranging from hundreds of thousands to three million, but he said they often reflect political viewpoints. **********He said he believed that the Vietnamese had overestimated the toll, while Thailand, which supports the Khmer Rouge in exile, had sought to underestimate it. Statistics on Cambodia's population in 1975 and now are considered unreliable by most experts. **********But Mr. Chandler said arguments over numbers were not the issue. **********''The important thing,'' he said ''is that Pol Pot was absolutely awful.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/26/busin.main_headline: Collapse Fails to Stop An Investment Team
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/26/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Collapse Fails to Stop An Investment Team
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/26/busin.body_text: **********John K. Castle and Leonard M. Harlan, with their new company and financing in place, are all set to start making leveraged buyout deals. But is this a good time, in the wake of the stock market collapse, to be starting a buyout company? **********''I think so, because prices are lower now than they were,'' Mr. Castle said. ''It's an opportunity to take advantage of the friction that occurs when financial markets are in some upheaval.'' **********While the uncertain stock market has curbed takeover activity, Mr. Castle observed: ''It takes a little while for things to get reformulated and repositioned so you can do deals. It isn't surprising there has been a little lapse here.'' **********Mr. Castle, 46, and Mr. Harlan, 51, formed Castle Harlan Inc. in July. This month they completed attracting capital for the Legend Capital Group, a $125 million limited partnership investment fund. Now the two Manhattan executives are ready to make their first purchases. **********They have known each other for 22 years. ''We can read each other's body English,'' Mr. Harlan said. Both were at the Harvard Business School at the same time, although they did not know each other then. Mr. Harlan was in the doctoral program and Mr. Castle was working on his M.B.A. **********Mr. Harlan had already received his Harvard M.B.A. and earlier had graduated with a degree in mechanical engineeering from Cornell. Before Mr. Castle received his Harvard M.B.A., he had graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he majored in economics and physics. **********The two men became acquainted when they joined the investment firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in the same week in 1965. Mr. Castle stayed there until last year, rising to chief executive. He left the brokerage to go out on his own, two years after the company was acquired by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. **********Mr. Harlan left Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in 1969 to form the Harlan Company, which at first assisted smaller companies in their growth plans and later became a major real estate company. **********Mr. Harlan will continue as chief executive of the Harlan Company. That company, he said, completed a buyout last year that gave its investors a threefold profit. **********As for Castle Harlan, ''our goal is to do another one of those,'' Mr. Harlan said. ''But nobody can ever guarantee it,''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/jobs/.main_headline: Jersey in Great Need Of Physical Therapists
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/jobs/.print_headline: Jersey in Great Need Of Physical Therapists
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/11/jobs/.body_text: **********WHEN Nancy Reger decided to become a physical therapist 13 years ago, the emphasis was on rehabilitating stroke and accident victims and using heat treatments and exercises to soothe sore backs and necks. Physical therapy was called ''shake and bake.'' **********Today, Mrs. Reger describes herself as a ''biomechanic'' who fixes and prevents muscular-skeletal problems, adding that she looks at the patient as a whole, not just as someone with an aching or disabled part. She runs a busy physical-therapy department at Somerset Medical Center in Somerville, and takes several continuing-education courses a year to keep up with her rapidly expanding field. **********She also gets two or three calls a week from executive head-hunters who offer her jobs with starting salaries of $30,000 to $50,000 annually, and some partnership possibilities. **********So far Mrs. Reger is staying put. But more physical therapists are leaving institutions in New Jersey for higher-paying careers in community-based agencies, industry and doctors' offices, creating serious shortages in some hospitals and rehabilitation centers. **********Although the shortage of physical therapists is nationwide, analysts say the situation is aggravated in New Jersey by the state's aging population, tightly regulated hospital rates and, until recently, the existence of only one college in the state that granted physical-therapy degrees. Two new training programs are set to begin, but labor experts still foresee chronic shortages well into the next decade. **********There are currently about 2,650 physical therapists who possess New Jersey licenses, up from 2,053 in 1984, a 29 percent increase, but no one is sure how many are actually working in the state. In 1984, the latest year for which figures are available, there were 1.7 physical therapists for every 10,000 people in New Jersey, compared with 2.3 per 10,000 nationwide. **********''Physical therapists are being sought everywhere,'' said Royce Buczek, chairman of the state's Board of Physical Therapy, which licenses and regulates therapists. ''There are a wide range of opportunitites from school districts to nursing homes, from fitness centers to rehabilitation programs.'' **********In addition, a growing number of physical therapists are starting private practices. State law bars them from treating patients without a doctor's prescription, but a recent change in New Jersey regulations permits them to ''evaluate and educate'' patients without such a referral. Similar rules exist in 36 other states, including 14 where no prescriptions are needed to obtain physical therapy. **********While many therapists in New Jersey believe the regulation change will bring more consumers directly to their doors, the Medical Society of New Jersey, the state's largest doctors' organization, has challenged the new rule in court. Doctors maintain that it violates state law by allowing physical therapists to practice medicine. **********The need for more physical therapists remains undisputed, however, particularly for disabled elderly people and children with physical and developmental handicaps - who are eligible under Federal law for physical therapy services through their public schools. According to estimates from the state's Bureau of Occupational Research, the field will grow 44 percent from now until 1995, with 110 to 150 new openings each year. The bureau also predicts that 660 positions now filled will open up during that time. Some of those 660 vacancies will be created by therapists leaving salaried positions for per diem work with placement agencies or as private contractors. **********Ronnie Silver, director of the Hackensack, N.J., office of Midpoint Associated Practitioners, based in New York, which supplies speech and occupational therapists as well as physical therapists, said that her business had grown fivefold in the last 10 months, fueled by staff shortages and therapists' desire ''to earn what they are worth.'' For example, 34 of the 36 part-time physical therapists in the state-run day schools for profoundly handicapped children now are private contractors, up from 18 two years ago. As private contractors they receive $30 to $35 an hour, compared with $18.70 they earned as civil service employees. **********Hospitals and rehabilitation centers also are using at least some outside therapists. Although no current data are available, according to Susan Tobier, president of the New Jersey Council of Hospital Physical Therapy Directors, most departments are down at least one full-time physical therapist and some have half their positions open. In a 1983 survey, there were 100 vacancies in hospitals alone. ''Competition for physical therapists is very tight,'' Ms. Tobier said. ''Salaries have escalated very fast, more so than the average profession.'' **********A survey earlier this year conducted by the New Jersey Hospital Association found that the average hourly wage for physical therapists in acute-care and specialty hospitals had jumped 18 percent in two years, from $11.54 to $13.57. Hospital administrators in New Jersey still complain that state-set hospital rates have kept salary levels relatively low, making it difficult to compete with facilties in New York and Philadelphia as well as with unregulated health-care providers within the state. **********Therapists like Mrs. Reger who are still in hospitals say that the need for their services has intensified as cost-saving measures have cut the average patient's length of stay. ''We used to have more time to rehabilitate patients,'' she said. ''Now we have to work on getting them functioning quickly so they can leave the hospital sooner.''  Several New Uses **********Mrs. Reger, whose eight-member department has been short one therapist for two years, noted that hospitals are using physical therapy in new ways. Three days a week, her staff runs a lively rehabilitation program for heart-attack and coronary-bypass patients, and another for people with breathing problems. The ''back school,'' which teaches people how to avoid spinal trouble, is booked through December. And physical therapists regularly counsel young women in the medical center's Eating Disorders Program who have a history of over-exercising to lose weight. **********Outside hospitals, some therapists are finding new markets for their skills while others are combining several part-time jobs into challenging full-time careers. Wayne Rath and his wife, Jean, for example, run the Spine Center of New Jersey, a home-based private practice in Somerville specializing in the relief and prevention of neck and back pain. For two half-days a week, however, the Raths move to Ethicon Inc., in Somerville, which produces the materials surgeons use to close wounds. **********There, in addition to treating work-related injuries, the pair has developed group exercise routines designed to prevent the problems that can plague people with jobs involving repetitive motions. For example, in one Ethicon department, 40 channel swagers, who fuse fine strands of suture material with tiny needles thousands of times a day, perform two seven-minute exercise routines during their shifts to stretch their arms, rotate their heads and flex their wrists. Officials credit the effort with a sharp drop in hand, neck and lower-back injuries. **********Another therapist, Jean Thomas, provides physical therapy to homebound Medicare patients for the Visiting Nurse Association in Middlesex County and works with head-injury victims at a rehabilitation center in Rocky Hill. Recently she helped a 57-year-old woman who had lost an arm in an industrial fire learn to use a prosthesis. ''I can give quality care and still have a flexible schedule,'' explained Mrs. Thomas, who also maintains a small private home-care practice. **********Some physical therapists, like Jeffrey Manheimer, president of Delaware Valley Physical Therapy Associates in Lawrenceville, have developed specialties not always associated with the field. Once a week he teaches practicing dentists and physical therapists at the New Jersey Dental School in Newark how to treat patients with head and facial pain caused by jaw problems. **********Marilyn King, a full-time physical therapist for the Teaneck public Schools, treats children with perceptual problems. ''Some of these kids will put their names in the middle of the page instead of on the top, or they can't space their letters properly,'' Mrs. King said. ''I have a child crawl under bars, fit through spaces, find out how thick his arm is and learn how far his head is from his chest.'' she explained. ''Once he gets a feeling for how his body relates to his environment, he can master the finer movements needed for schoolwork.''  Easy to Fill Class **********With such a varied opportunities and rising salaries, officials of the two new physical-therapy training programs in New Jersey say they will have no trouble filling classes. The first 20 students will begin at Stockton State College in Pomona, near Atlantic City, in January. That two-year program, designed for upper-division students, will award bachelor of science degrees in physical therapy. **********The other new program is co-sponsored by Rutgers University Graduate School in Camden, where it is situated, and the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, based in Newark. It will offer a master's degree in physical therapy, with the first class of 20 enrolling next fall. **********The only existing in-state physical therapy program, run by Kean College in Elizabeth and the University of Medicine and Dentistry, will award 32 bachelor of science degress this spring. **********Joseph Affanato is administrator of the Betty Bacharach Rehabilitation Hospital in Pomona, on the campus of Stockton State College, and was instrumental in setting up the physical therapy program there. He recalled recently that until now, New Jersey, the nation's fifth-largest industrial state with the second biggest geriatric population, only had one school for training physical therapists. ''Even with all three of the programs cranked up next year,'' he said, ''we will still be way behind the national per-capita average for physical therapists.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/28/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Genrad to Close Testing Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/28/busin.body_text: **********Genrad Inc. said today that it was discontinuing operations at its semiconductor test division in Milpitas, Calif. The company, based in Concord, Mass., is a major manufacturer of electronic test systems. **********Genrad said it would take a one-time charge of $34.5 million to cover the phasing-out of its current products and the writing-off of assets and facilities. The charge also includes the cost of severance pay to terminated employees, the company said. **********The company invested heavily in its semiconductor test division, said William R. Thurston, Genrad's president and chief executive, and it became the market leader among American vendors of test equipment for high-speed, very-large-scale integrated circuits, or VLSI, in 1985 and 1986. **********But ''the serious recession in the semiconductor industry, coupled with intense competition from eight vendors in a market whose 1986 size totaled less than $325 million, prevented it from reaching sustainable profitability,'' Mr. Thurston said. Genrad will seek a buyer for the division, he added. **********While the semiconductor industry is in the midst of a recovery, its two-year slump has taken a heavy toll on the producers of equipment used to manufacture or test chips. Faced with strong competition in a shrinking market, several companies have reduced their operations to remain competitive. **********Millard Phelps, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist Inc. in San Francisco, concurred. ''It has been generally felt that a consolidation was inevitable,'' he said. **********But Mr. Phelps said that, while Genrad had had one of the first VLSI testers on the market, the company failed to upgrade its product to remain competitive. ''Any buyer would have to be prepared to upgrade the product line and be capable of doing so,'' he said. **********Genrad also said it would continue to support its existing installed semiconductor test systems with applications, service and software. A worldwide support staff of about 100 people will be maintained to provide field service and engineering assistance. **********Including the charge for the shutdown, Genrad reported a second-quarter loss of $38.3 million, more than three times the $11.1 million it lost in the comparable period last year. The loss from the discontinued operation was $4.3 million, the company said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/12/busin.body_text: **********From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response from readers. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits. **********This time, it was ''Misery on the Meatpacking Line'' by William Glaberson (June 14) that stirred up readers. Following are some of their comments. **********To the Editor: Your article on Morrell and the meatpacking industry was wonderful. The people in Sioux City and Sioux Falls are really thrilled. **********I think most of the people in these plants have assumed for a long time that getting hurt is just an inevitable risk of packinghouse work - unpleasant but unavoidable. So if the company did not worry much about safety, the workers took it in stride. Until now. Recent attention from outside the region (from Congress, from OSHA, from The New York Times) has led many packinghouse workers to revise their low expectations and see present conditions as unacceptable by any standard. Maybe the employers are seeing the same disturbing reflection. Hopefully, the upshot will be a safer industry. **********Thank you for helping us change this industry's practices and assumptions. ELEANOR KENNELLY  Director of Special Services, Food and Allied Service Trades Department, A.F.L.-C.I.O  Washington, D.C., June 19 **********To the Editor: It is clear that a lot of work went into Mr. Glaberson's piece, and I commend his effort. I do take exception, however, to some implications and omissions in the story. **********First, I am disappointed with the omission of relevant information we provided about safety initiatives and improvements in the meat industry. Specifically, there was no mention that the meat industry had the second best improvement rate of the 10 industries with the highest accident and injury rates in 1984-85. This improvement is significant and demonstrates concern and initiative on the industry's part. **********The headline and lead paragraphs indicate that this story is about the meatpacking industry. Yet, the story focused almost exclusively on one company - even though you spoke with officials at several other companies in interviews we helped arrange. **********I recognize these complex issues are difficult to cover in all aspects, but I do feel we deserved some recognition for the progress and attention being given to this issue.  C. MANLY MOLPUS  President, American Meat Institute  Washington, D.C., June 30 **********To the Editor: It was with great interest and a broken heart that I read your article. **********I quit my job on the kill floor of Monfort of Colorado's Grand Island, Neb., plant after four and a half years there. During most of that time I was actively involved in trying to form a union in order to curb the great excesses of management. **********I saw men and women stitched and in casts, one man walking slowly because of a painful back injury caused when a steer fell on him. People were called from their sick beds and told they would be fired if they did not come to work. The turnover rate, as best we could tell, was in excess of 100 percent. Many of us wondered where they all came from. **********Surely, I thought, these people would rise up angry. But we were unsuccessful in forming a union in two National Labor Relations Board elections, both marked by numerous charges against the company's anti-union campaign. **********Much has been made about packinghouse automation, but air knives and down pullers are not very new and conveyor belts do not sound like automation. The rise in productivity has been made simply by increasing the speed the cattle go down the line, and yelling at everyone to keep up. **********Surely, justice requires other than this. I have lost faith in a system that rewards excesses to the clear detriment of such a large number of people. LARRY PETTIT  San Francisco, June 15 **********To the Editor: One of the major goals of the Reagan Administration has been reducing government regulation of business - getting the government off the backs of the American people. Your article helps put this in prospective. More aggressive regulation could well have prevented the accidents Mr. Glaberson described, and others like them. Hopefully, the next administration, whether Republican or Democratic, will put the government back on our backs. JACK KAPLAN  Hamden, Conn., June 15 **********To the Editor: Your revelations are the kind I would rather shut my eyes to or not know about, but all the more important that you have exposed them. Naively, I thought this kind of inhuman treatment of workers had been eliminated by legislation and by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. How wrong I was.  HOPE COBB  Princeton, N.J., June 15 **********To the Editor: Mr. Glaberson provides a compelling, if depressing, insight into the corporate ethics of yet another American industry. The reader can only wonder if there is any morality at all guiding the operations of big business in America. THOMAS J. JOYCE  Monroe, N.Y., June 22 **********To the Editor: I read your horror story and gave it to read to those around me who usually don't look into the business section. I must say that I hardly believe your report. How can we understand that no union, no health or social administration puts an end to so much inhumanity in the workplace? I wonder what the public would say if we read such monstrosities out of Russia. We, I am constantly told, are a country that values life and the individual. Will anything be done soon? E. MARCU  New York, June 16 **********To the Editor: Your story is too familiar. People become ill, injured and killed in the workplace daily. **********Senior management must accept the responsibility to provide a safe workplace. Toward this end, their interest, support and active involvement are essential. In the cases where this corporate commitment has been effectively carried out, the record shows great achievement in avoiding injuries, illness and death. Further, the direct and indirect savings to these organizations represent a significant return on investment for the capital spent on effective safety programs. **********Workers have a similar responsibility to behave safely and act responsibly, but management's influence is paramount. People respond to management's philosphy and attitude. **********Articles such as this one help all of us by pointing out areas of real opportunity. Reducing cost and improving productivity is second only to the humanitarian benefits achieved through an effective safety program. ROBERT F. DeSIERVO  Director Risk Control Services, Crawford Risk Management Services  Dallas, June 17

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/13/busin.main_headline: Burlington Bid Rise Hinted by Edelman
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Burlington Bid Rise Hinted by Edelman
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/13/busin.body_text: **********Asher B. Edelman and Dominion Textile Inc. hinted yesterday in a letter written to Burlington Industries that they might raise their joint bid for the company from $77 a share. **********The investor group was outbid on Wednesday by a leveraged buyout group led by Morgan Stanley & Company, which has offered $78 a share, or $2.5 billion on a fully diluted basis. **********The Edelman-Dominion group's letter advised Burlington that it was ''willing to consider raising the price'' if the company either unraveled certain agreements it made with Morgan Stanley or made the same benefits available to other bidders. Currently, Morgan Stanley is entitled to a multimillion-dollar consolation fee and expense money from Burlington in the event that its current proposal fails. **********Burlington's stock closed unchanged yesterday, at $77.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Arbitragers said they were already heavily invested in Burlington and saw greater profit potential in other situations. **********Burlington, which said it had received the letter but declined comment, has endorsed the Morgan Stanley plan. In a lawsuit filed in Greensboro, N.C., Burlington accused the outside bidders of misappropriating inside information supplied by a former Burlington executive, James J. Ammeen. Burlington won a preliminary injunction in the lower court, but the decision is being appealed. **********Documents linked to that lawsuit, which had inadvertently been made public and have since been put back under seal, disclosed that Paine Webber Inc. initially estimated the worth of Burlington's shares at $63 to $80, after taxes, in a liquidation, and at up to $109, before taxes. The valuations were part of a report that Paine Webber had prepared in an effort to interest Dominion in taking over the Greensboro company. **********The lawsuits' defendants - Mr. Edelman, Dominion, Paine Webber and Mr. Ammeen - are hoping the report will show that the valuations prepared by Paine Webber could not have relied upon inside information because they were off the mark, particularly in the case of those divisions under Mr. Ammeen's control. **********Paine Webber's sales estimates for each of the 24 divisions were off by at least $300,000 and by as much as $15 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/29/busin.body_text: **********A Delaware judge ruled today that Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. may not use recently purchased shares of the Newmont Mining Corporation to vote on the proposed takeover of Newmont by the Texas investor T. Boone Pickens. **********But the judge let Consolidated Gold Fields, Newmont's ally and largest shareholder, retain ownership of the 15.6 million shares. The purchases last week increased its Newmont stake to 49.9 percent from 26.2 percent. **********The Pickens group had asked that the purchases be invalidated. **********In his ruling, Vice Chancellor Jack B. Jacobs of the Delaware Chancery Court also said that the Pickens group, Ivanhoe Partners, could take no action in its bid, other than to extend its deadline of next Monday. **********The judge said Consolidated Gold Fields should either have the shares put into escrow or not vote them. **********The court allowed the unusual arrangement because Consolidated Gold Fields had argued that a financial calamity would result if the share purchases were invalidated. The ruling will remain in effect at least until Thursday, when another hearing on the matter is set.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/31/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; The Matter Of Finding Angels
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/31/busin.body_text: **********AS you can tell by the television commercials for toilet tissue, the most sought-after consumer benefit is softness. As in ''Please don't squeeze the Charmin.'' **********The challenge for an advertising agency is to communicate a message about such a low-interest product in a memorable way. **********Just such a challenge faced Altschiller Reitzfeld when Georgia-Pacific, a client of some six years, assigned it a new premium two-ply product with four possible names. One of them, Angel Soft, hit the hot button at the agency. **********Out West the agency was already advertising the client's M.D. brand with pairs of cuddly little animals, because it is two-ply. Angels, of course, are much harder to find. **********But cherubs are like angels and babies are like cherubs, so all the agency really had to do was put wings on babies. Easier said than done, but it has been done and the advertising is now on network television. **********First, to get the tots, the production company R. Greenberg & Associates, which had been retained by the agency, contacted Herman & Lipson & Lipson, a casting firm, which in turn got in touch with 10 of perhaps 20 of the city's children's talent agents. **********Each sent 10 tads to the caster's place at 24 West 25th Street in Manhattan, where videotapes were made of each and every one of them. From the tapes the agency and the production company made the choice. **********Meanwhile the matter of wings had to be faced up to. You know how it is with cherubs. **********The solution came from the puppeteers at Three Design of 568 Broadway, who devised little flapping pink plush wings that they could operate from the end of a three- to four-foot pole. The wings were just held up behind the babes and flapped as they were being filmed. **********This was one of the ways the agency managed to keep down the costly optical work required when trick photography is used. **********The actual shooting was done at the Kaufman Astoria Studio in Queens, where the 30 selected kids were filmed, 10 a day, for three days and where a large room equipped with playpens was kept for their off-duty lounging pleasure. And, as required by state law, there was a nurse on duty, Mimi Plastek, who usually works at a Manhasset, L.I., health center. **********After the three days, Robert Reitzfeld, vice chairman and creative director of the agency, and Rosalind Greene, senior vice president and copy group head, had some thoughts on wee ones. **********''Some have it and some don't,'' Bob Reitzfeld said, adding that ''some have too much of it.'' **********''And personality has nothing to do with beauty,'' Roz Greene said. **********The two of them, along with David Altschiller, chairman, had created the spots. **********According to Mr. Reitzfeld, the law says that children 3 to 7 months of age may spend only six hours on the set with a camera schedule of half-hour-on and half-hour-off. The camera schedule holds true for children 7 months and up, except they can be on the set eight hours a day. **********Under the Screen Actors Guild contract, each tad got $333.25 for the day, which is merely the tip of the iceberg because if the spots run often enough they can make as much as $15,000 to $30,000, which isn't bad for a day's work. **********The agency has produced two 30-second spots and two 15-second spots, which began running a week ago. They are really delightful.  In the end, a dozen children were used, with one cuter than the next. **********What adds to the charm of the commercials is that the supplier of the voice-over is Sterling Holloway, who was the television voice of Winnie the Pooh. His voice was recorded in New York after being transmitted from the West Coast by satellite. **********Music for the spots was supplied by John Sebastian, who sang with the Lovin' Spoonful group of the 1960's. **********However, Advertising Age recently published an article that Georgia-Pacific was planning to spend $75 million for advertising and promotion over a six-month period in an effort to upgrade its Coronet line. Coronet Angel Soft is certainly such an attempt. **********In 1981, Media Decisions reported in 1983, Coronet was backed by only $1.4 million in advertising. These days you couldn't get one angel airborne for that kind of money.

They said they were urgently trying to get in touch with Angolan officials about it. ]  The Angolan press agency, monitored in Lisbon, said the plane, which it did not identify by type, was downed Tuesday over Otchinjau, in Cunene Province, which borders South-West Africa, also known as Namibia. South-West Africa is ruled by South Africa in defiance of the United Nations. **********The Angolan press agency said the pilot, who was rescued and in good health, had a United States passport. It did not identify him.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/busin.main_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM: TAX REVISION AT THE STATE LEVEL;
States Should Follow the Federal Cue
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM: TAX REVISION AT THE STATE LEVEL;
States Should Follow the Federal Cue
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/22/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: THIRTY-FIVE states are likely to collect higher tax revenues in 1987 because of Federal tax revision, and there is much debate about what the states should do with this ''windfall.'' Should it be spent on education and social programs? Or should it be returned to the taxpayers? If the latter, would it be best to lower maximum tax rates and increase the capital gains exclusion, which might help the rich? **********THIRTY-FIVE states are likely to collect higher tax revenues in 1987 because of Federal tax revision, and there is much debate about what the states should do with this ''windfall.'' Should it be spent on education and social programs? Or should it be returned to the taxpayers? If the latter, would it be best to lower maximum tax rates and increase the capital gains exclusion, which might help the rich? Or would it be better to increase the standard deductions and the personal exemption, while lowering sales and property taxes, which might help the poor and middle-income people? **********These are all valid questions, but couching the issue in these terms diverts attention from the most important points. First, there is no ''windfall,'' only a federally mandated tax increase. Moreover, outside of New York and a few other high-tax states, the revenue gains will be slight - on average less than 5 percent of total tax collections. **********Far more important, Federal tax revision has presented the states with a historic opportunity to restructure, simplify and broaden their tax systems, increasing equity while fostering economic development. In fact, this is probably more than an opportunity; it may be an imperative. **********In an era when states are battling to build and sustain economic development efforts, those that resist the trend toward lower rates, a broad tax base, fewer incentives and a simpler tax structure may find themselves losing the competition. For states like New York, with taxes far above the national norm, lower rates are all the more important in attracting and retaining business. **********Over the last several months, in a study for the American Legislative Exchange Council, we worked with legislators and business representatives from all 50 states to identify the crucial areas of tax reform at the state level. Four things bear careful consideration: **********No. 1, the federally mandated tax increases must be returned. **********Second, as we said earlier, states need to emulate the Federal Government, flattening and reducing tax rates, particularly individual and corporate income taxes, while broadening their tax bases and making an effort to simplify the code. States that stimulate development through lower tax rates, rather than incentives, will prove most successful in attracting business in the years ahead. **********Third, states should abolish most incentives and preferences, seeking instead to equalize tax treatment of different industries. Through the years, states have fallen over themselves to offer businesses lucrative tax incentives, even though it has been demonstrated repeatedly that such incentives figure very little, if at all, in business location decisions. IN MANY states, the result is a hodge-podge of preferences that can severely distort investment decisions. A year from now, when most state tax revisions are complete, the states that have slashed rates while at the same time eliminating these and other preferences will be the most attractive for business. **********Fourth, all states should eliminate income tax burdens on the poor in conformity with the Federal definition. This is a matter not just of fairness but of efficiency. Traditionally, most of the states have relied on the Federal Government for taxpayer surveillance. When the Internal Revenue Service audited a taxpayer it would notify the state, which would then conduct its own audit. Under Federal tax revision, six million poor households have been relieved of their Federal income tax liabilities. To keep track of these poor taxpayers would be extremely costly for states. Whether for fairness or efficiency, it is again in the states' interest to emulate the Federal example. **********While they are reviewing their tax systems, states should also consider the role of excise, sales and minimum taxes. Excise taxes are imposed in a selective manner on a narrow segment of a state's tax base, such as liquor, gasoline or tobacco. These taxes should be either eliminated or incorporated in a general broadening of the sales tax. **********Many analysts object to sales taxes as regressive, but this need not be so. Sales taxes could be broadened to include such items as personal services, food and medicine. With the broadening, the overall rate could be lowered, while certain items (such as food and medicine) could be taxed at lower rates. **********Tax revision is particularly important in high-tax states like New York, whose state and local tax burden is 50 percent above the national average. Moreover, the unnecessary complexity of the New York State tax code and tax forms produces a tremendously high compliance cost. Simplification does not necessarily mean that you forfeit revenue. Indeed, simplification can often generate additional revenue. **********After the dust settles, businesses will begin once again to assess state tax systems, looking at the overall burden and complexity. If New York and other high-tax states simply return the windfall but fail to lower rates and restructure their systems, their competitive position may deteriorate. **********In sum, what is important is the overall level of state and local taxation. The best tax incentive of all is a broad-based tax structure that levies taxes uniformly at low rates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/07/busin.body_text: **********A subpoena to one of the largest ''junk bond'' customers of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is a highlight of the Securities and Exchange Commission's broadening inquiry into takeover abuses by issuers and buyers of these high-yield, high-risk instruments, lawyers close to the investigation said today. **********They said that, in addition to subpoenaing the trading records of Guy O. Dove 3d, a former Drexel employee and currently a top money manager for the Clarendon Group, a Bermuda-based holding company, the S.E.C. had been gathering records on a number of other big Drexel junk bond customers. **********Though the S.E.C. has subponeaed Mr. Dove, it does not mean that he has violated any laws. Often the agency subpoenas many sources to assemble enough information to bring a case. Tip-Off Possibility Studied **********Attorneys close to the Government's investigation say that one focus of the S.E.C. inquiry is the possibility that Drexel may have tipped off large investors about upcoming takeover bids as part of its process of trying to raise capital for the deals. Drexel is well known for its ability to raise large amounts of financing for such bids by lining up junk bond buyers. **********Drexel's chief executive, Fred Joseph, has said in the past that the firm has had to experiment with several methods to try to get commitments from investors to buy the bonds without providing secret inside information about the deals that some might trade on illegally. **********Mr. Joseph has acknowledged that on occasion it appeared that there had been insider trading, but that he did not know if it emanated from Drexel's junk bond buyers. As a result of those suspicions, Mr. Joseph said that the firm eventually changed its practice several years ago and no longer gave out any advance information about pending takeover bids. **********''The S.E.C is definitely worried that Drexel clients on a regular basis misappropriated confidential takeover information, bought stock based on these feelers and repeated violate the securities laws,'' said one lawyer who requested anonymity. ''If you look at it, it is almost a fail-safe system.'' However, the sources add that, without hard evidence that such an informal system was intended to encourage insider trading by both Drexel officials and its clients, the S.E.C. will have a difficult time proving such a case. Linked to Boesky Case **********The investigation of Drexel's clients grows out of the Government's $100 million insider trading case against Ivan F. Boesky. **********In addition to Mr. Dove, the S.E.C. has served subpoenas on the Clarendon Group and Clarendon's president, Rodrigo Rocha. Two years ago, Mr. Dove left Drexel to manage Clarendon's multibillion-dollar portfolio. **********With the Dove and Clarendon subpoena, the S.E.C. is seeking information from one of Drexel's largest buyers of junk bonds - perhaps its largest, according to Wall Street sources. **********One of Clarendon's primary business activities involves borrowing funds that city and local government have raised through municipal bond offerings but have yet to spend. Clarendon then guarantees the local governments a certain rate of return and repayment of the loan through its insurance company, and then reinvests the funds in high-risk bonds. **********''They essentially are living on spreads, and they are working with huge amounts of money,'' said one Wall Street source familiar with the company. ''Their return is often 400 to 500 basis points,'' or 4 to 5 percentage points. None Specifically Named **********According to Lionel Pashkoff, attorney for Clarendon and Mr. Dove, who is with the Washington law firm of Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine, Unterberg, Manley, Myerson & Casey, none of the Clarendon parties are specifically named in the S.E.C. formal order of investigation. Naming them would have been a sure indication that the Government suspected them of illegal activities. ''The order just says, 'In the matter of trading in certain securities,' '' Mr. Pashkoff said. He added that he understood other Drexel clients had received similar subpoenas for information. **********In 1982, Mr. Dove was charged with trading on insider information in connection with the Advent Corporation. At a time when he was a consultant to Advent's board, and just before the company declared bankruptcy, Mr. Dove sold Advent stock short and reaped a profit of $22,000, according to the S.E.C. He settled the case in June 1982, by agreeing to disgorge the illegal profits, while neither admitting nor denying guilt. **********Mr. Dove has offices in Beverly Hills and London and manages Clarendon's assets through the Garrison Capital Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/10/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Interstate Alters Latin Loan Status
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/10/busin.body_text: **********The First Interstate Bancorp said it would place $320 million in Brazilian loans and $14.5 million in Ecuadorean loans on nonaccrual status. The Brazilian action would cover all medium- and long-term loans on which interest payments have been suspended since February. The Ecuadorean step covers all loans to that country, aside from those guaranteed by the United States Government. **********The change would reduce the bank's net income for the first quarter by about $4.6 million and for the year by about $15.4 million. When a loan is placed on nonaccrual status, the bank can record interest income only when it is actually received, not when it is due. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/25/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Pannill Knitting Seeks a Purchaser
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/25/busin.body_text: **********The Pannill Knitting Company, one of four American manufacturers of sweatshirts and sweatpants, said it had retained a unit of Merrill Lynch & Company to seek a buyer. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Merrill Lynch unit, Merrill Lynch Interfunding Inc., said it might sell its 5.7 percent of Pannill's 15 million outstanding shares -in the open market or in a private transaction - to facilitate a sale. **********William G. Pannill, the company's chairman, said there had been no developments since the board authorized Merrill Lynch to seek prospective buyers on Sept. 8. He said a leveraged buyout was not being considered. In 1984, a management group including Mr. Pannill purchased the company, based in Martinsville, Va., in a leveraged buyout for about $230 million.
