https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/13/world.main_headline: Iraqi Jets Raid Greek Ship in Gulf, Killing Sailor
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/13/world.print_headline: Iraqi Jets Raid Greek Ship in Gulf, Killing Sailor
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/13/world.body_text: **********Iraqi warplanes raided a Greek-owned ship in the Persian Gulf today, killing at least one crewman in their ninth attack in a week on tankers either leased by Iran or trading with it. **********In Iran, the leader of the Revolutionary Guards said Iran produces 70 percent of its weapons for the war with Iraq, including advanced missiles and multiple rocket launchers. **********In its report on the raid, Iraq said its jets hit ''a large naval target,'' its usual term for a tanker, at midday today. **********Shipping executives identified it as the Greek-owned Marianthi M, a 21,166-ton tanker registered in Panama and chartered by Iran. **********The Marianthi M, which was said in one report to be ablaze, sent a distress call from 60 miles southeast of Iran's port of Bushire. In Athens, the owners said a crewman was killed and another was wounded. Weapons Production Reported **********The Iranian press agency quoted Mohsen Rafiq Doust, Government minister of the Revolutionary Guards, as saying Iranian experts ''have access to advanced technology in military weaponry and can manufacture even such things as aircraft and surface-to-air missiles.'' **********The agency said he spoke at a ceremony to mark the start of production of ''mini-Katyusha missile launchers'' at a ''military industries plant'' in Shiraz. The Katyusha is a Soviet-built launcher that can fire several rockets at once. **********Mr. Rafiq Doust said the launchers could be mounted on boats or cars. **********No mention was made of Iran's claim last week that it has produced a version of the American Stinger, a shoulder-fired, anti-aircraft missile.  Iraqi Kurds Seize 3 Italians **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 12 (AP) -Iraqi Kurds who support Iran said today that they had kidnapped three Italian engineers in northern Iraq and demanded that Italy withdraw its warships from the gulf. **********A statement from Iraqi Kurdistan National Union said the group seized the Italians to protest ''Italian aid to the Iraqi regime and Italian military presence in the gulf waters.'' **********The statement was typewritten in Arabic and delivered to a Western news agency in West Beirut. **********Eight Italian warships, including minesweepers, are in the gulf region or on their way. **********In Rome, the Foreign Ministry identified the abducted Italians as Sergio Cominetti, Giuseppe Carrara and Roberto Diotallevi. It said Mr. Cominetti was kidnapped ''around the middle of September'' near Mosul in northern Iraq and the others were taken ''around 10 days ago'' in an area it did not name. **********Italian news agencies said Mr. Carrara and Mr. Diotallevi work for Gruppo Industrie Elettromeccaniche and were kidnapped Oct. 2 from the company's thermoelectric plant in Baiji, 60 miles north of Baghdad. They said Mr. Cominetti works for Societa Anonima Elettrificazione.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/04/busin.main_headline: An Industry Built on Dubious Results
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/04/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM: THE HOME HEALTH EXAM MARKET; An Industry Built on Dubious Results
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/04/busin.body_text: **********THE Food and Drug Administration has been boasting that medical test kits for home use are 95 to 99 percent effective before they can be approved for sale. The F.D.A. also claims home tests are as effective as their counterpart diagnostic kits used in ''clinical settings'' - tests performed in commercial laboratories, doctors' offices and hospitals. The unfortunate truth is that the F.D.A. has no effectiveness standards for professionally performed tests, let alone at-home tests. **********When queried directly, an F.D.A. spokesman admitted that such ''standards'' are not official written policy. They are instead ''verbal expressions'' offered by scientists at the F.D.A.'s Center for Devices and Radiological Health. In other words, effectiveness standards for medical tests are wishful thinking. **********What is more, the agency also maintains that, prior to sale, every medical test, whether for expert or home use, has demonstrated its safety by proving the device or product will not cause injury. Safety must be considered relative since it is evaluated by weighing a test's probable benefits to health against its possible harm. But the F.D.A.'s claims contradict a Congressional report that states that proof that a medical test will never cause injury or will always be effective is not a requirement for agency approval. **********A bit of background: prior to 1976, there were no regulations governing the use of any medical test, device or procedure. Then Congress passed a law that required the F.D.A. to guarantee any medical device used for diagnostic purposes as effective and safe prior to being marketed. Through the ensuing years, medical test devices, along with their related chemical components, were ultimately placed in three classes, primarily associated with their potential for harm but with no reference to effectiveness. **********Class I tests were considered to have the least danger - akin to drugs that can be purchased without a prescription. Thermometers and blood testosterone tests are in Class I. Tests assigned to Class II were those the agency felt could be unsafe if randomly used. These tests were supposed to meet stringent performance standards. Simple urine sugar tests and even blood thyroid tests are in this broad category. As of this year, for the nearly 2,000 test devices allocated to Class II, not one performance standard has been set. **********Class III devices are deemed so dangerous that they are ostensibly required to prove their safety before marketing. Class III includes all new diagnostic devices such as magnetic resonance imagers, AIDS antibody tests and catheters used for X-rays of the heart's circulation. **********But, F.D.A. ''approval'' does not take into account who uses a specific test device once it is sold. This means the agency cannot be blamed for a mistake in reading an X-ray picture, a false-positive AIDS test or a heart catheter that causes, rather than helps diagnose, heart damage. **********The F.D.A. has approved the use of contrast media (dye-like substances injected or swallowed that stand out on an X-ray); ergo, they must be at least 95 percent effective as well as safe. But to doctors, effectiveness is equated with accuracy; it cannot be relative when a life depends on the proper diagnosis. Yet X-ray specialists admit in their own professional journals that contrast media X-rays of the gall bladder are less than 50 percent accurate and that at least 800 people die each year from a reaction to the contrast substances. **********While keeping in mind that the stress electrocardiogram also has the F.D.A.'s imprimatur, in reality this test is rated from only 12 to 50 percent accurate when used to detect heart disease in healthy people. In patients with known heart disease, the test has been shown to be wrong at least half the time. **********AS for safety, for every 10,000 people who perform on a treadmill, while the electrocardiogram is taken, four suffer heart attacks and one dies as a consequence of the test. **********Possibly the worst example of test ineffectiveness is the one for blood cholesterol. The College of American Pathologists, the peer group for laboratory testing, recently sent out an ''unknown'' blood sample to 5,000 laboratories to measure this test's accuracy. Less than half of the laboratories surveyed came within the 95 percent effectiveness range claimed by the F.D.A. **********Experts in the field blame the errors on the so-called ''standards'' used for calibration of test instruments and the controls used to monitor the determinations. The Commerce Department's Bureau of Standards obviously agrees and is now in the process of trying to correct the problem. Considering the facts, the Commerce Department and the Centers for Disease Control are not in error when they call the cholesterol test inaccurate. **********It is wrong, and even dangerous, for the F.D.A. to tell the public that home medical tests are as accurate as their counterparts done in clinical settings, since neither has any official accuracy standards at this time. This does not mean medical tests are bad. Rather, they are diagnostic adjuncts and should not be considered innocuous. The F.D.A., in spite of its boasts, does not deny that the standards for medical tests approval are less rigorous than would be required for the sale of a prescription drug. Unfortunately, however, even the F.D.A.'s drug evaluations no longer appear as stringent as they once were in the effort to hasten the availability of a new drug.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/28/world.main_headline: BRITISH PAPER DEFIES A BAN ON SPY STORY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/28/world.print_headline: BRITISH PAPER DEFIES A BAN ON SPY STORY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/28/world.body_text: **********In an unusual challenge to the Government, a British newspaper ignored a court ban today and published details of a book asserting that British intelligence agents plotted against Prime Minister Harold Wilson. **********The Government quickly took up the challenge from the newspaper, The Independent, and announced that it would seek a contempt-of-court judgment to stop further publication of accusations from the memoirs of Peter Wright, a retired British spy whom the Government has sought to silence. **********The Independent, calling for parliamentary oversight of Britain's intelligence services, devoted its front page to three articles on the memoirs. The book charges that a group of about 30 British agents spied on, conspired against and defamed Prime Minister Wilson, who served three terms as Prime Minister between 1964 and 1976, because they disliked his visits to the Soviet Union and considered him untrustworthy. **********The memoirs, called ''Spycatcher,'' have been examined and debated for months in the courts in Australia, where the Thatcher Government has mounted a thus far unsuccessful challenge to prevent publication. Secrecy Called Endemic **********Two other London newspapers, The Evening Standard and The Daily News, followed The Independent's lead in publishing details and also faced the Government's contempt of court challenge. **********''We have endemic secrecy here,'' said Andreas Whittam Smith, editor of The Independent, which was founded last fall. He said it was ''ludicrous'' that Parliament and the public had been denied information that has been easily accessible to the rest of the world. **********In conjunction with the court fight in Australia, the Thatcher Government obtained a British court ruling last July that generally enjoined the press from reporting Mr. Wright's charges to British citizens by way of correspondents covering the Australian court fight. That wider ruling grew out of the Government's invoking national secrecy and acting against two other newspapers, The Guardian and The Observer, which had initially published details of Mr. Wright's charges about agents of M.I.5, the Government Secret Service. **********Mr. Whittam Smith maintained in an interview that no such general ban could be binding on Fleet Street and that he was free to publish since there was no specific injunction against his newspaper. **********''This is a matter of overwhelming public interest,'' Mr. Whittam Smith said. ''When you look at the activities of M.I.5 in trying to destabilize and bring down the Prime Minister of that day, we have something exceedingly serious.'' He contended that wayward Government agents had proved adept at ''protecting their backs'' and should henceforth be closely monitored by a joint committee of the Houses of Commons and Lords. Secrecy Laws Are Extensive **********The British Government uses extensive secrecy laws to exercise some of the most far-reaching powers over the press in the Western world. Critics have complained that successive Prime Ministers protect their predecessors from late emerging accusations, in effect, by staunchly defending their own perogatives under the official secrets act. **********At the same time, the British public is treated to an endless, confusing array of articles in the newspapers rooted in rumors of double-agent ''moles'' and compromising homosexuality in the highest levels of the intelligence services. **********The precise truth of these articles and the extent of possible official damage often is never clearly ascertained, in part because Britain has no constitution for providing the extensive investigation powers akin to those of the United States Congress. Amid the latest such rumor barrage, Prime Minister Thatcher confirmed last week that Sir Maurice Oldfield, the late director of M.I.6, another intelligence agency, was a homosexual, but she offered no other details. **********Mr. Wright charges that M.I.5, which specializes in counterintelligence, was penetrated by Soviet agents - a scandal well known now for years - and that it also regularly engaged in unlawful activities inside Britain. Most of the charges have long since been published, although often left unverified, and that fact was part of Mr. Wright's defense. **********The Government accuses Mr. Wright of violating his promise as a British agent not to disclose the inner workings of M.I.5, where he served as a high-ranking official until retirement in 1976.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/busin.main_headline: Boesky Gets Jail For Insider Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/busin.print_headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS; Boesky Gets Jail For Insider Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/busin.body_text: **********Ivan F. Boesky was sentenced to three years in prison for his part in Wall Street's biggest insider trading scandal. Mr. Boesky, once a leading arbitrager who amassed a fortune speculating in corporate takeovers, had pleaded guilty in April to one count of conspiracy to make false statements to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Boesky could have been sentenced to up to five years and ordered to pay a $250,000 fine. But Judge Morris E. Lasker of Federal District Court in Manhattan noted that he had already paid a $100 million civil penalty to the S.E.C. Mr. Boesky is scheduled to enter prison on March 24. *********** Oil prices dropped sharply, reaching their lowest levels in 10 months, because OPEC failed to take action to stop its members from cheating on prices and production levels. Instead, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries simply extended the group's $18-a-barrel price and its current production quotas through the first six months of next year. The price of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark American crude oil, fell to $15.58 a barrel on Friday, from $18.31 a week earlier. *********** The stock market advanced sharply, shaking off fears of the triple witching hour, the quarterly confluence of the expirations of stock index futures, index options and individual stock options. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 108.26 points, or 5.8 percent, for the week, a record point gain. It closed at 1,975.30. *********** The Bank of Boston became the first major American bank to acknowledge that many of its Latin American loans were worthless. It said it would write off $200 million of its $1 billion debt in the region. *********** House and Senate negotiators approved a package of individual and corporate tax law changes that would raise $9 billion in new taxes in 1988 and another $14 billion in 1989. *********** Mexico's central bank devalued the peso by 18 percent against the dollar to bring the official exchange rate more in line with the free market rate. By the end of the week, the peso trading at 2,280 to the dollar. *********** The A. H. Robins Company said it had received a takeover offer from Sanofi, a French pharmaceutical company. Robins said the deal would provide the $2.48 billion it needs to compensate women injured by its Dalkon Shield birth control device. *********** Consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in November and consumer spending advanced five-tenths of 1 percent. The increase in the Government's Consumer Price Index followed an October rise of four-tenths of 1 percent. It brought this year's inflation to an annual rate of 4.7 percent. **********Home construction rebounded last month after dropping in October. The Government said that housing starts rose 7.5 percent. **********Industrial production rose four- tenths of 1 percent in November, and the nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 81.7 percent of capacity, the highest level in more than three years. *********** The British Petroleum Company said it would attempt to take over Britoil P.L.C. in a bid that values the company at more than $4 billion. British Petroleum already owns 24.9 percent of Britain's largest independent oil company. The move is opposed by the British Government. *********** An Indian court ordered the Union Carbide Corporation to pay about $270 million as interim compensation to victims of the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/world.main_headline: U.S. and China Agree to Curb Textile Imports
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/world.print_headline: U.S. and China Agree to Curb Textile Imports
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/20/world.body_text: **********The United States and China, after a year of often contentious negotiations, concluded an agreement early today that will drastically curb China's shipments of textiles and apparel to the United States through 1991. It starts Jan. 1. **********In recent years China has sharply boosted production capacity for these products, which are now its main source of foreign earnings. In the last year China replaced Taiwan as the leading supplier to the United States. **********Moreover, textile and apparel sales here contributed heavily to the $3.1 billion trade surplus that China recorded with the United States in the first 10 months of this year. **********Under the memorandum of understanding - initialed at 1 A.M. by the chief American textile negotiator, William H. Houston 3d, and China's chief negotiator, Li Guo Dong - the growth rate of China's exports will be cut back to 3 percent from the 19 percent prevailing since July 1983. **********The United States has recently negotiated long-term textile agreements with the four other major suppliers -Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Japan - curbing their export growth to around 1 percent. China was given a higher rate, an American spokesman, Gary Holmes, explained, because it is poorer country and because textiles are a much more important factor in the Chinese economy than in the four others. **********The agreement settles an issue that has long been a point of friction between the two countries. **********Chinese sensitivity was demonstrated in 1983 when it banned further purchases of cotton, soybeans and chemical fibers from the United States in retaliation for quotas on certain textile products that were unilaterally imposed a few months earlier by the Reagan Administration. The sanctions imposed by both countries were lifted when the two nations concluded their first major textile agreement in July of that year. **********But textiles are also a highly sensitive subject in the United States. The pact has already touched off complaints from domestic producers and their supporters on Capitol Hill, who feel the United States was too generous with the Chinese. **********Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, said in the Senate this morning that the agreement was a ''giveaway'' that will cost ''untold thousands of American jobs.'' **********According to Robert G. Laidlaw, president of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, the industry's lobbying organization, the Administration has ''sent a clear signal that the import problem will continue and the textile and trade deficit will worsen.'' **********Domestic producers have been seeking legislation that would impose even tighter curbs on imports. **********A bill that passed the House over Administration opposition last September would cut imports from all countries to 1 percent growth. The vote was 263 to 156 - still 27 votes shy of the 290 needed to guaranty an override of an almost certain Presidential veto. **********A parallel bill has yet to reach the floor of the Senate. Backers expect it to be voted on sometime next year, making textile trade into an election issue. **********The industry had earlier maneuvered quota legislation through both chambers only to have Mr. Reagan's veto sustained by the House in 1986. **********The five countries where the United States now has long-term pacts supply 50 percent of American imports. The United States Trade Representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said the five agreements, combined with other international undertakings, ''solve the problem of textile and apparel import surges into the United States.'' **********He noted that recent figures showing large profits for domestic textile and apparel manufacturing companies ''would suggest that these companies are already reaping the benefits of our earrlier negotiating successes.'' **********But a representative said the reason for the high profits was an investment of $8 billion in plant modernization and equipment since 1981, which is now endangered by import rises. **********In the first 10 months of this year China was the 13th largest trading partner of the United States. Imports accounted for 1.68 percent of the American total.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/30/world.main_headline: A YEAR AFTER CHAOS, SHAMIR IS VOTED PARTY CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/30/world.print_headline: A YEAR AFTER CHAOS, SHAMIR IS VOTED PARTY CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/30/world.body_text: **********A year after its convention broke up in chaos and fistfights, the right-wing Herut Party reconvened today and elected Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir as its chairman. **********In an impassioned acceptance speech, Mr. Shamir urged the 2,000 Herut convention delegates to fight any attempt to force Israel to relinquish the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********''They will be in our hands foreover,'' declared Mr. Shamir, as the party's faithful, gathered at the Tel Aviv Fairgrounds, roared their approval. **********But while Mr. Shamir's election to party chairman went smoothly in an open display of hands, the same was not true in the balloting for the other three top positions in the Herut leadership, which are being fought over by Mr. Shamir's three main rivals: Housing Minister David Levy, Industry Minister Ariel Sharon and Moshe Arens, a Minister Without Portfolio. **********Five hours after voting for these key secondary posts was completed, vote counting had not begun because of procedural disputes. **********In the competition for the secondary posts, which could have a large influence on succession in the party after the 73-year-old Mr. Shamir retires, Mr. Levy was running against a pro-Sharon legislator, Meir Cohen Avidov, for the post of deputy party chairman. **********Mr. Sharon was running against a pro-Levy legislator, Ovadia Ali, for head of the party central committee, which chooses all the party candidates for Parliament. **********Mr. Arens was running against a pro-Levy party official, Yoram Aridor, for chief of the Herut Party secretariat, or bureaucracy. **********It was not clear whether the convention would conclude peacefully and with declarations of unity, or explode in a welter of accusations of vote-rigging, table-turning and other unpleasantness as did the earlier round of this convention a year ago. **********Together with the small Liberal Party, Herut forms the right-of-center Likud bloc in Parliament. **********A year ago, the Herut Party gathered for its first convention since Menachem Begin, its founder, retired as Prime Minister and party leader in 1983. That convention broke up in disarray when the party's main power brokers - Mr. Shamir, Mr. Sharon, Mr. Levy and Mr. Arens -could not agree on how to divide the key positions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; A Wrinkled Peasant In Skin Care Promotion
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/busin.body_text: **********A number of ad agencies are getting inspiration these days from the ancient Soviet citizens who appeared in the Dannon Yogurt commercials shot a decade ago by Marsteller, now HCM. **********One of the agencies is Launey, Hachmann & Harris, working for (of all things) Dr. Jonathan Zizmor's Skin Care Clinic and Facial Treatment Center. And instead of using some peaches-and-cream complexioned lovely to adorn a four-color ad, the agency has come up with a pleasant, but prune-faced, peasant in her babushka in drab black and white. **********The headline explains the strange choice of models: ''It takes more than yogurt for beautiful skin.'' **********It should stand out starkly amid the beautiful perfection in the pages of New York Woman, where it is scheduled to run in the March/April issue, and Modern Bride's June/July issue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Cablevision to Add Adams-Russell
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/16/busin.body_text: **********The Cablevision Systems Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Adams-Russell Company, a publicly held cable concern based in Waltham, Mass., for $474 million, or $43.075 a share. **********Adams-Russell has 225,000 subscribers, and the price per subscriber - $2,089 - appears to be a record, said Paul Kagan, who heads Paul Kagan Associates, a Carmel, Calif., media consulting firm. He said the price reflected the industry's growing optimism about cable's future. One reason for the optimism is recent deregulation, which has permitted cable operators to charge more for basic cable services. In 1984 Congress passed, and the President signed, the Cable Communication Policy Act, which provided for full deregulation of fees beginning this year. **********Cablevision, with 708.000 subscribers, is the nation's 16th-largest cable company. The acquisition would make it the 11th largest. **********Charles Dolan, the chairman and largest shareholder of Cablevision, reached yesterday on vacation in Nantucket, Mass., said, ''It is a big gulp for us, but we don't anticipate the systems will be any less expensive than they are today.'' **********Cablevision has been on the sidelines in the consolidation spree of recent years, acquiring primarily small systems. **********''This was the first time we reached out for an multi-system operator,'' Mr. Dolan said. ''The banks will support us. Our company is in very good shape and we have a lot of unused cash flow.'' **********Cablevision Systems also manages and operates affiliates in Boston and Chicago. Mr. Dolan noted that there are many close-together Cablevision and Adams-Russell systems. Adams-Russell and Cablevision both have systems in New York and Massachussettes,
