https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.main_headline: The Contras in Costa Rica: A Tangled Tale Is Told in Lawsuit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.print_headline: The Contras in Costa Rica: A Tangled Tale Is Told in Lawsuit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/13/world.body_text: **********Two American freelance journalists living here are at the heart of an unresolved lawsuit charging that a broad conspiracy surrounded Nicaraguan rebel activities in Costa Rica, including an assassination attempt, drug-dealing and gun-running. **********The two journalists, Tony Avirgan and Martha Honey, claim that the conspiracy was carried out by a network of former C.I.A. operatives, right-wing Cubans, Nicaraguan rebels and American mercenaries who operated here in support of the rebels, known as contras. **********Even though a range of investigations by Government agencies and news organizations have failed to validate the lawsuit's central claims, the two journalists and the Christic Institute, a liberal Washington-based organization that has taken up their case, have doggedly pressed the suit in public for more than a year, attracting attention. **********Several of the central figures in the Iran-contra affair who are also defendants in the case say they have have spent an extraordinary amount of time and effort fighting the suit. **********References to the allegations have been made during the Congressional Iran-contra hearings. Charges Are Denied **********American officials and several of those accused of illegal activity by the two journalists have repeatedly denied the accusations. Some American officials contend that the two reporters are political activists and that they have created a conspiracy theory to press their opposition to American policy in Central America. **********Mr. Avirgan and Ms. Honey, who are husband and wife, deny that they are biased. They base their assertions on their investigation of a bombing that almost killed rebel leader Eden Pastora in 1984 as he spoke to a crowded news conference. The blast killed at least four people and wounded more than 20, including Mr. Avirgan. **********The suit, which the Christic Institute filed on behalf of Ms. Honey and Mr. Avirgan in Miami last year before the Iran-contra scandal was disclosed, charges that 29 men conspired to run guns, deal drugs and kill Mr. Pastora in an illegal effort to press the contra war from Costa Rica. **********The lawsuit does not charge that the C.I.A. was involved but does name some former senior officials of the agency. Drugs were sold, the suit charges, to buy guns for the rebels, though it is not clear who was in charge of the shipments. Iran-Contra Figures Are Named **********Those named in the suit include Richard V. Secord, the retired general who was the point man in setting up a secret supply network for the contras overseen by former White House aide Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. Also named are contra leader Adolfo Calero and Robert Owen, Mr. North's emissary to the contras. **********Mr. Secord, Mr. Calero and Mr. Owen have denied the accusations against them. **********Several news organizations, as well as Congressional investigators, have looked into the allegation that drugs were sold to buy weapons for the contras, and have so far been unable to prove it. **********Mr. Avirgan is a television cameraman who has worked for ABC, CBS and the BBC in England. Ms. Honey has been a stringer for several newspapers, including The New York Times and now writes for the Times of London and the Sunday Times of London. Journalists Got Too Close **********Their investigations apparently worried members of Mr. North's secret contra supply network. An ex-C.I.A. agent, Glenn A. Robinette, told Congressional investigators that Mr. Secord paid him $100,000 last year to investigate Mr. Avirgan and Ms. Honey in order to develop ''derogatory'' information about them. **********Mr. Robinette said he came to Costa Rica and paid people for information. Mr. Secord has said he paid Mr. Robinette to investigate the two reporters only because they were close to revealing Mr. North's secret contra supply network. **********Mr. Secord has denied involvement with any conspiracy that involved drug-dealing or the attempt to kill Mr. Pastora. **********In the last year, Mr. Avirgan and Ms. Honey say they have received numerous anonymous death threats, and their lawyers and friends have been detained and harassed by the Costa Rican narcotics police, who have received training and funding from the American Embassy here. In addition, the two reporters, who have lived here for four years, say their house has been burglarized three times. Targets of a Setup **********Last month, they were the targets of what one Costa Rican official called a clumsy setup that involved mailing a package of cocaine to them, supposedly sent by Nicaraguan Interior Minister Tomas Borge. Two weeks ago, a rightist political group unsuccessfully demanded that the two reporters be expelled as ''spies.'' **********A senior Costa Rican official said a review had shown that Mr. Avirgan and Ms. Honey had broken no laws. **********Three drug-traffickers now imprisoned in the United States have told reporters and Congressional investigators that some drug planes were allowed to land in the area in northern Costa Rica from which the contras operated. Guns were also run to the rebels, according to several ex-contras and mercenaries. In addition, someone built and planted a very professional bomb that almost killed Mr. Pastora. **********But American officials say the drug trafficking, gun-running and the bombing are separate events that do not, as the two reporters contend, form part of a conspiracy. Theory on Assassination **********The man who tried to kill Mr. Pastora has never been found. American officials assert he was an agent of the Sandinistas, a claim they have not proved. In their investigation, Mr. Avirgan and Ms. Honey concluded that Mr. Pastora's rightist opponents within the contra movement hired a Libyan assassin named Amac Galil to plant the bomb. **********The two journalists have a witness, a former contra adviser named Jack Terrell, who told a Costa Rican court last year that he was in a meeting where the bomb attack and other plans to kill Mr. Pastora were discussed with senior contra officials, including Mr. Calero, and an American rancher here named John Hull. **********Mr. Calero and Mr. Hull have denied ever discussing killing Mr. Pastora. **********Mr. Avirgan and Ms. Honey contend that the contras killed a key source of theirs to keep him from talking. The two say they never met their source, but they communicated with him through a Costa Rican carpenter. Victims of a Hoax? Critics of the two journalists say they are victims of a hoax or have created a tale conveniently based on a witness who cannot be produced. **********The journalists have also charged that American Embassy officials here had obstructed their investigative efforts on two occasions. **********Two mercenaries arrested while aiding the contras here, Steven Carr and Robert Thompson, have told reporters that American Embassy officials helped them jump bail last year and escape from Costa Rica. Mr. Carr, a principal source for Mr. Avirgan and Ms. Honey, died of a cocaine overdose after reaching the United States. **********An embassy spokesman confirmed that embassy officials had met the two mercenaries, but denied they helped them leave Costa Rica. **********The one sustained official investigation here of the bombing foundered when the Costa Rican policeman in charge of the case dropped the inquiry in 1985. Mr. Avirgan and Ms. Honey contend that the American Embassy offered the policeman a chance to study in the United States on the condition that he leave immediately, forcing him to drop the investigation. **********The American Embassy spokesman said that while the policeman had been sent to study in the United States, the trip had been approved in advance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/24/busin.body_text: **********THE 134-year-old Mount Sinai Medical Center has been driven by circumstance into 20th-century marketing and will soon be unleashing its first multimedia advertising campaign. The theme, created by the year-old Grace & Rothschild agency, is ''Take Good Care of Yourself.'' **********The two 30-second commercials will begin to run Thursday on all local commercial channels as well as on Channel 13 and several health-related cable programs. **********That along with radio, newspaper and magazine advertising will, in the belief of Natal K. Matschulat, vice president, marketing and development, give Mount Sinai the loudest hospital voice in New York and perhaps in the nation. Hospitals have become intensely competitive in trying to fill their beds, and she will not disclose for publication the size of her ad budget, which is sizable in light of the limited area involved. **********Ms. Matschulat, with packaged-goods marketing and agency experience, has in a year with the hospital established its first marketing department, staffed with five professionals. Now she is prepared to do something about getting a better share for Mount Sinai in a marketplace where hospitals are operating with 81 percent of their beds filled, in comparison with 96 percent two years ago. **********The difficulty with hospital advertising is that persuading a potential patient to go to a particular hospital is not enough because the patient, except in emergency cases, cannot check himself in. So the advertising aims to get consumers to seek out physicians connected with the hospital and to get physicians with more than one hospital affiliation to increase the traffic they send to Mount Sinai. And it would not hurt if the advertising also engendered a giving spirit among potential contributors to the current $165 million building fund. **********''We were looking for advertising to give the hospital a personality,'' Ms. Matschulat said, ''a personality of top medical care. Fortunately, we had the kind of a staff to justify that kind of claim.'' **********''Top doctors equal top medicine,'' said Roy Grace, the agency's chairman. **********''And top-quality medical care is the bottom line to the consumer,'' added Ms. Matschulat. **********To get across this message of a superior staff leading to superior care, the TV spots will use a series of vignettes, each about someone in a far-off land who has been helped toward a healthier existence by Mount Sinai Medical Center. **********Each commercial opens with a description of three people who have been aided and ends with the voice-over saying, ''And while people around the world have been helped by procedures developed by doctors at Mount Sinai, people in New York can be helped by something even better: the doctors themselves.'' **********The radio advertising will be pretty much the same but lengthened to a more leisurely 60 seconds. **********''And it has to be human, not haughty, relating to people, yet dignified,'' Mr. Grace said.  Each of the two print ads deals with a different medical breakthrough by doctors at the hospital. This facet of the campaign, aimed at adults 25 years old and up, will run through May 31 in The New York Times, metro editions of Time and Newsweek, New York magazine and the On The Avenue insert in Avenue magazine. **********According to the Nov. 20 issue of Hospital magazine, 1986 marketing spending by hospitals came to $1.1 billion, up 56 percent from the $700 million spent the year before. The average marketing budget, exclusive of salaries, was $227,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/22/world.body_text: **********Kim Dae Jung, one of the losers in the presidential election last week, has apologized for the opposition's failure to field a single candidate and said the split was one reason for the Government's victory. **********''I don't know what to say to console you for your disappointment, especially when I think that one of the reasons why I failed to change the regime is because I failed to achieve a single candidacy,'' Mr. Kim said in a front-page newspaper advertisement Monday. ''I think my responsibility is overwhelming, and I sincerely apologize.'' **********Together, the two main opposition candidates, Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam, received 55 percent of the vote, while Roh Tae Woo, the ruling party candidate, won with just 37 percent. Kim Dae Jung's apology didn't mean he believed the opposition defeat was his fault, however; he continued to charge that election fraud would have made it impossible for the opposition to win in any case. **********Mr. Kim's apology comes at a time when opposition groups seem demoralized and uncertain over their next step. Faced with public anger over the opposition split, they are debating whether to stage a full-scale drive to overturn the elections. Such a call for nationwide demonstrations worked in June, forcing the Government to reverse itself and allow direct presidential elections, but it is by no means clear that the public would take to the streets again this time around. No Move to Reunify Opposition **********Moreover, the opposition remains divided from a campaign in which the two Kims issued increasingly angry denunciations of each other. And many politicians want to focus on legislative elections, which the ruling party now would like to schedule for early February, before Mr. Roh takes power. **********Choi Jang Jip, an associate professor of political science, said that for the most part, people are not eager to demonstrate. ''People are exhausted and disappointed,'' he said. **********Mr. Kim did not issue a direct call for demonstrations in his statement, although he said he would join in the struggle of students, workers, farmers and religious leaders to overturn the election. But he said he opposed violence. **********''I think it's only natural that I should join them in this struggle and sacrifice myself in this fight,'' he said. ''I denounce violence and disorder, and I sincerely hope that our young men and democratic citizens will no longer be sacrificed.'' Fraud Is Still Emphasized **********Mr. Kim also detailed a long list of examples of election fraud. Indeed, the bulk of his statement was devoted to a discussion of fraud. **********''This was a rigged election, orchestrated by big money, Government power and the mass media,'' he said. ''Thousands and thousands of specific cases of fraud were committed throughout the election process. Under such circumstances, no opposition party, even in a developed nation, could have won.'' **********Kim Young Sam also repeated his earlier apologies over the failure to field a single candidate, but like Kim Dae Jung he did not accept full responsibility for the opposition defeat. **********''It is clear that the major reason I didn't win the election is because of the well-organized corrupt election practices,'' he told reporters this morning. **********On Monday, he called for people to join him in resisting the results of the election. ''I announce that this election is completely annulled,'' he said. ''This struggle shall be peaceful and nonviolent,'' **********But he did not say how the struggle would take place, nor did he set any dates for demonstrations. **********As the aftershocks of the election continued, Stephen Cardinal Kim Sou Hwan, an influential Roman Catholic leader, broke his silence on the election results. **********''Although we have a winner in this election, it is a shame that not everyone can share the joy of victory,'' said Cardinal Kim, who played an important role in pushing the Government in June to compromise and allow presidential elections. **********''The night is still long,'' he said, ''and the dawn of celebration still seems far away.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/world.main_headline: U.S. Sees Progress in Moscow on a Missile Accord
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/world.print_headline: U.S. Sees Progress in Moscow on a Missile Accord
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/25/world.body_text: **********Despite their failure to set a date for a summit meeting, the United States and the Soviet Union bridged important differences on the emerging agreement to ban medium-range and shorter-range missiles, Administration officials said today. **********The officials gave details of the progress made in Moscow on the issues of the West German Pershing 1A missiles and verification of a treaty. **********Some Soviet officials, in seeking to resolve the remaining differences, appeared to operate on the assumption that a summit meeting would be held later this year, the officials reported. **********Kenneth L. Adelman, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said that one ranking Soviet official stressed the need to conclude the treaty by Nov. 15 so that a summit meeting could be held next month. Reagan Sees 'No Hurry' **********In his weekly radio address, President Reagan reaffirmed today his refusal to negotiate a compromise on the scope of testing of his space-based defense system, widely known as ''Star Wars.'' The Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said that progress must be made on this issue to justify a summit. **********''No date was set for a summit meeting, but we're in no hurry, and we certainly will not be pushed into sacrificing essential interests just to have a meeting,'' Mr. Reagan said. **********On the treaty to ban medium-range and shorter-range missiles, the Soviet Union demanded - before Secretary of State George P. Shultz went to Moscow - that it be allowed to keep a small force of shorter-range missiles until West Germany's 72 Pershing 1A missiles are eliminated. The United States had rejected this demand because it does not want a precedent for including the forces of other countries in a Moscow-Washington accord. **********But on Thursday in Moscow, a compromise was worked out under which almost all American and Soviet shorter-range missiles would be eliminated within 12 to 18 months, Mr. Adelman said. The Soviet Union would be allowed to keep 80 to 100 shorter-range missiles for about two and half years. America would be allowed to keep a similar number of Pershing 1A's on its territory for the same period. Exchange of Data **********This compromise would let the Russians maintain that they were keeping some shorter-range missiles to offset the West German force. And the United States would be able to assert that the Soviet Union was not being compensated for the West German missiles. **********Bonn has assured Moscow that all the West German missiles will be eliminated when all American and Soviet missiles are eliminated under the treaty. American and Soviet medium-range missiles are to be eliminated within three years after a pact. **********On other issues, both sides agreed to exchange data on missiles in Geneva on Monday. And they agreed on a schedule for dismantling medium- and shorter-range missiles. **********In addition, Soviet officials reportedly were more receptive to the American idea of ''challenge'' inspections on short notice when treaty violations are suspected. The United States wants its officials to carry out such inspections within six hours of arriving on Soviet territory. The Russians are now more open to the idea of quicker inspections if weather permits. Differences Remain **********But important differences remain on how to conduct such inspections. The United States is still insisting that they be confined to the United States and the Soviet Union. It also wants the right to inspect some facilities for mobile long-range missiles to make sure that they do not hide medium-range or shorter-range missiles. The United States is no longer insisting that installations for all long-range land-based missiles be open to inspection. **********The Soviet Union wants to broaden the inspections to include Western Europe and other countries. Soviet officials suggested that there could be continuous monitoring outside some types of SS-25 mobile long-range missile installations to insure that the medium-range missiles are not hidden inside. Both sides seem to be shying away from conducting such inspections in factories that manufacture missiles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/07/busin.body_text: **********The sanctions imposed on Japan by the United States in April following complaints that it had breached a semiconductor trade pact are working, an American industry spokesman said today. **********''Since the sanctions have been levied, there has been a shift in position,'' said Andrew Procassini, the Semiconductor Industry Association, an American trade group. ''The dumping situation has improved in the United States and even in third countries.'' **********But he said it was too soon to lift the sanctions, adding that Japan had not opened its market sufficiently to foreign chip or semiconductor makers. Attitudes have improved, but billings have not improved, he said. **********In April, the United States raised tariffs on $300 million worth of Japanese electronic exports, accusing Japan of failing to honor a 1986 pact to stop selling chips below production costs and open its market to foreign companies. **********President Reagan lifted some of the sanctions in June, saying Japanese companies had stopped dumping chips in other countries where Japanese and American manufacturers compete.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/28/world.main_headline: PANAMA MILITARY ARRESTS KEY CRITIC IN NEW CRACKDOWN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/28/world.print_headline: PANAMA MILITARY ARRESTS KEY CRITIC IN NEW CRACKDOWN
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/28/world.body_text: **********Attacking with guns and tear gas, security forces in Panama arrested a leading critic of the military leader today, hours after the main opposition newspaper was shut down and all radio and television stations put under censorship. **********It was the harshest effort so far to break growing opposition to the Panamanian regime. **********The Panamanian Army said the critic, Roberto Diaz Herrera, a retired colonel whose charges of corruption and political killings prompted a wave of unrest, was arrested with 45 other people after a siege at his home. The military said the arrests were made after the authorities met resistance to a search for weapons.  [ In Washington, a senior State Department official said that Colonel Diaz had been arrested and that the United States government was certain that he was in good health even though the armed forces used tear gas and guns in making the arrest. ]  Reports on Casualties Conflict Accounts from Panama said the siege at Colonel Diaz's home went on for four hours and included rifle and automatic-weapons fire and the use of tear gas. **********The Panamanian Army said there were no deaths or injuries in the shootout, although there were other reports of one or more deaths. **********The army crackdown came on the first day of what appeared to be the most effective opposition general strike in a prolonged showdown between civilian opposition parties and the regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Opposition leaders strongly criticized the army's actions and promised further protests. Capital Reported Paralyzed **********''Each day we are living in a more typical repressive dictatorship led by a military chief who is rejected by society but who maintains himself by force,'' Ricardo Arias Calderon, the chief opposition leader and head of the Christian Democratic Party, said in a telephone interview.  [ In Washington, American policy makers said they were expecting opposition to military rule to increase as a result of the latest crackdown. Page A6. ] **********The general strike that began today reportedly closed down the capital as well as other major cities in a strong repudiation of the regime. A Western diplomat reached by telephone said the capital was ''closed up like a Sunday afternoon.'' **********Panama has been in political turmoil for two months, since Colonel Diaz, the former No. 2 man in the army, publicly denounced General Noriega and repeated longstanding accusations that the general has been involved in running drugs, stealing votes, killing political opponents and other forms of corruption. Protests Have Grown **********The denunciation touched off civil protests that grew stronger as Colonel Diaz shut himself in his home and continued to denounce the army-backed dictatorship he had so recently served. He sought to protect himself from reprisal by relying on dozens of armed bodyguards and the Roman Catholic Archbishop's public pledge of political asylum. **********According to diplomats and Panamanian politicians reached by telephone today, two army helicopters backed by army units attacked Colonel Herrera's home early this morning, and a prolonged exchange of gunfire ensued. **********There were conflicting accounts of the outcome of the attack. Mr. Arias said in a telephone interview that several people in the neighborhood where the attack occurred told him the assault lasted an hour and a half, starting at 6 A.M. with helicopters bombarding Colonel Diaz's house with tear gas canisters. The army later asserted that the gunfire lasted seven minutes.  Maj. Edgardo Lopez, head of the military press office, said this evening that Colonel Diaz had been placed ''under the Attorney General's custody'' and said it was likely that the prisoner would face a variety of criminal charges, including illegal weapons possession and sedition. **********Major Lopez denied that the colonel had been injured, contradicting a report by Alvin Weeden, Colonel Diaz's lawyer, who said that he had been told by Roman Catholic Church officials that the colonel had been wounded, but that they did not know the extent of his injuries. Main Newspaper Closed **********In addition, policemen closed and occupied the main opposition newspaper, La Prensa, on Sunday night, charging that it had ''incited the disturbance of public order,'' Winston Robles, the newspaper's editor, said in a telephone interview. **********The editors of El Extra and El Siglo, two smaller opposition papers, said they also had been shut down. **********At the same time, President Eric Arturo Delvalle's office issued a decree effectively censoring all radio and television stations. The decree said they would lose their right to broadcast if they announced anything deemed prejudicial ''to public order.'' **********Mr. Robles said he did not know how long the occupation of his paper would last. It has been among the strongest critics of General Noriega. **********Several Panamanians reached by telephone said that the main afternoon television newscast today contained no news about the army crackdown and that the announcer told listeners that a military censor was in the studio. Ready for a Fight **********The attack on Colonel Diaz and the closing of the press appear likely to raise tensions that have been building over the last seven weeks as protests have grown against what appears to be the last traditional military dictatorship in Central America. After several shootings, an attack on the United States Embassy that appeared to have army backing, and indications that General Noriega is determined to hang on to power, the Reagan Administration has increasingly criticized the general's monopolization of power and has distanced itself from his regime. **********But Mr. Noriega, who has a reputation as one of the toughest and shrewdest military dictators in recent Latin American history, appears ready to put up a hard fight. **********He and his predecessors have built a political organization that dominates the country by controlling key businesses, the government press and the official government party while reportedly paying off, threatening or even killing opponents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/04/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; BROOKLYN NEIGHBORHOOD HELPS REVIVE STOREFRONTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/04/busin.body_text: **********A year ago not one of the 14 storefronts on Nostrand Avenue between Martense Street and Linden Boulevard in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn held a business. Some had stood empty as long as eight years. **********Today every space has a new tenant and a fresh look. The spaces were leased within a few weeks last fall after Avi Raz, the new owner of the building where the stores are situated, put more than $1 million into renovating them. Now all of the shops -which include an ice cream parlor, a pet shop, two shoe stores, a video store and a women's dress shop -have new interiors and identical green and white awnings. The merchants pay up to $1,700 a month. **********The renewed business strip is the centerpiece of a commercial revitalization effort led by the Erasmus Neighborhood Federation, formed in 1978. It started an economic development arm in 1980 to halt the decline of the area's shopping streets. **********According to Barbara Wolff, a vice president of New York City's Public Development Corporation, over the last three years the Erasmus Neighborhood Federation has used $137,000 in grants from the city's Office of Business Development to help store owners refresh their space and bring new investment to the area.   $ ? * * **********The redevelopment effort started with a $115,000 grant for new exterior signs and refurbished interiors for 16 businesses in the redevelopment area. It runs on Nostrand Avenue from Linden Boulevard to Snyder Avenue and on Church Avenue from Bedford Avenue to Brooklyn Avenue. **********''Our overall objective was to fill some of the empty spaces,'' said V. Renee Williams, executive director of the Erasmus Neighborhood Federation. ''But rather than start from scratch we wanted to do something first that would strengthen the existing businesses, show the community that things were improving and attract outside investment.'' **********Last year the organization received a $72,000 grant to continue the program of facade improvement and to strengthen security. This year the group is working with an additional $15,000 in grant money. **********The key to success of the economic development effort, Ms. Williams said, was a series of commercial market reports, land use surveys and population studies done with help from the Pratt Institute Center for Community and Ecomomic Development and the city's Department of Planning. The group used the reports to determine what types of businesses the community needed. **********One study, for example, indicated that the neighborhood could support an additional 23,000 square feet in supermarket businesses, 9,000 feet in clothing and general merchandise stores, 4,500 feet of fast-food businesses and 1,000 square feet in stores that sold personal care products. **********''We live in the area and knew that people here had money to spend,'' said Mildred Keel-Williams, project director for the economic development arm. ''But the reports were proof that many people in the area own their own homes, that they spent money on certain things and that they were going outside the neighborhood to places like Flatbush Avenue and downtown Brooklyn to shop.'' **********Mr. Raz, whose company, Sella Properties, has developed retail projects in other parts of the city, saw the same commercial potential that the Erasmus Neighborhood Federation did. Originally he had planned to spend less on the renovation and increase the number of store spaces on Nostrand Avenue. **********After consulting with the neighborhood organization and the Nostrand-Church Merchants Association, however, he reduced the number of stores, doubled his investment and let the community organizers have a say in which leases were signed.  $ ? * * * In addition to what Mr. Raz spent on renovation, the community organization contributed $1,000 for each store improvement. **********The partnership paid off. After work on the first three storefronts was completed, Mr. Raz said, a window sign began advertising the retail space, and within a week 303 merchants had responded. **********The new businesses are in spaces from 350 to 600 square feet, and the merchants pay an average of $36 a square foot rent on an annual basis. **********Ms. Williams said one indication of the area's new commercial strength was a ripple effect. Two years ago, for example, the neighborhood had one supermarket. Without direct assistance from the Erasmus Neighorhood Federation, in the last year a new market has opened in an old hardware store, a supermarket has opened in a former theater and the Key food store, which had been destroyed by fire, was rebuilt. **********''There are other things that show that what we have done has worked,'' she said. ''Store spaces in secondary retail locations, like Rogers Avenue, are filling up. And it used to be that when someone went out of business they just left and the store stayed empty. Now when a business decides to close, it can easily sell the lease.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/world.main_headline: A TWISTER IN CANADA KILLS AT LEST 31
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/world.print_headline: A TWISTER IN CANADA KILLS AT LEST 31
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/01/world.body_text: **********A tornado tore through parts of Edmonton and its suburbs today, killing at least 31 people and injuring more than 150, civil and rescue officials said. **********One, and perhaps more, twisters hit at about 3 P.M. local time, leaving a swath of destruction and debris. **********A trailer park and a small industrial park were leveled, trapping people in buildings, and cars on a freeway were tossed into the air, injuring dozens of motorists. **********Joan Rossall, head of the Edmonton Ambulance Authority, said 28 people died in the city. Jocelyn Tennison, a spokeswoman for neighboring Strathcona County, said 3 were confirmed dead there. **********At least 100 people were taken to Edmonton hospitals in ambulances that had to struggle through debris-clogged streets. Ms. Tennison said 150 people were injured in Strathcona. Ms. Rossall couldn't provide exact figures but said many of the injured in Strathcona were taken to Edmonton hospitals. Most Victims at Trailer Park **********Mayor Laurence Decore said 24 of the victims died in the trailer park, in northeast Edmonton, where an estimated 200 mobile homes were flattened. **********''The park is just flat. There's nothing there,'' said Karen Laursen, a resident of the trailer park. She sobbed as she described what greeted her when she rushed home. **********''My house was sitting up against a neighbor's house in 50 million pieces,'' she said. ''There were a few dead people lying in the street.'' **********Three people trapped in a passenger train also were among the dead, according to a radio station. Others were trapped in the wreckage or in crushed vehicles. **********A spokesman for the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, Bob Moffat, told Canadian radio that the twister had touched down twice just south of Edmonton, a city of 530,000. 'A Deafening Roar' **********An Edmonton resident, Tom Harding, described the tornado as ''just a massive roar, a deafening roar.'' **********''The debris from around the funnel itself was half a mile in each direction,'' Mr. Harding said. ''There are cars crushed like pop cans, there are buildings totally destroyed, people trapped in the buildings. It's worse than a war.'' **********He said major power lines were ''crumbled like matchsticks'' by the force of the storm. **********Witnesses said broken gas mains had started several fires, trees had been uprooted, power lines had been downed and streets had been flooded by an accompanying deluge of rain and hail. Declaration as a Disaster Area **********An ambulance service spokesman said that a large number of accidents had been reported and that five people had been trapped in buildings. **********By nightfall, the city and county had been declared disaster areas. **********Hospitals were calling for qualified doctors and nurses to help attend the injured, and hotels in the city were offering free emergency shelter to the homeless. **********By evening, the skies had cleared in Edmonton, and rescue services went to work.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/13/busin.main_headline: Fireman's Fund To Buy Its Stock
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Fireman's Fund To Buy Its Stock
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/13/busin.body_text: **********The Fireman's Fund Corporation, a major insurance company based in Novato, Calif., said that its board has authorized the repurchase of up to six million shares, or about 9.5 percent of its outstanding common stock. In December, the board had authorized the repurchase of 5 percent of common shares, nearly all of which have been purchased. **********A spokesman said the repurchases were being made to help build the company's long-term value. While Fireman's shares dropped to $33 last month when the company announced a surprise addition of $476 million to its loss reserves, they have since rebounded and closed today at $37.875, up $1.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Fireman's also said that it had realized capital gains of about $114 million, after taxes, through the first 40 days of the third quarter. This compares with $18.5 million earned in the third quarter of 1986.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/world.main_headline: BREAKTHROUGH FOR OLD ADVERSARIES  For the President, Compromise and a Sense of Accomplishment
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/world.print_headline: MISSILE ACCORD; BREAKTHROUGH FOR OLD ADVERSARIES  For the President, Compromise and a Sense of Accomplishment
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/19/world.body_text: **********Propelled by his desire for an achievement in foreign policy and by the perseverance of aides like Secretary of State George P. Shultz, President Reagan is on the brink of concluding the first major arms control agreement with the Soviet Union since 1979. **********After years of frigid hostility toward Moscow, his Administration has begun to engage the Russians in a broader, more fruitful dialogue than was possible, even during the detente of the 1970's. The gains, realized this week in three days of intensive talks with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, include the prospect of a summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, in the United States. It will be their third meeting in three years. **********Mr. Reagan may be assailed by some of his more fervent supporters who are wary of any arms accords with the Russians. But, in a sense, the President has rebuffed liberal critics who had accused him of insincerity on arms control when he first proposed eliminating all medium-range missiles, a concept that seemed so ambitious that it might be a ploy to make the Russians look intransigent. A Less-Polemical Style **********The upswing in relations has resulted partly from Mr. Gorbachev's more open style of diplomacy and the modicum of liberalization he is trying to introduce into Soviet society. Soviet high school students, previously barred from participating in exchange programs in the United States, are now doing so in small numbers. Private diplomatic discussions on the Middle East, Afghanistan and other areas of conflict are less polemical and more workmanlike. **********In addition, Mr. Reagan has surrounded himself in his second term with fewer ideologues and more pragmatic foreign-policy professionals who have made careers of analyzing Soviet affairs and searching for areas of overlapping interests. The years spent grappling with the hard realities of world affairs seem to have ground away that sharp edge of dogmatism that marked his first term. **********The Soviet-American relationship has long been cyclical, swinging back and forth between periods of acute tension and those of constructive accord. Thus, the cold war of the 1950's ultimately gave way to detente, which came to an end when Soviet troops went into Afghanistan in 1979. Sense of Accomplishment **********Now, a new phase has begun, though the mood can easily deteriorate again. So there was no euphoria this week in Washington, just a satisfying sense of accomplishment among hard-headed Soviet and American officials. **********From their meetings in Geneva in 1985 to Reykjavik, Iceland, in 1986 to their prospective summit meeting in the United States before the end of this year, President Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev have meshed their different positions for arms control in their basic agreement, announced today, to eliminate land-based missiles with ranges of 300 to 3,400 miles. Despite the two sides' inability to come to terms on reducing strategic, long-range nuclear weapons, the narrower accord creates an atmosphere of compromise in which achievements in other fields seem possible. **********''Things have changed tremendously in the relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union,'' Secretary Shultz said. ''We see very worthwhile discussions and movement in terms of behavior in the human rights area. Our discussions on regional issues have become increasingly rewarding.'' **********On the Soviet military presence in Afghanistan, Mr. Shultz declared: ''We had the most thorough and searching discussion of that subject that Mr. Shevardnadze and I have ever had.'' **********The Soviet Foreign Minister had a similar assessment of the state of relations. **********''I believe this is the beginning of a new period,'' he said of the prospective treaty. ''I would call it the material basis - a very substantive, a very good material basis - for that new period.'' **********Two developments this week illustrated the point. One was Mr. Shevardnadze's quick apology today for the wounding by Soviet soldiers in East Germany of an American serviceman attached to a United States liaison team. **********The other telling development was in human rights: Both sides agreed to establish a permanent channel - through the United States Embassy in Moscow and the Soviet Foreign Ministry - to discuss rights issues including the cases of Soviet citizens who wish to emigrate. **********American officials regard this as an important achievement, especially in view of past Soviet aversion to serious discussion of human rights issues. **********But it is Mr. Gorbachev who has brought a new tactic to dealing with this. He has been willing to respond to American pleas on highly visible people, like Iosif Begun and Viktor Brailovsky, Jewish dissidents who were informed shortly before Mr. Shevardnadze's visit that they would be getting exit visas, after more than 15 years of waiting. **********Mr. Shultz told another former dissident, Natan Sharansky, that he was upset by the Soviet use of people in this manner, and he expressed his intention to continue pressing for improvements in overall emigration policies. **********Mr. Reagan, who met twice with Mr. Shevardnadze this week, reportedly raised the rights issue. And evidently, he has not lost his critical eye. As Mr. Reagan was trying to leave the White House press room this morning after announcing the Soviet-American agreement on missile reductions, a reporter shouted a question: ''What about the evil empire, Mr. President?'' It was a reference to a 1983 speech in which Mr. Reagan warned of ''the aggressive impulses of an evil empire.'' **********''Oh, I still don't think it's lily white,'' Mr. Reagan replied.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/20/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Cautious Tack For Hot Fund
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/20/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Cautious Tack For Hot Fund
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/20/busin.body_text: **********MANY mutual funds with ''aggressive growth'' as their investment objective are pouring money into the stock market these days. But the Strong Opportunity Fund - a big winner last year with a total return of 59.9 percent in this venturesome category - has switched lately to a more conservative tack. **********''When stock prices began to rise sharply in early January, we went to a fully invested position,'' said Richard S. Strong, the fund's co-portfolio manager. ''But, in order to keep risk under control, the fund now has moved 15 percent into cash.'' **********''At the same time, we have been taking money out of stocks that performed well,'' he added, ''and rotating into laggard issues as a means of maintaining our exposure to the market.'' **********This switching process has been speeded up in the last two weeks, while stock prices repeatedly have climbed to record levels. Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.46, closing at a record high of 2,244.09. **********''We feel it is a time to avoid the temptation to chase stocks,'' said Mr. Strong, who also serves as chairman of Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. in Milwaukee. ''We are trying to keep our wits about us during this period of euphoria.'' **********This approach appears to be paying off. Between year-end 1986 and the Feb. 12 market close, the Opportunity Fund showed a total return - market appreciation plus reinvested dividends - of 19.83 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was ahead 14.17 percent for the same period, according to Lipper Analytical Services. Last year, when the Opportunity Fund ranked 12th best among 950 funds, the S.&P. index had a return of 18.67 percent and the average equity fund was ahead 15.90 percent. **********Stocks holdings that have been cut back include Lotus Development, Merck, Squibb, Syntex, Texas Air and Aristech Chemical, a company spun off by the USX Corporation in November. ''The drug stocks have enjoyed a huge run,'' Mr. Strong pointed out. ''We also took some money out of Atari after the holding doubled.'' **********Consumer-related stocks, a sector that posted strong gains for the last several years as the beneficiary of low inflation and improved corporate profits, made up 10.5 percent of the fund's portfolio at the end of the third quarter of 1986. Since that time, Revlon Group, Sara Lee and Shaklee have been sold. **********''More recently, we cut in half our holdings in RJR Nabisco,'' the 44-year-old money manager said. ''We sold the stock at $63 a share, which compares with our cost basis of $52. In the future, if this stock moves down 5 or 10 percent in price, we would expect to add to our position.'' **********Other consumer-related issues still remaining in the portfolio include Anheuser-Busch, Philip Morris and Ralston Purina. **********The fund has been adding to holdings in Borg-Warner, Federal Express and the Circle K Corporation. On a cost basis, it is about even in Federal Express and slightly ahead in Borg-Warner. Circle K, an operator of convenience stores, remains slightly below the fund's average cost. **********But Mr. Strong remains optimistic that Circle K's earnings, which he said had been hurt by competitive pricing, will increase for its fiscal year ending April 30, 1988. ''I just like the business,'' he said. ''Sometimes I sit in the parking lot of a convenience store in my neighborhood, Wirth Park Foods, and watch the people buying newspapers and milk and packages of sandwich meat. They always seem to forget something and go back and buy more.'' **********Home Shopping Network, the cable television retailer that ranked as last year's star new issue, was a stock that helped the fund's stellar performance in 1986. Earlier in February, the stock traded as high as $47 before falling sharply. ''We had taken profits in Home Shopping previously,'' Mr. Strong said. ''But we bought shares on the price break. We also have been buying GAF and Harcourt Brace.'' **********Technology stocks have been a strong group since the start of 1987, but this sector is notable by its absence in the fund's portfolio. ''The closest thing to a technology stock that we own is Medtronic, the dominant producer of pacemakers,'' the money manager said. **********As for first-time purchases, the fund invested in Gundle Enviromental System, a recent new issue. ''The company makes plastic liners for landfills to keep refuse intact,'' Mr. Strong explained. **********The Opportunity Fund, which completed its first full year of operation in 1986 and now has $32 million in assets, is the latest addition to a family of eight mutual funds managed by Strong/Corneliuson. Total assets under management are $3.3 billion. ''We are doing the same thing in our other two equity funds and various accounts - cutting back on winner stocks, rotating into laggards and raising a smidgen of cash,'' Mr. Strong said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.main_headline: PRETORIA TERMS SCHOOL ROLLS 'ENCOURAGING' AFTER BOYCOTTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.print_headline: PRETORIA TERMS SCHOOL ROLLS 'ENCOURAGING' AFTER BOYCOTTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/08/world.body_text: **********The authorities said today that enrollment in the nation's segregated black schools was ''very encouraging'' at the start of a new academic year after months of boycotts. **********Reporters touring this vast black township and others outside Johannesburg, however, gained the impression that attendance at high schools, which have gained a reputation for protest, was far lower than at primary schools. **********The authorities, moreover, made clear that about 70 high schools here and in the restive Eastern Cape, closed last year because of classroom protest, would remain shut until parents assumed responsibility for their children's attendance and behavior. **********Teen-age students have been at the forefront of the protest and violence in which 2,300 people, most of them black, have been killed since the nation's newest phase of revolt began in September 1984. Parents Urge Return to Class **********In recent months, however, black parents and community and church leaders have urged teen-agers to return to their classes, abandoning their slogan, ''Liberation before education.'' **********''The picture is very encouraging; pupils have returned to school in very large numbers,'' said Job Schoeman, spokesman for the white-run ministry that handles black education. **********Mr. Schoeman said it was too early for definitive figures about the enrollment, but he forecast that more than 1.8 million blacks, the entire black school population outside so-called tribal homelands, would attend classes. **********The authorities have given students more than a week to complete enrollment procedures, and some teen-agers, interviewed at random, said they were eager to return to school but wanted first to see what their peers did. **********Some also urged the lifting of regulations, imposed under an emergency decree in force since June 12, that give the authorities wide powers to bar politically involved students from schoolgrounds, to prohibit politically inspired pamphlets or T-shirts in schools and to issue student identity cards. Boycott Targets Have Widened **********Since early 1984, classroom boycotts have been used as part of a widening protest, initially directed at inferior black education but increasingly fueled by wider political demands, such as those for the release of the jailed black leader Nelson Mandela and for the end of the banning of some black political organizations. **********Some of Soweto's schools bear the scars of the protests, in the form of shattered windows and political slogans opposing apartheid rule. **********Some politically involved students have renamed their schools. The Lobone state secondary school has been renamed ''Nelson Mandela School,'' and another bears the spray-painted slogan, ''Communist school,'' and is named by its students after Emma Sathekge, a 13-year-old girl who died when a police truck ran over her in early 1984. **********Emergency censorship, tightened last month, prevents reporters from giving details of any security force action or presence in Soweto or anywhere in the country. The authorities say the censorship rules are part of a response to a ''revolutionary onslaught'' orchestrated by the outlawed and exiled African National Congress, which marks its 75th anniversary Thursday. The congress is the most prominent of guerrilla organizations seeking the overthrow of white minority rule. **********Foreign Minister Roelof Botha confirmed today that South Africa had put pressure on the authorities in neighboring Mozambique to expel six congress officials from the capital, Maputo. Reports from Mozambique on Tuesday said President Joaquim Chissano had acceded to Pretoria's demands. **********The action seemed to show the vulnerability of black-ruled nations supporting the congress to a variety of South African military, economic and other pressures. #6 Are to Be Expelled Foreign Minister Botha said the six who are to be expelled from Mozambique had been identified as members of an insurgent committee channeling arms and ammunition into South Africa through Swaziland. **********''The Mozambican Government has been made aware of the seriousness of this issue and was requested to make arrangements to urgently remove the relevant people from Mozambique,'' Mr. Botha said. ''Although this is not mean to be a threat,'' his statement said, ''the South African Government would have no choice but to take steps to avert the threat if the Mozambican Government did not see its way clear to remove it.'' **********For its part, the congress, in comments published today in the Zimbabwean capital, Harare, urged South Africa's 45,000 policemen - almost half of whom are black - to turn against their Government. The congress was quoted by the semi-official Zimbabwean news agency as saying it would seek to step up guerrilla activity inside South Africa this year and carry its campaign into segregated white areas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/11/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Notes, Bonds Little Changed
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/11/busin.body_text: **********After a day of nervous and erratic trading following the end of the economic summit meeting in Venice, Treasury note and bond prices were little changed. **********Financiers and traders around the world seemed uncertain about how to react to the outcome of the meeting. Although it produced another statement endorsing stable exchange rates at about current levels, there were no new agreements among the seven leading industrialized countries to enforce their desires. Uncertainty in Market **********The absence of any new agreements left the foreign exchange market as uncertain as ever. With no clear-cut flow of investor orders, bond prices continued to move in tandem with the dollar, falling about the same time as the dollar weakened and rising when the dollar strengthened. **********Traders in both markets said they were waiting for data on American trade flows for April and the Producer Price Index for May, both scheduled for publication tomorrow. A rumor that the trade deficit would be $10 billion, down from a monthly average of $13.67 billion in the first quarter, helped raise bond prices for a while, but was quickly dismissed. **********By late in the day, the 8 3/4 percent Treasury issue due in 2017 was offered at 100 9/32, up 3/32, to yield 8.72 percent. Early in the day, when the dollar was as low as 141.7 yen, the bellwether 8 3/4 percent issue was about 99 7/8, but it rose to as high as 101 10/32 around midday, when the dollar was also up to about 142.8 yen. Heavy Selling in Futures **********Much of the late afternoon drop in Treasury bond prices was attributed to heavy selling in the futures market just before the close. The September bond contract was as high as 91 10/32 before closing at 90 6/32. **********In the corporate market, the strength in bond prices early in the day encouraged issuers and underwriters to offer at least seven new issues with a face value of more than $1.5 billion. **********Among the new issues, the Chase Manhattan Corporation offered $275 million of subordinated capital notes due in 1999 to replace an issue it started to sell in mid-May but then withdrew from the market. **********The new 10 percent notes were offered at 99 3/4, to yield 10.036 percent to maturity in 12 years, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. Rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service the notes yield about 1.49 percentage points more than Treasury issues of similar maturity. **********Chase's earlier offering proposed a yield of 10 percent, but was withdrawn after Citicorp announced it would add $3 billion to its loan loss reserve. **********Banking companies have been eager to sell capital notes in the last few months before the Federal Reserve changes the definition of what kinds of securities may be counted as primary capital. Currently, notes such as those offered by Chase are eligible because they are accompanied by the issuer's promise to arrange, by one means or another, an equal amount of equity financing over the next 12 years. The Fed has proposed that future debt offerings counted as primary capital be designed so that if a banking company's financial condition worsened severely it would not pay interest in cash and the debt would be automatically converted to equity or preferred stock. **********Elsewhere in the financial sector, the Santa Barbara Savings and Loan Association introduced a new wrinkle to mortgage-backed bonds in a $100 million financing underwritten by Salomon Brothers. Called mandatory collateral substitution bonds, the five-year bonds carry an 8 3/4 percent interest rate and were offered at 99 7/8, to yield 8.78 percent. **********The savings and loan institution will set aside $118 million worth of Government agency-backed mortgage securities as collateral, or well below the $150 million that would have been used as collateral for earlier issues of mortgage-backed bonds. **********Analysts at Salomon said the lesser amount of collateral was acceptable to rating agencies and investors because it was enough to buy zero coupon Treasury securities that would cover the interest and principal payments on the bonds. The mortgage securities would be sold and used to buy zero coupon Treasury issues if the savings and loan became insolvent, or if the collateral dropped below a threshold level. **********Securities dealers have lost vast sums in the last few years as they learned that the value of the mortgage securities does not fluctuate in tandem with Treasury securities. Salomon Brothers analysts said yesterday, however, that their simulations of different interest rate conditions showed the collateral would be sufficient. They noted that as the value of the collateral declined, the cost of the zero coupon Treasury issues was also falling.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/14/busin.body_text: **********The dollar opened at 143.50 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today, up from Friday's close of 142.53.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/21/busin.body_text: **********The Bank of Japan, as expected, today announced a half-point cut in its basic interest rate, to an all-time low of 2.5 percent. **********The cut in the discount rate will take effect Monday. The announcement came on the eve of the meeting in Paris this weekend of monetary authorities from the world's largest industrial democracies. **********Japanese officials hope the action will help ease pressure from Japan's trading partners, who want more stimulus of Japan's domestic economy. The United States in particular has been pressing Japan to spur economic growth, which American officials hope will cause Japanese consumers to spend more on imports. **********The surging value of the yen on foreign-exchange markets during the last year and a half has put Japan's economy into the worst slump in more than a decade. Bank Governor Comments **********Satoshi Sumita, governor of the Bank of Japan, told Japanese reporters today that the bank was acting in an effort to spur Japan's economy and stabilize exchange rates. He said the decision showed that Japan would cooperate with other nations to coordinate monetary and fiscal policies. **********''Stability in foreign exchange rates is not only vital to the Japanese economy but to the world's economic growth,'' Mr. Sumita said. **********But he also said that monetary measures alone would not be enough to stimulate the economy, and that Japan's ability to take further monetary measures was limited. During the last year, Japan has trimmed its basic interest rate by half, from 5 percent, to the 2.5 percent rate. **********Mr. Sumita urged the Government to make more use of fiscal policies to stimulate the economy. The Government has proposed a budget that is the most austere in 30 years. Decision Is Praised **********Business leaders and economists welcomed the news of a discount rate cut, although they said that a reduction of this size would probably not have a dramatic effect on either exchange rates or economic growth. **********''It is certainly helpful, although to what extent I really don't know,'' said Susumu Taketomi, senior economist of the Industrial Bank of Japan. ''After all, this is the fifth cut, so the marginal effect may be limited. If somebody expects an immediate favorable impact on the economy, he would be disappointed.'' **********Both stock prices and the value of the dollar, which had risen yesterday as rumors of an imminent discount rate cut swept through markets, dropped today. The dollar closed in Tokyo at 153.77 yen, down from Thursday's close of 154.73 yen.
