https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/21/busin.main_headline: Time Sharing on the Connecticut Shore
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/21/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; Time Sharing on the Connecticut Shore
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/21/busin.body_text: **********At the close of the 1930's, when Catskill hotels were fashionable resorts for Jewish families from New York City, Bill Hahn, a hotelier and showman, thought he would be able to attract some Catskill devotees to a similar hotel by the shore if he could find a suitable property. **********He did. In 1940 he purchased a turn-of-the century waterfront estate in Westbrook, Conn., facing Long Island Sound near the mouth of the Connecticut River. He provided his guests with accommodations in the house and in cottages on the 14-acre property, and later, in the Catskills tradition, booked big-name entertainers, among them Barbra Streisand, Woody Allen and Art Carney. **********By the end of the 1970's, however, the original clientele had lost interest. Thus for several years after Mr. Hahn's death in 1979 the property lay empty and virtually forgotten. **********This summer, however, for the first time in almost a decade, new life -and some of the former guests - is coming back to the old estate. But now many of them are not staying there as guests but as owners of time-share units in the complex. **********This newly minted Billy Hahn's, now called Water's Edge Inn and Resort, is the creation of Michael Dattilo, a developer from Spring Valley, N.Y. In 1982 he and a group of investors purchased the property for $1.5 million and they have already spent around $7 million to restore the old mansion as a 32-bedroom hotel and conference center and to construct 34 of 70 planned town house-style units. All of the units are being sold either in weeklong segments as traditional short-term time shares or as quarter-shares. **********A time share buys the right to use accommodations in a resort for a specific period each year. A quarter-share entitles the owner to 13 weeks' use each year. The block of time is often rotated so that each owner gets a chance for a prime season. **********The time shares at Water's Edge are being sold either on a fixed-week basis between May and September or as a floating week during off-season periods. Fixed-week purchase buys a specific week each year. A floating week entitles an owner to select different off-season weeks each year with requests being filled on a first-come, first-served basis. **********Even though time shares have acquired a questionable image in recent years - many have proved difficult to resell and have lost up to 30 percent of their value upon resale - the units at Water's Edge have been so popular that the first two phases are virtually sold out. The developers have even been able to raise the prices on the final phases of the project. **********The initial prices ranged from $5,000 to $16,000, depending on season and size of unit. Later prices range from $9,000 to $22,000. Quarter-share units, which will go on the market this week starting at $94,000, will be ready for occupancy by next summer. Financing is being offered by the seller, with a minimum 10 percent down payment required. **********According to Maureen L. Magee, assistant project manager, the surprising strength in the market has come from people living less than a half-hour away. Many of them, she said, have been attracted by the idea that the purchase of even the least expensive week can provide them with year-round free access to the resort's health club and recreational facilities - swimming, beach, boat rentals -as well as swapping privileges in hundreds of affiliated time-share resorts worldwide. **********Others, like Mira and Morris Bramson, were attracted by the resort's one-and-a-half-hour proximity to their New Rochelle residence. **********The Bramsons, who purchased in June, were also drawn by the strength of demand at Water's Edge. ''Prices were going up so fast,'' Mrs. Bramson said. They have purchased one fixed and one floating week for a combined, discounted total of $22,500. They used equity financing from their primary residence, the least costly method, they decided. ''We hope to use the fixed week here and the other one to exchange and travel somewhere else,'' Mrs. Bramson said. **********All of the units, which are fully furnished and equipped, have a New England-style gray shingle exterior facade with lattice balconies. Interior space ranges from 600 to 950 square feet. Set on a steep hillside that winds down to a private sandy beach, the units look out over the portion of Long Island Sound that faces Orient Point and Fishers Island. **********The mansion has been restored as a traditional New England inn. Many of Mr. Hahn's original pieces of furniture have been restored, ''and people keep offering me old photos from those days,'' said Evan Smith, the manager. ''Hahn's memory is so powerful that we're making a collection of those photos and using them to decorate one of our conference rooms.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/world.main_headline: IRANIAN OFFICIALS URGE 'UPROOTING' OF SAUDI ROYALTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/world.print_headline: IRANIAN OFFICIALS URGE 'UPROOTING' OF SAUDI ROYALTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/03/world.body_text: **********Iran, vowing to avenge the deaths of hundreds of Iranian pilgrims in a riot in Mecca, called today for the ''uprooting'' of the Saudi Arabian royal family, raising the specter of religious war in the already tense Persian Gulf region. **********According to the official Islamic Republic News Agency, one million Iranians converged on the Parliament building in Teheran today, screaming ''Revenge! Revenge!'' in a rally marking what was officially described as ''a day of hate.'' **********The press agency quoted the powerful Speaker of the Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, as telling the crowd that ''we, as soldiers of God and implementers of divine principles, oblige ourselves to avenge these martyrs by uprooting Saudi rulers from the region.'' Threat Increases Around Gulf **********The Mecca clash appeared certain to fuel passions in the region, where Iran and Iraq have waged war for nearly seven years. The increased threat was not only to Saudi Arabia, but to Kuwait, which is aligned with Saudi Arabia and allows Iraqi oil exports to pass through its pipelines and ports. **********Warships of the United States, which Iran has accused of complicity in the Mecca riot, are escorting Kuwaiti oil tankers, in effect supporting Iraq. France, embroiled in its own diplomatic dispute with Iran, has dispatched a naval task force to the gulf. **********Iran said today that its Revolutionary Guards, the theocracy's shock troops, would begin three days of naval maneuvers in the gulf on Tuesday. The maneuvers, announced earlier, are code-named Martyrdom. Iranian Delegation Turned Back **********The clash in Mecca on Friday came when Saudi security units moved in to halt a forbidden political demonstration by Iranian pilgrims in front of the Grand Mosque at the beginning of the hajj, or pilgrimage. Saudi officials said 402 people died in the rioting. **********A Saudi statement issued Saturday night said the dead included 275 Iranians, 85 Saudi citizens and security men and 42 pilgrims of other nationalities. **********Saudi Arabia today turned back an Iranian delegation arriving in Jidda to look into the clashes when it turned out that they had not come to say they were sorry. **********''Their purpose was not to apologize or to try to ameliorate relations between the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and Iran,'' the Saudi Arabian press agency said, ''but was limited to a wish to investigate matters reflecting the security of the state and its sovereignty and dignity.'' Dispute Over Weapons Used **********With the Saudis, following normal procedures during the pilgrimage, having closed their borders and sealed off Mecca, it was difficult to obtain an independent account of the clash. **********Saudi officials said the victims of the violence Friday were trampled in a rout after the police moved in to disperse Iranian pilgrims who were burning automobiles and fighting with other pilgrims. ''Not a single bullet was fired,'' the Saudi Information Minister, Ali Hassen al-Shaer insisted. **********Iranian officials, however, said the police opened fire on them with machine guns and other weapons. The Iranian press agency today asserted that women pilgrims had been killed and then thrown on a garbage dump and that some of the dead had shotgun wounds. **********When news of the deaths reached Teheran on Saturday, crowds sacked the Saudi and Kuwaiti Embassies. 'Wicked Wahhabis' Denounced **********At the rally in Teheran today, Hojatolislam Rafsanjani touched on the 1,300-year-old schism between Shiites and Sunnis - the great divide in Islam. Shiites predominate in Iran, but Sunni rulers preside over substantial numbers of Shiites in Kuwait, Bahrain and the oil-producing Eastern Province of Saudi Arabia. **********''To take revenge for the sacred bloodshed is to free the holy shrines from the mischievous and wicked Wahhabi,'' Hojatolislam Rafsanjani said. **********The Wahhabi are a strict sect of orthodox Sunnis who count the Saudi royal family among their adherents. The Wahhabi consider Shiites to be heretics. In the early years of this century, raiding parties of Wahhabis from Saudi Arabia sacked the sacred Shiite holy sites at Karbala and Najaf, in what is now Iraq. **********The split between Sunni and Shiite Moslems dates to the struggle for the succession to the Prophet Mohammed in the seventh century. Mohammed's son-in-law, Ali, became the fourth Caliph, or successor, but was ousted by what was to be the Umayyid dynasty. His followers - Shiites, meaning partisans - were to become largely an underclass, scattered in pockets in the Arab world, clinging to an emotional, messianic religion with an emphasis on martyrdom. **********The Iranian revolution, toppling the American-backed Shah, gave new impetus to the Shiites. Accusations of Apostasy **********Iran's Interior Minister, Ali Akhbar Mohtashemi, sent a message today to his Saudi counterpart, Prince Nayef, accusing the Saudis of supporting ''paganism and apostasy.'' **********''Our courageous mobilized people in the Persian Gulf will take revenge on the U.S. forces for the pure blood of the pilgrims of the House of God,'' Mr. Mohtashemi told the Saudi Interior Minister. **********The Iranian official charged that the Saudi leaders had ''supported the pioneers of paganism and apostasy, that is the United States, the Soviet Union and Zionism. **********''The Moslem nation and the Party of God all over the world will give an appropriate response by direct attacks on U.S. interests and and their presence all over the world,'' Teheran radio quoted Mr. Mohtashemi as saying. **********On Saturday, Ayatollah Hussein Ali Montazeri, the designated successor to the Iranian leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, urged that control of the holy shrines be wrested from the Saudi royal family. For Iran, a Political Forum **********As custodians of the holy sites in Mecca, where Mohammed was born, and Medina, where he died, the Saudi royal family is in charge of a complex set of logistics attending the annual ritual of the pilgrimage, which a devout Moslem of means should make at least once in his life, as one of the five pillars of his faith. **********The formal ceremonies of the hajj are to begin Monday with the pilgrims standing on the Plain of Arafat, where Mohammed delivered his last sermon, and will then include sacrificing of sheep and circling the Kaaba, or sacred black rock, seven times. **********But for Iran, eager to export its Islamic fundamentalist revolution, the pilgrimage, the major religious event of the year, has also become a political mission and a forum. **********The demonstrators on Friday were clearly following the urgings of Ayatollah Khomeini, who had sent a message to pilgrims urging them to carry out a ''disavowal of the pagans'' and to hold a ''unity rally'' seeking ''deliverence from the infidels.'' **********The Iranian delegation of 155,000, the largest single group at the pilgrimage, includes half of the members of Parliament and relatives of those killed or wounded in the war with Iraq.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/15/busin.main_headline: First Boston Is Barred By Citicorp in U.S. Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/15/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; First Boston Is Barred By Citicorp in U.S. Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/15/busin.body_text: **********Citicorp announced yesterday that First Boston would not participate in the domestic sale of its worldwide $1 billion stock offering, but it gave no reason. **********According to a report yesterday in The Wall Street Journal, Citicorp and Merrill Lynch & Company, the lead underwriter for the upcoming sale, dropped First Boston because it was managing and underwriting an offering of six million shares by the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. **********Analysts said Citicorp might have decided that information that would have been available to First Boston as an underwriter of its offering might have given it a competitive advantage in deciding on the best timing for the Manufacturers Hanover issue. **********John J. Maloney, Citicorp's director of press information, said that Citicorp had held talks with First Boston and it was decided that First Boston would not participate in the domestic offering, but he would not elaborate further. **********According to First Boston, Citicorp also forced Merrill Lynch to remove itself from the Manufacturers Hanover underwriting group. A First Boston vice president, William W. Galvin 3d, said that, ''obviously, we and Citicorp have a difference of opinion on what a conflict of interest is because our London office is still in the overseas underwriting group handling Citicorp's stock offering.'' **********The decision to drop one securities dealer from a syndicate group and force another to remove itself from yet another selling syndicate underscores the increasing pressure among the big banks to bring their deals to market quickly for fear that investors may not be able to digest the large volume of stock offerings expected. **********The banks are selling shares to raise equity capital after recent additions to loan-loss reserves were made to cover possible losses on loans to developing countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/11/busin.body_text: **********When Merrill Lynch & Company suffered a stunning $275 million loss from mortgage-securities dealings last month, it was quick to blame an unauthorized series of transactions and an adverse market. **********But the seeds of that disaster were sown by Merrill over the last few years in a number of decisions about how it would conduct its business, according to a large number of senior officials at the firm and other Wall Street executives familiar with Merrill's operation. **********Just over a year ago, Merrill began a vigorous push to expand its role in the lucrative mortgage-securities business, a push that meant Merrill's salesmen and traders had to handle far larger sums in a volatile market. **********Merrill chose throughout its pursuit of that business to trade in a manner that permitted a high degree of risk in hopes of earning greater profits, said those officials, few of whom would speak for the record. An Incendiary Combination **********There had been warnings that this combination could prove incendiary. Most notably, the firm lost $37 million early last year from mortgage-securities trading, in part because a senior trader exceeded his trading limits, Merrill officials said. **********The trader, Howard A. Rubin -who had been lured from Salomon Brothers in 1985 with a guaranteed salary of $1 million, triple his Salomon income - was given a second chance and later promoted to chief mortgage-securities trader. However, when he made the unauthorized trades that Merrill said contributed to its $275 million loss last month, he was dismissed. **********The experience was chastening for Merrill. Besides letting Mr. Rubin go, it suspended his immediate boss, Gregory Herschell, who had been hired a year before from Paine Webber Inc. In addition, Merrill relieved both Brian Barefoot, head of all securities trading, and Jerome P. Kenney, chief executive of Merrill's capital markets division, of their trading responsibilities. **********Now the firm's executives are wrestling with the more important question of whether they should shift to a more cautious - and potentially less profitable - trading stance. **********It is not a simple issue. Last year, Merrill's mortgage-backed securities department was able to more than make up the $37 million loss and turn in a record year, its officials say. Its trading philosophy thus served it well in that case. **********Now it must decide whether it is willing to ride the roller coaster again. Merrill also has to determine whether it can continue to expand in mortgage-backed securities should it choose to make permanent its temporary changes in management. **********Daniel P. Tully, Merrill's president, assumed direct control of trading in the wake of the recent loss. Last week he released a statement saying the firm's philosophy will not change. ''Merrill Lynch intends to remain the leading securities trader in the world,'' said Mr. Tully, who has moved his office temporarily to Merrill's trading floor. **********But another senior official said that ''the risk profile will change,'' adding that the firm had not fully understood or controlled what risks it took in the recent mortgage-securities problem. ''The ship will sail closer to shore,'' he said. **********The ultimate decision will be watched carefully, several analysts said, since it is the first major problem that William A. Schreyer, Merrill's chairman, and Mr. Tully have faced since assuming the top jobs in 1984. **********Mr. Schreyer was infuriated when informed of the problems, according to other Merrill officials. It was not clear when he learned the full extent of the loss, but at Merrill's annual meeting on April 24 he was optimistic and gave no hint of the disaster that was already unfolding.  The Cruelest Month Strikes Many Firms **********''They have a real credibility problem,'' said Perrin Long, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Securities. To be sure, April was a brutal month for all of Wall Street's major firms, several of which have acknowledged losing $20 million to $50 million. But the magnitude of Merrill's loss seems to point to a problem of its management and control. **********Early in 1986, Merrill found itself lagging behind in the surging business of mortgage-backed securities, which involves underwriting and trading bonds created by pooling hundreds of home mortgages. Merrill was playing catchup to the giants in this market, Salomon Brothers Inc. and the First Boston Corporation. It felt it had to -that as a significant firm it could no longer be in the second tier of this important business. **********Merrill began creating and selling huge amounts of mortgage-backed securities and its ranking jumped. In 1985, the firm was listed fourth among mortgage-securities underwriters, with 6 percent of the market, according to IDD Information Services. In the first four months of 1987, Merrill clambered into second place, getting 16.5 percent of the market. **********In building the business, Merrill never altered its risky trading policy, which evolved over time and was never seriously challenged, officials at the firm said. It adhered to that policy even after suffering a $20 million loss in early 1984, last year's $37 million loss and a $40 million loss in November from trading in takeover stocks, according to officials at the firm.  Many Traders Prefer To Hedge Their Bets **********Some major Wall Street firms operate on a trading policy of trying to avoid risk altogether. **********Although there are always risks in the fast-paced financial markets, traders at these firms generally work to accommodate their customers and the firm's needs and try to build up profits steadily little by little with the lowest possible risk. They avoid what are known as ''naked,'' or unhedged, positions, where the firm simply owns a large amount of a security, whose price can fluctuate with the market. **********The approach of other firms, including Merrill, however, has been to allow its professionals to take large risks in the market - in effect, making bets on which way they feel prices are headed. **********Firms that take this added risk from time to time generally establish clear procedures for arriving at a viewpoint, buttressed by elaborate research and deliberations at senior levels. **********Merrill took that riskier second tack but never implemented a clearcut mechanism for senior executives to participate in speculative decisions, some of its officials now concede. In the case of the $275 million loss, the senior officials said there had never been a thorough review of whether the firm was willing to accept certain risks.  'A Bumpy Ride' Went On and On **********The consequence of Merrill's approach has been erratic trading results that have long concerned analysts. ''In these trading areas, they have never been as profitable as their flow of business and share of the market would suggest they should be,'' said Samuel Liss, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. ''They had a bumpy ride in trading before this.'' **********That Merrill failed to heed earlier warnings has been particularly disheartening to some ot its officials. **********The $20 million loss in 1984, these sources said, was the result of a group of traders selling short $900 million of 12 1/2 percent Government National Mortgage Association bonds, known as Ginnie Maes, one of the basic mortgage-backed securities. **********The short sale, in which borrowed securities are sold on a bet that the price will drop, was a gamble that turned sour. Merrill made some personnel changes, but its trading philosophy was maintained. **********Then, in November, Merrill was hit with huge losses in its arbitrage desk, which speculates in takeover stocks. The desk, led by Timothy L. Tabor, had invested millions of dollars in several stocks that plunged on the news that the arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky had admitted to insider-trading violations.  Finding Vindication In a Risky Approach **********Merrill then gambled further, officials at the firm said. It held onto many of the stocks, anticipating a revival in prices. In fact, prices did rise, reducing Merrill's losses to $40 million, officials said. Once again, the firm felt vindicated in its trading style. (Mr. Tabor left Merrill in February and shortly afterward was indicted on insider-trading charges relating to his former employment at Kidder, Peabody & Company. He has pleaded not guilty.) That strategy was followed again with the recent mortgage-securities loss, which was first reported, on April 29, as $250 million. Once the extent of the problem began to surface at Merrill after April 13, the firm's officials worked for nearly two weeks trying to trade out of the situation, using a variety of tactics, in the hope that the market would improve. **********It did not, and Merrill then closed out most of its positions by April 24 -ironically, just before a rally on April 27 and 28. **********Merrill announced on Friday that its loss was $275 million, not $250 million, which raised additional questions as to how competently Merrill had handled the huge positions before finally selling all the securities. **********Merrill has not been helped by the heavy turnover in personnel on its mortgage-securities trading desk in the last three years. One senior executive was moved to operations. Another returned to Salomon Brothers, his previous employer. The three traders involved in the 1984 loss moved to another firm that year and a trader who replaced them left to work as a squash and tennis professional. **********All these factors came together explosively early in April.  A New Instrument, Grasped Imperfectly **********On April 8, Merrill underwrote $925 million of complex, ''stripped'' mortgage-backed securities, which were invented just a year ago to fit an environment of stable interest rates. The stripping involves splitting the bond into two parts, one that pays interest only, another paying principal only, and then selling the two separately. The bonds are thus known as I.O./P.O.'s. **********Merrill was able to sell only the I.O. portion of the underwriting, which was an attractive security in the April environment of rising rates. **********One reason it could not sell the P.O. portion was because it was overpriced, according to officials at Merrill and other firms. That left Merrill holding an extraordinarily volatile instrument, which one bond expert has described as ''highly radioactive nitroglycerin.'' **********Rather than quickly trying to find a way to unload the remaining securities, Merrill's traders - with their penchant for taking risks - were willing to hold the P.O.'s. **********Trading by Mr. Rubin then aggravated the situation, according to Merrill officials. They said he proceeded to create an additional $800 million of the I.O./P.O.'s without authorization and sold off only the I.O. part between April 8 and 10, just before the bond market was struck by a sudden surge in interest rates. **********The value of the unsold P.O.'s from the $925 million offering, combined with the $800 million in trades initiated by Mr. Rubin, plummeted. **********It was not until April 13, however, that the firm began to learn of Mr. Rubin's unauthorized trades, Merrill officials have said. He arranged the transactions through Merrill's Chicago office because the customers were in the Middle West. **********Whenever the salesperson in Chicago called the New York office for the missing trade confirmations and details of the transaction, he was routed to Mr. Rubin, who was able to put him off for several days before owning up to the transaction, the Merrill officials said. **********Mr. Rubin said through his attorney on Friday that it would be inappropriate to comment until the investigation is finished. **********Eventually, other senior officials at Merrill were called in and Mr. Rubin acknowledged the trades, officials at the firm said.  Officials Tried to Trade Out of Trouble **********But bond prices had already dropped, handing Merrill some losses. Merrill officials worked for nearly two weeks trying to salvage the situation, based partly in the hope that bond prices would revive. Merrill's traders even tried to buy back some of the I.O.'s to recouple with the P.O.'s but found the owners reluctant to part with them, according to sources with knowledge of these efforts. **********In retrospect, it seems Merrill was willing to accept too much risk in this instance without understanding how vulnerable it had left itself. ''We didn't understand the risks we were taking or the volatility of the security,'' said one senior Merrill executive. **********Merrill is not alone, though. Senior officials on other Wall Street firms describe these mortgage-backed securities as flawed because of their high volatility. ''Sometimes our technology in creating these securities outpaces our ability to cope with them,'' said Laurence D. Fink, co-head of trading at First Boston. **********At Merrill, trading operations remain in limbo, with its top officials temporarily relieved of their responsiblities while the company conducts an investigation. It has also commissioned an outside investigation, led by William P. Rogers, the former Cabinent officer who headed the Government's investigation of the space shuttle Challenger explosion, and Irving M. Pollack, a former commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********A major aim of the investigation, several Merrill officials said, is to determine whether fraud was committed. If so, Merrill could try to recoup some of the losses from an insurance policy protecting it against fraud. **********But even collecting millions of dollars from its insurance company will not relieve Merrill from a decision on how it will trade in the future.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/11/busin.body_text: **********About 5,000 New York employees are expected to lose their jobs when E. F. Hutton & Company merges with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. next month, executives of the two companies said here today. **********''There will be some trimming of people in New York in some areas where there will be redundancies -processing areas, investment banking areas, capital markets trading areas,'' said Joel Margolies, the vice chairman of Shearson and the director of its domestic branches. ''But there is no trimming expected anywhere in the retail division of either Shearson Lehman or Hutton.'' **********While some of the losses will be accomplished through layoffs, a major portion will come through attrition, according to Jerome H. Miller, the senior executive vice president and managing director of E. F.Hutton. **********In New York yesterday, Hutton told its employees that those being dismissed because of the impending merger would receive from two weeks' pay for less than three years of service to a maximum of a year's salary for 13 years of service or more. **********A seven-page memorandum to New York employees said that, with some exceptions, no new hiring would occur until further notice. The memorandum also said that, except for the sales staff, most Hutton employees would be required to complete new job applications and take polygraph or drug tests. **********Mr. Margolies said the companies now have about 20,000 New York employees, out of a total work force of 45,000 worldwide. The New York workers ''are pretty evenly divided between capital markets, investment banking and processing,'' he said. The reductions are expected to occur over a period of six months to a year, Mr. Margolies said. **********Mr. Miller and Mr. Margolies made their remarks at a stop in Atlanta while touring Hutton and Shearson offices in several cities. Mr. Margolies said employees in the offices outside New York were being told this week that few, if any, of them would lose their jobs in the merger.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.main_headline: Market Turmoil; CENTRAL BANKERS PERMIT THE DOLLAR TO SLIDE FURTHER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.print_headline: Market Turmoil; CENTRAL BANKERS PERMIT THE DOLLAR TO SLIDE FURTHER
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/29/busin.body_text: **********The world's central banks allowed the dollar to slide a notch today in international markets, apparently fearful that efforts to maintain its value would rattle stock markets and undermine economies. **********Throughout the day, as the dollar fell to near-record lows against such leading currencies as the West German mark and the Japanese yen, central banks tempered the decline by buying dollars. The official buying, including that of the Federal Reserve, was broad but modest, currency traders and economists said. **********The restrained buying, economists said, indicated a desire to moderate the decline, not to arrest or reverse it. Threats to Economy Cited **********This, officials said, marks an apparent shift in the Administration's eight-month-old policy of keeping the value of the dollar steady. The Administration appears to have changed its stance because the policy was threatening the economy with previously unforeseen hazards, such as higher interest rates and a recession. **********It was unclear tonight whether the dollar's decline today of percent against the yen and 1.53 percent against the mark had been too much in the view of the central banks. In the past three days, the total decline has been 4 2.4 percent against the yen and 2 percent against the mark. Greater Intervention Possible **********If those declines are viewed as too much too fast, the central banks could be expected to intervene to a greater extent. **********But today, the limited intervention was being noticed. ''What the intervention tells you,'' said Allan R. Leslie, vice president of the Discount Corporation of New York, ''is that they don't want the dollar to come down quickly, but that they won't try to stop it from ratcheting down slowly.'' **********Administration officials declined to comment on their objectives. **********The decline of the dollar had little of its customary effect on the stock market. A dollar decline typically arouses two worries, that inflation will increase because imports will cost more in less-valuable dollars, and that interest rates would then rise to offset the higher inflation. The stock market then suffers. A broad spectrum of economists contend that the United States needs a cheaper dollar to help reduce its huge trade deficit. A cheaper dollar means lower prices for American goods sent abroad and higher prices for goods the United States imports. As a result, American manufacturers are able to find more buyers both here and abroad. **********Allan H. Meltzer, an economist at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, said: ''We see the market taking exchange rates down. We don't see a lot of effort to stop it. So letting the dollar down must be their policy.'' **********In allowing a cheaper dollar, the Administration raises questions about the prospects for the foreign investment in American securities that has helped the United States carry its huge budget deficit and kept interest rates lower than they would be if Americans alone were financing it. Until the dollar stabilizes at a new level, a declining dollar diminishes the value of those investments, and that could discourage foreigners from buying the securities. Pressure on Louvre Accord **********At least for now, though, economists say, the relationship between markets and currency developments seems to have changed. In February, the seven leading industrial democracies signed an agreement to keep their currencies steady while making changes in their domestic economies. That agreement, known as the Louvre accord, has come under growing pressure because none of the countries has lived up to it. **********Earlier this year, the United States was raising interest rates to support the dollar in accordance with the Louvre agreement. Germany and Japan, however, then began raising their interest rates - in apparent violation of the accord - because they feared inflation in their economies. The United States opposes higher interest rates abroad because they weaken foreign economies and cut demand for American goods. **********The interest rate increases overseas put even more pressure on the United States to raise its rates further. The rising American rates are widely seen as a main cause of the stock market rout, because rising rates normally chill an economy. **********''Now we've got a situation where the dollar is slipping ,'' said Anthony M. Solomon, former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, ''and my advice would be you shouldn't resist it too hard. Some degree of slippage to a new, moderately lower plateau is probably desirable to avoid another upward shift of interest rates. And I think that's what they're doing.'' **********The dollar ended trading today in New York worth 1.7389 West German marks, down from 1.7565 late Tuesday and 1.7750 late Monday. Against the Japanese yen, the dollar fell to 138.75, from 140.90 Tuesday and 142.20 Monday.  [ In Thursday trading in Tokyo, the dollar came near its postwar low of 137.25 yen in late afternoon but recovered slightly to 137.50 yen, although it remained down from Wednesday's close. ]  The decline, sharp by midday today, accelerated after a statement by Jacques Delors, the French president of the 12-nation Commission of the European Community. ''Let us not have any illusions,'' he said of the dollar and mark exchange rate, then well under 1.80. ''The Americans are prepared to let it fall to 1.60.'' **********As the dollar began to fall even further, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d denied the report. In a statement issued in Washington, Mr. Baker said that Mr. Delors's remarks ''do not reflect the policies of the United States Government.'' Other officials said Mr. Delors had had no part in multilateral deliberations on the dollar. **********Currency experts said the absence of central bank intervention until now showed that the dollar had clearly pierced levels that had been established under the Louvre accord. The range established for the mark-dollar exchange rate was generally understood to have been 1.80 to 1.90 marks to the dollar. **********Economists said they expect Mr. Baker and the other participants in the Louvre accord to call another meeting fairly soon to decide whether they want to maintain a stable dollar policy at a lower exchange level. **********At least two senior members of the Administration - the President's chief economist, Beryl W. Sprinkel, and the budget director, James C. Miller 3d - have been arguing that all attempts to stabilize exchange rates should be abandoned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/16/busin.body_text: **********With its attack on I.B.M. showing little sign of abating, the Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday reported an 81 percent rise in net income, to $307.6 million, or $2.29 a share, from $170 million, or $1.32 a share, in the period a year earlier. **********Operating revenues for the company's third fiscal quarter jumped to $2.4 billion, a 26 percent increase from $1.9 billion. The company attributed much of the rise to the success of its new efforts in I.B.M.'s strongholds, such as banks, insurance companies and other financial services groups. **********Meanwhile, Apple Computer Inc., lifted by the strong response to its new Macintosh SE computer, recorded surprisingly high sales and earnings in its second fiscal quarter. Apple reported its revenues rose by 40.6 percent. Stock Price Drops, Rebounds **********Digital's performance slightly exceeded the expectations of analysts. Nevertheless, its stock dropped slightly soon after the earnings were announced, apparently because investors felt that the better-than-expected results announced this week by the International Business Machines Corporation portended an even stronger performance by Digital. Digital's shares ultimately closed on the New York Stock Exchange at $161.25, up 62.5 cents. **********Much of Digital's sales increases appeared to come in the heart of its VAX minicomputer line, at a time when I.B.M.'s mid-range computers have been its weakest performers. Digital's president, Kenneth H. Olsen, said he continued ''to be encouraged by the strong customer acceptance of the integrated networking solutions and wide range of compatible computer systems'' that the company offers. I.B.M.'s New Ammunition **********But some analysts questioned how long the company's two-year surge would last. I.B.M. is preparing to ship within three months its mid-range ''VAX-killer,'' the Model 9370, in its biggest effort yet to stop large corporate customers from defecting to Digital's VAX systems. **********Some of the machines in I.B.M.'s new personal computer line, called the Personal System/2, are also expected to nip at Digital's sales of the Microvax II and other small computers. **********''D.E.C. will continue to do well, but until now it has been an easy game for them,'' said Fred Cohen, the technology analyst at L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin. ''Now, they are going to have to earn it a little more.'' Backlog of Orders **********Officials of Digital, which is based in Maynard, Mass., indicated that in the last quarter they have built a substantial backlog of orders and have watched their internal sales soar. **********''The only thing that has not turned up,'' said Mark A. Steinkrauss, ther company's director of investor relations, ''is the manufacturing sector. Everything else grew very nicely.'' Digital officials also maintain that their surveys show increasing success in the mainframe market, an area where the company has never been a serious player. Recently, Digital announced a set of mainframe-like products that are built by linking together up to four of the largest VAX machines. But it is too early to tell how widely accepted the new products will be. **********In the quarter, Digital also bought back 2.2 million shares of its own stock, leaving about 129 million shares outstanding. The stock price has surged in recent months, and the purchases cost Digital $323.2 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/26/busin.main_headline: GRAY MARKET FOR CHIPS SHRINKING BUT STILL BIG
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/26/busin.print_headline: GRAY MARKET FOR CHIPS SHRINKING BUT STILL BIG
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/26/busin.body_text: **********The Southeast Asia gray market for Japanese chips, which is at the center of a bitter trade dispute, is shrinking but remains significant, participants in the market say. **********Buyers and sellers of semiconductors described how Japanese middlemen evade sales restrictions by using couriers to deliver the chips to electronics companies in Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan. **********Duke Liao, general manager of the Datatech Enterprises Company, a Taiwan technology concern, said that in the last three weeks the supply of Japanese chips in Taiwan had dried up. For example, he said, he used to buy Japanese 256K dynamic random access memory chips (called Drams) for $1.60 to $1.80 each. Now Japanese brokers are quoting them at more than $2.20, and no one is willing to buy at that price, he said. **********American officials calculate the Japanese companies' cost of producing chips at approximately $2.50 each. The exact cost depends on the manufacturer's volume. **********The gray market involves computer chips sold outside Japan by private exporters rather than the makers themselves. **********The private exporters buy in Japan because last summer's agreement does not forbid sales below cost there, and chip prices in Tokyo are lower than anywhere else. Companies may be willing to sell below cost to get rid of inventories, to maintain relationships with customers and to expand their market share. **********There seems to be only one proven case of a Japanese manufacturer directly selling chips abroad at less than the cost of production, but Japanese officials acknowledge that Japan's pledge not to dump chips in the United States and third-country markets does cover sales abroad by intermediaries. **********Because of such sales, a Japanese company's Hong Kong office may ask full price for its chips, while local brokers who bought them cheaply in Tokyo offer them for less. **********To counteract the problem, Washington is threatening to impose sanctions, probably in the form of tariffs. **********While it is difficult to control intermediaries, industry officials point to some improvement in recent weeks. **********''Yes, we've seen a change but, no, we don't believe it yet,'' said James N. Chapman, the Asia/Pacific marketing manager for the Intel Corporation, an American manufacturer of chips. Mr. Chapman said that while the gray market had dried up somewhat in the last month, he did not regard the improvement as a trend because, to his mind, Japanese companies violated the anti-dumping pact for the previous six months. **********Mr. Liao and other Taiwan and Hong Kong buyers of chips said they dealt with middlemen rather than the Japanese manufacturers themselves. Mr. Liao said he did not realize he was buying below the ''fair market'' value of the chips, as established in the trade agreement. **********Furthermore, Japanese officials say, the production cost is calculated as the average cost of making each chip. Because of high fixed costs, the marginal cost of producing additional chips is much lower than the average cost. Therefore a company can actually make money by producing extra chips for, say, $1.25 each and selling them for $1.50, even though the average cost of all its chips is $2.50. **********Annie Tsao, general manager of the Auto Computer Company in Taiwan, confirmed that Japanese chips had disappeared from the Taiwan market in the last few weeks. Until then, she said, 80 percent of the chips purchased by her company originated in Japan. But Japanese brokers have not been able to get export licenses, cutting off the supply, and dealers have raised the price of other chips by 30 percent in the last few weeks, she said. **********An official of Japan's Ministry of Trade and Industry said Japan was not shutting off chip exports to Taiwan, but he said the authorities were examining export licenses more carefully than in the past. **********Tokyo, he said, is trying to assure that licenses are granted for exports to a particular user of chips but not to brokers intending to supply the gray market. **********A Hong Kong computer manufacturer, who conceded using gray market chips, said it was common for brokers to avoid export licenses altogether and to simply have couriers carry suitcases full of chips as airliner luggage. Japanese customs officials are bribed to look the other way, he said. **********Other electronics executives in Hong Kong confirmed this statement and said the gray market was widespread throughout the region. **********The Japanese trade official said that anyone exporting chips worth more than 50,000 yen (about $335) without an export license was breaking the law and was subject to a fine. But he said he had never heard of anyone being caught.

The Treasury continues to reduce the amount of bills outstanding, and the $12.8 billion of bills to be sold this week compares with $13.06 billion of maturing issues. **********On Wednesday, government securities dealers expect the Treasury to announce auctions for the week of Sept. 21 of new notes due in two, four and seven years. Analysts cautioned, however, that those auctions might be delayed if Congress did not approve a new Federal debt ceiling. As occurred last month, approval of the debt ceiling legislation could be delayed if legislators attempt to combine it with legislation to reduce the Federal deficit in the 1988 fiscal year and beyond. Flurry of Offerings Expected **********In the corporate market, high interest rates the last few months have sharply reduced the willingness of corporations to issue bonds. New issues totaled less than $700 million in the last two weeks, and in the last seven weeks, the weekly average of about $1 billion is well below the $3.3 billion weekly average during the first half of the year, according to Salomon Brothers data. **********But on Friday, as bond prices rose for the third consecutive day, investment bankers said they expected a flurry of offerings early this week by corporations that have either delayed needed financings or else want to take advantage of the recent improvement in bond prices to sell debt before interest rates rise further. **********The lack of new corporate offerings has heightened interest among investors and securities dealers for various offerings this month by Federal agencies. **********One day this week, underwriters led by Salomon Brothers expect to announce interest rates on about $130 million of bonds backed by Department of Education loans to colleges and universities. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/busin.main_headline: Calvin Klein Officer Goes to Leslie Fay
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Calvin Klein Officer Goes to Leslie Fay
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/02/busin.body_text: **********Joel H. Newman has left as president of Calvin Klein Industries to join the Leslie Fay Company as vice chairman and chief operating officer. **********Mr. Newman, 45 years old, has had a steadily rising career from its beginning in the finance department of Bloomingdale's. At Leslie Fay, he will have responsibility for planning, operations, human resources and finance, the company said. **********Leslie Fay, a New York-based clothing maker, made some changes to accommodate Mr. Newman. Alan Golub, who had been vice chairman, becomes president and will continue to head Leslie Fay sportswear companies. **********Mr. Golub succeeds John J. Pomerantz as president. Mr. Pomerantz remains as chairman and chief executive. **********Leslie Fay has been searchng for a new executive since Walter Leiter resigned in December as president and chief financial officer. **********In the announcement of Mr. Newman's appointment, Mr. Pomerantz said that Leslie Fay considered him ''one of the outstanding executives in our inudstry.'' **********And Mr. Klein, vice chairman and co-owner of Calvin Klein Industries, chimed in with his own statement yesterday. ''Joel Newman did a fine job at Calvin Klein Industries,'' he said. ''We will all miss him and wish Joel the best of luck in his new endeavor.'' **********Mr. Newman joined Calvin Klein in 1984 as executive vice president and was named president in 1985. Before that, he was with the Batus retail division of B.A.T. Industries and as such was president of a Batus unit, Kohl's Department Stores. He also helped engineer for Batus the 1982 purchase of Marshall Field & Company. **********Mr. Newman, who did not return phone calls at his new Leslie Fay offices yesterday, helped back to health Calvin Klein's Puritan Fashions subsidiary together with Robert J. Suslow, who preceded him as Calvin Klein president. Mr. Newman also worked for Mr. Suslow at Batus when Mr. Suslow was chairman there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/04/world.main_headline: Vietnam Jails 17 for Attempted Guerrilla Invasion
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/04/world.print_headline: Vietnam Jails 17 for Attempted Guerrilla Invasion
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/04/world.body_text: **********A Vietnamese tribunal sentenced 17 people to prison today on charges of trying to stage a guerrilla invasion with American and Thai backing. **********The three-day trial, conducted with maximum publicity on the stage of the municipal theater here, turned into an unexpected, sustained attack on the United States and Thailand at a time when Hanoi is trying to improve relations with both nations. **********Uncharacteristically, China - usually portrayed here as the third partner in an anti-Vietnamese clique - was not mentioned as a supporter of the rebel organization, identified by the Vietnamese as the Armed Forces of Resistance. The group was said to have infiltrated Laos from Thailand in July, planning to enter Vietnam to commit sabotage and foment an uprising. **********The leader of the guerrillas was reported to be a former South Vietnamese admiral, Hoang Co Minh, who became an American citizen a few years ago. Hanoi says Mr. Minh was killed in Laos in August with more than 100 other members of the group. Picture of a U.S. General **********''Obviously, the U.S. imperialists are the mastermind, the inciter and supporter of Hoang Co Minh and his followers,'' the 16-page indictment said. The only evidence offered was a picture of Mr. Minh meeting an American general, identified as Paul Weigand, in Tokyo, possibly in 1982.  [ In Washington, officials of the Army, Air Force and Marine Corps said they could find no record of a Gen. Paul Weigand. ]  At the trial today, the presiding judge, Tran Tuan Sy, called the Thais ''the implementing agents of the American reactionaries.'' The indictment and court testimony held that Thailand had armed, trained and recruited resistance fighters from refugee camps where Vietnamese exiles were ''starved and beaten.'' **********Reporters here for the trial could not recall such charges of abuse from Vietnamese refugees, who are visited regularly in Thai camps. **********The United States and Vietnam do not have diplomatic relations. No American officials are reachable from here for comment. **********Dinh Van Be, charged with being one of the commanders, received a term of life imprisonment. Sixteen other defendants were given terms ranging from 3 to 19 years, and another defendant was put on probation. **********All the defendants had pleaded guilty after extensive confessions. **********Judge Sy demanded the deportation from the United States of what he called the remaining rebel ringleader, identified as Nguyen Kim. He also said the Thai and American Governments should dissolve such resistance groups now or ''bear the responsibility for the destabilization of Southeast Asia.'' New York Group Mentioned **********Among the groups mentioned was a New York City committee reported to have been set up in 1984 and based in the Murry Bergtraum High School at 411 Pearl Street near Chinatown. Other groups were reported to be found in California. Ethnic Chinese defendants in this trial have been so identified in the indictments. **********The trial proceedings were broadcast live through loudspeakers in the street outside the municipal theater, where a crowd gathered this afternoon for the sentencing. **********An exhibition of evidence was mounted in the galleries around the main auditorium. In one exhibit, an organizational chart of the resistance army had an American flag at its apex. The indictment said American intelligence agents worked with the group. **********Those Vietnamese who will talk about this trial and foreign diplomats in the region who have been following events since the attempted invasion of central Vietnam say Hanoi may intend to send a variety of messages. Message to Young Dissenters **********Internally, the proceedings and the sentences meted out to the young men, most in their 20's, tells the country's restive youth that this kind of dissent will be dealt with harshly. The sentences also make clear that in an era of some economic liberalization under a new party leadership, political opposition will not be tolerated. **********The Government may have also wanted to deter Vietnamese from fleeing to Thailand by repeatedly describing refugee camps there as places of terror and hard labor. More boat people are fleeing Vietnam this year than at any time since the early 1980's. **********Some diplomats suggest that in the point-counterpoint politics of Vietnam these treason cases, which reached trial unusually quickly, may show the determination of the Interior Ministry or other security organizations not to appear soft toward the West or Vietnam's non-Communist neighbors. **********Foreign Ministry officials have been playing down the American angle in discussions with reporters this week. **********Finally, the trial coincides, many diplomats think deliberately, with a much-publicized Vietnamese troop withdrawal from Cambodia and the opening of talks between the Hanoi-backed Phnom Penh Government and the Cambodian resistance movement under Prince Norodom Sihanouk. **********In the trial, prosecutors referred again and again to the case as a demonstration of the need for ''Vietnam-Laos-Kampuchean solidarity.'' Two defendants were Cambodians.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/02/world.main_headline: THOSE 'NEW' SAVANTS: PASSE, OR PAST THEIR PRIME?
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/02/world.print_headline: PARIS JOURNAL; THOSE 'NEW' SAVANTS: PASSE, OR PAST THEIR PRIME?
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/02/world.body_text: **********He is known just by his initials, B.H.L., in the way some of the legendary film actors of France, like Fernandel and Raimu, used to be called only by single names, which were emblems of nationwide recognition. **********Bernard-Henri Levy, the writer and philosopher, is not a movie star, even if he is often pictured in the glossy magazines in this country in carefully framed profile, or staring slightly downward at the camera with a look of calculated intensity in his eyes, his long hair silhouetted against backlights and his shirt unbuttoned nearly to the waist. **********Mr. Levy, who is 38 years old, is a commentator and thinker about town very much in the French mold, a man who writes about such difficult subjects as Marxism, structuralism, existentialism, freedom, while living a publicly flamboyant life (he admits to a certain narcissism), always studiously casual, frequently on television, setting all sorts of fashions. **********His 1977 book, ''Barbarism With a Human Face,'' was a sensation here, a point of repair for the group just then coming to be known as the New Philosophers, still the dominant current in French intellectual life. It marked a decisive rejection of Marxist totalitarianism, which it described in entirely negative terms, something the previous generation of French thinkers, dominated by leftist sentiment, had been loath to do. A Lament and an Accusation **********Now Mr. Levy has created new controversy, publishing two weeks ago a slender volume called ''Eloge des Intellectuels,'' or ''Elegy for the Intellectuals.'' **********The book is both a lament and an accusation against his own kind, in which he argues that the serious thinkers on moral and political issues in France have in recent years lost their historic role. They are suffering a ''disgrace, a discredit, a muted disqualification'' such that France, the country that invented the concept of the intellectual, ''does not know what to think of them anymore.'' **********''Intellectuals are neither hated nor vilified nor even really denounced,'' Mr. Levy writes, lamenting past days when French political thinkers were taken seriously enough to be made to suffer for their ideas. **********''Elegy for the Intellectuals'' is one of two works attracting attention here these days that, taken together, reflect a kind of pause, a sense of alarm, and maybe even a new stage in the life of the mind in France. Both are marked by varying degrees of nostalgia, pessimism and disillusionment over the intellectual profession, which has been both worshiped and ostracized with a heated sort of passion that in itself is one of the chief characteristics of the French. 'The Failure of Thought' **********The other book, being reviewed together with Mr. Levy's slender volume, is a somewhat thicker, more deliberate, and, according to some, more probing work, by Alain Finkielkraut called ''La Defaite de la Pensee,'' or ''The Failure of Thought,'' one of whose themes, at times overlapping that of Mr. Levy's, is the decline of cultural standards. **********Mr. Finkielkraut, a 38-year-old writer whose previous books have been widely admired here, concentrates on what he sees as an attack on the fundamental values established in the 18th-century French Enlightenment. But his historical excursion is aimed at explaining why, as he sees it, cultural standards have shrunk into insignificance as cultural figures have been transformed from elites of taste and discrimination into creatures of the mass media marketplace. **********''The boundary line between culture and entertainment has become blurry,'' Mr. Finkielkraut writes. ''Today,'' he says, ''it is common to designate as culture activities in which thought plays no role at all.'' **********A similar point, though differently expressed, is getting most attention in Mr. Levy's book. It is his charge that a group of popular stars have, in the country of Montaigne and Voltaire, Zola and Camus, replaced serious thinkers as the most conspicuous trend-setters, commentators and spiritual guides of France. **********Mr. Levy specifically mentions a popular singer of satirical songs named Renaud, who was invited some time ago to appear on this country's highest-brow literary program. Among the others is Bernard Tapie, a wealthy businessman and the star of a television program called ''Ambition,'' who has made free enterprise into a glitzy sort of media campaign. A Political Danger **********These are ''appealing figures,'' Mr. Levy writes. But in the context of France's intellectual history, they mark a decline. They are basically too simple and monotonous to be valid as spiritual guides. Yet, Mr. Levy concludes, their prominence signals a real political danger, because, as he puts it, intellectual ''clarity,'' an appreciation of complexity, and the ability to make learned distinctions are among the fundamental conditions of democratic life. **********''France,'' Mr. Levy said in a recent conversation, ''is a country where the glory of literature has always been linked by a concrete, massive engagement in the affairs of the century.'' **********Referring to past figures like Sartre, Camus and Mauriac, Mr. Levy said: ''Because they wrote novels, and because their talent was recognized, they were authorized and required to intervene in the issues of the day and to say, rightly or wrongly, what was true and good. This profile is very French.'' **********Mr. Levy, Mr. Finkielkraut and others have tried to follow the profile. Some years ago, for example, Mr. Finkielkraut was arrested, interrogated and then expelled from the Soviet Union, where he was campaigning on behalf of Soviet Jews. **********Mr. Levy has performed many well-publicized exploits. He has carried radios to anti-Soviet guerrillas in Afghanistan, demonstrated on behalf of Indochinese boat people on the Thai-Cambodian border and visited Ethiopian refugee camps to protest the forced evacuation of villages. **********Now, in what some critics are calling a self-criticism, Mr. Levy, in ''Elegy for the Intellectuals,'' has all but announced the end of the New Philosophy, saying that it has been swept away with the other ideologies. **********''It was victorious,'' he writes of his school of thought. ''It swept its opposition away.'' But it then dragged after it a ''sad vulgate'' consisting of ''soft, obsessionally modest, and weak thinking,'' which, he goes on, ''made uncertainty its final word and minimalism its entire program.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/20/busin.main_headline: Golden Nugget's Leader Hailed for Sale Move
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/20/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Golden Nugget's Leader Hailed for Sale Move
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/20/busin.body_text: **********Stephen A. Wynn's move this weekend to sell the Golden Nugget Casino/ Hotel in Atlantic City represents an emboldened move by the company back to Las Vegas, market analysts said yesterday. **********The sale to the Bally Manufacturing Company, valued at $439 million, should increase the Golden Nugget's borrowing capacity and cash position as it begins a $350 million building program in Las Vegas, according to the analysts. **********Mr. Wynn, the 45-year-old chairman and president of Golden Nugget Inc., announced last year that the company had acquired land adjacent to Caesars Palace on the Las Vegas Strip, with plans to develop a luxury resort called the Bombay. Mr. Wynn's company also owns the Golden Nugget casino in Las Vegas. **********''It was an absolutely brilliant move,'' said Marvin B. Roffman, an analyst for Janney Montgomery Scott, a securities firm. ''But from an operating basis, Golden Nugget stock is overvalued.'' Mr. Roffman said the the Atlantic City casino was the company's chief earnings base whereas ''the Las Vegas casino has not made a nickel in years.'' **********''Steve Wynn noted the opportunity to take a fat profit on the property,'' said Steven Eisenberg, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company. ''We'll see in two years if it was the right move. Golden Nugget's priorities changed.'' **********Mr. Wynn's office said he was out of town yesterday and not available for comment. **********Analysts say Golden Nugget will now reduce its debt to about $100 million from $300 million, will increase its cash position to about $400 million and will improve its borrowing capacity. **********Some analysts say the retreat from Atlantic City also represents worries about the casino market there. Analysts say that the Atlantic City market may have become saturated and that overregulation, lack of transportation and insufficient convention space may have made the environment unattractive. **********A native of New Haven, Mr. Wynn grew up in Maryland, where his parents ran a legal bingo parlor. A Golden Nugget spokesman said he made his first $35,000 investment in Las Vegas in 1967, as one of the orginal investors in the Frontier Hotel. **********Mr. Wynn eventually sold his stock in the Frontier and bought a statewide liquor business. He sold that in 1972 and, with the proceeds from that and other investments, began buying stock in the Golden Nugget. The same year, he won a seat on the company's board and became chairman. **********He is married and has two daughters, and he divides his time between Las Vegas and Atlantic City. He also keeps a ski home in Sun Valley, Idaho.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/07/busin.body_text: **********Companies **********Texaco was handed a major defeat by the Supreme Court, which ruled unanimously that a Federal District Court should not have excused Texaco from posting a bond of more than $10 billion as it pursues its appeal of the judgment that Pennzoil won in 1985. The ruling will greatly increase pressure on Texaco, the nation's third-largest oil company, to settle the complex suit and could push it into bankruptcy proceedings. Texaco said it would press its case aggressively in the Texas courts.  [ Page A1. ]  Lawyers for Pennzoil and Texaco said the critical question now was what form and amount of security Texaco would be forced to post as it pursues its appeal.  [ D21. ]  Some suppliers said they were growing increasingly concerned that Texaco would seek protection from creditors in bankruptcy court.  [ D21. ]  Texaco's bonds fell in light trading. The company has more than $8 billion of outstanding debt.  [ D21. ] **********Gencorp offered $130 a share for more than half its stock, to ward off a takeover. The company said it would sell its tire, soft-drink bottling and broadcasting businesses and concentrate on aerospace and automotive operations. The investor group trying to buy the company did not immediately comment on the plan.  [ D1. ] **********Standard Oil advisers called B. P.'s $70-a-share bid inadequate. Mr. Wyman, overthrown by a board room revolt last September, also holds stock options whose value was not disclosed. Gold prices dipped in New York.  [ D24. ] **********Silver futures advanced, extending a rally that has raised prices nearly 20 percent in two weeks. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/13/world.main_headline: Seville Journal; Was Columbus a Whiner? You Could Look It Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/13/world.print_headline: Seville Journal; Was Columbus a Whiner? You Could Look It Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/10/13/world.body_text: **********Christopher Columbus was a chronic whiner. Cervantes asked the Crown for permission to travel to the New World to escape debt that dogged him throughout his life. **********These and other bits of information about Spain's relationship to the Americas hundreds of years ago are contained in the millions of documents stored here at the Archive of the Indies. **********Based on Columbus's letters and memos, it is the opinion of Rosario Parra Cala, the archive director, that he was not shy about registering grievances with his benefactors and others. ''He was always complaining about something - about not being adequately compensated by the Crown for his services, about being in poor health in Jamaica; always something,'' she said of the man being honored Oct. 12, 495 years after his journey to the Americas. **********Within the walls of the two-story 16th-century building are 40 million documents, neatly preserved in 43,000 boxes stored on mahogany shelving brought from Cuba. Although they are merely records and cold statistics, with no interpretation or analysis, they have attracted scholars from all over the world and resulted in important discoveries. Treasure Hunter Is Helped **********Last year, for example, Dr. Eugene Lyon, a University of Florida history professor, made public analyses of shipping data on Columbus's favorite vessel, the Nina, from documents here. The findings are expected to contribute to the understanding of those early voyages. **********Information from the archive was also instrumental in helping Mel Fisher, the treasure hunter, strike it rich two years ago by locating the sunken Spanish galleon Nuestra Senora de Atocha and her $100 million cargo. The ship went down in the Gulf of Mexico in a hurricane in 1622. **********Reading through the documents can be about as thrilling as culling water and electric bills in the records room of New York City Hall, except that the records here are from Spain's glory days of empire-building. They date from as far back as 1492, an era of exciting discovery and pioneering, change and conquest, hardship and abuse. **********The archive is not open to the public, and scholars wishing access must present a written request from their institutions. Treasure hunters like Mr. Fisher, not as welcome here as scholars, find the wealth of information invaluable. Mr. Fisher was so appreciative that he donated a cannon from the galleon. Bureaucratic in the Extreme **********The Spanish were extremists in bureaucratic demands. ''Down to every detail, everything done had to be approved in Spain,'' Miss Parra said. ''All laws, all changes in laws, construction plans, all of it had to have permission from Seville. **********''Copies of everything - birth, marriage and death certificates, for example - were sent here. The documents here are administrative, not a chronicle; they make dull reading, but they are very important.'' **********Most of the material is well preserved - there is no air conditioning or heating in the archive, leaving those using it sometimes sweating and sometimes shivering - but there is an active restoration process with a staff of half a dozen. The archive is also working to computerize and microfilm every piece of paper. **********Miss Parra said the history of the Americas is not just for historians. Geologists, philosophers and military scholars are making more use of it. ''More economists are visiting nowadays,'' she said. ''Previously, language and religion were major topics of research.'' **********Victoria Stapells Johnson, a Canadian, began research here 12 years ago as an anthropologist but became attracted to treasure hunting and is now in love with it. She said that her most exciting project was helping Mr. Fisher in his hunt for the Nuestra Senora de Atocha, but that she also works for scholars. **********But for an American, at this time of year, the main treasure in this storehouse of the administrative capital of the now-gone empire revolves around Columbus and the approaching 500th anniversary of his discoveries. The American Ambassador, Reginald Bartholomew, visited the archive recently and said it was sheer joy to hold in his hands personal letters between Christopher Columbus and Queen Isabella and King Ferdinand. Letters to Columbus **********Miss Parra said other communications to or from Columbus in the archive include an authorization dated April 30, 1492, for insurance policies for his crew and exemption from taxes on provisions bought in Seville for his trip; a letter from the King and Queen dated Aug. 23, 1493, telling him to prepare an army of conquest in Barcelona for his second trip, and a letter from Jamaica, dated July 7, 1503, saying he was in poor health. **********Other documents bestow on Columbus the titles of admiral, viceroy and governor general of the Indies. There is a letter from the Crown to the treasurer directing him to pay the navigator, a letter on sending prisoners to the New World and a letter from Queen Isabella suggesting a good position in the army for a friend. **********Cervantes, like the hero in his ''Don Quixote de la Mancha,'' was considered brave and unselfish - and was also a poor money manager. He served time in prison on occasion for nonpayment of debt, which led to his request, never granted, to leave the country.

https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/25/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Kinder-Care Seeks Florida Thrift Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/25/busin.body_text: **********Kinder-Care Inc., a day-care provider, plans to buy the American Savings and Loan Association of Miami for about $138 million, American's chairman said. Kinder-Care Inc., which operates day-care centers, owns Centerbanc Savings Association of St. Petersburg, Fla. **********Under a tentative agreement, Kinder-Care and Centerbanc would pay $17 for each of the 8.1 million shares of American Savings, said Morris Broad, American's chairman. American, with assets of some $3.1 billion and 41 branches, is Florida's fourth-largest savings and loan association, Mr. Broad said. Centerbanc has about $600 million in assets.
